superEntry.entry:
alphabetical letter s c
The twelfth letter of the alphabet; called siynN. It is one of the letters termed mahomuwsap [or non-vocal, i. e. pronounced with the breath only, without the voice]; and of the letters termed OasaliyRap, as also S and z, because proceeding from the tip of the tongue: its place of utterance is between that of S and that of z: and Az says hat it is never conjoined with either of these two letters in any Arabic word: (TA:) it is a sibilant letter; and is distinguished from S by the raising of the tongue to the palate [in the utterance of the latter], and from z by the suppression of the voice [in the utterance of the former]. (K in art. syn.) It is one of the letters of augmentation [occurring in the form AisotafoEala and its derivatives]. (S and L in art. syn.) [See also siynN in art. syn. It is sometimes substituted for S; as in saqorN, for SaqorN: and for X, as in siToranojN, for XiToranojN: (see De Sacy's Chrest. Arabe, sec. ed., ii. 230-233: and iii. 530-532:)] and AZ says that some of the Arabs substitute for it t, (S and L and K * in art. syn,) as in the saying (S and L in art. syn) of 'Alyà Ibn-Arkam, (L ib.,)
yaA qabaHa QllRehu baniI AlsRiEolaAti
Eamoraw bona yarobuwEK XiraAra AlnRaAti
layosuwA OaEfRaMCa walaA OakoyaAti
[O, may God remove far from good, or from prosperity, the sons of the Sialáh, 'Amr Ibn-Yarbooa, the worst of mankind: they are not chaste, nor sharp in intellect]: he means AlnRaAsi and biOakoyaAsi: (S and L ib.:) and in like manner one says TasotN for TasRN. (TA in art. kyt.) ― -b2- yesL in the Kur [commencing ch. xxxvi.] is like MlLmL and HemL at the commencement of chapters of the same; and is said by 'Ikrimeh to mean yaA UinosaAnu [O man]; because it is followed by the words UinRaka lamina Almurosaliyna: (S and L in art. syn:) or it means either thus, or yaA sayRidu [O man of dignity]. (K in art. syn.) ＝ -A2- sa is a particle peculiarly prefixed to the aor., rendering it clearly denotative of the future, (Mughnee, and S * and L * in art. syn,) as in sayafoEalu [He will do such a thing], (S and L ib.,) and considered as forming a part thereof, for which reason it does not exercise any government upon it: it is not contracted from sawofa, contrary to what the Koofees hold: nor is the extent of the future with it shorter than it is with sawofa, contrary to what the Basrees hold: the analytical grammarians term it Harofu tanofiysK, by which is meant a particle of amplification; because it changes the aor. from the strait time, which is the present, to the ample time, which is the future: but plainer that their expression is the saying of Z and others, [that it is] a particle denoting the future. (Mughnee.) Kh asserts that it corresponds [as an affirmative] to [the negative] lano. (S and L in art. syn.) Some assert that it sometimes denotes continuance, not futurity: this is mentioned in relation to the saying in the Kur [iv. 93], satajiduwna Mxariyna [as though meaning Ye continually find others]; and they adduce as an evidence thereof the saying in the same [ii. 136], sayaquwlu QlsRafahaMCu mina QlnRaAsi maA walRaAhumo Eano qibolatihimo [as meaning The light-witted of the people continually say, What hath turned them away, or back, from their kibleh?]; affirming that this was revealed after their saying maA walRaAhumo: but this the grammarians know not; and that this verse was revealed after their saying mA wlRAhm is not a fact agreed upon: moreover, if it be conceded, still continuance is inferred from the aor.; like as when you say, fulaAnN yaqoriI AlDRayofa and yaSonaEu Aljamiyla, you mean that it is his custom to do thus. (Mughnee.) Z asserts that when it is prefixed to a verb signifying what is liked or disliked, it denotes that the event will inevitably happen: i. e., when it is prefixed to a verb signifying a promise or a threat, it corroborates and confirms its meaning. (Mughnee.) ＝ -A3- [As a numeral, s denotes Sixty.]

saA c
saA i. q. sawofa, q. v.

1 saOabahu c
1. saOabahu, (S, M, K,) aor.
saAa^a
, (M, K,) inf. n. saOobN, (S, M,) He throttled him, syn. xanaqahu; (S, M, IAth, K;) i. e., squeezed his throat: (IAth:) or, so that he died, (S,) or so that he killed him. (M, K.) ― -b2- And saOabahu He widened it; namely, a siqaMC [or skin for water or milk]. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- saOaba mina AlXRaraAbi, (M, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above; (M;) and saYiba, (M, K,) aor.
saAa^a
, (K,) inf. n. saOabN; (M;) He was satisfied with drinking of wine or beverage. (M, K.)

saOobN c
saOobN and misoOabN↓ A [skin such as is termed] ziqR, (S, M, K,) for wine: (M:) or such as is large: (M, K:) or a ziqR of any kind: (M:) or a receptacle of skin, or leather, in which the ziqR is put: (M, K:) the former also occurs in a verse in which it is read without C, for the sake of the rhyme: (M:) and its pl. is suWuwbN: (S, M, K:) and (so in the S, but in the K “ or, ”) the latter (msOb) signifies a skin for honey; (S, K;) and in a verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb, (S, M, K,) cited voce xaAfapN, (S, M,) it is written misaAbN, (S, M, K,) without C: (S, M:) and it signifies also a skin in which clarified butter is put. (S and L voce misaAdN.)

suWobaAni c
suWobaAni, in the following saying, (IJ, M,) UinRahu lasuWobaAnu maAlK, meaning Verily he is one who pastures, or tends, the cattle, and takes care of them, and manages them, well, (IJ, M, K, *) is from saOobN signifying “ a ziqR ” because the ziqR is made only for the preservation of its contents. (IJ, M.)

misoOabN c
misoOabN: see saOobN. ― -b2- Also, (K,) applied to a man, (TA), Who drinks much water. (K.)

1 suYida c
1. suYida: see 1 in art. swd.

4 UisoMdN c
4. UisoMdN signifies The hastening, or being quick, in journeying; (S, K;) and is mostly used in relation to journeying by night: (S:) or the journeying all the night; (M;) or the journeying in the night without alighting to rest; (Mbr, S, K;) and taOowiybN signifies the “ journeying in the day without alighting to rest: ” (Mbr, S:) or the journeying of camels night and day (AA, S, M, K) together. (M, K.) And saOadN↓ occurs [as an inf. n. in the sense of UisoMdN]; but [ISd says] I know not any verb [properly] belonging to it. (M.) ― -b2- You say also, AsOd AlsRayora He prosecuted the journey with energy, (M,) or persistently, or continually. (MA.) [See an ex. in a verse of Aboo-Duwád cited voce maroduwnN.]

saOodN c
saOodN [an inf. n. of which the verb is not mentioned,] The act of walking, or going any pace on foot. (M.)

saOadN c
saOadN: see 4, above.

suWodapN c
suWodapN Somewhat remaining of youthfulness (S, K) and strength (S) in a woman. (S, K. * [See also suWorapN.])

misoOadN c
misoOadN A skin for clarified butter, (S, K, [see badorapN,]) or for honey; as also misaAdN, without C; the former of the measure mifoEalN, and the latter of the measure fiEaAlN: or a [skin of the kind called] ziqR, smaller than the Hamiyt [which is similarly described as a skin, or small skin, of the kind called ziqR]: (El-Ahmar, L:) but Sh says, what we have heard is misoOabN, meaning a large [skin of the kind called] ziqR. (L.)

masoWuwdN c
masoWuwdN: see art. swd.

saAcajN c
saAcajN (O, K, TA) and saAcijN (TA) arabicized from [the Pers.] saAdaho: (O, K: [in some copies of the K saAcaho:]) this is the only explanation in some of the copies of the K: (TA:) Plain; i. e. without variegation, decoration, embellishment, or engraved or sculptured work: (O, TA:) or without any hair upon it: or of one unmixed colour: this last is [said to be] the correct meaning [in many instances]; but the sheykh Welee-ed-Deen El-'Irákee says, in the Expos. of the “ Sunan ” of Aboo-Dáwood, respecting a pair of boots of the Prophet, described as xufRaAni OasowadaAni saAcajaAni or saAcijaAni, that this phrase seems to mean A pair of black boots of one unmixed colour; the last word being used in this sense in the common conventional language; though he had not found it with this meaning in the lexicons, nor in the books of authors on the strange words occurring in traditions. (TA.) ― -b2- Also Free from self-constraint: and one who knows not badness, wickedness, deceit, or guile; in whom is no latent rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, nor cunning: (O:) or free in intellect; and easy [or simple or artless] in nature or disposition. (TA in art. sdj.) ― -b3- HujRapN saAcajapN, also written saAcijapN, is used by authors on the scholastic theology of the Muslims as meaning An argument, a plea, an allegation, an evidence, or a testimony, that is undecisive: and sometimes the same epithet is used [in like manner] in other cases. (L.) ＝ -A2- In some copies of the K, it is said to be [the name of] Certain roots and shoots, that grow in waters, useful for such and such things; arabicized from sAch [or saAdaho]: (TA:) or certain leaves and shoots, (O, CK,) used as a medicine, having a flower; one sort thereof called ruwmiIRN; and another, hinodiIRN; [the latter name, i. e. saAcajN hinodiIRN, as well as saAcajN alone, applied in the present day to malabathrum, or Indian spikenard;] growing in waters that collect and stagnate in black muddy lands, (O,) standing up on the surface of the water, (O, CK,) like the plant called Eadasu AlmaMCi, (O,) without attachment to a root; (O, CK;) beneficial for swellings of the eye. (CK.)

1 saOara c
1. saOara: see 4, in two places. ＝ -A2- saYira, aor.
saAa^a
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. suWorN, (Msb,) It remained; became left, as a residue. (Msb, K.)

4 AsOr c
4. AsOr He left a remainder, or somewhat remaining; (IAar, M, K;) as also saOara↓, (IAar, K,) or saOara suWorFA, (A,) inf. n. saOorN: (TK:) or he left somewhat of the beverage in the bottom of the vessel from which he had drunk; (S, TA;) as also AsOr fiI AlUinaMCi suWorFA: (A:) the doing of which is prescribed in a trad. (TA.) You say also AsOrhu He left it remaining. (Msb.) And AsOr suWorFA and suWorapF He left a remainder, or residue. (T, TA.) And AsOr minohu XayoYFA He left somewhat of it remaining. (M.) And OasoOarati AlUibilu fiI AlHawoDi; and suWorFA saOarato↓; The camels left some water remaining in the trough, or tank. (A.) Also AsOr mina AlTRaEaAmi suWorapF (tropical:) He left somewhat remaining of the food. (A.) And AsOr mino HisaAbihi (tropical:) He left somewhat of his calculation unreckoned. (M, * TA.)

5 tsORr c
5. tsORr (so in the Tekmileh and M and CK, and in a MS. copy of the K; but in some copies of the K, and in a copy of the A, tasaMCara↓;) He drank the remains: (A:) or the remainder of the nabiyc; (K;) or so tsORr AlnRabiyca. (Lh, M.)

6 tasaARa^a
6: see what next precedes.

suWorN c
suWorN A remainder, or residue; (T, M, Msb, K;) of a thing, (M,) or of anything; (TA;) as also suWorapN↓: (T:) or a remainder of beverage in the bottom of a vessel after one has drunk; (S, * A;) such as is left by a rat or mouse &c. after drinking: (S:) properly applied to a remainder of water left by the drinker in a vessel or wateringtrough: and tropically to (tropical:) a remainder of food, &c.: (Mgh:) and suWorapN↓ signifies likewise (tropical:) a remainder of food: (A:) pl. of the former OasoMrN, (S, M, Mgh, Msb,) and, by transposition, MsaArN, like MbaArN and MraAmN, pls. of biYorN and riYomN. (M.) [See also saAYirN, below.] ― -b2- AlSRaqori suWorapu↓ means (tropical:) What remains of the portion of the flesh of the game that is given to the hawk which has captured it. (A.) ― -b3- And suWorapN↓ also signifies (tropical:) A remainder of youthful vigour in a man, (M, K,) or in a woman who has passed the prime of youth, (Lth,) or in a woman who has passed the period of youth but not been rendered decrepit by old age. (A.) [See also suWodapN.] ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) What is good, or excellent, of property, or of camels or the like: pl. suWarN. (L.) [App. because such is left when one has parted with the bad.] ― -b5- suWorapN↓ mina AlquroMni (tropical:) [means A chapter of the Kur-án;] so called because it is a portion, (A,) or a remainder: (TA:) or it may be from the signification immediately preceding: (L:) or it is a dial. var. of suwrapN: (K:) pl. suWarN. (A, TA.) ― -b6- fulaAnN suWoru XarRK means Such a one is very evil or mischievous. (A.)

suWorapN c
suWorapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in five places.

saORLrN c
saORLrN One who leaves a remainder, or residue, (S, M, K,) of beverage in the bottom of the vessel from which he has drunk: (S, M:) [and (tropical:) of food in a dish; &c.:] deviating from rule, (S, M,) like jabRaArN from Oajobara: (S:) [see darRaAkN, which is said to be the only other instance of the kind:] by rule it should be musoYirN↓; (S, K;) which is [said to be] also allowable: (K:) but MF denies this; (TA;) or it may be [regular] from saOara or [irregular] from OasoOara. (T, TA.)

saAYirN c
saAYirN The rest, or remainder, (T, and M in art. syr, and Msb and K,) of a thing, (Z, M, Msb,) whether little or much; (T, Msb;) and of men, or people: (Sgh; Msb:) not the whole, or all, as many imagine it to mean, (Sgh, Msb, K,) though people use it in this latter sense, (IAth,) which Sgh asserts to be a vulgar error: (Msb:) it occurs repeatedly in trads., and always in the former sense: (IAth:) or it is sometimes used [in chaste Arabic] in the latter sense: (K:) and is correctly so used accord. to AAF and J and IJ and ElJawáleekee and IB, the last of whom confirms this signification by many examples and evident proofs: but whether, in this sense, it is derived from AlsRayor, as AAF and J and others hold, or from suwrN the “ wall which surrounds a town or city, ” as others hold, is disputed: (TA:) and saAru AlXRaIoCi is a dial. var. of saAYiruhu. (S in art. syr.) ― -b2- An Arab of the desert became the guest of a party, and they ordered the female slave to perfume him; whereupon he said, baToniI EaTRiriI wasaAYiriI cariI [My belly perfume thou, and the rest of me leave thou]: (K:) but in other lexicons than the K, we find OaEoTiriI. (TA in art. ETr.) This saying is a well-known prov. (TA.) [In the TA it is added that sAYry here signifies the whole of me, or all of me: but this is an evident mistake.] You say this to a man who gives you what you do not want, and refuses you what you want. (Sgh, TA in art. ETr.) ― -b3- It is related, also, that a hostile attack was made upon a people, and they cried out for aid to the sons of their uncle; but these held back from them until they had been made captives and taken away; then they came inquiring respecting them; and the person asked replied, OasaAYira Alyawomi waqado zaAla AlZRuhoru [What, all the day, when the noon has passed?] (K:) i. e., Dost thou covet what is remote, (maA baEuda, (S, K, TA, in a copy of the S and in one of the K and in the CK maA baEodu,) when [reason for] despair hath become manifest to thee: for when one wants the whole day, and the noon has passed, he must despair like as he despairs of accomplishing his want at sunset. (S in art. syr, and K.) This saying is a prov.; (S, A;) and is used with reference to a thing which one hopes to attain when its time has passed. (A.)

OasaAYiru c
[OasaAYiru expl. by Golius as a pl. meaning “ Partes reliquæ ” is an evident mistake, app. caused by a misunderstanding of the latter prov. mentioned above.]

musoYirN c
musoYirN: see saORLrN.

saOosamN c
saOosamN a dial. var. of saAsamN without C; A certain tree; [accord. to some,] i. q. XiyzaI. (TA.) [See art. ssm.]

1 saOalahu c
1. saOalahu (S, M, K) with kacaA following it, and saOalahu Eano kacaA and bikacaA, (S, * K,) aor. yasoOalu, (M,)
inf. n. suWaAlN and masoOalapN, (S, M, K,) which latter is also pronounced masalapN, without the hemzeh, (TA,) and tasoMlN and saMlapN, (M, K,) and saOalapN or saOolapN, (accord. to different copies of the K, the former of these two accord. to the TA, [and it appears from a statement that will be found below, voce suWolN, that one of these is correct, but in an excel-lent copy of the M, in the place thereof, I find, and saMCalahu↓, as a verb, doubly trans., first thus by itself, and secondly by means of Eano, as shown by an ex. in a verse cited below, (see 3,) and this also is correct,]) all [sometimes] signify the same, (S, * K,) i. e. He asked him such a thing; or asked him, interrogated him, questioned him, or inquired of him, respecting such a thing: but En kcA is more common than bkcA: when saOala means the asking, or demanding, of property, it is trans. [only] by itself or by means of mino [so that you say saOalahu kacaA and saOala minohu kacaA meaning he asked, or demanded, of him such a thing]: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and one says also saAla, aor. yasaAlu, (Akh, S, M, Msb, K,) like xaAfa, aor. yaxaAfu; (Msb, K;) which is of the dial. of Hudheyl; the medial letter of this being originally w, as is shown by the phrase, mentioned by AZ, humaA yatasaAwalaAni: (TA:) [respecting this dial. var., see what follows:] the imperative (S, Msb, K, TA;) of saOala (S, Msb, TA) is AisoOalo; (S, M, Msb, K, TA;) and (S, K, &c.) that of saAla, (S, Msb, TA,) salo, (S, Msb, K, TA,) dual. salaA, and pl. saluwA, [these two being] irregular; (Msb;) and AAF mentions that Aboo-'Othmán heard one say Aisalo, [a form omitted in some copies of the K, but mentioned in the CK,] meaning AisoOalo, suppressing the C, and transferring its vowel to the preceding letter, like as some of the Arabs said laHomaru for AlOaHomaru [as many do in the present day]: (M:) accord. to ISd, (TA,) the Arabs universally suppress the C in the imperative except when they prefix to it fa or wa; (M, TA;) saying faQsoOalo and waQsoOalo: (TA:) or when wa [or fa] is prefixed, it is allowable to pronounce the C and also to suppress it, as in saying waQsoOaluwA and wasaluwA: (Msb:) and for the pass. suYila, one may say siyla, and suyila, in this instance making the kesreh to partake of the sound of dammeh, and suwla; and also suyila, in which the middle letter is pronounced with a sound between that of C and that of I, or resembling that of w. (IJ, TA.) As Er-Rághib says, suWaAlN signifies The asking, or demanding, knowledge, or information, or what leads thereto: and the asking, or demanding, property, or what leads thereto. (TA.) saOalotuhu Eani AlXRaIoCi means I asked of him information respecting the thing: (IB, TA: [and the like is said in the Msb:]) and saOalotuhu AlXRaIoCa [is sometimes used in the same sense, as has been shown above, but generally] means I asked him to give me the thing: (IB, TA:) you say, saOalahu maAlFA He asked, demanded, or begged, of him property, and in like manner, saOala minohu and saOala Uilayohi [followed by maAlFA]: (MA:) and saOalotu QllReha AlEaAfiyapa, inf. n. suWaAlN and masoOalapN, I begged, or sought, of God health, or freedom from disease, &c. (Msb.) The saying in the Kur [lxx. 1], saOala saAYilN biEacaAbK waAqiEK means Eano EacaAbK [i. e. An asker asked respecting a falling punishment]: (S:) [for] one says, xarajonaA nasoOalu Eano fulaAnK and bifulaAnK [meaning We went forth asking respecting such a one]: (Akh, S:) or the phrase in the Kur means a caller called [for a falling punishment]: (TA:) and some read saAla saAYilN bEcAb wAqE, (Bd, TA,) [likewise] from AlsRuWaAlu: (Bd:) or this means saAla waAdK bEcAb wAqE [i. e. a valley flowed with a falling punishment]; (Bd, TA;) so some say; (TA;) from AlsRayalaAnu. (Bd.) The saying, in a trad., nahaI Eano kavorapi AlsRaWaAli [He (Mohammad) forbade much questioning or inquiring] is said to relate to subtile questions or inquiries, that are needless; like another trad., mentioned below, voce, masoOalapN: or to the begging, of men, their property needlessly. (TA.)

3 saMCalahu c
3. saMCalahu, (M, TA,) inf. n. musaMCalapN: (TA:) see 1, first sentence. Aboo-Dhu-eyb says,
OasaMCalota rasoma AldRaAri Oamo lamo tusaAYili
Eani AlsRakoni Oamo Eano Eahodihi biAlOawaAYili
[Didst thou ask the remains of the dwelling, or didst thou not ask, respecting the inhabitants, or respecting their knowledge of the former occupants?]. (M, TA.) ― -b2- In the saying of Bilál Ibn-Jereer,
wajadota bihimo EilRapF HaADiraho
UicaA Difotahumo Oawo saMyalotahumo
[When thou becomest their guest, or askest of them, thou findest with them a ready excuse], saMyalotahumo is a combination of two dial. vars.; the C being in the original phrase saMCalotu zayodFA, and the I being a substitute in the phrase saAyalotu zayodFA; the measure of saMyalotahumo being faEaAyalotahumo: (M, K: *) so said Ahmad Ibn-Yahyà, [i. e. Th,] who had at first ignored the expression: (M:) and it is an instance of which we know not a parallel in the language. (M, K. *) ― -b3- [Accord. to analogy, saMCalaha also signifies He asked him, &c., being asked by him, &c. ― -b4- And Freytag states that Reiske has explained saMCala as meaning He always demanded that another should express wishes for his health: but I know not any instance of its being used in this sense.]

4 OasoAa^a
4: OasoOalahu suWolahu↓, (K,) or suWolatahu↓, (S,) and masoOalatahu↓, (S, K,) He accomplished for him his want. (S, K.)

5 tsORl c
5. tsORl, in the modern language, signifies He begged, or asked alms; as also tasawRala: both probably post-classical.]

6 tasaMCaluwA c
6. tasaMCaluwA They asked, or begged, one another. (S, Msb, K.) You say, humaA yatasaMCalaAni, (M,) and also yatasaAwalaAni, (M, Msb, K,) and yatasaAyalaAni. (TA.) In the Kur [iv. 1], some read waQtRaquwA QllReha QlRaciI tasRaMCaluwna bihi; and others, tasaMCaluwna bihi: in each case, originally tatasaMCaluwna: the meaning is, [And fear ye God,] by Whom ye demand [one of another] your rights, or dues: (M:) or by Whom ye ask, or demand, one of another; (Bd, Jel;) saying, I ask thee, or beg thee, by God; and I beseech thee, or adjure thee, by God. (Jel.) ― -b2- One says also tasaMCaluwA Alqawoma, meaning They [together] asked, or begged, the people. (Mgh in art. nqD.)

suWolN c
suWolN, (S, M, K;) also pronounced suwlN, without C, (S, K,) [A petition; or a request; meaning] a thing that people ask or beg; (S;) or a thing that one has asked or begged; (M, K;) as also suWolapN↓, (IJ, M, K,) which is likewise pronounced suwlapN, without C; (K;) and suWuwlN↓; (Har p. 422; [or this is app. pl. of suWolN, like as buruwjN is of burojN, and buruwdN of burodN, &c.;]) [and saOolapN↓ or saOalapN, as will be shown by what follows;] and masoWuwlN↓; (Msb;) [and masoOalapN↓:] see 4: the first of these said by Z to be of the measure fuEolN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN; like EurofN and nukorN. (TA.) Thus in the Kur [xx. 36], qado Ouwtiyta suWolaka yaA muwsaI Thou hast been granted thy petition, or the thing that thou hast asked, O Moses. (S, M, TA.) In the saying AallRehumRa OaEoTinaA saOalaAtinaA↓ [O God, grant Thou us our petitions], mentioned by Aboo- 'Alee on the authority of AZ, the inf. n. is used as a subst., properly so termed, and is therefore pluralized. (M.)

saOolapN c
saOolapN or saOalapN; pl. saOalaAtN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

suWolapN c
suWolapN: see 4: and see also soWolN.

suWalapN c
suWalapN, (S, K,) also pronounced suwalapN, (TA,) A man (S) who asks, or begs, much; (S, K;) as also saORLlN↓, and saWuwlN↓: (TA:) such is improperly termed saAYilN↓. (Durrat el-Ghowwás, in De Sacy's Anthol. Gramm. Ar., p. 47 of the Ar. text.)

suWaAlN c
suWaAlN an inf. n. of 1. (S, M, K, &c.) ― -b2- [It is often used as a subst. properly so called; like masoOalapN; meaning A question; an interrogation; correlative of jawaAbN: and a demand, or petition: and as such has a pl., suWaAlaAtN; perhaps postclassical.]

saWuwlN c
saWuwlN: see suWalapN.

suWuwlN c
suWuwlN: see suWolN [of which it is app. pl.].

saORLlN c
saORLlN: see suWalapN.

saAYilN c
saAYilN [i. e. Asking; meaning interrogating, questioning, or inquiring; and demanding, or begging;] has for its pl. saOalapN and suWRaAlN. (TA.) See suWalapN. ― -b2- It also means [A beggar; i. e.] a poor man asking, or begging, a thing. (Er-Rághib, TA.) So it has been expl. as used in the Kur [xciii. 10], where it is said, waOamRaA QlsRaAYila falaA tanoharo [And as for the beggar, thou shalt not chide him, or address him with rough speech]: or, accord. to El-Hasan, it here means the seeker of knowledge. (TA.)

masoOalapN c
masoOalapN, an inf. n. of 1, is tropically used in the sense of a pass. part. n. [with the noun qualified by it understood; meaning (tropical:) A thing asked; i. e. a question; a problem, or proposition; a matter, or an affair, proposed for decision or determination]: (TA:) and the pl. is masaAYilu. (Msb, TA.) So in the saying, taEalRamotu masoOalapF (tropical:) [I learned a
question, or problem, &c.]. (TA.) The saying, in a trad., kariha AlmasaAYila waEaAbahaA means (assumed tropical:) [He (Mohammad) disliked and discommended] subtile questions, such as are needless. (TA.) ― -b2- See also suWolN: ― -b3- and see 4.

masoWuwlN c
masoWuwlN [pass. part. n. of 1: and used as a subst.]: see suWolN.

1 saYima minohu c
1. saYima minohu, (S, M, Msb, K,) and saYimahu, (M, Msb, K,) aor.
saAa^a
, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. saOamN (S, M, K) and saOomN (K) and saOamapN (S, M) and saMmN and saMmapN, (S, Msb, K,) He turned away with disgust from it; was averse from it; was disgusted at it or with it; loathed, or nauseated, it; (S, M, Msb, K;) namely, a thing; (S, M, K;) syn. malRa, (S, M, Msb, K,) and Dajira: (Msb:) saMmapN exceeds malaAlN. (Ham pp. 775-6.) It is said in the Kur [xli. 49], laA yasoOLmu QloUinosaAnu mino duEaMCi Qloxayori [Man will not turn away with disgust from, or will not be weary of, praying for good, or wealth, or prosperity]. (Msb.) And in a trad., UinRa QllReha laA yasoOamu HatRaI tasoOamuwA Verily God will not turn away with disgust until ye turn away with disgust; like laA yamalRu HatRaI tamalRuwA, and thus the trad. is commonly related. (TA.) And it is related in a trad. of 'Áïsheh that she used to say to the Jews, Ealayokumo AlsRaOomu waAlcRaOomu waAllRaEonapu [Disgust, or loathing, and contempt, and cursing, rest upon you]: thus related with C, meaning ye shall turn away with disgust from your religion: but commonly related without C [and with a different meaning], as will be stated hereafter [in art. swm]. (IAth, TA in this art. and in art. swm.)

4 AsOmhu c
4. AsOmhu He, or it, made him to turn away with disgust, to be averse, to be disgusted, to loathe, or to nauseate. (M, K.)

saWuwmN c
saWuwmN an [intensive] epithet from 1 [meaning Wont, or much disposed, to turn away with disgust, to be averse, to be disgusted, to loathe, or to nauseate]: (S, M, K:) or much affected with vexation, or disgust; having little patience. (Ham p. 532.)

1 saMhu c
1. saMhu, (S, M, K,) like ramaAhu, [or rather like daEaAhu,] incorrectly [and differently] written in copies of the K, (TA,) i. q. saMCahu, (S, M, K, TA,) formed from the latter by transposition; (S, M;) mentioned by Sb: you say, saMhu AlOamoru, like saMCahu [The affair displeased, grieved, or vexed, him]: (M:) and saOawotuhu, meaning suWotuho [I displeased, grieved, or vexed, him]. (S, TA.) ― -b2- And saOaA bayonahumo, (K, TA,) inf. n. saOowo, (TA,) He created, or excited, disorder, or discord, between them, or among them; made, or did, mischief between them, or among them: (K, TA:) mentioned by Az: app. a dial. var. of saEaI. (TA.)

4 OasoOayotu Alqawosa c
4. OasoOayotu Alqawosa I made a siYap [q. v.] to the bow. (K, TA.)

saOapN c
saOapN: see what next follows.

suWapN c
suWapN: see what next follows.

siYapN c
siYapN of a bow, and suWapN↓, (Ibn-Málik, Az, ISd, K, TA,) and saOapN↓, (Ibn-Málik, K, TA,) [in the CK erroneously written sACap, and it is there implied that the other vars. are siyoYapN and suwoCapN,] dial. vars. of siyapN, (K, &c.,) i. e. The curved extremity thereof. (TA.) [See also art. syw.]

masoMpN c
masoMpN, like masoEaApN, is a dial. var. of masaMCapN, [or] formed from the latter by transposition; and has for its pl. masaMCK: whence the saying, Oakorahu masaAYiyaka [I dislike, or hate, thy vices, faults, or acts of disobedience]: (TA:) Sb mentions this saying; (M, TA;) and says, masaMCapN is pluralized, and then the pl. is transformed, so that it is as though it were pl. of masoMpN, like masoEaApN. (M.)

1 sabRahu c
1. sabRahu, (S, M, K,) [aor.
sabuba
,] inf. n. sabRN, (M,) He cut him, or it. (S, M, K.) ― -b2- And i. q. Eaqarahu [i. e. He wounded him; or hocked, houghed, or hamstrung, him; &c.]. (S, * K.) ― -b3- And, (S, M, K,) aor. as above, (S, TA,) and so the inf. n., (M, TA,) (tropical:) He pierced him in the sabRapN, i. e. the Aisot. (S, M, K, TA.) [See an ex. in a verse cited in the first paragraph of art. sr.] ― -b4- Also sabRahu, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) aor. as above, (S, M,) inf. n. sabRN (S, M, Msb, K) and sibRiybaI, (K,) [but the latter, accord. to analogy, has an intensive signification,] He reviled him, vilified him, upbraided him, reproached him, defamed him, or gave a bad name to him; (S, M, A, MA, K, Bd in vi. 108, &c.;) from the same verb in the first of the senses expl. in this art.; (M;) as also sbRbhu↓; (K;) or the latter signifies he reviled him, vilified him, &c., much; syn. Oakovara sabRahu; (M;) or is more than sabRahu (Oakovaru mino sabRahu). (TA.)

2 sabRaRa
2: see what next precedes. ＝ -A2- sbRb liloOamori, (MA,) inf. n. tasobiybN, (KL, PS,) (assumed tropical:) He made, or appointed, or prepared, a means, or cause, (MA, KL, PS,) of attaining, or accomplishing, the thing, or affair. (MA.) [And sbRb, alone, (assumed tropical:) He, or it, caused or, occasioned.] You say, sabRaba QllRehu laka sababa xayorK (tropical:) [May God make, or appoint, or prepare, for thee a means of attaining good, or prosperity]. (A, TA.) And sbRb lilomaMCi majorFI (tropical:) He made, or prepared, a channel for the water. (A, TA.)

3 sAbRhu c
3. sAbRhu, inf. n. sibaAbN (S, * M, A, Msb, K *) and musaAbRapN, (M, Msb, KL, TA,) He reviled him, vilified him, upbraided him, reproached him, defamed him, or gave a bad name to him, (M, A, KL, TA,) being reviled, &c., by him. (M, A, TA.) You say, bayonahumaA sibaAbN Between them two is mutual reviling, &c. (A.) And AlmizaAHu sibaAbu AlnRawokaI [Jesting is the mutual reviling, &c., of those that are foolish, or stupid]. (A, TA.) And it is said in a trad., sbaAbu Almusolimi fusuwqN (TA) The mutual reviling of the Muslim is a departure from obedience to God. (El-Munáwee in his Expos. of the Jámi' es-Sagheer of Es-Suyootee.)

5 tsbRb c
5. tsbRb [as quasi-pass. of 2, (assumed tropical:) It was, or became, made, or appointed, or prepared, as a means, or cause, of attaining, or accomplishing a thing, or an affair; followed by liOamorK. And It was, or became, caused, or occasioned]. You say, tsbRb maAlu AlfaIoCi (assumed tropical:) [The property of the spoil, or acquisition, or tribute, termed faIoC was caused, or occasioned, to accrue]: for that whereby the property is caused, or occasioned, [to be obtained, as the abandonment of their abodes by unbelievers, or their making peace with Muslim invaders on the condition of paying a poll-tax or the like,] is made a means, or cause, of the accruing of the property to those to whom it is due of the recipients of the faIoC (Az, TA.) [See also 10.] ― -b2- tsbRb bihi UilaI XaIoCK (assumed tropical:) He made use of it as a means, or cause, of attaining, or accomplishing, a thing. (M.) And OatasabRabu bifulaAnK Uilayoka (assumed tropical:) [I make use of such a one as a means of access to thee]. (TA in art. crE.) ― -b3- [Hence, in the present day, tsbRb is used as meaning (assumed tropical:) He trafficked; because trafficking is a using means to procure subsistence.]

6 tasaAbRaA c
6. tasaAbRaA, (K,) [or tsAbRwA,] inf. n. tasaAbRN, (S,) They two cut each other, (S, * K,) [or they (i. e. more than two persons) cut one another.] ― -b2- [Hence, (see 1, last sentence,)] tsAbRwA, (S, M, A, MA, K,) inf. n. as above; (S;) and AstbRwA↓; (A, MA;) They reviled, vilified, upbraided, reproached, defamed, or gave bad names to, one another. (S, M, A, MA.) And bayonahumo OusobuwbapN yatasaAbRuwna bihaA (S, M, A, * TA) Between them is a thing [meaning reviling or vilifying speech] with which they revile, or vilify, &c., one another. (M, TA.)

8 Uisotababa
8: see the next preceding paragraph.

10 AstsbR liOabawayohi c
10. AstsbR liOabawayohi [He invited, or attracted, reviling, or vilifying, to his two parents]. (A.) It is said in a trad. of Aboo-Hureyreh, laA tamoXiyanRa OamaAma Oabiyka walaA tajoliso qabolahu walaA tadaEohu biQsomihi walaA tasotasibRa lahu, i. e. [By no means walk thou before thy father, nor sit down before him, nor call him by his name,] nor expose him to reviling, or attract reviling to him, by reviling another's father, for in that case he may revile thy father in requital to thee. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Aisotasobaba lahu AlOamoru (tropical:) (A, TA) [The thing, or affair, or event, became caused, or prepared, for him: thus expl. by IbrD: see also 5].

R. Q. 1 sabosaba c
R. Q. 1. sabosaba (assumed tropical:) He severed his tie, or ties, of relationship, by unkind behaviour to his kindred. (AA.) ＝ -A2- He went a gentle pace. (AA. [Freytag, on the authority of “ Hamak. Waked., ” assigns this meaning to tasabosaba↓.]) ＝ -A3- He smelt a foul smell. (AA.) ＝ -A4- He discharged his urine. (M, K.) He made water to flow. (K.)

R. Q. 2 tasabosaba c
R. Q. 2. tasabosaba It (water) ran, or flowed. (K.) ― -b2- See also R. Q. 1.

sibRN c
sibRN One who reviles, vilifies, upbraids, reproaches, or defames, much, being reviled, &c.; (A'Obeyd, S, M, Msb, * K;) as also misabRN↓. (S, K.) And [simply] One's mutual reviler or vilifier &c.; (A'Obeyd, S, M, K;) as also sabiybN↓
(M, K.) A poet, (S,) namely, 'Abd-Er-Rahmán Ibn-Hassán, satirizing Miskeen Ed-Dárimee, (TA,) says,
laA tasubRanRaniI falasota bisibRiI
UinRa sibRiI mina AlrRijaAli Alkariymu
[Thou shalt by no means revile me; for thou art not my mutual reviler: verily he, of men, who is my mutual reviler is the generous]. (S, TA.) [See also musotabRN: and sabRaAbN.] ＝ -A2- A veil, or the like; syn. sitorN. (M.) ― -b2- A woman's muffler, or head-covering; syn. ximaArN. (S, M, Msb, K.) ― -b3- A turban. (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K.) El-Mukhabbal Es-Saadee says, (S, M, Mgh,) using it in this sense, (M, Mgh,)
waOaXohadu mino EawofK HuluwlFA kaviyrapF
yaHujRuwna sibRa AlzRiboriqaAni AlmuzaEofaraA
[And I witness many persons of 'Owf, alighting during their journeys, going repeatedly to and fro to see Ez-Zibrikán's turban dyed with saffron]: (S, M, Mgh:) for it was a custom of the chiefs of the Arabs to dye their turbans with saffron: or, as some say, the meaning is his Aisot; [but this is correctly, or more commonly, termed sabRap;] and Ktr asserts that he was suspected: (M:) he says that Ez-Zibrikán used to tinge his Ast yellow; but this is a strange saying. (TA in art. zbrq.) ― -b4- Also, and sabiybapN↓, An oblong piece (S, M, K) of cloth, (M,) or of thin cloth, (K,) or of thin linen cloth, (S,) or of white cloth: (M:) or a thin garment: (Aboo-'Omar, TA:) or so the latter word: (M:) or this signifies a linen stuff that is brought from the region of the Nile, of a kind commonly known among the merchants by [the name of] krx, some of which are made in Misr, and their length is eight by six [cubits: cubits being meant because the ns. of number here are fem., and ciraAE is fem.]: (Sh, TA:) or this same word signifies an oblong piece of cloth of any kind, or, as some say, of linen: (TA:) the pl. of the former is subuwbN; (S, K, TA;) and of the latter, sabaAYibN: (S, M, K, TA:) in a verse of 'Alkameh Ibn-'Abadeh, the phrase bisabaA AlkatRaAni is used for bisabaAYibi AlktRAn. (M.) ― -b5- See also sababa, first signification.

sabRapN c
sabRapN i. q. AisotN (tropical:) [The podex, or the anus]: (S, M, A, K:) because it is discommended. (A.) [See also sibRN.] ＝ -A2- maDato sabRapN mina AldRahori (tropical:) A space, or long space, of time passed; (S, M, A;) [thus termed] because time is always complained of; (A;) and so sanobapN, in which the n is [said to be] a substitute for the [former] b of sabRapN, in like manner as it is substituted in the case of UijRaASN and UinojaASN; because [it is asserted, though this is contradicted, that] there is no word of which the radical letters are snb. (M.) And maA raOayotuhu munocu sabRapK (assumed tropical:) I have not seen him for, or during, a space, or long space, of time; (S, K; *) like as you say munocu sanobapK. (S.) And EiXonaA bihaA sabRapF and sanobapF (assumed tropical:) We lived in it a space, or long space, of time. (Ks, TA.) And OaSaAbatonaA sabRapN mina AlHarRi, and Albarodi, and AlSRaHowi, (K, * TA,) and AlrRawoHi, (TA,) (tropical:) A period of some days' continuance [of heat, and of cold and of serene weather, and of gentle wind, betided us]. (K, TA.) [The pl. is sibaAbN.] One says, AldRahoru sibaAbN (assumed tropical:) Time consists of vicissitudes; one turn is thus, and one is thus. (ISh, TA.)

subRapN c
subRapN A disgrace; a shame; a thing that occasions one's being reviled. (S, M, A, K.) One says, SaAra hecaA AlOamoru subRapF Ealayohi This thing became a disgrace to him, occasioning his being reviled. (S.) And Oanota subRapN EalaI qawomika [Thou art a disgrace to thy people]. (A.) [And masabRapN↓, in like manner, (a word of the class of maboxalapN and majobanapN, being originally masobabapN,) signifies A cause of reviling, or of being reviled; as is shown by the saying of Tufeyl El-Ghanawee, cited in the TA in art. Eqb,
falamo yajidi AlOaqowaAmu fiynaA masabRapF
And the people did not find in us a cause of reviling, or of being reviled: pl. masaAbRu.] One says, UiyRaAka waAlmasabRapa↓ and AlmasaAbRa [Beware thou of, or avoid thou, the cause of reviling or of being reviled, and the causes thereof]. (A.) ― -b2- Also One whom people revile (S, K) much. (K.) See also subabapN.

AlsRibRapu c
AlsRibRapu: see AlsRabRaAbapu.

sababN c
sababN A rope, or cord; (S, M, A, Msb, K;) as also sibRN↓; (S, M, K;) the latter of the dial. of Hudheyl, (S,) and occurring in this sense in a verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb cited voce xayoTapN; (S, M;) accord. to some, as there meaning a wooden peg, [a meaning assigned to it in the K,] but the former is the correct meaning: (M:) the pl. of both words is OasobaAbN, (M, TA, *) [and] the pl. of the latter word is subuwbN (S, TA) also: (TA:) or sababN signifies any rope let down, or made to descend, from above: (AO, TA:) or a strong and long rope, but no rope is so called except one by means of which one ascends and descends: (Khálid Ibn-Jembeh, TA:) or this appellation is only given to a rope of which one end is attached to a roof or ceiling or the like: (TA:) or one by means of which one ascends palm-trees: (Er-Rághib, TA:) [and] a rope by means of which one reaches, or gains access to, water. (TA.) faloyamodudo bisababK UilaI QlsRamaMCi vumRa liyaqoTaEo, in the Kur [xxii. 15], means Let him stretch a rope to the roof, or ceiling, of his dwelling; then let him die strangled: i. e. let him die of rage: (M, TA:) or, as some say, let him stretch a rope to the lowest heaven; then let him traverse the intervening space until he reach the highest part thereof. (Bd.) The saying
jabRato nisaMCa AlEaAlamiyna biAlsRababo
has been expl. in art. jb: in this instance, a rope or cord, may be meant; or a string, or thread. (M, TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (Msb,) (tropical:) A thing (S, M, Msb, K) of any kind (S, Msb, K) by means of which one attains, reaches, or gains access to another thing: (S, M, Msb, K:) pl. as above. (M.) One says, jaEalotu fulaAnFA liI sababFA UilaI fulaAnN fiI HaAjatiI, i. e. (assumed tropical:) [I made such a one] a means of access [to such a one in the case of my want]. (TA.) Hence, (M,) OasobaAbu AlsRamaMCi (assumed tropical:) The places of ascent of the heaven, or sky: (M, K:) or the tracts, or regions, thereof: (S, K:) or the gates thereof. (Ibn-Es-Seed, K. [See an ex. in a verse cited voce vamaAnuwna.]) And the saying, AirotaqaI fiI AlOasobaAbi, meaning (assumed tropical:) He excelled [or attained to excellence] in religion. (M.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) A road, or way. (A. [There mentioned among proper, not tropical, significations.]) So in the saying, in the Kur xviii. 88 and 91, vumRa QtRabaEa sababFA (assumed tropical:) [Then he followed a road, or way]. (Bd.) [And] so in the saying, maA liI Uilayohi sababN (assumed tropical:) [There is not for me any road, or way, to him, or it]. (A.) So too sabiybapN↓: pl. sabaAYibu. (Ham p. 347.) ― -b4- [(assumed tropical:) A mean, or means, used in order to any end: a means by which a thing is brought about: a cause; but more properly only a second cause: an occasion, or accidental cause: and a reason, or motive.] One says, hecaA sababu hecaA (assumed tropical:) [This is the cause, or occasion, of this]. (Msb.) And bisababihi kaAna kacaA (assumed tropical:) [Because of him, or it, it was thus, or such a thing was]. (Msb in art Ajl.) And sabRaba QllRehu laka sababa xayorK (tropical:) [May God appoint, or prepare, for thee a means, or cause, of good, or prosperity]. (A.) ― -b5- (tropical:) A connexion, or tie, (S, A, K, TA,) of relationship (S, K, TA) by marriage; distinguished from nasabN, which is by birth: from the same word as signifying “ a rope by means of which one reaches, or gains access to, water. ” (TA.) One says, AinoqaTaEa bayonahumu AlsRababu i. e. (tropical:) The connexion, or tie, [of affinity between them was severed,] and AlOasobaAbu the connexions, or ties. (A) wataqaTRaEato bihimu AlOasobaAbu [in the Kur ii. 161] means, accord. to I'Ab, (assumed tropical:) And their ties and affections [shall be dissundered]: or, accord. to AZ, (assumed tropical:) and their places of abode [shall be divided asunder]. (TA.) [But] qaTaEa QllRehu bihi AlsRababa means (assumed tropical:) [God cut short, or may God cut short,] his life. (M, K.) ― -b6- Also, [from the same word as signifying the “ cord, or rope, of a bayot, ” properly meaning “ tent, ” and tropically “ verse, ”] (assumed tropical:) A portion, or division, of a foot of a verse, consisting of a movent letter and a quiescent letter; and also one consisting of two movent letters: pl. OasobaAbN. (M, K. [In some of the copies of the K, the latter kind is not mentioned.]) sababN xafiyfN (assumed tropical:) [A light cord] means a movent letter followed by a quiescent letter; as qumo and mino: and sababN vaqiylN (assumed tropical:) [A heavy cord], two movent letters; as laka and lima. (KT.) sababaAni maqoruwnaAni (assumed tropical:) [Two conjoined cords] means two portions in which are three successive short vowels followed by a quiescent letter; as mutafaA in mutafaAEiluno, and Ealatuno in mufaAEalatuno: and sababaAni maforuwqaAni (assumed tropical:) [Two disjoined cords], two portions of which each consists of a movent letter and a quiescent letter, and which is followed by a movent letter; as musotafo in musotafoEiluno, and Eiyluno in mafaAEiyluno. (M, TA.)

subabapN c
subabapN One who reviles people; (S, K;) as also
masabRapN↓. (K.) One says, laA takuno subabapF walaA subRapF↓ [Be not thou a reviler of others, nor one whom others revile]. (A.)

sababiIRN c
[sababiIRN Causative.]

sababiyRapN c
[sababiyRapN Causality.]

sabiybN c
sabiybN: see sibRN, second sentence. ＝ -A2- Also The hair of the forelock, (AO, S, M, A, K,) and of the tail, (S, M, A, K,) the latter meaning [only] assigned to it by Er-Riyáshee, (TA,) and of the mane, (S, M, K,) of a horse: (M, A, K:) pl. OasaAbiybu and sabaAYibu. (A, TA.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) A lock (xuSolap) of hair; as also sabiybapN↓: (M, K:) pl. sabaAYibu: which is also expl. as (tropical:) syn. with cawaAYibu [app. as meaning pendent locks, or pendent plaits, of hair]: (TA:) thus in the phrase AimoraOapN Tawiylapu AlsRabaAYibi (tropical:) A woman having the cwAYb long. (A, TA.)

sabiybapN c
sabiybapN see sibRN: ― -b2- and sabiybN: ― -b3- and sababN. ― -b4- Ealayohi sabaAYibu AldRami means (tropical:) Upon him are, or were, streaks of blood: (A, TA:) the sing. of sbAYb in this sense is sabiybapN. (Ham p. 347.) ＝ -A2- Also [Trees of the kind called] EDaAh abounding in a place. (M, K.)

sabRaAbN c
sabRaAbN [That cuts much, or sharply]. sabRaAbu AlEaraAqiybi means The sword: (K, TA:) or is an epithet applied to the sword: (A:) because it cuts the ErAqyb [or hock-tendons]: (TA:) [but Z holds it to be tropical, from the signification following; for] it is added in the A, as though it were hostile to the ErAqyb, and reviled them. (TA.) ― -b2- [One who reviles much or frequently; or a great reviler: a meaning indicated in the Msb, and of frequent occurrence.]

AlsRabRaAbapu c
AlsRabRaAbapu, an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant, (M,) (tropical:) [The index, or fore finger;] the finger that is next to the thumb (S, M, A, * Msb, K, TA) and middle-finger; (M, TA;) between these two; (TA;) as also AlsRibRapu↓: (K:) so called because one [often] points with it in reviling: (Msb:) called by persons praying AlmusabRiHapu and AlsRabRaAHapu [because it is raised in asserting the unity of God]. (TA in the present art. and in art. sbH.)

sabosabN c
sabosabN A desert; or a desert in which is no water, or in which is neither water nor herbage; syn. mafaAzapN (S, K) and qaforN: (TA:) or a tract of land level and far-extending: (M, K:) or a [desert such as is termed] qafor that is far-extending, whether level or not level, rugged or not rugged, without water and without any one to cheer by his presence: (ISh, TA:) or a land affected with drought, barrenness, or dearth: (Aboo-Kheyreh, TA:) and basobasN signifies the same: (TA:) pl. sabaAsibu: (M, TA:) A 'Obeyd explains sabaAsibu and basaAbisu as syn. with qifaArN, [pl. of qaforN]. (TA.) One says also baladN sabosabN, (S, (K,) [using the latter word as an epithet;] and baladN sabaAsibu, (Lh, S, M, K,) thus using the pl. as though he termed every part of the balad a sabosab; (Lh, M;) or the pl. is added to give intensiveness to the meaning: (IAth, TA voce baloqaEN, q. v.:) but some say subaAsibN↓, with damm; and this is more common, because it is a sing. epithet. (MF, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also i. q. saAsabN [or sayosabN (q. v. in art. ssb), if not a mistranscription for this last], i. e. A kind of tree, from which arrows, or, as in the book of AHn, camels' saddles (riHaAl), are made: Ru-beh says, [accord. to one reading, another being given in art. ssb, q. v.,]
raAHato waraAHa kaEaSaA AlsRabosaAbi↓
[She went, and he went, like the rod of the sebsáb, meaning, the arrow]; in which the last word is a dial. var. of AlsRabosab, or the A is inserted by poetic license. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, perhaps,] AlsRabaAsibu, (M, K,) or yawomu AlsRabaAsibi, (S, TA,) A certain festival of the Christians; (S, * TA;) i. q. OayRaAmu, AlsRaEaAniyni, (Abu-l-'Alà, M, K,) or yawomu AlsRaEaAniyni [Palm-Sunday; now commonly called OaHadN AlXRaEaAniyn or Eiydu AlXRaEaAniyn, with X]. (TA.)

sabosaAbN c
sabosaAbN: see the next preceding paragraph.

subaAsibN c
subaAsibN: see the next preceding paragraph.

OusobuwbapN c
OusobuwbapN [like OuhojuwRapN, contr. of OumoduwHapN,] A thing [meaning reviling speech] with which persons revile one another: (M, TA:) pl. OasaAbiybu. (A, TA.) Using it in this sense, (M, TA,) one says, bayonahumo OusobuwbapN yatasaAbRuwna bihaA [Between them is reviling speech] (S, M, A, * K) with which they revile one another. (M, TA.)

OasaAbiybu c
OasaAbiybu pl. of sabiybN: ＝ -A2- and also of OusobuwbapN. ＝ -A3- OasaAbiybu Alwajohi The beauties of the face. (TA in art. sr.)

misabRN c
misabRN: see sibRN, first signification.

masabRapN c
masabRapN: see subRapN, in two places: ― -b2- and subabapN.

musabRabN c
musabRabN [Much reviled: see its verb]. ― -b2- musabRabapN as an epithet applied to camels, (S, K, TA,) or to horses, (A,) and to wild asses, (TA,) means (tropical:) Goodly, or excellent: (S, A, * K, TA:) because (S, TA) they are such that one says of them, (S, A, TA,) when admiring them, (S, TA,) or when deeming them goodly, or excellent, (A,) May God curse them, (qaAtalahaA QllRehu, S, A, TA,) and abase them: (OaxozaAhaA: A, TA:) how goodly, or excellent, are they! (TA.) ＝ -A2- [Also Made, appointed, or prepared, as a means, or cause, of attainment or accomplishment, liOamorK for a thing, or an affair. And Caused, or occasioned: and a thing caused or occasioned; an effect.] One says, hecaA musabRabN Eano hecaA [This is caused, or occasioned, by that: this is an effect of, or arising from, that]. (Msb.)

musabRibN c
musabRibN [Reviling much: see its verb. ＝ -A2- And Making, appointing, or preparing, a means, or cause: and causing, or occasioning: and a causer]. musabRibu AlOasobaAbi [The Appointer, or Preparer, of means or causes; or the Causer of causes;] is an epithet applied to God. (S.)

musotabRN c
musotabRN [act. and pass. part. n. of 8]. It is said in a trad., AlmusotabRaAni XayoTaAnaAni (A, TA) The two mutual revilers are two devils. (El-Munáwee in his Expos. of the Jámi' es-Sagheer of EsSuyootee.)

1 sabaOa Alxamora c
1. sabaOa Alxamora, (S, M, K,) aor.
sabaAa
, (M, K,) inf. n. saboCN (S, M, K) and sibaMCN, (M, K, TA,) like kitaAbN, (TA, in the CK sabAC,) [but see sibaMCN below,] and masobaON; (S, K;) and AstbOhA↓; (S, M, K;) He bought wine, syn. XaraAhaA, (M, K,) which mostly means “ he sold it, ” (TA,) or AiXotaraAhaA, (S, O,) which is well known as meaning “ he bought it, ” wherefore it is here used in the S and O, (TA,) in order that he might drink it: (S, O:) accord. to Ks, (TA,) when you buy wine to carry it to a place, you say, sabayotu Alxamora, without C; (S, TA;) and so say the [other] celebrated lexicologists, except Fei, accord. to whom you say in this case [as in others], sabaOotuhaA; and it is itself called sabiyoYapN: (TA:) the verbs are only used, in the sense of buying, in relation to wine. (S, Msb, TA.) [See also art. sbI.] ― -b2- And sabaOa AlXRaraAba He collected the wine in vessels: occurring in this sense in a trad. (Aboo-Moosà, TA.) ＝ -A2- sabaOatohu, (M,) or sabaOati Aljiloda, (K,) said of fire, (M, K,) and of whips, (M,) It, or they, burned, or hurt, (M, K,) or, as some say, (M, but in the K “ and, ”) altered, (M, K,) him, (M,) or the skin: (K:) and in like manner one says of the sun, and of fever, and of journeying. (M.) ― -b2- And sabaOotuhu biAlnRaAri I burned him with fire: (AZ, S:) or sabaOa jilodahu, inf. n. saboCN, He burned his skin; or, as some say, stripped it off: (M:) or sabaOa Aljiloda he burned the skin: and sabaOa signifies also he stripped off [skin], or he skinned. (K.) ― -b3- And sabaOotu AlrRajula, (inf. n. saboCN, TA,) I flogged the man. (S, K. *) ＝ -A3- sabaOa EalaI yamiynK kaAcibapK, (S, M,) aor.
sabaAa
, inf. n. saboCN, (M,) He passed over a false oath [that he had sworn], not caring for it: (S): or he swore a false oath: and some say, sabaOa EalaI yamiynK, aor. and inf. n. as above, meaning he passed over an oath [that he had sworn], lying. (M.) ＝ -A4- sabaOa is also syn. with SaAfaHa [He took by the hand: &c.]: (O, K:) deemed by MF a strange meaning. (TA.)

4 AsbO c
4. AsbO He (a man) was, or became, silent. (Sh, TA in art. rTm.) ― -b2- AsbO liOamori QllRehi He, (M, K,) or his heart, (L,) was, or became, submissive to the decree of God. (M, L, K.) ― -b3- And AsbO EalaI AlXRaIoCi His heart became in a bad state, or heavy, (xabuva, [so in the M and in a copy of the K, in the CK and TA xabata, and thus in my MS. copy of the K, but there altered from xabuva, app. on the authority of the TA, and I think it a mistranscription, although expl. in the TA as meaning AinoxaDaEa, which is a signification of Oaxobata, the explanation of AsbO in the next preceding sentence,]) at the thing. (M, K.)

7 AnsbO c
7. AnsbO It (the skin) was, or became, stripped.
off. (S, M.) ― -b2- And It (a person's skin) peeled off, or became abraded. (TA.)

8 UisotabaAa
8: see 1, first sentence.

sabaON c
sabaON: see sabiyoYapN ＝ -A2- tafarRaquwA OayodiI sabaA, and OayaAdiI sabaA, (M, K,) and with cahabuwA in the place of tfrRqwA, (T, TA,) They became scattered, or dispersed, (K, TA,) and they went away in a state of dispersion, in the ways of Seba, (T, TA,) a people of El-Yemen, who were dispersed in consequence of the inundation of their lands by the bursting of their [famous] dam, (TA,) and who became proverbial on that account: (M, K, TA:) sabaA is here made indecl., (M, K, TA, [banuwhu in the CK being a mistranscription for banawohu, wherefore kmA tabadRad has been there interpolated, immediately before banuwhu,]) with the last letter quiescent, and forms, with the preceding word, a compound like xamosapa EaXara [which implies that we should read OayodiI sabaA and OayaAdiIasabaA, but I have never found it thus written]: (TA:) it is not formed from sabaOa by suppression of the C, but is a substitute for that word, (M, K, TA,) on account of the frequent use of this phrase. (M, TA.) [See also art. sbI.]

suboOapN c
suboOapN A long, or far, journey, (IAar, T, M, K,) that alters one: (IAar, M, TA:) so termed because the sun alters him who makes a long journey. (T, TA. [See 1.]) You say, UinRaka laturiydu suboOapF Verily thou desirest a long journey, (IAar, M, K, *) that will alter thee. (IAar, M.) In the case of a short journey, you say, turiydu surobapF. (T, TA.)

AlsRabaYiyRapu c
AlsRabaYiyRapu, (S, and so in a copy of the K,) or AlsRabaAYiyRapu↓; (so in another copy of the K and accord. to the CK;) MF says that the former is the correct term, but both are correct; (TA;) Certain of the gulaAp, (S, K, TA,) i. e. extravagant zealots of the class of innovators; a party of the gulaAp of the XiyEap [q. v.]; who are divided into eighteen sects: (TA:) they are so called in relation to Seba (sabaO) the father of 'Abd-Allah, (K,) or in relation to 'Abd-Allah Ibn-Seba. (S.)

sibaMCN c
sibaMCN [The purchase of wine;] a subst. from sabaOa Alxamora; (S;) or an inf. n. (M, K, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also sabiyoYapN, in two places.

sabiIoCN c
sabiIoCN The skin, or slough, of a serpent; (K;) as also sabiIRN; for it is with, and without, C. (TA.)

sabiyoYapN c
sabiyoYapN (S, M, K) and sibaMCN↓ (M, K) and, accord. to Ks, sabaOo↓, but the form commonly known is sibaMCN↓, with kesr to the s, and with medd, (IAmb, TA,) Wine, (S, M, K,) in an absolute sense; (TA;) or, [as is perhaps meant in the S,] wine that is bought to be drunk, not for merchandise. (Har p. 409, in explanation of the first word.) [See an ex. of the second in a verse of Lebeed cited in art. dkn: and see also sabiyRapN, in art. sbI.]

AlsRabaAYiyRapu c
AlsRabaAYiyRapu: see AlsRabaYiyRapu, above.

sabRaMCN c
sabRaMCN A vintner, or seller of wine. (S, M, K.) ― -b2- [It is said in a marginal note in my MS. copy of the K that it signifies also A seller of graveclothes: but this is evidently a mistake, app. occasioned by a mistranscription, for sayRaMC, with I.]

masobaON c
masobaON A road (S, K) in a mountain. (S.)

1 sabata c
1. sabata, (S, M, Msb,) aor.
sabuta
(S, Msb) only, (S,) or
sabita
, (so written in a copy of the M,) [both of which are said by MF to be indicated, or implied, in the K, but this is not clearly the case,] inf. n. sabotN, (M, K, * TA,) He rested: (S, M, Msb, K: *) and ceased, or abstained, from works: (TA:) and was, or became, quiet, still, or motionless: (M, TA:) and Asbt↓ signifies [the same, or] he was, or became, motionless: (S, TA:) Az says that sabata in the first of these senses is not known in the language of the Arabs: (TA:) [but J says that] the primary signification of subaAtN is “ rest: ” and hence the former of these verbs signifies he slept. (S.) ― -b2- And sabatati Alyahuwdu, (S, * A, K,) aor.
sabita
(S, K) and
sabuta
, (K,) inf. n. sabotN, (S, K,) The Jews kept, or performed, the ordinances of their sabot [or sabbath]: (S, K: *) or sabatuwA, aor.
sabita
(M, Msb) and
sabuta
, (M,) inf. n. sabotN; (Msb;) and AsbtwA↓; (S, M, Msb;) they entered upon the sabot [or sabbath]: (S, M:) or they (the Jews) ceased from seeking the means of subsistence, and the labouring to acquire gain. (Msb.) It is said in the Kur [vii. 163], wayawoma laA yasobituwna And on the day when they were not keeping the ordinances of their sabot: (S:) where some read lA yusobituwna↓, from Oasobata; and some, lA yusobatuwna↓, in the pass. form, meaning when they were not made to enter upon [the observance of] the sabot. (Bd.) ＝ -A2- sabatato, aor.
sabita
, inf. n. sabotN, She (a camel) went the pace termed sabotN meaning as expl. below. (M.) ― -b2- And sabotN signifies also The outstripping in running. (M.) ＝ -A3- And as inf. n. of sabata said of a man, (TK,) sabotN also signifies The being confounded, or perplexed, unable to see one's right course, (K, TA,) and being [therefore] silent, or lowering the eyes, looking towards the ground. (TA.) ＝ -A4- sabata AlXRaIoCa, (M, TA,) inf. n. sabotN, (M, A, Mgh, K,) i. q. qaTaEahu [meaning He cut the thing; or cut it off; severed it; and intercepted, or interrupted, it; put a stop, or an end, to it; or made it to cease; relating to ideal as well as real objects; for instance, to work, or action, as is shown in the TA]; (M, A, Mgh, K, TA;) as also sbRthu↓: expl. by Lh as relating particularly to necks. (M, TA.) [Hence,] sabata EilaAwatahu, (S, M,) inf. n. sabotN, (S, K,) He smote his neck [so as to decapitate him]: (S, M, K:) and subitato EilaAwatuhu, His head was cut off. (A. [This is there said to be tropical; but why, I do not see.]) ― -b2- And sabatati AllRuqomapu HaloqiI, and sabRatatohu↓, i. q. qaTaEatohu [i. e. The morsel, or gobbet, obstructed, or stopped, my fauces]: but the verb without teshdeed is the more usual. (M, TA.) ― -b3- And sabata raOosahu, (M, A, Mgh, Msb,) aor.
sabita
, (M, Msb, TA,) inf. n. sabotN, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) He shaved his head: (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K:) and in like manner, sabata XaEarahu, he shaved off his hair; (TA;) as also sbRthu↓ and Asbthu↓. (AA, TA in art. sbd.) ― -b4- And sabotN also signifies The letting down the hair, or letting it fall or hang down, after (lit. from, Ean,) [the twisting, or plaiting, termed] AlEaqoS. (S, K.) ＝ -A5- subita He (a man) was, or became, affected with [the kind, or degree, or semblance, of sleep termed] subaAt [q. v.]: (IAar, M, TA:) and (TA) he swooned: (Msb, TA:) and he became prostrated like him who is sleeping, generally closing his eyes; said of a sick man: (TA:) and also he died. (Msb, TA.)

2 sabRata
2: see 4: ＝ -A2- and see also 1, latter half, in three places.

4 Oasobata
4: see 1, former half, in four places. ― -b2- Asbtt AlHayRapu, inf. n. UisobaAtN The serpent was, or became, silent; or bent down its head, or lowered its eyes, looking towards the ground. (TA.) ＝ -A2- [Asbt It (a drug) produced the kind, or degree, or semblance, of sleep termed subaAt: and hence, it torpified, or benumbed: often used in this sense in medical works: and sbRt↓ is also used in this sense in the present day.] ＝ -A3- See also 1, near the end of the paragraph.

7 Ansbt c
7. Ansbt [It became cut off, interrupted, put a stop to, or put an end to, or it ceased: meanings indicated in this art. in the M and TA. ― -b2- ] It became extended: (K:) or long and extended, together with softness. (TA.) It is said in a description of the countenance of the Prophet, (TA,) kaAna fiI wajohihi QnosibaAtN There was, in his face, length, and extension. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- It (a hide) became soft by the process of tanning. (IAar, TA.) ― -b4- Ansbtt AlrRuTabapu The date became wholly pervaded by ripeness: (M, TA:) and became soft. (TA.) And Ansbt AlrRuTabu The dates became all ripe, or ripe throughout. (M, TA.)

sabotN c
sabotN Rest: (S, K:) and quiet, stillness, or freedom from motion. (TA.) [See 1, of which it is an inf. n.] See also subaAtN. ― -b2- AlsRabotu, (M, K,) or yawomu AlsRaboti, (S, Msb,) [The sabbath, or Saturday;] one of the days of the week; (M, K;) the seventh of those days: (M:) so called because the creation commenced on the first day of the week and continued to [the end of] Friday, and on the sbt there was no creation, the work having ceased thereon: or, as some say, because the Jews ceased thereon from work, and the management of affairs: (M, TA:) or because the days [of the week] end thereon: (S, TA:) Az says that he errs who asserts it to have been so called because God commanded the Children of Israel to rest thereon, and that God created the heavens and the earth in six days, whereof the last was Friday, then rested, and the work ceased, and therefore He named the seventh day ywm Alsbt: this, he says, is an error, because [he affirms that] sabata as meaning “ he rested ” is not known in the language of the Arabs, but signifies qaTaEa; and rest cannot be attributed to God, because He knows not fatigue, and rest is only after fatigue and work: (TA:) the pl. [of pauc.] is OasobutN and [of mult.] subuwtN: (S, M, Msb, K:)
it has no dim. (Sb, S in art. Ams.) ― -b3- sabotN also means A week; from the sabot to the sabot [i. e. from the sabbath to the sabbath]: so in the saying, in a trad., famaA raOayonaA AlXRamosa sabotFA [And we saw not the sun for a week]: as when one says “ twenty autumns ” meaning “ twenty years: ” or it means in this instance a space of time, whether short or long. (TA.) ― -b4- I. q. burohapN [i. e. A space, or period, or a long space or period,] (M, K, TA) mina AldRahori [of time]: (TA:) so in the saying, Oaqamotu sabotFA [I remained, staid, dwelt, or abode, a space, or a long space, of time]; as also sabotapF↓ and sanobatFA↓ and sanobatatFA↓. (M, K.) ― -b5- And i. q. dahorN [meaning Time; or a long time; or a space, or period, of time, whether long or short; &c.]; as also subaAtN↓. (S, M, K.) And [hence] AibonaA subaAtK↓ means (assumed tropical:) The night and the day: (S, M, K:) Ibn Ahmar says,
wakunRaA wahumo kaQbonaIo subaAtK tafarRaqaA
siwFI vumRa kaAnaA munojidFA watahaAmiyaA
[And we were, with them, like the night and the day that parted asunder alike, then became one going towards Nejd and one going towards Tihámeh]: (S, K:) such, they say, is the meaning: (S:) or, as IB says, on the authority of Aboo-Jaafar Mohammad Ibn-Habeeb, AbnA sbAt were two men, one of whom saw the other in a dream, and then one of them awoke in Nejd, and the other in Tihámeh: or they were two brothers, one of whom went to the east to see where the sun rose, and the other to the west to see where it set. (L, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A certain pace (S, M, K) of camels: (S, K:) or a quick pace: (TA:) or i. q. EanaqN [q. v.]: (AA, S:) or a pace exceeding that termed AlEanaqu. (M.) ＝ -A3- A swift, or an excellent, horse; (K, TA;) that runs much. (TA.) ― -b2- A boy, or young man, of bad disposition, or illnatured, and bold, or daring. (K) ― -b3- A man cunning, i. e. possessing intelligence, or sagacity, or intelligence mixed with craft and forecast; and excellent in judgment; or very cunning &c.; (K, TA;) silent, or lowering his eyes, looking towards the ground; (TA;) and subaAtN↓ signifies the same. (K, TA.) ― -b4- A man who sleeps much; (K;) i. e. kaviyru AlsRubaAti. (TA.) See also masobuwtN. ＝ -A4- See also what next follows.

subotN c
subotN A certain plant, resembling the xiTomiIR [or marsh-mallow]; (Kr, M, K;) as also sabotN↓, (K [there expressly said to be with fet-h],) or sibotN↓: (M [so written in a copy of that work]:) said to be a certain plant used for tanning. (MF.) See the next paragraph.

sibotN c
sibotN The hides, or skins, of oxen; (M, K;) whether tanned or not tanned: so some say: (M:) or (so accord. to the M, in the K and TA “ and, ” but the w is omitted in the CK,) any tanned hide; (As, AA, M, K;) said to be so called [because the tanning removes the hair,] from AlsRabotu, “ the act of shaving: ” (AA, TA:) or such. as is tanned with qaraZ [q. v.]: (M, K:) or only ox-hides tanned: so says AHn on the authority of As and AZ: (TA:) or ox-hides tanned with qaraZ, (S, Mgh,) whereof are made [the sandals called] niEaAlN sibotyRapN↓: (S) these are hence thus called: (Mgh:) they are sandals having no hair upon them: (M, Msb:) or sandals tanned with qraZ: (AA, TA:) accord. to Az, they are thus called because their hair has been shaven off (subita, i. e. Huliqa,) and removed by a wellknown process in tanning, (Mgh, * TA,) so that they are soft; and they are of the sandals of people that lead a life of ease and softness: (Mgh:) IAar says that they are thus called because of their having become soft by the tanning: accord. to this, they should be called sabotiyRap↓; and so accord. to a saying of EdDáwoodee, that they are called in relation to suwqu AlsRaboti [“ the Market of the Sabbath ”]: it is also said that they are called in relation to the subot↓, with damm, which is a plant used for tanning therewith; so that they should be called subotiyRap↓, unless the appellation be an instance of a rel. n. deviating from its source of derivation [or unless this plant be also termed sibotN, as it is accord. to a copy of the M]: (TA:) see subotN. It is related of the Prophet, that he saw a man walking among the graves wearing his sandals, and said, yaA SaAHiba AlsRibotayni AixolaEo sibotayoka [meaning (tropical:) O wearer of the pair of sandals of sibot, pull off thy pair of sandals of sibot]: (S, * TA:) and accord. to the A, they are thus termed tropically: it is like the saying “ Such a one wears wool, and cotton, and silk; ” meaning “ garments made thereof; ” as is said in the Nh: but, as some relate it, what he said was, yaA SaAHiba AlsRibotiyRayoni↓, the last of these words being a rel. n.; and thus it is found in the handwriting of Az, in his book. (TA.)

sibitRN c
sibitRN, (M, L, K,) like filizRN, (TA,) [in a copy of the M erroneously written sibot,] A certain plant; [anethum graveolens, or dill, of the common garden-species;] an arabicized word, from [the Pers.] XibitR [or Xibito]: (AHn, M, L:) or i. q. XibitRN; both words arabicized from Xiwico [or Xiwido]: (K:) asserted by some to be the same as sanRuwtN [q. v.]: (M, L:) Az says that XibitRN, the name of a well-known herb, or leguminous plant, is an arabicized word; that he had heard the people of El-Bahreyn call it sibitRN, with the unpointed s, and with t; that it is originally, in Pers., Xiwico; and that it has another dial. var., namely, sbT [i. e. sibiTRN]. (El-Jawáleekee, TA.)

sabotapN c
sabotapN: see sabotN, in the middle of the paragraph. ＝ -A2- Also Goats, collectively. (K.)

sabotaMCu c
sabotaMCu A [desert such as is termed] SaHoraMC: (AZ, K:) or OaroDN sabotaMCu is like SaHoraMCu: or a land in which are no trees: (M:) and i. q. masobuwtapN↓ [i. e. a bare land; as though shorn of its herbage]: (TA:) pl. sabaAtiIRu. (M.) ― -b2- Also, [in like manner] a fem. epithet, Having spreading, or expanded, ears, whether long or short. (K.)

sabotiIRN c
sabotiIRN One who fasts alone on the sabot [i. e. sabbath, or Saturday]: thus in the saying mentioned by Th, on the authority of IAar, laA taku sabotiyRFA [Be not thou one who fasts &c.]. (M.)

niEaAlN sibotiyRapN c
niEaAlN sibotiyRapN, and sabotiyRapN, and subotiyRapN; and the dual. of sibotiIRN, applied to a pair of sandals: see sibotN, in four places.

sibotaAnN c
sibotaAnN, with kesr, Foolish, stupid, or of little sense; (K, TA;) confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course; without understanding. (TA.)

subaAtN c
subaAtN primarily signifies Rest [like sabotN]: (S, Msb:) and hence, sleep: (S, K:) or heavy sleep: (Msb:) or sleep that is hardly perceptible (xafiIR, M, K, [in some copies of the K, as mentioned by Freytag, xafiyf, i. e. light,]), like a swoon: (M:) or the commencement of sleep in the head [and its continuance] until it reaches the heart: (Th, M, K:) or the sleep of one who is sick; i. e. light sleep: (TA:) and sabotN↓ signifies the same as subaAtN. (T, TA.) Hence, in the Kur [lxxviii. 9, and in like manner the word is used in xxv. 49], wajaEalonaA nawomakumo subaAtFA; (S;) i. e. qaToEFA; as though a man, when he slept, were cut off from [the rest of] mankind: (IAar, TA:) or sbAt is when one is cut off, or ceases, from motion, while the soul still remains in the body; i. e., the text means, And we have made your sleep to be rest unto you: (Zj, TA:) or we have made your sleep to be a cutting off from sensation and motion, for rest to the animal forces, and for causing their weariness to cease: or, to be death: (Bd:) or, to be rest unto your bodies by the interruption of labour, or work. (Jel.) ＝ -A2- See also sabotN, latter half, in three places.

sabuwtN c
sabuwtN A she-camel that goes the pace termed sabotN: or constantly going the pace termed EanaqN. (M.)

sabanotFI c
sabanotFI, (S, M, K,) as also sabanodFI, (S,) Bold, or daring; (S, M, K;) as an epithet applied to anything [i. e. man or brute]: the I is added to render it quasi-coordinate to the class of quinqueliteral-radical words, not to denote the fem. gender, for it receives p as a termination [to denote the fem.], becoming sabanotaApN; (S;) and has tenween. (TA.) A poet applies the fem. epithet to a she-camel. (S.) ― -b2- Also The leopard; (S, M, K;) so too with p; (AHeyth, L in art. sbd;) and so sabanodFI: probably thus called because of his boldness, or daringness: (S:) or, as some ay, the lion: fem. with p: or the fem, signifies a bold, or daring, lioness: or a she-camel of bold, or daring, breast; but this last is not of valid authority: (M:) and a beast of prey [absolutely]: (L in art. syd:) pl. sabaAnitu; (K, TA;) and some of the Arabs make sabaAtiI [or rather sabaAtK] to be its pl. (TA.) ― -b3- The fem. also, applied to a woman, signifies Sharp in tongue; or clamorous; or clamorous and foul-tongued; or long-tongued and vehemently clamorous. (TA.)

sanobapN c
sanobapN: see sabotN, in the middle of the paragraph.

sanobatapN c
sanobatapN: see sabotN, in the middle of the paragraph.

musobitN c
musobitN Motionless; not moving. (S, K.) ― -b2- And, accord. to the L and K, Entering upon the day called AlsRabotu [i. e. the sabbath]: but correctly, entering upon the observance of the sabot [or sabbath]. (TA.)

masobuwtN c
masobuwtN Affected with [the kind, or degree, or semblance, of sleep termed] subaAt [q. v.]: (IAar, M:) or affected with a swoon: and, applied to a sick man, prostrated like him who is sleeping, generally closing his eyes: (S:) or confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course: (Msb:) and sabotN↓ signifies the same as masobuwtN; as in the saying, cited by As,
yuSobiHu maxomuwrFA wayumosiI sabotaA
[He is in the morning affected with the remains of intoxication, and he is in the evening affected with sleep, or heavy sleep, &c.]. (T, TA.) ― -b2- Also Dead. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- raOosN masobuwtN [A head cut off.] (A.) ― -b2- OaroDN masobuwtapN: see sabotaMCu.

ruTabN munosabitN c
ruTabN munosabitN Dates that have become all ripe, or ripe throughout. (S, K.) And raTabapN munosabitapN [A date that is ripe throughout: and also] a soft date. (TA.)

1 sabaHa c
1. sabaHa, aor.
sabaHa
, inf. n. saboHN (Msb, K) and sibaAHapN, (S, * K,) or the latter is a simple subst., (Msb,) He swam, syn. EaAma, (S, * K,) biAlnRahori and fiyhi [in the river], (K,) or rather biAlmaMCi (MF, TA) or fI AlmaMCi (Msb) [i. e. in the water], for it is likewise in the sea, and in a pool, and also in any expanse: (MF, TA:) [or he swam upon the surface, without immersing himself; for,] accord. to Z, there is a difference between EawomN and sibaAHapN; the former signifying the “ coursing along in water with immersion of oneself; ” and the latter, the coursing along upon water without immersion of oneself. (MF, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AlnRujuwmu tasobaHu fiI Alfalaki (A, TA) (tropical:) The stars [swim, or glide along, or] pass along, in the firmament, with a spreading forth. (TA.) It is said in the Kur xxi. 34 and xxxvi. 40, with reference to the sun and the moon, (Bd and Jel in xxi. 34,) with which the stars are meant to be included, (Jel ibid.,) kulRN fiI falakK yasobaHuwna, i. e. (assumed tropical:) All [glide or] travel along swiftly, [in a firmament,] like the swimmer (Bd and Jel ibid.) upon the surface of the water, (Bd ibid.,) or in the water; (Jel ibid.;) wherefore the form of the verb used is that which is appropriate to rational beings, (Bd and Jel ibid.,) swimming being the act of such beings. (Bd ibid.) ― -b3- And [hence] one says, sabaHa cikoruka AlXRamosi wa Alqamari masaAbiHa↓ (tropical:) [Thy fame has travelled as far as the sun and the moon; lit., swum along the tracts along which swim the sun and the moon]. (A, TA.) ― -b4- [Hence, likewise, as inf. n. of sabaHa, aor. as above,] saboHN also signifies (tropical:) The running of a horse (S, L, K, * TA) in which the fore legs are stretched forth well [like as are the arms of a man in swimming]. (L, K, * TA.) ― -b5- And (assumed tropical:) The being quick, or swift. (MF.) ― -b6- And (assumed tropical:) The being, or becoming, remote. (MF.) ― -b7- And (assumed tropical:) The travelling far. (K.) You say, sabaHa fiI AlOaroDi (assumed tropical:) He went, or travelled, far, in, or into, the land, or country: (O, TA:) and sabaxa: both thus expl. by Abu-l-Jahm El-Jaafaree. (TA.) ― -b8- And (assumed tropical:) The journeying for the purpose of traffic (taqalRub [q. v.]); and [a people's] becoming scattered, or dispersed, in the land, or earth. (K.) And (assumed tropical:) The busying oneself in going to and fro, or seeking gain, (IAar, TA,) and occupying oneself according to his own judgment or discretion, in the disposal or management of affairs, in respect of the means of subsistence. (IAar, S, K, TA.) You say, fulaAnN yasobaHu AlnRahaAra kulRahu fiI Talabi AlmaEaAXi (tropical:) [Such a one busies himself in going to and fro, or occupies himself according to his own judgment or discretion, in seeking the means of subsistence]. (A, TA.) And sabaHa fiI HawaAYijihi (assumed tropical:) He occupied himself according to his own judgment or discretion in the accomplishment of his needful affairs. (Msb.) ― -b9- As used in the Kur [lxxiii. 7], where it is said, UinRa laka fiI AlnRahaAri saboHFA TawiylFA, it is variously explained: (S, TA:) accord. to Katádeh (S) and El-Muärrij, (S, TA,) the meaning is, (assumed tropical:) [Verily thou hast in the day-time] long freedom from occupation; (S, K, * TA;) and in this sense, also, its verb is sabaHa, aor.
sabaHa
: (JM:) [thus it has two contr. significations:] or, accord. to Lth, (assumed tropical:) leisure for sleep: (TA:) accord. to AO, the meaning is, (assumed tropical:) long-continued scope, or room, for free action; syn. mutaqalRabFA TawiylFA: and accord. to ElMuärrij, it means also (assumed tropical:) coming and going: (S, TA:) accord. to Fr, the meaning is, (assumed tropical:) thou hast in the day-time the accomplishment of thy needful affairs: (TA:) or the meaning is, (assumed tropical:) [long] occupation of thyself in thy affairs of business; not being free from occupation therein for the reciting of the Kur-án. (Jel.) Some read saboxFA, which has nearly the same meaning as saboHFA. (Zj, TA.) ― -b10- As inf. n. of sabaHa, (TK,) it signifies also (assumed tropical:) The state of sleeping. (K.) And as such also, (TK,) (assumed tropical:) The being still, quiet, or motionless. (K.) ― -b11- [Also (assumed tropical:) The glistening of the mirage.] You say, sabaHa AlsRaraAbu, or AlMlu, meaning lamaEa [i. e. (assumed tropical:) The mirage glistened]. (O.) ― -b12- And (assumed tropical:) The digging, or burrowing, in the earth, or ground. (K, * TA.) You say of the jerboa, sabaHa fiI AlOaroDi (assumed tropical:) He dug, or burrowed, in the earth, or ground. (O, TA.) ― -b13- And (assumed tropical:) The being profuse in speech. (K.) You say, sabaHa fiI AlkalaAmi (assumed tropical:) He was profuse in speech. (O, TA.) ― -b14- See also the next paragraph. in two places.

2 tasobiyHN c
2. tasobiyHN signifies The declaring [God] to be far removed, or free, from every imperfection or impurity, or from everything derogatory from [his] glory; syn. tanoziyhN, (S, O, Msb, TA,) and taqodiysN: (Msb:) the magnifying, celebrating, lauding, or praising, and glorifying, God; and declaring Him to be far removed, or free, from everything evil. (TA.) You say, sabRaHa QllReha, (T, A, Mgh, Msb, TA,) and sbRH lilRehi, (Kur lvii. 1 &c., and A,) in which the l is redundant, (Jel in lvii. 1 &c.,) inf. n. tasobiyHN, and suboHaAnN is a subst. that [sometimes] stands in the place of the inf. n., (T, TA,) or it is an inf. n. of which the verb is sabaHa, (K, TA,) He declared God to be far removed, or free, from every imperfection or impurity &c., (A, Mgh, TA,) or from what they say [of Him] who disacknowledge [his attributes]; (Msb;) [i. e. he declared, or celebrated, or extolled, the perfection or purity, or absolute glory, of God;] and he magnified, celebrated, lauded, or praised, God, by the mention of his names, saying suboHaAna QllRehi and the like: (Msb:) and sbRH [alone], (Mgh, K,) inf. n. tasobiyHN, (K,) he said suboHaAna QllRehi; (Mgh, K;) as also sabaHa↓, inf. n. suboHaAnN; (K, TA;) the latter, which is like Xakara, inf. n. XukoraAnN, a dial. var. mentioned by ISd; and no regard should be paid to the saying of Ibn-Ya'eesh and others, that sbHAn is an inf. n. of which the verb is obsolete: accord to El-Mufaddal, suboHaAnN is the inf. n. of sabaHa↓ signifying he raised his voice with supplication, or prayer, and magnification or celebration or praise [of God, as when one says suboHaAna QllRehi or the like]; and he cites as an ex.,
qabaHa QloUilehu wajuwha tagoliba kulRamaA
sabaHa AlHajiyju wa kabRaruwA UiholaAlaA
[May God remove far from good, or prosperity, or success, the persons (wujuwha here meaning nufuwsa) of the tribe of Teghlib, whenever the pilgrims raise their voices with supplication, &c., and say AallRehu Oakobaro, ejaculating labRayoka]. (MF, TA.) wanaHonu nusabRiHu biHamodika, in the Kur ii. 28, is a phrase denotative of state, (Ksh, Bd, Jel,) meaning While we declare thy remoteness from evil [of every kind], (Ksh, Bd,) or while we say suboHaAna QllRehi, (Jel,) praising Thee, (Ksh,) [or with the praising of Thee, i. e.] making the praising of Thee to be an accompaniment, or adjunct, to our doing that: (Ksh, Bd, Jel:) so that we are the more worthy to be appointed thy vice-agents. (Ksh, * Bd, * Jel.) fasabRiHo biQsomi rabRika AlEaZiymi, in the Kur lvi. 73 and last verse, means Therefore declare thou the remoteness from what is unsuitable to his majesty by mentioning the name of thy Lord, or by mentioning the Lord, for the pronouncing of the name of a thing is the mentioning of it, [i. e., of the thing itself,] the great name, or the great Lord: (Bd:) or it means therefore pray thou commencing with, or uttering, the name of thy Lord [the great name or Lord]: (Kull p. 211:) [for] ― -b2- tasobiyHN also signfies The act of praying. (K, Msb.) You say, sabRaHa meaning He prayed. (A, Mgh.) And [particularly] He performed the [supererogatory] prayer of [the period termed] AlDRuHaI. (TA.) And fulaAnN yusabRiHu QllReha, i. e. yuSalRiI AlsRaboHapa↓, meaning Such a one performs prayer to God, either obligatory or supererogatory: [but generally the latter: (see
suboHapN:)] and yusabRiHu EalaI raAHilatihi performs supererogatory prayer [upon his camel that he is riding]. (Msb.) It is said in the Kur [iii. 36], wasabRiHo biQloEaXiIRi waQloUibokaAra, i. e. And pray thou [in the evening, or the afternoon, and the early morning]. (TA.) And it is related of 'Omar, OanRahu jalada rajulayoni sabRaHaA baEoda AlEaSori, meaning [That he flogged two men] who prayed [after the prescribed time of the afternoon-prayer]. (S, TA.) You say also, biyadihi yusabRiHu bihaA suboHapN↓ [i. e. In his hand is a string of beads by the help of which he repeats the praises of God: see suboHapN, below]. (A, Msb. *) ― -b3- Also The making an exception, by saying Uino XaMCa QllRehu [If God will]: because, by so saying, one magnifies God, and acknowledges that one should not will unless God will: and thus is expl. the saying in the Kur [lxviii. 28], Oalamo Oaqulo lakumo lawo laA tusabRiHuwna [Did I not say to you, Wherefore will ye not make an exception? addressed to the owners of a garden, who “ swore that they would certainly cut its fruit when they should be entering upon the time of morning, they not making an exception ”]. (TA.)
