3 sAbHhu c
3. sAbHhu, [inf. n. musaAbaHapN,] i. q. raAsaAhu, (T and K in art. rsw,) i. e. He swam with him. (TK in that art.) [And app. also He vied, or contended, with him in swimming.]

4 AsbHhu c
4. AsbHhu He made him to swim (K, TA) fiI AlmaMCi [in the water] or fawoqa AlmaMCi [upon the water]. (TA.)

saboHapN c
saboHapN Garments of skins: (K:) or, accord. to Sh, sibaAHN, which is the pl., signifies shirts of skins, for boys: AO corrupted the word, relating it as written subojapN, with j, and with damm to the s; whereas this signifies “ a black [garment of the kind called] kisaMC: ” and a verse cited by him as presenting an ex. of its pl., in its last word, is from a poem of which each verse has for its fundamental rhyme-letter the unpointed H: ISd, in art. sbj, mentions sibaAjN as signifying “ garments of skin, ” and having sbjp for its sing.; but says that the word with the unpointed H is of higher authority; though he also states it, in the same art., to have been corrupted by AO. (TA.) ― -b2- [A meaning belonging to suboHapN (q. v.) is assigned in some copies of the K to saboHapN.] ＝ -A2- AlsRaboHapu, (K,) or saboHapu, from saAbiHN as an epithet applied to a horse, or mare, (IAth, TA,) is a proper name of A horse, or mare, belonging to the Prophet: (IAth, K, TA:) and of another belonging to Jaafar the son of Aboo- Tálib; (K;) or this was a mare named samoHapu: (O:) and of another belonging to another. (K.)

suboHapN c
suboHapN Beads (S, Msb, K, TA) strung (Msb, TA) upon a string or thread, (TA,) [ninety-nine in number, and having a mark after each thirtythree,] with which (by counting them, K) one performs the act termed AltRasobiyH [meaning the repetition of the praises of God, generally consisting in repeating the words suboHaAna QllReho thirtythree times, AlHamodu lilReho thirty-three times, and AallRehu Oakobaro thirty-three times, which is done by many persons after the ordinary prayers, as a supererogatory act]: (S, A, Msb, K:) its appellation implies that it is an Arabic word; but Az says that it is post-classical: its pl. is subaHN (Msb) and subuHaAtN also. (Har p. 133.) See 2, last sentence but one. ― -b2- Also Invocation of God; or supplication: (K:) and prayer, (A, Msb,) whether obligatory or supererogatory: (Msb:) or supererogatory praise; (S;) and supererogatory prayer; (S, A, Mgh, K;) because of the tasobiyHN therein. (Mgh.) You say, fulaAnN yuSalRiI AlsRuboHapa, expl. above; see 2, in the latter part of the paragraph. (Msb.) And qaDaIsuboHatahu He performed, or finished, his prayer: (A:) or qaDayotu suboHatiI means I performed, or finished, my supererogatory praise and such prayer. (S.) And SalRaI AlsRuboHapa He performed the supererogatory prayer: (A:) and suboHapa AlDRuHaI [the supererogatory prayer of the period termed AlDRuHaI]. (Msb.) ― -b3- suboHapu QllRehi, (IAth, K, TA,) with damm, (TA, [but in my MS. copy of the K written saboHap, and so in the CK,]) means (assumed tropical:) The greatness, or majesty, of God: (IAth, K, TA:) or [the pl.] AlsRubuHaAtu, occurring in a trad., means (assumed tropical:) the greatness, or majesty, and the light [or splendour], of God: (Msb:) or by the saying subuHaAtu wajohi rabRinaA, with damm to the s and b, is meant (assumed tropical:) the greatness, or majesty, of the face of our Lord: (S:) or subuHaAtu wajohi QllRehi means (assumed tropical:) the lights [or splendours], (K,) or, accord. to ISh, the light [or splendour], (TA,) of the face of God: (ISh, K, TA:) some say that subuHaAtu Alwajohi means (assumed tropical:) the beauties of the face; because, when you see a person of beautiful face, you say, suboHaAna QllRehi [to express your admiration]: and some, that [when it relates to God] it denotes a declaration of his being far removed from every imperfection; meaning suboHaAna wajohihi. (TA. [See suboHaAn.]) One says, [addressing God,] OasoOaluka bisubuHaAti wajohika Alkariymi, with two dammehs, meaning (tropical:) [I ask Thee] by the evidences of thy greatness, or majesty, [or of the greatness, or majesty, of thy glorious face,] by the acknowledgement whereof thy praise is celebrated. (A.) ― -b4- AlsRubuHaAtu also signifies (assumed tropical:) The places of prostration [probably meaning in the reciting of the Kur-án]. (K.) ＝ -A2- Also, i. e. [the sing.,] suboHapN, A piece of cotton. (TA.)

suboHaAnN c
suboHaAnN is the inf. n. of sabaHa as syn. with sabRaHa [q. v.]; (K, TA;) and is a subst. that [sometimes] stands in the place of the inf. n. of the latter of these verbs, i. e. in the sense of tasobiyHN. (T, TA.) ― -b2- suboHaAna is a proper name in the sense of AltRasobiyH, and [for this reason, and also because it ends with A and n,] it is imperfectly decl., and is also invariable; being put in the accus. case in the manner of an inf. n. (Mgh.) You say suboHaAna QllRehi, meaning I declare [or celebrate or extol] the remoteness, or freedom, of God [from every imperfection or impurity, or from everything derogatory from his glory, i. e.] from the imputation of there being any equal to Him, or any companion, or anything like unto Him, or anything contrary to Him; or from everything that should not be imputed to Him: (L:) [I declare, or celebrate, or extol, his absolute perfection or glory or purity: or extolled be his absolute perfection &c.:] or I declare the remoteness of God, or his freedom (baraMCap), from evil, (Zj, * S, K, TA,) or from every evil; (TA;) and [especially] from the imputation of his having a female companion, and offspring: (K:) or I declare God's being very far removed from all the foul imputations of those who assert a plurality of gods: (MF:) [it sometimes implies wonder, and may well be rendered how far is God from every imperfection! &c.:] in this case, sbHAn is a determinate noun; (K;) i. e., a generic proper name, for AltRasobiyH, like as barRapu is for AlbirRu. (MF:) Zj says, (TA,) it is put in the accus. case in the manner of an inf. n.; (S, K;) i. e., as the absolute complement of a verb understood; the phrase with the verb supplied being OusabRiHu QllReha suboHaAnahu; (MF;) meaning OubarRiYu QllReha mina AlsRuwoCi baraMCapF; (S, K, MF;) sbHAn thus supplying the place of the verb: accord. to Ibn-El-Hájib and others, when it is prefixed to another noun or pronoun, governing it in the gen. case, it is a quasi-inf. n.; and when not so prefixed, it is a proper name, imperfectly decl.: but to this it is objected that a proper name may be thus prefixed for the purpose of distinction, as in the instances of HaAtimu TayRiYK and zayodu AlfawaArisi: some say that it is an inf. n. of an obsolete verb; but this assertion is not to be regarded; for, as an inf. n., its verb is sabaHa, like Xakara of which the inf. n. is XukoraAnN: others say that it may be an inf. n. of sabRaHa, though far from being agreeable with analogy: and some derive it from AlsRaboHu as signifying “ the act of swimming, ” or “ the being quick, or swift, ” or “ the being, or becoming, remote, ” &c.: (MF:) [hence F adds,] or the phrase above-mentioned denotes quickness in betaking oneself to God, and agility in serving, or obeying, Him; [and therefore may be rendered I betake myself quickly to the service of God, and am prompt in obeying Him;] (K;) so accord. to ISh, to whom a man presented himself in a dream, and indicated this explanation of the phrase, deriving it from sabaHa Alfarasu [“ the horse ran stretching forth his fore legs, as one does with his arms in swimming ”]. (L.) fasuboHaAna QllRehi Hiyna tumosuwna waHiyna tuSobiHuwnu, [in which sbHAn is used in the place of the inf. n. of sabRaHa, and sabRiHuwA is understood before it,] in the Kur [xxx. 16], means Therefore perform ye prayer to God [or declare ye the remoteness of God from every imperfection &c.] when ye enter upon the time of evening and when ye enter upon the time of daybreak. (Fr, TA.) And suboHaAna QllRehi EamRaA yaSifowna, in the Kur xxiii. 93, means Far [or how far] is God from that by which they describe Him! (Jel.) One says also, suboHaAnaka QllRehumRa wabiHamodika, meaning sabRaHotuka bijamiyEi MlaAYika wabiHamodika sabRaHotuka [i. e. I glorify Thee by
enumerating all thy benefits, and by the praising of Thee I glorify Thee]. (Mgh. [See also the prep. bi.]) ― -b3- suboHaAna mino kacaA, (Msb, K,) or suboHaAna QllRehi mino kacaA, (S,) and suboHaAna mino fulaAnK, (A,) are (tropical:) phrases expressive of wonder (S, A, Msb, K) at a thing (S, Msb, K) and a person; (A;) originating from God's being glorified (Oano yusabRaHa QllRehu) at the sight of what is wonderful of his works, and afterwards, by reason of its being frequently said, employed in relation to anything at which one wonders; (Er-Radee, TA;) meaning (assumed tropical:) [I wonder greatly (lit., with wondering) at such a thing and such a person; as is shown by what follows; or] how extraordinary, or strange, is such a thing [and such a person!]. (Msb.) El-Aashà says,
Oaquwlu lamRaA jaMCaniI faxoruhu
suboHaAna mino Ealoqamapa AlfaAxir
(S, Msb *) (assumed tropical:) [I saying, when his boasting reached me, I wonder greatly at' Alkameh the boasting]; i. e. AlEajabu minohu, (S,) or [rather] EajabFA lahu [for OaEojabu EaHabFA lahu], lit. I wonder with wondering at him; (Msb;) [or how extraordinary a person is 'Alkameh the boasting!:] sbHAn being without tenween because it is regarded by them as a determinate noun, and having a resemblance to a fem. noun: (S:) [though in what quality it resembles a fem. noun, except in its being of one of the measures of broken pls., I do not know:] or it is imperfectly decl. because it is a determinate noun, being a proper name for AlbaraMCap (IJ, IB) and AltRanoziyh, (IJ,) and because of the addition of the A and n: (IJ, IB:) this is the true reason: but some hold that it is rendered determinate by its being prefixed to a noun understood, governing it in the gen. case; the complete phrase being suboHaAna QllRehi mino Ealoqamapa. (MF.) ― -b4- suboHaAnFA, thus with tenween, as an indeterminate noun, occurs in the phrase suboHaAnahu vumRa suboHaAnFA, in a poem of Umeiyeh. (IB.) ＝ -A2- suboHaAn is also used in the sense of nafos, in the saying Oanota OaEolamu bimaA fiI suboHaAnika [Thou art possessed of more, or most, knowledge of that which is in thine own mind]. (K.)

sabuwHN c
sabuwHN: see saAbiHN, in three places.

sibaAHapN c
sibaAHapN an inf. n., (K,) or a simple subst., (Msb,) from sabaHa; (Msb, K;) Natation; or the act [or art] of swimming: (S, A, Msb, * K:) or the coursing along upon water without immersion of oneself. (MF, TA. [See 1, first sentence.])

sabRaAHN c
sabRaAHN: see saAbiHN, in two places.

subRuwHN c
subRuwHN, also pronounced sabRuwHN, (T, S, Msb, K, &c.,) the latter the more agreeable with analogy, but the former the more common, (Th, T, S, Msb, *) one of the epithets applied to God, (T, S, A, Msb, * K,) because He is an object of tasobiyH, (K,) and [often] immediately followed by qudRuwsN, (A, Msb, K,) which is likewise also pronounced qadRuwsN, though the former pronunciation is the more common: (Th, T, S, Msb: *) it signifies [All-perfect, all-pure, or all-glorious; i. e.] far removed, or free, from everything evil, (Zj, Mgh, Msb, TA,) and from every imperfection [and the like]. (Msb. [See 2, and see also suboHaAna QllRehi.]) It is said (S, Msb) by Th (S) that there is no word like the two epithets above, of the measure fERuwl with damm as well as with fet-h to the first letter, except crRwH: (S, Msb:) but the following similar instances have been pointed out: stRwq among epithets, and crRwH and XbRwT and frRwj and sfRwd and klRwb among substs. (TA.) Sb says, layosa fiI AlkalaAmi fuERawolN biwaAHidapK [expl. voce curRaAHN]: (S:) [or] accord. to AHei, Sb said that there is no epithet of the measure fuERuwlN except subRuwHN and qudRuwsN: Lh mentions sutRuwqN also, as an epithet applied to a diroham, as well as satRuwqN. (TA.)

AlsRabRaAHapu c
AlsRabRaAHapu: see AlmusabRiHapu, in two places.

saAbiHN c
saAbiHN and sabRaAHN↓ (Msb, K) and sabuwHN↓ (K) are part. ns., or epithets, from sabaHa in the first of the senses assigned to it above: (Msb, K:) [the first signifies Swimming, or a swimmer:] the second has an intensive signification [i. e. one who swims much, or a great swimmer; as also the third]: (Msb:) the pl. of the first, accord. to IAar, not of the first and last as it appears to be accord. to the K, is subaHaMCu: (MF:) that of the second is sabRaAHuwna: (K:) and that of the third is subuHN or sibaAHN, the former reg., and the latter irreg. (MF.) ― -b2- AlsRaAbiHaAt, (K, &c.,) in the Kur [lxxix. 3], accord. to Az, (TA,) means The ships: (K:) or (assumed tropical:) the souls of the believers OarowaAHu AlmuWominiyna [for which Golius seems to have found in a copy of the K OazowaAju AlmuWominiyna, for he gives as an explanation piæ et fidelium uxores,,]) (K, TA) which go forth with ease: or (assumed tropical:) the angels that swim, or glide, (tasobaHu,) from (mn [app. a mistranscription for bayona between]) the heaven and the earth: (TA:) or (assumed tropical:) the stars, (K,) which swim, or glide along, (tasobaHu,) in the firmament, like the saAbiH in water. (TA.) [The meanings fœminæ jejunantes and veloces equi and planetæ, assigned to this word by Golius as on the authority of the KL, are in that work assigned to saAYiHaAt; the first of them as the meaning of this word in the Kur lxvi. 5.] And you say nujuwmN sawaAbiHu (tropical:) [Stars gliding along in the firmament: swAbH being a pl. of saAbiHN applied to an irrational thing, and of saAbiHapN]. (A.) ― -b3- saAbiHN is also applied as an epithet to a horse, (S, IAth, A, L,) meaning (tropical:) That stretches forth his fore legs well in running [like as one does the arms in swimming]; (S, * IAth, L;) and in like manner sabuwHN↓ [but in an intensive sense]: (A, L:) the pl. [of the former] is sawaAbiHu and subRaHN. (A.) And sawaAbiHu also signified (tropical:) Horses; (K, TA;) as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant; (TA;) because they thus stretch forth their fore legs in running. (K, * TA.) Hence, (TA,) AlsRabuwHu↓ is the name of A horse of Rabeea Ibn-Jusham. (K, TA.) And in like manner, AlsRabRaAHu↓ is the name of A celebrated courser: (TA:) and of A certain camel. (K, TA.)

tasobiyHaAtN c
tasobiyHaAtN and tasaAbiyHu [pls. of tasobiyHapN A single act of tasobiyH: see 2]. (A.)

masobaHN c
[masobaHN A place of swimming, &c.: pl. masaAbiHu.] ― -b2- See an ex. of the pl. in the first paragraph of this art.

musabRaHN c
musabRaHN, accord. to AA and the K, applied as an epithet to a [garment of the kind called] kisaMC, means Strong: and accord. to the former, musabRajN, so applied, means “ made wide. ” (TA.)

musabRiHN c
musabRiHN [act. part. n. of 2]. falawolaA OanRahu kaAna mina AlmusabRiHiyna, in the Kur [xxxvii. 143], means And had he not been of the performers of prayer, (A, * Mgh, Msb, K, *) as some say. (Mgh.)

AlmusabRaHapu c
AlmusabRaHapu (A, Msb, TA) and AlsRabRaAHapu↓ (A, TA) (tropical:) [The index, or fore finger;] the finger that is next the thumb: (Msb, TA:) so called because it is like the glorifier when one makes a sign with it [by raising it] when declaring [the unity of] the divine essence. (Msb, TA. *) One says, OaXaAra Uilayohi biAlmusabRiHapi and biAlsRabRaAHapi↓ (tropical:) [He pointed towards him, or it, with the fore finger]. (A, TA.)

1 sabixati AlOaroDu c
1. sabixati AlOaroDu, (JK, A, Msb,) aor.
sabaxa
, inf. n. sabaxN; (Msb;) and Asbxt↓; (JK, A, Msb, K;) The land, or earth, exuded water and produced salt: (JK, K:) or was, or became, salt; had in it salt. (A, Msb.) And sabixa AlmakaAnu, inf. n. as above, The place produced salt, and was such that the feet sank in it. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 2. ＝ -A3- saboxN, an inf. n. of which the verb is sabaxa, aor.
sabuxa
, (TK,) means also (assumed tropical:) The being in a state of sleep: (AA, S:) and tasobiyxN↓ (assumed tropical:) The sleeping soundly: (S:) or both have this meaning: (K:) or the former signifies (assumed tropical:) the being in a state of rest, and easing the body by sleep: (IAar, L:) and ↓the latter, (assumed tropical:) the sleeping every hour: (TA:) and the former signifies also (assumed tropical:) the being unoccupied, at leisure, or free from work or business; (AA, S, K;) and so ↓the latter. (K.) In the Kur lxxiii. 7, some read saboxFA [instead of saboHFA, q. v.]; (S, K;) meaning (assumed tropical:) rest, and easing of the body by sleep; (IAar, L;) and said by Fr to be from tasobiyxN, in the first of the senses expl. in the next paragraph: (L:) or (assumed tropical:) freedom from occupation or work or business. (S.) Accord to Zj, AlsRaboHu and AlsRaboxu are nearly the same in meaning. (TA.) You say also saboxN mino nawomK and maXoIK and HarRK [app. meaning (assumed tropical:) A ceasing from sleeping and from walking or journeying and of heat]. (JK.) ― -b2- And sabaxotu AlnRawoma, inf. n. saboxN, (assumed tropical:) [I slept long; or] I lengthened sleeping. (JK.) ― -b3- And sabaxotu fiI AlOaroDi (assumed tropical:) I went, or travelled, far, in, or into,
the land, or country; (JK, K, * TA;) like sabaHotu. (TA.)

2 tasobiyxN c
2. tasobiyxN [inf. n. of sbRx] The separating, or plucking asunder, and loosening, of cotton, and making it [or spreading it out] wide. (Fr, L.) ― -b2- And The winding of cotton and the like, (K, TA,) such as wool, and soft hair (wabar), after the separating and loosening, for a woman to spin it; (TA;) [as also saboxN, inf. n. of sabaxa↓; see sabiyxN.] ― -b3- [Hence,] (tropical:) The act of lightening, or alleviating. (S, A, K.) It is related in a trad. that the Prophet said to 'Áïsheh, when she had cursed a thief, (S, A, TA,) who had stolen something from her, (S, A, TA,) who had stolen something from her, (S, TA,) laA tusabRixiI Eanohu biduEaAYiki Ealayohi, (S, A, * TA,) meaning (tropical:) Do not thou alleviate (S, A, TA) the merited punishment of his crime by thy cursing him. (S, * TA.) And a poet says,
fasabRixo Ealayoka AlhamRa waQEolamo biOanRahu
UicaA qadRara AlrRaHomenu XayoYFA fakaAYinu
[Then alleviate thou the disquietude of thy mind; and know that, when the Compassionate decreeth a thing, it happeneth]. (S.) One says also, sabRaxa QllRehu Eanoka AlHumRaI May God alleviate thy fever. (S.) And AallRehumRa sabRixo EanRaA AlOacaI O God, remove from us, or alleviate to us, that which harms, or hurts. (TA.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) The act of stilling, quieting, rendering motionless, appeasing, tranquillizing, calming, allaying, assuaging, or quelling. (K.) ＝ -A2- Also (assumed tropical:) The becoming [alleviated, or lightened,] still, quiet, motionless, appeased, tranquil, calm, allayed, assuaged, or quelled. (K, * TA.) One says of heat, (S, K,) and of anger, (TA,) sbRx, (S, K,) inf. n. as above; and tsbRx↓; (K;) (assumed tropical:) It became abated, or allayed, (S, K, TA,) and alleviated. (S.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) The ceasing of veins from the throbbing occasioned by pain therein. (IAar, L, K. *) ― -b3- See also 1, in three places.

3 sAbx c
3. sAbx expl. by Freytag as meaning He contended with another in swimming is a mistake for sAbH.]

4 Asbx c
4. Asbx He reached salt earth in digging (S, K) a well. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 1, first sentence.

5 tasabRaxa
5: see 2, near the end of the paragraph.

sabaxN c
[sabaxN is expl. by Freytag as applied in the Deewán of Jereer to A dense cloud that is seen suspended apart from other clouds.]

sabixN c
sabixN; and its fem., with p: see sabaxapN, in three places.

saboxapN c
saboxapN: see the next paragraph, in three places.

sabaxapN c
sabaxapN and saboxapN↓ [A piece, or tract, of] land that exudes water and produces salt: (K:) pl. (of the former, S, or of the latter, Msb) sibaAxN: (S, A, Msb, K:) OaroDN sabixapN↓ [also] signifies as above; (JK;) or land containing sibaAx, (S, A,) i. e. [places that exude water and produce salt, or simply] salt; (A;) or salt land or earth, as also ArD saboxapN↓, in which the latter word is a contraction of sabixapN, and ArD sabaxapN also: (Msb:) and sabixN↓ signifies a place producing salt, (Msb, * TA,) and in which the feet sink: (TA:) the pl. of sabixapN↓ is sabixaAtN. (Msb.) The Prophet said to Anas, on his mentioning El-Basrah, Uino mararota bihaA wadaxalotahaA faUiyRaAka wasibaAxahaA, meaning [If thou pass by it and enter it, then beware thou of] its tracts of land overspread with saltness, that seldom, or never, give growth to anything but some trees, or shrubs. (L.) ― -b2- Also, (K,) or the latter, i. e. saboxapN↓, (JK,) A thing that overspreads water (JK, K, TA) in consequence of its having been long left, (TA,) resembling [the green substance called] TuHolub, (JK, K,) or such as THlb and the like. (TA.)

sabiyxN c
sabiyxN Cotton, and wool, and soft hair (wabar), separated, or plucked asunder, and loosened; as also musabRaxN↓: (TA:) [and sabiyxapN↓, in which the p is added to convert the epithet into a subst., signifies a portion, i. e. a loose flock, thereof; and its pl. is sabaAYixu, whence] one says, TaArato sabaAYixu AlquToni [The loose flocks of the cotton flew about]. (A.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (tropical:) Feathers (riyX) that fall off (S, A, K) and become scattered: (K:) as also musabRaxN↓: (TA:) the pl. of the former (K, TA) [used as a subst.], in this and in the following senses, (TA,) [or rather of sabiyxapN↓ as a n. un. thus used,] is sabaAYixu. (K, TA.) One says, waradotu maMCF Hawolahu sabiyxu AlTRayori, and sabaAYixuhu↓, i. e. (tropical:) [I came to water around which were] the feathers that had fallen off [and become scattered] of birds. (A.) ― -b3- Also Cotton made wide for a medicament to be put upon it (K, TA) and for it to be applied upon a wound: (TA:) and sabiyxapu↓ signifies a portion of cotton thus prepared for this purpose. (JK, K. *) ― -b4- And Cotton, (S, K,) and wool, and soft hair (wabar), (S,) wound, after the separating and loosening, (S, K, in the former baEoda AlnRadofi yusobaxu↓ i. e. yulafRu,) to be spun (S, K) by a woman: (S:) and sabiyxapN↓ signifies a portion thereof. (S.)

sabiyxapN c
sabiyxapN; and its pl., sabaAYixu: see the next preceding paragraph, in five places.

musabRaxN c
musabRaxN: see sabiyxN, in two places.

1 sabVda
1: see what next follows.

2 sbRd XaEarahu c
2. sbRd XaEarahu, (AA, TA,) inf. n. tasobiydN, (K, TA,) He shaved off his hair; (AA, K, TA;) as also sabadahu↓, (AA, K,) inf. n. sabodN; (K, TA;) and Asbdhu↓, (AA, TA,) inf. n. UisobaAdN: (K, TA:) or all signify he shaved off his hair and [so] removed it utterly: and sabata XaEarahu and sbRthu and Asbthu also have the former signification accord. to AA: (TA:) [and] tasobiydu AlrRaOosi signifies the removing utterly the hair of the head [by shaving]: (S:) or sbRd XaEarahu signifies he shaved off his hair and then left it until it had grown a little: (A'Obeyd, L:) or he removed utterly his hair, making it to be [shaven] close to the skin; (A'Obeyd, M, L;) as also smRdhu. (A'Obeyd, L.) ― -b2- And He let the whole of his hair grow ample and long: thus it has two contr. significations. (M.) ― -b3- And tasobiydN signifies also The combing, or combing down, or letting down and loosing, and then moistening, and leaving, the hair of the head. (Suleymán Ibn-El-Mugheyreh, L, K. *) ― -b4- And The rendering [one's hair] matted, or compacted, and dusty. (M, L.) ― -b5- And [hence, app., the objective complement being meant to be understood,] The leaving off, or neglecting, the anointing of oneself [or of one's hair], (A'Obeyd, S, K, TA,) and washing: and some say tasomiydN, which signifies the same. (A'Obeyd, TA.) ＝ -A2- tasobiydN is also used [intransitively,] as signifying The appearing of the hair of the head: (K:) or the growing after some days: (M:) or sbRd AlXRaEaru means The hair grew so that its blackness appeared after the shaving. (S, M.) ― -b2- And The coming forth of the down [of a young bird]: (M:) or the appearing of the feathers of a young bird. (K.) You say, sbRd Alfaroxu The young bird began to show its feathers, or to become fledged. (S.) ― -b3- And The growing of fresh shoots upon, or among, the old portions of the [plant called] naSiIR; as also UisobaAdN↓: (K:) you say [of that plant], sbRd and Asbd↓: (TA:) or sbRd AlnRabaAtu The plant had heads coming forth, before the spreading thereof. (M.)

4 Oasobada
4: see 2, in three places; first and last sentences.

sibodN c
sibodN i. q. daAhiyapN [as meaning Cunning, or very cunning: and perhaps also as meaning a calamity: pl. OasobaAdN]. (S, M, K.) You say, huwa sibodu OasobaAdK He is cunning, or very cunning, (daAhK, S, M, or daAhiyapN, K,) in theft, or robbery. (S, M, K.) ― -b2- And [hence, perhaps, or the reverse may be the case,] A wolf: (K:) it occurs, in the accus. case, in a verse, in this sense, (TA,) or in the former sense; (S;) or, as some relate it, the word in this instance is siydFA [which has the latter meaning]. (S, TA.)

sabadN c
sabadN Hair [of goats]; syn. XaEarN; (As, S, M;) as also sabRuwdN↓: (M:) or a small quantity thereof: (K:) or fur [of camels]; syn. wabarN. (M.) One says, maA lahu sabadN walaA labadN (As, S, M, K) He has neither goats' hair nor wool: (As, * S, * M:) or neither camels' fur nor wool: or neither camels' fur nor goats' hair: meaning (tropical:) he has neither goats nor sheep: or (tropical:) neither camels nor sheep: or (tropical:) neither camels nor goats: (M:) or (tropical:) neither little nor much; (As, S, K, TA;) i. e. he has not anything. (TA.) [See also labadN.] Hence sabadN is an appellation for (assumed tropical:) Cattle (maAlN). (TA.) Hence also the saying of' Átikeh Bint-Zeyd,
lamo yadaEohu QllRehu yamoXiI bisabado
[i. e. (assumed tropical:) God let him not walk with goats, &c.]; meaning (assumed tropical:) God reduced him to poverty, so that He left not [to him] anything. (Ham p. 495.) ― -b2- Also sing. of OasobaAdN (TA) which signifies Black garments or cloths [app. of goats' hair or of
camels' fur]. (K, TA.) ― -b3- OasobaAdN, (K, TA,) as pl. of sabadN, (TA,) signifies also The heads of the [plant called] naSiIR when they first come forth: (K, TA:) or, as pl. of sabadN, the heads of plants coming forth, before spreading. (M.) ― -b4- And, likewise as pl. of sabadN, Remains of plants or herbage in a land. (TA.) [See also sabidN.] ＝ -A2- sabadN also signifies Unluckiness, ill luck, or evil fortune: (M:) or so subadN↓: (K, TA:) so says Lth, on the authority of ADk. (TA.)

sabidN c
sabidN A remnant of herbage or pasturage. (K.) [See also sabadN, last sentence but one.]

subadN c
subadN A certain bird, (S, M, K,) having plumage so soft, or smooth, that when two drops of water drop upon it, (S, M, * K,) upon its back, (S, M,) they run off from it; (S, * M, K, * TA;) or such that when a drop of water drops upon its back, it runs [off] (M:) the Arabs liken to it a horse when he sweats: (S:) or a certain bird like the eagle: (TA:) or the male eagle: (M, TA:) or the swallow of the desert (xuTRaAf barRiIR): (As, TA:) or a bird like the xuTRaAf; when water falls upon it, it runs off from it quickly: so says Aboo-Nasr; and so Skr in his Expos. of the poetry of Hudheyl, on the authority of As: (TA:) said by As to be a certain black bird: (so in a marg. note in one of my copies of the S:) pl. sibodaAnN. (S, M.) ― -b2- Also A piece of cloth with which the watering-trough (K, TA) such as is termed marokuwR [q. v.] (TA) is rendered close, or firm, [in its bottom and sides,] (yusadRu, [in the L yusobadu, but I know not any apposite meaning of this verb,]) in order that the water may not become turbid: (K:) it is spread therein; and the camels are made to drink [the water] above it. (L.) ― -b3- See also sibodapN. ＝ -A2- And see sabadN, last sentence.

sibodapN c
sibodapN, (M, L,) or subadN↓, (K,) or both, (TA,) The pubes. (M, L, K.)

sabRuwdN c
sabRuwdN: see sabadN, first sentence.

sabanodFI c
sabanodFI Tall, or long; (K;) in the dial. of Hudheyl: (TA:) and also bold, or daring; (S, M, K;) applied to anything [i. e. to any creature]; (S, K;) of the dial. of Hudheyl: (M:) as also sabanotFI: (S, TA:) or, so applied, bold, or daring, to undertake anything: and the fem. [sabanodaApN, like sabanotaApN,] is said to signify a bold lioness: and a bold-breasted she-camel: and in like manner [the masc. signifies] a bold-breasted he-camel: (M, L:) and, (S, M, L, K,) as also sibinodFI, (M, L,) the leopard; (As, S, M, L, K;) and so sabanotFI, (As, S, L,) or sabanotaApN, which is also applied to a beast of prey [absolutely]: (A Heyth:) or the lion: (M, L:) pl. sabaAnidu and sabaAnidapN: or the meaning of this, or these, [i. e. of the latter pl. or of both, for the pronoun (hiIa) may relate to the latter or to both,] is idle, and sportful, and vain, or frivolous, persons; (K, TA;) like sabaAdirapN. (TA.)

musabRadN c
musabRadN, like muEaZRamN, (TA,) or musabRidN↓, (accord. to a copy of the M,) as meaning (assumed tropical:) Consummate, (M, * TA,) is applied as an epithet to a calamity, daAhiyap, (M, TA,) which a poet terms, for the sake of the measure, OamRu faOorK, because it is termed OumRu OadoraASK, and diroSN is applied to a young one of a bitch, and of a she-wolf, and of a she-cat, and of the [species of faOor called] jurac, and of the jerboa. (M.)

musabRidN c
musabRidN [act. part. n. of 2]. It is said of Ibn-'Abbás, qadima makRapa musabRidFA raOosuhu, meaning He came to Mekkeh having his head unanointed and unwashed. (A'Obeyd, S.) ＝ -A2- See also the next preceding paragraph.

1 sabara AljuroHa c
1. sabara AljuroHa, (S, M, A, &c.,) aor.
sabura
(S, M, Msb) and
sabira
, (M, TA,) inf. n. saborN; (S, M, Msb, K;) and Astbrhu↓; (K;) He probed the wound; measured its depth with the misobaAr, i. e., with an iron or other instrument; (A, Mgh:) tried, (K,) or examined, (S,) or endeavoured to learn, (Msb,) its depth; (S, Msb, K;) examined its extent. (M.) ― -b2- sabarahu (assumed tropical:) He determined, or computed by conjecture or by the eye, its measure, quantity, size, or bulk. (M, K, * TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) He tried, proved, or tested, it; proved it by experiment or experience; (S, M, TA;) namely, anything; as also Astbrhu↓. (S.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) He elicited its true, or real, condition. (TA.) ― -b5- It is related in the trad. of the cave, that Aboo-Bekr said to Mohammad, laA tadoxulohu HatRaI Oasoburahu qabolaka (assumed tropical:) Do not thou enter it until I explore it before thee, and see if there be in it any one, or anything that may hurt. (TA.) ― -b6- mafaAzapN laA tusobaru (tropical:) A desert of which the extent cannot be known. (A.) ― -b7- sabarotu fulaAnFA (tropical:) [I searched into such a one]. (A.) — fuyhi xayorN kaviyrN laA yusobaru (tropical:) [In him is much good, the extent of which cannot be known]. (A.) ― -b8- OamorN EaZiymN laA yusobaru (tropical:) [A great affair, of which the uttermost cannot be known]. (A.) ― -b9- Ausoburo liI maA Einodahu (assumed tropical:) Learn thou for me what he has [in his mind, or in his possession]. (M.) ― -b10- sabarotu Alqawoma, aor.
sabura
and
sabira
, inf. n. saborN, (assumed tropical:) I observed the people attentively, with investigation, one after another, that I might know their number. (Msb.)

8 Uisotabara
8: see 1, in two places.

saborN c
saborN: see siborN. ＝ -A2- Also The lion. (El-Mu- ärrij, K.)

siborN c
siborN (S, M, K) and saborN↓ (M, K) The source, or origin, [of a thing,] syn. OaSolN: (M, K:) pl. of both OasobaArN. (M.) ― -b2- (tropical:) Form, or appearance; figure, feature, or lineaments; external state or condition; state with regard to apparel and the like; (S, M, K;) or goodly form or appearance &c.; (K;) aspect; garb, or habit; (TA;) colour, or complexion; (M, K;) beauty; (K;) brightness of countenance: (M:) pl. of both as above. (M.) ― -b3- IAar says, I heard Aboo-Ziyád El-Kilábee say, I returned from Marw to the desert, and one of its people said to me, OamRaA AlsRiboru faHaDariIRN waOamRaA AllRisaAnu fabadawiIRN (tropical:) As to garb and appearance, [thou art like] an inhabitant of a town; but as to tongue, an inhabitant of the desert. (S, * TA.) ― -b4- You say, fulaAnN Hasanu AlHibori waAlsRibori (tropical:) Such a one is beautiful and of goodly appearance. (S.) [See also HiborN.] ― -b5- A woman of the desert said, OaEojabaniI siboru fulaAnK (tropical:) The good condition, and flourishing state of body, of such a one pleased me: and raOayotuhu sayRiYa AlsRibori (tropical:) I saw him to have an altered and ill appearance of body: thus she assigned to sbr two significations. (TA.) ― -b6- One says also, UinRahu laHasanu AlsRibori (tropical:) Verily he is goodly in complexion and appearance. (TA.) ― -b7- siborN also signifies (tropical:) A characteristic by which one knows the generousness or ungenerousness of a beast. (AZ, M.) ― -b8- And (assumed tropical:) One's knowledge of the fruitfulness or unfruitfulness [or the good or bad condition] of a beast. (AZ, TA.) ― -b9- Also (assumed tropical:) Likeness; syn. XabahN. (K, TA. [In some copies of the K, subRapN, which is an evident mistake.]) So in the phrase, occurring in a trad., galaba Ealayohimo siboru OabiI bakorK (assumed tropical:) The likeness (Xabah) of Aboo-Bekr predominated in them. (IAar, TA.) One says also, Earafahu bisibori Oabiyhi (assumed tropical:) He knew him by the appearance and likeness of his father. (TA.) ― -b10- Also the former (siborN), Enmity, (K,) accord. to El-Muärrij; but Az says that this is strange. (TA.)

saborapN c
saborapN A cold morning, between daybreak and sunrise: (S, M, A, Mgh, K:) or from the time a little before daybreak to daybreak: or from daybreak to sunrise: (M:) or a cold morning during the period next after sunrise: (Msb:) pl. sabaraAtN: (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K:) which latter is also expl. as signifying the intenseness of the cold of winter, and of the year. (TA.)

suborutN c
suborutN and siboraAtN and suboruwtN and siboriytN: &c.: see art. sbrt.

suboruwrN c
suboruwrN Poor; (K, TA;) possessing no property: like suboruwtN, in this sense, and in that following. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) Land in which is no herbage. (K, TA.)

sibaArN c
sibaArN and misobaArN↓ A probe; an instrument with which a wound is probed; (S, M, K;) as also misobarN↓: (Ham p. 818:) a twist like a wick, (T, Msb,) or a similar thing, (Msb,) which is put into a wound (T, Msb) to ascertain its depth; (Msb;) an iron or other instrument with which the depth of a wound is measured: (A, Mgh:) pl. of the first, suburN; and of ↓the second, masaAbiyru. (Msb.) It is said in a prov., maA Eurifa lawo laA AlmisobaAru↓ gaworu AljuroHi [Were it not for the probe, the depth of the wound would not be known]. (A.) And baEiydu AlmisobaAri↓ is applied as an epithet to a woman's vulva [or vagina, in an obvious sense,] by Ibn-Habeeb: and accord. to the K, to a woman [in allusion to her vagina]. (TA in art. xjI.)

sabaArK c
sabaArK an irreg. pl. of suboruwtN: see the latter in art. sbrt.

saAbiriIRN c
saAbiriIRN A coat of mail made of slender rings, and strongly: (K:) so called in relation to the king Sáboor. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) or from
Sáboor, a province of Persia, (Mgh, Msb,) A thin, or delicate, kind of garment or cloth, (IDrd, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) of excellent quality: (K:) and anything thin, or delicate. (M.) Whence the prov., EaroDN saAbiriyRN (S, M, * K *) A slight exhibition: (M:) [see variations of this phrase in art. ErD, under EaraDa AlXRaIoCa:] said to him to whom a thing is shown in a slight manner: (S:) because the garment or cloth called sAbrIR, (S, K,) being of the best of qualities, (S,) is desired when exhibited in the slightest manner. (S, K. [See the first paragraph in art. ErD; and see also EaraDa EalaIRa sawoma EaAlRapK in the first paragraph of art. swm.]) ― -b3- A certain sort of dates, (S, Msb, K,) of good quality. (Msb, K.) It is said that the best of the dates in El-Koofeh are the nirosiyaAn and the sAbrIR. (S.) ― -b4- naxolapN saAbiriyRapN A palmtree of which the unripe dates are yellow and somewhat long. (AHát, Msb.)

masobarN c
masobarN (assumed tropical:) [The internal state or condition of a man]. You say, Hamadotu masobarahu and maxabarahu (assumed tropical:) [I praised his internal state or condition]: (S:) and masobarapN↓ also signifies (assumed tropical:) The internal state or condition; an internal, or intrinsic, quality; or the intrinsic, or real, as opposed to the apparent, state, or aspect. (TA.)

misobarN c
misobarN: see sibaArN.

masobarapN c
masobarapN The utmost point of a wound. (M.) ― -b2- See also masobarN.

misobaArN c
misobaArN: see sibaArN, in four places. ― -b2- It may also be applied to (assumed tropical:) A man who probes a wound. (Ham p. 818.)

masobuwrN c
masobuwrN Goodly in form or appearance; in figure, feature, or lineaments; in external state or condition; in state of apparel or the like. (K, TA.)

Q. 1 saborata c
Q. 1. saborata He begged; and became lowly, humble, or submissive; or affected to be like the masaAkiyn [or destitute, or needy, &c.]; syn. qanaEa; (K, TA; [omitted in the CK, and in my MS. copy of the K erroneously written qaniEa;]) and tamasokana. (TA.)

suborutN c
suborutN: see suboruwtN.

siboraAtN c
siboraAtN: see the next paragraph, in two places.

suboruwtN c
suboruwtN A desert, syn. qaforN, (S, K,) or a plain, syn. qaAEN, (M,) in which is no herbage: (M, K:) or weak land: (TA:) and OaroDN suboruwtN and siboriytN↓ (As, Lh, M) and siboraAtN↓ (M) Land in which is no herbage; (M;) or land in which is nothing: (As, Lh, M:) pl. sabaAriytu and sabaArK, the latter anomalous, mentioned by Lh: (M:) accord. to A'Obeyd, the pl. sabaAriytu signifies deserts, or waterless deserts, (falawaAtN,) in which is nothing: and accord. to As, land [or lands] in which nothing grows: (TA:) and one says also OaroDN sabaAriytu, (M, K,) a phrase of the same class as vawobN OaxolaAqN, (K,) as though the sing. suboruwtN or siboriytN were applied to every portion thereof. (M.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) applied to a man, (AZ, S, TA,) Needy, in want, indigent, (AZ, As, S, M, K, TA,) poor, (AZ, As, K, TA,) possessing little, (M, TA,) or, as some say, possessing nothing; (S, * M, TA;) and siboriytN↓ signifies the same, (AZ, S, M, K,) as also siboraAtN↓, and suborutN↓: (M, K:) also bankrupt, or insolvent; syn. mufolisN: (TA in explanation of the first [but equally applying to all]:) the epithet applied to a woman is suboruwtapN and siboriytapN↓; (AZ, S;) the latter of which is applied to a man [app. in intensive sense, agreeably with analogy,] as well as to a woman: (M:) and the pl. is sabaAriytu, applied to men and to women. (AZ, S.) ― -b3- [Hence, also,] applied to a youth, or young man, Beardless; or having no hair upon the sides of his face. (M, K, TA. [In the K, this signification is immediately followed by the mention of the pls. sabaAriytu and sabaArK.]) ― -b4- And Little, or small, in quantity or number; (S, M, K;) paltry, or inconsiderable: (K:) applied to a thing, (S, K,) and (S) to property, or cattle. (S, M.) ― -b5- Also Tall, or long. (M, TA.) ― -b6- And A skilful, or an expert, guide, well acquainted with the lands. (TA.) It is mentioned by Sb, who says that it is of measure fuEoluwlN, like zunobuwrN and EuSofuwrN; and most hold him to be right: but some of the authors on inflection assert that it is of the measure fuEoluwtN, from sabarotu AlXRaIoCa meaning “ I tried, proved, or tested, the thing, or proved it by experiment or experience; ” and that the t is added to give intensiveness to the signification; which several deny: (MF, TA:) suboruwrN, however, is mentioned in the K, in art. sbr, as meaning “ poor, ” and land “ in which is no herbage. ” (TA.)

siboriytN c
siboriytN and siboriytapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.

sanobariytN c
sanobariytN A man (TA) of evil disposition or nature. (K, TA: but omitted in the CK.)

musaboratN c
musaboratN Bald, or bare of hair. (K, TA: but omitted in the CK.)

1 sabiTa c
1. sabiTa, aor.
sabaTa
; (Sb, S, M, Msb, K;) and sabuTa, aor.
sabuTa
; (M, Msb, K;) inf. n. sabaTN, of the former verb, (S, Msb,) or saboTN, (so in the K, as is remarked in the TA,) and subuwTapN, (M, Msb, K,) which is of the latter verb, (M, Msb,) and sabaATapN and subuwTN, (M, K,) which are also of the latter verb; (M;) It (hair, S, Msb) was, or became, lank, not crisp: (S, M, * Msb, K: *) or the former verb is used in this sense, said of hair; and the latter is said of a man, signifying he was, or became, lank, not crisp, in his hair. (TA.) ― -b2- sabaATapN, relating to a man, also signifies The being tall: (M:) or the being long in the [bones called] OalowaAH [pl. of lawoHN], and even therein. (TA.) ― -b3- Also sabuTa, inf. n. sabaATapN; (M, TA;) and sabiTa, inf. n. sabaTN; (M;) (tropical:) He (a man) was, or became, easy, or facile, biAlomaEoruwfi in beneficence. (M, TA.) And subuwTapN is likewise expl. as signifying (tropical:) The being liberal, bountiful, or munificent. (M, TA.) ― -b4- And sabaATapN, relating to rain, (tropical:) The being abundant and extensive. (Sh, K, TA.) [ ― -b5- See also the part. n. sabiTN.] ＝ -A2- sabaTa Ealayohi AlEaTaMCa (tropical:) He gave to him successive and large gifts. (Sgh, TA.) ＝ -A3- subiTa He was affected with fever. (Sgh, K.) [See sabaATi.]

2 sabRaTato c
2. sabRaTato, (M, K, &c.,) inf. n. tasobiyTN, (S, K,) She (a camel, AZ, As, M, K, and a ewe, K) cast her young one, or fœtus, in an incomplete state: (M, K:) or before its form was apparent; (AZ, K;) like OajohaDato and rajaEato: (AZ:) or when its fur had grown, before completion; as also sabRagatN: (As, TA:) or sbRTt biwaladihaA she (a camel) cast her young one when its hair had grown: and sbRTt she (a ewe) cast her young one, or fœtus, abortively. (S.) The epithet applied to her in this case is musabRiTN↓ [without p]. (M, K.)

4 AsbT c
4. AsbT He (a man, S, M) extended himself, or became extended or stretched, (S, M, K, TA,) upon the ground, (S, TA), in consequence of being beaten, (M, K, TA,) &c.: (TA:) he fell (M, K, TA) upon the ground, (TA,) and was unable to move, (M, K, TA,) by reason of weakness, (M, TA,) or from drinking medicine, or some other cause; on the authority of AZ: (M:) he fell upon the ground, and became extended or stretched, in consequence of being beaten, or from disease, and in like manner from drinking medicine. (TA.) And AsbT biAlOaroDi He clave to the ground. (Ibn-Jebeleh, M, K.) ― -b2- He was silent, by reason of fear, or fright: (M, L, K:) he was silent and still; or he lowered his eyes, looking towards the ground, and was still. (O.) ― -b3- AsbT fiI nawomihi He shut, or closed, his eyes, or eyelids, in his sleep. (Sgh, K.) ― -b4- AsbT Eani AlOamori He feigned himself negligent of the thing or affair, inattentive to it, or heedless of it. (Sgh, K.)

saboTN c
saboTN: see sabiTN, throughout.

siboTN c
siboTN A grandchild; (S, Msb, K;) a son's child, and a daughter's child: (M, TA:) pl. OasobaATN; (S, Msb, TA;) which is commonly used by the vulgar as signifying daughters' children; distinguished by them from OaHofaAdN [which they apply to son's children, pl. of HafiydN]; but the leading lexicologists expressly declare that it includes sons' children and daughters' children, as it is said to do by ISd: IAar explained siboTN and siboTaAni and OasobaATN as signifying the particularly distinguished, and choicest, of children. (TA.) It is said in a trad., (TA,) AlHasanu waAlHusayonu siboTaA rasuwli QllRehi El-Hasan, and El-Hoseyn are the two grandsons of the Apostle of God. (M, TA. *) ― -b2- A tribe of the Jews: pl. OasobaATN: (M, Msb, K:) siboTN (M) and OasobaATN (S, Msb) in relation to the Jews, (M, Msb,) or [rather] the Children of Israel, (S,) being like qabiylapN (M) and qabaAYilu (S, Msb) in relation to the Arabs: (S, M, Msb:) and the former are thus called to distinguish them from the children of Ishmael. (M, TA.) In the phrase, waqaTRaEonaAhumu QvonataIo EaXorapa OasobaATFA [And we divided them into twelve
divisions, tribes], (S, M, K,) in the Kur [vii. 160], (S, M,) AsbATA is a substitute (S, M, K) for AvntI EXrp, (S, M,) not a specificative, (S, M, K,) because the specificative may only be a sing.; (S, M;) the meaning being wqTREnAhm AvntI EXrp firoqapF AsbATFA, (Akh, Zj, S,) and therefore the numeral is fem.; (Akh, S;) or this is a mistake; for it should be firaqFA AvntI EXrp; and therefore the numeral is fem. (Abu-l-'Abbás, TA.) Accord. to Ktr, you say, hecaA siboTN and hecihi siboTN, and heWulaMCi siboTN and using sbT as a pl., meaning firoqapN. (TA.) The saying
kaOanRahu siboTN mina AlOasobaATi
is [asserted to be] a mistake, inasmuch as its author imagined that siboTN meant a man: (M:) IDrd ascribes it to El-'Ajjáj or Ru-beh: it occurs in an Ourojuwzap by the latter. (Sgh, TA.) [But it is applied to a single man: for] it is said in a trad., (TA,) HusayonN siboTN mina AlOasobaATi, i. e. Hoseyn is [as though he were] a nation of the nations (OumRapN mina AlOumami K) in goodness; so expl. by Aboo-Bekr: (TA:) or one of the fathers of tribes; because of the multitude of his descendants: or one of the sons of daughters. (So in a marginal note in a copy of the “ Jámi' es-Sagheer ” of Es-Suyootee.) ― -b3- Also A generation (qaron) that comes after another. (Zj, TA.) ＝ -A2- And siboTN riboEiyRapN, (TA in the present art. and in art. rbE,) or riboEiyRapN sabaTN↓, (so accord. to a copy of the M, in the present art.,) A palmtree of which the fruit ripens in the end of the summer, or hot-season. (M, TA.)

sabaTN c
sabaTN: see the next paragraph, first sentence. ＝ -A2- Also Such as is fresh of the [plant called] HaliIR; one of the plants of the sands; (M;) [i. e.] the [plant called] naSiIR, while fresh; (A'Obeyd, S, O, K;) when it has dried up, called HaliIR; (A'Obeyd, S, O;) a plant like the viyl [q. v.], except that it becomes tall; growing in the sands: (Lth, TA:) n. un. with p: (Lth, S:) it is one of those that, when they dry up, become white, [as is said of the HaliIR,] resembling hoariness, like the vumaAm [or panic grass]: (AHn, O: in the TA, the namRaAm:) it is asserted that the Arabs say, “ The SilRiyaAn is the bread of the camels, and the sabaT is their xabiyS: ” (AHn, O:) its manner of growth is like [that of] duxon [q. v.]; and it is a good pasture: (K:) AHn says, a desert-Arab, of 'Anazeh, told me that its manner of growth is like that of large duxon, falling short of [so I render duwna, but this also signifies exceeding,] curap [q. v.], and it has grain like the grain termed bazor [q. v.], which will not come forth from its envelopes but by bruising, or pounding, and men extract it and eat it, made into bread, and cooked: (M, O:) the n. un. is with p: and the pl. is OasobaATN. (M.) Also The tree that has many branches and one OaSol [meaning stem]: (K:) so says Az.; adding that hence is derived OasobaATN [pl. of siboTN]; as though the father represented the tree and the children represented the branches: (TA: [but this is questionable:]) accord. to Abo-Ziyád, a certain tree, (AHn, M, O,) growing in the sands, (AHn, O,) tall, having slender branches, eaten by the camels and the sheep or goats, (AHn, M, O,) and collected by men, who sell it upon the roads (EalaI AlTRuruqi), (AHn, O,) or with the tamarisk (maEa AlTRarofaMCi); (so in the TA;) without blossom and without thorns, having thin leaves of the size of [those of] the kurRaAv [or leek] (AHn, M, O) when this first comes forth. (AHn, O.) ― -b2- See also the last sentence of the next preceding paragraph.

sabiTN c
sabiTN and saboTN↓ and sabaTN↓, (the first and third of these in one copy of the S, and the second alone in another copy of the S, and all in the M and Msb and K,) the first of the dial. of El- Hijáz, (TA,) from sabiTa, and the second from sabuTa, the last being an inf. n. used as an epithet, (Msb,) Lank, not crisp; (S, M, * Msb, K; *) applied to hair: (S, Msb:) pl. sibaATN, which is said by Sb to be of the measure most common for a pl. of an epithet of the measure faEalN, (M,) or faEolN. (TA.) ― -b2- sabiTu AlXRaEari, (S, M,) and saboTuhu↓, (M,) A man having lank hair: (S, M:) and in like manner sibaATN, alone, applied to a number of persons. (TA.) saboTN↓ is also metonymically applied to (tropical:) A foreigner, like as [its contr.] jaEodN is to an Arab. (TA.) ― -b3- sabiTN also signifies Tall; (M, K;) applied to a man: (M:) or, as also saboTN↓, (TA,) or sabiTu Aljisomi, (M,) so applied, long in the [bones called] OalowaAH [pl. of lawoH], (M, TA,] and even therein: (TA:) or sabiTu Aljisomi or saboTuhu↓, (accord. to different copies of the K,) or both, (S, TA,) goodly in stature, or person, or proportion, (S, K,) and evenness. (S.) Also Having extended limbs, and perfect in make. (TA.) And sabiTu AlqaSabi, and saboTuhaA↓, A man [long and even, or] extended, and without protuberances, in the bones of the fore arms and the shanks. (TA.) And sabiTu AlbanaAni and saboTuhaA↓, (tropical:) Long in the fingers. (TA.) And sabiTu Alxaloqi A man lank in make: (L in art. rd:) and sabiTapu Alxaloqi, and saboTatuhu↓, (tropical:) a woman lank, or soft, or tender, in make. (M, Z, TA.) And sabiTu AlsRaAqayoni A man soft, or flaccid, or uncompact, in the shanks. (Ham p. 238.) ― -b4- Alyadayoni saboTu↓, (M, K, TA,) and sabiTuhumaA, (TA, and so in the CK,) and sabiTu AlkafRayoni, (TA,) (tropical:) A man who is liberal, bountiful, or munificent. (M, K, TA.) And sabiTN biAlomaEoruwfi (tropical:) A man easy, or facile, in beneficence. (M, TA.) ― -b5- maTarN sabiTN, (Sh, TA,) and saboTN↓, (Sh, K,) (tropical:) Rain pouring abundantly and extensively, (Sh, K,) and consecutively. (Sh, TA.)

sibiTRN c
sibiTRN: see sibitRN.

sabaATi c
sabaATi Fever: (M, O, K:) so called because the man attacked by it extends himself, and becomes relaxed: (Skr, O:) or fever attended with shivering, or trembling. (O.)

subaATN c
subaATN (AA, S, M, K) and subaATu, being perfectly and imperfectly decl., (AA, K,) and also written with X, (TA, and K in art. XbT,) The name of a month in Greek; (S;) a certain month, [next] before McaAru; (K;) the month that is between the winter and the spring; (M;) [the fifth month of the Syrian year, corresponding with February O. S.;] it is in the winter-quarters, and in it is the completion of the day whereof the fractions circulate in the years: when the said day is complete in that month, the people of Syria call that year EaAmu Alkabiysi; and when a child is born, or a person arrives from a country, in that year, they consider it fortunate. (Az, TA.) [See kabiysN.]

subaATapN c
subaATapN Sweepings, syn. kunaAsapN, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) which are thrown every day in the courts of houses. (K.) ― -b2- Also A place in which sweepings (Mgh, TA) and dirt (TA) are thrown: occuring in a trad., (Mgh, TA,) and so expl. by El-Khattábee: (Mgh:) but some assign to it there the former meaning. (TA.) [It should be observed that kunaAsapN also is said to have both these meanings.] ― -b3- Also What falls from, or of, hair when it is combed. (M, TA.) ＝ -A2- A raceme of a palm-tree, with its fruit-stalks (EaraAjiyn) and its fresh ripe dates: of the dial. of Egypt. (TA.)

saAbaATN c
saAbaATN A roof (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) between two walls, (S,) or between two houses, (M, K,) having beneath it a road, or way, or passage, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) which is a thoroughfare: (Mgh:) pl. sawaAbiyTu (S, Msb, K) and saAbaATaAtN. (S, K.)

maA liI OaraAka musobiTFA c
maA liI OaraAka musobiTFA Wherefore do I see thee hanging down thy head like one in grief, or anxiety, lax in body? (S.) And tarakotuhu musobiTFA I left him (meaning a sick person) not moving nor speaking. (TA.) ＝ -A2- OaroDN musobiTapN, (M, and so in some copies of the S,) or masobaTapN↓, (thus in other copies of the S, and in the O,) Land abounding with sabaT [q. v.]. (S, M, * O.)

masobaTapN c
masobaTapN: see what next precedes.

musabRiTN c
musabRiTN: see 2.

Q. 4 AisobaTarRa c
Q. 4. AisobaTarRa He stretched himself: (M:) he lay upon his side, and stretched himself. (S, K.) ― -b2- He (a slaughtered beast) stretched himself to die. (TA.) ― -b3- AsbTrRt AlUibilu fiI sayorihaA The camels hastened, (M, * K, * TA,) and stretched themselves, in their march, or course. (TA.) ― -b4- AsbTrRt lahu AlbilaAdu The provinces became rightly disposed to him. (Fr, K. *)

sibaTorN c
sibaTorN A lion stretching himself when about to spring or leap. (S, K.) ― -b2- A quick camel: pl. sibaToraAtN: it has no broken pl. (Sb, M.) ― -b3- Also, the pl. above mentioned, Camels long, upon the surface of the ground [or horizontally]. (S, K.) The t [says J] is not the denotative of the fem. gender: (S:) it is like that in rijaAlaAtN (S, K) and HamRaAmaAtN, as masc. pls.: (S:) but IB says, the t in this word is the denotative of the fem. gender; for it is an epithet applied to jimaAlN, which is fem. as a [broken] pl.; as is shown by the saying AljimaAlu saArato, and raEato, &c.: and he adds, J's saying that it is like rjAlAt and HmRAmAt
is a mistake, inasmuch as he confounds rjAlAt with HmRAmAt; for rijaAlN is a fem. pl., as is shown by one's saying AlrRijaAlu xarajato, and saArato; but HamRaAmN is masc., and should not regularly have a pl. with A and t, but, as Sb says, it has this pl. form, like some other masc. words, in lieu of a broken pl., and would not have it if it had a broken pl. (TA.) ― -b4- Also the sing., Penetrating; effective; (Lth, M, K;) [as though stretching far;] sharp in intellect; clever; acute: (K: [in the CK, AlmADiI AlsRahomi is put by mistake for AlmADI AlXRahomu:]) or sharp in intellect, and very bold or daring or courageous. (TA.) ― -b5- Lank hair. (M.) ― -b6- A man (Sh) lank and tall. (Sh, K.) ― -b7- And with p, A corpulent woman. (M.)

sibaToraI c
sibaToraI A proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of the body from side to side. (M, K.)

subaATirN c
subaATirN: see what next follows.

sabayoTarN c
sabayoTarN and subaATirN↓ Tall, or long. (M, K.) ― -b2- Also the former, A certain bird having a very long neck, (S, K,) which one sees always in shallow water; surnamed Oabuw AlEayozaAri. (S.) [Freytag says, on the authority of Dmr, that it is also called mAlk AlHzyn. See art. mlk.]

1 sabaEahumo c
1. sabaEahumo, aor.
sabaEa
(S, Msb, K) and
sabiEa
(Yoo, Msb, K) and
sabuEa
, (Yoo, Msb,) inf. n. saboEN, (Msb,) He was, or became, the seventh of them: (S, Msb, K:) or he made them, with himself, seven: (S in art. vlv:) or it signifies, (S, and so in some copies of the K,) or signifies also, (Msb, and so in some copies of the K,) he took the seventh part of their property, or possessions. (S, Msb, K.) And He made them, they being sixty-nine, to be seventy with himself. (A 'Obeyd, S in art. vlv.) And sabaEa also signifies He made sixteen to be seventeen. (T in art. vlv.) ― -b2- sabaEotu lahu AlOayRaAma, aor.
sabaEa
, inf. n. as above, I completed to him the days by making them seven: and sabRaEotuhaA↓ signifies the same in an emphatic manner. (Msb.) [See also 2.] ― -b3- sabaEa AlHabola, (K,) aor.
sabaEa
, inf. n. as above, (TA,) He made the rope, or cord, of seven strands. (K, TA.) ― -b4- subiEa Almawoluwdu The infant had its head shaven, and an animal [generally a goat] sacrificed by way of expiation for it, on the seventh day [after its birth, (commonly called yawomu AlsRubuwEi,) agreeably with an ordinance of Mohammad; the sacrifice being for the expiation of original sin]. (IDrd.) ＝ -A2- sabaEa Alganama He (a wolf) seized the sheep, or goats, and broke their necks, or killed them, or made them his prey, (S, K, TA,) and ate them. (TA.) ― -b2- subiEati AlwaHoXiyRapN The female wild animal had her young, or young one, eaten by the sabuE [or beast, or bird, of prey]. (TA.) ― -b3- sabaEahu He stole it; [as though, like a sabuE, he made it his prey;] as also AstbEhu↓. (AA, K.) ― -b4- He shot him [with an arrow or the like], or hurled at him and struck him [with a lance, or a missile of any kind]; namely, a wolf: or he frightened him; namely, a wolf; (K;) and also, a man. (TA.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) He reviled, vilified, or vituperated, him; charged him with a vice or fault or the like; (S, K, TA;) assailed him with foul language, such as displeased him: (TA:) or he bit him (K, TA) with his teeth, like as does the sabuE. (TA.)

2 sbREhu c
2. sbREhu, inf. n. tasobiyEN, He made it seven; or called it seven; (S, K;) as also AsbEhu↓. (TA.) See also 1. ― -b2- He made it to have seven angles, or corners; to be heptagonal. (K.) ― -b3- He (God) gave him his reward, or recompense, seven times, or seven fold. (K.) An Arab of the desert said to a man who had done a good act to him, (TA,) sabRaEa QllRehu laka May God give thee thy reward, or recompense, seven times, or seven fold. (K, TA.) The Arabs also said, sabRaEa QllRehu laka OajorahaA May God multiply to thee the reward, or recompense, for it; meaning, for this good act: (Aboo-Sa'eed:) [for] tasobiyEN is used by them to signify the act of multiplying, though it be more than seven fold. (TA.) And sabRaEa QllRehu lifulaAnK is used as meaning May God make a thing to be followed by another thing to such a one; in relation to good and to evil; as also tabRaEa lahu. (TA.) And sabRaEa QllRehu laka meaning May God bless thee with seven children. (TA.) ― -b4- He washed it (namely, a vessel,) seven times. (K.) Hence the saying of Aboo-Dhu-eyb,
kanaEoti QlRatiI qaAmato tusabRiEu suWorahaA
[Like her who has arisen to wash out seven times her remains of beverage in the bottom of a vessel, left by a drinker; that drinker, as is said in a marginal note in my copy of the TA, being her dog]: or, accord. to Es-Sukkaree, the meaning is, to give as alms her suWor [remains of beverage in the bottom of a vessel after one had drunk, or remains of food &c.,], thereby seeking to have her reward, or recompense, multiplied; suWorahaA being used by the poet for bisuWorihaA. (TA.) ― -b5- sbRE AlquroMna [app. followed by lahu or Ealayohi] He appointed him the reading, or recitation, of the Kur-án [in seven portions so that he should complete the whole] in every seven nights. (O, L, K.) ― -b6- sbRE liQmoraOatihi, (K, TA,) or EinodahaA and lahaA OasobaEa↓, (TA,) He remained with his wife seven nights. (K, TA.) In like manner one says valRava; and thus of every number from one to ten; in relation to any saying or action. (TA.) ― -b7- sbREt She (a woman) brought forth at seven months. (TA.) ― -b8- sbRE daraAhimahu He made his dirhems to be seventy complete; but this is post-classical; (K;) and in like manner, drAhmh saboEana↓, meaning the same, and also post-classical, and not allowable; the proper phrase to express the meaning “ I made it to be seventy ” being kamRalotuhu saboEiyna. (TA.) ― -b9- sabRaEati Alqawomu The people, or company of men, completed the number of seven hundred men: (K, TA:) occurring in a trad, (TA.)

3 sibaAEN c
3. sibaAEN (K,) inf. n. of sAbE, (TK,) The performing of the act of coïtus, (IAar, Th, K,) with a woman. (TK.) ― -b2- The vying with another in the endeavour to surpass him in obscene, or lewd, language, and in frequency of coïtus, and in speaking plainly of such subjects as should only be alluded to, in relation to women: (IAar, K: *) such seems to be its meaning in a trad. in which the doing this is forbidden. (IAar.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) Mutual reviling, vilifying, or vituperating; (K, TA;) when each of two men assails the other with foul language, such as displeases him: (TA:) this is said by some to be its meaning in the trad. in which it is forbidden. (TA.)

4 AsbE c
4. AsbE, said of a party of men, It became seven: (S, K:) also, it became seventy. (M and L in art. vlv.) ― -b2- Said of a man, it signifies He was, or became, one whose camels came to the water on the seventh day [counting the day of the next preceding watering as the first]. (S, K.) ― -b3- AsbE liQmoraOatihi: see 2. ― -b4- OasobaEato She brought forth her seventh offspring. (TA in art. bkr.) ― -b5- AsbEhu: see 2, first signification. ＝ -A2- It (a road) abounded with sibaAE [or animals of prey]. (TA.) ― -b2- AsbE AlrRuEoyaAnu The pastors had their beasts fallen upon by the sabuE [or animal of prey]. (Yaakoob, S, K.) ＝ -A3- AsbEhu i. q. OaToEamahu AlsRabuEa [which may be rendered He gave him as food the animal of prey, or he gave him as food to the animal of prey; but it seems from what here follows that the former is meant]: (S, K:) in the “ Mufradát, ” [he gave him as food] the flesh of the sabuE. (TA.) ＝ -A4- He gave him, or delivered him, (namely, his son,) to the ZuWuwrap [which means both nurse and nurses]. (S, K.) ― -b2- He left him to himself; or left him without work, or occupation; namely, his slave; syn. Oahomalahu. (S, K.) [See musobaEN.]

8 UisotabaEa
8: see 1.

Q. Q. 1
Q. Q. 1: saboEana: see 2. last sentence but one.

saboEN c
saboEN fem. of saboEapN, q. v. ＝ -A2- See also sabuEN in two places. ＝ -A3- AlsRaboEu The place to which mankind shall be congregated (K, TA) on the day of resurrection. (TA.) Hence the trad., (K, TA,) which relates that while a pastor was among his sheep, or goats, the wolf rushed upon him, and took from them a sheep, or goat, and the pastor pursued him until he rescued it from him; whereupon the wolf looked aside towards him, and said to him, (TA,) mano lahaA yawoma AlsRaboEi, meaning Who will be for it [namely, the sheep, or goat, as aider, or defender,] on the day of resurrection? (K, TA:) thus expl. by I Aar, and mentioned by Sgh and the author of the L: (TA:) but to this is contradictory, or repugnant, yaEokuru, [in the CK erroneously written yaEokaru,]) the saying of the wolf, (K, TA,) after the words mentioned above, (TA,) “ the day when it shall have no pastor but me; ” for the wolf will not be a pastor on the day of resurrection: or the meaning is, who shall be for it on the occasion of trials, when it shall be left to itself, without pastor, a spoil to the animals of prey: the animal of prey being thus made to be a pastor to it: (K, TA:) this is in the way of a trope: and accord. to this explanation, it may be [yawoma AlsRabuEi↓] with damm to the b:
(TA:) or yawomu AlsRaboEi was a festival of their's in the Time of Ignorance, on which they were diverted from everything by their sport: (AO, K, TA:) and accord. to one relation [of the trad.] it is with damm to the b. (L, K.)

suboEN c
suboEN (S, Msb, K) and subuEN↓, (Mgh, Msb,) of which the former is a contraction, (Msb,) A seventh part; one of seven parts; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also sabiyEN↓; (S, Msb, K;) the last not heard by Sh on any authority beside that of AZ: (TA:) pl. of the first (Msb) and second (Mgh, Msb) OasobaAEN. (Mgh, Msb, TA.) Hence, OasobaAEN AlquroMni [The seven sections, or volumes, of the Kur-an,] in which one reads: said to be postclassical. (Mgh.) ＝ -A2- See also OusobuwEN, in three places.

siboEN c
siboEN A certain ZimoC of the OaZomaMC of camels; (T, S, K;) i. e. their coming to the water on the seventh day [counting the day of the next preceding watering as the first]; (K;) or [in other words, which have virtually the same meaning,] their remaining in their places of pasturing five complete days, and coming to the water on the sixth day, not reckoning the day of the [next preceding] return from the water. (Az, TA.) You say, waradato Uiboluhu siboEFA His camels came to the water &c. (S, K.) ― -b2- Also The seventh young one, or offspring. (A in art. vlv.)

sabaEN c
sabaEN: see what next follows.

sabuEN c
sabuEN (S, Sgh, Msb, K) and saboEN↓, (Sgh, Msb, K,) a dial. var., (Sgh, Msb,) and the form in common use with the vulgar, (Msb,) adopted also by several readers of the Kur in v. 4, (Msb, TA,) and often occurring in the poems of the Arabs, (TA,) and sabaEN↓, (Sgh, K,) a form adopted by two readers of the Kur in the place above mentioned, and perhaps a dial. var., (Sgh, TA,) The animal of prey; the rapacious animal; (K;) [whether beast or bird; being sometimes applied to the latter, as, for instance, in the K, voce mixolabN; but generally to the former:] or whatsoever has a fang, or canine tooth, with which it makes hostile attacks, and seizes its prey; (Msb;) such as the lion, [to which it is particularly applied by most of the Arabs in the present day,] and also (TA) such as the wolf and the lynx and the leopard, (Msb, TA,) and the like of these, that has a fang, and attacks men and beasts and makes them its prey: (TA:) the fox, however, is not thus called, though having a fang, (Msb, TA,) because he does not attack with it nor take prey, (Msb,) or because he does not attack small beasts, nor seize with his fang any animal; (TA;) and in like manner the hyena (Msb, TA) is not reckoned among the hostile animals thus called, wherefore the Sunneh allows that its flesh may be eaten, and requires that a compensation be made for it [by the sacrifice of a ram] if it be smitten [and killed] in the sacred territory or by a person in the state of ihrám: but as to the jackal, it is a noxious sbE, and its flesh is unlawful, because it is of the same kind as wolves, except that it is smaller in size and weaker in body: thus says Az: but some others say that the sbE is any hostile beast having a mixolab [or tearing claw]: and it is said in the Mufradát to be thus called because of the perfectness of its strength; for AlsRaboEu [seven] is one of the perfect numbers: (TA:) the pl. is sibaAEN, (Sb, S, Msb, K,) i. e., of sabuEN, which has no other pl.; (Sb, Msb;) OasobuEN is also a pl., (Sgh, Msb, K,) but this is pl. of pauc. of saboEN↓, (Sgh, Msb,) which, not being a contraction [of sabuEN, but a dial. var. thereof], has also for its pls. [of mult.] subuwEN and subuwEapN, like SuquwrN and SuquwrapN, pls. of SaqorN. (TA.) See also saboEN: [and see sabuEapN.] You say of him who is very injurious, or mischievous, maA huwa UilRaA sabuEN mina AlsRibaAEi (tropical:) [He is none other than one of the animals of prey]. (TA.) ― -b2- AlsRabuEu is also the name of (assumed tropical:) The constellation [Lupus] behind [i. e. on the east of] Centaurus, containing nineteen stars in the figure. (Kzw.)

subuEN c
subuEN: see suboEN.

saboEapN c
saboEapN, (S, K,) sometimes pronounced sabaEapN↓ but some disallow this latter, and say that it is pl. of saAbiEN, (K,) [Seven;] a well-known number; and called one of the perfect numbers: (TA:) fem. saboEN. (S, K.) You say, saboEapu rijaAlK [Seven men]: and saboEu nisowapK [seven women]. (S, K.) ― -b2- Oaxacahu Oaxoca saboEapK: see sabuEapN. ― -b3- wazona saboEapK means Of the weight of seven mavaAqiyl: (S, K:) one says, Oaxacotu minohu miAYapa dirohamK wazona saboEapK, meaning [I took, or received, from him a hundred dirhems] every ten whereof were of the weight of seven mithkáls. (TA.) [But see dirohamN.] ― -b4- UiHodaI mino sboEK [lit. One of seven;] means (assumed tropical:) a great, momentous, or difficult, thing, or affair: (Sh, K: *) an affair difficult to decide: perhaps as being likened to one of the seven nights in which God sent the punishment upon [the tribe of] 'Ád: or, as some say, the seven years [of famine in the days] of Joseph. (Sh, TA.) ― -b5- AlsRaboEu AlmavaAniI The Fátihah; [or first chapter of the Kur-án;] because it consists of seven verses: or the long chapters from Albaqarap to AlOaEorAf [a mistake for AlOanofaAl]; as in the Mufradát: or, as in the L, to AltRawobap, reckoning Altwbp and AlAnfAl as one chapter, for which reason they are not separated by the basomalap. (TA.) [See also mavonFI.] ― -b6- El-Farezdak says,
wakayofa OaxaAfu AlnRaAsa waQllRehu qaAbiDN
EalaI AlnRaAsi waAlsRaboEayoni fiI raAHapi Alyadi
meaning [And how should I fear men when God is comprehending mankind and] the seven heavens and seven earths [in the palm of the hand?]. (K.) ― -b7- See also OusobuwEN; last sentence. ― -b8- [saboEapN is also used in a vague manner, as meaning Seven or more; or several; or many; as Bd says, in ix. 81, and as is indicated, though not plainly declared, in the TA. See 2: and see also saboEuwna. ― -b9- Respecting a peculiar pronunciation of the people of El-Hijáz, and a case in which saboEap is imperfectly decl., see valaAvapN. See also sitRapN.] ― -b10- saboEapa EaXara [indecl. in every case, meaning Seventeen,] is pronounced by some of the Arabs saboEapa EoXara: and [the fem.] saboEa EaXorapa, thus in the dial. of El- Hijáz [and of most of the Arabs], is pronounced saboEa EaXirapa in the dial. of Nejd. (S in art. EXr.) ＝ -A2- See also sabuEapN, in two places.

sabaEapN c
sabaEapN: see saboEapN.

sabuEapN c
sabuEapN and saboEapN↓, the latter a contraction of the former, The lioness. (ISk, S, Msb, K.) Hence the saying, Oaxacahu Oaxaca saboEapK↓, (ISk, S, K,) or AlsRaboEapi, (Msb,) He seized him with the seizing of a lioness, (ISk, S, K,) or of the lioness, (Msb,) which is more impetuous (Oanozaqu) than the lion, (ISk, S,) or more bold than the lion: (Msb:) or the saying is, Oaxacahu Oaxoca saboEapa (S, K) he seized him with the seizing of Seb'ah, who was a certain strong man, (Ibn-El-Kelbee, S,) or a certain insolent and audacious rebel, (Ibn-El-Kelbee, Lth, K,) of the Arabs, (TA,) whom one of the kings of El-Yemen seized, and, after having cut off his hands and feet, or arms and legs, crucified; [so that the meaning is, he punished him with the punishment of Seb'ah;] and hence it was said, laOuEacRibanRaka EacaAba saboEapa [I will assuredly punish thee with the punishment of Seb'ah]; (El-Kelbee, Lth, K; *) and laOaEomalanRa bika Eamala saboEapa I will assuredly do with thee as was done with Seb'ah: (O:) or the man's name was sabuEN, and it was contracted, and made fem. by way of contempt: or the meaning of the first saying is, he seized him with the seizing of seven men: (K:) and in like manner the last saying is expl. by some [who say saboEapK instead of saboEapa]. (TA.) The dim. is subayoEapN↓. (Msb.) [See also sabuEN.]

sabuEiIRN c
[sabuEiIRN Of, or relating to, an animal of prey.]

saboEuwna c
saboEuwna [Seventy;] a well-known number; (K;) the round number that is between sitRuwna and vamaAnuwna. (TA.) ― -b2- The Arabs also use it as meaning [Seventy or more; or] many. (TA.) Thus it is used in the Kur [ix. 81], where it is said, Uino tasotagofiro lahumo saboEiyna marRapF falano yagofira QllRehu lahumo, meaning If thou beg forgiveness for them many times, even then God will not forgive them; not that God would forgive them if forgiveness were begged more than seventy times: (Bd, * TA:) and saboEapN and saboEumiAYapK and the like are used in the same manner. (Bd.) ― -b3- [Also Seventieth.]

subaAEa c
[subaAEa as meaning Seven and seven, or seven and seven together, or seven at a time and seven at a time, seems not to have been used; for] A'Obeyd says that more than OuHaAda and vunaMCa and vulaAva and rubaAEa has not been heard, excepting EuXaAra. (TA in art. EXr.)

sabuwEN c
sabuwEN [app. Wont to frighten]: (TA: [in which the meaning here given seems to be indicated.])

subuwEN c
subuwEN: see OusobuwEN, in four places.

sabiyEN c
sabiyEN: see suboEN: ― -b2- and saAbEN.

subayoEapN c
subayoEapN dim. of sabuEapN, q. v.

subaAEiIRN c
subaAEiIRN A garment, or piece of cloth, seven cubits, or seven spans, in length. (TA.) ― -b2- A great and tall camel; (En-Nadr, K;) [as though seven cubits in height:] fem. with p. (K.). And subaAEiIRu Albadani, (S, K,) applied to a man, has the like meaning; (K;) complete, or full-grown, in body; (S, TA;) [or seven spans in height; for] when a boy has attained seven spans, he is a man. (S, voce xumaAsiIRN, q. v.)

saAbiEN c
saAbiEN [act. part. n. of 1: generally meaning Seventh]: pl. sabaEapN. (K.) You say, kunotu saAbiEahumo [I was the seventh of them]. (S, K.) And hecaA hecaA sabiyEu↓, meaning saAbiEuhu [This is the seventh of this: not the seventh part; though the former has also this latter meaning]. (TA.) And huwa saAbiEu saboEapK [He is the seventh of seven]. (TA.) And huwa saAbiEN sitRapF [He is making six to become seven]. (TA.) ― -b2- UibilN sawaAbiEu [pl. of saAbiEapN] Camels coming to the water on the seventh day [counting the day of the next preceding watering as the first]. (TA.) [See siboEN.] ― -b3- [saAbiEa EaXara and saAbiEapa EaXorapa, the former masc. and the latter fem., meaning Seventeenth, are subject to the same rules as vaAliva EaXara and its fem., expl. in art. vlv, q. v.]

OusobuwEN c
OusobuwEN A certain number of days; (S, * Msb, K; *) i. e. seven days; a week; (Msb;) also termed subuwEN↓, (Lth, Msb, K,) by some of the Arabs; (Lth, Msb;) [and suboEN↓, as shown by what follows:] pl. of the first OasaAbiyEu. (Msb, TA.) One says, Oaqamotu Einodahu suboEayoni↓ [in the sense of OusobuwEayoni, which is more common,] i. e. I remained at his abode two weeks. (TA.) ― -b2- Also The seventh day; and so subuwEN↓; as in a trad., where it is said, UicaA kaAna yawoma subuwEihi, meaning When his seventh day after the celebration of his marriage is come. (TA.) [yawomu AlsRubuwEi↓ is used in this sense in the present day: and also as meaning The seventh day after childbirth; in which sense it is generally to be understood when used unrestrictedly; as this day is celebrated with more rejoicing than the former: also as meaning the seventh day after the return from pilgrimage.] ― -b3- And Seven circuitings [round the House of God, meaning the Kaabeh]: (Lth, Mgh, Msb:) pl. OasaAbiyEu (S, Mgh, Msb) and OusobuwEaAtN. (Lth, Mgh, Msb.) You say, TaAfa biAlbayoti OusobuwEFA, (S, Mgh, * K,) and subuwEFA↓, (Lth, IDrd, K,) but A boo Sa'eed says, I know not any one who has said this except IDrd, and the former is the word commonly known, (TA,) and saboEFA↓, (K,) and suboEFA↓, (TA,) He circuited round the House [of God] seven times, (S, TA,) or seven circuitings; (Mgh;) and valaAvapa OasaAbiyEa [thrice seven times, or thrice seven circuitings]. (S.)

musobaEN c
musobaEN Given, or delivered, to the ZuWuwrap [which means both nurse and nurses]: (Skr, S, TA:) this is the primary signification: (Skr:) or whose mother dies, and who is therefore suckled by another; (K; in which the next following signification may be regarded as implied, TA;) left to himself; or left without work, or occupation; applied to a slave; syn. muhomalN: (Skr, S:) or mutorafN, (Sgh, K,) [which has the same and other significations; or] which is [here] nearly the same as muhomalN, for he who is muhomal is usually mutoraf: (TA:) or one who is left to himself with the sibaAE [or animals of prey] so that he becomes like one of them in mischievousness, or noxiousness, or evilness: (AO, K:) or who is left to himself and not restrained from his daringness, so that he remains daring: and a slave left to himself, and daring; left until he has become like the sabuE: (TA:) or one whose origin is suspected; (K;) whose father is not known: (Er-Rághib, Sgh:) or a bastard: (K:) or one whose lineage is of slaves, (K, TA,) or ignoble, (TA,) up to seven male ancestors, (K, TA,) or, to seven female ancestors; (TA;) or, to four male ancestors; (En-Nadr, K;) or whose lineage is traced up to four female ancestors all of them slaves: (TA:) or born at seven months; (K, TA;) not matured by the womb, his months not being completed. (Az, IF, TA.)

musobiEN c
musobiEN One whose camels come to the water on the seventh day [counting the day of the next preceding watering as the first]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- A slave finding a sabuE [or rapacious animal] among his sheep, or goats. (Aboo-Sa'eed Ed-Dareer, S.)

OaroDN masobaEapN c
OaroDN masobaEapN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) with fet-h (S, Msb) to the first and third letters, (Msb,) like maroHalapN, (K) and macoOabapN, with an inseparable p, (Sb,) A land containing, (S,) or abounding with, (Mgh, Msb, K,) sibaAE [or animals of prey]. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.)

musabRaEN c
musabRaEN A verse consisting of seven feet. (TA.) ― -b2- A camel having, in the middle part of his back, between the withers and the rump, seven vertebrae redundant [app. meaning in size]. (TA.) ― -b3- [See also muvalRavN.]

masobuwEN c
masobuwEN A rope consisting of seven strands. (M, voce mavoluwvN.) ＝ -A2- With p, A cow, (S, TA,) [app. meaning a wild cow,] or [other] female wild animal, (TA,) whose offspring has been eaten by the sabuE [or beast, or bird, of prey]. (S, TA.)

mutasabRaEN c
mutasabRaEN The place of a sabuE [or beast, or bird, of prey]. (TA.)

1 sabaga c
1. sabaga, (Msb, K, &c.,) aor.
sabuga
(MA, Msb) and
sabaga
, (MA,) inf. n. subuwgN, (Msb, K, &c.,) It (a garment [&c.]) was complete, full, ample, or without deficiency: (MA, Msb:) it (a thing, Lth, Msb, of any kind, JK, Msb, such as a garment, TA, a coat of mail, JK, Msb, TA, and the like, TA, and hair, JK, TA) was long, (JK, Msb, K,) from above to below, (Msb,) or reaching to, or towards, the ground. (Lth, K.) [Hence,] cuw subuwgK [The ample, or long, &c.,] was the name of a coat of mail belonging to the Prophet. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence also] sabagato quSayoraI Alfarasi The qSyry [app. here meaning the rib next the flank] of the horse was of full length. (TA.) ― -b3- And sabaga AlmaTaru (tropical:) The rain approached the earth, and extended. (TA.) ― -b4- And sabagati AlnRiEomapu, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. as above, (S, Msb,) (tropical:) The benefit, or boon, was, or became, ample. (S, Msb, K, TA.) One says, AlHamodu lilRehi EalaI subuwgi AlnRiEomapi Praise be to God for the ampleness of the benefit, or boon. (TA.) ― -b5- And sabaga libaladihi (assumed tropical:) He tended towards, and reached, his town, or country; (AA, * K;) inf. n. as above. (TA.)

2 sabRagato c
2. sabRagato, inf. n. tasobiygN, She (a camel, As, JK, S, or a pregnant female, K) cast her young one, or fœtus, (As, JK, S, K,) in an incomplete state, (TA,) or when its hair had grown, (As, S, K,) or when its fur had grown; (JK;) accord. to the T, (TA,) i. q. OajohaDat: (JK, TA:) or, accord. to AA, sabRagati AlUibilu biOawolaAdihaA the camels cast their young abortively; and, in like manner, accord. to Lth, one says of all pregnant females: (TA:) [see also sabRaqat:] the epithet applied to her is musabRigN↓, without p. (As, K, TA.)

4 Asbghu c
4. Asbghu He made it complete, full, ample, or without deficiency; (Msb;) he made it wide; namely, his garment [&c.]: and he made it long; namely, [his garment, and the like, and] his hair, (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Asbg QllRehu Ealayohi AlnRiEomapa (S, Msb, * K *) (tropical:) God made the benefit, or boon, complete, full, or ample, to him. (S, * Msb, * K, * TA.) And Asbg lahu fiI AlnRafaqapi (assumed tropical:) He expended upon him what was completely sufficient for his wants; bestowed upon him amply. (TA.) ― -b3- And Asbg AlwuDuwoCa, (K,) inf. n. UisobaAgN, (S,) (tropical:) He performed completely the [ablution termed] wDwC, (S, K, TA,) making it to reach to the proper places thereof, and giving fully to every member its due. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- And Asbg He put on a wide, or an ample, [or a long,] coat of mail. (KL.)

subugN c
subugN: see musobigN.

sabogapN c
sabogapN (tropical:) Plentifulness, and pleasantness or easiness, and softness or delicacy, of life. (K, TA.) One says, UinRahumo lafiI sabogapK mina AlEayoXi (tropical:) Verily they are in a state of plentifulness, &c., of life. (TA.)

saAbigN c
saAbigN, applied to a thing (JK, S) of any kind, (JK,) Complete, full, ample, or without deficiency: (S, TA:) [and] long. (JK.) You say, diroEN saAbigapN A coat of mail that is wide, or ample, (S, K, * TA,) and long: (K, TA:) or such that one drags it upon the ground, or [that falls] against one's ankles, by reason of length and ampleness: pl. sawaAbigu. (TA.) And canabN saAbigN A complete, a full, or an ample, tail. (S.) And dalowN saAbigapN (tropical:) A long dlw [or leathern bucket]. (TA.) And naAqapN saAbigapu AlDRaroEi (tropical:) A she-camel full, or without lack or defect, in the udder: (Lth, and so in the K accord. to the TA:) or saAbigapu AlDRuluwEi without lack or defect, and long, in the ribs. (So
in copies of the K.) And EajiyzapN saAbigapN and OaloyapN saAbigapN (Msb, K) signify in like manner, (K,) [or] (tropical:) A long buttock. (Msb, TA. *) And rajulN saAbigu AlOaloyatayoni (assumed tropical:) A man large in the buttocks. (TA.)
