And faHolN saAbigN (tropical:) A stallion long in the veretrum: (S, K, TA:) the contr. thereof is termed kamiXN. (S, TA.) And livapN saAbigapN (tropical:) A foul, or an ugly, gum. (Lth, K, TA.) ― -b2- And maTorapN saAbigapN (tropical:) A compious rain. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- And niEomapN saAbigapN (tropical:) A complete, a full, or an ample, benefit, or boon. (K, * TA.) ― -b4- See also tasobigapN.

Oasobagu c
Oasobagu More [and most] complete, full, ample, or free from deficiency [in breadth and in length]: occurring in this sense in a trad., relating to a coat of mail. (TA.)

tasobiagN c
tasobiagN: see what next follows.

tasobigapN c
tasobigapN (JK, S, K) and tasobagapN and tasobigN↓ and tasobagN, (JK, K,) the first of which is the most chaste, (TA,) I. q. migofarN [q. v.]: (JK:) or a portion of the mail of the coat of mail, that is conjoined to the helmet, and protects the neck: (JK, S, K:) for the helmet becomes lengthened (tasobugu) thereby; and but for it, there would be between it and the opening at the neck of the coat of mail an intervening space: (S:) or the mail composing the raforaf of the helmet, at the bottom thereof, with which the man protects his neck, and which is also called the migofar: or, accord. to “ the Book of the Coat of Mail and the Helmet, ” by AO, the raforaf of the helmet is other than its tasobigap; for he says that, of helmets, there is that which has a raforaf, [consisting of] rings [or mail] encompassing the bottom thereof, so as to surround the back and other parts of the neck, and the two cheeks, and to reach to the maHojiraAni [q. v.] of the two eyes; and he afterwards says, but when it [the helmet] is not of plate, or expanded metal, but is [a head-covering] of mail, it is called migofarN and gifaArapN and tasobigapN: (TA:) [the pl. is tasaAbigu:] and the helmet [that has a tasobigap attached to it, accord. to those who mean by this term the mail attached to the bottom thereof,] is called saAbigN↓: (JK:) or, accord. to As, one says bayoDapN lahaA saAbigN, (S,) or lahaA tasaAbigu. (K, TA: in the CK [erroneously] tasaAbugN.)

musobigN c
musobigN, (S, A, L, TA,) in the O and K subugN↓, like EunuqN, which seems to be a mistranscription, copied by the author of the K, accord, to his usual practice, from the O, (TA,) A man having upon him a coat of mail such as is termed saAbigapN. (S, A, O, L, K.)

musabRagN c
musabRagN is expl. by Kr as meaning The young that is cast by its mother after the soul has been blown into it. (TA. [But see its verb, 2.])

musabRigN c
musabRigN: see 2.

misobaAgN c
misobaAgN A she-camel that usually casts her young abortively: but a term not well know, (IDrd, TA.)

1 sabaqahu c
1. sabaqahu, (S, O, Msb, K, &c.,) aor.
sabiqa
(O, Msb, K) and
sabuqa
, (O, K,) but the former is of higher authority, or more usual, (O, TA,) inf. n. saboqN, (S, Msb,) He preceded him; he was, or became, got, went, or came, before him, or ahead of him; he outwent, or outstripped, him; he had, got, or took, precedence of him; syn. taqadRamahu; (K, TA;) in running, and in everything. (TA.) Some read, in the Kur [xxi. 27], laA yasobuquwnahu biAlqawoli, thus, with damm, meaning They say not [anything] without his having taught them: (O, TA:) or they say not anything until He has said it: originally, laA yasobuiqu qawoluhumo qawolahu [their saying does not precede his saying]: this reading is from the phrase saAbaqotuhu fasabaqotuhu, [expl. below,] aor. of the latter Oasobuquhu. (Bd.) See 3. ― -b2- sabaqa Alfarasu fiI AlHalobapi The horse outstripped, or came in first, among those started together for a wager, or in the race-ground. (O, K.) Hence the trad. of 'Alee, sabaqa rasuwlu QllRehi waSalRaI Oabuw bakorK wavalRava Eumaru (assumed tropical:) [The Apostle of God came in first in the race, and Aboo-Bekr came in next, and 'Omar came in third]. (O, TA.) [And sabaqa used in like manner with the objective complement understood means He preceded, &c., as above; and hence, he was, or became, first, foremost, or beforehand; he had, or got, the priority, or precedence. And He was, or became, one of the first or foremost: see saAbiqN. See also qaSabu AlsRaboqi in art. qSb.] ― -b3- sabaqa AlnRaAsa UilaI AlOamori [He preceded the other people; was, or became, before them; or had, got, or took, precedence of them; in betaking, or applying, himself to the affair]. (S, K.) And in like manner one says, lahu saboqN fiI hecaA AlOamori To him belongs priority, or precedence, in this affair; like saAbiqapN; syn. qudomapN. (A, TA.) ― -b4- [Hence,] sabaqa wahomuhu UilaI XaIoCK fagaliTa fiyhi (assumed tropical:) [He preconceived a thing, and therefore made a mistake, or erred, respecting it]. (Msb, in explanation of duxila Ealayohi.) [And sabaqa cihonuhu UilaI AlXRaIoCi means in like manner (assumed tropical:) He preconceived the thing: or his mind adverted hastily, before reflection, or without premeditation, to the thing; from what next follows.] ― -b5- sabaqa Uilayohimo He went, or passed, hastily, or quickly, to them. (TA.) ― -b6- [And hence,] sabaqa Uilayohi minRiI qawolN (assumed tropical:) A saying proceeded hastily, before reflection, or without premeditation, to him from me; syn. faraTa: (S in art. frT:) and sabaqa minohu kalaAmN (assumed tropical:) speech proceeded hastily, &c., from him; syn. faraTa: (Msb in that art.:) [but this phrase also means, more agreeably with the primary signification of the verb, (assumed tropical:) speech proceeded previously from him; (see the Kur x. 20, &c.;) and in like manner the former phrase.] See also 8. And sabaqahu AlqaIoCu, (S, Msb, K, all in art. crE,) i. e. sabaqahu fiI Alxuruwji UilaI fiyhi [meaning (assumed tropical:) The vomit came forth to his mouth before he was aware]. (TA in that art.) [And sabaqa Alqalamu (assumed tropical:) The pen anticipated, skipping over something, in transcribing.] ― -b7- One says also, sabaqotu EalayohK, meaning (tropical:) I overcame him. (TA.) And sabaqa EalaI qawomihi (assumed tropical:) He overcame his people in generosity. (TA.) And sabaqahu fiI Alkarami (assumed tropical:) He exceeded him in generosity. (TA.)

2 sbRq c
2. sbRq, (inf. n. tasobiyqN, Mgh,) He took, or received, the sabaq [i. e. stake, or wager, laid at a race or a shooting-match, to be taken by the successful competitor]: (IAar, O, K:) or sabRaqotuhu I took, or received, the sabaq, from him. (Az, Mgh, Msb.) ― -b2- And He gave the sabaq: (IAar, O, K:) or sabRaqotuhu I gave him the sabaq. (Az, Mgh, Msb.) Thus it has two contr. significations. (IAar, Az, Mgh, O, Msb, K.) Hence, in the trad. of Rukáneh the wrestler, maA tusabRiquniI, i. e. What wilt thou give me [if I overcome]? and he said, The third of my sheep, or goats. (Mgh.) And sabRaqa Albadorapa bayona AlXRuEaraMCi (tropical:) He made the [sum of money termed] bdrp to be a sabaq [i. e. stake, or wager,] among the poets, to be taken by him who should overcome. (Z, TA.) And it is said in a trad., Oamara biUijoraMCi Alxayoli wasbRaqahaA valaAvapa OaEocuqK mino valaAvi naxalaAtK, meaning [He ordered the making of the horse to run, and] gave them as a sabaq [three racemes of dates from three palm-trees]: or it may mean, he took, or received, as their sabaq: or it [i. e. sbqhA] may be without teshdeed, [as a subst. with its affixed pronoun,] meaning the property assigned [as their sabaq]. (L, TA.) ― -b3- One says also, sabRaqotu bayona Alxayoli [app. meaning I gave a sabaq among the horses]: (O:) or sabRaqotu Alxayola, and bayonahaA sAbqt↓, meaning I sent forth the horses with their riders upon them, to see which of them would outstrip. (TA.) ― -b4- And sbRqt AlXRaApu, inf. n. as above, The ewe, or she-goat, cast her young one, or fœtus, in an incomplete state: (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K:) but sbRgt, with g, is better known. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.) ＝ -A2- sabRaqotu AlTRaAYira (tropical:) I put the sibaAqaAni [or pair of jesses] upon the legs of the bird, and [so] shackled it. (TA.)

3 saAbaqotuhu c
3. saAbaqotuhu, inf. n. musaAbaqapN and sibaAqN, [I strove, or contended, with him to precede him; to be, or become, get, go, or come, before him, or ahead of him; to outgo, or outstrip, him; to have, get, or take, precedence of him; in running (i. e. I raced, or ran a race, with him); and in everything.] (Msb, TA.) You say, saAbaqotuhu fasabaqotuhu↓ [I strove, or contended, with him to precede him, &c., and I surpassed him, or overcame him, in doing so]: (S:) the aor. of the latter verb in this case is Oasobuquhu, (Bd in xxi. 27,) and the inf. n. is saboqN. (S.) ― -b2- See also 6. ― -b3- And see 2.

4 Asbq Alqawomu UilaI AlOamori c
4. Asbq Alqawomu UilaI AlOamori [perhaps a mistranscription for Astbq↓] The people, or party, hastened to the thing, or affair; or employed the fulness of their power, or force, to hasten to it; syn. baAdaruwA. (TA.)

6 tsAbqA c
6. tsAbqA and AstbqA↓ signify the same: (K, TA:) thus the saying [in the Kur xii. 25] AlbaAba waQsotabaqaA↓ means tasaAbaqaA Uilayohi, i. e. And they strove, or contended, each with the other, to precede, or get before, to the door. (TA.) [And
both are trans. by means of UilaI:] you say, tsAbqwA UilaI kacaA and Uilayohi AstbqwA↓ [They strove, or contended, together, to precede, or be first, in attaining to such a thing: and so saAbaquwA↓: see the Kur lvii. 21, here saAbiquwA UilaI magofirapK is expl. by Bd as meaning saAriEuwA musaAraEapa AlmusaAbiqiyna fiI AlmiDomaAri i. e. Strive ye, one with another, in hastening, with the striving of those that contend to outstrip in the hippodrome, to obtain forgiveness]. (Msb.) And you say, fiI AlEadowi AisotabaqonaA↓, meaning tasaAbaqonaA [i. e. We strove, or contended, one with another, to precede, get before or ahead, or outstrip, in running: and in like manner each of these verbs is used in relation to any object of contention for precedence]. (S.) ― -b2- And tsAbqwA and AstbqwA↓ (tropical:) They competed, or contended, together in shooting. (TA.) cahabonaA nasotabiqu↓, in the Kur [xii. 17], means (assumed tropical:) We went to compete, or contend, together in shooting: (S, Bd:) or in running. (Bd.) ― -b3- And ↓the latter of these verbs, as well as the former, signifies also They laid bets, wagers, or stakes, one with another. (TA.)

8 Uisotabaqa
8: [Astbqhu and Astbq Uilayohi i. q. baAdara Uilayohi. Thus] faQsotabiquwA AlxayoraAti, in the Kur [ii. 143 and v. 53], means Therefore hasten ye to good acts, &c.; or employ the fulness of your power, or force, in hastening thereto; syn. baAdiruwA UilayohaA. (O.) See also 4. ― -b2- You say also, Astbq Uilayohi AlOamoru, (K in art. bdr,) or sabaqa↓, (M in that art.,) The thing, or event, came to him, or happened to him, hastily, quickly, or speedily; and beforehand [or before he expected it]; syn. badarahu, and badara Uilayohi. (M and K in that art.) ― -b3- faQsotabaquwA AlSRiraATa, in the Kur xxxvi. 66, in which AlSrAT is in the accus. case because of UilaI suppressed before it, or by making AlAisotibaAqu to imply the meaning of AlAibotidaAru, (Bd,) means And they would hasten, make haste, or strive to get first or beforehand, to the road that they were wont to travel: (Bd, Jel:) or (tropical:) they would go along the road and leave it behind them, (Bd, * O, K, TA,) so that they would wander from the right way. (O, K, TA.) ― -b4- See also 6, throughout.

siboqN c
siboqN A competitor of another in striving to precede, to be before or ahead, to outgo or outstrip, or to have precedence: [pl. OasobaAqN; and the sing. is also used as a pl.:] you say, humo siboqiI and OasobaAqiI: (L:) and humaA siboqaAni They are two that compete &c. (El-Moheet, O, K.)

sabaqN c
sabaqN A stake, or wager, that is laid between the persons concerned in a race, (T, S, O, Mgh, * Msb, * K,) and in a shooting-match; in the former case taken by [the owner of] the one that outstrips; (T, TA:) and suboqapN↓ signifies the same: (K:) pl. of the former OasobaAqN. (O, K.) It is said in a trad., laA sabaqa UilRaA fiI xufRK Oawo HaAfirK Oawo naSolK, meaning There shall be no stake, or wager, except in the case of the racing of camels, or of horses or mules or asses, or in the case of [the arrowhead or lance-head, i. e.] shooting or casting [the lance]: for all these affairs are preparations for engaging in fight with the enemy; and mules and asses are included because they carry the baggage of the army. (O, TA.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) The lesson of a boy, that is learned each day in the school; also called UimaAmN. (TA in art. Am.)

suboqapN c
suboqapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

sibaAqN c
sibaAqN an inf. n. of 3 [q. v.]. (Msb, TA.) ― -b2- [As a simple subst., A race, or contest in running. ― -b3- And The preceding part of a discourse &c. You say sibaAqu AlkalaAmi wasiyaAquhu The preceding and following parts of the discourse; the context, before and after.] ― -b4- sibaAqaA AlbaAziI The qayodaAni [or pair of shackles, i. e. jesses,] of the hawk or falcon, of leathern thongs or straps, or of other material. (S, O, K.)

sabuwqN c
sabuwqN: see saAbiqN.

huwa sabRaAqu gaAyaAtK c
huwa sabRaAqu gaAyaAtK (tropical:) He is one who [often] obtains the winning canes (qaSabaAt AlsRaboq [see art. qSb]). (O, K, TA.)

saAbiqN c
saAbiqN [act. part. n. of 1, Preceding, &c.: and sometimes it means one of the first or foremost: as is shown by what here follows]: sometimes what is thus termed has one coming up with it; as [sometimes happens] in the case of the sAbq of horses: and sometimes it is like him who obtains the winning-cane (qaSabap AlsRaboq [see art. qSb]); for he outstrips to it and has none to share with him in it, there being none coming up with him. (Msb.) It is applied to a horse That outstrips; as also sabuwqN↓: (T, Msb, TA: *) and the pl. [masc., i. e. pl. of the former,] applied to horses is subRaqN and [fem., i. e. pl. of saAbiqapN,] sawaAbiqu: (TA:) [or] sawaAbiqu may be pl. of saAbiqN regarded as a subst. like kaAhilN and gaAribN of which the pls. are kawaAhilu and gawaAribu. (Ham p. 46.) ― -b2- By the saAbiqaAt mentioned in the Kur lxxix. 4 are meant The angels that precede the devils with the revelation [that they convey] to the prophets: (TA:) or the angels that precede the jinn, or genii, in listening to the revelation: (T, K, TA:) or the angels that precede with the souls of the believers to Paradise (Bd, Jel) and with the souls of the unbelievers to Hell: (Bd:) or the horses [that precede in battle]: (Zj, TA:) or the souls of the believers, that go forth with ease: or the stars [that precede other stars]. (TA. [See more in the Expositions of Bd and others.]) ― -b3- [The pl.] subRaqN, applied to palm-trees, means (assumed tropical:) That produce their fruit early. (TA.)

saAbiqapN c
saAbiqapN [fem. of saAbiqN, q. v.: and also a subst. formed from the latter by the affix p, signifying Priority, or precedence]. One says, lahu saAbiqapN fiI hecaA AlOamori (tropical:) [To him belongs priority, or precedence, in this affair,] when he has preceded the [other] people [in betaking, or applying, himself] to the affair: (S, K, TA:) like as you say, lahu saboqN [mentioned above: see 1]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Also, as used by physicians, A predisposition to disease.]

saAbiqiyRapN c
saAbiqiyRapN [The state, or condition, of preceding]. (De Sacy's Anthol. Gramm. Ar. p. 302.)

Oasobaqu c
Oasobaqu [More, and most, preceding or prevenient; more, and most outgoing or outstripping; &c.]. Oasobaqu mina AlOajali and mina AlOafokaAri are provs. [meaning More prevenient than the period of death and than the thoughts]. (Meyd.)

musabRaqN c
musabRaqN A horse much, or often, outstripped. (Msb.)

masobuwqiyRapN c
masobuwqiyRapN [The state, or conditon, of being preceded]. (De Sacy's Anthol. Gramm. Ar. p. 302.)

1 sabaka c
1. sabaka, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
sabika
, (S, K,) so says El-Fárábee, and so in the Jm, and in the handwriting of Aboo-Sahl El-Harawee, (TA,) or
sabuka
, (Msb,) thus in the handwriting of Az, (TA,) inf. n. sabokN, (S, Mgh, Msb,) He melted, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, TA,) and cleared of its dross, (Mgh,) and poured forth (K, TA) into a mould, (TA,) gold, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) or silver, (S, Mgh, TA,) &c.; (S, TA;) and sbRk↓ signifies the same, (K,) inf. n. tasobiykN; (TA;) this inf. n. and sabokN both signifying the melting of gold and silver, and pouring it forth into a misobakap [or mould] of iron, like the half of a cane divided lengthwise. (Lth, TA.) ― -b2- Hence, sabokN is metaphorically used in the sense of tajoribapN. (Har pp. 140 and 211.) One says, fulaAnN sabakatohu AltRajaAribu (tropical:) [Such a one, tryings tried, or have tried, him]. (TA.) And kalaAmN laA yavobutu EalaI AlsRaboki is another tropical phrase [app. meaning (tropical:) Speech or language, that does not stand good, or is not sound, or valid, when tried, or tested; that will not stand trying, or testing]. (TA.)

2 sabRaka
2: see the preceding paragraph.

7 Ansbk c
7. Ansbk said of tibor [i. e. native, or unwrought, gold or silver or the like], It melted. (TA.)

sabiykN c
sabiykN, applied to tibor [i. e. native, or unwrought gold or silver or the like, Melted and cleared of its dross, and poured forth into a mould], i. q. masobuwkN↓. (TA.)

sabiykapN c
sabiykapN [a subst. formed from the epithet sabiykN by the affix p, An ingot, i. e.] a piece (Lth, Mgh, Msb, K) of gold, (Lth, Mgh, Msb, TA,) or of silver, (Lth, S, Mgh, TA,) &c., (Mgh,) [i. e.,] sometimes, of any metal, (Msb,) of an oblong form, (Mgh, Msb,) that has been melted, (Lth, S, Mgh, Msb, K, TA,) and cleared of its dross, (Mgh,) and poured forth (K, TA) into a mould, (TA,) [i. e.,] into a misobakap of iron like the half of a cane divided lengthwise: (Lth, TA:) pl. sabaAYiku. (Lth, S, Msb.) An Arab of the desert likened to it a difficult mountain that he desired to ascend, because of its smoothness; saying, OaIRu sabiykapK hecihi [What an ingot is this!]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- The pl. is also applied to wuqaAq [i. e. (assumed tropical:) Thin, flat, bread]; this being so called because it is made of choice, or pure, flour; and is as though it were prepared therefrom by being melted and poured into a mould (kaOanRahu subika minoha), and cleared from the bran. (TA.)

sabRaAkN c
[sabRaAkN A melter and purifier and caster, or one who makes sabaAYik, of gold, or silver, or the like. ― -b2- Hence,] huwa sabRaAkN lilokalaAmi a tropical phrase [app. meaning (tropical:) He is a trier, or tester, or a purifier, of speech, or language: see 1]. (TA.)

sunobukN c
sunobukN: see art. snbk.

misobakapN c
misobakapN A mould of iron like the half of a cane divided lengthwise, into which molten gold and silver (Lth, TA) and the like (TA) are poured: (Lth, TA:) pl. masaAbiku. (TA.)

masobuwkN c
masobuwkN: see sabiykN.

Q. 4 AisobakarRa c
Q. 4. AisobakarRa i. q. AisobaTarRa in its several significations: (K:) i. e. (TA) ― -b2- He stretched himself: (TA:) he lay upon his side, and stretched himself: (AA, S, TA:) [&c.] ― -b3- He (a youth, or young man,) became tall: (Lh:) and AsbkrRt She (a girl) became of erect and justly-proportioned stature. (S, K.) An ex. occurs in a verse of Imra-el-Keys, cited voce mijowalN. (S.) ― -b4- It (a plant) became tall and full-grown: (TA:) and it (anything) became extended, and long, or tall. (Lh.) ― -b5- He went at random, or heedlessly; without consideration, or certain aim. (Lh.) ― -b6- It (a river) flowed. (TA.) ― -b7- AsbkrRt Eayonuhu His eye shed tears. (Lh.) But ISd says that this is not known in classical Arabic. (TA.)

musobakirRN c
musobakirRN [act. part. n. of the verb above]. ― -b2- A youth, or young man, of just proportion, and full grown. (Aboo-Ziyád El-Kilábee, S, K.) ― -b3- Hair that hangs down; lank; not crisp: (S, K:) or of just length: or full-grown, and standing out. (TA.) ― -b4- And Anything extended, and long, or tall. (Lh.)

2 sbRlhu c
2. sbRlhu, inf. n. tasobiylN, means jaEalahu fiI sabiyli QllRehi [He assigned it, or the profit, or revenue, or usufruct, thereof, to be employed in the way, meaning cause, of God, or of religion; or in the doing of anything, or all, that God has commanded, or of the works whereby one pursues the way that leads to advancement in the favour of God; he dedicated it to pious, or charitable, uses or purposes]; (K, TA;) as though [meaning] he made it a trodden way [whereby to advance] to [the favour of] God. (TA.) You say, sbRl DayoEatahu, using the verb in this sense [i. e. He assigned the profit, or revenue, or usufruct, of his estate to be employed in the cause of God, or of religion]; (S;) to be given to the wayfarer, and the poor, and the warrior against unbelievers, and others. (TA voce sabiylN.) And sbRl AltRamarapa He assigned the profit to be employed in the ways of good works (Mgh, Msb) and the various kinds of pious deeds: (Msb:) or he made the profit to be allowable, or free, to those for whose benefit the property itself was made unalienable in perpetuity. (TA. [See an ex. in the first paragraph of art. Hbs, relating to some palm-trees which 'Omar desired to give in charity.]) ＝ -A2- sbRl, [either sabRala or, subRila both app. allowable, (see the part. ns., below,)] He (a man) was, or became, long in the sabalap [q. v.]; as though he had a long sabalap given to him. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 4.

4 Oasobalati AlTRariyqu c
4. Oasobalati AlTRariyqu The road had many passengers following, or succeeding, one another, or going repeatedly to and fro, upon it. (M, K.) ＝ -A2- Asbl UizaArahu, (S, M, K,) inf. n. UisobaAlN, (TA,) He let loose, let down, or lowered, his waist-wrapper; (S, M, K;) and so AlsRitora the veil, or curtain, (Msb,) or he let down, let fall, or made to hang down, the veil, or curtain: (Mgh:) the former act is forbidden in a trad. (TA.) And Asblt cayolahaA [She made her skirt to hang down; or to hang down low, so that she dragged it on the ground]; said of a woman. (M.) And Asbl vawobahu He dragged his garment [on the ground]; (O;) and sbRlhu↓ signifies the same, (O, TA,) inf. n. tasobiylN. (TA.) And Asbl canabahu He made his tail to hang down; he hung down his tail; said of a horse. (M.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Asbl AlmaMCa (assumed tropical:) He (a man) poured forth the water. (Msb.) And Asbl damoEahu (M, K, TA) (tropical:) He shed, or let fall, his tears. (K, TA.) ＝ -A3- The verb is also similarly used intransitively. (TA.) You say, of a part of the beard, Asbl EalaI AlSRadori [It fell, or hung down, upon the breast]. (Az, O, TA.) ― -b2- And Asbl AlmaTaru (tropical:) The rain let fall a shower, and became dense; as though it let down a curtain: (A, TA: [but accord. to this explanation, the verb is app. trans.; and the phrase, elliptical:]) or the rain fell continuously, or in consecutive showers, and in large drops: and in like manner, AldRamoEu the tears. (S, K,) ― -b3- And Asblt AlsRamaMCu (AZ, S, M, K) (assumed tropical:) The sky let fall its rain issuing from the clouds and not as yet having reached the earth: (AZ, S, TA:) or [simply] the sky rained. (K.) And Asblt OarowaAqu AlEayoni (tropical:) The sides of the eye shed tears. (O, K, * TA, all in art. rwq.) ― -b4- And Asbl Ealayohi (tropical:) He poured forth his speech against him abundantly, [or in torrents,] (A, K, * TA,) like as rain pours. (A. TA.) ＝ -A4- Asbl AlzRaroEu The seed-produce put forth its sunobul [or ears]; (S;) and so sanobala↓; (S, Mgh, Msb;) or put forth its sabal, (Msb in explanation of the former,) which is syn. with sunobul, (S, M, Msb, K,) or its sabuwlap: (K in explanation of the former:) [Mtr says,] tasanobala↓ I have not found. (Mgh.)

Q. Q. 1 sanobala c
Q. Q. 1. sanobala: see 4, last sentence: ＝ -A2- and art. snbl.

Q. Q. 2 tasanobala c
Q. Q. 2. tasanobala: see 4, last sentence.

sabalN c
sabalN A thing that one has let loose, let down, let fall, or made to hang down, and to drag [on the ground]; like as naXarN signifies “ a thing that one has spread ” &c.: whence the trad., mano jarRa sabalahu mina AlxuyalaMCi laA yanoZuru QllRehu yawoma Alqiyemapi [He who drags what he has made to hang down of his garment from pride, or self-conceit, God will not look towards him on the day of resurrection]: (O:) or sabalN means garments made to hang down [so as to drag]; and is pl. of sabalapN↓; [or rather a coll. gen. n. of which sabalapN is the n. un.;] whence jarRa sabalatahu, (TA,) which means [He dragged his garment; though said to mean,] his garments. (K, TA.) ― -b2- Also (tropical:) Rain: (S, M, K:) or rain issuing from the clouds and not as yet having reached the earth: (AZ, S, TA:) or flowing rain: and likewise flowing blood. (Ham p. 359.) ― -b3- [Hence, app., as indicating swiftness,] sabalu is the name of (assumed tropical:) A certain mare, (S, K,) an excellent mare, said by As to have been the mother of OaEowaju, and to have belonged to [the tribe of] Ghanee. (S, TA.) ― -b4- And sabalN [or sabalu as a fem. proper name] is a name for (assumed tropical:) A ewe, or she-goat: and such is called to be milked by saying sabalo sabalo. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also i. q. sunobulN↓, (S, M, Msb, K,) which signifies The ears of corn: (MA: [and in like manner both are expl. in the KL, but as singulars, app. because used as gen. ns.:]) n. un. of the former with p↓, and so of ↓the latter: and the pl. of sunobulN↓, which is of the measure funoEulN, is sanaAbilu: (Msb:) or this is pl. of sunobulapN, (S,) as also sunobulaAtN: (Kur xii. 43 and 46:) or sunobulapN [in the CK (erroneously) subolap] signifies an ear of corn [so I render zaroEapN (in the CK zuroEap)] that is bending, or inclining, as also sabuwlapN↓ [mentioned in one of my two copies of the S as syn. with sunobulapN but not in the other copy] and subuwlapN↓ (M, K) and sabalapN↓; (K;) or, accord. to Lth, sabuwlapN↓ signifies an ear (sunobulap) of millet (curap), and of rice, and the like, when bending, or inclining: (O, TA:) and some say that sabalN signifies spreading, or expanding, awn of the sunobul [or ears of corn]; (M, TA;) or the extremities thereof; (TA;) and the pl. is subuwlN; (M;) or sbwl is syn. with sunobulN, in the dial. of bnw hmyAn [?]. (TA.) AlsRunobulapu↓ is also the name of A certain sign of the Zodiac [i. e. Virgo]: (S in the present art., and K in art. snbl:) [or Spica Virginis;] a star in Virgo; thus called by astrologers; also called AlsRimaAku AlOaEozalu. (Kzw. [See art. smk.]) AlTRiybi sunobulu↓ is A well-known plant, [spikenard, which is called in the present day AlsRunobulu AlhinodiIRu,] brought from India. (O. [See also art. snbl.]) ― -b2- Also sing. of OasobaAlN, which signifies (assumed tropical:) The uppermost parts of a bucket, (O,) or the lips thereof: (S:) or sabalapN↓ is the sing. of OasobaAlN in these senses; and signifies (tropical:) the head of a vessel [like as it signifies the “ ear, ” which is the “ head, ” of a culm of wheat &c.]. (TA.) You say, malaOahaA UilaI OasobaAlihaA (tropical:) He filled it (i. e. the winecup, AlkaOosa, M, TA, or the bucket, AldRalowa, O) to its edges, (M, K, TA,) and to its lips. (K.) And a poet says, (S,) namely Bá'ith Ibn- Sureym El-Yeshkuree, (TA,)
Uico OarosaluwniI maAtiHFA bidilaAYihimo
famalaOotuhuA EalaqFA UilaI OasobaAlihaA
[When they sent me drawing with their buckets, and I filled them with blood to their brims]: he says, they sent me seeking to execute their blood-revenges, and I slew many: AlEalaq meaning
“ blood. ” (S, TA. [See also Ham p. 268, where some different readings are mentioned; and it is said that the AsbAl may mean the knots that are connected with the cross-pieces of wood of the bucket.]) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) A number of spears, few or many. (K. [Perhaps because their heads are likened to the heads of corn.]) ＝ -A3- Also The nose: (K:) pl. sibaAlN: so in the Moheet. (TA.) One says, Oarogama QllRehu sabalahu [May God make his nose to cleave to the earth, or dust: or (assumed tropical:) abase, or humble, him]. (TA.) ＝ -A4- And Garments made of the hards, or hurds, of flax of the coarsest of qualities: and so sabalapN↓ [if one of these words be not a mistranscription for the other]. (TA.) ＝ -A5- And A certain disease in the eye, [thus riyHu AlsRabali is expl. in the M,] resembling a film, as though it were the web of a spider, with red veins: (S:) or a film of the eye, from the swelling, or inflation, of its external veins upon the surface of the mulotaHimap, (K,) which is one of the layers of the eye, (TA,) [namely, the tunica albuginea, or white of the eye, so called in the present day,] and the appearance of a web, or thing woven, between the two, [i. e. between those veins and the white tunic,] like smoke: (K:) or a film covering the eye; as though from UisobaAlo meaning the “ letting down ” of a veil, or curtain. (Mgh.) ＝ -A6- Also A reviling, or vilifying. (K.) One says, bayoniI wa bayonahu sabalN Between me and him is a reviling, or vilifying: so in the Moheet. (TA.)

sabilN c
sabilN [is app. a possessive epithet, meaning Having length and flaccidity]. xuSoyapN sabilapN means [A scrotum] that is long (M, K, TA) and flaccid. (TA.)

subolapN c
subolapN (assumed tropical:) A rain of wide extent. (IAar, O, K.)

sabalapN c
sabalapN: see sabalN, in five places. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) The XaArib [or mustache]: (S:) or the daAYirap [or small protuberance termed Hivorimap, q. v.,] in the middle of the upper lip: or the hair that is upon [app. meaning of] the XaArib; (M, K;) whence the saying, TaAlato sabalatuka faquSRahaA [thy hair of the mustache has become long, therefore clip it]; and it is tropical: (TA:) or the extremity of that hair: (M, K:) or the two mustaches together: (M, K: *) or what is upon the chin, to the extremity of the beard: or the fore part of the beard: (M, K:) or what hangs down, of, or from, the fore part of the beard: (Zj, in his “ Khalk el-Insán: ”) or, accord. to Az, it signifies, with the Arabs, the fore part of the beard, and what hangs down thereof, or therefrom, upon the breast: or, accord. to IDrd, some of them apply it to the extremity of the beard; and some, to the hair of the mustache that hangs down on the beard: in a trad., in which it is said that he [Mohammad] was full in the sabalap, Az says that it means the hairs beneath the lower jaw: accord. to AZ, it is what appears, of the fore part of the beard, after [or exclusive of] the hair of the side of each cheek and the Euvonuwn [here app. meaning the portion of the beard next the front of the throat], and what is concealed [thereof]: (TA:) or, accord. to Th, the beard altogether: (M:) the pl. is sibaAlN, (S, K,) [to which p is sometimes added, agreeably with a common license, as appears from an ex. in what follows,] and sabalaAtN, occurring in the saying, UinRahu lacuw sabalaAtK, mentioned by Lh, in which the term sabalap is made to apply to every separate portion [so that the meaning is, Verily he has a sabalap]. (M.) One says, of enemies, humo Suhobu AlsRibaAli (assumed tropical:) [They are red, or reddish, in respect of the mustaches, &c.: see art. Shb]. (TA.) And of a man who has come threatening, one says, jaMCa fulaAnN wa qado naXara sabalatahu (tropical:) [Such a one came having spread out his mustache, &c.]. (K, * TA.) And in a trad. respecting Dhu-th-Thudeiyeh, [see art. vdI,] it is said, Ealayohi XuEayoraAtN mivolu sibaAlapi AlsRinRawori [app. meaning (assumed tropical:) Having upon him small hairs like the whiskers of the cat]. TA.) ― -b3- sabalapu AlbaEiyri means (assumed tropical:) The part of the camel, in which he is stabbed, or stuck, in the uppermost part of the breast; (T, M;) called also the tariybap: (T:) or the fur that flows down upon that part of the camel. (M, K. [In the CK, manoxarih is erroneously put for manoHarihi.]) You say lataba fiI sabalapi AlnRaAqapi, meaning (assumed tropical:) He stabbed, or stuck, the she-camel in the part above mentioned: (M in art. ltb: [in the K, in the present art., kataba is erroneously put, in this phrase, in the place of lataba:]) Az heard an Arab of the desert say latama fiI sabalapi baEiyrihi, [which means the same as lataba,] and he supposes the sabalap to be hairs in the part above mentioned. (TA.) You say also, baEiyrN Hasanu AlsRabalapi, meaning (assumed tropical:) [A camel goodly in respect of] the thinness of his skin (jilodihi): so in the O and K: but accord. to the T, of his cheek (xadRihi); and this is probably the right explanation. (TA.)

sabalaAniIRN c
sabalaAniIRN: see Oasobalu.

sabiylN c
sabiylN A way, road, or path; (S, M, Msb, K;) and what is open, or conspicuous, thereof; (M, K;) and Er-Rághib adds, wherein is easiness: (TA:) and sabiylapN↓ signifies the same: (Ibn- 'Abbád, K:) the former is masc. and fem.; (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) like zuqaAqN; (Msb;) made fem. by the people of El-Hijáz, and masc. by Temeem; (Akh, S voce zuqaAqN;) but mostly fem.; (IAth, TA;) in the Kur it is made masc. in vii. 143, and fem. in xii. 108: (S, M, TA:) pl. subulN, (M, K,) or, accord. to ISk, it has this pl. when masc., and subuwlN, like EunuwqN when fem., (Msb, [but this distinction and the latter pl. are both strange,]) and it has also as a pl. [of pauc.] OasobilapN. (TA.) In the saying, wa EalaI QllRehi qaSodu AlsRabiyli [And upon God it rests to show the right way (see art. qSd)], (M, K,) in the Kur [xvi. 9], (M,) it is used as a gen. n., because it is added, wa minohaA jaAYirN. (M, K.) ― -b2- Aibonu AlsRabiyli means (assumed tropical:) The son of the road; (M, K;) he whom the road has brought, or [as it were] brought forth; (IB;) the wayfarer, or traveller: (Mgh, Msb:) or he who travels much or often: (TA:) or the traveller who is far from his place of abode: (Er-Rághib:) as used in the verse of the Kur, (M, Mgh, Msb,) ix, 60, (M,) it means the person to whom the way has become cut short [so that he is unable to continue his journey]; (M, K;) to which has been added, who desires to return to his country, or town, and finds not what will suffice him: (TA:) or the traveller who is cut off from his property: (Mgh, Msb:) or the person who desires to go to a country, or town, other than his own, for a necessary affair: or, accord. to Ibn-'Arafeh, the guest who has become disabled from proceeding in his journey, his means having failed him: to such should be given as much as will suffice him to his home. (TA.) ― -b3- taqoTaEuwna AlsRabiyla, in the Kur [xxix. 28], means (assumed tropical:) [And ye cut off] the way of offspring [by your unnatural practices]: or and ye oppose yourselves to men in the roads [or road] for the purpose of that which is excessively, or enormously, foul or abominable. (TA.) ― -b4- [sabiylu QllRehi means (assumed tropical:) The way, or cause, of God, or of religion; or the way whereby one seeks approach to God, or advancement in his favour.] It is said in the Kur [ii. 191], wa OanofiquwA fiI sabiyli QllRehi, meaning (assumed tropical:) And expend ye in warring against unbelievers and the like, and in every good work commanded by God; (M, K;) such being of the ways [that lead] to God: (M:) mostly used in relation to warring against unbelievers and the like. (M, K.) And in the same, iii. 163, QlRaciyna qutiluwA fiI sabiyli QllRehi, meaning [Who have been slain in the cause of God, or of his religion, i. e.,] for the sake of the religion of God. (Jel.) And you say, jaEala DayoEatahu fiI sabiyli QllRehi (assumed tropical:) [He made his estate to have its profit, or revenue, or usufruct, employed in the cause of God, or of religion]. (S.) ― -b5- sabiylN also signifies (assumed tropical:) A means of access; a connexion, or a tie: so in the saying, in the Kur [xxv. 29], yaA layotaniI QtRaxacotu maEa QlrRasuwli sabiylFA (assumed tropical:) [O would that I had obtained, with the Apostle, a means of access to Paradise]: (S, Msb, TA:) thus it has been explained: (TA:) or the meaning is, [O would that I had taken, with the Apostle,] a way to safety: or one way, the way of truth. (Bd.) ― -b6- [Also, in the present day, applied to A public drinking-fountain.]

sabuwlapN c
sabuwlapN and subuwlapN: see sabalN, in three places.

sabiylapN c
sabiylapN: see sabiylN, first sentence.

saAbilN c
saAbilN Travelling upon a road: pl. sawaAbilu and [coll. gen. n.] saAbilapN↓; (TA:) this last signifies travellers, (S, M, *) or a company of people, (Mgh, K,) following, or succeeding, one another, or going repeatedly to and fro, (S, M, Mgh, K,) upon the roads, (S, Mgh,) or upon the road, (M, K,) for the accomplishment of their wants: it is made fem. as denoting a jamaAEap. (Mgh.) ― -b2- Also, saAbilapN↓, (TA in art. Xgr,) or sabiylN saAbilapN, (M, K, * TA,) A travelled road; (M, K, TA;) a beaten road. (TA in art. Xgr.) ＝ -A2- gayovN saAbilN (assumed tropical:) Rain falling continuously, or in successive showers, and in large drops, and copiously. (TA.)

saAbilapN c
saAbilapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

sunobulN c
sunobulN and sunobulapN: see sabalN, in five places: and see also art. snbl.

salosabiylu c
salosabiylu the name of A certain fountain in Paradise: determinate; [without tenween;] but occurring at the end of a verse of the Kur [lxxvi. 18], (Akh, S, K,) and being with fet-h, (Akh, S,) A is added to it, (Akh, S, K,) for the sake of conformity [with the endings of other verses before and after it]. (K.) See also art. slsbl.

Oasobalu c
Oasobalu (tropical:) A man long in the sabalap [q. v., here said in the TA to mean the beard, but this is questionable], as also sabalaAniIRN↓ and musobilN↓ and musobalN↓ and musabRilN↓ and musabRalN↓. (M, K, TA.) ― -b2- And the fem., sabolaMCu, (assumed tropical:) A woman having hair in the place of the mustache. (TA.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) An eye having long lashes. (M, K.)

musobalN c
musobalN: see the next preceding paragraph.

musobilN c
musobilN A man lengthening his garment, and making it to hang down to the ground. (IAar, TA.) [And in like manner,] applied to a woman, [though without p,] Who has made her skirt to hang down [app. to the ground]. (M.) ― -b2- See also Oasobalu. ― -b3- And Almusobilu signifies (tropical:) The penis: (M, K, TA:) because of its pendulousness. (TA.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) The [lizard called] DabR. (K.) ― -b5- And the fifth of the arrows used in the game called Almayosir: (M, K:) or the sixth of those arrows, (Lh, S, M, K,) also called AlmuSofaHu, (S,) in which are six notches, and to which are assigned six shares [of the slaughtered camel] if it win, and six fines if it do not win: (M:) pl. AlmasaAbilu. (TA.) ― -b6- And musobilN is one of the names of Dhul-Hijjeh; (M, K; *) of the time of 'Ád. (M.)

musabRalN c
musabRalN: see Oasobalu. ― -b2- Also An ugly old man: (K:) app. because of the length of his beard. (TA.)

musabRilN c
musabRilN: see Oasobalu.

1 sabaI AlEaduwRa c
1. sabaI AlEaduwRa, (S, M, Msb, K,) wa gayorahu, (M,) aor. yasobiI, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. saboIN (S, M, Msb, K) and sibaMCN, (S, M, K,) or ↓the latter is a simple subst., as also sibFA↓ or sibFI, (Msb,) He made captive, captived, or took prisoner, [the enemy, and other than an enemy;] (S, K;) as also AisotabaAhu↓. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] tasobiI qaloba AlrRajuli (assumed tropical:) [She captivates the heart of the man], said of a woman. (S.) ― -b3- And sabayotu qalobahu and Aisotabayotuhu↓ (assumed tropical:) I captivated his heart. (M.) And qaloba Aisotabato↓ AlfataI, said of a girl, or young woman, i. q. sabatohu [i. e. (assumed tropical:) She captivated the heart of the youth, or young man.] (TA.) ― -b4- One says also, UinRa AllRayola TawiylN wa laA Ousoba lahu and lA OusobaI lh, the latter on the authority of Lh, who says that it means a prayer, (M, TA,) for which reason the verb [in the former instance] is in the mejzoom form, (TA,) i. e. [Verily the night is long, and] may I not be made as the captive [to it]. (M, TA.) ― -b5- sabaI Alxamora, (S, M, K,) aor. as above, (M,) inf. n. saboIN and sibaMCN, (T, M, K,) though J says only the latter, (K,) He conveyed wine from one town, or country, to another; (S, K;) or he brought wine from one land to another; as also AisotabaAhaA↓: (M:) [and] so sabaOahaA, with hemz: (Msb:) or sabaOotu, with hemz, means “ I bought ” (S, M) wine, to drink it. (S. [See art. sbO.]) ― -b6- sabaAhu QllRehu, (ISk, S, M, K,) aor. as above, (S,) inf. n. saboIN, (S, M,) God estranged him; (ISk, S, M, K;) removed him far away; (S, K;) and cursed him: (M:) or it is like the saying laEanahu QllRehu: (S:) [or may God estrange him; &c.:] one says, maA lahu sabaAhu QllRehu [What ails him? May God estrange him; &c.]. (TA.) ― -b7- sabaI AlmaMCa, (M, K,) aor. as above, (M,) inf. n. saboIN, (TA,) He dug until he reached the water. (M, K.)

5 tsbRI lahu c
5. tsbRI lahu (assumed tropical:) He manifested, or showed, love, or affection, to him; and became inclined to him. (TA.)

6 tsAbwA c
6. tsAbwA They made one another captive. (Az, K.)

8 UisotabaIa
8: see 1, in four places.

saboIN c
saboIN i. q. masobiIRN↓ [i. e. Made captive]; (M;) or AlsRaboIu signifies maA yusobaI [i.e. what is made captive; but I rather think that the right explanation is mano yusobaI i. e the person who is made captive; agreeably with what follows]: pl. subiIRN: (M, K:) one says qawomN saboIN [a company, or party, of men made captive]; the latter word in this case being an inf. n. used as an epithet; [therefore, as such, it is applicable to a single person, male or female, as well as to a pl. number;] and accord. to As, one says not otherwise than thus in speaking of a company, or party, of men: (Msb, TA:) [but] sabiIRN↓ is [also] applied to a single person, to the male and the female, (M, K,) i. e. to the latter, as to the former, without p, (M,) as meaning made captive: (K:) or sabiIRN is applied to a boy, or young man, or male slave, as also masobiIRN↓; and sabiyRapN to a girl, or young woman, or female slave, as also masobiyRapN↓; (Msb;) or to a woman, in this sense: (S:) and the pl. of sabiIRN↓, (M, K,) or of sabiyRapN, (Msb,) is sabaAyaA, (M, Msb, K,) applied to women. (M.) ― -b2- Also Women, (IAar, M, K,) universally; (IAar, M;) because they captivate the hearts; or because they are made captive, and possessed as property. (M, K.)

sabFA c
sabFA: see sabiIRN. ＝ -A2- Also A tribe of El-Yemen; regarded as a HaIR, perfectly decl.; and regarded as a qabiylap, [and therefore a fem. proper name,] imperfectly decl. [and written sabaA]: (M, TA:) or, as is said in the Msb, it is the name of a town, or province, in El-Yemen; masc., and therefore perfectly decl.; and fem., and therefore imperfectly decl.; called by the name of its builder: (TA:) [hence,] one says, cahabuwA OayodiI sabaA and OayaAdiI sabaA, [making the last word to be without tenween either as a fem. proper name or because of pausing after it,] i. e. They went away scattered, or dispersed: (S, M, K:) J says, (TA,) they are two nouns made one, like maEodiI kariba, perfectly decl. because not occurring otherwise than as a denotative of state, [and therefore indeterminate,] whether you make the former to be a prefixed noun governing the latter in the gen. case, or do not so. (S, TA. [See also art. sbO.]) ＝ -A3- In a verse of 'Alkameh Ibn-'Abadeh, the phrase bisabaA AlkatRaAni is used for bisabaAYibi AlkatRaAni. (M in art. sb: see sibRN.)

sibFA c
sibFA or sibFI: see 1, first sentence.

sabaMCN c
sabaMCN: see sabiIRN.

sibaMCN c
sibaMCN: see 1, first sentence.

sabiIRN c
sabiIRN: see saboIN, in two places. ― -b2- Also, (K,) or EuwdN sabiIRN, (M,) A branch, or piece of stick or wood, brought by a torrent from one tract, or region, to another, (M, K,) or from a distant place; (M;) and sabaMCN↓ and sabFA↓ signify the same. (K.) ― -b3- sabiIRu AlHayRapi The slough of the serpent; (M, * K;) as also sabiyWuhaA. (K in art. sbO. [Accord. to different copies of the K in the present art., saboCN or siboCN or saboIN, all of which are wrong.]) ― -b4- sabiyRapN [or durRapN sabiyRapN] A pearl, or large pearl, brought out by the diver (K, TA,) from the sea. (TA.) ― -b5- Also, [or xamorN sabiyRapN,] Wine brought from one town, or country, to another: (S, M, K:) if bought to be drunk, it is termed sabiyoYapN, with C: (S, M:) or, perhaps, the former may be an instance of the alleviation of C. (M. [See also sabiyoYapN in art. sbO.])

saAbiyaMCu c
saAbiyaMCu The maXiymap [or membrane enclosing the fœtus in the womb], which come forth with the young: (S, K:) or a thin pellicle over the nose of the fœtus, which dies if it be not removed from it at the birth: (K:) or the water that comes forth upon the head of the fœtus, (T, M,) [i. e.] at the birth: (T:) pl. sawaAbiI [or sawaAbK]. (S.) ― -b2- Hence, as being likened thereto, because of its fineness, (M,) (assumed tropical:) The dust of the burrows, or holes, of the jerboa; (K;) or fine dust which the jerboa extracts from its burrow, or hole: said by Abu-l-'Abbás to be [one] of the burrows, or holes, of the jerboa; but this saying of his has been rebutted. (M.) ― -b3- Hence also, (M,) (tropical:) Increase or offspring [of camels or the like]; (S, M, K, TA;) called by the name of that from which they come: (M, TA:) or (so accord. to the M, but accord. to the K “ and ”) camels for breeding: and numerous cattle: (M, K:) or also sheep, or goats, having numerous offspring: (T, S, K:) and it is also applied to denote a large number [app. of animals &c.]. (TA.) One says, liMli fulaAnK saAbiyaMCu, meaning (tropical:) [To such a one belong] numerous cattle. (TA.)

UisobaMCapN c
UisobaMCapN A streak of blood; (AO, S, M, K;) as also OusobiyRapN↓: (M, TA:) pl. OasaAbiIRu. (AO, S, M, K.) ― -b2- And An extended thread or string of [goats'] hair. (TA.) ― -b3- And [the pl.] OasaAbiIRu signifies The conspicuous tracks of a road. (TA.)

OusobiyRapN c
OusobiyRapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

masobiIRN c
masobiIRN; and its fem., with p: see saboIN, in three places.

1 satRahu c
1. satRahu, [aor.
satuta
, accord to rule, and inf. n. app. satRN, q. v.,] He attributed or imputed to him, or charged him with, or accused him of, a fault, or defect, or the like; as also sadRahu; syn. EaAbahu. (TA. [The sense in which EAbh is there used is indicated by the context.])

satN c
satN a dial. var. of AisotN: see the latter word in art. sth, in two places.

satRN c
satRN Foul, or evil, speech or language. (IAar, K.) ― -b2- And also, [like sadRN,] A fault, or defect, or the like; syn. EayobN. (K.)

sitRN c
sitRN: see sitRapN, of which it is the fem. ― -b2- sitRiI said to a woman means, (K, TA,) accord. to the explanation of IAmb, (TA,) yaA sitRa jihaAtiI [O thou who occupiest the six places in relation to me; or, who art above me, below me, before me, behind me, on my right, and on my left]: (K, TA:) as though alluding to her holding the speaker in her possession: (TA:) or it is an incorrect expression; (K;) or it is vulgar, and held in low estimation; (IAar, TA;) and is correctly sayRidatiI [my lady, or my mistress]: (K:) it may be regarded as a contraction of sayRidatiI, accord. to Esh-Shiháb El-Kásimee: (TA:) and Es-seyyid 'Eesà Es-Safawee says that it should not be restricted to the class of expression used as vocatives. (MF, TA.)

sitRapN c
sitRapN (Lth, T, S, M) and sitRa↓, (Lth, T, S, M, K,) the former masc. and the latter fem., (S,) [signifying Six,] are originally sidosapN (Lth, T, M) and sidosN; (Lth, T, S, M, K;) the latter s is changed into t, and the d is incorporated into it; (Lth, T, S, M, K;) for the dim, of sitRapN is sudayosapN [and that of sitRN is sudayosN], and the pl. is OasodaAsN. (Lth, T, S.) You say, EinodiI sitRapu rijaAlK wa nisowapK [I have with me, or at my abode, six men and women], i. e., three men and three women: and you may say, EinodiI sitRapu rijaAlK wa nisowapN, meaning, six men, and also women: and in like manner you do in the ease of any number that can be divided so as to apply to two plurals, as six and seven and the higher numbers: but in the case of a number that cannot be divided so as to apply to two plurals, as five and four and three, you put the latter noun in the nom. case only, saying, for ex., EinodiI xamosapu rijaAlK wa nisowapN. (ISk, S.) [Respecting a peculiar pronunciation of the people of El-Hijáz, and a case in which sitRap is imperfectly decl., see valaAvapN and tisoEapF.] ― -b2- sitRapa EaXara [indecl. in every case, meaning Sixteen,] is pronounced by some of the Arabs sitRapa EoXara: and [the fem.] sitRa EaXorapa, thus in the dial. of El-Hijáz [and of most of the Arabs], is pronounced sitRa EaXirapa in the dial of Nejd. (S in art. EXr.) ― -b3- sitRumiAYapK [meaning Six hundred] should be written thus, without separating the two words; because sitRN is originally sidosN and the union of the two words is to compensate for the incorporation of the d into the t. (El-Hareeree, in De Sacy's Anthol. Gramm. Ar., p. 72 of the Arabic text.)

sitRuwna c
sitRuwna [Sixty,] one of the tenfold numbers, (M, TA,) namely, that between xamosuwna and saboEuwna, (TA,) is derived from sitRN. (M, TA.) ― -b2- [Also Sixtieth.]

saAtRN c
saAtRN [Sixth]. You say, jaMCa fulaAnN saAdisFA and saAdiyFA and saAtRFA [Such a one came sixth]; sAdsA being formed from sidosN; and sAtRA, from sitRapN and sitRN: in sAdyA, the [latter] s [of sAdsA] is changed into I; for certain letters in other cases are sometimes so changed; as in OamRaA and OayomaA and tasanRana and tasanRaI, and taqaDRaDa and taqaDRaI, and talaERaEa and talaERaI, and tasarRara and tasarRaI. (ISk, S.)

AisotN OsA OsI Ost Ast Qst MsI Mst
AisotN: see arts. Ast and sth: it is properly mentioned in the latter art., being originally satahN. (S, TA.)

1 satara c
1. satara, aor.
satura
(S, M) and
satira
, (M,) inf. n. satorN (S, M) and satarN, (M,) He, or it, veiled, concealed, or hid, a thing; (M;) covered it: (S:) and stRr↓ signifies the same, (M,) [or has an intensive sense, or denotes frequency or repetition of the action, or its application to many objects: accord. to Golius, “ sub velo, obtenso eo [sic], ne quis vir intueretur eam, custodivit puellam: et clam asservavit habuitque eam: ” as on the authority of the KL: in which I find nothing of the kind but tasotiyrN expl. by the words dr Prdh dAXtn (to have or hold, within a curtain.] ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) He protected another. (The Lexicons passim.) ＝ -A2- saturato, inf. n. sataArapN, (tropical:) She (a woman) was, or became, satiyrap, (A,) i. e., modest, or bashful. (M.) ― -b2- And satura, inf. n. sitorN, (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, intelligent. (M.)

2 satRara
2: see the preceding paragraph.

3 saAtarahu AlEadaAwapa c
3. saAtarahu AlEadaAwapa, inf. n. musaAtarapN, (tropical:) [He concealed enmity with him]. (A.) [See also the act. part. n., below.]

5 tasatRara
5: and 7: see the next paragraph.

8 Asttr c
8. Asttr and tstRr↓ (S, M, K) and Anstr↓ (IAar, M) It became veiled, concealed, or hidden; or it veiled, concealed, or hid, itself: (M:) it became covered; or it covered itself. (S, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] fulaAnN laA yasotatiru mina QllRehi bisitorK (tropical:) [Such a one does not protect himself from the displeasure of God by piety; i. e.,] such a one does not fear God. (A, TA.)

sitorN c
sitorN and sutorapN↓ [which latter see also below] and sitaArapN↓ (S, M, K) and sitaArN↓ (K) and satarapN↓ and UisotaArN↓ (TA) and UisotaArapN↓, (M, K,) which last is only known to occur in one instance, in a trad., (M, TA,) and misotarN↓, (M, K,) Anything by which a person or thing is veiled, concealed, hidden, or covered; a veil; a curtain; a screen; a cover; a covering; a covert; (S, M, K:) [and the first and second, anything by which one is protected, or sheltered:] the pl. of sitorN is sutuwrN and OasotaArN (S, M, K) [the latter a pl. of pauc.] and suturN; (M, TA;) which last is also pl. of sitaArN↓, (K,) like as kutubN is of kitaAbN; (TA;) and the pl. of sitaArapN↓ is sataAYiru. (S, K.) ↓ [Hence the phrase] hataka QllRehu sitorahu [lit., God rent open, or may God rend open, his veil, or covering; meaning,] (tropical:) God manifested, or made known, or may God manifest, or make known, his vices, or faults: (A:) [or God disgraced, or dishonoured, him, or exposed him to disgrace, or dishonour, or may God disgrace or dishonour him &c.] And madRa AllRayolu OasotaArahu (tropical:) [Night spread its curtains]. (A.) And AllRayoli OamudRu UilaI QllRehi yadaIRa taHota sitaAri↓ (tropical:) [I stretch forth my hands in supplication to God beneath the veil of night]. (A.) ― -b2- sitorN also signifies (tropical:) Fear. (K.) [Because by it one protects himself from the displeasure of God. See 8.] And (tropical:) Modesty, or bashfulness. (K.) One says, maA lifulaAnK sitorN wa laA HijorN (tropical:) Such a one has not modesty nor intelligence. (TA.) ― -b3- And Intelligence; syn. EaqolN. (M.) In the K it is explained by EamalN; but this appears to be a mistranscription, for EaqolN. (TA.)

satarN c
satarN A shield. (M, K.)

sutorapN c
sutorapN: see sitorN. ― -b2- Its predominant application is to A thing which a person praying sets up before him; [sticking it in the ground, or laying it down if the ground be hard, in order that no living being or image may be the object next before him;] such as a whip, and a staff having a pointed iron at its lower extremity. (Mgh.) [See EanazapN: and see my “ Modern Egyptians, ” 5th ed., p. 72.] ― -b3- Also A parapet, or surrounding wall, of a flat house-top. (Mgh.) ― -b4- And i. q. ZulRapN [q. v.]. (Mgh.)

satarapN c
satarapN: see sitorN.

sitarapN c
sitarapN: see satiyrN, in two places.

sitaArN c
sitaArN: see sitorN, in three places.

satiyrN c
satiyrN (S, M, K) and masotuwrN↓, (S, A, K,) applied to a man, (S, A, &c.,) and satiyrapN (S, M, A, K) and satiyrN and satirapN↓, (M,) applied to a girl (S) or female, (M, &c.,) [properly Veiled, concealed, or covered. ― -b2- And hence,] (tropical:) Modest; bashful; (M;) chaste: (S, K:) pl. of satiyrN, as masc., sutaraMCu; (M;) and of masotuwrN↓, [masotuwruwna and] masaAtiyru; (A;) and, app. of satiyrN [as fem.] and satiyrapN also, sataAYiru; and the pl. of satirapN↓ is satiraAtN only, accord. to a rule laid down by Sb. (M.) ― -b3- XajarN satiyrN (tropical:) Trees having many boughs or branches. (A.) ＝ -A2- satiyrN applied to God is of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure faAEilN, meaning (assumed tropical:) Veiling, or protecting; a veiler, or protector. (TA.)

sitaArapN c
sitaArapN: see sitorN, in two places. ― -b2- Also The piece of skin that is upon the nail. (K.)

satRaArN c
satRaArN One who veils, or conceals, [much, or often; or who does so] well. (KL.) [Hence,] AallRehu satRaAru AlEuyuwbi (tropical:) God is He who is wont to veil
vices, or faults]. (A.) ― -b2- And The keeper of the curtain [that hangs over, and closes, the door of a chamber]. (MA.)

UisotaArN c
UisotaArN: see sitorN. ＝ -A2- Also Four: (S, M, A, K:) said by Aboo-Sa'eed and Az to be arabicized, from the Pers. JahaAro: pl. OasaAtiyru and OasaAtiru. (TA.) It is applied to men: (S, M:) and you also say, Oakalotu UisotaArFA mina Alxabozi meaning I have eaten four cakes of bread. (TA.) ― -b2- And The fourth of a party of people. (TA.) ― -b3- And The weight of four mithkáls (mavaAqiyl) and a half: (S, K: [see riTolN:]) likewise arabicized: (Az:) [app. from the Greek σατὴρ:] pl. OasaAtiyru. (S.)

UisotaArapN c
UisotaArapN: see sitorN.

misotarN c
misotarN: see sitorN.

masotuwrN c
masotuwrN: see satiyrN, in two places. ― -b2- HijaAbFA masotuwrFA, in the Kur xvii. 47, means A veil covered by another veil; implying the thickness of the veil: (S:) or mstwrA is here of the measure mafoEuwlN in the sense of the measure faAEilN, like maOotiyRFA in the Kur xix. 62, (S, M,) which some say is the only other instance of the kind; (TA;) and Th explains it as signifying preventing, or hindering, or obstructing; and says that it is of the measure mafoEuwlo because the veil itself is hidden from man. (M.)

jaAriyapN musatRarapN c
jaAriyapN musatRarapN A girl kept behind, or within, the curtain. (S.)

huwa mudaAjK musaAtirN c
huwa mudaAjK musaAtirN (tropical:) [He is a wheedler, or cajoler, who conceals enmity]. (A.)

satRuwqN c
satRuwqN (S, Mgh, K) and sutRuwqN, (S, K,) [said to be] the only instances of the kind except sbRwH and qdRws and crRwH, all of which are with damm and with fet-h, (S,) [but see subRuwHN,] as also tusotuwqN↓, (K,) this last mentioned by Lh on the authority of a desert-Arab of Kelb, (TA,) applied to a dirhem, Such as is termed zayofN (S, K) and nabahorajN (S) or bahorajN (K) [i. e. bad, &c.]; worthless; (TA;) coated with silver: (K:) accord. to ElKarkhee, such as consists for the most part of brass or of copper: and it is said in the “ Risáleh Yoosufeeyeh ” that the satRuwqap↓ it is unlawful to take, as being fuluws [which means certain small coins of copper; whence it seems that stRwqp has a pl. meaning, though otherwise it would seem to be a sing. subst.]: it is said to be arabicized, from siho tuw, (Mgh, TA,) which is Pers., meaning “ three fold; ” as is [thought to be] indicated by its being said to be coated with silver. (TA.)

satRuwqapN c
satRuwqapN: see the preceding paragraph.

tusotuwqN c
tusotuwqN: see the preceding paragraph.

musotaqapN c
musotaqapN (S, O, K) and musotuqapN, (O, K,) the latter allowed by Ibn-'Abbád, (O,) A fur-garment, (farowap, K,) or one of what are termed firaMC, (S, O,) with long sleeves: (S, O, K:) accord. to A'Obeyd, (S, O,) arabicized, from the Pers. muXotaho: [or app., in the sense above expl., from the Pers. muXotiI; and in the sense following, from the former Pers. word:] pl. masaAtiqu. (S, O.) ― -b2- Also An instrument with which the Sanoj [q. v.] and the like are beaten. (K.)

1 satahahu c
1. satahahu, (S, K,) aor.
sataha
, (K,) inf. n. satohN, (S,) He struck his Aisot; (S, K;) i. e. a man's. (S. [See Aisot below.]) ― -b2- And, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He followed him from behind, (K, TA,) not quitting him; because following his Aisot. (TA.)

4 Ousotiha c
4. Ousotiha He (a man) was, or became, large in the buttocks. (TA.)

satohN c
satohN and sutohN: see AisotN, below.

sitohN c
sitohN: see AisotN, below, in two places.

satahN c
satahN: see AisotN, below, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also Largeness of the Aisot. (S, K.)

satihN c
satihN; and its fem., with p: see Oasotahu, in two places: and see what next follows.

satahiIRN c
satahiIRN Of, or relating to, the Aisot; and in the same sense, if you will, you may say AisotiIRN↓; and satihN↓ also, with kesr to the t, like as they said HariHN. (S.)

sutohumN c
sutohumN: see Oasotahu, in three places.

sutayohapN c
sutayohapN dim. of AisotN, from the original of the latter, i. e. satahN. (TA.)

sutaAhiIRN c
sutaAhiIRN: see Oasotahu, in two places.

sutayohiIRN c
sutayohiIRN: see what next follows.

sayotahiIRN c
sayotahiIRN, thus correctly, in the handwriting of Sgh, on the authority of Fr; in the K, sutayohiIRN↓; (TA;) One who always walks, or goes, at the rear of a people, or party, (IB, K, TA,) remaining behind them, and looking to their goods. (IB, TA.)

AisotN OsA OsI Ost Ast Qst MsI Mst
AisotN (S, Mgh, K, written with the conjunctive hemzeh, Msb in art. Ast) and satahN↓ (S Mgh, K) and satohN↓ (K) and sitohN↓ (CK [but not in my MS. copy of the K nor in the TA, and of doubtful authority, as will be seen from what follows,]) signify the same, (S, * Mgh, * K,) i. e. The podex, buttock or buttocks, posteriors, rump, or croup; and sometimes the anus; (S;) satahN↓ being the original form, as is shown by the pl., (S, Mgh,) which is OasotaAhN; (S, Mgh, K;) like jamalN and OajomaAlN: it may not be [sitohN↓ and sutohN↓] like jicoEN and qufolN, of which the pls. are also of the measure OafoEaAlN, because, when you restore the C which is the final radical, and reject the medial radical [which is t], you say sahN, with fet-h, (S, Mgh, *) which has both of the meanings expl. above, as also suhN, (K,) but [SM says,] this last, mentioned by the author of the K, is strange, and I have not seen it on the authority of any one [else]: (TA:) and some say satN, (IKh, S, Mgh, TA,) suppressing the final radical [of satahN], (S,) i. e., without h at the end and without hemzeh [or A] at the beginning. (TA.) [All are of the fem. gender.] It is said in a trad., AlEayonu wikaMCu AlsRahi, or, as some relate it, AlsRati, (S, Mgh, TA,) [The eye is the tie of the anus,] meaning that when one [closes the eye and] sleeps, the tie of the sah becomes loosed, and the excrement and wind issue. (TA.) And Oabuw AlOasotaAhi means He who has large posteriors. (Az, TA.) biQsoti fulaAnK is a phrase of the Arabs significant of reviling; (S;) said when holding one in contempt; meaning laSiqa AlEaAru biQsoti fulaAnK (assumed tropical:) [May disgrace cleave to the Ast of such a one]. (Mgh.) And yaA Qbona QsotihaA (tropical:) [O son of her Ast], (K, TA,) a prov. of the Arabs, (TA,) is an allusion to one's father's UiHomaAD [see 2 in art. HmD] of the former's mother; (Z, TA;) and is said to mean OanRahu wulida mini QsotihaA: (TA:) and the Arabs called the sons of the female slave banuw QsotihaA. (Sh, TA.) And one says to a man who is deemed abject and weak, Aisotu OumRika OaDoyaqu [lit. Thy mother's Ast is too contracted], and Aisotuka OaDoyaqu mino Oano tafoEala kacaA wa kacaA [Thine Ast is too contracted, meaning (assumed tropical:) thine ability is too small, for thy doing such and such things]: (TA: [see also Freytag's Arab. Prov., i. 607:]) and Oanotumo OaDoyaqu OasotaAhFA mino Oano tafoEaluwhu [in like manner] is an allusion to inability [meaning (assumed tropical:) Ye are unable to do it]. (K.) The saying of a poet,
wa Oanota makaAnuka mino waAYilK
makaAnu AlquraAdi mini Qsoti Aljamalo
(tropical:) [And thou, thy place in the tribe of Wáïl is like the place of the tick in the rump of the camel,] is tropical; for they do not [properly] say Aisotu Aljamali, but Eajuzu Aljamali. (S.) One says also to a man who is deemed low, or base, Oanota AlAisotu AlsRufolaI, (TA,) and Ant AlsbRahu AlsRufolaI, meaning (assumed tropical:) Thou art among others in the condition of the Ast of mankind: (S, TA:) and of low, or base, men, one says, heWulaMCi AlOasotaAhu; and of such as are excellent, heWulaMCi AlOaEoyaAnu, and Alwujuwhu. (TA.) And one says, laqiytu minohu Qsota Alkalobapi, (A, K,) a prov., (TA,) meaning (assumed tropical:) I experienced from him, or it, what I disliked, or hated. (A, K, TA. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov., ii. 445.]) And Aisotu AlbaAYini OaEorafu, or OaEolamu: see art. byn. And maA laka QsotN maEi Qsotika (assumed tropical:) Thou hast no one [with thee] to assist thee: (A, K, TA:) another prov., related on the authority of AZ as said to one who has no large amount of property, nor number of men. (Sgh, TA.) And tarakotuhu biQsoti AlOaroDi, another prov., (TA,) meaning (assumed tropical:) I left him destitute, poor, (K, TA,) possessing nothing: (TA:) or tarakotuhu biQsoti Almatoni (assumed tropical:) I left him on the hard ground, alone. (Meyd.) And maA laka fiI hecaA AlOamori QsotN wa laA famN (assumed tropical:) Thou hast not in this thing, or affair, root nor branch: Jereer says,
famaA lakumu QsotN fiI AlEalaMCi wa laM famu
[And ye have not any root in eminence, nor branch]. (TA.) And kaAna celika EalaI Qsoti AldRahori (tropical:) That was in the beginning of time: (A, K, TA:) or in the olden time; (AO, S, TA;) as also EalaI UisRi AldRahori. (AO, TA.) See also art. Ast. [And see other exs. in Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 355 and 378 (a variation of a prov. mentioned in the preceding page) and 607 and 622 and 729-730.]

Oasotahu c
Oasotahu, applied to a man, (ISk, S, Mgh,) Large in the Aisot, (ISk, S, Mgh, K,) or Eajuz; (S;) as also sutaAhiIRN↓, (ISk, S, Mgh, K,) and sutohumN↓: (S:) and so, applied to a woman, satohaMCu [fem. of the first], and sutohumN↓, in which the m is augmentative, (ISk, S,) and satihapN↓: (TA:) pl. [of the first] sutuhN, like kutubN, and sutohaAnN: (K:) and musotahN↓, applied to a man, signifies large in the buttocks. (TA.) ― -b2- And, as also sutaAhiIRN↓ and satihN↓ and sutohumN↓, A seeker, or desirer, of the Aisot; (K;) or one addicted thereto; (TA;) i. q. luwTiIRN [one addicted to the crime of the people of Lot]. (TK.)

AisotiIRN AstI Asty Qst Qsty Qstyy
AisotiIRN: see satahiIRN, with which it is syn.

musotahN c
musotahN: see [its syn.] Oasotahu.

sutohumN c
sutohumN Large in the posteriors: (K:) accord. to the S, syn. with Oasotahu; [see this latter, in art. sth, in three places;] and the m is augmentative: (TA:) some explain it as syn. with AisotN: the author of the K [a mistake for the S], in art. sth, as meaning large in the Aisot. (MF, TA.)

1 sataI c
1. sataI, (K,) aor. yasotiI, said of a camel, (TA,) He hastened, made haste, or went quickly; (K, TA;) as also sadaI: mentioned by Az. (TA.)

2 satRaIa
2: see 4, in two places.

3 saAotaIa
3: sAtAhu, (K,) inf. n. musaAtaApN, (TA,) He played with him the [game called] XafalRaqap [expl. in art. Xflq in the K as consisting in one's striking with the hand, or with the fore part of the foot, the hinder part, or backside, of a man, from behind him, and so throwing him down prostrate: whence it seems that the verb is perhaps irregularly derived from the satahahu, q. v.]. (K.)

4 AstI AlvRawoba c
4. AstI AlvRawoba (S, K) and stRAhu↓ (M, TA) are syn. with AsdAhu (S, K) and sdRAhu, (M, TA,) [i. e. He set, or disposed, the warp of the garment, or piece of cloth,] said of a weaver; contr. of OaloHamahu; except that stRI↓ means he did so for himself and for another, whereas sdRI means he did so for another, tsdRI meaning he did so for himself. (TA.)

12 UisotawotaIa
12: [accord. to the S and K]. AisotaAtato, inf. n. AisotiytaMCN, said of a she-camel, She became relaxed by reason of last: (S, K:) thus mentioned here by J and in the K; but its proper place, as is evident, is art. AtI, in which it has been explained. (TA: see 10 in art. AtI.)

satFI c
satFI is syn. with sadFI, (S, M, K,) relating to a garment, or piece of cloth; (S, M;) as also OusotiIRN↓; (K;) both signify [The warp thereof;] the contr. of luHomapN; like sadFI and OusodiIRN: (M:) and sataApN↓ is [the n. un. of the former, or] syn. with sadaApN, relating to a garment, or piece of cloth: (AZ, S:) [whence,] one says to him who neither harms nor profits, maA Oanota luHomapN wa laA sataApN↓ [lit. Thou art neither a woof nor a warp: see also a similar saying voce niyrN]: (TA: [see also sadFI:]) and OusotiIRN↓ signifies also vawobN musodFI or musadRFI (accord. to different copies of the K) [lit. a garment, or piece of cloth, having its warp set or disposed; perhaps meaning having a good, or strong, warp; in art. Asd written, as from the L, masodiIRN, for which I find no other authority]; so expl. by AHeyth: but accord. to others, it is what the weavers term satFI, as mentioned above, i. e. the warp. (TA. [See also OusotiIRN in art. Ast, and OusodiIRN in art. Asd and in art. sdw and sdI.]) ＝ -A2- Also i. q. maEoruwfN [as meaning A favour, benefit, benefaction, or the like]; (K;) in this sense also a dial. var. of sadFI. (TA.) ＝ -A3- Also a dial. var. of sadFI signifying Dates while continuing green and small; syn. balaHN. (TA.)

sataApN c
sataApN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

OusotiIRN c
OusotiIRN: see satFI, above, in two places.

1 sajiHa c
1. sajiHa, aor.
sajaHa
, inf. n. sajaHN, (so accord. to the L, and the text of the K followed in the TA,) or sajoHN, (so accord. to the CK and my MS. copy of the K,) and sajaAHapN, [which last suggests that sajuHa also may be used in the sense here following,] said of a cheek, It was even, and soft, and long, in moderation, with little flesh, (M, TA,) and wide: (TA:) or was smooth, and long, with little flesh, and wide. (L. [See sajaHN, below.]) ― -b2- sajuHa, inf. n. sajaAHapN, is said of a man's natural disposition, [meaning It was, or became, gentle, or easy: (see sajiyHN, voce sujuHN, below:)] and one says, fiI Eaqolihi rajaAHapN wa fiI xuluqipi sajaAHapN [In his intellect is gravity, and in his natural disposition is gentleness, or easiness]. (A.) ＝ -A2- sajaHati AlHamaAmapu i. q. sajaEat [i. e. The pigeon cooed; or reiterated its voice or cry; &c.]: (Lth, K:) but said by some to be a mispronunciation, and disallowed by IDrd. (MF.) ＝ -A3- sajaHa lahu bikalaAmK He expressed a meaning to him obliquely, indirectly, obscurely, or allusively, by speech; as also sjRH↓: (Az, K:) so in the “ Nawádir. ” (Az, TA.)

2 sajRaHa
2: see what next precedes.

4 UisojaAHN c
4. UisojaAHN signifies The pardoning, or forgiving, with goodness. (S, O, K.) One says, malakota faOasojiHo; (S, A, O, TA;) a prov., relating to pardoning, or forgiving, when having power [to punish or to take vengeance]; (TA;) meaning [Thou hast become possessed of power, then pardon, or forgive, with goodness; or] thou hast attained thine object, then act with goodness; (A, * TA;) and thou hast obtained power, then pardon, or forgive, in an easy and a good manner: (TA:) it was said by the Prophet to Ibn-ElAkwa', and by 'Áïsheh to 'Alee on the “ Day of the Camel. ” (O.) And one says also, UicaA saOalota faOasojiHo When thou askest, or beggest, then make thy words, or expressions, easy, and be gentle. (S.)

7 AnsjH liI bikacaA c
7. AnsjH liI bikacaA i. q. AinosamaHa [app. syn. with OasomaHa, or perhaps a mistranscription for this last word, meaning He was liberal, or generous, to me with such a thing; or he complied with my desire in such a thing]. (K.)

sujoHN c
sujoHN: see sujuHN, in five places.

sajaHN c
sajaHN Beauty, and justness of proportion, (T, S, L,) of the make, (T,) or of the face, (S,) or of a man. (L.) [See also 1, first sentence.]

sujuHN c
sujuHN Soft, or gentle, and even, or easy; as also sajiyHN↓. (K.) You say miXoyapN sujuHN An easy (S, A) and a direct, or right, (A,) gait, or manner of going. (S, A.) And maXaI fulaAnN maXoyFA sujuHFA and sajiyHFA↓, and miXoyapF sujuHFA, Such a one walked, or went, with an easy gait or manner of going: (L:) or with an equable gait, without inclining the body from side to side in pride. (T.) And xuluqN sajiyHN↓ A gentle, or an easy, natural disposition. (L.) And rajulN sujuHN A man easy and good in natural disposition: (Har p. 314:) and Alxuluqi sajiyHu↓ [which means the same]. (A.) ＝ -A2- Also The middle of a road, (S, A, K,) or its main part, or beaten track; (A, K;) and so sujoHN↓: (S, A, K:) because of its evenness. (TA.) One says, xalRi lahu Eano sujoHi↓ AlTRariyqi or sujuHi AlTryq [Leave thou for him the middle of the road]. (S, accord. to different copies.) And mano Talaba biAlHaqRi wa maXaI fiI sujoHihi↓ OawoSalahu QllRehu UilaI nujoHihi [He who seeks, demands, or sues for, that which is a right, or due, and goes in the beaten track thereof, God will conduct him to the attainment of his object]. (A, TA.) ＝ -A3- And Measure, size, or proportion; (S, K;) as also sujoHN↓, (S,) and sajiyHapN↓: (S, A, K:) so in the saying, banaI Alqawomu buyuwtahumo EalaI sujuHK waAHidK (S, K *) and waAHidK sujoHK↓ (S) and sajiyHapK waAHidapK (S, A) [The people, or party, constructed their tents, or houses, of one uniform measure &c.].

sajoHapN c
sajoHapN: see sajiyHapN.

sujaAHN c
sujaAHN The air. (O, K.) [Perhaps a mistranscription for saHaAHN.]

sajaAHN c
sajaAHN i. q. tujaAha: (Fr, O, K: *) so in the saying, qaEadotu sijaAHa wajobihi [I sat over against, or fronting, his face]. (Fr, O.)

sajiyHN c
sajiyHN: see sujuHN, in four places.

sajiyHapN c
sajiyHapN: see sujuHN, in two places. ― -b2- Also Natural disposition; (S, A, K;) and so sajoHapN↓ (K, in the TA sjH,) and masojuwHapN↓ and masojuwHN↓, (K,) the last an inf. n., though having no verb. (Abu-l-Hasan, TA.) You say, huwa kariymu AlsRajiyHapi He is generous in respect of the natural disposition. (A.) And rakiba fulaAnN sajiyHapa raOosihi Such a one followed his own opinion. (AZ, TA.)

OasojaHu c
OasojaHu Beautiful, and of just proportion; (T, S, L, K;) applied to the make, (T,) or to the face, (S,) or to a man: (L:) or a face equable in form. (A.) And rajulN OasojaHu AlxadRayoni (A, L, TA) A man even, and soft, and long, in moderation, with little flesh, and wide, in the cheeks: (TA:) or smooth, and long, with little flesh, and wide, in the cheeks. (L.) ― -b2- Also A camel thin in the lip. (Ham p. 283.) ― -b3- And the fem., sajoHaMCu, A she-camel perfect, or complete, (L, K,) in length, or tallness, and in largeness: (L:) and a she-camel long in the back. (K.)

masojuwHN c
masojuwHN: see sajiyHapN. ― -b2- Also i. q. jihapN [The place, or point, towards which a person, or thing goes, tends, or is directed]. (O, K.)

masojuwHapN c
masojuwHapN: see sajiyHapN.

1 sajada c
1. sajada, (S, A, Msb, K, &c.,) [aor.
sajuda
,] inf. n. sujuwdN, (Msb,) He was, or became, lowly, humble, or submissive; syn. xaDaEa, (S, A, K, TA,) or taTaAmana, and calRa: (Msb:) or he bent him-self down towards the ground: (Aboo-Bekr, TA: [and such is often meant by xaDaEa and by taTaAmana:]) [or it has both of these significations combined; i. e. he was, or became, lowly, humble, or submissive, bending himself down; for] the primary signification of AlsRujuwdu is tacalRulF together with taTaOomunN [or taTaAmunN]. (Bd in ii. 32.) And Asjd↓ He lowered his head, and bent himself; (AA, S, Mgh, K;) said of a man; (AA, S, Mgh;) and put his forehead on the ground: (Mgh:) and likewise said of a camel; (S, A;) in the latter case tropical; (A;) as also sajada; (A, Mgh, Msb;) meaning (tropical:) he lowered his head, (S, A, Mgh, Msb,) to be ridden, (S, Mgh,) or to his rider, (A,) or on the occasion of his being ridden, or mounted. (Msb.) ― -b2- The sujuwd of prayer is from sajada in the first of the senses expl. above; (S;) and means The [prostrating oneself;] putting the forehead on the ground: (S, Mgh:) sajada, (ISd, Msb, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (ISd, TA,) signifies he put his forehead on the ground: (ISd, Msb, TA:) but sujuwd to God denotes a particular manner [of doing this; i. e. the prostrating oneself in prayer by dropping gently upon the knees, placing the palms of the hands on the ground, a little before the place of the knees, and then putting the nose and forehead on the ground, the former first, between the two hands]. (Msb.) ― -b3- It is said of Kisrà, in a trad., kaAna yasojudo lilTRaAliE, i. e. He used to lower himself, or bend himself down, to the arrow passing beyond the butt, going over it; which they used to reckon like that which hit the butt; meaning that he used to concede to the shooter thereof: or, accord. to Az, it means that he used to lower his head when his arrow was elevated [too high] above the object shot at, in order that the arrow might be rightly directed, and might hit the circle. (TA.) ― -b4- And [as salutation is often accompanied with a bending of the body,] sujuwdN also signifies (assumed tropical:) The act of saluting. (L, TA.) [You say, sajada lahu (assumed tropical:) He saluted him. And also (assumed tropical:) He paid respect, or honour, to him; or magnified him; see Ham p. 294.] ― -b5- You say also, sajadati AlnRaxolapu (tropical:) The palm-tree bent, or inclined, (AHn, Mgh, TA,) by reason of the abundance of its fruit. (Mgh.) And AlsRafiynapu tasojudu lilrRiyHi (tropical:) The ship bends, or inclines, by the influence of the wind. (A, TA.) ― -b6- wa QlnRajomu wa QlXRajaru yasojudaAni, in the Kur [lv. 5], means, accord. to Fr, (assumed tropical:) [And the herbs and the trees] turn towards the sun and incline with it until the afternoon-shade becomes broken: (TA:) or the herbs and the trees humbly submit to his will. (Bd, Jel.) The sujuwd of inanimate things to God we understand, in the Kur, as denoting obedience to that whereto they are made subservient, and as a fact to be believed without inquiry into the manner thereof. (I'Ab, L.) ＝ -A2- Also He stood erect: (Lth, Msb, K:) so in the dial. of Teiyi. (Msb.) It is said in the K, immediately after the mention of the first signification and this last, that thus the verb has two contr. meanings: but it may be said that there is no [necessary, or absolute,] contrariety between AlxuDuwE and AlAinotiSaAb. (MF.) ＝ -A3- sajidato rijoluhu, aor.
sajada
, (tropical:) His leg became inflated, or swollen. (K, TA.)

4 Asjd c
4. Asjd: see 1, second sentence. ― -b2- Also, (K,) inf. n. UisojaAd, (S,) (tropical:) He looked continuedly and tranquilly: (TA:) or he looked continuedly, (S, K,) and lowered the eyelids in a languid, or languishing, manner, (S, [the inf. n. being there expl. by UidaAmapu AlnRaZari wa UimoraADu AlOajofaAni,]) or lowering the eyelids [&c.], (K, * TK,) with a look indicative of [amorousness, and feigned coyness or opposition, or] confidence in one's love, and consequent presumptuousness: (TA:) or he had a languid, or languishing, eye. (L.) ― -b3- And Asjdt EayonahaA (tropical:) She lowered her eye. (A, TA.)

sajodapN c
sajodapN A single act of sujuwd [as meaning prostrating oneself in prayer or the like: pl. sajadaAtN]: so in the phrase sajadotu sajodapF [I performed a prostration of myself]: (Msb:) and qaraOotu suwrapa AlsRajodapi [I recited, or read, the chapter of the prostration; which is the thirty-second chapter of the Kur-án]. (S, * Msb.)

sijodapN c
sijodapN a subst. from sajada; (S;) A species, or sort, [or kind,] of sujuwd [as meaning prostration of oneself in prayer or the like]: so in the phrase sajadotu sijodapF TawiylapF [I performed a long kind of prostration of myself]. (Msb.)

rajulN sajRaAdN c
rajulN sajRaAdN [A man who prostrates himself much, or frequently, in prayer or the like]. (A, TA.)

sajRaAdapN c
sajRaAdapN A [small mat, such as is termed] xumorap, (S, Mgh, L, TA,) [of an oblong shape, and a small oblong carpet,] upon which one prostrates himself [and stands and sits in prayer]; (L, TA;) also called sujRaAdapN↓, (A, TA,) and misojadapN↓. (A, L, TA.) You say, basaTa sajRaAdatahu &c. [He spread his prayer-mat, or prayer-carpet]. (A.) ― -b2- And The mark of sujuwd [or prostration in prayer] upon the forehead [when dust adheres to it]. (S, A, Mgh.)

sujRaAdapN c
sujRaAdapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

saAjidN c
saAjidN act. part. n. of sajada: (L:) [Being lowly, humble, or submissive: bending himself down towards the ground: &c.: and hence, prostrating himself in prayer; putting his forehead on the ground: &c.:] pl. sujRadN (S, A, L) and sujuwdN. (L.) ― -b2- wa QdoxuluwA QlobaAba sujRadFA, in the Kur [ii. 55 and vii. 161], means And enter ye the gate bending down your heads: (I'Ab, K:) it was a narrow [or low] gate. (I'Ab.) ― -b3- And sujRadFA lilRehi, in the Kur xvi. 50, means (tropical:) Humbling themselves to God, with subserviency. (TA.) ― -b4- You say also XajarapN saAjidapN, and XajarN saAjidN and sawaAjidu, [this last word being pl. of saAjidapN,] (tropical:) A tree, and trees, bending, or inclining: (A:) and naxolN sawaAjidu (assumed tropical:) palm-trees bending, or inclining: (AHn:) and najolapN saAjidapN (assumed tropical:) a palm-tree bent by its fruit. (K.) [But it is said that] EulobN sawaAjidu, occurring in a verse of Lebeed, means (assumed tropical:) Firmly-rooted [tall] palm-trees. (IAar.) ― -b5- And fulaAnN saAjidu Almanoxiri (tropical:) Such a one is object, low, humble, or submissive. (A, TA.) ― -b6- And EayonN saAjidapN (tropical:) A languid, or languishing, eye. (A, K.)

Oasojadu c
Oasojadu (tropical:) Having his leg inflated, or swollen: (K, TA:) applied to a man. (TA.)

daraAhim AlOasojaAd c
daraAhim AlOasojaAd, (O, K,) or AlUisojaAd, (S, O, K,) thus some relate it, with kesr to the C, (O, K,) in the saying of El-Aswad Ibn-Yaafur.
mino xayori ciI naTafK OaganRa munaTRaqK
waAfaI bihaA lidaraAhimi AlUiOasojaAdi
