[Of the wine of one with earrings, having a nasal twang, girded with a waist-belt, i. e., of a foreigner: he brought it for what are termed drAhm AlAsjAd], (S, * O, K, but in the copies of the K kadaraAhim, [which I think a mistranscription,]) means dirhems whereon were effigies to which people performed the act of sujuwd: (S, O, K:) it is said that upon them was the effigy of Kisrà, and he who beheld them lowered his head to them and showed humility [as the Persians in the present day do to the picture of their King]: (IAmb, TA:) or AlOasojaAd means the tax called jizoyap: (O, K:) so says AO, (O,) or A 'Obeyd: (TA:) or the Jews and the Christians: (O, K:) some say the former and some say the latter: (O:) and it is read with kesr to the C, and expl. as meaning the Jews, (O, K,) by IAar. (O.) [Whatever be the signification of the last word, the verse plainly means, “ of wine of a foreigner, sold by him for foreign money. ”]

masojadN c
masojadN The forehead, (S, K,) where is the
mark made by the sujuwad [or prostration in prayer]. (S.) [Said in the TA to be tropical; but not so accord. to the A.] And sing. of masaAjidu which signifies The parts of a man that are the places of sujuwd; (Lth, Mgh, Msb, L;) AlmasaAjidu meaning the forehead, the nose, the hands, the knees, and the feet: (Mgh, L:) or the forehead, the hands, and the knees: (Mgh:) or the seven MraAb; (S, K;) namely, the forehead, the hands, the knees, and the feet: (TA in art. Arb:) such, accord. to some, is its meaning in the Kur lxxii. 18. (L.) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph, in two places.

masojidN c
masojidN [Any place in which one performs the act of sujuwd, or acts of worship or devotion; and particularly a mosque; a Muslim temple; an oratory;] a house in which one performs the act of sujuwd; (IB;) a house of prayer; (Mgh, Msb;) any place in which one performs acts of worship or devotion: (Zj:) a word of well-known meaning; (K;) sing. of masaAjidu; (S, Mgh, K;) and also pronounced masojadN↓: (S, K:) this latter word signifies, accord. to IAar, the miHoraAb [here meaning oratory, or place of private prayer,] of a house; and the place of prayer of the congregations; (TA;) or it signifies any of the parts of the ground, as well as of the body, that are the places of sujuwd: (Lth, L:) or the place of the forehead [on the ground in the act of prostration in prayer]. (IB.) Fr says, (S,) the mafoEl of every verb of the class of faEala having its aor. of the measure yafoEulu is with fet-h to the medial radical letter, whether it be a subst, or an inf. n., (S, K,) without any difference, so that you say, daxala madoxalFA, and hecaA madoxaluhu; (S;) except some words (S, K) among substs., (S,) as masojidN and maToliEN (S, K) and magoribN (S) and maXoriqN and masoqiTN and maforiqN and majozirN and masokinN and marofiqN (S, K) from rafaqa, aor. yarofuqu, (S,) and manobitN and manosikN (S, K) from nasaka, aor. yanosuku; (S;) these being with kesr (S, K) to the medial radical letter (K) as a sign of their being substs.; but sometimes some of the Arabs pronounce it with fet-h in the subst.: masokinN and masokanN have been transmitted; and we have heard Almasojidu and Almasojadu↓, and AlmaToliEu and AlmaTolaEu: and he further says, (S,) fet-h is allowable, (S, K,) in all of these, (S,) even if we have not heard it: but when the verb is of the class of faEala having its aor. of the measure yafoEilu, the n. of place [or time] is with kesr, and the inf. n. is with fet-h, to distinguish the one from the other; so that you say, nazala manozalFA, meaning nuzuwlFA, and hecaA manozilupu, meaning daAruhu. (S, K. *) ― -b2- [Hence masojidN jaAmiEN A congregational mosque; i. e. a mosque in which a congregation assembles to perform the Friday-prayers.] Almasojidu AlHaraAmu [The sacred mosque of Mekkeh]. (Msb in art. Hrm.) Almasojidu AlOaqoSaI The furthest mosque [which is in Jerusalem]. (Msb in art. qSw.) masojidu Alxayofi The mosque of the xayof [q. v.] in Minè. (S &c. in art. xyf.) And AlmasojidaAni The two mosques; that of Mekkeh and that of El-Medeeneh: (S, Mgh:) so in a verse cited in the first paragraph of art. vrw. (S.)

misojadapN c
misojadapN: see sajRaAdapN.

1 sajarahu c
1. sajarahu, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
sajura
, (Msb,) inf. n. sajorN (Msb, TA) and sujuwrN; (TA;) and sjRrhu↓, inf. tasojiyrN; (TA;) He filled it; (S, A, Msb, K;) namely, a river, or channel for water; (S, A, K;) and a vessel; as also sakarahu; (TA;) with water. (S.) You say, sajara AlsRayolu AlMbaAra [The torrent filled the wells]. (A.) And sujirati AlvRimaAdu The vmAd [see its sing. vamadN] became filled by the rain. (S.) In the Kur [lxxxi. 6], wa UicaA QlobiHaAru sujirato, some read thus; and others, sujRirato↓; (Zj;) and Th explains it, and so Zj the former reading, as signifying, And when the seas shall be filled: but ISd says that there is no way of understanding this unless it mean filled with fire: or it means and when the seas shall overflow: or shall meet together and become one sea: (TA:) or sujRirato↓ signifies shall flow forth, one into another, and thus become one sea, (Zj, Bd,) and so be filled: (Bd:) and there are other explanations of the above-mentioned words of the Kur, which see below. ― -b2- sajara AlmaMCa fiI Haloqihi He poured the water into his throat. (K.) ― -b3- sajara AltRanRuwra, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
sajura
, inf. n. sajorN; (S;) and sjRrhu↓; (Bd in lxxxi. 6;) or the latter has an intensive signification; (Mgh;) He heated the oven; (S, A, K;) kindled fire in it: (Msb:) or filled it with firewood, to heat it: (Mgh Bd:) or he heated it fully with fuel. (TA.) The words of the Kur quoted above, w AcA AlbHAr sujirato, are said to signify And when the seas shall be set on fire: (El-Hasan El-Basree:) or shall become without water, (Katádeh,) or shall be dried up, by the kindling of fire therein: (B:) or shall be kindled, and become fire: (Jel:) or shall be mixed together, and dry up, and become fire; (El-Ubbee;) an explanation founded upon the license to employ a homonym in its several significations together: (MF:) or by “ sea ” is meant hell. (Kaab.) You say also, sajara Alwaquwda biQlomisojarapi [He stirred the fuel with the msjrp]. (A.) ＝ -A2- sajarati AlnRaAqapu, (S, A, K,) aor.
sajura
, (S,) inf. n. sajorN (S, A, K) and sujuwrN; (S, K;) and sjRrt↓, inf. n. tasojiyrN; (A;) (tropical:) The she-camel prolonged her yearning cry (Haniyn, S, A, K) after her young one, (As, A,) and filled her mouth with it. (A.) ＝ -A3- sajarahu, inf. n. sajorN; [and sjRrhu↓, and sawojarahu↓; (see the pass. part. ns., below;)] He made it [namely hair or the like] to hang down. (TA. [See also sarajato XaEorahaA.]) ＝ -A4- sajarahu; (A, K;) and sjRrhu↓, (A,) inf. n. tasojiyrN; (TA;) and sawojarahu↓; (IJ, A, K;) He put a saAjuwr upon, or around, his (a dog's) neck: (A:) or he bound him (a dog) with a sAjwr. (K.)

2 sjRr AlmaMCa c
2. sjRr AlmaMCa, inf. n. tasojiyrN, He opened a way to the water; made it to flow forth, (Aboo-Sa'eed, K,) whithersoever he would. (Aboo-Sa'eed.) ― -b2- See also 1, throughout.

3 saAjarahu c
3. saAjarahu, (A,) inf. n. musaAjarapN, (A, K,) (tropical:) He acted or associated with him as a friend, or as a true friend; (A, * K, * TA;) mixed, or held intercourse, with him: from sajarati AlnRaAqapu. (A.)

7 Ansjr c
7. Ansjr It (a vessel) became full. (TA.) ― -b2- [It (hair) hung down. (See the part. n., voce masojuwrN.)] ― -b3- Ansjrt AlUibilu The camels followed one another in a continuous series, or uninterruptedly, in their march, or progress: (S, K: * [but in some copies of the K, for Ansjr fiI AlsRayori, is put Oasojara:]) or they advanced and hastened; as also AnXjr. (TA.)

Q. Q. 1 sawojarahu c
Q. Q. 1. sawojarahu: see 1, last two sentences.

sajarN c
sajarN (T, S, M, K, &c.) and sujorapN↓ (T, M, K) Turbidness, or dinginess: this is the primary signification: and hence, (TA,) (tropical:) an intermixture of redness in the white of the eye: (S, K:) or redness in the white of the eye: (T:) or redness inclining to whiteness: or redness inclining to blueness: or redness in the black of the eye: or an intermixture, or a tinge, of redness in the black of the eye: or a slight redness mixing with the blackness: or an inclining of the black to redness: or a slight whiteness in the black of the eye: or a dinginess in the interior of the eye, arising from neglecting, or leaving off, the use of collyrium. (TA.)

sujorapN c
sujorapN: see sajarN. ― -b2- Also [A fall of] rainwater which fills what are called vimaAd [pl. of vamadN, q. v.]: pl. sujarN. (S.)

biYorN sujurRN c
biYorN sujurRN A full well. (TA.)

sajuwrN c
sajuwrN Fuel with which an oven (tanRuwr) is heated; (S, A, Mgh, K;) as also misojarN↓ (K) and misojarapN↓. (TA). [See also misojarapN below.]

sajiyrN c
sajiyrN (tropical:) A man's friend, or true or sincere friend: pl. sujaraMCu: (S, A, K:) from sajarati AlnRaAqapu; because each of two friends yearns towards the other. (A.) ― -b2- And hence, (assumed tropical:) A sword. (Ham p. 265.)

saAjirN c
saAjirN A torrent that fills everything. (TA.) ― -b2- A place upon which a torrent comes and which it fills: (S, A, K:) a possessive epithet, or of the measure faAEilN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also masojuwrN.

saAjuwrN c
saAjuwrN A wooden thing, or piece of wood, (S, K,) that is put, (S,) or hung, (K,) upon the neck of a dog: (S, K:) or a collar, (TA,) or ring or collar of iron, (A,) that is put upon the neck of a dog: (A, TA:) [pl. sawaAjiyru or sawaAjiru.] One says, fiI OaEonaAqihimo sawaAjiru (tropical:) Upon their necks are iron collars. (A.)

Oasojaru c
Oasojaru, applied to a pool of water left by a torrent (gadiyrN), (assumed tropical:) Having mud unmixed with sand; or having good mud: (S, K:) or (assumed tropical:) of which the water inclines to a red colour; which is the case when its rain-water is recent, before it has become clear: (TA:) and (tropical:) rain-water intermixed with turbidness and redness. (A.) ― -b2- (tropical:) A man having what is termed sajarN or sujorapN in the eye or eyes: fem. sajoraMCu (TA.) ― -b3- EayonN sajoraMCu
(tropical:) An eye of which the white is intermixed with redness: (S, A, K:) an eye in which is what is termed sajarN [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b4- qaTorapN sajoraMCu (tropical:) A turbid drop: (A, * TA:) and in like manner nuTofapN. (TA.)

misojarN c
misojarN: see sajuwrN: and also what here follows.

misojarapN c
misojarapN: see sajuwrN. ― -b2- Also [and app. misojarN↓] A piece of wood, or stick, with which the fuel in an oven (tanRuwr) is stirred. (A, L, TA.)

masojuwrN c
masojuwrN Filled: (AZ:) applied to the sea in this sense: (S:) or the sea [itself]: (K: [in the TA, by the omission of waQllRabanu after AlbaHoru, it is made to signify “ a sea of which the water is more than it is itself; ” a meaning which, as there remarked, is not found in other lexicons:]) and masojuwrN biAlnRaAri filled with fire: ('Alee:) and EayonN masojuwrapN, and musajRarapN↓, a full eye or source; syn. mufoEamapN. (A, TA.) ― -b2- Milk of which the water is more than it is itself. (Fr, S, K.) ― -b3- Made to flow forth. (TA.) ― -b4- Empty. (AZ, Aboo-'Alee.) Thus it bears two contr. significations. (TA.) ― -b5- Kindled. (K.) ― -b6- Still, or quiet; (K;) as also saAjirN↓: (TA:) or still, or quiet, and full at the same time. (A 'Obeyd, TA.) ― -b7- luWoluWN masojuwrN Pearls strung and hanging down: (A 'Obeyd, S, K:) or that have fallen and become scattered from their string: and luWoluWapN masojuwrapN is said to signify a pearl of much brilliancy. (TA.) ― -b8- XaEarN masojuwrN, (TA,) and musajRarN↓, and musawojarN↓, (K,) and munosajirN↓, (S, K,) Hair made to hang down; (K;) hanging down. (S, K.) ― -b9- kalobN masojuwrN, (AZ, A,) and musajRarN↓, (A,) and musawojarN, (S, A,) A dog having a saAjuwr (q. v.) upon his neck. (AZ, S, A.)

musajRarN c
musajRarN: see masojuwrN, in three places. ― -b2- Also, Dried up; of which the water has sunk into the ground. (TA.)

musawojarN c
musawojarN: see masojuwrN, in two places.

munosajirN c
munosajirN: see masojuwrN.

1 sajisa c
1. sajisa, (S, A, K,) aor.
sajasa
, (K,) inf. n. sajasN, (TA,) It (water) became altered, changed in odour, or stinking; syn. tagayRara: (IAar, A 'Obeyd, S, A, K:) it became turbid, thick, or muddy: (ISk, A, K:) or it became corrupted, and stirred up. (TA.)

2 sjRshu c
2. sjRshu, inf. n. tasojiysN, He made it (namely, water,) turbid, thick, or muddy. (K, TA.)

sajosN c
sajosN: see the next paragraph, in five places.

sajasN c
sajasN: see the next paragraph, in five places.

sajisN c
sajisN: see the next paragraph, in five places.

maMCN sajiysN c
maMCN sajiysN Water that is altered, changed in odour, or stinking; syn. mutagayRirN: turbid, thick, or muddy: as also sajisN↓, (K, TA,) and sajosN↓: (TA:) or corrupted, and stirred up; as also musajRasN↓: or the last signifies made turbid, thick, or muddy, and stirred up: the [only] form mentioned in the S is sajasN↓: but Aboo-Sahl says that sajisN↓ is the form learned by him in reading under Aboo-Usámeh in the Musannaf; and as to sajasN↓, it is only an inf. n. (TA, from a note in the handwriting of Aboo-Zekereeyà.) ― -b2- Hence the saying, (TA,) laA Mtiyka sajiysa QllRayaAliI I will not come to thee to the end of nights: (TA:) or ever; (S, K;) as also sajiysa AllRayaAliIi wa AlOayRaAmi, (TA,) and sjiysa AlOawojasi, (S, K,) and sajiysa AlOawojusi, (K,) and sajiysa EujayosK: (S, K:) or while time lasts; as also sajiysa AldRahori, and sajiysa AlOawojasi: (A:) it is from sajiysN meaning “ turbid, ” because water thus termed is the last that remains: Eujayos is a corroborative; and Eajosu AllRayoli signifies “ the last part of the night: ” (TA:) or sajiysa AllRayaAliI means while the nights glide along continuously. (Ham p. 243.)

saAjisiIRN c
saAjisiIRN A ram having much wool: fem. with p: (A:) or a ram having white wool, good for tupping, or covering, and of excellent breed. (K, * (TA.) And Certain sheep [i. e. a breed of sheep] belonging to the Benoo-Teghlib, (K, * TA,) in El-Jezeereh. (TA.)

musajRasN c
musajRasN: see sajiysN.

1 sajaEa c
1. sajaEa, aor.
sajaEa
, inf. n. sajoEN, He pursued an even, uniform course; he pursued an even course, following one order: this is the primary signification. (TA.) [It seems to be properly intrans.; but is sometimes used as a trans. verb, li or UilaI being perhaps understood; as in the following phrase;] sajaEa celika AlmasojaEa He pursued, or aimed at, that object of pursuit or aim; (K, TA;) occurring in a trad. (TA.) ― -b2- And It was even and uniform, one part thereof being like another. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence,] sajaEati AlHamaAmapu, (IDrd, S, Msb, K,) aor.
sajaEa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. sajoEN, (Mbr, TA,) and quasi-inf. n. sijoEN↓, (TA,) The pigeon continued its cry uninterruptedly in one uniform way or manner; or called, and prolonged its voice or cry, modulating it sweetly: (Mbr, in the “ Kámil; ” and TA:) or cooed: or reiterated its voice or cry: syn. hadarato: (S, Msb:) and SawRatato: (Msb:) or radRadato SawotahaA. (IDrd, K.) It is said in a prov., laA Mtayka maA sajaEa AlHamaAmu [I will not come to thee as long as the pigeon cooes;] meaning I will never come to thee. (Lh.) ― -b4- You say also, sajaEati AlnRaAqapu, (S, TA,) inf. n. sajoEN, (TA,) The she-camel prolonged her yearning cry in one uniform manner. (S, TA.) ― -b5- And sajaEati Alqawosu (tropical:) The bow prolonged its twang in one uniform manner, monotonously. (TA.) ― -b6- And hence by way of comparison to the sajoE of the pigeon, sajaEa kalaAmahu (tropical:) He (a man) made his speech, or language, [to be rhyming prose, i. e.,] to have fawaASil like the rhymes of verse, without its being measured. (Msb.) And sajaEa [alone], (S, K,) aor.
sajaEa
, (K,) inf. n. sajoEN; (S, TA;) and sjRE↓, inf. n. tasojiyEN; (S, TA;) (tropical:) He (a man, S) spoke, or uttered, [or composed,] (S, * K, TA,) rhyming speech or language, (S,) [i. e., rhyming prose, i. e.,] speech, or language, having fawaASil (K, TA) like the fawaASil of verse, without measure: as is said in a description of Sijistán, watamoruhaA
wa liSRuhaA baTalo
maAWuhaA waXalo
wa Uino qalRuwA DaAEuwA
Uino kavura AljayoXu bihaA jaAEuwA
daqalo
[Its water is such as scantily distils, in interrupted drops, from mountains or rocks, and its robber is a man of courage, and its dates are of the worst kind: if the army be numerous in it, they hunger; and if they be few, they perish]: so says Lth. (TA.) You say also, sajaEa biAlXRaIoCi, meaning (tropical:) He uttered the thing in the manner above described. (TA.) [See also sajoEN, below.]

2 sajRaEa
2: see the preceding paragraph.

sajoEN c
sajoEN; [originally inf. n. of sajaEa, q. v.;] (S, Msb, K, &c.;) or, as some say, sijoEN↓, but the former is that which commonly obtains, the latter being said to be a subst. like ciboHN meaning “ what is slaughtered, ” unknown, however, in the lexicons, and probably one of the instances of the elicitations of the foreigners, (MF, TA,) the object of him who says that it is sijoEN being app. to make a distinction between the simple subst. and the inf. n., as in the case of the simple subst. and the inf. n. of sajaEa said of the pigeon; [see sajaEati AlHamaAmapu;] (TA;) and OusojuwEapN↓; (S, * K;) (tropical:) Rhyming speech or language; (S, K, TA;) [i. e. rhyming prose; i. e.] speech, or language, having fawaASil like the rhymes of verse, without being measured; so called as being likened to the sajoE of the pigeon; (Msb;) or because of its uniformity, (TA,) and the mutual resemblance and agreement of the words which end its clauses: (IJ, TA:) or a consecution [of clauses] of speech or language, with one rawiIR [which is the principal, or only, rhyme-letter]: (Jm, K:*) or it consists in the agreement of the endings of words [or clauses], in a certain order, like the agreement of the rhymes (qawaAfK) [of verses]: (Mbr, in the “ Kámil; ” TA:) each clause ends with a quiescent letter; and consists of at least two words: (Kull p. 208:) [see an ex. in the first paragraph of this art.:] you say also kalaAmN musajRaEN↓ (S) and kalaAmN masojuwEN↓, meaning the same as sajoEN: (TA:) the pl. of sajoEN is OasojaAEN (S, K) and, accord. to IJ, sujuwEN, but ISd says, I know not whether he have related this from another or coined it, (TA,) and OasaAjiyEu, (S,) or this last is pl. of OusojuwEapN↓ (K) [and is also a pl. pl., i. e. pl. of OasojaAEN, like as OazaAhiyru is pl. of OazohaArN which is pl. of zahorN, and many similar instances might be added, such instances being numerous app. because OafoEaAlN is properly a measure of a pl. of paucity]. AlsRajoEu AlmuTarRafu is That [rhyming prose] in which the two words [that end two corresponding clauses] agree in the letter of the sajoE but not in measure; as AlrRimamo and AlOumamo: and AlsRajoEu AlmutawaAziI is that in which the measure is observed in the two words as well as the letter of the
sajoE; as Alqalamo and Alqasamo. (K T.) It is said in a trad., that Mohammad forbade sajoE in prayer: [but many of the forms of prayer which he himself prescribed, and many others commonly used by Muslims in every age to the present time, are sajoE, and the Kur-án is a composition of the same kind, though some do not allow this term to be applied to it, because sajoE is a highly artificial style of prose-language, characterized by a kind of rhythm as well as rhyme, and it is obviously not proper to ascribe such artificial language to God, nor is it proper to use it in prayer, wherefore] Az says that sajoE is disapproved in prayer because it resembles the language of the diviners, or soothsayers, but that other kinds of rhyming styles are allowable in xuTab and rasaAYil. (TA.) He is also related to have said, UiyRaAkumo wa sajoEa AlkuhRaAni (tropical:) [Avoid ye the rhyming prose of the diviners, or soothsayers]. (TA.) One says also, bayonahumo OusojuwEapN↓ [Between them is a discourse, or colloquy, oral or written, in rhyming prose]. (S.)

sijoEN c
sijoEN: see sajaEati AlHamaAmapu: ― -b2- and see sajoEN.

sajuwEN c
sajuwEN: see saAjiEN.

sajRaAEN c
sajRaAEN: see saAjiEN.

sajRaAEapN c
sajRaAEapN: see saAjiEN.

saAjiEN c
saAjiEN Pursuing [an even, uniform, course, or] a direct, or right, course, (AZ, S, K, TA,) in going, or journeying, (AZ, S, TA,) [and] (tropical:) in speech, &c. (K, TA.) Dhu-r-Rummeh says,
qaTaEotu bihaA OaroDFA taraI wajoha rakobihaA
UicaA maA EalawohaA mukofaOF gayora saAjiEi
i. e. [I traversed, or have traversed, with her a land in which thou wouldst see the face of every one of the company of travellers riding over it, when they get upon it,] jaAYirFA gayora qaASidK [turning aside from the right course, (or rather turned aside, unless, which is not improbable, the right reading be mukofiYFA,) not direct], (AZ, S, TA,) or not direct towards one point: (TA:) but in the O we find, as on the authority of AZ, gayora saAjiEi gyr jaAYirK Eani AlqaSodi [which is evidenily a mistranscription; the right reading being gayora saAjiEi OaIo jaAYirFA Eani AlqaSodi, or the like]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] A face justly proportioned; [symmetrical;] well, or beautifully, formed. (K.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] HamaAmapN saAjiEapN, and sajuwEN↓, (K,) without p, (TA,) [A pigeon continuing its cry uninterruptedly in one uniform way or manner; or calling, and prolonging its voice or cry, modulating it sweetly: or cooing: (see 1:) or] reiterating its voice or cry: pl. [of the former or of both] sujRaEN and [of the former] sawaAjiEu. (K.) ― -b4- And naAqapN saAjiEN A she-camel prolonging her yearning cry in one uniform manner: (TA:) or quavering, and prolonging her voice, [in the copies of the K muToribap, but correctly muTarRibap,] in her yearning cry: (K:) or tall; (AA, K;) but Az says, I have not heard this on any authority beside that of AA. (TA.) ― -b5- [And hence,] saAjiEN also signifies (tropical:) [A rhyming-proser, or rhyming-prosaist;] one who speaks, or utters, [or composes,] sajoE: and in like manner, [sajRaAEN↓ (mentioned by Golius, and by Freytag as on the authority of the K, in no copy of which do I find it,) meaning one who speaks, or utters, or composes, sajoE much: and] sajRaAEapN↓ [meaning one who does so very much: the three epithets being similar to raAjizN and rajRaAzN and rajRaAzapN]. (K, TA.)

OusojuwEapN c
OusojuwEapN: see sajoEN, in three places.

masojaEN c
masojaEN A place, or an object, [to which latter it is applied in a phrase mentioned in the second sentence of this art.,] of pursuit or aim; syn. maqoSidN. (K.)

musajRaEo c
musajRaEo: see sajoEN.

masojuwEN c
masojuwEN: see sajoEN.

1 sajafa Albayota c
1. sajafa Albayota: see 2. ＝ -A2- sajifato, aor.
saHafa
, inf. n. sajafN, She (a woman) was, or became, slender in the waist: and lank in the belly. (TK.) [See also sajafN, below.]

2 sjRf Albayota c
2. sjRf Albayota, (K,) inf. n. tasojiyfN, (TA,) He let down the curtain (AlsRajof) upon [the entrance of] the tent, or chamber; as also sajafahu↓, and Asjfh↓: (K, TA:) accord. to the T, AltRasojiyf signifies the letting down of the sajofaAni [or two separate halves, that hang side by side, of a curtain]: accord. to the M, the letting down of the curtain. (TA. [See also what next follows.])

4 Asjf AlsRitora c
4. Asjf AlsRitora He let down the curtain. (S, K, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Asjf AllRayolu (tropical:) i. q. Oasodafa, (S, K, TA,) i. e. The night became dark. (TA.) ― -b3- See also 2.

sajofN c
sajofN: see the next paragraph.

sijofN c
sijofN and sajofN↓ [of which the former is the more common] A curtain; a veil; or a thing that veils, conceals, hides, covers, or protects; (S, K;) as also sijaAfN↓, and sijaAfapN↓: (TA:) or a pair of curtains having an opening between them: (IDrd, K:) or each half of a pair of curtains, (Lth, K, TA,) divided in the midst, (Lth, TA,) by which any door, or entrance, is veiled; (Lth, K, TA;) as also sijaAfN↓: (K, TA:) this last is not a pl. of sijofN: (TA:) thus AlsRijofaAni signifies the two separate halves [that hang side by side, so as to meet together,] of the curtain of a tent, (Lth, S, TA,) in the fore part thereof: (S:) so in a verse of En-Nábighah EdhDhubyánee cited in the second paragraph of art. rfE: (S, TA:) the pl. of sijofN and sajofN is OasojaAfN and sujuwfN; and the pl. of sijaAfN↓ is sujufN. (TA.) [Hence] one says, OaroxaI AllRayolu sujuwfahu (tropical:) The night let down its curtains. (TA.) ― -b2- sijofN also signifies The part that is behind a door or an entrance. (O, TA.)

sajafN c
sajafN Slenderness of the waist: and lankness of the belly. (K.) One says fiI xaSorihi sajafN In his waist is slenderness: and fiI baTonihi sajafN In his belly is lankness. (TA.) [See also sajifato, in the first paragraph.]

sujofapN c
sujofapN A period (saAEapN) of the night; (K;) like sudofapN. (TA.)

sijaAfN c
sijaAfN: see sijofN, in three places. ― -b2- Hence, The thing [i. e. edging, such as a fringe, &c., (thus applied in the present day,)] that is affixed to the borders of a garment, or piece of cloth. (TA.)

sijaAfapN c
sijaAfapN: see sijofN. ― -b2- Hence the saying of Umm-Selemeh to ' Áïsheh, wajRahoti sijaAfatahu i. e. hatakoti sitorahu and Oaxacoti wajohahaA (assumed tropical:) [i. e. wajoha sijaAfatihi (as in the JM in art. wjh in explanation of wajRahoti sidaAfatahu) Thou hast rent open his veil, or covering; both of these explanations meaning the same, as is said in the O and K in art. sdf]: but it is also related otherwise, i. e. wjRht sidaAfatahu, which has the same meaning. (TA. [See art. sdf.])

bayotN musajRafN c
bayotN musajRafN [A tent; or chamber,] having a pair of curtains (sijofaAni) upon its entrance, or door. (As, TA.) El-Farezdak applies this masc. sing. epithet to a pl. n., saying AlHijaAlu AlmusajRafu. (TA.)

1 sajala AlmaMCa c
1. sajala AlmaMCa, (S, K,) inf. n. sajolN, (TA,) He poured out, or forth, the water, (S, K, JM, TA,) continuously. (JM, TA.) ― -b2- Hence, sajala AlquroMna He read, or recited, the Kur-án continuously. (JM. [See also saHala.]) ― -b3- See also 2: ― -b4- and 4.

2 sjRl c
2. sjRl, inf. n. tasojiylN, (S, Msb, K,) said of a judge, (S,) or kádee, (Msb,) He wrote a sijilR [q. v.]: (S, * K:) or he decided judicially, and recorded his sentence in the sijilR: (Msb:) and Mtr says that UisojaAlN↓ may be syn. with tasojiylN, signifying the writing of sijilRaAt [pl. of sijilRN], though not found by him in the lexicons: (Har p. 473:) [but I have found it, for Sgh says,] the UisojaAl of the kádee and his tasojiyl are one [in meaning]. (O.) You say, sjRl bihi He decided it judicially, [and recorded it in the sijilR;] or he decreed it decisively; so expl. by the Shereef: or, as in the 'Ináyeh, he established it and recorded it [in the sijilR]. (TA.) And sjRl AlqaADiI lifulaAnK bimaAlihi The kádee secured to such a one his property [by a judicial decision recorded in the sijilR]. (TA.) And sjRl Ealayohi AlqaADiI [The kadee decided judicially against him, and recorded his sentence in the sijilR]. (Mgh.) ― -b2- And sjRl Ealayohi bikacaA (assumed tropical:) He rendered him notorious by reason of such a thing, and stigmatized him with it. (Z, TA.) ＝ -A2- And sjRl bihi He threw it from above; as also sajala↓, inf. n. sajolN. (K.) ＝ -A3- And sjRl, inf. n. as above, He (a man, TA) became affected with carnal appetite. (K.)

3 sAjlhu c
3. sAjlhu, (K,) inf. n. musaAjalapN, (S, IB, TA,) [and app. sijaAlN also, (see sajolN,)] He vied, competed, or contended for superiority, with him; emulated, or rivalled, him; or imitated him; (S, IB, * K;) doing like as he did; (S, IB;) originally in the drawing of water; (S, * IB;) each of them bringing forth in his sajol [or bucket] the like of what the other brought forth [or endeavouring to do so]; the one, of them, that desisted being overcome: (IB:) and also, (assumed tropical:) in running: or in watering. (S.) Hence, fulaAnN yusaAjilu fulaAnFA (tropical:) Such a one vies with such a one, each of them producing, [of the evidences] of nobility, the like of what the other produces; the one, of them, that desists being overcome. (IB.) El-Fadl Ibn- 'Abbás Ibn-'Otbeh Ibn-Abee-Lahab says,
mano yusaAjiloniI yusaAjilo maAjidFA
yamolaOu AldRalowa UilaI Eaqodi Alkarabo
[He who contends for superiority with me contends for superiority with one possessing glory, who fills the bucket to the tying of the rope that is attacked to the middle of its cross-bars]: and hence the saying, AlHarobu sijaAlN. (S. [See sajolN.])

4 Asjlhu c
4. Asjlhu He gave him a bucketful (sajolFA) or two bucketfuls (sajolayoni): (K:) or, as some say, (assumed tropical:) he gave him much. (TA.) ― -b2- And Asjl AlHawoDa He filled the watering-trough, or tank; (S, K;) as also sajalahu↓. (JM.) ― -b3- Ousojilati Albahiymapu maEa OumRihaA The beast was sent forth, or set loose or free, with its mother. (TA.) It is said in a trad., laA tusojiluwA OanoEaAmakumo, meaning Set not loose your cattle in men's fields of seed-produce. (TA.) ― -b4- And you say, Asjl AlnRaAsa He left, or left alone, the people. (K.) ― -b5- And Asjl lahumu AlOamora (assumed tropical:) He made the affair free, or allowable, to them. (K.) ― -b6- And Oasojalotu AlkalaAma (assumed tropical:) I made the speech, or language, to be unrestricted. (S.) ＝ -A2- Asjl He (a man, TA) abounded in goodness, (K, TA,) and beneficence, and gifts to men. (TA.) ＝ -A3- Oasojalotu lilrRajuli, inf. n. UisojaAlN, I wrote a writing for the man. (Msb.) ― -b2- See also 2.

6 tsAjlwA c
6. tsAjlwA They vied, competed, or contended for superiority, one with another; emulated, or rivalled, one another; or imitated one another; [originally, in the drawing of water: and hence, (assumed tropical:) in other things: (see 3:)] (S, TA:) and humaA yatasaAjalaAni They two vie, &c., each with the other. (K.)

7 Ansjl c
7. Ansjl It (water) poured out, or forth; or became poured out, or forth; (S, K;) [app., continuously: see 1.]

sajolN c
sajolN A full bucket: so accord. to Az and ElFárábee and others: (MS:) or a bucket containing water, whether little or much: such as is empty is not called sajolN nor canuwbN: (S:) or a great bucket: (Msb: [see also sajiylN:]) or a great bucket that is full (K, TA) of water: (TA:) and a bucketful; the quantity that fills a bucket: (K:) it is of the masc. gender [though dalowN (the most common word for “ a bucket ”) is generally fem.]: (S, K:) pl. sijaAlN. (S.) ― -b2- And [hence,] (assumed tropical:) A share, or portion; (Msb;) like dalaApN [which likewise originally signifies “ a bucket ”]. (S in art. dlw. [See also sajiylN.]) And hence is derived the saying, AlHarobu sijaAlN, [as though meaning (assumed tropical:) War is an affair of shares, or portions;] i. e. the victory in war is shared by turns among the people [engaged therein]: (Msb:) [but it is implied in the S that it is from AlmusaAjalapu, and that sijaAlN is here an inf. n. like musaAjalapN, agreeably with analogy; and if so, the saying may be rendered war is a contention for superiority: (see 3:)] or the saying AlHarobu bayonahumo sijaAlN means (assumed tropical:) [War between them consists of portions, in such a manner that] a sajol [or portion] thereof is against these, and another is against these: (K:) originating from the act of two men drawing water with two buckets from a well, each of them having [in his turn] a full bucket. (TA.) You say also, OaEoTaAhu sajolahu mino kacaA (tropical:) He gave him his share, or portion, of such a thing; like as one says, canuwbahu. (Har p. 19.) The phrase sajolN sajiylN↓ in the saying lahumo mina Almajodi sajolN sajiylN (K, * TA) has an intensive signification; (K, TA;) [the saying app. meaning (assumed tropical:) They have, of glory, a large share.] ― -b3- Hence likewise, metaphorically applied to signify (tropical:) A gift: one says jawaAdN EaZiymu AlsRajoli (tropical:) [A bountiful man who is large in gift]. (Har ibid. [The first word in this saying is there written jwRAd.]) One says also, lahu birRN faAYiDu AlsRijaAli (assumed tropical:) [He has overflowing goodness or beneficence]. (TA.) ― -b4- Also (assumed tropical:) A bountiful man. (Abu-l-' Omeythil, K.) ― -b5- And (assumed tropical:) A great udder: pl. sijaAlN and sujuwlN. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also sijilRN, in two places.

sijolN c
sijolN: see the next paragraph.

sijilRN c
sijilRN A writing; or paper, or piece of skin, written upon; (K, * TA;) as also sujulRN (TA) and sijolN↓ (K, TA) [and sajolN↓, as appears from what follows]: or a TuwmaAr [meaning a roll, or scroll, or the like,] for writing upon or written upon: (Bd in xxi. 104:) and a written statement of a contract and the like; (K, TA;) i. e. (TA) i. q. SakRN: (S, TA: [but see this word, which has also other meanings, and among them that here following, which is the most common meaning of sijilRN:]) the record of a kádee, or judge, in which his sentence is written; (Msb;) a judicial record: (Mgh:) [see also maHoDarN:] pl. sijilRaAtN. (Msb, K.) kaTaIRi AlsRijilRi lilokitaAbi, in the Kur xxi. 104, means Like the folding of the TuwmaAr [expl. above] for the purpose of writing [thereon]: or for what is to be written: (Bd:) or upon what is written; (Bd, * Jel;) i. e., upon the written record [of the works] of the son of Adam at his death: (Jel:) or AlsRijilR here has the third of the meanings here following: (Bd, Jel:] or the second thereof. (Bd.) ― -b2- And A writer, or scribe: (K:) and so some explain it in the verse above cited. (TA.) ― -b3- And AlsRijilRu A certain scribe of the Prophet. (K.) ― -b4- And A certain angel, (K,) who folds the written statements of [men's] works. (Bd ubi suprà.) ― -b5- And, without the article, A man, in the Abyssinian language. (K.) In the verse cited above, I' Ab read AlsRajoli↓, and explained it as meaning A certain man: but it is also said to mean a certain angel: and another reading is AlsRujulRi, a dial. var. mentioned above. (TA.)

AlsRijaAlu c
AlsRijaAlu a name for The ewe. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.) ― -b2- And sijaAl sijaAl [i. e. sijaAlo sijaAlo, so in my MS. copy of the K, but in the CK sijAli sijAli,] is A call to the ewe to be milked. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, K.)

sajuwlN c
sajuwlN A she-goat abounding in milk: thus correctly, as in the O: in the copies of the K, in the place of EanozN is put EayonN [making the meaning to be a spring abounding in water or an eye abounding in tears]. (TA.)

sajiylN c
sajiylN, applied to a bucket (dalow), Large, or big; as also with p: (K:) or sajiylapN↓ [alone, i. e. as a subst., rendered such by the affix p,] signifies a large, or big, bucket. (S.) ― -b2- And, applied to an udder (DaroE), Long: (S:) or pendent and wide; as also Oasojalu↓: (K:) or this latter, applied to an udder, but only of a sheep or goat, wide, flaccid, and tossing about; striking the animal's hind legs, from behind. (ISh, TA.) ― -b3- And, with p, applied to a testicle (xuSoyap), Flaccid and wide in the scrotum. (K.) ― -b4- See also sajolN. ― -b5- Also Hard, and strong. (K.) ＝ -A2- And A share, or portion: (K:) IAar says, it is of the measure faEiylN from sajolN meaning “ a full bucket ” [and likewise “ a share, or portion ”]; but, he adds, it does not please me. (TA.)

sajaAlapN c
sajaAlapN, in a testicle, Flaccidity and wideness in the scrotum. (K.)

sajiylapN c
sajiylapN: see sajiylN.

sijRiylN c
sijRiylN Stones like lumps of dry, or tough, clay: arabicized from sanoG wa Gilo; (K, TA;) which are Pers. words, meaning “ stone and clay; ” the conjunction falling out in the arabicizing: (TA:) or baked clay: (Jel in xi. 84 and xv. 74 and cv. 4:) or stones (S, K) of clay (S) baked by the fire of Hell, whereon were inscribed the names of the people [for whom they were destined]: (S, K:) so in the Kur; as is indicated therein, in li. 33 and 34: (S:) or mino sajRiylK in the Kur means mino sijilRK, i. e. of what had been written [or decreed] for them, that they should be punished therewith; and sijRiyl means the same as sijRiyn, mentioned and expl. in the Kur lxxxiii. 8 and 9: (K:) AO says that mn sjRyl means many and hard; and that sijRiynN is syn. with sijRiylN in this sense: (TA:) it is also said to be from sijRiynN meaning Hell; the n being changed into l: (Bd in xi. 84:) also, to be from Oasojalotuhu meaning “ I sent forth him or it: ” or from Oasojalotu meaning “ I gave; ” and to be from AlsRajolu. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also i. q. daAYimN; and so sijRiyno [q. v.]. (L in art. sjn.)

sajanojalN c
sajanojalN A mirror: (S, K:) or a Chinese mirror: (MA:) [said to be] a Greek word (ruwmiIRN),
(S, K,) arabicized: (S:) and some say zajanojalN. (Az, TA.) [Pl., accord. to Freytag, sanaAjilu.] ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) Pieces such as are termed sabaAjilu, of silver; (K, * TA;) as being likened to the mirror. (TA.) ― -b3- And Gold. (K.) ― -b4- And Saffron. (K.)

Oasojalu c
Oasojalu: see sajiylN. ― -b2- sajolaMCu, [the fem.,] applied to a she-camel, (S, K,) means (assumed tropical:) Long in the udder: (S:) or big in the udder: pl. sujolN. (K.) ― -b3- And, applied to a woman, (assumed tropical:) Big in the posteriors: (K:) pl. as above. (TA.)

musojalN c
musojalN Allowed, or made allowable, to every one; (S, K;) not denied to any one. (S.) ― -b2- Mohammad Ibn-El-Hanafeeyeh said, in explaining the words of the Kur [lv. 60], halo jazaMCu QloUiHosaAni UilRaA QloUiHosaAnu [Shall the recompense of doing good be other than doing good?], hiIa musojalapN lilobarRi wa AlfaAjiri, meaning (assumed tropical:) It is unrestricted in its relation to the righteous and the unrighteous: a righteous person is not made to be conditionally intended thereby, exclusively of an unrighteous. (As, S, TA.) ― -b3- And one says, faEalonaAhu wa AldRahoru musojalN (assumed tropical:) [We did it when fortune was unrestricted], i. e., when no one feared any one. (K.)

1 sajma AldRamoEu c
1. sajma AldRamoEu, (S, K, JM,) aor.
sajuma
, (JM,) inf. n. sujuwmN and sijaAmN; (S, K;) and Ansjm↓; (S, JM;) The tears flowed: (JM:) or poured forth; (TA in explanation of the latter verb;) and so the latter verb said of water. (TA.) ― -b2- And sajama Eani AlOamori (tropical:) He held back from the thing, or affair, delaying to do it; (A, K, TA;) and shrank from it. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- sajamati AlEayonu damoEahaA, (S, K, *) aor.
sajuma
and
sajima
inf. n. sajomN and sujuwmN and sajamaAnN, The eye shed its tears in drops: or shed its tears, little or much: (K:) or poured forth its tears. (TA.) And in like manner, sajamati AlsRaHaAbapu AlmaMCa (tropical:) The cloud poured forth the water, (K, TA,) little or much: (K:) and AlsHAbp Asjmt↓ (assumed tropical:) The cloud rained continually; as also Avjmt: (IAar, TA:) and Asjmt AlsRamaMCu The sky poured forth [rain]; as also Avjmt. (S.) And sajamahu [He poured it forth, app. meaning either damoEahu or AlmaMCa]; and [so] Asjmhu↓; and [app. in an intensive sense] sjRmhu↓, inf. n. tasojiymN and tasojaAmN. (K: omitted in the TA.)

2 sajRama
2: see the last sentence above.

4 Oasojama
4: see 1, last two sentences.

7 Uinosajama
7: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- Ansjm AlkalaAmu (tropical:) The language was, or became, rightly, or regularly, ordered, arranged, or disposed. (TA.)

damoEN sajomN c
damoEN sajomN and sijaAmN↓ and sujuwmN↓ (TA) [are instances of inf. ns. used as epithets, (as is said in the TA of the first and second, to which the third is obviously similar,) meaning Tears flowing, or pouring forth: or the first may be more correctly rendered tears shed in drops, or simply shed, or poured forth].

sajamN c
sajamN Tears: (K:) or flowing tears. (TA.) ― -b2- And Water: (so in copies of the K:) i. e. the water of the sky: (TA:) or water that is apparent, or manifest. (CK.) ＝ -A2- Also The leaves of the [tree called] xilaAf [q. v.]; (K;) to which broad and long arrow-heads are likened. (TA.)

sijaAmN c
sijaAmN an inf. n. used as an epithet: see sajomN. (TA.)

EayonN sajuwmN c
EayonN sajuwmN [An eye shedding many tears]. (S, TA.) ― -b2- And saHaAbN sajuwmN (assumed tropical:) [Clouds pouring forth much rain; like sajRaAmN]. (TA.) ― -b3- And naAqapN sajuwmN (tropical:) A she-camel yielding much milk: (A, TA:) or that parts her hind legs on being milked, and raises her head: (K, TA: [in the CK, saEaTato is erroneously put for saTaEato:]) as also misojaAmN↓. (K.) ― -b4- rajulN sajuwmN Eani AlmakaArimi (tropical:) A man who shrinks from generous actions. (TA.)

sujuwmN c
sujuwmN: see sajomN. [As it is originally an inf. n., used as an epithet,] you say also OaEoyunN sujuwmN Eyes shedding tears in drops, or simply shedding tears, or pouring forth tears; i. q. sawaAjimN [pl. of saAjimapN↓ fem. of saAjimN↓, of which last, accord. to Freytag, sujumN is a pl.]. (TA.)

saHaAbN sajRaAmN c
saHaAbN sajRaAmN (assumed tropical:) Clouds pouring forth much rain. (TA. [See also sajuwmN.])

saAjimN c
saAjimN; and its fem., with p: see sujuwmN.

saAjuwmN c
saAjuwmN A certain dye. (K.)

Oasojamu c
Oasojamu A camel that does not utter the grumbling cry termed rugaMC: (S, TA:) or that does not bray clearly: (TA:) i. q. Oazoyamu. (K.)

misojaAmN c
misojaAmN: see sajuwmN.

OaroDN masojuwmapN c
OaroDN masojuwmapN (tropical:) Land watered by rain. (S, TA.)

1 sajanahu c
1. sajanahu, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
sajuna
, inf. n. sajonN, (S, Msb,) He imprisoned him. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] it is said in a trad., maA XaIoCN OaHaqRa biTuwli AlsRajoni mino lisaAnK (assumed tropical:) [There is not anything more deserving of long restraint than a tongue]. (L.) ― -b3- And sajana AlhamRa (tropical:) He secreted anxiety; did not reveal it. (L, K.) A poet says,
wa laA tasojunanRa AlhamRa UinRa lisajonihi
EanaMCF wa HamRilohu AlmahaAraI AlnRawaAjiyaA
(tropical:) [And by no means secrete thou anxiety: verily to the secreting thereof pertains embarrassment: but load with it fleet camels of Mahreh]. (L.)

2 sjRnhu c
2. sjRnhu, inf. n. tasojiynN, i. q. XaqRaqahu [He cut it, or divided it, lengthwise; clave it; split it; &c.]. (K.) ― -b2- And sjRn AlnRaxola He made the palmtrees to be such as are termed silotiyn [or sijRiyn; i. e. he dug at their feet trenches to conduct the water to them when it did not reach to them]. (K.)

sijonN c
sijonN A prison; (S, L, Msb, K;) as also sijRiynN↓: (L:) pl. of the former sujuwnN. (Mgh, Msb.)

sajiynN c
sajiynN is syn. with masojuwnN↓ [Imprisoned]; pl. sujanaMCu and sajonaI: and is applied to a female likewise, as also sajiynapN; pl. sajonaI and sajaAYinu. (K.)

sajRaAnN c
sajRaAnN The keeper of a prison. (K.)

sijRiynN c
sijRiynN: see sijonN. ― -b2- [In the Kur lxxxiii. 7,] A certain place in which is the record [of the deeds] of the wicked; (S, L, K;) or, as I 'Ab says, in which are their registers: AO says, it is of the measure fiERiylN from AlsRijonu, like AlfisRiyqu from Alfisoqu: (S, L:) or a certain valley in Hell: or a certain stone, [or rock,] (L, K,) beneath, (L,) or in, (K,) the seventh earth: (L, K:) [these explanations are given by those who hold that maA sijRiynN in the next verse is for maA kitaAbu sijRiynK:] or it there means a register comprising the deeds of the wicked, (Bd, Jel, *) of the jinn, or genii, and of mankind, (Bd,) or of the devils and the unbelievers: (Jel:) or mA sjRyn in the next verse is for mA ktAb sjRyn, and the meaning is the place, (Bd, Jel,) which is beneath the seventh earth, the abode of Iblees and his forces: (Jel:) IAth says, it occurs in a trad. with the article Al; and without that article it is a proper name for the fire [of Hell], and hence the mention of it in the Kur lxxxiii. 7. (L.) [See also sijRiylN.] ＝ -A2- Also Anything hard: (L:) and hard, vehement, or severe; (S, L, K;) applied to a beating. (S, L.) ― -b2- And Continuing, lasting, or everlasting; syn. daAYimN; (L, K;) as also sijRiylN: so accord. to El-Muärrij. (L. [See, again, sijRiylN.]) ＝ -A3- And i. q. EalaAniyap: (L, K:) so in the saying, Eamila celika sijRiynFA [He did that openly, or publicly]. (L.) ＝ -A4- Also Palm-trees (naxol) such as are termed silotiyn (As, L, K) in the dial. of the people of El-Bahreyn; (As, L;) [app. meaning that the latter word is of that dial.; for it is said that] the Arabs [app. the Arabs in general] say sijRiyn in the place of silotiyn, which is not Arabic: (L:) the palm-trees thus termed are such as have trenches dug at their feet to conduct the water to them when it has not reached to them. (L, and K in art. sltn.)

saAjuwnN c
saAjuwnN Iron such as is termed Oaniyv [i. e. female, meaning soft]. (L.)

masojanapN c
[masojanapN, accord. to Freytag, The act of imprisoning: but it seems rather to be a word of the class of maboxalapN and majobanapN &c., and to signify a cause of imprisonment.]

masojuwnN c
masojuwnN: see sajiynN.

1 sajaA c
1. sajaA, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) aor. yasojuw, (S, Msb,) inf. n. sujuwRN (S, K, TA) and sajowN, (TA,) said of the night, (Fr, IAar, Msb, TA,) &c., (TA,) It was, or became, silent, quiet, or still: (Fr, IAar, S, K, TA:) and dark: (Fr, TA:) or its darkness became extended: (IAar, TA:) or it covered, or concealed, by its darkness. (Msb, TA.) wa QllRayoli UicaA sajaA, in the Kur [xciii. 2], means And the night when it becomes still, silent, or quiet:
(IAar, Zj, S, Jel:) or when it covers with its darkness: (Jel:) or when its people become silent: or when its darkness becomes still: from sajaA AlbaHoru, inf. n. sujuwRN, The sea became calm. (Bd.) And one says, sajati AlrRiyHu The wind became still. (TA.) ― -b2- sajati AlnRaAqapu The she-camel prolonged her Haniyn [or cry of yearning towards her young one]. (K.) ― -b3- See also 2.

2 sjRI c
2. sjRI He covered anything; as also AsjI↓, and sajaA↓. (IAar, TA.) You say, sjRI AlmayRita, (S, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. tasojaypN, (S, Mgh, K,) He covered the dead person (Mgh, Msb, K) with a garment, or piece of cloth, (Mgh, Msb,) and the like. (Msb.)

3 sAjAhu c
3. sAjAhu, (K,) inf. n. musaAjaApN, (TA,) He touched it. (K.) One says, OataAnaA biTaEaAmK famaA saAjayonaAhu i. e. [He brought us food, and] we did not touch it. (AZ, TA.) ― -b2- And i. q. EaAlajahu [meaning He worked, or laboured, upon it, or at it; &c.]. (K.) One says, halo tusaAjiI DayoEapF i. e. tuEaAlijuhaA [meaning Dost thou work, or labour, upon a landed estate? or, probably, dost thou cultivate a landed estate by the work, or labour, of others?]. (Aboo-Málik, TA.)

4 Oasojawa
4: see 2. ＝ -A2- Asjt AlnRaAqapu The she-camel had much milk. (Sgh, K.)

sajiIRN c
[sajiIRN A sincere companion and friend. (Golius, from Meyd.)]

sajiyRapN c
sajiyRapN A nature; or a natural, a native, or an innate, disposition or temper or the like; syn. xuluqN, and TabiyEapN, (S,) or gariyzapN: (Msb:) or a faculty, or quality, firmly rooted in the mind, not easy of removal: (MF:) pl. sajaAyaA. (Msb.)

naAqapN sajowaMCu c
naAqapN sajowaMCu A she-camel still, or quiet, when being milked. (M, K.) ― -b2- And A she-camel whose fur is unruffled: and XaApN sajowaMCu a sheep whose wool is unruffled. (TA.) ― -b3- And riyHN sajowaMCu A gentle wind. (TA.) ― -b4- And AimoraOapN sajowaMCu AlTRarofi i. e. saAjiyatuhu↓, (K,) meaning A woman languid, or languishing, in the eye. (TA.)

saAjK c
saAjK Still, silent, or quiet: thus applied to the sea [as meaning calm, or unruffled]. (S, K.) And layolapN saAjiyapN A calm night, in which the wind is still, and such as is not dark: (T, TA:) or a night in which the cold has become allayed, and in which the wind and the clouds have become still, and which is not dark. (M, TA.) And TarofN saAjK A still, or motionless, eye: (S, K:) [or] EayonN saAjiyapN, accord. to IAar, means an eye that has a languid, or languishing, look; which is an accessory to beauty in women. (TA.) See also the next preceding paragraph.

1 saHRa c
1. saHRa, (S, A, TA,) aor.
saHuHa
, (S, TA,) inf. n. saHRN, (S, K, &c.,) He poured out, or forth, (S, A, K,) water, (S, A,) &c.: (S:) or, accord. to IDrd, saHRN signifies the pouring out, or forth, in consecutive quantities: or, accord. to the Msb, [but this art. is not in my copy of that work,] the pouring forth much, or abundantly; and the like is said in the Jámi' of Kz. (TA.) You say also, saHRati AlsRamaMCu maTarahaA [The sky poured forth its rain]. (A, TA.) See also an ex. of the inf. n. voce saHRaMCu, below. ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, AisotanoXadotuhu qaSiydapF fasaHRahaA EalaIRa (tropical:) [I asked him to recite an ode, and he poured it forth to me; lit., upon me], inf. n. as above. (A.) ― -b3- [Hence likewise,] saHRN signifies also (assumed tropical:) The act of flogging. (K, TA.) One says, saHRahu miAYapa sawoTK, (S, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He inflicted upon him a hundred stripes of a whip. (S, TA.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) The act of beating, striking, or smiting. (K.) ― -b5- And (assumed tropical:) The act of thrusting or piercing [with a spear or the like]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- saHRa, (S, A,) aor.
saHuHa
, (S,) so says Fei, or, accord. to some,
saHiHa
, agreeably with analogy, (TA,) inf. n. saHRN (S, K) and suHuwHN, (K,) or the former is the inf. n. of the trans. verb, and the latter is that of the intrans., (MF,) It flowed from above; (S, K;) [i. e. it flowed down;] said of water, (S,) and of rain, and of tears; (S, A;) as also tasaHosaHa↓ and tsHRH↓: (K:) or saHRa signifies, or signifies also, it poured out, or forth, vehemently: (TA:) and tsHsH↓, it flowed; said of water, (S, TA,) and of a thing. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] saHRati AlXRaApu, (S, A, TA,) and Albaqarapu, (TA,) aor. tasiHRu, (S, TA,) or, accord. to Lh and Z, tasuHRu, (TA,) inf. n. saHRN, (K,) or suHuwHN, (S, A,) or both, (TA,) and suHuwHapN, (S, Ibn-Et-Teiyánee, TA,) (tropical:) The sheep or goat, and the animal of the ox-kind, became fat: (AZ, AHn, S, TA:) or became fat to the utmost degree: (K:) or became fat so as to flow with grease: (A:) or became fat, but not to the utmost degree. (TA.)

5 tasaHRaRa
5: see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph.

7 AnsHR EaraqFA c
7. AnsHR EaraqFA It (a camel's arm-pit) poured with sweat. (TA.)

R. Q. 2 tasaHosaHa c
R. Q. 2. tasaHosaHa: see 1, latter half, in two places.

saHRN c
saHRN Rain pouring abundantly and extensively: (K in art. sbT:) and saHosaAHN↓ (S, K) and saHosaHN↓ (K) rain pouring vehemently, (S, K, * TA,) paring the surface of the earth: (TA:) and saHuwHN↓, applied to rain that falls in large drops, pouring much, or abundantly; and also applied to a thundering cloud, (HanRaAnapN, i. e. saHaAbapN fiyhaA raEodN, [or, accord. to the S and A, to any cloud, saHaAbap,]) pouring forth much rain: (Ham p. 391: [in which it is said that in the latter case it may be proper; and in the former case, tropical:]) and EayonN saHosaAHapN↓, so in a copy of the K, [and thus in my MS. copy of it,] in other copies saHRaAHapN↓, but the former is the right, (TA,) an eye pouring forth tears abundantly, or much: (K, TA:) and TaEonapN musaHosiHapN↓ (S, TA) [a spear-wound, or the like,] flowing [with blood]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] HalifN saHRN (assumed tropical:) A swearing in which oaths pour forth consecutively. (L.) ＝ -A2- Also (assumed tropical:) i. q. qasobN [i. e. Dry, or tough, dates, that crumble in the mouth and have hard stones]; (K:) Az relates his having heard the Bahránees thus term a certain kind of qasob: (TA:) or (tropical:) scattered dates: (A:) or (tropical:) dry, or tough, dates, (K, TA,) not sprinkled with water [in order that they may stick together, for thus they do for this purpose, or they sprinkle the palm-leaf-receptacle of the dates for this purpose], (TA,) scattered (K, TA) upon the ground, not collected in a receptacle, and not packed; (TA;) as also suHRN↓, (IDrd, K,) which is of the dial. of El-Yemen. (IDrd.)

suHRN c
suHRN: see what next precedes.

saHaAHN c
saHaAHN The air. (Fr, T, O, K.) [See also sujaAHN, which is perhaps a mistranscription.]

saHuwHN c
saHuwHN: see saHRN.

saHRaMCu c
saHRaMCu a fem. epithet, an instance of faEolaMCu having no OafoEalu, [i. e. not having OasaHRu for the masc. form], occurring in a trad., in which it is said, (TA,) yamiynu QllRehi saHRaMCu laA yagiyDuhaA XaIoCN QllRayola wa QlnRahaAra (A, TA) i. e. (tropical:) The right hand of God is continually pouring with gifts, nothing will render it deficient, night and day: or, as some relate it, the phrase is yamiynu QllRehi maloOaI saHRFA↓ [the right hand of God is full, with pouring forth]; the last word being with tenween, as an inf. n.: it is thus likened to the abundant source that is not diminished by drawing from it, nor by descending into it and filling the bucket. (TA.) ― -b2- You say also gaArapN saHRaMCu (A, TA) (tropical:) [An incursion into the territory of an enemy] that pours calamity upon people with sudden impetuosity. (TA.) ― -b3- [Golius explains saHRaMCu, on the authority of Meyd, as signifying (assumed tropical:) A hot wind: it is probably a mistranscription for saxonaMCu.]

saHRaAHapN c
saHRaAHapN: see saHRN.

saHosaHN c
saHosaHN: see saHRN. ― -b2- Also, applied to land (OaroDN), (assumed tropical:) Wide, or spacious: but IDrd says, I know not the truth of this. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, and saHosaHapN↓, A court, or a spacious portion in which is no building or that is vacant, of a house, (S, K, TA,) and of a place of alighting, or of a settlement, or of a collection of houses or tents: the former expl. by IAar as meaning a man's quarter, or tract, in which he alights. (TA.)

saHosaHapN c
saHosaHapN: see what next precedes.

saHosaAHN c
saHosaAHN; and its fem., with p: see saHRN: ― -b2- and see also the fem. in what here follows.

XaApN saAHRN c
XaApN saAHRN, (A, K,) after the manner of a possessive noun, (TA,) and saAHRapN, (K,) the latter occurring in a trad., or, as some relate it, saHosaAHapN↓, which means the same, (TA,) (tropical:) A sheep, or goat, that is fat: (S, TA: but in the former, only a pl., as applied to sheep or goats, is mentioned; namely, the first of the pls. below:) or that flows with grease by reason of its fatness: (A:) or full of fat: (TA:) or fat in the utmost degree: (K:) [or fat, but not in the utmost degree; for] one says mahozuwlN; then manoqK when it has become a little
fat; then XanuwnN; then samiynN; then saAHRN; and then muvaroTimN, which means fat in the utmost degree: (Aboo-Ma'add El-Kilábee, TA:) pl. suHRaAHN, (Th, S, L,) thus in the handwriting of J, and mentioned by Aboo-Mis-hal, (TA,) or siHaAHN (IKtt, K) and suHaAHN, which is extr. [in form]. (K.) And laHomN saAHRN (assumed tropical:) Fat flesh-meant; as though, by reason of its fatness, it poured forth grease. (As, S, TA.)

farasN misaHRN c
farasN misaHRN (tropical:) A swift horse; (Kz, K, TA;) as though it poured forth running; (S, Kz, TA;) likened to rain in swiftness. (TA.)

TaEonapN musaHosiHapN c
TaEonapN musaHosiHapN: see saHRN.

1 saHabahu c
1. saHabahu, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
saHaba
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. saHobN, (Msb, TA,) He dragged it, or drew it along, (S, A, Msb, K,) namely, his cayol [or skirt], (S,) or a thing, such as a garment &c., (TA,) upon the ground. (Msb, K, TA.) One says of a woman, tasoHabu cayolahaA [She drags, or draws along, her skirt upon the ground]. (TA.) And saHabati AlriyHu AltRuraAba [The wind drew along the dust upon the ground]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] saHabati AlrRiyaAHu OacoyaAlahaA (tropical:) [The winds dragged their skirts upon the ground; i. e., blew so as to efface the traces upon the ground]. (A: in the TA, AlrRiyHu.) And AisoHabo cayolaka EalaI maA kaAna minRiI (tropical:) [Drag thy skirt over that which has proceeded from me; i. e. efface what has proceeded from me, as when a person dragging his skirt effaces the traces upon the sand or dust over which he walks]. (A, TA.) And maA QsotaboqaI rajulN wudRa SaAHibihi bimivoli maA saHaba AlcRayola EalaI maEaAyibihi (tropical:) [A man has not preserved, or kept alive, the love, or affection, of his companion with anything that is in its effect like his dragging the skirt over his vices, or faults]. (A, TA.) ― -b3- [Hence like wise, as will be shown by what next follows,] saHaba, aor.
saHaba
, (K, TA,) inf. n. as above, (S, TA,) means also (tropical:) He ate and drank vehemently. (S, K, TA.)

4 OasoHabotu mina AlTRaEaAmi wa AlXRaraAbi c
4. OasoHabotu mina AlTRaEaAmi wa AlXRaraAbi (tropical:) I took, or ate and drank, much of the food and beverage; as also tasaHRabotu↓: because it is the habit of the glutton to draw and appropriate to himself the victuals [and beverages]. (A, TA.)

5 tasaHRaba
5: see 4. ― -b2- tsHRb Ealayohi (assumed tropical:) He acted, or behaved, towards him with boldness, or presumptuousness; or did so confiding in his love, or affection: (Az, S, MA, TA:) or with coquettishness, and feigned opposition. (Az, * MA, TA. *) ― -b3- tasaHRabato fiI HaqRihi, occurring in a trad. of Sa'eed and [a woman named] Arwà, means (assumed tropical:) She took his right, or rightful property, by force, and annexed it to her own, and to her land. (TA.)

7 AnsHb c
7. AnsHb It was, or became, dragged, or drawn along, (S, A, Msb, K,) upon the ground: (Msb, K:) said of one's skirt, (S,) or of a thing, such as a garment &c. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AinosaHabato fiyhaA calaAcilu AlrRiyHi (tropical:) [The skirts of the wind were, or became, dragged upon it, i. e., upon the ground (AlOaroD), so as to efface the traces upon it]. (A, TA.)

suHobapN c
suHobapN i. q. giXaAwapN [app. as meaning particularly A covering, or film, upon the eye: expl. by Freytag, from the Deewán el-Hudhaleeyeen, as meaning oculorum caligo]. (K.) ― -b2- And Remains of water in a pool left by a torrent; as also suHaAbapN↓: (K, TA:) dim. of the former suHayobapN↓. (TA.)

rajulN saHobaAnu c
rajulN saHobaAnu A man who takes, or carries, or sweeps, away everything by which he passes. (K.) ― -b2- [Golius explains saHobaAnN, as on the authority of Meyd, as meaning A portion of water remaining in a skin or other thing: but I think that this is a mistranscription for suHobapN.]

saHaAbN c
saHaAbN [termed in the S and K pl. of saHaAbapN, as also suHubN and saHaAYibu,] is, accord. to As, [correctly,] a coll. gen. n., used alike as masc. and fem. and sing. and pl.; (MF, TA;) and saHaAbapN is its n. un.; (MF, Msb, * TA;) and suHubN is pl. of saHaAbN or of saHaAbapN; (L, Msb, * MF, TA;) it may be pl. of either of these; (L, MF, TA;) and saHaAYibu is pl. of saHaAbapN absolutely, and of saHaAbN when used as fem.: (MF, TA:) it signifies Clouds [or a collection of clouds]; (S, K, KL, TA, &c.;) and [clouds] from which the rain comes: (TA:) so called because drawn along in the air; (Msb, TA;) or because they draw along one another; or because the winds draw them along; (TA;) or because they draw along their fringes. (TA in art. Hbw.) One says, maTaratohumu AlsRaHaAbapu [The cloud rained upon them]. (A.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Oaqamotu Einodahu saHaAbapa nahaAriI (tropical:) I remained at his abode the whole of my day: originally said in relation to a cloudy day; and then proverbially used in relation to any day. (A, TA.) And maA zilotu OafoEaluhu saHaAbapa yawomiI (tropical:) I ceased not to do it the whole of my day. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- maMCu AlsRaHaAbi [properly The water of the clouds] is a term for (assumed tropical:) wine. (TA in art. jfn.) ― -b4- AlsRaHaAbu is a name of (assumed tropical:) The Prophet's turban; (Mgh, TA:) it was thus called as being likened to the sHAb of the rain because of its being drawn along in the air. (TA.) ― -b5- Also the name of A sword of Dirar Ibn-El-Khattáb. (K.)

saHaAbapN c
saHaAbapN n. un. of saHaAbN [q. v.]. (As, Msb, &c.)

suHaAbapN c
suHaAbapN: see suHobapN.

suHayobapN c
suHayobapN dim. of suHobapN, q. v. (TA.)

OusoHuwbN c
OusoHuwbN (tropical:) A man who eats and drinks much, (S, A,) or vehemently: (K:) Az says that the word known to him in the former sense is OusoHuwtN, with t; but that perhaps AsHwb is allowable. (L, TA.)

masoHabN c
[masoHabN A place of dragging, or drawing along, of a skirt, or garment, &c., upon the ground: pl. masaAHibu: see Har p. 78.]

1 saHatahu c
1. saHatahu, [aor.
saHata
, inf. n. saHotN,] He extirpated it, eradicated it, exterminated it, or destroyed it utterly; as also AsHthu↓: (S, K, TA:) both signify he, or it, made it to go, go away, pass away, or depart; made away with it, did away with it, made an end of it, or destroyed it; namely, a man's property: and the latter, he destroyed utterly what he (a man) possessed. (TA.) You say, saHata AlxitaAna, inf. n. as above; and AsHthu↓; He performed the circumcision so as to remove the prepuce utterly. (TA.) And saHata XaEarahu He removed his hair utterly in shaving and cutting: (A:) and saHata raOosahu, inf. n. as above; and AsHthu↓; He shaved his head so as to remove the hair utterly. (Lh, TA.) And saHata AlXRaHoma Eani AllRaHomi, (aor. as above, K,) He peeled off the fat from the flesh; (S, A, K;) as also saHafahu. (S.) And saHata XayoYFA, aor. and inf. n. as above, He peeled, or peeled off, a thing by little and little. (L, TA.) And saHata wajoha AlOaroDi He, or it, effaced the traces, or the like, upon the surface of the earth. (A, TA.) fayasoHatakumo biEacaAbK, in the Kur xx. 64, means Lest He destroy you [by a punishment], (Bd, Jel,) or utterly destroy you; (Bd;) and some read fayusoHitakumo↓, (S, Bd, Jel,) which means the same; (Bd, Jel;) this being of the dial. of Nejd and Temeem; and the former, of the dial. of El-Hijáz: (Bd:) or (tropical:) lest He harass, or distress, or afflict, you [by a punishment]: (A, TA:) or (assumed tropical:) lest He pare you [from the surface of the earth thereby]. (TA.) saHatonaAhumo and OasoHatonaAhumo↓ both signify (tropical:) We harassed, or distressed, or afflicted, them: and saHatahumo [and OasoHatahumo↓], He slaughtered them. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also the next paragraph, in two places.

4 OasoHata
4: see above, in six places. ― -b2- [Hence,] OusoHita, said of a man, (assumed tropical:) His property went away. (Lh, TA.) ＝ -A2- AsHt He gained, or earned, what is termed suHot [i.e. gain that was unlawful, &c.]; (S, A, K;) as also saHata↓: (K:) or he earned little. (Msb.) You say, AsHt fiI tijaAratihi He earned such gain in his traffic; (S, A;) as also fiyhaA saHata↓: (TA:) or he earned little therein; and so AsHt tijaAratahu. (Msb.) And AsHtt tijaAratuhu His traffic was, or became, disapproved, abominable, or foul, and unlawful. (K.)

saHotN c
saHotN inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (L, TA.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) Vehemence of eating and drinking. (TA.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) Punishment, castigation, or chastisement. (TA.) ― -b4- barodN saHotN, (K,) [as also saxotN, q. v.,] and baHotN, and laHotN, (TA,) [and laxotN,] i. q. SaAdiqN [i. e. (assumed tropical:) Vehement, or intense, cold: see baHotN &c.]. (K.) ― -b5- See also suHotuwtN: ― -b6- and masoHuwtN: ― -b7- and see the paragraph here following, in two places.

suHotN c
suHotN (S, A, Msb, K) and suHutN↓, (S, Msb, K,) the former a contraction of the latter, (Msb,) A thing that is forbidden, prohibited, or unlawful; (S, A, K;) and (so in the A, but in the K “ or ”) what is disapproved, abominable, or foul, of gains, (A, K, TA,) that occasions disgrace (K, TA) and bad repute; as the price of a dog, and of wine, and of a pig; (TA;) any pro-
perty that is forbidden, not lawful to be gained (Msb, TA) nor to be eaten; (Msb;) anything forbidden, or unlawful, and of bad repute: sometimes it means what is disapproved; and sometimes, what is unlawful; the context showing in which sense it is used: and it is also applied to signify a bribe that is given to a judge or the like: so called because it cuts off blessing: (TA:) in the Kur v. 46, some read lilsRuHoti; and some, lilsRuHuti; (Bd, TA;) and it has also been read as the inf. n., lilsRaHoti↓: (Bd:) the pl. is OasoHaAtN. (K.) ― -b2- Also Little, or small, in quantity or number; paltry, mean, or inconsiderable. (Msb.) ― -b3- maAluhu suHotN or saHotN↓ (accord. to different copies of the K [the former the better known]) His property may be taken and destroyed with impunity: and in like manner, damuhu sHt His blood may be shed with impunity. (K, * TA.) ― -b4- See also masoHuwtN.

suHutN c
suHutN: see the next preceding paragraph.

saHotiIRN c
saHotiIRN: see what next follows.

suHotuwtN c
suHotuwtN An old and worn-out garment or piece of cloth; as also saHotN↓ and saHotiIRN↓. (K.) ― -b2- [A mess of] sawiyq [or meal of parched barley, &c.,] having little grease or gravy [mixed with it]; as also siHotiytN↓; (K;) the latter a dial. var. of sixotiytN [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b3- And A desert (mafaAzapN) of which the earth is soft. (K.)

siHotiytN c
siHotiytN: see the next preceding paragraph.

saHiytN c
saHiytN: see masoHuwtN, in two places. ― -b2- saHaAbapN saHiytapN A cloud that carries away, or sweeps away, that by which it passes. (TA.)

EaAmN OasoHatu c
EaAmN OasoHatu, and OaroDN saHotaMCu, (assumed tropical:) A year, and a land, in which is no pasture. (K.)

OusoHuwtN c
OusoHuwtN: see the following paragraph.

musoHatN c
musoHatN: see the following paragraph.

masoHuwtN c
masoHuwtN (assumed tropical:) Property (maAlN) made to go away, or depart; made away with, made an end of, or destroyed; as also musoHatN↓, (S, K,) as in a verse cited voce mujalRafN, (S,) and suHotN↓ and saHiytN↓. (K.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A man who eats and drinks vehemently; as also saHotN↓ and saHiytN↓: (TA in the present art.:) and OusoHuwtN↓ signifies [the same, or] a man who eats and drinks much., (Az, TA voce OusoHuwbN, q. v.) And masoHuwtu Aljawofi (assumed tropical:) A man (S) who does not become satiated: (S, K:) having a capacious belly, (K, TA,) and who does not become satiated with food: (TA:) and as some say, hungry: (TA:) and one who suffers much from indigestion. (K, TA.) And masoHuwtu AlmaEidapi (tropical:) A man having a greedy, or gluttonous, stomach. (A, TA.)

1 saHajahu c
1. saHajahu, (S, A, K, TA,) aor.
saHaja
, (K, TA,) inf. n. saHojN, (TA,) He abraded, or otherwise removed, its outer integument, or superficial part; (S, A, K, TA;) relating to one's skin: (S, A, TA:) and he scratched him; or wounded him in the outer skin: also he rubbed it, namely, a thing, with another thing, so as to abrade, or remove, its superficial part: and it, namely, a thing, hitting another thing, abraded from it a little of its superficial part; as when a thing hits the solid hoof previously to [that state of attenuation and abrasion which is termed] AlwajaI. (TA.) You say, saHajotu jilodahu I abraded, or removed, the outer integument [i. e. the cuticle] of his skin. (S.) And OaSaAbahu XaIoCN fasaHaja wajohahu [A thing hit him, and abraded the cuticle of his face]. (S.) And saHaja AlEuwda biAlmiboradi He abraded the outer part of the wood, or piece of wood, or stick, with the file. (TA.) And yasoHaju AlOaroDa bixufRihi, referring to a camel, (S, K, TA,) He pares the surface of the ground with his foot, so that he is not slow in becoming attenuated and abraded in the sole. (TA.) And saHajati AlrRiyaAHu AlOaroDa [The winds pared the surface of the earth, removing the dust and pebbles: like sahajat]. (A.) ― -b2- Also He bit him so as to make a mark, or marks, upon him; [or so as to lacerate his skin;] used especially in relation to wild asses; and so sHRjhu↓, [but in an intensive sense, i. e. he so bit him much, or many times, (see musaHRajN,)] inf. n. tasoHiyjN and musaHRajN [of which latter see an ex. in the next paragraph]. (TA.) ― -b3- also signifies The combing gently upon the skin of the head: (K, TA:) [combing the hair with a gentle pressure upon the skin of the head:] one says, saHaja XaEarahu biAlmuXoTi, inf. n. saHojN, He combed his hair [pressing the comb] gently [upon the skin of his head]. (TA.) ― -b4- And The going quickly [as though paring the surface of the earth with the feet, or making marks upon it]. (O, K.) You say, marRa yasoHaju He passed along going quickly: and [so] yasoHaju AlsRayora. (O, TA.) ― -b5- And A running of beasts falling short of such as is vehement. (K.) ― -b6- And [hence, app.,] saHaja AlOayomaAna, (TA,) aor. as above, (K, TA,) (assumed tropical:) He made the oaths to follow one another with little, or no, interruption. (K, * TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 7.

2 sHRjhu c
2. sHRjhu, (S, K,) inf. n. tasoHiyjN and musaHRajN, [of which latter, see an ex. in what follows,] (TA,) He abraded, or otherwise removed, its outer integument, or superficial part, much, or often. (S, K.) ― -b2- See also 1. An ex. of the latter inf. n. occurs in the following hemistich of the “ Jeemeeyeh ” of El-'Ajjáj:
jaOobaA taraI biliyitihi musaHRajaA
[A bulky, or strong, wild ass, in the side of whose neck thou seest much biting, or lacerating of the skin, that has made marks upon it]: thus heard by AHát from the mouth of AZ, and thus recited by the former to As, who disallowed it, and said, taliylahu [i. e. whose neck, or cheek, thou seest to be much bitten, &c., instead of biliyitihi], but abstained from objecting after AHát had adduced other exs. [of similar inf. ns.], and among them the saying in the Kur [xxxiv. 18], wa mazRaqonaAhumo kulRa mumazRaqK: Az says that msHRjA is here made an inf. n., like tasoHiyjFA. (TA)

5 tsHRj c
5. tsHRj It had its outer integument, or superficial part, abraded, or otherwise removed, much, or often: (S, K:) said of the skin [&c.]. (S.)

7 AnsHj c
7. AnsHj It had its outer integument, or superficial part, abraded, or otherwise removed: (S, K:) said of the skin: (S:) [and it seems from the phrase saHaju Alfaxicayoni occurring in the O and K in art. bcH, that saHija↓, inf. n. saHajN, may signify the same: but saHaju may there be a mistranscription for saHoju.] One says, AinosaHaja jiloduhu mino XaIoCK marRa bihi His skin had its cuticle abraded in consequence of a thing that passed by him. (TA.)

saHojN c
saHojN inf. n. of saHaja. (TA.) ― -b2- And [hence, Dysentery, or the like; because attended by abrasion, or excoriation, of the colon;] a certain disease of the bowels; (PS;) an abrading disease in the belly. (TA.) You say, bihi saHojN (S) i. e. In him is the disease above mentioned. (PS.)

saHuwjN c
saHuwjN: see saHRaAjN.

saHiyjN c
saHiyjN Having its outer integument, or superficial part, abraded, or otherwise removed; as also masoHuwjN↓. (TA.)

saHRaAjN c
saHRaAjN A camel that pares the surface of the ground with his foot, (S, * K, * TA,) so that he is not slow in becoming attenuated and abraded in the sole. (TA.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) A man who makes oaths to follow one another with little, or no, interruption: (TA:) and so misoHaAjN↓ and saHuwjN↓ applied to a woman. (K, * TA.) And HalifN saHRaAjN (assumed tropical:) A swearing in which the oaths are made so to follow one another. (TA.)

saAHijN c
[saAHijN act. part. n. of saHaja: fem. with p: pl. of the fem. sawaAHiju. Hence,] riyaAHN sawaAHiju [Winds paring, or that pare, the surface of the earth, removing the dust and pebbles]. (A, TA.)

masoHajN c
[masoHajN A place of abrasion, &c.: pl. masaAHiju. ― -b2- Hence,] one says, of an ass, (A,) i. e. a wild ass, (TA,) Ealayohi AlmasaAHiju Upon him are the marks, or scars, of the biting of other asses. (A, TA.)

misoHajN c
misoHajN The [instrument called] miboraAp with which one pares, or shapes, wood. (O, K.) ― -b2- [And hence, app., A rain that is as though it pared the surface of the earth. Accord. to Freytag, masoHajN occurs in this sense in the Deewán of Jereer: pl. masaAHiju: but the correct word is evidently misoHajN.] ― -b3- Also, and misoHaAjN↓, (O, K, TA,) A wild ass that bites [other asses] much, or frequently: (TA:) [or each signifies, though not so expl. in the TA,] an ass [i. e. a wild ass] that runs a pace falling short of such as is vehement. (O. K.)

musaHRajN c
musaHRajN An ass [i. e. a wild ass] much bitten. (S, A, K.) ― -b2- [See also 2.]

misoHaAjN c
misoHaAjN: see misoHajN: ― -b2- and see also saHRaAjN.

masoHuwjN c
masoHuwjN: see saHiyjN.

1 saHarahu c
1. saHarahu He, or it, hit, or hurt, his saHor [or lungs, &c.], (Mgh, TA,) or his suHorap [i. e. heart]. (TA.) ― -b2- And the same, aor.
saHara
, inf. n. siHorN, (T, TA,) [said to be] the only instance of a pret. and aor. and inf. n. of these measures except the verb faEala, aor. yafoEalu, inf. n. fiEolN, (MF,) (tropical:) He turned it, (T,) or him, (TA,) Eano wajohihi [from its, or his, course, or way, or manner of being]: and hence other significations here following. (T, TA. [Accord. to the T, this seems to be proper; but accord. to the A, tropical.]) In this sense the verb is used in the Kur xxiii. 91. (Fr.) The Arabs say to a man, maA saHaraka Eano wajohi kacaA wa kacaA (tropical:) What has turned thee from such and such a course? (Yoo.) Oufika and suHira are syn. [as meaning (tropical:) He was turned from his course &c.]. (TA.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) He turned him from hatred to love. (TA.) ― -b4- Hence, (TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (T, S, TA,) and inf. n. also saHorN, (KL, TA,) (tropical:) He enchanted, or fascinated, him, or it; (S, * K, * KL, PS;) and so sHRrhu↓ (MA, TA) [in an intensive or a frequentative sense, meaning he enchanted, or fascinated, him, or it, much, or (as shown by an explanation of its pass. part. n.) time after time]: and saHara Eayonahu He enchanted, or fascinated, his eye. (MA.) You say, saHara AlXRaIoCa Eano wajohihi, meaning (tropical:) He (an enchanter, saAHirN) apparently turned the thing from its proper manner of being, making what was false to appear in the form of the true, or real; causing the thing to be imagined different from what it really was. (T, TA. [See siHorN, below.]) And AlmaroOapu tasoHaru AlnRaAsa biEayonihaA (tropical:) [The woman enchants, or fascinates, men by her eye]. (A.) And saHarahu bikalaAmihi (assumed tropical:) He caused him, or enticed him, to incline to him by his soft, or elegant, speech, and by the beauty of its composition. (Msb.) ― -b5- (tropical:) He deceived, deluded, beguiled, circumvented, or outwitted, him; (S, Mgh, K; *) as also sHRrhu↓, [but app. in an intensive or a frequentative sense,] (K, TA,) inf. n. tasoHiyrN. (TA. [Accord. to the Mgh, the former verb in this sense seems to be derived from the same verb in the first of the senses expl. in this art.]) ― -b6- And in like manner, (assumed tropical:) He diverted him [with a thing], as one diverts a child with food, that he may be contented, and not want milk; syn. EalRalahu; as also sHRrhu↓, inf. n. tasoHiyrN. (S, TA.) One says, saHarahu biAlTRaEaAmi wa AlXRaraAbi, and sHRrhu↓, (assumed tropical:) He fed him, and diverted him [from the feeling of want], with meat and drink. (TA.) ― -b7- And saHarotu AlfiDRapa (assumed tropical:) I gilded the silver. (Ham p. 601.) ― -b8- siHorN is also syn. with fasaAdN [as quasi-inf. n. of Oafosada, as is indicated in the TA; thus signifying The act of corrupting, marring, spoiling, &c.: see the pass. part. n. masoHuwrN]. (TA.) [Hence,] one says, saHara AlmaTaru AlTRiyna and AltRuraAba, (assumed tropical:) The rain spoiled the clay, and the earth, or dust, so that it was not fit for use. (TA.) ― -b9- And one says of the adhesion of the lungs to the side by reason of thirst, yasoHaru OalobaAna Alganami, meaning (assumed tropical:) It causes the milk of the sheep, or goats, to descend before bringing forth. (TA.) ＝ -A2- saHara also signifies He went, or removed, to a distance, or far away; syn. tabaAEada; (T, K;) said of a man. (T, TA.) ＝ -A3- saHira, aor.
saHara
, (assumed tropical:) He went forth early in the morning, in the first part of the day; or between the time of the prayer of daybreak and sunrise; syn. bakRara. (O, K. [See also 4.])

2 sHRr c
2. sHRr, inf. n. tasoHiyrN: see 1, in four places. ― -b2- Also (tropical:) He fed another, or others, with the food, or meal, called the saHuwr: (M, Mgh, TA:) or saHRarahumo signifies he gave to them the meal so called. (Mgh.)

4 AsHr c
4. AsHr (tropical:) He was, or became, in the time called the saHar; (S, A, K;) as also AstHr↓. (TA.) And (tropical:) He went, or journeyed, in the time so called: (S, K, TA:) or he rose to go, or journey, in that time; and so AstHr↓: (TA:) or this latter signifies he went forth in that time. (A. [See also 1, last sentence.])

5 tsHRr c
5. tsHRr (A, Mgh, Msb) and tsHRr AlsRaHuwra (Az, TA) (tropical:) He ate the food, or meal, [or drank the draught of milk,] called the saHuwr. (Az, A, Mgh, Msb, TA.) ― -b2- And tsHRr bihi (tropical:) He ate it, (S, * K, * TA,) namely, food, or sawiyq [q. v.], [or drank it, namely, milk,] at the time called the saHar. (TA.)

8 AstHr c
8. AstHr: see 4, in two places. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) He (a cock) crowed at the time called the saHar: (S, K:) and he (a bird) sang, warbled, or uttered his voice, at that time. (TA.)

saHorN c
saHorN, and saHarN↓, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) sometimes thus because of the faucial letter, (S,) and suHorN↓, (S, Msb, K,) and, accord. to El-Khafájee, in the 'Ináyeh, siHorN↓, but this is not mentioned by any other, and therefore requires confirmation, (TA,) The lungs, or lights: (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K:) or what adheres to the gullet and the windpipe, of [the contents of] the upper part of the belly: or all that hangs to the gullet, consisting of the heart and liver and lungs: (Msb, TA:) and the part of the exterior of the body corresponding to the place of the lungs: (Mgh, TA: *) and saHorN signifies also the liver; and the core, or black or inner part, (sawaAd,) and sides, or regions, of the heart: (TA:) and suHorN↓, the heart; (ElJarmee, K;) as also suHorapN↓: (TA:) the pl. (of saHorN, S, Msb) is suHuwrN, and (of suHorN↓, S, Msb, and of saHarN↓, Msb) OasoHaArN. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- Hence, Ainotafaxa saHoruhu, (S, A, K,) and Ainotafaxato masaAHiruhu↓, (A, K,) (tropical:) His lungs became inflated, or swollen, by reason of timidity and cowardice: (A:) said of a coward: (S:) and of one who has exceeded his due bounds: Lth says that, when repletion arises in a man, one says Antfx sHrh, and that the meaning is, [as given also in the K,] he exceeded his due bounds: but Az says that this is a mistake, and that this phrase is only said of a coward, whose inside is filled with fear, and whose lungs are inflated, or swollen, so that the heart is raised to the gullet: and of the same kind is the phrase in the Kur [xxxiii. 10] wabalagati Alquluwbu AlHanaAjira. (TA.) ― -b3- And AlmuqaTRaEapu AlOasoHaAri, and AlsRuHuwri, (assumed tropical:) [She that has her lungs burst asunder], an appellation given to the Oaronab [i. e. hare, or female hare], (S, K,) or to the swift Arnb, (TA in art. qTE,) by way of good omen, meaning that her lungs will burst asunder; like AlmuqaTRaEapu AlnRiyaATi: (S:) and some (of those of later times, S) say AlmuqaTRiEapu, with kesr to the T; (S, K;) as though, by her speed and vehemence of running, she would burst asunder her lungs; (S;) or because she bursts the lungs of the dogs by the vehemence of her running, and the lungs of him who purses her. (ISh, Sgh.) ― -b4- And AinoqaTaEa minohu saHoriI (tropical:) I despaired of him, or it. (A, K.) And OanaA minohu gayoru Sariymi saHorK (tropical:) I am not in despair of him, or it. (A, B.) Sariymu saHorK is also expl. as signifying (tropical:) Having his hope cut off: and (tropical:) anything despaired of. (TA.) And Surima saHoruhu means (tropical:) His hope was cut off. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also The scar of a gall on the back of a camel, (K, TA,) when it has healed, and the place thereof has become white. (TA.) ＝ -A3- And The upper, or highest, part of a valley. (TA.) ＝ -A4- See also saHRaArapN. ＝ -A5- And see saHarN, in two places.

suHorN c
suHorN: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.

siHorN c
