siHorN: see saHorN, first sentence. ＝ -A2- [Also] an inf. n. of saHarahu, meaning (tropical:) The turning a thing from its proper manner of being to another manner: (T, TA: [accord. to the T, this seems to be proper; but accord. to the A, tropical:]) and hence, (T, TA,) (tropical:) enchantment, or fascination: (T, * S, * MA, KL, PS:) for when. the enchanter (AlsRaAHiru) makes what is false to appear in the form of truth, and causes a thing to be imagined different from what it really is, it is as though he turned it from its proper manner of being: (T, TA:) the producing what is false in the form of truth: (IF, Msb:) or, in the common conventional language of the law, any event of which the cause is hidden, and which is imagined to be different from what it really is: and embellishment by falsification, and deceit: (Fakhred-Deen, Msb:) or a performance in which one allies himself to the devil, and which is effected by his aid: (TA:) i. q. OaxocapN [meaning a kind of enchantment, or fascination, which captivates the eye and the like, and by which enchantresses withhold their husbands from other women]: (S:) and anything of which the way of proceeding or operation (maOoxacuhu) is subtile: (S, K:) accord. to Ibn-Abee-'Áïsheh, siHor is thus called by the Arabs because it changes health, or soundness, to disease: (Sh:) [and in like manner it is said to change hatred to love: (see 1:)] pl. OasoHaArN and suHuwrN. (TA.) ― -b2- Also (tropical:) Skilful eloquence: (TA:) or used absolutely, it is applied to that for which the agent is blamed: and when restricted, to that which is praiseworthy. (Msb.) Thus it is in the saying of Mohammad, UinRa mina AlbayaAni lasiHorFA
(tropical:) [Verily there is a kind of eloquence that is enchantment]: because the speaker propounds an obscure matter, and discloses its true meaning by the beauty of his eloquence, inclining the hearts [of his hearers] in like manner as they are inclined by siHor: or because there is in eloquence a novelty and strangeness of composition which attracts the hearer and brings him to such a pass as almost diverts him from other things; therefore it is likened to siHor properly so called: and it is said to be AlsRiHoru AlHalaAlu [or lawful enchantment]. (Msb.) The saying of Mohammad mentioned above was uttered on the following occasion: Keys Ibn-'Ásim El-Minkaree and EzZibrikán Ibn-Bedr and 'Amr Ibn-El-Ahtam came to the Prophet, who asked 'Amr respecting EzZibrikán; whereupon he spoke well of him: but Ez-Zibrikán was not content with this, and said, “ By God, O apostle of God, he knows that I am more excellent than he has said; but he envies the place that I have in thine estimation: ” and thereupon 'Amr spoke ill of him; and then said, “ By God, I did not lie of him in the first saying nor in the other; but he pleased me, and I spoke as pleased; then he angered me, and I spoke as angered: ” then Mohammad uttered the above-mentioned words. (TA.) Their meaning is, but God knows best, he praises the man, speaking truth respecting him, so as to turn the hearts of the hearers to him, (K,) or to what he says; (TA;) and he dispraises him, speaking truth respecting him, so as to turn their hearts also to him, (K,) or to what he says after. (TA.) A' Obeyd says nearly the same. Or, as some say, the meaning is, that there is an eloquence that is sinful like siHor. (TA.) ― -b3- Also (tropical:) Skill; science: Mohammad said, mano taEalRama baAbFA mina AlnRujuwmi faqado taEalRama baAbFA mina AlsRiHori (tropical:) [He who learneth a process of the science of the stars (meaning astrology or astronomy) learneth a process of enchantment], which may mean that the science of the stars is forbidden to be learned, like the science of enchantment, and that the learning of it is an act of infidelity: or it may mean that it is skill, and science; referring to what is acquired thereof by way of calculation; as the knowledge of eclipses of the sun or moon, and the like. (ISd, TA.) ― -b4- Also (tropical:) Food; aliment; nutriment: so called because its effect is subtile. (TA.) ― -b5- gayovN cuw siHorK means (assumed tropical:) Superabundant rain. (TA.)

saHarN c
saHarN: see saHorN, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) and saHorN↓, (TA,) and suHurN↓, (Msb,) and saHariIRN↓, and saHariyRapN↓, (K,) (tropical:) The time a little before daybreak: (S, K:) or [simply] before daybreak: (Msb:) or the last part of the night: (Lth, Mgh:) or the last sixth of the night: (Mgh:) the pl. of saHarN (Msb) and of saHorN↓ (TA) and of suHurN↓, (Msb,) is OasoHaArN: (Msb, K, TA:) the saHar is thus met. called because it is the time of the departure of the night and the coming of the day; so that it is the mutanafRas [lit. the “ time of the breathing, ” by which is meant the “ shining forth, ”] of the dawn: (A:) there are two times of which each is thus called; one, which is [specially] called AlsRaHaru AlOaEolaI, [or the earlier saHar,] (A, Mgh,) is before daybreak; (Mgh;) or a little before daybreak: (A:) and the other, at daybreak: (A, Mgh:) like as one says “ the false dawn ” and “ the true: ” (A:) the earlier saHar is also called suHorapN↓: (S, K:) or the suHorap is the same as the saHar: or it is the last third of the night, to daybreak. (TA.) Using saHar indeterminately, you make it perfectly decl., and say, Oatayotuhu bisaHarK [I came to him a little before daybreak], agreeably with the phrase in the Kur liv. 34; (S;) and in like manner, bisuHorapK↓ [in the earlier saHar]: (S, K:) you also say saHarFA, and suHorapF↓, (A,) and saHarFA mina AlOasoHaAri: and maA zaAla EinodanaA munocu AlsRaHari [He ceased not to be with us, or at our abode, from a little before daybreak]: and laqiytuhu biAlsRaHari AlOaEolaI, and biOaEolaI saHarayoni, and biOaEolaI AlsRaHarayoni, (TA,) and fiI OaEolaI AlsRaHarayoni, (A, TA,) [I met him in the earlier saHar;] but biOaEolaI saHarK, a phrase used by El-'Ajjáj, is erroneous: (TA:) and hecihi AllRayolapi laqiytuhu saHariIRa↓ and saHariyRatahaA↓ [I met him in the time a little before daybreak of this last night]. (TA.) When, by saHar alone, you mean the saHar of the night immediately preceding, you say, laqiytuhu saHara yaA hecaA [I met him a little before daybreak this last night, O thou man], (S, K,) making it imperfectly decl. because it is altered from AlsRaHara, (S,) or because it is for biAlsRaHari; (TA;) and it is thus determinate by itself, (S, K,) without its being prefixed to another noun and without Al: (S:) and in the same sense you say bisaHara: (TA:) and you say, siro EalaI farasika saHara yaA fataI [Go thou on thy horse a little before daybreak this night, O youth: so in the TA; but in two copies of the S, for siro I find siyra]: you do not make it to terminate with damm, [like qabolu and baEodu &c.,] because it is an adv. n. which, in a place where it is fitting to be such, may not be used otherwise than as such: (S:) and [in like manner] you say, laqiytuhu suHorapa↓ yaA hecaA [I met him in the earlier saHar of this last night, O thou man]. (TA.) If you make saHar the proper name of a man, it is perfectly decl.: and so is the dim.; for it is not of the measure of a noun made to deviate from its original from, like Ouxaru: you say, siro EalaI farasika suHayorFA↓ [Go thou on thy horse a very little before daybreak: so in the TA; but here again, in two copies of the S, for siro I find siyra]: you do not make it to terminate with damm, [like qabolu &c.,] because its being made of the dim. form does not bring it into the class of adv. ns. which may also be used as nouns absolutely, though it does bring it into the class of nouns which are perfectly declinable. (S, TA.) ― -b2- saHarN also signifies (tropical:) Whiteness overspreading blackness; (K;) like SaHarN; except that the former is mostly used in relation to the time so called, of daybreak; and the latter, in relation to colours, as when one says HimaArN OaSoHaru; (TA;) and suHorapN↓ signifies the same; (TA;) i. q. SuHorapN. (K.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) The extremity (T, A, K) of a desert, (T,) and of the earth or a land, (A,) or of anything: (K:) from the time of night so called: (A:) pl. OasoHaArN. (T, A, K.)

saHirN c
saHirN: see saHiyrN.

suHurN c
suHurN: see saHarN, first sentence, in two places.

suHorapN c
suHorapN: see saHorN: ＝ -A2- and saHarN, in five places.

saHariIRN c
saHariIRN and saHariyRapN: see saHarN; each in two places.

saHuwrN c
saHuwrN A meal, or food, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) or [particularly] sawiyq [generally meaning meal of parched barley], that is eaten at the time called the saHar; (S, * Mgh, Msb, K* TA;) or a draught of milk that is drunk at that time. (TA.) It is repeatedly mentioned in trads. [relating to Ramadán, when the Muslim is required to be exact in the time of this meal], and mostly as above; but some say that it is correctly [in these cases] with damm, [i. e. suHuwr, which see below,] because the blessing and recompense have respect to the action, and not to the food. (TA.)

suHuwrN c
suHuwrN, an inf. n. [without a verb properly belonging to it, or rather a quasi-inf. n., for its verb is tasaHRara], (TA,) The act of eating the meal, or food, [or drinking the draught of milk,] called the saHuwr [q. v.]. (Msb, TA.)

saHiyrN c
saHiyrN: see masoHuwrN. ― -b2- Also A man having his lungs (saHoruhu) ruptured; and so saHirN↓. (TA.) ― -b3- And Having a complaint of the belly, (K, TA,) from pain of the lungs. (TA.) ― -b4- And A horse large in the belly, (K,) or in the jawof [which often means the chest]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- [And An arrow wounding the lungs: so accord. to Freytag in the “ Deewán el-Hudhaleeyeen. ”]

suHayorFA c
suHayorFA: see saHarN, in the latter half of the paragraph.

suHaArapN c
suHaArapN The parts, of a sheep or goat, that the butcher plucks out (K, TA) and throws away, (TA,) consisting of the lungs, or lights, (saHor) and the windpipe, (K, TA,) and the appendages of these. (TA.)

saHRaArN c
saHRaArN: see saAHirN, in two places.

saHRaArapN c
saHRaArapN (tropical:) A certain plaything of children; (A, K, TA;) having a string attached to it; (A;) which, when extended in one direction, turns out to be of one colour; and when extended in another direction, turns out to be of another colour: (A, * TA:) it is also called saHorN↓: and whatever. resembles it is called by the former appellation: so says Lth. (TA.)

saAHirN c
saAHirN (tropical:) [An enchanter;] a man who practices siHor; as also saHRaArN↓ [in an intensive sense, or denoting habit or frequency]: pl. of the former saHarapN and suHRaArN; and of ↓the latter, saHRaAruwna only, for it has no broken pl. (TA.) [Hence,] one says, lahaA EayonN saAHirapN (tropical:) [She has an enchanting, or a fascinating, eye], and EuyuwnN sawaAHiru [enchanting, or fascinating, eyes]. (A, TA.) And OaroDN saAHirapu AlsRaraAbi (tropical:) [A land of delusive mirage].(A, TA.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) Knowing, skilful, or intelligent. (S, * TA.)

musaHRarN c
musaHRarN, of which the pl. occurs in the Kur xxvi. 153 and 185, means Having suHor or saHor [i. e. lungs]; (Bd, TA;) or created with saHor [or lungs]; (S;) i. e. a human being: (Bd:) or diverted [from want] with food and drink: (S, * TA:) and this seems to be implied by the explanation in the K; which is hollow; from Fr: (TA:) or enchanted time after time, so that his intellect is disordered, or rendered unsound: (A, TA:) or enchanted much, so that his reason is overcome: (Bd, Jel:) [see also masoHuwrN:] or deceived, deluded, beguiled, circumvented, or outwitted. (TA.)

masoHuwrN c
masoHuwrN Having his lungs (saHoruhu), or his heart (suHoratuhu), hit, or hurt; as also saHiyrN↓ [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b2- [(tropical:) Enchanted, or fascinated.] ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) Deprived of his reason or intellect; corrupted or disordered [in his intellect]. (IAar, Sh.) [See also musaHRarN.] ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) Food (TaEaAmN) marred, or spoilt, (K, TA,) in the making thereof. (TA.) (assumed tropical:) Herbage marred, or spoilt. (TA.) (assumed tropical:) A place marred, or spoilt, by much rain, or by scantiness of herbage. (K.) The fem., with p, accord. to Az, signifies (assumed tropical:) Land (OaroDN) marred, or spoilt, by superabundant rain, or by scantiness of herbage: accord. to ISh, (assumed tropical:) land in which is little milk; i. e. [because] without herbage: accord. to Z, [in the A,] (tropical:) land that produces no herbage. (TA.) ― -b5- And the fem., applied to a she-goat, (tropical:) Having little milk: (A, TA:) or large in her udder, but having little milk. (Ham p. 26.)

masaAHiru c
masaAHiru: see saHorN, second sentence.

1 saHafahu c
1. saHafahu, (S, K, TA,) aor.
saHafa
, (K, TA,) inf. n. saHofN, (S, TA,) He pared it, or peeled it, off; (S, K, TA;) namely, a thing; (TA;) and [particularly] the fat from the back (S, K) of the sheep or goat, (S, TA,) not of the she-camel, as is indicated by the context in the K, (TA,) by reason of its abundance, after which he roasted it, (S, TA,) i. e., accord. to the S, the fat, but correctly the sheep or goat: (TA:) so says ISK. (S, TA.) ― -b2- And saHafahu, (Lth, TA,) inf. n. as above, (Lth, K, TA,) He removed it, or stripped it off, namely, hair from skin, so that none of it remained. (Lth, K, TA.) ― -b3- Hence, (TA,) saHafati AlUibilu (tropical:) The camels ate what they would. (K, TA.) ― -b4- And saHafati AlrRiyHu AlsRaHaAba (assumed tropical:) The wind removed the clouds; (Lth, K;)as also OasoHafatohu↓, (Zj, K, TA: in the CK AsotaHafRatuhu.) ― -b5- saHafa raOosahu, (S, K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He shaved his head (S, K, TA) so as to remove the hair utterly. (TA.) ― -b6- saHafa AlXRaIoCa, and AlnRaxolapa wagayorahaA, (K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) He burned the thing, and the palm-tree &c.; (K, TA;) in the case of the palm-tree, by kindling fire at the stumps of the branches, being unable to strip them off. (Aboo-Nasr, TA.) ― -b7- And saHafahu He (i. e. God) caused him to be affected with suHaAf, i. e. consumption, or ulceration of the lungs. (TA.)

4 AsHf c
4. AsHf He sold the fat termed saHofap. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also 1.

saHofN c
saHofN Fat, as a subst.: pl. siHaAfN. (TA.) An Arab of the desert said, OatawonaA biSiHaAfK fiyhaA liHaAmN wasiHaAfN They brought us bowls in which were sorts of flesh-meat and of fat. (IAar K, * TA.)

saHofapN c
saHofapN A piece, or portion, of fat; in a general sense: (TA:) or the portion of fat that is upon the back, (S, K, TA,) sticking to the skin, in the part between the two shoulder-blades, extending to the haunches: so says ISk: (S, TA:) or that is upon the two sides and the back: and it is never but from fatness: accord. to IKh, it is in all beasts except the camel: ISd says that, accord. to some, it is in the camel [also]. (TA.) ― -b2- And [the dual] saHofataAni The two sides of the tuft of hair that is between the lower lip and the chin: (Aboo-Sa'eed, K:) pl. saHafaAtN. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also saHiyfN. ＝ -A3- [Freytag makes it to be also syn. with masoHafN, as on the authority of the K, in which I do not find it in this sense.]

suHafapN c
suHafapN: see what next follows.

suHafoniyapN c
suHafoniyapN (in which the n is augmentative, TA) A man having the head shaven; (IB, K, TA;) as also suHafapN↓. (IB, TA.) ― -b2- And with the article Al, What one has shaven off: thus it is sometimes a subst.; and sometimes, [i. e. in the former sense,] an epithet. (IB, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A certain beast, or creeping thing: (Seer, TA:) [SM says,] I think it is the sulaHofiyap [or tortoise]. (TA.)

suHaAfN c
suHaAfN Consumption; or ulceration of the lungs; syn. silRN. (S, K.)

saHuwfN c
saHuwfN A bucket (dalow) that takes, and bears away, the water that is in a well. (Seer, K.) ＝ -A2- Also, applied to a she-camel, Of which the fat has gone away. (ISd, TA.) ― -b2- And, applied to a sheep or goat, or to a ewe or she-goat, (XaAp,) Having a portion of fat such as is termed saHofap, or two such portions of fat; as also OusoHuwfN↓: (TA:) or, so applied, (S,) and applied to a she-camel, (S, K,) and to a he-camel, (K,) having abundance of saHaAYif, (S, * K, TA,) pl. of saHiyfapN [q. v.]; or having abundance of the fat termed saHofap. (TA.) ― -b3- Also A she-camel long in the teats. (IDrd, K.) ― -b4- And A she-camel narrow in the orifices of the teats. (IDrd, K.) ― -b5- And A she-camel that drags her feet, or the extremities of her feet, upon the ground, in going along; (K, TA;) so say some; i. e., by reason of fatigue: a dial. var. of zaHuwfN. (TA.) ― -b6- And A sheep, or ewe, thin in the wool of the belly. (K.) ― -b7- In the K, three other meanings are erroneously assigned to this word; one of them belonging to saHiyfapN, and each of the others to saHiyfN. (TA.)

saHiyfN c
saHiyfN, (ISk, S, Sgh, TA,) accord. to the context in the K saHuwfN, which is wrong, in this and the next sense, (TA,) The sound of the mill when one grinds. (ISk, S, Sgh, K *) And The sound of the streaming of milk from the udder; (O, K, * TA;) as also saHofapN↓. (K, * TA.)

saHiyfapN c
saHiyfapN The fat called saHofapN that one has pared off from the back of a sheep or goat. (ISk, S.) ― -b2- And sing. of saHaAYifu, (Lth, TA,) which signifirs The layers of fat between the layers [of flesh] of the flanks: and similar wide portions of fat that are seen adhering to the skin. (Lth, K, TA.) ― -b3- Also A rain (maTorapN) that sweeps away that along which it passes: (S, O, L, TA:) in the K, by the omission of kasafiynapK, this meaning is erroneously assigned to saHuwfN: accord. to As, a sharp rain, that sweeps away everything: and saHiyqapN, with q, a vehement rain, consisting of large drops, but of little width: pls. saHaAYifu and saHaAYiqu. (TA.)

OusoHuwfN c
OusoHuwfN: see saHuwfN. ― -b2- OusoHuwfu AlOaHaAliyli, (K,) mentioned by ISh, on the authority of Aboo-Aslam, (TA,) and UisoHawofu AlAHAlyl, (K,) thus accord. to Sb, (TA,) A she-camel wide in the orifices of the teats: (Aboo-Aslam, K:) or having much milk, the streaming of which causes a sound to be heard. (Aboo-Málik, K, * TA.)

masoHafN c
masoHafN The mark, or track, of a serpent, upon the ground; (Ibn-'Abbád, K;) as also mazoHafN. (TA.)

OaroDN musoHafapN c
OaroDN musoHafapN, with fet-h [to the H, or perhaps to the m and H], A land of which the herbage is thin [or scanty]: mentioned in the K in art. sxf, as being [written musoxifapN,] like maHosinapN. (TA.)

misoHafapN c
misoHafapN A thing with which flesh, or flesh-meat, is pared. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

masoHuwfN c
masoHuwfN A man affected with suHaAf, i. e. consumption, or ulceration of the lungs; (S;) syn. masoluwlN. (K.)

1 saHaqahu c
1. saHaqahu, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
saHaqa
, (Msb, K) inf. n. saHoqN, (Msb,) He bruised, brayed, or pounded, it; syn. daqRahu; (Mgh, K;) namely, a thing, (S, TA,) or medicine: (Mgh, Msb:) or i. q. sahakahu [app. as meaning he bruised, brayed, or pounded, it coarsely; but see this latter verb]: (S, K:) or it signifies [he did so in a degree] less than what is meant by daqRahu: (Lth, K:) or [he powdered, or pulverized, it; i. e.] he bruised, brayed, or pounded, it finely: or he bruised, brayed, or pounded, it time after time. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] saHaqati AlrRiyHu AlOaroDa, (K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) (tropical:) The wind effaced the traces of the ground, (K, TA,) and carried away the broken particles [that were upon it]: (M, TA:) or passed along as though it were bruising, or braying, or pounding, (kaOanRahaA tasoHaqu,) the dust: (O, K:) or pared, or abraded, the surface of the earth by its vehement blowing; as also sahakatohaA [q. v.]. (T, A, TA.) ― -b3- And saHaqahu, (K, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) (tropical:) He wore it out; namely, a garment. (K, TA.) And saHaqahu marRu AlzRamaAni (assumed tropical:) The course of time rendered it (a garment) thin and worn out. (O, TA.) And saHaqahu AlbilaA (assumed tropical:) [Wear wasted it]; namely, a garment. (TA.) ― -b4- Also He, or it, rendered it soft, or
smooth; namely, a hard thing. (K.) ― -b5- And (assumed tropical:) He destroyed it; and so AsHqhu↓. (Har p. 257-8.) ― -b6- saHaqa Alqamolapa He killed the louse. (K.) ― -b7- saHaqa raOosahu He shaved his head. (K.) ― -b8- saHaqati AlEayonu damoEahaA The eye spent its tears; (K, TA;) shed them, or let them fall. (TA.) ― -b9- See also 4. ＝ -A2- saHuqa, aor.
saHuqa
, inf. n. suHuwqapN, (assumed tropical:) It (a garment) was, or became, old, and worn out; (K;) [and so, app., saHiqa, inf. n., saHaqN, accord. to a usage of this noun, in the Deewán el-Hudhaleeyeen, mentioned by Freytag, and agreeably with the phrase vawobN saHiqN, mentioned below;] as also AsHq↓, (Yaakoob, S, Msb, K,) inf. n. UisoHaAqN. (Msb.) ＝ -A3- saHuqa, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
saHuqa
; and saHiqa, aor.
saHaqa
; (K;) inf. n. suHoqN (S, * Msb, * K) [and app. suHuqN also]; It (a thing, S, or a place, Msb) was, or became, distant, or remote; (S, Msb, K;) as also AsHq↓, and AnsHq↓. (TA.) suHoqN and suHuqN are both syn. with buEodN. (S, K.) One says, suHoqFA lahu, (S, Msb,) a form of imprecation, (Msb,) meaning May God alienate him, or estrange him, from good, or prosperity! or curse him! i. e. may he not be pitied with respect to that which has befallen him! like buEodFA lahu: the most approved way is to put the noun thus in the accus. case as an inf. n.; but the tribe of Temeem say, buEodN lahu, and suHoqN. (TA in art. bEd.) ― -b2- saHuqati AlnRaxolapu The palm-tree became tall: (K:) or tall with smoothness [of its trunk]. (TA.) ＝ -A4- saHaqati AldRaAbRapu, [inf. n. saHoqN,] The beast ran vehemently: or ran a pace above that termed maXoIN and below that termed HuDorN, (K, TA,) agreeably with what is said in explanation of AlsRaHoqu in the S: or below that termed HuDorN and above that termed saHojN. (TA.)

3 musaAHaqapu AlnRisaMCi c
3. musaAHaqapu AlnRisaMCi [meaning (tropical:) The mutual act, of women, indicated by the epithet saHRaAqapN (q. v.), as also tasaAHuqN↓,] is post-classical: (T, TA:) such it is said to be. (Mgh.)

4 AsHqhu c
4. AsHqhu: see 1. ― -b2- Said of God, (S, TA,) He removed him far away, or alienated him, or estranged him, in a general sense, or from good, or prosperity; syn. OaboEadahu; (S, O, K, TA; [accord. to the CK AnsHqhu, which is wrong;]) as also saHaqahu↓: or, from his mercy. (TA.) ＝ -A2- AsHq as intrans.: see 1, in two places. ― -b2- Also, [in the CK, erroneously, AnsHq,] said of a came's foot, It was, or became, smooth, with a degree of hardness; syn. marana. (ISk, S, O, K.) ― -b3- And said of an udder, It lost its milk, and became wasted, and clave to the belly: (ISk, S, O, K:) or it dried up: (As, TA:) or it went away; and wasted. (A'Obeyd, TA.) ― -b4- And AsHqt AldRalowu The bucket became empty of what was in it. (TA.)

6 tasaAHuqN c
6. tasaAHuqN The act of rubbing together. (KL.) See also 3.

7 AnsHq c
7. AnsHq [It was, or became, bruised, brayed, or pounded: &c.:] quasi-pass. of saHaqahu as expl. in the first sentence of this art. (S, O, K.) ― -b2- Said of a garment, It was, or became, [worn out; or thin and worn out; (see 1;) or] threadbare, or napless, while new. (TA.) ― -b3- And [said of a place,] It was wide, or ample. (O, K.) ― -b4- See also 1. ― -b5- AnsHq AldRamoEu The tears were shed. (TA.)

saHoqN c
saHoqN An old and worn-out garment, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) that has become thin, (O,) and threadbare; (Ham p. 591;) also used as a prefixed noun, (Mgh, Msb,) so that you say saHoqu vawobK [meaning as above], (Mgh,) and saHoqu burodK [an old and worn-out burod], and saHoqu EimaAmapK [an old and worn-out turban]: (Mgh, Msb:) and one says vawobN saHoqN, [using it as an epithet,] (O, TA,) and vawobN saHiqN↓, (Har p. 258, [but for this I have found no other authority, and it may be a mistranscription,]) and vawobN munosaHiqN↓ likewise signifies an old and worn-out garment: (TA:) saHoqN applied to a garment is an inf. n. used as a subst.: (O, TA:) the pl. is suHuwqN. (TA.) Hence one says saHoqu dirohamK, meaning (tropical:) A [bad] dirhem [or] such as is termed zaAYifN. (Mgh.) ― -b2- Also A pastor's bag (kinofN): so in a verse cited voce xufRN. (S in art. xf.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) Thin clouds: (K:) likened to an old and worn-out garment. (TA.) ― -b4- And The mark, or scar, of a gall, or sore, on the back of a camel, when it has healed, and the place thereof has become white: (TA:) [like saloqN and salaqN.]

saHiqN c
saHiqN: see the next preceding paragraph.

suHoqapN c
[suHoqapN Baldness: of the dial. of El-Yemen. (Freytag, from IDrd.)]

saHuwqN c
saHuwqN Tall; applied to a palm-tree; (S, Msb, K;) as also suyoHuwqN; (S;) and to a he-ass and to a she-ass; (S, K) and by some, metaphorically, to a woman; (TA;) and sawoHaqN↓ signifies the same, (K,) applied to a man; (TA;) and AlrRijolayoni sawoHaqu↓ long in respect of the legs: (IB:) or saHuwqN applied to a palm-tree signifies tall so that its fruit is far above the gatherer; As says, I know not whether that be with a bending: or, accord. to Sh, so applied, smooth and tall, having no stumps of the branches remaining [upon the trunk]; and to such the neck of a horse is likened by a poet: and applied to a he-ass and to a she-ass, tall, and advanced in age: (TA:) pl. suHuqN, (S, O, Msb,) like rusulN, (Msb,) or suHoqN. (So in the K.) One says also janRapN suHuqN, meaning A garden of tall palm-trees. (TA.)

saHiyqN c
saHiyqN Bruised, brayed, or pounded: (Mgh:) [&c.: (see 1, first sentence:)] i. q. masoHuwqN↓: (O:) applied to musk; (Mgh, O;) and to saffron. (Mgh in art. wrs.) ― -b2- and Distant; remote; (S, Msb, K;) applied to a thing, (S,) or to a place; (Msb, K;) as also OasoHaqu↓; (IB, TA;) and saAHiqN↓ in the same sense, applied to a place, is allowed in poetry. (TA.) One says, UinRahu labaEiydN saHiyqN [app. meaning Verily he, or it, is very distant or remote]. (TA.)

saHiyqapN c
saHiyqapN A great rain that sweeps away that along which it passes: (K:) or, accord. to As, saHiyfapN, with f, has this meaning; and the former word signifies a vehement rain, consisting of large drops, (TA in the present art.,) but of little width: pls.saHaAYiqu and saHaAYifu. (TA in art. sHf.)

saHRaAqapN c
saHRaAqapN [Fricatrix; quæ confrictu libidinem alterius explet: (Golius, from Meyd:)] an epithet of evil import, applied to a woman: (O, K:) pl. saHRaAqaAtN: of such it is said that they are cursed by God. (Mgh.)

saAHiqN c
saAHiqN: see saHiyqN. ― -b2- You say also suHoqN saAHiqN, meaning Great distance or remoteness. (TA.)

sawoHaqN c
sawoHaqN: see saHuwqN, in two places.

OasoHaqu c
OasoHaqu: see saHiyqN. ― -b2- [Also Bald: of the dial. of El-Yemen. (Freytag, from IDrd.)]

misoHaqN c
misoHaqN An instrument with which one bruises, brays, or pounds: &c.: (yusoHaqu bihi:) [see 1, first sentence.] (TA.)

masoHuwqN c
masoHuwqN: see saHiyqN.

munosaHiqN c
munosaHiqN: see saHoqN. ― -b2- Also Wide, or ample. (TA.) ― -b3- damoEN munosaHiqN Tears pouring forth; syn. munodafiqN: (Lth, Az, TA:) in the K, munodafiEN: (TA:) pl. masaAHiyqu, which is extr.; (K;) like makaAsiyru, pl. of munokasirN. (TA.)

1 saHalahu c
1. saHalahu, aor
saHala
, (K,) inf. n. saHolN, (S, TA,) He pared it; peeled it; or stripped off, scraped off, rubbed off, abraded, or otherwise removed, its outer covering or integument, or superficial part: or he pared, peeled, or stripped, it off: (S, K, TA:) this is the primary signification: (S:) and he filed it. (TA.) It is said in a trad., fajaEalato tasoHaluhaA lahu, i. e. And she betook herself to paring off from it the flesh that was upon it for him: or, as some relate it, tasoHaAhaA, which means the same. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AlrRiyaAHu tasoHalu AlOaroDa (tropical:) The winds strip off what is upon the earth, (K, TA,) or the surface of the earth. (TA: and the like is said in the S.) ― -b3- And saHalahu miAYapa sawoTK, (S, K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He struck him a hundred lashes, or strokes of a whip, (S, K, TA,) and pared off his skin, (TA,) or as though he pared off his skin. (S.) ― -b4- And saHala fulaAnN (assumed tropical:) Such a one reviled [another], and blamed [him: like as you say, qaXara biAllRisaAni]. (K. [See misoHalN as meaning “ a tongue. ”]) One says, wajada AlnRaAsa yasoHaluwnahu (assumed tropical:) He found the people reviling him, (K, TA,) and blaming him, and speaking evil of him behind his back, or in his absence, or otherwise. (TA.) ― -b5- saHalotu AlXRaIoCa i. q. saHaqotuhu [I bruised, brayed, or pounded, the thing: or pulverized it: &c.]. (S.) ― -b6- saHala AlvRiyaAba He washed the clothes, [beating them in doing so,] and removed [or rubbed off] from them the soils. (TA.) ― -b7- saHalotu AldRaraAhima I made the pieces of money smooth. (S.) Accord. to ISk,
I poured out, or forth, the pieces of money; as though I rubbed them, one against another. (S.) [Or] saHala AldRaraAhima, aor. as above, (K,) and so the inf. n., (TA,) i. q. AinotaqadahaA [which signifies He picked the pieces of money, separating the good from the bad; or examined them to do so: and also he received the pieces of money]. (K.) And saHalotuhu miAYapa dirohamK I paid him a hundred dirhems in ready money. (S.) [Or] saHala Algariyma miAYapa dirohamK He paid the creditor a hundred dirhems in ready money. (K.) ＝ -A2- saHala AlvRawoba, (K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) He wove the garment, or piece of cloth, of spun thread not formed of two twists: (K:) or he wove it without having twisted its warp [i. e. without having made its warp to consist of threads of two twists]. (TA.) ― -b2- And saHalotu AlHabola I formed the rope of a single twist; (S, TA;) and accord. to some, one says also OasoHalotuhu↓, but the former is the chaste expression. (TA.) [Hence,] suHilato mariyrapu fulaAnK is said of one whose strength has become weakened; meaning (tropical:) His well-twisted rope, or rope of two twists, has become a rope of a single twist. (TA.) ― -b3- saHala AlqiraMCapa, inf. n. saHolN, He performed the reading, or recitation, in consecutive portions, continuously: and some relate it with j [i. e. sajala]: saHolN is syn. with sarodN, signifying the making [a thing] to be consecutive in its parts, or portions. (TA.) ― -b4- baAtati AlsRamaMCu tasoHalu layolatahaA (tropical:) The sky continued pouring forth water that night: (As, S, TA:) inf. n. as above. (TA.) ― -b5- And saHalati AlEayonu, (K,) aor. as above, (TA,) inf. n. saHolN and suHuwlN, (tropical:) The eye wept; (K;) poured forth tears. (TA.) ＝ -A3- saHala, aor.
saHila
(S, K) and
saHala
, (K,) inf. n. saHiylN and suHaAlN, (S, * K, [the latter inf. n. erroneously written in the CK siHAl,]) He (an ass) made a rolling sound in his chest; whence the ass of the desert is called misoHalN↓: (S: [see also saHiylN below:]) he (a mule, K, and an ass, TA) brayed. (K, TA.)

3 sAHlwA c
3. sAHlwA, (S, K,) inf. n. musaAHalapN, (TA,) (tropical:) They took, (S,) or came, (K,) to the saAHil [or shore, &c., of the sea]. (S, K, TA.) Hence, in a trad. respecting Bedr, fasaAHala biQloEiyri And he brought the caravan to the saAHil of the sea. (TA.) ＝ -A2- huwa yusaAHiluhu, inf. n. saHaAlN and musaAHalapN, He contends, disputes, or litigates, with him. (TA.)

4 AXHl fulaAnFA c
4. AXHl fulaAnFA (assumed tropical:) He found the people reviling such a one, (K, TA,) and blaming him, and speaking evil of him behind his back, or in his absence, or otherwise. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 1, in the latter half of the paragraph.

7 AnsHl c
7. AnsHl It became pared, or peeled; or had its outer covering or integument, or its superficial part, stripped off, scraped off, rubbed off, abraded, or otherwise removed: or it became pared, peeled, or stripped, off. (K.) It is said, in this sense, of the surface of the earth [as meaning (assumed tropical:) It was stripped of what was upon it by the wind: see 1, third sentence]. (TA.) ― -b2- AnsHlt AldRaraAhimu The pieces of money became smooth. (S.) ＝ -A2- It poured out, or forth; or became poured out, or forth. (TA.) ― -b2- AnsHlt AlnRaAqapu (assumed tropical:) The she-camel was, or became, quick, or swift, in her going, or pace. (As, TA.) ― -b3- AnsHl biAlkalaAmi (tropical:) He (an orator, S, TA) ran on with speck: (S, K, TA:) or was fluent, and diffuse, or without pause, or hesitation, therein. (TA.)

saHolN c
saHolN A white garment or piece of cloth: (Msb:) or a white, thin garment or piece of cloth: (TA:) or a white garment or piece o cloth, of cotton, (S, K,) of those of El-Yemen: (S:) pl [of mult.] suHuwlN and suHulN (S, Msb, K) and [of pauc.] OasoHaAlN. (K. [See also viyaAbN saHuwliyRapN, below.]) ― -b2- And A garment, or piece of cloth, of which the spun thread is not composed of two twists; as also saHiylN↓: (K:) or, as some say, the latter is not applied to a garment, or piece of cloth; but to thread, in a sense expl. below: (TA:) or, accord. to Aboo-Nasr, it (the latter) is applied also to a garment, or piece of cloth, of which the spun thread is a single yarn: the muboram is that of which the spun thread is twisted of two yarns: and the mitoMm is that of which the warp and the woof are each of two yarns. (S, TA.) ― -b3- Also, (K,) or saHiylN↓, (S,) or both, (TA,) A rope that is of a single strand; (K, TA;) or the latter, a rope that is twisted of one twist, like as the tailor twists his thread: the muboram is that which is composed of two twists twisted together into one: (Aboo-Nasr, S, TA:) such a rope is also termed masoHuwlN↓; but not musoHalN↓, for the sake of [analogy to] muboramN; (S, TA;) or the latter epithet is sometimes applied to it: (S, TA: [see also misoHalN:]) saHiylN↓ likewise signifies thread not twisted; (Aboo-Nasr, S, TA;) or spun thread not composed of two twists. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also Ready money: (S, TA:) an inf. n. used as a subst. [properly so termed]. (TA.)

suHaAlN c
suHaAlN: see saHiylN.

siHaAlN c
siHaAlN: see misoHalN.

saHuwlN c
saHuwlN One who beats and washes and whitens clothes: hence, accord. to some, viyaAbN saHuwilyRapN [q. v.]. (TA.)

saHiylN c
saHiylN: see saHolN, in three places. ＝ -A2- Also, and suHaAlN↓, [both mentioned above as inf. ns., (see 1, last sentence,)] The rolling sound in the chest of the ass: (S, K:) or the former, [and probably the latter also,] the most vehement braying of the wild ass. (TA.)

suHaAlapN c
suHaAlapN Filings of gold and of silver (S, K) and the like, (S,) or of anything. (TA.) ― -b2- The husks of wheat and of barley and the like (K, TA) when stripped off therefrom, and so of other grains, as rice and [the species of millet called] duxon: accord. to Az, the particles that fall off of rice and of millet (curap) in the process of bruising, or braying, or pounding, like bran. (TA.) ― -b3- And [hence,] (tropical:) The refuse, or lowest or basest or meanest sort, of a people or party of men. (IaAr, K, TA.)

viyaAbN saHuwliyRapN c
viyaAbN saHuwliyRapN Certain garments, or pieces of cloth, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, TA,) of cotton, (S, TA,) white, (Mgh, TA,) so called in relation to saHuwlN, (S, Mgh, Msb,) a place, (S, K,) or town, (Mgh, Msb,) of El-Yemen, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) where they are woven, (K,) or whence they are brought: (Msb:) some say suHuwliyRapN, with damm; (Mgh, Msb, TA;) so say Az and El-Kutabee; (Mgh;) a rel. n. from suHuwlN, pl. of saHolN, (Mgh, Msb, * TA,) meaning “ a white garment or piece of cloth (Mgh, TA) of cotton; ” (TA;) but this is [said to be] a mistake; (Msb;) or it is allowable because fuEuwlN sometimes occurs as the measure of a sing., to which this pl. is likened; as is said in the O: (TA:) or the former appellation is applied, as some say, to garments, or pieces of cloth, beaten and washed and whitened; so called in relation to saHuwlN meaning “ one who beats and washes and whitens clothes. ” (TA.)

saAHilN c
saAHilN (tropical:) A shore of a sea or great river (S, Msb, K, TA) [and] of a river (nahor) like judRN; (Mgh in art. jd;) [generally, a sea-shore, seacoast, or seaboard;] and a tract of cultivated land, with towns or villages, adjacent to a sea or great river: (K:) a reversed word, (IDrd, S, K,) by rule masoHuwlN, (IDrd, K,) of the measure faAEilN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, (TA,) because the water abrades it, (IDrd, S, K, TA,) or comes upon it: (TA:) or [it is a possessive epithet, like laAbinN and taAmirN,] meaning having abrading water (cuw saAHilK mina AlmaMCi) when the tide flows and ebbs and so sweeps away what is upon it. (K.) And The side (siyf) of a valley. (K. in art. syf.) Pl. sawaAHilu. (Msb.)

UisoHilN c
UisoHilN A kind of trees, (AHn, S, K,) resembling the [species of tamarisk called] Oavol, and growing in the places where the [trees called] OaraAk grow, in plain, or soft, tracts: (AHn, TA:) its twigs are used for cleaning the teeth: (AHn, K * TA:) and Imra-el-Keys likens the fingers of a woman to tooth-sticks (masaAwiyk) thereof. (S, TA. [See EM p. 30.]) It is [said to be] a word that has no parallel in form except UicoxirN and UijoridN and UibolimN and UivomidN. (TA.)

OasaAHilu c
OasaAHilu [a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned] Water-courses, or places in which water flows. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

musoHalN c
musoHalN: see saHolN.

misoHalN c
misoHalN An implement for cutting, hewing, or paring, (Lth, K, TA,) of wood. (Lth, TA.) ― -b2- A file. (S, K.) ― -b3- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) The tongue, in an absolute sense: (K, TA:) [see miboradN: or as being an instrument of reviling,] from saHala “ he reviled. ” (TA.) J explains AlmisoHalu as meaning AllRisaAnu AlxaTiybu, (K, TA,) and MF defends this as meaning The tongue that speaks well: (TA:) [and it is said in the Ham p. 683 to signify AllRisaAnu AlRaciI laA yataOatRaI lilokalaAmi, app. meaning the tongue that does not prepare itself for speech; i. e, the ready tongue:] but [F says that] the right reading is AllRisaAnu waAlxaTiybu (K) [i. e.] ― -b4-
misoHalN also signifies i. q. xaTiybN (assumed tropical:) [A speaker, an orator, or a preacher; or a good speaker &c.]: and and eloquent xaTiyb; (K, TA;) one who scarcely, or never, stops short in his speech; excelling such as is termed miSoqaEN. (TA.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) One who is skilled in the reading, or reciting, of the Kur-án: (K:) from saHolN meaning the “ making ” [a thing] “ to be consecutive in its parts, or portions; ” and the “ pouring forth ” [water &c.]. (TA.) ― -b6- A copious rain: (K:) from saHolN meaning the act of “ pouring forth. ” (TA.) ― -b7- A water-spout (miyzaAb) of which the water is not to be withstood [so I render laA yuTaAqu maAWuhu, app. meaning, that pours forth its water with such violence that no obstruction will resist it]. (O, K.) ― -b8- The mouth of a mazaAdap [or leathern water-bag]. (O, K.) ― -b9- A brisk, lively, sprightly, or active, waterer, or cup-bearer. (O, K.) ― -b10- Extreme (nihaAyapN) in bounty, or munificence. (O, K.) ― -b11- A courageous man, who acts, (yaEomalu, so in the M and K, TA,) or charges, or makes an assault or attack, (yaHomilu, so in the O, TA,) alone, or by himself. (M, O, K.) ― -b12- The flogger who inflicts the castigations appointed by the law (O, K) before, or in the presence of, the Sultán. (O.) ＝ -A2- I. q. lijaAmN [as meaning The bridle, or headstall and reins with the bit and other appertenances]; as also siHaAlN↓; (K;) like as you say minoTaqN and niTaAqN, and miYozarN and UizaArN: (TA:) or its faOos; (K;) which is the piece of iron that stands up in the mouth [from the middle of the bit-mouth]; as IDrd says in the “ Book of the Saddle and Bridle: ” (TA:) and two rings, (K, TA,) one of which is inserted into the other, (TA,) at the two extremities of the Xakiym of the bridle, (K, TA,) which is [generally applied to the bit-mouth, but is here said by SM to be] the piece of iron that is beneath the lower lip: or, accord. to IDrd, the misoHal of the bridle is a piece of iron which is beneath the lower jaw; and the faOos is the piece of iron that stands up in the Xakiymap; and the Xakiymap is the piece of iron that lies crosswise in the mouth: and the pl. is masaAHilu: (TA:) or the misoHalaAni are two rings at the two extremities of the Xakiym [or bit-mouth] of the bridle, one of which is inserted into the other [so that they occupy the place of our curb-chain]: (S:) they are [also said to be] the xadRaAni [lit. two cheeks] of the bridle: (TA:) the misoHal is beneath the part in which is the bridle, and upon it flow the foam and blood of the horse. (Az, TA voce qayoqabN. [See also lijaAmN and faOosN.]) One says of a horse when exerting himself, and being quick, in his going, and thrusting forward therein his head, rakiba misoHalahu [He bore upon his bridle, &c.]. (O, TA.) And hence, (TA,) this phrase means [also] (assumed tropical:) He (a man, TA) followed his error, not desisting from it: (K, TA:) misoHalN signifying (assumed tropical:) error: (K:) and [in like manner] TaEana fiI misoHali DalaAlatihi means (assumed tropical:) He hastened, and strove in his error. (TA.) Also, the former of these two phrases, (assumed tropical:) He resolved, or determined, upon the [or his] affair, and strove, or exerted himself therein: (O, TA:) [for] misoHalN signifies also (assumed tropical:) decisive resolution or determination. (O, K, TA.) And (assumed tropical:) He went on with energy in his discourse, sermon, speech, oration, or harangue: (S, TA:) and so in his poetry. (A, TA.) ― -b2- Also, [from the same word as meaning the “ bridle, ” or “ headstall &c., ”] (tropical:) The side of the beard: [like as it is called EicaAr because it is in the place corresponding to that of the EicaAr of a horse or the like: (jAnibi in the CK is a mistake for jaAnibu:)] or the lower part of each EicaAr [or side of the beard], to the fore part of the beard; both together being called misoHalaAni: (K, TA: [Aasofala in the CK is a mistake for Oasofalu:]) or the place of the EicaAr: (Az, TA:) or the temple; misoHalaAni meaning the two temples: (TA:) and (K) the EaAriD [or side of the cheek] of a man. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, K.) One says, XaAba misoHaluhu, meaning (tropical:) The side of his beard became white, or hoary. (TA.) ＝ -A3- A clean (O, K, TA) thin (TA) garment, or piece of cloth, of cotton. (O, K, TA. [See also saHolN.]) ― -b2- A rope, (K,) or string, or thread, (M, TA,) that is twisted alone: (K:) if with another, [i. e. with another strand,] it is termed muboramN, and mugaArN. (TA. [See, again, saHolN.]) ― -b3- A sieve. (O, K.) ＝ -A4- The wild ass: (S, TA:) [because of his braying:] see 1, last sentence: an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates. (TA.) ― -b2- A brisk, lively, sprightly, or active, ass. (O.) ― -b3- A low, vile, mean, or sordid, man. (O, TA.) ― -b4- A devil. (O, TA.) ― -b5- The name of The taAbiEap (S, O) or [familiar] jinnee or genie (K) of [the poet] El-Aashà. (S, O, K. [In the K it is implied that it is with the article Al: but accord. to the S and O and TA, it is without Al.])

musaHRalapN c
musaHRalapN A ball of spun thread. (AA, TA.)

masoHuwlN c
masoHuwlN [Pared, peeled, &c.: see 1. ― -b2- And hence, because abraded by the feet of men and beasts,] A road. (TA in art. rfg.) ― -b3- And An even, wide place. (O, K.) ＝ -A2- See also saHolN. ＝ -A3- As an epithet applied to a man, Small and contemptible. (O, K.) ― -b2- And the name of A camel belonging to [the poet] El-' Ajjáj. (O, K.)

1 saHima c
1. saHima, aor.
saHama
, inf. n. saHamN; and saHuma; He, or it, was, or became, black. (Msb.)

2 saHRamuwA wajohahu c
2. saHRamuwA wajohahu They blackened his face; syn. HayRayuwhu; as also saxRamuwhu. (A, TA.)

4 AsHmt AlsRamaMCu c
4. AsHmt AlsRamaMCu The sky poured forth its water: (K:) mentioned as on the authority of IAar: but it has been mentioned before, on his authority, as with j. (TA.)

saHamN c
saHamN: see suHomapN. ＝ -A2- A sort of tree; (S, K;) like saHomaMCu↓: (S:) the latter also signifies a sort of tree: (K:) the former is said by ISk to be a certain plant: and by AHn, to be a plant that grows like the naSiIR and SilRiyaAn and Eanokav, except that it is taller; the saHamap [i. e. the single plant of this species] being sometimes as tall as a man, and larger. (TA.) ＝ -A3- Also Iron: (IAar, K:) n. un. with p; meaning a lump, or piece, of iron. (IAar, TA.)

suHumN c
suHumN [a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned,] The blacksmith's hammers. (IAar, K.)

suHomapN c
suHomapN Blackness; (S, Msb, K;) as also saHamN↓, [mentioned above as inf. n. of saHima,] and suHaAmN↓; (K;) like [suxomapN and] saxamN: (TA in art. sxm:) a blackness like the colour of the crow to which the epithet OasoHamu↓ is applied. (Lth, TA.)

suHaAmN c
suHaAmN: see the next preceding paragraph.

suHayomN c
suHayomN: see the next following paragraph.

OasoHamu c
OasoHamu Black; (S, Msb, K;) like Oasoxamu; (TA in art. sxm;) applied to the crow; see suHomapN: (Lth, TA:) fem. saHomaMCu; (Msb, TA;) applied to a plant of that colour; (ISk, TA;) and particularly to the naSiIR when it is of that colour, and thus applied as an intensive epithet; and to a woman in the same sense: (TA:) and UisoHimaAnN↓ signifies anything black (ISd, K) accord. to some; but this is a mistake, for it is only OasoHamu. (ISd, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AlOasoHamu is the name of A certain idol, (K, TA,) which was black. (TA.) ― -b3- And The night. (TA.) ― -b4- [Hence likewise,] OasoHamu signifies also Clouds (saHaAbN): (S, K:) or, as some say, black clouds: and saHomaMCu signifies a black cloud. (TA.) ― -b5- Also Blood into which are dipped the hands of persons swearing, one to another; (K;) or blood into which the hand is dipped on the occasion of swearing with another or others: said to have this meaning in the saying of El-Aashà,
raDiyEaIo libaAni vadoIi OumRK taHaAlafaA
biOasoHama daAjK EawoDu laA tatafarRaqu
[Two foster-brothers by the sucking of the breast of one mother swore together, by dark blood into which they dipped their hands, that you, or they, i. e. a tribe (qabiylap) or a company of men (jamaAEap), for, without the context, the meaning is doubtful, should not ever become separated]: or it has here one, or another, of three meanings here following. (S.) ― -b6- The womb. (S.) ― -b7- The nipple of a woman's breast: (K:) or the blackness of the nipple of a woman's breast. (S.) ― -b8- A skin such as is termed ziqR for wine: (S, K:) because of its blackness: and suHayomN↓ also signifies a ziqR (TA.) ― -b9- Also A horn: (S, K:) thus in the saying of Zuheyr,
watacabiybuhaA Eanohu biOasoHama micowadi
[And the frequent repelling of her, or them, from him with a horn; so that mcwd is merely an explicative adjunct, for it also means a horn, or it may be rendered here an instrument for repel-ling]: (S, * TA:) or [AsHm is here an epithet, and] the meaning is, with a black horn. (TA.) Another poet uses the phrase tacubRu bisaHomaAwayoni. [so in the TA, app. a mistranscription for tacubRu,] i. e., [reading tacubRu, She repels] with a pair of horns; using the fem, as meaning biSiySyatayoni;
as though he said biSiySiytayoni saHomaAwayoni [with two black horns]. (IAar, TA.) ― -b10- The fem., AlsRaHomaMCu also signifies The dubur [here meaning anus]: (K:) because of its colour. (TA.) ― -b11- For another signification of the fem., see saHamN.

OusoHumaAnN c
OusoHumaAnN Of the colour termed OudomapN [here app. meaning tawniness] in an intense degree. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A sort of tree. (M, K.) A poet uses the phrase AlOusoHumaAnu AlOasoHamu [The black, or dark, AsHmAn]. (M, TA.)

UisoHimaAnN c
UisoHimaAnN: see OasoHamu, first sentence.

1 saHana c
1. saHana, (S, L, K,) aor.
saHana
, (K,) inf. n. saHonN, (L,) He broke a stone. (S, L, K.) And He crushed, bruised, brayed, or pounded, a thing. (L.) ― -b2- Also He rubbed [in the CK celika is erroneously put for dalaka] a piece of wood so as to make it smooth, (L, K,) with an instrument called misoHan, without taking anything from it. (L.)

3 sAHn AlmaAla c
3. sAHn AlmaAla: see 5. ― -b2- The inf. n. musaAHanapN signifies also The meeting [another] face to face. (L, K.) ― -b3- And you say, saAHanotuka, (L,) inf. n. musaAHanapN, (S, L, K,) I mixed with thee in familiar, or social, intercourse: (L:) and did so in a good manner. (S, L, K.) And saAHanahu AlXRaIoCa He joined, or took part, with him in the thing. (L.)

5 tsHRn AlmaAla c
5. tsHRn AlmaAla He looked at the saHonaMC [or aspect &c.] of the mAl [i. e. cattle, or other property]; as also sAHnhu↓. (L, K.) You say, tasaHRanotu AlmaAla faraOayotu saHonaMCahu HasanapF [I looked at the aspect of the cattle, or other property, and saw the aspect thereof to be goodly]. (S, L.)

saHonN c
saHonN A numerous congregation: so in the phrase yawomu saHonK [A day of a numerous congregation]. (K.)

siHonN c
siHonN Quarter, shelter, or protection; syn. kanafN: so in the saying, huwa fiI siHonihi [He is in his quarter or shelter or protection]. (K.)

saHonapN c
saHonapN and saHanapN↓, (L, K,) or the latter, and, as sometimes pronounced, saHonapN, (S,) and saHonaMCu↓ and saHanaMCu↓, (S, L, K,) pronounced saHanaMCu by Fr, the only person heard by A'Obeyd to pronounce it thus, and said by Ibn-Keysán to be thus pronounced because of the faucial letter, (S, L,) but saHonaMCu↓ is better, (L,) Aspect, appearance, or external state or condition: (S, L, K:) and simply state, or condition: (L:) and colour: and softness, or smoothness, of the external skin: and i. q. naEomapN [as meaning softness, or delicateness: in the CK. AlnRiEomapu is erroneously put for AlnRaEomapu]. (L, K.) You say, UinRahu laHasanu AlsRaHonapi (L) and AlsRaHonaMCi↓ (S, L) [Verily he is goodly in aspect, &c.]: and heWulaMCi qawomN HasanN saHanatuhumo↓ [These are a people, or party, whose aspect, &c., is goodly]. (S, L.) And saHonapN is also expl. as signifying The beauty of the hair, and of the complexion, and of the external skin, of a man. (L.) And it occurs in a trad. as meaning The external skin of the face; and is sometimes pronounced siHonapN↓, and is also called the saHonaMC↓. (L.)

siHonapN c
siHonapN: see what next precedes.

saHanapN c
saHanapN: see saHonapN, in two places.

saHonaMCu c
saHonaMCu and saHanaMCu: see saHonapN; the former in four places.

musoHinN c
musoHinN A horse goodly in condition; as in the saying, jaMCa Alfarasu musoHinFA [The horse came goodly in condition]: fem, with p: (L, K:) you say farasN musoHinapN, (L,) or musaHRanapN↓, (S, [so in my copies,]) a mare goodly in condition and in aspect, (L,) or goodly in aspect. (S.)

misoHanN c
misoHanN An instrument with which wood is rubbed so as to make it smooth without taking anything from it. (L.)

misoHanapN c
misoHanapN A thing with which stones are broken. (S, L, K.) I. q. SalaMCapN [i. e. A stone such as fills the hand: or a stone with which, or on which, one brays, or powders, perfumes or other things]. (L, K. [In the CK, AlSRalAbapu is erroneously put for AlSRalaMCapu or its var. AlSRalaAyapu.]) A thing with which gold is rubbed so that it becomes smooth and glistening. (Skr pp. 154 and 155.) And its pl. masaAHinu is said to signify Stones with which are crushed, or brayed, the stones of [i. e. containing] silver. (Skr, L.) And Mill-stones with which one grinds. (Skr.) And Thin stones with which iron is made thin, (L, * K, [in the former of which yhbRI is erroneously put for yumohaI,]) like [as is done with] the misanR. (L.) And Stones of [i. e. containing] gold and silver: (Skr, K:) so says Ibn-Habeeb. (Skr.)

farasN musaHRanapN c
farasN musaHRanapN: see musoHinN.

1 saHaA AlTRiyna c
1. saHaA AlTRiyna, (K,) first pers. saHawotu (S, Msb) and saHayotu, (S,) aor. yasoHuw, (S, Msb, K,) and yasoHaI, and yasoHiI, (S, K,) inf. n. saHowN (Msb, TA) and saHoIN, (K, TA,) He scraped off, (S, K,) or cleared away, (Msb, K,) [the clay, soil, or mud,] Eano wajohi AlOaroDi [from the surface of the earth], (S, Msb,) with the misoHaAp [q. v.]. (Msb.) ― -b2- saHaA Aljamora He cleared, or swept, away the live, or burning, coals: (K:) ISd says, I think that Lh has mentioned this; but the verb well known in this sense is with x (TA. [See saxaA.]) ― -b3- saHaA AlXRaHoma Eani AlUihaAbi, inf. n. saHowN, He scraped, or pared, off the fat from the skin, or hide. (TA.) It is said in a trad., as some relate it, fajaEalatN tasoHaAhaA, or, as others relate it, tasoHaluhaA, both meaning the same, i. e. And she betook herself to paring, or stripping, off from it the flesh that was upon it. (TA in art. sHl.) And AllRaHoma AstHI↓ signifies He pared, or stripped, off the flesh. (TA.) ― -b4- saHaA AlXRaEara, (K,) aor. yasoHuw and yasoHiI, inf. n. [app. saHowN and] saHoIN, (TA,) He shaved off the hair; as also AstHAhu↓. (K.) ― -b5- saHawotu AlqiroTaAsa, and saHayotuhu, aor. OasoHRI, I scraped off, or otherwise removed, the superficial part of the paper. (S.) [And] saHaA mina AlqiroTaAsi He took, a little from the paper. (K, * TA. [See siHaMCapN, second sentence.]) ― -b6- saHaA AlkitaAba, (K,) first pers. saHawotu and saHayotu, (S,) aor. yasoHuw and yasoHiI, (TA,) He bound the writing (S, K) with a siHaMCap (K) or with the siHaMC [q. v.]; (S;) and so sHRAhu↓, (K,) inf. n. tasoHiyapN; (TA;) and AsHAhu↓; (K;) as in the M. (TA.)

2 1a2RaRa
2: see the next preceding sentence.

4 AsHI c
4. AsHI He (a man S) had many OasoHiyap [pl. of siHaMCapN, (q. v.,) n. un. of siHaMCN]. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- See also 1, last sentence.

7 AnsHI c
7. AnsHI It was, or became, pared; or pared off. (TA.)

8 Ui1ota2a2a
8: see 1, in two places.

saHFA c
saHFA: see the next paragraph, in two places.

saHaApN c
saHaApN The qiXor [or covering, integument, peel, or the like,] of anything: pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] saHFA↓. (S.) See also siHaMCapN. ＝ -A2- A certain thorny tree; (K, TA;) the fruit thereof is white: it is a herb in the spring-season, as long as it remains green: when it dries up in the hot season, it is a tree. (TA.) ＝ -A3- A bat: (ISh, S, K:) pl. saHFA↓; (K;) or [rather] it is the n. un. of saHFA, which is syn. with xufRaAXN [used as a gen. n.]: (ISh, S:) and siHaMCN↓ is a dial. var. of saHFA used in this sense, accord. to Az. (TA.) ＝ -A4- I. q. saAHapN [i. e. The court, or open area, of a house]: (S, K:) formed from the latter word by transposition: (TA:) one says, laA OarayanRaka bisaHosaHiI wasaHaAtiI [I will assuredly not see thee in my quarter, or tract, and my court]. (S.) And I. q. naAHiyapN [A side, region, quarter, or tract, &c.]. (K.)

siHaMCN c
siHaMCN: see siHaMCapN, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also A certain plant, (S, K,) having thorns, (K,) and having a blossom of a red hue inclining to whiteness, called the bhrnp [app. a mistranscription for bahoramap]: (TA:) the bees feed upon it, (S, K,) and their honey in consequence thereof becomes sweet (S, K *) in the utmost degree. (K.) ＝ -A3- See also saHaApN.

siHaMCapN c
siHaMCapN, of a writing, (S, K, TA, [in the CK and in my MS. copy of the K, written, saHaACap,]) and siHaMCN↓, (TA,) or [rather] the former is the n. un. of the latter, (S,) A certain thing with which a writing is bound; (S, K, TA;) called in Pers. muhor naAmah, (PS,) or banod naAmah; (Adillet el-Asmà of Meyd, cited by Golius;) and in Turkish naAmah baAgiI; (Mirkát el-Loghah, cited by the same;) [a sealed strip of paper with which a letter, or the like, is bound:] the letter of a kádee to another kádee is perforated for the siHaMCap, and is then sealed [upon this strip:] (Mgh in art. xzm:) pl. OasoHiyapN. (S.) [The same seems to be meant by what here follows:] siHaMCapu AlqiroTaAsi, (K, TA,) with C, (TA,) and siHaAWuhu↓, (K, TA,) with w [and.],
(TA,) or saHaAtuhu↓, (so in the CK,) or this last also, like HaSaAp, is a dial. var. of the first, (TA,) and siHaAyatuhu↓, (K, TA, [in the CK written with fet-h to the s, but it is]) like kitaAbap, with I, (TA,) What is taken from paper; (K;) the small portion [or strip, app.,] that is taken from paper: (TA:) pl. OasoHiyapN [as above]. (K.) ― -b2- Also, (S, M,) or siHaAyapN↓, (K,) A portion (K) of cloud. (S, K.) One says, maA fiI AlsRamaMCi siHaMCapN mino saHaAbK [There is not in the sky a portion of cloud]. (S.) ― -b3- AlsRiHaMCapu [in the CK AlsRaHACap] also signifies OumRu AlrRaOosi [q. v.], (K, TA,) [app. here meaning The meninx; for SM adds,] in which is the brain; (TA;) as also AlsRiHaAyapu↓, with kesr [to the s]. (K.)

siHaAyapN c
siHaAyapN, (K, TA,) [in the CK saHaAyapN, but it is] with kesr, (TA,) Anything that is pared, or peeled, from a thing. (K, TA.) ― -b2- See also siHaMCapN, in three places. ＝ -A2- Also The art, or craft, of making the kind of implement called misoHaAp: (K, TA:) in this sense, likewise, with kesr, agreeably with analogy. (TA.)

saHRaMCN c
saHRaMCN A maker of the kind of implement called misoHaAp. (T, K.)

saAHK c
saAHK, applied to a [lizard of the species called] DabR, That feeds upon the plant called siHaMC. (S.)

saAHiyapN c
saAHiyapN, (S, K,) [from saAHK,] the p denoting intensiveness, (TA,) A torrent that carries away everything; (K;) that pares and sweeps away everything. (TA.) ― -b2- And A rain that falls with vehemence, (S, K,) paring the surface of the earth. (S.)

OusoHiyRapN c
OusoHiyRapN (with damm, TA) Any integument of skin upon the portions of flesh that are on bones. (Az, K.)

OusoHuwaAnN c
OusoHuwaAnN, with damm, (S, K,) A man (S) that eats much. (S, K.) ― -b2- And (K) Beautiful, or comely, (K,) so expl. by AO, (TA,) [and] tall, (K,) thus expl. by Fr, likewise applied to a man. (TA.)

misoHaApN c
misoHaApN A shovel, or spade, of iron; (MA, PS;) an implement (S, Msb, K) like the mijorafap, except that it is of iron, (S, Msb,) with which clay, soil, or mud, is cleared away (Msb, K) from the surface of the earth: (Msb:) a misoHaAp [for digging, i. e. a spade,] has a cross piece of wood upon which the digger presses his foot: K, voce EitorN:) and there is a curved kind, [app. a sort of hoe,] such as is called in Pers. kananod: (S:) pl. masaAHK. (S, Msb.) Ru-beh likens the toes, or extremities of the fore parts of the hoofs, of horses, to masaAHK; because with them they pare the ground: so in the T: or, accord. to the M, he likens thereto the hoofs of asses. (TA.) ― -b2- misoHaApu AlnRaAri means [The fire-shovel;] a thing with which the fire is stirred. (TA voce miHoraAvo.)

1 saxabN c
1. saxabN [inf. n. of saxiba] i. q. SaxabN [inf. n. of Saxiba], (A, K,) signifying The raising a loud cry, or a clamour: (TA:) or it [is used as a subst., and] signifies a confusion of sounds. (Mgh, MF, TA.) The substitution of s for S is allowable in every word containing x: [for instance,] in a trad. [cited voce xaXabN, q. v., as some relate it], the hypocrites are described as xuXubN biAllRayoli suxubN biAlnRahaAri. (TA.)

sixaAbN c
sixaAbN A necklace (qilaAdap) made of [the composition termed] sukR and of other things, without any jewels: (S:) or a qilaAdap of cloves and sukR and maHolab [q. v.], without jewels, (A, K, TA,) and without pearls: and likewise, of gold: and of silver: or, accord. to Az, it is, with the Arabs, any qilaAdap, whether with jewels or without: accord. to IAth, a string on which are strung beads, worn by boys and by girls: (TA:) it is thus called because of the sound of its beads when in motion: (MF, TA:) pl. suxubN. (S, K.) [Hence] one says, wajadotuka waAriva AlsRixaAbi [I have found thee to be the inheritor of the sxAb], meaning, (tropical:) like the boy that has no knowledge. (A, TA.)

saxobarN c
saxobarN A certain kind of trees, (S, K,) the heads of which, when it grows tall, bend and hang down; [a coll. gen. n.;] n. un. with p: (TA:) it resembles the Uicoxir; (K;) or it is like the vumaAm [or panic grass], and has a [root such as is termed] jurovuwmap; its branches, or twigs, are, in abundance, like the krAv [app. karaAv, a certain large tree, growing on the mountains]; and its fruits resemble brooms of reeds, or are more slender: (AHn:) serpents make their abodes at its roots. (TA.) It is related in a trad. of Ibn-Ez-Zubeyr, that he said to Mo'áwiyeh, laA tuToriqo UiToraAqa AlOufoEuwaAni fiI OuSuwli AlsRaxobari [Do not thou look down upon the ground like as does the male viper at the roots of the sakhbar]; meaning (assumed tropical:) do not thou affect heedlessness of the state in which we are, or of the affair in which we are engaged. (TA.) One says also, rakiba fulaAnN AlsRaxobara, meaning, (assumed tropical:) Such a one acted perfidiously, treacherously, or unfaithfully. (S.) And a poet says,
waAlgadoru yanobutu fiI OuSuwli AlsRaxobari
(assumed tropical:) [And perfidy grows at the roots of the sakhbar]: (S:) [because the viper lives there: or] the poet means, that the people of whom he speaks dwelt in places where the sakhbar grew; and they are thought to have been of the tribe of Hudheyl: IB says that he likens the perfidious to this tree because, when it is full-grown, its head hangs down, not remaining erect; and that he means, ye do not remain faithful, like as this tree does not remain in one state. (TA.)

saxotN c
saxotN, (S, K,) originally Pers., (TA,) Vehement, or intense; (S, K;) as also saxiytN↓ (K) and sixotiytN↓. (S, K.) One says, hecaA HarRN saxotN, (Lh, S,) or saxotN laxotN, (TA,) This is vehement, or intense, heat; a phrase well known in the language of the Arabs, who use certain Pers., or foreign, words, as, for instance, balaAs for misoH. (Lh, S, TA. [See also saHotN.]) And HalifN sixotiytN↓ Vehement swearing. (S.) And kacibN sixotiytN↓ A vehement lie: and a pure, or an unmixed, lie. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, from the Pers., Anything hard and thin or fine. (TA.)

saxiytN c
saxiytN: see the preceding paragraph: ― -b2- and that here following.

sixotiytN c
sixotiytN: see the first paragraph, in three places. ― -b2- Also Dust rising very high: (S, K:) and saxiytN↓ likewise signifies [the same, or] dust rising high; (TA in art. Xxt;) as also XixotiytN and XaxiytN and XixRiytN; (K in that art.;) said to be arabicized words from the Pers. saxoto: (TA in that art.:) and the first (sxtyt [and app. the others also]), fine dust. (TA in the present art.) And Anything fine; as, for instance, flour, or meal. (AA, TA.) Fine sawiyq [or meal of parched barley, &c.]: (As, TA:) or swyq that is not moistened with any seasoning, or savoury admixture: (S:) or swyq having little grease or gravy [mixed with it]; as also siHotiytN and suHotuwtN. (K and TA in the present art. and in art. sHt.) And Fine HuwRaAraI [or white flour]. (As, K.)

sixotiyaAnN c
sixotiyaAnN and saxotyAn (K, TA) and accord. to some suxotyAn; the second of which is asserted by the expositors of Bkh to be the most common and most chaste; but Esh-Shiháb [El-Khafájee], in the “ Sharh esh-Shifà, ” mentions only the form with kesr to the s and fet-h and kesr to the t; and Ibn-Et-Tilimsánee mentions only the form with damm to the s and fet-h and kesr to the t, adding that it is also written with j; MF, however, deems what this last says to be very strange, and more especially with respect to the word's being written with j, which he affirms to be unknown; (TA;) [Morocco-leather; so in the present day;] tanned goat's skin; an arabicized word, (K,) from the Pers.: expl. by IAth as jujube-coloured [or dark dull red] skins (juluwdN EunRaAbiyRapN); not [such as from their red colour are termed] OudomN. (TA.)

sixotiyaAniIRN c
sixotiyaAniIRN A preparer and seller of sixotiyaAn. (K, * TA.)

suxodN c
suxodN [The matter contained in the secundines;] a yellow, thick water [or fluid], that comes forth with the fœtus; (S, M, K;) as also suxotN: (M, TA:) hence, in a trad., the appearance upon the face produced by excitement from remaining awake during the night is termed, by way of comparison, suxod upon the face: (S, * L:) or blood and water in the membrane that envelops the fœtus of a beast: or what comes forth with the membrane that envelops the fœtus: said to be
peculiar to the human species: or common to the human species and beasts: (L:) or the water [or fluid] in that membrane; as also suxotN and nuxoTN and faqoCN: (IAar, TA in art. fqO:) or [the placenta; i. e.] a thing like the liver, or like the spleen, compact, which is in the membrane that envelops the fœtus of a beast: sometimes children play with it: or that membrane itself: and i. q. rahalN [which is expl. as meaning yellow water in the suxodK, and it is also the inf. n. of rahila, q. v.]: and SuxodN is a dial. var. thereof in all its senses, those above mentioned and those following. (L.) ― -b2- Also The urine of a camel's fœtus (faSiyl) in its mother's belly. (L.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) Yellowness in the face [as in the trad. above mentioned]. (L.)

musaxRadN c
musaxRadN (assumed tropical:) Having the stomach in a heaving state, agitated by a tendency to vomit, or disordered; (K;) yellow, (S, K,) heavy, (S,) and swollen, (S, K,) by disease or by some other cause. (TA.)

1 saxira minohu c
1. saxira minohu, (Fr, Akh, S, A, Msb, K,) and bihi, (AZ, Akh, S, Msb, K,) like as one says DaHika minohu and bihi, and haziYa minohu and bihi, (Akh, S,) but the former is the more chaste, (En-Näwawee, TA,) and is that which occurs in the Kur ix. 80, and xi. 40, [&c.,] (TA,) and J says that the latter is the worse of the two, (S,) and Fr disallows it absolutely, (TA,) aor.
saxara
, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. saxarN (S, Msb, K) and saxorN (K) and suxorN and suxurN (S, K) and suxorapN (K) and masoxarN, (S, K,) He mocked at, scoffed at, laughed at, derided, or ridiculed, him; (S, * A, Msb, K, &c.;) as also Astsxr↓: (A, * K:) and yasotasoxiruwna↓, in the Kur xxxvii. 14, signifies, accord. to Ibn-Er-Rummánee, they invite one another to mock, scoff, deride, or ridicule. (TA.) ― -b2- It is said in a trad., Oatasoxaru minRiI waOanaA Almaliku Dost thou mock at me, or deride me, when I am the king? or, as some say, it is tropical, and means, (tropical:) dost thou put me in a place which I do not regard as my right? so that it seems to denote a species of mockery. (TA.) ― -b3- And in another trad. it is said, OanaA Ouquwlu kacaA walaA Oasoxaru (tropical:) [I say so, and I do not jest]; meaning I say not aught but the truth. (A, * TA.) ― -b4- The words (of the Kur [xi. 40] TA) Uino tasoxaruwA minRaA faUinRaA nasoxaru minokumo kamaA tasoxaruwna are said to signify If ye deem us ignorant, we also deem you ignorant like as ye deem us ignorant. (K.) ＝ -A2- saxarahu: see 2. ― -b2- saxarati AlsRafiynapu, aor.
saxara
, (tropical:) The ship had a good wind and voyage; (K;) [as though it made the wind subservient, or submissive, to it; (see 2;)] it obeyed, and ran its course. (TA.)

2 sxRrhu c
2. sxRrhu, inf. n. tasoxiyrN, He constrained him, or compelled him, (JK, S, K,) namely, a servant, or a beast, to do what he [the latter] did not desire, (JK, TA,) or to work, without recompense, or hire, or wages, (S, K,) and without price; (TA;) as also tsxRrhu↓: (S, Mgh, * K:) and [in like manner,] saxarahu↓, aor.
saxara
, inf. n. sixoriIRN and suxoriIRN, he constrained him to do what he did not desire; compelled him: (K:) or sxRrhu, he made use of him without compensation, (A, Msb,) fiI AlEamali [in work]. (Msb.) You say, tasaxRarotu↓ daAbRapF lifulaAnK I rode a beast belonging to such a one without recompense. (TA.) ― -b2- He brought him under, or into subjection; rendered him subservient, submissive, tractable, or manageable. (S, K.) You say, sxRr QllRehu AlUibila God hath made the camels subservient, or submissive, and manageable. (Msb.) And in the Kur [xiv. 37], it is said, wasaxRara lakumu QlXRamosa waQloqamara (assumed tropical:) And He hath made subservient to you, or submissive for you, the sun and the moon [to run their appointed courses]. (TA.) suxRira lahu [as also lh tusuxRira↓] signifies (assumed tropical:) It (anything) was rendered submissive or manageable or practicable, to him, or prepared or disposed for him agreeably with his desire. (TA.) You say also, sxRr QllRehu AlsRafiynapa, inf. n. tasoxiyrN, (tropical:) God made the ship to obey and to run its course; to have a good wind and voyage. (TA.) saxRarahaA Ealayohimo, in the Kur lxix. 7, means (assumed tropical:) He sent it upon them by force; namely, the wind: (Jel:) or made it to prevail against them by his power. (Bd.)

5 tasaxRara
5: see 2, in three places.

10 Uisotasoxara
10: see 1, in two places.

suxorapN c
suxorapN One who is mocked at, scoffed at, laughed at, derided, or ridiculed; a laughingstock; (S, A, K;) as also sixoriIRN↓ and suxoriIRN; (Az, A;) which are used as sing., as in the phrase AitRaxacuwhu suiHoriyRFA they made him a laughingstock; (A;) and as pl., as in humo laka suixoriIRN, and also suixoriyRapN↓, the former being masc. and the latter fem., they are to thee laughingstocks; the former occurring in the Kur [see xxiii. 112, and xxxviii. 63, and xliii. 31,] with damm and with kesr accord. to different readings. (Az, TA.) ― -b2- Also One who is constrained, or compelled, to do what he does not desire, or to work, without recompense, or hire, or wages; (JK, S, * Mgh, * Msb, * K, * TA;) applied to a servant, (JK, S, Msb,) and to a beast; (JK, Msb;) as also suxoriIRN↓ (Msb, K) and sixoriIRN; (K) or the former of these, only, is used in this sense; and the latter, and sometimes the former also, in the sense immediately preceding: (TA:) and suxorapN is also used as a pl., (JK, A,) as in the phrase heWulaMCi suxorapN lilsRuloTaAni these are persons made use of without compensation for the Sultán: (JK, * A:) it also signifies one who employs any person, (K, TA,) or beast, (TA,) that he has subjected, or compelled to obey him, without recompense, or hire, or wages: (K, TA:) [or this is a mistake, and the correct signification is] one who is so employed by him who has subjected him. (L.) ― -b3- It is also syn. with tasoxiyrN [inf. n. of 2]. (TA in art. smE.)

suxarapN c
suxarapN One who mocks at, scoffs at, laughs at, derides, or ridicules, others, (S, K,) much. (S.) [See also masoxarapN.]

suxoriIRN c
suxoriIRN and sixoriIRN (T, S, Msb, K) and suixoriyRapN (T, S, K) Mockery; scoff; derision; ridicule. (T, S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- See also suxorapN, in three places.

suxRarN c
suxRarN A certain herb, or leguminous plant, (Sgh, K,) in Khurásán; (K;) accord. to AHn, i. q. sayokuraAnN [q. v.]. (TA.)

sufunN sawaAxiru c
sufunN sawaAxiru [pl. of safiynapN saAxirapN] (tropical:) Ships obeying, and having a good wind. (S.)

masoxarapN c
masoxarapN [An occasion, or a cause, of mockery, scoffing, derision, or ridicule]: pl. masaAxiru. (A.) You say rubRa masaAxira yaEudRuhaA AlnRaAsu mafaAxira [Many occasions of mockery, &c., men reckon occasions of boasting, or glorying]. (A.) And huwa masoxarapN [He is a cause of mockery, &c.]. (A.) [See also maxosarapN.] ― -b2- Also One who mocks at, scoffs at, laughs at, derides, or ridicules, others. (A.) [See also suxarapN.]

musaxRarN c
musaxRarN Any one that is constrained, or compelled, [brought into subjection, or made subservient or submissive,] and managed, unable to free himself from constraint. (TA.) ― -b2- waQlnRujuwmu musaxRaraAtN biOamorihi [in the Kur xvi. 12 means And the stars are made subservient, or submissive,] running their courses. (Az, TA.)

1 saxiTa c
1. saxiTa, aor.
saxaTa
, inf. n. saxaTN (S, * Msb, K *) [and masoxaTN, (see suxoTN, below,)] He was, or became, displeased, or discontented; (S, * K, TA;) as also tsxRT↓; (K, TA;) syns. kariha and takarRaha [the latter of which, app. referring particularly to tsxRT↓, properly and generally signifies, when intrans., he expressed, or showed, dislike, displeasure, disapprobation, discontent, or hatred]: (TA:) he was, or became, angry; (S, Msb, TA;) and tsxRT↓ signifies the same; or he became angered; syn. tagaDRaba. (TA.) You say, saxiTa Ealayohi [He was, or became, displeased, or discontented, or angry, with him]. (Kur v. 83.) And saxiTahu He was, or became, displeased, or discontented, with him; as also tsxRThu↓; both expl. by lamo yaroDa bihi; (Ham p. 502;) and the latter by takarRahahu [which signifies as above, like karihahu, and also he expressed, or showed, dislike of it, displeasure with it, disapprobation of it, discontent with it, or hatred of it]; (K, TA;) and lamo yaroDahu; (TA;) as in the saying, kulRamaA Eamilotu lahu EamalFA tasaxRaTahu↓ [Every time that I did for him a deed, he expressed, or showed, dislike of it, &c.]; and in like manner, OaEoTaAhu qaliylFA fatasaxRaTahu↓ [He gave him little and he expressed, or showed, dislike of it, &c.]: (TA:) and [hence,] EaTaMCahu tasaxRaTa↓ He deemed his gift little, and it did not stand with him in any stead; expl. by AisotaqalRahu walamo yaqaEo minohu mawoqiEFA. (S, K.) You say also, AallRehu yasoxaTu lakumo kacaA, meaning God forbiddeth you such a thing: or will punish you for such a thing: or it may refer to the desire of punishing for it. (TA.)

4 AsxThu c
4. AsxThu [He displeased, or discontented, him:] he angered him; made him angry. (S, Msb, K.)

5 tasaxRaTa
5: see 1, in seven places.

suxoTN c
suxoTN, (S, Msb, K,) a subst. from saxiTa, (Msb,) Dislike, displeasure, disapprobation, or discontent; (TA;) contr. of riDFI; (S, K, TA;) as also suxuTN↓ (Sgh, K) and saxaTN↓ (S, K) and masoxaTN↓: (Sgh, K:) [the last two of which are inf. ns.:] anger; (Msb;) as also saxaTN↓. (TA.)

saxaTN c
saxaTN: see suxoTN, in two places.

suxuTN c
suxuTN: see suxoTN.

saAxiTN c
saAxiTN [Displeased; discontented:] angry. (S.)

masoxaTN c
masoxaTN: see suxoTN.

masoxaTapN c
masoxaTapN [A cause, or means, or an occasion, of dislike, displeasure, disapprobation, or discontent: and, of anger: or a cause, &c., of procuring dislike, &c.: pl., app., masaAxiTu and masaAxiTapN. Hence the saying,] AlbirRu maroDaApN lilrRabRi masoxaTapN lilXRayoTaAni [Piety is a cause of approbation to the Lord; a cause of disapprobation, or anger, to the devil]. (TA.)

masoxuwTN c
masoxuwTN Disliked, disapproved, or hated: (A, K:) in this sense applied to a gift. (A, TA.) You say also, huwa masoxuwTN Ealayohi He is an object of anger. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Transformed, or metamorphosed, into a worse, or more foul, or more ugly, shape: [and hence applied by the Arabs in the present day to any idol or other image of ancient workmanship; such being regarded by them as metamorphosed in consequence of having incurred the wrath of God:] and short: but thus applied, it is a vulgar term. (TA.)

1 saxufa c
1. saxufa, [aor.
saxufa
,] inf. n. saxaAfapN (Mgh, Msb, TA) and suxofN, or, accord. to Kh, the former only, (Msb,) said of a garment, or piece of cloth, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) It was, or became, thin, flimsy, or unsubstantial; (Msb;) scanty in the yarn; (Mgh, Msb;) or thin in texture. (TA.) And saxufa, (TA,) inf. n. saxaAfapN, said of anything, It was, or became, thin, slender, or unsubstantial. (Msb, * TA. [See saxaAfapN below, voce suxofN.]) And saxufa, inf. n. suxofN, (K,) or rather saxaAfapN, accord. to what is said below of a distinction between these two ns., (TA,) said of a skin for water or milk, It was, or became, unsound, (K, TA,) altered for the worse, old, and worn out. (TA.) ― -b2- saxufa, aor. saxaAfapN, [or suxofN, q. v. infrà,] is also said of a man, meaning He was, or became, slender, or shallow, or weak, in intellect. (S, K. *) And it is also said of the intellect, meaning It was, or became, slender, &c. (K, * TK.)

2 sxRfhu c
2. sxRfhu, inf. n. tasoxiyfN, [It rendered him thin, lean, or emaciated,] said of hunger. (A, TA.)

3 sAxfhu c
3. sAxfhu, (S, K,) inf. n. musaAxafapN, (TA,) i. q. HaAmaqahu [He aided him in his foolishness, or stupidity]. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- musaAxafapN signifies [also] The showing, or making a show of, foolishness or stupidity. (KL.)

4 Asxf c
4. Asxf, inf. n. UisoxaAfN, said of a man, His property became little, or scanty. (TA.) ＝ -A2- maA Oasoxafahu How [slender, shallow, weak,] deficient, or defective, is he in intellect! (Sb, TA.)

10 Astsxfhu c
10. Astsxfhu He deemed him slender, shallow, or weak, in intellect: but this is perhaps postclassical.]

saxofN c
saxofN Slenderness of the means of subsistence. (AA, K.) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph.

suxofN c
suxofN (AA, JK, S, Mgh, Msb, K) and saxofN↓ (JK, K) and suxofapN↓ and saxaAfapN↓ (K) Slenderness, shallowness, or weakness, of intellect, (AA, JK, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) &c.: (K:) or, as some say, a lightness [of body] incident to a man when he is hungry: [but it is not clearly shown whether this refer to all of the foregoing words or only to the last, or last two, of them: (see saxofap, below:)] and some say that suxofapN↓ signifies weakness of intellect; or deficiency thereof: (TA:) or suxofN is in the intellect; and saxaAfapN↓ is [thinness, &c., (see 1,)] in everything; (Kh, Msb, K, TA;) as, for instance, in clouds, and in a skin for water or milk, and in herbage, and in a garment, or piece of cloth, &c. (TA.)

saxofapu AljuwEi c
saxofapu AljuwEi, (S, K,) and suxofatuhu↓, (JK, K,) The thinness, and leanness, or emaciation, consequent upon hunger. (JK, S, K.) One says, bihi saxofapN mina AljawEi In him is thinness, &c., consequent upon hunger. (S, TA.)

suxofapN c
suxofapN: see suxofN, in two places: ― -b2- and see the paragraph here next preceding.

saxiyfN c
saxiyfN, applied to a garment, or piece of cloth, (JK, Mgh, Msb, K, TA,) Thin, flimsy, or unsubstantial; (Msb;) scanty in the yarn; (Mgh, Msb;) or thin in texture. (JK, TA.) It is also applied to anything, as, for instance, clouds (saHaAb), and herbage, (JK,) in both of these cases meaning Thin; (TA;) and to a skin for water or milk [as meaning unsound, altered for the worse, old, and worn out; see 1]: (JK:) and to the iron head or blade of an arrow or a spear or the like as meaning long and broad [and app. thin]. (AHn, TA.) ― -b2- Also, applied to a man, Slender, or shallow, or weak, in intellect: (JK, S, Mgh, Msb, K: *) and, thus applied, (K,) or saxiyfu AlEaqoli, (TA,) lightwitted; or light, or unsteady, in intellect: (K, TA:) from the same epithet applied to a garment, or piece of cloth. (Mgh, Msb.)

saxaAfapN c
saxaAfapN: see suxofN, in two places. [And see also 1, of which it is an inf. n.]

OaroDN musoxifapN c
OaroDN musoxifapN A land in which is little herbage: (ISh, K:) from saxiyfN as an epithet applied to a garment, or piece of cloth. (TA.) [See also ArD musoHafapN, in art. sHf.]

1 saxalahumo c
1. saxalahumo, aor.
saxala
, (K,) inf. n. saxolN, (TA,) He drove away, repelled, or banished, them: (K, TA: [in the CK, naqRAhumo is erroneously put for nafaAhumo:]) and xasialahumo signifies the same. (TA.) ― -b2- And saxala AlXRaIoCa He took the thing by deceit (K, TA) and by seizure: but not known to Az except on the authority of Lth; and its correctness is doubted by him, unless it be formed by transposition from xalasa, like as they said jacaba and jabaca, and baDRa and DabRa. (TA.)

2 sxRlt AlnRaxolapu c
2. sxRlt AlnRaxolapu, inf. n. tasoxiylN, The palmtree bore dates such as are termed [suxRal, i. e.] XiyS: (S, TA:) so in the dial. of El-Hijáz: (TA:) or it was weak in its date-stones and its dates: or it shook off its dates. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And sxRl, (K,) or sxRl AlnRaxolapa, (TA,) said of a man, He shook the palm-tree in order that its dates might fall off. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- And sxRlhu, (S,) or sxRlhumo, inf. n. as above, (K,) He attributed, or imputed, to him, or them, a vice, fault, or defect, (S, K, TA,) and reckoned him, or them, weak: of the dial. of Hudheyl. (S, TA.)

4 Asxlhu c
4. Asxlhu It (an affair, or event, TA) kept him, or held him, back; delayed him, or retarded him. (K, TA.)

saxolN c
saxolN: see saxolapN. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) An infant that is an object of love to his parents: (IAar, O, TA:) originally, the “ offspring of the sheep or goat ” [app. as a sing. as well as a coll. gen. n.]. (TA.) ― -b3- See also suxRalN, in two places.

saxolapN c
saxolapN A lamb, or kid, in whatever state it be; (K;) male or female: (TA:) or a lamb, or kid, when just born; male or female: (S, M, O, Msb, K:) or, accord. to some, peculiarly applied to a lamb; and this is affirmed by 'Iyád and Er-Ráfi'ee: accord. to some, peculiarly to a kid; and so affirms IAth: (TA:) [see also bahomN, in three places:] pl. saxolN↓, (S, O, Msb, K,) [or rather this is a coll. gen. n.] like as tamorN is of tamorapN, (Msb,) [and is app. also used as a sing., (see the next preceding paragraph,)] and [the pl. properly so termed is] sixaAlN (S, O, Msb, K) and sixalapN, which is extr.
