[as a pl. form, so much so that Sb holds it to be a quasi-pl. measure, not a broken pl. measure, as is said in the TA voce jibaOapN]. (K.)

suxRalN c
suxRalN (Az, S, O, K) and suxRaAlN↓, (Az, O, K,) applied to men, Weak; (S, O, K;) bad, vile, or base; (K;) or low, ignoble, mean, or sordid: (Az, O:) a pl. having no sing.: (Az, S, O:) or its sing. is saxolN↓: (K, TA: in the CK suxRalN [like the former pl.]:) so says Khálid. (IJ, TA.) ― -b2- Also suxRalN, (CK,) or saxolN↓, (TK,) [in the TA without any syll. signs,] Anything not completed. (IJ, K.) ― -b3- Also the former, (S, O, K,) in the dial. of the people of El-Medeeneh, (S, O,) The sort of dates termed XiyS, (S, O, K,) i. e. of which the stones do not become hard: (TA:) or, accord. to 'Eesà Ibn-'Omar, dates of which two or three grow together in one place, intermingling. (O, TA.)

suxaAlapN c
suxaAlapN Refuse; syn. nufaAyapN. (JK, O, K, TA: in the CK nuqAyap.)

suxRaAlN c
suxRaAlN: see suxRalN.

masxuwlN c
masxuwlN Pronounced to be low, base, vile, mean, or contemptible: (K:) like maxosuwlN. (TA.) ― -b2-
Unknown: (S, O, K:) and so maxosuwlN. (O.) A poet says,
turaI fiI AlsRamaMCi walaA tuEolamu
waOanotumo kawaAkibu masoxuwlapN
[And ye are stars unknown, that are seen in the sky but not known]: or, as some relate it, maxosuwlapN. (S, O.)

2 saxRama wajohahu c
2. saxRama wajohahu, [inf. n. tasoxiymN,] He blackened his face (S, Mgh, Msb, K) with suxaAm, i. e. crock of the cooking-pot, (Msb,) or it is from AlsRuxaAmu; (Mgh;) like sHRmhu, (Z, TA,) which is from AlOasoHamu. (Mgh.) 'Omar said of him who bears false witness, yusaxRamu wajohuhu [His face shall be blackened]. (TA.) And one says, saxRama QllRehu wajohahu, i. e. May God blacken his face: (S:) [or (assumed tropical:) may God disgrace him:] or (tropical:) may God hate him, or hate him in the utmost degree; and be angry with him. (Msb.) ― -b2- sxRm AlmaMCa, He heated the water, (IAar, K, TA,) and made it to boil. (IAar, TA.) ― -b3- And sxRm biSadorihi, inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) He angered him. (K.) ＝ -A2- sxRm AllRaHomu, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) The flesh-meat became stinking; (K, TA;) became altered [for the worse]. (TA.)

5 tsxRm Ealayohi c
5. tsxRm Ealayohi (assumed tropical:) He became affected with rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, against him: (K:) or he became angered against him. (TA.)

saxamN c
saxamN: see what next follows.

suxomapN c
suxomapN, (S, TA, [so in both of my copies of the former, erroneously written by Golius and Freytag, in the first of the following senses, saxamapN,]) with damm, (TA,) Blackness; (S, TA;) as also saxamN↓, (K, TA,) and [suHomapN and] saHamN. (TA.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) Anger. (TA.) See also saxiymapN.

suxaAmN c
suxaAmN Crock, or black matter, [that collects upon the outside] of a cooking-pot. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.) ― -b2- And Charcoal: (K:) heard in this sense from a man of Himyer. (As, TA.) ― -b3- [Hence,] Black hair. (TA.) And layolN suxaAmN and suxaAmiIRN↓ Black night. (Ham p. 38.) ＝ -A2- Also Soft feathers beneath the upper feathers of a bird: (K, * TA:) n. un. with p. (TA.) ― -b2- And Soft to the feel, (K, TA,) and goodly; (TA;) applied to a garment, or piece of cloth; such as [the kind of cloth called] xazR; and cotton; and the like: (K, TA:) you say vawobN suxaAmu AlmasRi a garment soft to the feel; such as xazR: and riyXN suxaAmN feathers soft to the feel: and quTonN suxaAmN [cotton soft to the feel]: it is not from the signification of “ blackness. ” (S.) And hence, (S,) xamorN suxaAmN Wine that descends smoothly and easily [down the throat]; as also suxaAmiyRapN↓ (S, K) and suxaAmiIRN↓, (K,) or, accord. to ' Alee Ibn- Hamzeh, only the former of these two: (TA:) and [in like manner] TaEaAmN suxaAmN food that is soft, or smooth, and easy in descent. (IAar.)

saxiymN c
saxiymN, applied to water, Neither hot nor cold; as also saxiynN. (AA, L in art. sxn.)

saxiymapN c
saxiymapN (S, K) and suxomapN↓ (K) Rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite; (S, K;) and anger in the soul: (S, TA:) pl. of the former saxaAYimu. (TA.) [See two exs. in the first paragraph of art. sl.] ― -b2- And the former, by a metonymy, is used as meaning (tropical:) Excrement, or dung: so in the trad., mano sakRa saxiymatahu fiI Tariyqi Almusolimiyna laEanahu QllRehu (tropical:) [Whoso voids his excrement in the road, or path, of the Muslims, him God curses]. (TA.)

suxaAmiIRN c
suxaAmiIRN, and suxaAmiyRapN: see suxaAmN, in three places.

Oasoxamu c
Oasoxamu Black; (S, K;) like OasoHamu. (TA.) ― -b2- [The fem.] saxomaMCu is said to be applied to wine (xamor) as meaning Inclining to blackness: but what has been said above [app. as to the word and the meaning] is more approved. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, applied to a [stony tract such as is termed] HarRap, Of which what is smooth, or soft, or plain, thereof, is intermixed with what is rugged. (K.)

musaxRamN c
musaxRamN One in whom is saxiymap, i. e. rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite. (K.)

1 saxuna c
1. saxuna, (JK, S, MA, L, Msb, K,) aor.
saxuna
; (TA;) and saxana, (S, MA, L, Msb, K,) aor.
saxuna
; (TK;) and saxina, (L, Msb, K,) which is of the dial. of Benoo-'Ámir, (L,) aor.
saxana
; (TK;) inf. n. suxuwnapN, (JK, S, MA, L, Msb, K,) which is of the first [agreeably with analogy] (JK, S, MA) and of the second also, (S,) and suxonapN, (JK, L, K,) which is of the first, (JK,) and suxonN, (MA, L, K, [accord. to some copies of the K, in which biDamRatayoni is put instead of biDamRihinRa after these three inf. ns., suxunN,]) which is likewise of the first, (MA,) [or of the first and second,] and saxaAnapN, (L, Msb, K,) [also of the first accord. to general analogy,] and saxanN, (K,) [which is of the third verb;] It was, or became, hot, or warm; (JK, S, MA, L, K;) said of water, (JK, S, L, Msb,) &c. (S, MA, L, Msb.) And saxanati AlnRaAru, and Alqidoru, [and saxunat,] aor.
saxuna
, inf. n. suxonN and suxuwnapN, [The fire, and the cooking-pot, became hot.] (L.) And saxunati AlOaroDu and saxanat and saxinat [The ground became hot]. (L.) And saxunato Ealayohi AlXRamosu [The sun became hot upon him]: in the dial. of Benoo-'Ámir saxinato. (L.) And saxuna Alyawomu, (L, Msb,) and saxana, aor.
saxuna
, and some say saxina, aor.
saxana
, inf. n. suxonN and suxunN, [The day was, or became, hot, or warm.] (L.) And saxunati AldRaAbRapu The beast, being made to run, became hot in its bones, and light, or agile, in its running; [or simply, became hot, or heated; (see EM pp. 172 and 173;)] as also saxanat. (L.) And saxinato Eayonuhu, with kesr, (JK, * S, MA, L, K,) and saxunato, (JK, L,) or the former only, (L,) inf. n. suxonapN (JK, S, * MA, L, K, [in the CK, erroneously, saxonap,]) and suxuwnN (JK, L, K) and saxanN, (L, K, [accord. to the CK saxonN, but this is a mistake,]) contr. of qarRato (S, * L, K *) [i. e.] His eye was, or became, hot, [or heated, or inflamed, by weeping, or by grief or sorrow; or hot] in its tears. (MA.)

2 saxRana
2: see the next paragraph.

4 Asxnhu c
4. Asxnhu; (L, Msb, K;) inf. n. UisoxaAnN, (S, L,) He heated it, or warmed it; made it hot, or warm; (S, * L, Msb, * K;) namely, water, (S, L, Msb,) &c.; (L, Msb;) as also sxRnhu↓, (L, Msb, K,) inf. n. tasoxiynN. (S, L.) And Asxn QllRehu Eayonahu, (S, L, K,) and biEayonihi, (L, K,) [God made his eye to become hot, or heated, or inflamed, by weeping, or by grief or sorrow; or, simply,] made him to weep. (S, L, K.)

saxonN c
saxonN: see suxonapN. ― -b2- [The signification of “ calor aquæ aliarumve rerum, ” assigned to it by Freytag as on the authority of J, is a mistake, probably occasioned by a fault in his copy of the S.]

suxonN c
suxonN an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (MA, L, K.) ― -b2- Also Hot, or warm; (MA, PS;) i. q. HaArRN; (S, MA, Mgh, L, K;) contr. of baAridN; (JK, L;) an epithet applied to water, (JK, MA, Mgh, L,) &c.; (Msb;) as is also (in the same sense, JK, MA, Mgh, L) saxiynN↓, (JK, S, MA, Mgh, L, Msb, K,) and saAxinN↓, (Msb,) and musoxanN↓, syn. with saxiynN like as muboramN is with bariymN, &c., (IAar, S, L,) or musaxRanN↓, [which is syn. with musoxanN as meaning heated, or warmed,] like muEaZRamN [in measure], (K,) and sixRiynN↓, (L, K,) and suxaAxiynN↓, which is the only instance of the measure, (S, L, K, [which measure is said in the S to be fuEaAEiylN, but in the K fuEaAliylN,]) and which is also applied to food; (L;) syn. HaArRN: (L, K:) or, accord. to AA, saxiynN↓, applied to water, means neither hot nor cold; as also saxiymN. (L.) And yawomN suxonN and saAxinN↓ (S, L, Msb, K) and saxonaAnN↓ or saxanaAnN↓, (accord. to different copies of the S,) or both these, (K,) and suxonaAnN↓, (L, K, * [in the CK and in my MS. copy of the K written suxonaAnu, which is incorrect, and in like manner saxonaAnN is there written saxonaAnu↓, but this, as well as saxonaAnN, may be correct, for it appears that saxonaAn has saxonaMCu for its fem. as well as saxonaAnapN,]) and suxaAxiynN↓ signifies the same, [i. e. A hot, or warm, day,] or, accord. to IAar, yawomN suxaAxiynN↓ signifies a day that is [so hot as to be] hurtful, and painful: (L:) and layolapN suxonapN (S, L, Msb, K) and saAxinapN↓ (L, Msb, K) and saxonaAnapN↓ or saxanaAnapN↓, (S, accord. to different copies,) or both, (K,) and suxonaAnapN↓, (L, K,) [i. e. a hot, or warm, night,] or yawomN saxanaAnN↓ signifies a day intensely hot, and layolapN saxonaMCu↓ [the latter word being fem. of saxonaAnu] a sultry night, or intensely hot so that it takes away the breath: (JK:) and it is said in a trad. of Mo'áwiyeh Ibn-Kurrah, XarRu AlXRitaMCi AlsRaxiynu↓, meaning [The worst of winter is] the hot in which is no cold; in the “ Ghareeb ” of El- Harbee, AlsRuxayoxiynu↓, expl. as meaning the same, but this is probably a mistranscription. (L.)

saxanN c
saxanN an inf. n. of 1 [q. v., last sentence]. See also suxonapN.

saxonapN c
saxonapN: see the next paragraph.

suxonapN c
suxonapN an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (JK, S, * &c.) [Hence,] one says, UinRiI laOajidu fiI nafosiI suxonapF, (L, K, *) as also saxanapF↓ (S, L, K, the only form mentioned in the S in this case) and saxonapF↓ (L, K) and sixonapF↓ and saxonFA↓, (K,) or saxanFA↓, (JK,) and saxonaMCa↓ (L) and suxuwnapF↓ (L, K) [and UisoxinapF↓ (in the JK erroneously written OsoxinapF) contr. of UiboridapF], meaning [Verily I find, or experience, in myself,] an excess of heat arising from pain: (S, L:) or [simply] heat: or fever. (L, K.) [Hence also,] suxonapu AlEayoni contr. of qurRatuhaA [i. e. it signifies A hot, or heated, or an inflamed, state of the eye, by reason of weeping, or of grief or sorrow; or heat in the tears of the eye: see 1, last sentence]. (S, L, K.)

sixonapN c
sixonapN: see the next preceding paragraph. ― -b2- One says also, Ealayoka biAlOamori Einoda sixonatihi, meaning (assumed tropical:) [Keep thou to the affair] while it is in its first state, before it become cold [i. e. unmanageable, like cold iron]. (L.)

saxanapN c
saxanapN: see suxonapN.

saxonaMCu c
saxonaMCu [as fem. of saxonaAnu]: see suxonN, latter part. ― -b2- See also suxonapN.

saxonaAnN c
saxonaAnN and saxonaAnu and suxonaAnN, and saxanaAnN in two places, and the same with p: see suxonN.

saxuwnN c
saxuwnN Broth heated, or made hot. (S, L, K.)

saxiynN c
saxiynN: see suxonN, in three places. [See also a saying of ' Amr Ibn-Kulthoom cited in the first paragraph of art. sxw and sxI.] ― -b2- Also, (K,) or saxiynu AlEayoni, (S, MA, L,) A man whose eye is [hot, or heated, or inflamed, by weeping, or by grief or sorrow; or] hot in its tears. (S, * MA, L, * K. *) ― -b3- And DarobN saxiynN, (K,) or sixRiynN↓, (L,) (assumed tropical:) A hot, [i. e.] painful, smiting. (L, K. [Both are probably correct: that the latter is so is shown by what here follows.]) Ibn-Mukbil says,
DarobFA taraAmato bihi AlOaboTaAlu sixRiynaA↓
[A smiting which the brave men cast, one at another, burning, or painful: the measure (basiyT) requires us to read the last word thus, with tesh-deed to the x]. (L.)

saxuwnapN c
saxuwnapN: see saxiynapN.

suxuwnapN c
suxuwnapN an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (JK, S, &c.) See also suxonapN.

saxiynapN c
saxiynapN A certain thin food, made of flour; (K;) a kind of food made of flour, thinner than [the kind of gruel called] EaSiydap and thicker than [the soup called] HasaMC; like nafiytap, it is eaten only in a time of straitness, and dearth, and leanness of the cattle; and Kureysh were taunted on account of their eating it; (S, L;) for they ate it much; and were called saxiynap: accord. to Az, it is also called saxuwnapN↓: accord. to AHeyth, on the authority of an Arab of the desert, it is flour thrown upon water or upon milk, and cooked, and then eaten [with dates (see xaziyrN)], or supped; and this is what is called HasaMC: [it is said in the Mgh to be the same as HasaMC:] accord. to others, hot food: or food made of flour and clarified butter: or, of flour and dates, thicker than HasaMC and thinner than EaSiydap. (L.)

sixRiynN c
sixRiynN: see suxonN: and saxiynN, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also, (L, K,) in the S saxiynN, which is a mistake, (K,) A misoHaAp [or shovel, or spade]: or a curved misoHaAp: of the dial. of 'Abd-El-Keys: (S, L:) pl. saxaAxiynu. (L, K.) [And] The marR [or shovel, or spade,] with which one works in earth or mud: (JK:) or the handle of the [implement called] miHoraAv [q. v.]; (L, K;) i. e., (L,) its marR, which is also called miEozaq. (IAar, L.) And A knife: or a butcher's knife: pl. as above. (IAar, L, K.)

suxaAxiynN c
suxaAxiynN: see suxonN, in three places. Also Rain coming in the intense heat of summer. (JK.)

AlsRuxayoxiynu c
AlsRuxayoxiynu: see suxonN, last sentence.

saAxinN c
saAxinN; and its fem., with p: see suxonN, in three places.

UisoxinapN c
UisoxinapN contr. of UiboridapN: (K:) [see the latter word: and] see suxonapN.

tasoxanN c
tasoxanN and tasoxaAnN: see the next paragraph; the latter, in two places.

tasaAxiynu c
tasaAxiynu, accord. to Th, (Mgh, L, Msb,) a pl. having no sing., (S, Mgh, L, Msb, K,) like taEaAXiybu; (S;) or its sing. is tasoxaAnN↓ and tasoxanN↓, (Mgh, L, Msb, K,) Boots; syn. xifaAfN [pl. of xufRN]: (JK, S, Mgh, L, Msb, K:) occurring in a trad., in which it is said, Oamarahumo Oano yamosaHuwA EalaI AlmaXaAwici waAltRasaAxiyni, (S, L,) [expl. as] meaning [He ordered them to wipe] the turbans and the boots. (L.) [But see what here follows.] ― -b2- Also A kind of thing like the TayaAlis [pl. of TayolasaAnN, q. v.]: (K:) Hamzeh El-Isbahánee says, tasoxaAnN↓ is an arabicized word from [the Pers.] taXokn [?], the name of a certain kind of headcovering, which the learned men, and the lawyers of the Persians or the judges of the Magians, exclusively of other persons, used to put upon their heads; and by such as knew not its Pers. original, it has been expl. as meaning a boot. (IAth, L.) ＝ -A2- Also i. q. maraAjilu [i. e. Cookingpots, or copper cooking-pots, &c.; pl. of mirojalN, q. v.]. (L, K. [In the CK, AlmaraAHilu AlxifAfu is erroneously put for AlmaraAjilu waAlxifaAfu. See also misoxanapN.])

musoxanN c
musoxanN: see suxonN, second sentence.

masoxanapN c
masoxanapN [A cause of heat or warmth]: see an ex. voce maboradapN [which signifies the contrary].

misoxanapN c
misoxanapN A cooking-pot (qidorN, JK, S, L) of the kind called biraAm [pl. of buromapN, q. v.], (L, K,) like the [vessel called] tawor [q. v.], (JK, S, L, K,) in which food is heated: or accord. to ISh, a small cooking-pot in which one cooks for a child. (L.)

musaxRanN c
musaxRanN: see suxonN, second sentence.

1 saxaA c
1. saxaA, aor. yasoxuw; (S, Msb, K;) and saxaI, aor. yasoxaI; (K;) and saxiIa, aor. yasoxaI; and saxuwa, aor. yasoxuw; (S, Msb, K;) inf. n. saxaMCN, (S, * M, Msb, * K, TA,) of the first verb, (M, Msb, * TA,) and of the second, (TA,) and suxuwRN, (M, K, TA, [in the CK saxow,]) of the first verb, (M, TA,) or of the last, (TA,) and suxuwRapN, (M, K, TA,) of the first verb, (M, TA,) or of the third, (TA,) and saxFI, (Msb, K, TA,) of the third verb, (Msb, TA,) and saxaAwapN, of the last verb; (S, Msb, TA;) He was, or became, liberal, bountiful, munificent, or generous; or he affected, or constrained himself, to be generous; (S, * Msb, * K, * TA;) syn. jaAda, and takarRama; (TA;) the inf. ns. signifying juwdN (S, Msb) and karamN (Msb) [or takarRumN]. And saxato nafosuhu His mind was, or became, liberal, &c. (Msb.) [Accord. to J,] the saying of 'Amr Ibn-Kulthoom, [relating to wine,]
UicaA maA AlmaMCu xaAlaTahaA saxiynaA
means [When the water mixes with it, and we drink it,] we are, or become, liberal, or bountiful, with our riches; and the assertion that sxynA is from AlsRuxuwnapu, in the accus. case as a denotative of state, is a mistake: (S:) the former is the saying of AA; and the latter, of As: but IB says, on the authority of IKtt, that the right explanation is that which J disallows; and Es- Safadee says the like. (TA.) [See also 5.] ― -b2- [Hence,] saxiyato nafosiI Eani AlXRaIoCi I left, or relinquished, the thing. (S.) And saxaA binafosihi Eanohu He left, or relinquished, it; (TA:) or he held himself far from it; or withdrew his heart from it; as also nafosahu Eanohu saxRaI↓ and sxRI binafosihi Eanohu: (MA:) or nafosiI Eano hecaA AlXRaIoCi saxRayotu↓ and sxRyt binafosiI Eanohu I left, or relinquished, this thing, and my soul did not strive with me to incline me to it. (JK.) And saxaA qalobiI Ealayoka [perhaps a mistranscription for Eanoka] I endured with patience the being debarred from thee. (JK.) ＝ -A2- saxaA, (K,) aor. yasoxuw, inf. n. saxowN, (TA,) He (a man) rested from his state of motion: (K:) from ISd. (TA.) ＝ -A3- saxaA AlnRaAra, aor. yasoxuw, inf. n. saxowN; (AA, S, K;) and saxiyahaA, aor. yasoxaI, inf. n. saxoIN; (AA, S;) and saxaAhaA, aor. yasoxaI, inf. n. saxoIN; (Sgh, K;) He made an opening in the live and extinct coals of the fire which had become collected together after it had been kindled: (T, S:) or he made a way [or vent] for the fire, beneath the cooking-pot: (M, K:) or saxaA AlnRaAra signifies fataHa EayonahaA [i. e. he made an opening in the live coals of the fire, that had become collected together, (as expl. in the TK in art. Sxw,) i. e., that had become compacted; in order that it might burn up well]; as also SaxaAhaA: or, as some say, he cleared, or swept, away the
live, or burning, coals of the fire; as also with H: (TA: [see saHaA:]) and AlnRaAra saxRayotu↓, inf. n. tasoxiyapN, I opened the heart of the place where the fire was kindled, in order that it might burn up well. (JK.) And one says, Aisoxa naAraka meaning Make thou a place upon which to kindle thy fire. (S.) ― -b2- And saxaA Alqidora, (K,) aor. yasoxuw, inf. n. saxowN, (TA,) He made a way [or vent] for the fire beneath the cooking-pot; (K;) mentioned by ISd, who adds that one says also, saxaA Aljamora mino taHoti Alqidori: (TA:) or the former phrase, [and app. the latter also,] he put aside the live coals from beneath the cooking-pot; (JK, TA;) as also saxRaAhaA↓. (JK.) ＝ -A4- saxiIa, aor. yasoxaI, inf. n. saxFA, said of a camel, (S, K,) and of a young weaned camel, (S,) He became affected with a limping, or halting, (S, K,) having leaped with a heavy load, in consequence of which a flatus had intervened between the skin and the shoulderblade: (S:) the epithet applied to the animal in this case is saxK↓, (S, K,) mentioned by Yaakoob, (S,) and saxiIRN↓, (JK, K,) this latter mentioned by Sgh, and anomalous, being of a measure proper to an epithet from a verb of the measure faEula, with damm to the medial radical; (TA;) and the pl. of this latter epithet is saxaAyaA and saxaAwaI. (JK.)

2 1a2RaRa
2: see above, in four places.

5 tsxRI c
5. tsxRI He affected, or constrained himself, to be liberal, bountiful, munificent, or generous, (S, K,) EalaI OaSoHaAbihi [over and above his companions]. (S.)

saxowN mino kalaAmK c
saxowN mino kalaAmK Somewhat of speech. (JK.)

saxK c
saxK: see saxiIRN: ＝ -A2- and see also 1, last sentence.

saxiIRN c
saxiIRN Liberal, bountiful, munificent, or generous; (S, * Msb, K;) as also saAxK↓ and saxK↓: (Msb, TA:) fem. of the first with p: pl. masc. OasoxiyaMCu and suxawaMCu: and pl. fem. saxiyRaAtN and saxaAyaA. (K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, UinRahu lasaxiIRu AlnRafosi Eanohu [Verily he is content to leave, or relinquish, it]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 1, last sentence.

saxaMCN c
saxaMCN A certain plant of the [season called] rabiyE: n. un. with p: (JK:) the latter, of which the former is [said to be] the pl., signifies a certain herb, or leguminous plant, (K, TA,) rising upon a stem, having what resembles in form an ear of wheat, in which are grains like those of the yanobuwt [which is variously explained], and a heart, or kernel, (lubaAb,) the grain of which is a remedy for wounds: it is also called SaxaMCapN; but the more approved pronunciation is with s. (TA in art. Sxw.)

saxowaMCu c
saxowaMCu: see the next paragraph.

saxaAwiIRN c
saxaAwiIRN applied to a place, and saxaAwiyRapN applied to a land (OaroDN), Soft in the earth [thereof]; (S, TA;) to which is added in the S, wahiIa manosuwbapN [and it is rel. n.]; but in the handwriting of Aboo-Zekereeyà wahiIa musotawiyapN [i. e. and such as is even, or level]: (TA:) or the former is pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] of the latter, which signifies land soft in the earth [thereof]: or wide, or ample: as also saxowaMCu↓: (K:) or this last signifies a soft, or plain, and wide, or ample, land: (S:) and its pl. is saxaAwaI and saxaAwiI [or rather saxaAwK, when indeterminate]: (S, K: [in the former, these two pls. are correctly written with the article AlsRaxaAwaI and AlsRaxaAwiI:]) or, accord. to AA, saxaAwiIRu signifies land, or lands, [for the explanation is ambiguous, app. meaning the latter,] in which is nothing; and in like manner saxaAwiyRapN [but app. as a n. un.]: accord. to As and A'Obeyd, land; but correctly lands: (TA:) or width, or wide extent, (JK, TA,) so some say, (TA,) of a desert, or waterless desert, and vehemence of heat thereof. (JK.)

saAxK c
saAxK: see saxiIRN.

OasoxaI c
OasoxaI [More, and most, liberal, bountiful, munificent, or generous]: see an ex. voce laAfiZN.

masoxaI AlnRaAri c
masoxaI AlnRaAri The place that is widened [or hollowed], in the fire, beneath the cooking-pot, in order that it may be able to burn up well: and hence, some say, is derived AlsaxaMCu meaning Aljuwdu; because the bosom becomes expanded on the occasion of giving. (TA.)

1 sadRa c
1. sadRa, (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
saduda
, (S, M, Msb, K,) inf. n. sadRN; (S, M, Mgh, Msb;) and sdRd↓; (M;) [but the latter has an intensive signification, or relates to several objects;] He closed, or closed up, an interstice, or intervening space: (M:) and stopped, or stopped up, (M,) or repaired, and made firm or strong, (S, A, K,) a breach, or gap, (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) and the like. (S, Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence one says,] sudRato Ealayohi AlTRariyqu (assumed tropical:) [The road, or way, became closed, or stopped, against him]. (K.) And sudRa Tariyquhu mino bayoni yadayohi wamano xalofihi (assumed tropical:) [His road, or way, became closed, or stopped, before him and behind him]. (Zj, M.) And sadRa AlOufuqa (tropical:) [It obstructed the horizon]; said of a multitudinous swarm of locusts. (S, A, * K.) And sadRa Ealayohimo, and OasadRa↓, It closed, or obstructed, against them, the horizon; [AlOufuqa being understood;] said of a collection of clouds rising. (M.) And sadRa maA waraMCahu [It barred, or excluded, what was behind it]. (M.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] sadadotu Ealayohi baAba AlkalaAmi (assumed tropical:) [I closed, or stopped, to him the door of speech; i. e.] I prevented him from speaking; as though I closed, or stopped, his mouth. (Msb.) And maA sadadotu EalaI lahawaAti xaSomK qaTRu (assumed tropical:) I never stopped the way of speech of an adversary, nor prevented his saying what was in his mind. (Shureyh, Mgh.) And maA sadadotu EalaI xaSomK qaTRu (assumed tropical:) I never stopped an adversary from speaking; (El-Fáïk, Mgh, L;) on the authority of Esh-Shaabee: (Mgh:) occurring in a trad. (L.) ― -b4- And Oabiyhi huwa yasudRu masadRa↓ (tropical:) [He fills up, or supplies, the place of his father]: and OasolaAfihimo yasudRuwna masadRa↓ (tropical:) [They fill up, or supply, the place of their ancestors]. (A, TA.) And yusadRu bihi AlHaAjapu (tropical:) Want is supplied thereby: (M, * TA:) [whence the saying,] taSadRaquwA walawo bitamorapK faUinRahaA tasudRu mina AljaAYiEi (assumed tropical:) [Give ye something as alms, though it be but a date, or a dried date; for it will supply somewhat of the want of the hungry]: a trad. (El-Jámi' es-Sagheer.) And yasudRu AlrRamaqa (assumed tropical:) [It stays, or arrests, the remains of life; as though it stopped the passage of the last breath from the body; or] it maintains, and preserves, the strength. (Msb in art. rmq.) ― -b5- And sadRahu (assumed tropical:) He attributed, or imputed, to him, or he charged him with, or accused him of, a fault; [as though he thereby stopped his mouth; (see sadRN;)] as also satRahu. (TA in art. st.) ＝ -A2- sadRa, aor. yasidRu, (S, L, K,) with kesr, (S,) inf. n. sadaAdN and suduwdN, (L, the former inf. n. expl. in the S and K as signifying AisotiqaAmapN,) said of a spear, and an arrow, (TA,) and a saying, (S,) and an action, (TA,) or a thing [absolutely]; (L;) or sadRa, [sec. pers. sadidota,] aor. yasadRu, with fet-h to the s, (A,) inf. n. sadadN, (TK, expl. in the S and K as signifying AisotiqaAmapN, like sadaAdN, of which it is said in the S to be a contraction,) said of a saying, and an affair; (A;) or sadRa, aor. yasidRu and yasadRu, inf. n. sadadN; (MA;) i. q. SaAra sadiydFA [i. e. It was, or became, right, direct, or in a right state; it had, or took, a right direction or tendency; it tended towards the right point or object]: (S, A, L, K, TA:) and [in like manner] AstdR↓ is syn. with AisotaqaAma [which signifies the same]; (S, K;) as also AsdR↓ and tsdRd↓: (TA:) AstdR↓ said of an affair signifies it was, or became, rightly ordered or disposed; in a right state. (Msb.) You say, lahu tsdRd↓ and AstdR↓ It was, or became, rightly directed towards it. (M.) And saAEiduhu AstdR↓ and tsdRd↓ His fore arm was, or became, in a right state, or rightly directed, EalaI AlrRamoIi [for shooting]; syn. AstqAm. (A.) A poet says,
saAEiduhu ramaAniI falamRaA QsotadRa↓
OuEalRimuhu AlrRimaAyapa kulRa yawomK
[I teaching him the art of shooting every day; and when his fore arm became in a right state, he shot me]: As says that [the reading] AXtdR, with X, is not to be regarded. (S, TA.) ― -b2- And sadRa, aor. yasidRu, with kesr to the s, (A, Msb, TA,) inf. n. suduwdN (Msb) [and app. also, as above, sadaAdN, q. v. infrà], is said of a man, (A, Msb, TA,) in like manner meaning SaAra sadiydFA [i. e. He was, or became, in a right state; he had, or took, a right direction or tendency; he tended towards the right point or object]: (A, TA:) or, (Msb,) as also AsdR↓, (S, K, TA,) he hit the right thing (S, Msb, K, TA,) in his saying (S, Msb, TA) and in his action: (Msb:) or AsdR↓ signifies he said, or did, what was right: (Msb:) or he sought what was right; (L, K;) as also sdRd↓; (L;) or it has this last meaning also. (S, * L.) You say, fiI Alqawoli UinRahu layusidRu↓ Verily he hits the right thing in the saying. (S, L.) And qado
maA XiYota Oasodadota↓ (S, * L) is said to a man when he seeks [or has sought] what is right, (S,) meaning Thou hast sought what is right; whether the person thus addressed have hit the right thing or not. (L.) One says also, sadRa Ealayoka AlrRajulu, aor. yasidRu, inf. n. sd [app. a mistranscription for sadaAd or suduwd], The man said, or did, what was right [against thee]: so in the handwriting of Sh. (Az, TA.)

2 sadRaRa
2: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- [Hence,] sdRd maloOahu [He filled it up]; namely, a vessel, and a water-ing-trough. (Aboo-Sa'eed, TA in art. xnq.) ― -b3- And sdRd Ealayohimo kulRa XaIoCK qaAluwhu (assumed tropical:) He annulled, in opposing them, everything that they said. (Jábir, as related by Aboo-'Adnán.) ＝ -A2- sdRdhu, (S, A, L, Msb, K,) inf. n. tasodiydN, (K,) He directed it, (A, * L, Msb, K,) namely, an arrow, (A, Msb,) naHowahu towards him or it, (A,) or UilaI AlSRayodi towards the game; (Msb;) and XdRdhu, with X, is a dial. var. thereof: (Towsheeh, TA:) and [in like manner] his spear; contr. of EaraDahu, (S, Msb,) or EarRaDahu. (L.) ― -b2- And He taught him the art of shooting. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, (M, A, K,) inf. n. as above, (S,) He directed, accommodated, adapted, or disposed, him (S, M, A, K) to that which was right, or words and of actions: (S, K: [and the like is implied in the M and A:]) said of God. (M, A.) And you say, sadRido SaAHibaka Teach thou thy companion, and direct him to the right course. (Sh, TA.) ― -b4- And [hence,] sadRido maAlaka Act thou well with thy property, or cattle. (L.) And sadRada AlUibila, inf. n. as above, He gave the camels easy access to every pasturage, and to every place where the ground was soft and spacious. (L.) ＝ -A3- See also 1, near the end of the paragraph.

4 Oasodada
4: see 1, near the beginning: ＝ -A2- and see also the latter half of the same paragraph, in five places.

5 tasadRaRa
5: see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph, in three places.

7 AnsdR c
7. AnsdR, said of an interstice, or intervening space, It became closed, or closed up; as also AstdR↓: (M:) and both, said of a breach, or gap, (M, A,) it became stopped, or stopped up, (M,) or repaired, and made firm or strong. (A.) Euyuwnu Alxarozi AisotadRato↓ and AinosadRato signify the same [i. e. The punctures made in the sewing of the skin became closed]; (S, K;) expressing a consequence of pouring water into-a skin. (S.)

8 Uisotadada
8: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places: ＝ -A2- and see also 1, in the latter half of the paragraph, in five places.

sadRN c
sadRN and sudRN↓ Any building, or construction, with which a place is closed or closed up, or stopped or stopped up: (M: [see also sidaAdN:]) a dam: (Msb:) a thing intervening, as a separation, a partition, a fence, a barrier, a rampart, or an obstacle, or obstruction, between two other things; (S, Msb, K:) and a mountain: (S, M, K: [in the last it seems that this meaning is restricted to the former word; but if restricted to either, it should be to the latter:]) or, as some say, anything that faces one, or is over against one, and bars, or excludes, (yasudRu,) what is behind it: whence goats are said to be sadRN yuraI mino waraAYihi Alfaqoru (assumed tropical:) [a barrier behind which is seen poverty]; meaning that they are not of great utility: (M:) or sadRN signifies what is made by man; and sudRN, what is created by God, (Zj, M, Msb, K,) as a mountain: (Msb:) in the Kur xviii. 92 and 93, and xxxvi. 8, some read with fet-h, and some with damm: (M, TA:) the pl. is OasodaAdN, [a pl. of pauc.,] (A, Msb,) or OasidRapN, [also a pl. of pauc.,] and suduwdN, [a pl. of mult.,] the latter of these two agreeable with general analogy, and the former of them anomalous, or, [ISd says,] in my opinion, this (OasidRapN) is pl. of sidaAdN. (M.) You say, Duriba bayonahumaA sadRN and sudRN [A barrier, or an obstacle, was set between them two]: and Duribato bayonahumaA AlOasodaAdu [Barriers, or obstacles, were set between them two]. (A.) And Darabato Ealayohi AlOaroDu biAlOasodaAdi (tropical:) [The earth, or land, set barriers, or obstacles, against him]; meaning, the ways became closed, or stopped, against him, and the courses that he should pursue became obscure to him: (K: in the CK Duribato:) the sing. of OasodaAdN [accord. to general analogy] is sudRN. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] the former (sadRN) also signifies, (Fr, S, M, L, K,) or sidaAdN↓, (A,) or the former and sadaAdapN↓, (L,) (tropical:) A fault, or defect, (Fr, S, M, A, &c.,) such as blindness and deafness and dumbness, (S,) or such as closes, or stops, one's mouth, so that he does not speak: (A:) pl. of the first, (S, M, K,) or of the second, (A,) OasidRapN, [a pl. of pauc.,] (S, M, A, K,) accord. to analogy suduwdN, (S, M, K,) or OasudRN [which is a pl. of pauc.]. (M.) You say, maA bihi sidaAdN↓ (tropical:) There is not in him any fault &c.: and fulaAnN bariIoCN mina AlOasidRapi (tropical:) Such a one is free from faults &c. (A.) And tasudRu faAhu Eani AlkalaAmi maA bifulaAnK sadaAdapN↓ (assumed tropical:) There is not in such a one a fault that stops his mouth from speaking. (Aboo-Sa'eed, L.) And laA tajoEalanRa bijanobika AlOasidRapa (tropical:) By no means render thou thy bosom contracted so that thou shalt be unable to return an answer, like him who is deaf or dumb. (S, K.) ― -b3- See also sudRN. ― -b4- sdR [so in the TA, i. e. either sadRN or sudRa,] also signifies (assumed tropical:) A she-camel by which the sportsman conceals himself from the game; also called dariyoYapNnd dariyEapN whence the saying, ramaAhu fiI sdRi naAqatihi (assumed tropical:) [He shot him, or shot at him, by his she-camel whereby he was concealing himself]. (IAar, TA.) ― -b5- And sadRN, (M,) or sudRN, (O, K,) is also syn. with ZilRN [as meaning (tropical:) Shade, or shadow; or cover, or protection]. (IAar, M, O, K, TA.) A poet cited by IAar says,
qaEadotu lahu fiI sadRi niqoDK muEawRadK
licelika fiI SaHoraMCa jicomK dariynuhaA
(tropical:) [I sat for him, i. e. lay in wait for him, in the shade, or cover, of a camel rendered lean by travel, accustomed to that, in a desert whereof the dry herbage was old]: i. e. I made him a cover, or screen, to me, in order that he might not see me: and by jicom he means “ old, ” because Aljicomu signifies AlOaSolu, and there is nothing older than the OaSol; and he uses it as an epithet because it implies the meaning of an epithet. (M.) ＝ -A2- sadRN also signifies A thing, (S, K,) [i. e.] a [basket such as is called] salRap, (M, TA,) made of twigs, (S, M, K,) and having covers (OaTobaAq): (S, K: [but this addition in the S and K seems properly to apply to the pl., as will be shown by what follows:]) pl. sidaAdN and suduwdN: (M, TA:) or, accord. to Lth, suduwdN signifies [baskets such as are called] silaAl, [pl. of salRapN,] made of twigs, and having covers (OaTobaAq); one of which is called [not sadRN but] sadRapN↓: and it is said also on other authority that the salRap is called sadRapN and TabolN. (L, TA.)

sudRN c
sudRN: see the next preceding paragraph, passim. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) A swarm of locusts obstructing the horizon: (M:) or so sudRN mino jaraAdK: (TA:) and jaraAdN sudRN (tropical:) locusts (S, M, A, K) that have obstructed, (S, K,) or obstructing, (M, A,) the horizon, (S, M, A, K,) by their multitude: (S, A, K:) in which case, sudRN is either a substitute for jaraAdN and therefore a substantive, or it is pl. of saduwdN↓ signifying that which obstructs the horizon and therefore an epithet. (M.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) A black cloud, (AZ, S, K, TA,) that has risen in any tract of the sky: (TA:) or a collection of clouds rising, obstructing the horizon: (M:) pl. suduwdN: (S, M, K:) [or] sadRN↓ and SadRN, but the former is the more approved, signify (assumed tropical:) a cloud, or collection of clouds, rising high, and appearing like a mountain. (M and L in art. Sd.) ― -b4- And A valley: (K:) so called because it becomes closed, or stopped up. (TA.) ― -b5- And A valley containing stones and masses of rock, in which water remains for some time, or a long time: pl. sidadapN: (S, L, K:) or you say, OaroDN bihaA sidadapN [a land in which are valleys containing stones and masses of rock, &c.]; and the sing. is sudRapN↓. (L.) ― -b6- And (assumed tropical:) The departure [or loss] of sight: (IAar, M:) from the same word in the first of the senses expl. in the next preceding paragraph. (M.)

sidRN c
sidRN: see sadiydN.

sadRapN c
sadRapN: see sadRN, last sentence.

sudRapN c
sudRapN A certain disease in the nose, (S, M, L, K,) which stops it up, (M, L,) attacking the passage of the breath, (L,) and preventing respiration; (S, L;) as also sudaAdN↓. (S, M, L, K.) A thing that obstructs the passage of the humours, and of the food, in the body. (KL.) [And Any obstruction in the body: pl. sudadN.] ― -b2- See also sudRN. ＝ -A2- Also [A vestibule, or porch, for shade and shelter, before the door of a house: this is a common signification of the word, and is app. what is meant by its being said that] the sudRap is what is before the door of a house: (M, A:) or, as some say, a saqiyfap [i. e. roof, or covering, such as projects over the door of a house &c.; or a place roofed over]; (M:) or a ZulRap [i. e. roof, or cover-
ing, for shade and shelter,] over a door: (Mgh:) or it is [a thing, or place,] like a SufRap [or saqiyfap] before a bayot [or house, or perhaps here meaning tent]: and a ZulRap at the door of a house (daAr): (AA, TA:) or, accord. to Aboo-Sa'eed, (TA,) in the language of the Arabs [of the desert] it signifies [a space such as is termed] a finaMC pertaining to a tent of hair-cloth and the like; and those who make it to be like a SufRap, or like a saqiyfap, explain the word accord. to the way in which it is used by the people of the towns and villages: (Msb, TA:) or it signifies the door [itself]: (S, A, Mgh, K:) or it has this meaning also: (Msb:) some thus apply it to the door itself: (A'Obeyd, L:) and the surrounding portico [of the interior court] of the largest, or larger, mosque: (M, TA:) pl. sudadN. (S, L, Msb, K.) You say, raOayotuhu qaAEidFA bisudRapi baAbihi [I saw him sitting in the vestibule of his door]: (S, TA:) and bisudRapi daArihi [in the vestibule before the door, or at the door, of his house]. (TA.) Abu-d-Dardà said, mano yagoXa sudada AlsRuloTaAni yaqumo wayaqoEudo, (S, L,) or mano yaOoti Alx, i. e. [He who comes to the vestibules, or gates, of the Sultán] experiences returns of recent and old griefs, disquieting him so that he is not able to remain at rest, but stands up and sits down: (Mgh in art. qdm:) this he said when he came to the gate of Mo'áwiyeh and did not receive permission to enter. (L.) And it is said in a trad., AlXRuEovu AlrRuWuwsi AlRaciyna laA tufotaHu lahumu AlsRudadu, (S, A,) meaning AlOabowaAbu [i. e. The shaggy, or dishevelled, and dusty, in the heads are those to whom the doors will not be opened]. (A.) ― -b2- Hence, Umm-Selemeh, addressing' Áïsheh, termed her a sudRap, i. e. a baAb [meaning (assumed tropical:) A means of communication[, between the Prophet and his people. (L, from a trad.) ＝ -A3- Also Palm-sticks, i. e. palmbranches stripped of their leaves, bound together, [side by side,] upon which one sleeps. (M.)

sadadN c
sadadN: see the next paragraph, in four places: ― -b2- and see also sadiydN.

sadaAdN c
sadaAdN [an inf. n. of the intrans. verb sadRa; as also sadadN↓]. [Hence,] one says, UinRahu lacuw sadaAdK Verily he has a faculty of hitting the right thing, or his object or aim, in speaking, and in the managing or disposing of affairs, and in shooting. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence also, as a subst.,] A thing that is right, syn. SawaAbN, (S, A, Msb, K,) and qaSodN, (S,) of what is said and of what is done; (S, A, * Msb, K;) as also sadadN↓, (S, A,) which is a contraction of the former. (S.) One says, qaAla sadaAdFA mina Alqawoli He said a right thing [lit. of what is said, i. e., a right saying]; (S, A;) as also sadadFA↓. (A.) And yuSiybu AlsRadaAda He hits the right thing in speech [or action]. (S.) And huwa EalaI sadaAdK mino Oamorihi and sadadK↓ [He is following a right course of action in respect of his affair]. (A.) And Oamoru fulaAnK yajoriI EalaI AlsRadaAdi The affair of such a one goes on according to that which is right. (S.) ― -b3- [And hence the saying,] OatatonaA riyHN mino sadaAdi OaroDihimo (tropical:) A wind came to us from the direction of their land. (A, TA.) ― -b4- It is also used as an epithet, syn. with sadiydN, q. v. (L.) ― -b5- And AlsRadaAdu [as though meaning The right projecter] is a name that was given to a bow belonging to the Prophet, as ominating the hitting of the object aimed at by that which was shot from it. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also sidaAdN, in three places.

sudaAdN c
sudaAdN: see sudRapN, first sentence.

sidaAdN c
sidaAdN A thing with which an interstice, or intervening space, is closed, or closed up: (AO, M, L: [see also sadRN:]) and a thing with which a breach, or gap, (M, A,) is stopped, or stopped up, (M,) or repaired, and made firm or strong: (A:) pl. OasidRapN. (M.) Primarily, accord. to ISh, (Meyd, in explanation of a prov. mentioned in what follows,) Somewhat of milk that dries up in the orifice of a she-camel's teat; (Meyd, K;) because it stops up the passage of the milk. (Meyd.) Also A stopper of a bottle (S, * Mgh, * Msb, K, * TA) &c.: (Msb:) in this sense [as well as in those before mentioned] with kesr (S, Mgh, Msb, K) only [to the s]: and so in the sense next following. (S, K.) A body of horse and foot serving as blockaders of the frontier of a hostile country. (S, K, * TA.) ― -b2- sidaAdN mino EawazK and sadaAdN↓, (ISk, S, M, Msb, K,) but the former is the more chaste, (S,) and it alone is mentioned by most authors in this saying, because it is from sdAd as meaning the “ stopper ” of a bottle; (Msb;) and some say that sadAd↓, with fet-h, is a corruption; (Msb, K;) expressly disallowed by As and ISh; (Msb;) a prov.; (Meyd;) meaning (tropical:) A thing by which want is supplied, (S, M, Msb, K,) and by which life is preserved; accord. to ISh, if incomplete; and accord. to As, a thing by which somewhat of the entire wants of one's case is supplied. (Msb.) One says also, OaSabotu bihi sidaAdFA mina AlEayoXi and sadaAdFA↓ (tropical:) I attained thereby a thing by which want was supplied; (S, K, * TA;) or a means of sustaining life. (AO, L.) ― -b3- See also sadRN, in two places.

saduwdN c
saduwdN: see sudRN.

sadiydN c
sadiydN, applied to a spear, Seldom missing; and [to the same, and] to an arrow, that hits the mark; (TA;) and to a saying, (S, M, L,) as also sadaAdN↓ (M, L) and sadadN↓; (L;) and an action; (TA;) and an affair, as also OasadRu↓; (S, A, L;) right, direct, or in a right state; having, or taking, a right direction or tendency; tending towards the right point or object: (S, M, A, L, TA:) and sidRN↓, applied to speech, signifies the same; (TA;) and true. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And applied to a man, meaning Who pursues a right course; as also OasadRN↓; (M;) and [in an intensive sense] sadRaAdN↓: (TA:) or, (Msb,) as also musidRN↓, (S,) who hits the right thing in his saying (S, Msb) and in his action. (Msb.)

sadaAdapN c
sadaAdapN: see sadRN, in two places.

sadRaAdN c
sadRaAdN: see sadiydN.

saAdRapN c
saAdRapN (tropical:) An eye (EayonN) of which the sight has gone; (A;) that has become white, and with which one does not see, but which has not yet burst: (Az, A, * L, K:) or that is open, but does not see strongly: (IAar, L, K:) pl. suduwdN, (IAar, L,) or sududN. (K.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) An old and weak she-camel. (IAar, K.)

OasadRu c
OasadRu: see sadiydN, in two places.

masadRN c
masadRN [properly A place of closing, or stopping, &c.]: see 1, in two places.

musidRN c
musidRN: see sadiydN.

musadRadN c
musadRadN Directed; pointed in a right direction. (S TA.) ― -b2- And A man directed, accommodated, adapted, or disposed, to that which is right [of words and of actions]; (L;) who does that which is right, (yaEomalu biAlsRadaAdi waAlqaSodi, S, L,) keeping to the right way; in which sense it is related by some with kesr, musadRidN↓. (L.) [Golius explains it as meaning, on the authority of the S, who executes his affairs with sure and good judgment, and with happy success: and Freytag thus explains musadRidN↓, as from the S.]

musadRidN c
musadRidN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

1 sadajahu biXaIoCK c
1. sadajahu biXaIoCK, (O, K,) aor.
saduja
, inf. n. sadojN, (TK,) He thought a thing to be in him; (O, K;) i. e. he suspected him of a thing: (TA:) or sadaja biXaIoCK he imagined, or thought, a thing. (L.) ― -b2- See also what next follows, in two places.

5 tsdRj c
5. tsdRj; (S, L, K;) and sadaja↓, inf. n. sadojN; (L;) He lied, affected lying, or lied purposely; and forged, or fabricated: (S, L, K: [in the CK, taxalRafa is erroneously put for taxalRaqa:]) he forged and uttered false and vain tales: (L:) or sadaja↓, aor.
sadija
, signifies [simply] he lied; (O, in the present art. and in art. srj;) like saraja. (O in art. srj.) [See also tsrRj.]

7 Ansdj c
7. Ansdj He fell prostrate; fell upon his face; (O, K, TA;) like him who is prostrating himself in prayer: (TA:) [it may perhaps be a mistranscription for AnsdH; which seems to be better known in this sense: but it is said to be] formed by transposition from Ansjd and [so] Andsj. (TA.)

sadaAjapN c
sadaAjapN, used by Ibn-El-Khateeb and others of the people of El-Andalus, [and by post-classical writers of other countries,] as meaning Easiness, and goodness of nature or disposition, [or rather simplicity, or plainness, of mind or manners,] is from saAcajN, an arabicized word from [the Pers.] saAdaho, signifying, with them, “ free in intellect, ” and “ easy in nature or disposition: ” frequent usage occasioned the change of the c into d. (TA. [See De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., 2nd ed., ii. 292.])

sadRaAjN c
sadRaAjN A great, or habitual, liar, (S, O, L, K,) who will not tell thee truly whence he comes, but will tell thee lyingly. (L.) [See also sarRaAjN.]

1 sadira c
1. sadira, aor.
sadara
, inf. n. sadarN and sadaArapN, (S, K,) He became dazzled by a thing at which he looked, so that he turned away his face from it: or became confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course: syn. taHayRara: (K:) and he (a camel) became dazzled by a thing at which he looked, so that he turned away his face from it, by reason of intense heat: (S, * K:) also, (TA,) or sadira baSaruhu, (M,) he [app. a man or any animal] was hardly able to see: (M, TA:) or sadira baSaruhu he was dazzled, or confounded or perplexed, and did not see well; as also AisomadarRa↓. (A, TA.) [See also sadarN, below.] ＝ -A2- sadara, (M, K,) or sadarato, (S,) aor.
sadura
, inf. n. sadorN, (M,) He, or she, let down, let fall, or made to hang down, his, or her, hair; (S, M, K;) and in like manner, a curtain, or veil, (M,) and a garment; (Lh;) a dial. var. of sadala. (S, K. *) ― -b2- Also sadara, aor.
sadira
, inf. n. sadorN and suduwrN, He rent his garment. (Yaa- koob, M.)

4 Asdrti AlXRamosu Eayonahu c
4. Asdrti AlXRamosu Eayonahu [The sun dazzled his eye, and confused his sight]. (K in art. jhr.)

5 tsdRr bivawobihi c
5. tsdRr bivawobihi He covered himself with his garment. (AA.)

7 Ansdr c
7. Ansdr It (hair, S, M, K, and a curtain or veil, M) hung down; (S, M, K;) a dial. var. of Ansdl. (S, K. *) ― -b2- Ansdr yaEoduw He was somewhat quick, or made some haste, running: (S, M: *) or he went down, or downwards, and persevered (A 'Obeyd, K) in his running, going quickly. (A 'Obeyd.) [In the CK, for yEdw, is put by mistake baEuda.]

Q. Q. 4 AisomadarRa baSaruhu c
Q. Q. 4. AisomadarRa baSaruhu His sight became weak, in the manner described below, voce samaAdiyru. (S in art. sdr, and M and K in art. smdr.) It is of the measure AifomaEalRa, from AlsRadaru; (IKtt;) the m being augmentative. (S.) See also sadira. ― -b2- AsmdrRt Eayonuhu His eye shed tears; accord. to Lh; but this is not known in the classical language. (M in art. smdr.)

sidorN c
sidorN [a coll. gen. n., The species of lote-tree called by Linnæus rhamnus spina Christi; and by Forskål, rhamnus nabeca;] the tree, or trees, of which the fruit is called nabiq and naboq: (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K:) sing., (Msb,) or [rather] n. un., (S, M, K,) sidorapN: (S, M, Msb, K:) and sometimes sidorN is used as meaning the smallest or smaller of numbers [generally denoting from three to ten inclusively]: (Ibn-Es-Sarráj, Msb:) AHn says, accord. to Aboo-Ziyád, the sidor is of the kind called EiDaAh, and is of two species, EuboriIRN and DaAlN: the EbrI is that which has no thorns except such as do not hurt: the DAl has thorns [which hurt]: the sdr has a broad round leaf: and sometimes people alight and rest beneath a tree of this kind; but the DAl is small: the best nbq that is known in the land of the Arabs is in Hejer (hajar), in a single piece of land which is appropriated to the Sultán alone: it is the sweetest of all in taste and odour: the mouth of him who eats it, and the garments of him who has it upon him, diffuse an odour like that of perfume: (M, TA:) it is [also] said that the sdr is of two species; whereof one grows in the cultivated lands, and its leaves are used in the ablution termed gusol, and its fruit is sweet; and the other grows in the desert, and its leaves are not so used, and its fruit is juicy: the zuEoruwr is so described that it may be supposed to be the wild nbq: (Msb:) when sidorN is used absolutely, with relation to the ablution termed gusol, it means the ground leaves of the tree so called: (Mgh, * Msb:) the pl. of sidorapN is sidoraAtN and sidiraAtN and sidaraAtN (S, K) and sidarN (S, M, K) and suduwrN, (M, K,) which last is extr. (M.) ― -b2- sidorapu AlmunotahaI is said to be The lote-tree in the Seventh Heaven; (Lth, K; *) beyond which neither angel nor prophet passes, and which shades the water and Paradise: (Lth:) in the Saheeh it is said to be in the Sixth Heaven: 'Iyád reconciles the two assertions by the supposition that its root is in the Sixth, and that it rises over the Seventh: accord. to IAth, it is in the furthest part of Paradise to which, as its furthest limit, extends the knowledge of ancients and moderns. (MF, TA.)

sadarN c
sadarN [see 1]. You say, fiI baSarihi sadarN, and samaAdiyru↓, In his sight is a confusedness, so that he does not see well. (A.) ― -b2- Some say that it signifies An affection resembling vertigo, common to a voyager upon the sea: or [simply] vertigo. (TA in art. bql.)

sadirN c
sadirN Having his eyes dazzled by a thing, so that he turns away his face from it: or in a state of confusion or perplexity, and unable to see his right course: syn. mutaHayRirN: (K:) as also saAdirN↓: (S, K:) and the former, a camel having his eyes dazzled by a thing, so that he turns away his face from it, by reason of intense heat: (S:) and also one having his eyes dazzled by snow; as well as by intense heat. (IAar.) ― -b2- Eayonuhu sadirapN His eye is confused in its vision, or dazzled, so that he cannot see well. (A.) ― -b3- And sadirapN means An old and weak she-camel. (IAar, TA in art. sd.) ― -b4- Also sadirN The sea: (S, M, K:) one of the [proper] names thereof; (S;) occurring only in a poem of Umeiyeh Ibn-Abi-s-Salt: (M:) he says,
fakaOanRa biroqiEa waAlmalaAYiku Hawolahu
sadirN tawaAkaluhu AlqawaAYimu Oajoradu
[And as though the first heaven, with the angels around it, were the sea, the winds deserting it, and smooth]: (S, M, TA: [but in the M and TA, for Hawolahu, we find HawolahaA; and in the S, for Oajoradu, we find Oajorabu, which is inconsistent with the rhyme of the poem:]) by AlqwAYm he means the winds; and by twAklh, [for tatawaAkaluhu,] tarakatohu [or rather tatorukuhu]: he likens the sky to the sea when calm: (TA:) Th quotes thus:
wakaOanRa biroqiEa waAlmalaAYiku taHotahaA
sadirN tawaAkaluhu qawaAYimu OarobaEu
and says that the poet likens the angels, with respect to their fear of God, to a man affected with a vertigo [lit., turning round, though it would seem more appropriate had he said, the poet likens them to a camel so affected, whom his four legs failed: he prefaces this explanation with the words, sadirN yaduwru waqawaAYimu OarobaEu humu AlmalaAYikapu; to which he or ISd adds, laA yadoriI kayofa xaloquhum: but (using a common phrase of ISd) I can only say, laA OadoriI kayofa hecaA; unless there be some omission in the transcription]: (M, TA:) Sgh says that the correct reading is sidorN, meaning the kind of tree so called, not the sea; and the author of the Námoos adopts his opinion; but MF rejects it: (TA:) some read raqoEFA [in the place of brqE] and explain it as meaning the seventh heaven. (TA in art. rqE.)

sidoriIRN c
sidoriIRN One who grinds and sells the leaves of the sidor. (TA.) [See also sadRaArN.]

sidaArN c
sidaArN A thing resembling a [curtain of the kind called] xidor: (K:) or resembling a kilRap, which is put across a [tent of the kind called] xibaMC. (M.)

sadRaArN c
sadRaArN A seller of the leaves of the sidor. (TA.) [See also sidoriIRN.]

saAdirN c
saAdirN: see sadirN. ― -b2- Also Losing his way: you say, UinRahu saAdirN fiI AlgaIRi Verily he is losing his way, in error. (A.) And OataI Oamorahu saAdirFA i. e. [He entered into, or did, his affair] in a wrong way. (Ham p. 432.) ― -b3- A man without firmness, or deliberation. (M.) You say, takalRama saAdirFA He spoke without deliberation. (A.) ― -b4- A man who cares not for anything, nor minds what he does: (S, * M, K:) or one who occupies himself with vain or frivolous diversion. (TA.)

sumoduwrN c
sumoduwrN A cloudiness of the eye; (K;) and weakness of sight: (TA:) and samaAdiyru [originally pl. of the preceding, app.,] weakness of sight, (S, M, K,) or something appearing to a man by reason of weakness of his sight, (M, K,) on the occasion of, (S, M,) or [arising] from, (K,) intoxication (S, M, K) by drink &c., (M,) and from [or if the reading in the CK be correct this prep. should be omitted] the insensibility arising from drowsiness and vertigo. (S, K.) The m is augmentative. (S: but the word is mentioned in the M and K in art. smdr.) See also sadarN. ＝ -A2- Also A king: because the eyes become weak, or dazzled, in consequence of looking at him. (K in art. smdr.)

AlOasodaraAni c
AlOasodaraAni The shoulder-joints, (S, M, A, K,) and the sides: (S, K:) or (so in the M, but accord. to the K “ and ”) two veins (M, K) in the eye, (M,) or in the two eyes: (K:) or beneath the temples. (M.) Hence the saying jaMCa yaDoribu Oasodarayohi He came beating (with his hands, TA) his shoulder-joints (S, A, K) and his sides; (S, K;) meaning, (tropical:) he came empty, (S, A, K,) having nothing in his hand, (S,) or having no occupation, (M,) and without having accomplished the object of his desire: (S, K:) and in like manner, OaSodarayohi: (S:) and jaMCa yanofuDu Oasodarayohi,
(AZ,) and OaSodarayohi, (TA,) and Oazodarayohi, (ISk,) he came shaking his shoulder-joints: (AZ:) or his sides: meaning as above. (TA.)

masoduwrN c
masoduwrN Hair [let down, or made to hang down, or] hanging down; like masoduwlN. (TA.)

musomadirRN c
musomadirRN A dazzled eye. (TA in art. smdr.) ＝ -A2- A long and direct road. (K ibid.) ― -b2- And hence, (TA ibid.,) (assumed tropical:) Right speech or language. (K and TA ibid.)

1 sadasa Alqawoma c
1. sadasa Alqawoma, (S, M, Msb, K, *) aor.
sadusa
, (S, M, Msb,) inf. n. sadosN, (M, Msb, TA,) He took the sixth part of the possessions of the people. (M, Msb, K.) ― -b2- And sadasa Alqawoma, aor.
sadisa
, (S, M, Msb, K,) inf. n. sadosN, (Msb, TA,) He was, or became, the sixth of the people: (M, Msb, K:) or he made them, with himself, six. (S in art. vlv.) And He made the people, they being fifty-nine, to be sixty with himself. (A 'Obeyd, S in art. vlv.) And sadasa also signifies He made fifteen to be sixteen. (T in art. vlv.)

2 sdRshu c
2. sdRshu, inf. n. tasodiysN, He made it six. (EshSheybánee, and K voce waHRadahu.) ― -b2- He made it to be six-cornered; six-angled; hexagonal: or sixribbed. (Sgh, TA.) ― -b3- sdRs liQmoraOatihi, or EinodahaA, He remained six nights with his wife: and in like manner the verb is used in relation to any saying or action. (TA voce sabRaEa.)

4 Asds Alqawomu c
4. Asds Alqawomu The party of men became six: (S, M, Msb:) also the party of men became sixty. (M and L in art. vlv.) ― -b2- Asds AlbaEiyru The camel cast the tooth after the rabaAEiyap; (S, Msb, K;) cast the tooth called sadiys; (M, A;) which he does in his eighth year: (S, IF, A, Msb:) and in like manner one says of a sheep or goat. (M.) ― -b3- Asds AlrRajulu The man was, or became, one whose camels came to water on the sixth day, counting the day of the next preceding drinking as the first. (S, * K, * TA.) [See sidosN.]

sudosN c
sudosN: see sudusN.

sidosN c
sidosN is the original form of sitRN, (M, K,) fem. of sitRapN, which is originally sidosapN, (M,) [meaning Six; for] the dim. [of sitRN is sudayosN↓, and that] of sitRapN is sudayosapN↓; and the pl. is OasodaAsN. (S in art. st, q. v.) ― -b2- Also [The drinking of camels on the sixth day, counting the day of the next preceding drinking as the first; as will be seen from what here follows;] the period of the drinking of camels [next] after that called ximosN: or after six days and five nights: (M, TA:) or their being kept from the water five days, and coming to it on the sixth: (S:) but Sgh says that this is a mistake, and that the correct meaning of the term is, their being kept from the water four days, and coming to it on the fifth; and so it is explained in the [A and] K: (TA:) or their drinking one day, then being kept from the water four days, then coming to it on the fifth day; so [by the application of the term sidosN] they include in their reckoning the first day in which the camels drink: (Aboo-Sahl, TA:) or their remaining in the place of pasture four days [after drinking], then coming to the water on the fifth: (TA:) pl. OasodaAsN. (M, Sgh, TA.) You say, waradato Uiboluhu sidosFA [His camels came to the water on the sixth day, counting the day of the next preceding drinking as the first]. (S, A, K.) [Hence the saying,] Daraba OaxomaAsFA liOasodaAsK [which see expl. voce ximosN]. (A.) ― -b3- Also The sixth young one, or offspring. (A in art. vlv.)

sadasN c
sadasN: see sadiysN, in three places: ― -b2- and, as an epithet applied to a calf, see EaDobN.

sudusN c
sudusN (S, M, A, Msb, K) and sudosN↓ (S, Msb, K) A sixth part; (S, M, A, Msb, K;) as also sadiysN↓, (S, Msb, K,) a form used by some, like as one says EuXorN and EaXiyrN: (S:) pl. OasodaAsN. (M, Msb, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, app., the saying, Daraba OaxomaAsahu fiI OasodaAsihi, which see expl. voce xumusN.]

sudaAsa c
[sudaAsa as meaning Six and six together, or six at a time and six at a time, seems not to have been heard: see EuXaAra. But Freytag mentions sudaAsN as used by El-Mutanebbee for sitRap.]

saduwsN c
saduwsN: see the next paragraph.

suduwsN c
suduwsN (Sh, S, M, K) and saduwusN↓, (Sh, M, K,) As used to say the latter, (S,) A [garment of the kind called] TayolasaAn: (M:) or a TylsAn, (S, M, K,) or any garment, (Sh,) of the colour termed xuDorap [here app. meaning a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour]. (Sh, S, M, K.) ＝ -A2- And the former, (K,) or the latter, (M,) Smoke-black of fat; or lamp-black; syn. niylanojN. (M, K.)

sadiysN c
sadiysN: see sudusN: ― -b2- and see sudaAsiIRN. ＝ -A2- Also The tooth that is before that called the baAzil; (S, K;) after that called the rabaAEiyap; (M, L, TA;) as also sadisN↓; (S, K;) masc. and fem., because the fem. names of teeth are all with p, except sadasN and sadiysN and baAzilN: (S:) the pl. (of the former, S,) is sudusN and (of the latter, S) sudosN. (S, K.) You say, of a camel, OaloqaI sadiysahu and sadasahu↓ [He cast his tooth called the sdys and sds]. (A.) ― -b2- And hence, (Mgh,) A camel, (M, A, Mgh, Msb,) and a sheep or goat, (M, TA,) casting his sadiys, (M, A, TA,) or his tooth that is after the rabaAEiyap; (Msb;) i. e., in the eighth year; (A, Mgh, Msb;) as also sadasN↓: (A, Mgh, TA:) masc. and fem.: (M, TA:) or a sheep or goat six years old: (S, K:) pl. sudusN. (M.) A poet, (S,) namely, Mansoor Ibn-Misjáh, speaking of a fine for homicide, taken from among selected camels, (TA,) says,
faTaAfa kamaA TaAfa AlmuSadRiqu wasoTahaA
yuxiyRiru minohaA fiI AlbawaAzili waAlsRudosi
[And he went round about, as the collector of the poor-rate went round about, amid them, preferring certain of them, among the nine-year-old and the eight-year-old camels]. (S, TA.) ＝ -A3- Also A sort of measure, or a sort of makRuwk, [in some copies of the K DarobN mina AlmakaAyiyli, and in others and in the O Drb mn AlmakaAkiyki,] (O, K,) with which dates are measured. (O.) ＝ -A4- sadiysa in the saying laA Mtiyka sadiysa EujayosK is a dial. var. of sajiysa, q. v. (S.)

sudayosN c
sudayosN and sudayosapN: see sidosN.

sudaAsiIRN c
sudaAsiIRN, applied to a garment of the kind called UizaArN, (S, A, K,) Six cubits in length; (A, K;) as also sadiysN↓. (S, * A, Msb, K.) ― -b2- Also [as meaning Six spans in height, said to be] applied to a slave. (Msb in art. xms.) [But see xumaAsiIRN.] ― -b3- [Also A word composed of six letters, radical only, or radical and augmentative.]

saAdisN c
saAdisN [Sixth]: fem. with p. (S, K, &c.) See also saAtRN, in art. st. ― -b2- [saAdisa EaXara, and the fem. saAdisapa EaXorapa, meaning Sixteenth, are subject to the same rules as vaAliva EaXara and its fem., expl. in art. vlv, q. v.]

sunodusN c
sunodusN: see art. snds.

musadRasN c
musadRasN A thing composed of six layers or strata, or of six distinct fascicles or the like. (TA in art. vlv. [See also masoduwsN, below.]) ― -b2- [Hexagonal; a hexagon.] ― -b3- A verse composed of six feet. (M.)

masoduwsN c
masoduwsN A rope composed of six strands. (M in art. vlv.)

sudogN c
sudogN a dial. var. of SudogN, (K,) which is the more common. (TA. [See the latter.])

misodagN c
misodagN: see what follows.

misodagapN c
misodagapN a dial. var. of miSodagapN [q. v.]; (TA;) as also mizodagapN; (L and TA in art. zdg;) and misodagN↓ and mizodagN signify the same [as dial. vars. of miSodagN]. (TA.)

2 sdRfhu c
2. sdRfhu, (M, TA,) inf. n. tasodiyfN, (TA,) He cut it in pieces; namely, a camel's hump. (M, TA.)

4 Asdf c
4. Asdf It (the night) became dark; (S, M, K;) accord. to some, after the jinoH [app. as meaning the first part thereof; or about the half; or a great, or the greater, part]: (M:) or let down its curtains, and became dark: and Azdf and Asdf signify the same. (AO, TA.) ― -b2- And Asdf Alqawomu The people, or party, entered upon the [period of the night called] sudofap. (M.) ― -b3- And Asdf He slept; (AA, K, TA;) as also Azdf. (AA, TA.) ― -b4- And (tropical:) His eyes became dark by reason of hunger or age: (K, TA:) said of a man. (TA.) ― -b5- Also, said of the daybreak, or dawn, It shone: (S, K, TA:) [thus,] as AO says, it has two contr. significations. (TA.) ― -b6- And He lighted the lamp: (K:) or one says, in the dial. of Hawázin, OasodifuwA, i. e. OasorijuwA [Light
ye a lamp, or with a lamp]; from AlsRiraAju: (S, TA:) or one says in that dial., OasodafuwA lanaA, i. e. OasorajuwA [They lighted for us a lamp, or with a lamp]. (M.) ― -b7- Also He moved away or aside [in order that the light might enter a place]. (K.) When a man is standing at a door or an entrance, one says to him, Oasodifo, i. e. Move thou away or aside from the door, or entrance, in order that the chamber, or tent, may become light. (AA, TA. [See also the last sentence of this paragraph.]) ― -b8- [In all of these senses, perhaps excepting one, it is intrans.: in others, trans.] ＝ -A2- You say of a woman, Asdft AlqinaAEa, (S, TA,) and AlHijaAba, (TA,) She let down [the head-covering, and the veil, or curtain]. (S, TA.) ― -b2- And Asdf AlsRitora He raised [the veil, or curtain]. (K.) ― -b3- One says also, Oasodifi AlbaAba Open thou the door, or entrance, in order that the chamber, or tent, may become light. (S.)

sadafN c
sadafN: see sudofapN, in three places. ― -b2- Also The night. (S, TA.) ― -b3- And The daybreak, or dawn: (AA, S, K:) and the advent thereof: (Fr, S, K:) and the whiteness of day. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A ewe: (Ibn-'Abbád, K:) or such as has a blackness like that of night. (TA.) ― -b2- And sadafo sadafo is A call to the ewe to be milked. (K.)

sadofapN c
sadofapN: see the next paragraph.

sudofapN c
sudofapN and sadofapN↓ i. q. sadafN↓, (As, S, M, K,) as meaning The darkness, (As, S, K,) in the dial. of Nejd, (As, S,) or of Temeem; (K;) or as meaning the darkness of night; or, as some say, after the jinoH [which here app. means the first part of the night; or about the half; or a great, or the greater, part]: (M:) and also as meaning the light, (As, S, K, and M in explanation of the first word,) in the dial. of others, (As, S,) or of Keys: (K:) thus having two contr. significations; (S, K;) or the darkness and the light are called by one and the same name because each of them comes upon the other: (K:) or the first, (S, M, K,) and second, (K,) the commingling of the light and the darkness, (S, M, K,) as in the time between the rising of the dawn, (S,) or as in the time between the prayer of the dawn, (M,) and that when the sun becomes white, (S, M,) accord. to some, as is said by A 'Obeyd; (S;) or, as 'Omárah says, the first signifies darkness in which is light, of the former part of the night and of the latter part thereof, between the redness after sunset and the darkness and between the dawn and the prayer [of the dawn]; And Az says that this is the correct explanation: (TA:) and the first and second, a portion of the night: (M, K:) or the first, a remaining portion of the night: (Ibn- Habeeb, TA:) or the first of five divisions of the night: (TA in art. xdr: see xudorapN, voce xadarN:) and the first, (K, TA,) i. e. with damm, (TA,) or the second, (CK,) as also sadafN↓, the blackness of night: (K:) the pl. of the first is sudafN; as in the saying of 'Alee, kaXafotu Eanohumo sudafa AllRayoli I removed from over them the darknesses of night: (TA:) and the pl. of sadafN↓ is OasodaAfN. (M, TA.) You say also, raOayotu sudofapa XaxoSihi mino buEodK (tropical:) I saw the blackness of his body, or form, from a distance. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also the first, A door, or an entrance: (M, K:) or its sudRap [i. e. vestibule, or porch, &c.]: (K:) and a sort of covering over a door to protect it from the rain. (K, * TA.)

suduwfN c
suduwfN [a pl. of which the sing. is app. sadafN, like XadafN,] The corporeal forms or figures or substances of men or other things which one sees from a distance: (K:) accord. to Sgh, (TA,) correctly with X: (K, TA:) but the truth is, that they are two dial. vars. (TA.)

sadiyfN c
sadiyfN A camel's hump: (S:) or a camel's hump cut into pieces: (M, TA:) or pieces [or slices] of a camel's hump: (Ham p. 258:) or the fat of a camel's hump: (M, K, and Ham p. 257:) [or a very fat hump of a camel: (Freytag, from the Deewán of Jereer:)] pl. sadaAYifu and sidaAfN. (TA.)

sidaAfapN c
sidaAfapN A veil, or covering; a thing that veils, conceals, covers, or protects: whence the saying of Umm-Selemeh to 'Áïsheh, (O, K, TA,) when she desired to go forth to El-Basrah, (TA,) qado wajRahoti sidaAfatahu i. e. hatakoti AlsRitora i. e. Oaxacoti wajohahaA [i. e. wajoha sidaAfatihi (JM in art. wjh) Thou hast rent open his veil, or covering, meaning the Prophet's, as is shown in the TA]: (O, K, TA:) or thou hast removed his veil, or covering: (O, TA:) or thou hast removed his veil, or covering, from its place, to which thou wast commanded to keep, and hast placed it before thee: (O, K, TA:) but the saying is also related otherwise, i. e. wajRahoti sijaAfatahu, mentioned before [in art. sjf]. (TA.) One says also, wajRaha fulaAnN sidaAfatahu, meaning Such a one quitted his veil, or covering, and came forth from [behind] it. (TA.)

Oasodafu c
Oasodafu, as an epithet applied to night, Dark, (M, [as also musodifN,]) or black. (K.)

musodifN c
musodifN Dark: [like Oasodafu:] and also light: having two contr. significations. (M, TA.) ― -b2- And Entering upon the [period called] sudofap. (TA.).

sanaAmN musadRafN c
sanaAmN musadRafN A camel's hump cut into pieces [or slices]. (M.)

HijaAbN masoduwfN c
HijaAbN masoduwfN A veil, or curtain, let down. (TA.)

1 sadalahu c
1. sadalahu, aor.
sadula
, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) and
sadila
, (M, K,) inf. n. sadolN, (S, M, Mgh, Msb,) He let it loose, let it down, lowered it, or let it fall; (S, M, K;) namely, his garment, (S, M,) and hair, (Fr, M, K,) and a veil, or curtain; (M;) and sadanahu signifies the same; (Fr, TA;) as also Asdlhu↓; (M, K;) or this latter is a mistake; (Mgh; [but this the author asserts because, he says, he had searched through books without finding it except in the “ Nahj-el-Balághah; ”]) not allowable; (Msb;) and the former signifies he let it down, or let it fall, namely, the garment, without drawing together its two sides: (Mgh, Msb:) or, as some say, he threw it upon his head, and let it loose, let it down, or let it fall, upon his shoulders: (Mgh:) and he let it down, or let it fall, namely, hair, not maEoquwf [i. e. made recurvate at the extremities], nor tied in knots: (Lth, TA:) and one says also, yazodulu vawobahu, changing the s into z. (Sb, M.) The sadol that is forbidden in prayer is The letting down one's garment without drawing together its two sides: or the enveloping oneself with his garment, and putting his arms within, and bowing the head and body, and prostrating oneself, in that state; as the Jews used to do; and this applies uniformly to the shirt and other garments: or the putting the middle of the UizaAr [or waist-wrapper] upon the head, and letting fall its two ends upon one's right and left, without making it to be upon his two shoulder-blades. (TA.) sadala EimaAmatahu bayona katifayohi is said in a trad. [as meaning He made the end of his turban to hang down between his two shoulder-blades]. (Mgh.) And one says also, XaEarahu EalaI sdRl↓ EaAtiqayohi waEunuqihi, [meaning He let his hair fall down abundant and long upon his shoulders and his neck,] inf. n. tasodiylN. (ISh, TA. [See its pass. part. n., voce munosadilN.]) ― -b2- Also, aor.
sadila
, (M, K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He slit it, or rent it; namely, his garment. (M, K.) ― -b3- And sadala fiI AlbilaAdi, (O, K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He went away into the countries, or provinces. (O, K.)

2 sadRala
2: see 1, last sentence but two.

4 Oasodala
4: see 1, first sentence.

5 tasadRala
5: see the next paragraph.

7 Ansdl c
7. Ansdl [and accord. to Freytag tsdRl↓ also, but he names no authority for this, and I have not found it in any MS. lexicon, but it is agreeable with analogy as quasi-pass. of 2,] It was let loose, let down, lowered, or let fall; said of hair [&c.]. (MA, KL.) ― -b2- And Ansdl yaEuduw He was somewhat quick, or made some haste, running; like Ansdr; the r and l being app. interchangeable. (Har p. 576.)

Q. Q. 1 sawodala c
Q. Q. 1. sawodala He (a man) had long mustaches, (IAar, TA,) or he had a long mustache. (As, K.)

sudolN c
sudolN and sidolN↓ [the former written in a copy of the M sadol, but said in the K to be with damm,] A veil, or curtain: pl. [of mult.] suduwlN and [of pauc.] OasodaAlN (M, K) and OasodulN. (K.) In a verse of Homeyd Ibn-Thowr, as it is related by Yaakoob, AlsRuduwl is used as a sing., because it is of a measure which is [in some instances] that of a sing., such as AlsRuduws, meaning a sort of garment: but others relate it differently, saying AlsRadiyl, which is correctly a sing. (M.) [See also sidonN.]

sidolN c
sidolN A string of gems or jewels: (S:) or a string of pearls or large pearls, reaching to the breast: (M, K:) pl. suduwlN. (S.) ― -b2- See also sudolN.

sadalN c
sadalN An inclining. (M, K.) [See Oasodalu.]

sidilRaI c
sidilRaI, of the measure fiEilRaI, an arabicized
word, originally, in Pers., siho dilaho [“ three-hearted ”], as though it were three chambers in one chamber (kaOanRahu valAavapu buyuwtK fiI bayotK), like the HaAriIR bikumRayoni [i. e., I suppose, “ like the garment of El-Heereh with two sleeves; ” app. meaning that it signifies An oblong chamber with a wide and deep recess on either hand at, or near, one extremity thereof; so that its ground-plan resembles an expanded garment with a pair of very wide sleeves: in the present day, it is commonly applied to a single recess of the kind above mentioned, the floor of which is elevated about half a foot or somewhat more or less above the floor of the main chamber, and which has a mattress and cushions laid against one or two or each of its three sides]. (S.) [Golius explains it, as on the authority of the S, (in which is nothing relating to it but what I have given above,) thus: Pers. siydalaho seu sidaraho, i. q. sudRarN.]

sadiylN c
sadiylN The thing [or hanging] that is let down, or suspended, upon the [kind of camel-vehicle for women called] hawodaj: (S, O, K:) pl. [of mult.] suduwlN and sadaAYilu and [of pauc.] OasodaAlN: (S, O:) the first of which pls. is expl. by As as meaning the pieces of cloth with which the hwdj is covered; as also suduwnN. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A thing [app. a hanging or curtain] that is extended across, or sideways, (yuEarRaDu,) in the space from side to side of the [tent called] xibaMC (fiI saEapi AlxibaMCi): and (some say, M) the curtain of the Hajalap [or bridal canopy, &c.,] of a woman: (M, K:) pls. as above. (TA.)

sanodalN c
sanodalN, or samanodalN, (accord. to different copies of the S,) A certain bird, that eats [the poisonous plant called] biyX [generally applied to the common wolf's-bane, aconitum napellus]: on the authority of El-Jáhidh. (S.) [See also art. smndl.]

sawodalN c
sawodalN The mustache. (S, IAar, K.) You say, TaAla sawodaluhu, (As, K,) or sawodalaAhu, (IAar,) His mustache, or mustaches, became long. (As, IAar, K.)

cakarN Oasodalu c
cakarN Oasodalu An inclining penis: (M, K:) pl. [by rule sudolN, but it is said to be] sudulN, i. e. like kutubN. (K.)

musodalN c
musodalN and musadRalN: see what follows.

munosadilN c
munosadilN Hair let loose, let down, lowered, or let fall: (S:) or lank, or long, and pendent; (M, K;) as also musodalN↓: (TA:) or abundant and long, (Lth, TA,) and so musadRalN↓, (ISh, TA,) falling upon the back. (Lth, TA.)

1 sadima c
1. sadima, (S, M, K,) aor.
sadama
, (K,) inf. n. sadamN, (S, M, K,) He repented and grieved: (S:) or he was, or became, affected with anxiety: or with anxiety together with repentance: or with wrath, or rage, together with grief. (M, K.) [Hence,] one says, maA lahu hamRN walaA sadamN UilRaA caAka [He has no object of anxiety nor of repentance and grief except that: or this saying may be from what next follows]. (S.) ― -b2- sadima biAlXRaIoCi, aor. and inf. n. as above, He desired the thing vehemently, eagerly, greedily, very greedily, or excessively; hankered after it, or coveted it; and he was, or became, devoted, addicted, or attached, to it: (TK:) [but these meanings of the verb are perhaps only inferred from the saying that] AlsRadamu is syn. with AlHiroSu: and AllRahaju biAlXRaIoCi, (M, K, [in the CK AllRahoju,]) and AlwuluwEu. (TA.) Hence the trad., mano kaAnati AldRunoyaA hamRahu wasadamahu jaEala QllRehu faqorahu bayona Eayonayohi [To whomsoever the present state of existence is the object of his anxiety and of his eager desire &c., God places his poverty before his eyes]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- And sdm, [i. e. sadima, as is indicated by the form of the part. n. sadimN, and by sadamN as an inf. n. used in the sense of that part. n.,] said of water, It became altered [for the worse] by reason of long standing, and overspread with [the green substance termed] TuHolub, and choked with dust and other things that had fallen into it. (A, TA.) ＝ -A3- [And sadima said of a stallion, He was withheld from covering: so in the Deewán of Jereer, accord. to Freytag: it is said of a stallion-camel: see sadimN.] ＝ -A4- sadama AlmaMCa Tuwlu AlEahodi biAlXRaAribapi [The length of time that had elapsed since the coming thereto of the drinkers] altered the water [for the worse]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- And sadama AlbaAba He shut, or closed, the door; syn. radRahu; (IAar, M, TA;) in the K, erroneously, radamahu: and so saTamahu. (TA.) ＝ -A5- See also sadiymN.

2 tasodiymN c
2. tasodiymN [inf. n. of sdRm] The binding, or closing, the mouth of a camel [with a muzzle; i. e. the muzzling of a camel: see the pass. part. n., below]. (KL.)

4 Ousodima c
4. Ousodima, said of water, It was prevented from flowing by dust and wind: so in the Deewán of Jereer, accord. to Freytag.]

7 Ansdm dabaru AlbaEiyri c
7. Ansdm dabaru AlbaEiyri The galls, or sores, on the back of the camel became healed. (K, TA.)

sudomN c
sudomN, as a sing. epithet: see sadimN, last sentence. It is also a pl. of saduwmN. (M, TA.)

sadamN c
sadamN inf. n. of sadima. (S, M, K. [See 1, first four sentences.]) ― -b2- See also sadimN, in two places.

sadumN c
sadumN: see the latter half of the next paragraph.

sadimN c
sadimN [is a part. n. of sadima: and is also app. used as an imitative sequent to nadimN]. You say [sadimN and] saAdimN↓ and sadomaAnu↓ (M, K, TA) meaning Repenting and grieving: (TA:) or affected with anxiety: or with anxiety together with repentance: or with wrath, or rage, together with grief: (M, K, TA:) and sadimN nadimN, in which one is used as an imitative sequent to the other; and naAdimN saAdimN↓, and nadomaAnu sadomaAnu↓, [app. in like manner,] AlsRadamu being seldom used without AlnRadamu: (TA:) or [nadimN sadimN, and] naAdimN saAdimN↓, and nadomaAnu sadomaAnu↓; in which one is said to be an imitative sequent to the other: (S:) or, accord. to IAmb, saAdimN↓ in the phrase rajulN saAdimN naAdimN means, as some say, altered [for the worse] in intellect in consequence of grief; from maMCN sudumN, i. e. “ water that has become altered [for the worse]: ” or, as others say, grieving, not able to go nor to come. (TA.) You say also rajulN sadimN A man affected with wrath, or rage. (S, TA.) ― -b2- And EaAXiqN sadimN Affected with amorous, or passionate, desire, in a vehement degree. (AO, K.) ― -b3- And in like manner, (TA,) faHolN sadimN (S, M, K) and sadamN↓ [which is an inf. n. used as an epithet] and masoduwmN↓ and musadRamN↓ (M, K) A stallion [camel] excited by lust for the female: (S, M, K:) or one that is sent among the she-camels, and that brays amidst them, and, when they have become excited by lust, is taken forth from them, because what he begets is disesteemed; (M, K, TA;) therefore, when he is excited by lust, he is shackled, and pastures around the dwelling; and if he attacks the she-camels, he is muzzled: (TA:) or one that is in any manner debarred from covering; (K;) or the last two epithets have this last signification. (M.) ― -b4- And naAqapN sadimapN An old and weak she-camel. (AO, (TA.) ＝ -A2- maMCN sadimN and sadamN↓ and sudumN↓ (M, K) and sadumN↓ (K) and saduwmN↓ (M, TA) and suduwmN↓ and sadiymN↓ (TA) i. q. munodafinN [i. e. Water filled up, stopped up, or choked up, with earth or dust; or into which the dust has been swept by the wind]: (M: [in the K and TA, erroneously, munodafiqN:]) pl. OasodaAmN [a pl. of pauc.] and sidaAmN [a pl. of mult.]; or the sing. and pl. are alike; (M, K;) [i. e.] you say maMCN OasodaAmN and sidaAmN, applying pl. epithets to a sing. noun; (Z, TA;) as well as miyaAhN OasodaAmN (IAmb, TA, and Ham p. 102) and sidaAmN (IAmb, TA) meaning waters altered [for the worse] (IAmb, TA, and Ham ubi suprà) in consequence of long standing, and so sudumN: (Ham:) this last is pl. of saduwmN↓, as also sudomN: (M, TA:) [and each of these two is also used as a sing.; i. e.] you say also rakiyRapN sudomN↓ and sudumN↓ meaning a well filled up, stopped up, or choked up, with earth or dust; or into which the dust has been swept by the wind: (S, K, TA: [in the CK, munodafiqapN is erroneously put for munodafinapN:]) or into which varieties of small rubbish, and dust, or small pebbles, whirled round by the wind, have fallen, so that it is nearly choked up: (Lth, TA:) and maMCN sudumN↓ is expl. as meaning water that has become altered [for the worse]: (IAmb, TA:) musadRamN↓, also, applied to water, signifies the same as sadimN; (M, K;) and so does masoduwmN↓: (TA:) [or ↓the former of these, so applied, prevented from flowing by dust and wind. (Freytag, from the Deewán of Jereer.)]

sudumN c
sudumN, as a sing. epithet: see the latter half of the next preceding paragraph, in three places. It is also a pl. of saduwmN. (M, TA.)

sadomaAnu c
sadomaAnu: see sadimN, second sentence, in three places.

saduwmN c
saduwmN and suduwmN: see sadimN, in the latter half of the paragraph; the former word, in two places.

sadiymN c
sadiymN: see sadimN, in the latter half of the para-
