graph. ＝ -A2- Also Mist; syn. DabaAbN: or such as is thin. (M, K.) ＝ -A3- And i. q. kaviyru AlcRikori (K) [app. as meaning Remembering God, or celebrating Him, much, or frequently: for SM adds], hence the saying,
laA yacokuruwna QllReha UilRaA sadomaA
[app. They remember not, or celebrate not, God, otherwise than doing so much, or frequently: from which it seems that one says, QllReha sadama↓, inf. n. sadomN, meaning He remembered, or celebrated, God, &c.]. (TA.) ＝ -A4- And i. q. taEabN [Fatigue: but I incline to think that this explanation is a mistranscription]. (TA.)

saAdimN c
saAdimN: see sadimN, second sentence, in four places.

musadRamN c
musadRamN: see sadimN, in the former half of the paragraph. ― -b2- Also A camel left to pasture by itself (K, TA) around the dwelling. (TA.) ― -b3- And A [camel of generous race, such as is termed] faniyq having a muzzle put upon his mouth. (S.) ― -b4- And A camel having galls, or sores, upon his back, and therefore exempted from the saddle until his galls, or sores, have become healed. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also sadimN, last sentence, in two places.

masoduwmN c
masoduwmN: see sadimN, in the former half of the paragraph: ＝ -A2- and again in the last sentence. ― -b2- Also A door shut, or closed. (TA.)

1 sadana c
1. sadana, (S, L, K,) aor.
saduna
, (S, L,) inf. n. sadonN and sidaAnapN, [or the latter, accord. to the Msb, seems to be a simple subst.,] He acted as minister, or servant, of the Kaabeh, and [so in the S and L, but in the K “ or ”] of the temple of idols; (S, L, K;) and performed the office of doorkeeper, or chamberlain. (K.) [And] sadana AlkaEobapa. aor.
saduna
, inf. n. sadonN, has the former meaning. (Msb.) A 'Obeyd says, (L,) sidaAnapu AlkaEobapi signifies The ministry, or service, of the Kaabeh, (Mgh, L,) and the superintendence thereof, and the opening and locking of its door. (L.) The sidaAnap and the liwaMC [q. v.] belonged to [the family named] Benoo-'Abd-ed-Dár in the Time of Ignorance, and the Prophet confirmed it to them in El-Islám: (S, L:) [in the first age of ElIslám,] the sdAnp of the Kaabeh belonged to the sons of 'Othmán Ibn-Talhah [of the family of Benoo-'Abd-ed-Dár]. (Mgh.) AlsRidaAnapu signifies [also (L)] AlHijaAbapu [which seems to be properly a subst., meaning The office of door-keeper, or chamberlain, but here seems, from the context, to be used as an inf. n., meaning the performing that office]: you say, sadanahu, aor. as above, [app. meaning He acted as door-keeper, or chamberlain, to it, namely a temple, or for him:] (M, L:) or sadanahu, inf. n. sidaAnapN, signifies he served it, or him. (MA.) ＝ -A2- sadana vawobahu, (S, L, K,) and AlsRitora, (S, L,) aor.
sadina
and
saduna
, (K,) He (a man, S, L) let down, or lowered, his garment, (S, L, K,) and the curtain, or veil, (S, L,) and AlXRaEarD the hair; like sadalahu [which is held by some to be the original, the n being held by them to be a substitute for l: see sidonN]. (Fr, TA in art. sdl.)

sadonN c
sadonN: see what next follows, in two places.

sidonN c
sidonN, (L, Msb,) or sadonN↓, (so in a copy of the M,) or sadanN↓, and sadaAnN↓, (K,) as also sadiynN↓, (AA, L, K,) A curtain, or veil: (AA, M, L, Msb, K:) [like sidolN and sudolN:] pl. of the first (L) or second (M) [and app. of the last also, like as OasodaAlN is pl. of sidolN or sudolN and also of sadiylN,] OasodaAnN; in which the n is said by some to be a substitute for l: (M, L:) or OasodaAnN is a dial. var. of OasodaAlN signifying the suduwl of the [kind of camel-vehicles for women called] hawaAdij; (S, L;) [i. e.,] accord. to ISk, it signifies the pieces of cloth with which the hawodaj is covered; (L;) as also suduwnN; (As, TA voce sadiylN;) and its sing. is [sadiynN, like sadiylN, or] sadonN↓. (L. [The last word is there thus written, in this instance, with fet-h.])

sadanN c
sadanN: see the next preceding paragraph.

sadaAnN c
sadaAnN: see the next preceding paragraph.

sadiynN c
sadiynN: see sidonN. ― -b2- Also Fat, as a subst. (AA, L, K.) ― -b3- And Blood. (K.) ― -b4- And Wool. (K.)

sidaAnapN c
sidaAnapN Ministry, or service. (Msb.) [And particularly The ministry, or service, and superintendence, of a temple of idols; and afterwards, of the Kaabeh: see 1.]

saAdinN c
saAdinN A minister, or servant, of the Kaabeh, (S, Mgh, L, Msb, K,) and [so in the S and L, but in the K “ or ”] of the temple of idols; (S, L, K;) and one who performs the office of doorkeeper, or chamberlain: (K:) pl. sadanapN: (S, Mgh, L, Msb, K:) or sadanapN signifies the doorkeepers, or chamberlains, (HujRaAb, [pl. of HaAjib,]) of the House [of God, i. e. the Kaabeh]; and the intendants of the idols in the Time of Ignorance; the latter being the primary application: (M, L:) but IB says that there is this difference between the saAdin and the HaAjib; that the latter precludes, and his license to do so belongs to another; whereas the sAdn precludes, and his license to do so belongs to himself. (L.)

1 sadaA biyadayohi c
1. sadaA biyadayohi, (M,) or biyadihi, (K,) [aor. yasoduw,] inf. n. sadowN, (S, M, K,) He stretched forth (S, M, K) his arms or hands, or, as when said of a camel, his fore legs, (M,) or his arm or hand, or his fore leg, (S, K, TA,) Uilayohi [towards him or it], (CK,) or naHowa AlXRaIoCi [towards the thing], like as do camels (kamaA tasoduw AlUibilu) in their going along; (TA;) as also AstdI↓, (M, K, TA,) in [some of] the copies of the K AsdI, but the former is the right. (TA.) You say of a man, sadaA, aor. yasoduw, He stretched forth his arm, or hand, towards a thing: and of a camel, sadaA, inf. n. sadowN, he stretched forth his fore leg in going along: (Msb:) or of a she-camel, sadato, (S, K,) aor. tasoduw, inf. n. sadowN, (S,) she went with wide steps; (K;) or she stretched forth her arms in going along, and went with wide steps: and maA OaHosana sadowa rijolayohaA waOatowa yadayohaA [How good, or beautiful, is her stretching forth of her hind legs, and her returning of her fore legs in her going!]. (S.) See also sataI. ― -b2- sadaA, (M,) or yasoduw, (S,) kacaA sadowa↓, (S, M,) He went, (M,) or he goes, (S,) towards, or in the direction of, such a thing; (S, M;) said of a man. (S.) ― -b3- sadowN also signifies The going at random, heedlessly, or in a headlong manner, without consideration, or without any certain aim, or object, not obeying a guide to the right course, in journeying; (S, M;) said in relation to camels and horses. (M.) ― -b4- Hence, (M,) sadaA biAljawoz, (K,) aor. yasoduw, (TA,) inf. n. sadowN, (M, TA,) He (a boy, or child,) played with walnuts, (M, K, TA,) throwing them into a hole; (TA;) a dial. var. of zadaA; (K;) or, accord. to the T, the latter is of the dial. of children; (TA;) as also AstdI↓, (M, K, TA,) in [some of] the copies of the K, erroneously, AsdI. (TA.) See also midoHaApN, in art. dHw. ＝ -A2- See also 5. ＝ -A3- sadiyati AalOaroDu The land was, or became, moistened by much dew, (S, Msb,) either from the sky or from the ground. (S.) And sadiyati AllRayolapu The night was, or became, moist with much dew. (M, * TA.) ― -b2- sadiIa Albusoru, (S, K,) or AlbalaHu, (M,) inf. n. sadFI; (TA;) and OasodaI↓; (M;) The dates in the state in which they are termed blH, or blH, [see these words,] were, or became, lax in their vafaAriyq [or bases, so as to be easily detached therefrom], (S, M, K,) and moist. (M.)

2 1a2RaRa
2: see 4, first three sentences, in four places. ― -b2- [Hence,] one says of honey, yusadRiyhi AlnRaHolu (assumed tropical:) [The bees make, prepare, or produce, it]. (M.) ― -b3- See 4, again, in two places. ＝ -A2- See also 5.

4 AsdI AlvRawoba c
4. AsdI AlvRawoba, (S, Msb, K,) and AstAhu; (S;) as also sdRAhu↓, (K,) inf. n. tasodiyapN; (TA;) and tsdRAhu↓; (K;) He set, or disposed, the warp (AlsRadaI) of the garment, or piece of cloth; (S, * Msb, K, * TA;) he made a warp (sadFI) in the garment, or piece of cloth: (Har p. 241:) or sdRAhu↓ means he did so for another; and tsdRAhu↓, he did so for himself. (M, TA.) [Golius explains sdRI↓ as signifying also “ Oblivit telam viscosiore aquâ, ut cui mistus fuerit panis, quod fit roboris conciliandi ergo; ” as on the authority of the KL; in my copy of which I find only its inf. n., tasodiyapN, expl. as meaning the weaver's making a warp in a garment, or piece of cloth (tAr drjAmh krdn jwlAh): and Freytag adds, as a signification assigned to the same verb by Jac. Schultens, “ Cirris s. fimbriis ornavit vestem. ”] ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, AlOumuwra wayuniyruhaA huwa yusadRiI↓ (A in art. nyr) or yusodiI (TA in that art.) [meaning (assumed tropical:) He commences things, or affairs, and completes them]. And OaloHimo maA Oasodayota (assumed tropical:) Complete what thou hast commenced (S and K in art. lHm) of beneficence. (S in that art.) ― -b3- Hence also, AsdI bayonahumo HadiyvFA i. q. nasajahu [i. e. (tropical:) He wove, or composed, or he forged, a discourse between them]. (M, TA.) ― -b4- And AsdI bayonahumaA i. q. OaSolaHa [i. e. (assumed tropical:) He effected a
rectification of affairs, an agreement, a harmony, or a reconciliation, between them two]. (AA, Az, K.) ― -b5- And AsdI Uilayohi (assumed tropical:) He did a benefit to him; as also sdRI↓, inf. n. tasodiyapN: (K:) or AsdI Uilayohi sadFI, and Ealayohi sdRAhu↓, (M, TA, [thus in the latter case, Elyh, not Alyh,]) or AsdI Uilayohi maEozuwfFA, (Msb,) he did to him, or conferred upon him, a benefit, benefaction, favour, or the like: (M, * Msb, TA:) [app. from AsdI AlvRawoba, and sdRAhu; and accordingly mentioned in the M in art. sdI: or] it is from sdI [or rather sadaA, inf. n. sadowN,] as meaning “ he (a camel) put forward his fore legs in going along; ” for he of whom one says OasodaAka xayorFA [he did to thee good, like OasodaI Uilayoka xayorFA,] is as though he stretched forth to the his arm, or hand, therewith, advancing: (Ham p. 696:) you say, AsdI niEomapF, meaning AiSoTanoE [i. e. he did a benefit, &c.]. (Idem p. 759.) ― -b6- You say also, Talabotu OamorFA faOasodayotuhu i. e. (assumed tropical:) [I sought a thing, and] I attained it, or obtained it: [as though meaning I stretched forth my hand to it and reached it:] if you do not attain it, or obtain it, you say, OaEomasotuhu: (S:) or UisodaMCN signifies the attaining quickly. (KL. [There expl. by the words zwd dryAftn: for which Golius seems to have found in his copy zwd rftn; for he has assigned to AsdI, as on the authority of the KL, the meaning of cito incessit.]) ＝ -A2- AsdAhu also signifies He left, let alone, or neglected, him, or it: (K:) he left him to himself, uncontrolled, (M, Msb,) neither commanded nor forbidden. (M.) And you say, Oasodayotu UibiliI, (AZ, T, S,) inf. n. UisodaMCN, (AZ, T,) I left my camels to pasture by themselves. (AZ, T, S.) ＝ -A3- AsdI AlbalaHu: see 1, last sentence. ― -b2- AsdI AlnRaxolu The palm-trees had dates such as are termed sadK. (As, T, S, K.)

5 tsdRAhu c
5. tsdRAhu: see 4, first sentence, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also He mounted it, or mounted upon it; (M, K;) he was, or became, or got, upon it; (S, M, K;) syn. rakibahu, (M, K,) and EalaAhu; (S, M, K;) namely, a thing. (M.) A poet says, (S, TA,) namely, Imra-el-Keys, (TA,)
favawobFA nasiytu wavawobFA Oajuro
falamRaA danawotu tasadRayotuhaA
[And when I drew near, I got upon her, and a garment I forgot, or neglected, and a garment I was dragging upon the ground: Oajuro being for OajurRu]. (S, TA.) And sdI jaAriyatahu [or sadaA↓ (for tsdRAhu meaning as expl. above is mentioned in the M in art. sdw), or it may be sdRI↓] signifies [in like manner] EalaAhaA. (TA.) ― -b2- And He followed him, (K, TA,) and overtook him. (TA.) ― -b3- And He overcame, or overpowered, him; namely, a man. (TA.) And He conquered, or mastered, it; namely, an affair. (TA.)

8 AstdI c
8. AstdI: see 1, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also, said of a horse, He sweated. (K.)

sadowN c
sadowN inf. n. of sadaA. (S, M, K.) Hence, sadaA sadowa kacA or yasoduw sadowa kacaA: see 1. And xaTaba AlOamiyru famaA zaAla EalaI sadowK waAHidK i. e. [The prince, or commander, recited an oration, or a harangue, &c., and ceased not to keep to] one proserhyme. (M.)

sadFI c
sadFI of a garment, or piece of cloth, (S, M, K, &c.,) The warp; (MA, KL;) contr. of luHomapN; (S, M, Msb;) i. e. (Msb [in the M “ and it is said to mean ”]) the portion [or threads] thereof extended longitudinally (M, * Msb, K *) in the weaving: (Msb:) and it is said to mean the lower, or lowest, part thereof: (M: [but this is a strange explanation, which I do not find elsewhere:]) it is [said to be] from AlsRadowu [inf. n. of sadaA] signifying “ the stretching forth the arm, or hand, or the fore leg, towards a thing: ” (Har p. 241: [but it is mentioned in the M as belonging to art. sdI; and its dual, mentioned below, requires its being so:]) and OasodiIRN↓, (M, K,) also [and more commonly] written OusodiIRN↓, (K,) signifies the same; (M, K;) as also sadaApN↓; (S, K;) or this last is the n. un. of sadFI, (M, TA,) having a more special signification, (Msb, TA,) [as though meaning a warp, or a sort of warp; or the luHomapN may be affixed for the purpose of assimilating the word to its contr. sadFI, with which it is often coupled:] the dual [of sadFI] is sadayaAni: (S, Msb, TA:) and the pl. is OasodiyapN (accord. to the S) or OasodaMCN. (Msb.) maA Oanota biluHomapK walaA sadaApK↓ [lit. Thou art neither a woof nor a warp] is said to him who neither harms nor profits. (TA. [See also satFI.]) ― -b2- Hence, as being likened thereto, (M, [see 2, second sentence,]) (tropical:) Honey in its comb; syn. XuhodN or XahodN. (M, K, TA.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) A benefit, benefaction, favour, or the like. (S, M, K, TA. [See also the next two sentences.]) ― -b4- The nightdew; (S, M, Msb, K;) by means of which seedproduce lives: (S, * Msb:) or, as some say, sadFI and nadFI are syn. [and both applied to dew in an absolute sense]: and the pl. is OasodaMCN. (M.) ― -b5- And (tropical:) Liberality, bounty, munificence, or generosity; as being likened thereto; and so nadFI. (S in art. ndw and ndI.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce riqobapN.] ＝ -A2- Green dates, (M, K,) with their XamaAriyx [or fruit-stalks]; (M;) as also sadaMCN↓; (M, K;) of the dial of El-Yemen: n. un. sadaApN↓ and sadaMCapN↓, (M, TA,) on the authority of AA, and of Sh also, who says that they are of the dial. of El-Medeeneh. (TA.) [See also the last sentence of the next paragraph: and see sayaAbN.] ＝ -A3- Also sometimes used in the sense of sudFI. (S, K.) See this latter word.

sadK c
sadK [originally sadiIN] Moist; applied in this sense to anything. (AHn, M.) ― -b2- And [particularly] Moist with dew, [or with night-dew, or with much thereof,] applied to a place. (M.) And you say OaroDN sadiyapN A land moist with much night-dew. (S, Msb.) And layolapN sadiyapN A night moist with much dew: (M, * TA:) the epithet [sadK] is seldom applied to a day. (M, TA.) ― -b3- And balaHN sadK Dates in the state in which they are termed balaH, (S, M, K,) accord. to As, when they have fallen, (T, TA,) that have become lax in their vafaAriyq [or bases, so as to be easily detached therefrom], (As, T, S, M, K,) and moist: (As, T, M:) one thereof [i. e. a balaHap] is termed sadiyapN: (As, T, TA:) the vuforuwq is the qimaE of the busorap [or balaHap]. (TA.) You say also basorN sadK; and busorapN sadiyapN, which is the same as sadaApN↓ [expl. above, voce sadFI]. (S.)

sudFI c
sudFI and sadFI↓, (S, M, K,) the former the more common, (S, K,) used alike as sing. and pl., (S, * M, K,) Left, let alone, or neglected; or left to pasture by itself or by themselves; (S, M, K;) applied to a camel, (K, TA,) and to camels: (S, K, TA:) you say naAqapN sudFI (TA) and UibilN sudFI: (S, TA:) and saAdK↓ signifies the same [as a sing. epithet]. (M, K.) OayaHosabu QloUinosaAnu Oano yutoraka sudFI, in the Kur [lxxv. 36], means Doth man think that he is to be left to himself, uncontrolled, neither commanded nor forbidden? (M.)

sadaApN c
sadaApN: see sadFI, in three places: and see also sadK.

sadaMCN c
sadaMCN: see sadFI, last sentence but two.

sadaMCapN c
sadaMCapN: see sadFI, last sentence but two.

saduwRN c
saduwRN A she-camel that stretches forth, and flings out, her fore legs in going along. (M.) [See also saAdK.]

AlrRumRaAnu AlsRadawiIRN c
AlrRumRaAnu AlsRadawiIRN The pomegranate of AlsRudayRaA, a town near Zebeed. (K.)

saAdK c
saAdK Stretching forth the arms, or fore legs, in going along, (M, * TA,) and wide in step; (TA;) applied to a camel: (M, TA:) and so sawaAdK, [pl. of the fem. saAdiyapN,] applied to she-camels: (S, K, * TA:) [see also saduwRN:] or, accord. to the T, the Arabs apply the term sawaAdK as a name for the fore legs of camels, because of their stretching them forth in going along; and then as a name for the camels themselves. (TA.) And saAdK signifies also Good in pace or going; applied to a camel; and so zaAdK. (TA.) ― -b2- See also sudFI. ＝ -A2- AlsRaAdiI is also used for AlsRaAdisu; (S, K, TA;) the s being changed into I. (TA.) One says, jaMCa fulaAnN saAdisFA and saAdiyFA [Such a one came sixth]. (ISk, S voce saAtRN, q. v.)

OusodiIRN c
OusodiIRN and OasodiIRN: see sadFI ― -b2- The former also signifies vawobN musadRFI [like OusotiIRN: see this last word, voce satFI]. (AHeyth, K.)

misodaApN c
[misodaApN A weaver's yarn-beam, or roller; i. e., as expl. by Golius, on the authority of Meyd, the implement on which the weaver rolls the warp.]

AlmasaAdiI c
AlmasaAdiI: see midoHaApN, in art. dHw.

sucobapN c
sucobapN A bag, or other receptacle, for travellingprovisions or for goods or utensils &c.; syn. wiEaMCN. (K.)

sacaAbN c
sacaAbN, said to be an arabicized word, because [it is asserted that] s and c are not combined in any Arabic word; [and if so, sucobapN also, men-
tioned above, is arabicized;] but in some of the books on plants it is written with the unpointed d; (TA;) i. q. fayojanN, (K,) which is an ancient Greek word, (TA,) [i. e. πήγανο, meaning Rue;] a well-known baqol [or kind of herb], (K,) having properties described in the medical books. (TA.)

sacaAbiIRN c
sacaAbiIRN A seller of sacaAb [or rue]. (K, * TA.)

saAcajN c
saAcajN and saAcijN, mentioned under this head in the O and K: see art. sAcj.

1 sarRahu c
1. sarRahu, accord. to the TA, has two contr. significations: for it is there stated that “ one says sararotuhu meaning katamotuhu and sararotuhu meaning OaEolanotuhu: ” and it is added that “ it will occur again soon: ” but it does not again occur in that work, nor have I found it in any other lexicon: I therefore think that it is a mistranscription, for Oasorarotuhu, first pers. of OasarRahu, q. v.] ＝ -A2- sarRahu, (S, O, Msb, K, &c.,) aor.
sarura
, (MS,) inf. n. masarRapN (S, O, K) and suruwrN [which latter, from the explanations of it which will be found below, seems to be generally, if not only, as an inf. n., that of surRa,] and surRN [which is also syn. with suruwrN in the senses assigned to the latter below] and surRaI and tasirRapN [which last may be also an inf. n. of srRrhu↓ expl. by Freytag as syn. with sarRahu in the sense here following, but without an indication of any authority], (O, K,) He, or it, rejoiced him; gladdened him; or made him happy; syn. OaforaHahu: (Msb, K:) [or made him to experience a pleasure, or delight, and dilatation of the heart, of which there was no external sign: see suruwrN, below.] And surRa, [inf. n. suruwrN, (see above,)] He rejoiced; was joyful, or glad; or was happy: (S, * A, * K:) [or he experienced a pleasure, or delight, and dilatation of the heart, of which there was no external sign; accord. to an explanation of suruwrN:] you say, surRa bihi and AisotasarRa↓ [He rejoiced, was joyful or glad, or was happy, by reason of him, or it]. (A.) ― -b2- sarRahu, (K,) aor. as above, (TA,) also signifies He saluted him with [the offering of what are termed] AlmasarRap, i. e. the extremities of sweet-smelling plants. (K.) ＝ -A3- Also sarRahu, (S, M,) aor. as above, inf. n. sarRN, (S,) or sirRN, (so in a copy of the M,) He cut his (a child's) sirar, or surR, i. e. navel-string. (S, M.) And surRa He (a child) had his navel-string cut. (K.) ― -b2- And sarRahu, aor. as above, He pierced him, or thrust him, [with a spear or the like,] in his surRap [or navel]: a poet says,
waUino OadobaruwA fahumu mano yusabo
nasurRuhumu Uino humu OaqobaluwA
[We pierce them in the navel if they advance; and if they retreat, they are those who are pierced in the podex; yusabo being for yusabRu]. (S.) ＝ -A4- sarRa AlzRanoda, aor. as above, inf. n. sarRN, He put a piece of wood, (M, K,) or a little piece of wood, (S,) in the interior of the znd [or piece of stick, or wood, for producing fire], (M,) or in its extremity, (S, K,) inserting it in its interior, (S,) in order that he might produce fire with it. (S, M, K.) One says, surRa zanodaka faUinRahu OasarRu Fill up the interior of thy znd, that it may produce fire, (AHn, M,) for it is [worn] hollow. (S, K.) ＝ -A5- sarRa, [sec. pers. sarirota,] aor. yasarRu, (IAar, Sgh, L, K,) inf. n. sararN, remarked upon by MF as extr., [though it is agreeable with a general rule,] said of a man, (TA,) He had a complaint of the surRap [or navel]. (IAar, Sgh, L, K.) ― -b2- Also, aor. and inf. n. as in the next preceding case, said of a camel, He had the pain, or disorder, termed sararN [q. v.]. (IAar, M.)

2 sarRaRa
2: see 1, second sentence. ＝ -A2- sarRarotuhu in the phrase sarRarotuhu surRiyRapF I gave him, or caused him to take, a concubine slave, doubly trans., is [said to be] changed to sarRayotuhu for alleviation of the pronunciation. (Msb.) ＝ -A3- srRrhu, inf. n. tasoriyrN, said of water, It reached his surRap [or navel]. (K.)

3 sArRhu c
3. sArRhu, inf. n. musaArRapN and siraArN, (S, M,) [He spoke, or discoursed, secretly to him or with him;] he acquainted him with a secret. (M.) You say, sArRhu fiI Oucunihi He spoke secretly to him in his ear. (S, * K, * TK.) And kaAna yuHadRivuhu kaOaxiI AlsRiraAri occurs in a trad., meaning He (Mohammad) used to talk to him ('Omar) in a low voice, like him who is telling a secret. (TA.) ― -b2- bayoEu AlsRiraAri is The selling in which one says, “ I will put forth my hand and thou shalt put forth thy hand, and if I produce my signet-ring before thee, it is a sale for such a price; and if thou produce thy signet-ring before me, for such a price: ” if they produce together, or do not both produce, they do thus again. (Mgh.)

4 AsrRhu c
4. AsrRhu, (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. UisoraArN; (Msb;) [and accord. to the TA sarRahu; but see the first sentence of this art.;] He concealed it; suppressed it; kept it secret; (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) namely, a story, or the like: (A, Mgh, Msb:) and, contr., he manifested it; revealed it; published it; made it known. (S, M, Msb, K.) Both of these significations have been assigned to the verb in the phrase waOasarRuwA QlnRadaAmapa, in the Kur [x. 55 and xxxiv. 32]: (S:) some say, that the meaning is They will manifest repentance: Th says, they will conceal it from their chiefs: the former [says ISd] is the more correct: (M:) the former meaning is also given on the authority of AO; but Sh says, I have not heard it on the authority of any other; and Az says that the lexicologists most strongly disapprove of the saying of AO; and it is said that the meaning is, they, the chiefs of the polytheists, will conceal repentance from the lower class of their people, whom they shall have caused to err; and in like manner say Zj and the [other] expositors. (TA.) In like manner also the two contr. significations are assigned to the verb in the saying of Imra-el- Keys, [in his Mo'allakah,] lawo yusirRuwna maqotaliI, which As used to quote with X, thus, lawo yuXirRuwna maqotaliI, meaning that they might publish, or make known, my slaughter. (S.) You say also, OasarRa Uilayohi HadiyvFA He revealed unto him a story (S, K) secretly. (TA.) An ex. occurs in the Kur lxvi. 3. (TA.) And Oasorarotu Uilayohi AlmawadRapa, and biAlmawadRapi, I showed, or manifested, to him love, or affection. (S.) It is said in the Kur [lx. 1], tusirRuwna Uilayohimo biQlomawadRapi, meaning, Ye reveal to them the news of the Prophet by reason of the love that is between you and them; the objective complement of the verb being suppressed: or AlmwdRp may be an objective complement, the b being a redundant corroborative, as in Oaxaca AlxiTaAma and Oaxaca bihi: (Msb:) and this interpretation is correct; for UisoraArN to a person necessarily implies revealing a secret to him and at the same time concealing it from another. (B.) ― -b2- waOasarRuwhu biDaAEapF, in the Kur xii. 19, signifies And they concealed, or kept secret, his case, making him as an article of merchandise: (Jel:) or they conjectured in their minds that they should obtain, by selling him, merchandise. (TA.) [See also an ex. voce AirotagaI, in art. rgw.] ― -b3- AsrR AlfaAtiHapa, and biAlfaAtiHapi, He recited the Fátihah [or First Chapter of the Kur-án] secretly, or inaudibly: (Msb:) or the latter form of expression is a mistake. (Mgh.) ― -b4- Oasorarotuhu also signifies nasabotuhu UilaI AlsRirRi [which may mean either I attributed it to secrecy, or, like many phrases of this kind, by inversion, I attributed to him secrecy, or mystery]. (Msb.)

5 tsrRr c and tsrRI
5. tsrRr tsrRI, (M, K,) and AstsrR↓, (K,) He took to himself a concubine-slave. (M, * K, * TA.) And tasarRarotu jaAriyapF, and tasarRayotuhaA, (S,) and AisotasarRayotuhaA↓, (TA,) I took to myself a girl, or young woman, as a concubine-slave. (S, * TA.) tasarRarotuhaA is [said to be] thus changed to tasarRayotuhaA, (T, S, Msb,) for alleviation of the pronunciation, (Msb,) on account of the three r s following one another, (T,) being like taZanRanotu and taZanRayotu. (T, * S.) Lth says that tsrRyt is a mistake; but Az says that it is correct. (TA.) AisotasarRaniI↓ occurs in a trad. as signifying He took me to himself as a concubine-slave; but by rule one should say tasarRaraniI, or tasarRaAniI: as to AstsrRnI↓, it [more properly] signifies “ He revealed to me his secret. ” (TA.) ― -b2- tasarRara fulaAnN binota fulaAnK [as though signifying Such a one took to himself the daughter of such a one as a concubine-slave] is said when a man of low birth takes as his wife a woman or girl of high birth because of the abundance of his property and the littleness of hers. (M.)

6 tsArRwA c
6. tsArRwA They spoke, or discoursed, secretly together; acquainted one another with secrets. (S, K.) [See also 3.] ＝ -A2- tsArRUilaI celika (tropical:) He experienced pleasure, or delight, at that: as, for instance, at his scratching a part of his body, or pressing, or kneading, it; and at a thing disliked by another person. (A, TA.) [But I am in some doubt as to the correctness of this, and incline to think that it is a mistake for AstsrR↓.]

10 AstsrR c
10. AstsrR He, or it, became concealed; or he,
or it, concealed himself or itself: (K:) it (a thing, or an affair,) became hidden or concealed or secret: (A, Msb:) it (the moon) became concealed (S, M, A, TA) by the light of the sun, (TA,) [i. e. by its proximity to the sun,] for one night, or for two nights. (AO, S.) ＝ -A2- AstsrRhu He took extraordinary pains in concealing it, or keeping it secret. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 5, in four places. ― -b3- AisotasarRaniI He revealed to me his secret. (TA.) ＝ -A3- See also 1; and see 6, last sentence.

sarRN c
sarRN A man who rejoices, or gladdens, another; or makes him happy; (S, K;) [and so saArRN↓:] fem. sarRapN; with which saArRapN↓ is syn. (Lh, M, K.) You say rajulN barRN sarRN A man who treats with goodness and affection and gentleness, and rejoices &c., (S, K, TA,) his brethren: (TA:) pl. barRuwna sarRuwna. (S, K.)

surRN c
surRN: see suruwrN: ＝ -A2- and sirRN, last sentence but one. ＝ -A3- It is also a contraction of sururN, pl. of sariyrN. (Sb, M.) ＝ -A4- Also, and sirarN↓, (S, M, K,) and sararN↓, (S, K, in the CK surar,) The navel-string of a child; i. e. the thing that the midwife cuts off from the navel (surRap) of a child; (S, K;) the thing that hangs from the navel (surRap) of a newborn child, and that is cut off: or sirarN↓ signifies the part that is cut off thereof, and that goes away: (M:) pl. (of sirarN, S, [or of surRN or sararN,]) OasirRapN, (Yaakoob, S, M, K,) which is extr. (M.) One says, Earafotu celika qabola Oano yuqoTaEa surRuka [I knew that before thy navel-string was cut]: one should not say surRatuka; for the surRap is not cut. (S.) And waAHidi waladato valaAvapF fiI sararK↓ She brought forth three [boys] consecutively, or one at the heels of another. (M.) [See also sirRN, last sentence.]

sirRN c
sirRN A secret; a thing that is concealed, or suppressed, (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) in the mind; (TA;) as also sariyrapN↓: (S, M, A, K:) or the former has the above-mentioned signification, and the latter signifies a secret action, whether good or evil: (Lth:) [and the former, also, a mystery:] pl. of the former, OasoraArN; (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) and of the latter, saraAYiru. (S, A, K.) It is said in a prov., maA yawomu Haliymapa bisirRK [The day of Haleemeh is not a secret]: applied to anything commonly known: alluding to Haleemeh the daughter of El-Hárith the son of Aboo-Shemir El-Ghassánee; for, when her father sent an army to El-Mundhir the son of Má-es-Semà, she took forth for the soldiers some perfume in a vessel (mirokan), and perfumed them with it. (S.) [You say also, huwa mawoDiEu sirRiI He is the depositary of my secret, or secrets.] The words of the Kur [lxxxvi. 9] yawoma tubolaI AlsRaraAYiru↓ signify In the day wherein the secret tenets and intentions shall be tried and revealed: (Jel:) or by AlsrAYr is here meant fasting, and prayer, and alms-giving, and ablution on account of the pollution termed janaAbap. (TA.) [See also a verse cited in the third paragraph of art. ErD.] ― -b2- A thing that is revealed, appears, or is made manifest: thus it has two contrary significations. (MF.) ― -b3- AlsRirRu [for maHalRu AlsRirRi, (assumed tropical:) The heart; the mind; the recesses of the mind; the secret thoughts; the soul;] is a syn. of AlDRamiyru. (K in art. Dmr. [See also sariyrapN.]) [laA tutoEibo sirRaka (assumed tropical:) Weary not thy heart, or mind, is a common modern phrase. And one says, of a deceased holy man, qadRasa QllRehu sirRahu (assumed tropical:) May God sanctify his soul.] ― -b4- sirRN also signifies Secrecy; privacy; contr. of EalaAniyapN. (S in art. Eln.) You say sirRFA waEalaAniyapF [Secretly and openly; or privately and publickly]. (Kur ii. 275, &c.) ― -b5- Concealment. (S.) ― -b6- Suppression; contr. of UiEolaAnN. (Msb.) [So in the phrase takalRama sirRFA He spoke with a suppressed, or low, voice; softly.] ― -b7- [One having private knowledge of a thing. You say,] fulaAnN sirRu hecaA AlOamori (assumed tropical:) Such a one has [private] knowledge of this thing. (TA.) ― -b8- (tropical:) The penis (T, S, M, K) of a man: (T:) and (tropical:) the vulva, or external portion of the organs of generation, of a woman. (K.) One says, AilotaqaI AlsRirRaAni (tropical:) The two pudenda met. (A.) ― -b9- (tropical:) Concubitus. (AHeyth, S, Mgh, K.) ― -b10- (tropical:) Marriage: (M, A, Msb, K:) pl. OasoraArN. (TA.) You say, waAEadahaA sirRFA (tropical:) He promised her marriage, she promising him the same. (A.) So, accord. to some, in the Kur ii. 235. (TA.) ― -b11- (tropical:) Plain declaration of marriage: (K:) i. e., a man's offering himself in marriage to a woman during her EidRap: so expl. as occurring in the Kur ubi suprà: (TA:) or a man's demanding a woman in marriage during her EidRap. (Mujáhid.) ― -b12- (tropical:) Adultery, or fornication: (AHeyth, (K:) so, accord. to Aboo-Mijlez and El-Hasan, in the Kur ubi suprà. (TA.) Hence the saying, laA yurojaI mino waladi AlsRirRi birRN (tropical:) One does not hope for filial piety from the offspring of adultery, or fornication. (TK.) ― -b13- (assumed tropical:) Origin; syn. OaSolN; (M, K;) as in the phrase huwa kariymu AlsRirRi kaviyru AlbirRi He is of generous origin, of much filial piety. (TK.) ― -b14- (assumed tropical:) The commencement, or first night, of a lunar month: (K, TA:) or its middle; (K;) app. meaning what are called AlOayRaAmu AlbiyDu: (TA:) but Az says, I know it not in this sense. (IAth.) ― -b15- (assumed tropical:) The interior of anything; its heart. (K.) Whence sirRu AlXRahori and AllRayoli (assumed tropical:) [The middle of the lunar month and of the night]. (TA.) ― -b16- The marrow of anything. (TA.) ― -b17- (tropical:) The pure, or choice, or best, part of anything. (Fr, M, K.) You say, OaEoTayotuka sirRahu (tropical:) I gave thee the pure, or choice, or best, part of it. (A.) ― -b18- (tropical:) The pure, or genuine, quality of race, or lineage: (S, A, K:) its best quality: (S, K:) and the middle sort thereof; (S;) and of rank, or quality, or the like: (M:) as also saraArN↓ and saraArapN↓. (M, K.) One says, huwa fiI sirRi qawomihi (tropical:) He is of the best [in race or family] of his people: (TA:) or of the middle sort of them. (S.) ― -b19- (tropical:) The low, or depressed, part of a valley: (K:) the best, (S, K,) or most fruitful, (As, M, TA,) part thereof: (As, S, M, K:) as also saraArN↓ (M, K) and saraArapN↓ (As, S, M, K) and surRapN↓: (M, K:) or the last signifies the middle of a valley: (S:) the pl. of sirRN is sirarN and suruwrN (M) and OasirRapN, like as OaqinRapN is of qinRN, (S,) or the last is pl. of saraArN↓, like as OaqocilapN is of qacaAlN; (M;) and that of saraArapN↓ is saraArN↓, (S,) or [this is a coll. gen. n., and the pl. is] saraAYiru: (M:) also surRapN↓ (assumed tropical:) the middle of a city: and OasirRapN the middles of meadows. (TA.) And OaroDN sirRN (assumed tropical:) Fruitful, good, land; (M, K;) as also sarRaMCu↓. (K, * TA.) ― -b20- Also (assumed tropical:) Goodness; excellence. (Msb.) ― -b21- Also, and surRN↓, (M, K,) and sirarN↓, (S, M, K,) and sururN↓, (K,) and siraArN↓, (S, M, K,) A line of the palm of the hand, (M, K, *) and of the face, (M,) and of the forehead: (S, M, Mgh:) pl. (of sirRN, TA, or of siraArN↓, S) OasirRapN, (M, TA,) and (of the same, K, or of sirarN↓, S, Mgh) OasoraArN; (S, M, Mgh, K;) and pl. pl., [i. e. pl. of OasoraArN,] OasaAriyru: (S, M, (Mgh, K:) this last, accord. to AA, signifies the lines in the forehead, from the shrivelling of the skin; and its sing. is sararN↓: (TA:) some also apply the pl. OasirRapN to (tropical:) lines, or streaks, of herbage; as being likened to the lines of the hand and of the face, but this is not of valid authority: (M:) and OasaAriyru (as pl. of OasoraArN, which is pl. of sirarN, TA) also signifies the beauties of the face, and of the cheeks, and of the elevated parts of the cheeks. (K, TA.) ― -b22- wulida lahu valaAvapN EalaI sirRK, (K,) and EalaI waAHidK sirarK↓, (K, * TA,) means Three children were born to him, whose navel-strings were cut in a similar manner, without any female among them. (K. [See also surRN.])

surRapN c
surRapN The navel; i. e. the place from which the navel-string (surR) has been cut off; (S;) the small cavity, or hollow, of the belly, (M, TA,) in the middle thereof; (TA;) what remains of the sirar: (M:) [see surRN:] pl. surarN [in the CK erroneously sirarN] and surRaAtN. (S, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] surRapu Alfarasi (assumed tropical:) [The navel of the horse,] the star, of Pegasus, that is in the head of Andromeda. (Kzw.) ― -b3- [Hence likewise] surRapN also signifies (assumed tropical:) A perforation in the middle of a jar such as is termed muzamRalap [q. v.], in which is fixed a tube of silver or lead, whence one drinks. (Har p. 548.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) The place where the water rests, in the furthest part, of a watering-trough, or tank. (K, TA.) ― -b5- See also sirRN, in two places, in the latter part of the paragraph.

sararN c
sararN a subst. from saArRahu [like its syn. najowaI from naAjaAhu, signifying Secret discourse, or a secret communication, between two persons or parties]. (M.) ＝ -A2- See also saraAru AlXRahori: ＝ -A3- and sirRN, last sentence but one: ＝ -A4- and surRN, in two places. ＝ -A5- Also A pain which a camel suffers in his kirokirap [or callous projection upon the breast], arising from a gall, or sore: (S, * K:) or sores in the hinder part of the krkrp of a camel, nearly penetrating into his inside, but not mortal: or a disease that attacks the horse: (M:) it is said by Lth to be a pain in the navel; but Az and others say that this is a mistake. (TA.) ― -b2- Also Hollowness of a spear-shaft [&c.]. (S, K.) [See OasarRu.]

sururN c
sururN: see sirRN, last sentence but one: ＝ -A2- and suruwrN. ＝ -A3- It is also a pl. of sariyrN [q. v.]. (S, M, Msb, K.)

sirarN c
sirarN: see saraAru AlXRahori: ＝ -A2- and sirRN, last two sentences, in three places: ＝ -A3- and surRN, in two places. ＝ -A4- Also The coats, or coverings, and earth, that are upon truffles; (S, K;) and sariyrN↓ signifies the same, (TA,) or the sand (K, TA) and earth and coats or coverings (TA) upon truffles: (K, TA:) here, and in some copies of the Tekmileh, for kamoOap, is put Oakamap: (TA:) or both signify the earth that is upon truffles: (M:) or the former signifies the round clod of earth in which a truffle grows: (ISh, TA:) pl. of the former, (ISh, S,) and of ↓the latter, (TA,) OasoraArN. (ISh, S, TA.)

saraAru AlXRahori c
saraAru AlXRahori and siraAruhu↓, (S, M, K,) but the latter is not approved by the lexicologists [in general], (Az,) and sararuhu↓ (S, M, K) and siraruhu↓, (M,) and layolapu AlsRiraAri↓ (S) [or AlsRaraAri &c.], The last night of the lunar month: (S, K:) or when the month is twenty-nine, it is the twenty-eighth night; and when the month is thirty, it is the twenty-ninth night: (Fr:) or the night in which the moon becomes concealed by the light of the sun: (M:) sometimes this is the case one night, and sometimes it is two nights. (AO, S.) [See also AldRaEojaMCu, voce OadoEaju.] ＝ -A2- saraArN is also syn. with sirRN, in two senses: see sirRN, in the latter part of the paragraph, in four places. ＝ -A3- It signifies also [Dates in the unripe state in which they are termed] sayaAbN [q. v.]. (K.)

siraArN c
siraArN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places: ＝ -A2- and sirRN, last sentence but one, in two places: ＝ -A3- and masarRapN.

saruwrN c
saruwrN: see what next follows.

suruwrN c
suruwrN, (S, M, A, Msb,) or saruwrN↓, when used as a simple subst., (IAar, Sgh, K,) but this is strange, and, accord. to MF, unknown, whether as a simple subst. or as an inf. n., (TA,) and surRN↓ (M, Msb) and sarRaMCu↓ and tasurRapN↓, (M,) Happiness, or joy, or gladness; syn. faraHN; (M, K; *) contr. of HuzonN: (S:) or dilatation of the bosom with delight, or pleasure, wherein is quiet or tranquillity or rest of mind, of short or of long continuance; whereas faraHN is dilatation of the bosom with delight, or pleasure, of short continuance, transitory, or fleeting, not lasting, as is the case in bodily and worldly pleasures; but faraH is sometimes called suruwr, and vice versâ: (Er-Rághib, TA in art. frH:) or suruwrN signifies pleasure, or delight, and dilatation of the heart, of which there is no external sign; distinguished from HubuwrN, which is cheerfulness, i. e., pleasure, or delight, or dilatation of the heart, which has a visible effect in the aspect. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also sing. of sururN↓, (TA,) which signifies The upper extremities of the stems of plants. (K, TA.) See also masarRapN.

sariyrN c
sariyrN [A couch-frame; a bedstead: a raised couch, or couch upon a frame: a throne:] a thing upon which one lies; syn. muDoTajaEN: (M, K:) or a thing upon which one sits: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OasirRapN and [of mult.] sururN, (S, M, Msb, K,) and some, for the latter, say surarN, as more easy of pronunciation, (S, Msb,) and make the same change in other similar pls., (S,) and he who says SiyodN [for SuyudN, pl. of SayuwdN,] says surRN for sururN. (Sb, M.) It is said to be derived from suruwrN, because it generally belongs to persons of ease and affluence and of authority, and to kings. (MF.) ― -b2- Hence, and as an appellation of good omen, (Er-Rághib,) A bier, before the corpse is carried upon it: (K:) when the corpse is carried upon it, it is called [niEoXN and] jianaAzapN. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence,] sariyru banaAti naEoXK (assumed tropical:) [The bier of BenátNaash;] the seven stars that are upon the neck and breast and two knees of the Greater Bear, resembling a semicircle; [app. τ, η, υ, ø, θ, e, and f; (as in Freytag's Lex.;)] also called AlHawoDu. (Kzw.) ― -b4- [Hence likewise] sariyrN also signifies (tropical:) Dominion, sovereignty, rule, or authority: and ease, comfort, or affluence: (S, * K: [in some copies of each of which, we find AlnRiEomapu in the place of AlnRaEomapu:]) and settled means of subsistence. (M, TA.) You say, zaAla Eano sariyrihi (tropical:) He ceased to enjoy authority, or power, and ease, comfort, or affluence. (A.) [See also an ex. in a verse cited in art. dgfl.] ― -b5- And (tropical:) The part where the head rests upon the neck: (S, M, K, TA:) pl. OasirRapN and saraAYiru. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also sirarN, in two places: ＝ -A3- and masarRapN.

saraArapN c
saraArapN: see sirRN, in the latter part of the paragraph, in three places. It signifies also (assumed tropical:) The best of the productive parts of a meadow. (TA.) ― -b2- And hence, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) Pureness, choiceness, or excellence, of anything: (M, K:) pureness, and excellence, of race, or lineage. (S.) It has no verb. (M.) You say, huwa fiI saraArapK mino EiyXapK (tropical:) [He is in the best condition, or mode, of life]. (A.) And lahaA EalayohaA saraArapN (assumed tropical:) She possesses superiority over her. (Fr.)

sariyrapN c
sariyrapN; and its pl. saraAYiru: see sirRN, first and fourth sentences, in three places. ― -b2- Also The heart, or mind. (KL. [And so sirRN, q. v.]) And One's inner man; syn. jawRaAniIRN: opposed to EalaAniyapN and barRaAniIRN [q. v.]. (T in art. br.)

sarRaMCu c
sarRaMCu Ampleness, or freedom from straitness, of the means, or circumstances, of life; syn. raxaMCN; [or a happy state or condition;] contr. of DarRaMCu; (S;) i. q. masarRapN↓ and saAruwraMCu↓ [contr. of maDarRapN and DaAruwraMCu]. (K.) ― -b2- See also suruwrN: ― -b3- and see sirRN, near the end of the paragraph. ― -b4- Also i. q. baToHaMCu [q. v.]. (TA.)

sirRiIRN c
sirRiIRN [rel. n. from sirRN; Of, or relating to, anything secret: a secret, or mysterious, thing. ― -b2- And] A man who does things secretly: pl. sirRiyRuwna. (M.)

surRiyRapN c
surRiyRapN A concubine-slave; a female slave whom one takes as a possession and for concubitus; (M;) a female slave to whom one assigns a house, or chamber, in which he lodges her, (S, K,) and whom he takes as a possession and for concubitus: (TA:) of the measure fuEoliyRapN, (S, M, Mgh, Msb,) from sirRN as signifying “ concubitus, ” (S, M, * Mgh, Msb, K,) or as signifying “ concealment, ” because a man often conceals and protects her from his wife; (S;) altered from the regular form of a rel. n., (S, M, Msb, K,) by its having damm [in the place of kesr]; (S, Msb;) for the rel. n. is sometimes thus altered, as in the instances of duhoriIRN from AldRahoru and suholiIRN from AlOaroDu AlsRaholapu: (S:) or it is with damm to distinguish it from sirRiyRapN, which is applied to “ a free woman with whom one has sexual intercourse secretly, ” (Msb,) or “ one who prostitutes herself: ” (TA:) or it is from surRN in the sense of suruwrN; because her owner rejoices in her; (Akh, * S, * Msb;) and if so, it is agreeable with analogy: (Msb:) so says A Heyth; and this is the best that has been said respecting it: (TA:) or it is of the measure fuERuwlapN, from sarowN, (M, Mgh,) the latter w being changed into I for euphony, and then the [other] w being incorporated into it and thus becoming I like it, after which the dammeh is changed into a kesreh because the I is next to it: (M:) the pl. is saraAriIRu (ISk, S, TA) and saraArK; (ISk, TA;) the latter, by poetic license. (Ham p. 304.)

sirRiyRapN c
sirRiyRapN A free woman with whom one has sexual intercourse secretly, (Msb, TA, *) or who prostitutes herself: (TA:) distinguished from surRiyRapN [q. v.]. (Msb, TA.)

surosuwrN c
surosuwrN Intelligent; knowing; skilful; (S, M, K;) entering much into affairs, (S, K,) by means of his good artifices or artful contrivances. (TA.) You say, huwa surosuwru maAlK He is one who manages well, or takes good care of, property, or cattle, (AA, M, * K, * TA,) knowing what is conducive to the good thereof. (AA, TA.) And huwa Qbonu surosuwrihaA He is the knowing with respect to it. (T in art. bnI.) ― -b2- A person beloved, or a friend; a special, or choice, companion; (K;) as also surosuwrapN↓. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also The naSol [or spun thread, that has come forth,] of the spindle. (K.)

surosuwrapN c
surosuwrapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

saArRN c
saArRN; and its fem., with p: see sarRN.

saAruwraMCu c
saAruwraMCu: see sarRaMCu.

OasarRu c
OasarRu An adventive; one abiding among a people to whom he is not related; syn. daxiylN. (S, K.) Lebeed says,
wajadRiI faArisu AlrRaEoXaMCi minohumo
raYiysN laA OasarRu walaA saniydu
[And my grandfather, the rider of Er-Raashà, was of them; a chief, not an adventive, nor of suspected origin]. (S.) ＝ -A2- Also a camel having a gall, or sore, in the kirokirap [or callous projection upon the breast]: (S:) or having a pain therein, arising from a gall, or sore: (K:) or
having sores in the hinder part thereof, nearly penetrating into his inside, but not mortal: or having the disorder termed DabRN, which is a tumour in the breast: (M:) fem. sarRaMCu. (M, K.) [See sararN.] ― -b2- zanodN OasarRu A znd [or piece of stick, or wood, for producing fire,] that has become hollow [by wear]. (AHn, S, M, K. [See 1, near the end of the paragraph.]) And qanaApN sarRaMCu A hollow spearshaft. (S, M, K.)

tasurRapN c
tasurRapN: see suruwrN.

masarRapN c
masarRapN an inf. n. of sarRahu [q. v.] (S, O, K.) ― -b2- [And A cause of suruwr, i. e. happiness, or joy, or gladness;] a thing whereby one is made happy, or joyful, or glad: pl. masaArRu. (Msb.) ― -b3- See also sarRaMCu. ― -b4- Also, [perhaps as being a cause of pleasure,] The extremities of sweet-smelling plants; (M, O, K;) and so suruwrN↓: (O, K:) or the latter, the upper halves of the stems of plants; (Lth, M, O; [but see suruwrN;]) properly, the parts of a lotus-plant that are concealed [by the water] and are consequently succulent and soft and beautiful: and sariyrN↓, the root, or lower part, of a lotusplant, whereon it rests: (O:) or this last, the pith of the lotus-plant; (M, K;) and so siraArN↓: (TA:) [accord. to Az,] Aibonu AlmasarRapi signifies the branch [or sprig] of rayoHaAn [or of a sweetsmelling plant]. (T in art bnI.)

misarRapN c
misarRapN An instrument in which one speaks secretly, like a TuwmaAr [i. e. a roll, or scroll] (S, K) &c. (TA.)

masoruwrN c
masoruwrN Happy, or joyful, or glad; or affected with suruwr [q. v.]. (S, TA.) ＝ -A2- Having the navel-string cut. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b2- And with p, applied to the kind of jar termed muzamRalap, Having a surRap, meaning a perforation in the middle, in which is fixed a tube of silver or lead, whence one drinks. (Har p. 548.)

waqafotu EalaI musotasarRihi c
waqafotu EalaI musotasarRihi I became acquainted with his hidden, or secret, affair. (A, * TA.)

1 saraOato c
1. saraOato, (S, K,) aor.
saraAa
, inf. n. saroCN; (S, TA;) and srROt↓, inf. n. tasoriYapN; (K;) said of the female locust, (S, K,) and of the female of the [lizard called] DabR, (TA,) [and of a fish, and the like, (see saroCN,)] She laid eggs: (S, K, TA:) and sarato, inf. n. sarowN, is a dial. var. thereof. (TA in art. srw.) [And accord. to El-Kanánee, as cited in the TA, it seems that one says also, of locusts (jaraAd), saraOa AlbayoDa and saraOa bihi.] ― -b2- Also, each of these two verbs, (K,) the former mentioned by IDrd, and ↓the latter by Fr, (TA,) said of a woman, She bore many children. (K.)

2 sarRaAa
2: see above, in two places.

4 AsrOt c
4. AsrOt, said of a female locust, [and app. of a female of the lizard called DabR, and a fish, and the like, (see saroCN,)] She attained the period of laying eggs. (S, K.)

saroCN c
saroCN and saroOapN↓ (M, K) and siroOapN↓ (K [for wyuksr in the CK should be watukosaru, referring to the second form,]) and siroCN↓, (TA, [accord. to which wtksr refers to the s in the first and second, but this I think improbable,]) or srOp is with kesr [only, i. e. siroOapN↓], (S, K, [supposing that in the latter the pronoun hiIa refers to srOp, but accord. to the TA it means Alkalimapu, so as to refer to srC also,]) and most hold this to be correct, (TA,) The egg, (S, K,) or eggs, (M,) of the locust, (S, M, K,) and of the [lizard called] DabR, (M, TA,) and of fish (M, K, TA) and the like; (M, TA;) and sirowapN signifies the same, but is originally with C: (S:) accord. to 'Alee Ibn-Hamzeh El-Isbahánee, siroOapN↓ and sirowapN signify the eggs of the locust; but some say, only when laid: accord. to Lth, srC [app. saroCN] signifies the eggs of the fish and the like, as also suruwoCN; [the former as a coll. gen. n., and the latter as its pl., agreeably with analogy;] and one is called srOp [app. saroOapN↓ as a n. un., agreeably with analogy; or it may be siroOapN↓]. (TA. [See also sirowapN in art. srw: and see dabFI.])

siroCN c
siroCN: see the next preceding paragraph.

saroOapN c
saroOapN: see saroCN, in two places.

siroOapN c
siroOapN: see saroCN, in four places.

sirowapN c
sirowapN, originally siroOapN [q. v., voce saroCN]. ― -b2- Also A dust-coloured arrow: in this sense like wise originally with C: thus expl. by 'Alee Ibn- Hamzeh. (TA.) [See also art. srw.]

saraMCN c
saraMCN A species of tree, of which bows are made: n. un. with p. (TA.) [See art. srI.]

saruwoCN c
saruwoCN, applied to a female locust, (El-Isbahánee, K,) and to the female of the [lizard called] DabR, (Lth, TA,) [and to a fish and the like, (see saroCN,)] Laying eggs: (El-Isbahánee, K, * TA:) or having eggs in her belly; not yet laid: (Lth, K, * TA:) pl. suruWN (Lth, El-Isbahánee, K) and surRaOo, which latter is extr. in form as pl. of a sing. of the measure faEuwlN, (K,) and suruwoCN [which is also extr., like hujuwdN as pl. accord. to some of hajuwdN]. (MF.)

OaroDN masoruWapN c
OaroDN masoruWapN, (S, K,) or masoruwoCapN, (TA,) A land containing sirowap [meaning locusts' eggs]: (ElIsbahánee, S:) or abounding with locusts (K, * TA) [or with locusts' eggs: for the explanation in the K is ambiguous].

UisoraAYiylu c
UisoraAYiylu a surname of [the patriarch] Jacob; (Ksh and Bd * and Jel * in ii. 38;) also pronounced UisoraAYilu, (Ksh and Bd ibid.,) and UisoraAYilRu, (Ksh ibid.,) and UisoraAlu, and UisoraAyiylu. (Bd ibid.) ― -b2- And the name of A certain angel; also pronounced UisoraAYiynu; in which the n is asserted by Yaakoob to be a substitute for the l. (TA.) ― -b3- [But the! is more properly to be regarded as a radical letter.]

1 saraba c
1. saraba aor.
saruba
, inf. n. suruwbN, He went forth: and he went away. (M.) You say, saraba fiI AlOaroDi, (M, A, Mgh, Msb,) aor. as above, (M, Msb,) and so the inf. n., (M, A, Msb,) He went away [into the country, or in the land]. (M, A, Mgh, Msb.) And saraba fiI HaAjatihi He went, or went away, (A'Obeyd, M,) or, as some say, during the day, (M,) for the accomplishment of his want. (A'Obeyd, M.) And huwa yasorubu AlnRahaAra kulRahu fiI HawaAYijihi [He goes, or goes away, all the day, accomplishing his wants]. (A.) ― -b2- saraba [or rather saraba fiI AlOaroDi] also signifies He (a man) went away at random into the country, or in the land. (Har pp. 448 and 511.) A poet says, (S,) namely, Keys Ibn-El-Khateem, (TA,)
OanRaI saraboti wakunoti gayora saruwbi↓
[i. e. Whence hast thou gone away at random? for thou wast not one wont to go away at random:] (S, TA:) thus, srbt, as related by IDrd: accord. to others, [sarayoti,] with I. (TA.) ― -b3- sarabati AlUibilu, aor. and inf. n. as above, The camels went away into the country, or in the land, going forth whithersoever they would: and in like manner saraba is said of a stallion [camel]': (Az, TA:) or saraba, (S, K,) said of a stallion [camel], aor. as above, (S,) and so the inf. n., signifies he repaired, or betook himself, to the place of pasture: (S, A, K:) and saraba AlmaAlu, aor.
saruba
, inf. n. sarobN, the camels, or cattle, pastured during the day without a pastor. (Msb.) ― -b4- saraba AlmaMCu, (A, Mgh, Msb,) aor. as above, (Msb,) inf. n. suruwbN; (Mgh, Msb;) or sariba, [aor.
saraba
,] inf. n. sarabN; (M;) The water ran (A, Mgh) upon the surface of the ground: (A:) or flowed; as also Ansrb↓: (M:) [or the latter signifies it ran swiftly: (see Har p. 586:)] and in like manner one says of the saraAb [or mirage], yasorabu, inf. n. sarabN, it runs. (AHeyth, TA.) And saribati AlEayonu, inf. n. sarabN; and sarabato, aor.
saruba
, inf. n. suruwbN; The Eyn [or source, or perhaps (assumed tropical:) eye, (see masorabN,)] flowed; as also tsrRbt↓: so says Lh. (M.) And saribati AlmazaAdapu, aor.
saraba
, (S, K,) inf. n. sarabN, (S,) The mzAdp [or leathern water-bag] flowed. (S, K.) And xaraja AlmaMCu sarabFA The water came forth from the punctures made in sewing the skin. (TA.) [Or] saribato said of a new [water-skin such as is termed] qirobap, or of a mazaAdap, signifies It had water poured into it in order that the thong [with which it was sewed] might become moistened, so as to swell, and fill up the holes made in the sewing. (M.) ― -b5- See also sarabN, below. ― -b6- [Golius explains saraba, inf. n. sarabaAnN, as on the authority of the KL, as signifying “ Ingressus fuit in rem, totum subivit implevitve locum: ” but this is a mistake, evidently occasioned by his finding sarabaAnN, explained in this sense, instead of sarayaAn, the reading in my copy of the KL.] ＝ -A2- sarobN [as an inf. n.] is [also] syn. with xarozN [signifying The sewing of a skin or the like]. (Kr, K, TA. [In a copy of the M, I find AlsRarabu Alxarazu erroneously written for AlsRarobu Alxarozu.]) You say, sarabotu Alqirobapa, inf. n. sarobN, I sewed the qrbp [i. e. water-skin, or milk-skin]. (TK.) ＝ -A3-
suriba, (M, K,) like EuniIa, [i. e. pass. in form but neuter in signification,] (K,) said of a man, (TA,) He became affected with suppression of the feces, or constipation of the bowels, (Oaxacahu HuSorN or HaSarN accord. to different copies of the K,) by the entrance of the fume of [molten] silver [see OusorubRN] into the innermost parts of his nose, and other passages, (K,) or into his mouth, and the innermost parts of his nose, and his anus, (M, * TA,) and other passages: (TA:) the epithet applied to a man thus affected is masoruwbN↓: (K:) sometimes he recovers, and sometimes he dies. (TA.)

2 sarRaba
2: [srRb app. signifies, primarily, He sent camels in a herd or drove, together, to pasture. And hence, ― -b2- ] srRb EalaIRa AlUibila (tropical:) He sent [against me] the camels [app. with armed riders], one detached number after another: (As, S, A, K, TA:) and in like manner, Alxayola (tropical:) [the horsemen]. (S, A, Mgh, TA.) It is said in a trad. of ' Áïsheh, [referring to girls who were her playmates,] kaAna yusarRibuhunRa UilaIRa fayaloEabona maEiI (assumed tropical:) He used to send them to me [app. party after party, and they would play with me]. (TA.) And one says, sarRabotu Uilayohi AlXRaIoCa (assumed tropical:) I sent to him the thing, one by one; or rather, portion by portion. (L, TA.) And sarRabotu Uilayohi AlOaXoyaMCa (tropical:) I gave him the things, one after another. (A, TA.) And sarRabahu He sent him back in his srb [i. e. sarob], meaning way [by which he had come]. (Har p. 20.) ― -b3- See also 4. ＝ -A2- srRb sarabFA He made a subterranean excavation. (M, A.) ― -b2- srRb AlHaAfiru, (As, TA,) inf. n. tasoriybN, (S, K,) The digger [of a well], in digging, took [i. e. dug] towards the right and left: (As, S, * K, * TA:) in some copies of the K, [and in the S,] right or left: but the former is the correct explanation. (TA.) ＝ -A3- srRb Alqirobapa, (S, M, A,) inf. n. as above, (K,) He poured water into the qrbp [i. e. water-skin, or milk-skin], in order that the holes made in the sewing might become filled up (S, M, A, K) by their being moistened, (S, K,) or by the moistening, and consequent swelling, of the thong [with which it was sewed]; the qrbp being new. (M.)

4 Asrb c
4. Asrb He made water to flow; as also srRb↓. (M.)

5 tasarRaba
5: see 1, near the middle of the paragraph. ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] tsrRbwA fiyhi (assumed tropical:) They followed one another continuously in it; namely, a road. (M.) ― -b3- See also 7. ＝ -A2- tsrRb mina AlmaMCi He became full of water. (TA.)

7 Uinosaraba
7: see 1, near the middle of the paragraph. ― -b2- Ansrb fiyhi He entered into it; (S, M, K;) i. e., a wild animal, into his sarab, (S, M, Msb,) meaning his subterranean habitation, (S, Msb,) or his place of abode; (M;) and a fox, (S,) into his burrow; as also tsrRb↓. (S, K.)

sarobN c
sarobN Pasturing maAl, (M, A, TA,) i. e. camels: (M, TA:) or camels, and maAl [here meaning cattle in general], that pasture: (S:) or maAl [i. e. camels or cattle] pasturing during the day without a pastor; an inf. n. used as a subst. in this sense; and saAribN↓ [meaning maAlN saAribN] signifies the same: (Msb:) or, accord. to IAar, (M,) any maAXiyap [i. e. camels and other cattle]; (M, K;) thus say IJ and Ibn-Hishám El-Lakhmee: and accord. to Kz, sirobN↓ also, [q. v.,] with kesr, signifies maAlN [syn. with maAXiyapN]; and IO says the like: (TA:) pl. of the former suruwbN, (M, TA,) and some say OasoraAbN [which is a pl. of pauc.]. (TA.) Hence the saying, Aicohabo falaA Oanodahu sarobaka, i. e. Go thou away, for I will not drive back thy [pasturing] camels; (S, Msb; *) they shall go, (S,) or I will leave them to pasture, (Msb,) where they will; (S, Msb;) meaning, I have no need of thee: (S:) in the Time of Ignorance, they used to divorce by saying thus, (S, M, Msb,) AicohabiI falaA Oanodahu sarobaki. (S, M, A.) ― -b2- [Freytag also explains it, from the Deewán el-Hudhaleeyeen, as meaning A sheep-fold.] ＝ -A2- Also A way, or road; (AZ, S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) and so sirobN↓ with kesr; (M, K;) the latter accord. to Aboo-' Omar and Th, but' disallowed by Mbr, who knew only the former in this sense; said by Ibn-Es-Seed to have been pronounced by AZ with fet-h, and by Aboo-' Omar with kesr: (TA:) and one's way, or course; (M, K, * TA;) the way by which one goes. (T, TA. [See also surobapN, and masorabN.]) One says, xalRi sarobahu Leave thou free, or unobstructed, his way (T, M, Mgh, Msb, TA) by which he goes, (T, TA,) and his course; (M, TA;) and so sirobahu↓, with kesr; (M, TA;) accord. to Aboo-' Omar: (TA:) or xalRi lahu sarobahu leave thou free, or unobstructed, to him his way. (S, A.) And OaTolaqa AlOasiyra waxalRaI sarobahu [He loosed the captive and left free to him his way]. (A.) Hence, in a trad., mano OaSobaHa MminFA fiI sarobihi, meaning fiI mutaqalRabihi and mutaSarRafihi [i. e. He who has become secure in his scope, or room, for free action]: or, accord. to one reading, the last words are fiI sirobihi↓, meaning, (tropical:) in respect of his wives, or women under covert, and his household, or family; a metaphorical sense, from the sirob of gazelles &c. (A, and so in the Fáïk. [See also sirobN.]) Hence also the saying, UicaA kaAn muxalRaI AlsRarobi, meaning When he is made to be in ample circumstances; not straitened. (Mgh.) And you say waAsiEu AlsRarobi, instead of AlsRirobi; meaning Whose way that he pursues is ample. (TA. [But see what follows.]) ＝ -A3- Also The bosom, or breast; or the mind; syn. SadorN. (Mbr, M, K.) UinRahu lawaAsiEu AlsRarobi means Verily he is of ample bosom, or mind; and judgment; and love: (M, TA:) or, as some say, ample of bosom, or mind; slow of anger. (M. [The latter meaning is assigned in the Msb and TA to waAsiEu Alsirobi: see the next paragraph.])

sirobN c
sirobN: see saAribN. ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] A qaTiyE, (S, M, K,) or jamaAEap, (Mgh, Msb,) [i. e. herd,] of gazelles, (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) and of oxen, (M, Mgh, Msb,) [app. meaning wild oxen,] and of [wild] asses, (M,) and of wild animals [in general], (S, Msb,) and [a flock or herd] of sheep or goats, (M,) and [a flock] of the birds called qaTFA, (S, Msb,) and of birds [in general], (M,) and [a party, or bevy,] of women, (S, M, Msb, K,) &c.; (K;) and, as used by El-' Ajjáj, it is of men also: (Sh, TA:) and a poet of the Jinn, as they assert, used it metaphorically in speaking of a sirob of the [lizards called] EaZaMC: (M:) it signifies also (assumed tropical:) a collection of palm-trees; (M, K; in some copies of the latter of which AlnRaHol is erroneously put for AlnRaxol; TA;) so says AHn; and Abu-l-Hasan thinks it to be by way of comparison: and surobapN↓ is like it [in its meanings]: (M: [particularly mentioned in the K as used in the last of the senses above mentioned:]) each of these words is said to be applied to a qTyE of the birds called qaTFA, and of gazelles, and of sheep or goats, on the authority of As; and the latter [or each] of them is applied to a qTyE of women as being likened to gazelles: (TA:) the pl. of the former is OasoraAbN; (Sh, M, Msb, TA;) and of ↓the latter, surubN, (K, accord. to the TA,) with two dammehs, (TA,) [in the CK suruwbN,] or surobN, (so in my MS. copy of the K, [either a contraction of the former pl. or a coll. gen. n. of which surobapN is the n. un.,]) or both. (TA. [See also surobapN below, where the pl. is said to be surabN.]) ― -b3- [Hence, as some explain them, two phrases mentioned below in this paragraph.] ― -b4- See also sarobN, first sentence. ＝ -A2- It is also syn. with sarobN as meaning A way, or road: and a course: see sarobN in two places. ― -b2- Also i. q. baAlN [app. as syn. with HaAlN, i. e. State, or condition]. (S, Msb, K.) One says, fulaAnN waAsiEu AlsRirobi, meaning raxiIRu AlbaAli [i. e. Such a one is in an ample, or unstraitened, state or condition: or the meaning may be, such a one is easy, or unstraitened, in mind: see what follows, and see also baAlN]: (S, Msb:) or, as some say, ample of bosom, or mind; slow of anger: (Msb, TA:) [see also waAsiEu AlsRarobi, in two places near the end of the next preceding paragraph:] MF thinks that for baAl we should read maAl, agreeably with an explanation of a phrase in what here follows. (TA.) ― -b3- Also The qalob [meaning heart, or mind]: (M, K:) and the nafos [meaning self]. (IAar, M, Msb, K.) One says, huwa MminN fiI sirobihi He is secure in, or in respect of, his heart, or mind: or, himself: (M:) but IDrd disallows this latter explanation; and says that the meaning is, his family, and his maAl [or camels, or cattle, or other property], and his, children; as though the phrase Mmn fI srbh were originally used in relation to the pastor, and the stallion [camel], and then extended in its relation to others, metaphorically: (TA:) or the meaning is [simply], his maAl: or, his people, or party: (M, TA:) or as expl. above, voce sarobN, q. v.: or, accord. to Kz, his way. (TA.) The pl. is siraAbN. (El-Hejeree, M, TA.) ＝ -A3- See also masorubapN.

sarab c
sarab A subterranean excavation: (M, K:) or a habitation (S, Mgh, Msb, TA) of a wild animal, (S, * Msb,) in, (S, Mgh, Msb,) or beneath, (TA,) the earth, or ground, (S, Mgh, Msb, TA,) having no passage through it; also called wakorN: (Msb:) such as has a passage through it is
termed nafaqN: (Mgh, Msb:) the burrow, or hole, (M, K,) of a wild animal, (K,) or of a fox, and likewise [the den] of a lion, and of a hyena, and of a wolf; and the place into which a wild animal enters: (M:) pl. OasoraAbN. (M, A, Msb.) In the saying in the Kur [xviii. 60], faQtRaxaca sabiylahu fiI QlobaHori sarabFA [And it (the fish) took its way into the sea &c.], Fr says that when the fish was restored to life by the water that came upon it from the fountain [of life], and fell into the sea, its way became congealed, and like a sarab [or subterranean excavation, &c.]: Zj says that srbA may be considered as put in the accus. case in two ways; either as a second objective complement of the verb, or as an inf. n. [of sariba↓, q. v.]: and AHát thinks that it here means cahaAbFA [going away]: or, accord. to IAth, sarabN signifies a secret, or hidden, place of passage: or, as used by El-Moatarid Edh-Dhafaree, it means [simply] a road, or way. (TA.) It signifies also A subterranean channel or conduit, by which water enters a HaAYiT [or garden, or walled garden of palm-trees]. (M, K.) And TariyqN sarabN means A way, or road, in which people follow one another continuously. (M.) ― -b2- Also Flowing water: (M, K: [see also saribN:]) or water flowing from a mazaAdap [or leathern water-bag] and the like: (S:) or water dropping from the punctures made in the sewing of a water-skin. (A.) ― -b3- And Water that is poured into a qirobap [or skin for water or milk], (M, K,) when it is new, or into a mazaAdap [or leathern water-bag], (M,) in order that the thong [with which it is sewed] may become moistened, (M, K,) so as to swell, and fill up the holes made in the sewing. (M.)

saribN c
saribN Flowing water. (S, * M. [See also sarabN.]) You say also mazaAdapN saribapN, i. e. [A leathern-water-bag] flowing. (S, K.)

sarobapN c
sarobapN: see the next paragraph. ＝ -A2- I. q. xarozapN [A single puncture, or stitch-hole, made in sewing a skin or the like]. (K. [There expressly said to be, in this sense, with fet-h; but I think that we should read surobapN, and xurozapN: see, again, the next paragraph.])

surobapN c
surobapN A short journey; (IAar, M;) or so sarobapN↓. (K. [But I think that the former is the right.]) You say, UinRaka laturiydu surobapF Verily thou desirest a short journey. (IAar, M.) A long journey is termed suboOapN. (TA.) ― -b2- And i. q. macohabN (S, M, A, K) and TariyqapN (A, K) [i. e. A way by which one goes or goes away, a proper meaning of the former word; and a way, course, mode, or manner, of acting or conduct or the like, which is a meaning of both of these words]. One says, fulaAnN baEiydu AlsRurobapi, (S, A, TA,) meaning [Such a one is] one who takes a distant way into the country, or land: (TA:) or meaning baEiydu Almacohabi (S, A) and AlTRariyqapi (A) [i. e., who follows a distant, or remote, way in journeying, and a long way, course, mode, or manner, of acting or conduct or the like. See also sarobN, and masorabN]. Esh-Shenfarà says,
EadawonaA mina AlwaAdiI AlRaciI bayona miXoEalK
wabayona AlHaXaA hayohaAta OanosaOotu surobatiI
[We passed from the valley that is between Mish' al and El-Hashà: distant was it: I made my way to lead me far off]; meaning, how distant was the place from which I commenced my journey! (TA.) And one says also, UinRahu laqariybu AlsRurobapi, meaning qariybu Almacohabi [i. e. Verily he is one who pursues a near way]; who hastens, or is quick, in accomplishing his want. (Th, M.) ＝ -A2- Also A portion, or detached number, (S, Mgh, Msb,) of what compose a sirob, (Mgh, Msb,) i. e., of a collection [or herd] of gazelles, and of [wild] oxen, (Mgh,) or [of a flock] of the birds called qaTFA, and of horses, and asses, and gazelles: (S:) pl. surabN, like gurafN pl. of gurofapN. (Msb.) See also sirobN, in two places; in the latter of which the pl. is said to be surubN and surobN. ― -b2- A collection of xayol [i. e. horses, or horsemen], from twenty to thirty, (M, K,) or from ten to twenty. (M.) ― -b3- A company of men who steal away from an army, and make a hostile incursion into the territory of a people, and return. (IAar, TA.) ― -b4- A row of grape-vines: (M, K:) and any Tariyqap [meaning row or line]. (M.) ― -b5- See also masorubapN. ― -b6- Also i. q. xurozapN [i. e. A seam, or a stitch, or a puncture, or stitch-hole, of a skin or the like]. (M. [See also sarobapN.])

saraAbN c
saraAbN [The mirage;] i. q. MlN: (As, M, TA:) or the semblance of water, (S, M, A, K,) of running water, (M,) at midday, (S, M, A, K,) cleaving to the ground, (M,) and [in appearance] lowering everything so that it becomes [as though it were] cleaving to the ground, having no XaxoS; (TA;) whereas the Ml is that which is in the DuHaI [or early part of the day when the sun is yet low], raising figures seen from a distance, and making them to quiver: (M:) [several other distinctions between the srAb and the Ml, mentioned here in the TA, see voce MlN:] saraAbN has no pl. (S and K voce nahaArN.) One says OaxodaEu mino saraAbK [More deceitful than a middaymirage]. (A.) ＝ -A2- saraAbi, like qaTaAmi, (A, K, TA,) i. e. indecl., with kesr for its termination, as also saraAbu, imperfectly decl., (TA,) determinate, (K, TA,) as a proper name, not having the article Al prefixed to it, (TA,) is the name of The she-camel of El-Basoos (Albasuws), (K,) or the she-camel El-Basoos, (A, TA,) for El-Basoos was her surname: (TA:) whence the saying OaXoOamu mino saraAbi [More inauspicious than Sarábi]: (A, K, TA:) a celebrated prov.: for she was the cause of a famous war. (TA.)

saruwbN c
saruwbN [Wont to go away at random]: see 1, near the beginning of the paragraph.

sariybapN c
sariybapN A sheep, or goat, (XaApN,) which one drives back, or brings back, from the water, when the sheep, or goats, are satisfied with drinking, and which they follow. (M, TA. [See also XariybapN.])

saAribN c
saAribN Going forth: and going away; as also sirobN↓; the latter expl. by IAar as syn. with caAhibN and maADK: (M: [in one place in the TA the latter is erroneously written syrb:]) or going away at random into the country, or in the land. (S, K.) See also sarobN, first sentence. You say maAlN saAribN, (A,) and faHolN saAribN, (TA,) i. e. [Camels, or cattle, and a stallion-camel,] repairing to the place of pasture: (A, TA:) and ZayobapN saAribN (M) or saAribapN (TA) [a she-gazelle] going away in her place of pasture. (M, TA.) A poet says, (S, M,) namely, El-Akhnas Ibn-Shiháb ElTeghlibee, (TA,)
wakulRu OunaAsK qaArabuwA qayoda faHolihimo
wanaHonu xalaEonaA qayodahu fahuwa saAribu
[And all other men have contracted the shackles of their stallion-camel; but we have pulled off his shackles, and he is going away whithersoever he will in his place of pasture]: (S, M, TA: but in the last, HalalonaA is put in the place of xalaEonaA: [in the Ham (p. 347) it begins thus: OaraI kulRa qawomK:]) this, says As, is a prov.; meaning [other] men have abode in one place, not daring to remove to another, and have contracted the shackles of their stallion, that is, confined him, that he may not advance, and be followed by their [other] camels; fearing a hostile attack upon them: but we are people of might, wandering about the land, and going whithersoever we will; and we have pulled off the shackles of our stallion, that he may go whither he will; and whithersoever he hastes away to herbage produced by the rain, thither we follow him: (IB, TA:) or it may be that by the fHl he means the chief, whom, Abu-l-'Alà says, he likens to the stallion-camel. (Ham p. 347.) And hence the saying in the Kur [xiii. 11], musotaxofK biQllRayoli wasaAribN biQlnRahaAri, (S, M, TA,) i. e. [Hiding himself by night, and] appearing by day: (S:) or appearing by day in his way, or road, or in the roads: or, as is related on the authority of Akh, appearing by night, and hiding himself by day; and Ktr says the same of sArb. (TA.)

OusorubN c
OusorubN, (M, K,) and OusorubRN, (M, Msb, K,) the former mentioned by Sh, (TA,) [the latter the more common,] a Pers. word, (M, TA,) arabicized, (Msb, TA,) originally Ousorubo, (M,) [or OusoruPo,] or Ousorufo, (Msb, MF, TA,) [and in the TA strb,] i. q. raSaASN [i. e. Lead], (M, Msb,) or MnukN [which signifies the same, or black lead, or tin, or pewter]. (K.) ― -b2- And the latter, The fume of [molten] silver. (M. [See 1, last sentence.])

masorabN c
masorabN A way by which one goes; [like sarobN and surobapN;] syn. macohabN: (Har p. 448:) a place in which the maAl [i. e. camels, or cattle,] go to pasture (tasorubu); (Ham p. 99;) and masorabapN↓ signifies [the same, or] a place of pasture: (S, K:) pl. of the former masaAribu, (Ham ubi suprà,) and so of the latter. (S, K.) ― -b2- And A channel of water. (A, and Har ubi suprà.) [Hence,] one says, AixoDalRato masaAribu Eayonayohi i. e. (tropical:) The channels of the tears [of his eyes became moist so as to scatter drops]. (A.)

masorabapN c
masorabapN: see the next preceding paragraph. ― -b2- Also The passage, and place of exit, of the dung; (Mgh, Msb, TA;) in this sense with fet-h (Mgh, Msb) only [i. e. to the r]; or so and likewise masorubapN↓: and both signify the upper part of the anus. (TA.) ― -b3- See also the next following paragraph. ― -b4- Also [A sitting-place] like a SufRap [q. v.], before a [chamber such as is called] gurofap: not mXrbp; for this is a gurofap [itself]. (TA.)

masorubapN c
masorubapN, (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) with damm to the r, (S, Mgh, Msb,) and masorabapN↓, (M, Msb,) with fet-h, (Msb,) i. e. to the r, (TA,) and surobapN↓, (M, K,) The narrow hair that extends from the breast to the navel: (S:) or the hair growing in the middle of the breast, extending to the belly: (M, K:) or the hair extending from the breast to the pubes: (A, Mgh:) or the hair of the breast, extending to the pubes: (Msb:) and sirobN↓, also, signifies the hair of the breast. (TA.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce jicomN.] ― -b2- The masaArib of beasts are The soft parts of their bellies: (M, TA:) or the msrbp of any beast means the upper parts, from the part next the neck to the root of the tail: and the soft parts of the belly, and the groins, or any similar parts. (A 'Obeyd, TA.) ― -b3- See also masorabapN.

masoruwbN c
masoruwbN: see 1, last sentence.

munosaribN c
munosaribN Very tall; (K, TA;) applied to a man: and very long; applied to hair. (TA.)

Q. 1 sarobaxotu fiI AlmaXoIi c
Q. 1. sarobaxotu fiI AlmaXoIi, inf. n. sarobaxapN, I walked, or marched, an hour, or a while: (JK:) [or in the middle of the day: and gently, or in a leisurely manner: for] ― -b2- sarobaxapN signifies The walking, or marching, in the middle of the day. (K.) And The walking, or marching, gently, or in a leisurely manner. (JK, K.) ― -b3- And The being light, or agile, or active; light in any work or action, or unsteady or lightwitted, or so on an occasion of anger, or hasty, with foolishness or ignorance; syn. xifRapN and nazaqN. (K.)

sarobaxN c
sarobaxN A wide, or spacious, land: (S, K:) or one far extending: (TA:) and a land in which one cannot find his way. (K, * TA.)

mahomahu sirobaAxN c
mahomahu sirobaAxN A desert, or waterless desert, wide, or spacious, (K, TA,) in the sides: (TA:) and mahomahN musarobaxN↓ a desert, or waterless desert, far extending, (K, * TA,) wide, or spacious: so in a verse of Aboo-Duwád cited voce maroduwnN, q. v. (TA.)

musarobaxN c
musarobaxN: see what next precedes.

Q. 1 sarobalahu c
Q. 1. sarobalahu, (S, K,) or sarobalahu sirobaAlFA, (M, Msb,) inf. n. sarobalapN, (KL,) He clad him with a sirobaAl. (S, Msb, K.)

Q. 2 tasarobala c
Q. 2. tasarobala, (S,) or tasarobala sirobaAlFA (Msb) or bisirobaAlK, (M, K,) He clad himself, or became clad, with a sirobaAl: (S, M, Msb, K:) and so tasarobana, in which, accord. to Yaakoob, the n is a substitute for the l of the former. (M.)

sarobalapN c
sarobalapN Broken, or crumbled, bread, (variydN, M, K,) or a mess of broken, or crumbled, bread, (variydapN, AA, TA,) having, (K,) or moistened with, (AA,) grease, or dripping, or gravy, (AA, K,) or having much thereof. (M.)

sirobaAlN c
sirobaAlN A shirt: (S, M, Msb, K:) and [so in the M, and in the Ham p. 65, but in the Msb and K “ or ”] a coat of mail: (M, Msb, K:) the former is the primary signification: (Ham p. 349:) or anything that is worn: (M, K:) pl. saraAbiylu, (Msb, TA,) which occurs in the Kur xvi. 83 [in the first and also in the second of the senses mentioned above]: (TA:) and sirobaAnN signifies the same as sirobaAlN, the n being, accord. to Yaakoob, a substitute for the l. (M.) ― -b2- In the following words of a trad. of 'Othmán, laA OaxolaEu sirobaAlFA sarobalaniyhi QllRehu [I will not pull off a garment with which God has invested me], it is metonymically applied to the office of Khaleefeh. (TA.)

Q. 2 tasarobana c
Q. 2. tasarobana: see tasarobala.

sirobaAnN c
sirobaAnN: see sirobaAlN.

1 saraja c
1. saraja, (O, K,) aor.
saruja
, (K,) inf. n. sarojN, (TK,) (assumed tropical:) He lied; as also sarija, (O, K,) aor.
saraja
; (K;) but the latter is outweighed [in authority]; (TA;) like sadaja: (O:) and so srRj↓: (TA:) and Xaraja. (O and K * in art. Xrj.) You say, takalRama fulaAnN bikalimapK fasaraja EalayohaA biOusoruwjapK↓ (assumed tropical:) [Such a one spoke a word, or sentence, and followed it with a lie]. (O.) ― -b2- And saraja Alkaciba, aor.
saruja
, inf. n. sarojN, (assumed tropical:) He forged the lie. (TA.) [See also 2.] ＝ -A2- sarajN, as an inf. n., signifies The being bright, or shining. (KL.) ― -b2- [And hence,] sarija, (O, K,) aor.
saraja
, (K,) inf. n. sarajN, (TK,) said of one's face, (assumed tropical:) It was, or became, beautiful: (O:) or, said of a man, (TA,) (tropical:) he was or became, beautiful in his face: (K, TA:) but said by some, to be post-classical; and by some, to be strange. (TA.) ＝ -A3- sarajato XaEorahaA, (O, K, TA, but not in the CK,) and srRjt↓, (K, TA, but not in the O,) [thought by SM to be a mistranscription for srRHt, with the unpointed H,] She (a woman, O) plaited her hair; (O, K;) like sajaratohu. (O.) ＝ -A4- [saraja, aor.
saruja
, expl. as signifying “ Ephippio instruxit instravitve equum ” by Golius and Freytag, by the latter as on the authority of the S and K, I do not find in either of those lexicons, nor in any other. The verb having this meaning is Asrj only.]

2 srRjhu c
2. srRjhu, (A, K,) inf. n. tasoriyjN, (K,) (tropical:) He rendered it beautiful; (A, K;) namely, a person's face; said of God: (A:) (assumed tropical:) he adorned, ornamented, decorated, or embellished, it; namely, a thing. (L.) The meaning given in the K [and A] has the authority of El-Beyhakee and IKtt and Es-Sarakustee and IKoot; but Aboo-' AbdAllah Mohammad Ibn-Esh-Shádhilee thought it to be not of established authority as belonging to the ancient language. (TA.) [Hence,] one says, sarRijo Uilayohi Oamoraka (assumed tropical:) Embellish and elucidate thou to him thy affair, or case. (Ham p. 326.) ― -b2- And i. q. wafRaqahu (assumed tropical:) [He accommodated, adapted, or disposed, him, or it, to a right course, or issue]. (TA.) ― -b3- One says also, srRj EalaIRa OusoruwjapF↓ (tropical:) [He forged against me a lie]. (A, TA.) And EalaIRa tsrRj↓ (tropical:) He lied, or lied purposely, against me. (A, TA. [See also tsdRj.]) And UinRahu yusarRiju AlOaHaAdiyva (tropical:) [Verily he forges traditions, or stories]. (A, TA.) ― -b4- See also 1, first sentence. ＝ -A2- srRjt XaEorahaA: see 1.

4 Oasorajotu AlsRiraAja c
4. Oasorajotu AlsRiraAja (O, Msb, TA) I lighted the lamp, or wick. (Msb, TA.) ― -b2- [And Asrj signifies also He lighted himself or another with a lamp &c.; and so Astsrj↓: or each of these, with bihi following it, he employed it (i. e. a lamp, or oil, &c.,) as a means of light: see AiSoTabaHa, in art. SbH.] ＝ -A2- Oasorajotu AldRaAbRapa, (S, K, *) or Alfarasa, (Msb,) I bound the saddle, or his saddle, upon the beast, or horse: (Msb, K:) or I made a saddle for the [beast, or] horse. (Msb.)

5 tasarRaja
5: see 2.

10 Uisotasoraja
10: see 4.

Q. Q. 1 sarojana AlOaroDa c
Q. Q. 1. sarojana AlOaroDa He manured the land with sirojiyn. (L in art. srjn.)

sarojN c
sarojN A certain appertenance of a horse or similar beast, (Msb, K, *) well known; (S, Msb;) i. e., his raHol [or saddle]: (TA:) an Arabic word; or, accord. to the Shifá el-Ghaleel, arabicized from srk [which is written by Freytag Xrk, and said by him to be Pers., but I know not either of these two words in Pers. with an apposite meaning]: (TA:) dim. surayojN↓: (Msb:) and pl. suruwjN. (Mgh, Msb, TA.) [Hence,] maAla sarojuka (assumed tropical:) Thy affair, or case, was or has become, in a disordered, or an unsound, state: a proverbial saying. (Ham p. 242.)

surojajN c
