surojajN Continuing, or lasting; or continuing, or lasting, long; or, for ever. (O, K.)

surojuwjN c
surojuwjN Foolish, or stupid. (O, K.)

sirojiynN c
sirojiynN i. q. zibolN [i. e. dung of horses or other solid-hoofed animals, or fresh dung of camels, sheep and goats, wild oxen, and the like; used for manure]: (Msb, and K in art. srjn:) a foreign, or Pers., word, (Msb,) originally sarokiyn, [meaning saroGiyno,] (Msb, K,) arabicized, (Msb, and S and K in art. srjn,) by the conversion of the k [or G] into j, and also into q, so that one says also siroqiynN [q. v.]: As is related to have said, I know not how to say it, and I only say rawovN: it is with kesr to the first letter in order to agree with Arabic words; fet-h not being allowable, because
there is no instance of the measure faEoliylN; though it is said in the M to be sirojiynN and sarojiynN: (Msb:) [the word being arabicized, all its letters should be regarded as radical; but] many assert the n to be augmentative [and therefore mention the word, or the two words, in the present art., as does the author of the Msb]. (TA.)

surojuwjapN c
surojuwjapN (S, O, K) and sirjiyjapN↓ (O, K) Nature; or natural, native, or innate, disposition, or temper, or the like: (S, O, K, TA:) and a way, mode, or manner, of acting or conduct or the like. (S, O, TA.) One says, humo EalaI surojuwjapK waAHidapK They are of one uniform nature or disposition. (As, S, O.) And Alkaramu mino sirojiyjatihi and surojuwjatihi Generosity is a quality of his nature or disposition. (Lh, TA.) And UinRahu lakariymu AlsRurojuwjapi and AlsRirojiyjapi Verily he is generous of nature or disposition. (AZ, TA.)

sirojiyjapN c
sirojiyjapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

siraAjN c
siraAjN a word of well-known meaning; (S, O, K;) i. q. miSobaAHN [i. e. A lamp, or its lighted wick, (the latter of which meanings is assigned to both of these words by Jel in xxiv. 35,)] (L, Msb, TA) that gives light by night: (L, TA:) or, properly, a lighted wick; its employment to signify the place thereof [i. e. a lamp, generally a vessel of glass having in its bottom a small glass tube into which the lower part of the wick is inserted,] being a well-known tropical application: (MF, TA:) pl. surujN. (O, Msb, TA.) [See also masorajapN.] ― -b2- [Hence,] the sun is called a siraAj [in the Kur lxxi. 15, and also xxv. 62, and lxxviii. 13], (S, O,) and AlsRiraAju, (K,) and siraAju AlnRahaAri (tropical:) [The lamp of day]. (A, TA.) So too is the Prophet. (Kur xxxiii. 45.) 'Omar, also, is called in a trad. siraAju Oaholi AljanRapi (assumed tropical:) [The lamp of the people of Paradise]. (TA.) And one says, AlhudiI siraAjN AlmuWominiyna (tropical:) [The Kur-án is the lamp of the believers], (A,) or siraAju AlmuWomini [the lamp of the believer]. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, metaphorically, (tropical:) The eye; because of its being often likened to a siraAj. (Har p. 554.)

surayojN c
surayojN dim. of sarojN, q. v. (Msb.)

siraAjapN c
siraAjapN The craft, or occupation, of the sarRaAj [or saddler]. (O, K, TA.)

suyuwfN surayojiyRapN c
suyuwfN surayojiyRapN, (O, K,) or surayojiyRaAtN, (As, S,) Certain swords so called in relation to a blacksmith named surayojN: (As, S, O, K:) or they may be so called because having much water, and [glistening] wavy marks or streaks or grain. (Ham p. 326.) [See also musarRajN.]

sarRaAjN c
sarRaAjN A saddler; i. e. a maker of suruwj [or saddles]: (O, K, * TA:) or a seller thereof. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also (tropical:) A great, or habitual, liar, (K, TA,) who will not tell thee truly whence he comes, but will tell thee lyingly. (TA.) One says, UinRahu sarRaAjN marRaAjN (tropical:) Verily he is a lying person, (A,) or a great, or habitual, liar, (TA,) who adds, or exaggerates, (yaziydu,) in his narration, or talk, or discourse. (A, TA.) And it is used alone, [without marRaAjN,] so that one says, rajulN sarRaAjN (tropical:) [A man who lies much, or habitually, &c.]. (TA.) [See also sadRaAjN.]

jabiynN saArijN c
jabiynN saArijN (assumed tropical:) [A side of a forehead, or a forehead itself,] clear, or white, [and bright,] like the siraAj [or lamp]. (Th, TA.)

siyrajN c
siyrajN i. q. XayorajN; (TA in the present art. and in art. Xrj; [but in the present art., gyr AlXRayoraji is erroneously put for Eayonu AlXRayoraji, meaning the same as AlXyrj;]) but vulgar; (TA in art. Xrj;) i. e. Oil of sesame, or sesamum: an arabicized word, from [the Pers.] XiyrahN. (TA in the present art.)

OusoruwjapN c
OusoruwjapN (tropical:) A lie. (TA.) See 1 and 2.

musorajN c
musorajN, applied to a horse, (A,) or beast (daAbRapN), [or app., when applied to the latter, with p,] Saddled; i. e. having the saroj bound upon it. (TA.)

masorajapN c
masorajapN, with fet-h (S, Mgh, O, Msb) to the m and r, (Msb,) [A lamp; i. e.] the thing in which is the wick and the oil: (S, Mgh, O, TA:) and also the thing upon which the siraAj [app. here meaning lamp] is put: (O:) or the thing upon which the misorajap↓ is placed: (Msb:) or misorajapN↓, with kesr, has the last of these meanings: masorajapN, with fet-h, having the first thereof: or, as some say, the reverse is the case; (Mgh;) [i. e.] misorajapN↓, with kesr, signifies the thing in which is the wick [and the oil]: and masorajapN, with fet-h, the thing upon which that is put: (A, TA:) the pl. (of either, Mgh) is masaAriju. (Mgh, Msb.) [See also siraAjN.]

misorajapN c
misorajapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.

musarRajN c
musarRajN (tropical:) A face rendered beautiful by God. (A.) ― -b2- A nose beautiful in thinness and evenness: used in this sense by El-'Ajjáj: likened by him to the kind of sword called surayojiIR. (S, O.)

Q. 1 sarojana c
Q. 1. sarojana: see art. srj.

sarojiynN c
sarojiynN: see art. srj.

1 saraHa AlmaAlu c
1. saraHa AlmaAlu, (TA,) or saraHati AlmaAXiyapu, (S, TA,) or AlUibilu, (Mgh, Msb,) aor.
saraHa
, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. suruwHN (S, A, Msb, K) and saroHN, (Mgh, Msb, K,) The cattle, or camels, pastured, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, TA,) or pastured where they pleased, (S, K, TA,) by themselves; (S, * Msb, K, * TA; *) [or in the morning; for] you say, saraHato biAlgadaApi and raAHato biAlEaXiIRi: (S:) or pastured in the morning until the DuHaI [or period of bright morning-sunshine]. (AHeyth, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] huwa yasoraHu fiI OaEoraADi AlnRaAsi [as though meaning He feeds upon the reputations of men;] i. e. (tropical:) he defames men; or defames men in their absence. (A, TA.) ― -b3- And saraHotu OanaA, inf. n. suruwHN, I went, or went away, in the morning. (AHeyth, TA.) And OasoraHu Uilayoka I go, or walk, to thee. (Har p. 44.) ― -b4- And saraHa AlsRayolu, (A, TA,) aor.
saraHa
, inf. n. saroHN and suruwHN, (TA,) The torrent ran, or flowed, easily: (A, TA:) on the authority of Aboo-Sa'eed. (TA.) ― -b5- And saraHa Albawolu, (A, K,) aor.
saraHa
, inf. n. saroHN (K) and sariyHN, (TA,) The urine had vent, poured out or forth, flowed, or streamed, (A, K, TA,) after its having been suppressed. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- saraHa AlmaAXiyapa, (AHeyth, S, A, * TA,) or AlUibila, (Mgh, Msb,) aor.
saraHa
, (Msb,) inf. n. saroHN; (S, A, Mgh, Msb, TA;) and srRHhA↓, (Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. tasoriyHN, (Mgh, K,) but the teshdeed in this verb denotes intensiveness, or muchness, or frequency, of the action, or its application to many objects; (Msb;) He sent forth, or set free, [or drove,] the cattle, or camels, to pasture, (S, * Mgh, Msb, * K, *) or to pasture where they pleased, (S, K, TA,) by themselves: (S, * Msb K, * TA:) [or he did so in the morning, as is indicated in the S; i. e.] he made them to go forth in the morning to the pasturage. (AHeyth, TA.) You say, OaraHotu AlmaAXiyapa and OanofaXotuhaA and OasamotuhaA and OahomalutuhaA and saraHotuhaA; this last alone without A. (S. [Yet Golius mentions the last also with A, though without assigning any authority for it.]) And hence, in the Kur [xvi. 6], Hiyna turiyHuwna waHiyna tasoraHawna [When ye bring, or drive, them back in the evening, and when ye send, or drive, them forth in the morning]. (AHeyth, S.) ― -b2- [Hence also,] saraHa, aor.
saraHa
, inf. n. saroHN; (K;) and srRH↓, (S, A, L,) inf. n. tasoriyHN; (L;) He sent (S, L, K) a messenger to another person, (A, TA,) or such a one to such a place, (S, L,) or to accomplish some needful affair. (L.) ― -b3- [And hence, app.,] saraHahu QllRehu, and srRHhu↓, (tropical:) God disposed him [to what was right or good], or adapted him [thereto]: mentioned by Az, on the authority of El-Iyádee, but as being strange. (TA.) One says, QllRehu liloxayori sarRaHaka↓ (tropical:) May God dispose thee, or adapt thee, to that which is good. (A.) ― -b4- And saraHa, aor.
saraHa
, inf. n. saroHN, He voided his excrement, or ordure; or, in a thin state; [the objective complement being understood;] syn. salaHa. (K.) ― -b5- And saraHotu maA fiI SadoriI, (K, * TA,) aor.
saraHa
, inf. n. saroHN, (K,) (assumed tropical:) I manifested, or gave forth, (Oaxorajotu,) what was in my bosom. (K, * TA.) ＝ -A3- sariHa, aor.
saraHa
, He set out easily in his affairs. (K.)

2 sarRaHa
2: see above, in four places. ― -b2- tasoriyHN also signifies The dismissing a wife by divorcement. (S, K.) You say, sarRaHahaA He dismissed her by divorcement: (A, Msb:) from sarRaHa AlUibila [expl. above]. (Msb.) And He sent her forth from his abode; (Bd in xxxiii. 48;) or let her go free; (Jel ibid.;) meaning one to whom he had not gone in. (Bd and Jel ibid.) [See also saraAHN, below; a subst. used as a quasi-inf. n. of this verb.] ― -b3- [Also The putting, or sending, another away, far away, or far off; removing him far
away; or alienating, or estranging, him: see Har p. 44.] ― -b4- And The act of removing, or clearing away: you say, srRH Eanohu He removed, or cleared away, from him [grief or sorrow]; syn. farRaja. (L, TA.) ― -b5- [And The causing water to flow; or letting it flow.] You say, sarRaHuwA AlmaMCa fiI Alxanodaqi [They caused the water to flow, or let it flow, into the moat]; from sarRaHa AlUibila. (Mgh.) ― -b6- And The letting down, and loosing, the hair, (S, K,) before the combing: (S:) or the disentangling the hair: or the separating it with the comb: or the combing it: (Mgh:) or the combing down the hair; and disentangling it with the comb. (Az, TA.) You say, sarRaHato XaEorahaA (A) or AlXRaEora, inf. n. as above, (Msb,) She combed [&c.] her hair (A) [or the hair]. ― -b7- [And it is used also in relation to poetry, or verses.] You say also, srRH AlXRaAEiru AlXRiEora [app. meaning The poet trimmed the poetry, or verses; as seems to be indicated by the context; for it is mentioned by Z immediately after what here precedes it]. (A.) ― -b8- And The act of facilitating, or rendering easy. (S, K.)

5 tsrRH c
5. tsrRH He (a man) went away, and went forth, from a place. (TA.) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph.

7 AnosiraAHN c
7. AnosiraAHN The act of running, or going along [quickly and easily]. (KL.) You say of a she-camel, AinosaraHato fiI sayorihaA She was, or became, quick and easy in her pace. (A.) ― -b2- And AnsrH He lay upon his back, or lay as though thrown down or extended, and parted his legs. (S.) ― -b3- And He was, or became, naked, bare, or without clothing. (KL. [See also its part. n., munosariHN.]) ― -b4- And It (grief or sorrow) became removed, or cleared away; [syn. Ainofaraja;] as also tsrRH↓; quasi-pass. of sarRaHa signifying farRaja. (L, TA.)

saroHN c
saroHN Cattle, or camels &c., pasturing, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) or pasturing where they please, by themselves: (S, A, K:) or only such as are sent, or driven, forth [to pasture] in the morning, and brought, or driven, back in the evening to their nightly resting-place: (L:) an inf. n. used as a subst. (Mgh, Msb.) A'Obeyd says that saroHN and saAriHN↓ and saAriHapN↓ signify Cattle, or camels &c.: and Khálid Ibn-Jembeh says that saAriHapN↓ means camels and sheep or goats: and a single beast; as well as a collection [of beasts]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A certain kind of trees, of great size, (S, K, TA,) and tall, (S, TA,) not depastured, or seldom eaten by the camels &c., but used for their shade: they grow in Nejd, in plain, or soft, and in rugged ground, but not in sand nor upon a mountain; and have a yellow fruit: (TA:) n. un. with p: and it is said to be the same as the MC: (S:) but this is a mistake; the fact being that it bears a kind of berry termed MC, (K, TA,) resembling the olive: (TA:) or any trees without thorns: (K:) n. un. in this sense with p: (Fr, Ham p. 603, TA:) or any tall trees: (K:) or [trees] of the kind called EiDaAh, great, with spreading branches, beneath which men alight in the Sayof [or summer]: (Ham ubi suprà:) accord. to AHn, the saroHap is a great tree with spreading branches, beneath which people often alight, widely extending; men alight beneath it in the Sayof [or summer], and pitch tents, or build houses, beneath it; and its shade is good: accord. to information given to Az by an Arab of the desert not known by him to have uttered a lie, it has a dusty colour, is not so tall as the Oavol [a species of tamarisk], has small leaves, and lank branches, or twigs, and always grows slanting, its inclination among all the trees being towards the south (Alyamiyn): Lth says that the saroH are a kind of trees that have a fruit, and they are the OalaMC (AlAlMC [app. a mistranscription for AlMC, i. e. the MC,]); but Az says that this is a mistake: Lth cites the saying of' Antarah,
baTalN kaOanRa viyaAbahu fiI saroHapK
tuHocaI niEaAlu AlsRiboti layosa bitawoCami
(L,) i. e. He is a man of valour, tall of stature, as though his clothes were upon a great tree such as is called srHp; sandals of sbt [q. v.] are cut and made for him, such as are worn by the kings; and he is not a twin; so that he has been well suckled: (EM p. 245:) thus he describes this person as tall of stature, showing that the srHp is a large tree: but the AlMC [or MC] has no trunk nor tallness: IAar says that the saroH are cakowaAn that have become large; and the ckwAn are certain trees having beautiful [shoots such as are termed] EasaAliyj: the pl. is siraAHN. (L.) ― -b2- The n. un., saroHapN, is applied to signify (tropical:) A man's wife, (S, A,) by a metonymy. (S.) The Arabs are said by Az to term a woman, or wife, a saroHp growing over water, because in this case it is in the most beautiful condition. (TA.) ― -b3- [Accord. to Forskål, (Flora Aegypt. Arab. pp. cvi. and 68,) the name of srH is applied to a plant of the class pentandria, which he terms Cadaba farinosa, (described by him in p. 68,) growing in the lower region of the mountains of Wádee-Surdud, in Tihámeh.] ＝ -A3- Also The exterior court or yard of a house, (K,) or, as in the L, of a gate, or door. (TA.)

suruHN c
suruHN Easy; as also sariyHN↓. (L.) You say, waladatohu suruHFA She brought him forth with ease. (TA.) And taxoruju suruHFA It passes forth easily and quickly: occurring in a trad., describing a draught of water that satisfies thirst (Xurobapu maMCK). (TA.) And naAqapN suruHN and munosariHapN↓ A quick, or swift, she-camel; (S;) as also saruwHN↓: (L:) or a she-camel quick and easy in pace. (A, MA, and Har p. 481.) And farasN suruHN and munosariHN↓ (K) and siroyaAHN↓, (TA,) or xayolN suruHN, (S,) A horse, or horses, quick, or swift. (S, K.) [See also saraAHi, and sarRaAHN.] And milaATN suruHu Aljanobi A shoulderblade, (TA,) or an upper arm-bone, of a camel, (ISh, T, TA,) quick to go and come [or move forwards and backwards]. (As, S, TA.) And miXoyapN suruHN An easy gait, or manner of going; (S, K;) like sujuHN. (TA.) And EaTaMCN suruHN (assumed tropical:) A gift promptly given, without deferring: (K:) or (tropical:) a gift that is easy and quick; a metaphorical phrase from naAqapN suruHN expl. above. (Har p. 481.) ＝ -A2- [See also sariyHapN, of which, in two senses, it is a pl.]

saroHapN c
saroHapN A single tree of the kind called saroHN [q. v.]. (Fr, S, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A she-ass that has attained to maturity but has not become pregnant. (O, K.) ＝ -A3- And saroHapu, (O,) or AlsRaroHapu, (K,) is the name of A certain dog. (O, K.)

siroHaAnN c
siroHaAnN, of the measure fiEolaAnN, the n being an augmentative letter, (Sb, S,) from the verb saraHa, (TA,) The wolf; (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also siroHaAlN; (Yaakoob, K;) fem. siroHaAnapN (Ks, S) and siroHaAlahN; (TA;) and the lion, (S, O, Msb, K,) in the dial. of Hudheyl: (S, O:) pl. saraAHiynu (S, A, O, Msb, K) and saraAHK and siraAHN, (O, L, K,) but the last not remembered to have been heard by Az. (L.) It is said in a prov.,
saqaTa AlEaXaMCu bihi EalaI siroHaAni
[The evening-meal, or supper, (i. e. the seeking for it,) made him to fall, or light, upon a wolf]: (S, Meyd:) accord. to A'Obeyd, it originated from a man's going forth to seek the eveningmeal, and falling upon a wolf, which devoured him: accord. to As, from the like accident to a beast: accord. to IAar, from a man's being slain by another man, named siroHaAn: it is applied to the seeking an object of want that leads one to destruction. (Meyd. [See Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 599: but the name there written “ Hasahah ” is huzolap; accord. to Meyd, the father, but accord. to the O, the brother, of Sirhán.]) ― -b2- Hence, (Mgh, Msb,) i. e. from AlsRiroHaAnu as meaning “ the wolf, ” or, as some say, “ the lion, ” (TA,) canabu AlsRiroHaAni The false dawn; (Mgh, O, K, TA;) i. e. the first [dawn]. (TA. [A term nearly agreeing with the Greek λυκόφως]) ― -b3- AlsRiroHaAnu, (O, K,) or siroHaAnN, (TA,) is also the name of A certain dog: and of a certain horse: and of another horse. (O, K.) ＝ -A2- Also The middle of a wateringtrough or tank: (O, K:) pl. as above. (K.)

saraAHN c
saraAHN a subst. from tasoriyHu AlmaroOapi; (S, Msb, K;) [i. e., a subst.] signifying The dismissal of a wife by divorcement: (Bd in xxxiii. 28 [where it is used as a quasi-inf. n., as it is also in verse 48 of the same chap.]:) like TalaAqN and firaAqN, it signifies divorcement explicitly. (L.) ― -b2- [And Dismissal in a general sense. Hence,] it is said in a prov., AlsRaraAHu mina AlnRajaAHi (tropical:) [i. e. Dismissal is a part of the accomplishment of one's want]; (S, A, L;) meaning, when thou canst not accomplish a man's want, make him to despair; for thy doing so will be in his estimation an act that will stand him in lieu of thy helping him to accomplish it: (S, L: [in some copies of the former, for faOayoYisohu, we find faMyasotahu:]) or it is applied to a man who does not desire to accomplish the want [of another]; and means, it behooves thee to make him to despair if thou accomplish not his want. (Meyd. [See a similar prov. voce XaraAHN.]) ― -b3- Also Haste, ex-
pedition, or promptness. (TA.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) Ease: so in the saying, AifoEalo celika fiI saraAHK warawaAHK (TA) i. e. (tropical:) Do thou that in a state of ease (S and A and K in art. rwH) and rest. (A in that art.) ＝ -A2- saraAHi [indecl.] like qaTaAmi, [app. as meaning The quick, or quick and easy in pace, like AlsRuruHu,] the name of a certain horse. (K.)

saruwHN c
saruwHN: see suruHN.

sariyHN c
sariyHN: see suruHN. ― -b2- OamorN sariyHN An affair done quickly, expeditiously, or promptly; (TA;) in which is no deferring. (A.) You say also, laA yakuwnu celika UilRaA fiI sariyHK That will not be save with quickness, expedition, or promptness. (TA.) And UinRa xayoraka lafiI sariyHK and AnR xyrk lasariyHN, Verily thy bounty is quick, expeditious, or prompt. (TA.) ― -b3- farasN sariyHN A horse without a saddle. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- See also the next paragraph, in five places.

sariyHapN c
sariyHapN A thong with which one sews soles or sandals or the like: (S, O, K:) pl. saraAYiHu (S, O, K *) and suruHN (TA) and [coll. gen. n.] sariyHN↓: (S, TA:) or, as some say, the thong wherewith is fastened, or tied, the xadamap which is a [thick plaited] thong that is fastened upon the pastern [of a camel, encircling it like a ring, for the attachment of a leathern shoe, or sandal]: (TA:) the pl. suruHN is also expl. as signifying the niEaAl [or leathern shoes, or sandals,] of camels: or, as some say, the thongs, or straps, of their niEaAl; each thong, or strap, being called sariyHapN: (L, TA:) Suh says, in the R, that sariyHN↓ signifies a kind of thing like the naEol with which camels' feet are clad. (TA.) The saraAYix of an arrow are The sinews that are wound around it; sing. sariyHapN: and also certain marks upon it, like those of fire. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A piece of a garment (K, TA) that has been much torn: (TA:) pl. saraAYiHu (K, TA) and [coll. gen. n.] sariyHN↓. (TA.) ― -b3- And A conspicuous elongated strip of ground, (O, K,) even, (O,) narrow, and having more trees, or shrubs, (O, K,) or, as Az says, having more plants, or herbage, and trees, or shrubs, (TA,) than what is around it, (O, K, TA,) and rising above what surrounds it; (TA;) so that one sees it to be oblong, abounding with trees, or shrubs, what is around it having few trees, or shrubs: and sometimes it is what is termed EaqabapN [app. as meaning a long mountain lying across the way, and over which one passes]: (O, TA:) pl. saraAYiHu (O, K, * TA) and [coll. gen. n.] sariyHN↓. (TA.) ― -b4- And An oblong, or enlongated, tract of blood, (K, TA,) when flowing: (TA:) pl. saraAYiHu (K, * TA) and [coll. gen. n.] sariyHN↓. (TA.)

siroyaAHN c
siroyaAHN: see suruHN. ― -b2- Also Tall; (S, K;) as an epithet applied to a man. (TA.) ＝ -A2- And Locusts, or the locust. (S, O, K, TA. [In the CK, and in my MS. copy of the K, AljawAdu is erroneously put for AljaraAdu.]) And OumRu siroyaAHK The female locust: (Aboo-'Amr Ez-Záhid, IB.) and the name of A certain woman, (S, K,) in one instance only. (Aboo-'Amr Ez-Záhid, IB.) ― -b2- AlsRiroyaAHu, (K,) or siroyaAHN, (O,) is the name of A certain dog. (O, K.)

sarRaAHN c
sarRaAHN [probably meaning Quick, or quick and easy in pace, like suruHN,] the name of a horse of El-Mohallak Ibn-Hantam. (O, K.)

saAriHN c
saAriHN and saAriHapN: see saroHN, second sentence, in three places. maA lahu saAriHapN walaA raAYiHapN [lit. He has not any camels, &c., that go away to pasture, nor any that return from pasture,] means (assumed tropical:) he has not anything: (S, TA:) and sometimes it means (assumed tropical:) he has not any people, or party. (Lh, TA.) ― -b2- sayolN saAriHN A torrent running, or flowing, easily. (Aboo-Sa'eed, A, TA.) ＝ -A2- saAriHN is also used as a subst., signifying A pastor who sends forth, or sets free, camels, or cattle, to pasture, or to pasture where they please, by themselves, or who sends them forth in the morning to the pasturage: and a people, or party, having camels, or cattle, pasturing, or pasturing where they please, by themselves, or sent forth in the morning to the pasturage. (TA.)

masoraHN c
masoraHN A place of pasturage: (K:) or a place into which beasts are sent forth, or sent forth in the morning, to pasture: (O:) pl. masaAriHu. (TA.) lahu UibilN qaliylaAtu AlmasaAriHi occurs in a trad., of UmmZara, meaning [He has camels whose places of pasturage are few; i. e.] his camels do not go forth into distant pasturage, but lie down in his outer court, or yard, in order that they may be near by to supply the guests with their milk and their flesh. (TA.)

misoraHN c
misoraHN A comb. (O, K.) ― -b2- And [the dual] misoraHaAni Two wooden things, or two pieces of wood, [composing a yoke,] that are bound upon the neck of the bull with which one ploughs. (AHn, TA.)

misoraHapN c
misoraHapN An instrument with which hair and flax or the like are separated and combed. (TA.)

masoruwHN c
masoruwHN The saraAb [or mirage]: (K: [in some copies of which, AlXRaraAbu is put in the place of AlsRaraAbu:]) mentioned on the authority of Th; but he was not sure of its correctness: (TA:) a dial. var. of maXoruwHN in this sense. (TA in art. XrH.)

munosariHN c
munosariHN; and its fem., with p: see suruHN, in two places. ― -b2- Also the former, (K, TA,) applied to a man, (TA,) Lying upon his back, or lying as though thrown down or extended, and parting his legs. (K, TA.) ― -b3- And Denuded, or divested, of his clothes; or making himself to be so: or having few clothes; lightly clad: (TA:) or coming, or going, forth from his clothes; (S, O, K;) or so munosariHN mino viyaAbihi. (A.) [Hence,] one says, huwa munosariHN mino OavowaAbi Alkarami (tropical:) He is divested, or divesting himself, of the apparel of generosity. (A.) ― -b4- And [applied to a camel as meaning] Divested of his wabar [i. e. fur, or soft hair]. (TA.) ― -b5- AlmunosariHu is also the name of A kind of verse; (S, O, K;) [namely, the tenth;] the [full] measure of which is
musotafoEiluno mafoEuwlaAtu musotafoEiluno
twice. (O.)

suroHuwbN c
suroHuwbN, applied to a mare, Long-bodied; (S, K; *) [said to be] applied only to a female: (S:) or, as some say, a mare that moves the fore legs quickly in running: and a horse of generous race, or excellent, and light, or active: said by Az to be mostly applied to the horse-kind, but restricted by some to the female. (TA.) And A she-camel swift, and long [in the body]. (TA.) It is also applied to a man, (K,) meaning Tall, and beautiful in body: and with p, to a woman: but not known to the Kilábees as applied to a human being. (TA.) ― -b2- AlsRuroHuwbu The jackal; syn. Aibonu MwaI. (K.) ― -b3- And A certain blind devil, dwelling in the sea. (K.) ＝ -A2- suroHuwbo suroHuwbo, (K, TA,) with the b quiescent, (TA,) [in the CK with bu,] A cry by which the ewe is called on the occasion of milking. (K.)

siroHaAlN c
siroHaAlN; fem with p: see siroHaAnN, in art. srH.

1 sarVda
1: sarada, aor.
saruda
, inf. n. sarodN, He carried on a thing, or put it forward from one stage to another, in regular order, consecutively, or one part immediately after another, uninterruptedly; he made it consecutive, successive, or uninterrupted, in its progressions, or gradations, or the like: (M, L:) [and so srRd↓, inf. n. tasoriydN; or this may have an intensive signification.] ― -b2- You say, sarada AldRiroEa, (A,) [aor. and] inf. n. as above, (S, K,) He fabricated the coat of mail (S, A, K) by inserting the rings one into another: (S, A:) [and so (as appears from an explanation of its pass. part. n.) srRdhA↓; or this may have an intensive signification:] and zaradahaA signifies the same. (K in art. zrd.) [See also sarodN below.] ― -b3- And sarada AlXRaIoCa (M,) inf. n. as above; (M, K;) and srRdhu↓, (M,) inf. n. tasoriydN; (K;) and Asrdhu↓, (M,) inf. n. UisoraAdN; (TA;) He perforated the thing [as one does in fabricating a coat of mail, (see, again, sarodN, below,) and in sewing leather]: (M, K:) some say that sarodN signifies the act of perforating. (S.) ― -b4- And sarada AlnRaEola wagayorahaA, [inf. n. as above and siraAdN,] He sewed the sandal &c.; (A;) [as also srRd↓, for] sarodN (S, K) and siraAdN (K.;) and tasoriydN↓ (S, K) signify the sewing of leather. (S, K.) ― -b5- And sarada xufRa AlbaEiyri, inf. n. sarodN, i. q. xaSafahu biAlqidRi [app. meaning He covered the camel's foot with thongs interwoven]. (M.) ― -b6- And sarada AlHadiyva (M, A, Msb) wanaHowahu, (M,) aor.
saruda
, (S, M, Msb,) inf. n. sarodN; (S, M, Msb, K;) and srRdhu↓; (TA;) (tropical:) He carried on, or continued, uninterruptedly, (S, * M, A, Msb, K, *) and well, (S, K,) the narrative, or tradition, or discourse, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) and the like; (M;) and in
like manner,AlqiraMCapa the recitation, or reading: (A:) from sarada AldRiroEa and AlnRiEaAla [or AlnRaEola, expl. above]: (Har p. 307:) and sarada AlquroMna He carried on, or continued, uninterruptedly and with rapidity the recitation, or reading, of the Kur-án. (M, L.) And sarada AlSRawoma (Sudot;, K *) or AlSRiyaAma, (TA,) and Sawomahu, aor.
saruda
, inf. n. sarodN, (K,) (assumed tropical:) He continued uninterruptedly the fast, (S, K,) and his fast. (K. [See also what next follows.]) ＝ -A2- sarida, aor.
sarada
, (K,) inf. n. saradN, (TK,) He (a man, TA) fasted uninterruptedly. (K.)

2 sarRada
2: see the preceding paragraph, in six places.

4 Oasorada
4: see 1. ＝ -A2- Asrd AlnRaxolu The palm-trees had hard green dates, which are termed saraAd. (K.)

5 tsrRd AldRurRu c
5. tsrRd AldRurRu (tropical:) The pearls, or large pearls, followed one another, or did so uninterruptedly, upon the string. (A.) And tsrRd damoEuhu kamaA yatasarRadu AllRuWoluWu (tropical:) His tears followed one another, or did so uninterruptedly, like as do pearls. (A.) And tsrRd AlHadiyvu, and, AlqiraMCapu, (tropical:) The narrative, or tradition, and the recitation, or reading, was carried on, or continued, uninterruptedly [and well: see 1]. (A.)

Q. Q. 3 AisoranodaAhu c
Q. Q. 3. AisoranodaAhu, (S, M, K,) inf. n. AisorinodaMCN, (S,) It (a thing, M) prevailed against him, or overcame him; (S, * M, K; *) like AigoranodaAhu: (S, * K:) these two are said to be the only verbs of this measure: (TA:) [but several others should be added; as AiEolanodaI and AikolanodaI and AigolanotaI:] the I in AsrndI [and the like] is to render it quasi-coordinate to [quadriliteral-radical verbs of the measure] AifoEanolala. (S.) A rájiz says,
qado jaEala AlnRuEaAsu yagoranodiyniI
OaToruduhu EanRiI wayasoranodiyniI
[Drowsiness was beginning to prevail against me; I driving it from me, and it overcoming me]. (S, M; but in the latter, with OadofaEuhu in the place of OaToruduhu.)

sarodN c
sarodN inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (S, M, &c.) [Hence,] waqadRiro fiI QlsRarodi, in the Kur xxxiv. 10, means And do thou make a due adaptation of the rings in the fabrication of the coats of mail: (Bd, Jel:) or and do thou properly adapt the nails, or pins, and the holes of the rings, [in the fabrication,] not making the former thick and the latter small, nor the reverse: (M, Bd, * L:) or AlsRarod means AlsRamor [i. e. the nailing, or the making firm, or fast, with nails], (Zj, M, L,) in this instance. (Zj, L.) ＝ -A2- Also (assumed tropical:) Coats of mail; (S, M, L, K;) a gen. n. in this sense: (S, K:) [and a single coat of mail; like zarodN and zaradN:] and (tropical:) any other Halaq [properly signifying rings, but here meaning mail]; (S, A, K;) [i. e.] it signifies also the like of coats of mail, made of Halaq: (M, L:) [said to be] so called because the two extremities of each ring are perforated by the nail, or pin; and these rings are [termed] Almusoradu↓: (L:) [if so, the word is an inf. n. used in the sense of a pass. part. n.,] see masoruwdN, [and then as a subst.; and, being originally an inf. n., it is used alike as sing. and pl.; or, as Z says,] it is an inf. n. used as a subst.: (A:) or AlsRarodu, as some say, means AlsRamoru, [as mentioned above,] and AlsRaradu↓ means AlHalaqu [like AlzRaradu]. (M.) ＝ -A3- Also (tropical:) Consecutive, or following one another: so in the phrase nujuwmN sarodN (tropical:) [Stars that are consecutive: the epithet retaining the masc. sing. form, though applied to a pl. subst., because originally an inf. n.; like EadolN in the phrase rijaAlN EadolN]. (A.) So too as an epithet applied to three of the sacred months, in the saying, valaAvapN sarodN wawaAHidN farodN [Three are consecutive and one is separate]: (A:) thus an Arab of the desert answered when asked if he knew the sacred months: (S, M, Msb:) the srd are Dhu-l-Kaadeh and Dhu-l-Hijjeh and El-Moharram, and the frd is Rejeb. (S, M.)

saradN c
saradN: see AlsRaradu in the next preceding paragraph.

saraAdN c
saraAdN Hard green dates: (K:) and dates that are injured by want of water, (K, TA,) and consequently dry up before ripening: (TA:) or unripe dates that drop before attaining to maturity, while green: n. un. with p: (AHn, M, TA:) or the latter signifies a date that becomes sweet before it becomes coloured, being such as is termed a balaHap. (M, TA.) [See busorN.] ＝ -A2- See also misoradN. ＝ -A3- [saraAdN and suruwdN said by Golius, and by Freytag after him, to signify the same as the “ Pers. ramiydano Pavidum fugacemque esse, ” as on the authority of the KL, are mistranscriptions for XiraAdN and XuruwdN, which I find thus expl. in the KL.]

siraAdN c
siraAdN: see misoradN

sariydN c
sariydN: see misoradN in two places.

siraAdapN c
siraAdapN The art of fabricating coats of mail; as also ziraAdapN. (TA in art. zrd.)

sarRaAdN c
sarRaAdN A fabricator of coats of mail; (TA in art. zrd;) i. q. zarRaAdN. (M and TA in art. zrd.) ― -b2- And A sewer of leather; (TA;) as also saAridN↓. (AA, L, TA.)

saromadN c
saromadN: and saromadiIRN: see art. srmd.

saranodFI c
saranodFI Strong: (S, M, K:) or bold, daring, brave, or courageous: (M:) and quick in his affairs: (K:) or a man who goes on, or advances, boldly; derived from AlsRarodu: (Sb, TA:) [accord. to Sb, therefore, this is its proper art; but accord. to the K, its proper art. is srnd, in which F mentions it again: it is perfectly decl., i. e., with tenween, for] the fem, is saranodaApN. (S, TA.) ― -b2- Also A sword that penetrates the thing that it strikes. (L.)

saAridN c
saAridN: see sarRaAdN.

Almusoradu c
Almusoradu: see sarodN.

misoradN c
misoradN (S, M, A, L, Msb) and siraAdN↓ (S, M, A, L) An instrument for perforating: (M, L, Msb:) and, (M,) or as some say, (Msb,) an instrument with which leather is sewed; (S;) syn. mixorazN; (M, L, Msb;) or UiXofFI; which is [said to be] the same thing as the mixoraz; (L;) as also sariydN↓: (K:) or an [instrument of the kind called] UiXofFI that has a hole at its extremity; (A;) and so sariydN↓ and saraAdN↓. (TA: [but the last I think a mistake for siraAd.]) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, huwa Qbonu misoradK, (K,) or huwa Qbonu OumRi misoradK, (A,) (tropical:) He is the son of a female slave: (A, K:) because she is a sewer of skins, or leather: (A:) an expression of vituperation. (K.) ― -b3- [Hence, likewise,] misoradN also signifies (tropical:) The tongue. (M, A.) So in the saying, fulaAnN yaxoriqu AlOaEoraADa bimisoradihi (tropical:) [Such a one wounds reputations with his tongue]. (A.) ＝ -A2- Also A sandal having its lisaAn [or tongue, i. e. the thing projecting in its fore part,] faced with another piece sewed on. (M, L.)

musarRadN c
musarRadN; and its fem., with p: see the next paragraph, in three places.

xarozN masoruwdN c
xarozN masoruwdN and musarRadN↓ [app. A sewing of leather or skin carried on in regular and uninterrupted order]. (S. [In one of my copies of the S, I find xaraz in the place of xaroz; and so in the L; but the latter appears from the context to be the right reading.]) ― -b2- And likewise diroEN masoruwdapN and musarRadapN↓, (S,) or diroEN masoruwdN, and labuwsN musarRadN↓, [though diroEN and labuwsN are both generally fem.,] and laOomapN sarodN↓, [in which the epithet retains the masc. form because originally an inf. n., like EadolN in the phrase AimoraOapN EadolN,] A coat of mail fabricated by inserting the rings one into another. (A.) And masoruwdapN signifies A coat of mail (diroEN) perforated [in its rings]. (S.)

luWoluWN mutasarRidN c
luWoluWN mutasarRidN (tropical:) Pearls following one another, or doing so uninterruptedly. (A.) And maAXK mutasarRidN (tropical:) One walking, or going, with consecutive, or uninterrupted, steps. (A.)

musoranodK c
musoranodK [A thing] that overcomes one. (S.)

sirodaAbN c
sirodaAbN, an arabicized word, (K,) from [the Pers.] sarodN [i. e. “ cold ”] and Mbo [“ water ”], (TA,) A subterranean structure, for the summer: (El-Ahmar, K:) or a narrow place into which one enters: (Msb:) [applied in the present day to a cellar, or subterranean vault, in which anything is put to be kept cool:] pl. saraAdibu (Msb) [or saraAdiybu].

AlsRirodaAbiyRapu c
AlsRirodaAbiyRapu A people of those who compose the extravagant zealots of the [sect called] raAfiDap [q. v.], who expect El-Mahdee's coming forth from the sirodaAb that is in Rei, wherefore they bring a saddled and bridled horse every Friday, after the prayer [of the congregations at noon], saying, “ O Imám: in the name of God: ” three times. (TA.)

dictScrap.label:
[Q. 1. sarodaqa, inf. n. sarodaqapN, He covered a house with an awning over its interior court, as a protection from the heat of the sun: so accord. to Golius, as on the authority of the KL: and the
same is indicated by the explanation of the pass. part. n. in the PS: but in the KL, I find only the inf. n. expl. by saraAParodaho karodano: the verb may, however, be better expl. as signifying he furnished with a suraAdiq, q. v.]

superEntry.entry:
suraAdiqN c
suraAdiqN, said by El-Jawáleekee to be an arabicized word from [the Pers.] saraAdaro or saraATaAqo, (MF,) An awning extended over the interior court of a house: (S, O, Msb, K:) [and the cover of a tent:] and any tent of cotton: (S, O, K, and mentioned in the Msb as on the authority of J:) or a [ tent of the kind called] fusoTaAT; (Bd in xviii. 28;) so says AO: (Msb:) also (Msb) an enclosure around a xayomap [or tent], consisting of pieces of cloth, without a roof: (Mgh, Msb:) or an enclosure (Hujorap) around a fusoTaAT: (Ksh and Bd ubi suprá:) or what surrounds the [tent called] xayomap and the [tent called] qubRap: (Ham p. 772:) or any wall or enclosure, or [tent such as is called] miDorab or [such as is called] xibaMC that surrounds a thing: (IAth, TA:) pl. suraAdiqaAtN: (S O, K:) it has this pl., though it is masc., because. it has no broken pl. (Sb, TA.) ElKedhdháb El-Hirmázee says, not Ru-beh as in the “ Book ” of Sb [and in the S], addressing Hakam Ibn-El-Mundhir Ibn-El-Járood,
suraAdiqu Almajodi Ealayoka mamoduwdo
(assumed tropical:) [The canopy of glory is extended over thee]. (O, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) Dust rising; or spreading, or diffusing itself. (Az, O, K.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) Smoke rising high, and surrounding a thing. (Az, O, K.) ― -b4- In the Kur xviii. 28, it is applied to what will surround the unbelievers, of the fire of Hell, (Ksh, Bd,) as being likened to a fusoTaAT, (Bd,) or to an enclosure around a fsTAT; or as meaning the smoke of the fire; or a wall thereof. (Ksh, Bd.)

bayotN musarodaqN c
bayotN musarodaqN (Lth, S, &c.) [A house, or tent,] having a suraAdiq: (Ksh in xviii. 28, and PS:) or having the whole of its upper part, and of its lower part, maXoduwd [accord. to the TK here meaning curtained, which seems to be the only apposite rendering, but I know not any authority for it], (Lth, JK, O, K, TA,) or masoduwd [i. e. closed, &c.]. (So in the CK.)

1 sariTahu c
1. sariTahu, aor.
saraTa
, inf. n. saraTN (S, M, Msb, K) and saraTaAnN; (M, K;) and saraTahu; (Sgh, K;) but the former is the more chaste, and is the form commonly known, and the latter is by some disallowed; (TA;) He swallowed it: (S, M, Msb, K:) or, as in some of the copies of the S, without chewing: or, accord. to the A, by little and little: (TA:) and AstrThu↓ signifies the same; (S, M, Msb, K;) and so tsrRThu↓: (As, K:) and in like manner, zaridahu and Azdrdhu (TA) [and tzrRdhu]. It is said in a prov., laA takuno HulowFA fatusoraTa walaA murRFA fatuEoqaI Be not thou sweet, so that thou shouldest be swallowed; nor bitter, so that thou shouldest be put out of the mouth because of thy bitterness: (S, TA:) or, accord. to one relation, fatuEoqiIa, i. e., so that thou shouldest be disliked for being very bitter: used in enjoining the taking of a middle course of conduct: so in the O. (TA.)

4 OasoraTotuhu ciraAEiI c
4. OasoraTotuhu ciraAEiI I put my fore arm upon his throat [from behind him], to strangle him, or throttle him. (TA in art. crE.)

5 tasarRaTa
5: see 1.

7 AnsrT fiI Haloqihi c
7. AnsrT fiI Haloqihi It (a thing, M) passed easily in his throat. (M, K.)

8 UisotaraTa
8: see 1.

Q. Q. 1 saroTama c
Q. Q. 1. saroTama: see art. srTm.

suraTN c
suraTN A man that swallows quickly; (Ibn- 'Abbád, O;) as also suraTapN↓ (Ibn-'Abbád, O) and suraToriTN↓: (O:) or saraToraTN↓ (so accord. to the TA) and misoraTN↓ and sarRaATN↓ a man that eats quickly: (TA:) or the first, and saraTaAnN↓ and siroTiyTN↓, (M, K,) a man (M) that swallows well, (M,) or largely. (K.) [See also suraATiIRN.] ― -b2- Also, and saraTaAnN↓, (M, K,) (tropical:) A horse (M, TA) that runs vehemently. (M, * K, TA.) [See again suraATiIRN.]

suraTapN c
suraTapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

siroTimN c
siroTimN and saroTamN: see suraATiIRN, in three places. ― -b2- Hence, (M,) the former also signifies (assumed tropical:) An eloquent speaker; (M, K;) as also saraTaAnN↓. (TA.) [See also art. srTm.]

saraTaAnN c
saraTaAnN: see suraTN, in two places: and surRayoTaI: and siroTimN. ＝ -A2- Also [The crab;] a certain aquatic creature; (S) a certain animal of the sea; (Msb;) a certain creeping thing (daAbRap), of aquatic creatures; (M;) a certain fluvial creeping thing (dAbRp); and also a marine kind, which is an animal that becomes hard like stone: the former kind is of much utility; the quantity of three mavaAqiyl of its ashes, when burnt in a cooking-pot of copper (nuHaAsK OaHomara [for the latter of which words we find in the CK xumRira]), with water or wine, or with half its weight of gentian (jinoTiyaAnaA), is very good against the bite of the mad dog; if its eye be hung upon a person affected with a tertian fever, he is cured; and if its leg be hung upon a tree, its fruit falls spontaneously: (K:) this is [said of] the srTAn that is bred in rivers: (TA:) of the marine kind, what is burnt is an ingredient in collyriums, (K,) for removing whiteness, (TA,) and in dentifrices (sanuwnaAt, so in copies of the K and in the TA [but in the CK, erroneously, sufuwfaAt]), and strengthens the gum: (TA:) pl. saraTaAnaAtN. (Msb.) ― -b2- AlsRaraTaAnu is also the name of (assumed tropical:) A certain sign of the Zodiac; (S, M, K;) [Cancer;] the fourth sign; so called because resembling the creature above mentioned in form. (TA.) ― -b3- [The disease called cancer;] a black-biliary tumour, which begins like an almond, and smaller, and when it becomes large, there appear upon it veins, red and green, resembling the legs of the saraTaAn: there is no hope for its cure; and it is treated medicinally only in order that it may not increase: (K:) a certain disease that attacks men and beasts: (M:) it is also (K) a certain disease in the pastern of a beast, rendering it hard, or rigid, so that the animal inverts his hoof: (S, K:) a certain disease that appears in the legs of beasts: (T, TA:) some say that it is a disease which affects a man in his fauces, having relation to the blood, and resembling the dubayolap [which is explained by ISh, in describing the disease termed caAtu Aljanobi, as an ulcer that perforates the belly]: and some say, that it is [the disease called] daMCu Alfiyli. (TA.)

siroTiyTN c
siroTiyTN: see suraTo.

suraToriTN c
suraToriTN or saraToraTN: see suraTN.

siriToraATN c
siriToraATN (Lth, Lh, S, M, K) and saraToraATN, (Lth, M, K,) the former said by Az to be a good form, like jilibRaAbN and sijilRaATN, but the latter to be the only instance of its form known to him, (TA,) and surayoTN↓, like zubayorN, (accord. to the K,) or surRayoTN↓, (as in the M,) like qubRayoTN, (TA, [in which this is said to be the right form,]) [The kind of sweet food called] faAluwcN, [Lh, S, M, K,) or faAluwcajN; (as in some copies of the K and in the TA;) so called because very delicious to eat and swallow, from saraTN signifying the “ act of swallowing; ” (Az, TA;) of the dial. of Syria: (Lh, M:) or [the kind of sweet food called] xabiySN. (M, K.)

suraATN c
suraATN: see suraATiIRN.

siraATN c
siraATN A road, or way: (Msb:) or a conspicuous road or way; (M, K;) so called because he who goes away on it disappears like food that is swallowed; (K) i. q. SiraATN, (S, M, Msb, K,) which is of the dial. of the early Kureysh, (Fr,) and is the more approved, on account of the mutual resemblance [of the S and T], (M, K,) though the former is the original; (M, Msb, K;) and ziraATN; for the saying that the pronunciation with the pure z is a mistake, is [itself] a mistake: (K:) [ISd says,] As mentions the reading AlzRiraAT, with the pure z; but this is a mistake; for he only heard the resemblance, and imagined it to be z; and As was not a grammarian, that he should be trusted in this matter: (M:) this is [itself, however,] a mistake; for AA is related to have read AlzRrAT, and the same is related of Hamzeh, by Ks. (TA.) One says also, huwa fiI diynihi EalaI siraATK musotaqiymK (tropical:) [He is, in respect of his religion, on, or in, a right way]. (TA.) [It is fem. as well as masc.: see zuqaAqN.]

sirowaTN c
sirowaTN: see suraATiIRN.

surayoTN c
surayoTN: see siriToraATN: ― -b2- and surRayoTaI.

surayoTaI c
surayoTaI: see surayoTaMCu: ― -b2- and surRayoTaI.

suraATiIRN c
suraATiIRN A great eater; (K;) as also sirowaATN↓
(Seer, M, K,) and siroTimN↓: (K:) or one who swallows everything; as also sirowaATN↓ (M) and siroTimN↓ and saroTamN↓; (Lh, M;) from AlAisotiraATu; the m, accord. to IJ, being augmentative; (M;) and so sirowaTN↓. (TA.) [See also suraTN.] ― -b2- Also, (S, M, K,) and suraATN↓, (M, K,) (tropical:) A sword that cuts (S, K, TA) much, or well; (K, TA;) that passes into the object that is struck with it; (M, TA;) that goes quickly into the flesh. (Ibn- Habeeb, O, in explanation of the former word.) ― -b3- suraATiIRu AljaroIi (tropical:) A horse that runs vehemently. (K, TA.) [See again suraTN.]

surayoTaMCu c
surayoTaMCu, (Jm, M, K, TA,) or surayoTaI↓, (L,) A kind of soup, or food that is supped, (Jm, M, K, TA,) like xaziyrap [q. v.]; (Jm, M, TA;) in the K, erroneously, like Hariyrap: (TA:) or resembling xaziyrap. (L in explanation of the latter word.) ― -b2- See also surRayoTaI.

sirowaATN c
sirowaATN: see suraATiIRN, in two places.

sarRaATN c
sarRaATN: see suraTN.

surRayoTN c
surRayoTN: see siriToraATN: ― -b2- and see also the paragraph here following.

surRayoTaI c
surRayoTaI a word occurring in the following prov.: AlOaxocu surRayoTaI waAlqaDaMCu DurRayoTaI, (S, K,) or surayoTaI↓ and DurayoTaI, (so in a copy of the M, without teshdeed,) and one says also sirRiyTaI↓ and DirRiyTaI, (O, K,) and surayoTaMCu↓ and DurayoTaMCu, (O, K, TA, in the CK surayoTA and DurRayoTN,) and surayoTN↓ and DurayoTN, (K, and so in a copy of the S,) each like zubayurN, (TA,) or surRayoTN↓ and DurRayoTN, (so in another copy of the S,) or both, (M,) [Taking, or receiving, is a swallowing, and paying is a making with the mouth a sound like that of the emission of wind from the anus; i. e.] one takes, or receives, a loan, or the like, (S, M, O, K,) and swallows it, (M, O, K,) and when payment is demanded of him he makes with his mouth a sound like that of the emission of wind from the anus: (S, M, O, K, TA:) meaning that taking, or receiving, is liked, and paying is disliked: (TA:) and AlOaxocu saraTaAnN↓, (O, K,) or, as some relate it, salajaAnN, (O,) waAlqaDaMCu layRaAnN. (O, K. [See 1 in art. slj.])

sirRiyTaI c
sirRiyTaI: see the next preceding paragraph.

masoraTN c
masoraTN and misoraTN↓ The gullet: (M, K:) also written with S. (M.)

misoraTN c
misoraTN: see what next precedes: ― -b2- and see also suraTN.

Q. 1 saroTama c
Q. 1. saroTama He (a man) was, or became, silent. (Sh, TA in art. rTm.) ― -b2- [From what follows, it would seem to signify also He was perspicuous in speech, or eloquent.]

saroTamN c
saroTamN Long, or tall; (S, K;) as also siroTimN↓: (K:) in the latter sense, the former epithet is applied to a man; as also siroTuwmN↓ and suraATimN↓: (M:) and a poet (namely 'Adee Ibn-Zeyd, TA) uses the phrase saroTamu AllRaHoyayoni [long in the two jaw-bones]. (S.) ― -b2- And The gullet; because of its width. (M.) ― -b3- And, as also siroTimN↓, Wide in the fauces, quick in swallowing, (M, K,) or that swallows much, (TA,) with [largeness of] body and make: (M, K:) or that swallows everything: held by Kh to be of the triliteral-radical class; (M, TA;) and mentioned in art. srT. (TA. [See suraATiIRN.]) ― -b4- And hence ↓the latter, (assumed tropical:) An eloquent speaker: (M in art. srT and in the present art., and K * in the former:) or perspicuous in speech; (M and K in the present art.;) as also saroTamN. (K.) ― -b5- saroTamN is also expl. as meaning AlcI ystwEb AlzmAm [which may be rendered That takes the whole of the nose-rein, or leading-rope; but the exact meaning must be determined from the context]; and so suroTumaAnN↓. (Freytag, from the Deewán of Jereer.)

siroTimN c
siroTimN: see saroTamN, in three places.

suroTumaAnN c
suroTumaAnN: see saroTamN, last sentence.

suroTuwmN c
suroTuwmN: see saroTamN, first sentence.

suraATimN c
suraATimN: see saroTamN, first sentence.

1 saruEa c
1. saruEa, aor.
saruEa
, inf. n. siraEN (S, Msb, K) and saraEN (TA [and mentioned in the K, but app. as a simple subst.,]) and siroEN and saroEN and saraAEapN (TA) and suroEapN, (K,) or this last is a simple subst. from OasoraEa, (Msb,) [but it is also generally used as syn. with the inf. ns. before mentioned when they are employed as simple substs., and is more common than any of them,] He, or it, was quick, expeditious, hasty, speedy, rapid, swift, or fleet: [in course, tendency, action, speech, &c.:] (S, K:) or, said of a man, i. q. OasoraEa [which may mean as above, or he hastened, made haste, or sped,] in his speech and in his actions: (IAar, TA:) but Sb makes a difference between saruEa and OasoraEa: see the latter below: (TA:) one says also sariEa, aor.
saraEa
; a dial. var. of saruEa: and tsrRE↓, said of an affair, or event, signifies the same as saruEa. (TA.) One says, AlsRiraEa AlsRiraEa like AlwaHaMCa AlwaHaMCa, (S, K,) i. e. [Make thou] haste; or haste to be first, or before, or beforehand: haste; or haste to be first, &c. (S and TA in art. wHI.) And saruEa maA faEalota caAka, (S, * TA,) and saroEa, which is a contraction of the former; for the Arabs contract by the suppression of dammeh and kesreh because they are difficult of pronunciation, saying faxocN for faxicN and EaDodN for EaDodN, but one should not say HajorN for HajarN, (S, TA,) or the like, accord. to the Basrees, though the Koofees allow the contraction in the case of fet-hah also, as in salofa for salafa; (M in art. slf;) and one says also suroEa, as a contraction of saruEa; all meaning saroEaAna [i. e. Quick was thy doing that: or how quick was thy doing that! or, which is nearly the same, excellently quick was thy doing that; for saruEa is similar to qaDuwa and ramuwa, denoting excellence]. (TA.)

2 sarRaEa
2: see 4.

3 musaAraEapN c
3. musaAraEapN signifies The hastening with another; or vying, or striving, with another, in hastening; or hastening to be, or get, before another or others; (S, K;) UilaI XaIoCK to a thing; (S;) as also tasaAruEN↓; syn. mubaAdarapN; (S, K;) with which, also, [not, however, as it is expl. above, but in the sense of buduwrN, i. e. simply the hastening to a thing,] UisoraAEN↓ is syn. (TA.) One says, saAraEuwA UilaI kacaA and Uilayohi tsArEwA↓, [They hastened, one with another, &c., to such a thing,] both signifying the same. (S.) And [of a single person,] sArE UilaI AlXRaIoCi He hastened to the thing; syn. bAdr. (Msb.) And it is said in the Kur [iii. 127], wasaAriEuwA UilaI magofirapK mino rabRikumo [And vie ye, one with another, in hastening to obtain forgiveness from your Lord]. (TA.) And again, [iii. 170,] QlRaciyna yusaAriEuwna fiI Alkufori Who fall into unbelief hastily, or quickly, (Bd, Jel,) and eagerly. (Bd.)

4 AsrE c
4. AsrE is originally trans.; (S, K;) [signifying He quickened, or hastened, himself, or his going, &c.;] and hence the saying, in a trad., UicaA marRa OaHadukumo biTirobaAlK maAYilK faloyusoriEi AlmaXoIa [When any one of you passes by a high wall, or the like, that is inclining, let him quicken, or hasten, the pace, or going]. (K, * TA.) But [it is used also elliptically, as meaning He hastened, in an intrans. sense; he made haste; he sped; he went quickly; and hence] you say, AsrE fiI AlsRayori, (S, K,) like saruEa [He was quick, expeditious, hasty, speedy, rapid, swift, or fleet, in going, journeying, or pace]: (K:) or [rather he hastened, made haste, or sped, therein; for] AsrE signifies he endeavoured, or sought, and affected, to be quick, &c., as though he hastened the pace, or going; but saruEa↓ denotes what is as it were an innate quality: (Sb:) the verb being originally trans., when you say of one AsrE fI Alsyr it is as though [meaning] he urged himself forward with haste; or he quickened, or hastened, the pace, or going; and it is only because the meaning is understood by the persons addressing one another, that the objective complement is not expressed: (Lth, K:) or the verb may be trans. by means of a particle and without a particle: or when made immediately trans., the phrase may be meant to be understood as elliptical. (TA.) [Accord. to Fei,] AsrE fiI maXoyihi, &c., inf. n. UisoraAEN, is originally AsrE maXoyahu [He quickened, or hastened, his pace, or going]; fI being redundant; or AsrE AlHarakapa fiI maXoyihi [he quickened, or hastened, the motion in his going]: and AsrE Uilayohi means AsrE AlmuDiIRa Uilayohi [he quickened, or hastened, the going to him]. (Msb.) srRE↓ is syn. with AsrE. (TA.) And you say, UilaI AlXRarRi tsrRE↓, (S, K,) meaning He hastened, or made haste, to [do] evil, or mischief; (K;) as also tzrRE. (Sgh and K in art. zrE.) And tsrRE↓
biAlOamori He hastened to do the thing, or affair; syn. baAdara bihi. (TA.) See also 3. ― -b2- AsrE Uilayohi occurs in a trad. as meaning He was quick, or hasty, in being angry with him, or in blaming him, or in reviling him. (Mgh.) ― -b3- AsrE bihi: see [its contr.] baTRaOa bihi. ― -b4- OasoraEuwA signifies also, Their beasts on which they rode were, or became, quick, swift, or fleet. (AZ, S, K.) ＝ -A2- maA OasoraEa maA SanaEota kacaA [How quick was thy doing that!]. (S, K.)

5 tasarRaEa
5: see 1 and 4; the latter in two places.

6 tasaAoraEa
6: see 3, in two places.

saroEN c
saroEN [originally an inf. n. of saruEa, like siroEN and saraEN accord. to the TA]: see sariyEN, in two places.

saraEN c
saraEN: see [1 and] suroEapN.

sariEN c
sariEN: see sariyEN.

suroEapN c
suroEapN Quickness, expedition, haste, speed, rapidity, swiftness, or fleetness; [of course, tendency, action, speech, &c.;] (S, K;) as also saraEN↓; (K;) [the former said in the K, and the latter in the TA, to be an inf. n. of saruEa:] and a hastening, making haste, or speeding; i. q. UisoraAEN [inf. n. of 4]; (TA;) or a subst. therefrom. (Msb.) You say, Eajibotu mino suroEapi caAka [I wondered at the quickness, &c., of that]. (S.)

saroEaAna c
saroEaAna and suroEaAna and siroEaAna (S, K) and saruEaAna↓, the last with damm to the r (IAar,) occurring in the phrase srEAna caA xuruwjFA, (IAar, S, K,) meaning saruEa caA xuruwjFA [Quick is this in coming forth: or how quick is this in coming forth! or, which is nearly the same, excellently quick &c.], (S, K,) are dial. vars., changed from the original form, which is saruEa, and, for this reason, (S,) made indecl., with the final vowel of saruEa for their termination. (S, K.) The word srEAn is used as a simple enunciative [placed before its inchoative], and also as an enunciative denoting wonder: [see buToMna:] and hence the saying, (K,) lasaroEaAna maA SanaEota kacaA How quick was thy doing that! (S, K.) The saying saraEaAna caA UihaAlapN originated from the fact that a man had a lean ewe, her snivel running from her nostrils by reason of her leanness, and it being said to him “ What is this? ” he answered, “ Her grease: ” whereupon the asker said as above: the last word is in the accus. case as a denotative of state; and the meaning is, Quick, or how quick, is this snivel [coming forth] in the state of melted grease! or the last word is a specificative, under the supposition that the action is transferred [from its proper agent, which thus becomes a specificative], as in the phrase taSabRaba zayodN EaraqFA; and the meaning to be understood is, Quick, or how quick, is the melted grease of this! the saying is applied to him who tells of a thing's coming to pass before its time: (O, K:) it is a prov. (TA.) ＝ -A2- saroEaAnu; and its fem., saroEaI: see sariyEN, in two places: see also the paragraph here next following, in two places,

saraEaAnu AlnRaAsi c
saraEaAnu AlnRaAsi, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and saroEaAnu↓ AlnAs, (IAar, K,) The first, or foremost, of the men, or people, (IAar, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) striving, one with another, to be the first to do a thing; (K;) so says As, with reference to soldiers hastening: (TA:) the former word in this phrase is [distinguished from saroEaAna in being] declinable in every case: (S:) in two trads. in which the phrase occurs, we find it differently related, saraEaAn and suroEaAn; the latter being pl. of sariyEN. (TA.) saraEaAnu Alxayoli, also, signifies The first or foremost, of the horsemen, and sometimes they said Alxyl saroEaAnu↓. (K.) Abu-l-'Abbás says that when srEAn is an epithet applied to men, it has both of the above-mentioned forms; but when applied to others, the former is the more chaste, though the latter is allowable. (TA.)

saruEaAna c
saruEaAna: see saroEaAna.

suraAEN c
suraAEN; and its fem., with p: see what next follows, in three places.

sariyEN c
sariyEN Quick, expeditious, hasty, speedy, rapid, swift, or fleet; [in course, tendency, action, speech, &c.;] (S, Msb, * TA;) as also sariEN↓ [and saroEN↓] and suraAEN↓, of which the fem. is with p, and saroEaAnu↓, of which the fem. is saroEaI; (TA;) i. q. musoriEN↓, (K,) which signifies as above; (TA;) [and which also signifies hastening, making haste, or speeding;] and misoraEN↓, also, signifies quick, &c., (sariyE,) to [do] good or evil: (K:) the pl. of sryE is suroEaAnN, (K,) and siraAEN is [also a pl. of the same,] syn. with musoriEuwna. (Msb.) You say, farasN sariyEN and suraAEN↓ [A quick, swift, or fleet, horse]: (IB:) and HijorN suraAEapN↓ meaning sariyEapN [a quick, swift, or fleet, mare]. (K.) And AisoEa EalaI rijolika AlsRaroEaI↓ [Go thou quickly; lit. go thou, or walk thou, or run thou, upon thy quick, or swift, leg]. (Fr.) And jaMCa saroEFA↓ meaning sariyEFA [He, or it, came quickly, hastily, speedily, &c.]. (TA.) And God is said [in the Kur ii. 198, &c.] to be sariyEu AlHisaAbi [Quick in reckoning], meaning that his reckoning will inevitably come to pass; or that one reckoning will not divert Him from another reckoning, nor one thing from another thing; or that his actions are quick, none of them being later than He desireth, because it is done without manual operation and without effort, so that He will reckon with mankind, after raising them from death and congregating them, in the twinkling of an eye, without numbering, or calculating: (K:) and [in like manner He is said in the same, chap. vi., last verse, to be] sariyEu AlEiqaAbi [quick in punishing]. (El-Mufradát, B.) ― -b2- Also A certain kind of going, or pace; coupled with sunobukN, which signifies another kind thereof. (Ibn-Habeeb, TA.) ― -b3- [AlsRariyEu The ninth metre (baHor) in prosody, in which each hemistich originally consisted of musotafoEiluno musotafoEiluno mafoEuwlaAtu.] ― -b4- And Oabuw sariyEK The [shrub called] Earofaj: or the fire that is therein. (K. [See zaHofapN.]) ＝ -A2- Also A shoot, or twig, that falls from the baXaAm [or tree of the balsam of Mekkeh]: pl. siroEaAnN and suroEaAnN. (K.)

OasoraEu c
OasoraEu [More, and most, quick, expeditious, hasty, speedy, rapid, swift, or fleet, of course, tendency, action, speech, &c.]. [It is said, of God, in the Kur vi. 62,] wahuwa OasoraEu AlHaAsibiyna [And He is the quickest of the reckoners]. (K.) [The fem.] suroEaI is applied to a she-camel by Honeyf El-Hanátim [as meaning Surpassingly quick or fleet]. (IAar, TA in art. bhI.)

musoriEN c
musoriEN: see sariyEN.

misoraEN c
misoraEN: see sariyEN.

misoraAEN c
misoraAEN Very quick, or hasty, (K, TA,) to [do] good or evil, (K,) or in affairs. (TA.)

1 sarifa c
1. sarifa, aor.
sarafa
, inf. n. sarafN, He was ignorant: or he was unmindful, negligent, or heedless. (Msb.) [In these senses it is trans.: you say,] sarifahu, (S, M, K,) aor.
sarafa
, (K,) inf. n. sarafN, (S, * M, K, *) He was unmindful, negligent, or heedless, of it; (S, M, K;) namely, a thing: (S, M:) and he was ignorant of it: (S, K:) and he missed it; (S, * M, K; * [in the first and third of which, only the inf. n. of the verb in this sense in mentioned, and expl. as syn. with xaTaON;]) syn. OaxoTaOahu. (M.) And Talabotuhumo fasarifotuhumo I sought them and missed them: or was ignorant of them. (Msb.) And sarifa Alqawoma He passed by the people, or party, and left them behind him. (M.) As relates, of an Arab of the desert, with whom some companions of his made an appointment to meet him in a certain place of the mosque, and to whom he broke his promise, that, being asked respecting that, he said, mararotu bikumo fasarifotukumo, meaning [I passed by you and] I was unmindful of you. (S.) And hence the saying of Jereer, (S, TA,) praising the Benoo-Umeiyeh, (TA,)
OaEoTawoA hunayodapa yaHoduwhaA vamaAniyapN
maA fiI EaTaAYihimu minRN walaA sarafu
meaning [They gave a hundred camels, eight persons driving them, or urging them by singing to them: there was not in their gift reproach for a benefit conferred, nor] unmindfulness: or the meaning is, nor missing (xaTaON); that is, they did not miss the proper place of the gift by their giving it to such as did not deserve it and refusing it to the deserving. (S, TA.) You say also, sarifotu yamiynahu I was unacquainted with, or knew not, his oath. (TA.) ― -b2- [sarafN is also, as expl. below, syn. with UisoraAfN, but as a subst., having no verb properly belonging to it.] ＝ -A2- sarafati AlXRajarapa, (ISk, S, K,) aor.
sarufa
, inf. n. sarofN, (ISk, S,) said of the surofap [q. v.], It ate the leaves of the tree: (ISk, S, K:) and sarafati AlxaXaba is likewise said of the surofap [as meaning it ate the wood]. (Z, TA.) And surifati AlXRajarapu, (ISk, S, M, TA,) inf. n. sarofN, (ISk,) The tree had its leaves eaten by the surofap: (S:) or was smitten, or lighted on, by the surofap: (ISk, M, TA:) and sarifa AlxaXabu [the wood was eaten by the surofap], the verb in this phrase being quasi-pass. of the verb in the phrase sarafati AlsRurofapu AlxaXabR, like as HaTima and
SaEiqa are quasi-passives of the verbs in the phrases HaTamatohu AlsRinRu and SaEaqatohu AlsRamaMCu: (Z, TA:) and [hence] one says also, sarifa AlTRaEaAmu (tropical:) The wheat, or food, was, or became, cankered, or eaten away; as though smitten, or lighted on, by the surofap. (M, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence also,] surifato Oucunu AlXRaApi (tropical:) The ear of the sheep, or goat, was entirely cut off. (A, TA.) ― -b3- And sarafato waladahaA (tropical:) She (a mother) injured her child by too much milk. (A, K, * TA.)

4 Asrf c
4. Asrf, (Msb,) inf. n. UisoraAfN, (M, Msb,) He exceeded, or transgressed, the just, or right, bound, or limit, or measure; acted extravagantly, exorbitantly, or immoderately: (M, Msb:) or UisoraAfN signifies the being extravagant in expenditure, syn. tabociyrN; (K) or so UisoraAfN fiI AlnRafaqapi: (S, TA:) or, as some say, tbcyr means the “ exceeding in respect of the right objects of expenditure, ” which is ignorance of the [right] manner, and of things that should prevent it; and AsrAf means the exceeding with respect to quantity [in expenditure], and is ignorance of the values of the right objects: (MF in art. bcr:) or the latter signifies the expending otherwise than in obedience of God, (Sufyán, K, * TA,) whether little or much; (TA;) as also sarafN↓: (M, TA:) it is also said to mean the eating that which it is not lawful to eat; and this is said to be meant in the Kur vi. 142 or vii. 29: and the putting a thing in a wrong place [as when one expends his money upon a wrong object]: and accord. to Iyás Ibn-Mo'áwiyeh, AlUisoraAfu is that [action] whereby one falls short of what is due to God. (TA.) You say also, Asrf fiI maAlihi, meaning He was hasty in respect of his property, [i. e. in expending it,] without pursuing the just course, or keeping within due bounds. (M.) And Asrf fiI AlkalaAmi and fiI Alqatoli He exceeded the due bounds, or just limits, in speech, and in slaying. (M.) AlUisoraAfu fiI Alqatoli, which is forbidden in the Kur xvii. 35, is said to mean The slaying of another than the slayer of one's companion: (Zj, M, Mgh: *) or the slaying the slayer without the authority of the Sultán: or the not being content with slaying one, but slaying a number of persons, because of the high rank of the slain and the low condition of the slayer: or the slaying one higher in rank than the slayer: (Zj, M:) or the slaying two when the slayer is one: or the maining or mutilating [before slaughter]. (Mgh.) UisoraAfN also signifies The committing of many faults, offences, or crimes, and sins. (TA.) And you say, Oakalahu UisoraAfFA (TA) and sarafFA↓, (M, TA,) meaning He ate it hastily. (M, TA.)

5 tsrRf c
5. tsrRf He sucked: and ate, gnawed, or devoured. (KL. [App. from surofapN, q. v. See also sarafati AlXRajarapa, &c., in the latter half of the first paragraph.])

sarafo c
sarafo inf. n. of sarifa [q. v.]. (S, * M, Msb, K. *) ― -b2- And also a subst. from Oasorafa; (Msb;) i. q. UisoraAfN; (M;) signifying Excess, or transgression, of the just, or right, bound, or limit, or measure; extravagant, exorbitant, or immoderate, action or conduct; (M, Msb, TA;) contr. of qaSodN. (S, K.) See also 4, in two places. ― -b3- [Hence,] (tropical:) The overflowing of water from the sides of a watering-trough, or tank; as in the saying, cahaba maMCu AlHawoDi sarafFA (tropical:) The water of the watering-trough, or tank, [went away running to waste, or] overflowed from its sides: (K, TA:) or sarafu AlmaMCi means (assumed tropical:) what goes, of water, without irrigating and without profit: [or rather its going for nought:] you say, Oarowati AlbiYoru AlnRaxiyla wacahaba baqiyRapu AlmaMCi sarafFA (assumed tropical:) [The well irrigated the palmtrees, and the rest of the water went for nought, in waste]. (Sh, TA.) ― -b4- And Addictedness (DaraAwapN, S, K, or lahajN M) to a thing, (M,) or in respect of wine. (K, TA.) It is said in a trad. (S, M) of 'Áïsheh, (TA,) UinRa lilRaHomi sarafFA kasarafi Alxamori [Verily there is an addictedness to flesh-meat like the addictedness to wine]: (S, M, TA:) i. e. he who is accustomed to it is addicted to the eating thereof, like as he who is constantly drinking wine is addicted thereto, having little selfrestraint therefrom: or the meaning here is unmindfulness [of consequences with respect to flesh-meat &c.]: or corruptness of conduct, arising from hardness of heart, and daringness to disobey, and self-impulsion to the gratification of appetite: (TA:) or it may be [that the meaning is, there is an extravagance with respect to flesh-meat &c.,] from AlUisoraAfu (S, TA) in expenditure for that which is not needed, or otherwise than in obedience [to the law of God]. (TA.) ― -b5- It is also said in a trad., laA yanotahibu AlrRajulu nuhobapF caAta sarafK wahuwa muWominN, meaning, caAta XarafK waqadorK kabiyrK [i. e. The man shall not take a thing as spoil that is of high and great estimation, he being a believer]: (K, TA:) [for] people disapprove of that: (TA:) and it is also related with X [i. e. cAt XarafK]. (K.)

sarifN c
sarifN Ignorant; (IAar, M, Msb, TA;) as also musorifN↓: (IAar, TA:) or unmindful, negligent, or heedless. (Msb.) And rajulN sarifN AlfuWaAdi (tropical:) A man missing, or mistaking, in heart, or mind; negligent, or heedless, therein. (S, K, TA.) And rajulN sarifu AlEaqoli (assumed tropical:) A man having little intellect, or intelligence: or (tropical:) corrupt in intellect; accord. to Z, from sarafati AlsRurofapu AlxaXaba, of which the quasipass. is sarifa [q. v.; meaning that it is from sarifN as a part. n. of this latter verb]. (TA.) ― -b2- OaroDN sarifapN, (S, M, K,) and waAdK sarifN, (M, TA,) A land, and a valley, abounding with the [worm, or caterpillar, or small creeping thing, called] surofap. (S, M, * K, TA.)

surufN c
surufN A certain white thing [or substance] resembling the web of the silkworm. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

surofapN c
surofapN [A certain worm, or caterpillar, or small creeping thing;] a small creeping thing that makes for itself a habitation, (S, K,) four-sided, or square, (S,) of fragments of wood, (S, K,) joining them together by means of its spittle, in the form of a naAWuws [here meaning coffin], (S,) which it then enters, and [therein it] dies: (S, K:) or the silkworm: or a certain small creeping thing, dust-coloured, that constructs a beautiful habitation in which it is: or a very small creeping thing, like the half of a lentil, that bores a tree, and then constructs therein a habitation of pieces of wood, which it conjoins by means of what resembles the web of the spider: or a very small dust-coloured creeping thing, that comes to a piece of wood and excavates it, and then brings a bit of wood and puts it therein, then another, then another, and then weaves what resembles the web of the spider: or, accord. to AHn, a certain small creeping thing, like the worm, inclining in some degree to blackness, found upon the [plants called] HamoD, that constructs a four-sided, or square, habitation, of pieces of wood, joining the extremities of these together by means of a thing [or substance] resembling the web of the spider: or the worm [or caterpillar] that weaves [a web] upon certain trees, and eats their leaves, and destroys the rest thereof by that weaving: or a certain worm [or caterpillar] like the finger, hairy, speckled with black or white, that eats the leaves of trees so as to make them bare: or a certain worm [or caterpillar] that weaves upon itself, of the size of the finger in length, a thing like the qiroTaAs [or roll, or scroll, of paper], which it enters, so becoming unattainable: or a certain light, small creeping thing, like a spider: (M:) pl. surafN. (TA.) Hence the prov., OaSonaEu mino surofapK [More skilled in fabricating than a surofap]. (S, M, K.) And one says also, OaxafRu mino surofapK [Lighter than a surofap]. (M.)

saraAfN c
[saraAfN, accord. to Freytag, (but he has not named his authority,) The erosion of a tree by wood-fretters (“ teredines, ” by which he means suraf, pl. of surofapN).]

saruwfN c
saruwfN Hard, severe, or difficult; great, momentous, or formidable: (O, K, TA:) an epithet applied to a day. (O, TA.)

sariyfN c
sariyfN A row of grape-vines. (O, K.)

saraAfiylu c
saraAfiylu: see UisoraAfiylu, below.

OusorufN c
OusorufN i. q. MnukN [i. e. Lead, or black lead, or tin, or pewter]; (O, K;) of Pers. origin, (O,) arabicized, from surubo, (O, L, K,) or Ousorubo. (CK.) [See also OusorubN.]

UisoraAfiylu c
UisoraAfiylu, (S, M, O, K,) and El-Kanánee used to say saraAfiylu↓, the name of A certain angel; (M; [in which it is mentioned among quadriliteral-radical words; but it is there said that the U may be radical;]) the angel who is to blow the horn on the day of resurrection: (Jel in vi. 73, &c.:) [see ruwHaAniIRN:] a foreign word (S, O, K) prefixed, (K,) or as though prefixed, (S, O,) to Uiylu: (S, O, K:) and UisoraAfiynu is a dial. var. of the same; (Kh, S, M, O, K;) like as they said jaboriynu and UisomaAEiynu and UisoraAYiynu. (Akh, S, O.)

musorifN c
musorifN [Exceeding, or transgressing, the just, or
right, bound, or limit, or measure; acting extravagantly, &c.: see its verb (4)]. ― -b2- See also sarifN. ― -b3- [Also] Denying, or disacknowledging, the favours, or benefits, or the unity, and the prophets and law, of God; a disbeliever, an unbeliever, or an infidel: it is said to be used in this sense in the Kur xl. 36. (TA.)

masoruwfN c
masoruwfN Eaten by the surofap [q. v.]. (TA.) And XajarapN masoruwfapN A tree of which the leaves have been eaten by the surofap; (S;) or smitten, or lighted on, by the surofap. (ISk, TA.) ― -b2- XaApN masoruwfapN (tropical:) A sheep, or goat, that has had its ear entirely cut off. (M, A.)

saraAfiylu c
saraAfiylu and UisoraAfiylu and UisoraAfiynu: see the next preceding art.

1 saraqa minohu maAlFA c
1. saraqa minohu maAlFA, (S, Mgh, O, Msb,) or AlXRaIoCa, (K,) and saraqahu maAlFA, (S, Mgh, O, Msb,) thus also they sometimes said, (S, O,) the prep. being suppressed for the sake of alleviation, but meant to be understood, (Ham p. 155,) aor.
sariqa
inf. n. saraqN (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K) and sariqN and saraqapN (Mgh, K) and sariqapN and saroqN, (K,) He stole from him property, [or the thing,] i. e. he took it [from him] secretly, and by artifice; (Mgh;) or he came clandestinely to a place of custody, and took what belonged to him, namely, another person; (O, K;) as also Astrqhu↓ [followed by minohu]. (IAar, K.) And saraqahumo [alone, He stole from them; or robbed them]. (JK and K in art. bwq.) It is said in a prov., suriqa AlsRaAriqu faQnotaHara (S, O) The thief was robbed, and in consequence slew himself: applied to him who has a thing not belonging to him taken from him, and whose impatience consequently becomes excessive. (Meyd, * O.) And srRqhu↓, inf. n. tasoriyqN signifies the same as saraqahu: El-Farezdak says,
laA taHosibanRa daraAhimFA sarRaqotahaA
tamoHuw maxaAziyka AlRatiI biEumaAni
[By no means reckon thou that dirhems which thou stolest will efface thy disgraceful practices that were committed in 'Omán]. (IB, TA.) And you say in selling a slave, bariYotu Uilayoka mina AlUibaAqi waAlsRaraqi [I am irresponsible to thee for running away and stealing]. (TA.) ― -b2- One says also, saraqa AlsRamoEa, meaning Astrqhu. (Msb. See 3.) ― -b3- And suriqa Sawotuhu [lit. His voice was stolen], meaning (tropical:) he became hoarse. (Z, TA.) ― -b4- And srqt yA qwm [app. suriqotu yaA qawomi, expl. as meaning srqt ErDI, which I think a mistranscription for suriqotu EiroDiI, i. e. (assumed tropical:) I have been robbed of my honour, or reputation, O my people]. (TA.) ― -b5- And saraqonaA layolapF mina AlXRahori (assumed tropical:) We passed pleasantly, or with enjoyment, a night of the month. (TA.) ― -b6- And saraqatoniI EayoniI (tropical:) My eye overcame me. (TA.) ＝ -A2- sariqa, aor.
saraqa
, (Yoo, IDrd, K,) inf. n. saraqN, (TK,) said of a thing, (Yoo, IDrd,) i. q. xafiIa [It was, or became, unperceived, or imperceptible, or hardly perceived or perceptible, &c.]. (Yoo, IDrd, K.) ― -b2- And sariqato mafaASiluhu, aor. as above, (IDrd, K,) and so the inf. n., (TA,) His joints became weak, or feeble; (IDrd, K;) as also Ansrqt↓. (K.)

2 srRqhu c
2. srRqhu: see 1. ― -b2- Also, (S,) inf. n. tasoriyqN, (K,) He attributed to him [or accused him of] theft. (S.) It is said in the Kur [xii. 81], accord. to one reading, UinRa Qbonaka surRiqa [Verily thy son has been accused of theft]. (S.)

3 huwa yusaAriqu AlnRaZara Uilayohi c
3. huwa yusaAriqu AlnRaZara Uilayohi (tropical:) He avails himself of, (S, O,) or seeks, (K,) his inadvertence, to look at him: (S, O, K:) [he takes an opportunity of looking at him by stealth:] and in like manner one uses the phrases AlnRaZari AisotarAqu↓ and tasarRuquhu↓ [as meaning (tropical:) the taking an opportunity of looking by stealth]: and AltRasarRuqu↓ [alone] signifies (assumed tropical:) the taking an opportunity of looking and of hearing: (TA:) [and the hearing discourse by stealth; as is indicated in the TA:] and AlsRamoEa Astrq↓ [and Astrq alone, as appears from an explanation of the part. n. musotariqN, below,] (tropical:) He listened, (S, O,) or heard, (Msb,) by stealth; (S, O, Msb;) as also AlsRamoEa saraqa↓. (Msb.)

5 tsrRq c
5. tsrRq He stole [by degrees, or] one thing and then another. (O, K.) So in the phrase tsrRq XiEoriI [He stole my poetry, bit by bit], used by Ru-beh. (O, TA.) ― -b2- See also 3, in two places.

7 Ansrq c
7. Ansrq He went, drew, or shrank, back, in order to go away, Eanohumo from them. (K, TA. [In this and the following sense, the verb is erroneously written in the CK Aasoraqa.]) ― -b2- And He was, or became, languid, and weak, or feeble. (O, K, TA.) See also 1, last sentence.

8 Astrq c
8. Astrq: see 1, first sentence: ― -b2- and see 3, in two places. [See also kabiysN.] ― -b3- Also (tropical:) He deceived, or circumvented, secretly, [or by stealth,] like him who [so] listens. (TA.) ― -b4- And you say, Astrq AlkaAtibu baEoDa AlmuHaAsabaAti (tropical:) The writer suppressed some of the items of the reckoning. (TA.)

Q. Q. 1 saroqana AlOaroDa c
Q. Q. 1. saroqana AlOaroDa He manured the land with siroqiyn. (L in art. srqn.)

saraqN c
saraqN Oblong pieces (S, O, Msb, * K) of silk; (S, O, Msb;) accord. to A'Obeyd, (S, O,) of white silk: (S, O, K:) or silk in general: (K:) said by A'Obeyd to be arabicized from the Pers. saraho, meaning “ good: ” (S, O:) n. un. with p; (S, O, Msb;) which is expl. as meaning a piece of good silk. (TA.)

sariqN c
sariqN and sariqapN↓ [the former of which is said in the Mgh and K, and the latter in the K, to be an inf. n., are also said to be] substs. from saraqa, [as such signifying Theft,] as also saroqapN↓, (O, K,) or siroqapN↓. (Msb.)

saroqapN c
saroqapN: see what next precedes.

siroqapN c
siroqapN: see what next precedes.

sariqapN c
sariqapN: see sariqN. ― -b2- Also, (Msb,) A thing stolen; (Mgh, Msb;) and so suraAqapN↓; [pl. of the latter suraAqaAtN;] whence the saying Einodahu suraAqaAtu AlXRiEori [He has stolen things of poetry or verse]. (TA.)

siroqiynN c
siroqiynN, (K, and S and Msb in art. srj,) sometimes written saroqiynN, (K,) as also sarojiyn, (Msb, TA,) Dung of horses or other solid-hoofed animals, syn. rawovN, and zibolN, (Msb,) or fresh dung of camels, sheep and goats, wild oxen, and the like; (TA in art. cOr;) a manure for land: (L:) arabicized from srkyn [or saroGiyno], (Msb, K,) a Pers. word. (Msb.) [See sirojiynN, in art. srj.]

saruwqN c
saruwqN [Thievish; a great thief]; an epithet applied to a man, and to a dog: pl. suruqN. (TA.)

suraAqapN c
suraAqapN: see sariqapN. ― -b2- Also A stealer of poetry or verses. (TA.)

saruwqapN c
saruwqapN [Very thievish; a very great thief]: it has no pl. (TA.)

saAriqN c
saAriqN [Stealing; a thief; or] one who comes clandestinely to a place of custody, and takes what does not belong to him: (O:) pl. saraqapN and surRaAqN (TA) and surRaqN. (Mgh.)

suwraqN c
suwraqN A certain disease in the members, or limbs. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.)

saAriqapN c
saAriqapN sing. of sawaAriqu, which signifies [Collars by means of which the two hands are confined together to the neck, called also] jawaAmiEu, (O, K, TA,) of iron, attached to fetters or shackles. (TA.) ― -b2- And the pl., sawaAriqu, signifies also The adjuncts (zawaAYid) in the catches (faraAX [q. v.]) of a lock. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

masoruwqu AlSRawoti c
masoruwqu AlSRawoti [lit. Having the voice stolen,] means (tropical:) hoarse in voice. (Z, TA.) And hence, masoruwqu AlbugaAmi (tropical:) [A young gazelle] having a nasal sound, or twang, in its cry; as though its voice were stolen: a phrase used by El-Aashà. (TA.)

musotariqN c
musotariqN (tropical:) Listening by stealth, (K, TA,) like the thief. (TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) Defective, weak in make. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.) ― -b3- musotariqu Alqawoli (tropical:) Weak in speech or saying. (A, TA.) ― -b4- musotariqu AlEunuqi (tropical:) Short in the neck; (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K, TA;) applied to a man; (Ibn-'Abbád, O, TA;) contracted therein. (A, TA.) [In the CK, Almusoriqu is erroneously put for Almusotariqu.]

Q. 1 saroqana c
Q. 1. saroqana: see the next preceding art.

saroqiynN c
saroqiynN: see the next preceding art.

suromN c
suromN The anus; (IAar, T;) the place of egress of the feces; i. e. the extremity of the rectum; (S, K;) a post-classical word: (S:) or the interior of the extremity of the rectum: (Lth, TA:) or the edge, or margin, of the rectum: accord. to some, peculiarly in beasts of prey that have
claws: pl. OasoraAmN. (M.) Hence the phrase rajulN waAsiEu AlsRuromi Daxomu AlbuloEuwmi, occurring in a trad., meaning (assumed tropical:) A man strong, or vehement, and violent, or wrongful or unjust or tyrannical in conduct: or a man prodigal of wealth and of blood: and therefore described as wide in the places of egress and ingress. (TA in art. blEm and in the present art.)

saramN c
saramN Pain of the anus. (K, TA.)

saromadN c
saromadN [signifies, or implies,] Continuance, or incessant continuance, (dawaAm, Kh, M, L, and AitRiSaAl, Kh, L,) of time, (Kh, M, L,) either of night or of day. (Kh, L.)
