[I have said “ or implies ” because I have not found it used otherwise than as an epithet, in the following senses.] ― -b2- Continuing; or continuing incessantly, or endlessly; syn. daAYimN; (Zj, S, L, K;) or daAYimN laA yanoqaTiEu. (Nh, L.) It is applied in this sense to night (Nh, L) [and also to day: to each in the Kur xxviii. 71 and 72]: and to night as meaning Long. (L, K.) ― -b3- Accord. to El-Fakhr Er-Rázee, it is derived from AlsRarodu, which denotes consecutiveness and uninterruptedness, and the m is added to give intensiveness to the signification: if so, its proper place is in art. srd; its measure being faEomalN: (MF:) [thus] its m is augmentative like the m in dulaAmiSN. (Bd in xxviii. 71.) ― -b4- One says also, huwa laka saromadFA He, or it, is thine ever, or for ever. (Mgh in art. smd.)

saromadiIRN c
saromadiIRN Having neither beginning nor end. (KT.)

AisoranodaAhu c
AisoranodaAhu: and saranodFI: and musoranodK: see art. srd.

Q. 1 sarohada c
Q. 1. sarohada, (S, K,) inf. n. sarohadapN, (S,) He fed, or nourished, a child well. (S, L, K.) ＝ -A2- And He cut a camel's hump [in pieces: see the pass. part. n., below]. (K.)

sarohadN c
sarohadN a term sometimes applied to The fat of a camel's hump. (S, L.) ＝ -A2- And Much water. (L.)

musarohadN c
musarohadN A fat camel's hump: (S, L, K:) or a camel's hump cut in pieces. (L.) ― -b2- Supplied with the comforts and conveniences of life, and well fed: and, with p, a woman fat, and well fed. (L.) [Applied also to a young camel: see an ex. in a hemistich cited in the first paragraph of art. rjl.]

1 saruwa c
1. saruwa, (S, M, Mgh, K,) aor. yasoruw; (S, K;) and saraA, (S, M, K,) aor. as above; (S, K;) and sariIa, (S, M, K,) aor. yasoraI; (S, K;) inf. n. saraAwapN, (S, M, K,) of the first verb, (S, M,) and sarowN, (Sb, Lh, S, M, Mgh, K,) of the same verb, (M, Mgh,) and of the second, (S, M,) and of the third, (S,) and sarFA and saraMCN, (M, K,) both of the third, but saraMCN, and this only, is mentioned by Lh as inf. n. of the second verb; (M;) He was, or became, possessed of liberality, bountifulness, munificence, or generosity, combined with manliness, or manly virtue: (S, Mgh:) or manliness, or manly virtue, (M, K,) and (M,) or combined with, (K,) high or elevated rank or condition, nobility, dignity, honour, or glory. (M, K.) ＝ -A2- sarowu AlmasaAqiI means The cleaning out of what are termed masaAqK [pl. of masoqaApN or misoqaApN, which see in art. sqI]. (TA.) ＝ -A3- sarowN also signifies, like tasoriyapN [inf. n. of srRI↓], and UisoraMCN [inf. n. of AsrI↓], The throwing off a thing from oneself [or from another]; (K, TA;) and the pulling off a thing. (TA.) You say, sarawotu AlvRawoba EanRiI, (ISk, S,) or Eanohu, aor. Oasoruw, (Mgh,) inf. n. sarowN, I threw off the garment from me, (ISk, S,) or I removed the garment from over him; (Mgh;) and sarayotu is a dial. var. thereof; (S;) or saraA vawobahu Eanohu, inf. n. sarowN; and srRAhu↓; he pulled off his garment from him: (M:) and sarawotu AljulRa Eani Alfarasi, (TA,) or Eano Zahori Alfarasi, (M,) and sarRayotuhu↓, and Oasorayotuhu↓, I threw off [the horse-cloth from the horse, or from the back of the horse]. (TA.) And sarawotu EanRiI diroEiI [I threw off from me my coat of mail]: in this case the verb is only with w. (S.) [Hence,] Eanohu surRiIa↓, (M,) or surRiIa Eanohu AlhamRu, (S, K, *) inf. n. tasoriyapN, (TA,) (tropical:) Anxiety became removed from him; as also Eanohu AnsrI↓ AlhamRu: (S, K, * TA:) or his anxiety became removed, or cleared away. (M, in explanation of the first of these phrases.) And Eanohu Alxawofu surRiIa↓ (assumed tropical:) Fear was made to quit him: the teshdeed denotes intensiveness. (TA.) And hence the phrase in a trad., Eanohu buraHaMCu AlwaHoIi falamRaA surRiIa↓ (assumed tropical:) [And when the vehement distress of mind arising from the oppression caused by inspiration was made to quit him]; referring to the Prophet. (Mgh.) ＝ -A4- sarato, (K,) inf. n. sarowN, (TA,) said of the female locust, She laid eggs: (K:) a dial. var. of saraOato. (TA.)

2 Alyawoma tasarRawona c
2. Alyawoma tasarRawona, said by the Prophet on the occasion of the expedition of Ohod, means Today ye shall have your sariIR [or that person, among you, who is distinguished by liberality and manliness, &c.,] slain: and [accordingly] Hamzeh was then slain. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 1, in six places.

3 sArAhu c
3. sArAhu, inf. n. musaAraApN, i. q. faAxarahu [i. e. He vied with him, or contended with him for superiority, in glory, or rather in liberality and manliness, &c.: see 1, first sentence]. (TA.)

4 AsrI c
4. AsrI He became in, or upon, land, or ground, such as is termed saraAp: belonging to the present art., accord. to Er-Rághib: (TA:) or he betook himself to the saraAp [app. meaning the mountainous tract so called]: (K and TA in art. srI:) it is like Oanojada and Oatohama. (TA in that art.) ＝ -A2- See also 1, in two places.

5 tsrRI c
5. tsrRI signifies takalRafa AlsRarowa, (S, K, * TA,) i. e. [He affected, or constrained himself, to possess liberality and manliness, &c., (see 1, first sentence,) or] high or elevated rank or condition, nobility, dignity, honour, or glory, and manliness, or manly virtue: (TA:) or it signifies Oaxaca surRiyRapF [he took a concubine-slave]: (K:) or ＝ -A2- one says also, tsrRI AljaAriyapa [He took the girl, or young woman, as a concubine-slave], from AlsRurRiyRapu; said by Yaakoob to be originally tasarRara, [which see in art. sr,] from AlsRuruwru. (S.) ― -b2- And tsrRAhu signifies Oaxaca OasoraAhu↓ [i. e. He took the best thereof]. (M, TA. [See also 8.])

7 Uinosarawa
7: see 1, in the latter part of the paragraph.

8 AstrI c
8. AstrI He chose, or selected, as being the best, (S, M, K,) a thing, (M,) or men, (S, K,) and camels, and sheep or goats. (S.) And Aisotarayotuhu I took the best of it. (T, TA. [See also 5, last sentence.]) And AisotaAra signifies the same as AstrI, being formed from the latter by transposition. (TA.) One says, AstrI Almawotu baniI fulaAnK, (S,) or AlHaIRa, (K,) i. e. Death chose [or took] the best of the sons of such a one, or of the tribe. (S, * K, * TA.)

sarowN c
sarowN an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (S, M, K, &c.) [Used as a simple subst., Liberality, bountifulness, munificence, or generosity, combined with manliness, or manly virtue; &c.] ― -b2- Hence, Oabuw AlsRarowi (assumed tropical:) Aloes-wood, or the like, that is used for fumigation; syn. Albaxuwru. (Har p. 228.) ＝ -A2- Also A part that rises from [the bottom of] a valley, and slopes down from the rugged portion of a mountain: (M, K:) or that rises from the channel in which the water flows, and slopes down from the rugged portion of a mountain: (M:) it is like a xayof. (S.) AlsRarowu, (S, K,) or sarowu Himoyara, occurring in a trad., is said to mean maHalRapu Himoyara [The settlement of Himyer]. (S, M, K.) ＝ -A3- And A certain kind of tree, (S, M, K,) well-known; (K;) [the common, or evergreen, cypress; cupressus sempervirens of Linn.: applied thereto in the present day: (Delile's Floræ Aegypt. Illustr., no. 900:)] n. un. with p. (S, M, K.) ＝ -A4- And Certain worms that light upon plants, (M, K, TA,) and eat them: (M:) AlvRiyaAb, in [some of] the copies of the K, is a mistranscription for AlnRabaAt: (TA:) sing. [or rather n. un.] with p. (M.)

saraApN c
saraApN The back (S, M, K) of anything: (S:) pl. sarawaAtN: (S, M, K:) it has no broken pl. (M.) And The higher, or highest, part of anything: (M in the present art., and K in art. srI:) so [for instance] of a mountain. (TA in art. srI.) [Hence,] saraApu Alyamani, (M,) or AlsRaraApu [by way of preeminence, for saraAp is prefixed to the names of a number of places and of tribes, as is said in the TA in art. srI], A certain mountain [or mountainous tract] commencing near 'Arafát and extending to Nejrán of El-Yemen: (Msb:) pl. as above. (M.) ― -b2- The highest [or most advanced state] of the day: (TA:) [or] the state of advancement, when the sun has become somewhat high, (syn. AirotifaAE,) of the day, (M, K, TA,) and so of other things; by some said to mean the middle thereof; (M;) so in the S, in relation to the day; but this is [said to be] a mistake: (TA:)
in a verse of El-Bureyk El-Hudhalee, of the night: pl. as above: and the sing. also occurs used as a pl. (M.) ― -b3- The middle of anything: pl. as above. (S.) The middle and main part of a road; (Mgh, Msb;) the hard and elevated part thereof. (K.) It is said in a trad., layosa lilonRisaMCi sarawaAtu AlTRariyqi (S, Mgh) The back and middle of the road, (S,) or the middle and main parts thereof, (Mgh,) are not for the women; meaning that they should walk upon the side parts. (S.) ― -b4- Accord. to Er-Rághib, A wide tract of land. (TA in art. srI.) ＝ -A2- It is also a pl., of a rare form, (S, Msb,) or a quasi-pl. n., (M, K,) of sariIRN [which see in several places]. (S, M, Msb, K.)

sarowapN c
sarowapN n. un. of sarowN [q. v.] in two senses. ＝ -A2- See also sirowapN.

surowapN c
surowapN: see what next follows.

sirowapN c
sirowapN (Th, AHn, T, S, M, K) and surowapN↓ (Th, M, IAth, K) and sarowapN↓ (Kr, M, K) A small arrow: (S:) or a small and short arrow: or an arrow broad and long in the head; (M, K, TA;) but therewithal slender and short; with which one shoots at the butt: (TA:) or such as is round and smooth, not broad; the broad and long being termed miEobalapN: (M:) or the very slenderest of arrow-heads, that penetrates into the coats of mail: (Th, M:) or it [is an arrow that] penetrates into the coats of mail, for which reason it is called AldRiroEiyRapu, its head entering like the needle: (T, TA:) or an arrow-head resembling an ordinary needle or a large needle: it is mentioned also in art. srI, [as being a small, short, round and smooth arrow-head, having no breadth, and as being called sirowapN and siroyapF,] because the word belongs to that art. and to this: (M:) [see also miromaApN; and see sirowapN in art. srO:] the pl. is surFI [or sirFI?] accord. to the T, or siraMCN accord. to the S. (TA.) ＝ -A2- The first (sirowapN) also signifies The locust in its first state, when it is a larva; (S;) or in its first state of growth, when it comes forth from its egg: (M:) originally with hemz: (S:) [see saroCN, in two places:] and siroyapN is a dial. var. thereof. (S.) [See also jaraAdN.]

sariIRN c
sariIRN, as an epithet applied to a man, (S, M, K, &c.,) may be from Aisotarayotu AlXRaIoCa “ I chose, or selected, the thing, ” or from AlsRaraApu “ the higher, or highest, part ” of a thing, (Ham p. 337,) or, accord. to Er-Rághib, from sarawotu AlvRawoba EanRiI “ I pulled off the garment from me, ” (TA, [in which this derivation is said to be good, but I think it far-fetched,]) Possessing liberality, bountifulness, munificence, or generosity, combined with manliness, or manly virtue: (S, Mgh:) or possessing manliness, or manly virtue, (M, K,) and, (M,) or combined with, (K,) high or elevated rank or condition, nobility, dignity, honour, or glory: (M, K:) or i. q. raYiysN [meaning a chief, or person high in rank or condition]: (Msb:) [or a generous and manly or noble person:] fem. with p: (M, K:) and masorawaAnN↓ signifies the same, applied to a man; and masorawaAnapN↓ applied to a woman: (M:) the pl. of sariIRN is OasoriyaMCu and surawaMCu (Lh, M, K) and surFI, (Az, K,) which is anomalous, (TA,) and saraApN, (T, S, Mgh, * Msb,) [originally sarawapN,] which is [also] anomalous, (T, TA,) the only instance of faEalapN as the measure of a pl. of a word of the measure faEiylN, (S, Msb,) or it is a quasi-pl. n., (Sb, M, K,) and its pl. is sarawaAtN; (S, M, Mgh, * K;) meaning saAdaAtN [or chiefs, &c.]; (Mgh); and suraApN, with damm, [originally surawapN,] is a dial. var. of saraApN, as pl. [or quasi-pl. n.] of sariIRN: (IAth, TA:) the pl. of sariyRapN is sariyRaAtN and saraAyaA. (M, K.) Also Chosen, or choice, or select: (M:) what is good of anything; pl. [or quasi-pl. n.] saraApN: (Ham p. 337:) the best, (Msb, TA, and Har p. 56,) and in like manner saraApN [as a pl.]; (M, Msb, TA, and Ham p. 57, and Har ubi suprà;) the former, of men, (Har ubi suprà,) and of camels; (S;) and the latter, of men, (S, TA, and Ham ubi suprà, and Har,) and of cattle or camels and the like, (S, M, TA,) as also the former. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also art. srI.

surRiyRapN c
surRiyRapN, said by some to be originally of the measure fuERuwlapN, from sarowN: see art. sr.

OasoraI c
OasoraI is of the measure OafoEalu [denoting the comparative and superlative degrees] from AlsRarowu signifying “ liberality, bountifulness, munificence, or generosity, combined with manliness, or manly virtue: ” [&c.:] whence the phrase OasoraAhumo suwdadFA, meaning The best of them in respect of chiefdom or the like: or it may be from AlsRuraI; meaning in this instance that the fame of the chiefdom, or the like, of him to whom it relates has pervaded the countries and spread among mankind; and this is more worthy of regard in respect of the method of grammatical analysis; from Mtr: (Har p. 363: [see art. srI:]) [ISd, however, assigns the word to the present art.:] see 5, last sentence.

OaroDN masoruwRapN c
OaroDN masoruwRapN A land containing the sirowap, or locust in its first state, when it is a larva. (S.) [In a copy of the M, it is said to be from AlsRarowapu; and the context there indicates the meaning to be A land infested by a worm of the kind termed sarowN, of which sarowapN is the n. un.: but probably AlsRarowapu, in this instance, is a mistranscription for AlsRirowapu, which is mentioned immediately after as meaning “ the locust in its first state of growth, when it comes forth from its egg. ”]

masorawaAnN c
masorawaAnN; and its fem., with p: see sariIRN.

Q. 1 sarowalahu c
Q. 1. sarowalahu, (inf. n. sarowalapN, TA,) He clad him with saraAwiyl. (S, M, K.)

Q. 2 tasarowala c
Q. 2. tasarowala He clad himself, or became clad, with saraAwiyl. (S, M, K.)

sirowaAlN c
sirowaAlN: see saraAwiyl, latter half, in two places.

sirowiylN c
sirowiylN: see saraAwiyl, in the latter half.

sirowaAlapN c
sirowaAlapN: see the next paragraph, latter half, in two places.

saraAwiyl c
saraAwiyl a Pers. word, (S, * M, Msb, * K,) originally XalowaAr, (MA, KL, [in the former loosely expl. by the word UizaArN, and so in the PS,]) of well-known meaning, (S,) [Drawers, trousers, or breeches; originally applied to such as are worn under other clothing;] a certain under-garment; (MA;) [but now applied also to such as are worn externally;] is masc. [and perfectly decl., i. e. with tenween], and fem. [and imperfectly decl., i. e. without tenween]; (S, M, Msb, K; *) sometimes masc., (Msb, K,) but not known to As otherwise than as fem.; (M;) accord. to the usage most commonly obtaining, it is imperfectly decl. and fem.: (MF:) Sb says that it is a sing., and is a foreign, or Pers., word, arabicized; resembling, in their [the Arabs'] language, what is imperfectly decl. [as a pl. of the measure faEaAliylu] when determinate and when indeterminate; but is perfectly decl. when indeterminate; and imperfectly decl. if applied as a proper name to a man, and so is its dim. if so applied, because it is fem. and of more than three letters: (S:) or it is imperfectly decl. as a proper name because it is also originally a foreign word; and its dim., surayoyiyl↓, [for surayowiyl, the w being changed into I, as in sayRidN for sayowidN,] is perfectly decl. unless used as a proper name, in which latter case it is imperfectly decl. [for the reason above mentioned or] because it is fem. and determinate: (IB, TA:) it (i. e. saraAwiyl) is made, as a pl., imperfectly decl. when indeterminate by some of the grammarians; (S;) and it occurs in poetry imperfectly decl. [when indeterminate]: (S, M, * IB, TA:) [but this may be by poetic license:] thus in the saying of Ibn-Mukbil,
OataI duwnahaA cabRu AlrRiyaAdi kaOanRahu
fatFI faArisiIRN saraAwiyla raAmiHu
[The came as an obstacle intervening in the way to her, or them, the wild bull, as though he were a Persian youth in drawers; one with a pair of horns]: (S, * IB, TA:) the former [however] is the usual way, [contrary to what has been said on the authority of MF,] though the latter is more valid: (S:) the pl. is saraAwiylaAtN: (S, M, Msb, K:) Sb says that it has no broken pl., because, if it had, it would be the same as the sing.: (M:) or, (K,) some say, (S, M, Msb,) namely those grammarians who make it imperfectly decl. when indeterminate, (S,) holding it to be [originally] an Arabic word, (Msb,) it is a pl. of which the sing. is sirowaAlapN↓ (S, M, Msb, K) and sirowaAlN↓ (S, K) and sirowiylN↓, which is [said to be] the only instance of a word of the measure faEowiylN: (K:) [this, therefore, confirms the opinion that I hold, that the measure of this word is fiEoliylN, and that all the words of the present art. are quadriliteral-radical, agreeably with an assertion in the TA that srl is not genuine Arabic: though it seems that all the lexicographers regard
the w in the words of this art. as augmentative:] a poet says,
falayosa yariqRu limusotaEoTifi * Ealayohi mina AllRuWomi sirowaAlapN↓
[Upon him is an under-garment of ignobleness, (i. e. ignobleness cleaves to him like a pair of drawers,) so that he does not become tenderhearted to one who endeavours to conciliate him]: (S, * M:) in the “ Mujarrad, ” saraAwiylu is made fem., and sirowaAlN↓ masc.: (Msb:) saraAwiyn is a dial. var.; (K;) or syn. with saraAwiyl; the n in the former being asserted by Yaakoob to be a substitute for the l [in the latter]: (M:) and XirowaAlN, with X, is likewise a dial. var. [of sirowaAlN], (K,) mentioned by Es-Sijistánee, on the authority of some one or more of the Arabs: (TA:) [the common modern pronunciation is XarowaAl: pl. XaraAwiyl.]

surayoyiyl c
surayoyiyl: dim. of saraAwiyl, q. v. (IB, TA.)

musarowalN c
musarowalN Clad with saraAwiyl; as also mutasarowilN↓. (A, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] TaAYirN musarowalN (tropical:) A bird whose plumage clothes its legs. (M, L, TA.) And HamaAmapN musarowalapN (tropical:) A pigeon having feathers upon its legs. (S, K, TA.) And farasN musarowalN, (K,) or farasN Oabolaqu musarowalN, (A'Obeyd, S, TA,) (tropical:) [A horse, or a black and white horse,] whose whiteness of the legs extends (A'Obeyd, S, K) beyond, (A'Obeyd, K, TA,) or to, (S,) the arms and thighs: (A'Obeyd, S, K:) or musarowalN applied to a horse means white in the hinder part, [and black, or of some other colour, in the hind legs,] the whiteness descending to the thighs. (A, voce Mzaru.) ― -b3- And Almusarowalu signifies (assumed tropical:) The wild bull: because of the blackness that is in his legs. (Az, TA.)

mutasarowilN c
mutasarowilN: see the next preceding paragraph.

saraAwyn c
saraAwyn: see saraAwiyl, in art. srwl.

1 saraI c
1. saraI, (S, M, K,) or saraI AllRayola (Msb) and biAllRayoli, (Mgh, Msb,) aor. yasoriI, (K,) inf. n. surFI (S, M, Mgh, K) and masorFI (S, K) and saroyapN and suroyapN (M, K) and siraAyapN; (S, * and TA as from the K, but not in the CK nor in my MS. copy of the K;) the first of a form rare among inf. ns., because it is one of the forms of pls., as is shown by the fact that some of the Arabs make it and hudFI fem., namely, Benoo-Asad, supposing them to be pls. of suroyapN and hudoyapN, (S,) and Lh knew not surFI but as a fem. noun; (M;) or the inf. n. is saroIN, and suroyapN and saroyapN are more special [in meaning, as will be shown below, voce saroyapN], and surFI is pl. of suroyapN; (Msb;) or saroyapN is an inf. n. un., and suroyapN is a simple subst., and so is surFI, (S, TA,) and so is siraAyapN (Msb, TA) also, as some say; (TA;) He journeyed, or travelled, by night, or in the night, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) in a general sense; (M, K;) accord. to AZ, in the first part part of the night, and in the middle thereof, and in the last part thereof; (Msb, TA;) and AsrI↓ signifies the same (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) in the dial. of El-Hijáz, (S, Msb,) inf. n. UisoraMCN; (M;) as also AstrI↓; (M, K;) and perhaps tsrRI↓ likewise. (Mgh.) [See also surFI and saroyapN below.] It is said in a prov., qunofucK cahabuwA UisoraMCa↓ [They went away in the manner of a hedge-hog's night-travelling; meaning they went away by night]; because the qnfc goes all the night, not sleeping. (M.) ― -b2- [Hence, as denoting unseen progress,] it is said also of the root of a tree, meaning It crept along beneath the ground; (Az, M, K;) aor. as above, (M,) inf. n. saroIN. (TA.) ― -b3- And it is said of ideal things, as being likened to corporeal things; tropically, and by extension of the signification; (Msb, TA;) or metaphorically; [as, for instance,] of calamities, and wars, and anxieties: (M, TA:) and the predominant inf. ns. [in these cases] are siraAyapN and sarayaAnN. (TA.) One says, saraI Eiroqu AlsRuwoCi fiI AlUinosaAni (tropical:) [The root, or strain, of evil crept in the man]. (Es-Sarakustee, Msb, TA.) And saraI fiyhi AlsRamRu (tropical:) [The poison crept in him, or pervaded him]; and similarly one says of wine; and of the like of these two things. (El-Fárábee, Msb, TA. [See also dabRa.]) And the lawyers say, saraI AljuroHu UilaI AlnRafosi (tropical:) [The wound extended to the soul], meaning that the pain of the wound continued until death ensued in consequence thereof: (Mgh, * Msb, TA:) and quTiEa kafRuhu fasaraI UilaI saAEidihi (tropical:) [His hand was cut off, and it extended to his upper arm], meaning that the effect of the wound passed by transmission: and saraI AltRaHoriymu, and AlEitoqu, (tropical:) The prohibition, and the emancipation, [extended, or] passed by transmission: phrases current among the lawyers, but not mentioned in books of repute, though agreeable with others here preceding and following. (Msb, TA.) One says also, saraI Ealayohi AlhamRu (tropical:) Anxiety came to him [or upon him] by night: and saraI hamRuhu (tropical:) His anxiety went away. (Msb, TA.) And similar to these is the phrase in the Kur [lxxxix. 3], waQllRayoli UicaA yasori (tropical:) And by the night when it goes away: (Msb, TA:) or, as some say, when one journeys in it; like as one says layolN naAYimN meaning “ night in which one sleeps: ” the [final] I [of the verb] is elided because it terminates a verse. (TA.) ― -b4- It is made trans. by means of b: (Msb:) one says, saraI bihi [He made him to journey, or travel, or he transported him, by night, or in the night; or it may be rendered he journeyed, or travelled, with him, by night, or in the night]; (M, Msb, K;) and in like manner, [and more commonly,] bihi OasoraI↓; (S, M, Msb, K;) and OasoraAhu↓; (S, M, K;) like as one says, Oaxaca biAlxiTaAmi as well as Axc AlxiTaAma. (S.) As to the saying in the Kur [xvii. 1], suboHaAna QlRaciI biEabodihi layolFA OasoraI↓ [Extolled be the glory of Him who transported his servant by night!], it is an instance of corroboration, (S, K, * TA,) like the saying, sirotu Oamosi nahaArFA and AlbaAriHapa layolFA: (S, TA:) or the meaning is [simply] sayRarahu: (K, TA:) accord. to 'Alam-ed-Deen Es-Sakháwee, layolFA is added, although AlUisoraMC is not otherwise than by night, because the space over which he was transported is not to be traversed in less than forty days, but was traversed by him in one night; as though the meaning [intended] were, fiI layolK waAHidK; and it denotes wonder: layolFA is here used instead of layolapF because when they say saraI layolapF the meaning generally is he occupied the whole of the night in journeying: Er-Rághib holds the verb in this instance to be from saraApN signifying “ a wide tract of land, ” to belong to art. srw, and to be like Oajobala and Oatohama; the meaning being, who transported his servant over a wide tract of land: but this is strange. (TA.) ＝ -A2- saraI mataAEahu, (M, K,) aor. yasoriI, (M, TA,) inf. n. saroIN, (TA,) He threw his goods, or utensils and furniture, upon the back of his beast. (M, K.) ― -b2- And saraI EanRiI AlvRawoba, inf. n. saroIN, He removed from over me the garment: but w is more approved [as the final radical: see 1 in art, srw]. (M, TA.) You say, sarayotu AlvRawoba and sarRayotuhu↓ I pulled off the garment: and Eanohu surRiIa↓ It was removed from over him, and removed from its place: the teshdeed denotes intensiveness. (TA.)

2 srRI c
2. srRI, (K,) or srRI sariyRapF, (TA,) inf. n. tasoriyapN, He (the leader of an army, TA) detached a sariyRap [q. v.] (K, TA) to the enemy by night. (TA.) ― -b2- srRI AlEaraqa Eano badanihi, inf. n. as above, He exuded the sweat from his body. (TA.) ― -b3- See also 1, last sentence, in two places.

4 OasoraIa
4: see 1, in the former half of the paragraph, in two places: ― -b2- and again, in the latter half, in three places. ― -b3- See also 4 in art. srw.

5 tasarRaIa
5: see 1, first sentence.

8 UisotaraIa
8: see 1, first sentence.

surFI c
surFI, [said by some to be an inf. n., by some to be a simple subst., and by some to be pl. of suroyapN, or supposed to be so, and therefore made fem., as mentioned in the first sentence of this art.,] meaning A journeying, or travelling, by night, or in the night, in a general sense, is masc. and fem., (M, K,) by some of the Arabs made fem., (S,) and not known to Lh but as a fem. noun. (M.) It is said in a prov.,
Einoda AlSRabaAHi yaHomadu Alqawomu AlsRuraI
[At daybreak, the party commend night-journeying]: applied to the man who endures difficulty, or distress, or fatigue, hoping for rest, or ease: (Meyd:) and in inciting to labour for the accomplishment of an affair with patience, and to dispose and subject the mind, until one commends the result thereof. (Har p. 555, q. v.)

saraApN c
saraApN: see art. srw.

saroyapN c
saroyapN and suroyapN↓ are inf. ns. of saraI: (M, K:) or have a more special signification than the inf. n. of that verb, which is saroIN: one says, sarayonaA saroyapF mina AllRayoli and suroyapF↓ [We journeyed by night a journey of the night]: and the pl. of suroyapN↓ is [said to be] surFI: (Msb:) or one says,
sarayonaA saroyapF waAHidapF [We journeyed by night a single night-journey]: and the subst. [signifying a journeying, or travelling, by night, or in the night,] is suroyapN↓, and surFI. (S, TA.)

suroyapN c
suroyapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in four places.

siroyapN c
siroyapN meaning An arrow-head, (As, M, TA,) such as is small, short, round and smooth, having no breadth, (M, TA,) is a dial. var. of sirowapN [q. v.], (As, TA,) or formed from the latter word by the substitution of I for w because of the kesreh: (M, TA:) accord. to the K, sariyRapN↓ signifies a small round arrow-head; but this is a mistake; the correct word being siroyapN, with kesr, and without teshdeed to the I. (TA.) ＝ -A2- It is also a dial. var. of sirowapN signifying The locust in its first state, when it is a larva. (S in art. srw.)

saraMCN c
saraMCN A certain tree, (AHn, S, M, K,) from which bows are made, (AHn, S, M,) the wood whereof is of the best of woods, and which is of the trees of the mountains: (AHn, M:) ElGhanawee El-Aarábee says, the naboE and XawoHaT [q. v.] and saraMC are one: (TA in art. XHT:) [it is also mentioned in the TA in art. srO:] n. un. saraMCapN. (M, K.)

sariIRN c
sariIRN i. q. nahorN [A river, &c.]: (Th, M:) or a rivulet, or streamlet: (S, M, Msb:) or a rivulet running to palm-trees: (M, K:) pl. [of pauc.] OasoriyapN (S, M, K) and [of mult.] suroyaAnN: (Sb, S, M, Msb, K:) OasoriyaMCu as its pl. has not been heard. (S.) Thus it has been expl. as occurring in the Kur xix. 24. (M, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also art. srw.

sariyRapN c
sariyRapN A portion of an army: (S, Msb:) of the measure faEiylapN in the sense of the measure faAEilapN; because marching by night, privily; (Mgh, Msb;) thus originally, and afterwards applied also to such as march by day: (Ham p. 45:) or it may be from AlAisotiraMCu “ the act of choosing, or selecting; ” because a company chosen from the army: (Mgh: [but if so, belonging to art. srw:]) from five persons to three hundred: (M, K:) or four hundred: (K:) or, of horsemen, about four hundred: (M:) or the best thereof, (S,) or the utmost, (Nh,) consists of four hundred: (S, Nh:) or, accord. to the “ Fet-h el-Bári, ” from a hundred to five hundred: (TA:) or nine, and more than this; three, and four, and the like being termed TaliyEapN, not sariyRapN: but it is related of the Prophet that he sent a single person as a sariyRap: (Mgh:) the pl. is saraAyaA (S, Msb) and sariyRaAtN. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- See also siroyapN.

siraAyapN c
siraAyapN A journeying, or travelling, by night, or in the night: (S, Msb, TA:) an inf. n.; (TA as from the K; [see 1, first sentence;]) or a simple subst. (Msb, TA.)

sarayaAniIRN c
[sarayaAniIRN, from the inf. n. sarayaAnN, Pervasive: occurring in philosophical works, and probably post-classical.]

AlsRuroyaAniyRapu c
[AlsRuroyaAniyRapu The Syriac language.]

sarRaMCN c
sarRaMCN One who journeys much, or often, by night. (K.)

saArK c
saArK Journeying, or travelling, by night, or in the night, in a general sense: (M, TA: *) pl. suraApN. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, because of his going [about] by night, (TA,) AlsRaAriI signifies The lion; as also AlmusaAriI↓ and AlmusotariI↓. (K, TA.)

saAriyapN c
saAriyapN A party, or company of men, journeying by night. (Er-Rághib, TA.) ― -b2- And A cloud that comes by night: (S, Msb:) or clouds that travel by night: (K:) or a cloud that is between that which comes in the early morning and that which comes in the evening: [perhaps thus termed as having previously travelled in the night:] or, accord. to Lh, a rain that comes in the night: (M, TA:) pl. sawaAriI [app. a mistranscription for sawaArK, being indeterminate]. (K, TA.) ― -b3- One says, jaMCa SabiyHapa saAriyapK He came in the morning of a night in which was rain. (TA.) ― -b4- And the pl. AlsRaAriyaAtu signifies The asses: (M:) or the wild asses: (TA:) because they rest not by night: (M:) or because they pasture by night. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A column, syn. OusoTuwaAnapN, (S, M, Msb, K,) of stone, or of baked bricks; so in the “ Bári': ” (TA:) pl. sawaArK. (Mgh.) ― -b2- [And A mast: see HanRa and SarRa: and see also SaAriyapN.]

OasoraI c
OasoraI [More, and most, used to night-journeying]. OasoraI mino qunofucK [More used to go about by night than a hedge-hog] is a prov. of the Arabs. (TA.) [See also the same word in art. srw.]

masorFI c
masorFI may be a n. of place and a n. of time, [signifying A place, and a time, of night-journeying,] as well as an inf. n. (Ham p. 23.) It is [used also in a larger sense, as] syn. with macohabN [A place, and a time, of going &c.: a way by which one goes &c.]. (Har p. 540.)

AlmusaAriI c
AlmusaAriI: see saArK, above.

AlmusotaraI c
AlmusotaraI: see saArK, above.

AlmutasarRiI c
AlmutasarRiI He who goes forth in, or among, the [company termed] sariyRap. (IAth, TA.)

saAsabN c
saAsabN and sayosabN↓, (M, K,) i. q. sabosabN, with two b s, (L, TA,) the second of which is commonly pronounced siysb, and by some sysm, (TA,) A kind of tree, (M, K,) a kind of lofty tree, (TA,) of which arrows are made, (M, K, TA,) and bows. (TA.) In the saying of Rubeh,
raAHato waraAHa kaEiSiIRi AlsRayosaAbN↓
[She went, and he went, like the rods of the seysáb, (of which see another reading voce sabosabN, in art. sb,) meaning, like arrows], it may be that AlsysAb is a dial. var. of AlsRayosab, or it may be that the A is added for the sake of the rhyme like as it is in AlEaqoraAb in a verse cited in art. Eqrb. (M. [Accord. to the K and TA, AlsRayosaAb↓ is used by Ru-beh for AlsRayosabaAn: but this is evidently a mistake.])

sayosabN c
sayosabN: see the preceding paragraph: ― -b2- and see also sayosabaAnN.

sayosabaA c
sayosabaA, and sayosabaI, and sayosabFI, and sayosabaMCu: see the paragraph that next follows.

sayosabaAnN c
sayosabaAnN and sayosabaI↓, (K,) or the former and sayosabaMCu↓, which is mentioned by Th, (M,) A kind of tree; (M, K;) accord. to AHn, it grows from its seeds, and becomes tall, but does not endure the winter; it has leaves like those of the difolaI [q. v.], beautiful; people sow it in the gardens, desiring its beauty; and it has a produce like the oblong pericarps (xaraAYiT) of sesame, but thinner: (M, TA:) AHn adds that, when its pericarps dry, it makes a rustling sound (a sound such as is termed xaXoxaXap) [in the wind], like the [species of cassia called] EiXoriq: (TA:) [the sesbania Aegytiaca of Persoon; æschynomene sesban of Linn.; (Delile, Flor. Aegypt. Illustr., no. 682;) dolichos sesban of Forskål (in his Flora Aegypt. Arab, p. lxx., no. 362):] AHn further says, waHakaI AlfarRaMCu fiyhi sayosabFA: (M, TA:) [this may perhaps mean that Fr has mentioned, as a var. of this word, sayosabN↓, as it is in the accus. case: but I think that the right reading is sayosabFI↓, and also sayosabaI, (which last has been mentioned above on the authority of the K,) for it is immediately added in the TA, “ it is masc. and fem., ” app. indicating that it is with, and without, tenween: then it is there further and strangely added, “ it is brought from India: ”] a rájiz uses the form AlsRayosabaA↓, at the end of a verse, for AlsRayosabaAna, necessarily eliding [the n for the sake of the rhyme]. (M, TA.)

sayosaAbN c
sayosaAbN: see the first paragraph, in two places.

saAsamN c
saAsamN, without C, (AHát, TA,) A kind of tree, of which arrows are made: (AHát, M:) a kind of black tree: (S, K:) or a kind of tree (AHn, M, K) of the mountains, of the [sort termed] Eutuq, (AHn, M,) of which bows are made: (AHn, M, K:) or, (K,) as some assert, (AHn, M,) the [tree called] Mbinuws [i. e. ebony]: (AHn, M, K:) or, (K,) as others assert, (AHn, M,) the [tree called] Xiyz: (AHn, M, K: [in some copies of the K XiyzaI, which means the same:]) but neither of these two is suitable for bows. (AHn, M.)

OusoTubRapN c
OusoTubRapN [an arabicized word, app. from the Greek σύππη σύπη,] Tow; i. e. what falls from flax in the process of combing. (K. [See also art. STb.])

masoTabapN c
masoTabapN and misoTabapN are sings. of masaATibu, which signifies The [wide benches, of stone or brick &c., generally built against a wall, called] dakaAkiyn, upon which people sit: (AZ, K:) [and particularly such as surround the court of a mosque: for] one says, raOayotuhumo qaAEidiyna EalaI AlmasaATibi, mean-
ing [I saw them sitting upon] the dakaAkiyn around the court of the mosque. (A. [See also art. STb.]) ― -b2- The pl. also signifies Blacksmiths' anvils. (IAar, K. [See, again, art. STb.]) ― -b3- And Waters stopped up, or choked up, with earth or dust; or altered for the worse by long standing; syn. miyaAhN sudumN [q. v.]. (IAar, K.)

1 saTaHahu c
1. saTaHahu, (A, K,) aor.
saTaHa
, (K,) inf. n. saToHN, (Msb,) He spread it, spread it out or forth, or expanded it: (A, Msb, K:) this is the primary signification. (Msb.) You say, saTaHa QllRehu AlOaroDa, inf. n. as above, God spread, or expanded, the earth. (S.) And saTaHa AltRamora, aor. and inf. n. as above, He spread the dates [to dry]. (Msb.) And saTaHa AlvRariyda fiI AlSRaHofapi [He spread evenly the crumbled, or broken, bread in the bowl]. (A.) And saTaHa suTuwHahu He made even his suTuwH [or flat roofs]; as also saTRaHahaA↓, (K,) inf. n. tasoTiyHN. (TA.) And saTaHa Albayota, aor. and inf. n. as above; [He made a flat roof to the house, or chamber;] as also sTRHhu↓. (TA.) And Alqabora saTRaHotu↓, inf. n. as above, I made the top [or roof] of the grave [flat] like the saToH [of a house]: (Msb:) tasoTiyHu Alqabori is the contr. of tasoniymuhu. (S, A.) ― -b2- He threw him down (A, L, K) [so that he lay] extended on the back of his neck, (A,) or spread upon the ground. (L.) And He threw him down on his side. (K.) And saTaHa AlnRaAqapa He made the she-camel to lie down on her breast. (TA.) ― -b3- And He sent him with his mother; namely, a lamb or kid, or a new-born lamb or kid. (O, K.)

2 saTRaHa
2: see above, in three places.

5 tasaTRaHa
5: see what next follows.

7 AnsH c
7. AnsH It was, or became, spread, spread out or forth, or expanded; as also tsTRH↓. (TA.) ― -b2- Said of a man, He became extended [lying] on the back of his neck, (S, Msb,) affected by a disease of long continuance, or crippled, (Msb,) and moved not: (S, Msb:) or he became thrown down [so that he lay] extended on the back of his neck. (A.)

Q. Q. 3
Q. Q. 3: [accord to the S, but of an extr. form]. AisolanoTaHa It (a thing) was, or became, long and wide. (AA, S. [Mentioned in the S in this art., as though of the measure AifolanoEala: see also art. slTH.])

saToHN c
saToHN a word of well-known meaning; (S;) The upper, or uppermost, part [or surface] of a house or chamber &c.; (Msb;) [the flat top or roof of a house &c.;] the back (Zahor) of a house or chamber (K, TA) when it is flat, level, or even; because of its expansion: (TA:) and the upper, or uppermost, part [or surface] of anything: (K:) or it has this last meaning [primarily]: and hence the saToH of a house or chamber: (A:) pl. suTuwHN. (Msb, TA.) ― -b2- [In geometry, A plane; i. e.] the saToH is that which is divisible in length and breadth and is terminated by a line [or lines]. (KT.)

saTiyHN c
saTiyHN Spread, spread out or forth, or expanded; as also masoTuwHN↓. (TA.) ― -b2- Extended, (Msb,) or thrown down [so as to be lying] extended, (A,) or lying as though thrown down or extended, (S,) on the back of his neck, (S, A, Msb,) in consequence of disease of long continuance, or crippleness; (S, Msb;) and munosaTiHN↓ signifies the same: (A:) or spread [upon the ground], slow in rising, by reason of weakness, (L, K,) or And One born weak, unable to stand and to sit, so that he is always spread [upon the ground]. (TA.) And Slain, spread [upon the ground]; as also masoTuwHN↓. (K.) ― -b3- See also the next paragraph.

saTiyHapN c
saTiyHapN One of the vessels for water; (TA;) a [leathern water-bag of the kind called] mazaAdap, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K, TA,) made of two skins (Mgh, TA) placed opposite to each other; it is small, and large; but the mzAdp [properly so called] is larger than it; (TA;) and saTiyHN↓ signifies the same. (S, K, TA.)

suTRaAHN c
suTRaAHN A certain kind of plant, (As, AHn, S, O, K,) of the plants that grow in plain, or soft, ground: (AHn, O:) n. un. with p: (As, AHn, S, O:) accord. to Az, the suTRaAHap is a certain herb, or leguminous plant, upon which cattle pasture, and with the leaves of which the heads are washed: (TA:) or it is a certain plant growing in plain, or soft, tracts, and spreading upon the ground: or a certain tree, or shrub, that grows in the places where cattle recline around the waters, spreading, but scanty, and of no use. (L.) And Any kind of plant that spreads (AHn, O, K) upon the ground, and does not grow tall: such as run and extend, as the melon or water-melon (biTRiyx), and the cucumber (qivRaMC), and the colocynth, are all called XaroIN: and such especially as are eaten [by men], like the gourd, and the cucumber (qivRaMC and xiyaAr), and the melon or water-melon (biTRiyx), are called yaqoTiynN. (AHn, O.)

masoTaHN c
masoTaHN, (Msb,) or misoTaHN↓, (K,) or both, (S, O,) the former because it means a place, (O,) A place (S, R, O, Msb) that is even, or level, (R,) in which, (S, O, Msb,) or upon which, (R,) dates are spread (S, R, O, Msb) and dried; (S, R, O;) i. q. jariynN; (K;) of the dial. of El-Yemen: (TA:) [pl. masaATiHu.] ― -b2- raOayotu AlOaroDa masaATiHa means I saw the land [bare, or] destitute of pasturage; likened to buyuwt masoTuwHap [i. e. flat-topped houses]. (TA.)

misoTaHN c
misoTaHN A rolling-pin; i. e. the implement with which bread [or dough] is expanded. (O, K.) ― -b2- The pole, (S, A, Mgh, O, Msb,) or a pole, (K,) of a [tent such as is called] xibaMC, (S, A, O, Msb, K,) or of a [tent such as is called] fusoTaAT. (Mgh.) ― -b3- The transverse piece of wood upon the two props of the grape-vine, with the hoops [that are affixed upon it]. (K.) ISh says that when a grape-vine had a raised support made for its branches to lie thereon, recourse was had to props, for [the feet of] which holes were dug in the ground, each prop having two forking portions [at the head]; then a piece of wood (xaXabapN, so in the O, in the TA [erroneously] XEbp,) is taken, and laid across two props, and this transverse piece of wood is called the misoTaH, [pl. masaATiHu,] and upon the masaATiH are placed hoops, from the nearest part thereof to the furthest; (O, TA;) and the msATH with the hoops are called msATH. (O.) ― -b4- A smooth piece of rock or hard stone, surrounded with stones, in which water collects: (S, O, K:) or a wide slab of rock or hard stone, bordered round, for the rain-water [to collect therein]: and sometimes God creates, at the mouth of the well, a smooth, even, piece of rock or hard stone, [thus called,] which is surrounded with stones, and from which the camels are watered, like the HawoD. (T, TA.) [See also HawiyRapN.] ― -b5- Also i. q. masoTaHN, q. v. (S, O.) ― -b6- And A mat (S, O, K) woven (O) of xuwS (A, K) or TufoI (O) [i. e. leaves] of the dawom [or Theban palm]; (O, K;) as also misoTaAHN↓. (A.) ― -b7- A large roasting-pan (miqolFI) for wheat, (K, TA,) which is roasted therein. (TA.) ― -b8- And A mug (kuwz) that is used in travelling, having one janob [app. here meaning flat side]; (O, K, TA;) as also misoTaHapN↓: it is like the miToharap; not foursided. (TA.)

misoTaHapN c
misoTaHapN: see what next precedes.

musaTRaHN c
musaTRaHN [Plane, or flat; opposed to kuriIRN &c.]. ― -b2- A flat roof (saToHN) made even. (A, TA.) ― -b3- A nose spreading very widely. (S, K.)

misoTaAHN c
misoTaAHN: see misoTaHN, last sentence but two.

masoTuwHN c
masoTuwHN: see saTiyHN, in two places. ― -b2- bayotN masoTuwHN [A house, or chamber, having a flat roof made to it]. (TA.)

munosaTiHN c
munosaTiHN: see saTiyHN.

1 saTara c
1. saTara, (S, M, Msb, &c.,) aor.
saTura
, (S, M, Msb;) inf. n. saTorN; (S, M, Msb, K; *) and sTRr↓; (M;) and AstTr↓; (S, M, A, Msb, K;) He wrote (S, M, * A, Msb, K) a writing or book. (M, Msb.) ― -b2- [And saTara He ruled a book. (See misoTarapN.)] ― -b3- Also saTara, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (K, TA,) (tropical:) He cut another man with a sword. (K, * TA.) ― -b4- And saTarahu He prostrated him; threw him down prostrate. (S.)

2 sTRr c
2. sTRr: see 1. ― -b2- Also, inf. n. tasoTiyrN, He composed (M, K) lies, falsehoods, (TA,) or OasaATiyr, i. e. stories having no foundation, &c. (M.) ― -b3- Also, [not tsTRr as in Gol.,] He said what was false: and he pretended a false thing. (KL.) And sTRr EalayonaA He told us OasaATiyr, i. e. stories having no foundation; or no right tendency or tenour: (M, K:) or he told us stories resembling falsehoods: (Lth:) or he embellished stories to us with lies: (TA:) or he related to us wonderful
stories of the ancients. (A.) And sTRr fulaAnN fulaAnFA Such a one told falsehoods to such a one. (Msb.) ― -b4- And sTRrhu He made him to form wishes, or desires. (Sgh, TA.)

4 AsTr QsomiI c
4. AsTr QsomiI He passed over the line in which was my name. (Az, K.) ― -b2- And AsTr (tropical:) He committed a mistake, or an error, (Ibn-Buzurj, K, TA,) in his reading, or recitation. (K.)

8 UisotaTara
8: see 1, first sentence.

11 AsTArR c
11. AsTArR, aor. yasoTaArRu, [app. signifies It (beverage, or wine,) became what is termed muisoTaAr or musoTaArR, q. v.] (TA.)

Q. Q. 1 sayoTara EalayonaA c
Q. Q. 1. sayoTara EalayonaA, (S, M, A, K,) inf. n. sayoTarapN; (A;) and sawoTara; (K;) or suwTira; (so in a copy of the M; [but see what is said below respecting the pass. form of sayoTara;]) and tasayoTara↓; (A, K;) He had, or exercised, absolute authority over us: (M, A, K:) or he was set in absolute authority over us, to oversee us, and to pay frequent attention to our various states or conditions, and to write down our manner of action: (S:) or he acted as a watcher and guardian over us, (M, K, TA,) paying frequent attention to us: (TA:) also written with S in the place of s; but originally it is with s, from AlsRaToru: and every s immediately followed by T may be changed into S: (TA:) the pass. form of sayoTara is not used. (T.)

Q. Q. 2 tasayoTara c
Q. Q. 2. tasayoTara: see the next preceding paragraph.

saTorN c
saTorN, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) originally an inf. n., [see 1,] (S,) and saTarN↓, (S, M, Msb, K,) A line (S, M, K) of a book or writing: (M, A, K:) and a writing: (S, K:) and (tropical:) a line or row (S, M, A, Msb, K) of buildings, (S, A,) and of trees, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) &c., (Msb, K,) and [particularly] of palm-trees, and the like, (M,) [and so, app., musoTaArN↓, q. v.:] pl. (of the former, S, Msb) OasoTurN (S, M, A, Msb, K) and (of the latter, S) OasoTaArN (S, M, A, K) [both pls. of pauc.] and (of the former, S, Msb) suTuwrN, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) and OasaATiyru (Lh, S, M, K) is a pl. pl., (S, K,) i. e. pl. of OasoTaArN. (S.) You say, kataba saTorFA mino kitaAbapK [He wrote a line of writing]: (A:) and banaI saTorFA (tropical:) He built a row (S, A) mino binaAYihi [of his building]: (A:) and garasa saTorFA (tropical:) He planted a row (S, A) mino wadiyRihi [of his palm-shoots, or young palm-trees]. (A.) ― -b2- [Hence the saying,] AijoEali AlOamora saTorFA waAHidFA (assumed tropical:) Make thou the affair, or case, [uniform, or] one uniform thing. (Fr, TA in art. bOj.) ＝ -A2- Also the former, (saTorN,) A yearling (EatuwdN, T, M, K) of goats, (M,) or of sheep or goats: (T, K:) and SaTorN is a dial. var. thereof. (IDrd, M.)

saTarN c
saTarN: see the next preceding paragraph.

suTurN c
suTurN: see OusoTuwrapN.

suTorapN c
suTorapN (tropical:) An object of wish or desire. (K, TA.) You say, raAjaEotu fulaAnFA walamo yusaAEido suToratiI (tropical:) [I consulted such a one, and he did not aid in the accomplishment of the object of my wish or desire]. (TK.)

saTRaArN c
saTRaArN: see what next follows.

saATirN c
saATirN (tropical:) A butcher; (Fr, O, K, TA;) as also saTRaArN↓. (Fr, O, TA.)

saATuwrN c
saATuwrN A butcher's cleaver; (MA, O, K; *) i. e. the great knife with which the butcher cuts [the slaughtered beast: pl. sawaATiyru]. (O.)

OusoTuwrapN c
OusoTuwrapN [resembling the Greek ἱστορία] (S, M, A, Msb, K) and OusoTuwrN (M, Msb, K) and UisoTaArapN (S, M, Msb, K) and UisoTaArN and UisoTiyrapN and UisoTiyrN (M, K) sings. of OasaATiyru, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) which signifies Lies; or falsehoods; or fictions: (S, Msb, TA:) or stories having no foundation, or no right tendency or tenour: (laA niZaAma lahaA:) [such as we commonly term legends:] (M, K:) or wonderful stories of the ancients: (A:) or their written stories: (Bd in viii. 31:) or their written tales: (Jel in lxxxiii. 13:) or their written lies: (Bd in xxiii. 85, and Jel in xxvii. 70:) or stories embellished with lies; as also suTurN↓: (TA:) or, accord. to some, OasaATiyru is pl. of OasoTaArN which is pl. of saTorN: or, accord. to AO, AsATyr is pl. of OasoTurN which is pl. of saTorN: or, accord. to Abu-l-Hasan, AsATyr has no sing.: (M:) or the pl. of OasoTurN, accord. to AO, is OasaATiru, i. e., without I: or, as some say, AsATyr is an irreg. pl. of saTorN. (TA.)

misoTarapN c
misoTarapN An instrument with which a book is ruled (yusoTaru) [made of a piece of pasteboard with strings strained and glued across it, which is laid under the paper; the latter being ruled by being slightly pressed over each string]. (TA.)

musaTRarN c
musaTRarN Written. (S, M.)

musaTRirN c
musaTRirN: see musayoTirN.

musoTaArN c
musoTaArN: see saTorN. ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) Dust rising into the sky; (K, TA;) as being likened to a row of palm-trees or other things. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, (thus in some copies of the K, and so correctly written accord. to Sgh, with damm, TA,) or misoTaArN, (thus in the S, and in some copies of the K,) with kesr to the m, (S,) or with teshdeed, [musoTaArRN,] as written by Ks, and this also shows it to be with damm, being in this case from UisoTaArRa, aor. yasoTaArRu, (Sgh, TA,) A kind of wine in which is acidity; (S;) an acid kind of wine: (A'Obeyd, K:) or a kind of wine which prostrates its drinker: (K:) or new, or recently-made, wine, (K,) of which the taste and odour are altered: (TA:) or wine made of the earliest of grapes, recently: (T, TA:) or a wine in which is a taste between sweet and sour; also termed musoTaArapN↓: (Har p. 618:) Az says, it is of the dial. of the people of Syria; and I think that it is Greek, [or perhaps it is from the Latin “ mustarius, ” which is from “ mustum, ”] because it does not resemble an Arabic form: it is with S, or, as some say, with s; and [app. a mistake for “ or ”] I think it to be of the measure mufotaEalN from SaAra, with the t changed into T. (TA.)

musoTaArapN c
musoTaArapN: see the next preceding paragraph,

musayoTirN c
musayoTirN (S, M, A, Msb, K) and musaTRirN↓, (S, K,) as also muSayoTirN, (S, A,) One who has, or exercises, absolute authority (M, A, K) over others: (M:) one who is set in absolute authority over a thing [or people], to oversee it, and to pay frequent attention to its various states or conditions, and to write down its manner of action: from AlsRaToru: (S:) or a watcher and guardian; (M, K;) one who pays frequent attention to a thing. (Msb, * TA.)

siToranojN c
siToranojN [commonly pronounced saToranoj] a dial. var. of XiToranojN. (K in art. XTrnj, q. v.)

1 saTaEa c
1. saTaEa, aor.
saTaEa
, (S, Mgh, * Msb, K,) inf. n. suTuwEN (S, K) and saToEN (TA) and saTiyEN, which last is rare, (K,) It rose: (S, Mgh, Msb, K, TA:) or it spread, or diffused itself: (Mgh, TA:) said of duct, and of the dawn, (S, Msb, K,) [meaning as above, and it radiated, gleamed, or shone, (see saATiEN,)] and of light, (TA,) and of lightning, and of the rays of the sun, (K,) and (tropical:) of odour, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) in relation to which last it is tropical, and signifies it diffused itself, and rose: or it was originally said only of light; and was then used absolutely, as meaning it appeared, or became apparent. (TA.) You say also saTaEa AlsRahomu The arrow, being shot, rose into the sky, glistening. (TA.) And yasoTaEu, the aor. of saTaEa, is used by Dhu-r-Rummeh, in describing an ostrich, as meaning He raises his head, and stretches his neck. (TA.) And you say, saTaEa liI Oamoruka (assumed tropical:) Thine affair became, or has become, apparent, or manifest, to me. (Lh.) ― -b2- saTaEatoniI raAYiHapu Almisoki (tropical:) The odour of the musk rose to my nose. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- saTaEotu AlXRaIoCa I laid hold of the thing with the palm of the hand, or with the hand, striking [the thing]. (Msb.) And saTaEa biyadayohi, inf. n. saToEN, He clapped with his hands: whence the subst. saTaEN [q. v.]. (IDrd, K.) ＝ -A3- saTiEa, aor.
saTaEa
, (K,) inf. n. saTaEN, (TK,) He was long-necked; he had a long neck. (K.) [See OasoTaEu.]

2 sTREhu c
2. sTREhu, inf. n. tasoTiyEN, He marked him (namely a camel) with the mark called siTaAE. (K.)

AisoTaEotuhu c
AisoTaEotuhu (for AisotaTaEotuhu), aor. OasoTiyEuhu (for OasotaTiyEuhu); or OasoTaEotuhu (for OaTaEotuhu), aor. OusoTyEuhu (for OuTiyEuhu): see in art. TwE. (TA.)

saTaEN c
saTaEN Length of neck. (S.) It is said of Mo- hammad, fiI Eunuqihi saTaEN In his neck was length. (TA.) [See OasoTaEu.] ＝ -A2- A clapping with the hands, or striking with one hand upon the other,
or upon the hand of another: (K:) or a striking a thing with the palm of the hand, or with the fingers. (TA.) And The sound of a striking or throwing: as in the saying, samiEotu liwaqoEihi saTaEFA XadiydFA [I heard, in consequence of its falling, a loud sound of a striking or throwing]. (K.) It is with fet-h to the medial radical because it is an onomatopœia, not an epithet nor an inf. n., for onomatopœias are sometimes made to differ [in form] from epithets. (Lth, K.)

siTaAEN c
siTaAEN The pole of the [tent called] bayot: (S, K:) and the longest of the poles of the [tent called] xibaMC: (K:) from saATiEN applied to the dawn: (Az, TA:) and a pole that is set up in the middle of the xbAC and of the [tent called] riwaAq: pl. [of pauc.] OasoTiEapN and [of mult.] suTuEN. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, as being likened thereto, (tropical:) The neck. (TA.) ― -b3- Hence also, (Az, TA,) (tropical:) A tall, bulky, camel. (Az, Ibn-'Abbád, K, TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) A mark made with a hot iron upon the neck of a camel, (Az, S, K,) or upon his side, (TA,) lengthwise: (Az, S, K, TA:) in the R, it is said to be upon the limbs, or members. (TA.)

saTiyEN c
saTiyEN Tall, or long. (K.) ― -b2- See also saATiEN.

saATiEN c
saATiEN Rising: or spreading, or diffusing itself: [and radiating, gleaming, or shining:] applied [to dust, (see 1,) and] to the dawn, and to light, and to fire [&c.]: applied to the dawn, it denotes that extending lengthwise into the sky, and called canabu AlsRiroHaAni [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also The dawn [itself]; (TA;) and so saTiyEN↓; (S, TA;) because of its shining, and spreading; when it first breaks, extending lengthwise. (TA.) ― -b3- naAqapN saATiEapN A she-camel having the front of the neck, and the [whole] neck, extended. (TA.)

OasoTaEu c
OasoTaEu Long-necked; (K;) applied to a camel, and an ostrich: (TA:) fem. saToEaMCu; applied to a she-camel, (TA,) and a she-ostrich. (S.) ― -b2- EunuqN OasoTaEu A long, erect, neck: (TA:) and EunuqN siToEaMCu a neck that is long, and erect in its sinews. (AO, in describing horses; and TA.)

misoTaEN c
misoTaEN Chaste in speech; or eloquent; (Lh, K, TA;) fluent in speech. (TA.)

musaTRaEN c
musaTRaEN (assumed tropical:) A camel marked with the mark called siTaAE; (S, TA;) fem. with p. and masoTuwEapN↓ signifies the same, applied to a she-camel. (TA.) ― -b2- And UibilN musaTRaEapN (assumed tropical:) Camels tall as the tent-poles called suTuEN, pl. of siTaAEN. (TA.)

masoTuwEapN c
masoTuwEapN: see musaTRaEN.

1 saTalahu c
1. saTalahu, inf. n. saTolN, said of a medicine, It intoxicated him: but it is a vulgar word. (TA.) ― -b2- [And hence, (assumed tropical:) He, or it, charmed, or fascinated, or delighted, him.]

7 AinosiTaAlN c
7. AinosiTaAlN A state of intoxication produced by the HaXiyX [or herb, or perhaps species of hemp,] known by the name of zyh; as also AisotiTaAlN↓. (De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., 2nd ed., i. 282; from the book entitled ktAb AlkwAkb AlsAYrp fI AxbAr mSr wAlqAhrp.) [Both app. post-classical: see 1, of which each is quasi-pass.]

8 AisotiTaAlN c
8. AisotiTaAlN: see what next precedes.

Q. Q. 2 jaMCa yatasayoTalu c
Q. Q. 2. jaMCa yatasayoTalu He came alone, having nothing with him. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

saTolN c
saTolN A Tusayosap [or small vessel of the kind called TasR, or Tasot, q. v.], (M, K,) like the tawor [q. v.], (M,) having a loop-shaped handle, (M, K,) like that of the mirojal; (TA;) well known: (S, Msb:) a genuine Arabic word: (M:) or an arabicized word: [said by Golius to be in Pers. saTalN:] and SaTolN is a dial. var. thereof: (Msb:) a vessel of copper, a large [vessel of the kind called] TaAs [q. v.], for the hot bath; (MA;) the thing [i. e. vessel] in which water is drawn from the hot bath: (KL:) [in the present day applied to a kind of pail, of tinned copper, which the women take with them to the hot bath, containing the water that they require for washing after the other operations of the bath; and also used for various other purposes; as also saTolapN↓:] and sayoTalN↓ signifies the same: (S, M, K, KL:) or this last signifies, (K,) or signifies also, (M,) a [vessel of the kind called] Tasot; (M, K;) not the well-known [vessel called] saTol: (K:) the pl. [of mult.] of saTolN is suTuwlN (M, Msb, K) and [of pauc.] OasoTaAlN. (Msb.)

saTolapN c
saTolapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

saATilN c
saATilN Dust rising, or rising high; as also TaAsilN. (K.)

sayoTalN c
sayoTalN: see saTolN. ＝ -A2- Also A tall man: (K:) or sayoTalN nayoTalN a man tall, or long, in body. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.)

OusoTuwlN c
OusoTuwlN A ship of war, prepared for fighting with. the unbelievers on the sea: mentioned by El-Makreezee in the “ Khitat; ” and he says, “ I do not think this word to be [genuine] Arabic: ” (TA:) [it is evidently from the Greek στόλος:] several writers mention it among arabicized words. (MF, TA.)

2 sTRn c
2. sTRn a verb of which only the pass. part. n. (q. v. infrà) is mentioned: if used, app. signifying He supported upon OasaATiyn, i. e. columns: ― -b2- and hence, upon long legs: ― -b3- and he made firm.]

saATinN c
saATinN i. q. xabiyvN [Bad, corrupt, &c.; like XaATinN]. (M, L, K.)

OasoTaAnN c
OasoTaAnN [a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned] Vessels of Sufor [or brass]. (L, K.)

OusoTuwaAnN c
OusoTuwaAnN, an arabicized word, (Az, L,) [app. from the Pers. Ousotuwno, like the word next following,] A man long in the legs and back. (M, L.) And A camel long in the neck, (M, L, K,) or (K) high. (S, M, L, K.) ― -b2- What is termed OusotuwaAnu Albayoti is well known [app. meaning The pole of the tent: (see what next follows:) and this seems to be the primary signification]. (M, L.)

OusoTuwaAnapN c
OusoTuwaAnapN a word of well-known meaning, (S, L,) arabicized from [the Pers.] Ousotuwino [which signifies the same], (K,) i. q. saAriyapN [meaning A column, of stone or of baked bricks]: (S, M, L, Msb, K:) pl. OasaATiynu (S, M, * L, Msb, K *) and OusoTuwaAnaAtN: (Msb:) it is of the measure OufoEuwaAlapN, (S, L, Msb, K,) because its pl. is OasaATaynu, the n being radical, (L, Msb,) accord. to Kh (Msb) and Fr, who says that it is the only instance of this measure; (L;) or of the measure fuEoluwaAnapN, (S, L, K,) accord. to Akh, but, (J says, L,) if so, the w is augmentative and has next to it two augmentative letters, and this is scarcely ever, or never, the case; (S, L;) IB, however, says that this is the true measure, as is shown by its pl., OasaATiynu, and its dim., OusayoTiynapN↓: (L:) accord. to some, it is of the measure OufoEulaAnapN, (S, L, Msb,) but, if it were so, it would not have for its pl. OasaATiynu, as there is no instance of the measure OafaAEiynu. (S, L.) ― -b2- [Also A portico. Hence, Oaholu AlOusoTuwaAnapi The Stoics. ― -b3- And A cylinder.] ― -b4- And The legs of a beast: (K:) [or rather the pl.] OasaATiynu has this meaning. (L.) ― -b5- And The penis. (K.)

OusayoTiynapN c
OusayoTiynapN dim. of OusoTuwaAnapN, q. v. (IB, L.)

musaTRanN c
musaTRanN [app. Supported upon OasaATiyn, i. e. columns. ― -b2- And hence,] A man, and a beast, having long legs. (L.) ― -b3- And OasaATiynu musaTRanapN (S, M, L, K,) [Columns] made firm. (K.)

1 saTaA bihi c
1. saTaA bihi (S, M, Msb, K, &c.) and Ealayohi (M, Msb, K,) aor. yasoTuw, (Msb,) inf. n. saTowN (S, M, Msb, K) and saTowapN, (M, Msb, K,) or the latter is an inf. n. un., (S,) He sprang, or rushed, upon him; made an assault, or attack, upon him; syn. SaAla: (M, K:) he sprang upon him and seized him violently or laid violent hands upon him: (Bd in xxii. 71:) he seized him violently with uplifted hand: (Er-Rághib, TA:) he overbore him, overpowered him, or subdued him, (qaharahu, Lth, S, Msb, K, or taTaAwala Ealayohi, T, TA,) by seizing him violently, or laying violent hands upon him, (Lth, S, K,) and abased him; or he seized him with great violence: (Msb:) or he stretched forth his hand to him [to seize him]. (Th, M, TA.) And in like manner, (M,) one says of a stallion [camel], yasoTuw EalaI Taruwqatihi [He springs, or rushes, upon, or he overbears, the she-camel that he covers]. (S, M. *) ― -b2- saTaA EalaI AlnRaAqapi, (S, M, K,) and Alfarasi, inf. n. saTowN and suTuwRN, (M,) He (the pastor) put his hand into the raHim [or vulva] of the she-camel, (S, M, K,) and of the mare, (M,) to extract, (S, K,) or and extracted, (M,) the sperma of the stallion: (S, M, K:) when this is not extracted, the she-camel
does not conceive: (S:) or this is done when she has been leaped by a stallion of low race; or when the sperma is bad, and she has not conceived in consequence of it. (M.) And He extracted from her (i. e. a she-camel, TA) the fœtus, dead: (M, TA:) and masaTa signifies “ he extracted the sperma of the stallion: ” thus Az distinguishes between the two verbs. (TA.) Accord. to IAar, one says, saTaA EalaI AlHaAmili, and saATa, which is formed by transposition, meaning He extracted the fœtus, or young one, of the pregnant female. (TA.) And A'Obeyd mentions AlsRaTowu as used in relation to a woman: it is said in a trad. of El-Hasan, laA baOosa Oano yasoTuwa AlrRajulu EalaI AlmaroOapi [There is, or will be, no harm in the man's extracting the fœtus of the woman]; (M, TA;) which Lth explains by saying, when her child sticks fast in her belly, dead, it may be extracted [by him] when fear is entertained for her and a woman is not found to do this. (TA.) ― -b3- saTaA said of a horse, (M, K,) inf. n. saTowN, (M,) He went at random, heedlessly, or in a headlong manner, not obeying guidance. (M, K.) ― -b4- Also, said of a horse, He went with wide step: (S, M, K:) or raised his tail in running; the doing of which is approved. (M.) ― -b5- Also (tropical:) It was, or became, abundant, or copious; said of water. (S, M, Msb, K, TA.) ― -b6- And (tropical:) He tasted food; (K, TA;) and took it with the hand, or with the extended hand. (TA.) ― -b7- And i. q. EaAqaba [app. as meaning He punished: see saTowapN, below]. (M, TA.) ― -b8- And saTaAhaA He compressed her; [and so saTaOahaA and XaTaOahaA;] on the authority of Aboo-Sa'eed. (TA.)

3 sATAhu c
3. sATAhu, (K,) inf. n. musaATaApN, (TA,) He treated him with hardness, severity, or rigour: (K, TA:) so says Az, on the authority of IAar. (TA.) ― -b2- And He treated him with gentleness, or tenderness. (IAar, T, TA.) Thus it has two contr. significations. (TA.)

saTowapN c
saTowapN [as a simple subst., or] as an inf. n. un., has for its pl. saTawaAtN. (S.) It signifies [A spring, or rush; or an assault, or attack: &c.: (see 1, first sentence:) impetuosity in war or battle:] a reviling: a beating: and punishment, or chastisement; as in the saying, AitRaqi saTowatahu [Guard thyself against his punishment, or chastisement; or it may mean in this phrase, his violence, or impetuosity]. (TA.)

saATK c
saATK [act. part. n. of 1, Springing, or rushing; making an assault, or attack: &c. ― -b2- Hence,] applied to a horse, That springs, or rushes, upon other horses, and stands upon his hind legs and attacks with his fore legs: (T, TA: [in the Ham p. 383, and raises his fore legs:]) or a horse wide in step: (As, S, M, K:) or that attacks other horses: (S:) or that raises his tail in his running; (S, M, K;) the doing of which is approved. (M.) ― -b3- And A stallion-camel excited by lust, and going forth from camels to other camels (S, K) in consequence thereof. (S.) ― -b4- And What is tall, or long, (K, TA,) of camels &c. (TA.) ― -b5- AlOayodiI AlsRawaATiI The hands that reach, or take, or take hold of, a thing. (TA.)

5 tsERb c
5. tsERb It (a thing, TA, [such as saliva, and any thick liquid,]) roped; i. e. drew out, with a viscous, glutinous, cohesive, sticky, ropy, or slimy, continuity of parts; or was, or became, viscous, glutinous, cohesive, sticky, ropy, or slimy; syn. tamaTRaTa. (K.)

7 AnsEb c
7. AnsEb It (water [&c.]) flowed; (K;) [or flowed in a continuous stream;] like AnvEb (TA) [and AncEb].

saEobN c
saEobN Any kind of wine, or beverage, &c., that ropes; i. e. that draws out, with a viscous, glutinous, cohesive, sticky, ropy, or slimy, continuity of parts; or that is viscous, glutinous, &c. (K.)

suEobuwbN c
suEobuwbN and suEobuwbapN: see the next paragraph.

saEaAbiybu c
saEaAbiybu What extend like threads, or strings, from honey (A, * K) and marsh-mallows, (K,) and the like: (A, K:) pl. of suEobuwbN↓. (TA.) You say, saAla famuhu saEaAbiyba His slaver extended, or stretched out, like threads, or strings. (A, K.) And fuwhu yajoriI saEaAbiyba His mouth runs with clear water, having an extended [or a ropy] flow; like yjrI vaEaAbiyba. (S.) ― -b2- And What follow the hand in milking, [stretching out] like phlegm: pl. of suEobuwbapN↓. (ISh, TA.)

huwa musaERabN lahu kacaA wakacaA c
huwa musaERabN lahu kacaA wakacaA To him are allowed, or permitted, such and such things: (K:) like musagRabN and muragRabN. (TA.)

saEotarN c
saEotarN A certain plant, (S, Msb, K,) of the kind called buquwl, (Mgh,) well known; (Msb, K;) and applied also to the grain, or seed, thereof: (Mgh:) [a species of origanum, or majoram: so in the present day; and so says Golius, as on the authority of Ibn-Beytár, “ origani species, sc. consonante voce, satureia, Hisp. axedrea: ” accord. to Forskål, (Flora Aeg. Arab. p. cxiv.,) “ thymus serpyllum: ”] some write the word in books of medicine with S, in order that [when written without the diacritical points] it may not be confounded with XaEiyrN: (S, Mgh:) in the T, it is with S, on the authority of AA, only; and thus in the book of Lth: in the Jámi' of ElGhooree, with s and S: (Mgh:) or the s is changed into S in the dial. of Bel'ambar [or Benu-l-'Ambar]; and some pronounced it only with S: (Msb:) accord. to Abu-l-'Alà, the vulgar pronounce it with s, and the approved word is with S. (Ham p. 462.) [In the present day, it is also written with z.]

saEotariIRN c
saEotariIRN i. q. XaATirN [q. v.], (K,) in the dial. of the people of El-'Irák. (TA.) ― -b2- And Generous, noble, or high-born, and courageous, brave, or strong-hearted. (K.) The pronunciation with S is of higher authority. (K. [This remark is probably there meant to relate to both of the words of this art.])

1 saEida c
1. saEida, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
saEada
; (Msb, K;) and suEida; (S, A, Msb, K;) inf. n. of the former, (Msb,) or of the latter, (MA,) or of both, (TA,) saEodN, (MA, Msb, TA,) and of the former, (MA,) or of both, (TA,) saEaAdapN, (MA, TA,) or this latter is a simple subst.; (Msb;) He (a man, S, A, Msb) was, or became, prosperous, fortunate, happy, or in a state of felicity; (S, MA, Msb, TA;) contr. of XaqiIa; (S, * Msb, K *) with respect to religion and with respect to worldly things. (Msb.) You say, saEidotu bihi and suEidotu [I was, or became, prosperous, &c., by means of him, or it]. (A.) In the Kur xi. 110, Ks read suEiduwA [instead of the common reading saEiduwA]. (S.) [See also saEaAdapN, below.] ― -b2- And saEada yawomunaA, aor.
saEada
, inf. n. suEuwdN (S, K) and saEodN, (K,) Our day was, or became, prosperous, fortunate, auspicious, or lucky; (S, K;) [contr. of naHisa; and in like manner the verb is used in relation to a star or an asterism &c.; and] suEida, inf. n. saEodN, signifies [likewise] the contr. of nuHisa. (Mgh.) [See also suEuwdapN, below.] ― -b3- saEada AlmaMCu fiIAlOaroDi means The water came upon the land unsought; i. e., came flowing [naturally] upon the surface of the land, not requiring a machine to raise it for the purpose of irrigation. (TA, from a trad.) ＝ -A2- See also 4, in three places.

3 sAEdhu c
3. sAEdhu, (A, L, Msb,) inf. n. musaAEadapN (S, L, Msb) and siEaAdN; (L;) and AsEdhu↓, (K,) inf. n. UisoEaAdN; (S;) He aided, assisted, or helped, him; syn. of the former EaAwanahu, (S, * L, Msb,) and of the latter OaEaAnahu: (S, * K:) [like as is said of EaAwanahu and OaEaAnahu,] both signify the same: or musaAEadapN signifies the aiding, or assisting, or helping, in any manner or case; and is said to be from a man's putting his arm, or hand, upon the saAEid [or fore arm] of his companion when they walk together to accomplish some object of want, and aid each other to do a thing: [so that saAEadahu more properly signifies he aided him, being aided by him: but see saAEidN:] whereas UisoEaAdN↓ signifies specially a woman's aiding, assisting, or helping, another to wail for a dead person: so says El-Khattábee: and this is what is meant in a trad. in which AsEAd is forbidden. (L.) One says, sAEdhu Ealayohi [He aided, assisted, or helped him against him, or it, or to do it]: and AlnRaAYiHapu AlvRakolaI OasoEadati↓ The wailing-woman assisted the woman bereft of her child to weep and wail. (A.) Accord. to Fr, [but this is questionable,] the primary signification of musaAEadapN and UisoEaAdN↓ is A man's performing diligently the command and good pleasure of God. (L.)

4 AsEdhu QllRehu c
4. AsEdhu QllRehu, [inf. n. UisoEaAdN,] God rendered him prosperous, fortunate, happy, or in a state of felicity; (S, Msb, K;) as also saEadahu↓, aor.
saEada
; (T, Msb, TA;) but the former is the more common. (Msb.) And AsEd QllRehu jadRahu, (A, L,) God made his good fortune to increase; as also saEada↓ jadRahu. (L.) And accord. to Az, AsEdhu QllRehu and saEadahu↓ signify God aided, assisted, or helped, him; and accommodated, adapted, or disposed, him to the right course. (L, TA.) See also 3, in four places.

5 tsERd c
5. tsERd He sought after the plant called saEodaAn. (K.)

10 AstsEd bihi c
10. AstsEd bihi He deemed it, or reckoned it, fortunate, auspicious, or lucky. (K.) You say, AstsEd biruWoyapi fulaAnK He deemed, or reckoned, the sight of such a one fortunate, auspicious, or lucky. (S.) ― -b2- He became fortunate by means of him, or it. (MA.) ― -b3- He sought good fortune by means of him, or it. (MA.) ― -b4- [And AstsEdhu He desired, or demanded, his aid or assistance: for] AisotisoEaAdN also signifies the desiring, or demanding, aid or assistance [of another]. (KL.)

saEodN c
saEodN an inf. n. of saEida, (Msb,) or of suEida, (MA,) or of both: (TA:) and of saEada: (K, TA:) [and also used as a simple subst.:] see saEaAdapN [with which it is syn.]: and see also suEuwdapN [with which it is likewise syn.]; i. q. yumonN. (S, A.) ― -b2- It is also an inf. n. used as an epithet, i. e. Prosperous, fortunate, auspicious, or lucky, applied to a day, and to a star or an asterism [&c.: so that it may be used alike as masc. and fem. and sing. and pl.: but it is also used as originally an epithet, forming its fem. with p; and in this case it has for pl. of mult. suEuwdN and pl. of pauc. OasoEudN]: you say yawomN saEodN, as well as yawomu saEodK [in which it is used as a subst.]; and kawokabN saEodN: and IJ mentions layolapN saEodapN, in which saEodapN is like jaEodapN as fem. of jaEodN. (L.) ― -b3- [Hence,] AlsRaEodaAni is an appellation of The two planets Venus and Mercury: like as [the contr.] AlnRaHosaAni is applied to Saturn and Mars. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA in art. nHs.) ― -b4- And [hence, also,] saEodN is an appellation given to Each of ten asterisms, (S, L, K,) four of which are in the signs of Capricornus and Aquarius, (S, L,) and are Mansions of the Moon: pl. [of mult.] suEuwdN (S, L, K) and suEudN; but the former is the more known, and more agreeable with analogy; and pl. of pauc. OasoEudN: (L:) they are distinguished by the following names: — saEodu AlcRaAbiHi, (S, L, K,) [or saEodN AlcRaAbiHu, see art. cbH,] Two stars near together, one of which is called AlcAbH because with it is a small obscure star, almost close to it, and it seems as though the former were about to slaughter it; and AlcAbH is a little brighter that it; (Ibn-Kunáseh;) they are the two stars [ α and β ] which are in one of the horns of Capricornus; so called because of the small adjacent star, which is said to be the sheep (XAp) of AlcAbH, which he is about to slaughter; the Twenty-second Mansion of the Moon: (Kzw:) [see also art. cbH:] ― -b5- saEodu bulaEa (S, L, K) Two obscure stars, lying obliquely, of which Aboo-Yahyà says, the Arabs assert that they rose [at dawn] when God said, yaA OaroDu QbolaEiI maMCaki [Kur xi. 46]; and said to be thus called because one of them seems as though about to swallow the other, on account of its nearness to it: (Ibn-Kunáseh:) or three stars [app. ε and μ with the star of the same magnitude next to them on the north] on [or rather near] the left hand of Aquarius; [the Twenty-third Mansion of the Moon:] (Kzw, descr. of Aquarius:) [See also art. blE:] ― -b6- saEodu AlsRuEuwdi (S, L, K) Two stars, the most approved of the suEuwd, and therefore thus named, resembling sEd AlcAbH [app. a mistake for saEodu AlbaAriEi, or some other sEd, not of the Mansions of the Moon,] in the time of their [auroral] rising; (Ibn-Kunáseh;) the star [ β] which is on the left shoulder-joint of Aquarius, together with the star [ δ] in the tail of Capricornus; [the Twentyfourth Mansion of the Moon:] (Kzw, descr. of Aquarius:) or a certain solitary bright star: (S:) ― -b7- saEodu AlOaxobiyapi (S, L, K) [also called AlOaxobiyapu and AlxibaMCu (see xibaMCN in art. xbI)] Three stars, not in the track of the other suEuwd, but declining from it [a little], in, or respecting, which there is a discordance; they are neither very obscure nor very bright; and are thus called because, when they rise [aurorally], the venomous or noxious reptiles of the earth, such as scorpions and serpents, come forth from their holes; (Ibn-Kuná- seh;) [and this observation is just; for this asterism, about the commencement of the era of the Flight, rose aurorally, in Central Arabia, on the 24th of February, O. S., after the end of the cold season: see manaAzilu Alqamari, in art. nzl:] or it consists of three stars, like the three stones upon which the cooking-pot is placed, with a fourth below one of them; (S;) the star [ γ] that is on the right arm, together with the three stars [ ζ, η, and π,] on the right hand of Aquarius: so called because, when it rises [aurorally], the venomous or noxious reptiles that have hidden themselves beneath the ground by reason of the cold appear: (Kzw, descr. of Aquarius; [in some copies, incorrectly, for “ that have hidden themselves, ” &c., “ hide themselves beneath the ground by reason of the cold: ”]) it is said that the sEd is one star, the brightest of four, the other three of which are obscure; and it is [correctly] said to be called thus because, when it rises [aurorally], the venomous or noxious reptiles that are hidden beneath the ground come forth: it is the Twenty-fifth Mansion of the Moon: (Kzw, descr. of the Mansions of the Moon:) ― -b8- the following are the other sEwd, which are not Mansions of the Moon: (S, L, K:) ― -b9- saEodu naAXirapa (S, L, K) [Two stars, situate, accord. to Ideler, as is said in Freytag's Lex., in the tail of Capricornus]: ― -b10- saEodu Almaliki (S, L, K) The two stars [a and o?] on the right shoulder of Aquarius: (Kzw:) ― -b11- saEodu AlbihaAmi (S, L, K) The two stars [ ε and θ?] on the head of Pegasus: (Kzw: [but ii. the copies of his work the name is written saEodu AlbahaAYimi:]) ― -b12- saEodu AlhumaAmi (S, L, K) The two stars [ ζ and 31?] on the neck of Pegasus: (Kzw:) saEodu AlbaAriEi (S, L, K) The two stars near together [ μ and and λ?] in the breast of Pegasus: (Kzw:) ― -b13- saEodu maTarK (S, L, K) The two stars [ η and ο?] on the right [or left?] knee of Pegasus: (Kzw: but there called saEodu AlmaTari:) ― -b14- each sEd of these six consists of two stars: between every two stars, as viewed by the eye, is [said to be] a distance of a cubit, (ciraAE,) (S, L,) or about a cubit; (K;) [but this is not correct;] and they are disposed in regular order. (S, L.) ― -b15- It is also the name of A certain object of idolatrous worship that belonged to the sons of Milkán (S, K) the son of Kináneh, (S,) in a place on the shore of the sea, adjacent to Juddeh. (TA.) A poet says,
wahalo saEodu UilRaA SaxorapN bitanuwfapK
mina AlOaroDi laA tadoEuw ligaIRK walaA ruXodi
[And is Saad aught but a mass of rock in a desert tract of the earth, not inviting to error nor to a right course?]. (S, TA.) Hudheyl is said to have worshipped it in the Time of Ignorance. (TA.) ― -b16- binotu saEodK is metonymically used as meaning (tropical:) The virginity, or hymen, of a girl or woman. (TA.) ― -b17- OasaEodN Oamo suEayodN↓, meaning (tropical:) Is it a thing liked or a thing disliked? (S, A, K,) is a prov., (S, A,) which [is said to have] originated from the fact that Saad and So'eyd, [the latter name erroneously written in some copies of the S and K saEiyd,] the two sons of Dabbeh the son of Udd, went forth (S, K, TA) to seek some camels belonging to them, (TA,) and Saad returned, but So'eyd was lost, and his name became regarded as unlucky: (S, K, TA:) Dabbeh used to say this when he saw a dark object in the night: and hence it is said in allusion to care for one's relation; and in inquiring whether a good or an evil event have happened. (TA.) [The saying may also be rendered, Is it a fortunate thing or a little fortunate thing?] ― -b18- saEodayoka, in the saying labRayoka wasaEodayoka, signifies Aiding Thee after aiding [i. e. time after time]; syn. UisoEaAdFA laka baEoda UisoEaAdK: (ISk, T, S, L, K:) or aiding Thee and then aiding: (Ahmad Ibn-Yahyà, L:) or aiding thy cause after aiding [i. e. time after time]: (T, L:) and hence it is in the dual number: (IAth, L:) El-Jarmee says that it has no sing.; and Fr says the same of it, and also of labRayoka: it is in the accus. case as an inf. n. governed by a verb understood. (L.) It occurs in the form of words preceding the recitation of the Opening Chapter of the Kur-án in prayer, labRayoka wasaEodayoka waAlxayoru bayona yadayoka waAlsRarRu layosa Uilayoka [meaning I wait intent upon thy service, or upon obedience to Thee, time after time, and upon aiding thy cause time after time; and good is before Thee, and evil is not imputable to Thee]. (L, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also The third part of the labinap [or gore] (K, TA) of a shirt: (TA:) [the dim.] suEayodN↓ signifies the fourth part thereof. (K, TA.)

suEodN c
suEodN and suEaAdaI↓ A certain kind of perfume, (S, K,) well known: (K:) or the former is pl. of suEodapN↓, [or rather a coll. gen. n. of which suEodapN is the n. un.,] and this last is [the name of] a certain kind of sweet-smelling root; it is a rhizoma (Oaruwmap), round, black, hard, like a knot; which forms an ingredient in perfumes and medicines: (AHn:) and suEaAdaI↓ is the name of its plant; (Lth, AHn;) and its pl. is suEaAdayaAtN: (AHn:) or the suEod is a certain plant having a root (OaSol) beneath the ground, black, and of sweet odour: and the suEaAdaI↓ is another plant: (Az:) [in the present day, the former of these two names (suEod) is applied to a species of cyperus: a species thereof is termed by Forskål (in his Flora Aegypt. Arab, pp. lx. and 14,) cyperus
complanatus; and he writes its Arabic name “ sæad ” and “ sææd: ”] it has a wonderful efficacy applied to ulcers, or sores, that heal with difficulty. (K.)

suEudN c
suEudN A certain sort of dates. (K, TA.)

suEodapN c
suEodapN: see suEodN [of which it is the n. un.].

duruwEN saEodiyRapN c
duruwEN saEodiyRapN Coats of mail of the fabric of a town called AlsRaEodu. (TA.)

saEodaAnN c
saEodaAnN, in which the n is an augmentative letter, because there is not in the language any word of the measure faEolaAlN except xazoEaAlN and qahoqaArN unless it is of the reduplicative class, (S,) A certain plant, (S, K,) growing in the plain, or soft, tracts, (TA,) one of the best kinds of the pastures of camels, (S, K,) as long as it continues fresh; (TA;) having [a head of] prickles, (T, S, K,) called Hasakapu AlsRaEodaAni, (T, S,) to which the nipple [or the areola] of a woman's breast is likened: (S, K: [see saEodaAnapN, below:]) the Arabs say that the camels that yield the sweetest milk are those that eat this plant: (TA:) and they fatten upon it: (Az, TA:) it is of the kind of plants called OaHoraAr [pl. of HurRN, meaning slender, and succulent or soft or sweet], dust-coloured, and sweet, and eaten by everything that is not large, [as well as by camels,] and it is one of the most wholesome kinds of pasture: (AHn, TA:) it is a herb, or leguminous plant, having a round fruit with a prickly face, which, when it dries, falls upon the ground on its back, and when a person walking treads upon it, the prickles wound his foot: it is one of the best of their pastures in the days of the ribyE, and sweetens the milk of the camels that feed upon it; for it is sweet as long as it continues fresh; and in this state men such it and eat it: (Az, L:) the n. un. is with p. (TA.) Hence the prov., maroEFI walaA kaAlsRaEodaAni [Pasture, but not like the sEdAn]: (S, K:) said of a thing possessing excellence, but surpassed in excellence by another thing; or of a thing that excels other things of the like kind. (TA.) ― -b2- Also The prickles of the palm-tree. (AHn, TA.)

suEodaAna c
