suEodaAna, like suboHaAna, is a name for AlUisoEaAd [inf. n. of 4, and, like sbHAn, invariable, being put in the accus. case in the manner of an inf. n.]: one says, suboHaAnahu wasuEodaAnahu, meaning OusabRiHuhu waOuTiyEuhu [i. e. I declare, or celebrate, or extol, his (i. e. God's) remoteness, or freedom, from every imperfection, or impurity, &c., (see art. sbH,) and I render Him obedience, or aid his cause]. (K, TA.)

saEodaAnapN c
saEodaAnapN n. un. of saEodaAnN. (TA.) ― -b2- saEodaAnapu AlvRanoduwapi The nipple of a woman's breast; as being likened to the [head of] prickles of the plant called saEodaAn, as mentioned above: (S, K:) or saEodaAnapu AlvRadoIi, i. e. the blackness [or areola] around the nipple: (A:) or the part surrounding the vadoI [here meaning nipple], like the whirl of a spindle. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence likewise,] saEodaAnapN signifies also The knot of the XisoE [or appertenance that passes between two of the toes and through the sole] of the sandal, (S, A, K,) beneath, (A, K,) next the ground; (S;) also called rugobaAnapN. (K in art. rgb.) ― -b4- And The knot beneath the scale of a balance: (K, * TA:) the knots beneath the scale of a balance (S, A) are called its saEodaAnaAt. (A.) ― -b5- And the pl., saEodaAnaAtN, Things in the lower parts of the [tendons, or sinews, called] EujaAyap, resembling nails (OaZofaAr). (S, K.) ― -b6- Also the sing., The callous protuberance upon the breast of the camel, (S, A, K,) upon which he rests when he lies down: (A, TA:) so called because of its roundness. (TA.) ― -b7- And The anus: (K:) or the sphincter thereof. (TA.) ― -b8- And The part of the vulva of a mare where the veretrum enters. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A pigeon: or AlsRaEodaAnapu is the name of a certain pigeon. (K, *, TA.)

saEiydN c
saEiydN, applied to a man, (S, Msb,) Prosperous, fortunate, happy, or in a state of felicity; (T, S, A, Msb, K;) with respect to religion and with respect to worldly things; (Msb;) as also masoEuwdN↓: (A, * K:) or the latter signifies, (T, S, Msb,) or signifies also, (K,) and so may the former signify, (T, TA,) rendered prosperous, fortunate, happy, or in a state of felicity, by God; (T, S, Msb, K;) irregularly derived from OasoEadahu, (S, * K * MF,) or regularly from saEadahu: (T, Msb:) one should not say musoEadN: (S, K:) fem. of the former [and latter] with p: (TA:) pl. of the former suEadaMCu, (A, Msb, TA,) and, accord. to Lh, saEiyduwna and OasaAEidu; but ISd says, I know not whether he mean [of] the [proper] name or of the epithet; but OasaAEidu as pl. of saEiydN is anomalous: (TA:) the pl. of masoEuwdN↓ is [masoEuwduwna and] masaAEiydu. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A nahor [i. e. river, or rivulet, or canal of running water,] (K, TA) that irrigates the land in the parts adjacent to it, when it is appropriated thereto: or a small nahor: the nahor for irrigation of a tract of seed-produce: pl. suEudN. (TA.)

suEayodN c
suEayodN: see saEodN, [of which it is the dim.,] in the last quarter of the paragraph, in two places.

saEaAdapN c
saEaAdapN an inf. n. of saEida (MA, TA) and of suEida, (TA,) or a simple subst., (Msb,) Prosperity, good fortune, happiness, or felicity, of a man; (S, Msb, K;) contr. of XaqaAwapN; (S, Msb, * K;) with respect to religion and with respect to worldly things: (Msb:) [and so saEodN↓ used as a simple subst.:] it is of two kinds; OuxoraAwiyRapN [relation to the world to come] and dunoyaAwiyRapN [relating to the present world]: and the latter is of three kinds; nafosiyRapN [relating to the soul] and badaniyRapN [relating to the body] and xaArijiyRapN [relating to external circumstances]. (Er-Rághib, TA in art. Xqw.) [See also what next follows.]

suEuwdapN c
suEuwdapN Prosperousness, fortunateness, auspiciousness, or luckiness, (S, L,) of a day, and of a star or an asterism [&c.]; (L;) [as also saEodN↓ used as a simple subst.;] contr. of nuHuwsapN. (S, L.)

AlsRaEiydapu c
AlsRaEiydapu A temple to which the Arabs (K, TA) of the tribe of Rabeea (TA) used to perform pilgrimage, (K, TA,) at [Mount] Ohod, in the Time of Ignorance. (TA.)

suEaAdaI c
suEaAdaI: see suEodN, in three places.

saEiydiyRapN c
saEiydiyRapN A sort of garments of the kind called buruwd, of the fabric of El-Yemen: (S, K:) app. so called in relation to the mountains of BenooSa'eed. (TA.) ― -b2- And HulRapN saEiydiyRapN [A certain kind of dress]: so called in relation to Sa'eed Ibn-El-'Ás, whom, when a boy, or young man, the Prophet clad with a HulRap, the kind of which was thence thus named. (Har. p. 596.)

saAEidN c
saAEidN The fore arm (ciraAE) of a man; (K;) the part of the arm from the wrist to the elbow; (T, L;) or from elbow to the hand: (Mgh, Msb:) so called because it aids the hand in seizing a thing (T, Msb) or taking it (T) and in work: (Msb:) or it signifies, (S,) or signifies also, (Msb,) the upper arm, or upper half of the arm, from the elbow to the shoulder-blade, syn. EaDudN, [q. v.,] (S, Msb,) of a man: (S:) [and in like manner, of a beast, both the fore shank and the arm:] in some one or more of the dialects, the upper of the zanodaAni [which may mean either the upper arm or the radius]; the ciraAE being the lower of them [which may mean either the “ fore arm ” or the “ ulna ”]: (L, TA:) of the masc. gender: (Msb:) pl. sawaAEidu. (T, Mgh, Msb, TA.) One says, XadRa QllRehu EalaI saAEidika and sawaAEidikumo [May God strengthen thy fore arm and aid thee, and your fore arms and aid you]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- And hence, [A kind of armlet;] a thing that is worn upon the fore arm, of iron or brass or gold. (Mgh.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] saAEidaA AlTRaAYiri (assumed tropical:) The two wings of the bird. (S, K.) ― -b4- And AlsRawaAEidu (tropical:) The anterior, or primary, feathers of the wing: so in the phrase, TaAYirN Xadiydu AlsRawaAEidi (tropical:) [A bird strong in the anterior, or primary, feathers of the wing]. (A, TA.) ― -b5- Also the sing., (assumed tropical:) A chief, upon whom people rely. (TA.) ― -b6- And the pl., sawaAEidu, (tropical:) The channels in which water runs to a river or small river (nahor), (S, A, K,) or to a sea or large river (baHor); (AA, S, K;) the sing. said by AA to be saAEidN, without p: or this latter signifies a channel in which water runs to a valley, and to a sea or large river (baHor): or the channel in which a large river (baHor) runs to small rivers (OanohaAr). (L.) And (tropical:) The places from which issues the water of a well: the channels of the springs thereof. (L.) ― -b7- Also (assumed tropical:) The medullary cavities; the ducts through which runs the marrow in a bone. (S, K.) ― -b8- And (tropical:) The ducts (AA, A, TA) in the udder (A, TA) from which the milk comes (AA, A, TA) to the orifice of the teat; as being likened to the swAEd of the baHor: (AA, TA:) the qaSab of the udder: (As, TA:) or saAEidN signifies the orifice of a she-camel's teat, from which the milk issues: and saAEidu AldRarRi, a duct by which the milk descends to the she-camel's udder: and in like manner saAEidN signifies a duct that conveys the milk to a woman's breast or nipple. (TA.) ― -b9- OamorN cuw sawaAEida means (tropical:) An affair having several modes, or manners, [in which it may be per-
formed,] and several ways of egress therefrom. (A, TA.)

saAEidapN c
saAEidapN The bone of the shank. (TA.) ― -b2- And A piece of wood, (K, TA,) set up, (TA,) that holds the pulley. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- saAEidapu is a name of The lion: (S, K:) imperfectly decl., like OusaAmapu. (TA.)

OasoEadu c
OasoEadu [More, and most, prosperous or fortunate or happy; an epithet applied to a man:] masc. of suEodaI: (S, K:) but IJ says that suEodaI as an epithet has not been heard. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A [cracking of the skin, such as is termed] XuqaAq, resembling mange, or scab, that happens to a camel, and in consequence of which he becomes decrepit, (K, TA,) and weak. (TA.)

masoEuwdN c
masoEuwdN: see saEiydN, in two places.

1 saEara AlnRaAra c
1. saEara AlnRaAra, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
saEara
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. saEorN; (Msb;) and AsErhA↓, (A, Msb, K,) inf. n. UisoEaArN; (Msb;) and sERrhA↓, (A, K,) inf. n. tasoEiyrN; (TA;) or the last has an intensive signification; (S;) He lighted, or kindled, the fire; or made it to burn, to burn up, to burn brightly or fiercely, to blaze, or to flame; syn. OawoqadahaA, (Msb, K,) or hayRajahaA and OalohabahaA. (S, A.) In the Kur lxxxi. 12, some read suEirato; and others, suERirato↓, which latter has an intensive signification. (S.) And saEara AlnRaAra He stirred the fire with a misoEar. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] saEara AlHaroba, (S, K,) aor. as above, (K,) and so the inf. n.; (TA;) and AsErhA↓, and sERrhA↓; (K;) (tropical:) He kindled war; (K, TA;) excited, or provoked, it. (S, TA.) And saEaruwA naAra AlHarobi (tropical:) [They kindled, or excited, the fire of war]. (A.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] saEarahumo XarRN (tropical:) [Evil, or mischief, excited them, or inflamed them]. (A.) And saEara EalaI qawomihi (tropical:) [He excited, or inflamed, against his people]. (A.) ― -b4- And saEarahumo XarRFA (tropical:) He did extensive evil, or mischief, to them: (ISk, S, TA: *) or he did evil, or mischief, to them generally, or in common; as also AsErhm↓, and sERrhm↓; (TA;) or one should not say AsErhm↓. (ISk, S, TA.) ― -b5- And saEaronaAhumo biAlnRaboli (assumed tropical:) We burned and pained them [or inflicted upon them burning pain] with arrows. (S.) ― -b6- And saEara AlUibila, aor. as above, (K,) and so the inf. n., (TA,) (tropical:) He (a camel, TK) communicated to the [other] camels his mange, or scab. (K, TA.) ― -b7- And suEira, (S, A,) inf. n. suEaArN, (TA,) (tropical:) He (a man) was smitten by the [hot wind called] samuwm. (S, A.) And (tropical:) He (a man) was, or became, vehemently hungry and thirsty. (TA.) And (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, mad, insane, or a demoniac. (MA.) ― -b8- You say also, saEarotu Alyawoma fiI HaAjatiI saEorapF (assumed tropical:) I made a circuit during the day, or to-day, for the accomplishment of my want. (S.) And laOasoEaranRa saEorahu, i. e. laOaTuwfanRu Tawofahu (assumed tropical:) [app. meaning I will assuredly practise circumvention like his practising thereof]. (Fr, O, K.) ― -b9- And saEara AllRayola biAlmaTiIR, inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) He journeyed throughout the night with the camels, or beasts, used for riding. (ISk, TA.) ― -b10- And saEarati AlnRaAqapu (assumed tropical:) The she-camel was quick, or swift, in her going. (TA.) [See also saEaraAnN, below.]

2 saERara
2: see 1, in four places. ＝ -A2- sERrhu [from siEorN], (Sgh, Msb,) inf. n. tasoEiyrN; (Msb;) and AsErhu↓; (Sgh, Msb;) He assigned to it a known and fixed price: (Msb:) or he declared its current price, or the rate at which it should be sold. (Sgh.) And sERr lahumo, (A, TA,) inf. n. as above; (S;) and lhm AsEr↓; (A;) He (a governor, A) fixed the amount of the prices of provisions &c. for them; (S, TA;) the doing of which is not allowable. (TA.) ― -b2- And sERrwA, inf. n. as above; and AsErwA↓; They agreed as to a price, or rate at which a thing should be sold. (K.)

3 sAErhu c
3. sAErhu app. signifies (assumed tropical:) He acted with him, or it, like one mad, or like a mad dog; for, accord. to Et-Tebreezee, (Ham p. 785,) it is from misoEarN as an epithet applied to a dog, meaning “ mad. ”]

4 OasoEara
4: see 1, in four places. ― -b2- OasoEaranaA qafozFA, said of a wild animal, means (assumed tropical:) He excited and annoyed us by leaping, or bounding. (TA, from a trad.) ＝ -A2- See also 2, in three places.

5 tasaERara
5: see the next paragraph.

8 AstErt AlnRaAru c
8. AstErt AlnRaAru, (S, A, Msb, K,) and tsERrt↓, (S, A, K,) [but the latter, app., has an intensive signification,] The fire burned or burned up, burned brightly or fiercely, blazed, or flamed. (S, A, Msb, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AstErt AlHarobu (tropical:) The war [raged like fire, or] spread. (K, TA.) And in like manner, (TA,) AstEr AlXRarRu (tropical:) The evil, or mischief, [raged, or] spread. (K, TA.) ― -b3- And AstEr AllRuSuwSu, (S, A, K,) or AstErt, (TA,) (tropical:) The thieves, or robbers, put themselves in motion, (K, TA,) for mischief, (TA,) as though they were set on fire. (S, K, TA.) ― -b4- And AstEr Aljarabu fiI AlbaEiyri (tropical:) The mange, or scab, began in the armpits and the groins or similar parts (AA, S, A, * K) and the lips (S) of the camels. (AA, S, A, K.) ― -b5- And AstEr AlnRaAsu fiI kulRi wajohK (assumed tropical:) The people ate the fresh ripe dates in every direction, and obtained them; like AisotanojawoA. (Aboo-Yoosuf, TA.)

ramoIN saEorN c
ramoIN saEorN (tropical:) A vehement shooting or throwing: (A:) [or a burning, painful shooting; as is indicated in the S:] one says DarobN haborN wa TaEonN natorN waramoIN saEorN (assumed tropical:) [a smiting that cleaves off a piece of flesh, and a piercing inflicted with extraordinary force, and a burning, painful shooting]. (S.) It is said in a trad. of 'Alee, AiDoribuwA haborFA waQromuwA saEorFA (assumed tropical:) [Smite ye so as to cleave off a piece of flesh, and] shoot ye quickly: the shooting being thus likened to the burning of fire. (TA.)

suEorN c
suEorN: see suEaArN. ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) Madness, insanity, or demoniacal possession; (K;) as also suEurN↓: (S, K:) so ↓the latter is expl. by AAF as used in the Kur liv. 47: and so it is expl. as used in verse 24 of the same chap.: (TA:) or it signifies in the former, (S,) or in the latter, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) fatigue, or weariness, or distress, or affliction, and punishment: (Fr, S, TA:) or, accord. to Az, UinRaA UicaA lafiI DalaAlK wasuEurK, in verse 24, may mean (assumed tropical:) verily we should in that case be in error, and in punishment arising from what would necessarily befall us: or, accord. to Ibn-'Arafeh, it means, in a state that would inflame and excite us. (TA.) ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) Hunger; and so suEaArN↓: (Fr, K, TA:) or the former signifies vehemence of desire for flesh-meat: (K, TA:) and ↓the latter, vehemence of hunger: (S:) or the burning of hunger: (TA:) and the burning of thirst. (A.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) A disease, such as the mange, or scab, that is transitive from one to another; or the transition of the mange, or scab, or other disease, from one to another; syn. EadowaI. (K. [See 1.])

siEorN c
siEorN The current price, or rate, at which a thing is to be sold: (MA, K:) pl. OasoEaArN. (S, A, Msb, K.) One says, lahu siEorN, meaning It is exceedingly valuable: and layosa lahu siEorN It is exceedingly cheap. (Msb.)

saEarN c
saEarN: see suEorapN.

saEirN c
saEirN (assumed tropical:) Mad, insane, or possessed by a demon: (K:) and so masoEuwrapN↓ applied to a she-camel: (S:) or the latter, so applied, that will not remain still; from suEurN meaning “ madness, or insanity, or demoniacal possession: ” (Ham p. 785:) [See also misoEarN:] the pl. of saEirN is saEoraI. (K.)

suEurN c
suEurN: see suEorN, in two places.

saEorapN c
saEorapN (assumed tropical:) A cough: (O, K:) or a sharp cough; as also saEiyrapN↓. (IAar, TA.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) The beginning of an affair or a case; and the newness thereof: (K, TA:) in some copies of the K, HidRatuhu is erroneously put for jidRatuhu. (TA.)

suEorapN c
suEorapN A colour inclining to blackness, (S, TA,) a little above what is termed OudomapN; as also saEarN↓. (TA.)

saEaraAnN c
saEaraAnN [an inf. n.] Vehemence of running. (O, K.) [See 1, last signification.]

siEoraArapN c
siEoraArapN (S, K) and suEoruwrapN↓ (K) (assumed tropical:) Daybreak. (K.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) The rays of the sun entering an aperture of a house or chamber: (K, * TA:) or the motes that are seen in the rays of the sun (Az, S, TA) when they fall into a chamber, moving to and fro. (Az, TA.)

suEoruwrapN c
suEoruwrapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

suEaArN c
suEaArN The heat (S, K) of fire; (S;) as also suEorN↓: (K:) and (tropical:) of night. (A.) ― -b2- See also suEorN, in two places. ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) Evil, or mischief: so in the saying, laA yanaAmu AlnRaAsu mino suEaArihi [Men will not sleep by reason of his evil, or mischief], occurring in a trad. (TA.)

saEuwrN c
saEuwrN (assumed tropical:) A she-camel quick, or swift, in her going. (TA.) [See 1, last signification.]

saEiyrN c
saEiyrN Lighted, or kindled; or made to burn, burn up, burn brightly or fiercely, blaze, or flame: (K, TA:) of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN: (TA:) [and thus] similar to dahiynN and SariyEN; for you say naArN
masoEuwrapN↓: (Akh, S:) or naArN saEiyrN signifies fire kindled, or made to burn &c., with other fire. (Lh, TA.) ― -b2- Also Fire (S, K) itself; (S;) and so saAEuwrapN↓ and saAEuwrN↓: (K:) or [so in the TA, but in the K “ and, ”] its flame; (K;) as also saAEuwrapN↓ and saAEuwrN↓. (TA.) ＝ -A2- AlsRaEiyru: see what next follows.

AlsRuEayoru c
AlsRuEayoru, (O, K,) and AlsRaEiyru↓, (S,) or the latter is a mistake, (O, TA,) A certain idol, (S, K,) belonging peculiarly to [the tribe of] 'Anazeh. (Ibn-El-Kelbee, S.) [See an ex. in a verse cited in art. mwr.]

saEiyrapN c
saEiyrapN: see saEorapN.

saAEuwrN c
saAEuwrN: see saEiyrN, in two places. ― -b2- Also A sort of fire-place, or oven, (tanRuwrN, K, TA,) dug in the ground, in which bread is baked. (TA.) ＝ -A2- And The chief of the Christians in the knowledge of medicine (K, TA) and of the instruments thereof: [said to be] originally saAEuwraMC, a Syriac word, meaning the investigator of the cases of the diseased. (TA.)

saAEuwrapN c
saAEuwrapN: see saEiyrN, in two places.

OasoEaru c
OasoEaru, applied to a man, Of the colour termed suEorapN: fem. saEoraMCu. (TA.) ― -b2- And, so applied, (TA,) Having little flesh, (K, TA,) lean, or lank in the belly, (TA,) having the sinews apparent, altered in colour or complexion, or emaciated, (K, TA,) and slender. (TA.)

masoEarN c
masoEarN The slender part of the tail of a camel. (K.) ― -b2- See also masaAEiru.

misoEarN c
misoEarN and misoEaArN↓ (S, K) The thing, (K,) or wood, (S,) or instrument of iron or of wood, (TA,) with which a fire is stirred [or made to burn or burn up &c.]: (S, * K, * TA:) pl. (of the former, A) masaAEiru (A, TA) and [of the latter] masaAEiyru. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence one says of a man, UinRahu lamisoEaru HarobK (tropical:) Verily he is one who makes the fire of war to rage; (S, A, * K, * TA;) a stirrer of the fire of war. (TA.) ― -b3- Also the former, (misoEarN), (assumed tropical:) Long; (AA, S, K;) applied to a neck (K) or some other thing: (TA:) or strong. (As, K.) ― -b4- And, applied to a dog, (assumed tropical:) Mad. (Ham p. 785.) [See also saEirN.] ― -b5- AlmisoEaru as an epithet applied to a horse means AalRaciI yuTiyHu qawaAYimahu mutafarRiqapN walaA Dabora lahu [i. e., app., That makes his legs to fall spread apart, and that has no leaping with his legs put together]: (K:) or, in the words of AO, [and so in the O,] AlcI tuTiyHu qawaAYimahu [app. whose legs thow makest to fall &c.]: (TA:) [in the CK, wlA Sabora lahu, which is, I doubt not, a mistake: and in the TA is added, wqyl wavobN mujotamiEu AlqawaAYimi, in which wqyl is evidently a mistranscription for wahuwa, referring to Dabor, which is well known as meaning wavobN mujotamiEu AlqawaAYimi:] and musaAEirN↓ signifies the same. (AO.)

misoEaArN c
misoEaArN: see the next preceding paragraph.

masoEuwrN c
masoEuwrN: see its syn. saEiyrN. ― -b2- [Hence,] (tropical:) A man smitten by the [hot wind called] samuwm. (S, A.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) Vehemently hungry and thirsty: (TA:) eager for food, even though his belly be full; (K;) and, it is said, for drink also. (TA.) ― -b4- See also saEirN.

masaAEiru c
masaAEiru [a pl. of which the sing., if it have one, is probably masoEarN↓,] (assumed tropical:) The armpits, and the groins or similar parts, (S, A, * K,) and the lips, (S,) of camels. (S, A, K.)

musaAEirN c
musaAEirN: see misoEarN, last sentence.

1 saEVTa
1: see what next follows.

4 AsEThu c
4. AsEThu, (S,) or AsETh dawaMCF, (AA, IDrd, Mgh, Msb, K,) He poured, (S, Mgh, Msb,) or introduced, (K,) medicine into his (a man's, S) nose; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also saEaTahu↓, aor.
saEuTa
and
saEaTa
, (K,) the former of which, namely
saEuTa
, is the more approved, inf. n. saEoTN. (TA.) Both are also written with S. (K and TA in art. SET.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AsEThu AlrRumoHa (tropical:) He pierced him in his nose with the spear: ('Eyn, K:) or it is like Oawojarahu, meaning he pierced him in his breast, or chest, with the spear. (S.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] AsEThu EilomFA (tropical:) He took extraordinary pains in making him to understand science, (K, TA,) and in repeating to him what he taught him. (TA.)

8 AstET c
8. AstET He (a man, S) poured medicine into his (i. e. his own) nose; or had it poured therein; (S, Mgh;) or introduced it, or had it introduced, therein: (K:) the pass. form, AusotuEiTa, is not allowable. (Mgh.)

10 AstsET c
10. AstsET (assumed tropical:) He (a camel, TA) smelled the urine of the she-camel, (K,) or somewhat thereof, (TA,) and it, (K,) or some of it, (TA,) entered into his nose; (K;) then he covered her, and failed not to impregnate. (TA.)

saEoTapN waAHidapN c
saEoTapN waAHidapN A single introduction of medicine into the nose; as also wAHdp UisoEaATapN↓. (Lth, K.)

suEaATN c
suEaATN: see saEiyTN, in four places.

saEuwTN c
saEuwTN Medicine that is poured, (S, Mgh, Msb,) or introduced, (K,) into the nose; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) [an errhine;] as also SaEuwTN; (Lh, K;) which is thought, by ISd, to be an instance of assimilation [like SiraATN for siraATN] such as Sb mentions. (TA.) ― -b2- Also Sweat. (TA.)

suEuwTN c
suEuwTN: see the next paragraph, in two places.

saEiyTN c
saEiyTN Sweet, or pleasant, odour, of wine and the like, or of anything: (A'Obeyd, K:) and sharpness, or pungency, of odour; as also suEaATN↓; (K;) the former, [for instance,] of mustard, (ISk,) and so suEuwTN↓: (TA:) and Almisoki suEaATu↓ signifies the odour of musk. (Fr.) A rájiz says, describing camels and their milk,
HamoDyRapN TayRibapu AlsRuEaATi
[That eat the plants called HamoD, sweet in odour]. (AHn.) And you say, huwa TayRibu AlsRuEuwTi↓ and AlUisoEaATi↓ [He, or it, is sweet in odour: but the latter is perhaps a mistranscription, for AlsRuEaATi]. (TA.) ― -b2- The dregs, lees, or sediment, of wine. (S, K.) ― -b3- The baAn [or ben]: (K:) the oil thereof: (IB, K:) the oil of mustard: (K:) and the oil of the zanobaq [or jasmine]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- I. q. musoEaTN [pass. part. n. of 4, q. v.]. (TA.)

UisoEaATN c
UisoEaATN: see the next preceding paragraph.

UisoEaATapN c
UisoEaATapN: see saEoTapN.

musoEuTN c
musoEuTN, (S, Msb, K,) and misoEaTN, (Lth, K,) the former an instance of the instr. n. with damm, (S, Msb, TA,) which is extr., (Msb, TA,) like munoxulN &c., (TA,) The thing, (K,) or vessel, or receptacle, (S, Msb,) into which saEuwT is put, (S, Msb, K,) and from which it is poured into the nose. (K.)

1 saEafahu biHaAjatihi c
1. saEafahu biHaAjatihi: see 4. ＝ -A2- saEifato yaduhu, (S, TA,) inf. n. saEafN, (S, K,) His hand became cracked around the nails; (S, K, * TA;) as also saYifato. (S, TA.) ― -b2- saEifati AlnRaAqapu, in the K, erroneously, suEifat, with damm, (TA,) or saEifa AlbaEiyru, (ISk, S,) The she-camel, (K, TA,) or he-camel, (ISk, S,) became affected with what is termed saEafN↓, meaning a disease in the mouth, like mange, or scab, in consequence of which the hair of the xuroTuwm [i. e. nose, or fore part of the nose,] falls off, (ISk, S, K,) and the hair of the eyes: (ISk, S:) the like thereof in sheep or goats is termed garabN: (S:) accord. to IAar, it is not used in relation to he-camels; and A'Obeyd says the like: accord. to some, as AZ says, it is allowable to use it in relation to he-camels; (TA;) but it is rarely thus used. (K, TA.) ― -b3- suEifa, (S, K,) like EuniIa, (K,) said of a boy, He became affected with the pustules termed saEofapN [q. v.]. (S, K.)

2 tasoEiyfN c
2. tasoEiyfN The mixing of musk and the like with aromatic perfumes (K, TA) and sweetscented oils. (TA.) One says, saERifo liI duhoniI [Mix thou for me my oil with aromatic perfumes]. (ISh, TA.)

3 sAEfhu c
3. sAEfhu, (K, TA,) inf. n. musaAEafapN, (S, TA,) He aided, assisted, or helped, him; [like OasoEafahu;] or [so accord. to the K, but accord. to the S “ and, ”] agreed, or complied, with him, (S, * K, TA,) to perform an affair, (TA,) acting towards him with reciprocal purity, or sincerity, of love, or affection, and aiding, assisting, or helping, with him, (K, TA,) well. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] sAEfhu jadRuhu (tropical:) His fortune aided him: and in like manner, sAEfthu AldRunoyaA (tropical:) [Worldly prosperity aided him]. (A, TA.)

4 AsEf c
4. AsEf, (K,) inf. n. UisoEaAfN, (TA,) It (a thing, TA) drew near, or approached: (K, TA:) and AsEf bihi it drew near, or approached, to him, or it. (TA.) ― -b2- AsEf lahu It (an object of the chase) became within his power, or reach. (K.) ― -b3- AsEf Uilayohi He tended, repaired, or betook
himself, to, or towards, him, or it. (TA.) ― -b4- AsEf biOaholihi He came to his family; syn. OalamRa. (K.) [And in a similar sense the verb is trans. without a particle, as will be shown by the last sentence of this paragraph.] ＝ -A2- OasoEafotuhu I aided, assisted, or helped, him to perform his affair. (Msb. [See also 3.]) ― -b2- And AsEfhu biHaAjatihi, (S, Msb, K, *) inf. n. UisoEaAfN, (Msb,) He performed, or accomplished, for him the object of his want; (S, Msb, K;) as also bihaA saEafahu↓, (Ibn-'Abbád, K, * TA,) aor.
saEafa
, (K,) inf. n. saEofN. (TA.) ― -b3- It is said in a trad., thus related, faATimapu baDoEapN minRiI yusoEifuniI maA yusoEifuhaA, meaning [Fátimeh is a part of me:] that betides, or happens to, [or affects,] me which betides, or happens to, [or affects,] her. (TA. [See another reading in art. bDE.])

saEofN c
saEofN A commodity; an article of merchandise. (O, K, TA.) One says, UinRahu saEofu sawoCK Verily it is a bad commodity. (O, TA.) ― -b2- And A man vile, or mean, and despised in all his circumstances. (AHeyth, O, K.)

saEafN c
saEafN Palm-branches, (Az, * S, Msb, K,) as long as they have the leaves upon them: when these are removed from them, called jariydN: (Msb:) or the part [or parts] of palm-branches upon which leaves have grown: (S voce EasiybN:) or the leaves of palm-branches, (Mgh, K, TA,) of which are woven [baskets of the kind called] zubul (Mgh) or zubolaAn (TA) [pls. of zabiylN], and [the similar receptacles called] jilaAl [pl. of julRapN], (TA,) and fans [which are made in the form of small flags], (Mgh, TA,) and the like: (TA:) and sometimes palm-branches themselves are thus called: (Mgh:) accord. to Lth, (Mgh, TA,) such as have become dry [of palm-branches] are mostly thus called; the fresh [palm-branch] being called XaTobapN: (Mgh, K, TA:) sing., (S,) or [rather] n. un., (Mgh, Msb,) with p: (S, Mgh, Msb:) which also signifies a palm-tree itself; and its pl. is saEafaAtN. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, as being likened to palm-leaves,] The forelock of a horse: so in the saying of Imrael-Keys,
waOarokabu fiI AlrRawoEi xayofaAnapF
kasaA wajohahaA saEafN munotaXiro
[And I ride, in war, or battle, a brisk, or an agile, leaving mare, whose face a spreading forelock has clad]: which shows that saEafN [properly] signifies the leaves [of a palm-branch]. (Az, TA.) [Jac. Schultens, as mentioned by Freytag, explains it as meaning A whiteness upon the forehead of a horse: but this explanation is perhaps conjectural, from the verse cited above.] ＝ -A2- The paraphernalia (jahaAz) of a bride: pl. suEuwfN. (IAar, K.) ― -b2- Anything good, goodly, or excel-lent, and consummate, such as a slave, or any precious thing, or a house that one possesses. (IAar, K.) ＝ -A3- A species of fly: mentioned by a poet as smiting a lion. (IB, TA.) ＝ -A4- See also 1.

saEofapN c
saEofapN A certain disease, (Kr, TA,) or pustules, (S, K, TA,) coming forth upon the head (Kr, S, K, TA) of a child, (S, K, TA,) and upon his face: (K, TA:) said by AHát to be daMCu AlvRaEolabi [i. e. alopecia], which occasions baldness; and saEafapN↓ is a dial. var. thereof in this last sense. (TA.)

saEafapN c
saEafapN n. un. of saEafN [q. v.]. (S, * Mgh, Msb.) ＝ -A2- See also the next preceding paragraph.

suEaAfN c
suEaAfN A cracking, and scaling off, around the nail: (TA:) or a cracking at the root of the nail. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.) [See 1.]

suEuwfN c
suEuwfN Large [drinking-cups or bowls such as are called] OaqodaAH. (IAar, K.) ― -b2- And The goods, or furniture and utensils, of a tent or house, (S, TA,) and its carpets or the like: or, as some say, particularly such as are held in little estimation, as the [drinking-vessel called] tawor, and the bucket, and the rope, and the like. (TA.) ― -b3- [See also saEafN, of which it is pl.] ＝ -A2- Also The natural dispositions, (AA, IAar, K, TA,) generous and other, of men: (IAar, K, TA:) AA says, I have not heard any sing. thereof. (TA.)

OasoEafu c
OasoEafu A camel having the disease termed saEafN (see 1): fem. saEofaMCu, applied to a she-camel: (ISk, S, K:) A'Obeyd mentions only the fem. epithet. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A horse white, (S, * K,) or hoary, (S,) in the forelock, (S, K,) when there is some other colour in it, different from the white: (TA:) when the whole of it is white, he is termed OaSobagu: (S, TA:) so in the “ Book of Horses ” by AO. (TA.)

masoEuwfN c
masoEuwfN A boy affected with the pustules termed saEofapN [q. v.]. (S, K.)

musaAEifN c
musaAEifN A place, (K,) and a place of alighting, (TA,) near. (K, TA.)

1 saEala c
1. saEala, aor.
saEula
, (S, O, Msb, K,) inf. n. suEaAlN (S, O, K) and suEolapN, (K,) or the latter of these is the inf. n., and the former is a simple subst., (Msb,) [He coughed:] suEolapN signifies [the having] a motion whereby nature expels somewhat hurtful from the lungs and the organs connected therewith: (Ibn-Seenà, K, TA:) wherefore the ducts of the lungs are called qaSabu AlsRuEaAli [the tubes of coughing, meaning the bronchial tubes,] because it [i. e. what is hurtful in the lungs] has its exit by them. (TA.) One says, UinRahu yasoEulu suEolapF munokarapF [Verily he coughs with an abominable coughing]. (TA.) And bihi suEolapN [In him is a coughing; i. e. he has a coughing, or cough]. (TA.) And OagoSRaka AlsRuWaAlu faOaxacaka AlsRuEaAlu [The question, or petition, has choked thee, and consequently coughing has seized thee]. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence the saying, ramaAhu fasaEala AldRama [He shot him, and he consequently coughed up blood]; i. e., he threw [up] blood from his chest. (TA.) ＝ -A2- saEila, aor.
saEala
, inf. n. saEalN; accord. to the K, app., saEala, aor.
saEula
, inf. n. saEolN; [and thus the pret. and inf. n. are written in the copies of the K;] but the former is the right; (TA;) (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, brisk, lively, or sprightly; (K, TA;) like zaEila, inf. n. zaEalN. (TA. [See the part. n., saEilN, below.])

4 AsElhu c
4. AsElhu It [made him to cough, or] occasioned him a coughing. (TA.) ＝ -A2- And (assumed tropical:) He, or it, made him, or pronounced him, to be like the siEolaAp [q. v.]. (O, TA.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) He. (a man, K, TA,) and it, (pasture, or herbage, O, TA,) rendered him (a horse, TA) brisk, lively, or sprightly; (O, K, TA;) as also OazoEalahu. (O, TA.)

10 AstsElt c
10. AstsElt (tropical:) She (a woman) became a siEolaAp, i. e., very clamorous, and foul-tongued; (S, O;) or like a siEolaAp, (K, TA,) in badness, wickedness, or guile, and clamorousness, and foulness of tongue: (TA:) similar to Astklbt, and to AstOsd said of a man, &c. (AZ, TA.)

saEalN c
saEalN Dry [dates of the bad sort termed] XiyS. (IAar, O, K.)

saEilN c
saEilN, applied to a horse, (assumed tropical:) Brisk, lively, or sprightly; like zaEilN. (AO, O, TA.)

siEolaI c
siEolaI: see the next paragraph.

siEolaApN c
siEolaApN and siEolaMCu↓ (S, O, K [app. thus, without tenween, as a fem. noun, though fiEolaAC without tenween is unusual,]) and siEolaI↓ (S, O, TA) The [kind of goblin, demon, devil, or jinnee, called] guwl: (K:) or the female of the guwl: (Abu-l-Wefee El-Aarábee, TA in art. gwl; and Har p. 76:) or the worst, most wicked, or most guileful, of the giylaAn [pl. of guwl]: (S, O:) or an enchantress of the jinn, or genii: (K:) pl. [of the first] saEaAlK [written with the article AlsRaEaAliI] (S, O, K) [and of the second saEaAliIRu] and of the third siEolayaAtN, which is said to signify the females of the giylaAn. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] siEolaApN signifies (tropical:) A very clamorous, foul-tongued, woman: (S, O, TA:) accord. to Aboo-'Adnán, a woman foul in face, evil in disposition, is likened to the siEolaAp: but some of the Arabs say that the Arabs do not apply the epithet siEolaApN to any but an old woman. (TA.) ― -b3- And [the pl.] AlsRaEaAliI signifies (tropical:) Horses; as being likened to what are [properly] so termed. (TA.) ― -b4- And [the same pl.] AlsRaEaAliI, (K, TA,) with kesr to the l, (TA,) [in the TK AlsRaEaAliIRu, and in the CK AlsRuEAleI↓,] signifies (assumed tropical:) A certain plant, the leaves of which make [the ulcers termed] dubayolaAt to discharge their contents, and dissolves them; and the fresh thereof remove the mange, or scab: it is a most excellent remedy for the cough; [wherefore it is also called HaXiyXapu AlsRuEaAli; (TK;)] and causes the erection of the cakar to subside (wayafuXRu AlAinotiSaAba, K, TA, for which we find in some copies of the K wanafosi AlAinotiSaAbi); even the fumigating of oneself therewith. (K.)

siEolaMCu c
siEolaMCu: see the next preceding paragraph.

suEaAlN c
suEaAlN an inf. n. of saEala [q. v.]: (S, O, K:) or a simple subst. [meaning A cough]. (Msb.)

AlsRuEaAleI c
AlsRuEaAleI: see siEolaApN.

saAEilN c
saAEilN [Coughing]. You say naAqapN saAEilN, (O,
K,) without p, (O,) meaning A she-camel having a cough. (O, K.) ― -b2- And UinRahu lacuw suEaAlK saAEilK [Verily he has a violent cough]: (O, K: *) a phrase having an intensive meaning: (K:) by rule one should say suEaAl musoEil; but thus the Arabs said, like as they said XugolN XaAgilN and XiEorN XaAEirN: and [in like manner] a poet cited by Lth says cuw saAEilK. (O.) ― -b3- See also what follows.

masoEalN c
masoEalN The part of the fauces, or throat, which is the place of coughing: (S, Msb:) or [simply] the fauces, or throat; as also saAEilN↓; (K) which latter is expl. by Az as meaning The mouth; because with it one coughs. (TA.)

1 saEaI c
1. saEaI, aor. yasoEaI, inf. n. saEoIN (S, Msb, K, &c.) [and masoEFI, agreeably with general analogy], He walked, went, or went along, (Er-Rághib, Msb, K, TA,) quickly: (Er-Rághib, Mgh, TA:) this, accord. to Er-Rághib, is the primary signification: and hence, AlsRaEoIu bayona AlSRafaA waAlmarowapi [The tripping to and fro between Es-Safà and ElMarweh]: (TA:) and saEaI fiI maXoyihi [app. meaning He tripped along, or he trudged along, in his walking]: (Msb:) [or] AlsRaEoIu signifies the going along with vigorousness, and with lightness, activity, or quickness. (Ham p. 665.) ― -b2- He (a man, S) ran; syn. EadaA; (IAar, S, K, TA;) or jaraI: by the former of which is meant [he went] a pace below what is termed AlXRadRu and above what is termed AlmaXoIu. (IAar, TA.) ― -b3- I. q. qaSada [as meaning He repaired, or betook himself]. (K.) The saying, in the Kur [lxii. 9], faOosoEawoA UilaI cikori QollRehi is expl. as meaning faAqoSiduwA [Then repair ye to prayer to God]: (TA:) or then go ye (faOomoDuwA) to prayer [to God]: (Jel:) and Ibn-Mes'ood read faOomoDuwA. (TA.) Or saEaI UilaI AlSRalaApi means He went to prayer, in any manner [i. e. whether quickly or not]. (Msb.) ― -b4- He was active, or busy and bustling, in procuring the means of subsistence: (TA:) he strove, laboured, or exerted himself; employed himself vigorously, strenuously, or with energy; in any affair, whether good or evil; but mostly used in relation to what is praiseworthy, or praised: (Er-Rághib, TA:) he occupied himself according to his own judgment or discretion or free will, in any work, or deed: (Msb:) he worked, or wrought, or did, (S, Msb, K, TA,) any work, or deed, good or evil: (TA:) he earned, or gained. (S, K, TA.) One says, huwa yasoEaI EalaI qawomihi He manages, conducts, orders, regulates, or superintends, the affairs of his people, or party. (Ham p. 771, Msb. *) And saEaI lahumo and Ealayohimo He worked, or wrought, and earned, or gained, for them. (TA.) And AlmaroCu yasoEaI ligaArayohi, a prove., meaning The man earns for his belly and his pudendum. (TA.) And saEaI AlmukaAtibu fiI Eitoqi raqabatihi, (S,) or fiI faki raqabatihi, i. e. [The slave who had made a contract with his master to pay him a certain sum for his emancipation] laboured to earn the means of releasing himself: (Msb:) the inf. n. of the verb thus used is sEaAyapN: (S, Msb:) and this term is employed when a slave emancipated in part, and in part retained in slavery, labours and earns for the completion of his release. (IAth, TA.) The saying, in the Kur [liii. 40], layosa liloUinosaAni UilRaA maA saEaI means [There is nothing imputable to the man] but what he hath wrought, or done. (Msb.) And falamRaA balaga maEahu OolsRaEoIa, in the same [xxxvii. 100], means And when he attained to working with him: or and when he was able to assist him in his working. (TA.) ― -b5- Also He superintended, managed, or conducted, in his own person, the collection of the poor-rates; (K, TA;) he went to exact them, and received them; (TA;) and the inf. n. in this case also is siEaAyapN: (K, TA:) or saEaI EalaI AlSRadaqapi, (S, Msb,) aor. yasoEaI, inf. n. saEoIN, (Msb,) he officiated in the exacting, or receiving, or collecting, of the poor-rate. (S, * Msb.) [And saEaI is trans. without a prep. as meaning He exacted the poor-rate:] a poet says, (namely, 'Amr Ibn-'Addà, TA,)
saEaI EiqaAlFA falamo yatoruko lanaA sabadFA
fakayofa lawo qado saEaI EamorNw EiqaAlayoni
[He exacted the poor-rate of a year, and left not to us camels' fur, or goats' hair: then how would be the case if 'Amr had exacted the poor-rate of two years?]. (S.) ― -b6- saEayotu fiI Oamori fulaAnK is said when one rectifies, redresses, or reforms, the affair of such a one, or mars, vitiates, or perverts it, by his saEoI [or striving, or labouring; and may be rendered I strove, or laboured, in respect of the affair of such a one, either to rectify, redress, or reform, it, or to mar, vitiate, or pervert, it]: and waQlRaciyna saEawoA fiI MyaAtinaA, in the Kur xxii. 50 [and xxxiv. 5], means And they who strive, or labour, in respect of our signs, to mar, or vitiate, or pervert, their meaning, by impugning their character; seeing that they called them enchantment, and poetry, and tales, or legends, or fictions: (Ksh in xxii. 50:) or these words of the Kur mean and they who strive, or labour, to falsify, or nullify, our signs; i. e. the Kur-án. (Jel.) ― -b7- saEaI bayonahumo means He created, or excited, disorder, or discord, between them, or among them; made, or did, mischief between them, or among them; as also saOaA, which is app., in this case, a dial. var. of saEaI. (TA in art. sOw.) [Hence,] saEaI bayona AlnRaAsi biAlnRamaAYimi [He created, or excited, disorder, &c., among the people by calumnies, or slanders: or it may be well rendered he busied himself among the people with propagating calumnies, or slanders]. (S and O in art. Akl; &c.) ― -b8- And saEaI (tropical:) He calumniated him, or slandered him, (S, Msb, K, * TA,) UilaI AlwaAliI [to the ruler, or magistrate]; (S, Msb, K;) inf. n. saEiAyapN. (TA.) ― -b9- saEato, said of a female slave, (K, TA,) aor. tasoEaI, inf. n. saEoIN, (TA,) She committed fornication, or prostituted herself. (K, TA.) [See also 3.] ＝ -A2- saAEaAniI fulaAnN fasaEayotuhu: see 3.

3 1aAo2a2a
3: saAEaAniI fulaAnN fasaEayotuhu↓, aor. of the latter OasoEiyhi, means [Such a one strove with me in walking, or going along, quickly, &c.,] and I overcame him [therein]. (S, TA.) The inf. n. musaAEaApN signifies The walking, or going, quickly [&c., or rather the striving, or contending, in doing so,] with any one. (KL.) Hence the trad. of 'Alee, in discommendation of worldly enjoyments, mano saAEaAhaA faAtatohu, meaning mano saAbaqahaA [i. e. He who runs a race with them, they evade him, or escape his pursuit]. (TA.) ― -b2- musaAEaApN also signifies One's committing fornication with a female slave: and a female slave's committing fornication with any one: (KL:) you say, of a man, zanaI and Eahara, and this is with a free woman and with a female slave; but one says in the case of a female slave, peculiarly, qado saAEaAhaA [He has committed fornication with her]; musaAEaApN not being with any but with female slaves: thus in a trad., UimaMCN saAEayona fiI AljaAhiliyRapi [Female slaves that committed fornication in the Time of Ignorance]: and OutiIa Eumara birajulK saAEaI OamapF [There was brought to 'Omar a man who committed fornication with a female slave]: (S, TA: *) [and hence, waladu AlmusaAEaApi (occurring in the L, in art. bhv, as mentioned by IAar on the authority of Abu-l-Mekárim), meaning The offspring of fornication, begotten on a slave:] or sAEAhA, (K, TA,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) signifies [or rather signifies also] He sought her for the purpose of fornication: (K, [in which the context seems to indicate that it relates to a female slave,] and TA:) accord. to Th, relating to the free woman and the female slave: it is also said that musaAEaApu AlmaroOapi signifies The imposing upon the woman, by her owner, an impost which she is to pay by means of [the gain of] prostitution: and it is said in a trad. that there shall be no musaAEaAp in El-Islám. (TA.) ＝ -A2- [It is said in the TA in art. rbE, that musaAEaApN from AlsRaAEapu is like muaXaAharapN from AlXRahoru and muraAbaEapN from AlrRabiyEu &c.; but I think that msAEAp in this instance is a mistranscription for musaAwaEapN: see art. swE.]

4 AsEAhu c
4. AsEAhu signifies jaEalahu yasoEaI, (K, TA,) i. e. He made him to earn, or gain. (TA.) ― -b2- And AsEI EalaI SadaqaAtihimo He employed a collector of their poor-rates. (TA.) [See also 10.] ― -b3- And OasoEawoA bihi They gave him, or performed or accomplished for him, what he desired, or sought, or needed. (Sgh, K, TA.)

10 AstsEI AlEaboda c
10. AstsEI AlEaboda (S, Msb, K) fiI qiymatihi (S, Msb) He required of the slave that he should labour to earn the means of releasing himself: (Msb:) or he imposed upon the slave work by means of which he should pay for himself, when he had been emancipated in part, in order to his completing his emancipation: and siEaAyapN↓ signifies the work so imposed. (K.) ― -b2- And AstsEAhu He employed him as collector of the poor-rate. (JM; and the like is said in the TA, from a trad.) [See also 4.]

saEowN c
saEowN: see the next paragraph, in two places: ＝ -A2- and see also saEowapN.

siEowN c
siEowN, with kesr, (T, S, TA,) [and saEowN↓, with fet-h, as shown by what follows,] or siEowapN↓, with kesr, (K,) or saEowapN↓, thus written in the M, with
fet-h, (TA,) and siEowaMCN↓, (T, S, ISd, K, [Freytag found this last written in a copy of the S saEowaAC, and in one of my copies of the S it is written siEaAwaI,]) which is said to be masc., (TA,) [and therefore with tenween, accord. to a general rule applying to ns. of the measure fiEolaMC,] and suEowaMCN↓, (IAar, Sgh, K,) A [portion, or short portion, such as is termed] saAEap, (S, M, K, &c.,) of the night: (S, M, TA:) [like sihowaMCN, q. v.:] one says, maDaI mina AllRayoli siEowN, (S, TA,) and saEowN↓, with fet-h as well as with kesr, (TA, and thus in the Ham p. 708,) and saEowapN↓, with fet-h, (TA,) [or siEowapN↓,] and siEowaMCN↓, (S,) [and suEowaMCN↓,] A portion (qiToEapN) of the night passed; (TA;) [or a short portion:] and sihowN mina AllRayoli signifies the same: (Ham p. 708:) or, as some say, sEwMC↓ signifies more than a sAEp, of the night, and likewise of the day; and one says, kunRaA Einodahu fiI siEowaAwaAtK mina AllRayoli and AlnRahaAri [app. meaning We were with him, or at his abode, during some considerable portions of the night and of the day]: so in the T. (TA.)

saEoIN c
saEoIN inf. n. of 1 [in most of its senses]. (S, Msb, K, &c.) ＝ -A2- See also saEoyapu.

saEaApN c
saEaApN The occupation of oneself according to his own judgment or discretion or free will (K, TA) in procuring the means of subsistence, and in earning, or gain. (TA.) Hence the prov., Xagalato saEaAtiI jadowaAIa [My occupation of myself in procuring the means of subsistence has diverted me from giving]: El-Mundhiree says that XiEaAbiI, with X, is a mistranscription: it is applied to him whose disposition is generous but who is in want. (TA. [See also art. XEb.])

saEowapN c
saEowapN: see siEowN, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also i. q. XamoEapN or XamaEapN [i. e. A piece of wax, or a candle]: (IAar, TA:) in the K, AlsmEp is erroneously put for AlXmEp: [so in the TA; but it is omitted in the CK and in my MS. copy of the K:] pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] saEowN↓. (TA.)

siEowapN c
siEowapN: see siEowN, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also, [accord. to the K, siEowapN, for it is there written with the article Al, but] accord. to IAar without the article Al, [app. siEowapu, as a proper name,] (TA,) A woman foul, unseemly, or obscene, in tongue; having little, or no, shame or modesty: (IAar, K, * TA:) AlxaAliEapu in the K is a mistranscription for AljaAliEapu, with jiym. (TA.)

saEoyapu c
saEoyapu a proper name for The she-goat. (K.) And she is called to be milked by the cry saEoI↓ saEoyah. (TA.)

siEowaMCN c
siEowaMCN and suEowaMCN: see siEowN, in five places.

siEaAyapN c
siEaAyapN an inf. n. of saEaI, in three of its senses. ― -b2- See also 10.

suEaAwiIRN c
suEaAwiIRN One who patiently endures sleeplessness and travel: (K:) very laborious, active, and bustling. (TA.)

saAEK c
saAEK act. part. n. of 1. (Msb.) A messenger; a courier, or messenger that journeys with haste; or a messenger on a beast of the post; syn. bariydN. (TA.) [See an ex. at the end of the first paragraph of art. rym.] ― -b2- Any manager, conductor, orderer, regulator, or superintendent, (S, K,) of a thing, over a people, or party, (S,) or of an affair, and of a people, or party, whatever it be: (K:) pl. suEaApN. (S, * TA.) Mostly, (S, TA,) or when used without restriction, (Msb,) applied to The intendant, or collector, of the poor-rate: pl. as above. (S, Msb, TA. [See rakiybN.]) And particularly The headman of the Jews and Christians, (K, TA,) from whose opinion, or judgment, they do not deviate, and without whom they do not decide an affair. (TA.) And [the pl.] suEaApN signifies Persons who take upon themselves responsibility for the prevention of the shedding of blood, and for the stilling of sedition, or discord, or the like; because they labour in the reforming, or amending, of the circumstances subsisting between parties. (TA.) ― -b3- Also A calumniator, or slanderer; [and especially] to the ruler, or magistrate: whence the saying, in a trad., AlsRaAEiI ligayori riXodapK The calumniator is not trueborn: and in another trad., AlsRaAEiI muvalitN [The calumniator of another to the ruler is a trebler of evil]; meaning that he destroys, by his calumny, himself, and the calumniated, and the ruler. (TA.)

masoEFI c
masoEFI, syn. with saEoIN, [an inf. n. of saEaI,] signifying The act of running, and working, and earning or gaining, [&c., when used as a simple subst.,] has for its pl. masaAEK. (Har p. 384.)

masoEApN c
masoEApN A means of attaining honour and eminence or elevation, in the various kinds of glory; (K;) a good, or laudable, act or endeavour; generosity: pl. masaAEK. (MA.) [See an ex. voce madoEaApN, and another voce OaqoEada.] J says, [in the S,] AlmasoEaApu waAHidapu AlmasaAEiI fiI AlkalaAmi waAljuwdi: and the author of the K, following Sgh, says that he has committed a mistake in saying fiI AlkalaAmi instead of fiI Alkarami: in some copies of the S is found fiI Alkarami; but this is an emendation: the original reading is fiI AlkalaAmi: which, however, should be termed a slip of the pen [rather than a mistake, for it cannot be that J was ignorant of the meaning of so common a word as masoEaApN]. (TA.)

masoEiIRN bihi c
masoEiIRN bihi Calumniated, or slandered, [and especially] to a ruler, or magistrate. (TA.)

1 sagiba c
1. sagiba, aor.
sagaba
; (S A, Msb, K;) and sagaba, aor.
saguba
; (A, K;) inf. n. sagabN, (S, A, * Msb, K,) which is of the former, (Sudot;, Msb, TA,) and sagobN, (K,) which is of the latter, (TA,) and suguwbN (K) and sagaAbapN and masogabapN, (A, * K,) the last syn. with majaAEapN; (S, Msb;) He was, or became, hungry: (S, A, Msb, K:) or suffered hunger together with fatigue. (A, Msb, K.) You say, bihi sagabN and masogabapN and sagaAbapN, [using these ns. as simple substs.,] In him is hunger: or hunger together with fatigue. (A.) And yatiymN cuw masogabapK [An orphan] having hunger. (S.) And fiI yawomK ciI masogabapK, in the Kur [xc. 14], means In a day of hunger. (TA.) [See also sagobapN and sagabN below.]

4 Asgb c
4. Asgb He (a man, TA) entered upon a state of hunger. (K.)

sagabN c
sagabN an inf. n. of sagiba [q. v.]. (S, &c.) ― -b2- It also signifies Thirst: but is unused: (K:) [or] thirst is sometimes thus termed. (Msb.)

sagibN c
sagibN: see saAgibN.

sagobapN c
sagobapN Hunger: or hunger combined with fatigue. (TA.) [See also 1.]

sagobaAnu c
sagobaAnu; and its fem., sagobaI: see the next paragraph, in three places.

saAgibN c
saAgibN and sagobaAnu↓ (S, A, Msb, K) and sagibN↓ (K) Hungry: (S, A, Msb, K, TA:) or suffering hunger together with fatigue: (A, Msb, K:) or thirsty: (TA:) fem. [of the second] sagobaI↓, (S, K,) pl. sigaAbN. (K.) You say also, huwa saAgibN laAgibN (A, TA) and lagobaAnu sagobaAnu↓ (TA) [He is hungry and fatigued, or fatigued in the utmost degree]. And it is said in a trad., daxala xayobara wahumo musogibuwna↓, expl. as meaning [He entered Kheyber] they being hungry. (TA.)

musogibN c
musogibN: see its pl. in what next precedes.

huwa musagRabN lahu kacaA c
huwa musagRabN lahu kacaA and masaERabN [the latter written in the CK musogabN] To him is allowed, or permitted, such a thing. (K, TA.)

1 safRa c
1. safRa, (A'Obeyd, Az, S, M, K,) aor.
safufa
, inf. n. safRu; (S, TA;) and AsfR↓, (A'Obeyd, S, M, K,) inf. n. UisofaAfN; (TA;) He wove (A'Obeyd, Az, S, M, Z, K) with his fingers (Z, TA) [or plaited] a mat, (A'Obeyd, TA,) or palm-leaves, (Az, S, M, K,) and any other thing that may be woven with the fingers; (TA;) like ramala and Oaromala. (A'Obeyd, TA.) ＝ -A2- safRa (Lth, O, K) EalaI wajohi AlOroDi, (Lth, O,) [aor.
safufa
accord. to the TK, but more probably
safifa
, agreeably with a general rule relating to intrans. verbs of this class,] inf. n. safiyfN, He (a bird) went along upon the surface of the earth. (Lth, O, K.) [See also 4.] ＝ -A3- safifotu, (S, M, Mgh, * Msb, K,) third pers. safRa, (Mgh,) aor. OasafRu, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. safRN; (M, Msb, K;) and Aisotafafotu↓; (S, M, Msb, K; [in one of my copies of the S, erroneously, Oasofafotu;]) I took [into my mouth], (S, K,) or ate, (Mgh, Msb,) medicine, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) and meal of parched barley or wheat, (S, M, Mgh,) and the like of either of these, (M,) or anything dry, (Mgh, Msb,) not moistened, (S, Msb, K,) and not kneaded [with water &c.]; (S;) or i. q. qamiHotu, (M, K, TA,) which signifies as above, (TA,) or I took it in the palm of my hand, (A and L in art. qmH,) and conveyed it to my mouth, (A in that art.,) or licked it up: (L in that art.:) and safRapN↓ signifies the doing thus once. (TA.) And [hence,] safRN signifies also Camels' eating
dry herbage. (K.) Hence the saying of 'Amr Ibn-Kulthoom,
tasafRu AljilRapu Alxuwru AldRariynaA
The she-camels advanced in age, abounding with milk, eating the [dry and] old and wasted herbage. (Mgh. [See EM p. 208: and the same, p. 224.]) Hence also the phrase, laOano OasafRa AltRuraAba Assuredly that I should eat the dust. (Mgh.) ― -b2- And safifotu AlmaMCa, (M, K,) aor. OasafRu, inf. n. safRN, (TA,) I drank much of the water without satisfying my thirst: (M, K:) and so safitRuhu, aor. Oasofatuhu, inf. n. safotN. (TA.) ― -b3- sufRa AlrRamaAdu fiI wajohihi: see 4.

4 AsfR c
4. AsfR: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- [Hence,] Oasofafotu AlXRaIoCa, inf. n. UisofaAfN, I stuck one part of the thing to another. (Yz, TA.) ― -b3- [And from the same signification, as is indicated in the O and TA,] AsRf AlnRaZara (tropical:) He looked sharply, (S, M, A, O, K,) and hardly, (S, O,) and minutely, (A,) towards, or at, (UilaI,) a person, (S, A, O,) and an affair, (A,) and AAF adds, and inclined towards the ground. (M.) ＝ -A2- Also He fed a camel with dry herbage. (K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AsfR Alfarasa AllijaAma (assumed tropical:) He put the bit into the mouth of the horse. (Moheet, L, K.) ― -b3- And AsfR AldRawaMCa (assumed tropical:) He stuffed the wound with the medicament: (M:) or AsfR AljuroHa dawaMCF (tropical:) he put a medicament into the wound; (K, TA;) as though he put safuwf to it. (TA.) ― -b4- And AsfR AlwaXoma naWuwrFA (assumed tropical:) He filled in the tattoo with nWwr [i. e. smoke-black of fat]. (M.) ― -b5- And OusifRa wajohuhu AlnRaWuwra (assumed tropical:) His face was sprinkled with nWwr. (S.) It is said in a trad., fakaOanRamaA OusifRa wajohuhu, meaning (assumed tropical:) His face was altered, (S, K, *) as though something that altered it had been sprinkled upon it. (S.) You say also, kaOanRa wajohahu OusifRa ramaAdFA, meaning (assumed tropical:) His face became of a blackish, or an ashy, hue, altered, as though ashes had been sprinkled upon it: and sufRa↓ AlrRamaAdu fiI wajohihi (assumed tropical:) [Ashes were sprinkled upon his face], meaning his face became altered. (Har p. 626.) ＝ -A3- Also It approached the earth, or ground; (S, M, K;) said of a bird in its flight; (S, K;) or of a bird &c.: (M:) or it (a bird) flew over the ground so near that its feet almost reached it. (A.) And AsfRt AlsRaHaAbapu The cloud approached the earth. (S, K.) ― -b2- Said of a stallion, He stooped his head to bite. (M, K.) And one says of man, AsfR mina AlOaroDi [and UilaI AlArD He stooped towards the ground]. (O in art. Xb.) ― -b3- And, said of a man, (S,) (assumed tropical:) He pursued small, or little, things: (S, K:) and (assumed tropical:) he followed after low, or mean, things: (K:) [(assumed tropical:) he stooped to such things:] or AsfR UilaI madaAqi AlOumuwri wa OalaAYimihaA (assumed tropical:) He approached [or pursued] small, or little, things, and the meanest, or most ignoble, thereof; or became mean, or ignoble: (M, * TA:) and AsfR liloOamori AldRaniIR, [or correctly AldRaniIoCi,] and Uilayohi, (assumed tropical:) He approached [the thing that was near, or that was low, or mean]; from AsfR said of a bird in its flight, meaning It approached the ground so that its feet almost touched it. (Har p. 206.) [Hence the saying,] taHafRaZo mino Algamali AlsRafosaAfi walaAtusifRa lahu baEoDa lUisofaAfi (tropical:) [Guard thyself from the bad action, and approach it not with any degree of approaching]. (TA.) ― -b4- You say also, maAOasafRa minohu bitaAfihK He obtained not [from him, or of it, a paltry acquisition], (K, TA,) [or] anything. (TA.) ― -b5- And AsfR He fled from his companion, (K, TA,) running most vehemently. (TA.)

8 Uisotafafa
8: see 1.

R. Q. 1 safosafa c
R. Q. 1. safosafa, (K,) inf. n. safosafapN, (S, M,) He cleared, or sifted, (Ainotaxala,) flour, (S, M, K,) and the like, (S, K,) with the munoxul [or sieve], and the like. (L, TA.) One says, samiEotu safosafapa Almunoxuli [I heard the sifting of the sieve]. (TA.) ― -b2- And safosafa Eamalahu (tropical:) He did his deed imperfectly, or not soundly. (IDrd, M, K, TA.) ― -b3- And safosafati AlriyHu The wind raised the fine dust, blowing a little above the surface of the earth. (TA.)

entry.key: laA tazaAlu tatasafosafu fiI hecaA AlOamori

superEntry.entry:
R. Q. 2 laA tazaAlu tatasafosafu fiI hecaA AlOamori c
R. Q. 2. laA tazaAlu tatasafosafu fiI hecaA AlOamori a phrase mentioned by Ibn-'Abbád as meaning Thou wilt not cease to destroy, or bring to nought, this thing, or affair. (O, TA.)

safo c
safo, with the f quiescent, i. q. sawofa; as in the phrase safo tafoEalu [Thou wilt do such a thing]: mentioned by Th. (M. [See art. swf; and see also the letter s.])

safRN c
safRN, accord. to the K, or sifRN↓, with kesr, accord. to Sgh, [in the O,] (TA,) A spadix, or a spathe, (TaloEap) of a male palm-tree. (AA, O, K) ― -b2- See also sifRu.

sufRN c
sufRN: see what next follows.

sifRN c
sifRN and sufRN↓, (O, K,) or the former and safRN↓, (so in a copy of the M,) The serpent called Oaroqam: (AA, O, K:) or the serpent that flies (M, O, K) in the air: (M, O:) and sometimes peculiarly applied to the Oaroqam: (M:) or the male serpent. (O.) And the Hudhalee poet EdDákhil Ibn-Harám uses the first of these words as meaning (assumed tropical:) A man like a sifR. (M.) ― -b2- See also safRN.

safRapN c
safRapN [an inf. n. un.]: see 1.

sufRapN c
sufRapN A plait of palm-leaves, (M, K, TA,) i. e. a safiyfap↓, (TA,) made according to the measure of the zabiyl or the julRap [of which it is to form a part]. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And A thing of the kind termed qaraAmilu [pl. of qiromilN], (K, TA,) [i. e. a plait] of [goat's] hair, or of wool, (TA,) which a woman attaches to her [plaits of] hair: it was not disapproved by Ibráheem En-Nakha'ee; (K, TA;) though he disapproved of other things attached to the hair: IAth explains it as a thing that a woman puts upon her head, and attaches to her hair in order that it may be lengthened [thereby]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- A small portion, (HabRapN,) and (S) a handful, (S, K,) of meal of parched barley or wheat, (S,) or of wheat, and the like. (K.) ― -b2- See also what next follows.

safuwfN c
safuwfN Medicine, (S, M, Msb, K,) and meal of parched barley or wheat, (S, M,) and the like of either of these, (M,) or anything dry, (Msb,) taken [into the mouth], (S, M, * K,) or eaten, (Msb,) not moistened, (S, M, * Msb, K,) or not kneaded [with water &c.]; (S;) and sufRapN↓ signifies the same; (M, K;) each a subst. from safifotu AlsRawiyqa and AldRawaMCa &c. (M.) ＝ -A2- Also Blackness of the gum. (M, TA.)

safiyfN c
safiyfN Woven [with the fingers, or plaited,] of palm-leaves. (KL.) ― -b2- [And hence,] The girth of the raHol [or camel's saddle], (S, M, K,) and of the [women's vehicle called] hawodaj: (M:) the fore-girth of the raHol; because made broad, like the safiyf of palm-leaves. (T, TA.) [See also the next paragraph.] ＝ -A2- A certain plant. (IDrd, K.) ＝ -A3- The sharpness of the ears of the wolf. (M, TA.) ＝ -A4- And AlsRafiyfu is A name of Iblees: (O, K:) so says AA: (O:) in one or more of the copies of the “ Nawádir, ” AlsRafosafu↓. (TA.)

safiyfapN c
safiyfapN A thing woven [with the fingers, or plaited,] of palm-leaves: (S, O:) a piece of woven [or plaited] work of palm-leaves (K voce EaraqN) &c.: (TA ibid.:) pl. safaAYifu. (TA.) See sufRapN, first sentence. ― -b2- A wide belly-girth with which a raHol [or camel's saddle] is bound, or fastened. (M.) [See also safiyfN.] ― -b3- The appertenance [or suspensory] of a water-skin (qirobap), which the carrier of the qrbp puts over his chest [when carrying the qrbp on his back]. (K voce EaraqN.) ― -b4- See also jumaAnN. ― -b5- A [receptacle for dates, such as is called] dawoxalRap, [made of palmleaves,] before it is woven. (M, TA.) ― -b6- And [the pl.] safaAYifu signifies Wide ribs: or, as some say, all the ribs. (M.)

safosafN c
safosafN A certain plant; (M, TA;) said by IDrd to be of the dial. of El-Yemen; that which the people of Nejd call the Eanoqaz, which is the marozanojuwX [or marjoram]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also safiyfN.

safosaAfN c
safosaAfN The dust of flour, that rises, (K,) or flies and rises, (TA,) at the sifting. (K, TA.) ― -b2- The fine particles or dust: (S, Mgh, K:) or such as rises, or spreads, of dust. (M.) ― -b3- Hence, (Mgh,) safosaAfu AlXiEori (Mgh, K) (assumed tropical:) What is bad of poetry, (K, TA,) imperfectly, or unsoundly, done. (TA. [In the CK, AlXRaEari is erroneously put for AlXiEori; and Freytag appears to have read AlXRaEiyri.]) safosaAfN signifies (assumed tropical:) Bad poetry: and (assumed tropical:) anything imperfectly, or unsoundly, done. (M.) Anything bad. (S, K. [Compare the Hebr. אֲסַפְסֻף occurring with the article, and with the quiescent, in Numbers xi. 4.]) (assumed tropical:) Such as is bad of natural dispositions. (M.) And (assumed tropical:) A contemptible, or despicable, thing or affair. (S, K.) It is said in a trad., UinRa QllReha yuHibRu maEaAliIa AlOamuwri wa yubogiDu safosaAfahaA, (S, M, Mgh, TA,) or yakorahu safosaAfahaA, (S, TA,) i. e. (assumed tropical:) [Verily God loves lofty things, or things whereby one acquires eminence or nobility, and] hates paltry, and mean, things. (Mgh, Sgh, TA.)

safosaAfN c
safosaAfN signifies [also] (assumed tropical:) An action, and a saying, in which is no good. (Ham p. 232; where the foregoing trad. is cited as an ex.) And (assumed tropical:) Any bad wind: (TA:) [or] safosaAfapN signifies a wind running a little above the ground; and so musafosifapN↓: (M:) or the latter, a wind that raises the fine dust, and runs a little above the ground. (S, K.) ― -b2- HalifN safosaAfN (tropical:) A false, or lying, swearing, in which is no ratification. (TA.)

sufaAsifN c
sufaAsifN Vehement hunger. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

musifRN c
musifRN [act. part. n. of 4, q. v.]. ― -b2- Anything cleaving, or sticking, to another thing. (A'Obeyd, TA.) ― -b3- marRa musifRFA He passed by fleeing from his companion, running most vehemently. (Ibn- 'Abbád, TA.)

musafosifapN c
musafosifapN: see safosaAfN, last sentence but one. ＝ -A2- Also, without the p, (tropical:) Ungenerous, or mean, in giving. (S, M.)

1 safaHa c
1. safaHa, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
safaHa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. safoHN, (Msb,) [and app. sufuwHN also, mentioned in what follows,] He poured out, or forth, water: (S, A:) and he shed blood, (S, A, Msb, K,) the blood of another; (S, A;) and tears; (Msb, K;) inf. n. as above, and sufuwHN: (K:) or safaHati AlEayonu damoEahaA [the eye shed its tears]. (A.) The saying, in a trad., faqatala EalaIraOosi AlmaMCi HatRaI safaHa AldRamu AlmaMCa has been explained as meaning [And he slew at the head of the water so that] the blood covered the water: but IAth says that this is not consistent with the language; for safoHN signifies the act of “ pouring out, or forth; ” and that the meaning may therefore be, that the blood made the water to pour forth; like as when, into a full vessel, something heavier than what is in it is poured; for in this case there comes forth from it as much as has been poured into it. (TA.) ― -b2- sufiHa fiI AlOarDi (assumed tropical:) [He was stretched, or extended, upon the ground], said of a camel. (K.) ＝ -A2- The verb is also used intransitively; you say, safaHa AlmaMCu, (Msb,) and AldRamoEu, inf. n. sufuwHN and safaHaAnN (O, K) and safoHN, (K,) The water, (Msb,) and the tears, (O, K,) poured out, or forth. (O, Msb, K.)

2 sfRH c
2. sfRH, inf. n. tasofiyHN, (assumed tropical:) He did a deed that profited him not; (K;) likened to the arrow called AlsRafiH. (TA.)

3 saAofaHa
3: [sAfHhu, inf. n. sifaAHN, and perhaps musaAfaHapN also, He contended with him in the shedding of blood.] You say, bayonahumo sifaAHN Between them is a shedding of blood. (TA.) ― -b2- And [hence,] bayonahumaA sifaAHN (tropical:) Between them two is a contending in fight: or, in hocking [of camels] (muEaAqarap). (A, TA.) ― -b3- And sifaAHN and musaAfaHapN also signify (tropical:) The committing fornication with another; (S, A, Msb, K;) liOanRa AlmaMCa yuSabRu DaAYiEFA; (Msb;) as also tasaAfuHN↓ [which is said of more than one pair]. (K.) You say, saAfaHahaA (tropical:) He committed fornication with her. (A, Msb.) And saAfaHatopu (tropical:) She committed fornication with him: (L:) or she abode with him in the practice of fornication. (TA.) [In all the copies of the S that I have been able to consult, three in number, I find saAfaHahu.] And fiI AlnikaAHi gunoyapN Eani AlsifaAHi (tropical:) [In marriage is that which renders one in no need of fornication]. (A, Msb.) In the Time of Ignorance, when a man demanded a woman in marriage, he said, AinokiHiyniI; and when he desired fornication, he said, saAfiHiyniI. (TA.)

4 OajorawoA UisofaAHFA c
4. OajorawoA UisofaAHFA (assumed tropical:) They made [horses] to run without a wager. (K.) [App., like 2, from AlsRafiyHu, the arrow thus called.]

5 tasafRaHa
[5: tsfRHaccord. to Freytag, signifies It was, or became, poured out, or forth: but he names no authority for this.]

6 tsAfHwA AldimaMCa c
6. tsAfHwA AldimaMCa [They mutually shed blood; lit., bloods]. (A.) ― -b2- See also 3.

safoHN c
safoHN The base, foot, bottom, or lowest or lower part, (OaSol, K, or Oasofal, S, A, K,) of a mountain, (S, A, K,) which is the part whereinto is poured (yusofaHu) the water [from the parts above]; i. e. the part where the side thereof rests upon the ground: (S: [as also SafoHN:]) or the [part called] EaroD thereof, [see this word,] that rests its side upon the ground: or the HaDiyD [app. as meaning the low ground at, or by, the base, or foot,] thereof: (K:) or the spreading part thereof: (A: [there said to be in this sense tropical; but why, I see not:]) or the face thereof: (Msb:) or the lowest, or lower, part thereof, where it is rugged: (Ham p. 80:) pl. sufuwHN. (K.) ― -b2- [The pl.] sufuwHN also signifies Rocks that are soft, or smooth, (K, TA,) and slippery. (TA.)

safuwHN c
safuwHN: see saAfiHN. You say jafonN safuwHN [An eyelid shedding copious tears]. (A.)

safiyHN c
safiyHN A sack; syn. juwaAliqN: (K:) safiyHaAni signifies a pair of sacks which are placed (S, L) upon a camel, (L,) like the xuroj. (S, L.) ― -b2- And A thick, or coarse, [garment of the kind called] kisaMC. (O, K.) ― -b3- AlsRafiyHu [incorrectly written by Freytag safiyHp, as on the authority of the S,] is the name of An arrow used in the game called Almayosir, to which no portion pertains: (S, A, * K:) it is the fourth of the arrows to which the term gufol is applied, which have no notches, and to which is assigned no portion and no fine; these being added only to give additional weight to the collection of arrows from fear of occasioning suspicion [of foul play]: the first of them is called AlmuSadRaru; the next, AlmuDaERafu; the next, AlmaniyHu; and the next, AlsRafiyHu. (Lh, TA.) ― -b4- See also musaAfiHN.

safRaAHN c
safRaAHN A shedder of much blood. (A.) [Hence,] AlsRafRaAHu is the name of A sword of Homeyd Ibn-Bahdal. (K.) ― -b2- [Hence also,] (assumed tropical:) A giver of many gifts; or one who gives much. (K.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) Chaste [or rather fluent or eloquent] in speech; syn. faSiyHN: (K:) or possessing ability for speech. (S.)

saAfiHN c
saAfiHN Pouring out, or forth; (O, L, Msb, K;) applied to water, (A, Msb,) [and blood,] and tears (damoEN): (O, L, K:) [accord. to some, unacquainted with the intrans. verb safaHa, a possessive epithet, i. e.] meaning cuw safoHK: (Ham p. 709:) syn. with safuwHN↓, [or rather this is an intensive epithet,] and masofuwHN↓ also is syn. with safuwHN; (TA;) or [rather] signifies poured out, or forth; (A, * L, Msb;) and is applied to water, (A, Msb,) and tears (damoEN). (L.)

OasofaHu c
OasofaHu (assumed tropical:) Bald in the fore part of the head; (K;) as also OasoqaHu (TA) [and OaSoqaHu].

masofaHN c
[masofaHN A place where water is poured out, or forth; and where blood, and tears, are shed: pl. masaAfiHu.] One says, lilowaAdiI masaAfiHu The valley has places where it pours out, or forth. (A, TA.)

musafiHN c
musafiHN (assumed tropical:) One who does a deed that profits him not. (K. [See 2.])

masofuwHN c
masofuwHN: see saAfiHN. ― -b2- [Hence,] applied to a camel, it means qado sufiHa fiI AlOaroDi wamudRa (assumed tropical:) [Stretched, or extended, upon the ground; wamudRa being an explicative adjunct]. (K.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) Wide. (K.) You say naAqapN masofuwHapu AlUiboTi (tropical:) A she-camel wide in the arm-pit. (A, K.) And jamalN masofuwHu AlDRuluwEi (tropical:) A camel [wide i. e.] not contracted in the ribs. (A, TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) Thick, coarse, or big. (K.) ― -b5- You say also, UinRahu lamasofuwHu AlEunuqi, meaning (assumed tropical:) Verily he is long, and thick, coarse, or big, in the neck. (TA.) ― -b6- And AlmasofuwHu is the name of (assumed tropical:) A horse of Sakhr Ibn-'Amr Ibn-El-Hárith. (K.)

musaAfiHN c
musaAfiHN (assumed tropical:) A fornicator. (TA.) And musaAfiHapN (assumed tropical:) A fornicatress; (TA;) a woman who does not abstain from fornication. (Aboo-Is-hák, TA.) Aibonu musaAfiHapK means (assumed tropical:) A son of a fornicatress; (TA;) and [in like manner] safiyHN↓ a son who is the offspring of fornication. (Sgh, TA in art. ErD.)

1 safida c and safada
1. safida safada, (S,) or safida EalaI AlOunovaI and [EalayohaA] safada, (K,) or safidahaA (M, Msb) and safadahaA, (M, A,) aor. of the former
safada
, (S, M, Msb, K,) and of the latter
safida
, (M, K,) inf. n. sifaAdN (S, M, Msb) and safodN, which are of both the verbs; (M;) and saAfadahaA↓, inf. n. sifaAdN; (A;) He leaped the female: (S, K:) said of a bird, (A, Msb,) &c.; (Msb;) or of any beast or bird of prey; (As, TA;) or of a quadruped and of a bird; (M, TA;) or of a goat (S, TA) and of a camel (As, S, TA) and of a bull and of a beast of prey and of a bird; (S, TA;) and, in poetry, of a swimmer [app. meaning a fish]: (M, TA:) sometimes, also, it is used to convey an allusion to AljimaAE [relating to human beings]. (A.)

2 tasofiydu AllRaHomi c
2. tasofiydu AllRaHomi (assumed tropical:) The arranging of the flesh-
meat upon the safRuwd, to roast: (K:) Z [app.] makes it tropical, by his derivation of safRuwdN [q. v.]. (TA.)

3 saAofada
3: see 1: ― -b2- and see also 6.

4 Asfdhu c
4. Asfdhu He made him to leap [the female]. (S, * K, * PS, TK.) ― -b2- OasofidoniI tayosaka, mentioned by Lh, means Lend me thy he-goat in order that he may leap my she-goat: and Umeiyeh Ibn-Abi-s-Salt uses its pass. part. n. metaphorically in relation to the zanod [or piece of stick used for producing fire]; saying,
waAlOaroDu SayRarahaA AlUilehu TaruwqapF
lilomaMCi HatRaI kulRu zanodK musofadu↓
[And the land, God made it to be soaked by the water, so that every znd was lent; no man being able to go far enough to cut one for himself]. (M, TA.)

5 tsfRd farasahu c
5. tsfRd farasahu He mounted his mare from behind; (M;) as also AstsfdhA↓: (AAF, M:) or baEiyrahu Astsfd↓ he came to his camel from behind, and mounted him: (IAar, K:) and [in like manner] tsfRdahu i. q. taEaroqabahu, (K,) i. e. he mounted him from behind. (TA.)

6 tsAfdt AlsibaAEu c
6. tsAfdt AlsibaAEu (S) and AlTRuyuwru, (A,) or tsAfd AlsibaAEu (K) and AlTRuyuwru, (TA,) and AlXiyaAhu sAfdt↓, (Msb, [perhaps a mistranscription for tsAfdt,]) The beasts of prey [and the birds and the sheep or goats] leaped one another. (TK.)

10 Uisotasofada
10: see 5, in two places.

safodu AlliqaAHi c
safodu AlliqaAHi A certain game, in which boys arrange themselves one behind another, every one laying hold upon the Hujozap [or uppermost part of the waist-wrapper] of his fellow, from behind him. (T in art. jEr, and TA.)

safuwdN c
safuwdN A mare that is not allowed to be leaped [by the stallion] until she has completed her munoyap, which is a period of twenty days. (Kr, M.)

safRuwdN c
safRuwdN (S, M, Msb, K) and sufRuwdN (M, TA) (assumed tropical:) An iron instrument, (S, M, K,) with curved prongs, (M, TA,) with which flesh-meat is roasted: (S, K:) Z makes is to be tropical, saying [in the A] that it is so called because of its adhering to that which is roasted upon it: (TA:) pl. safaAfiydu. (Msb, TA.) [For instances of substs. similar to safRuwdN and sufRuwdN, see subRuwHN.]

UisofanodN c
UisofanodN and UisofinodN Wine: (K:) the etymologists assert that its d is a substitute for the T in UisofanoTN, which is one of the names of wine. (TA.)

musofadN c
musofadN pass. part. n. of 4, q. v.

1 safara c
1. safara, (S, M, A, K,) aor.
safira
, inf. n. saforN, (M, K,) He swept a house, or chamber, (S, M, A, K,) &c. (M.) ― -b2- And He, or it, [swept away; or took away, or carried off, in every direction: and] dispersed: (M, K:) and removed, took off, or stripped off, a thing from a thing which it covered. (M * A, * K.) You say, safarati AlrRiyHu AltRuraAba, and Alwaraqa, (assumed tropical:) The wind swept away the dust, and the leaves: or too them away, or carried them off, in every direction. (M.) And safarat i AlrRiyHu Algayoma (assumed tropical:) The wind dispersed the clouds: (M, TA:) or (assumed tropical:) removed the clouds from the face of the sky. (A, * TA.) And you say of a woman, safarato, (S, M, A, Mgh, K,) aor.
safira
, (M,) inf. n. sufuwrN, (M, Mgh,) meaning She removed her veil (M, A, Mgh) Eano wajohihaA from her face: (A, M:) and [elliptically] (M) she uncovered her face: (S, M, K:) [for] safarotu AlXRaIoCa, [being for sfrt Eani AlXRaIoCi,] aor.
safira
, inf. n. saforN [or sufuwrN?], signifies I uncovered the thing; made it apparent, or manifest: (Mgh:) [but accord. to Mtr,] the phrase tasofiru wajohahaA [meaning she uncovers her face] is of weak authority. (Mgh.) ― -b3- Hence, i. e. from safarato meaning “ she uncovered her face, ” (M,) safarotu bayona Alqawomi, (S, M, Mgh, * Msb, K,) aor.
safira
(S, Msb, K) and
safura
, (K,) inf. n. sifaArapN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and safaArapN and saforN, (K,) (assumed tropical:) I made peace, effected a reconciliation, or adjusted a difference, between the people; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) because he who does so exposes what is in the mind of each party: (TA:) or I exposed what was in the mind of this and the mind of this in order to make peace, &c., between the people. (M.) [See also sifaArapN, below.] ― -b4- [And likewise, perhaps, from safarato meaning “ she uncovered her face, ”] safarati AlXRamosu, aor.
safira
, inf. n. saforN, (assumed tropical:) The sun rose. (Msb.) ― -b5- See also 4, in two places. ― -b6- safara, (S,) Msb,) aor.
safira
, (S,) or
safura
, (Msb,) inf. n. sufuwrN, (S,) or safarN, (Msb,) [the former of which inf. ns. perhaps indicates a radical relation to safarato said of a woman, and of the sun, expl. above,] He went forth to journey: (S, Msb:) this verb, however, in this sense, [which appears to have been unknown, or not acknowledged, by the authors of the M and K, (see musaAfirN,)] is obsolete; but its inf. n. safarN is used as a simple subst. (Msb. [See 3, the verb commonly used in this sense.]) ― -b7- [Hence, app,] safara XaHomuhu (tropical:) His fat went away. (A, TA.) ― -b8- and safarati AlHarobu (tropical:) The war declined; syn. walRat. (A, K.) ＝ -A2- safara AlkitaAba, (S, A,) aor.
safira
, inf. n. saforN, (S,) He wrote the book, or writing. (A. [See siforN.]) ＝ -A3- safara AlbaEiyra, (S, K,) or safarahu biAlsRifaAri, (M,) aor.
safira
, (M, K,) inf. n. saforN; (M;) and Asfrhu↓, (AZ, M, K,) inf. n. UisofaArN; (TA;) and sfRrhu↓, (Kr, M, K,) inf. n. tasofiyrN; (TA;) He put the sifaAr [q. v.] upon the nose of the camel. (S, M, K.) ＝ -A4- safara Ailganama He sold the best of the sheep, or goats. (K.)

2 sfRrhu c
2. sfRrhu, inf. n. tasofiyrN, He sent him to go a journey. (K, TA.) ― -b2- sfRr AlUibila, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He pastured the camels between sunset and nightfall, and in the safiyr, (K, TA,) i. e., the whiteness [of the sky] before night: (TA:) or he fed the camels with safiyr [q. v.]: (so in the O:) and sfRr farasahu, inf. n. tasofiyru, He fed his horse with safiyr: or he kept him continually going, and trained him, in order that he might become strong to journey. (JM.) ― -b3- sfRr AlnRaAra, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He made the fire to flame, or blaze; (K, TA;) kindled it; or made it to burn, burn up, or burn brightly or fiercely, (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 1, last sentence but one.

3 saAofara
3: [sAfr is trans. and intrans.] You say, AlrRiyaAHu yusaAfiru baEoDuhaA baEoDFA [The winds vie, one with another, in sweeping the ground, effacing one another's traces]: for the east wind removes and disperses the longitudinal traces made by the west wind, and the south wind makes traces across them. (S, * K, * TA.) ＝ -A2- And sAfr, inf. n. musaAfarapN (S, Msb, K) and sifaArN, (S, K,) He journeyed, or went, (K,) or went forth to journey, (S, Msb,) UilaI baladi kacaA [to such a country, or town]. (S, K.) And saAfara safarFA baEiydFA [He journeyed, or went, a far journey]. (A, Mgh.) [See also 1.] ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) He died. (K.) ― -b3- And saAfarati AlXRamosu Eano kabidi AlsRamaMCi (tropical:) [The sun declined from the middle of the sky]. (A.) ― -b4- And saAfarato Eanohu AlHumRaI (tropical:) [The fever departed from him]. (A.)

4 Asfrt AlXRajarapu c
4. Asfrt AlXRajarapu The tree had its leaves blown off [and swept away] by the wind; (K, * TA;) they having become changed in colour, and white. (TA.) ― -b2- And Asfr, (inf. n. UisofaArN, Mgh, Msb,) It (the dawn, or daybreak,) shone, (T, S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) so that there was no doubt respecting it; (T, TA;) as also safara↓, (M, K,) aor.
safira
, (K,) inf. n. saforN: (TA:) it has a special relation to colour; meaning it shone in colour. (B, TA.) ― -b3- It (the moon) caused a shining [in the sky] before its rising. (M.) ― -b4- (tropical:) It (a man's face) shone (S, M) [with happiness (see musofirN)]; or with beauty; for you say, Asfr HusonFA; (S;) as also safara↓: (M:) or became overspread with beauty. (Msb.) ― -b5- And He entered upon the time of dawn, or daybreak; (M;) or the time when the dawn became white. (K.) The Prophet said, OasofiruwA biAlfajori, meaning Perform ye the prayer of daybreak when ye enter upon the time in which the dawn shines, or becomes white: (S, * Msb:) or when the dawn has become manifest, so that there is no doubt respecting it, every one knowing it to be the true dawn when he sees it; accord. to EshSháfi'ee and Ibn-Hambal and others: (T, TA:) or prolong ye the prayer of daybreak until ye enter upon the time when the dawn becomes white: (S, TA:) some say that it relates especially to nights in [the end of] which the moon shines, because in such the commencement of daybreak is not manifest: (TA:) or Oasofara biAlSRalaApi means he performed prayer in the shining of the dawn: and the b is for the purpose of making the verb transitive. (Mgh.) ― -b6- Asfrt AlHarobu (tropical:) The war became vehement. (A, K.) ＝ -A2- See also 1, last sentence but one.

5 tsfRr c
5. tsfRr means OataI bisafarK, (O, K,) i. e. He came in [the time of] the whiteness of day [either before sunrise or after sunset]. (TA.) ― -b2- And tsfRrt AlUibilu The camels pastured between sunset and nightfall, (O, K,) and in the safiyr, (K, TA,)
i. e. the whiteness [of the sky] before night. (TA. [But see 2, second sentence.]) ＝ -A2- tsfRr AlnisaMCa (O, K, TA) Eano wujuwhihinRa (O, TA) i. q. AisotasofarahunRa↓, (O, K, TA,) i. e. He sought the brightest of the women in face and in beauty (TA, TK *) for marriage. (TK.) ― -b2- And tsfRr XayoYAF mino HaAjatihi (tropical:) He attained, or obtained, somewhat of the object of his want (O, K, TA) before its becoming beyond his reach. (TA.) ― -b3- And tsfRr fulaAnFA (assumed tropical:) He sought to obtain of such a one the half (AlnRiSofa, O, K, TA [in the CK. AlnRaSafa, by which, if it be correct, may perhaps be meant what was equitable, and AlnRiSofa may bear the same interpretation,]) of a claim (tabiEap) that he had upon him. (O, K, TA.) ＝ -A3- tsfRr Aljilodu The skin received, or had, a mark, or an impression: (O, K:) from saforN meaning OavarN. (TA.)

7 Ansfr Algayomu c
7. Ansfr Algayomu (assumed tropical:) The clouds became dispersed: (M, TA:) [or] became removed from the face of the sky. (TA.) ― -b2- Ansfr muqadRamu raOosihi mina AlXRaEari (assumed tropical:) The fore part of his head became divested of the hair. (S, K. *) ― -b3- Ansfrt AlUbilu fiI AlOaroDi (assumed tropical:) The camels went away into the country, or land. (M, K. *)

9 UisofarRa
9: [AisofarRiti AlXRamosu, inf. n. AisofiraArN, app. means The sun became white, previously to setting.] See safarN.

10 Astsfr AlinRsaMCa c
10. Astsfr AlinRsaMCa: see 5. ＝ -A2- Astsfrhu He sent him as a safiyr [q. v.]. (JM.)
