saforN c
saforN: see musaAfirN, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also A mark, an impression, a trace, or a vestige, (OavarN, K, TA,) remaining: (TA:) pl. sufuwrN. (K.) [Accord. to Freytag, it occurs in the Deewán El-Hudhaleeyeen as meaning The track, or trace, of a surge, or torrent.]

siforN c
siforN A book, or writing: (S, M:) or a great, or large, book: or a section of the Book of the Law revealed to Moses: (M, K:) or a book that discovers, or reveals, truths: (TA:) or a book is thus called because it discovers things, and makes them evident: (M:) pl. OasofaArN. (S, M.) ― -b2- With respect to the saying of Aboo-Sakhr El-Hudhalee,
zlilayolaI bicaAti Albayoni daArNEarafotuhaA
waOuxoraI bicaAti AljayoXi MyaAtuhaAsiforu
Skr says, [the poet means,] the marks, or traces, thereof had become effaced: [accordingly, the verse may be rendered, To Leylà there was in Dhát-el-Beyn an abode that I knew, and another in Dhát-el-Jeysh whereof the marks, or traces, are effaced:] IJ says, [app. holding the meaning to be, the marks, or traces, whereof are (like those of) an ancient book, such as a portion of the Mosaic Law,] the last word should be from the phrase safarotu Albayota, i. e. “ I swept the house, or chamber; ” as though the writing were swept off from the Tiros [or “ written paper ” or the like, to which the poet seems to compare the site of the abode in Dhát-el-Jeysh]. (M, TA.)

safarN c
safarN Journey, or travel; the act of journeying or travelling; (S, A, K;) contr. of HaDarN: (M, K:) thus called because of the going and coming in it, like the going and coming of the wind sweeping away fallen leaves: (M:) or the act of going forth to journey; an inf. n. used as a simple subst.: (Msb:) [therefore] the pl. is OsofaArN: (S, M, A, Msb, K:) [and therefore it is often used as a n. un.; but, properly speaking, the n. un. is saforapN↓:] you say, kaAnato saforatuhu qariybapF [His journey was near]: and the pl. of saforapN, accord. to rule, is safaraAtN. (Msb.) In law, [as relating to the obligation of fasting &c.,] The going forth with the intention of performing a journey of three days and nights, or more. (KT.) ＝ -A2- Also The whiteness of dawn or daybreak: (A:) or the whiteness of the day: (S, M:) and i. q. SabaAHN [dawn, or morning, or forenoon; but app. here used in the first of these senses]: (M:) and safiyrN↓, the whiteness [of the sky] before night: (A, TA:) or the former, the remains of the whiteness of day after sunset. (K.) You say safarFA i. e. SabaAHFA [app. as meaning In the dawn]. (A.) And the prose-rhymer says, UicaA TalaEati AlXRiEoraI safarFA lamo tarafiyhaA maTarFA (S, * TA) i. e. When Sirius rises in the whiteness of day [meaning in the clear twilight of morning, thou seest not then rain: for Sirius rises aurorally, in Arabia, in the middle and the latter half of July, when rain scarcely ever falls there]. (S. [Accord. to the TA, the meaning, app. taken without consideration from one of the foregoing explanations of safarN, is, when Sirius rises at nightfall: but this is during the usual winter-rains.]) You say also, laqiytuhu safarFA, and fiI safarK, meaning EinodaQsofiraAri↓ AlXRamosi lilguruwbi, thus related, with s [in the word AsfrAr (not with S), and app. meaning I met him when the sun was becoming white, previously to the setting]. (M.) And baqiIa safarN mino nahaArK [There remained a white gleam of daylight]. (A.)

saforapN c
saforapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

suforapN c
suforapN The food of the traveller; (M, K;) the food that is prepared for the traveller, (S, Msb,) or for a journey: (TA:) pl. asufarN. (Msb.) This is the primary signification. (TA.) You say, OakaluwA AlsRuforapa They ate the food for the journey. (A.) ― -b2- Hence, (tropical:) The receptacle thereof; (TA;) the piece of skin in which it is put. (S, * M, * Msb, K, * TA.) [This is commonly of a round form, with a running string; so that it is converted into a bag to contain the food, at one time, and at another time is spread flat upon the ground, when persons want to eat upon it.] ― -b3- And hence, (tropical:) The thing [whatever it be] upon which one eats: (TA:) [in the desert, it is generally a round piece of skin, such as I have described above: in the towns, in the houses of the middle classes, a round tray of tinned copper, which is usually placed on a low stool; and in the dwellings of some of the highest classes, and the lowest, respectively, of silver and wood:] accord. to the T, suforapN has the last of the significations given before this, and the thing which it denotes is thus called because it is spread when one eats upon it. (TA.)

sifaArN c
sifaArN (Lh, S, M, K) and sifaArapN↓ (Lh, M) A piece of iron, (S, M, K,) or a cord, (M,) or a piece of skin, (K,) that is put over the nose [and jaws] of a camel, in the place of the Hakamap [q. v.] (Lh, S, M, K) of the horse: (S, K:) or a cord that is attached to the xiTaAm [q. v.] of a camel, a part being twisted round it, and the rest being made a rein: and sometimes it is of iron: (Lth:) pl. [of pauc., of the former,] OasofirapN (M, K) and [of mult.] sufurN (S, M, K) and [of either] safaAYiru. (M, K.)

safiyrN c
safiyrN Leaves which the wind sweeps away; (M;) leaves which fall from trees (S, A, K) and which the wind sweeps away, (A,) or because the wind sweeps them away: (S:) or leaves of herbs; because the wind sweeps them away: (T, TA:) or what have fallen of the leaves of trees and of the lower portions of seed-produce. (JM.) ＝ -A2- Also A messenger: (S:) and (assumed tropical:) a mediator; or a man who makes peace, effects a reconciliation, or adjusts a difference, between a people; (S, M, Msb;) as also saAfirN↓: (Msb:) or a messenger who makes peace, &c.: (T, Mgh, TA:) [see 1:] pl. of the former sufaraMCu, (S, M, Mgh,) and of the latter safarapN. (Har p. 255. [See also sifaArapN, below.]) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) A commissioned agent, a factor, or a deputy; and the like: pl. as above: app. so called because he discovers, and makes manifest, the affair in which he acts as a substitute for another person. (Msb.) ＝ -A3- See also safarN.

sufaArapN c
sufaArapN Sweepings. (S, M, K.)

sifaArapN c
sifaArapN an inf. n. of safara in the phrase safara bayona Alqawomi [q. v.]. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.) [And hence, The office of the safiyr (q. v.). See also De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., sec. ed., i. 126 and 172: and Quatremère's Hist. des Sultans Mamlouks, i. 193.] ＝ -A2- Also The falling of one's hair from [above] his forehead. (Sgh, TA.) ＝ -A3- See also sifaArN.

saAfirN c
saAfirN [act. part. n. of 1:] A woman having her face uncovered: (S, M, Mgh, K:) pl. sawaAfiru. (TA.) ― -b2- And a horse (assumed tropical:) having little flesh: (K:) or so saAfiru AllRaHomi, a phrase used by Ibn-Mukbil. (TA.) ― -b3- See also safiyrN. ― -b4- And see musaAfirN, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also A writer; a scribe: (Akh, S, M, K:) in the Nabathæan language saAfiraA: (M:) pl. safarapN: (Akh, S, M, K:) which is also applied to the angels who register actions. (M, K.)

tasofiyrapN c
tasofiyrapN: see misofarapN.

masofarN c
masofarN sing. of masaAfiru, (A,) which signifies The part that appears [or parts that appear] of the face. (S, A, * K.) ― -b2- [Also, or masofirN, A place of journeying or travelling: in which sense, likewise, its pl. is masaAfiru.] One says, bayoniI wabayonahu masaAfiru baEiydapN [Between me and him, or it, are farextending tracts to be travelled]. (A.)

musofirN c
musofirN [act. part. n. of 4, q. v.:] (tropical:) A face shining (A, TA) with happiness. (A.) ― -b2- AlnRaAqapu Almusofirapu
AlHumorapi [in the CK (erroneously) AlHumorapu] means (assumed tropical:) [The she-camel] that is somewhat above such as is termed SahobaMC [in respect of redness]. (O, K, TA.)

misofarN c
misofarN: see misofarapN. ― -b2- Also A man (TA) that journeys, or travels, much; (K;) and so misofaArN↓: (A:) or that journeys, or travels, much, and is strong for journeying: (M:) and, applied to a camel, (S, M, A,) strong for journeying; (S, M, A, K;) fem. with p, (S, M, K,) applied to a she-camel, (S, M,) as also misofaArN↓, thus applied. (M.)

misofarapN c
misofarapN A broom; a thing with which one sweeps; (S, M, K;) as also misofarN↓, and tasofiyrapN↓, of which last, (expl. by maA yusofaru bihi,) the pl. is tasaAfiyru. (TA.)

musafRirN c
musafRirN i. q. mujalRidN [i. e. One who binds books (OasofaAr, pl. of siforN), or covers them with leather]. (A, TA.)

misofaArN c
misofaArN: see misofarN, in two places.

masofuwrN c
masofuwrN Distressed, or fatigued, by journeying or travel. (TA.)

musaAfirN c
musaAfirN A man journeying, or travelling; a traveller; a wayfarer; (S, M, K;) as also saAfirN↓; (M, * K;) which latter is [said to be] not a part. n., but [a possessive epithet] meaning cuw safarK, (M,) having no verb belonging to it (M, K) that we have seen; (M;) or it is from safara, and signifies going forth on a journey: (S, Msb:) pl. of the former musaAfiruwna, (S,) and of the latter sufRaArN (S, M, A, Msb, K) and OasofaArN (M, K) and sufRarN; (TA;) and you also say qawomN saAfirapN↓ [fem. of saAfirN], (S, * M, Msb, K,) and qawomN saforN↓, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) [saforN being a quasi-pl. n.,] like SaHobN in relation to SaAHibo: (S, Mgh, Msb:) and saforN↓ is also used as a sing., (M, K,) being originally an inf. n. (TA.) ― -b2- musaAfirapN is used by Zuheyr as a name for A [wild] cow. (M, TA.)

safarojalN c
safarojalN [The quince; pyrus cydonia of Linn.;] a certain fruit, (K,) well known; (S, K;) abundant in the land of the Arabs: (AHn, TA:) it is astringent, or constipating; strengthening; diuretic; exites the appetite (K, TA) for food and venery; (TA;) allays thirst; and when eaten upon [other] food, loosens [the bowels]; and the most beneficial thereof is that which has been scooped out, and had its pips extracted, and honey put in the place thereof, and been plastered over with clay, and baked (K, TA) in the oven: (TA:) [a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. with p: (K:) and pl. safaAriju: (S, K:) the dim. is sufayorij and sufayojilN, mentioned by Az. (TA.) ― -b2- [safarojalN hinod iIRu Annona glabra; a species of custard-apple; mentioned by Forskål, Flora Aegypt. Arab., p. cxiv.] ＝ -A2- The saying of Sb, that there is not in the language the like of sfr jAl does not mean that this word is applied to anything: and in like manner his saying that there is not in the language the like of Asfrjlt does not mean that this word is used. (TA.)

1 safuTa c
1. safuTa, aor.
safuTa
, (M, K,) inf. n. safaATapN, (M, TA,) He was, or became, cheerful, happy, or free from straitness, in mind: liberal, bountiful, or munificent. (M, K, TA.)

4 maAOasofaTa nafosahu Eanoka c
4. maAOasofaTa nafosahu Eanoka How pleased, or content, is his mind to give thee up, or relinquish thee! syn. maA OaToyabahaA. (IAar, K.)

5 tsfRT Alxamora c
5. tsfRT Alxamora It (a jar) drank up, or absorbed, the greater part of the wine. (K.)

8 AisotifaATN c
8. AisotifaATN The drinking up entirely [what is in a vessel]; syn. AiXotifaAfN. (K.)

safaTN c
safaTN A thing (M, Mgh, Msb, K) like a juwaAliq [or sack], (M, K,) or like a qufRap [or basket woven of palm-leaves], (K,) in which are stowed perfume and similar things, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) of the apparatus of women: (Mgh, TA:) an Arabic word, well known: (TA:) pl. OasofaATN. (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K.) ― -b2- And hence, (tropical:) A casket, or small chest. (Mgh.) It is related that an Arab of the desert, passing by at the burial of Mo- hammad, asked why they had not placed the Apostle of God in a safaT of brown aloes-wood encased with gold. (TA.)

safiyTN c
safiyTN Cheerful, happy, or free from straitness, in mind: liberal, bountiful, or munificent. (S, M, K.) You say, huwasafiTu AlnRafosi He is cheerful, happy, or free from straitness, and liberal, in mind: (TA:) or cheerful, or brisk, to do what is kind or beneficent. (As.) And nafosuhu safiyTapN bikacaA [His mind is pleased, or content, with such a thing]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Vile, or mean, and despised in all his circumstances: (M, K:) a man, (IAar, M, K,) or thing, (IAar, M,) of no estimation. (IAar, M, K.) Thus it has two contr. significations. (K.) ― -b2- What drop from the tree, of green unripe dates. (M, L, K.[AlmutasAfiTu in the CK is a mistake for AlmutasaA qiTu.]) ＝ -A3- OamowAluhumo safiyTapN bayonahumo Their possessions are mixed among them. (AZ, S.)

sufaATapN c
sufaATapN The goods, or utensils and furniture, of a house or tent. (IDrd, S, [but wanting in one copy,] M, K.)

safRaATN c
safRaATN A maker of what is called safaT. (TA.)

UisofanoTN c
UisofanoTN, (S, M, K,) so in the handwriting of J, (TA,) and UisofinoTN, (M, K,) also written with S, (As, and K in art. SfT,) Perfumed juice of grapes: (M, L, K:) or wine in which are aromatics: (TA:) or the upper part of wine; (AO, M, K;) the clear part thereof; (AO, TA;) so called because the jars (dinaAn) have drunk up, or absorbed, the greater portion of it, (K, TA,) the clear part remaining; (TA;) or from safiyTN in the first of the senses assigned to it above: (IAar, K:) or various wines mixed together: (TA:) or it signifies a certain sort of beverage or wine: and is a Persian word, [originally UisofanodN,] arabicized: (S, K:) or, accord. to As, a Greek word, (S, M,) signifying wine: (TA:) if not Arabic, all its letters are radicals: and Sb says that it is a quinqueliteral-radical word, like UiSoTabolN. (TA.)

musafRaTu AlrRaOosi c
musafRaTu AlrRaOosi A man having a head like a safaT. (IAar, K.)

1 safaEatohu AlsRamuwmu c
1. safaEatohu AlsRamuwmu, (S,) or safaEa AlsRamuwmu wajohahu, (K,) and AlnRaAru, (S,) and AlXRamosu, (TA,) aor.
safaEa
, (K,) inf. n. safoEN, (TK,) The hot wind, (S, K,) and the fire, (S,) and the sun, (TA,) smote, or burned, (S, K,) him, (S,) or his face, (K,) slightly, (S, K,) so that it altered the colour of the external skin, (S,) and, as some add, blackened it; (TA;) as also sfREhu↓, (K,) inf. n. tasofiyEN. (TA.) [It is app. from sufoEapN signifying “ blackness tinged with redness. ”] ― -b2- [And hence,] safaEahu, aor. as above, (K,) and so the inf. n., (TA,) He made a mark upon it: and he made a mark upon it with a hot iron, or with fire. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- Also, aor. as above, (L, K,) and so the inf. n., (L,) (assumed tropical:) He slapped (L, K) it, a man's face, (L,) or him, a man, (K,) with his hand. (L.) And (assumed tropical:) He struck it (a man's neck) with his expanded hand: in which sense it is also written with S. (TA.) And (assumed tropical:) He struck him, or beat him, (K,) with a staff, or stick. (TA.) And (assumed tropical:) He (a bird) slapped it, (S, [in which only the inf. n. is mentioned,] and K,) namely, the object struck by him, (K,) with his wing, (S,) or with his wings. (K: and so [as is implied in the TA] in some copies of the S.) ― -b4- safaEa binaASiyathi, (Lth, S, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) He laid hold upon, or seized, (Lth, S, K,) and dragged, (Lth, K,) his nASyp, (Lth, S, K,) i. e. the fore part of his head (TA) [or his forelock or the hair over his forehead]: or safoEN signifies the laying hold upon, or seizing, the sufoEap of the head, i. e. the black part of its nASyp. (ElMufradát, TA.) You say, safaEa binaASiyapi Alfarasi liyarokabahu [He laid hold upon, or seized, the forelock of the horse, to mount him]. (TA.) And safaEa birijolihi He laid hold upon, or seized, and dragged, his foot. (TA.) And safaEa biyadihi He laid hold upon his hand: (IAar:) or he laid hold upon his hand and raised him: often used in this sense by 'Obeyd-Allah Ibn-Al-Hasan, Kádee of El-Bas- rah. (Sgh.) It is said in the Kur [xcvi. 15], lanasofaEFA biAlnRaASiyapi; (S, K, &c.;) [or lanasofaEaA; (see Oalifu AlnRuwni Alxafiyfapi in art. A;)] the Arabs [sometimes] substituting A for the quiescent n [in a case of this kind]; (Sgh;) i. e. We will assuredly take by the nASyp (Az, S, TA) to the fire [of hell]: (Az, TA:) or we will assuredly lay hold upon his nASyp and drag him thereby with violence to the fire: (Bd:) or we will assuredly drag him thereby to the fire: (O, K:) or we will assuredly blacken his face; the nASyp being put for the face because it is the fore part thereof: (Fr, Az, K:) or we will assuredly mark him with the mark of the people of the fire, (O, K,) making his face black, and his eyes blue: (O:) or we will assuredly abase him: or, render him despicable:
(O, K:) or we will assuredly abase him and make him to stand: so in the L and other lexicons; for these, instead of OwlanuqomiYanRahu in the O and K, have walanuqiymanRahu, and this is shown to be the right reading by the last explanation in the sentence next preceding. (TA.) ＝ -A2- safiEa, aor.
safaEa
, inf. n. safaEN, It (a thing) was, or became, of the colour termed sufoEap, i. e. black tinged, or intermixed, with red. (Msb.)

2 safRaEa
2: see 1; first sentence.

3 sAfEhu c
3. sAfEhu, inf. n. musaAfaEapN, (S, TA,) (tropical:) He slapped him, being slapped by him: he struck him, or beat him, being struck, or beaten, by him: and he fought with him; namely his adversary: (TA:) [or he charged upon, or assaulted, or attacked, him, the latter doing the same; for] musaAfaEapN is like muTaAradapN. (S.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) He embraced him, being embraced by him. (TA.)

5 tsfRE c
5. tsfRE He warmed himself, (K, TA,) biAlnRaAri with the fire. (TA.)

8 AusotufiEa lawonuhu c
8. AusotufiEa lawonuhu His colour became altered by reason of fear, or the like, (K, TA,) as, for instance, disease. (TA.) ― -b2- [AisotafaEa He, or it, became swollen, or affected with a tumour; for] AisotifaAEN is like tahabRujN, (K, TA,) with b before the j. (TA: [in the CK tahayRuj.]) ＝ -A2- AisotafaEa [from safoEN] He (a man) put on, or clad himself with, his garment: and AisotafaEato She (a woman) put on her garments. (TA.)

safoEN mina AlnRaAri c
safoEN mina AlnRaAri A mark, from fire, altering the colour of a man. (TA.) ＝ -A2- safoEN also signifies A garment of any kind: (K:) but mostly such as is dyed: pl. sufuwEN. (TA.) ― -b2- [And hence, perhaps,] The spathe, or spadix, (TaloE,) of a tree called ZimoxN. (AA, T in art. Zmx.)

sufoEN c
sufoEN: see OasofaEu, of which it is pl., though sometimes used as a subst.

safaEN c
safaEN: see sufoEapN.

safoEapN c
safoEapN (assumed tropical:) A stroke from a devil: (TA:) or a touch of madness or diabolical possession, in a person, as though a devil had laid hold upon his naASiyap: (S, TA:) [see safaEa banaASiyatihi:] or a stroke with the evil eye: (TA:) or a stroke of an [evil] eye by which one is affected from the jinn's looking at him; as also naZorapN: (T in art. nZr:) or an evil eye. (K, TA: [in the CK, for safoEapNOIo EayonN, is put safoEapN Oawo EayonN.]) One says, bahi safoEapN In him is a touch of madness, &c. (S.) And OaSaAbatohu safoEapN An evil eye smote him. (K, TA.)

sufoEapN c
sufoEapN Blackness tinged, or intermixed, with redness: (Lth, S, Msb, K:) or blackness that is not much: or blackness with another colour: or blackness with blueness; or, with yellowness; accord. to the Towsheeh: but Lth says that, as meaning a colour, it has the first of all these meanings only: (TA:) or [simply] blackness. (Mgh.) In the face, it is A blackness in the cheeks of a wan, or haggard, woman: (S:) and safaEN↓ [which is properly the inf. n. of safiEa, q. v.,] a blackness tinged with redness in the cheeks of a wan, or haggard, woman, (O, K,) and of a sheep, or goat. (O.) One says also, OaraIfiI wajohihi sufoEapF mino gaDabK (tropical:) I see in his face a change to blackness in consequence of anger. (TA.) The sufoEap of the head is The blackness of its naASiyap [i. e. fore part, or forelock, or hair over the forehead]. (El-Mufradát, TA.) And sufaEN [which is the pl.] signifies Black spots, or specks, on the face of a bull. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A spot of ground, in the traces of a house, differing, in its blackness, from the rest of the colour of the ground: (S, TA:) [i. e. a black, or dark, patch of ground where a house has stood:] or dung of beasts, (K, TA,) or sand, (TA,) or ashes, or sweepings commingled and compacted together, in the traces left by the inhabitants of a house, differing in colour from the ground [around]; (K, TA;) so says Lth. (TA.)

saAfiEN c
saAfiEN [act. part. n. of safaEa,] A man laying hold upon, or seizing, the naASiyap [or forelock] of his horse [to mount him]. (S, * and Ham p. 7.) ＝ -A2- sawaAfiEu [pl. of saAfiEapN,] Burning blasts of the [wind called] samuwm. (S, K.)

OFsofaEu c
OFsofaEu Of a black colour tinged, or intermixed, with redness: (S, Msb:) or black: (Mgh:) applied to a man: (S:) fem safoEaMCu: (Mgh, Msb:) and sufoEN [is the pl., and] signifies blacks inclining to redness. (K.) Applied to an ostrich, i. q. Oarobadu [which is variously explained, as signifying Of a colour inclining to blackness, or of the colour of dust, &c.]. (TA.) And the fem., applied to a ewe, Having black cheeks, the rest of her being white. (TA.) The masc. also signifies A wild bull: (K:) or, applied to a wild bull, it signifies having in his cheeks a blackness inclining a little to redness. (TA.) And The hawk; (K;) because it has spots of black: (Er-Rághib:) all hawks are sufoEN: (S:) and the fem., A pigeon (HamaAmapN); because of the sufoEap upon its neck: (S:) or, applied to a pigeon, it signifies of which the sufoEap is upon its neck, (K, TA,) exclusively of the head, (TA,) in the part on each side of the neck above the ring. (K, * TA.) It is also a name for Sheep, or goats; used when they are called to be milked: (K:) so in the O: but in some copies, and in the TS, for the she-goat: (TA:) thus in the phrase, OaXoli Uilayoka AlOasofaEa [Call thou to thee the sheep, or goats, or the she-goat, to be milked]: (O, TS, K:) mentioned by Ibn-'Abbád. (TA.) ― -b2- Applied to a garment, or piece of cloth, Black. (K.) ― -b3- ↓The pl. is also applied to The OavaAfiIR, (Lth, S, K,) or three stones upon which the cooking-pot is set up; (TA;) because of their blackness: (Lth, Er-Rághib:) [see HaADinN:] and a single one thereof is called safoEaMCu: (K:) or an iron OuvofiyRap [meaning trivet], (K, TA,) upon which the cooking-pot is set up; and this is said to be the primary application. (TA.) ― -b4- sufoEN also signifies The seeds, or grain, of the colocynth; (Ibn-'Abbád, K;) because of their blackness: (TA:) n. un. with p. (K.)

musafRaEN c
musafRaEN applied to a man clad in armour, Black from the rust of the iron. (TA.) Applied to a bull, Having black spots, or specks, on his face. (TA.)

masofuwEN c
masofuwEN A man (I'Ab) smitten by an evil eye. (I 'Ab, K.) ― -b2- masofuwEu AlEayoni A man whose eye is sunk, or depressed, in his head. (I 'Ab, K.) ― -b3- [See also maXofuwEN.]

musaAfiEN c
musaAfiEN (assumed tropical:) Striking, or beating, another, being struck, or beaten, by him. (K.) (assumed tropical:) Charging upon, or assaulting, or attacking, another who is doing the same. (K.) ― -b2- [And hence,] (assumed tropical:) The lion (K, TA) that prostrates his prey. (TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) Embracing. (K.) ― -b4- (tropical:) I. q. musaAfiHN; (Ibn-'Abbád, K;) i. e. having sexual intercourse without marriage. (TA.)

1 safaqa AlbaAba c
1. safaqa AlbaAba, (T, S, Msb, K,) aor.
safiqa
, inf. n. safoqN; (Msb;) and Asfqhu↓; (T, S, Msb, K;) He shut, or closed, the door; (T, S, Msb, K;) or locked it: (Msb:) and in like manner with S [in the place of the s]. (TA.) ― -b2- safaqa wajohahu, (inf. n. as above, TA,) He slapped his face. (IDrd, Msb, K.) [See also Safaqa.] ― -b3- AlsRafoqu fiI AlOasowAqa, occurring in a trad., means The striking of the hands [of the contracting parties] on the occasion of selling and buying [in token of the ratification thereof in the markets]: and so with S. (TA.) ― -b4- safaqa OomoraOatahu, inf. n. as above, i. q. OaSaAbahaA [app. meaning He compressed his wife; like ASAb minohaA]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- safuqa, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
safuqa
, (K,) inf. n. safaAqapN, (S, Msb,) It (a garment, or piece of cloth,) was thick, substantial, close, or compact, in texture; (T, S, Msb, K;) not saxiyf; (T;) contr. of saxufa: (Msb:) [and so Safuqa.]

4 Oasofaqa
4: see above, first sentence. ― -b2- Asfq Alganama He milked the sheep, or goats, but once in the day: and so with S. (TA.) ― -b3- Asfq AlvRawoba He (a weaver) made the garment, or piece of cloth, thick, substantial, close, or compact, in texture. (TA.)

7 Ansfq c
7. Ansfq It (a door) became shut, or closed: (S, TA:) and so with S. (TA.)

OaEoTaAhu safoqapa yamiynihi c
OaEoTaAhu safoqapa yamiynihi i. q. baAyaEahu [He sold and bought with him: he made a covenant, a compact, an engagement, or the like, with him: or he promised, or swore, allegiance to him]: (O, K:) occurring in a trad., related thus and with S. (TA.) ― -b2- And AiXotarayotu AlXRayYayoni safoqapF waAHidapF, (O,) or fiI safoqapK waAHidapF, (K,) I purchased the two things by a single act of purchasing. (O, K.)

safiyqN c
safiyqN, applied to a garment, or piece of cloth, Thick, substantial, close, or compact, in texture. (T, S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- And [hence,] safiyqu Alwajohi (assumed tropical:) A man (S, O, TA) having little shame. (S, O, K, TA.)

safiyqapN c
safiyqapN A broad, thin, long piece of wood, which is put, or laid down, and upon which are then wound the [mats of reeds called] bawaAriIR, (Lth, O, K,) above the house-tops of the people of ElBasrah. (Lth, O. [See also saqiyfapN.]) ― -b2- And Any piece of gold, and of silver, or other metal, that is beaten thin and long. (Lth, O, K. * [See, again, saqiyfapN.])

1 safaka c
1. safaka, aor.
safika
(S, M, O, Msb, K) and
safuka
, (O, Msb, TA, &c.,) inf. n. safokN, (S, O, Msb,) He shed, poured forth, or caused to run or flow, blood, (S, O, Msb, K, TA,) and tears, (S, O, Msb, TA,) and water, and any fluid or liquid, but app. most especially blood. (TA.) ― -b2- And [hence,] safaka AlkalaAma, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) (tropical:) He poured forth speech profusely, (K, TA,) with haste, or quickly. (TA.)

2 sfRkhu c
2. sfRkhu, inf. n. tasofiykN, He fed him (i. e. his guest) with something whereby to content, or satisfy, him, [so as to allay the craving of his stomach,] before the morning-meal; i. q. lamRajahu (O, TA.)

6 tsAfkwA dimaMCahumo c
6. tsAfkwA dimaMCahumo [They contended together in the mutual shedding of blood]. (TA in art. njz)

7 Asfk c
7. Asfk, said of blood, (K, TA,) and tears, and water, and any fluid or liquid, (TA,) It was, or became, shed, poured forth, or caused to run or flow; or it poured forth, or flowed. (K, TA.)

sufokapN c
sufokapN A portion of food that is presented to a guest, to content, or satisfy, him, [so as to allay the craving of his stomach,] before the morningmeal; like lumojapN. (IAar, O, K. *)

safuwkN c
safuwkN: see safRaAkN, in two places. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) The soul: (K:) [like kacuwbN: app. because of its proneness to lying.]

safiykN c
safiykN Blood, (K, TA,) and tears, and water, and any fluid or liquid, (TA,) Shed, poured forth, or caused to run or flow; as also masofuwkN↓ (K, TA.)

safRaAkN c
safRaAkN One who sheds blood, and tears, much; (Msb;) [as also safuwkN↓.] You say safRaAkN lildRimaMCi A great shedder of blood. (TA.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) Eloquent; (Kr, K;) an able speaker. (S, K.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) Mendacious; a great, or habitual, liar; (TA;) as also safuwkN↓, (K,) or safuwkN baAlkalaAmi (TA.)

saAfikN c
saAfikN Shedding, or pouring forth, blood and tears [&c.]. (Msb.) You say EuyuwnN sawaAfiku Eyes shedding, or pouring forth, tears. (TA.) ― -b2- And dumuwEN sawaAfiku [Tears pouring forth; properly] meaning cawaAtu safokK [having a shedding or pouring forth], the latter word being pl. of saAfikapN: so as used in a verse of Mutemmim Ibn-Nuweyreh: but the obviously-right expression is masofuwkapN↓ (Ham p. 370.)

misofakN c
misofakN (assumed tropical:) Loquacious; garrulous. (K, * TA.)

misofuwkN c
misofuwkN: See safiykN and saAfikN.

1 safala c
1. safala, aor.
safula
; (M, MA, Mgh, O, * Msb, K;) and safula, aor.
safula
; (M, Msb, K;) and safila, (O, K,) aor.
safala
; (K;) inf. n. (of the first, Mgh, Msb, TA, and of the last, TA) sufuwlN (M, MA, Mgh, Msb, K) and safaAlN (M, MA, K, TA, in the CK [erroneously] sifAl,) and of the second safaAlapN (TA;) and tsfRl↓; (M, K;) He, or it, was, or became, low; (M, * Mgh, O, K; *) the first contr. of EalaA (Mgh, O;) and the third, of EaliIa; and (assumed tropical:) both are said of a man; (O;) sufuwlN and safaAlN being the contr. of EuluwRN and EalMCN: (S, K:) or became lower than another: (Msb:) [and] the first signifies it descended, subsided, or sank downwards. (MA.) Hence the phrase binotu binoti binotK waUino safalato (assumed tropical:) [A daughter of a daughter of a daughter, and if she be lower in descent]: safulato i. e. with damm to the f, in this case, is a mistake. (Mgh.) And safalato manozilatuhu Einoda AlOamiyri (assumed tropical:) [His station with, or in the estimation of, the commander, governor, or prince, was, or became, low, or lower]. (TA.) And Oamoruhumo fiIsafaAlK (assumed tropical:) [Their case is in a low state]. (TA.) And safala fiIAlXRIoCi, (K, * TA, [in the former of which the context implies that it is safula, but it is]) like naSara, [aor.
safula
,] (TA,) inf. n. sufuwlN, [It subsided in the thing;] it descended from the upper, or uppermost, part of the thing, to the lower, or lowest, part thereof. (K.) ― -b2- And safula, [aor.
safula
,] inf. n. safaAlapN (Fr, S, MA, Mgh, O, K *) and safaAliyapN (MA) and sufolN, (Fr, O,) (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, low, base, vile, ignoble, mean, or sordid; (Fr, S, MA, Mgh, O, K; *) as also safala, with fet-h, (Fr, O,) or safila. (MA.) You say, safala, like qatala, (Msb,) or safula, like karuma, (K,) fiI xuluqihi, and Eamalihi, (Msb, K,) and nasabihi, (TA,) [aor. in either case
safula
,] inf. n. safolN (Msb, K) and sufolN (K) and sifaAlN, (Msb, * K, [in the former without any indication of the syll. signs,]) the last like kitaAbN; (K;) [and app. safila also accord. to the MA, as shown above;] and tsfRl↓, and Astfl↓; (TA;) (tropical:) He was low, base, vile, ignoble, or mean, in his lot, [or, as seems to be indicated in the Msb, inferior to others,] in respect of his disposition, and his deed, and his lineage: (TA:) tsfRl↓ is the contr. of jaAda. (Msb.)

2 tasofiylN c
2. tasofiylN The act of lowering, or depressing; syn. taSowiybN. Sudot;, O.)

3 huwyusaAfilu fulaAnFA c
3. huwyusaAfilu fulaAnFA (assumed tropical:) He vies with, or imitates, such a one in his low, base, vile, ignoble, mean, or sordid, actions. (TA.)

5 tasafRulN c
5. tasafRulN [quasi-pass. of 2,] The being lowered, or depressed; syn. taSawRubN (S, O;) contr. of taEalR. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 1, first sentence: ― -b3- and the same, last sentence, in two places.

8 Uisotafala
8: see 1, last sentence.

sufolN c
sufolN and sifolN↓ (S, M, Mgh, O, Msb, K) [but it is strangely added in the Msb that IKt disallowed the pronunciation with damm] and sifolapN↓ (M, K) and sufaAlahN↓ (S, O, K) The lowest, or lower, part [of a thing]; contr. of EulowN (S, M, Mgh, O, Msb, K) and EilowN (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K) and EilowapN (K) and EulaAwapN; (S, O, K;) [and so saAflapN↓, contr. of EaAlyapN:] kulR XaIoCK sufaAlahu↓ signifies, (K,) or is said to signify, (M,) the lowest, or lower, part of anything; i. e. Oasofaluhu↓ (M, K;) and EulaAwatuhu [The contr., i. e.] OaEolaAhu. (M.)

sifolN c
sifolN: see the next preceding paragraph.

safilN c
safilN from safila, and safiylN↓ from safula, (assumed tropical:) A low, base, vile, ignoble, mean, or sordid, man: (MA:) or safylN↓ signifies low (saAfilN↓) [in condition], deficient in lot, or fortune: (TA:) and safilapN↓, (S, M, MA, Mgh, Msb, K,) said by some to be from this word as signifying the “ legs ” (Mgh, Msb) of a camel (Mgh) or of a beast, or quadruped, (Msb,) and sifolapN↓, (S, M, MA, Mgh Msb, K,) a contraction of safilapN, (S, Mgh, Msb, or it may be pl. of safiylN↓, like as EiloyapN is of EaliIRN, (Mgh,) (assumed tropical:) low, base, vile, ignoble, mean, or sordid, persons; (S, * MA, Mgh, Msb;) or the lowest, or lower, basest, or baser, vilest, or viler, &c., of mankind, or of people; the refuse, or rabble, thereof: (S, * M, K:) and sifilapN↓, with two kesrehs, is a dial. var. of safilapN and sifolapN, mentioned by Sgh and IB on the authority of Yoo and IKh, and is said to mean the lowest, basest, &c., of the low, base, &c.: the pl. of sifolapN↓ is sifalN; (TA;) one should not say, huwa safilapN↓ because this is [used only as] a pl.: (S:) the vulgar say rajulN mino qawomK sifalK sifolapN↓; (S, Mgh; *) but this has been disallowed: (Mgh:) a man is related to have said to his wife, (Mgh, TA,) who had called him sifolapN, (TA,) Uino kunotu sifolapF faOanoti TaAliqN, (Mgh, TA,) meaning If I be low, base, &c., in my intellect and my religion [thou art divorced]; (Mgh;) whence it seems that sifolapN may be applied to a single person; but this requires consideration. (TA.) OayomaAnu AlsRafilapi↓ means (assumed tropical:) [The oaths] of the ignorant: or accord. to Aboo- Haneefeh, of the heretics, or schismatics: such [oaths] are said to be wawajohi QllRehi and waOmaAnapi QllReh. (Mgh.)

sifolapN c
sifolapN see sufolN: ― -b2- and see also safilN, in three places.

safilapN c
safilapN The legs (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) of a camel (S, M, Mgh, K) or of a beast, or quadruped: (Msb:) because they are lowest. (M.) ― -b2- See also saAfilapN: ― -b3- and see safilN, in three places.

sifilapN c
sifilapN see safilN.

sufoliIRu c
sufoliIRu [Of, or relating to, the lowest, or lower, part or place;] a rel. n. from sufolN. (TA.) [Hence, the pl.] sufolyRuwna means Persons alighting,
or abiding, in the lowest, or lower, parts of a country: opposed to EalyRuwna (TA in art. Elw.) ― -b2- It is also opposed to EaliIRN [in relation to condition]: whence the saying, mano yaroHami AlsRufoliIRa yaroHamohu AlEaliIRu (assumed tropical:) He who has mercy on the low in condition, on him will the high in condition have mercy]. (TA.) sufoliyRuwna, meaning (assumed tropical:) Persons low in condition, is opposed to EaliyRuwna, meaning “ opulent persons. ” (TA in art. Elw.)

safiylN c
safiylN: see safilN, in three places.

sufaAlapN c
sufaAlapN see sufolN, in two places. ― -b2- One says, qaEada sufaAlapa AlrRiyHi, and fiI sufaAlapi AlrRiyHi, (M, K, * TA,) or bisufaAlapiAlrRiyH, (S,) [He sat in, or on, the leeward side; like as one says in French, sous le vent;] in, or on, the side, or quarter, towards which the wind blew; (S, M, K, * TA;) and particularly with respect to the object or objects of the chase [in order that his smell might not be perceived thereby]: (TA in the present art. and in art. Elw:) opposed to EulaAwatahaA, and fiI EulaAwatihaA, (M, K, * TA,) or biEulaAwatihaA. (S.)

saAfilN c
saAfilN Low; contr. of EaAlK. (S, Msb, * TA.) See also safilN: and see an ex. voce Oasofalu

saAfilapN c
saAfilapN: see sufolN. ― -b2- [Hence,] saAfilapu AlrRumoHi half that is next to the zujR [or pointed iron shoe, or foot,] of the spear: (M, K:) [opposed to EaAliyatuhu.] ― -b3- And AlsRaAfilapu The bottom, podex, posteriors, or buttocks; and the anus; syn. AlmaqoEadapu, (S,) and AldRuburu; (TA;) as also AlsRafilapu↓; syn. AldRuburu. (L in art. xjr.)

Oasofalu c
Oasofalu Lower, and lowest; contr. of OaEolaI (M, Msb, K:) fem. sufolaI: (TA:) and pl. OasaAfilu. (M, TA.) One says, SaAraOasofala mino gayorihi [He, or it, became lower than another]. (Msb.) And it is said in the Kur [viii. 43], wQlrRakobu Oasofala minokumo The caravan being in a place lower than ye; Asfl being here an adv. n.: or, as some read, Oasofalu minokumo, i. e. being lower than ye. (M.) ― -b2- vumRa radadonaAhu Oasofala saAfiliyna↓, in the Kur [xcv. 5], means (assumed tropical:) [Then we rendered him the lowest of low: or] we reduced him to extreme old age, or decrepitude: or to a state of perishing, or passing away: or to a state of error; relating to him who has disbelieved; (M, K;) for every infant is born of the natural constitution with which he is created in his mother's womb, and he who disbelieves and errs is reduced to this state: (M:) or the meaning is, we have made him to be of the people of the fire [of Hell]: or [we have made him to go down] to the fire [of Hell]. (Bd.) ― -b3- sufolay muDara [The lower of Mudar] is said to denote those of Mudar with the exception of Kureysh and Keys: opposed to EuloyaAmuDara. (TA in art. Elw.) ― -b4- See also sufolN. ― -b5- The pl. OasaAfilu means The lower, or lowest, parts of valleys [&c.]. (TA.) The phrase kilaAbu AlOasaAfili occurs in a verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb as meaning [The dogs] of the lower, or lowest, parts of the valleys. (M.) ― -b6- And (assumed tropical:) The young ones of camels. (As, S, * TA.)

1 safanahu c
1. safanahu, (S, M, L, K,) aor.
safina
, (M, L, K,) inf. n. safonN, (S, M, L,) i. q. qaXarahu [i. e. He divested or stripped it of, or he stripped off, scraped off, rubbed off, abraded, or otherwise removed, its outer covering or integument, or superficial part; he pared it, peeled it, &c.: and he, or it, pared, peeled, stripped, or rubbed, it off; namely, anything superficial and generally a thing adhering to the surface of another thing]. (S, M, L, K.) Imra-el-Keys says,
fajaACa xafiyRFA yasofinu AlOaroDa baTonuhu
taraIAltRuroba minohu laASiqFA kulRa maloSaqi
[And he came clandestinely, his belly paring the ground, thou seeing the dust sticking to him with the utmost sticking]; (S, M, L; but in the S, laAziqFA and malozaqi;) meaning that he came cleaving to the ground in order that the objects of the chase might not see him and flee from him. (S, L.) ― -b2- And He pared and smoothed it; as also sfRnhu↓ [but app. in an intensive sense, or used in relation to several objects]. (M, L.) ― -b3- And safanati AlriyHu AltRuraAba, (M, L,) aor. as above, (L,) and so the inf. n., (M, L,) The wind reduced the dust to a fine powder: (M, L:) or safanat iAlriyHu AltRuraAba Eano wajohi AlOroDi [The wind pared off the dust from the surface of the earth]. (S, L.) ― -b4- And safanati AlrRiyHu, aor.
safuna
, (Lh, M, L, K,) inf. n. sufuwnN, (Lh, M, L,) The wind blew upon the surface of the earth [app. removing the dust]; as also safinati, (Lh, M, L, K,) aor.
safana
. (K.) ― -b5- And AlsRafiynapu tasofinu EalaI wajohi AlOaroDi The ship, or boat, sticks upon the ground. (L.)

2 safRana
2: see the preceding paragraph.

safanN c
safanN A carpenter's adz, or axe, (L,) or a large adz or axe, (M, L,) or a thing (S, L, K) of any kind, (K,) with which one hews, or shapes out, or pares, a thing; as also misofanN↓: (S, L, K:) or an adz with which palm-trunks are pared; as also safarN and XafarN. (ISk, L.) ― -b2- Also Rough skin, (S, M, L, K,) thick, or coarse, (M,) such as the skins of crocodiles, (S, L,) which is put upon the hilts of swords: (S, M, L:) or the skin of the fish called OaTuwm, which is a rough skin, wherewith whips and arrows are rubbed [to smooth them], and which is upon the hilts of swords: (Mgh, L: *) accord. to AHn, (M, L,) a rough piece of the skin of the [lizard called] DabR, or of the skin of a fish, with which the arrow is rubbed so as to remove from it the marks of the paring-knife: (M, L, K:) or, as some say, (M, L,) a stone with which one shapes out, or pares, and smooths: (M, L, K:) sometimes, accord. to Lth, an iron implement with which one rubs wood so as to smooth it: (L:) accord. to AHeyth, a cane which is hollowed, and has some notches cut in it, through which an arrow is put and repeatedly drawn [to smooth it]; also called TariydapN. (L in art. Trd.) See an ex. in a verse cited in art. xwf, conj. 5.

safuwnN c
safuwnN A wind that blows upon the surface of the earth [app. removing the dust]; (M, K;) as also saAfinapN↓: (K:) or the former, a wind always blowing: (L:) and ↓the latter signifies a wind as though wiping the surface of the earth; (A 'Obeyd, L;) or paring it; (L;) or [simply] a wind; (S;) and its pl. is sawaAfinu. (A 'Obeyd, S, L, K.)

safiynN c
safiynN: see safiynapN, in two places.

sifaAnapN c
sifaAnapN The craft, or occupation, of constructing, (M, L, K,) and of navigating, (M, L,) ships or boats. (M, L, K.)

safiynapN c
safiynapN A ship, or boat; (M, L;) of the measure faEylapN in the sense of the measure faAEilapN; (IDrd, S, M, L, Msb;) as though it pared the surface of the water; (IDrd, S, L, Msb;) or so called because it pares [meaning skims] the surface of the water; (M, L;) or because it pares the sands [by running aground] when the water is little [in depth]; or because [in that case] it sticks upon the ground; or it may be from safanN meaning “ a carpenter's adz or axe with which he hews &c., ” and, if so, having the meaning of the measure mafoEuwlapN: (L:) the pl. is safaAYinu and sufunN (M, L, Msb, K) and [coll. gen. n.] safiynN↓: (S, M, L, Msb, K:) the first of these is a regular pl.: (Sb, M, L:) the second is pl. of the third, (Msb,) or it is as though it were pl. of the third: (Sb, M, L:) ↓the third is anomalous, being of a class proper to created things, as in the instances of tamorapN and tamorN, and naxolapN and naxolN, and only heard in a few instances in the cases of things made by art; and some say that it is a dial. var. of safiynapN. (Msb.) [Hence,] AlsRafiynapu (assumed tropical:) [The constellation Argo;] one of the southern constellations, of which the stars are five and forty, the bright great star upon the southern oar being sohayolN [i. e. Canopus], accord. to Ptolemy, and it is the most remote star from the sfynp, in the south, and is marked on the astrolabe; but some of the Arabs say that the bright star at the extremity of the second oar [but what star is meant thereby I know not] is called suhayolN, without restriction. (Kzw.) ― -b2- [Also An oblong book: and a commonplace book: app. post-classical.]

safRaAnN c
safRaAnN A constructor, or builder, of ships or boats: (M, L, K:) and a navigator, (M, L,) or a master, (S, Msb,) of a ship or boat. (S, M, L, Msb.)

safRaAnahN c
safRaAnahN A pearl. (K.)

saAfinapN c
saAfinapN; pl. sawaAfinu: see safuwnN, in two places.

AlsRaAfiynu c
AlsRaAfiynu A certain vein in the inner side of the spine, extending lengthwise, with which is united the niyaAT [q. v.] of the heart. (K.) [Golius and Freytag explain it as meaning the “ Saphæna: ” but this is called AlSRaAfinu.]

siyfanRapN c
siyfanRapN A certain bird [found] in Egypt, that
does not alight upon a tree without eating all the leaves thereof. (K.)

msofanN c
msofanN: see safanN.

UisofandN c
UisofandN and UisofanoTN: see arts. sfd and sfT.

1 safiha c
1. safiha, (S, MA, Msb,) aor.
safaha
; (Msb;) and safuha, [aor.
safuha
;] (S, Msb;) inf. n. safahN and safaAhapN (S, MA, Msb, K *) and safaAhN, (S, MA, K, *) [all mentioned in the MA as of the former verb, and so in the TA when that verb is trans., but properly] the first is of the former verb, and the second is of the latter verb, (S, Msb,) and so is the third; (S;) He (a man, S) was, or became, such as is termed safiyh; (S, TA;) [i. e.] he was, or became, unwise, witless, or destitute of wisdom or understanding, or [rather] lightwitted. (MA.) ― -b2- The phrase safiha nafosapu, [of which an instance occurs in the Kur ii. 124, and] to which gabina raOoyahu and baTira EayoXahu and Oalima baTonahu and wafiqa Oamorahu and raXida Oamorahu are similar, was originally safihato nafosu zayodK [or rather safihato nafosuhu i. e. Himself, or his mind, was, or became, lightwitted, &c.]; but when [the dependence of] the verb became transferred [from the nfs] to the man, what followed the verb was put in the accus. case by being its objective complement, for the phrase became identical in meaning with nafosahu safRaha↓ [he made himself, or his mind, lightwitted, &c.]: so say the Basrees and Ks; and it is allowable with them to make this accus. to precede [the verb]; like as it is allowable to say, gulaAmahu Darab zayodN: (S, TA:) accord. to the K, the verb thus used has three forms; (TA;) you say safiha nafosahu and raOoyahu, (K, TA,) and Hilomahu, (TA,) and safuha, and safaha, meaning Hamalahu EalaIAlsRafahi [which is virtually the same as safRahahu i. e. he made himself, or his mind, lightwitted, or unwise, &c., and in like manner his judgment, or opinion, and he made his gravity, or forbearance, or the like, to become levity, or hastiness, &c.]: or he attributed safah [i. e. lightwittedness, &c., to himself, or his mind, and to his judgment, or opinion]: or he destroyed it; (K, TA;) agreeably with the meaning assigned to safiha nafosahu by AO: (TA:) or this means he held himself in mean, or light, estimation; (MA, and Ksh and Bd in ii. 124;) and rendered himself low, base, or contemptible: (Bd ibid.:) but Lh says that safiha nafosahu, with kesr [to the f], inf. n. safahN and safaAhapN and safaAhN, means Hamalahu EalaI AlsRafahi [or HamalahaA], and is the approved form, and that some say safuha, which is rare: and accord. to J and others, (TA,) when they say sfh nafosahu, and raOoyahu, they do not say it otherwise than with kesr [to the f], because faEula is not trans.: (S, TA:) so that the three forms of the verb mentioned in the K require consideration: (TA:) accord. to Fr, when [the dependence of] the verb in the phrase safiha nafosahu became transferred from the nfs to the possessor thereof, what followed the verb became an explicative, to indicate that the safah [or lightwittedness, &c.,] was therein; and by rule it should be safiha zayodN nafosFA, for the explicative should not be otherwise than indeterminate; but it was left in its state of a prefixed noun, and put in the accus. case in the manner of an indeterminate noun as being likened thereto; [the meaning, therefore, accord. to him, is he was, or became, lightwitted, &c., as to his mind;] it is not allowable, however, in his opinion, to make this accus. to precede [the verb], because the explicative may not precede; and similar to this is the phrase Diqotu bihi caroEFA, and Tibotu bihi nafosFA, meaning DaAqa caroEiIbihi and TaAbato nafosiI bihi: (S, TA:) but this saying [of Fr] is disallowed by the grammarians; for they say that explicatives are indeterminate, and that determinate nouns may not be used as indeterminate: some of the grammarians say that UilRaAmano safiha nafosahu in the Kur [ii. 124] means AlRA mn safiha fiInafosihi [but he who is lightwitted, &c., in his mind], i. e., who becomes safiyh; [the prep.] fI being suppressed [and the noun therefore put in the accus. case agreeably with a general rule]: Zj holds that the approvable saying is, that it means UilRaA mano jahila nafosahu, i. e., but he who is [ignorant or silly or foolish or] unreflecting in his mind: and in like manner, safiha raOoyahu means jahilahu [i. e. he was ignorant, &c., in his judgment, or opinion]; and his judgment, or opinion, was unsound, without rectitude: and safiha nafosahu signifies also he lost himself, or his own soul. (TA.) safiha AlHaqRa is likewise expl. as meaning AlHaqRa safRaha↓ [He made the truth, or right, to be foolishness, or the like]; and Yoo held the one to be a dial. var. of the other, and the measure of the former verb to denote intensiveness; and accord. to this explanation one may say, safihotu zayodFA meaning zayodFA safRahotu↓ [I pronounced Zeyd lightwitted, &c.]: or the meaning is jahila AlHaqRa [he ignored the truth, or right], and he did not see it to be the truth, or right: (TA:) or he regarded the truth, or right, as foolishness, or ignorance. (S and TA in art. gmT.) See also 2. ― -b3- safiha Ealayohi signifies jahila [i. e., when thus trans. by means of EalaI, He feigned ignorance to him]; as also safuha, (K, TA,) and tsAfh↓. (K.) ― -b4- And safihotu naSiybiI [and it is implied in the K that one says safahotu nSybI also, but only the former is authorized by the TA,] I forgot my share, or portion. (Th, K, TA.) ― -b5- And safaha SaAHibahu, aor.
safuha
, He overcame his companion in what is termed musaAfahap [inf. n. of 3, q. v.]. (K.) You say, saAfahahu↓ fasafahahu. (TA.) ― -b6- safihati AlTRaEonapu, (JK, K, TA,) inf. n. safahN, (TA,) (tropical:) The spear-wound, or the like, emitted blood which came from it quickly (JK, K, TA) and dried up (wajafRa [in the TK wixf]): (K, TA:) so in the A. (TA.) ― -b7- safiha AlXRaraAba, (S, K,) inf. n. safahN, (TA,) He drank much of the beverage, or wine, without having his thirst satisfied thereby. (S, K, TA.) See also 3. And safiha AlmaMCa (tropical:) He drank the water immoderately. (TA.) ― -b8- And safihotu and safahotu signify Xugilotu, (so in the CK,) in [some of] the copies of the K Xagalotu, but the right reading is Xugilotu [i. e. I was occupied, or busied, or diverted from a thing]: or, accord. to the copies of the K, taXagRalotu; but correctly, or Xagalotu [i. e. I occupied, or busied, or diverted from a thing]. (TA.)

2 safRaha
2: see 5. ― -b2- [Hence,] sifihihu, inf. n. tasofiyhN, (S, Msb, K,) signifies jaEalahu safiyhFA [i. e. He, or it, made him to be, or he pronounced him to be, lightwitted, &c.]; as also safihahu↓; (K, TA;) on the authority of Akh and Yoo: (TA:) or he attributed to him what is termed safah [i. e. lightwittedness, &c.]: (S, Msb:) or he said to him that he was such as is termed safiyh. Msb.) And sfRh Aljaholu Hilomahu Ignorance made him light, inconstant, unsteady, irresolute, or fickle; syn. OaTaAXahu and OaxafRahu. (TA.) See also 1, in three places.

3 sAfhhu c
3. sAfhhu, (S, MA, K,) inf. n. musaAfahapN, (S, KL,) He acted [in a lightwitted manner,] foolishly, or ignorantly, with him; (MA, KL;) showed lightness, levity, weakness of mind, and lack of Hilom [or gravity, &c.], with him. (KL.) You say, saAfahahu fasafahahu: see 1, near the end of the paragraph. [sAfhh in this instance may mean as above, or may have the meaning here next following.] ― -b2- He reviled him; or he reviled him, being reviled by him; syn. XaAtamahu: whence the prov., safiyhN lamo yajido musaAfihFA↓ [A lightwitted person found not a reviler, or mutual reviler]; (K, TA;) mentioned in the S. (TA.) [See also 5.] ― -b3- sAfh AldRanRa, (S, K,) or AlwaToba, (S,) (assumed tropical:) He sat with (qaAEada) the dnR [or wine-jar], (S, K,) or the wTb [or milk-skin], (S,) and drank from it while after while. (S, K.) And sAfh AlXRaraAba (tropical:) He exceeded the due bounds in respect of the beverage, or wine, drinking it without measure; (K, TA;) as also safihahu↓. (K.) And saAfahotu AlmaMCa (tropical:) I drank the water immoderately, (Lh, TA,) or without measure. (A, TA.) [See also 1, near the end of the paragraph.] ― -b4- And saAfahati AlnRaAqapu AlTRariyqa (tropical:) The she-camel kept to the road, or way, (A, K, TA,) or took to it, (A, TA,) with a vehement pace: (A, K, TA:) or was light, or agile, in her pace, or going. (TA.)

4 Oasofahotuhu c
4. Oasofahotuhu I found him to be safiyh [i. e. lightwitted, &c.]. (TA. [There said to be tropical; but I see not why.]) ― -b2- Oasofahaka QllReh AlXRaraAba (assumed tropical:) May God make thee to drink of the beverage, or wine, without having thy thirst satisfied thereby: or Oasofahahu QllRehu God made him, or may God make him, to drink without having his thirst satisfied: (S, accord. to different copies:) or Asfh QllRehu fulaAnRaA AlmaMCa God made, or may God make, such a one to drink much water. (TA.)

5 tsfRht AlrRiyaAHu c
5. tsfRht AlrRiyaAHu The winds became in a state of commotion. (TA.) ― -b2- tsfRht AlrRiyHu AlXRajara, (S,) or AlguSuwna, (K, TA,) and AlrRiyHu safRahati↓ AlguSuwna, (Ham p. 359,) The wind made the trees, (S,) or the branches, (K,) to bend, or incline: (S, K:) and put the branches in motion: (K,
and Ham ubi suprà:) or ruffled, and put in motion, the branches. (TA. [There said to be tropical: but see what is said of the primary signification of safahN, below.]) ― -b3- [Hence,] it is said in a prov., furaArapN tasafRahato qaraArapF A lamb, or kid, made a sheep, or goat, to incline [to silly behaviour]: applied to the old whom the young incites to lightwittedness (AlsRafah) and levity. (Meyd. [See also a similar prov. in Freytag's Arab. Prov., ii. 253.]) ― -b4- tsfRhhu Eano maAlihi He deluded him, or beguiled him, of his property. (S, K.) ― -b5- tsfRh Ealayohi He acted with safaAhap [i. e. lightwittedness, &c.], or foolishly, towards him. (MA.) ― -b6- And tasafRahotu Ealayohi signifies OasomaEotuhu [as meaning I reviled him]. (S.) [See also 3.]

6 tsAfh Ealayohi c
6. tsAfh Ealayohi: see 1, in the last quarter of the paragraph. ― -b2- [And tsAfhwA They behaved in a lightwitted, foolish, or ignorant, manner, one with another. See also 3, which has a similar meaning. ― -b3- And They reviled one another: as seems to be indicated in the TA. See also Har p. 522: and see, again, 3.] ― -b4- tasaAfahu OaXodaAquhaA, in a verse of Khalaf Ibn-Is-hák El-Bahránee, [describing swift camels,] means Their sides of the mouth casting forth their foam, one at another: like the saying of El-Jarmee,
tasaAfahu OaXodaAquhaA biAllRugaAmi
[Their sides of the mouth casting forth the foam, one at another]. (TA. [tsAfh, there written without any syll. signs, is app. thus, (for tatasaAfahu,) not tusaAfihu.])

safahN c
safahN, (S, TA,) as also safaAhapN↓ and safaAhN↓, (TA,) [all mentioned as inf. ns. in the first paragraph of this art.,] primarily signifies xifRapN [in its proper sense of Lightness], and motion, commotion, or agitation. (S, TA.) ― -b2- And hence (S, TA) the first, (S, K, TA,) like each of the others, (K, TA,) signifies [generally Lightwittedness, or the like;] the contr. of HilomN; (S, K, TA;) [i. e.] xifRapN [as meaning lightness or levity, inconstancy, unsteadiness, irresoluteness; or lightness or levity, &c., and hastiness; for, as is said in the TA in art. rjH, the contr. of HilomN is described by the terms xifRapN and EajalN, like as HilomN is described by the term viqalN]; and slenderness, shallowness, or weakness, of judgment; qualities which deficiency of intellect, or understanding, necessarily involves: (Bd in ii. 12, in explanation of safahN:) or xifRapu HilomK [i. e. slightness of gravity or staidness or sedateness or calmness &c.]: or jaholN [i. e. ignorance, or silliness or foolishness]: (K, TA:) all of which explanations are nearly alike: (TA:) or safahN is a deficiency in intellect or understanding: (Msb:) or a lightness, or levity, accidental to a man, arising from joy or anger, inducing him to act unreasonably and unlawfully. (KT.)

safaAhN c
safaAhN: see the next preceding paragraph.

safyihN c
safyihN [Having the quality termed safahN; i. e., accord. to the explanation of the primary signification of the latter, above, Light; and in a state of motion, commotion, or agitation:] applied to a camel's nose-rein, (S, K,) light: (S:) or quivering; (K, TA;) because of the she-camel's shaking it, and contending in pulling it. (TA: but there said to be, when thus applied, tropical.) Dhu-rRummeh says,
EalaI Zahori miqolaAtK safiyhK jadiyluhaA
i. e. [Upon the back of a she-camel that had brought forth but once and not conceived after,] whose nose-rein was light. (S. In the TA, zimaAmuhaA is here put in the place of jadiyluhaA.) And one says also naAqapN safiyhapu AlzimaAmi, (K, TA,) meaning [A she-camel whose nose-rein is light, or quivering: or] light, or agile, in pace or going. (TA: in which this, also, is said to be tropical.) ― -b2- Also Lightwitted; light of intellect or understanding; (TA;) deficient in intellect or understanding; (Msb;) ignorant; (Mujáhid, K, TA;) weak; foolish, stupid, unsound in intellect or understanding, dull therein, or having little, or no, intellect, or understanding; (Mujáhid, TA;) and saAfihN↓, also, [which is syn. with safiyhN in all the senses mentioned above,] is expl. by IAar as having this last meaning of foolish, stupid, &c.: (TA:) the fem. is safiyhapN: (Msb, K:) and the pl. of the masc., (K,) or of the masc. and fem., (Msb, TA,) is sufahaMCu, (Msb, K, TA,) and of both, sifaAhN, and of the fem., safiyhaAtN also and safaAYihu and sufRahN. (K, TA.) In the Kur ii. 282, safiyhFA means, accord. to Ibn-'Arafeh, Ignorant of the ordinances, or statutes; one who does not dictate well, and knows not what dictation is; for he who is ignorant in all his circumstances may not deal with another upon credit: accord. to ISd, ignorant or Sagiyr [meaning under the age of puberty]; not ignorant of dictating, as Lh asserts it to mean, because it is added, “ or not able to dictate, himself: ” this, says Er-Rághib, denotes safah in respect of worldly matters: in the Kur lxxii. 4, safiyhunaA denotes safah in religion. (TA.) In the Kur iv. 4, the pl. AlsRufahaMC is said to mean Women, and young children; because they are ignorant of the proper object of expense: and I'Ab is related to have said that women are termed AlsRufRahu and AlsRufahaMCu: (Lh, TA:) Az, also, says that a woman is termed safiyhapN because of the weakness of her intellect, and because she does not manage well her property; and in like manner are termed children as long as they are not known to be characterized by maturity of intellect, and rectitude of actions, and good management of affairs. (TA.) ― -b3- vawobN safiyhN (tropical:) A garment, or piece of cloth, badly woven; thin, flimsy, unsubstantial, or scanty in the yarn. (K, * TA.)

safaAhapN c
safaAhapN: see safahN.

saAfihN c
saAfihN: see safyhN. ― -b2- Also, applied to a man, (assumed tropical:) Vehemently thirsty: and so saAhifN. (Az, TA.)

waAdK musofahN c
waAdK musofahN (tropical:) A valley filled [with water]: (K, TA:) as though it exceeded the due bounds, and became such as is termed safiyh: imagined to be from Osofahotuhu signifying “ I found him to be safiyh. ” (TA.)

TaEaAmN masofahapN c
TaEaAmN masofahapN, (K, TA, in the CK [erroneously] musofihN,) as also masohafapN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) Food that incites [in the CK yutoEibu is erroneously put for yaboEatu] to the drinking of much water. (IAar, * K, TA.)

musaAfihN c
musaAfihN act. part. n. of 3, q. v.

1 safaA c
1. safaA, (S, M,) aor. yasofuw, inf. n. sufuwRu, (S, TA,) like EuluwRu, (TA,) or safowN, (so accord. to a copy of the M,) He was quick, or swift, in walking, or going, and in flying. (S, M.) ＝ -A2- safati AlrRiyHu AltRurAba, (S, M, Mgh, K,) aor. tasofiy, (S, K,) inf. n. safoyN, (S, M,) The wind raised the dust, or made it to fly, and carried it away, or dispersed it; (S, Mgh, K;) and cast it: (Mgh:) or bore it, carried it, or carried it away; (M, K;) as also Oasofatohu↓, (K,) a dial. var. of weak authority, mentioned by Sgh on the authority of Fr; (TA;) [or it may be thus expl. by a mistake originating from the fact that] IAar mentions safati AlrRiyHu and Osofato, [as syn.,] but [in a sense to be expl. hereafter,] not making either of them trans.: (M:) [and saAfati↓ AlrRiyHu AltRuraAba occurs in the M and L in art. snf:] and tasofiy bihi, relating to the wind and the dust, also occurs; the b being redundant, or added because the verb implies the meaning of ramat [which is trans. by means of bi]. (Mgh.) ― -b2- And safati AlriyHu The wind blew; as also Osofat↓. (IAar, TA.) And safato Ealayohi AlriyaAHu [The winds blew upon him, or it]. (Z, TA.) ― -b3- And safaI AltRuraAbu, aor. yasofiI, [The dust, or earth, poured down,] the verb being intrans. as well as trans. (Ham p. 454. [It is there indicated that the meaning is AinohaAla.]) ＝ -A3- safiIa: see safFA, below. ＝ -A4- safiyato yaduhu His hand became much cracked, or chapped, (K, TA,) in consequence of. work. (TA.) ＝ -A5- And safiIa, [aor. yasofaI,] inf. n. safFA and safaMCN, He was, or became, lightwitted; or unwise, witless, or destitute of wisdom or understanding; i. q. safiha, inf. n. safahN and safaAhN; (M, K;) as also AsfI↓. (Az, K.)

3 sAft AlriyHu AltRuraAba c
3. sAft AlriyHu AltRuraAba: see 1. ＝ -A2- sAfAhu, (S, K,) inf. n. musaAfaApN and sifaMCN, i. q. saAfahahu [He acted in a lightwitted manner, foolishly, or ignorantly, with him]. (S, K.) ＝ -A3- And He treated him medically, or curatively: (K:) from safaMCN. (TA. [But see sifaMCN, below.])

4 AsifI c
4. AsifI He took for himself a mule such as is termed safowaMC, i. e. quick [&c.]. (K.) ＝ -A2- Osofato said of the wind, intrans. and trans.: see 1, in two places. ＝ -A3- AsfI said of corn, It became rough, or coarse, in the extremities [or awn] of its ears. (S, K.) ― -b2- Asft said of buhomaI [or barley-grass], It let fall its safaA [or prickles, or awn, or extremities]. (M, K.) ― -b3- And AsfI said of a man, He took the prickles [or awn or extremities] of the buhomaI [or barley-grass]. (TA.) ＝ -A4- Also, said of a man, He removed dust, or earth, (safFA, TA) from one place to another.
(Az, K.) ＝ -A5- And Asft said of a she-camel, (tropical:) She became lean, or emaciated, (K,) so that she was like the safA [or prickles of barley-grass]. (TA.) ＝ -A6- See also 1, last sentence. ＝ -A7- AsfAhu It (an affair, or event, M) incited him (a man, K) to unsteadiness, and levity. (M, K.) ― -b2- And hence, perhaps, (M,) AsfI bihi He did evil or ill, or acted ill, to him, or with him, (M, K,) i. e., his companion. (M.)

8 AstfI wajohahu c
8. AstfI wajohahu i. q. AiSoTarafahu, (Sgh, K,) i. e. He turned away his face. (TK.)

safFA c
safFA Lightness, thinness, or scantiness, in the hair of the forelock, (S, M, Mgh, K,) of the horse, in which it is discommended, (S, * Z, Mgh,) and of the mule and ass, in both of which it is commended: (Z, Mgh:) or shortness, and scantiness, of the forelock: accord. to Th, it is safaMCN↓, with medd: which is metaphorically used by a poet as meaning scantiness in milk. (M.) [Accord. to the TK, the former is an inf. n., of which the verb is safiIa↓, said of a horse, as meaning He was, or became, light, thin, or scanty, in the forelock.] ― -b2- And, accord. to IAar, A whiteness [or a tinge thereof] in the hair [of a horse]: particularly said by him in one place to be such as is termed Oadoham, and such as is OaXoqar. (M, in art. sfw.) ＝ -A2- Also, [but more properly written safFI, the last radical in this case being Ii,] Dust, or earth; (S, M, K;) and so saAfK↓: (TA:) or this is applied to earth, or dust, [as meaning pouring down,] from safaI AltRuraAbu [expl. above]: (Ham p. 454:) the former signifies dust, or earth, though not raised and carried away, or dispersed, by the wind: or, accord. to the T, whatever is raised and carried away, or dispersed, by the wind: (TA:) accord. to IAar, dust, or earth, taken forth from a grave or a well: (M:) safaApN is a more special term, (S,) the n. un., (M,) safaApN mino turaAbK signifying a collection (kubRapN) of dust, or earth. (Ham p. 810.) ＝ -A3- Also Any kind of tree having prickles, or thorns: (K: [but this seems to have been erroneously taken from what here follows:]) the prickles [or awn or beard] of buhomaI [or barley-grass], (S, M,) and of the ears of corn, [of wheat or barley, (TA in art. xdX,)] and of anything having prickles: accord. to Th, the extremities of buhomaI: n. un. safaApN, as above. (M.) ＝ -A4- Also Leanness, or emaciation, (K, TA,) in consequence of disease. (TA.) ＝ -A5- It is also an inf. n. of safiIa as syn. with safiha, expl. above. (M, K.)

safaMCN c
safaMCN: see the first sentence of the next preceding paragraph: it is expl. in the K [and also in the M] as signifying A stopping, stopping short, or ceasing, of the she-camel's milk: and ISd cites [in the M, after Th], from a poet, the phrase faI OalobaAnihinRa safaMCu [ending a verse,] referring to [she-camels such as are termed] qalaAYiS: but Az relates it differently, fiI OalobAbihinRa with b [in the place of n]; saying that safaMCN means lightness, or levity, in anything; and ignorance; and that the phrase, as he cites it, means in whose faculties of understanding is lightness. (TA.) [See 1, last sentence: and] see also what next follows.

sifaMCN c
sifaMCN, accord. to the K, signifies A medicine, or remedy: [see 3, last signification:] but this requires consideration; for it is said in the M, [AlsRafaMCu↓ signifies unsteadiness, and levity; and IAar says,] AlsRafaMCu from AlsRafiIRu is like AlXRaqaMCu from AlXRaqiIRu. (TA.)

safiIRRu c
safiIRRu Dust raised, or made to fly, and carried away, or dispersed, by the wind; (S, K;) and (K) so saAfK↓, (M, K,) i. q. masofiIRN↓; a possessive epithet, or of the measure faAEilN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN. (M. [See another explanation of saAf voce safFA, from the Hamáseh. Freytag explains both safiIRN and saAfK, as on the authority of the K, as epithets applied to the wind, not to the dust.]) ― -b2- Also Clouds; [app. as being driven by the wind;] syn. saHaAbN. (S.) ＝ -A2- And i. q. safiyhN [Lightwitted, &c.: see 1, last sentence]. (M, K.) [And it seems to be indicated in the S that saAfK↓ is syn. with saAfihN, which is syn. with safiyhN.]

safRaMCN c
safRaMCN: see musofK.

saAfK c
saAfK: fem. saAfiyapN, pl. sawaAfK: see this last in the next paragraph: ― -b2- and for the first, see safFA: and safiIRN, first sentence. ＝ -A2- See also safiIRN again, last sentence.

saAfiyaMCu c
saAfiyaMCu Dust, syn. gubaArN: (M, K:) or dust (turaAbN) and dry herbage or the like: (Ham p. 445:) or dust (turaAbN) with the wind: (M:) or wind that bears, or carries, or carries away, dust, (M, K, TA,) much, upon the surface of the earth, impelling it against men: (TA, and in like manner in the Ham ubi suprà:) and riyaAHN sawaAfK↓, (TA,) pl. of riyHN saAfiyapN, (Ham ubi suprà,) winds that raise the dust, or make it to fly, and carry it away, or disperse it: you say, laEibato bihi AlsRawaAfaI [The winds raising the dust, &c., made sport with him, or it]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Also Tracks, or streaks, upon a pool put in motion by the wind: so says Freytag; but he names not any authority for this.]

OsofaI c
OsofaI applied to a horse, (As, S, M, Mgh,) Light, thin, or scanty, in the hair of the forelock: (As, S, M, Mgh, K:) or short and scanty therein: fem. safowaMCu: (M:) [and accord. to some, it seems to be in like manner applied to a mule and an ass: (see safFA:)] one says farasN OasofaI and bagolapN safowaMCu: (Mgh:) [or,] accord. to As, OasofaI in the sense first expl. above is not applied to anything but a horse: applied to a mule, it means (assumed tropical:) quick, or swift: (S:) or bagolapN safowaMCu signifies (tropical:) a she-mule that is quick, or swift, (S, M, A, K, TA,) like the wind, (A, TA,) active, or light, (S,) of middling make, compact and strong in the back; (M, TA;) and in like manner safowaMCu is applied to a wild she-ass. (M.) ― -b2- Accord. to IAar, AlOasofaI applied to the horse signifies AalRaciy tanoziEuhu XaEarapN bayoDaMCu [app. meaning Distinguished by some white hairs, though I find no authority for thus rendering the verb here used] whether he be bay or of some other colour: or having that whiteness of the hair which is termed safFA [expl. above], which is particularly said by him in one place to be in such as is termed Oadoham, and such as is OaXoqar: and the fem. in this sense also is as above. (M.) ― -b3- One says also riyHN hawojaMCu, meaning (tropical:) A swift wind; like as one says musofK. (TA.)

musofK c
musofK [and, accord. to Golius, safRaMCN↓, mentioned by him as on the authority of the K, in which, however, I do not find it, nor did Freytag,] A calumniator, or slanderer. (K.)

masofiIRN c
masofiIRN: see safiIRN.

1 saqiba c
1. saqiba, aor.
saqaba
, inf. n. saqabN, He, or it, was, or became, near. (Msb.) saqabN is syn. with qurobN. (S, A, K.) You say, saqibato daAruhu, (S, and so in the K accord. to the TA,) with kesr [to the q], (S,) [inf. n. as above;] or saqabat, (so in the CK and in my MS. copy of the K and in my copy of the Mgh,) inf. n. saqobN, (so in my copy of the Mgh,) or suquwbN; (K;) [but I believe the verb to be correctly saqibat, like its syn. Saqibat, and the inf. n. to be correctly saqabN, and perhaps suquwbN also;] His house was near; (S, Mgh, K;) as also Oasoqabat↓. (S, K.) It is said in a trad., AljaAru OaHaqRu bisaqabihi, meaning [The neighbour has a better, or the best, claim to pre-emption] by reason of his being near: (S, * A, Msb:) or the b is a connective of AHqR with its complement, (Mgh, Msb,) not to denote a cause, (Mgh,) and bisaqabihi is expl. as meaning biAlXRufoEapi; (Mgh, Msb;) i. e. the neighbour has a better, or the best, claim to AlXRufoEap [or pre-emption], when his house is contiguous: (Mgh:) IAth says that it is adduced as an evidence that AlXRufoEap belongs to the neighbour though not a sharer; i. e., that he has a better claim thereto than one who is not a neighbour: but some explain AljAr as meaning the partner, or sharer: or the meaning of the trad. may be, the neighbour has a better, or the best, claim to kindness and assistance because of his being near. (L, TA. [See also another reading (biSaqabihi), and explanations thereof, in art. Sqb.])

4 Asqbhu c
4. Asqbhu He made him, or it, to be near: (K:) or Asqb daArahu he made his house to be near. (S.) [And so with S.] ＝ -A2- See also the paragraph above. ＝ -A3- Oasoqabato is also said of a she-camel, meaning She brought forth mostly males. (A, * TA.) [And Asqb He got, or got mostly, male offspring.] In the following saying, (S, TA,) of Ru-beh, describing the two parents of a man eulogized [by him], (TA,)
wakaAnati AlEirosu AlRRatiI tanaxRabaA
lifaHolK OasoqabaA garRaMCa misoqaAbFA↓
[And the wife whom he chose was generous, or noble, or fair, one that brought forth, or brought
forth mostly, male offspring, to a male that begot, or begot mostly, such offspring,] the last word is a verb, in the pret. tense, not an epithet applied to fHl. (S, * TA. [In the former, only the second hemistich is cited.])

6 tsAqbt OaboyaAtuhumo c
6. tsAqbt OaboyaAtuhumo was probably used as meaning Their tents, or houses, were near together: see the part. n. of this verb below.]

saqobN c
saqobN The young one of a camel: or, when just brought forth: (K:) or only the male young one of a camel: (S, K:) [see also SaqobN:] when a she-camel has brought forth her young one, the latter, when just born, is called saliylN, before it is known whether it is a male or a female; but when it is known, if it is a male, it is called saqobN: (As, TA:) the female is not called saqobapN, (S, K,) but HaAYilN: (S:) or it is [sometimes] called by the former of these appellations: (K:) [see De Sacy's Chrest. Arabe, 2nd ed., ii. 358: and see saqobapN below:] the pl. is OasoqubN [a pl. of pauc.] and siqaAbN and suquwbN and suqobaAnN. (K.)
OacalRu mina AlsRuqobaAni bayona AlHalaAYibi
[More vile than the male young ones of camels among the milch camels] is a prov. [from a verse of Keys Ibn-El-Khateem]. (TA.) ― -b2- Tall: (K: [see also sakobN:]) or anything tall, together with plumpness; or fatness, softness, thinness of the skin, and plumpness. (S. [See also SaqobN.]) Applied to a branch, Juicy, thick, and long: (Az, TA: [and so SaqobN:]) or anything of the like kind full and complete. (ADk, TA.) In the following verse, cited by Sb,
wasaAqiyayoni mivola zayodK wajuEalo
saqobaAni mamoXuwqaAni makonuwzaA AlEaDalo
saqobaAni signifies TawiylaAni [tall], and is also written SaqobaAni: (Sh, TA:) [so that the meaning may be, And two waterers, or givers of drink, like Zeyd and Jo'al: they being two tall persons, light of flesh, compact in the muscles: I suppose humaA to be understood before the latter hemistich; because of the ns. in the nom. case: and I have substituted makonuwzaA for manokuwzaA, the reading in the TA, doubtless a mistranscription:] or it is for mivola saqobayoni [meaning like two male young ones of camels]. (L, TA.) ― -b3- And The pole of a [tent such as is called] xibaMC; (S, K;) as also saqiybahN↓: and so SaqabN: (S:) pl. of the first siqobaAnN. (K.)

saqabN c
saqabN inf. n. of saqiba [q. v.]. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- See also saAqibN, in three places.

saqobapN c
saqobapN The female foal of a wild ass. (S, K, * TA.) ― -b2- [See also saqobN, of which, in the first of the senses assigned to it above, it is said by some to be the fem.]

siqaAbN c
siqaAbN A bit of cotton which a woman afflicted (K, TA) by the death of her husband, in the Time of Ignorance, after shaving her head, and scratching her face, (TA,) used to make red with her blood, (K, TA,) i. e. her own blood, (TA,) and put upon her head, making its extremity to protrude from a hole, or rent, of her qinaAEi [or head-covering], in order that people might know her to be so afflicted. (K, * TA.)

suquwbN c
suquwbN a pl. of saqobN [q. v.]. (K.) ― -b2- Also The hind legs of camels: (IAar, K:) pronounced also with S. (IAar, TA in art. Sqb.)

saqiybN c
saqiybN: see saAqibN.

saqiybapN c
saqiybapN: see saqobN, last sentence. ― -b2- Also A baker's kneading-board: or his rolling-pin. (MA.)

saAqibN c
saAqibN [in the CK vAqb] Near; (A, Msb, K;) and likewise with S; (A;) as also saqytN↓ (Msb) and saqabN↓, [likewise pronounced with S,] (Mgh, K, * TA,) for cuw saqabK, or it may be an inf. n. used as a subst. or an epithet, (Mgh,) and musoqibN↓. (K, * TA.) You say makaAnN saAqibN A near place: (A:) and manozilN saqabN↓ and musoqibN↓ a near place of alighting or abode: (K, * TA:) and mino daArihi daAriIsaqabN↓ My house is near his house. (Mgh.) ― -b2- Also Distant: (Msb, K:) this meaning is mentioned by some, as well as the former: (Msb:) thus it has two contr. meanings: (K:) the latter of these is mentioned in the Mj; and the following verse is cited as a proof thereof;
tarakota OabaAka biOaroDi AlHijaAzi
waruHota UilaI baladK saAqibi
[Thou leftest thy father in the land of El-Hijáz, and wentest to a distant country]. (MF, TA.)

sawoqabN c
sawoqabN A man tall and slender. (Suh, TA.)

Oasoqabu c
Oasoqabu or OaSoqabu, occurring in a trad., accord. to different relaters, Nearer [and nearest]. (TA in art. Sqb.)

musoqibN c
musoqibN: see saAqibN, in two places.

misoqabN c
misoqabN The dam of a saqob [q. v.]; as also masoqaAbN↓: (K:) [or] the latter signifies a she-camel that usually brings forth males. (S.)

misoqaAbN c
misoqaAbN: see what next precedes: and see a verse cited above, conj. 4.

OaboyaAtuhumo mutasaAqibapN c
OaboyaAtuhumo mutasaAqibapN Their tents, or houses, are near together. (K.)

1 saqara AlXRamosu c
1. saqara AlXRamosu, (S,) aor.
saqura
, inf. n. saqorN, (TA,) The sun scorched, or burned, him, altering the colour of his complexion and shin, (S, * TA,) and pained him, or pained his brain by its heat: (TA:) melted and heated him, or it. (TA.) And saqaratohu AlnRaAru The fire altered the colour of his skin; or scorched his skin, and altered its colour; as also Saqaratohu. (Bd in liv. 48.)

saqorN c
saqorN The heat, and hurtful action, of the sun. (K.)

saqaru c
saqaru Hell: (S, K:) one of the [proper] names thereof: (S:) Aboo-Bekr says, There are two opinions respecting this word: some say, that the fire of the world to come is thus called, and that the derivation of the word is unknown, and that it is imperfectly decl. because it is determinate and a foreign word: others say that it is from saqaratohu AlXRamosu, because it melts the bodies and souls, and that it is an Arabic word; and he who holds it to be such says that it is imperfectly decl. because it is determinate and of the fem. gender. (TA.)

saqaraAtN c
saqaraAtN The vehemence of the stroke of the sun. (S.)

musomaqirRu c
musomaqirRu A day vehemently hot. (S in this art., and K in art. smqr.) This is its proper place. (TA.)

suquroqaEN c
suquroqaEN, an arabicized word from sukurokah, (S, K,) [or sukuroGaho, so written in Persian,] A certain beverage, (O, K,) the wine of the Abyssinians, (S,) made from curap [or millet]: (S, K:) or a certain beverage of the people of El-Hijáz, from barley and [other] grains; to which they have become addicted: (Lth, K:) Lth says, (TA,) it is an Abyssinian word, (K, TA,) not of the language of the Arabs, because (TA) there is not in the language a quinqueliteral-radical word having damm to the first syllable and fet-h to the last, (K, TA,) except such as is reduplicative, like curaHoraHN. (TA.) [See also sukurokapN, and mizorN, and gubayoraMCu.]

1 saqaTa c
1. saqaTa, (S, M, &c.,) aor.
saquTa
, (M, MS,) inf. n. suquwTN (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and masoqaTN, (S, K,) It fell; fell down; dropped; dropped down; tumbled down; (M, Mgh, Msb, K;) upon the ground; (Mgh;) or from a higher to a lower place; (Msb;) namely, a thing from the hand; (S;) or from a high place, as a roof of a house; and from a low place, as when said of a person in an erect posture; (B;) also said of a building; (TA in art. hwr;) and of a jurof [q. v.]: (Msb and TA in that art.:) [and often used by anatomists and physicians, as meaning it delapsed; it slipped, or fell, down:] and AisRaAqaTa↓ [originally tasaAqaTa] signifies the same; (K;) as in the phrase in the Kur [xix. 25], tasRaAqaTo Ealayoki ruTabFA janiyRFA, or yasRaAqaTo, accord. to different readings, It, namely the palm-tree (naxolap) accord. to the former reading, and the trunk (jicoE) accord. to the latter reading, shall drop upon thee with fresh ripe dates, plucked; rTbA jnyRA being transferred from its proper place, and used as a specificative; the meaning being, yasRaAqaTo ruTabu AljicoEi: so says Fr. (Az, TA.) [This phrase of the Kur, with the above-mentioned explanation, but less fully given, occurs in a copy of the S which, throughout this art., differs much from other copies.] You say also, saqaTa fulaAnN magoXiyRFA Ealayohi [Such a one fell down in a swoon]. (TA.) And mano naAzaEa OaTowala minohu saqaTa AlXRagozabiyRapa [He who contends with one taller than himself falls by the trick which consists in one's twisting his leg with the leg of the other]. (TA.) ― -b2- saqaTa Alwaladu mino baToni Oumihi, (Kh, S, Msb, K,)
inf. n. suquwTN, (Msb,) The child, or fœtus, came forth [or fell] from the belly of its mother (Msb, K) abortively, or in an immature, or imperfect, state, (Msb,) or dead, (A,) but having the form developed, or manifest: (Msb:) you do not say waqaEa (Kh, S, Msb, K) unless the child is born alive. (A, TA.) ― -b3- suqiTa fiIyadihi, and fI OusoqiTa↓ ydh, (Fr, Zj, S, M, K,) but the former is more common, and better, (Fr,) the latter allowed by Akh, but disallowed by AA and by Ahmad Ibn-Yahyà [i. e. Th], (S,) [lit. There was a falling, and there was a making to fall, upon his hand; i. e., of his hand upon his hand, or of his teeth upon his hand, by reason of repentance, and grief, or regret; meaning] (tropical:) he repented, (Fr, Zj, S, M, K,) of what he had done; and grieved for, or regretted, an act of inadvertence; (Zj, M;) or, and became confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course: (O, K:) or both signify, (TA,) or signify also, (K,) or the former signifies also, (M,) he slipped; fell into an error, or a fault; committed a mistake. (M, K.) Hence the saying in the Kur [vii. 148], walamRaA suqiTa fiI Oayodiyhimo (tropical:) And when they repented: (S:) or struck their hands upon their hands, by reason of repentance; accord. to AAF: (M:) or repented greatly; because he who repents, and grieves, or regrets, bites his hand in sorrow, so that his hand is fallen upon [by his teeth]: (Bd:) the phrase was not known to the Arabs before the time of the Kur-án: (O:) it has also been read saqaTa fI Aydyhm, (Akh, S, M,) as though AlnRadamu were understood; (Akh, S;) i. e. saqaTa AlnRadamu; like as you say, qado HaSala fiI yadihi mino hecaA makoruwhN, likening what comes into the heart, and into the mind, to what comes into the hand, and is seen with the eye: (M, TA:) and this, as well as the former, is tropical. (TA.) ― -b4- saqaTa Alqamaru (tropical:) The moon set: and in like manner AlnRajomu [the star, or asterism; generally meaning the Pleiades; and when this is the case, the phrase in most instances means the Pleiades set at dawn: see masoqTN]. (Mgh, TA.) ― -b5- saqaTa AlrRajulu (tropical:) The man died. (TA.) ― -b6- [And (assumed tropical:) The man tottered by reason of age.] You say of an old man, saqaTa mina Alkibari (assumed tropical:) [He tottered by reason of age]. (S in art. drhm.) ― -b7- saqaTa UilaIRa Alqawomu, (M, K,) inf. n. suquwTN, (TA,) (tropical:) The people, or company of men, alighted at my abode: (M, K, TA:) they came to me.
