(TA.) saqaTa UilaI jiyraAnK lahu, occurring in a trad., means (tropical:) He came to some neighbours of his, and they gave him refuge, and protected him. (M, TA.) And it is said in a postclassical prov., HayovumaA saqaTa laqaTa [Wherever he alights he picks up something]: applied to him who practises evasions, shifts, artifices, or the like. (Meyd, and Har p. 660.) ― -b8- saqaTa EalaI DaAlRatihi (tropical:) He stumbled upon, lighted on, or became acquainted with, the place of his stray, or lost, beast; he lighted on his stray, or lost, beast. (TA.) Mohammad said to El-Hárith Ibn-Hassán, on the latter's asking him respecting a thing, EalaI Alxabiyri saqaTota (tropical:) On the possessor of knowledge thou hast lighted: and this is a prov. current among the Arabs. (TA.) And it is said in a prov.,
saqaTa AlEaXaMCu bihi EalaI siroHaAni
(assumed tropical:) [The evening-meal, or supper, (i. e. the seeking for it,) made him to fall, or light, upon a wolf: or srHAn, as is said in a copy of the S, is here the name of a certain man: see also art. srH]: applied to him who seeks an object of desire, and falls into a thing that destroys him. (TA.) ― -b9- saqaTa also signifies He descended [from the place which he occupied], and his place became vacant. (TA.) And you say, saqaTa fulaAnN mino manozilatihi (tropical:) [Such a one fell from his honourable station]. (TA.) And saqaTa fulaAnN mino EayoniI (tropical:) [Such a one fell from the place which he held in my regard]. (TA.) saqaATapN, as an inf. n., meaning (assumed tropical:) The being ignoble in respect of the deeds or qualities of one's ancestors, and of oneself, [as though its verb were saquTa,] is a mistake, although it has been used, for the purpose of assimilation, coupled with waqaAHapN. (Mgh.) ― -b10- [Also, (assumed tropical:) He dropped off; fell behind: he, or it, remained behind, or in the rear. See saAqiTN.] ― -b11- saqaTa Eani AlTRariyqi (assumed tropical:) [He deviated from the road]. (IAar, TA in art. fjr.) ― -b12- saqaTa fiI kalaAmihi, (M, K,) and bikalaAmihi, (TA,) inf. n. suquwTN; (M, TA;) and fI klAmh OasoqaTa↓; (S, TA;) (tropical:) He committed a mistake in his speech. (M, K, TA.) And takalRama famaA saqaTa bikalimapK, (M, TA,) and kalimapF maA OasoqaTa↓, and fiI kalimapK maAOasoqaTa↓, (M, K,) (tropical:) He spoke, and did not commit a mistake in a word. (M, K, TA.) And takalRama bikalaAmK famaA saqaTa biHarofK, and HarofFA maA OasoqaTa↓, [held by him on whose authority it is mentioned to mean (assumed tropical:) He spoke speech, and did not drop a letter, or a word; for this is] said by Yaakoob to be like daxalotu bihi and Oadoxalotuha, &c. (S.) ― -b13- saqaTa cikoruhu (assumed tropical:) [The mention of him, or it, was, or became, dropped, left out, or omitted]. (TA, passim.) And saqaTa AlrRajulu (tropical:) The man's name fell out, or became dropped, from the register of soldiers or pensioners. (TA.) ― -b14- saqaTato quwRatuhu duwna buluwgi AlOmori [His power fell short of the attainment or accomplishment, of the affair.] (TA in art. crE.) ― -b15- [saqaTa, inf. n. suquwTN, likewise signifies (assumed tropical:) It (a claim or demand, a due, an argument or a plea, a condition, a law, a command or prohibition, a gift, a reward, a punishment, a good action, a sin, &c.,) became null, annulled, void, of no force, or of no account; as though it fell to the ground, or became dropped; whence saqaTa Hukomuhu, by which phrase baTala, q. v., is expl. in the Msb.] You say, saqaTa AlfaroDu (assumed tropical:) [The assigned, or appointed, gift, or soldier's stipend or pay, became annulled], meaning saqaTa Talabuhu waAlOamoru bihi (assumed tropical:) [the demand for it and the order for it became dropped]. (Msb.) And UicaASaHRati AlmawadRapu saqaTatN XuruwTu AlOadabi wa AltRakoliyfi (assumed tropical:) [When love, or affection, is free from imperfection, the conditions of politeness and constraint become annulled]. (TA.) And saqaTato xaTaAyaAhu (assumed tropical:) His sins fell [from him]; went away; or departed. (TA in art. xr.) ― -b16- saqaTa AlHarRu, (M, K,) aor.
saquTa
, inf. n. suquwTN, (M,) (tropical:) The heat fell [like as one says of rain]; (M, K;) it befell; (TA;) it came. (K.) But saqaTa EanRaA AlHarRa (assumed tropical:) The heat left us or quitted us: (IAar, M, K:) as though the verb had two contr. significations. (M, K. *) ― -b17- saqaTa AlHadiyvu minoka Uilayohi waminohu Uilayoka (tropical:) [Discourse fell from thee to him, and from him to thee]: (M:) or saqaTa mino kulK EalaI AlARxari (tropical:) [it fell from each to the other]. (K.)

3 sAqThu c
3. sAqThu, (S, M, K,) inf. n. musaAqaTapN and siqaATN, (M, K,) i. q. OasoqaTahu↓ [q. v.]: (K:) or he made it to fall, fall down, drop, drop down, or tumble down, in consecutive portions or quantities; syn. taAbaEa UisoqaATahu [in the CK AasoqATahu]: (M, K:) or it has both of these significations. (So in the L, and in some copies of the S; but in one copy of the S, the former only is mentioned.) A poet says, (S, M,) namely Dábi Ibn-El-Hárith ElBurjumee, (TA,) describing a [wild] bull and the dogs, (S,)
yusaAqiTu Eanohu rawoquhu DaAri yaAtihaA
siqaATa Hadiydi Alqayoni Oaxowala OaxowalaA
[His horn makes to fall consecutively from him those of them that were trained for hunting, as the iron of the blacksmith makes sparks to fall consecutively, scattered about]. (S, M.) ― -b2- sAqT Alxayola (tropical:) He (a horse) outstripped the [other] horses: (TA:) [as though he made them to drop behind him, one after another.] ― -b3- sAqThu AlHadiyva, (M, K,) inf. n. siqaATN (S, M, A) and musaAqaTapN, (TA,) (tropical:) [He discoursed with him alternately;] discourse fell (saqaTa) from each of them to the other, (M, K,) so as that one discoursed, and the other listened to him, and when he became silent, he who had been silent discoursed: (S, K:) or he discoursed to him telling him thing after thing. (A, TA.) ― -b4- kaAna yusaAqiTu celika Eano rasuwli QllRehi (assumed tropical:) He used to relate that from the Apostle of God amid his discourse; as though he mixed his discourse therewith. (TA, from a trad.) ＝ -A2- sAqT Alfarasu AlEadowa, (M, K,) inf. n. siqaATN, (S, M, K,) (tropical:) The horse came [running] in a slack, or languid, manner: (S, * M, K, TA:) or siqaATN in a horse is the incessantly having the foot wounded and made to bleed by stones, or hurt thereby. (A, TA.) You say also farasN rayRvu AlsiqaATi (assumed tropical:) A horse slow in running. (TA.) ― -b2- sAqT AlrRajulu, inf. n. siqaATN, (tropical:) The man failed of attaining to the condition of the generous, or noble. (TA.)

4 AsqThu c
4. AsqThu He made it to fall, fall down, drop, drop down, or tumble down; threw it down; dropped it; let it fall; (S, * M, Mgh, Msb;) upon the ground; (Mgh;) or from a higher to a lower place. (Msb.) See also 3, first sentence. ― -b2- OasoqaTatN, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) or AsqTt waladahaA, (M, K,) or the latter is wrong, (MF,) for the Arabs disused, as some say, the objective complement after this verb, scarcely, or never, saying OasoqaTato siqoTFA, nor do they say, OusoqiTa Alwaladu, (Msb, MF,) or the lawyers use these last two phrases, but they are not Arabic, (Mgh,) or a phrase like the last, i. e. OusoqiTati AlOajinRapu, occurs in an Arabic verse, (TA,) She (a pregnant female, Mgh, Msb, or a woman, M, B, and so in a copy of the S, or a camel or other animal, as in some copies of the S and in the O, or, accord. to El-
Kálee, only said of a woman, like as AjhDt is only said of a she-camel, TA,) cast her young one, or fœtus or her young; brought forth her young one, or fœtus, or her young, abortively, or in an immature, or imperfect, state, (S, * M, Msb, K, B,) or dead, (Mgh,) but having the form developed, or manifest. (Mgh, Msb.) ― -b3- OusoqiTi fiI yadihi: see 1. ― -b4- AsqThu AlsRuloTaAnu (tropical:) [The Sultán made him to fall, or degraded him, mino manozilatihi from his honourable station]. (TA.) ― -b5- [AsqT also signifies (assumed tropical:) He dropped, left out, or omitted, a letter of a word, a word of a phrase, &c.] You say, AsqT HarofFA, and kalimapK, and fiI kalimapK, and fiIkalaAmihi: see 1. And AsqT AlfaAriDu Qsomahu (tropical:) The appointer, or registrar, of the stipends of soldiers or pensioners dropped, left out, or omitted, his name. (TA.) ― -b6- [Also (assumed tropical:) He, or it, annulled; made, or rendered, null, void, of no force, or of no account; he rejected; said in relation to a claim or demand, a due, an argument or a plea, a condition, a law, a command or prohibition, a gift, a reward, a punishment, a good action, a sin, &c.; of any of these you say, AsqThu, and AsqT Hukomahu: see an ex. voce hadara: and see 1, near the end of the paragraph. Hence,] AsqT mina AlvRamani kacaA (assumed tropical:) He abated of the price so much; syn. HaTRa. (Mgh and Msb in art. HT.) ― -b7- AsqThu is erroneously put in the K, in one instance, for AstsqThu. (TA.) See 5. ＝ -A2- OasoqaTuwA lahu biAlkalaAmi (tropical:) They reviled him with evil speech. (TA.)

5 tsqRThu c
5. tsqRThu (tropical:) He sought his mistake, or error: (S, K, TA:) (tropical:) he strove, or laboured, to make him commit a mistake, or an error; or to make him lie; or to make him reveal what he had to tell; (M, K, TA;) as also AstsqThu↓; (M, TA;) in the copies of the K, OasoqaTahu↓, which is a mistake. (TA.) ― -b2- tsqRT Alxabara (tropical:) He took, or received, the news, or information, by little and little; (K, TA;) thing after thing: mentioned by Aboo-Turáb, on the authority of Abu-l-Mikdám EsSulamee. (TA.)

6 tsAqT c
6. tsAqT: see its variation AisRaAqaTa in 1; first sentence. ― -b2- It fell in consecutive portions or quantities [like the leaves of a tree, &c.; by degrees; gradually]. (M, K.) A poet says,
kanajomi AlvRurayRaA waOamoTaArihaA
wayawomK tasaAqaTu lacRaAtuhu
i. e. (assumed tropical:) [Many a day] of which the pleasures come one thing after another; [such a day being like the asterism of the Pleiades, and the pleasures thereof like its rains;] meaning the abounding of its pleasures. (TA.) And you say, tasaAqaTa UilaIRa xayoru fulaAnK (tropical:) [The wealth of such a one fell, or came, to me, one thing after another]. (TA.) ― -b3- tsAqT EalaI AlXRaINCi He threw himself upon the thing. (S.) You say, tsAqT EalaI AlrRajuli yaqiyh binafosihi [He threw himself upon the man, protecting him with his own person]. (TA.)

10 UisotasoqaTa
10: see 5.

saqoTN c
saqoTN: see siqoTN, in three places: ＝ -A2- and saqiyTN, in two places: ― -b2- and saAqiTN: ― -b3- and saqoTapN.

suqoTN c
suqoTN: see siqoTN, in three places.

siqoTN c
siqoTN and suqoTN↓ and saqoTN↓ A child, or young one, or fœtus, that falls from the belly of the mother abortively, or in an immature, or imperfect, state, (S, M, Msb, K,) or dead, (Mgh,) but having the form developed, or manifest; (Mgh, Msb;) for otherwise it is not so called; (Mgh;) whether male or female: (Msb, TA:) the first of these three forms is the most common: and the pl. is OasoqaATN. (TA.) The reward which a father will receive for such offspring is [held to be] more than that for adult offspring. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (M, B, TA,) the same three words, (K,) or siqoTu AlnRaAri and suqoTuhaA↓ and saqoTuhaA↓, (S, M, Msb,) (tropical:) What falls, (S, M, Msb, K,) of fire, (S,) from the zanod, (Msb,) or between the zanodaAni, (M, K,) when one produces fire, (S,) or before the emission of the fire is thoroughly effected: (M, K:) masc. and fem. (Fr, S, K.) ― -b3- Also siqoTu ramolK and suqoTuhu↓ and saqoTuhu↓ (S, M, Msb, K,) and masoqaTuhu↓ (M, K) and masoqiTuhu↓ (M, TA) [The fall, or slope, of a tract, or quantity, of sand;] the place where sand [falls, or slopes, and] ends: (S:) or the place to which the extremity of sand extends: (Msb:) or the place where the main portion of sand ends, and where it [falls, or slopes, and] becomes thin; (M, K;) for it is [derived] from suquwTN [inf. n. of 1]. (M.) ― -b4- Also siqoTN (tropical:) The edge, or extremity, of a cloud: (M, K:) or the part of a cloud where the edge, or extremity, is seen as though it were falling upon the earth, in the horizon. (S.) ― -b5- And hence, or from the same word as used in relation to sand, (TA,) (tropical:) The similar part of a [tent of the kind called] xibaMC: (S:) or the lowest strip of cloth, that is next the ground, on either side of a xbMC: (A, TA:) or the side of a xbMC: (K:) or [each of] the two sides thereof. (M.) ― -b6- Also, (S, M, K,) and siqaATN↓ and masoqaTN↓, (M, K,) (tropical:) The wing; (K;) each of the two wings; (S, M;) of a bird; (M, K;) or of a male ostrich. (S.) And siqoTu janaAHi AlTRaAYiri (tropical:) The part of the wing of the bird which it drags upon the ground. (S, TA.) ― -b7- [And hence,] siqoTaA AllRayoli (tropical:) The two sides of the darkness of night; (TA;) the beginning and end thereof; (S, TA;) as also siqaATaAhu↓: (TA:) whence the saying of the poet, (S, TA,) namely Er-Rá'ee, (TA,)
HatRaI UicaAmaA OaDaMCaAlSRuboHu wa OanobaEavato
Eanohu naEaAmapu ciI siqoTayoni muEotakiri
(tropical:) [Until, when the dawn shone, and the blackness of confused night became dispelled from it]: he means by nEAmp the “ blackness ” of night: he says that the night, having its beginning and end, passed, and the dawn shone clearly. (S, TA.)

saqaTN c
saqaTN What is made to fall, thrown down, or dropped, of, or from, a thing, (M, K,) and held in mean estimation: (TA:) and [in like manner] suqaATapN↓ the refuse of anything; (IDrd;) or what falls, of, or from, a thing, (M, K,) and is held in mean estimation; (TA;) as also suqaATN↓; (K;) or, accord. to some, this last is a pl. [or rather a coll. gen. n.], and suqaATahN↓ is its sing. [or n. un.]; and suqaATaAtN is also a pl. of this last. (TA.) [Hence,] saqaTu AlTRaEaAmi (tropical:) What is worthless, of food: (M, K: *) or what falls from, or of, food: (M:) and [in like manner] suqaATapN↓ and suqaATN↓ refuse that falls, and is held in mean estimation, of, or from, food and beverage and the like: (TA:) the pl. of saqaTN is OasoqaATN. (K.) And saqaTu AlmataAEi (tropical:) What is worthless, paltry, mean, vile, or held in little account, of the furniture or utensils of a house or tent, or of household goods: (S, Msb, K:) or the refuse thereof; (Mgh;) and so AlmataAEi suqaATapu↓: (TA:) and saqaTu Albayoti signifies the same; (M;) or such articles of the tent or house as the needle and the axe and the cookingpot and the like: (Lth:) pl. as above. (M.) And hence, MasoqaATu AlnRaAsi (q. v. infrà, as also saqaTu AlnRaAsi, voce saAqiTN). (Lh, M.) saqaTN also signifies (assumed tropical:) Things of which the sale is held in mean estimation; such as the seeds that are used in cooking, for seasoning food; and the like; (M, TA;) or such as sugar and raisins. (A, TA.) Also (assumed tropical:) The parts of a slaughtered beast that are held in mean estimation; such as the legs and the stomach and the liver, and the like of these: pl. as above. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) A mistake, or an error, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) in speech, (M, Msb, K,) in reckoning, (S, M, K,) in writing, (S, M, Mgh, K,) and in action; (Msb;) as also siqaATN↓. (M, K.) [See also saqoTapN↓.] ― -b3- (tropical:) A disgraceful; or shameful, thing; a vice, or fault, or the like. (M, K, TA.) ― -b4- saqaTu AlkalaAmi (tropical:) Evil speech. (TA.)

saqoTapN c
saqoTapN [A fall: or] a violent fall. (M, TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) A slip, lapse, fault, or wrong action; as also siqaATN↓; (S, K;) and saqoTN↓; which last is also used in a pl. sense: (TA:) or the second (sqAT) is pl. of saqoTapN: (Msb, K:) as sing., it is an inf. n. of saAqaTa: (TA:) and saqoTapN also signifies a bad word or saying, that swerves from rectitude: (TA in art. Ewr:) its pl., or one of its pls., is saqaTaAtN. (TA.) You say, laAyaxoluw OaHadN mino saqoTapK (tropical:) [No one will be free from a slip]. (TA.) And AlkaAmilu mano EudRato saqaTaAtuhu (tropical:) [The perfect is he whose slips are so few that they may be counted]. (TA.)

saqaTiIRu c
saqaTiIRu (Mgh, K) and saqRaATN↓, (S, Mgh, K,) the latter disallowed by some, (Mgh, TA,) but occurring in a trad., (S, Mgh, TA,) A seller of what is worthless, or mean, or vile, of the furniture or utensils of a house or tent, or of household goods; (S, K;) or of the refuse thereof; (Mgh;) of what are termed saqaTu AlmataAEi: (S, Mgh, K:) those who disallow the latter epithet term such a person SaAHibu saqaTi: (TA:) or ↓the latter epithet signifies a seller of things of which the sale is held in mean estimation; such as the seeds that are used in cooking, for seasoning food; and the like; which are termed saqaTN. (M.) [See also OasoqaATiIRN.]

saqaATN c
saqaATN: see saqRaATN.

suqaATN c
suqaATN: see saqaTN, in two places.

siqaATN c
siqaATN What falls from palm-trees, of unripe dates: (K:) or such are termed siqaATu AlnRaxoli: (M:) sqAT, thus used, may be a sing., or pl. of saAqiTN [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) Dates that are brought from El-Yemámeh by those who journey thither to procure them. (M, K.) ― -b3- See also saqoTapN: and saqaTN, near the end of the paragraph: ― -b4- and see siqoTN, in two places, near the end of the paragraph.

saquwTN c
saquwTN: see saAqiTN.

saqiyTN c
saqiyTN Hoar-frost, or rime; i. e. dew that falls and congeals upon the ground; (S, M, K;) also called jaliydN and DariybN; (S in art. jld;) of the dial. of Teiyi. (M.) ― -b2- Snow; (S, TA;) as also saqoTN↓. (K, TA.) ― -b3- Hail: (K:) or this is called saqiyTu AlsRaHaAbi. (M, TA.) ― -b4- What falls, or has fallen, of dew, (M, K, TA,) upon the ground; (M, TA;) as also saqoTN↓. (K, TA.) ― -b5- durRNsaqiyTN Scattered pearls. (TA.) And waraqN siqaATN [Scattered leaves]: the latter word is pl. of saqiyTN, like as TiwaAlN is pl. of TawiylN. (TA.) ― -b6- See also saAqiTN. ＝ -A2- A whelp; syn. jirowN. (TA.) ＝ -A3- It is also said by some to signify Baked pottery; but the correct word in this sense is with X. (TA.)

suqaATapN c
suqaATapN: see saqaTN, in four places.

saqiyTapN c
saqiyTapN: see saAqiTN, in two places.

saqRaATN c
saqRaATN (S, Sgh, L, K) and saqaATN↓, (K,) or saqRaATN waraMCa AlDRariybapi, (M,) A sword that falls behind the object struck therewith, cutting it so as to pass to the ground: (S, K:) or that cuts the object struck therewith, and then reaches to what is after it: (M, K:) or that cleaves so as to reach to the ground after cutting: (IAar, M:) or that passes through the object struck therewith, and then falls. (Expos. of the Deewán of the Hudhalees.) ＝ -A2- See saqaTiIRN, in two places.

suqRayoTN c
suqRayoTN i. q. HabRu AlEaziyzi [The small tubercles that compose the root of the cyperus esculentus: or that plant itself]. (TA.)

suqRaATapN c
suqRaATapN [A door-latch;] a thing that is put over the upper part of a door, and that falls upon it, so that it becomes fastened. (TA.)

saAqiTN c
saAqiTN Falling; falling down; dropping; dropping down; tumbling down; as also saquwTN↓; (M, K;) which latter is both masc. and fem. (M, TA.) ― -b2- saAqiTapN↓ [its fem., as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates,] A fruit that falls before maturity: pl. sawaAqiTu: which also signifies what falls from palm-trees: or branches that fall; not fruits. (Mgh.) ― -b3- huwa saAqiTN fiI yadihi: see masoquwTN. ― -b4- laAqiTapN likulRi saAqiTapK↓ (tropical:) For every saying that falls from one, there is a person who will take it up: (Msb:) or for every word that falls from the mouth of the speaker, there is a person who will hear it and pick it up and publish it: a prov., relating to the guarding of the tongue: (TA:) the p in lAqTp is either to give intensiveness to the meaning or for the purpose of assimilation. (Msb.) ― -b5- mino HarK sawaAqiTu↓ (tropical:) Fallings of heat. (M, TA.) [See 1, near the end of the paragraph.] ― -b6- saAqiTN also signifies Hanging down; pendent; pendulous: and the pl. is suqRaATN. (TA.) ― -b7- [And Tottering by reason of age.] You say XayoxN saAqiTN kibarFA [An old man tottering by reason of age]. (K in art. drhm.) ― -b8- Also (assumed tropical:) Low, ignoble, base, vile, or mean, in respect of the deeds or qualities of his ancestors, and of himself; (S, Mgh;) and so saAqiTapN↓: (S:) or, (assumed tropical:) in respect of the deeds or qualities of his ancestors, and of his race; and so saAqiTapN↓: (TA:) (assumed tropical:) one who is not reckoned among the better, or best, class of young men; as also saqoTN↓: (K:) (tropical:) one who is, or remains, behind, or in the rear of, other men: (M, K:) [obscure, unnoted, reputeless, or of no reputation:] pl. suqRaATN (S, Mgh, TA) and saqoTaI (S, TA) and siqaATN, which last is like niyaAmN as pl. of naAYimN, and suqaTaMCu, [by rule a pl. of saqiyTN, which see in what follows,] and sawaAqiTu↓ [is pl. of saAqiTapN]. (TA.) The epithets saAqiTN maAqiTN laAqiTN are used together, as signifying (assumed tropical:) Low, ignoble, base, vile, or mean; applied to a man; as is said in the L: or, accord. to the O, [and the S in art. mqT,] the Arabs say, in reviling, fulaAnN saAqiTu bonu maAqiTi boni laAqiTK, meaning Such a one is a slave of a slave of a slave of a freedman, son of a slave of a slave of a freedman, son of a slave of a freedman; the sAqT being the slave of the mAqT, and the mAqT being the slave of the lAqT, and the lAqT being the slave of the freedman. (TA.) suqRaATu AlnRaAsi signifies, accord. to IAar, (assumed tropical:) The refuse, rabble, or lowest or basest or meanest sort, of mankind, or of people; (TA in art. xXr;) as also AlnRaAsi saqaTu↓, (TA,) and AlnRaAsi OasoqaATu↓, as being likened to those articles of a tent or house which are termed saqaTN, q. v.: (Lh, M:) and suqRaATu Aljunodi (assumed tropical:) Soldiers of whom no account is made. (TA.) saAqiTapN↓, (M, L, TA,) in the K saqiyTapN↓, but this is a mistake, (TA,) or, applied to a man, only used when immediately followed by laqiyTapN, (TA in art. lqT,) also signifies (assumed tropical:) Deficient in intellect, or intelligence, or understanding; (M, L, K;) as also saqiyTN↓; (Ez-Zejjájee, M, L, K;) and saqiyTap↓ is the fem. of the latter; (M, L, TA;) and signifies also, applied to a woman, (assumed tropical:) Low, ignoble, base, vile, or mean, (S, TA,) and stupid. (So in some copies of the S, and in the TA.) You say also, AlfiEoli huwa saAqiTapu↓ (assumed tropical:) [He is mean in conduct: or one of whose actions no account is made]. (TA.) ― -b9- Also, [as signifying (assumed tropical:) Vile, mean, or paltry,] applied to a thing: (TA in art. lqT:) [a thing] (assumed tropical:) falling short of the due, or just, mean. (M in art. wsT.) ― -b10- saAqiTu AlXRadi (assumed tropical:) A horse that runs interruptedly. (A, TA.) ― -b11- sawaAqiTu↓ (tropical:) Persons who come to El-Yemámeh to bring thence for themselves provisions of dates. (M, K, TA.) ― -b12- And ↓this last word, (assumed tropical:) Small, low mountains, [as though] cleaving to the ground. (TA.)

saAqiTapN c
saAqiTapN, and its pl. sawaAqiTu: see saAqiTN, throughout.

OasoqaATiIRu c
OasoqaATiIRu (assumed tropical:) One who sells the parts of a slaughtered beast that are called saqaTN [q. v.]. (TA.) [See also saqaTiIRRN.]

misoqiTN c
misoqiTN (S, M, K) and masoqaTN, (M, K,) the former extr. [with respect to rule, though the contr. with respect to usage], (M,) and the latter an inf. n. as well as a noun of place [and of time], (S, K,) A place [and a time] of falling, falling down, dropping, dropping down, or tumbling down, (S, M, K,) of a thing; (M, TA;) as, for instance, of a whip, and of rain: pl. masaAqiTu. (TA.) ― -b2- masoqiTu AlrRaOosi, (K,) and masoqaTuhu, (As,) and AlmsqT alone, (A, TA,) (tropical:) The place of birth. (K, TA.) You say, hecaAmasoqiTu raOosiI (tropical:) This is my birthplace. (S.) And AlbaSorapu masoqaTu raOosiI (tropical:) [El-Basrah is my birth-place]. (M.) And huwa yaHinRu UilaImasoqiTihi (tropical:) He yearns towards his birth-place. (A, TA.) ― -b3- QtaAnaA fiI masoqiTi AlnRajomi (tropical:) He came to us at the time of the setting of the star, or asterism; (S, TA;) [meaning, at the time of the auroral setting of the Pleiades: see manaAzilu Alqamari, in art. nzl.] ― -b4- masoqiTN also signifies The place of the ending of anything. (TA.) See siqoTN, in three places.

musoqiTN c
musoqiTN Casting her young one or fœtus; bringing it forth abortively, or in an immature, or imperfect, state, (M, K,) [or dead, but having the form developed, or manifest: see 4.]

entry.key: hecaA AlfiEolu masoqaTapN laloUinosaAna mino OaEoyuni AlnRaAsi

superEntry.entry:
hecaA AlfiEolu masoqaTapN laloUinosaAna mino OaEoyuni AlnRaAsi c
hecaA AlfiEolu masoqaTapN laloUinosaAna mino OaEoyuni AlnRaAsi (tropical:) [This deed is a cause of a man's falling from the place which he holds in the regard of people]: (S, K: *) said when one does a thing that is not proper for him to do. (TA.)

misoqaATN c
misoqaATN Accustomed to cast her young; to bring them forth abortively, or in an immature, or imperfect, state, (K,) [or dead, but having the form developed, or manifest: see 4.]

tamorapN masoquwTapN c
tamorapN masoquwTapN [A fallen date]: some say that this means saAqiTapN: others, caAtu suquwTK [having a falling]: it may be from OasoqaTihu; like maHomuwmN from OaHamRahu QllRehu. (TA.) ― -b2- huwa masoquwTN fiI yadihi (tropical:) He is repenting, and abject; as also fiI saAqiTN↓ yadihi (TA.)

maXaI mutasaAqiTFA c
maXaI mutasaAqiTFA (tropical:) [He walked, or went, in a slack, or languid, manner; as though repeatedly stumbling; or as though throwing himself down: see 3, near the end; and see also 6]. (A in art. TrH.)

1 saqafa Albayota c
1. saqafa Albayota, (S, O, Msb, K,) aor.
saqufa
, (S, O, Msb,) or
saqafa
, (K, [but this is app. a mistake, being anomalous,]) inf. n. saqofN, (S, O, Mgh,) He made a saqof [i. e. ceiling, or roof,] to the house or chamber or tent; [he ceiled it, or roofed it;] (S,
O, Msb, K;) as also Asqfhu↓; (Msb;) and sqRfhu↓, inf. n. tasoqiyfN; (O, K;) or this last has an intensive signification. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- saqifa, [aor.
saqafa
,] inf. n. saqafN, He was, or became, tall, and bent, or bowed; said of a man, and of an ostrich, &c. (TA.) ＝ -A3- See also 5.

2 saqRafa
2: see 1. ＝ -A2- suqifa, inf. n. tasoqiyfN, He was made an OusoqufR [i. e. a bishop]. (O, K.)

4 Oasoqafa
4: see 1.

5 tsqRf c
5. tsqRf He became an OusoqufR [i. e. a bishop]; (O, K;) as also sqf↓ [app. saqafa], inf. n. siqRiyfaI [like xiliyfaI inf. n. of xalafa]. (TK.)

saqofN c
saqofN The ceiling, roof, or covering, (JK, MA, PS,) of a house or chamber or tent; (JK, S, MA, K, PS;) as also saqifN↓; (K;) so called because of its height, and the tallness of its wall [or walls]: (TA:) pl. of the former suquwfN and suqufN, (S, Msb, K,) the latter pl. on the authority of Akh, (S,) extr., (Msb,) or, accord. to Fr, this is pl. of saqiyfN↓, (S, Msb, TA,) or, accord. to Fr, it may be a pl. pl., i. e. you may say saqofN and suquwfN and [then] suqufN [as pl. of suquwfN], (TA,) and suqofN [also] is a pl. of saqofN. (Ham p. 227.) [In the Kur xliii. 32,] Aboo-Jaafar read saqofFA mino fiDRapK; with fet-h: (TA:) others read suqufFA: (S, TA:) in the former reading, it is a sing. denoting a pl. meaning; i. e., “ we would have made to the house of every one of them a saqof of silver. ” (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] The sky, or heaven: (S, K:) this is called saqofu AlOaroDi [the ceiling, or roof, of the earth]: of the masc. gender: occurring in the Kur xxi. 33 and lii. 5. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, applied to the laHoI [or part on which the beard grows] Long, and flaccid, or pendulous; syn. TawiylN musotaroxK. (S, K.) ＝ -A3- See also OusoqufRN.

suqofN c
suqofN: see OusoqufRN. ＝ -A2- Also a pl. of saqofN [q. v.: perhaps a contraction of suqufN]. (Ham p. 227.)

saqafN c
saqafN Tallness, with a bending, or bowing: (S, K:) it is in a man, (S,) [and] in an ostrich &c. (K.) [See 1, second sentence.]

AlsRuqafaMCa c
AlsRuqafaMCa in the saying of El-Hajjáj, UiyRaAIawahecihi OlsRuqafaMCa [Beware ye of me with respect to these sqfAC], (S, K, * TA,) is [said to be] a word of which the meaning is unknown: (S:) Kt says, “ I have asked often respecting it, and no one knew it: ” but accord. to Z, as is related by IAth, (TA,) it is said to be a mistranscription for AlXRufaEaMC, (K, * TA,) pl. of XafiyEN; (TA;) for they used to assemble in the presence of the Sultán and intercede for him who was suspected, (K, TA,) and for criminals; and he [i. e. El-Hajjáj] forbade their doing that. (TA.)

saqiyfN c
saqiyfN: see saqofN, in two places: ― -b2- and see also the paragraph here following, in two places.

saqiyfapN c
saqiyfapN A SufRap, (S, Msb, K, TA,) or the like, (TA,) [i. e. a roof, or covering,] such as projects [over the door of a house], (TA,) [or of which the ends of the beams rest upon opposite houses; i. e.] a ZulRap; [often applied in the present day to a roofed, or covered, portion of a street or the like;] and any wing or porch or other thing [of a building] that is roofed over: (Msb:) of the measure faEiylapN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlapN: (TA:) pl. saqaAYifu (Msb) and [coll. gen. n.] saqiyfN↓. (MA.) ― -b2- Any broad piece of wood, such as a plank, or a broad piece of stone, with which one may form a roof (O, K, TA) to the lurking-place of a hunter &c. (O, TA.) And [the pl.] saqaAYifu signifies The TwAyq [app. a mistranscription for TawaAbiq, and, if so, meaning, agreeably with a modern usage, flat stones covering a hollow such as that] of the lurking-place of the hunter. (TA.) [And The pieces of wood which form the roof of the kind of vehicle called maHomil: see EaAriDapN: and see also xucoruwfN.] ― -b3- (tropical:) A plank [app. of the deck] of a ship or boat: (S, K, TA:) pl. as above. (S, TA.) ― -b4- (tropical:) A single cranial bone of the head of the camel: (Ibn- 'Abbád, K, TA:) the cranial bones being termed saqaAYifu AlrRaOosi. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.) ― -b5- And (tropical:) A single rib of a camel: (K, TA:) its ribs being termed saqaAYifu (Az, Z, O, TA) and saqiyfN↓. (O, TA.) One says, hadama AlsRafaru saqaAYifa AlbaEiyri [Travel disjointed, or luxated,] the ribs of the camel. (Az, Z, TA.) ― -b6- Also (tropical:) A splint; i. e. a piece of wood with which a bone is set, or reduced from a fractured state: (O, K, TA:) pl. as above. (O, TA.) ― -b7- And A broad and long piece of wood, which is put, or laid down, and upon which are wound the mats of reeds (AlbawaAriIR) above the house-tops of the people of El-Basrah. (TA. [See also safiyqapN.]) ― -b8- And (assumed tropical:) Any piece of gold, and of silver, that is beaten thin and long. (TA. [See, again, safiyqapN.])

saqRaAfN c
saqRaAfN One whose occupation is the construction of ceilings or roofs (suquwf). (TA.)

siqiyfaI c
siqiyfaI [and OusoqufiyRapNi↓ or OusoqufiyRapN] The office of an OusoqufR [i. e. of a bishop]. (K, * O, TA.) [See also 5.]

Oasoqafu c
Oasoqafu Tall, and bent, or bowed; (S, K;) applied to a man, (S, TA,) and to an ostrich, &c.; (K, TA;) as also with damm, (K,) i. e. AusoqufN↓: (TA:) fem. saqofaMCu, (K,) mentioned by IB as an epithet applied to a female ostrich: (TA:) and hence the OusoqufR↓ of the Christians, (S, K,) accord. to ISk [and others ignorant of its true derivation], because he affects lowliness. (S.) And, applied to a man, [simply,] Tall; (K;) likened to the saqof [or ceiling, or roof,] in height; (TA;) and so musaqRafN↓: (O, K:) or thick and big in the bones: (K:) and [simply] bent, or bowed: (TA:) and, applied to an ostrich, crooked in the neck (K, TA) and the legs: (TA:) fem. as above; (K;) which is applied to a female ostrich as meaning long and crooked in the legs: (O:) or to a she-camel as meaning long in the hind legs, and in like manner applied to a she-ostrich. (JK.) ― -b2- And, applied to a camel, Having no fur upon him. (K.)

OusoqufN c
OusoqufN: see the next preceding paragraph: ― -b2- and the next following also.

OusoqufRN c
OusoqufRN and OusoqufN↓, (S, Msb, K,) as also saqofN↓ (K) and saqofN↓, (TA,) [each a variation of] a foreign word used by the Arabs, (TA,) [from the Greek ἐπίσκοπος, A bishop; i. e.] a headman of the Christians (S, Msb, K) in religion; (S, K;) or [more exactly] one who is above the qisiys [i. e. presbyter, or priest], and below the maToraAn [or metropolitan]: (K:) or one who is learned (K, TA) in their religion: (TA:) or a king who affects lowliness in his gait: (K: [a very strange explanation:]) pl. OasaAqifapN (Msb, K) and OasaAqifu. (K.) See also Oasoqafu.

OusoqufiyRapN c
OusoqufiyRapN or OusoqufiyRapN: see siqiyfaI.

musaqRafN c
musaqRafN Wide in the bone [or bones] of the body. (JK.) ― -b2- See also Oasoqafu.

XaEarN musaqofafN c
XaEarN musaqofafN, (K accord. to the TA,) or musotaqifRN↓, (so in several copies of the K,) or both, (TK,) Hair that is raised, and shaggy, or dishe-velled, or disordered. (K.)

musotaqifRu c
musotaqifRu: see what next precedes.

1 saqima c
1. saqima, aor.
saqama
; (S, Msb, K;) and saquma, aor.
saquma
; (Msb, K;) inf. n. saqamN, (S, Msb, TA,) of the former verb; (S, Msb;) and suqomN, of the latter verb, (Msb,) and saqaAmapN and saqaAmN, (TA,) [also of the latter verb, the last like jamaAlN of jamula, &c.,] or the last is a simple subst.; (Msb;) He was, or became, diseased, disordered, distempered, sick, or ill; syn. mariDa: (S, K, TA:) or he was long diseased &c. (Msb.) [See also suqomN below.]

2 saqRama
2: see what next follows.

4 Asqmhu c
4. Asqmhu, (S, Msb, TA,) inf. n. UisoqaAmN; (TA;) and sqRmhu↓, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. tasoqiymN; (TA;) He (God) [or it] caused him to be, or become, diseased, disordered, distempered, sick, or ill: (S, TA:) or caused him to be long diseased &c. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- And Oasoqama AlrRajulu The man had his family affected with diseases, and the diseases came afterwards upon him. (TA.)

suqomN c
suqomN and saqamN↓ and saqaAmN↓ [are all inf. ns.; or the last, accord. to the Msb, is a simple subst.; and all are used as substs., signifying] A disease, disorder, distemper, malady, sickness, or an illness; syn. maraDN: (S, K, TA:) suqomN and maraDN are both said to be in the body, and also (assumed tropical:) in religion [&c., as is implied by phrases mentioned below, voce saqiymN]: (Aboo-Is-hák, TA in art. mrD:) pl. [of the first] OasoqaAmN. (TA.) saqamu↓ Aljufuwni means (assumed tropical:) Languidness, and slowness in motion, of the eyelids. (Har p. 113.)

saqamN c
saqamN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

saqimN c
saqimN: see saqiymN.

saqaAmN c
saqaAmN: see suqomN.

saqiymN c
saqiymN Diseased, disordered, distempered, sick, or ill; (S, K, TA;) as also saqimN↓: (TA:) or long diseased &c.: (Msb:) pl. of the former siqaAmN, (Msb, K,) like kiraAmN pl. of kariymN. (Msb.) See also misoqaAmN, and musoqimN. The phrase Uiniy saqiymN, occurring in the Kur [xxxvii. 87], as a saying of Abraham, is expl. by some as meaning [Verily I am] smitten with the TaAEuwn [or pestilence]: or the meaning is, I shall be diseased at a future time, when the period shall have come; and it is said that he inferred, from looking at the stars, the time of a fever's coming to him: or it means (assumed tropical:) verily I am sick of your worshipping what is not God: IAth says that, in truth, it is one of his three lies; all of which were for the sake of God and his religion. (TA.) You say also qalobN saqiymN (tropical:) [A diseased, a sickly, or an unsound, heart]: and fahomN saqiymN (tropical:) [Diseased, unsound, faulty, or weak, understanding]: and kalaAmN saqiymN (tropical:) [Unsound, faulty, or weak, language]. (TA.) And huwa saqiymu AlSRadori Ealayohi (tropical:) He is affected with rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, against him. (TA.)

sawoqamN c
sawoqamN A kind of tree resembling the xilaAf [q. v.], but not the same as this latter: (TA:) or a kind of large tree, (AHn, K, TA,) exactly like the OavoOab, (AHn, TA,) which is a tree of the figkind, (TA in art. vOb,) except that it is taller than the latter, and less broad, having a fruit like the fig (Altiyn), which, when green, is [like] stone in hardness, but when it ripens it becomes somewhat yellow, and soft, and very sweet, and of a pleasant odour, and people send it, one to another, as a present. (AHn, TA.) [Forskål, in his Flora Aegypt. Arab., p. cxxiv., mentions sqm, which is evidently a mistranscription for swqm, and which he writes in Italic letters “ sokam, ” as one of the names of the ficus sycomorus; and app. of another species or variety of fig which he terms ficus sycomoroides.]

musoqimN c
musoqimN rajulN saqiymN↓ A man who is diseased and whose family are diseased. (TA.)

masoqamapN c
masoqamapN [A cause of disease: a word of the same class as majobanapN and many others of the measure mafoEalapN]: see an ex. voce kiZRapN.

misoqaAmN c
misoqaAmN i. q. saqiymN↓ [Diseased, disordered, &c.]: (TA:) or [rather, agreeably with analogy,] much, or often, diseased &c.: (S, TA:) and accord. to Lh it is also applied as an epithet to a female. (TA.)

saqomuwniyaA c
saqomuwniyaA, (so in copies of the K,) or saqamuwniyaMCu, (Mgh, Msb,) said to be an ancient Greek word, [ Σκαμμωηία] or, as some say, (Msb,) Syriac, (Mgh, Msb,) [Seammony;] a certain plant, from the hollows of which is extracted a mucilage, which is dried, and is called by the name of its plant: it is more repugnant to the stomach and the bowels than all the laxatives; but it is rendered good by aromatic substances, such as pepper and ginger and aniseed: the weight of six barleycorns thereof to twenty eases the yellow bile, and noxious viscosities, from the most remote parts of the body; and a portion thereof with a portion of turobud, or tirbad, [so in different copies of the K, or turobac, or tirobac, i. e. turpeth,] in fresh milk, taken fasting, will not leave a single worm in the belly: it is wonderful in that effect, and proved by experiment. (K.)

1 saqaAhu c
1. saqaAhu, aor. yasoqiyhi, (K,) inf. n. saqoIN; (TA; [see also siqaAyapN, which is likewise said to be an inf. n. of the same verb;]) and sqRAhu↓, (K,) with teshdeed; (TA;) and AsqAhu↓; (K, TA; [in the CK, erroneously, AsotaqAhu;]) all have one meaning; (TA;) [i. e. He gave him to drink, generally water, often milk, and sometimes poison or some other thing: and the first often signifies he watered him, namely, a beast; and in like manner seed produce &c., i. e. irrigated it; as will be shown by what follows:] or saqaAhu [is said when you mean he gave him drink] liXafatihi [to his lip], (S,) or biAlXRafapi [by means of the lip], as also sqRAhu↓; and AsqAhu↓ means he directed him to water, (K,) or he watered (saqaI) his cattle or his land: (S, * K:) or both of them, (K, TA,) i. e. saqaAhu and AsqAhu↓, (TA,) signify he assigned to him, or gave to him, (jaEala lahu,) water, (K, TA,) or drink, or water for irrigation; so that saqaAhu is like kasaAhu, and AsqI↓ is like Malobasa, as Sb says: (TA:) or, as some say, saqayotuhu I gave him water to his mouth; and Oasoqayotuhu↓, I assigned to him, or gave to him, (jaEalotu lahu,) drink, or water for irrigation, that he might do as he would; and like them are kasawotuhu and Oakosayotuhu: (Ham p. 45:) Er-Rághib says that AlsRaqoIu signifies the giving one drink; and AlUisoqaMCu↓, the giving one drink so that he may take it howsoever he will; so that the latter is more ample in meaning than the former. (TA.) Both saqaI and AsqI↓ are sometimes used in relation to what is in the bellies of camels or other cattle; [meaning their milk;] as in the Kur [xxiii. 21], where it is said, mimRaA fiI buTuwnihaA nusoqiykumo↓, or nasoqiykumo, [i. e. We give you to drink of what is in their bellies,] accord. to different readings. (TA.) One says, saqaAhu AlmaMCa, [He gave him to drink water, or the water,] inf. n. as above: (Mgh:) and AlmaMCa saqRayotuhu↓ [I gave him to drink water, or the water, much, or often]: the teshdeed denotes muchness, or frequency. (S.) [See also a tropical usage of the former verb in a verse cited in p. 85, col. 3: and another, from Tarafeh, in p. 134, col. 3. One says also, saqaI AlmaMCa, without a second objective complement, He supplied, or gave, water, or the water.] And saqayotu AlzRaroEa, [I watered, or irrigated, the seed-produce,] inf. n. as above; as also Oasoqayotuhu↓, (Msb.) And saqayotu fiI Alqiroyapi and fiyhaA Oasoqayotu↓ [I poured water into the water-skin]: a poet says, [in one of my copies of the S, Dhu-r-Rummeh,]
wamaAXanRataA xaroqaMCa waAhK kilaAhumaA
saqaI fiyhimaA musotaEojilN lamo tabalRalaA
biOanobaEa mino Eayonayoka lildRamoEi kulRamaA
taEarRafota daArFA Oawo tawahRamota manozilaA
[And two old and worn-out skins of an unskilful woman who has not sewed them well, each of them unsound, into which a person in haste has poured water, they not having been previously moistened, (tabalRalaA being for tatabalRalaA,) are not more liable to the shedding of their water than are thine eyes to the shedding of tears whenever thou investigatest a dwelling or imaginest a place of alighting, or abode]. (S.) [And hence, app.,] saqaI fulaAnN fiI cakarihi (assumed tropical:) Such a one became vehemently affected by sexual appetite. (JK.) One says also, saqaAhu QllRehu Algayova and AsqAhu↓ (S, Msb, * K) God sent down rain to him, or may God send &c.: (K:) both of these verbs being used by Lebeed in his saying,
saqaI qawomiI baniI majodK waOasoqaI
numayorFA waAlqabaAYila mino hilaAli
[May He send down rain to my people, the sons of Mejd, and may He send down rain to Numeyr, and the tribes of Hilál]. (S.) [Hence,] one says, saqaI QllRehu EaSora AlXRabiybapi (assumed tropical:) [May God freshen as with rain the times, or mornings, or afternoons, of youth, or young manhood]. (A and TA in art. Xb.) And saqayotu fulaAnFA, (S,) and Oasoqayotuhu↓, and saqRayotuhu↓, (S, K, *) which last is the form in most repute as expressive of a prayer, (Ham p. 45,) and of which the inf. n. is tasoqiyapN, (K,) I said to such a one saqaAka QllRehu [May God send down rain to thee], (S and K in explanation of the second and third,) or saqoyFA [which virtually means the same, for saqaAka QllRehu saqoyFA]: (S in explanation of the first and second, and K in explanation of the second and third:) [or,] accord, to some, one says saqayotuhu when it [which he gives, i. e. water or the like,] is in his hand; [agreeably with the first explanation in this art.;] and Oasoqayonuhu↓ signifies I prayed for him, saying saqoyFA laka. (Msb.) ― -b2- saqaI baTonuhu, (JK, S, MA, K,) inf. n. saqiIN; (JK, S;) and suqiIa, (JK, IAth, TA,) or saqiI, aor. yasoqaI, inf. n. siqFI or saqFI; (MA;) and AstsqI↓; (JK, S, K; [in my copy of the Msb AstqI, which I doubt not to be a mistranscription, as the verb most commonly known in the sense here following is AstsqI, and as this is not there mentioned;]) His belly [was, or became, diseased with dropsy, i. e.] had yellow water [meaning serum] (JK, S, Msb, K, * TA) apparent in it, (JK,) or collected in it; (S, K, TA;) for which there is scarcely, or never, any cure; (Msb, TA;) his belly became swollen [with dropsy]. MA.) ― -b3- [In the phrase written in the CK suqiIa qulobuhu EadaAwapFu, the verb is correctly suqiIa: see 2.] ― -b4- saqaIAlEaraqu The sweat flowed without stopping. (TA.) ― -b5- saqaI AltRawoba, and sqRAhu↓, He made the garment, or piece of cloth, to imbibe a dye. (TA.) ― -b6- [saqaI also signifies He tempered
steel; and is used in this sense in the present day: and accord. to a reading in one of my copies of the S, in art. Xrx, sqRI↓ also has this meaning.] ― -b7- See also 4, last sentence.

2 saqRaIa
2: see 1, in six places. ― -b2- suqiIa qalobuhu EadaAwapF, (K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, suqiIa,]) and biAlEadaAwapi, (TA, and thus, and thus only, in the JK,) inf. n. tasoqiyapN, (JK, TA,) (tropical:) His heart was made to imbibe enmity, (K, TA,) is said of a man to whom a thing that he dislikes, or hates, has been repeatedly done. (TA.)

3 musaAqaApN c
3. musaAqaApN [The giving to drink, one with another. See a tropical usage of its verb in an ex. cited in art. Xf, conj. 8. ― -b2- ] The drawing of water together. (KL.) ― -b3- And a man's employing a man to take upon himself, or manage, the culture [or watering & c.] of palm-trees or grape-vines [or the like] on the condition of his having a certain share of their produce: (S, TA:) Az says that the people of El-'Irák term it muEaAmalapN. (TA.)

4 OasoqaIa
4: see 1, in thirteen places. ― -b2- One says also, Oasoqayotuhu rakiyRatiI I assigned to him my well [to draw water therefrom]: and Oasoqayotuhu jadowalFA mino nahoriI I assigned to him [a streamlet as] a place, or source, of irrigation, from my river, or rivulet; and Oasoqayotu lahu minohu [which means the same]. (TA.) ― -b3- And AsqAhu It produced in him [dropsy, or] yellow water. (JK. [See 1, near the end of the paragraph.]) ― -b4- And He gave him a made [shin such as is termed] siqaMC: (Az, K, TA: [it is said in the TA that wahaba minohu in the K should be wahaba lahu, as in the explanation by Az: but see art. whb, in which it is said that whb mnh is allowable, and occurs in several trads.:]) or he gave him a hide to make of it a siqaMC: (K:) or AsqAhu UihaAbFA has the latter meaning: (JK, TA:) and Oasoqi UihaAbahaA occurs in a trad. as meaning Give thou its hide to him who will make of it a siqaMC, (TA,) or make thou its hide to be a siqaMC for thee. (JK.) ― -b5- Also, (JK, S, K, TA,) and saqaAhu↓, (K,) the latter mentioned as on the authority of IAar, but disallowed by Sh, (TA,) i. q. AigotaAbahu (tropical:) [He spoke evil of him, or traduced him, in his absence or otherwise], (JK, S, K, TA,) in a foul manner; (TA;) and imputed to him a vice, fault, or the like: (S, TA:) and J cites [in the S] a verse of Ibn-Ahmar ending with the phrase OasoqaI siqaAYiyaA↓ [app. as meaning (assumed tropical:) Who has spoken evil of me, & c.]. (TA.)

5 tsqRI c
5. tsqRI It (a thing) received, or admitted, moisture, (M, TA,) or irrigation; or became plentifully irrigated, or succulent, or sappy. (M, K, TA.) The Hudhalee (El-Mutanakhkhil, TA) says.
mujadRalN yatasaqRaI jiloduhu damahu
kamaA taqaTRara jicoEu AldRawomapi AlquTulu
meaning [Thrown down upon the ground, his skin] becomes drenched with his blood (yataXarRabuhu) [like as drips the severed trunk of the Theban palm-tree]: or, as some relate the verse, yatakasRaI [becomes overspread, here meaning suffused], from Alkisowapu. (S, TA.) ― -b2- tasaqRati AlUibilu AlHawocaAna (assumed tropical:) The camels ate the HwcAn (a certain plant, TA) in its fresh and moist state, and became fat upon it. (K.)

6 tasaAqawoA c
6. tasaAqawoA They gave to drink, one to another, (S, MA, TA,) with the full measure of the vessel in which they were given to drink. (S, TA.) [See also 3.]

8 AstqI c
8. AstqI He drew water (TA) min AlbiYori [from the well], (S, TA,) and mina AlnRahori [from the river, or rivulet]. (TA. [Golius and Freytag make the verb in this sense, erroneously, AstsqI; but the former mentions AstqiIi also in the same sense.]) [And AstqI EalaI baEiyrK He drew water upon a camel in a manner expl. voce saAniyapN, q. v.: often occurring in the Lexicons.] ― -b2- And (tropical:) He was, or became, fat, (K, TA,) and satisfied with drinking of water. (TA.) ― -b3- See also 10, in two places.

10 AstsqI c
10. AstsqI He sought, or demanded, drink (siqoyFA, K, TA, [in the CK saqoyFA,] i. e. maA yuXorabu, TA); mnohu [from him]; as also AstqI↓. (K, TA. [In the CK is immediately added after this explanation, wsaqiyRFA: but this is a mistranscription for wataqayRaOa; expressing another signification of these two verbs, which will be expl. below.]) And He asked, begged, or prayed, for rain; (Msb, * TA;) i. q. AisotamoTara (S in art. mTr, and Msb. *) [Hence, SalaApu AlAisotisoqaMCi The prayer of the petitioning for rain. And AstsqI lahaA He said saqaAhaAQllRehu May God send down rain upon it, namely, a land: see Har p. 300.] ― -b2- And He constrained himself to vomit; or vomited intentionally; syn. taqayRaOa; [see a statement above, in this paragraph, respecting a mistranscription in the CK;] as also AstqI↓; (K, TA;) mentioned by ISd. (TA.) ― -b3- See also 1, in the last quarter of the paragraph.

saqoI c
saqoI in the phrase saqoIu AlfuraAti, which means The towns, or villages, [or lands,] watered by the Euphrates, is said by Mtr to be an inf. n. used as a subst. [properly so termed, and, being originally an inf. n., it may be used alike as sing. and pl.]; or, in this phrase, a noun that should be prefixed to it [such as caAt], is suppressed: or, accord. to some, it is siqoI [q. v.], an instance of the measure fiEolN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN; and thus it is in the handwriting of EI- Hareeree in his 22nd Makámeh. (Har p. 246.) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph.

siqoIN c
siqoIN Drink; or what is drunk; (TA;) or what is given to drink; (K, TA;) a subst. from saqaAhu and OasoqaAhu; (S, TA; [in the former of which, this meaning is indicated, and also the meaning of water given to drink to cattle; and water with which land is irrigated;]) in the M, drink given to camels: (TA:) pl. OasoqiyapN. (S, TA.) And [particularly] A share, or portion, of water [for irrigation]: one says, kamo siqoIu OaroDika [How many bucketfuls or skinfuls, (the specificative being suppressed,) virtually meaning how much, is the share, or portion, of water for the irrigation of thy land?]. (S, TA.) ― -b2- And Water, (K, TA, [in the CK mA, a mistranscription for maMCN,]) i. e. yellow water [meaning serum, effused in dropsy], incidental in the belly, (K, TA,) scarcely, or never, curable; (TA;) as also saqoIN↓: (K: [wayufotaHu being there added: and the word as meaning “ yellow water ” is written only with fet-h in the JK: but in the TA, wyftH forms part of the addition here following:]) or it is in white nafaAfiyx [meaning cells] in the fat of the belly; [in which sense, also, the word is written only with fet-h in the JK;] and it [app. meaning the belly] is opened (wayufotaHu) on the occasion of its issuing: so says ISd: (TA:) a subst. from saqaI baTonuhu [q. v.]. (S, TA.) And A skin [or membrane] containing yellow water, which cleaves asunder from over the head of the young one [at the birth]: (K, TA:) or, as in the T, the water that is in the [membrane called] maXiymap, that comes forth EalaI raOosi Alwaladi [meaning at the birth]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also Land that is irrigated; having the meaning of the measure mafoEuwlN, like niqoDN [in the sense of manoquwDN]: (Er-Rághib, TA: [see also saqoI:]) or it signifies, (K,) or so saqiIRN↓, of the same measure as XaqiIRN and SabiIRN, (Mgh,) and masoqawiIRN↓, (S, Mgh, K,) app. a rel. n. from masoqFI, not from masoqiIRN, for if it were from the latter it would be masoqiIRN, (M, TA,) [or, accord. to some, if from masoqiIRN, it may be either masoqiIRN or masoqawiIRN, (see Lumsden's Arab. Gr. p. 630,)] seed-produce irrigated (S, Mgh, K) by water running upon the surface of the earth; (S, Mgh;) [i. e., not by rain only;] saqiIRN↓ being the contr. of baxosiIRN; (Mgh;) and masoqawiIRN↓, contr. of maZomaYiIRN, (Mgh, TA,) which signifies “ watered [only] by the rain; ” and the vulgar say misoqaAwiI↓. (TA.)

baTonN saqK c
baTonN saqK A belly swollen [with dropsy]. (MA.)

suqoyaA c
suqoyaA A giving of drink; [or a giving to drink;] like [the inf. n.] saqoIN. (Er-Rághib, TA.) ― -b2- And A sending down of rain upon mankind and the lands: (TA:) a subst. from saqaAhu QllReh Algayova. (S, K, * TA. *) One says, daEawotu lahu biAlsRuqoyaA [I prayed for him for the sending down of rain]. (JK.) And it is said in a form of prayer, suqoyaA raHomapK walaA suqoyaA EacaAbK [We ask of Thee a sending down of a rain of mercy, and not a sending down of a rain of punishment]; meaning, send Thou down upon us a rain in which shall be benefit, without injury, and without laying waste. (Msb.) One says also OaroDN xaAfiDapu AlsRuqoyaA Land easy of irrigation [either by the rain or otherwise]: (K in art. xfD:) and the contr. is termed raAfiEapu AlsRuqoyaA. (TA in that art.) ― -b3- Also i. q. Xrb [i. e. XirobN, meaning A beast's share, or portion, of water]: so in the Kur xci. 13. (Jel.)

siqMCN c
siqMCN A skin, (KL,) or a qirobap, (JK,) [i. e.] a skin of a young goat or sheep when it has entered
its second year, (M, K,) used for water and for milk, (ISk, JK, S, Msb, K, KL,) or, accord. to ISd, only for water: (TA:) it is termed Aibonu OadiymK [made of one hide; but there are larger sorts]; and if larger, it is termed Aibonu Oadiymayoni [made of two hides], and Aibonu valaAvapi MdimapK [made of three hides]: (T and TA in art. bnI:) accord. to ISk, the waTob is peculiarly for milk; and the niHoI, for clarified butter; and the qirobap, for water: (S:) the pl. (of pauc., S) is OasoqiyapN and OasoqiyaAtN and (of mult., S) OasaAqK, (S, K,) or this last is a pl. pl. (T, TA.) ― -b2- See also 4, last sentence. ― -b3- [And see a phrase voce HicaMCN, in art. Hcw, where it is applied to (assumed tropical:) The stomach of a camel, in which water is stored.]

saqiIRN c
saqiIRN: see siqoIN, last sentence, in two places. ― -b2- Also A cloud having large drops [of rain], (S, K,) vehement in the falling [thereof]: (S:) [like ramiIRN and rawiIRN:] pl. OasoqiyapN. (S, K.) ― -b3- And The papyrus (barodiIR): (JK, S, K:) or tender papyrus: so called because of its growing in, or near to, water: (TA:) occurring in a verse of Imra-el- Keys, cited voce mucalRalN: (S, TA: [but see what is said under this word, mclRl: and see Ham p. 555:]) n. un. saqiyRapN. (S.) ― -b4- And Palm-trees; (S, K;) and saqiyRapN signifies [the same, or] palmtrees that are irrigated by means of water-wheels (dawaAlK, [pl. of daAliyapN, q. v.]). (TA.)

suqaAyapN c
suqaAyapN: see what next follows.

siqaAyapN c
siqaAyapN and suqaAyapN↓ and masoqaApN↓ and misoqaApN↓ A place for giving to drink or for watering: (K, * TA:) what is termed siqaAyapu AlmaMCi is well known: (S:) i. e. siqaAyapN signifies a place made, or prepared, for the giving to drink to people: (Msb:) a construction for water: (Mgh:) or a place in which beverage is made, or prepared, at the fairs, or festivals, &c.: (JK, T, TA:) [and particularly a place in which a beverage made of raisins steeped in water was given at the general assembly of the pilgrims:] and masoqaApN↓ signifies a drinkingplace [in a general sense]: and he who pronounces it with kesr to the m [misoqaApN↓] makes it to be like the utensil called misoqaApu AldRiyki [the drinking-vessel of the cock]: (S:) [see turofapN:] and the pl. is masaAqK. (TA.) ― -b2- siqaAyapN also signifies A vessel in which one is given to drink: (K:) in the Kur [xii. 70], it means the king's drinking-cup; (Mgh;) his SuwaAE, in [or from] which he drank, (JK, S, TA,) and with which they measured corn; and it was a vessel of silver. (TA.) ― -b3- And siqaAyapu AlHaAji means The beverage made of raisins steeped in water which [the tribe of] Kureysh used to give to the pilgrims to drink: it was under the superintendence of El-'Abbás in the Time of Ignorance and in El-Islám: (TA:) or siqaAyap in this phrase is an inf. n.; so in the Kur ix. 19; (Mgh;) where it is said, OajaEalotumo siqaAyapa QloHaAji waEimaArapaQlomasojidi QloHaraAmi kamano Mmana biMllRehi waQlyawomi QloMxiri; the two words sqAyp and EmArp being inf. ns. of saqaI and Eamara; (Bd;) the meaning being OajaEalotumo Oahola siqaAyapi AlHaAji wa EimaArapi Almasojidi AlHaraAmi [i. e. Have ye made, or pronounced, the authors of the giving to drink to the pilgrims, and of the keeping in repair of the sacred mosque, to be like him who has believed in God and the last day?]; and this is confirmed by another reading, which is, suqaApa AlHaAji waEamarapa Almasojidi: (Ksh, Bd:) or the meaning is, OajaEalotumo siqaAyapa AlHaAji kaUiymaAni mano Mmana [&c., i. e. have ye made, or pronounced, the giving to drink to the pilgrims, &c., to be like the belief of him who has believed &c.?]. (Bd.) [See also rifaAdapN.]

saqRaMCN c
saqRaMCN; and the fem. saqRaMCapN and saqRaAyapN: see saAqK, in six places. ― -b2- AlsRaqRaMCu is also the appellation of A certain intelligent bird, that draws water for itself. (JK.) [It is applied in the present day, by some, to The pelican: and by some, to the aquiline vulture; commonly called the raxam.]

saAqK c
saAqK and saqRaMCN↓ Giving to drink; or one who gives to drink: (K, TA:) the former signifies [generally as above, or a cup-bearer: and also] watering seed-produce; or a waterer of seedproduce: (Msb:) [and ↓the latter generally signifies a water-carrier:] the pl. of the former is suqRFI, (K, TA,) with damm and then teshdeed, (TA,) [accord. to the CK suqiIRN, which is app. a mistranscription,] and suqRaMCN, (K, TA,) like rumRaAnN, (TA,) or suqaApN: (CK: [this last is a well-known pl. of saAqK, and as such has occurred above, voce siqaAyapN:]) the pl. of saqRaMCN↓ is saqRaAWuwna: (K:) and a woman is termed saqRaMCapN↓ and saqRaAyapN↓. (S, K.) It is said in a prov.,
Aisoqi raqaAXi UinRahaA saqRaAyapN↓
[Give thou to drink to Rakáshi: verily she is one who gives to drink: raqaAXi being a woman's name]: it is applied to him who does good: meaning do thou good to him, because of his doing good. (A'Obeyd, S.) ― -b2- [Hence,] saAqiI AlEayoni A certain vein [app. the central artery of the retina] which passes from the interior of the head to the eye, and the severing of which occasions the loss of the sight. (JK.) [See also the next paragraph.]

saAqiyapN c
saAqiyapN [a subst. from sAqK, made so by the affix p,] A rivulet, or streamlet, (T, K, TA,) for the irrigation of seed-produce; (T, TA;) a small channel for the irrigation of land; (Msb;) it is larger than a jadowal, and than a nahor: (Mgh:) pl. sawaAqK. (Mgh, TA.) It is now vulgarly applied to designate The [kind of water-wheel for irrigation termed] duwlaAb [q. v.]. (TA in art. dlb.) ― -b2- And [the pl.] AlsRawaAqiI signifies Certain veins which discharge into the OaboharaAni [dual of Oaboharu, q. v.]. (JK.)

masoqFI c
masoqFI A time [and a place] of giving to drink. (JK, TA.)

masoqaApN c
masoqaApN: see siqaAyapN in tow places. One says when the Sultán has dealt gently with his subjects in his government of them, Oabolaga AlsRuloTaAnu AlrRaAtiEa masoqaAtahu (assumed tropical:) [The Sultán has caused the beast pasturing at pleasure amid abundant herbage to come to his drinking-place]. (TA.) [See also XarabapN.]

misoqaApN c
misoqaApN: see siqaAyapN, in two places. ― -b2- Also A thing which is made for the jiraAr [or water-jars], and upon which the mugs are hung. (JK, TA.)

masoqiIRN c
masoqiIRN [Given to drink: and] watered seedproduce [&c.]. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] UinRahu lamasoqiIRu AldRami Verily he is tinged with redness. (JK.)

masoqawiIRN c
masoqawiIRN and misoqaAwiI: see siqoIN, last sentence, in three places.

1 sakRa AlXRaIoCa c
1. sakRa AlXRaIoCa, aor.
sakuka
, (TA,) inf. n. sakRN, (K, TA,) i. q. sadRahu [i. e. He closed or closed up, or he stopped or stopped up, or repaired, and made firm or strong, the thing]. (K, * TA.) [In the place of sadRuAlXRaIoCi, the explanation of the inf. n. accord. to the reading in the TA, we find in the CK XadRu AlXRaIoCi: and it seems that XadRahu is a correct meaning of sakRahu; for it is said that] from masokuwkN as signifying maXoduwdN is the post-classical phrase sakRu AlOabowaAbi [i. e. The making fast of doors]. (TA.) [In the present day, sakRa AlbaAba, aor. and inf. n. as above, means He locked, and he bolted, the door.] ― -b2- And sakRahu, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (S, K, TA,) He clamped it (DabRabahu) with iron; namely, a door, (S, K, TA,) and wood. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also sakRahu, aor. as above, (S, TA,) and so the inf. n., (K, TA,) He cut off his ears. (S, K, * TA.) ＝ -A3- sakRa bimaA fiI baTonihi, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (K, TA,) He cast forth what was in his belly; (K, * TA;) muted, or dunged; (TA;) said of an ostrich: (K, TA:) and so sajRa. (TA.) And sakRa bisaloHihi, (AA, TA,) inf. n. as above, (K, TA,) He cast forth his excrement, or ordure, (AA, K, TA,) in a thin state; (AA, * K, TA;) as also zakRa, (AA, TA,) and hakRa. (TA.) And huwa yasukRu, inf. n. as above, He voids thin excrement or ordure; (As, S, TA;) as also yasujRu, inf. n. sajRN. (As, TA.) And Oaxacahu sakRu [He was taken with a looseness of the bowels;] he had thin evacuations of the bowels; expl. by qaEada maqaAEida riqaAqFA: and Oaxacahu sakRN fiI baTonihi [signifies the same; or] his bowels became loose; as also sajRN; so says Yaakoob; and he asserts it to be formed by substitution; but which of the two is so formed is unknown. (TA.) ― -b2- sakRa fiI AlOaroDi He went at random in the land, or country, not knowing whither to go, and was perplexed. (Ibn-'Abbád, O. [See also 7.]) ― -b3- One says also, Oayona tasukRu Whither goest thou? (Ibn-'Abbád, O.) ― -b4- maA sakRa samoEiI mivolu celika AlkalaAmi The like of that speech has not entered my ear, or ears: and fiI masaAmiEiI mivoluhu maAQsotakRa↓ The
like of it has not entered my ears. (TA.) ＝ -A4- sakRa, [sec. pers., app., sakukota,] aor.
sakuka
, (TA,) inf. n. sukRN, (K, TA,) It (one's nature, or disposition,) was, or became, base, ignoble, mean, or sordid. (K, * TA.) ＝ -A5- sakRa, (Msb, TA,) sec. pers. sakikota, (Msb, K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, sakikota,]) inf. n. sakakN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, TA,) said of a man, &c., (K,) (assumed tropical:) He was small in the ear, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, TA,) with a sticking thereof to the head, and small projection thereof: (K, TA:) or he was short in the ear, with a sticking thereof to the part behind it: (TA:) or he was small in the quwf [here meaning either the upper part or the helix (in the CK quwb)] of the ear, and narrow in the ear-hole. (K, TA.) And (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, deaf. (K, TA.)

7 AnskRt AlUibilu c
7. AnskRt AlUibilu The camels went at random. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, TA. [See also sakRa fiI AlOarDa, above.]) AinosikaAkN in the case of the birds called qaTFA means Their going at random, and depressing their breasts, after soaring in their flight and circling in the air. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

8 AstkR c
8. AstkR It (a thing) was, or became, closed or closed up, or stopped or stopped up, or repaired, and made firm or strong; quasi pass. of 1 in the first of the senses assigned to it above; syn. AinosadRa. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AstkRt masaAmiEuhu (tropical:) His ears became stopped up, or deaf, (S, Msb, K, *) and narrow [in the aperture]. (S, K.) ― -b3- And AstkR AlnRabotu (assumed tropical:) The herbage became luxuriant and dense, (S, K,) its interstices becoming closed up. (S.) And AstkRt AlrRiyaADu (assumed tropical:) The meadows became luxuriant and dense [in their herbage]. (As, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 1.

sakRN c
sakRN A nail; a pin, or peg, of iron; as also sakiIRN↓; (S, K;) like as one says dawRN and dawiIRN: (S:) pl. sikaAkN (S, K) and sukuwkN. (K.) [A verse of Aboo-Dahbal El-Jumahee is cited as an ex. in the TA as follows:
diroEiI dilaASN sakRuhaA sakRN Eajabo
wajawobuhaA AlqaAtiru mino sayri Alyalabo
but see yalabN.] ＝ -A2- A straight, or an even, building, and excavation, (O, K,) like a wall, without curvity, or bending. (O.) ― -b2- A coat of mail narrow in the rings; (S, K;) as also sukRN↓, and sakRaMCu↓: (K:) or, accord. to the O, soft in the rings. (TA.) ― -b3- See also the next paragraph.

sukRN c
sukRN A well narrow (Lth, AZ, As, S, O, K) in its cavity, or interior, (Lth, O,) or from its top to its bottom, (AZ, S, O,) or in its aperture; as also sakRN↓, and sakuwkN↓: (K:) or a well even in its cavity, or interior, and in its casing: or, accord. to Fr, one well, or strongly, or compactly, cased, and narrow; the pl. of sukRN is sikaAkN; and the pl. of sakuwkN↓ is sukRN, so that the latter is both a sing. and a pl. (TA.) ― -b2- And A narrow road: (I'Abbád, O:) or a road stopped up: (K:) or a road narrow and stopped up. (Lh, TA.) ― -b3- See also sakRN. ― -b4- Also The hole of the scorpion, (Ibn- 'Abbád, S, O, K,) in the dial. of the BenooAsad; (Ibn-'Abbád, O;) and of the spider, (O, K,) likewise, because of its narrowness. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A sort of perfume, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) prepared from raAmak [q. v.], (K,) or from musk and raAmak, (O,) the former being bruised, or pounded, sifted, kneaded with water, and wrung hard, and wiped over with oil of the xiyriIR [q. v.] in order that it may not stick to the vessel, and left for a night; then musk is pounded, or powdered, (yusoHaqu,) and put into it by degrees, and it is [again] wrung hard, and cut into small, round, flat pieces, and left for two days, after which it is perforated with a large needle, and strung upon a hempen string, and left for a year; and as it becomes old, its odour becomes the more sweet. (K.) ＝ -A3- Also pl. of OasakRu. (K.)

sikRapN c
sikRapN A ploughshare; i. e. the iron thing with which the ground is ploughed; (S, TA;) the iron appertenance of the plough. (K.) Hence the trad., maA daxalati AlsRikRapu daAra qawomi UilRaA calRuwA [The ploughshare enters not the abode of a people, or party, but they become abased]; meaning, in consequence of the violence and the demands that the agriculturists experience from the ruling power. (TA.) ― -b2- And A die, i. e. an engraved piece of iron, (S, * Msb, K, TA,) having an inscription upon it, (TA,) with which dirhems and deenárs are stamped, (S, * Msb,) or upon which pieces of money (daraAhim) are struck: (K:) pl. sikakN. (Msb.) ― -b3- And, because stamped therewith, A coined dirhem, and deenár; (TA;) which latter is called [also] sikiIRN↓, (O, K, TA,) [in the CK sakiIR, but it is] with kesr. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A row (TariyqapN muSoTafRapN, S, O, Msb, or saTorN, K, or saTorN maSoTafRN, TA) of palm-trees. (S, O, Msb, K, TA.) Hence their saying, (S,) or the saying of the Prophet, (O,) xayoru AlmaAli muhorapN maOomuwrapN Oawo sikRapN maOobuwrapN, (S, in the O skRp mObwrp Aw mhrp mOmwrp,) meaning [The best of property is] a prolific filly (TA) or a row of palm-trees fecundated: (S, TA:) or, accord. to As, skRp mObwrp here signifies a ploughshare properly prepared [for ploughing]; and, he says, the meaning is, that the best of property is a brood [of a mare] or seed-produce. (S.) [It has been suggested to me that, if Tryqp in the explanation above have the signification here assigned to it, the epithet mSTfRp is redundant; and therefore that Tryqp alone may be the proper explanation, and may mean in this case, as it does in many others, a tall palm-tree, or the tallest of palm-trees, or a smooth palm-tree, or a palm-tree the head of which is reached by the hand; and that mSTfRp may have been added in consequence of misunderstanding, and sTr substituted for Tryqp for the same reason: but I think it much more probable that the epithet has been added because Tryqp is ambiguous; and this is confirmed by what here follows.] ― -b2- Also A zuqaAq [meaning street]: (S, O, * Msb:) or [rather] a wide zuqaAq: (Msb:) or an even road, (K, TA,) [or street,] of such as are termed OaziqRap [pl. of zuqaAq]: (TA:) so called because the houses therein form a row or rows [on either side]; (O, TA;) being likened to a sikRap of palm-trees: (TA:) [in the present day, often applied to a highway, and to any road:] pl. sikakN [as above]: (O:) and sakaAYiku↓ is syn. with [sikakN as meaning] OaziqRapN. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also, app., one says,] AijoEali AlOamora sikRapF waAHidapF (assumed tropical:) Make thou the affair, or case, [uniform, or] one uniform thing. (Fr, TA in art. bOj.) ― -b4- And Oaxaca AlOamora bisikRatihi, (K,) and Oadorakahu bisikRatihi, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) [He took the thing, and he attained it, in its proper way, or] when it was possible. (K, TA.) ― -b5- And fulaAnN SaEobu AlsikRapi (tropical:) Such a one will not remain quiet, or still, or steady, by reason of hastiness of temper. (Ibn- 'Abbád, Z, O, TA.) ＝ -A3- Also The house [or station] of the bariyd [or messenger that journeys on a beast of the post, or messengers on beasts of the post: it is likewise called sikRapu Albariydi: see bariydN]: and OaSoHaAbu AlsRikaki, occurring in a letter of 'Omar Ibn-'Abd-El-'Azeez, means the burud [or messengers on beasts of the post] who are stationed there to be sent on affairs of importance. (Mgh.) sikRapu Albariydi is well known [as having the meaning assigned to it above: and also as meaning The space, or distance, between each station of the messengers above mentioned and the station next to it: see, again, bariydN]. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.)

sakakN c
sakakN inf. n. of sakRa, sec. pers. sakikota. (Msb, TA. [See 1, last sentence but one.])

sukukN c
sukukN [a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned,] Bustards; syn. HubaArayaAtN. (TA.)

sukaAkN c
sukaAkN The air that is next to the clouds, or to the higher part, (EanaAn,) of the sky; as also sukaAkapN↓: (S, K:) or both signify the air, or atmosphere, between heaven and earth: like luwHN: the pl. of the second is sakaAYiku. (TA.) Hence the saying, laA OafoEalu celika walaw nazawoata fiIAlsRukaAki, meaning [I will not do that even if thou leap] into the sky. (S.) ― -b2- Also The part, of an arrow, which is the place of the feathers. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, K.)

sakuwkN c
sakuwkN: see sukRN, in two places.

DarabuwA buyuwtahumo sikaAkFA c
DarabuwA buyuwtahumo sikaAkFA [They pitched their tents] in one row: (Th, K:) and said with X, [i. e. XikaAkFA,] accord. to IAar: (TA:) but Th says that it is only with s, deriving it from sikRapN signifying “a wide zuqaAq.” (TA in art. Xk.)

sukaAkapN c
sukaAkapN Small in the ear, (M, K,) or in the ears. (IAar, TA.) [See also OasakRu.] ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) One who is alone in his opinion, having none to share with him in it, (AZ, K, TA,) who acts without caring how his opinion happens to be: pl. sukaAkaAtN: it has no broken pl. (AZ, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also sukaAkN.

sakaAYiku c
sakaAYiku pl. of sukaAkapN as syn. with sukaAkN [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b2- See also sikRapN, in the latter half of the paragraph.

sakRiI c
sakRiI: see sakRN

sikRiIRN c
sikRiIRN: see sikRapN, in the former half of the paragraph. ＝ -A2- Also i. q. bariydN [meaning either A beast of the post or a messenger who journeys on a beast of the post]: a rel. n. from sikRapN. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, TA.)

sakRaAkN c
sakRaAkN [A stamper of money;] one who strikes the sikRap. (TA.) ― -b2- [And said by Golius, as on the authority of Meyd, to signify A maker of knives; like sakRaAnu.]

sakRaAkapN c
sakRaAkapN [as a coll. gen. n., app. derived from sikRapN signifying “a road,”] Wayfarers. (TA.)

sikRiynN c
sikRiynN, mentioned by Ibn-'Abbád in this art., and said in the Mgh to be of the measure fiEoliynN from AlsRakRu, or fiERiylN from AlsRukuwnu: see art. skn.

OasakRu c
OasakRu Small in the ear, (Mgh, K,) with a sticking thereof to the head, and small projection thereof: (K:) or short in the ear, with a sticking thereof to the part behind it: (TA:) or small in the qwf [meaning either the upper part or the helix] of the ear, and narrow in the ear-hole: (K:) applied to a man, (Mgh, K,) &c.: (K:) fem. sakRaMCu: (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K:) applied [to a woman, as is implied in the K, and to a female bird, and particularly to a female ostrich, and] to a single bird of the species called qaTFA, because having no ear [apparent or projecting], (TA,) and to a she-goat, meaning, with the lawyers, having no ear except the ear-hole, or, accord. to El-Kudooree, naturally earless: (Mgh:) and applied to an ear, as meaning small: (S, Msb:) pl. sukRN: applied [to human beings, &c., more commonly to birds, and particularly] to ostriches, (K,) and to birds of the species called qaTFA: (TA:) it is said that every sakRaMC is oviparous, and every XarofaMC is viviparous; the former meaning a female that has no ear (S, O) apparent, or external; (O;) and the latter, “a female that has an ear (S, O) apparent, or external, (O,) though it be slit.” (S.) A rájiz says,
layolapu HakR Klayosa fiyhiA XakRu
OaHukRu HatRaI saAEidiI munofakRu
OasoharaniI AlOusayowidu AlOasakRu
[A night of scratching: there is no doubt respecting it: I scratch so that my fore arm, or my upper arm, (for sAEd is used in both of these senses,) is dislocated: the little black thing without ears having rendered me sleepless]: he means the fleas, using the sing. as a gen. n. (TA.) ― -b2- Also Having the ears cut off. (TA.) [This seems to be the primary, though not a usual, signification.] ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) [Having the ears stopped up: (see 8:) or] deaf. (K.) It is applied in this sense to the ostrich, because [they say that] he does not hear. (Lth, TA.) ― -b4- And AlOasakRu was the name of A certain horse. (O, K.) ― -b5- See also sakRN.

minobarN masokuwkN c
minobarN masokuwkN [A pulpit] nailed with nails of iron: but also said to be with X, [i. e. maXokuwkN,] meaning maXoduwdN [made firm or strong, &c.]. (TA.)

1 sakaba c
1. sakaba, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
sakuba
, (A, TA,) inf. n. sukuwbN (S, A, Msb, K) and sakobN (Msb) and tasokaAbN, (S, [this last assigned in the K to the trans. verb,]) said of water, (S, A, Msb, K,) and a flow of tears (damoE), (A, TA,) and the like, (TA,) It poured out or forth; or was, or became, poured out or forth; (S, A, Msb, K;) as also Anskb↓. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- And sakabahu, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor. as above, (A, TA,) inf. n. sakobN (S, Mgh, K) and tasokaAbN, (K, [the latter assigned in the S to the intrans. verb,]) He poured it out or forth; namely, water, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) and a flow of tears, (A, TA,) and the like; (TA;) as also Askbhu↓. (A.) The people of El-Medeeneh say, Ausokubo EalaI yad aIRa Pour thou out, or forth, upon my hands. (A.) And it is said in a trad., haAhunaA tusokabu AlEabaraAtu [Here tears are to be poured forth], meaning this is the place in which one should weep, seeking forgiveness. (Mgh.)

4 Oasokaba
4: see the next preceding paragraph.

7 Uinosakaba
7: see the next preceding paragraph.

sakobN c
sakobN and saAkibN↓ and sakuwbN↓ and sayokabN↓ (K) and sakiybN↓ (CK [omitted in the TA and in my MS. copy of the K]) and OusokuwbN↓ (K) Water poured out or forth, or being poured out or forth: or poured out or forth, (K, TA,) running upon the surface of the earth without any excavation: (TA:) or the first signifies water poured out or forth; and is an inf. n. used as an epithet, like SabRN and gaworN applied as epithets to water: and sakuwbN↓, water running upon the surface of the earth without any excavation: and OusokuwbN↓, water pouring out or forth, or being poured out or forth; (S;) or, as some say, pouring much: (Har pp. 469 et seq.:) and also this last, running water: (TA:) or this signifies daAYimu AlhaTalaAni [i. e. continually pouring, or continually pouring dispersedly and in large drops; as also sakobN; for hence it appears evident that AlhaTalaAnu AldRaAYimu as an explanation of AlsRakobu and AlOusokuwbu in the K is a mistake for AldRaAYimu AlhaTalaAni]; and is applied as an epithet to water and to blood; (A;) and also [probably in this sense] to clouds (saHaAbN); and to a wound made with a spear or the like (TaEonapN): and saAkibN↓ is applied as an epithet to tears (damoEN). (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence] sakobN applied to a horse means (tropical:) Wide in step: (S, A, K:) or fleet, or swift, or excellent in running; (A, K;) that runs much: (Mgh, TA:) or light, or active: and OusokuwbN↓, so applied, has one or another of these meanings: (A:) or the former, thus applied, that runs vehemently; as also fayoDN; likened to water pouring forth: (EthThaalebee, TA:) also, (K, TA,) applied to a horse and a man and a boy, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) light of spirit; and brisk, lively, or sprightly, (K, TA,) in work, or action. (TA.) AlsRakobu was the name of the first horse possessed by the Prophet; (Mgh, * K;) as also AlsRakabu↓: and the name of a horse of Shebeeb Ibn-Mo'áwiyeh. (K.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] (assumed tropical:) A certain sort of clothes, or garments, (T, S, K,) thin so as to resemble dust, and as though resembling pouring water by reason of its thinness; and so, accord. to IAar, sakabN↓. (T, TA.) ― -b4- Applied to a man, (assumed tropical:) Tall; (K;) a dial. var. of saqobN [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b5- And (tropical:) A necessary thing or affair: (A, K, TA:) and (tropical:) a disgrace (subRapN) that is necessary, or unavoidable. (A, TA.) Lakeet Ibn-Zurárah said to his brother Maabad, when he required him to ransom him with two hundred camels, he being a captive, numiyTu Eanoka XayoYFA yakuwnu EalaI Oaholi bayotika subRapF sakobFA, meaning (tropical:) [We will put away from thee a thing that would be to the people of thy house] a necessary, or an unavoidable, disgrace. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also Copper, or brass; syn. nuHaAsN: or lead: (IAar, K:) and so sakabN↓, (K,) in the latter sense, or in both senses, or in all the senses. (TA.)

sakabN c
sakabN: see the next preceding paragraph, latter half, in three places. ＝ -A2- Also A certain kind of tree, (S, K,) of sweet odour, (S,) as though its odour were that of [the perfume called] xaluwq [q. v.], growing apart from others, upon a single root, having a downy substance, and leaves like those of the SaEotar [a species of origanum, or marjoram], except in being more green: it grows in the plains and the valleys; and what has dried up thereof is of no use to any one: it has a fruit which is eaten, and the people of El-Hijáz make of it a [beverage such as is termed] nabiyc: its fruit does not grow forth in one year, but only in several years: AHn says that the sakab is a herb that rises to the height of a cubit, having dustcoloured leaves like those of the hinodabaMC [or endive], and a blossom intensely white, of the form of that of the firosik [i. e. peach, or a species or variety thereof]: (TA:) n. un. with p: (S, TA:) As mentions the sakab as one of the plants of the plain, or soft, tracts. (TA.) ― -b2- It is also said to be The [plant called] ryH [app. rayRiH or riyH which seem to be coll. gen. ns. of each of which the n. un. is with p (see rayRiHapN)], having a yellow blossom. (TA.) ― -b3- And The anemone (XaqaAYiqu AlnRuEomaAni). (K.) ― -b4- And One of the trees of the hot season. (TA.)

sakaAbN c
sakaAbN and sakaAbi, the latter [indecl., with kesr for its termination,] like qaTaAmi, and sakRaAbN↓, [all app. meaning The fleet, or swift, like AlsRakobu and AlOusokuwbu,] are names of certain horses. (K: the second only mentioned in the S.)

sakuwbN c
sakuwbN: see sakobN, in two places.

sakiybN c
sakiybN: see sakobN.

sakRaAbN c
sakRaAbN: see sakaAbN.

saAkibN c
saAkibN: see sakobN, in two places. ＝ -A2- [And act. part. n. of sakabahu. Hence,] saAkibu AlmaMCi (assumed tropical:) [The sign of Aquarius;] the eleventh of the signs of the Zodiac; also called AldRalowu. (Kzw.)

sayokabN c
sayokabN: see sakobN

OusokubRapN c
OusokubRapN The OusokufRap [i. e. threshold] of a door. (K.)

UisokaAbN c
UisokaAbN: see the next paragraph.

OusokuwbN c
OusokuwbN: see sakobN, in three places. ― -b2- Also Lightning extending towards the earth. (K.) So in the saying of Zuheyr El-Mázinee,
baroqN yuDiIoCu OamaAma Albayoti Ousokuwbu
[Lightning shining, or shining brightly, before the tent, or house, extending towards the earth]; as though it were pouring forth rain. (TA.) ― -b3- And A row of palm-trees; (IAar, K;) as also OusoluwbN: if of other than palm-trees, it is termed OunobuwbN, and midaAdN. (IAar, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also i. q. UisokaAfN [A maker of shoes or boots, or a sewer of leather, &c.]; like UisokaAbN↓: or a blacksmith. (K.)

Almisokabapu c
Almisokabapu [altered in a copy of the A from Almasokabapu, which may perhaps be the right word,] The higher, or highest, rivulet, or small channel for irrigation, from which the other rivulets, or small channels, are supplied with water. (A.) ― -b2- [In a copy of the A (in art. sTb), AlmasoTabap, which I believe to be in that instance a mistranscription for Almskbp, occurs expl. as meaning (assumed tropical:) The Milky Way.]

Q. 1 sakobaja c
Q. 1. sakobaja He prepared sikobaAj. (TA.)

sikobaAjN c
