sikobaAjN an arabicized word, (O, Msb, K,) with kesr (Msb, K) to the s, not with fet-h, because there is no word of the measure faEolaAlN except of the reduplicate class [like zalozaAlN &c.], (Msb,) from siko, meaning “vinegar,” in Pers., and baAj, [arabicized from the Pers. baAhaA,] i. e. lawonN [as meaning “a sort,” or “species,” of food or viands]; (O; [in which it is erroneously said that baAj is in Pers. baAwaA;]) or from [the Pers.] sirokaho PaAJaho; [sirokaho meaning “vinegar;” and PaAJaho “sheeps' feet,” or “trotters;”] (TA;) [but the former derivation is evidently the more probable;] A well-known kind of food; (Msb;) flesh-meat cooked with vinegar: this is the best that is said [in explanation of the word]: (TA:) [in the present day, applied to a sort of food composed of flesh-meat, wheat-flour, and vinegar; and sometimes to other varieties of food, but vinegar, I believe, enters into the composition of them all: also called sikobaA; from the Pers. siko “vinegar,” and baA “spoon-meat:” accord. to Golius, on the authority of the Loghat NiametAllah Khaleel Soofee, a sort of food composed of flesh-meat cut in pieces, (to which are afterwards added raisins, a few figs, and some vetches,) with vinegar and honey, or acid syrop: and sikobaAju Albaqari is a name given to such food prepared with beef:] sikobaAjN OaSofaru is a well-known sort of broth [or soup] in which is saffron, wherefore it is termed ASfr. (Mgh.)

sakobiynajN c
sakobiynajN an arabicized word [from the Pers. sakobiynahN]; (O;) [Sagapenum;] a certain medicine, (O, K,) well-known; (K;) the gum of a certain tree (O, TA) in Persia, (TA,) [supposed to be the ferula Persica,] in which is no useful property, but only in its gum: some say that there is a sort of qinRap [or galbanum] that changes from its original state and becomes skbynj. (O.)

1 sakata c
1. sakata, (S, Msb, TA,) aor.
sakuta
, (Lth, TA,) inf. n. sukuwtN and sakotN (S, A, Msb, K) and sukaAtN (S, K) and saAkuwtapN, (K,) [all these ns. said in the K to signify the same, but this is not exactly the case, for the last is of an intensive form,] He was, or became, silent, mute, or speechless; contr. of naTaqa; (TA;) i. q. Samata: (Lth, Msb, TA:) or sakata is said of him who has the power, or faculty, of speech, but abstains from making use of it; whereas Samata is sometimes said of that which has not the power, or faculty, of speech: (Er-Rághib, MF, TA:) or sakata, aor.
sakuta
, inf. n. sukuwtN and sakotN, signifies he (a man) ceased, or stopped, speaking; and sakata, aor.
sakuta
, inf. n. sakotN, (assumed tropical:) he (a man) was, or became, still, or quiet; syn. sakana: (Zj, TA:) [it is said that] Askt↓, also, is syn. with Samata, like sakata; (Msb;) accord. to AZ, one says of a man, Samata and OaSamata and sakata and Oasokata↓: (TA:) or, as some say, Askt↓ signifies he was, or became, silent, or he spoke not; and he ceased [from speech], or broke off [therefrom], or became cut short [therein]: (Msb:) or sakata signifies he was, or became, silent intentionally; and Askt↓, he was, or became, silent by reason of thought or disease or fear: (TA:) or you say takalRama vumRa sakata without A [when you mean he spoke and then became silent, i. e., intentionally]; (S) but you say Askt↓ when you mean his speech became broken off, or cut short, and so he spoke not. (S, K.) It is said in a prov., sakata OalofFA wnaTaqa xalofFA He held his tongue from a thousand words (sakata Eano Oalofi kalimapK), and then uttered what was wrong. (ISk, S and Msb in art. xlf.) And you say [of the quiescent h that is sometimes added at the end of a word, after a vowel or a letter of prolongation, as in lamo yaroDaho and waA zayodaAho], hecihi haMCu AlsRakoti [This is the hAC of pausation]. (A, TA.) One says also, of a she-camel, sakatato, inf. n. sukuwtN, meaning She uttered not the [grumbling] cry termed rugaMC when the saddle was put upon her. (ISd, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence sakata, aor. as above, inf. n. sakotN, as syn. with sakana, meaning as expl. above; and also (assumed tropical:) It was, or became, still, quiet, motionless, at rest, stilled, quieted, appeased, tranquillized, calm, allayed, assuaged, or quelled; it remitted; it subsided; and so Askt↓.] You say, Darabahu HatRaI sakatato Harakatuhu (A) or Hrkth Oasokatato↓ (TA) (tropical:) [He beat him until his motion became stilled]; and HtRI Oasokata↓ (assumed tropical:) [until he became still]. (TA.) And sakata AlgaDabu i. q. sakana, (S, Msb, TA,) meaning fatara [i. e. (assumed tropical:) The anger remitted; or became stilled, appeased, or allayed]; (TA:) as also Askt↓: (Msb:) and sakata Eanohu AlgaDabu (tropical:) [Anger, or the anger, became stilled so that it departed from him]. (A.) Hence, in the Kur [vii. 153], walamRaA sakata Eano muwsaI AlgaDabu, (S,) meaning, accord. to Zj, sakana [i. e. (assumed tropical:) And when the anger became stilled so that it departed from Moses]: or, as some say, the phrase is inverted, the meaning being walamRaA sakata muwsaI Eani AlgaDabi [And when Moses was silent, ceasing from anger]: but the former is the explanation of those skilled in the Arabic language. (TA. [See also 4.]) You say also, sakata AlHarRu, meaning (assumed tropical:) The heat became vehement, or intense, the wind being still. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] (assumed tropical:) He died: (K:) occurring in this sense in a trad. (TA.) ― -b4- saAkataniI fasakatRu: see 3. ＝ -A2- sakata said of a horse, [from AlsRukayotu,] He came in tenth in a race. (TA.)

2 sakRata
2: see 4, in two places.

3 saAokata
3: saAkataniI fasakatRu↓ [may mean He kept silence with me and I was silent: or he vied with me in keeping silence and I surpassed therein: or it may have both of these meanings; both being agreeable with analogy]. (S, TA; in neither of which it is explained.)

4 Askt c
4. Askt as an intrans. verb: see 1, in nine places. ― -b2- He turned away, and spoke not; occurring in this sense in a trad.: and Askt Eani AlXRaIoCi He turned away from the thing. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Askthu and skRthu↓ (S, A, Msb) both signify the same, said of God (S) [and of a man]; He made him, or rendered him, silent, mute, or speechless; (Msb;) [he silenced, or hushed, him;] namely, a person speaking. (A.) And Askthu EaniI [He made him to abstain from speaking of, or to, me]. (As, TA in art. nSt.) And Askt AlSRabiIRa bisukotapK [He silenced, or hushed, the child with a sukotap]. (Lh, S, A, K.) And Ousokita means He was silenced in a dispute or the like. (A, TA.) ― -b2- [And hence, (assumed tropical:) He stilled, quieted, appeased, tranquillized, calmed, allayed, assuaged, or quelled, it.] In the Kur vii. 153, some read, walamRaA sukita↓ Eano muwsaI AlgaDabu and Ousokita [i. e. (assumed tropical:) And when the anger was stilled so that it was made to depart from Moses]. (Bd. [For the usual reading see 1, latter part.])

sakotN c
sakotN an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (S, &c.) ― -b2- And [hence,] A division [or pause] between two musical sounds, or notes, without breathing; (T, K, TA;) as also sakotapN↓. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also sikRiytN, in two places.

sakotapN c
sakotapN A single state of silence, muteness, or speechlessness. (Msb.) One says, lilojubolaI SaroxapN vumRa sakotapN [To the pregnant woman is attributable a vehement cry, then a silence]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- In prayer, A silence [or pause] after the commencement; [i. e. after what precedes the first recitation of the Opening Chapter of the Kur-án;] which is approved: and, in like manner, after the ending of the recitation of the Opening Chapter of the Kur-án. (T, TA.) ― -b3- See also
sakotN. ― -b4- Also A certain disease [by which a person loses his powers of speech and motion], (S, K, TA,) well known among the physicians; (TA;) [i. e. apoplexy; thus called in the present day:] accord. to some, the word in this sense should be written sikotapN↓, because it denotes a mode [of silence or stillness]; but this is incorrect, being at variance with the authority of transmission. (TA.) ― -b5- See also the next paragraph: ＝ -A2- and see sikRiytN.

sukotapN c
sukotapN: see sikotapN. ― -b2- Also A thing (S, A, Msb, K) of any kind (S) with which one silences, or hushes, or quiets, a child, (S, A, Msb, K,) or other person; (S, K;) [generally meaning a lullaby of any kind for a child:] and somewhat remaining in a bag or other receptacle, (K, TA,) i. e. of food. (TA.) One says, maA lahu sukotapN liEiyaAlihi, and sakotapN↓, meaning He has not any food with which to silence, or quiet his family, or household. (Lh, TA.)

sikotapN c
sikotapN is a subst. from sakata; [signifying Silence, &c.; like sukuwtN used as a subst.;] as also sukotapN↓. (Lh, TA.) ― -b2- See also sakotapN.

sukaAtN c
sukaAtN Constant, or continual, silence. (Msb.) Hence, by way of comparison, one says, AlUifoHaAmu sukaAtN [as though meaning The state of being silenced in a dispute, &c., is a state of constant, or continual, silence: but it seems to mean, more probably, AlAfHAm (as an act. inf. n.) is an act that silences; agreeably with what here follows]. (Msb.) ― -b2- ramaAhu bisukaAtK (AZ, M, K) and sukaAtapK↓, (AZ, S, M, A, K,) to which latter is generally added waSumaAtapK, (M, TA,) He (a man, S, M, and God, TA) smote him, or afflicted him, with a thing that silenced him; (S, A, K;) thought by ISd to mean, with anxiety, or grief, that silenced him, or a thing in consequence of which he became silent: not expl. by AZ. (TA.) ― -b3- [In like manner] one says also, ramaAhu biAlmusokitaAti↓ [He smote him, or afflicted him, with the words, or acts, that silenced him]. (T in art. rm, from Aboo-Málik.) And bihi sukaAtN [He has in him that which makes him silent]: said of one long silent in consequence of disease (A, TA) or of some evil in him. (TA.) And OaSaAba sukaAtFA He met with, or experienced, a disease that prevented him from speaking. (TA.) ― -b4- huwaEalaI sukaAti AlOamori He is at the point of accomplishing the affair. (K.) And kunotu EalaI sukaAti hecihi AlHaAjapi I was at the point of attaining this want, or needful affair. (S.) ― -b5- HayRapN sukaAtN (tropical:) A serpent that bites before one has knowledge of it; (S, A, K, TA;) as also sakuwtN↓. (TA.)

sakuwtN c
sakuwtN: see sikRiytN. ― -b2- Applied to a she-camel, That does not utter the [grumbling] cry termed rugaMC when the saddle is put upon her. (M, TA.) ― -b3- See also sukaAtN, last sentence.

sukayotN c
sukayotN: see sikRiytN. ― -b2- AlsRukayotu and AlsRukRayotu↓, (S, Msb, K,) sometimes pronounced thus with teshdeed, (S,) the former being the more common, (Msb,) The tenth horse in a race; i. e. the last of them; (Msb;) the last horse among those that start together in a race, (S, K,) of the ten that are reckoned; (S;) also called AlfisokilRu (S, Msb) and AlqaAXuwru; those that come in after this one not being reckoned. (S.) The other nine are thus called, beginning with the first of these: AlmujalRiI, AlmuSalRiI, AlmusalRiI, AltRaAliI, AlmurotaAHu, AlEaATifu, AlHaZiIRu, AlmuWamRalu, and AllRaTiymu. (TA.) Sb says that sukayotN is a contracted dim. of sukRayotN; the uncontracted dim. of which is sukayokiytN. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence,] one says, fulaAnN sukayotu AlHalobapi [lit. Such a one is the tenth horse of those that are started together for a wager], meaning (tropical:) such a one is scrupulously nice and exact, or neat, [and therefore deliberate,] in his handicraft. (A, TA.)

sukaAtapN c
sukaAtapN: see sukaAtN.

sukRayotN c
sukRayotN: see sikRiytN. ― -b2- AlsRukRayotu: see AlsRukayotu.

sikRiytN c
sikRiytN (S, A, Msb, K) and saAkuwtN↓ (S, A, K) and sakuwtN↓ (A, TA) and sukayotN↓ and sukRayotN↓ and sikotiytN↓ and saAkuwtapN↓, (K,) [all intensive epithets, and the last doubly intensive,] A man constantly, or continually, silent: (S in explanation of the first and second:) or much, or often, silent, (Msb in explanation of the first, and K in explanation of all above-cited therefrom,) restraining himself from speech; (Msb;) and sakotN↓ signifies the same: (K:) and ↓this last, [which is originally an inf. n., and therefore used as an intensive epithet, like EadolN &c.,] (AZ, K,) and saAkuwtN↓ and saAkuwtapN↓ and sakotapN↓, (TA,) [but the last, which is written in the TA without any syll. signs, is doubly intensive, as is also that next preceding it,] a man who speaks little, (AZ, K, TA,) without inability to express his mind, or to express what he would say, (AZ, TA,) and, when he speaks, does so well. (AZ, K, TA.)

sikotiytN c
sikotiytN: see the next preceding paragraph.

saAkitN c
saAkitN [part. n. of 1; Silent, &c.: pl. sukuwtN]. (TA.)

saAkuwtN c
saAkuwtN: see sikRiytN; each in two places.

saAkuwtapN c
saAkuwtapN: see sikRiytN; each in two places.

QsokaAtN c
QsokaAtN The temperate days in the latter, or last, part of the Sayof [app. here meaning summer]. (K.) ― -b2- Remains of anything: (K:) as though pl. of sukotapN, before mentioned. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, (K,) or OasokaAtN mina AlnRaAsi, (IAar, Lh,) Sundry, or scattered, parties, or classes, of people: (IAar:) or i. q. OawobaAXN [i. e. a medley, or mixed multitude; or the lowest or basest or meanest sort, or refuse, or riffraff]: (Lh, K:) IAar does not assign to it a sing.: some say that its sing. is skt [app. sakotN]; but this demands consideration. (TA.)

UisokaAtapN c
UisokaAtapN, of the measure UifoEaAlapN from AlsRukuwtu; A silence [or pause] of short duration, requiring something to be said or read or recited after it: or an abstaining from elevating the voice in speech; not an absolute silence, in which one ceases, or abstains, from reading or reciting or speaking; for it occurs in a trad. in the words, maA taquwlu fiI UisokaAtatika [What dost thou say in thy AskAtp?]. (IAth, TA.)

ramaAhu biAlmusokitaAti c
ramaAhu biAlmusokitaAti: see sukaAtN.

AlmusakRatu c
AlmusakRatu The last of the qidaAH [or arrows used in the game called Almayosir]. (K.) This is omitted in some of the copies of the K. (MF.)

AlHikomapu Almasokuwtu EanohaA c
AlHikomapu Almasokuwtu EanohaA The secrets of the science of the Divine Essence. (TA in art. Hkm, q. v.)

1 sakira c
1. sakira, aor.
sakara
, inf. n. sakarN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and sukorN, (A, Mgh, K,) or this is a simple subst., (S, Msb,) and sukurN and sakorN (K) and sikarN (Msb) and sakaraAnN, (K,) He was, or became, intoxicated, inebriated, or drunken; (MA, KL, &c.;) contr. of SaHaA. (S, A, K.) [See also sukorN, below.] ― -b2- [Hence,] sakira EalaIRafulaAnN, (A,) inf. n. sakarN, (K,) (tropical:) Such a one was, or became, violently angry with me: (A:) or angry; or enraged. (K.) And lahu EalaIRa sakarN (tropical:) He has violent anger against me. (A.) ― -b3- And sakirato OaboSaArunaA; and sakirat OaboSaAru Alqawomi; and sakirato Eayonuhu: see 2. ― -b4- Also sakira, aor.
sakara
, (TK,) inf. n. sakarN, (IAar, K,) It (a wateringtrough, or tank, TK) was, or became, full. (IAar, K, TK.) ― -b5- And sakirati AlrRiyHu, (A, and so in my MS. copy of the K,) or sakarat, (S, O, and so in the CK,) aor.
sakura
, (S, O,) or, as some relate a verse of Jendel Ibn-El-Muthennà Et- Tuhawee, in which it occurs,
sakara
, (O,) [indicating that the pret. is sakirat or that the aor. is irreg.,] inf. n. sukuwrN (S, O, K) and sakaraAnN, (K,) (tropical:) The wind became still, (S, A, O, K,) after blowing. (S.) And sakara, [or sakira,] inf. n. sukuwrN, (tropical:) It (water) became still, ceasing to run: so says AZ: and (tropical:) it (the sea) became calm, or motionless: so says IAar. (TA.) And sakira, (A,) or sakara, aor.
sakura
, (TA,) (tropical:) It (food [in a cooking-pot], or hot water, A, or a hot thing, TA) ceased to boil, or estuate, (A, TA,) or to burn, or be hot: (TA:) and (assumed tropical:) it (heat) became allayed, or it subsided. (TA.) ＝ -A2- sakarahu: see 4. ― -b2- Also, (IAar, TA,) aor.
sakura
, (TK,) inf. n. sakorN, (K,) He filled it. (IAar, K, * TA.) ― -b3- Also, (S, Mgh, Msb,) aor. as above, (S, Msb,) and so the inf. n.; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) and skRrhu↓, inf. n. tasokiyrN; (MF;) He stopped it up, or dammed it; namely, a river, or rivulet. (S, Mgh, Msb, K, MF.) And hence, sakara AlbaAba, and skRrhu↓, (assumed tropical:) He closed, or stopped up, the door. (TA.) ― -b4- sukirato OaboSaArunaA: see 2.

2 skRrhu c
2. skRrhu: see 4. ― -b2- And see also 1, last two explanations. ― -b3- sukirato OaboSaArunaA, in the Kur [xv. 15], means (tropical:) Our eyes have been prevented from seeing, and dazzled: (S, K:) or have been covered over: (Aboo-' Amr Ibn-El-' Alà, S, K:) and sukirato↓, without teshdeed, have been prevented from seeing: (Fr, K: *) or this latter, which is the reading of El-Hasan, means, accord. to him, have been enchanted: (S:) or both mean, have been covered
and closed by enchantment, so that we imagined ourselves to behold things which we did not really see: (T, TA:) Mujáhid explains the latter reading as meaning, have been stopped up; i. e., have been covered by that which prevented their seeing, like as water is prevented from flowing by a sikor [or dam]: (A 'Obeyd:) and another reading is sakirato↓, meaning, have become dazzled, like those of the intoxicated: (Ksh, Bd: *) AO says that OaboSaAru Alqawomi sakirato↓ means (tropical:) The people became affected by a giddiness; and an affection like cloudiness of the eye, or weakness of the sight, came over them, so that they did not see; and Aboo-'Amr Ibn-El-'Alà says that this signification is derived from sukorN; as though their eyes were intoxicated: Zj says that Eayonuhu sakirato↓ means (assumed tropical:) his eye became dazzled, and ceased to see. (TA.) ― -b4- sukRira liloHaAjapi, meaning (assumed tropical:) His judgment, or opinion, was confused respecting the object of want, is said of a man only before he has determined upon the thing alluded to. (TA.) ― -b5- skRrhu, inf. n. tasokiyrN, also signifies He squeezed his throat, or throttled him. (S, K.) One says, AlbaEiyru yusakRiru Mxara biciraAEihi HatRaI yakaAdu yaqotuluhu [The camel throttles another with his arm so that he almost kills him]. (S.)

4 Askrhu c
4. Askrhu It (wine, or beverage,) intoxicated, or inebriated, him; (S, A;) or deprived him of his reason; (Msb;) as also, accord. to some, sakarahu↓; (MF, TA;) but the former is that which commonly obtains; (TA;) [and skRrhu↓ has the same signification; or its inf. n.] tasokiyrN signifies the causing, or making, to be affected with the remains of intoxication. (KL. [See the pass. part. n. of this last, below.]) The first is also said of qryD [app. a mistranscription for qryS, which may be syn. with qaAriSN, meaning “ sour milk, ” for this has an effect like intoxication when too much of it has been drunk]; and thus applied it is tropical. (TA.)

6 tsAkr c
6. tsAkr He feigned intoxication, or a state of drunkenness. (S, A. *)

8 Astkr AlDRaroEu c
8. Astkr AlDRaroEu The udder became full of milk. (MA.) ― -b2- And Astkrt AlsRamaMCu The sky rained vehemently. (MA.)

sakorN c
sakorN: see sakoraAnu: ＝ -A2- and sikorN. ＝ -A3- Also A certain herb, or leguminous plant, (baqolapN,) of such as are termed OaHoraAr [pl. of HurRN], (Aboo-Nasr, K,) which is of the best of buquwl: (TA as from the K: [but not in my MS. copy of the K nor in the CK:]) AHn says that no description of its general attributes or qualities had come to his knowledge. (TA.)

sukorN c
sukorN an inf. n., (A, Mgh, K,) or a simple subst., signifying Intoxication, inebriation, or drunkenness; i. e. the state thereof; (S, Msb;) a state that intervenes as an obstruction between a man and his intellect; mostly used in relation to intoxicating drinks: but sometimes as meaning (assumed tropical:) such a state arising from anger, or from the passion of love: a poet says,
sukoraAni sukoru hawFI wasukoru mudaAmapK
OanRaI yufiyqu fatFI bihi sukoraAni
[Two intoxications, the intoxication of love and the intoxication of wine: how shall a youth recover his senses in whom are two intoxications?]. (Er-Rághib, TA.)

sikorN c
sikorN a subst. from AlsRakoru (Mgh, K) as meaning “ the stopping up, or damming, ” of the river, or rivulet; (K;) i. e. A dam; a thing with which a river, or rivulet, is stopped up; (S, * Msb, K, TA;) and sakorN↓, originally an inf. n., occurs in the same sense: (Mgh:) the pl. of the former is sukuwrN. (K.)

sakarN c
sakarN Wine: (K:) so, accord. to Fr and others in the Kur [xvi. 69], tatRaxicuwna minohu sakarFA warizoqFA HasanFA, meaning, ye obtain therefrom wine, and raisins and dried dates and the like; this being said before wine was prohibited: (TA:) and the [beverage called] nabiyc (S, A) prepared from dried dates: (S:) so in the Kur, ubi suprà: (S:) or the expressed juice of fresh ripe dates when it has become strong; (Mgh, Msb;) originally an inf. n.: (Mgh:) or an infusion of dried dates, untouched by fire: (A 'Obeyd:) a beverage, (A,) or nabiyc, (K,) made from dried dates and from kaXuwv [a species of cuscuta, or dodder] (A, K) and myrtle, Ms, (A,) which is the most bitter beverage in the world, (A,) and forbidden like wine; (TA;) or made from dried dates and kXwv, disposed layer upon layer, upon which water is poured; and some assert that sometimes myrtle (Ms) is mixed with it, and this increases its strength: (AHn:) also anything that intoxicates: (K:) and what is forbidden [that is obtained] from fruit (I'Ab, T, K) [of the palm-tree and grape vine], meaning wine, before its being forbidden; and AlrRizoqu AlHasanu is what is lawful [that is obtained] from grapes and dates: (I 'Ab, T, TA:) and vinegar; (K;) accord. to some of the expositors of the Kur, ubi suprà; but this is a meaning unknown to the leading lexicologists: (B, TA:) and food: (K:) so accord. to AO alone; as in the following saying of a poet;
jaEalota OaEoraADa AlkiraAmi sakaraA
[Thou hast made the reputations of the generous to be food: or] thou hast made the vituperation of the generous to be food to thee: but the leading lexicologists disallow this; and Zj says that the more probable meaning here is wine. (TA.)

sakirN c
sakirN: see sakoraAnu: ― -b2- and sikiyrN.

sakorapN c
sakorapN A fit of intoxication: (A, Mgh:) pl. sakaraAtN. (Mgh.) You say, cahaba bayona AlSRaHowapi waAlsRakorapi He went away in state between that of sensibility and insensibility, or mental perception and inability thereof. (TA.) ― -b2- And (tropical:) A fit of anger. (TA.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) An overpowering sensation of delight, affecting youth. (TA.) ― -b4- sakorapu Almawoti (tropical:) [The intoxication of death; meaning] the confusion of the intellect by reason of the severity of the agony of death: (B, TA:) the oppressive sensation attendant upon death, which deprives the sufferer of reason: (Bd in 1. 18:) the oppressive sensation, (S, A, * Mgh, K,) and disturbance of the mind, and insensibility, (K,) attendant upon death. (S, * A, Mgh, K.) And in like manner, sakorapu Alhami, (K,) and AlnRawomi, (TA,) (tropical:) The oppressive sensation, &c., attendant upon anxiety, (K,) and upon sleep. (TA.)

sakarapN c
sakarapN I. q. XayolamN; (K;) [or resembling the Xayolam; (see zuWaAnN;) a certain plant, app. called by the former name because a decoction thereof is used as an anæsthetic; said to be] the same that is called murayoraMCu, that is [often found] in wheat. (TA.)

sakoraAnu c
sakoraAnu (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and sakoraAnN, (TA,) which latter is seldom used, and is of the dial. of the Benoo-Asad, as is said in the S and Msb of its fem., (TA,) and sakorN↓; (K; [in the TA sakirN↓, but this is afterwards mentioned in the K as an intensive epithet;]) fem. [of the first,] sakoraI; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) and [of the second,] sakoraAnapN; (S, Msb, K;) and [of the third,] sakorapN; (K; [in the TA sakirahN;]) Intoxicated; inebriated; drunken: (S, Msb, K:) [see sukorN:] pl. sukaAraI [which is said in the TA to be also pl. of sakirN] and sakaAraI, (S, Msb, K:) of which the former is the more common, or, as some say, the latter, and the former of which is said to be the only instance of the kind, except kusaAlaI and EujaAlaI and guyaAraI, (TA,) [to which should be added HuyaAraI, and probably some other instances,] and sakoraI; (S, K;) or this is a fem. sing. applied as an epithet to a pl. n.; (Fr;) and in the Kur iv. 46, ElAamash read sukoraI, with damm, which is very strange, since no pl. of the measure fuEolaI is known. (TA.) Th says that the words of the Kur [iv. 46] laA taqorabuwAQlSRalaApa waOanotumo sukaAraI [Engage ye not in prayer when ye are intoxicated] was said before the prohibition of wine was revealed: others say that the meaning is, when ye are intoxicated with sleep. (TA.)

sukurokapN c
sukurokapN, written by Sh sukorukapN: see art. skrk. (TA.)

sakuwrN c
sakuwrN: see sikiyrN.

sukRarN c
sukRarN [Sugar;] a certain sweet substance, (TA,) well known: (Msb, TA:) a Pers. word, (S,) arabicized, (S, K,) from Xakaro: (K:) n. un. with p [signifying a piece of sugar]: (S, K:) it is hot and moist, accord. to the most correct opinion; but some say, cold: and the best sort of it is the transparent, called TabarozacN; and the old is more delicate than the new: it is injurious to the stomach, engendering yellow bile; but the juice of the layomuwn and naAranoj counteract its noxiousness: it is said to be a word recently introduced; but some say that it occurs in one trad. (TA.) ― -b2- Also Like sukRar [or sugar] in sweetness: so used by Aboo-Ziyád El-Kilábee. (TA.) ― -b3- Also A certain kind of sweet fresh ripe dates; (K;) a sort of fresh ripe dates, likened to sugar in sweetness: (Mgh:) or a kind of very sweet dates; (AHát, T, Msb;) known to the people of ElBahreyn, (T,) and in Sijilmáseh and Dar'ah, and, as some say, in El-Medeeneh, where, how-
ever, they require to be dried artificially. (MF.) ― -b4- A kind of grapes, which, being affected by what is termed maraq, fall off, (K,) for the most part: their bunches are of middling size; and they are white, juicy, and very sweet, (TA,) of the best kinds of grapes; (K;) and are made into raisins. (TA.)

sukRariIRN c
sukRariIRN [Sugary; saccharine. ― -b2- And] Cake containing sugar, or barley-sugar, with almonds, or pistachio-nuts. (MA.)

sakRaArN c
sakRaArN One who makes, or sells, the beverage called nabiyc; syn. nabRaAcN. (S, K.)

sikRiyrN c
sikRiyrN One who intoxicates himself much, or often; a drunkard; a tippler; (K;) as also misokiyrN↓ (S, K) and sakuwrN↓ (IAar, K) and sakirN↓: (K:) or constantly intoxicated: (S:) the pl. of sakirN is sukaAraI, which is also pl. of sakoraAnu. (TA.)

riyHN saAkirapN c
riyHN saAkirapN (tropical:) Wind becoming still. (A.) And layolapN saAkirapN (tropical:) A still night; a night in which the wind is still; (S, * A;) a night in which there is no wind. (TA.) And maMCN saAkirN (tropical:) Still, not running, water. (AZ, TA.)

sayokuraAnN c
sayokuraAnN A certain plant, always green, the grain whereof is eaten: (K: [but this description seems to be an incorrect abstract of what here follows:]) Ed-Deenawaree [i. e. AHn] says, it is of the plants that continue green throughout the whole of the summer: I asked a sheykh of the Arabs of Syria, and he said, it is the suxar, [correctly suxRar,] and we eat it in its fresh state, with what an eating! and, he said, it has green grains, like the grain of the raAziyaAnaj [or fennel], except that they are round: (O:) [in the present day, it is applied to henbane, or a species thereof: accord. to Forskål, (Flora Aegypt. Arab., p. lxiii.,) hyoscyamus datora. See also XayokuraAnN.]

musakRarN c
musakRarN Affected with the remains of intoxication. (S, K.)

misokiyrN c
misokiyrN: see sikiyrN.

sukurRujapN c
sukurRujapN, or sukurRajapN, accord. to different authorities, (TA,) or both, (MF,) not an Arabic word, but occurring in a trad.; [arabicized from the Pers. sukoraJahN, meaning A saucer;] a sort of small bowl-shaped vessel, in [or out of] which one eats: it is of two sizes; the larger holding six ounces; and the smaller, three ounces, or four mithkáls, or between two thirds of an ounce [and some other quantity more or less (for there is an omission in this place in my original)]: in such vessels, placed upon the tables, around the meats, the Arabs used to put sauces and the like to excite the appetite and to aid digestion: expl. by Ed-Dáwoodee as a small, varnished, bowlshaped vessel. (TA.)

sukurokapN c
sukurokapN, (Mgh, and so in some copies of the K,) thus written by IAth, (TA,) [and thus in copies of the S and A voce mizorN, and of the S and K voce suquroqaEN, and of the Mgh and Msb and K voce gubayoraMCu, &c.,] or sukorukapN, thus written by Sh, (TA in art. skr, and thus in a copy of the K,) an Abyssinian word, (TA,) arabicized, (Mgh, TA,) A certain beverage, (Mgh, K, TA,) of the Abyssinians, (Mgh,) prepared from curap [or millet], (Mgh, K, TA,) which intoxicates; the wine of the Abyssinians; also called suquroqaEN [q. v.], (TA,) and gubayoraMCu, (Mgh and Msb and K in art. gbr, and TA in the present art.,) and mizorN [q. v.]. (A in art. mzr.)

1 maA sakifotu AlbaAba c
1. maA sakifotu AlbaAba, (Ibn-'Abbád, K, TA,) and baAbahu, (TA in art, Etb,) aor.
sakafa
, (K,) I did not tread, or have not trodden, upon the threshold of the door, (Ibn-'Abbád, K, TA,) and of his door; (TA;) as also mA tasakRafotuhu↓: (K:) and lahu baAbFA laA OatasakRafu↓ [I will not tread upon the threshold of a door of his; or] I will not enter a house, or chamber, of his. (Z, TA.)

4 Askf c
4. Askf, (inf. n. UisokaAfN, Msb,) He was, or became, an UisokaAf [q. v. infrà]. (IAar, T, Msb, K.)

5 tasakRafa
5: see 1, in two places.

sikaAfapN c
sikaAfapN The craft, or handicraft, of the UisokaAf [q. v.]: (K:) termed by Lth an inf. n., the source of AlUisokaAfu, having no [unaugmented] verb. (TA.)

sakRaAfN c
sakRaAfN: see UisokaAfN.

saAkifN c
saAkifN The lintel of a door, in which turns the SaAYir, (O, K, TA,) this latter word meaning [the upper and] the lower extremity of the door, the upper of which turns [in a socket in the lintel, and the lower in a socket in the threshold]: so says En-Nadr. (O, TA. [The explanation of SaAYirN in the O seems to have been mutilated by a copyist, and requires the additions which I have made, according to modern usage.])

sayokafN c
sayokafN: see UisokaAfN.

OasokafN c
OasokafN: see UisokaAfN, in two places.

OusokufRu AlEayonayoni c
OusokufRu AlEayonayoni The parts on which grow the eyelashes of the two eyes: (IAar, K:) or the lower eyelids. (Z, K.)

OusokufRapN c
OusokufRapN The threshold of a door, (S, O, K,) upon which one treads; (O, K;) as also OusokuwfapN↓: (TA:) or the lintel of a door: and sometimes [or rather almost universally] used in the former sense, which is the only meaning mentioned in the T [and] in the Abridgment of the 'Eyn [and in most other lexicons]: pl, AskAf [app. OasokaAfN, and, if so, anomalous]. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- Also The xrqp [i. e. xiroqap, or rag, or ragged garment, or perhaps it is a mistranscription for Hirofap, i. e. craft, or handicraft, like sikaAfapN,] of the UisokaAf: extr.: on the authority of Fr. (TA.)

UisokaAfN c
UisokaAfN (Sh, S, M, Msb, K, &c.) and OusokuwfN↓ (Sh, S, M, K) and OasokafN↓ and sakRaAfN↓ and sayokafN↓ (K) A maker of boots, (Sh, Msb, K,) or of shoes or sandals; (MA;) or a sewer of boots &c.: (Msb;) or the first word, (Msb, K, TA,) as used by the Arabs [of the desert], (Msb, TA,) any artificer, or artisan, (Msb, K, TA,) thus expl. in the M, and so its three [perhaps a mistake for four] dial. vars., but said by J [in the S] to be a meaning not known, (TA,) except the maker of boots, for he is called OasokafN↓, (K, TA,) i. e. when they mean such as is called UisokaAfN in the cities or towns or villages: (TA:) or a carpenter; (K;) in which sense it is used by Esh-Shemmákh, but J says, [in the S,] only on the ground of supposition; (TA;) and any handicraftsman who works with an iron tool: (AA, K, * TA:) pl. OasaAkifapN (S, Msb, TA) [and OasaAkiyfu]. ― -b2- Also the first word, Skilful with an affair. (O, K.) Sh says, I heard El-Fak'asee say, UinRaka lUisokaAfN bihecaA AlOamori, meaning Verily thou art skilful with this affair. (O.) ＝ -A2- Accord. to Ibn-'Abbád, AlUisokaAfu is also used (O, K) by Ibn-Mukbil (O) as meaning The redness of wine: but this is a mistranscription, (O, K,) and a perversion of the meaning: (O:) the right word is AlUisokaAb. (O, K.)

OasokuwfN c
OasokuwfN: see the next preceding paragraph.

OusokuwfapN c
OusokuwfapN: see OusokufRapN.

1 sakana c
1. sakana, (S, Mgh, L, Msb, K,) aor.
sakuna
, (L,) inf. n. sukuwnN, (S, Mgh, L, Msb, K,) said of a thing, (S, L,) of a thing that moves, (Mgh, Msb,) It was, or became, still, motionless, stationary, in a state of rest, quiet, calm, or unruffled, (hadaOa, Abu-l-'Abbás, L, or qarRa, K,) after motion; (Abu-l-'Abbás, L;) its motion [ceased, or] went away; (L, Msb;) and in like manner said of a man, and of a beast: (Abu-l-'Abbás, L:) and said of anything such as wind and heat and cold and the like; of rain; [and of pain;] and of anger; [&c.;] it was, or became, still, calm, tranquillized, appeased, allayed, assuaged, or quelled; [it died away, passed away, or ceased to be: and it remitted, or subsided; became alleviated, light, slight, or gentle:] and said of a man [or beast or the like, and of a voice or sound], he [or it] was, or became, still, or silent. (L.) [Hence,] one says, sakana AldRamoEu, and AldRamu, meaning raqaOa [The tears, and the blood, stopped, or ceased to flow]. (S and Mgh in art. rqAN.) [And one says of heat, and cold, and pain, &c., sakana Eanohu It passed away from him; quitted him. And sakanati AlnRaAru The fire became extinguished; or became allayed or assuaged; subsided; or ceased to flame or blaze or burn fiercely,] ― -b2- [Hence also, It (a letter) was or became, quiescent; i. e., without a vowel immediately following it; contr. of taHarRaka.] ― -b3- And sakana Uilayohi, (Msb, [where the aor. is said to be
sakina
, but this is either a mistake or rare, for the aor. accord. to common usage is
sakuna
, as in the Kur vii.] 189 and xxx. 20,]) inf. n. sukuwnN (Mgh, Msb) and sakanN, (Msb,) He trusted to it, or relied upon it, so as to be, or become, easy, or quiet, in mind; i. q. rakana Uilayohi; (S and K &c. in art. rkn;) and
AiTomaOanRa Uilayohi; (TA in art. Tmn;) [and AiEotamada Ealayohi; and waviqa bihi; &c.; and he inclined to it; syn. maAla Uilayohi; and became familiar with it; syn. AisutaOonasa bihi, and Oalifa; agreeably with explanations here following;] namely, a thing: (Msb:) and sakana UilayohaA, aor.
sakuna
, he trusted to her, or relied upon her, so as to be, or become, easy, or quiet, in mind; &c., as above; syn. AiTomaOanRa UilayohaA; (Ksh and Bd in vii. 189, and Ksh in xxx. 20;) and maAla UilayohaA; (Ksh in vii. 189, and the same and Bd in xxx. 20;) and AisotaOonasa bihaA, and Oalifa; (Bd in the same two places;) namely, his wife. (Ksh and Bd.) ― -b4- And sakana AlRadAra, (S, MA, Mgh, L, Msb, K,) and fiI AldRaAri, (Mgh, Msb,) and biAlmakaAni, (L,) aor.
sakuna
, (L, Msb, JM,) inf. n. sukonaI (MA, Mgh, L, JM) and sukuwnN (MA, L) and sukonN, (MA,) or sukonaI↓ is a simple subst., and the inf. n. is skn, (Msb, [accord. to which the latter is app. sakanN, for it is there said that the verb in this case is like Talaba, the unaugmented inf. n. of which is TalabN, but this inf. n. sakanu I have not found elsewhere, and what is generally used as the inf. n. or quasi-inf. n. of the verb in this case is sukonaI↓,]) or sukonaI↓ is a subst. in the sense of UisokaAnN, as expl. below, (Mgh,) [or rather it is also a subst. in this sense,] He inhabited, or dwelt or abode in, the house [and the place]. (MA, Mgh.) walahu maA sakana fiI QllRayoli waQlnRahaAri, in the Kur [vi. 13], is from AlsRukonaI (Ksh, Bd) or from AlsRukuwnu: (Bd:) if from the former, (Ksh, Bd,) it signifies To Him belongeth what taketh up its abode in the night and the day; (IAar, Ksh, * Bd, * L, Jel;) meaning, what the night and the day include within their limits: (Ksh, * Bd:) or, if from AlsRukuwnu, (Bd,) what is still, or motionless, (Abu-l-'Abbás, Bd, L,) and what moves; one of the two contraries being mentioned as sufficient [to show what is intended] without the other; (Bd;) app. meaning the creation, collectively, or all created beings. (Abu-l-'Abbás, L.) ― -b5- And sakana, (L, K,) aor.
sakuna
, (K,) He became such as is termed misokiyn [q. v.]; (L, K;) as also sakuna, (K,) and Askn↓, and tskRn↓, and tamasokana↓: (L, K:) and [thus it means particularly] he was, or became, lowly, humble, or submissive; and low, abject, abased, and weak; as also Askn↓, (L,) and tskRn↓, and tamasokana↓; (S, * L;) the former of these being the regular form, (S, L,) and the more common and more chaste; (L;) the latter of them anomalous, [from Almisokiynu,] like tamanodala from Alminodiylu, and tamadoraEa from AlmidoraEapu; (S, L;) and Astkn↓, (L, Msb,) and AisotakaAna↓, of the measure AifotaEala (L, Msb, K) from Almasokanapu (L, K) or from AlsRukuwnu, (Msb,) with A added, (L, Msb,) the vowel of the medial radical letter being thus rendered full in sound, (L, Msb, K,) or it is of the measure AisotafoEala from Alkiynapu, signifying “ evil state or condition, ” (Msb,) or from Alkayonu signifying “ the [piece of] flesh in the interior of the vulva, ” because he who is lowly and abject is the most obscure of mankind. (L. [See also arts. kwn and kyn.])

2 skRnhu c
2. skRnhu, (S, L, Msb, K,) inf. n. tasokiynN, (S, L, K,) He, or it, caused it to be, or become, still, motionless, stationary, in a state of rest, quiet, calm, or unruffled; (S, * L, Msb, K;) namely, a thing: (S, L, Msb:) [and caused it, namely, anything such as wind, and heat, and cold, and the like, as rain, and pain, and anger, to be, or become, still, or calm; stilled, calmed, tranquillized, appeased, allayed, assuaged, or quelled, it; caused it to die away, pass away, or cease to be: and caused it to remit, or subside; to become alleviated, light, slight, or gentle: and caused him, and it, namely, a man or beast or the like, and a voice or sound, to become still, or silent: (see 1, first sentence:)] and Asknhu↓ signifies the same. (L.) [Hence,] one says of God, skRn damoEahu, meaning OaroqaOahu [He caused his tears to stop, or cease flowing]. (S and TA in art. rqO.) ― -b2- [And hence, He made it (a letter) quiescent; i. e., made it to be without a vowel immediately following it; contr. of HarRakahu.] ＝ -A2- tasokiynN also signifies The straightening a cane, or spear, (SaEodap,) with fire [which is termed AlsRakan]. (IAar, L, K.) ＝ -A3- And The constantly riding a light and swift ass which is termed sukayon. (IAar, L, K.)

3 sAknhu c
3. sAknhu, inf. n. musaAkanapN, i. q. jaAwarahu [meaning He lived in his neighbourhood, or near to him]. (TA in art. jwr.)

4 Askn c
4. Askn: see 1, near the end, in two places. ＝ -A2- Asknhu: see 2, first sentence. ― -b2- [Hence,] said of poverty, It made him to be little, or seldom, in motion. (Aboo-Is-hák, L, K.) ― -b3- And, said of God, He made him to be such as is termed misokiyn [q. v.]. (L, K.) ― -b4- And Asknhu AldRaAra, (S, L, Msb, K,) or Almanozila, (MA,) He made him [or gave him] to inhabit the house, or abode; (S, * MA, L, * Msb, * K; *) he lodged him therein. (MA.)

5 tskRn c
5. tskRn, said of a man, is from AlsRakiynapu [i. e. He had, or possessed, or affected, the quality thus termed; meaning he was, or became, or affected to be, calm, tranquil, grave, staid, steady, or sedate; &c.]. (L.) See also Q. Q. 2, below: and see 1, above, near the end, in two places.

8 Astkn c
8. Astkn, and its var. or syn. AisotakaAna: see 1, near the end.

Q. Q. 2 tamasokana c
Q. Q. 2. tamasokana He affected to be like, or he imitated, such as are termed masaAkiyn [pl. of misokiynN, q. v.]. (IAth, L.) ― -b2- See also 1, near the end, in two places. You say, tamasokana lirabihi He humbled, or abased, himself to his Lord; or addressed himself with earnest, or energetic, supplication to Him: and tskRn↓ is like tamasokana. (Lh, L.)

sakonN c
sakonN, a quasi-pl. n. of saAkinN↓, like as XarobN is of XaAribN, called by Akh a pl., (L,) The inhabitants, people, or family, of a house or tent; (S, L, K;) a household. (L.) ― -b2- And The collective body of the people of a tribe: one says, taHamRala AlsRakonu facahabuwA [The collective body of the people of the tribe bound the loads, or burdens, upon their beasts, and went away]. (Lh, L.) ― -b3- See also sakanN. ― -b4- And see the paragraph here next following.

sukonN c
sukonN: see sukonaI. ― -b2- And see also masokanN, in three places. ― -b3- Also, (L, JM, [thus written in both, and expressly said in the latter to be “ with damm, ”]) or sakanN↓, (thus in copies of the K,) or sakonN↓, (thus in the CK,) [but the first is app. the right,] Food, aliment, or victuals, syn. quwtN; (L, K, JM;) like nuzolN meaning “ food (TaEaAm, L, JM) of a party alighting to partake of it, ” and said to be called sukonN because by means of it a place is inhabited, like as the nuzol of an army means the “ appointed rations of an army alighting at a place. ” (L.)

sakanN c
sakanN A thing, (S, L, Msb, K,) of any kind, (S, L,) to which one trusts, or upon which one relies, so as to be, or become, easy, or quiet, in mind; (S, L, Msb, K;) and in like manner, a person, or persons, to whom one trusts, &c.: applied in this sense to a family, or wife, (L, Msb,) as well as to property, (Msb,) &c.: (L, Msb:) and hence [particularly] signifying a wife. (L.) One says, [app. using it in this sense, as seems to be indicated by the context in the S,] fulaAnN Oobonu AlsRakani [Such a one is the son of the sakan]; and As used to say AlsRakoni↓: (S, L:) accord. to Ibn-Habeeb, one says sakan and sakon. (L.) And it is said in the Kur [vi. 96], jaEala OollRayola sakanFA He hath made, or appointed, the night to be a resource for ease, or quiet. (L.) And in the same [ix. 104], UinRa SalawaAtika sakanN lahumo, i. e. [Verily thy prayers for forgiveness are] a cause of ease, or quiet, to them. (Zj, L.) [And sukonapN↓ seems to have a similar meaning: for] ISh says, tagoTiyapu Alwajohi Einoda AlnRawomi sukonapN, app. [The covering of the face on the occasion of sleep is a cause of ease, or quiet,] in the case of loneliness, or of fear arising therefrom. (L.) And it is said in a trad., AallRehumRa Oanozilo EalayonaA fiI OaroDinA sakanahaA, meaning O God, send down upon us, in our land, the succour, or relief, of its inhabitants, [app. alluding to rain,] to which they may trust so as to be easy, or quiet, in mind. (L.) ― -b2- Also i. q. masokinN. (Lh, L, and Ham p. 400.) See the latter word, in three places. ― -b3- And Fire; [app. first applied thereto as being a cause of ease, or comfort;] (S, L, K;) as in the saying [of a rájiz],
wasakanK tuwqadu fiImiZalRaho
[And a fire kindled in a large tent of hair-cloth, or in a booth, or shed], (S, L,) describing himself as driven to have recourse thereto by the night, and by a moist wind, or a wind cold with moisture; and [afterwards used without any allusion to its being a cause of ease, or comfort,] as in the saying of another, describing a cane,
OaqaAmahaA bisakanK waOadohaAno
meaning He straightened it with fire and oils. (L.) ― -b4- And Mercy, pity, or compassion. (K,
[See also sakiynapN.]) ― -b5- And i. q. barakapN [A blessing; prosperity, or good fortune; increase; &c.]. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also sukonN: ＝ -A3- and sukonaI: ＝ -A4- and see saMkinN.

sakonapN c
[sakonapN A quiescence of a letter; its having no vowel immediately following; opposed to HarakapN: pl. sakanaAtN.] ― -b2- tarakotuhumo EalaI sakanaAtihimo: see sakinapN.

sukonapN c
sukonapN: see sakanN.

sakinapN c
sakinapN A place; [properly] a place of habitation or abode: pl. sakinaAtN. (L.) It is said in a trad., AisotaqirRuwA EalaI sakinaAtikumo faqadi QnoqaTaEati Alhijorapu, (S, L, K, *) i. e. Rest ye, or remain ye, at your places, (S, L,) or in your places of habitation or abode, (S, L, K,) for emigration has [ended, having] become no longer needful. (L.) And one says, AlnRaAsu EalaI sakinaAtihimo, [virtually] meaning, accord. to Fr, The people are in their right state: (S, L:) and in like manner is expl. the saying, tarakotuhumo EalaI sakinaAtihimo and sakanaAtihimo↓ and nazalaAtihimo; but the approved explanation is, [I left them] at their places of habitation, which is that of Th; or, as in the M, their places of alighting, or abode. (L.) ― -b2- Also The part, of the neck, which is the resting-place of the head. (S, L, K.) So in the saying, (S, L,) attributed to several poets, (L,)
biDarobi yuziylu AlhaAma Eano sakinaAtihi
[With a smiting that removes the heads from their resting-places on the necks]. (S, L.)

sukonaI c
sukonaI is an inf. n. of sakana in the phrase sakana AldRaAra: (MA, Mgh, L, JM:) or a simple subst. therefrom: (Msb:) or a subst. in the sense of UisokaAnN, like ruqobaI in the sense of UiroqaAbN: (Mgh:) see 1, in three places: or it is a subst. (S, L, K) also (L) from Oasokanahu AldRaAra, (S, L, K,) like as EutobaI is from UiEotaAbN, (S, L,) and so is sakanN↓, (Lh, L, K,) [which is app. mentioned in the Msb as an inf. n. of the former verb,] signifying, as also sukonN↓, [so in one place, as on the authority of Lth, in the L, and said in the MA to be, like sukonaI, an inf. n. of the verb first mentioned above,] The making [or giving] a man a place, or an abode, to inhabit, without rent; (L, and Ham p. 400 in explanation of the first of these words;) the term sukonaI being similar to EumoraI. (L.) ― -b2- See also masokanN, in five places.

sukayonN c
sukayonN An ass light, or active, and quick, or swift: and sukayonapN is applied to a she-ass (L, K) in the same sense. (L.) ― -b2- Hence the latter is used as a name for (assumed tropical:) A girl, or young woman, or a female slave, that is of a light, or an active, spirit. (L.) ― -b3- The former also signifies A wild ass. (L.) ― -b4- And AlsRukayonapu is the name of The gnat that entered into the nose of Numrood [or Nimrod]. (L, K.)

sakiynapN c
sakiynapN (S, L, Msb, K) and sikRiynapN↓ (Ks, L, K) and sakRiynapN↓, (L, Msb,) mentioned in the “ Nawádir, ” (Msb,) on the authority of AZ, (L,) but of a measure of which there is no [other] known instance, (L, Msb,) Calmness, or tranquillity; (S, L, Msb, K;) gravity, staidness, steadiness, or sedateness; (S, L, Msb;) and a quality inspiring reverence or veneration: (Msb:) and, as some say, mercy, pity, or compassion: [see also sakanN:] and aid or assistance; or victory or conquest: and a thing whereby a man is calmed, or tranquillized: (L:) pl. of the first word sakaAYinu. (Har p. 62.) One says of a man who is calm or tranquil, or grave &c., Ealayohi AlsRakiynapu [Upon him is resting, or abiding, calmness &c.]. (L.) And it is said in a trad., respecting the Prophet, on the occasion of the coming down of revelation, fagaXiyatohu AlsRakiynapu, meaning And calmness, or tranquillity, and gayobap [i. e., as here used, absence of mind from self and others by its being exclusively occupied by the contemplation of divine things], came upon him. (L.) And in the Kur [ii. 249], it is said, [with reference to the coming of the ark of the covenant,] fiyhi sakiynapN mino rabRikumo, meaning [In which shall be] a cause of your becoming tranquil, [or easy in your minds,] when it cometh to you [from your Lord]: (Zj, L, K:) or, as some say, there was in it a head like that of the cat; when it uttered a cry, victory betided the Children of Israel: (L:) or a thing having a head like that of the cat [and a tail like that of the cat (Bd)], of chrysolite and sapphire, and a pair of wings: (L, K:) or an image like the cat, that was with them among their forces, on the appearance of which their enemies were routed: or an animal having a face like that of a human being, compact [in substance], the rest thereof being unsubstantial like the wind and the air: or the images of the Prophets, from Adam to Mohammad: (Bd:) or the signs, or miracles, with the performance of which Moses was endowed, and to which they trusted so as to be easy, or quiet, in their minds: (L:) or by the taAbuwt to which these words refer is meant the heart, [or rather the chest, i. e. bosom,] and the skynp is the knowledge, and purity, or sincerity, in the heart [or bosom]. (Bd.) In a trad. of' Alee, respecting the building. of the Kaabeh, it is said, faOarosala QllReh Uilayohi AlsRakiynapa, meaning [And God sent to him] the wind swift in its passage. (L.)

sukayonapN c
sukayonapN fem. of sukayonN [q. v.]. (L, K. *)

AlTRurRapu AlsRukayoniyRapu c
AlTRurRapu AlsRukayoniyRapu [The hair over the forehead (of a girl or woman) that is cut with a straight, or even, edge, or with two such edges one above the other, so as to form a kind of border, after the fashion of Sukeyneh,] is so called in relation to Sukeyneh the daughter of El-Hoseyn. (S, L, K.)

sakRaAnN c
sakRaAnN A maker of sakaAkiyn [or knives], (ISd, L, K, *) pl. of sikiynN; (ISd, L;) as also sakaAkiyniIRN↓, (ISd, L, K,) which latter is held by ISd to be post-classical, being formed from the pl., whereas by rule it should be formed from the sing. (L.)

sukRaAnN c
sukRaAnN The canab, (Lth, S, MA, Mgh, L,) [i. e.] the rudder, (MA, KL, PS,) of a ship or boat, (Lth, S, MA, Mgh, L,) by means of which it is rightly directed, (Lth, Mgh, * L,) and made still, or steady; (Mgh, L;) its xadof; (AA, L;) i. q. xayozuraAnN and kawovalN [meaning the same, or its tiller]: (A 'Obeyd, L:) it is an Arabic word. (L.) Hence the saying of Tarafeh, (L,) likening to it the elevated neck of a she-camel, as being long, and quick in motion, (EM p. 73,) [and thus app. applying it to the upper and narrow part of a rudder,]
kasukRaAni buwSiIK bidijolapa muSoEidi
(L, EM,) i. e. Like the sukRaAn of a vessel of the sort called buwSiIR [ascending the Tigris]. (EM.) ＝ -A2- Also pl. of saAkinN [q. v.]. (L, Msb.)

sikRiynN c
sikRiynN a word of well-known meaning; (S, Msb, K;) i. e. A knife; (MA, PS;) i. q. mudoyapN; (L;) as also sikRiynapN↓, (ISd, L, K,) a dial. var., (ISd, L,) occurring in a trad., but the former is that which is commonly known: (L:) so called because it stills the animals slaughtered with it: (Az, L, Msb:) of the measure fiERiylN: (IDrd, L, Msb:) or, accord. to some, its n is augmentative, so that it is of the measure fiEoliynN: (Msb:) it is masc., and sometimes fem.: (Zj, IAmb, * L, Msb, K: *) not heard as fem. by IAar: (L:) held to be only masc. by AZ and As and some others: (Msb:) but sometimes it occurs in poetry as fem. on the ground of meaning [as being syn. with mudoyapN or XaforahN], (Msb,) and as such it occurs in a trad.: (L:) the pl. is sakaAkiynu. (ISd, MA, L.) [See an ex. in a prov. cited voce salFI.]

sakRiynapN c
sakRiynapN: see sakiynapN.

sikRiynapN c
sikRiynapN: see sakiynapN: ― -b2- and see also sikRiynN.

sakaAkiyniIRN c
sakaAkiyniIRN: see sakRaAnN.

saAkinN c
saAkinN Still, motionless, stationary, in a state of rest, quiet, calm, or unruffled: [applied to a letter, quiescent; i. e. without a vowel immediately following it:] still, calm, tranquil, becoming appeased or allayed or assuaged or quelled; [dying away, passing away, or ceasing to be: remitting, or subsiding; becoming alleviated, light, slight, or gentle:] still, or silent. (L. [See its verb, sakana, first sentence.]) ― -b2- Inhabiting, dwel-ling, or abiding; an inhabitant, or a lodger: (L, Msb:) and sakanN↓ signifies the same as saAkinN [app. thus used]: (L:) the pl. of saAkinN is sukRaAnN. (L, Msb.) You say, humo sukRaAnu fulaAnK [They are the lodgers of such a one]. (S, L.) And sukRaAnu AldRaAri signifies The Jinn, or Genii, inhabiting the house. (L. [Respecting the custom of sacrificing an animal to the Jinn on the occasion of buying a house, in order to prevent any injury from the Jinn thereof, see cibojN. The belief that houses are inhabited by Jinn obtains among the Arabs in the present day.]) See also sakonN. ― -b3- [Other meanings are indicated by explanations of its verb.]

Oasokanu c
[Oasokanu More, and most, still, &c.]

masokanN c
masokanN and masokinN; (S, L, Msb, K;) the people of El-Hijáz say the former, (S, L,) and the latter is anomalous; (L;) [A place of habitation;] a place of alighting, abiding, sojourning, or lodging; an abode, or a dwelling; (S, L, K;) a house, or a tent; (S, L, Msb;) pl. masaAkinu: (Msb:) and sakanu↓ signifies the same as masokinN, [thus in the
Kur xvi. 82,] (Lh, L, and Ham p. 400,) as also sukonaI↓, (Lh, L,) and sukonN↓: you say, daArN fiyhaA sakanN↓ and sukonN↓, i. e. sukonaI↓ [or masokanN, meaning A house in which is a place of habitation, or a lodging]: (L: [sakanN↓ and sukonN↓ are there mentioned as syn., each of them, with masokanN and sukonaI, but in different places; and I incline to think that sukonN thus mentioned may be a mistranscription for sakanN: I have not found it elsewhere in this sense:]) and daAriI laka sukonaI↓, in which the last word is [said to be] virtually in the accus. case, as a denotative of state, meaning [My house is for thee,] as made [or given] to be inhabited, or as being inhabited: (Mgh:) or laka daAriI hecihi sukonaI↓, meaning To thee this my house is a lent dwelling-place: and AlmaroOapi sukonaI↓ means The wife's dwelling-place in which the husband lodges her. (L.)

maroEFI musokinN c
maroEFI musokinN Abundant pasturage, [that causes people to abide in it,] not requiring to go away; like murobiEN and munorilN. (L.) ― -b2- OaSobaHuwA musokiniyna They became in the state termed masokanapN. (L, K.)

masokanapN c
masokanapN (L, Msb, K) The state of him who is termed misokiynN: primarily, lowliness, humility, or submissiveness: and meaning also lowness, abjectness, ignominiousness, abasement, or humiliation; and paucity of property; and an evil state or condition; also poverty of mind; and weakness; (IAth, L:) it is from AlsRukuwnu [an inf. n. of sakana meaning as expl. in the first sentence of this art.]. (L.)

musokaAnN c
musokaAnN, meaning “ an earnest, ” or “ earnest money, ” and of which [as well as of misokiynN] the pl. is masaAkiynu, belongs to art. msk. (TA.)

misokiynN c
misokiynN (S, Mgh, L, Msb, K, &c.) and masokiynN, (L, Msb, K,) the latter anomalous, for there is no [other] instance of the measure mafoEiylN, (L,) of the dial. of Benoo-Asad, (L, Msb,) mentioned by Ks as heard by him from some one or more of that tribe, (L,) others saying misokiynN, (Msb,) of the measure mifoEiylN (L) from AlsRukuwnu, because the person to whom it is applied trusts to, or relies upon, others, so as to be, or become, easy, or quiet, in mind: (Mgh, L, Msb:) primarily, (L,) it signifies Lowly, humble, or submissive; (IAth, Mgh, L;) and therefore the Prophet said, AallRehumRa OaHoyiniI misokiynFA waOamitoniI misokiynFA waAoHoXuroniI fiI zumorapi AlmasaAkiyni [O God, make me to live lowly, and make me to die lowly, and gather me among the congregation of the lowly]: (Mgh, * L:) and hence it sometimes applies to him who possesses little and [sometimes] to him who possesses much: (L:) sometimes, (S,) it signifies (S, IAth, L, Msb, K) also (IAth, L) low, abject, ignominious, or in a state of abasement or humiliation; (S, IAth, L, Msb, K;) and weak; (S, L, K;) and subdued, or oppressed; though possessing riches or competence: (Msb:) [therefore] Sb says, it is one of the words expressive of pity, or compassion; [and as such may be rendered poor;] you say, mararot bihi Almisokiyna [I passed by him, I mean the poor man], putting it in the accus. case by the implication of OaEoniI, though it may be in the genitive case as a substitute [for the pronoun], and in the nom. case by the suppression of huwa meant to be understood: (L:) in other cases, (S,) it is syn. with faqiyrN, (S, L, Msb,) meaning (Msb) destitute, i. e. possessing nothing: (L, Msb, K:) or accord. to ISk, mskyn means thus; but the fqyr is he who possesses a sufficiency of the means of subsistence: (Msb:) or the former means possessing somewhat; (L;) or [rather] needy, i. e. possessing what is not sufficient (L, K) for him (K) or for his family: (L:) or caused by poverty to have little power of motion; (L, K;) thus expl. by Aboo-Is-hák; but this is improbable; for mskyn has the meaning of an active part. n., and his explanation [like one of the others mentioned above] makes it to have that of a pass. part. n.: (L:) Yoo says the like of ISk: (Msb:) he used to say that the mskyn is in a harder condition than the fqyr: (S, L, * Msb: *) he says, I asked an Arab of the desert, Art thou fqyr? and he answered, No, by God, but rather mskyn; (S, L, * Msb;) but 'Alee Ibn-Hamzeh says that this man may have meant that he was low, or abject, by reason of his distance from his people and his home; and that he does not think he meant anything but that: (L:) [J also adds,] it is said in a trad. that the mskyn is not he whom a mouthful or two mouthfuls will turn back, or away, but is only he who does not beg, and who is not known so that he may be given [anything]; (S;) but Ziyádet-Allah Ibn-Ahmad says that the fqyr is he who sits in his house, not begging, and the mskyn is he who begs and is given; and hence it is argued that the latter is in a better condition than the former; though it indicates that the former is more highminded than the latter: (L:) accord. to As, the mskyn is better in condition than the fqyr; and this is [said to be] the right assertion, (Mgh, L, Msb,) for the pl. of the former is applied in the Kur xviii. 78 to men possessing a ship, or boat, which is worth a considerable sum; (L, Msb;) but they may have been thus termed because they were humbled and abased by the tyranny of the king who took every ship, or boat, that he found upon the sea, by force; (L;) and it is said that these men were hirers, not owners, of the vessel: (TA voce faqiyrN, q. v.:) 'Alee Ibn-Hamzeh says, that the mskyn is better in condition than the fqyr is shown by a passage in the Kur [ix. 60], where it is said that the poor-rates are for the fuqaraMC and the masaAkiyn; for you will find the classes to be there mentioned in such an order that the second is better in condition than the first, and the third than the second, and in like manner the fourth and the fifth and the sixth and the seventh and the eighth: and he says that the same is shown by the fact that the Arabs sometimes used mskyn as a proper name, but not fqyr: (L:) or when these two words are used together, they differ in signification; and when used separately, they [sometimes] signify the same: (El-Bedr El-Karáfee, TA in art. fqr:) [see more voce faqiyrN:] a woman is termed misokiynapN (Sb, S, L, Msb, K) and misokiynN also; (S, L, K;) the former by way of assimilation to faqiyrapN; (Sb, S, L;) the latter being accord. to rule, for an epithet of the measure mifoEiylN is regularly applied alike to a male and a female; (S, Msb;) or, as Abu-l-Hasan says, this is only when it is an intensive epithet, which misokiynapN is not: (L:) the pl. is masaAkiynu and misokiynuwna, (S, L, K,) applied to men, (K,) or to a company of people, (S, L,) and misokiynaAtN applied to female. (S, L, K.)

1 salRa AlXRaINCa c
1. salRa AlXRaINCa, (S, M, Mgh,) aor.
salula
, (S, M,) inf. n. salRN; (S, M, Mgh, K;) and AstlRhu↓, (M,) inf. n. AisotilaAlN; (K; [in the CK, AliAsolAl is put in the place of AliAsotilaAl;]) He drew the thing out or forth from another thing: (Jel in xxiii. 12:) or he pulled out the thing, or drew it forth, gently: (M, K: *) or he drew, or pulled, the thing out, or forth, as a sword from its scabbard, and a hair from dough. (Mgh.) You say, salRa AlsRayofa, (S, Msb,) aor. and inf. n. as above; (Msb;) and AstlRhu↓, both signifying the same; (S;) [i. e. He drew the sword;] as also AslRhu↓, inf. n. UisolaAlN. (TA.) In the saying of El-Farezdak,
gadaApa tawalRayotumo kaAnRa suyuwfakumo
caMniynu fiI OaEonaAqikumo lamo tusalosali↓
[In the morning when ye turned back, as though your swords were cMnyn (pl. of cuWonuwnN a species of fungus) upon your necks, (for the sword was hung upon the shoulder, not by a waist-belt,) not drawn forth], he has separated the doubled letter: thus the verse is related by IAar: but by Th, lamo tasalRali↓ [for tatanasalRali]. (M.) It is said in a trad., laOasulRanRaka minohumo kamaA tusalRu AlXRaEorapu mina AlEajiyni [I will assuredly draw thee forth from them like as the single hair is drawn forth from dough]. (TA.) And in another trad., AallRehumRa Oosolulo saxiymapa qalobiI (tropical:) [O God, draw forth the rancour of my heart]: and hence the saying AlhadaAyaA tasulRu AlsRaxaAYima wataHulRu AlXRakaAYima (tropical:) [Presents draw away feelings of rancour, and loose, or melt, resistances, or incompliances]. (TA.) And sulRa, said of a colt, means He was drawn forth a saliyl [q. v.]. (M, TA.) ― -b2- Also He took the thing. (Msb.) Hence one says, tusalRu AlmayRitu mino qibali raOosihi UilaI Alqabori, i. e. [The dead body] is taken [head-foremost to the grave]: (Msb:) [or is drawn forth &c.: for] it is said of the Apostle of God, sulRa mino qibal raOosihi, meaning He was drawn forth [&c.] from the bier. (Mgh.) ― -b3- Also, aor. and inf. n. as above, He stole the thing: (Msb, TA:) or he stole it covertly, secretly, or clandestinely; (TA;) and so AslRhu↓. (TK. [But see 4, below, where AslR meaning “ he stole ” is mentioned only as intrans.]) You say, salRa AlbaEiyra jawofi AllRayoli He drew away the camel from among the other camels in the middle of the night: and in like manner you say of other things. (TA.) ＝ -A2- salRa, aor.
salila
, (K,) inf. n. salRN, (TK,) said of a man; (TA;) or salRato, aor.
salala
, [whence it would seem that the sec. pers. of the pret. is salilota, and the inf. n. salalN,] said of a
sheep or goat, XAp; (M;) He, or it, lost his, or its, teeth: (M, K:) on the authority of Lh. (M.) ＝ -A3- sulRa, (M, Msb, K,) in the pass. form, (Msb,) with damm, (K,) He was, or became, affected with the disease termed silR [q. v.]. (M, Msb, K.)

4 Oasolala
4: see 1, second sentence. ― -b2- AslR, (ISk, S, M, Mgh,) inf. n. UisolaAlN, (ISk, S, K,) also signifies He stole: (ISk, S, Mgh:) or he stole covertly, secretly, or clandestinely. (M, K.) See also 1, in the latter half of the paragraph. You say, AslR mina Almagonami He stole of the spoil. (Mgh.) ― -b3- UisolaAlN signifies also An open raid or predatory incursion. (TA.) ― -b4- And AslR He aided another to steal, or to steal covertly, secretly, or clandestinely. (TA.) ― -b5- [See also UisolaAlN below. Accord. to Freytag, AslR signifies He received a bribe: but this requires consideration: he gives no authority but the K, which does not justify this explanation.] ＝ -A2- AslRhu He (God) caused him to be affected with the disease termed silR [q. v.]. (S, M, Msb, K.)

5 tslRl c
5. tslRl: see 7: and see also 1, in the former half of the paragraph. ― -b2- Also i. q. AiDoTaraba [It was, or became, in a state of commotion, agitation, &c.]; said of a thing; as though it were imagined to be repeatedly drawn forth. (Er-Rághib, TA.)

7 AnslR c
7. AnslR It (a thing) became pulled out, or drawn forth, gently; (M;) it became drawn, or pulled out or forth, as a sword from its scabbard, and a hair from dough. (Mgh.) You say, AnslR AlsRayofu mina Algamodi The sword [became drawn from the scabbard: or] slipped out from the scabbard. (TA.) And AnslR qiyaAduAlfarasi mino yadihi [The leading-rope of the horse slipped out or] came forth [from his hand]. (Mgh.) ― -b2- And [hence], as also tslRl↓, (S, M, K,) He slipped away, or stole away; i. e., went away covertly, secretly, or clandestinely: (M, K:) or he went forth, mino bayonihimo [from among them]. (S.) And Ainosalalotu mino bayoni yadayohi I went away, and went forth, deliberately, or leisurely, and by degrees, from before him. (TA.) Sb says that Ainosalalotu [used in this or a similar sense] is not a quasi-pass. verb; but is only like [a verb of the measure] faEalotu; like as Aifotaqara is like DaEufa. (M.) It is said in a prov., ramatoniI bidaAYihaAwaQnosalRato [She reproached me with her own fault, and slipped away]: (S, Meyd, TA:) [originally] said by one of the fellow-wives of Ruhm, daughter of El-Khazraj, wife of Saad Ibn-Zeyd-Menáh, on Ruhm's reproaching her with a fault that was in herself. (Meyd, TA. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. cap. x. no. 2; and another prov. there referred to in cap. ii. no. 78.]) And one says also, bikacaA AstlR↓, meaning He went away with such a thing covertly, secretly, or clandestinely. (TA.)

8 Uisotalala
8: see 1, first and second sentences: ＝ -A2- and see also 7, last sentence.

10 Astsl AlnRahoru jadowalFA c
10. Astsl AlnRahoru jadowalFA (tropical:) The river had a rivulet or streamlet, branching off from it. (TA.)

R. Q. 1 salosalapN c
R. Q. 1. salosalapN [as inf. n. of sulosila (see musalosalN below)] signifies A thing's being connected with another thing. (M, K.) [It is also inf. n. of salosala, as such signifying The connecting a thing with another thing.] ― -b2- [Hence, or the reverse may be the case,] salosalotuhu I bound him with the silosilap [or chain]. (O. TA.) ― -b3- And salosalotu AlmaMCa fiI AlHaloqi I poured the water into the throat, or fauces, [app. in a continuous stream.] (S, * O.) ― -b4- And maAsalosala TaEaAmFA He did not eat food: (K:) as though he did not pour it into his throat, or fauces. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Accord. to IAar, salosala signifies He ate a salosalap, i. e., a long piece of a camel's hump. (O.) ＝ -A3- See also 1, third sentence.

R. Q. 2 tasalosala c
R. Q. 2. tasalosala, said of water, It ran into the throat, or fauces: (S, O:) or it ran down a declivity, or declivous place: (M, K:) or (assumed tropical:) it became [fretted with a succession of ripples] like a chain, in running [in a shallow and rugged bed], or when smitten by the wind. (S.) ― -b2- And, said of lightning, (assumed tropical:) It assumed the form of salaAsil, [i. e. chains, meaning elongated streams,] pl. of silosilapN [q. v.], in the clouds. (M.) ― -b3- And tasalosulN signifies (assumed tropical:) The glistening, and [apparent] creeping, of the diversified wavy marks, streaks, or grain, [resembling a chain, (see musalosalN,) and also likened to the creeping of ants, (see firinocN, and rubadN,)] of a sword. (TA. [See also OavorN.]) ― -b4- And tasalosala said of a garment, (assumed tropical:) It was worn until it became thin; (O, K;) like taxaloxala. (O.)

salRN c
salRN, (M, K,) applied to a man, (M,) Whose teeth are falling out; (M;) losing his teeth: (K:) fem. with p: (M, K:) likewise applied to a sheep or goat (XaAopN); on the authority of Lh; (M;) and to a she-camel whose teeth have fallen out from extreme old age; or one extremely aged, having no tooth remaining; on the authority of IAar. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also salRapN, in two places.

sulRN c
sulRN: see what next follows.

silRN c
silRN (S, M, Msb, K) and sulaAlN↓, (S, M, K,) the former [the more common, and] often occurring in the verses of chaste poets, though El-Hareeree says in the “ Durrat el-Ghowwás ” that it is an erroneous term of the vulgar, and that the latter is the right term, (TA,) signify the same, (S, M, K,) as also sulRN↓ and salRapN↓, (K,) [Consumption: or phthisis:] an emaciating, oppressive, and fatal malady: (T, TA:) a certain disease, well known; said in the medical books to be one of the diseases of girls, because of the abundance of blood in them: (Msb:) accord. to the physicians, (TA,) an ulcer, (K, TA,) or ulcers, (Msb,) [or ulceration,] in the lungs; (Msb, K, TA;) succeeding (tuEaqRibu [grammatically referring to salRap]) either caAt AlrRiYap [i. e. inflammation of the lungs] or caAt Aljanob [i. e. pleurisy]: (in the CK, biEaqabi cAt AlrRiyRpi AwcAti Aljanobi is [erroneously] put in the place of tuEaqRibu caAta AlrRiYapi Oawo caAta Aljanobi: and in what here follows, the gen. case is put in the place of the nom. in four instances:) or a rheum (zukaAmN), and defluxions (nawaAzilu), or a long cough, and attended with constant fever. (K, TA.) ― -b2- Hence the saying, in a trad., gubaArucayoli AlmaroOapi AlfaAjirapi yuwrvu AlsRilRa (assumed tropical:) [The dust of the skirt of the vitious woman occasions the loss of property]; meaning that he who follows vitious women and acts vitiously, loses his property, and becomes poor: the diminution and departure of property being likened to the diminution and wasting away of the body when one has the disorder termed silR. (TA.)

salRapN c
salRapN The drawing of swords; (S, M, K;) as also silRapN↓. (K.) So in the saying, OatayonaAhumo Einoda AlsRalRapi [We came to them on the occasion of the drawing of swords]. (S, M, K.) ― -b2- And Theft: (S, Msb:) or covert, secret, or clandestine, theft; (M, K;) like UisolaAlN [except that the former is a simple subst., and the latter is an inf. n., i. e. of 4]: (K:) one says, fiI baniI fulaAnK salRapN [Among the sons of such a one is theft, or covert theft]: (S:) and AlxalRapu tadoEuw UilaI AlsRalRapi [Want invites to theft, or covert theft]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also (tropical:) The rush (dufoEap) of a horse among other horses, in running: (TA:) or the rush (dufoEap) of a horse in striving to outstrip: (S, TA: [I read fiI sibaAqihi, as in a copy of the S; instead of fI siyaAqihi, as in other copies of the S and in the TA:]) so in the saying, farasN Xadiydu AlsRalRapi (tropical:) [A horse of which the rush &c. is vehement]: (S, TA:) and xarajato salRatuhu EalaI Alxayoli (S) or EalaI saAYiri Alxayoli (TA) (tropical:) [His rush in striving to outstrip proceeded against the other horses]. ― -b2- And A revulsion of shortness of breathing (AirotidaAdu rabowK) in the chest of a horse, in consequence of his suppressing such shortness of breathing [so I render mino kabowapK yakobuwhaA, but this phrase admits of other renderings, as will be seen in art. kbw]: (M, K:) when he is inflated thereby, one says, Oaxoraja salRatahu [app. meaning he has manifested his revulsion of shortness of breathing]; and thereupon he is urged to run with vehemence, and made to sweat, and coverings are thrown upon him, and that shortness of breathing (celika AlrRabowu) passes forth. (M.) ― -b3- [In a sheep or goat, or a ewe or she-goat, it seems to mean Power, or force, of long continuance: see masoluwlapN, voce masoluwlN.] ＝ -A3- See also silRN. ＝ -A4- Also A [basket of the kind called] juwnap: (K:) or a thing like the juwnap, (M,) or like the covered juwnap, which is also called sabacapN; so says Az: (TA:) a receptacle in which fruit is carried: (Msb:) [sometimes covered with red skin: (see HawarN:) in the present day commonly applied to a basket made of twigs, oblong and deep, generally between a foot and a foot and a half in length:] and salRN↓ signifies the same: (M, K:) what is termed salRapu Alxubozi [the bread-basket] is well known: (S:) salRapN meaning as expl. above is not thought by IDrd to be an Arabic word: (M:) [the dim. sulayolapN↓ occurs in the K voce juwnapN, and in the Mgh voce raboEapN, &c.:] the pl. is silaAlN (M, K) and salRaAtN (Msb) and [coll. gen. n.] salRN↓, of
which Abu-l-Hasan says that it is in his opinion a rare kind of pl. [or coll. gen. n.] because it denotes what is made by art, not created, and it should more properly be regarded as of the class of kawokabN and kawokabapN [which are syn.] because this is more common than the class of safiynapN and safiynN. (M.) ＝ -A5- Also A fault, or defect, in a water-ing-trough or tank, or in a [jar of the kind called] xaAbiyap: (M, K:) or a breach between the OanoSaAbi, (K,) or [more properly] between the naSaAYib, [i. e. the stones set up, and cemented together with kneaded clay, around the interior,] (M,) of a watering-trough or tank. (M, K.) ― -b2- And Fissures in the ground, that steal [i. e. imbibe] the water. (TA.) ＝ -A6- Also One's sewing [a skin, or hide, with] two thongs in a single puncture, or stitch-hole. (M, K.)

silRapN c
silRapN: see salRapN, first sentence.

sulaAlN c
sulaAlN i. q. silRN, q. v. (S, M, K.)

saliylN c
saliylN A drawn sword; i. q. masoluwlN↓. (M, K.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A child, or male offspring; [because drawn forth;] (S, M, Msb, K;) as also sulaAlapN↓; (M, Mgh, Msb, K;) metonymically so termed: (Mgh:) or, when it comes forth from the belly of its mother; as also ↓the latter; the former so called because created from the [sperma genitalis, which is termed] sulaAlap: (Akh, TA:) fem. of the former saliylapN↓, (S, M, Msb, K,) applied to a daughter. (AA, K.) ― -b3- A colt; (M, K;) and with p a filly; (S, * M, TA;) the p being affixed, though slyl is of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, because the word is made a subst.: (Ham p. 102:) or, as some say, (M, in the K “ and ”) the former signifies a colt that is born not in a [membrane such as is called] maAsikap nor [in one such as is called] salFI: if in either of these, it is termed baqiyrN [not buqayorN as in the CK]. (M, K.) [See also duEomuwSN.] ― -b4- And A young camel when just born, before it is known whether it is a male or a female. (As, S, TA.) ＝ -A2- Clear, or pure, beverage or wine; (K, TA;) as though gently drawn away from dust or motes or particles of rubbish or the like: such is said to be the beverage, or wine, of Paradise: or cool beverage or wine: or such as is clear from dust or motes or particles of rubbish or the like, and from turbidness; of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN: or such as is easy [in its descent] in the throat, or fauces. (TA.) [See also sulaAlapN, and salosaAlN.] ＝ -A3- The channel of the water, or place in which the water flows, in a valley: or the middle of a valley, (M, K, *) where flows the main body of water. (M.) And A wide (S, M, K) and deep (M, K) valley, (S, M, K,) that gives growth to the [trees called] salam and samur, (S, K,) or that gives growth to the salam and DaEap and yanamap and Halamap; (M;) and saAlRN↓ signifies the same: (M, K:) or this latter, a place in which are trees: (TA:) or a narrow channel of a torrent in a valley: (As, S, TA:) or a low place surrounded by what is elevated, in which the water collects: (En-Nadr, TA:) pl. of both sulRaAnN, (M, K,) or of the former accord. to Kr, (M, TA,) and of the latter accord. to As [and the S], (TA,) or that of the latter is sawaAlRu. (En-Nadr, K, TA.) One says saliylN mino samurK like as one says gaAlRN mino salamK. (S.) The phrase saAla AlsRaliylu bihimo [lit. The wide, or wide and deep, valley, &c., flowed with them] is used by the poet Zuheyr (S, IB) as meaning (assumed tropical:) they journeyed swiftly. (IB, TA.) ＝ -A4- The brain of the horse. (M, K.) ― -b2- The hump of the camel. (M, K.) ― -b3- The nuxaAE [or spinal cord]. (M, K.) ― -b4- And saliylu AllRaHomi The [portions that are termed] xaSiyl [q. v. voce xaSiylapN] of flesh: [the former word in this case being app. a coll. gen. n., of which the n. un. is saliylapN↓ (q. v.); the more probably as it is added that] the pl. is salaAYilu. (TA.)

sulaAlapN c
sulaAlapN What is, or becomes, drawn forth, or drawn forth gently, from, or of, a thing: (M, K:) or so sulaAlapu XaIoCK: (S:) [an extract of a thing: and hence,] the clear, or pure, part, or the choice, best, or most excellent, part [of a thing]; (Mgh; and Ksh and Bd and Jel in xxiii. 12;) because drawn from the thick, or turbid, part. (Mgh.) It is said in the Kur [xxiii. 12], walaqado xalaqonaA QloUinosaAna mino sulaAlapK mino TiynK, meaning [And verily we created man from] what was drawn forth from every kind of dust, or earth: (Fr, TA:) or from a pure, or choice, or most excellent, sort of earth or clay. (Ksh, Bd, Jel.) ― -b2- And [hence,] The sperma genitalis of a man, or human being; (S, TA;) what is drawn from the Sulob [app. here meaning loins] of the man and from the taraAYib [pl. of tariybap, q. v.,] of the woman: (AHeyth, TA:) the water (maMC) that is drawn from the back. ('Ikrimeh, TA.) ― -b3- See also salylN, second sentence, in two places.

saliylapN c
saliylapN: see saliylN, second sentence. ― -b2- Also A sinew, (EaSabapN, (M, K, or EaqabapN, K,) or a portion of flesh having streaks, or strips, (M, K,) that separate, one from another. (TA.) And The oblong portion of flesh of the part on either side of the backbone: (K:) or this is called saliylapu Almatoni: (M:) [or] accord. to As, [the pl.] salaAYilu signifies the long streaks, or strips, of flesh extending with the backbone. (TA.) See also saliylN, last sentence. [Also] A small thin thing [or substance] resembling flesh: pl. salaAYilu. (TA in art. xXm.) And salaAYilu AlsRanaAmi Long slices cut from the camel's hump. (TA.) ― -b3- And the pl., Oblong nagafaAt [or portions of dry mucus or the like] in the nose. (M.) ― -b4- Also [Goats'] hair separated, or plucked asunder, with the fingers, then folded, and tied; then the woman draws from it one portion after another, which she spins: (M:) or saliylapN mino XaEarK signifies what is drawn forth from a Dariybap of [goats'] hair, which is a portion thereof separated, or plucked asunder, with the fingers, then folded, and rolled up into long portions, the length of each being about a cubit, and the thickness that of the half of the fore arm next the hand: this is tied, then the woman draws from it one portion after another, and spins it. (S.) [See also EamiytapN.] ＝ -A2- Also A certain long fish, (K, TA,) having a long minoqaAr [app. meaning beak-like snout, or nose]. (TA.)

sulayolapN c
sulayolapN: see salRapN (of which it is the dim.), in the latter half of the paragraph.

sulRaMCN c
sulRaMCN; n. un. with p; mentioned in the M and K in this art. as well as in art. slO: see the latter art.

salRaAlN c
salRaAlN: see saAlRN. ＝ -A2- [And it seems to be somewhere mentioned in the S, though not in the present art., as meaning A maker of the sort of baskets called silaAl (pl. of salRapN): for Golius explains it, as on the authority of J, as signifying qui sportas qualosque contexit.]

salosalN c
salosalN and salosaAlN↓ and sulaAsilN↓ (S, M, K) Sweet water, (M, K,) that descends easily in the throat, or fauces; (M;) water that enters easily into the throat, or fauces, by reason of its sweetness and clearness: (S:) or cold, or cool, water: (M, K:) or water that has fluctuated to and fro, in the place where it has continued, until it has become limpid, or clear. (Er-Rághib, TA.) And the first and ↓second, Mellow wine: (M, K:) the former is expl. by Lth as meaning sweet and clear, that runs [easily] into the throat, or fauces, when drunk. (TA.) ― -b2- And gadiyrN salosalN [A pool of water left by a torrent] which, being smitten [or blown upon] by the wind, becomes [rippled so as to be] like the silosilap [or chain]. (TA.)

sulosulN c
sulosulN A boy, or young man, light, or active, in spirit; as also lusolusN. (IAar, O.)

silosilN c
silosilN: see silosilapN, in two places.

salosalapN c
salosalapN [as an inf. n.: see R. Q. 1. ＝ -A2- Also] A long piece of a camel's hump: (IAar, O, K:) accord. to AA, it is called lasolasapN: accord. to As, lisolisapN. (O.)

silosilapN c
silosilapN A chain, i. q. zinojiyro in Pers.; (KL;) rings (daAYirN [app. used as a coll. gen. n., though I do not know any authority for such usage of it,] K [in the M daAYirapN]) of iron (S, M, K) or the like (M, K) of metals: derived from AlsRalosalapu signifying “ the being connected ” with another thing: (M: [see R. Q. 1:]) pl. salaAsilu. (S, Mgh, TA.) It was a custom to extend a silosilap over a river or a road, the ships or beats or the passengers being arrested thereby, for the purpose of the taking of the tithes from them by an officer set over it. (Mgh.) ― -b2- [Hence,] silosilapu baroqK (tropical:) An elongated stream of lightning [like a chain] in the midst of the clouds: (S, TA: *) or salaAsilu Albaroqi means what have assumed the form of chains (maAtasalosala), of lightning, (M, K,) in the clouds; (M;) and AlsRaHaAbi [i. e., of the clouds in like manner]: (K: [but I think that waAlsRaHaAbi in the K is evidently a mistranscription for fiI AlsRaHaAbi the reading in the M:]) sing. silosilapN (M, K) and silosilN↓, (K,) thus in the copies of the K, but in the L silosiylN↓, which is [said to be] the correct
word. (TA.
