[See, however, what follows.]) And in like manner, salaAsilu AlrRamoli (assumed tropical:) What have assumed the form of chains (maA tasalosala) of sands: (M:) or salaAsilu signifies (tropical:) sands that become accumulated, or congested, (yanoEaqidu,) one upon another, and extended along: (A'Obeyd, S, O, K, TA:) you say ramolN cuwsalaAsila (tropical:) [sands having portions accumulated, or congested, &c.]: and caAtu salaAsila, which has been expl. as meaning (assumed tropical:) elongated sands: (TA:) sing. silosilapN (M, TA) and siloslN↓, (M,) or silosiylN↓; and AlrRamoli salosuwlu↓, with fet-h [to the first letter], is a dial. var. of silosiyluhu. (TA.) ― -b3- And salaAsilu kitaAbK (tropical:) The lines of a book or writing. (O, K, TA.) ― -b4- And birocawonN cuw salaAsila (assumed tropical:) [A hackney] upon whose legs one sees what resemble salaAsil [or chains]. (M.) ＝ -A2- Also The waHarap, (O, K,) which is a small reptile, [a species of lizard, the same that is called Alsilosilapu AlrRaqoTaMCu, (see OaroqaTu,)] spotted, black and white, having a slender tail, which it moves about when running. (TA.)

salosaAlN c
salosaAlN: see salosalN, in two places.

salosuwlN c
salosuwlN: see silosilapN.

silosiylN c
silosiylN: see silosilapN, in two places.

sulaAsilN c
sulaAsilN: see salosalN.

saAlRN c
saAlRN [act. part. n. of salRa, Drawing out, or forth: &c. ― -b2- Stealing: or stealing covertly, secretly, or clandestinely:] a thief; as also salRaAlN↓ [which is commonly applied in the present day to a horse-stealer and the like] and OasalRu↓. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also saliylN.

OasalRu c
OasalRu: see the next preceding paragraph.

UisolaAlN c
UisolaAlN A bribe. (S, M, K.) It is said in a trad., laA UigolaAla walaA UisolaAla There shall be no treachery, or perfidy, and no [giving or receiving of a] bribe: or, and no stealing. (S in this art. and in art. gl. [See 4.])

masalR c
masalR in the phrase maDojaEuhu kamasalRi XaTobapK, in the trad. of Umm-Zara, meaning [His sleepingplace is] like a green palm-stick drawn forth from its skin [by reason of his slenderness], or, as some say, a sword drawn forth [from its scabbard], is [originally] an inf. n. used in the sense of a pass. part. n. (TA. [See also art. XTb.])

misalRapN c
misalRapN A large needle: (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K:) [a packing-needle:] pl. masaAlRu. (S, Mgh, Msb.)

musalRilN c
musalRilN Subtle of machination in stealing. (TA.)

masoluwlN c
masoluwlN: see saliylN. ― -b2- [Hence, elliptically,] A man (Msb) whose testicles have been extracted. (Mgh, Msb.) ＝ -A2- Also Affected with the disease termed silR: (S, M, Msb, K:) [regularly derived from sulRa, but] anomalous [as derived from OasalRahu]: (S, M, Msb:) Sb says, as though the silR were put into him. (M.) ＝ -A3- AA says that the masoluwlap of ganam [meaning sheep or goats, i. e., applied to a XaAp, meaning a sheep or goat, or a ewe or she-goat,] is One whose powers, or forces, are of long continuance (AalRatiI yaTuwlu quwaAhaA): and that one says [of such] fiI fiyhaA salRapN [in which phrase fI seems evidently to have been preposed by mistake: see salRapN]. (O, TA.)

musalosalN c
musalosalN A thing having its parts, or portions, connected, one with another. (S, O.) ― -b2- And [hence, (see silosilapN,)] Chained; bound with the silosilap. (TA.) [AlmaroOapu Almusalosalapu is the name of The constellation Andromeda; described by Kzw and others.] ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) Lightning that assumes the form of chains (yatasalosalu) in its upper portions, and seldom, or never, breaks its promise [of being followed by rain]. (IAar, TA.) ― -b4- Applied to hair, [as also mutasalosilN↓, (K in art. Hjn,) (assumed tropical:) Forming a succession of rimples, like water running in a shallow and rugged bed, or rippled by the wind; (see R. Q. 2;) or] crisp, or curly, or twisted, and contracted; syn. jaEodN. (Mgh.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) A sword having in it, or upon it, diversified wavy marks, streaks, or grain, resembling the silosilap [or chain]. (TA.) [See also musalRasN.] ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) A garment, or piece of cloth, figured with stripes, or lines; (K;) as also mulasolasN: as though formed by tranposition. (TA.) Also, and mutasalosilN↓, (assumed tropical:) A garment, or piece of cloth, woven badly (M, K) and thinly. (M.) ― -b7- HadiyvN musalosalN (assumed tropical:) A tradition [related by an uninterrupted chain of transmitters,] such as when one says, I met face to face such a one who said, I met face to face such a one, and so on, to the Apostle of God. (O, TA.)

mutasalosilN c
mutasalosilN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) A garment worn until it has become thin, (TA.)

1 salaOa AlsRamona c
1. salaOa AlsRamona, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
salaAa
, (M, Msb, K,) inf. n. saloCN; (M, Msb;) and AstlOhu↓; (S, K;) He cooked the samon [here meaning butter], (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) and worked it together, (S, Mgh, K,) and melted its zubod [or fresh, unclarified, portion], (M,) until it became clear (Mgh, Msb) from the milk remaining in it; (Msb;) he cleared the smn [or butter] from the zubod [or fresh, unclarified, portion]; (Ham p. 2, in explanation of the former phrase; [i. e. he clarified the butter:] and suliYa samonFA, said of fresh butter, it was made into samon [or clarified butter; i. e., was clarified]. (Mgh.) ― -b2- And salaOa Alsimosima, (M, K,) [aor. and] inf. n. as above, (M,) He pressed the sesame, or sesamum, (M, K,) and extracted its oil. (M.) ＝ -A2- salaOa AlnRaxola, (AZ, S,) or AlnRaxolapa, (AHn, M,) or AljicoEa, (M, K,) and AlEasiyba, [aor, and] inf. n. as above, (AZ, AHn, S, M,) He plucked off the prickles, (AZ, S, M, K,) i. e. (K) what are called the sulRaMC, (AHn, M, K,) of the palm-trees, (AZ, S,) or of the palm-tree, (AHn, M,) or of the palm-trunk, (M, K,) and of the [part called] Easiyb [of a palm-branch]. (AZ, AHn, S, M.) ＝ -A3- salaOahu miAYapa sawoTK, (As, S, M, K, *) [aor. and] inf. n. as above, (M,) He inflicted upon him a hundred lashes of the whip. (M, K. *) ― -b2- And salaOahu miAYapa dirohamK, (As, S, M, K, *) [aor. and] inf. n. as above, (M,) He payed him, or payed him in ready money, a hundred dirhems, (As, S, M, K, *) promptly, or quickly. (K.)

8 UisotalaAa
8: see above, first sentence. [See also 8 in art. slI].

silaMCN c
silaMCN [Clarified butter;] the subst. from salaOa AlsRamona: pl OasoliYapN. (S, M, K.) El-Farezdak says,
kaAnuwA kasaAliYapK HamoqaMCa Uico Haqanato
silaMCahaA fiI OadiymK gayori marobuwbi
[They were like a stupid female clarifying butter, when she collected her clarified butter in a skin not seasoned with rob]. (S.) ＝ -A2- See also what follows.

sulRaOCN c
sulRaOCN The prickles of the palm-tree: [a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. with p. (S, M, Msb, K.) ― -b2- Also, (K,) or [correctly the n. un.] sulRaMCapN, (M,) A sort of arrow-head, or spear-head, (M, K, *) in shape like the prickle of the palm-tree: (M, K:) and slACp, app. [silaMCapN] without teshdeed [and with kesr], occurs in a trad. in this sense; for it is said that its pl. is silaMCN↓, of the same measure as HimaArN. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A certain bird, (M, K,) dust-coloured, and long-legged. (M.)

1 salabahu c
1. salabahu, (S, A, K,) aor.
saluba
, (TA,) inf. n. salobN (S, K) and salabN, (K,) from the former of which the pl. suluwbN has been formed, on the authority of hearsay, (El-Jurjánee, Msb in art. qSd,) He seized it, or carried it off, by force; (S, A, K;) as also Astlbhu↓. (S, K.) You say, salabahu AlXRaIoCa, aor.
saluba
, inf. n. salobN and salabN; and UiyRaAhu Astlbhu↓; (M, TA;) He seized, or carried off, by force [from him the thing; or he spoiled him, despoiled him, plundered him, or deprived him, of the thing]. (TA.) And salabotuhu vawobahu, (Mgh, * Msb,) aor.
saluba
, (Msb,) inf. n. salobN, (Mgh, Msb,) I took away from him his garment; (Mgh, * Msb;) as also Aslbthu↓ [perhaps a mistranscription for Astlbthu↓, but another instance of the former of these two verbs, in a similar sense, occurs in what follows]: originally, salabotu vawoba zyadoK [I took away the garment of Zeyd]; but the verb has been made to have zyd for its object, and the vwb is postponed, and put in the accus. case as a specificative [though by rule the specificative should be indeterminate]; and it may be suppressed, [so that you may say simply, salabotuhu, meaning I took away from him what was upon him or with him, spoiled him, or plundered him,] the meaning being understood. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence] one says also, salabahu fuWaAdahu waEaqolahu (tropical:) [He, or it, despoiled him, or deprived him, of his heart and his reason], and Aslbhu↓. (A, TA.) [The latter one might think to be a mistranscription for Astlbhu↓ were it not for an instance of the same verb before men-
tioned, and for the fact that it is immediately followed in the A by wahuwa musolabu AlEaqoli: perhaps, however, musolab may be here a mistake for musolib.] ― -b3- And Ausolubo hecihi AlqaSabapa (assumed tropical:) Peel thou this cane, or reed. (TA.) ― -b4- [In grammar and logic, salobN is used to signify (assumed tropical:) Privation, or deprivation, in a general sense; and (assumed tropical:) negation; opposed to UivobaAtN and UiyjaAbN.] ＝ -A2- salobN [as an inf. n. of which the verb (app. salaba) is not mentioned] (assumed tropical:) The going, or journeying, lightly and quickly. (M, K.) Ru-beh says,
qado qadRaHato mino salobihinRa salobaA
qaAruwrapu AlEayoni faSaArato waqobaA
(assumed tropical:) [The black of the eye became depressed so that it became a hollow in consequence of their going with much lightness and quickness: salobaA, for salobFA, being an absolute complement to the inf. n. in salobihinRa]. (M. [See also 7.]) ＝ -A3- saliba [or salibato, as appears from what follows], aor.
salaba
, (assumed tropical:) He [or she] put on black garments (K, TA) which women wear at assemblies for the purpose of mourning. (TA. [See also 5.])

2 salRaba
2: see 5, in three places.

3 sAlbhu AlXRaIoCa c
3. sAlbhu AlXRaIoCa, if used, means He contended with him in a mutual endeavour to seize, or carry off, the thing by force. See 6.]

4 Aslbt c
4. Aslbt, said of a she-camel, (S, M, K,) (tropical:) She became deprived of her young one by death (M, K, TA) or by some other means: (M, TA:) or she cast her young one in an imperfect state. (S, M, K.) ― -b2- Aslb AlXRajaru (tropical:) The trees became bare of their fruit, and dropped their leaves. (K, TA.) ― -b3- Aslb AlvRumaAmu (S, TA) (assumed tropical:) The vmAm [or panic grass] put forth its xuwS [or leaves, so that it became fit to be cut: see salabN]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 1, in two places.

5 tslRbt c
5. tslRbt, (S, K,) said of a woman, (S,) i. q. OaHadRato [i. e. (assumed tropical:) She abstained from the wearing of ornaments, and the use of perfumes, and dye for the hands &c., and put on the garments of mourning,] EalaI zawojihaA [for her husband]: (K:) or, as some say, UiHodaAdN is for the husband; (S, A;) but tasalRubN is sometimes for another than the husband: (S, TA:) [therefore] tslRbt signifies (assumed tropical:) she put on the black garments of mourning; (M, TA;) as also slRibt↓: (M, A:) you say, EalaI tusalRibu↓ zawojihaA or HamiymihaA (Lh, M) (assumed tropical:) She puts on the black garments of mourning [for her husband or her loved and loving relation or friend]: (M:) and EalaI mayRitihaA salRabato↓ (assumed tropical:) She put on the black garments of mourning for her dead one: tasoliybN having a general application. (A.)

6 tsAlbA AlXRaIoCa c
6. tsAlbA AlXRaIoCa They both contended together, each endeavouring to seize, or carry off, the thing by force. The inf. n. occurs in the S and K in art. xls, as a syn. of taxaAlusN.]

7 Anslb c
7. Anslb (assumed tropical:) He went a very quick pace: (K:) or he went well; said of a horse and of a camel: (KL:) but mostly (TA) one says, Anslbt AlnRaAqapu (assumed tropical:) The she-camel went so quick a pace that she was as though she went forth from her skin: (S, TA:) [or she outstripped: see an ex. voce EaAsijN.]

8 Uisotalaba
8: see 1, in four places.

silobN c
silobN The longest [thing] of the apparatus of the plough: (AHn, M, K:) or a piece of wood that is joined to the base of the luWomap [here meaning ploughshare], its end being [inserted] in the hole, or perforation, of the latter. (M, K.)

salabN c
salabN: see saliybN. ― -b2- Spoil, plunder, or booty; (TA;) what is seized, or carried off, by force, (M, Msb, K, TA,) from a man, of spoils, whatever it be; (TA;) comprising all the clothing that is upon the man; (Mgh, Msb, TA;) accord. to Lth and Az (Mgh) and the Bári'; (Msb;) or whatever one of two antagonists in war takes from the other, of the things upon him and with him, i. e. of clothes and weapons, and his beast: of the measure faEalN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, i. e., (TA,) i. q. masoluwbN [used in the manner of a subst., or as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant]: (Mgh, TA:) pl. OasolaAbN. (M, A, Msb, K.) You say, Oaxaca salaba Alqatiyli [He took the spoil of the slain man], and OasolaAba AlqatolaI [the spoils of the slain men]. (A.) ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) The hide and shanks and paunch of a slaughtered animal. (K. [App. so called because given to the slaughterer, as though they were his spoil; or, in the case of an animal of the chase, to the dog or dogs: see the verses cited voce badanN.]) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) The peel, or rind, [or skin,] of a cane, or reed, (K, TA,) and of a tree. (TA.) And [particularly] The bark, or rind, of a kind of tree (S, K) well known (S) in El-Yemen, of which ropes are made, (S, K,) and which is coarser and harder than the fibres of the Theban palm-tree: (S:) hence it is that a well-known kind of [thick] rope [made of the fibres of the common palm-tree] is called by the vulgar salabapN↓: (TA:) or the bark of a kind of tree of which are made [baskets of the kind called] silaAl: (Sh, TA:) there is a market called suwqu AlsRalRaAbiyna↓ in El-Medeeneh, (Sh, S, K, TA,) and in Mekkeh also, as being the market [of the sellers, or manufacturers, of what are made] of salab: (Sh, TA:) it is also [said to be] (K) a certain kind of tall tree, (M, K,) growing symmetrically, which is taken and laid beneath hot ashes (yumalRu) and then split asunder, whereupon there comes forth form it a white muXaAqap [or coarse fibrous substance] like [the fibres of the palm-tree, called] liyf; and it is one of the best of the materials of which ropes are made: the n. un. is with p: (M:) and (M, K) AHn says, (M,) it is a certain plant (M, K) which grows in form like candles, except that it is larger and longer, and of which are made ropes of every sort: (M:) and (M, K) some say, (M,) it is the fibrous substance (lyf) of the Theban palm-tree, (M, K,) this Lth asserts it to be, (TA,) which is brought from Mekkeh, (M,) and Lth adds, and it is white; but Az says that Lth has erred respecting it: A'Obeyd says, I asked respecting it, and was told, it is not the fibrous substance of the Theban palm-tree, but is a kind of tree well known in El-Yemen, of which ropes are made: and some say that it is the xuwS [or leaves] of the vamaAm [or panic grass]: and this [says SM] is what is commonly known among us in El-Yemen: (TA:) [accord. to Forskål, (Flor. Aegypt. Arab., p. cx.) this name is applied in El-Yemen to a species of hyacinth, which he terms hyacinthus aporus.] A poet says, (S,) namely, [Murrah] Ibn-Mahkán [El-Temeemee], (M,)
fanaXonaXa Aljiloda EanohaAwahoIa baArikapN
kamaA tunaXoniXu kafRaA faAtilK salabaA
(S, M, *) i. e. And he stripped off quickly the skin [from her, while she was lying upon her breast, like as the two hands of the twister of ropes strips off quickly the seleb]: (S in art. nX:) some read qaAtilK, meaning [by the word following it] “ what is seized, or carried off by force, from one slain: ” (M:) As read faAtilK, with f; IAar, with q: Th says that the right reading is that of As. (S in the present art.)

salibN c
salibN Light, or active, (K, TA,) and quick. (TA.) You say, rajulN salibu Alyadayoni biAlTRaEoni A man light, or active, in the arms, or hands, in thrusting, or piercing: and vaworN salibu AlTRaEoni biAlqaroni A bull light, or active, in thrusting, or piercing, with the horn. (S, TA.) And farasN salibu AlqawaAYimi A horse light, or active, (S, M, K,) in the legs, (M, K,) [i. e.,] in the shifting of the legs: (S:) or, accord. to Az, the right meaning is, long in the legs: (TA:) [for] ― -b2- salibN signifies also Long or tall; (S, M, K;) applied to a spear, and to a man [&c.]: pl. sulubN. (M.)

sulubN c
sulubN, as a sing., see saliybN, in three places. ― -b2- It is also a pl. of salibN [q. v., last sentence]: (M:) and of silaAbN, as a subst.: (S, K:) and of saluwbN as an epithet applied to a spear: (Ham p. 171:) and of the same, (S, M,) or of silaAbN, (M,) as an epithet applied to a she-camel (S, M) and to a woman: (M:) and of saliybN as an epithet applied to a tree. (S.)

sulobapN c
sulobapN i. q. jurodapN [i. e. The denuded, or unclad, part, or parts, of the body]: (IAar, K:) or a state of nudity. (TA.) One says, maA OaHosana sulobatahaA [How goodly is what is unclad of her person! or, her state of nudity!]. (K.)

salabapN c
salabapN: see salabN, in the former half of the paragraph: ― -b2- and see also silaAbN. ＝ -A2- Also A string, or cord, that is tied to the xaTom [i. e. muzzle, or nose,] of the camel, exclusive of the xiTaAm [q. v.]. (M.) ― -b2- And A sinew that is bound upon an arrow: accord. to AHn, the sinew that is wound upon the liyT [or skin of the reed, or cane,] of the arrow. (M.)

silaAbN c
silaAbN sing. of sulubN, which signifies The black garments of women at their assemblies for mourning: (S:) MF says that the former is expl. in the K as meaning black garments, which necessarily implies that it is a pl.; and the latter is there said to be its pl., which necessarily implies that it is a sing.: (TA:) [but it may be replied that the
author of the K regarded the former as a pl. without a sing.; and the latter, as a pl. pl.:] or both signify black garments worn by women; and the sing. is salabapN↓: (M:) accord. to the T, silaAbN signifies a black garment with which a woman mourning for the death of her husband covers her head: accord. to the R, a black xiroqap [or piece torn off from a garment or cloth] that is worn by a woman bereft of her child, or of a person beloved, by death. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also saliybN.

saluwbN c
saluwbN: see saliybN, in four places. ＝ -A2- Also A spear that takes away life: pl. sulubN. (Ham p. 171.)

saliybN c
saliybN i. q. masoluwbN↓ [as meaning Seized, or carried off, by force: ― -b2- and more commonly spoiled, despoiled, plundered, or deprived of what was upon one or with one]: (S, A, * Msb:) as also salabN↓ [but app. in the former sense only]. (S.) [Hence] one says XajarapN saliybN (tropical:) A tree despoiled, or deprived, of its leaves and its branches: (M, K, TA:) or of which the leaves and fruit have been taken: (A:) pl. sulubN, as in the phrases naxolN sulubN palm-trees upon which is no fruit, and XajarN sulubN trees upon which are no leaves; the sing. being of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN: (S:) and one says also XajarapN sulubN↓, [using sulubN as a sing., like other words of the same measure mentioned in what follows,] meaning a tree of which the leaves have become scattered, or strewn. (Az, TA.) And saliybN is applied to a woman as meaning (assumed tropical:) Whose husband has died, or her loved and loving relation or friend, and who puts on the black garments of mourning for him; as also musalRibN↓ and saluwbN↓: (Lh, M:) or musalRibN↓, so applied, signifies [simply] (assumed tropical:) putting on, or wearing, the black garments of mourning. (M. [See an ex. of this last word with the affix p, used as a pl., in a verse cited voce xaTobN; and an ex. of its pl., musalRibaAt, in a verse cited voce vadoIu.]) Also, applied, to a she-camel, and so saAlibN↓ and saluwbN↓ and musolibN↓, (K,) the last in one instance in the copies of the K erroneously written musalRibN, (TA,) and sulubN↓, (K, TA,) with damm to the first and second letters, (TA,) [in the CK sulobN, and said to be with damm,] or saluwbN↓ thus applied, (S, M,) and silaAbN↓, (M,) (assumed tropical:) Whose young has died: (M, K:) or that has cast her young one in an imperfect state: (S, M, K: and in this latter sense, as applied to a she-camel, musolibN↓ is particularly mentioned in the M:) and in like manner applied to a woman: (M, K:) the pl. (of saluwbN, S, M, or silaAbN, M) is sulubN (S, M, K, TA, in the last expressly stated to be like kutubN, but in the CK sulobN,) and salaAYibu: (M, K:) and sometimes they said AimoraOapN sulubN↓, like naAqapN EuluTN and farasN furuTN, and numerous other instances that have been enumerated by A'Obeyd, in which words of the measure fuEulN, without p, are used as fem. epithets: (M:) or saluwbN↓ signifies (tropical:) a she-camel whose young one has been taken; and its pl. is salaAYibu; (A:) and, applied to a she-camel, it signifies also AalRatiI yuromaI waladuhaA (tropical:) [which may mean whose young one is cast abortively; or cast away because abortive; or cast at, or shot at, and killed]: (L, TA:) and is also applied to a she-gazelle, as meaning despoiled, or deprived, of her young one: and so saAlibN↓. (M.) Applied to a man, (M,) it signifies also AlEaqoli musotalabu↓ (assumed tropical:) [Despoiled, or deprived, of reason]; (M, K;) and you say [also] AlEaqoli musolabu↓, [perhaps a mistranscription for musolib↓, see 1,] a tropical expression: (A:) pl. salobaI. (M, K.)

salabuwtN c
salabuwtN, (Lh, M, K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, salabuwbN,]) of the measure faEaluwtN, from salabahu AlXRaIoCa, (M,) and salRaAbapN↓, are [doubly intensive] epithets of which each is applied to a man and to a woman; (Lh, M, K;) meaning Wont to spoil, or plunder, people [very often, or] constantly. (TK.)

salRaAbN c
salRaAbN [One who spoils, or plunders, people much or often. ＝ -A2- And A seller, or manufacturer, of ropes, or baskets, made of salab]: see its pl., voce salabN.

salRaAbapN c
salRaAbapN: see salabuwtN.

saAlibN c
saAlibN: see saliybN, in two places.

OusoluwbN c
OusoluwbN A row of palm-trees; as also OusokuwbN. (IAar, TA in the present art. and in art. skb. [This is app. the primary signification; as seems to be indicated, by its occupying the first place, in the TA.]) ― -b2- A road, or way, (M, Msb, K, TA,) that one takes: (M, TA:) any extended road or way: a way or direction [in which one goes]: (TA:) a way, course, mode, or manner, of acting or conduct or the like: (A, TA:) a mode, manner, sort, or species; syn. fanRN: (S, M, * Msb, TA:) pl. OasaAliybu. (S, M, A, Msb.) You say, huwa EalaI OusoluwbK mino OasaAliybi Alqawomi, i. e. [He is following] a way of the ways of the people, or party. (Msb.) And humo fiI Ousoluwbi sawoCK [They are in a bad, or an evil, way]. (TA.) And salaka Ousoluwbahu He pursued his way, course, mode, or manner, of acting or conduct or the like. (A, TA.) And Oaxaca fiI OasaAliyba mina Alqawoli He began, or entered upon, modes, manners, sorts, or species, [meaning varieties, or diversities,] of speech; syn. funuwnK, (S,) or OafaAniyna. (M.) And kalaAmuhu EalaI OasaAliyba HasanapK [His speech, or language, is according to good, or beautiful, modes, manners, sorts, or species]. (A, TA.) And one says of him who is proud, Oanofuhu fiI OusoluwbK (M, A) [His nose is kept in one direction], meaning (tropical:) he looks not to the right nor to the left. (A.) [Hence it is said that] OusoluwbN signifies also (tropical:) Elevation in the nose, from pride. (K, TA.) ― -b3- Also The aperture of a watering-trough, or tank, through which the water flows. (IAar, TA in art. byb.) ― -b4- And The neck of the lion. (K.)

OusoluwbapN c
OusoluwbapN A certain game of the Arabs of the desert: or some action that they perform among them: one says, bayonahumo OusoluwbapN [Among them is a performance of what is termed Aslwbp]. (Lh, M.)

musolabu AlEaqoli c
musolabu AlEaqoli: see saliybN, last sentence.

musolibN c
musolibN: see saliybN, in three places.

musalRibN c
musalRibN: see saliybN, in two places. ― -b2- maAliI OaraAka musalRibFA i. e. [What hath happened to me that I see thee] unfamiliar, not inclining to any one? is a saying whereby a man is likened to a wild animal: one says also, UinRahu lawaHoXIRN musalRibN, meaning Verily he is unsociable and ungentle. (AZ, L, TA.)

masoluwbN c
masoluwbN: see saliybN, first sentence.

musotalabu AlEaqoli c
musotalabu AlEaqoli: see saliybN, last sentence.

Almusotalibu c
Almusotalibu the name of A sword of 'Amr Ibn Kulthoom: and of another, belonging to Aboo-Dahbal. (K.)

1 salata AlmiEaI c
1. salata AlmiEaI, aor.
salita
, (M, K) and
saluta
, (K,) inf. n. salotN, (M, TA,) He extracted, or made to come forth, [the contents of] the gut [by compressing it] with his hand. (M, K. [In both it is expl. by Oaxorajahu biyadihi: but it seems that a fault has been accidentally committed by a copyist in the former or in its original, and thence passed into the latter; and that the words which I have supplied are necessary to explain the true meaning. That such is the case, appears from what here follows.]) It is said in the L that AlsRalotu signifies The griping, with the hand, a thing that is contaminated by dirt, or filth, so that what is in it comes forth; and thus is done with a gut. (TA.) It is also said to signify The extracting, or causing to come forth, what is fluid, or moist, adhering to another thing. (MF, TA.) [Hence,] salata xamoXahu i. e. muxaATahu Eano Oanofihi [He cleansed his nose of the mucus that was in it by compressing it with his fingers]: occurring in two trads.; in one of which, the Prophet is related to have been in the habit of doing this to El-Hoseyn when he used to carry him upon his shoulder. (TA.) [Hence, likewise,] it is said in a trad., fayanofucu AljaHiymu UilaI jawofihi fayasolutu maAfiyhi, i. e. [And the fire of Hell shall penetrate to his inside, and] shall exscind and extirpate what is in it. (TA.) ― -b2- You say also, salata AlqaSoEapa, (S, A, K,) aor.
saluta
, inf. n. salotN; (S;) and AstlthA↓; (K;) He cleansed the bowl by taking off with his finger what remained upon its sides; (S;) he wiped the bowl (A, K) with his fingers (A) or with his finger. (K.) And salatato xiDaAbahaA Eano yadihaA, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
saluta
, inf. n. salotN, (Msb,) She cast from her, or from her hand, the remains of her stuff for dyeing the hands or hair: (S, K:) or she put away, or removed, that stuff from her hand: (Msb:) or she wiped off, and cast away, that stuff from her hand: (TA:) or salata AlxiDaAba, aor.
saluta
, he took away, and wiped off, the material for dyeing the hands or hair; and in like manner. a similar thing; and sweat; and blood. (Mgh.) salata AldRama EanohaA occurs in a trad. as meaning He
removed the blood [from her or it]. (TA.) ― -b3- salata dama Albadanapi (M, K) means, accord. to Lh, He scraped off the blood of the bdnp [or beast brought to Mekkeh for sacrifice, or there sacrificed,] with the knife: but [ISd says, (and in like manner halata dama Albadanapi is expl. in the L as on the authority of Lh,)] in my opinion the meaning is, he scraped off the skin of the bdnp with the knife so that he made its blood to appear. (M. [The explanation in the K is made up from the two different explanations in the M, being as follows: qaXarahu HatRaI OaZohara damahaA, as though meaning he scraped off the dried blood of the bdnp so that he made its fresh blood to appear: but in the copy of the K followed in the TA, AlnRadabap (i. e. the scar) is put in the place of Albadanap, and the former of these two (i. e. Alndbp) I regard as the right word.]) ― -b4- salata also signifies (assumed tropical:) He cut off a thing. (K. [This is said in the TA to be the primary meaning: but accord. to the A, the phrase here following, in which it has this meaning, is tropical.]) You say, salata Oanofahu, (S, M, A, K,) aor.
salita
and
saluta
, inf. n. salotN, (M,) (tropical:) He cut off his nose (S, M, A, K) entirely (TA) with a sword. (S, A.) And salata yadahu biAlsRayofi (assumed tropical:) He cut off his hand, or arm, with the sword. (M.) And salata XaEarahu (assumed tropical:) He shaved off his hair. (M, K.) And salata raOosahu (tropical:) He shaved his head. (As, S, L.) ― -b5- salatahu (assumed tropical:) He beat, struck, or smote, him: (K, TA:) and flogged him. (TA.) You say, salatRuhu miAYapa sawoTK (assumed tropical:) I inflicted upon him a hundred strokes of the whip. (S, TA.) ― -b6- And salata bisaloHihi (assumed tropical:) He cast forth his excrement, or ordure. (K.)

7 Anslt EanRaA c
7. Anslt EanRaA He stole, or slipped, away from us without his being known to do so. (M, K.)

8 Uisotalata
8: see 1, in the former half of the paragraph.

sulotN c
sulotN A species of XaEiyr [or barley], (Lth, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) having no hush, (Lth, S, Mgh, Msb,) Oajoradu [which may mean either beardless or smooth], (Lth,) [in appearance] as though it were wheat, (S,) growing in El-Ghowr and El- Hijáz; (Mgh, Msb;) the sawiyq [or meal of the parched grain] whereof is employed as a cooling diet in the Sayof [or summer]: (TA:) or i. q. XaEiyr [i. e. the common barley]; (M, K;) as some say: (M:) or the sour (HaAmiD) sort of XEyr: (M, K:) or a white XEyr, without husk: or, as some say, a species of wheat; but the explanation next preceding this last is the more correct, for AlbayoDaMCu and AlsRulotu are mentioned in a trad. as distinct, each from the other, and by the former is meant wheat: (TA:) or a species of XEyr with a thin husk and small grain: (IF, Msb:) or a grain between wheat and barley (XEyr), not having a husk like that of the latter, and thus being like wheat in smoothness, and like barley (XEyr) in its nature, or quality, and in its coolness: (Az, Msb:) accord. to Es-Seydelánee, like barley (XEyr) in its form, and like wheat in its nature, or quality; but this is a mistake: (Ibn-Es-Saláh, Msb:) [gymnocrithon (i. e. hordeum nudym) of Galen: tragus of Diosc. (Golius.)]

cahaba minRiI falotapF wasalotapF c
cahaba minRiI falotapF wasalotapF It (a thing, or an affair, TA) escaped me: (K, TA:) accord. to some, sltp is here an imitative sequent. (TA.)

salotaMCu c
salotaMCu A woman who does not make frequent use of HinRaMC [for tinging, or dyeing, her hands]; (S;) a woman who does not frequently tinge her hands with xiDaAb: (M:) or a woman who does not make use of xiDaAb for herself (M, A, K) at all: so some say. (M.) It is related of the Prophet, in a trad., that he cursed such a woman. (TA.)

sulaAtapN c
sulaAtapN What is extracted, or made to come forth, (M, K, *) from a gut [by compressing it] with the hand. (M.) ― -b2- What is taken off with the finger from the sides of a bowl, to clean it. (S, K. *)

Oasolatu c
Oasolatu A man (S) whose nose has been cut off (S, M, K) entirely. (S, K.)

misolaAtu HinRaMCu c
misolaAtu HinRaMCu [app. An instrument with which HnRMC is scraped off, or removed, from the hand]. One says, OaEoTiniI misolaAta HinRaAYika [Give thou to me &c.]. (A.)

masoluwtN c
masoluwtN That whereof the flesh that was upon it has been taken off or away, or removed. (K.) ― -b2- And A shaven head. (As, S, L.)

silotimN c
silotimN A calamity, or misfortune. (S, M, K.) ― -b2- A hard, or severe, year. (S, M, K.) ― -b3- A [goblin, or demon, such as is termed] guwl. (S, M, K.) ― -b4- A she-camel having no tooth remaining, and whose lower lip has fallen and she is unable to raise it. (K, TA. [The explanation in the CK is faulty: the last words should be laA tasotaTiyEu rafoEahu.]) Some say that the m is augmentative. (TA.) ― -b5- One says also maA OaSaAba silotimFA, [in the CK salotamFA,] meaning He got not anything. (K, TA.)

1 salija c
1. salija, aor.
salaja
, inf. n. salajaAnN (S, O, Msb, K) and salojN, (S, O, K,) He swallowed (S, O, Msb, K) a morsel, or mouthful, or gobbet, (S, O, K,) and food, (TA,) or a thing; (Msb;) as also salaja, aor.
saluja
; (Msb;) and tslRj↓: (O, K: *) or salajaAnN signifies the eating quickly. (TA.) Hence the saying, AlOakolu salajaAnN waAlqaDaMCu layRaAnN [Eating is a swallowing, and paying is a putting off], (S, Meyd, O,) or AlOaxocu salajaAnN Alx [Taking, or receiving, is a swallowing, &c.]: (Meyd, TA:) i. e., when a man receives a loan, or the like, he devours it [greedily]; but when he from whom he has received it demands his due, he puts him off by promising to pay it: (S, O:) a prov., (Meyd, O, TA,) applied to him who takes the property of others and to whom it is easy to do so; but when he is sued for payment, puts off, and it is difficult to him: (Meyd:) meaning that one loves to take, and hates to return, or restore. (L. [See also surRayoTaI.]) ― -b2- salaja AlnRaAqapa, said of a young camel, He sucked the she-camel; (O, K;) as also malajahaA. (L, TA.) ＝ -A2- salajati AlUibilu, aor.
saluja
, (S, K, TA,) inf. n. suluwjN; (TA;) and salijat, aor.
salaja
; (K, TA;) or the latter only accord. to AHn; (TA;) or the latter is better than the former accord. to Sh; (O, TA;) The camels had a looseness (S, K) of their bellies (S) from eating the plant called sulRaj. (S, K.)

5 tslRj c
5. tslRj: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- Also He persevered, or persisted, in drinking (Lh, O, K) the beverage called nabiyc, (Lh,) or wine; (O, K;) like tazalRaja; (Lh;) meaning he made it to enter his silRijaAn; (O;) or as though he filled with it his silRijaAn, (K,) i. e. his Huloquwm: (TA:) and so Astlj↓. (O, K.)

8 Uisotalaja
8: see what next precedes.

saliyjN c
saliyjN: see salajolajN, below.

saliyjapN c
saliyjapN A saAjap, (O, K,) i. e. an oblong and squared piece of wood of the tree called saAj, as brought from India, (TA in art. swj,) from which a door is cloven, or divided off, lengthwise: (O, K:) so says AHn. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also what next follows.

sulRajN c
sulRajN A certain plant, (S, K,) upon which the camels pasture, (S,) soft, flaccid, or fragile, of the shrub-kind; (TA;) also called sulRujaAnN↓, (K, TA,) or sulRajaAnN↓, (CK,) like qmRHAn; (K;) and saliyjapN↓: (TA:) or the slRjAn↓, (O, TA,) i. e. sulRajaAn, with damm to the s, and teshdeed and fet-h to the l, (O,) is a species of the sulRaj; (O, TA;) and this last is one of the largest of the kind of trees called HamoD: (O:) accord. to AHn, (TA,) or as is said by some one or more of the Arabs of the desert, (O,) the sulRaj is a large kind of trees, like the tails of the [lizards called] DibaAb [pl. of DabRN], green, and having thorns, and [of the kind termed] HamoD: (O, TA:) in the T it is said to be a sort of HamoD that ceases not to be green in the summer, or hot season, and in the rabiyE [app. here meaning autumn], and is weak, or weak and soft: Az also says that it grows in the plains, or level tracts, has a fruit, or produce, with a sharpness in the extremities thereof, and is green in the [season called] rabiyE, and then dries up, and becomes yellow: and he adds, [contr. to what has been said above, from his work, the T,] it is not reckoned among the trees called HamoD. (L, TA.)

sulRaHaAnN c
sulRaHaAnN or sulRuHaAnN: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.

silRijaAnN c
silRijaAnN The Huloquwm [properly the windpipe, but here app. meaning the gullet: see 5]. (O, K.) One says, ramaAhu QllRehu fiI silRijaAnihi [May God smite him, or afflict him, in his slRjAn]. (O.)

TaEaAmN salajolajN c
TaEaAmN salajolajN and sulajolajN and saliyjN↓ Good,
or pleasant, food, (O, K, TA,) that is swallowed (K, TA) with ease. (TA.)

Oasolaju c
Oasolaju Bald in the fore part of the head; like Oasolaxu; but the former is the more common. (TA in art. slx.)

salojamN c
salojamN and sulaAjimN↓ Tall, or long; (S, K;) as epithets applied to a horse, and to a man, and to the iron head or blade of an arrow &c.: (K:) or, applied to this last, the former word signifies long and broad: (AHn, TA:) or slender; as also salomajN: and the pls. of these two words are salaAjimu and salaAmiju: which, applied to such iron heads or blades, signify [also] sharpened, or pointed, or sharp-pointed: (TA:) and salaAjimu applied to arrows signifies long in the iron heads. (S.) salojamN and sulaAjimN↓ are also applied as epithets to a camel: (S, K: [in the former it is implied that in this case they have the first of the significations above; but see what follows:]) thus applied, they signify Advanced in age, and strong: (K:) or the former, so applied, signifies strong: (S voce SaloxadN:) the pl. of each is salaAjimu, with fet-h [to the s]. (S, K.) ― -b2- Also the former, applied to the laHoI [or jaw-bone], Strong, (K, TA,) full-sized, (TA,) and thick, or compact. (K, TA.) And, applied to a head, Long in the laHoyaAni [or jaw-bones]. (K, TA.) ― -b3- Also A well ancient (EaAdiyRapN) and having much water. (K.) ＝ -A2- salojamN is also the name of A certain well-known plant; (K, TA;) of those termed buquwl; which is eaten; (TA;) [namely, colza; or brassica napus oleifera: so in the present day:] it is an arabicized word, [from the Pers. Xalogamo,] originally with X, but pronounced by the Arabs with s: (AHn, TA:) one should not say valojamN, nor XalojamN, or this is a word of weak authority: (T, K, TA:) Az says that some pronounce it with X, but that it is correctly with s. (TA.)

sulaAjimN c
sulaAjimN: see the preceding paragraph, in two places.

sihaAmN musalojamaAtN c
sihaAmN musalojamaAtN Arrows made long and broad [in their iron heads]. (TA.)

1 salaHa c
1. salaHa, (S, Mgh, K,) aor.
salaHa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. saloH, (S, Mgh, Msb,) said of a man, (TA,) He voided his excrement, or ordure; (S, K;) [or thin excrement: see saloHN: and] said of a bird, it muted, or dunged; (Msb;) like tagawRaTa (Mgh, * Msb) said of a man: (Msb:) and said also [of other animals, as, for instance,] of a camel, (S, K, TA,) and of a bull. (K in art. vlT.)

2 slRHhu c
2. slRHhu He armed him with a weapon or weapons. (A.) And slRHhu AlsRayofa, (K, TA,) and Alqawosa, (TA,) He armed him with the sword, (K, TA,) and the bow. (TA.) ＝ -A2- slRH AlUibila, (A, TA,) inf. n. tasoiyHN, (TA,) It caused the camels to void sulaAH [or thin excrement; i. e. it purged them]; said of a herb. (A, TA.) [See also 4.] ＝ -A3- slRH niHoyahu, inf. n. as above, He rubbed over his niHoI [or skin for holding clarified butter] with suloH, i. e. rob, or inspissated juice. (K, TA.)

4 AslHhu c
4. AslHhu He made him to void sulaAH [or thin excrement]. (S, K.) [See also 2.]

5 tslRH c
5. tslRH He wore, or put on, [or armed himself with,] a weapon, or weapons. (S, A, L, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] tasalRaHati AlUibilu biOasoliHatihaA: see silaAHN.

saloHN c
saloHN Excrement, ordure, or dung: (L, TA: [and evidently so accord. to the Msb; in my copy of which, and so, app., in the copy used by SM, immediately after the mention and explanation of the verb salaHa, is added, whw slHp tsmyp bAlmSdr; plainly showing, by what follows slHp, that this word is a mistranscription for saloHuhu; and that the meaning is, “ and it is its saloH, an instance of the inf. n. used as a subst. properly so called; ” i. e., the dung of a bird is called its saloH; for the verb is there said to relate to a bird; though in truth it has a general application:]) or such as is thin, of any dung: (L, TA: [and this is the sense in which it is commonly known:]) and sulaAHN↓ signifies [the same: i. e.] excrement, ordure, or dung, (S, A, MA, L, K, KL,) of a human being, (KL,) or of a bird (MA) [and of any animal]: or thin excrement or dung: (MA:) this latter is said to be the correct meaning in a marginal note in a copy of the S: (TA:) the pl. of the former is suluwHN and suloHaAnN. (L, TA.) [ramaI bisaloHihi frequently occurs in the Lexicons &c., meaning He cast forth his excrement, or ordure; or properly, in a thin state.] yaA saloHa AlguraAbi [lit. O dung of the crow], an expression used by 'Omar, means yaA xabiyvu (assumed tropical:) [O foul, or filthy, man]. (Mgh.)

suloHN c
suloHN signifies rubR [i. e. Rob, or inspissated juice, generally of dates,] with which a skin for clarified butter is rubbed over, (K, TA,) for the purpose of seasoning it. (TA.)

siloHN c
siloHN: see silaAHN.

salaHN c
salaHN Rain-water in pools left by torrents: (K:) so says ISh: but not heard by Az from the Arabs. (TA.)

sulaHN c
sulaHN The young of the Hajal [or partridge]; (S, K;) like sulakN and sulafN: (S:) [a coll. gen. n.: n. un. with p: for] it is said in the T that sulaHapN and sulakapN signify the young one of the Hajal: (TA:) pl. siloHaAnN, (T, S, K,) like silokaAnN. (T, TA.)

silaHN c
silaHN: see silaAHN.

suloHaAnN c
suloHaAnN: see silaAHN.

sulaAHN c
sulaAHN: see saloHN. ― -b2- [Also A looseness, or flux of thin excrement from the bowels: diarrhœa.]

silaAHN c
silaAHN, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) as also saliHN↓ (accord. to the K) or siloHN↓ (accord. to the Msb) and suloHaAnN↓, (K,) [the last mentioned in the L as a pl.,] A weapon, or weapons; i. e. an instrument, or instruments, of war; (A, K;) the thing [or things] with which one fights in war, and repels, or defends oneself; (Msb;) anything with which one repels the enemy, as a sword and spear &c.: (Ham p. 73:) or a weapon, or weapons, of iron: (Lth, Mgh, K:) it is of the masc. gender, (S, Msb, TA,) accord. to the more approved usage, (TA,) or that which most prevails, (Msb,) because in the pl. it takes the form of OasoliHapN, which is a pl. form of a masc. n., (S, Msb, *) as in the instances of OaHomirapN, pl. of HimaArN, and OarodiyapN, pl. of ridaMCN, (S,) but it is also fem., (S, Msb, K,) and has also for pls. suluHN and suloHaAnN, (L,) and the pl. fem. is silaAHaAtN. (Msb.) You say rajulN cuw silaAHK [A man having a weapon or weapons]. (K.) And qawomN cawuw silaAHK [A people, or party, having weapons, or arms]. (S, A, K.) And labisa AlsRilaAHa [He wore, or put on, the weapon, or the weapons, or arms]. (S, A, K.) And Oaxaca Alqawomu OasoliHatahumo The people, or party, took their weapons, or arms, each taking his. (Msb.) ― -b2- A sword (Az, Mgh, K) alone is sometimes termed silaAHN. (Az, Mgh.) ― -b3- And A bow without a string (K) is likewise thus termed. (TA.) ― -b4- And A staff, or stick. (K.) ― -b5- silaAHu lvRawori means (assumed tropical:) The horns of the bull. (S, * TA.) ― -b6- cuw AlsRilaAHi is (tropical:) an appel-lation of AlsRamaAku AlrRaAmiHu [i. e. The star Arcturus]. (A, TA.) ― -b7- And Oaxacati AlUibilu silaAHahaA and biOasoliHatihaA mean (tropical:) The camels became fat, and of goodly appearance; (A, L, TA;) i. e. their fat became as though it were weapons with which they prevented their being slaughtered: (L, TA:) and the like has been mentioned before, [voce rumoHN,] in art. rmH. (TA.)

saAliHN c
saAliHN A man having, (K,) or having with him, (S,) a weapon, or weapons: (S, K:) an epithet [of the possessive kind, having no verb,] similar to taAmirN and laAbinN. (TA.) ＝ -A2- And A she-camel that has voided excrement, [or thin excrement,] in consequence [of the eating] of herbs, or leguminous plants. (S, K.)

OasolaHu mino HubaAraI c
OasolaHu mino HubaAraI [More wont to mute than a bustard] (Meyd, A, Mgh) and mino dajaAjapK [than a domestic hen]: the former mutes in the time of fear; and the latter, in the time of security: (Meyd:) a prov. (Meyd, Mgh.)

UisoliyHN c
UisoliyHN A certain plant, the pasturing upon which causes the milk (S, K) of the camels (S) to become abundant: (S, K:) or a certain kind of tree, or shrub, that has this effect: (L:) [see also UisoliyxN:] it was said to an Arab woman of the desert, “ What is thy father's tree? ” and she answered, Xajarapu OabiI AlUisoliyHo rugowapN waSariyHN wasanaAmN UiToriyHo [The tree of my father is the isleeh: froth upon the milk, and milk free from froth; and a long, or tall, hump: these are the consequences of pasturing upon it]: (S, * L:) or it is a certain
herb, or leguminous plant, of those that are slender and soft (mino OaHoraAri Albuquwli), growing in the winter, that causes the camels to void sulaAH [or thin excrement] when they eat much of it: or a certain herb (EuXobap), resembling the jirojiyr [or rocket], growing upon tracts of sand such as are termed Huquwf: or a certain kind of plant, growing conspicuously in plain, or soft, tracts, having a thin and delicate leaf, and a pericarp (sinofap) stuffed with grains, or seeds, like those of the poppy; which is one of the plants of the rain of the Sayof [here meaning spring (see zamanN)], and which causes the cattle to void sulaAH: n. un. with p: Aboo-Ziyád says that the places in which the AslyH grows are sands. (L.)

masolaHapN c
masolaHapN A vagor [or frontier of a hostile country]: (K:) or a place of arms or weapons, (Mgh,) like a vagor and a maroqab [which is an elevated place of observation], (S, Mgh, TA,) wherein are parties that watch the enemy, lest they should make an invasion at unawares, and, when they see them, inform their companions, in order that they may prepare themselves for them: (Nh, TA:) pl. masaAliHu. (S, Mgh.) ― -b2- Also, [in one of my copies of the S erroneously written musalRaHap,] A people, or party, having arms, or weapons; an armed people or party; (S, A, K, TA;) composing a numerous body, in a place of observation, with the keeping of which they are entrusted, at the frontier of an enemy's country; a single person of whom is termed masolaHiIRN↓; (A, * L;) and masolaHapN [also] is thus applied to a single person in a saying of 'Omar: (Mgh:) they are thus called because of their having weapons, or because of their occupying the place called masolaHapN: (Nh:) or the mslHp of the army are a party of capturers that go before the army, exploring for them the way, and searching as spies to learn news of the enemy, lest the enemy should make a sudden assault upon them; not suffering any one of the enemy to enter the territory of the Muslims, and warning the Muslims of the approach of an army. (ISh.)

masolaHiIRN c
masolaHiIRN: see the next preceding paragraph.

Q. 4 AisolaHabRa c
Q. 4. AisolaHabRa It was, or became, right, direct, rightly directed, straight, or even. (S, K.) ― -b2- It (a road) was extended: (S:) or conspicuous and extended. (K.) ― -b3- [And app. It was, or became, spread out, or expanded: see the part n., below.]

suloHuwbN c
suloHuwbN A woman who cares not for what she does nor for what is said to her. (AA, TA.)

musoliHabRN c
musoliHabRN Right, direct, rightly directed, straight, or even: (S, K:) like mutolaYibRN. (TA.) ― -b2- Extended: (S:) or conspicuous and extended: (K:) applied to a road: (S, K:) like muTolaHibRN. (L.) ― -b3- I. q. munobaTiHN [app. as meaning Spread out, or expanded]. (TA.) ― -b4- ZalRa yawomanaA musoaHibRFA means Our day was, or became, one of protracted journeying. (L, TA.)

sulaHofaI c
sulaHofaI (AZ, Msb, K) and suloHafaI, (Fr, K,) pronounced by the vulgar siloHafaI, (TA,) and sulaHofaApN [which is the most common of the dial. vars.] (S, Msb, K) and siaHofaApN (Fr, K) and suloHafaApN, (Msb,) and sulaHofaMCu, (AZ, Msb, K,) and sulaHofiyapN, (S, K,) [The tortoise, commonly so called; and also the turtle, or sea-tortoise; applied to both in the present day;] a certain wellknown beast; (K;) [and] a certain aquatic animal; (Msb;) called in Pers. baAxaho and kaXafo (MA, PS) and sanoGo PuXoto; (MA;) applied to the male and the female: (Msb:) pl. salaAHifu: (S, Msb:) or, accord. to Fr, the male of the salaAHif is called gayolamN; and the female is called slHfAp in the dial. of Benoo-Asad: (Msb:) [it is said to be derived from the Pers. swlAx PAI; because there is a hole in the body, into which the foot enters: (Freytag's Lex.:)] its blood and its gall-bladder are [asserted to be] beneficial to him who is affected with epilepsy; and the smearing with its blood, to the joints; (K, TA;) which thereby become strong: (TA:) and it is said that when the cold has become intense in a place, (K, TA,) and one fears for the seedproduce from it, (TA,) and this beast is placed upside-down, so that its fore and hind legs are towards the air, the cold will not alight upon that place. (K, TA.) ― -b2- [AlsRulaHofaApu or AlsRuloHafaApu is also a name of (tropical:) The constellation Lyra; commonly called AlXRaloyaAqu.]

1 salaxa c
1. salaxa, (S, A, Msb, K, &c.,) aor.
salaxa
, (S, K, [as in the Kur xxxvi. 37,]) or
salixa
, (Msb, [but this I find in no other lexicon,]) and
saluxa
, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. saloxN, (S, Msb,) He stripped off (S, K) the hide, or skin, of a sheep or goat: (S:) or he skinned a sheep or goat. (A, Msb.) And sulixa jiloduhaA [Its skin was stripped off]. (A.) One does not say of a camel, salaxotu jilodahu; but kaXaTotuhu, and najawotuhu, and Oanojayotuhu. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) He pulled off or stripped off [a garment]. (K, TA.) You say of a woman, salaxato diroEahaA, (S, TA,) and salaxato EanohaA diroEahaA, (A, TA,) (tropical:) She pulled off her shift; stripped it off. (S, TA.) ― -b3- And [hence,] salaxa AlXRahora, (S, A, Msb,) or Xahorahu, (K,) aor.
salaxa
(L, Msb) and
saluxa
, (L,) inf. n. saloxN and suluwxN, (L, Msb,) (tropical:) He passed the month, or his month; (S, K, TA;) came to the end of it. (S, A, Msb, K.) salaxonaA AlXRahora means (tropical:) We passed forth from the month; having pulled off from ourselves every night one thirtieth part until the nights were complete, when we pulled off from ourselves all of it: and OaholalonaA hilaAla Xahori kacaA means “ We entered upon [the period of the new moon of] such a month; clothing ourselves with it and increasing the clothing of ourselves therewith until the passing of the half of it: ” then we pull off from ourselves [by degrees] the whole of it: hence a verse cited voce jumaAdaI. (T, TA.) And one says of God, salaxa AlnRahaAra mina AllRayoli (tropical:) He drew forth gently the day from the night: (K, TA:) or He separated the day from the night. (Jel in xxxvi. 37.) ― -b4- See also 7, in three places. ― -b5- salaxa AlHarRu jiloda AlUinosaAni and [in an intensive sense] slRxhu↓ (assumed tropical:) [The heat made the skin of the man to peel off; or excoriated the man]. (TA.) And salaxa Aljarabu jilodahu (tropical:) [The mange, or scab, excoriated him, i. e., a camel]: (A, TA:) [and so salaxahu without the mention of the skin:] see saAlixN. And sulixa AlZRaliymu (assumed tropical:) The ostrich had a disease in his feathers [app. such as caused many of them to fall off]. (TA.) ― -b6- salaxa AlnRabaAtu (assumed tropical:) [The plant shed its foliage, and then became altogether green again: (see saAlixN:) or] the plant became green again after having dried up. (M, K.) ― -b7- fasalaxuwA mawoDiEa AlmaMCi kamaA yusolaxu AlUihaAbu faxaraja AlmaMCu, in a trad. respecting Solomon and the hudohud [or hoopoe, i. e. (assumed tropical:) And they stripped off the surface of the place of the water, like as the hide is stripped off, and thereupon the water came forth], means that they dug until they found the water. (TA.) ― -b8- sulixa mino baToni OumRihi, said of a child, means (assumed tropical:) He was drawn out from the belly of his mother. (TA.) ― -b9- saloxu AlXiEori is (assumed tropical:) The substituting throughout the poetry, for the original words, other words synonymous therewith: what falls short of this is termed masoxN. (TA. [See Har p. 263.])

2 salRaxa
2: see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph.

5 tasalRaxa
5: see the next paragraph, first sentence.

7 Anslx jiloduhu c
7. Anslx jiloduhu and [in an intensive sense] tslRx↓ [His skin became stripped off: ― -b2- and (assumed tropical:) he became excoriated by heat]. (A, TA. [The latter meaning is indicated in the TA.]) ― -b3- Anslxt AlHayRapu mino qiXorihaA [The serpent cast off, or divested itself of, its slough]: (S:) and salaxat↓ AlHayRapu, (L, K,) aor.
salaxa
, inf. n. saloxN, (L,) [signifies the same, or] the serpent withdrew itself from its slough: (L, K:) and in like manner one says of any creeping thing: (L:) and one says of the serpent termed AlsRaAlixu [q. v.], jilodahu yasolaxu↓ [He casts off his slough]. (S.) ― -b4- One says also of a man, Anslx mino viyaAbihi (assumed tropical:) [He became stripped, or divested, or he divested himself, of his clothes]. (S.) ― -b5- And Anslx AlXRahoru (S, A, Msb, K) mino sanatihi (S) (tropical:) The month passed, or passed away [from its year]; (Msb, K, TA;) as also salaxa↓. (K.) And Anslx AlnRahaAru mina AllRayoli (S, A, K) (tropical:) The day became drawn forth gently from the night; (K, TA;) came forth from the night so as not to leave with it aught of its light. (TA.) [As used in this phrase and in others,] Anslx minohu means (assumed tropical:) It became altogether separated from it; quitted it entirely. (MF.)

9 AslRx c
9. AslRx, inf. n. AisolixaAxN He lay upon his side. (K.)

saloxN c
saloxN: see misolaAxN in two places. ― -b2- saloxu AlXRahori (assumed tropical:) The last, or end, of the month; (Msb, K;) as
also munosalaxahu↓: (K:) or the last day thereof. (MA.)

siloxN c
siloxN: see misolaAxN, in two places.

salaxN c
salaxN The spun thread that is upon the spindle. (K.)

saloxapN c
saloxapN: see misolaAxN.

saliyxN c
saliyxN A skinned sheep or goat; (L;) as also masoluwxN↓ (S, K) and masoluwxapF↓: (TA:) or this last is an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant, meaning a skinned sheep or goat, without head and without legs and without belly: (Mgh:) and the first is an epithet applied to a sheep or goat until some part of it has been eaten; after which, what remains is called XilowN, whether much or little. (L.) ＝ -A2- saliyxN maliyxN A thing, (JK,) accord. to the K a person, but this is not in the other lexicons, (TA,) insipid; without taste. (JK, K, TA.) ― -b2- And A man (TA) vehement in jimaAC, without impregnating. (K, TA.)

fiyhi salaAxapN wamalaAxapN c
fiyhi salaAxapN wamalaAxapN In it (accord. to the K in him, but see saliyxN, TA) is insipidity, or tastelessness. (K, * TA.)

sulaAxapN c
sulaAxapN [app. A piece of skin, or hide, stripped off]. (K voce jarRN.) ＝ -A2- The urine of the mountaingoat. (KL.) [In Pers. salaAHahN: thus, with H, and with fet-h to the first letter, accord. to Johnson's Pers. Ar. and Engl. Dict. Golius adds, on the authority of Ibn-Beytár, that it is black and viscous like pitch, and is collected from the rocks.]

saliyxapN c
saliyxapN (assumed tropical:) A certain perfume, or odoriferous substance, resembling bark stripped off, (JK, K, TA,) and having XuEab [or forking projections]. (TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) Of the [plants called] rimov (JK, S, K) and Earofaj, (JK, S,) [Such as has been stripped of what was good for pasture;] the portion that has in it nothing for pasture (JK, S, K, TA) remaining; (TA;) consisting only of dry wood: (S, TA:) and of the Erfj, such as is thick, of what has become dried up. (TA.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) The oil of the fruit, or produce, of the baAn [or bentree] before it has been seasoned (K, TA) with aromatics: when it has been seasoned with musk and [other] perfume, and then expressed, it is termed manoXuwXN; and one says of it, nuXRa. (TA.) Also (assumed tropical:) Offspring: (JK, K, TA:) because it has been drawn out (sulixa i. e. nuziEa) from the belly of its mother. (TA.)

sulRaxapN c
sulRaxapN an extr. pl. [or quasi-pl. n.] of saAlixN, q. v. (TA.)

salRaAxN c
salRaAxN A skinner, or flayer. (KL.)

saAlixN c
saAlixN Skinning, or flaying. (KL.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) Mange, or scab, in consequence of which the camel is excoriated (yusolaxu↓). (K.) ― -b3- [A serpent casting off its slough. And hence,] A black serpent, (JK, S, K,) intensely black: (JK, TA:) you say, Oasowadu saAlixN, (S, K,) not prefixing the former word so as to govern the latter in the gen. case: [so called] because it casts off its slough (yasolaxN jilodahu) every year: (S:) the female is called OasowadapN, and is not qualified by the epithet saAlixapN: (S, K:) and you say OasowadaAni saAlixN, (K,) not giving to the epithet the dual form, accord. to AZ and As; but IDrd authorizes its being in the dual form, though the former mode is the better known: (TA:) and OasaAwidu saAlixapN and sawaAlixu and sulRaxu and sulRaxapN↓, (K,) which last is extr. [i. e. anomalous]. (TA.) ― -b4- Also (assumed tropical:) A plant of the kinds termed HamoD &c. that has shed its foliage (salaxa) and then become altogether green again. (TA.)

Oasolaxu c
Oasolaxu, applied to a man, (JK,) (assumed tropical:) Very red [as though skinned]. (JK, K.) ― -b2- And [its pl.] saloxaI, applied to camels, (assumed tropical:) Having mange, or scab, by which they are excoriated. (JK.) ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) Bald in the fore part of the head: (K:) but Oasolaju is more common in this sense. (TA.)

UisoliyxN c
UisoliyxN A certain plant. (K.) [Perhaps a dial. var. of UisoliyHN, or a mistranscription for this latter.]

masolaxN c
masolaxN A place in which sheep or goats are skinned. (Msb.)

misolaAxN c
misolaAxN A skin, or hide; (JK, S, K;) as also saloxN↓: (TA:) or, of a sheep or goat; (A;) as also siloxN↓, i. e. its skin, or hide, that is stripped off. (K, TA.) [Hence,] one says, fulaAnN HimaArN fiI misolaAxi UinosaAnK (tropical:) [Such a one is an ass in the skin of a man]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- And The slough of a serpent; (JK, S, A, L, K;) as also siloxN↓, (MA, KL, and so in the CK,) or saloxN↓, (TA,) and saloxapN↓. (L, and so in copies of the K and in the TA.) ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) A palm-tree of which the unripe dates fall and become scattered about in a green state. (S, K.)

masoluwxN c
masoluwxN; and with p: see saliyxN.

munosalaxu AlXRahori c
munosalaxu AlXRahori: see saloxN.

1 salisa c
1. salisa, [aor.
salasa
,] inf. n. salasN and salaAsapN and suluwsapN, [It was, or became, loose, not tight; as meaning slack; the only signification indicated by ISd; (see salisN, below;) and also as meaning unsteady:] (M:) [in the K, salasN and salaAsapN are said to be simply substs.: see the former of these two words below.] ― -b2- salisa, (Msb, TA,) aor.
salasa
, inf. n. salasN (Msb) [and app. salaAsapN also, (see salasN below,)] said of a colt, (TA,) [and of a horse, and, tropically, of a man, (see salisN,)] He was, or became, tractable, submissive, compliant, obsequious, (TA;) or easy, (Msb, TA,) and gentle. (Msb.) You say, salisa liI biHaqRiI (tropical:) (He was easy to me in giving me my due, or right]. (A, TA.) And salisa bawoluhu, (TA,) inf. n. salasN, (Msb,) (assumed tropical:) His urine flowed involuntarily; he was unable to retain his urine; (Msb, TA;) by reason of disease. (Msb.) [The explanations of salasN and salisN &c. below will serve to give further illustrations of this verb.] ― -b3- salisati AlnRaxolapu, aor.
salasa
, The palm-tree lost the stumps, or lower ends, of its branches; (Ibn-'Abbád, K;) as also Oasolasat↓: and the epithet applied to the palm-tree in this case is misolaAsN↓; (K;) or, accord. to the Tekmileh and O and L, musolisN↓; but it seems that naxolapN musolisN↓ means a palm-tree that lets fall and strews its unripe dates; and misolaAsN↓, that usually does thus: (TA:) and salasN↓ means what falls from the palm-tree. (Ibn-Abbád, TA.) ― -b4- salisati AlxaXabapu, (inf. n. salasN, TA,) The piece of wood became old and crumbling and wasted. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ＝ -A2- sulisa, (S, M, K,) inf. n. salosN and salasN, (IAar, M,) He became bereft of reason. (S, M, K.)

2 slRs c
2. slRs, (Ibn-'Abbád,) inf. n. tasoliysN, (K,) He set, fixed, or put together, a composite ornament, of the ornaments worn by women, not consisting of xazar [or beads]. (Ibn-'Abbád, K, * TA.)

4 Oasolasato c
4. Oasolasato She (a camel) produced her young one before the completion of the days: (T, K:) the epithet applied to her in this case is musolisN↓; and to the young one, musolasN↓, (TA,) and salasN↓. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.) ― -b2- See also 1.

salosN c
salosN A string upon which beads, (M,) or white beads worn by female slaves, (S, K,) are strung: (S, M, K:) pl. suluwsN: (S, M:) or [a woman's ear-drop; i. e.] the woman's ornament called qurT. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ― -b2- And [the pl.] suluwsN signifies also Women's mufflers, or headcoverings; syn. xumrN [pl. of ximaArN]: so says IAar; and he cites as an ex.,
qado malaOato marokuwRahaA ruWuwsaA
kaOanRa fiyhi EujuzFA juluwsFA
XumoTa AlrRuWuwsi Oaloqati AlsRuluwsaA
[They (referring to camels) had filled their watering-trough with heads, as though there were in it old women sitting, with grizzled heads, having thrown off the mufflers]: they having eaten of [the kind of plants, or trees, called] HamoD, so that their faces and heads had become white, he likens them to old women that had thrown off the mufflers. (M.)

salasN c
salasN and salAsapN↓ [said in the M to be inf. ns. of salisa, (q. v.,) and in the K to be simply substs., signify, as substs., Looseness; as meaning slackness; and as meaning unsteadiness: ― -b2- and also] Easiness, gentleness, tractableness, submissiveness; compliance, or obsequiousness. (S, K.) [Hence,] one says, fiI kalaAmihi salaAsapN↓ (tropical:) [In his speech is easiness]. (A.) ＝ -A2- For the former, see also 1: ― -b2- and 4.

salisN c
salisN part. n. of salisa; as also saAlisN↓: (M:) Loose, not tight; meaning [slack; (see 1, first sentence;) and also] unsteady; applied to a nail, (A, TA,) and to any other thing. (TA.) A rájiz says,
mamokuwrapN garovaI AlwiXaAHi AlsRaAlisi↓
taDoHaku Eano ciI OuXur K guDaArisi
[A female of slender make, whose loose wiXaAH (q. v.) required more than it had within it to fill it, laughing so as to discover cool and sweet serrated and sharp teeth]. (M, TA.) ― -b2- Easy; applied to a thing: (S:) easy, (Msb, K,) gentle; (S, Msb, K;) tractable; submissive; compliant; obsequious; (S, K;) applied [to a horse and the like, and, tropically,] to a man. (S.) You say, farasN salisu AlqiyaAdi [A horse easy to be led; tractable]. (A.) And fulaAnN salisu AlqiyaAdi and AlqiyaAdi misolaAsu↓ (tropical:) [Such a one is easy to be led, or persuaded; tractable, submissive, or compliant]. (A.) ― -b3- (tropical:) A man easy in private conference; expl. by saholu Alxalowapi. (Msb.) ― -b4- Beverage, or wine, that descends gently or easily [down the throat]. (TA.) ― -b5- salisu Albawoli A man whose urine flows involuntarily; who is unable to retain his urine; (S, A, Msb, K;) by reason of disease. (Msb.)

salisapN c
salisapN A certain herb, bearing a near resemblance to the naSiIR, (AHn, M, K, * TA,) except that it has a grain like that of the [species of barley called] sulot; (AHn, TA;) and when it dries up, it has an awn that flies about, when it is put in motion, like arrows, sticking into the eyes and the nostrils, and often blinding the pasturing beasts: (AHn, M, TA:) the places of its growth are the plain, or soft, tracts. (AHn, TA.)

sulaAsN c
sulaAsN Loss, or departure, of reason or intellect. (S, M, K.)

salaAsapN c
salaAsapN: see salasN, in two places.

saAlisN c
saAlisN: see salisN, in two places.

musolasN c
musolasN: see 4.

musolisN c
musolisN: see 1, in two places: ― -b2- and see also 4.

musalRasN c
musalRasN A sword having wavy marks resembling a chain: occurring in a verse of Ibn-Kilábeh ElHudhalee, as some relate it; but accord. to others, mulasolas, formed by transposition from musalosal. (TA.)

misolaAsN c
misolaAsN: see salisN: ― -b2- and see also 1, latter part, in two places.

masoluwsN c
masoluwsN Bereft of reason, or intellect; (S, M;) and [of bulk] of body, (M, TA,) as some say; but accord. to the T, one says rajulN masoluwsN in respect of his reason, or intellect, but maholuwsN in respect of his body: (TA:) possessed, or insane. (K.)

salosabiylN c
salosabiylN, a quinqueliteral-radical word, (M,) Easy [as a beverage] in the utmost degree: (TA:) [applied as an epithet to milk, (laban, so in a copy of the M, and so in the CK,) or signifying smooth, (layRin, so in copies of the K,)] in which is no roughness: (M, K:) and sometimes applied as an epithet to water, (M, TA,) or beverage, meaning easy of entrance into the throat, or fauces. (TA.) ― -b2- And Wine: (K:) so accord. to some, as in the saying of 'Abd-Allah Ibn-Rawáhah, in which it is [said to be] used as a syn. adjunct to the preceding word:
UinRahumo Einoda rabRihimo fiI jinaAnK
yaXorabuwna AlrRaHiyqa waAlsRalosabiylaA
[as though meaning Verily they are with their Lord, in gardens, drinking wine and fermented juice of the grape: but the meaning may be, the choicest of wine, or the sweetest thereof, &c., (see raHiyqN,) and wine easy to swallow, or the like]. (TA.) ― -b3- And A certain fountain in Paradise [mentioned in art. sbl, q. v.]: (M, K:) Aboo-Bekr says that it may be a proper name of the fountain, and properly imperfectly decl. [i. e. without tenween] as being determinate and of the fem. gender, but made to be with tenween at the end of a verse in the Kur [lxxvi. 18] in order that it may be conformable with other endings of verses; or it may be an epithet applied to the fountain, and therefore perfectly decl.: (TA:) Sb mentions it as an ex. of an epithet: IAar says that he had not heard it except in the Kur-án: (M, TA:) I'Ab says that salosabiylFA [in the Kur] means that slips, or steals, (yanosalRu,) into the throats, or fauces: [as though the radical letters were only s and l, which some assert to be the case:] accord. to Aboo-Jaafar El-Bákir, it means soft in the part between the Hanojarap [or head of the windpipe] and the Haloq [or fauces]: the explanation as meaning [salo sabiylFA i. e.] salo rabRaka sabiylFA UilaI hecihi AlEayoni [Ask of thy Lord a way of access to this fountain] is a mistake, not allowable. (TA.) ― -b4- The pl. is salaAsibu and salaAsiybu: and the pl. of [the fem.] salosabiylapN is salosabiylaAtN. (TA.) ― -b5- [In the present day it is applied to An artificial fountain that throws up water.]

1 saluTa c
1. saluTa, aor.
saluTa
, (M,) inf. n. salaATapN, (S, M, B,) He, or it, overcame, prevailed, or predominated: (S, TA:) or was, or became, firm, or established, in superior power or force: (B, TA:) he possessed power of dominion or sovereignty or rule. (M.) ― -b2- It (anything, as, for instance, a solid hoof, and a camel's foot,) was, or became, strong, or hard. (M.) ― -b3- He was, or became, sharp. (TA.) And the same verb, (M, Msb, K,) inf. n. as above (S, M, Msb, K) and suluwTapN, (S, M, K,) He was, or became, chaste, or perspicuous, in speech, or eloquent, and sharp in tongue: (S:) or long-tongued;; (M, K;) as also saliTa, aor.
salaTa
, (K,) inf. n. salaTN: (TS, TA:) or clamorous and foultongued: (Msb:) [or this verb, said of a man, has the first of these three significations; but] saluTato, inf. n. salaATapN, signifies she (a woman) was, or became, long-tongued, and vehemently clamorous. (Lth.) [See saliyTN, below.]

2 slRThu Ealayohi c
2. slRThu Ealayohi, (S, M, Msb,) inf. n. tasoliyTN, (M, K,) also written with S, (Ibn-'Abbád, and K in art. SlT,) He (God, S) made him to overcome him; to prevail, or predominate, over him; or to have, or exercise, superior power or force over him: (S, K:) he made him to have mastery, dominion, or authority, and power, over him: (Msb:) he made him to have, or exercise, absolute dominion or sovereignty or rule, over him; (M;) or absolute superiority of power or force: (K:) he gave him power over him, and superior power or force. (TA.) [You say also, slRT Ealayohi AlkilaAba He set the dogs upon him.]

5 tslRT Ealayohimo c
5. tslRT Ealayohimo He overcame them; prevailed or predominated, over them; or was made to do so; he had, or exercised, or was made to have or exercise, superior power or force over them: (S:) he had, or was made to have, mastery, dominion, or authority, and power, or absolute dominion or authority and power, over them: (Msb:) he had, or received, power over them; and superior power or force; quasi-pass. of salRaTahu Ealayohimo. (TA.)

saloTN c
saloTN: see saliyTN; for the former, in four places; and for the latter, in seven.

saliTN c
saliTN: see saliyTN; for the former, in four places; and for the latter, in seven.

suloTapN c
suloTapN: see suloTaAnN; for the latter, in three places.

saloTanapN c
saloTanapN: see suloTaAnN; for the latter, in three places.

salaTaAnapN c
salaTaAnapN, and siliTaAnapN, or siliTRaAnapN: see saliyTN.

saliyTN c
saliyTN Strong, or hard; (M, K;) as also saliTN↓, (M,) or saloTN↓. (K.) You say, HaAfirN saliTN↓, (M,) or saloTN↓, (TA,) and saliyTN, (M, TA,) A strong, or hard, solid hoof. (M, TA.) And AlHaAfiri daAbRapN saliTapu↓ A beast having a strong, or hard, hoof. (M.) And AlxufRi baEiyrN saliTu↓ A camel having a strong, or hard, foot. (M.) ― -b2- Sharp; applied to anything. (K.) You say also sanaAbiku saliTaAtN↓ Sharp edges of the fore parts of hoofs. (S, TA.) ― -b3- Chaste in speech, or eloquent, (S, K,) and sharp in tongue: (S:) an epithet of praise when applied to the male, and of dispraise when [with p] applied to the female: (IDrd, K:) also, (K,) long-tongued; (M, K;) and so saliTN↓, (M,) or saloTN↓; (K;) fem. saliyTapN, and salaTaAnapN↓, (M, K,) and siliTaAnapN↓, (K,) or siliTRaAnapN↓; (M;) the last written [thus] with tesh-deed to the T in the Jm., and there explained as signifying long-tongued and clamorous: (TA:) or saliyTN signifies clamorous and foul-tongued; and so saliyTapN applied to a woman: (Msb:) or the latter, applied to a woman, clamorous: (S:) or long-tongued and vehemently clamorous: (Lth:) or saliyTapu AllRisaAni is applied to a woman in two senses; signifying sharp-tongued; and long-tongued. (Az, TA.) You say also, lisaAnN saliyTN, (M, K,) and saliTN↓, (M,) or saloTN↓, (K,) A long tongue. (M, K.) ＝ -A2- Oil of olives; (S, M, Msb, K;) so applied by the generality of the Arabs: but by the people of El-Yemen applied to oil of sesame, or sesamum: (S, M:) IDrd, in the Jm, says the reverse; and IF has followed him; but what J says is right, as Sgh, has observed in the O: (TA:) also, (K,) or as some say, (M,) any oil expressed from grains or berries: (M, K:) pl. suloTaAnN. (Msb, K.)

OasolaTu c
OasolaTu More, and most, overcoming, prevailing, predominating, or superior in power or force. (Har p. 661.) ― -b2- huwa OasolaTuhumo lisaAnFA He is the most chaste, or eloquent, and the sharpest, [&c., (see an ex. voce siloqN,)] of them in tongue. (S.)

Q. 3 AisolanoTaHa c
Q. 3. AisolanoTaHa It (a thing) was, or became, long and wide. (AA, O and L in this art.: mentioned in the S in art. sTH.) ― -b2- It (a valley) became wide: (K:) accord. to IF, both the l and n are added to give intensiveness to the signification. (O.) ― -b3- He (a man) extended himself or became extended [app. on the ground]; syn. AinobasaTa: (L:) or he became thrown down upon his face: or he lay, or lay as though thrown down or extended: or he stretched himself; or lay, and stretched himself; upon his face, extended upon the ground: syn. AinoTabaHa: (O:) or he lay as though thrown down or extended, upon the back of his neck: (Ibn-'Abbád, O:) or he (a man, L) fell upon his face: (L, K:) and upon his back. (L.)

suloTaHN c
suloTaHN, (K,) or suloTuwHN↓, (O,) A smooth mountain: (O, K:) so says Ibn-'Abbád. (O.)

saloTaHapN c
saloTaHapN, applied to a girl, or young woman. Broad. (K.)

suloTuwHN c
suloTuwHN: see suloTuHN.

sulaATiHN c
sulaATiHN wide. (Lth, T, O, K.) It is said of rain [as meaning Wide-spreading]. (O.)

salanoTaHN c
salanoTaHN A wide open tract; (IDrd, O, K;) as also musolanoTiHN↓. (K.)

musolanoTiHN c
musolanoTiHN: see what next precedes.

1 salaEa raOosahu c
1. salaEa raOosahu, aor.
salaEa
, (S, Msb,) inf. n. saloEN, (S, TA,) He clave, or split, his head, [i. e., the skin thereof, (see saloEapN,)] (S, Msb, TA,) by striking it, with a staff, or stick. (TA.) ＝ -A2- saliEato, qadamahu, (S, K, *) aor.
salaEa
, inf. n. salaEN, (S, K,) His foot became chapped, or cracked, (S, K,) in its upper part and in its under, like zaliEato. (S, TA.) [See also 5.] ― -b2- salaEa jiloduhu biAlnRaAri, [so in the L and TA, app. a mistranscription for saliEa,] inf. n. salaEN, His skin became burned by fire so that the mark thereof was seen upon it. (L, TA.) ― -b3- saliEa, aor.
salaEa
, inf. n. salaEN, He was, or became, affected with baraS [i. e. leprosy, particularly the white, malignant kind thereof]. (IDrd, K.)

2 tasoliyEN c
2. tasoliyEN [inf. n. of salRaEa as used in the phrase slRE Albaqara, or viyraAna AlwaHoXi, (see musalRaEapN,)] signifies a practice which was observed in the Time of Ignorance, when the people were afflicted with drought, or barrenness of the earth; which was The hanging the [kind of tree, or plant, called] salaE, with the [species of swallow-wort called] EuXar, to wild bulls, and sending them down from the mountains, having kindled fire in the slE and EXr; seeking thereby to obtain rain: (K, TA:) or the loading the backs of those animals with the fire-wood of the slE and EXr, then kindling fire therein; seeking to obtain rain by the flame of the fire, which was likened to the gleaming of lightning. (TA.) [See also salaEN, where a meaning somewhat different from those above is indicated.])

4 AslE c
4. AslE He (a man, TA) had a [wound in the head, such as is termed] XajRap, (K, TA,) i. e., a saloEap: (TA:) or he had a [kind of ulcer in the belly, called] dubayolap. (TA.)

5 tslRE Eaqibuhu c
5. tslRE Eaqibuhu His heel became chapped, or cracked. (Sgh, K.) [See also 1; and see 7.]

7 AnslE c
7. AnslE It clave, or split, or slit, in an intrans. sense. (S, K.) [See also 1, and 5.]

saloEN c
saloEN A chap, or crack, in the human foot: pl. suluwEN. (S, K.) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph, in two places.

siloEN c
siloEN A cleft, or fissure, in a mountain, (Lh, IAar, Yaakoob, S, K,) having the form of a crack; (TA;) as also saloEN↓, (S, K,) accord. to some: (S, TA:) pl. [of either] OasolaAEN (Yaakoob, S, K) and (of the latter, TA) suluwEN. (K.) ＝ -A2- Also A like, or fellow; (AA, L, K;) and so saloEN↓: (L, TA:) pl. OasolaAEN. (IAar, L, K.) You
say, hecaA siloEu hecaA This is the like of this. (TA.) And gulaAmaAni siloEaAni Two boys, or young men, that are fellows, or equals in age: and gilomaAnN OasolaAEN. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) And OaEoTaAhu OasolaAEa Uibilihi He gave him the likes, or fellows, of his camels. (L.) ＝ -A3- And the pl. OasolaAEN signifies also The portions of flesh that cling to the nasayaAni [or two sciatic veins] of a mare when she is fat. (Sgh, K.)

salaEN c
salaEN [originally inf. n. of saliEa, q. v.,] Marks left by fire upon the skin. (TA.) ＝ -A2- A certain kind of bitter tree; (S, K;) which, in the Time of Ignorance, was used in one or the other of the manners described above in the explanations of tasoliyEN; (K, TA;) or they used, in the case of drought, or barrenness of the earth, to hang somewhat of this tree and of the EuXar to the tails cunaAbaI [a sing. used as a pl.]) of [wild] bulls or cows, then to kindle fire therein, and make them to ascend upon the mountain; and thus, they assert, they used to obtain rain: (S, TA:) the author of the K says that J has made a mistake in saying cnAbI, in the above-cited passage; that he should have said OaconaAb; but others had made this remark before the author of the K; and 'Abd-El-Kádir Ibn-'Omar El-Baghdádee says that the mistake is to be imputed to these, and not to J, who has only used a sing. in the sense of a pl., like as AldRubura is used in the Kur [liv. 45], for AlOadobaAra: (MF, TA:) AHn cites an Arab of the desert, of the saraAp, as saying that the slE grows near to a tree, and then clings to it, and climbs it, with long, green, leafless shoots, twining upon the branches and interweaving themselves, and having a fruit like bunches of grapes, which is small, and, when ripe, becomes black, and is eaten only by the monkeys, or apes, not by men, nor by the beasts that are left to pasture at their pleasure; and adding, I have not tasted it, but I think that it is bitter; and when it is broken, there flows from it a viscous fluid, clear, and having strings: such is the description of the man of the srAp: (TA:) or it is a certain poisonous plant, (K, TA,) not to be tasted, like zaroE [here meaning wheat or barley] when it first comes forth, scantily scattered in the ground, and having a small, yellow, prickly leaf, its prickles being downy; it is a herb, or leguminous plant, which spreads itself upon the surface of the ground, like [the plant called] raAHapu Alkalobi, having no root, and it is not improbable that the ostrich may feed upon it, notwithstanding its bitterness, for it sometimes feeds upon the colocynth: (Aboo-Ziyád, TA:) or it is a species of aloes: (K:) or a herb, or leguminous plant, (K, TA,) of those termed cukuwr [that are hard and thick, or thick, and inclining to bitterness, or thick and rough], (TA,) of bad, or nauseous, or disgusting, taste: (K, TA:) so says Aboo-Nasr: (TA:) [Forskål found this name applied in El-Yemen to the sælanthus quadragonus: (Flora Ægypt. Arab., pp. cv. and 33:) and the cacalia sonchifolia: (Ibid., p. cxix.:) and the name of saE OaboyaD, or salaE Albaqar, to the senecio hadiensis. (Ibid., pp. cxix. and 149.)]

saloEapN c
saloEapN A wound by which the head is broken, syn. XajRapN, (S, L, Mgh, Msb, K,) of whatever kind it be; as also salaEapN↓: or that [only] cleaves the skin: (K:) pl. salaEaAtN (Msb, K, [in the CK, erroneously, saloEaAtN,]) and silaAEN, and quasi-pl. n. [or coll. gen. n.] salaEN. (K.) ― -b2- See also what next follows.

siloEapN c
siloEapN [A ganglion;] a thing like the gudRap, that comes forth upon the body, or person; (K, * TA;) as also saloEapN↓, (K,) which is the form of the word now commonly known, (TA,) and salaEapN↓, (K,) and silaEapN↓: (Ibn-'Abbád, K:) or an excrescence (S, Mgh, K) of flesh, (Mgh,) that arises in the body, (S, Mgh, K,) or a [kind of spontaneous swelling that comes forth upon the body, such as is termed] xuraAj, (Msb,) like the gudRap, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) that moves about when moved, (S, Msb, K,) or moves to and fro between the skin and the flesh, (Mgh,) and varies from [the size of] a chick-pea to [that of] a melon; (S, K;) also termed DawaApN: (S:) the physicians say that it is a thick tumour, not adhering to the flesh, moving about when moved, having a cyst, or case which encloses it, and capable of increase, because it is extrinsic to the flesh, wherefore the doctors of practical law allow its being cut off, when it is safe to do so: (Msb:) or a xuraAj [vide suprà] in the neck: (K:) or a gudRap in the neck: (Ibn-'Abbád, K:) pl. silaEN. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] A thing [i. e. a knob] that comes forth in a tree. (AHn, TA in art. blT.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] A leech; (K;) because it attaches itself to the body like the gudRap: (TA:) pl. silaEN. (K.) ＝ -A2- A commodity; an article of merchandise; (S, * Mgh, * Msb, K; *) a thing with which one trafficks: (K:) pl. silaEN. (Msb, K.)

salaEapN c
salaEapN: see saloEapN: ― -b2- and siloEapN.

silaEapN c
silaEapN: see siloEapN.

saliyEapN c
saliyEapN Nature, or disposition: so in the phrase UinRahu lakariymu AlsRaliyEapi [Verily he is generous in respect of nature, or disposition]. (TA.) [But perhaps this may have originated from a mistranscription for saliyqapN.]

sawolaEN c
sawolaEN The bitter aloe. (IAar, Sgh, K.)

OasolaEu c
OasolaEu A man having the foot chapped, or cracked: pl. suloEN. (K.) ― -b2- A man having his skin burned by fire so that the mark thereof is seen upon it. (TA.) ― -b3- A man affected with baraS [i. e. leprosy, particularly the white, malignant kind thereof]. (Mgh, K.) ― -b4- And Humpbacked. (TA.)

musoliEN c
musoliEN [A man having a wound in the head, such as is termed saloEap: (see 4; and see also masoluwEN:) or] having a [kind of ulcer in the belly, called] dubayolap. (TA.)

misolaEN c
misolaEN A guide that directs aright: (Lth, K:) so called because he cleaves the desert. (TA.)

bayoquwrN musalRaEapN c
bayoquwrN musalRaEapN A number of [wild] bulls or cows having some firewood of the salaE hung to their tails, [with EuXar, and then set on fire,] (S, * TA,) or having their backs laden therewith. (TA.) [See 2, and see also salaEN.]

masoluwEN c
