masoluwEN A man having [the skin of] his head cleft, or split; (Msb;) a man having [a saloEap, i. e.] a XajRap; as also munosaliEN↓. (TA.) [See also musoliEN.] ― -b2- Having a siloEap, i. e. [ganglion, or] thing like the gudRap, &c. (K.) ― -b3- masoluwEapN The main part, or middle, of a road; the part of a road along which one travels; syn. maHajRapN: (Ibn-'Abbád, L, K:) because it is cleft, or furrowed. (L.)

munosaliEN c
munosaliEN: see masoluwEN.

1 salagati Albaqarapu c
1. salagati Albaqarapu, and AlXRaApu, aor.
salaga
, inf. n. suluwgN, The bovine animal, and the sheep or goat, shed the tooth [next] behind that called the sadiys; (S, K;) as also Salagat: (S:) this is in the sixth year; (S, K;) and suluwgN in cloven-hoofed animals is like buzuwlN in camels: for it is the furthest of their teeth [that they then shed]: (S:) or bred its [tooth called the] naAb: (K:) or attained its full fatness: (TA: [or more probably, I think, its full age; for I think that smnhA in the TA is a mistranscription for snRhA: see OasanRa:]) the epithet is saAligN↓ and SaAligN, applied [to the male and] likewise to the female, without p: (S:) you say baqarapN saAligN and naEojapN saAligN: (Lth, K:) the young one of the baqarap in the first year being termed EijolN, then tabiyEo, (S, Sgh, K,) or, correctly, accord. to IB, in the first year EijolN and tabiyEN, (TA,) then jacaEN, then vaniIRN, then rabaAEK, then sadiysN, then saAilgu sanapK and saAligu sanatayon i, and so on; and the young one of the XaAp in the first year being termed HamalN or jadoIN, then jacaEN, then vaniIRN, then rabaAEK, then sadiysN, then saAligN: (S, Sgh, K:) and sulRagN is [the pl.,] applied to [bovine animals and] sheep or goats, like SulRagN. (TA.) ― -b2- You say also, salaga AlHimaAru, meaning qariHa [i. e. The ass finished teething]. (TA.)

saAilgN c
saAilgN: see the preceding paragraph.

1 salafa c
1. salafa, (S, M, Msb, K,) aor.
salufa
, (S, M, Msb,) or, accord. to some,
salifa
, and accord. to IKtt, salafN and
salifa
, (MF,) inf. n. safN, (S, K,) or suluwfN, (Msb,) [both app. correct,] It (a thing, K) [and also he (a man)] passed; passed away; (S, Msb, K;) came to an end, or to nought; or became cut off: (Msb:) and, (K,) inf. n. salofN, (M, MF, and so in copies of the K,) or safN, (so in the CK,) and suluwfN, (M, K,) he (a man, K) [and also it (a thing)] went before, or preceded; (M, K;) and so sAlf↓, said of a camel. (K.) In a verse cited voce salofa radaAdN is used by poetic
license for salafa: but this kind of contraction is allowed by the Basrees only in verbs of which the medial radical letter is with kesr or damm, as in Ealoma for Ealima, and karoma for karuma. (M. [See saruEa.]) ― -b2- You say also, salafa lahu EamalN SaAliHN, meaning A good, or righteous, deed of his preceded [so as to prepare for him a future reward]. (TA.) ― -b3- And salafati AlnRaAqapu, inf. n. suluwfN, The she-camel was, or became, among the foremost of the camels in arriving at the water. (TA.) ― -b4- [Golius and Freytag mention also salafa as a trans. verb; the former explaining it as signifying “ Præteriit, præcessit, rem; ” and the latter adding “ tempore, ” and assigning to it the inf. ns. salofN and suluwfN; as on the authority of the K; in which I find no indication of such a usage of this verb.] ＝ -A2- salafa AlOaroDa, (S, M, K;) aor.
salufa
, inf. n. salofN; (S, M;) and AslfhA↓; (M, K;) He turned over the land for sowing: (M, K:) or (so in the K, but in the M “ and ”) he made it even with the misolafap [q. v.]. (S, M, K.) ― -b2- salafa AlmazaAdapa, inf. n. salofN, [in some copies of the K salaf,] He oiled, or greased, the mzAdp [or leathern water-bag]. (K.)

2 tasoliyfN c
2. tasoliyfN signifies The making [a thing] to go before, or precede. (S, K.) ― -b2- And I. q. UisolaAfN. (K.) See 4, in six places. ― -b3- And The giving to another the portion of food termed sulfap [q. v.]. (S.) You say, slRf AlrRajula, (S,) or Alqawoma, (M,) inf. n. as above, (S,) He gave to the man, (S,) or to the people or party, (M,) the portion of food so called; (S, M;) as also [slRf lahu, or] slRf lahumo. (M.) ― -b4- And The eating of the [portion of food termed] sulofap. (K.) [See also 5.]

3 sAlf c
3. sAlf: see 1, first sentence. ＝ -A2- sAlfhu fiI AlOaroDi, (Ibn-'Abbád, K,) inf. n. musaAlafapN, (Ibn- 'Abbád, TA,) i. q. saAyarahu [i. e. He went, or kept pace, or ran, with him, or he vied, contended, or competed, with him in going or running, in the land; as though striving to be before him]. (Ibn- 'Abbád, K.) ― -b2- And sAlfhu He equalled him in an affair. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

4 Aslfhu c
4. Aslfhu He did it previously, or beforehand. (O and TA in art. zlf.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Aslf fiI, kacaA, (S, Mgh, Msb, TA,) inf. n. UisolaAfN; (TA;) and fiyhi slRf↓, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) inf. n. tasoliyfN; (Msb, TA;) He paid in advance, or beforehand, for such a thing, (S, Mgh, TA,) i. e. a commodity described to him, (S,) or wheat or the like, for which the seller became responsible, [with something additional to the equivalent of the current price at the time of the payment, (see salafN,)] (TA,) to be delivered at a certain period: (S:) and Oasolama signifies the same. (TA.) You say, Oasolafotu Uilayohi fiI kacaA and Uilayohi salRafotu↓ [I paid in advance to him for such a thing, &c.]. (Msb.) Hence the saying in a trad., fayusalRifo mano salRafa↓ fiI kayolK maEoluwmK wawazonK maEoluwmK UilaI OajalK maEoluwmK i. e. He who pays in advance for a commodity for which the seller is responsible, let him pay in advance for a certain measure, and a certain weight, to be delivered at a certain period. (TA.) ― -b3- And Aslfhu maAlFA, (S, M, Mgh, TA,) and slRfhu↓, (M, Mgh, TA,) He lent him property [to be repaid, or returned, without any profit]. (M, Mgh, TA. [See, again, salafN.]) [Whence one says, Aslfhu UiHosaAnFA and slRfhu, and slRfhu↓, meaning (assumed tropical:) He did to him, to be requited it, a good action and an evil action; as is shown by the words maA Oasolafota mino UisaMCapK Oawo UiHosaAnK wamaA tuEoTiyhi lituqoDaAhu in art. qrD in the K, and by the corresponding words maA salRafota mino UiHosaAnK wamino UisaMCapK in the same art. in the S: see also Bd in xxxvi. 11: and see zalRafahu. And hence,] a poet says,
AljaAra XirobFA wahoIa HaAYimapN tusalRifu↓
waAlmaMCu lazonN bakiIoCu AlEayoni muqotasamu
(assumed tropical:) [They (referring to camels) yield promptly to the neighbour a draught of milk, while they are thirsty, and going round about the water, when the water is crowded upon, scanty in the source, divided by lot]. (TA. [See also some verses of El-Akra' Ibn-Mo'ádh, in which the former hemistich occurs with a different latter hemistich, in the Ham p. 753.]) ＝ -A2- See also 1, last sentence but one.

5 tslRf c
5. tslRf He received payment in advance: and Astslf↓ [perhaps a mistranscription for Astlf↓] signifies [the same; or] he took, or received, what is termed salaf. (Msb.) ― -b2- [And hence,] tslRf minohu He received from him a loan; syn. AiqotaraDa; as also Astlf↓. (A in art. qrD.) And tslRf minohu kacaA He received as a loan from him such a thing. (TA.) ― -b3- See also 10. ― -b4- And tslRf He ate the [portion of food termed] sulofap. (MA.) [See also 2.]

6 tsAlfA c
6. tsAlfA They two took as their wives two sisters. (M, K.)

8 Uisotalafa
8: see 5, in two places.

10 Aisotasolafotu minohu daraAhima c
10. Aisotasolafotu minohu daraAhima I sought, or demanded, of him money as a loan; as also tasalRafotu↓. (S, * TA.) Hence, Astslf mino OaEoraAbiIRK bakorFA He sought, or demanded, as a loan, from an Arab of the desert, a [youthful he-camel such as is termed] bakor. (TA.) ― -b2- And Astslf vamanahu He sought, or demanded, its price in advance; syn. AisotaqoraDahu. (Har p. 530.) ― -b3- See also 5. ＝ -A2- [And Astslf He took as his wife the wife of his deceased brother: so in a version of the Bible, in Deut. xxv. 5: mentioned by Golius.]

salofN c
salofN A [bag for travelling-provisions &c., such as is termed] jiraAb, (M, K,) of any sort: (M:) or a large jiraAb: (S, M, K:) [and the contr., i. e. a small one: (Freytag, from the Kitáb el-Addád:)] or a hide not well, or not thoroughly, tanned: (M, K, TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OasolufN and [of mult.] suluwfN. (M, K.)

sulofN c
sulofN [perhaps a mistranscription for sulafN, q. v.,] A certain species of bird, not particularized. (TA.) ― -b2- See also misolafN.

silofN c
silofN; and its fem., with p; and their duals: see salifN, in five places: ＝ -A2- and see salafN, last sentence.

salafN c
salafN Such as have gone before, or preceded; (M, Msb; *) [i. e. the preceding generations;] as also saliyfN↓ and sulofapN↓ and saluwfN↓; all quasipl. ns.; (M;) of which the sing. is saAlifN↓: (M, Msb: *) or such as have gone before, or preceded, of a man's ancestors (S, K) and of his relations, (K,) that are above him in age and in excellence; [but this addition is not always agreeable with usage;] one of whom is termed saAlifN↓: (TA:) the pl. of salafN is OasolaAfN and sulRaAfN, (S, K,) [the former a pl. of pauc. and the latter of mult.,] or the latter is pl. of saAlifN↓, and so is salafN [said to be, though this is more properly termed, as it is in the M, a quasi-pl. n.]: (IB, Msb, TA:) and, accord. to Zj, sulufN is pl. of saliyfN↓, and sulafN is pl. of sulofapN↓, which means a company (EuSobapN) that has passed away: (M:) or saAlifN↓ and saliyfN↓ signify the same; going before; preceding; syn. mutaqadRimN. (S.) [Accord. to Abu-lMahásin, AlsRalafu is particularly applied to 'Áïsheh the wife of Mohammad, the three Khaleefehs Aboo-Bekr and 'Omar and 'Othmán, Talhah and Ez-Zubeyr, the Khaleefeh Mo'áwiyeh, and 'Amr Ibn-El-Ás. (De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., sec. ed., i. 156.)] And AlsRalafu AlSRaAliHu is applied to the first chief persons of the Tábi'ees. (TA.) And AlsRalafu AlmuqadRamu is an appellation of the prophet Mohammad. (Ham p. 780.) [Hence, macaAhibu AlsRalafi The tenets of the early Muslims.] ― -b2- Also A people, or party, going before, or preceding, in journeying. (TA.) ― -b3- And [simply] A company of men; as in the saying, jaMCaniI salafN mina AlnRaAsi [A company of men came to me]. (M.) ― -b4- And Any good, or righteous, deed, that one has done beforehand [by way of preparing a future reward]: or any faraT [i. e. cause of reward, or recompense, in the world to come, such as a child dying in infancy], that [as it were] goes before one. (A 'Obeyd, O, K.) ― -b5- And i. q. salamN; (T, Hr, Mgh, O, K, TA;) i. e. Any money, or property, paid in advance, or beforehand, as the price of a commodity for which the seller has become responsible and which one has bought on description: (T, TA:) or payment for a commodity to be delivered at a certain [future] period with something additional to [the equivalent of] the current price at the time of such payment; this [transaction] being a cause of profit to him who makes such payment; and salamN also has this meaning: (TA:) or a sort of sale in which the price is paid in advance, and the commodity is withheld, on the condition of description, to a certain [future] period: (S, O:) it is a subst. from AlUisolaAfu. (Msb, * K, TA.) ― -b6- And A loan (qaroDN) in which is no profit (Hr, O, Mgh, K, TA) to the lender (Hr, O, K, TA) except recompense [in the world to come] and thanks, (TA,) and which it is incumbent on the recipient thereof to return as he received it: (Hr, O, K, TA:) thus the Arabs term it: (Hr, O, TA:) and in this sense also the word is a subst.
from AlUisolaAfu. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A stallion-camel. (IAar, M, TA.) ＝ -A3- Also, (M,) or sulofapN↓, (O, TA,) The prepuce of a boy; (M, O, TA;) so says Lth; (O, TA;) and salifN↓ and silofN↓ signify the same; for this is meant by Aljilodu as an explanation of AlsRalifu and AlsRilofu in the K, in some copies of which Alxulodu is erroneously put for Aljilodu. (TA.)

salifN c
salifN and silofN↓ The husband of the sister of the wife of a man: (S, K:) and [the duals] salifaAni (M, TA) and silofaAni↓ (M, K) signify the two husbands of two sisters: (M, K:) accord. to IAar, the epithet salifapN [or silofapN↓] is not applied to a woman; (M;) one only uses the term salifaAni applied to two men: (M:) or, (M, K,) accord. to Kr, salifataAni, (M,) or silofataAni↓, (K,) is applied to the two wives of two brothers: (M, K:) [in the present day, silofapN↓ is used as meaning a woman's husband's sister, and her brother's wife:] the pl. applied to men is OasolaAfN, (M, K, TA,) and that applied to women is salafN. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also salaAYifu, last sentence.

salafN c
salafN The young one of the Hajal [or partridge]: (S, M, K:) or, accord. to Kr, of the qaTaAp [n. un. of qaTFA, q. v.]: (M:) AA says that he had not heard sulafapN, applied to the female; but if one said sulafapN, like as one says sulakapN as meaning a single female of what are termed silokaAni, it would be approvable: (S:) the pl. is silofaAni (S, M, K) and sulofaAnN: (M, K:) some say that silofaAnN signifies a species of bird, not particularized. (M.) [See also sulaHN and sulakN.]

sulofapN c
sulofapN: see salafN, first sentence, in two places. [Hence,] one says, jaAWuwA sulofapF sulofapF, meaning They came [one before another; or, which is virtually the same,] one after, or near after, or at the heels of, another. (AZ, K.) ― -b2- Also A portion of food (S, M, TA) which a man takes betimes, (S,) or with which one contents, or satisfies, himself [so as to allay the craving of his stomach], (M,) before the [morning-meal called] gadaMC; (S, M, TA;) i. q. lumojapN (K, TA) and luhonapN: (TA:) or a luhonap that is supplied betimes for a guest, before the gadaMC. (TA.) ― -b3- And AlsRulofap also signifies That which a woman reposits, or prepares, or provides, [app. of food,] to present to her visiter. (M.) ＝ -A2- Also A piece, or portion, of land of seed-produce made even [with the misolafap, q. v.]: pl. sulafN. (Az, O, K.) ＝ -A3- And Thin skin (M, O, K) which is put as a lining to boots, (O, K,) sometimes red, and [sometimes] yellow. (O.) ― -b2- See also salafN, last sentence.

silofapN c
silofapN; and its dual: see salifN, in three places.

OaroDN salifapN c
OaroDN salifapN Land in which are few trees. (AA, K.) ＝ -A2- [See also salafN.]

sulaAfN c
sulaAfN (T, S, M, Mgh) and sulaAfapN↓ (T, M, Mgh) The portion that flows before its being expressed, (S, Mgh,) of the juice of the grape; (S;) and this is the most excellent of wine: (Mgh:) or the first that is expressed, of wine: or the portion that flows without its being expressed: or the first that descends, thereof: (M:) or the clearest, or purest, and most excellent, of wine, such as flow from the grapes without their being pressed, and without steeping, or maceration; (T, TA;) and in like manner, such as flows from dates, (T, TA,) and from raisins, before water has been added to it (T, M, * TA) after the exuding of the first thereof; (T, TA:) or the latter signifies the first that is expressed, of anything: (M:) or it has this meaning also: and the former is a name for wine [absolutely]: (S:) or each has this meaning: (K:) or each signifies the clear, or pure, of wine, and of anything. (M.) ― -b2- sulaAfu AlEasokari: see saAlifN.

saluwfN c
saluwfN: see salafN, first sentence. ― -b2- Also, applied to a she-camel, (S, M, K,) That is among the foremost of the camels when they come to the water: (S, K:) or that precedes the [other] camels to the watering-trough or tank: (M:) or that precedes, or leads, the other camels; opposed to EanuwdN. (El-Keysee, TA in art. End.) ― -b3- And A swift, or fleet, horse: (M, K:) pl. sulofN. (K.) ― -b4- And An arrow having a long head: (M:) or a long arrow-head. (K.)

saliyfN c
saliyfN: see salafN, first sentence, in three places. ＝ -A2- Also A road, or way. (TA.)

sulaAfapN c
sulaAfapN: see sulaAfN.

saAlifN c
saAlifN Passing; passing away; coming to an end, or to nought; becoming cut off: (Msb:) and going before; preceding: (S:) pl. sulRaAfN and [quasi-pl. n.] salafN: (IB, Msb, TA:) see salafN, first sentence, in four places. [Hence,] AlOumamu AlsRaAlifapu The peoples going before, or preceding, [or that have gone, or passed away, before,] those remaining, or continuing: (K, * TA:) pl. sawaAlifu. (TA.) One says, kaAna celika fiI AlOumami AlsRaAlifapi waAlquruwni AlsRawaAlifi [That was in the time of the preceding peoples, and the preceding generations]: the pl. in this instance being used because every portion of the qrwn is termed saAlifapN. (TA.) [Hence also,] AlEasokari sulRaAfN, in the K, by implication, AlEskr sulaAfu↓, the former word like guraAb, whereas it is correctly like rumRaAn, The van of the army, as expl. in the K. (TA.)

saAlifapN c
saAlifapN [fem. of saAlifN, q. v. ― -b2- And hence, as a subst.,] The side of the fore part of the neck, from the place of suspension of the ear-ring to the hollow (qalot [in the CK erroneously qalob]) of the collar-bone: (S, K:) or the upper, or uppermost, part of the neck: (M:) or the side of the neck, (M, Mgh, TA,) from the place of suspension of the ear-ring to the HaAqinap [here meaning the pit of the collar-bone]: pl. sawaAlifu. (M.) In the saying UinRahaA lawaDRaAHapu AlsRawaAlifi [Verily she is fair in respect of the saAlifap], mentioned by Lh, the term sAlfp is made applicable to every part thereof, and then the pl. is used accordingly. (M.) It is said in a trad. respecting [the covenant at] El-Hodeybiyeh, laOuqaAtilanRahumo HatRaI tanofarida saAlifatiI i. e. [I will assuredly fight with them, or combat them,] until the side of my neck shall become separate from what is next to it: an allusion to death. (TA.) ― -b3- And [hence, i. e.] by the application of the name of the place to that which occupies the place, (assumed tropical:) The locks of hair that are made to hang down upon the cheek [or rather upon the side of the fore part of the neck]: said by MF to be metonymical, or tropical. (TA.) ― -b4- Also The fore part of the neck of a horse (K, TA) &c.: so in the O and L. (TA.)

bayonahumaA OusoluwfapN c
bayonahumaA OusoluwfapN Between them two is SihorN [i. e. affinity, app. by their having married to sisters: see salifN]. (O, K.)

musolifN c
musolifN, (S, M, O, L,) thus in some copies of the K, as in the S &c., but in other copies of the K, erroneously, sulofN↓, (TA,) A woman that has attained the age of five and forty years, (S, M, O, K,) and the like: (S, M, O:) or i. q. naSafN [i. e. middle-aged, or forty-five years old, or fifty years old]: (M:) an epithet specially applied to a female. (S, O.) A poet says,
wakaAEibN wamusolifu
fiyhi valaAvN kaAldRumaI
[Among them three females like the images of ivory, or of marble, &c., and one with swelling breasts, and one of middle age, &c.]. (S, M: in the O with UilaI in the place of fiyhaA.)

misolafapN c
misolafapN An instrument with which land is made even, (S, M, O, K, TA,) of stone: A 'Obeyd says, I think it is a stone made round [or cylindrical, i. e. a stone roller,] which is rolled upon the land to make it even. (TA.) [In the present day, applied to A harrow.]

OaroDN AljanRapi masoluwfapN c
OaroDN AljanRapi masoluwfapN, occurring in a trad., The ground of Paradise is made even: (As, T, S, O, TA:) said by As to be of the dial. of El-Yemen and Et-Táïf: accord. to IAth, smooth and soft. (TA.)

1 salaqahu c
1. salaqahu, (S, K,) [aor.
saluqa
,] inf. n. saloqN, (TK,) He prostrated him on the back of his neck; (K;) or threw him down on his back; (S;) as also saloqaAhu↓, inf. n. siloqaMCN. (S, K.) You say, TaEanotuhu fasalaqotuhu and saloqayotuhu↓, i. e. [I thrust him, or pierced him, and] threw him down on his back. (S.) And salaqaniI liHulaAwapi AlqafaA and EalaI qafaAIa saloqaAniI↓ He threw me down on my back: and so with S; but more commonly with s. (TA, from a trad.) And salaqahu AlTRabiybu EalaI Zahorihi The physician extended him on his back. (TA.) And salaqahaA, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He threw her down on the back of her neck [or on her back] for the purpose of compressing her; namely, his wife: (Msb:) or he spread her, and then compressed her; (S, K;) as also saloqaAhaA↓; (S;) namely, a girl, or young woman. (K.) ― -b2- He thrust him, or pierced him, (K, TA,) with a spear; (TK;) and pushed him, or repelled him; and dashed himself, or his body, against him; (TA;) and saloqaAhu↓ signifies the same; (K, TA;) inf. n. siloqaMCN: (TA:) [and he struck him, or
smote him; for the inf. n.] saloqN signifies the act of striking, or smiting. (TA.) [Hence,] salaqahu biAlkalaAmi, (S, K,) aor.
saluqa
, (TA,) inf. n. saloqN, (S, TA,) (tropical:) He hurt him, or displeased him, with speech; (S, K, TA;) spoke strongly, or severely, to him; (S, TA;) made him to hear that which he disliked, or hated, and did so much: (TA:) and salaqahu bilisaAnihi (assumed tropical:) he said to him that which he dislike, or hated. (Msb.) saquwkumo biOalosinapK HidaAdK, in the Kur xxxiii. 19, means (tropical:) They hurt you, or displease you, (Fr, Jel, TA,) by what they say, or bite you, (Fr, TA,) or are extravagant, or vehement, in speech to you, (AO, S, TA,) or smite you, (Bd, Jel,) with sharp tongues: (Fr, Bd, TA:) saloqN signifying the act of assaulting, and smiting, with force, with the hand, or arm, or (assumed tropical:) with the tongue: (Bd:) and the verb is also with S; but this is not allowable in the reading [of the Kur]. (TA.) ― -b3- You say also, salaqati AlOaqodaAmu waAlHawaAfiru AlTRariyqa, (TK,) inf. n. saloqN, (K,) The feet of men, and the hoofs of horses or the like, marked, or made marks upon, the road. (K, TK.) ― -b4- And salaqahu He flayed him with a whip. (K.) ― -b5- He galled it; namely, the back of his camel. (TA.) ― -b6- He (a beast) abraded the inner side of his (the rider's) thigh. (TA.) ― -b7- He peeled it off; namely, the flesh from the bone (Eani AlEaZomi); syn. AilotaHaAhu; (O, K, TA;) he removed it therefrom. (TA.) ― -b8- He removed its hair, (Msb, K,) and its fur, (K,) with hot water, (Msb, K,) leaving the traces thereof remaining; (K;) aor.
saluqa
, inf. n. saloqN. (Msb.) ― -b9- He boiled it with fire: (K:) or he boiled it slightly: inf. n. as above. (TA.) You say, salaqotu Albaqolu I boiled the herbs, or leguminous plants, with fire, slightly: (S:) or I boiled them with water merely: thus heard by Az from the Arabs: (Msb:) and in like manner, eggs, (S, Msb,) in their shells: so says Az. (Msb.) You say also, salaqotu XayoYFA biAlmaMCi AlHaArRi [I cooked a thing with hot water]. (Lth, TA.) And suliqa is said of anything as meaning It was [boiled, i. e.] cooked with hot water (TA.) ― -b10- salaqa Albarodu AlnRabaAta The cold nipped, shrunk, shrivelled, or blasted, the herbage, or plants; syn. OaHoraqahu [q. v.]. (K.) ― -b11- salaqa AlmazaAdapa, (inf. n. as above, TA,) He oiled, or greased, the leathern water-bag: (S, K:) and in like manner, AlOadiyma [the hide, or tanned hide]. (TA.) And salaqa AlbaEiyra (K, TA) biAlhinaMCi (TA) He smeared the camel all over with tar: (K, TA:) from Ibn-'Abbád. (TA.) ＝ -A2- salaqa AljuwaAliqa, aor.
saluqa
, (TA,) inf. n. saloqN, (S, TA,) He inserted one of the two loops of the [sack called] jwAlq into the other: (S, TA:) or salaqa AlEuwda fiI AlEurowapi he inserted the stick into the loop [of the jwAlq]; as also Aslqhu↓: (K:) accord. to AHeyth, saloqN signifies the inserting the [stick called] XiZaAZ at once into the two loops of the [two sacks called] juwaAliqaAni when they are put and bound upon the camel. (TA. [See also qaTaba AljuwaAliqa.]) ＝ -A3- salaqa AlHaAYiTa: see 5. ＝ -A4- suliqato OafowaAhunaA mino Oakoli waraqi AlXRajari Our mouths broke out with pimples, or small pustules, from the eating of the leaves of trees. (TA. [See sulaAqN.]) ＝ -A5- AlitRaI suliqa EalayohaA hecihi saliyqatuhu↓ and suiqahaA [This is his nature, to which he was constitutionally adapted or disposed]: said by Sb. (TA.) ＝ -A6- salaqa, [intrans., aor.
saluqa
,] (S, K,) inf. n. saloqN, (TA,) He called out, cried out, or shouted; or did so vehemently; or with his utmost force: (S, K:) a dial. var. of Salaqa: (S:) he raised the voice: (Ibn-El-Mubárak, TA:) or he raised his voice on the occasion of the death of a man, or on the occasion of a calamity: (A 'Obeyd, TA:) accord. to IDrd, the meaning [of the inf. n.] is a woman's slapping and scratching her face: but the first explanation is more correct. (TA.) ― -b2- Also He ran. (K.) You say salaqa saloqapF He ran a run. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.)

4 Aslq c
4. Aslq, said of a man, His camel's back became white after the healing of galls. (TA.) ＝ -A2- And He hunted, snared, or trapped, a she-wolf, (IAar. K,) which is called siloqap. (IAar.) ＝ -A3- See also 1, in the latter half of the paragraph.

5 tasalRaqa
5: see Q. Q. 3. ― -b2- tslRq EalaI firaAXihi (IAar, K, TA) ZahorFA libaTonK (IAar, TA) He was, or became, restless, agitated, or in a state of commotion, upon his bed, by reason of anxiety or pain: (IAar, K, TA:) but Az says that the verb known in this sense is with S. (TA.) ＝ -A2- tslRq AljidaAra, (S, K,) or AlHaAYiTa; and salaqahu↓, inf. n. saloqN; (TA; [comp. the Chald. ???;]) He ascended, climbed, or scaled, the wall: (S, K, TA:) or tasalRuqN signifies the ascending a smooth wall: or it is like the tasalRuq of the Messiah to Heaven. (TA.)

7 Anslq c
7. Anslq [app. signifies It was, or became, affected with what is termed sulaAq; said of the tongue: and in like manner said of the eye: or,] said of the tongue, it was, or became, affected with an excoriation: and AinosilaAqN in the eye is a redness incident thereto. (TA.)

Q. Q. 1 saloqaAhu c
Q. Q. 1. saloqaAhu &c.: see 1, in five places.

Q. Q. 3 AisolanoqaI c
Q. Q. 3. AisolanoqaI, of the measure AifoEanolaI, (S,) He lay, or slept, (naAma,) on his back; (Seer, S, O, K;) like AisotaloqaI [which belongs to art. lqI]; (O, K;) as also tslRq↓. (TA.)

saloqN c
saloqN The mark, or scar, of a gall, or sore, on the back of a camel, when it has healed, and the place thereof has become white; (K;) [like saHoqN;] as also salaqN↓. (S, K.) ― -b2- And The mark made by the [plaited thong called] nisoE upon the side of the camel, (K, TA,) or upon his belly, from which the fur becomes worn off; (TA;) and so saliyqapN↓: (S, K: *) salaAYiqu [is pl. of ↓the latter word, and] signifies the marks made by the feet of men and by the hoofs of horses or the like upon the road: (K, TA:) and to these the marks made by the [plaited thongs called] OanosaAE upon the belly of the camel are likened. (TA.)

siloqN c
siloqN [Bete; and particularly red garden-bete: so called in the present day; and also called Xawanodar and sawanodar and banojar:] a certain plant, (S, Msb,) or herb (baqolapN), (K,) that is eaten, (S,) well known; (Msb, K;) i. q. jgndr [or Jugunoduro, whence the vulgar name Xawanodar, and hence sawanodar]; so says ISh; i. e. in Pers.; in some of the MSS. jlndr [a mistranscription for JuGunoduro]; a plant having long leaves, and a root penetrating [deeply] into the earth, the leaves of which are tender, and are cooked: (TA:) it clears [the skin], acts as a dissolvent, and as a lenitive, and as an aperient, or a deobstruent; exhilarates, and is good for the niqoris [i. e. gout, or podagra,] and the joints: its expressed juice, when poured upon wine, converts it into vinegar after two hours; and when poured upon vinegar, converts it into wine after four hours; and the expressed juice of its root, used as an errhine, is an antidote to toothache and earache and hemicrania. (K.) [See also HumRaADN, and kuronubN.] siloqu AlmaMCi and siloqu AlbarRi, also, are the names of Two plants. (K.) ＝ -A2- Also The he-wolf: (S, Msb, K:) and siloqapN↓ the she-wolf: (S, K:) or the latter signifies thus; but siloqN is not applied to the he-wolf: (K:) the pl. of siloqapN is suloqaAnN and siloqaAnN: (JM, TA;) or these are pls. of siloqN; and the pl. of siloqapN is silaqN and siloqN, (K,) or [rather] this last is a coll. gen. n. of which siloqapN is the n. un. (Sb.) Hence the prov., OasolaTu mino siloqapK↓ (JK, Meyd) i. e. More clamorous than a she-wolf: or it may mean more overpowering. (Meyd.) ― -b2- And hence, (TA,) siloqapN↓ is applied to a woman as meaning (tropical:) Clamorous; or long-tongued and vehemently clamorous, (S, K, TA,) foul, evil, or lewd; (K, TA;) likened to the she-wolf in respect of her bad qualities: (TA:) pl. suloqaAnN and siloqaAnN. (K.) ― -b3- siloqapN↓ also signifies A female lizard of the kind called DabR, (JK,) or a female locust, (TA,) when she has laid her eggs. (JK, TA.) ＝ -A3- Also A water-course, or channel in which water flows, (K, TA,) between two tracts of elevated, or elevated and rugged, ground: or, accord. to As, an even, depressed tract of ground: (TA:) pl. suloqaAnN (K) and OasolaAqN and OasaAliqu, which (i. e. the second and third of these pls.) are also said to be pls. of salaqN [q. v.]. (TA.)

salaqN c
salaqN An even plain: (S:) or a smooth, even, tract, of good soil: (O, K: [a meaning erroneously assigned in the CK to saloqapN:] or a depressed, even, plain, in which are no trees: (ISh:) or a low tract, or portion, of land, that produces herbage: (JK:) pl. [of mult.] suloqaAnN (S, O, K) and siloqaAnN (K) and [of pauc.] OasolaAqN, (JK, O, K,) and OasaAliqu is also a pl. of salaqN, or of its pl. OasolaAqN, as is likewise OasaAliyqu: (TA:) samolaqN↓, also, with an augmentative m, signifies the same, and its pl. is samaAliqu: (S:) or the pl. suloqaAnN signifies meadows (riyaAD) in the higher parts of [tracts such as are termed] biraAq [pl. of buroqapN] and qifaAf [pl. of qufRN]. (Az, TA in art. rwD.) ― -b2- See also saloqN.

siloqapN c
siloqapN: see siloqN, in four places.

saloqaApN c
saloqaApN A certain mode of compressing, upon the back. (Ibn-'Abbád, K, TA.) [See 1.]

sulaAqN c
sulaAqN Pimples, or small pustules, that comes
forth upon the root of the tongue: or a scaling in the roots of the teeth: (S, K:) sometimes it is in beasts (dawaAbR). (TA.) ― -b2- And A thickness, or roughness, in the eyelids, by reason of a corrosive matter which causes them to become red and occasions the falling off of the eyelashes and then the ulceration of the edges of the eyelids: (K:) thus slAq of the eye is expl. in the “ Kánoon. ” (TA.)

saliyqN c
saliyqN What fall off [app. of the leaves] (S, K) from trees, (S,) or from shrubs, or small trees; (K;) or from trees which the cold has nipped, or blasted: or, accord. to As, trees which heat, or cold, has nipped, or blasted: (TA:) pl. suloqN. (K.) ― -b2- And What has dried up of [the plant called] Xiboriq, (Ibn-'Abbád, K,) and become parched by the sun. (Ibn-'Abbád.) ＝ -A2- Also Honey which the bees build up (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K) along the length of their hive, or habitation: (K:) or, accord. to the T, saliyqapN↓ signifies a certain thing which the bees fabricate in their hive, or habitation, lengthwise: (TA:) pl. suloqN. (K.) ＝ -A3- Also The side of a road. (K.) The two sides of the road are called saliyqaA AlTRariyqi. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O.)

saliyqapN c
saliyqapN What is cooked with hot water (maA suliqa), of herbs, or leguminous plants, and the like: (K:) or, accord. to Az, what is cooked (maA Tubixa) with water, of the herbs, or leguminous plants, of the [season called] rabiyE, and eaten in times of famine: pl. salaAYiqu, which occurs in a trad., and, as some relate it, with S. (TA.) ― -b2- And Millet (curapN) bruised, (IAar, IDrd, Z, K,) and dressed, (IAar, IDrd, K,) by being cooked with milk: (IAar:) or OaqiT [a preparation of dried curd] with which are mixed [plants called] TaraAvyv. (K.) ＝ -A2- Accord. to Lth, (TA,) The place where the [plaited thong called] nisoE comes forth [from the ropes that form the breast-girth], (O, K, TA,) in the side of the camel: said by him to be derived from the phrase salaqotu XayoYFA biAlmaMCi AlHaArRi; because it is [as though it were] burnt by the ropes: or, accord. to another explanation, its pl., salaAYiqu, signifies the strips of flesh between the two sides. (TA.) ― -b2- See also saloqN, in two places. ＝ -A3- And see saliyqN. ＝ -A4- And The nature, or natural disposition or constitution, (AZ, IAar, S, K,) of a man. (IAar, S.) See 1, in the last quarter of the paragraph. One says, UinRahu lakariymu AlsRaliyqapi Verily he is generous in respect of nature. (AZ.) [See also saliyqiyRapN.]

saluwqiIRN c
saluwqiIRN [applied in the present day to A greyhound, and any hunting-dog;] a sort of dog: (MA:) and a sort of coat of mail: (TA:) saluwqiyRapN↓ [as a coll. n.] is applied to certain coats of mail: (S, K: *) and to certain dogs: so called in relation to saluwqu, [said by Freytag to be written in the K saluwqp, but it is there said to be like Sabuwr,] a town in El-Yemen; (S, MA, K; *) or a town, or district, in the border of Armenia, (K,) called AllRaAn [or laAn]: (TA:) or the coats of mail are so called in relation to the former slwq; (so in a copy of the S;) and the dogs, in relation to saluwq which is the city of AllRaAn [or laAn]: (S, TA: *) or both are so called in relation to salaqiyRapu, a town in the Greek Empire, (IDrd as on the authority of As, and K,) said by ElMes'oodee to have been on the shore of [the province of] Antioch, remains of which still exist; (TA;) and if so, it is a rel. n. altered from its proper form. (K, TA.) ― -b2- [It is also said in the TA to signify A sword: but a verse there cited, after Th, as an ex. of it in this sense, is mistranscribed, and casts doubt upon the orthography of the word, and upon this explanation.]

kalaAmN saliyqiIRN c
kalaAmN saliyqiIRN [Natural, or untaught, speech;] speech whereof the desinential syntax is not much attended to, but which is chaste and eloquent in respect of what has been heard, though often tripping, or stumbling, in respect of grammar: (Lth, L, TA:) or the speech which the dweller in the desert utters according to his nature and his proper dialect, though his other speech be nobler and better. (L, TA.) And saliyqiyRapN↓ [in like manner, the p being affixed to the epithet saliyqiIRN to convert it into a subst.,] signifies The dialect in which the speaker thereof proceeds loosely, or freely, according to his nature, without paying much attention to desinential syntax, and without avoiding incorrectness. (O, TA.) You say, fulaAnN yatakalRamu biAlsRaliyqiyRapi↓, meaning Such a one speaks according to his nature, not from having learned. (S, K.) And fulaAnN yaqoraOu biAlsRaliyqiyRapi↓ Such a one reads, or recites, according to the natural condition in which he has grown up, not as having been taught. (TA.)

saluwqiyRapN c
saluwqiyRapN: see saluwqiIRN. ＝ -A2- Also The sitting-place of the rubRaAn [or captain] of a ship. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

saliyqiyRapN c
saliyqiyRapN: see saliyqiIRN, in three places.

salRaAqN c
salRaAqN: see misolaqN, in two places.

AlsRulaAqu c
AlsRulaAqu A certain festival of the Christians; (K;) that of the Ascension of Jesus into Heaven: (TK:) derived from salaqa AlHaAYiTa [expl. above (see 5)]: said by IDrd to be a foreign word (OaEojamaIRN), and in one place said by him to be Syriac, arabicized. (TA.)

saAliqapN c
saAliqapN A woman raising her voice, on the occasion of a calamity, (K, TA,) or on the occasion of the death of any one: (TA:) or slapping her face: (K, TA:) thus says Ibn-El-Mubárak: but the former explanation is the more correct: it occurs in a trad., in which such is said to have been cursed by the Prophet; and, as some relate it, with S. (TA.)

samolaqN c
samolaqN: see salaqN: and see also art. smlq.

sayolaqN c
sayolaqN Quick, or swift; a fem. epithet; (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, K;) applied to a she-camel: (Ibn- 'Abbád, O:) in the Tekmileh, saliyqN, which is a mistake: in the L, a she-camel having a penetrative energy in her pace. (TA.)

AlOasaAliqu c
AlOasaAliqu What is next to the lahawAt [app. here a pl. used as a sing., meaning the uvula] of the mouth, internally: (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K:) or the upper parts of the interior of the mouth: (TA:) or the upper parts of the mouth, (M, TA,) those to which the tongue rises: thus applied, it is a pl. having no sing. (TA.)

xaTiybN misolaqN c
xaTiybN misolaqN and misolaAqN↓ and salRaAqN↓ (tropical:) An eloquent speaker or orator or preacher: (S, K, TA:) because of the vehemence of his voice and his speech. (S, TA.) And lisaAnN misolaqN and salRaAqN↓ (tropical:) A sharp, cutting, or eloquent, tongue. (TA.)

misolaAqN c
misolaAqN: see the next preceding paragraph.

masoluwqapN c
masoluwqapN, meaning A skinned fowl cooked [i. e. boiled] with water, by itself, [and also any boiled meat, is agreeable with a classical usage of the verb from which it is derived, but] is [said to be a vulgar term. (TA.)

1 salaka AlTRariyqa c
1. salaka AlTRariyqa, (IAar, MA, Msb,) or AlmakaAna, (K,) aor.
saluka
, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. suluwkN (MA, Msb, K) and salokN, (K, [but I doubt this latter's being correctly used as an inf. n. of the verb in the sense here immediately following,]) He travelled, (MA,) or went along in, (Msb,) the road, (IAar, MA, Msb,) or the place: (K:) or salaka AlmakaAna he entered into the place. (TK.) [In these and similar instances, it seems that the prep. fiI is suppressed, and the noun therefore put in the accus. case, as in daxala Albayota &c.: for it is said that] salaka as meaning He entered (daxala) is intrans.: (Kull p. 206:) Anslk↓ [likewise] has this meaning: (S:) Aslk↓ as an intrans. verb [in the sense of salaka] is extr. (Msb.) [salaka TariyqFA is also often used tropically, as meaning (tropical:) He pursued a course of conduct or the like.] ＝ -A2- And salakahu AlTRariyqa, (IAar, Msb,) or AlmakaAna, and fiyhi, (K,) [inf. n. salokN;] and UiyRaAhu Aslkhu↓, (Msb, K,) this also is allowable, (IAar, TA,) and fiyhi, and Ealayohi; (K;) He made him [to travel or] to go along in [or to enter] the road, (IAar, * Msb,) or the place: (K:) and so salaka bihi AlTRariyqa: (Msb:) and slRkhu↓, inf. n. tasoliykN, signifies the same as [salakahu thus used, and] Aslkhu. (TA.) And slakatu AlXRaIoCa fiI AlXRaIoCi, (S, Msb,) inf. n. salokN, (S,) I made the thing to enter, or I inserted it, or introduced it, into the thing: (S:) or I made the thing to go, or pass, through the thing: (Msb:) and Oasolakotuhu↓ signifies the same. (S. [See an ex. of the latter verb in a verse of 'Abd-Menáf Ibn-Riba El-Hudhalee, voce UicaA; cited there and here also in the S.]) You say, salaka AlxayoTa fiI AlUiborapi He inserted the thread into the needle. (MA.) And salaka yadahu fiI Aljayobi He inserted [his hand, or arm, into the opening at the neck and bosom of the shirt]; as also OasolakahaA↓: (K:) and so into the skin for milk or water, and the like. (TA.) And it is said in the Kur [xxvi. 200], kacelika salakonaAhu fiI quluwbi Almujorimiyna Thus we have caused it to enter [into the hearts of the sinners]. (S.) And in the same [xxxix. 22], fasalakahu yanaAbiyEa fiI AlOaroDi [And
hath caused it to enter into springs in the earth]. (TA.)

2 salRaka
2: see 1. ― -b2- [In the present day, slRk signifies He cleared a passage or way. And He cleaned out a pipe for smoking. ＝ -A2- And, from silokN, He wound thread upon a reel or into a skein.]

4 Oasolaka
4: see 1, in four places.

7 Uinosalaka
7: see 1, second sentence.

silokN c
silokN Thread, or string, (S, Mgh, K,) with which one sews: (K:) or upon which beads are strung; (Ham p. 42;) [but] not having beads upon it; for if it have, it is termed simoTN: (S and Mgh in art. smT:) [in the present day it signifies wire:] a pl. [or rather a coll. gen. n.] of which the sing. [or n. un.] is silokapN↓: the pl. [of pauc.] of silokN is OasolaAkN and [of mult.] suluwkN. (K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, hecaA kalaAmN raqiyqu AlsRiloki (tropical:) This is speech, or language, [subtile; or] abstruse in its course, or tenour; i. e. xafiIRu Almasolaki↓. (TA.) ― -b3- And maA Oanota bimunojaridi AlsRiloki, (AZ, TA in art. jrd,) or bimutajarRidi AlsRiloki, (so in a copy of the A in that art.,) said to one who is shy, or bashful, (assumed tropical:) meaning [Thou art] not free from shyness in appearing [before others]: (AZ, TA in that art.:) or (tropical:) thou art not celebrated, or well-known. (A and TA in that art.) ＝ -A2- Also The first of what is emitted by the she-camel [from her udder], before the libaO [or biestings]. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

sulakN c
sulakN The young one of the Hajal [or partridge]; (S, K;) like sulaHN: (S in art. slH:) or of the bird called qaTFA: (K:) fem. sulakapN, (S, K,) and silokaAnapN↓, but the latter is rare: (K:) pl. silokaAnN, (S, K,) like SirodaAnN pl. of SuradN (S) [and siloHaAnN pl. of sulaHN].

silokapN c
silokapN: see silokN.

TaEonapN sulokaI c
TaEonapN sulokaI [A thrust, or piercing thrust,] directed right towards the face. (S, K.) And OarN sulokaI [An affair] rightly directed; (K, TA;) and so raOoIN [an opinion]: (TA:) or the former, [an affair] following one uniform course. (ISk, TA.) ― -b2- In the saying of Keys Ibn-'Eyzárah,
gadaApa tanaAdawoA vumRa qaAmuwA faOajomaEuwA
biqatoliIa sulokaI layosa fiyhaA tanaAzuEu
he means [In the morning when they congregated, then arose and determined upon my slaughter] with a strong resolution in respect of which there was no contention. (TA.)

salakuwtN c
salakuwtN, like jabaruwtN [in measure], A certain bird. (K.)

silokaAnapN c
silokaAnapN: see sulakN.

masolakN c
masolakN [A place of passage of a man or beast and of anything;] a way, road, or path: pl. masaAliku. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] masolakaA AlmaroOapi [The vagina and rectum of the woman]. (M in art. fyD. [See OafaADa AlmaroOapa in that art.]) ― -b3- [Hence, also,] one says, xuco fiI masaAliki AlHaqRi (tropical:) [Enter thou upon the ways of truth]. (TA.) ― -b4- See also silokN.

masolakapN c
masolakapN A border (TurRap) slit from the side of a garment, or piece of cloth: (K:) so called because extended, like the silok. (TA.)

musalRakN c
musalRakN Slender, or lean, (IDrd, K, TA,) in body; applied to a man and to a horse. (IDrd, TA.) And musalRakN AlcRakari Sharp in the head of the penis: and so musamolakN AlcRakari. (AA, TA.)

1 salima c
1. salima, [aor.
salama
,] inf. n. salaAmapN (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and salaAmN (A, TA) and salamN and salomN and silomN, (Bd in xxxix. 30,) He was, or became, safe, or secure; or he escaped; (M, TA;) or he was, or became, free; (TA;) mina AlMfaAti [from evils of any kind], (S, Mgh,) or mina AlMfapi [from evil of any kind], (K,) or mina AlbalaMCi [from trial, or affliction], (A, TA,) or mina AlOamori [from the affair]: (M:) he (a traveller) was, or became, safe, secure, or free, from evils of any kind: (Msb:) and salima mina AlEayobi he was, or became, free from fault, defect, imperfection, blemish, or vice; syn. bariYa. (Msb in art. brO.) [Hence,] one says, laA biciI tasolamu maA kaAna GacaA wakacaA, (ISk, S, K, *) meaning No, by God [or Him] who maketh thee to be in safety, (ISk, S, K,) [such and such things were not;] and to two persons lA bcI tasolamaAni, and to a pl. number lA bcI tasolamuwna, and to a female lA bcI tasolamiyna, and to a pl. number [of females] lA bcI tasolamona. (ISk, S, K. *) And laA OafoEalu celika biciI tasolamu, meaning, biciI salaAmatiki [i. e. I will not do that, by the Author (lit. Lord or Master) of thy safety]; and in like manner, bcI tasolamaAni, and bcI tasolamuwna. (Sb, M. [See also cw.]) And Aicohabo biciI tasolamu, i. e. Aicohabo bisalaAmatika [Go thou with thy safety; or, with the Author of thy safety to protect thee; meaning go thou in safety]; and [to two persons] AicohabaA biciI tasolamaAni. (S, K.) cI is thus prefixed to a verb [as virtually governing it in the gen. case] like as Myap is in an instance mentioned under this latter word; but these are two extr. instances; for only a noun significant of time is [regularly] prefixed to a verb, as in the phrase hecaA yawomu yufoEalu, meaning yufoEalu fiyhi: (Akh, S:) it is not prefixed to any but this verb tasolamu [and its variations as above mentioned]. (Sb, M, K.) ― -b2- And hence, (Mgh,) one says also, salimato lahu AlDRayoEapu, meaning [The landed estate] was, or became, free from participation to him; syn. xalaSat. (Mgh, TA.) ＝ -A2- slmhu, [app. salamahu, or perhaps salimahu, for some verbs of this measure are trans., as Hasiba and wariva,] inf. n. slm, [app. salamN, q. v. infrà,] He made him a captive. (TA.) ＝ -A3- salamatohu AlHayRapu, (TA,) inf. n. salomN, (M, K, TA,) The serpent bit him: (M, * K, * TA:) mentioned by Az, but he adds that no one but Lth has said this. (TA.) ＝ -A4- salama Aljiloda, aor.
salima
, (S, K,) inf. n. salomN, (TA,) He tanned the skin with [qaraZ, i. e. leaves of] the salam [or mimosa flava]. (S, K, TA.) ― -b2- salama AldRalowa, (M, K,) aor.
salima
, inf. n. salomN, (M,) He finished making the leathern bucket; and made it firm, strong, or sound, or made it firmly, strongly, or soundly. (M, K.)

2 slRmhu c
2. slRmhu, (S, M, Msb, K,) inf. n. tasoliymN, (K,) He (God) made him to be safe, secure, or free; saved, secured, or freed, him; (M, Msb, TA;) mina AlMfaAti [from evils of any kind], (S, Msb,) or mina AlMfapi [from evil of any kind], (K,) or mina AlOamori [from the affair]. (M.) [Freytag assigns the same meaning to Aslmhu↓ also, as on the authority of the Ham; in which I find no explanation of this verb except one which will be found later in this paragraph.] ― -b2- [Hence,] AltRasoliymu is also syn. with AlsRalaAmu, (S, K, TA,) as meaning The saluting, or greeting, one with a prayer for his safety, or security, or freedom, from evils of any kind in his religion and in his person; and the interpretation thereof is [the expressing a desire for] AltRaxoliySN; (Mbr, TA;) or the saluting, or greeting, one with a prayer for his life; or, by saying salaAmN Ealayoka [q. v. infrà, voce salaAmN]; syn. AltRaHiyRapu. (TA.) You say, salRama Ealayohi [meaning He so saluted, or greeted, him]. (M, Msb.) [This, when said of God, virtually means salRamahu, i. e. He saved him; and should be rendered agreeably with this explanation in the phrase commonly used after the mention of the Prophet, SalRaI QllRehu Ealayohi wasalRama May God bless and save him. You say also, salRama Ealayohi biAlxilaAfapi He saluted him with the acknowledgment of his being Khaleefeh; saying, salaAmN Ealayoka yaA Oamiyra AlmuWominiyna Salutation to thee, or peace be on thee, &c., O Prince of the Faithful.] AltRasoliymapu signifies The salutation that is pronounced on finishing every two rek'ahs in prayer: (Har p. 180:) [and also that which is pronounced after the last rek'ah of each of the prayers (i. e. after the sunneh prayers and the fard alike), addressed to the two guardian and recording angels: (see my “ Modern Egyptians, ” ch. iii., p. 78 of the 5th ed.:) and salRama means He pronounced either of those salutations.] ― -b3- [Hence also,] slRm Uilayohi AlXRaIoCa, (S, K, *) inf. n. as above; (K;) and Aslm↓ Alyh AlXICa; (M;) He gave to him the thing; (S, * M, K;) or delivered it to him: (M:) [he resigned it to him:] and slRm Uilayohi AlwadiyEapa, (Mgh,) or slRm AlwadiyEapa liSaAHibihaA, He delivered the deposit [to him, or] to its owner: (Msb:) and Aslm↓ AlvRawoba UilaI AlxayRaATi (Mgh) signifies the same as slRmhu Uilayohi [i. e. He delivered the garment, or piece of cloth, to the tailor]. (Har p. 166.) ― -b4- See also 4, in two places. ― -b5- You say also, slRm AlOajiyru nafosahu lilomusotaOojiri The hired man gave himself up, or gave authority over himself, to the hirer. (Msb.) And Oasolamotuhu↓ and salRamotuhu I left him in the power of him who desired to kill him or to wound him. (Ham p. 115.) And lilohalakapi Aslmhu↓ [He gave him up to destruction]: in this case with [the prep.] l only. (Har p. 166.) And
AlrRajula Aslm↓, (S, * M, Msb, *) or AlEaduwRa, (K,) He left, forsook, or deserted, (M, K,) the man, (S, * M, Msb, *) or the enemy; (K;) or abstained from aiding, or assisting, him; (S, M, Msb, K;) and threw him into destruction. (IAth, TA.) And limaA bihi Aslmhu↓ He left him [to that bane which was in him: app. referring to the bite of a serpent, or any evil affection: see saliymN, third sentence]. (S, * M.) ― -b6- And slRm Oamorahu UilaI QllRehi and Aslmhu↓, both meaning the same, (S, Msb, K, TA,) i. e. He committed his case to God. (TA.) ― -b7- And slRm AldRaEowaI He acknowledged the truth [or justice] of the claim, demand, or suit; [he conceded its truth or justice;] from slRm AlwadiyEapa liSaAHibihaA, expl. above; denoting an ideal delivering [or yielding of a thing to another person]. (Msb.) [Hence one says, slRm OanRahu kacaA He conceded that it was thus.] ― -b8- And AltRasoliymu signifies also [The assenting, or] the giving [one's] approval (S, K, TA) unreservedly, (S,) to that which is ordained, or decreed, (S, K, TA,) by God; and the submitting to his commands; and the abstaining from offering opposition in the case in which it is not becoming [to do so]. (TA.) You say, slRm liOamori QllRehi He assented to the command of God: [or he gave his approval to it:] or he submitted to it; as also Aslm↓. (MA.)

3 sAlmhu c
3. sAlmhu, (M, Msb,) inf. n. musaAlamapN (S, M, Msb) and silaAmN, (M, Msb,) He made peace, or became at peace or reconciled, with him; or he reconciled himself with him: [implying mutual concession, or a compromise:] (S, * M, Msb:) and saAlamaA They made peace, or became at peace or reconciled, or they reconciled themselves, each with the other. (K.)

4 Oasolama
4: see 2, in nine places. [The first of the meanings there assigned to this verb is, in my opinion, more than doubtful. In all its senses, it seems to be properly trans.: when it is used as an intrans. verb, an objective complement is app. understood. Thus,] Oasolama is syn. with Oasolafa [as meaning He paid in advance, or beforehand]; (S, M, Mgh, Msb;) AlvRamana [the price] being suppressed, though sometimes it is expressed; (Mgh;) as also slRm↓; (M;) and tslRm↓, as occurring in a trad., where it is said, mano tasalRama fiI XaIoCK falaA yaSorifuhu UilaI gayorihi [Whoso pays in advance for a thing, he shall not turn it over, or transfer it, to another than him]; but Kt says that he had not heard this verb thus used except in this instance. (TA.) So the first of these verbs signifies in the saying, Aslm fiI AlTRaEaAmi (S) or fI AlburRi (Mgh) [He paid in advance for the wheat], and fI AlXRaIoCi [for the thing], as also slRm↓. (M.) And hence the saying, UicaA Oasolama SuwfFA fiI libodK Oawo XaEarFA fiI misoHK lamo yajuzo [If he give in advance wool for felt, or goats' hair for a garment, or piece, of haircloth, it will not be allowable]. (Mgh.) And so in the phrase, Oasolamotu Uilayohi [I paid in advance to him]. (Msb.) ― -b2- Also [He resigned, or submitted, himself; nafosahu being understood: or] he was, or became, resigned, or submissive; (M, K;) and so Astslm↓: (S, M, Msb, K:) you say, Aslm lilRehi [He resigned, or submitted, himself, or he was, or became, resigned, or submissive, to God: see also an ex. (before referred to) in the last sentence of the second paragraph: or he was, or became, sincere in his religion, or without hypocrisy, towards God: see musolimN]: (Msb:) [or] Aslm signifies he entered into AlsRilom, (S, Msb,) which here means AlAisotisolaAm [i. e. the state of resignation, or submission]. (S.) ― -b3- And He became a Muslim; as also tslRm↓; (M, * K;) as in the saying, kaAna kaAfirFA vumRa tasalRama, i. e. Oasolama [He was an unbeliever, or a denier of the unity of God, &c.; then he became a Muslim]: (M:) or he entered [the pale, or communion, of] the religion of AlUisolaAm. (S, * Msb.) AlUisolaAmu as a principle of the law of God is The manifesting of humility or submission, and outward conforming with the law of God, and the taking upon oneself to do or to say as the Prophet has done or said: for this, the blood is to be spared, and one may demand the repelling of evil: (T, * M:) and if there is therewith firm belief with the heart, it is UiymaAnN: (T:) this is the doctrine of Esh-Sháfi'ee; but the doctrine of Aboo-Haneefeh makes no difference between these two terms: (KT:) [agreeably with the former doctrine,] Th well and briefly says, AlAslAm is with the tongue, and AlAymAn is with the heart: and he says, in explaining verse 48 of ch. v. of the Kur, that every prophet has been sent with AlAslAm, though the ordinances differ. (M.) ― -b4- One says also, Oasolamotu Eanohu, meaning I left it [app. an affair, as in an explanation in the TK,] after I had been [engaged] in it. (Ibn-Buzurj, K.) And Aslm occurs intransitively in the saying, kaAna raAEiIa ganamK vumRa Oasolama, meaning [He was a pastor of sheep, or goats; then] he left them. (M.) ― -b5- [Freytag assigns to Aslm another signification “ Adscendere fecit (vid. a sulRam), ” as from the Ham, p. 39: but this is app. a mistake, into which he has been led by a saying, there cited, of Zuheyr, which I read thus:
hawiIRa AldRalowi OasolamahaA AlrRiXaMCu
(meaning, The descent, or as the descent, of the bucket that the well-rope has let go): and by its being there said that “ you should not prefer any reading of hwI to that with damm, though it has been said otherwise: ” whereas the correct reading is, in my opinion, hawiIR, agreeably with what here follows:] Er-Riyáshee says, on the authority of AZ, that AlhawiIRu, with fet-h, is downwards; and with damm, upwards; and he cites the saying above as an ex. of the word as meaning downwards. (TA in art. hwI.)

5 tslRm minohu c
5. tslRm minohu He asserted, or declared, himself to be free from, or clear of, or quit of, it, or him. (M.) ― -b2- tslRm is also syn. with Ousolama, in two senses: see the latter, in two places. ＝ -A2- And tslRmhu signifies He took it, or received it; namely, a thing given, or delivered. (S, M, Msb, K.)

6 tsAlmwA c
6. tsAlmwA, (M,) and tsAlmA, (K,) inf. n. tasaAlumN, (S,) They, (M,) or they two, (K,) made peace, or became at peace or reconciled, (S, * M, K,) one with another, (S, M,) or each with the other. (S, K.) [See also 8.] ― -b2- One says of a man, (M,) of a great, or frequent, liar, (TA,) laA tasaAlamu xayolaAhu, [for tatasaAlamu,] (M,) or laA yatasaAlamu xayolaAhu, (K, TA,) [(assumed tropical:) His two troops of horses will not agree in pace, each with the other;] meaning (tropical:) [his assertions will not be found to agree together; or] he will not say what is true, so that it may be accepted from him: for tasaAlamato, said of horses, means (assumed tropical:) they kept pace, one with another; (tasaAyarato [q. v.];) not exciting one another. (M, K, TA.)

8 Astlm c
8. Astlm He became at peace, or reconciled. (TA.) Hence the saying, (TA,) huwa laA yasotalamu EalaI saxaTihi He will not become at peace, or reconciled, during his displeasure at a thing. (K, TA.) [See also 6.] ― -b2- Astlm AlzRaroEu The seed-produce put forth its ears. (K.) ＝ -A2- Astlm AlHajara He touched, (S, K,) or reached, (Mgh,) the stone, [meaning the Black Stone of the Kaabeh,] by kissing, or with the hand: (S, Mgh, K:) or he wiped it, or stroked it, with the hand: (Mgh:) or he kissed the stone: or he embraced it: (M:) and AisotaloOamahu signifies the same; (M, K;) but is not the original: (M:) accord. to ISk, the Arabs pronounced it with hemz, contr. to analogy; (Msb;) or it should not be pronounced with hemz, though some thus pronounce it, (S,) the original being Astlm, (ISk, Msb,) because it is from silaAmN [pl. of salimapN] signifying “ stones, ” (ISk, S, * M, Msb, * [in the Mgh, from salimapN signifying “ a stone, ” and in the Msb the pl. of salimapN is said to be salaAmN, like kalaAmN,]) accord. to Sb, who says that it does not denote the act of taking; (M;) or, accord. to Sb, it is from AlsRalaAmu, with fet-h, meaning “ salutation, ” and it means the touching with the hand by way of salutation in order to obtain a blessing thereby: (TA:) but accord. to IAar, the original is with hemz, from AlmulaMCamapu, meaning AlAijotimaAEu [“ the coming together, ” &c., because denoting contact]. (Msb.) Abu-t-Tufeyl is related to have said, raOayotu rasuwla QllRehi SalRaI QllRehu Ealayohi wasalRama yaTuwfu EalaI raAHilatihi yasotalimu bimiHojanihi wayuqabRilu AlmiHojana [i. e. I saw the Apostle of God (may God bless and save him) circuiting around the Kaabeh, upon his camel, touching the Black Stone with his hooked staff, and kissing the hooked staff]. (TA.) The primary signification of AlAisotilaAmu is [said to be] The wiping, or stroking, the salimap, i. e. the stone: afterwards it was used in relation to other things, and one said Aisotalamotu yadahaA, meaning I stroked, or kissed, her hand. (Har pp. 30 and 31.) ― -b2- Astlm AlxufRu qadamayohi means The boot rendered his feet soft [after he had been accustomed to walking barefoot]. (TA.)

10 Uisotasolama
10: see 4, in the former half of the paragraph. ＝ -A2- Astslm vakama AlTRariyqi He went upon the middle of the road, not missing it. (K, * TA. [In the CK, after wAsotasolama AnqAda, for wvakama AlTRariyqi, meaning wAstslm vakama AlTRariyqi, is erroneously put wtasalRama
AlTRariyqa, assigning to tslRm a meaning belonging to Astslm.])

Q. Q. 2 tamasolama c
Q. Q. 2. tamasolama [from musolimN] He named, or called, himself a Muslim; or he named himself Muslim; his name having before been Mohammad: (M, K:) mentioned by Er-Ru-ásee. (M.)

salomN c
salomN: see the next paragraph, in six places. ＝ -A2- Also A leathern bucket (dalowN) having one Eurowap [or loop-shaped handle], (T, S, M, K,) with which the waterer walks, like the buckets (dilaMC) of the attendants of the camels or other beasts upon which water is drawn or which carry water, (T, TA,) or like the dalow of the water-carriers: (S, K:) expl. in the S as above as on the authority of AA; but IB says that the correct explanation is, having one Earoquwap [or stick fixed across from one part of the brim to the to the opposite part, serving as a handle as well as to keep it from collapsing]: (TA:) of the masc. gender [whereas dalowN is fem.]: (M:) pl. [of pauc.] OasolumN and [of mult.] silaAmN, (M, K,) and Lh mentions as its pl. OasaAlimu, which is extr. [unless as a pl. pl., i. e. pl. of OasolumN]. (M.)

silomN c
silomN Peace, or reconciliation; as also salomN↓; (S, M, Msb, K;) masc. and fem.; (S, Msb, K; *) and salamN↓ and salaAmN↓ are like silomN [in signification]: (M: [the context there shows that the signification mentioned above is what is meant in this instance:]) or silomN signifies the making peace, or becoming at peace or reconciled, with another or others; (Ham p. 80;) as also salomN↓; and both are sometimes fem. as being syn. with muSaAlaHapN. (L voce janaHa, q. v.) In the saying of El-Aashà,
OacaAqatohumu AlHarobu OanofaAsahaA
waqado tukorahu AlHarobu baEoda AlsRilimo↓
[War made them, or has made them, to taste its draughts, and verily war is disliked after peace], he has transferred the vowel of the m to the l, in pausing; or it may be that he has inserted a kesreh in imitation of the preceding kesreh: it is not an instance like Uibil, in the opinion of Sb; for in his opinion the latter is the only instance of its kind. (M.) It is said in a trad., respecting El-Hodeybiyeh, Oaxaca vamaAniyna mino Oaholi makRapa silomFA, or salomFA↓, or salamFA↓, accord. to different relations, meaning [He took forty of the people of Mekkeh] peaceably: thus expl. by El-Homeydee, in his “ Ghareeb. ” (TA. [See also salamN below.]) ― -b2- Also i. q. salaAmN↓, (S, K, TA,) as signifying Selfresignation, or submission; (TA; [and thus the latter is expl. in one place in the S;]) which is also a signification of salamN↓: (S, M, K, TA:) and this is meant in the Kur [iv. 96], where it is said, lasota muWominFA walaA taquwluwA limano OaloqaI Uilayokumu QlsRalaAma↓, (Bd, TA,) or AlsRalama↓, as some read, (Bd,) [i. e. And say not ye to him who offers to you submission, Thou art not a believer:] or AlsRalaAma↓ here means the salutation of AlUisolaAm [by saying salaAmN Ealayokumo]: (Bd, TA: *) or salutation, and submission by uttering the profession of AlUisolaAm; and so AlsRalama↓: (Jel:) [or the latter here means, simply, salutation; and this is app. what is meant by its being said that] AlsRalamu is the subst. from AltRasoliymu; (K;) [but accord. to SM,] this means the unreserved approval of what is decreed; and this is said to be meant by the reading AlsRalama mentioned above. (TA.) ― -b3- And [hence] AlsRilomu signifies also AlUisolaAmu [as meaning The religion of the Muslims; because it is a religion of self-resignation, or submission]: (S, K:) this is meant in the Kur [ii. 204], where it is said, AudoxuluwA fiI AlsRilomi kaAfRapF [Enter ye into the religion of El-Islám wholly]; (S, Bd, Jel;) and so AlsRalomi↓, as some there read; (Bd, Jel;) or both there mean submission and obedience to God: (Bd:) [and] AlsRalamu↓ [also] has the former meaning. (M.) ＝ -A2- Also, (S, M, K,) and salomN↓, (M,) A man, (S, K, TA,) [and] a woman, (M,) who makes peace, or is at peace, with another; (S, M, K;) and in like manner, a company of men (qawomN). (M.) This is said to be meant in the Kur [xxxix. 30], where it is said, warajolFA silomFA lirajulK, as some read, i. e. And a man who is at peace with respect to a man: (TA:) or silomFA and salomFA↓ and salamFA↓, three different readings, in the place of [the more common reading] saAlimFA, are all inf. ns. of salima, used as epithets [syn. with saAlimFA], or caA is suppressed before them. (Bd.) You say, OanaA silomN limano saAlamaniI [I am one who is at peace with respect to him who is at peace with me]. (S, TA.) And a poet says, [using this word in two different senses, the latter of which has been mentioned above,]
liOaholiki faQqobaliI silomiI
OanaAYilu UinRaniI silomN
[O Náïleh, (naAYilu being for naAYilapN, a woman's name, apocopated,) verily I am one who is at peace with respect to thy family, therefore accept thou my submission]. (TA. [It seems to be there indicated by the context that slmI here means my peace, or reconciliation; which is less appropriate than the meaning that I have assigned to it.])

salamN c
salamN: see salaAmN: and see also silomN, in seven places. ― -b2- Also, in buying or selling, (Msb,) the subst. from Oasolama fiI AlXRaIoCi and salRama signifying Oasolafa, (M,) i. q. salafN; (S, Msb, K;) i. e. Any money, or property, paid in advance, or beforehand, as the price of a commodity for which the seller has become responsible and which one has bought on description: (T and TA in art. slf:) or payment for a commodity to be delivered at a certain [future] period with something additional to [the equivalent of] the current price at the time of such payment; this [transaction] being a cause of profit to him who makes such payment: (TA in that art.:) or a sort of sale in which the price is paid in advance, and the commodity is withheld, on the condition of description, to a certain [future] period: (S and O in that art., in explanation of salafN:) but it is said in a trad. that the term salamN as meaning salafN was disliked; app. because the former is applied to obedience, and self-resignation, or submission, to God. (TA.) ＝ -A2- And The making [one] captive. (K. [See 1, in the latter part of the paragraph.]) ＝ -A3- And A captive; (K;) because he submits himself. (TA.) One says, Oaxacahu salamFA, (M, TA, [in the TK biAlsRalami,]) He took him [a captive], (TA,) or made him captive, (M,) without war: (M, TA:) or he brought him in a state of submission, not resisting; and so, if wounded: (IAar, M, TA:) and thus El-Khattábee has expl. the phrase in the trad. respecting El-Hodeybiyeh cited above, voce silomN. (TA.) ＝ -A4- Also A sort of tree, (S, M, Msb, K,) [the mimosa flava of Forskål, who writes its Arabic name in Italic characters syllæm, and in Arabic characters slym, (Flora Aegypt. Arab., p. cxxiii.,)] a species (M) of the [kind of thorny trees called] EiDaAh, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, TA, [not gaDaAp, as in the Lexicons of Golius and Freytag,]) the leaves whereof are the qaraZ, with which skin is tanned: (TA:) AHn says, its branches are long, like rods; and it has no wood such as is used in carpentry, even if it grows large: it has slender, long thorns, grievous when they wound the foot of a man; and a yellow [fruit such as is termed] baramap [n. un. of baramN, see this word, and see also HubolapN,] which is the sweetest of the baram in odour; and they tan with its leaves: and it is said, on the authority of the Arabs of the desert, that it has a yellow flower, containing a green grain (HabRap xaDoraMC [or this may mean a grain of a dark, or an ashy, dustcolour]), of sweet odour, in which is somewhat of bitterness, and of which the gazelles are very fond: (M:) the n. un. is with p: (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K:) and pl. OasolaAmN, (M,) and silaAmN is said by IB to be pl. of the n. un., like as UikaAmN is of OakamapN. (TA.) [Hence,] caAtu OasolaAmK A land (OaroD) that gives growth to the [trees called] salam. (K.) See also slamaAn.

salimN c
salimN Stones; (S, M;) as also silaAmN↓: (M:) and salimapN↓ [as n. un. of the former and sing. of the latter, (incorrectly written by Freytag, in one place, salamapN, and incorrectly said by him to be of the dial. of the people of Himyer,)] signifies a stone: (S, M, Mgh, Msb:) [or] the pl. [or quasipl. n.] of salimapN in this sense is salaAmN↓, like kalaAmN in measure: (Msb:) or salimapN↓ signifies stones; (K;) or hard stones; (TA;) and silaAmN↓ is its pl.: (K:) [said to be] so called because of their freedom (slaAmap) from softness: (TA:) or this last signifies stones, the small thereof and the large; and they assign to it no sing.: (ISh, TA:) or slAm [probably meaning salaAmN↓] is a quasi-pl. n.: (Aboo-Kheyreh, TA:) and it is also said to be a name for any broad stone. (TA.) See also salamaAn. A poet says, (namely, Bujeyr Ibn- 'Anameh, IB, TA,)
yaromiI waraAYiI biQmosahoki waQmosahomi waQmosalimaho
[He casts from behind me (i. e. defends me) with the arrow and the stone]: this [usage of Am for Al] is of the dial. of [Teiyi and] Himyer. (S, TA.)

AlsRilimo c
AlsRilimo for AlsRilomo: see silomN, second sentence.

salimapN c
salimapN: see salimN, in two places: and salamaAn. ＝ -A2- Also A woman soft, or tender, in the OaToraAf [or fingers, or other extremities]. (K.) ― -b2- And An old and weak she-camel. (IAar, TA in art. sd.)

salomaI c
salomaI A certain plant (K, TA) which becomes green in the [season called] Sayof [app. here meaning spring]. (TA.) ― -b2- Oabuw salomaI The [species of lizard called] wazag: (K:) or, some say, [as is said in the M,] Oabuw salomaAna↓. (TA.) ― -b3- See also the next paragraph. ― -b4- [In the CK, by a mistranscription, a meaning belonging to sulaAmaI is assigned to salomaI.]

AlsRalomaMC c
AlsRalomaMC, accord. to Aboo-Mis-hal, as meaning The earth, occurs in the prov., OanofN qiI AlmaMCi waQsotN fiI AlsRalomaMCi [A nose in the water and a rump on the earth]: and if this be correct, it may be derived from slAm [i. e. silaAmN] meaning “ stones: ” and it may be originally AlsRalomaI↓, and lengthened for the sake of the rhyme. (Ham p. 214.) [But the reading commonly known is, OanofN fiI AlsRalomaMCi waQsotN fiI AlmaMCi.]

huwa salomaAnu bayotihi c
huwa salomaAnu bayotihi He is the special, or particular, friend of his [another's] house; one who mixes with him much: from the saying of the Prophet, salomaAnu minRaA Oaholi Albayoti [Selmán is of us, the people of the house]; referring to Selmán El-Fárisee. (Har p. 472.) ― -b2- Oabuw salomaAna: see salomaI. ― -b3- Also A species of the [black beetles called] jiEolaAn [pl. of juEalN, q. v.]: (M:) or i. q. juEalN, (IAar, K,) or Oabuw jaEoraAn, with fet-h [app. a mistake for kesr] to the j: (Kr, TA:) or the largest of the jiEolaAn: or a certain insect like the juEal, having a pair of wings: (TA:) or the male of the [black beetles called] xanaAfis [pl. of xunofasaMCu, q. v.]. (IAar, TA in art. frD.)

salamaAn c
salamaAn or salimaAn, accord. to different readings, occurs in a trad. of Ibn-'Omar, in which it is said, kaAna yuSalRiI Einoda salamaAnK fiI Tariyqi makRapa [He used to pray at certain selem-trees, or certain stones, in the road of Mekkeh]: each may be a pl. [or rather a quasi-pl. n.]; the former, of salamapN↓, the “ tree so called; ” the latter, of salimapN↓, “ stones ” [or a “ stone: ” but both of these explanations are strange]. (TA.)

salaAmN c
salaAmN, (S, K, TA,) in its primary acceptation, (TA,) is syn. with salaAmapN↓, (S, K, TA,) as is also salamN↓, (S, [so in one of my copies, but omitted in the other copy,]) and signifies Safety, security, immunity, or freedom, from faults, defects, imperfections, blemishes, or vices, (S, * [mentioned in one only of my two copies, and there as relating peculiarly to the third word,] K, [in which it ostensibly relates peculiarly to the first word, but in the CK, by the omission of a w before it, it is made to relate only to the second word,] and TA, [accord. to which it relates to the first and second words, as it is well known to do,]) and from evils of any kind: (TA:) or [simply] safety, security, immunity, or freedom; as also salaAmapN↓: (Sb, M:) IKt says that these two words may be dial. vars. [syn. each with the other]; or the former may be pl. of the latter [or rather a coll. gen. n. of which the latter is the n. un.]: (M, TA:) and Suh says, in the R, that most of the lexicologists hold them to have one [and the same] meaning: but that if they considered the language of the Arabs, and the distinction, or limitation, denoted by the p, they would see that between them is a great difference [inasmuch as the former has a large range of meaning which the latter has not, as will be seen from what follows]. (TA.) salaAmN Ealayokumo is an announcement of the continuance of salaAmap [or safety, &c.]: (Bd in xiii. 24:) [it may therefore be rendered Safety, &c., be, or light and abide, on you; or, generally, peace be, or light and abide, on you; for] it means nothing disliked, or evil, shall befall you henceforth: (Bd in xvi. 34:) and salaAmN Ealayoka [may be rendered in like manner; for it virtually] means I will not do to thee anything that is disliked, or evil; (Bd and Jel in xix. 48;) nor say to thee henceforward what would annoy thee, or be disagreeable, or evil, to thee. (Bd ibid.) It may also be [rendered May safety, &c., or peace, be, or light and abide, on you; as] a prayer for salaAmap, to those to whom it is addressed, from the state in which they are at the time. (Bd in xxviii. 55.) [It is generally held that this salutation may not be used by, nor to, any but a Muslim.] In the beginning of an epistle, the approved practice is to write salaAmN Ealayoka, without the article Al; and in repeating it, at the end, to write it with that article. (Durrat el-Ghowwás, in De Sacy's Anthol. Gramm. Arabe, p. 72 of the Arabic text. [In the latter case, the general practice in the present day is to write simply waAlsRalaAm, suppressing Ealayoka.]) In saluting the dead, one puts Ealayoka first, saying, Ealayoka salaAmu QllRehi. (Ham p. 367.) You also say, maA kaAna kacaA wakacaA laA bisalaAmatika↓ [No, by thy safety, such and such things were not]. (S.) AlsRulaAmu is also a name of God, (S, M, Msb, K,) [applied to Him in the Kur lix. 23, accord. to some for cuw AlsRalaAmi, i. e. cuw AlsRalaAmapi,] because of his safety, or freedom, from defect, and imperfection, and cessation of existence; (IKt, M, TA;) or from variations, and as being the everlasting, who brings the creation to nought and will not come to nought; or, accord. to Suh in the R, He is so named [as being the Author of Safety, Security, &c.; i. e.] because He has rendered all his creatures safe, or free, from defectiveness, or unsoundness, and mankind and the jinn, or genii, from the betiding of injustice, or wrong, to them, from Him; and the expositors who assert that He is thus named because of his safety, or freedom, from imperfections, and evils of any kind, utter an unseemly saying, making salaAmN to be syn. with saAlimN↓, which latter applies only to him who is liable to evil of any kind, and who expects it, and then becomes safe, or free, from it. (TA.) daAru AlsRalaAmi is an appellation of Paradise, (M, K,) [applied thereto in the Kur vi. 127 and x. 26,] as being the abode of everlasting safety, or security; (Zj, M, TA;) the abode of safety, or security, from evils of any kind, from death and decrepitude and diseases [&c.]: (TA:) or as being the abode of God. (M, TA.) ― -b2- See also silomN, in four places. ― -b3- [As is there stated,] it signifies also Salutation, or greeting; (M, TA;) particularly the salutation of AlUisolaAm [by saying salaAmN Ealayoka or salaAmN Ealayokumo, expl. above]; (Bd in iv. 96;) a subst. (S, Mgh, Msb, TA) from salRama Ealayohi, (Msb,) [i. e.] from AltRusoliymu, (S, Mgh, TA,) like kalaAmN from AltRakoliymu. (Mgh. [See 2, third sentence.]) ― -b4- In the saying in the Kur [xxv. 64], waUicaA xaATabahumu QlojaAhiluwna qaAluwA salaAmFA [And when the ignorant speak to them, they say, salaAmFA], this last word signifies tasalRumFA, (Sb, M,) or tasalRumFA minokumo [for natasalRamu minokumo tasalRumFA We declare ourselves to be clear, or quit, of you], and mutaArakahF lalumo [for nutaArikukumo mutaArakapF we relinquish you], (Bd,) [and means] there shall be neither good nor evil between us (Sb, M, Bd) and you: it is not the slAm that is used in salutation; for the verse was revealed at Mekkeh, and the Muslims had not then been commanded to salute the believers in a plurality of gods: (Sb, M:) [in iv. 88 of the Kur, which was promulgated afterwards, at ElMedeeneh, is a general command to return a salutation with a better or with the same; but the Sunneh prescribes that the salutation of salaAmN Ealayoka or salaAmN Ealayokumo when addressed to a Muslim by one not a Muslim is to be returned only by saying waEalayoka or waEalayokumo:] or the meaning in xxv. 64 is, they say a right saying, in which they are secure from harming and sinning. (Bd.) Sb asserts that Aboo-Rabee'ah used to say, UicaA laqiyta fulaAnFA faqulo salaAmFA, meaning tasalRumFA [for OatasalRamu minoka tasalRumFA, i. e. When thou meetest such a one, say, I declare myself to be clear, or quit, of thee]: and he says that some of them said salaAmN, meaning The case of me and thee is the [case of] being clear, or quit, each of the other; and the [case of] mutual relinquishing. (M.) [It is usual, in the present day, to say, AifoEalo kacaA waAlsRalaAm, meaning Do thou such a thing, and there will be an end of altercation between us.] ＝ -A2- See also saliymN. ＝ -A3- Also A kind of trees; (S, M, Msb, K;) they assert that they are evergreen; nothing eats them; but the gazelles keep to them, and protect themselves by their shade, but do not hide among them; and they are not great trees, nor of the kind called EiDaAh: (AHn, M:) they are also called silaAmN↓; (K;) or this is pl. of salamapN [n. un. of salamN], which is of another kind; like as UikaAmN is pl. of OakamapN: (IB, TA:) n. un. with p. (S, M.) AlsRalaAmu Ealayoka was said to an Arab of the desert; and he replied, AljavojaAvu Ealayoka: and being asked, “ What is this reply? ” he answered, “ They are two bitter trees: thou hast put upon me one, so I have put upon thee the other. ” (K.) ＝ -A4- See also salimN, in two places.

silaAmN c
silaAmN: see salimN, in two places: ＝ -A2- and the paragraph here next preceding, last sentence but two.

saliymN c
saliymN i. q. saAlimN↓, (S, M, K,) which means Safe, secure, or free, (Msb,) from evils of any kind; (K, Msb, TA;) applied to a man: (M:) pl. sulamaMCu; (M, K, TA;) in some copies of the K salomaI, like jaroHaI pl. of jariyHN; (TA;) [but this is probably its pl. only when it is used in the sense of jariyHN or the like, as seems to be the case from what follows.] Also, (M,) applied to a
heart: (S, M:) biqalobK saliymK, in the Kur xxvi. 89, means With a heart free from unbelief: (M, TA:) or, divested of corruptness, or unsoundness: (Er-Rághib, TA:) in the Kur xxxvii. 82, some say that it means with a grieving, or sorrowful, heart; from saliymN in the sense here next following. (Bd.) ― -b2- Also i. q. ladiygN [meaning Bitten by a serpent]; (S, M, K;) as also salaAmN↓ (S, K) and masoluwmN↓: (K:) app., (S,) as implying a good omen, of safety; (S, M;) or because the person is left (musolamN) to that [bane] which is in him: (IAar, S, * M:) and sometimes it is metaphorically used as meaning (tropical:) wounded: (M:) or it means wounded, at the point of death, (M, K,) as some say: (M:) pl. salomaI. (M, and Ham p. 214.) ＝ -A2- Also, (M, K,) of a horse, (M,) The part, of the hoof, that is between the OaXoEar [or hair, or extremity of the skin, next the hoof], (M, TA,) or that is between the OamoEar [q. v.], (K,) but the former is the right, (TA,) and the interior of the hoof. (M, K, TA.)

salaAmapN c
salaAmapN [the most usual inf. n. of salima]: see salaAmN, in three places. ＝ -A2- Also n. un. of salaAmN applied to a kind of trees [described above]. (S, K.)

sulaAmaI c
sulaAmaI, a noun of the fem. gender, (Msb,) A certain bone that is in the firosin [q. v., here meaning foot] of the camel: (S, K:) this is said by A'Obeyd to be the primary signification: (S:) or the sulaAmaI of the camel are the bones of the furosin [or foot]: (M:) [for] sulaAmaI is used alike as sing. and pl., and sometimes it has also a pl., (S,) which is sulaAmayaAtN: (S, M, K:) or it is a pl. [or rather a coll. gen. n.], of which the sing. [or n. un.] is sulaAmayapN, signifying the Oanomalap [q. v.] of [any of] the fingers: (IAth, TA:) [but this is a strange explanation:] it is said that the last parts in which muxR [here meaning marrow or pulp and the like] remains in a camel when he has become emaciated are the sulaAmaI and eye; and when it has gone from these, he has none remaining: (S:) the pl. sulaAmayaAtN, (S, TA,) or sulaAmaI, (M, Msb,) also signifies the bones of the OaSaAbiE, (S, M,) so says Kh, and Zj adds that they are also called the qaSab, (Msb,) of the hand and of the foot; (M;) [i. e., of the fingers and of the toes; and this seems to be the most common meaning, in relation to a human being; namely, the phalanges of the fingers and of the toes;] that are between every two joints [and what are beyond the extreme joints] of the OaSaAbiE: accord. to Lth, the slAmI are the bones of the OaSaAbiE [or fingers and toes] and the OaXaAjiE and the OakaAriE, and are hard and compact bones like kiEaAb [pl. of kaEobN]: (TA: [see the words that I have here left untranslated, for the senses in which they are here used are doubtful:]) accord. to IAar, (M,) certain small bones, of the length of the UiSobaE [or finger], (M, K,) or nearly so, (M,) or less, (K,) of which there are four, or three, (M,) [or app., five, for the meaning here seems to be the metacarpal and metatarsal bones, to which the terms sulaAmaI and sulaAmayaAtN are sometimes applied, (see OaXojaEu and muXoZN,)] in the hand and in the foot, (K,) [i. e.] in each hand and foot: (M:) Ktr says that the slAmyAt are the Euruwq [app. a mistake for EiZaAm i. e. bones] of the outer side of the hand and foot: (Msb:) slAmI is also said to signify any small hollow bone: and any bone of a human being: and ISh says that in every horse are six slAmyAt [app. in the fore legs and the same in the hind legs; for he seems to mean that the term slAmI is applied to each of the pasternbones and to the coffin-bone; these three corresponding to the phalanges of a human being: see faSRN]: (TA:) it is not allowable to write slAmI otherwise than with what is termed the short alif. (MF, TA.) ＝ -A2- sulaAmaI, (M, K,) like sukRaAraI, (K, TA, [in the CK like sakoreI, which is shown to be wrong by a verse cited in the M and TA,]) signifies also The [south, or southerly, wind called] januwb. (M, K.)

salaAmaAnN c
salaAmaAnN A kind of tree, (S, M, K,) growing in soft, or plain, tracts: (M:) AZ says, it is like the OalaMC, which is a tree resembling the myrtle, which changes not in the midst of summer, and which has a produce resembling the head [or ear] of millet (curap), except that it is smaller than the AlMC; tooth-sticks (masaAwiyk) are made from it; and its produce is like that of the AlMC; and it grows in the sands and the deserts: (TA in art. AlO:) n. un. with p. (M.)

namolu sulayomaAnu c
