namolu sulayomaAnu Red ants [lit. the ants of Solomon]. (TA voce OaHowaI, in art. Hw.)

sulRamN c
sulRamN A ladder, or a series of stairs or steps, syn. miroqaApN, (M, K,) and darajapN, (M,) or miEoraAjN, (Msb,) upon which one ascends; (S, Mgh;) either of wood or of clay [&c.]: (Mgh:) said by Zj to be so called because it delivers thee (yusalRimuka) to the place to which thou desirest to go, (Mgh, TA,) i. e., to some high place, and thou hopest for safety (AlsRalaAmap) by means of it: (Er-Rághib, TA:) masc. and fem.; (Lth, M, Mgh;) [app., accord. to Lth and F, generally fem.; for] accord. to Lth, one says, hiIa AlsRulRamu and huwa AlsRulRamu; (Mgh;) [and F says,] it is sometimes made masc.: (K:) pl. salaAliymu (S, Mgh, K) and salaAlimu, (K,) [which latter is the original, for] the I in salaAliymu is added by poetic license. (M, TA.) [Hence,] AlsRulRamu (assumed tropical:) Certain stars, below [those called] AlEaAnapu, on the right of them; (K;) as being likened to the sulRam [above-mentioned]. (TA.) ― -b2- And The garoz [or stirrup of the camel's saddle] (S, K) is sometimes thus called [as being a means of mounting]. (S.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) A means to a thing; (K, TA;) because it leads to another thing like as does the sulRam upon which one ascends. (TA.) ― -b4- And AlsRulRamu is the name of The horse of Zebbán (in the CK Zeiyán) Ibn-Seiyár. (K.)

saAlimN c
saAlimN: see saliymN; and see salaAmN, near the middle of the paragraph. [See also an ex. voce XaAjibN.] ― -b2- [Hence,] kalimapN saAlimapu AlEayonayoni (tropical:) A good word or expression or sentence. (TA.) ＝ -A2- The saying of J [in the S], (K,) in which he has followed his maternal uncle El-Fárábee, (TA,) that it signifies The portion of skin between the eye and the nose, is a mistake; (IB, K;) and his citation, as an authority, of the verse of 'AbdAllah Ibn-'Omar (K) in which he says,
wajilodapu bayona AlEayoni waAlOanofi saAlimu
(TA,) is futile: (K:) for, as IB says, Sálim was the son of Ibn-'Omar, who, by reason of his love of him, thus makes him to be as the skin between his eyes and his nose: or, as MF says, the truth is, that the said verse is by Zuheyr, and Ibn-'Omar used it as a proverb: and [SM says], if this be correct, it strengthens the saying of J. (TA.)

Oasolamu c
Oasolamu [More, and most, safe or secure or free from evils of any kind]. You say, hecaA Oasolamu mino hecaA [This is more safe &c. than this]: and hecaA AlOasolamu [This is the most safe &c.]; and hecihi AlsRulomaI. (Ham p. 214.) ＝ -A2- And AlAslm [app. AlOasolamu] signifies, like AlTfI [i. e. AlTRafoIu]; The leaves (xuwS) of the dawom [or Theban palm]. (Ibn-Beytár, app. from AHn, cited by De Sacy in his Chrest. Arabe, 2nd ed., iii. 480.)

AlUisolaAmu c
AlUisolaAmu [inf. n. of 4, q. v. ― -b2- It is the general term for The religion of Mohammad: differing from AlUiymaAnu, as shown above: see 4. ― -b3- And hence, for Oaholu AlUisolaAmi, or the like,] The Muslims, collectively. (M in art. byD, &c.)

UisolaAmiIRN c
UisolaAmiIRN [Of, or relating to, AlOisolaAm as meaning the religion of Mohammad. ― -b2- And particularly] A poet of the class next after the muxaDoramuwn and next before the muwalRaduwn. (Mz 49th nwE.) [See the Preface to the present work, p. ix.] The most celebrated of the poets of this class, it seems, were Jereer, El-Farezdak, El-Akhtal, and Dhu-rRummeh, who were contemporaries, and flourished in the first and second centuries of the Flight. (Mz ubi suprà, and Ibn-Khillikán in art. jariyr.) ― -b3- lafoZN UisolaAmiIRN A word, or phrase, introduced, or used in a new sense, on the occasion of the promulgation and establishment of the religion of AlUisolaAm, by means of the Kur-án &c. (Mz 20th nwE.)

AlOusayolimu c
AlOusayolimu [The vena salvatella;] a certain vein (S, M, K) in the hand, (M,) between the little finger and the finger next to this: (S, K:) it occurs only [thus] in the dim. form. (M.)

musolimN c
musolimN act. part. n. of 4 [q. v.]. (Msb.) waQjoEalonaA musolimiyna laka, in the Kur ii. 122, means And make both of us self-resigned, or submissive, to Thee: (Bd, Jel:) or, sincere in religion, or without hypocrisy, towards Thee; syn. muxoliSayoni: (M, Bd:) and therefore mslmyn is made trans. by means of l. (M.) ― -b2- [It commonly means One who holds, or professes, the religion of AlUisolaAm.] And one says, kaOana kaAfirFA vumRa huwaAlyawoma musolamapN↓ [He was an unbeliever: then, to day, he has become a Muslim]. (M.)

masolamapN c
masolamapN: see what next precedes.
AlmusalRam is said to be used in the sense of Almusotalam↓ in the saying of El-'Ajjáj,
bayona AlSRafaA waAlkaEobapi AlmusalRammi
[Between Es-Safà and the Kaabeh of which the Black Stone is touched with the hand, or kissed: see 8]. (M.)

masoluwmN c
masoluwmN: see saliymN. ― -b2- ― -b3- Also A hide, or skin, tanned with [qaraZ, or leaves of] the salam. (S, M.)

OaroDN masoluwmaMCu c
OaroDN masoluwmaMCu A land abounding with the trees called salam. (M, K.) ― -b2- Suh says, on the authority of AHn, that masoluwmaMCu is a name for A collection of salam; like maXoyuwxaMCu applied to “ many elders, or men advanced in age. ” (TA.)

Almusotalam c
Almusotalam: see AlmusalRam. ― -b2- musotalamu Alqadamayoni means A man soft, or tender, in the feet. (TA.)

Q. 4 AisolahabRa c
Q. 4. AisolahabRa, said of a horse running, He stretched himself forth; or extended, or elongated, himself: (S: [the meaning is there indicated, and it is expressed by an interlinear explanation in one of my copies of that work:]) or he pressed onward with a penetrative energy or force, or with sharpness of spirit. (TA.) Some hold that the h in the words of this art. is augmentative: others, [app. the greater number,] that it is radical. (MF.)

salohabN c
salohabN, sometimes pronounced with S, (S, TA,) Long, or tall; (K, TA;) as an epithet of general application: (TA:) or a tall man: pl. salaAhibapN. (K.) ― -b2- Applied to a horse, Long-bodied: (S:) or, so applied, large, (K, TA,) and long, or tall, (TA,) and long in the bones; as also salohabapN↓, (K, TA,) which is applied to the male: (TA:) and the former, likewise applied to a horse, that presses onward with a penetrative energy or force, or with sharpness of spirit: (TA:) or, so applied, large and long or tall: and likewise applied to a spear: and tropically, [but in what sense is not explained,] to a wind (riyHN). (A.) ― -b3- The fem. salohabapN↓ signifies Corpulent, or large in body; (K, TA;) not an epithet of commendation: (TA:) or, applied to a woman, it signifies tall or beautiful. (JK.) ― -b4- And salohabN is the name of A certain dog. (K, * TA.)

salohabapN c
salohabapN: see salohabN, in two places.

silohaAbN c
silohaAbN: see what follows.

silohaAbapN c
silohaAbapN and silohaAbN↓, each as a fem. epithet, (K, TA,) and each with kesr [to the s], (TA,) [but each in the CK is with fet-h,] Bold, daring, brave, or courageous. (K.)

1 salaA Eanohu c
1. salaA Eanohu, (S, M, Msb, K,) first pers. salawotu, (S, Msb,) aor. yasoluw, (Msb, K,) and yasolaA also, [or yasolaI,] though neither the second nor the third radical is a faucial letter; (Ham p. 568;) and salaAhu, (M, K,) aor. yasoluwhu; (K;) and saliIa Eanohu, first pers. salytu, (S, Msb,) aor. yasolaI; (Msb;) or saliyahu, (M, K,) aor. yasolaAhu; (K;) and salaAhu, first pers. salayotuhu, aor. yasoliyhi; (TA in art. slI, on the authority of Esh-Shereeshee;) inf. n. suluwRN, (S, M, Msb, K,) of the first, (S, Msb, TA,) and salowN, (M, K,) [app. of the second,] and sulowaAnN, (M, MA, K,) of the first, as also salowapN, (MA,) or this last is a simple subst., (M, * Msb, K,) and suliIRN, (S, M, MA, K,) of the third, (S,) or of the first, (MA,) and siliIRN [with kesr substituted for damm because of the kesr of the medial radical]; (M, TA;) He was, or became, forgetful, unmindful, or neglectful, (M, K, TA,) or diverted from the remembrance, (TA,) of him, or it: (M, K, TA:) he endured with patience the loss, or want, of him, or it: (Msb:) he was, or became, content, or happy, without him, or it: (PS:) [or he experienced comfort, or consolation, for the loss, or want, of him, or it:] accord to AZ, AlsRuluwRu [or rather suluwRu AlUilofi Eani AlOilafi] signifies the familiar's being content, or happy, without the familiar: (Msb:) or AlsRuluwRu [or AlsRuluwRu Eano XaIoCK] signifies the being content, or happy, without a thing. (Ham p. 403.) One says also, salaA Eani AlHubRi, meaning He was or became, free from love, or affection. (MA.) [And salaA Eani AlhamRi He was, or became, free from anxiety. See also 5.] ― -b2- Also maA saliytu Oano Oaquwla caAka, meaning I did not forget, but neglected, to say that: and one does not say saliytu Oano Oaquwlahu except as meaning maA saliytu Oano Oaquwlahu. (AZ, TA.)

2 salRAhu Eanohu c
2. salRAhu Eanohu, (M, TA, *) inf. n. tasoliyapN; (TA;) and Eanohu AslAhu↓; (M, K;) He, or it, made him, or rendered him, forgetful, unmindful, or neglectful, (M, K, TA,) or made him to be diverted from the remembrance, (TA,) of him, or it: (M, K, TA:) [made him to endure with patience the loss, or want, of him, or it: made him to be content, or happy, without him, or it: or comforted him, or consoled him, for the loss, or want, of him or it: see 1, first sentence:] and the former verb occurs, in a verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb, followed by an accus. as a second objective complement, in the place of a gen. preceded by Eano. (M, TA.) And one says also, salRaAniI mino hamRiI, inf.n. as above; and OasolaAniI↓; meaning [He freed me from my anxiety; or] he removed from me my anxiety. (S.) And slRAhu [alone] He, or it, [made him to be content, or happy; comforted, or consoled, him; or] freed him from grief [or anxiety]. (MA.)

4 Oasolawa
4: see 2, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also AslI Alqawomu The people, or party, were, or became, secure, or safe, from the beast of prey. (K.)

5 tslRI Eanohu c
5. tslRI Eanohu quasi-pass. of salRaAhu Eanohu (M) or of OasolaAhu Eanohu (M, K) [and therefore signifying He was made, or rendered, forgetful, unmindful, or neglectful, or was made to be diverted from the remembrance, of him, or it: was made to endure with patience the loss, or want, of him, or it: was made to be content, or happy, without him, or it: or was comforted, or consoled, for the loss, or want, of him, or it]: or tslRI signifies takalRafa AlsRulowaAna [he affected the being forgetful, &c., of a person, or thing]: (Ham p. 403:) [he made himself content, or happy: comforted, or consoled, himself: diverted, or amused, himself: and, like salaA, (with which it is said in the Ham p. 572 to be syn.,) or nearly so,] he became free from, or he relinquished, anxiety. (MA.) See also what next follows.

7 AnslI Eanohu AlhamRu c
7. AnslI Eanohu AlhamRu Anxiety became removed, or cleared away, from him; as also tslRI↓. (S.)

8 Uisotalawa
8: see art. slI.

salFA c
salFA or salFI: see art. slI.

salowapN c
salowapN, (M, Msb, K,) as also sulowapN↓, (M, K,) a subst. from salaA Eanohu (M, Msb, K) [as such signifying A state of forgetfulness, unmindfulness, or neglectfulness, or of diversion from remembrance, of a person or thing: patient endurance of a loss or want: content, or happiness, in a case of privation: or comfort, or consolation, for a loss or want: accord. to the MA, the former is an inf. n.]. One says, saqayotaniI minoka salowapF and sulowaAnFA↓ Thou hast made me content, or happy, [or hast infused into me content, or happiness,] without thee [or in thine absence]. (As, S.) And huwa fiI salowapK mina AlEayoXi He is in a state of life ample in its means or circumstances, unstraitened, or plentiful, and pleasant. (AZ, S.)

sulowapN c
sulowapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

salowaI c
salowaI [accord. to those who make the alif to be a sign of the fem. gender] or salowFI [accord. to those who make that letter to be one of quasicoordination] A certain bird, (S, M, Msb, K,) [in the present day applied to the quail,] i. q. sumaAnaI [which is also applied in the present day to the quail], (Ksh and Bd and Jel in ii. 54,) [or] white [?], resembling the sumaAnaI, (M,) or like the pigeon, but longer in the shank and neck than the latter, and of a colour resembling that of the sumaAnaI, quick in motion: accord. to Akh, the word is used as sing. and pl.: (Msb:) [or] Akh says, I have not heard any sing. thereof, and it seems that the single one is thus called like the pl. number, in like manner as dfolaI is [said to be] applied to one and to the pl. number: (S:) or the n. un. is salowaApN; (M, K;) of which Lth cites as an ex. this saying, [in which balRalahu should be balRalahaA,]
kamaA QnotafaDa AlsRalowaApu balRalahu AlqaToru
[Like as shakes the selwáh which the rain has much wetted]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also Honey; (S, M, K;) and so sulowaAnapN↓, with damm: (K:) the former is used in this sense by a poet, (S, M,) namely, Khálid Ibn-Zuheyr; and Zj says that Khálid has made a mistake, the word slwI signifying only a certain bird; but, accord. to AAF, (M,) ― -b2- AlsRalowaI signifies [also] Whatever renders thee forgetful, or content, or happy, in a case of privation; (kulRu maA salRaAka, M, K;) and honey is thus called because it renders thee thus by its sweetness. (M.)

sulowaAnN c
sulowaAnN A water which is drunk and which
renders one forgetful, or content, or happy, in a case of privation; or comforts, or consoles, for a loss or want: (Lh, M, K:) or a thing that is given to drink to the passionate lover in order that he may be forgetful, or content, or happy, without the woman: (Lh, M:) or it consists in one's taking some of the dust, or earth, of a grave, and sprinkling it upon water, and giving it to drink to the passionate lover, (M, K, *) whereupon his love dies: (K:) or rain-water poured upon a certain bead (xarazapN) called sulowaAnapN↓, of which they used to say that when the passionate lover drank this water he became forgetful, or content, or happy, in his privation: (S:) or a certain medicine which is given to drink to him who is in grief and in consequence of which he becomes happy; (S, K;) called by the physicians mufarRiHN: (S:) or a certain bead (xarazapN) for captivating, or fascinating, also called sulowaAnapN↓, (Lh, M, K,) and salowaAnapN↓, (Sgh, K,) with which women captivate, or fascinate, men, restraining them from other women: (Lh, M:) or sulowaAnapN↓ signifies [or, accord. to the K, signifies also] a certain bead (xarazapN, M, K,) transparent, (M,) which, when one has buried it in the sand and then scraped the sand up from over it, is seen to be black, and is given [in water] to drink to a man, and renders him forgetful, or content, or happy, in a case of privation: (M, K: *) or a pebble upon which water is poured and given to drink to a man, who thereupon becomes forgetful, or content, or happy, in a case of privation: (M:) Ru-beh says,
lawo OaXorabu AlsRulowaAna maA saliytu
maAbiI ginFI Eanoki waUino ganiytu
(S, M, *) and Nuseyr Ibn-Abee-Nuseyr, in answer to a question of As respecting the meaning of AlslwAn, said that it is a bead (xarazapN) which is bruised, or pulverized, [and upon which water is then poured,] the water of which occasions in the drinker thereof forgetfulness, or content, or happiness, in a case of privation: but As disallowed this, and said that it is an inf. n. of salawotu, and that the meaning is lawo OaXorabu AlsRuluwRa [i. e. (assumed tropical:) Were I made to drink forgetfulness, &c., I should not become forgetful, &c.: there is not in me freedom from want of thee, though I be free from want of others]. (TA.) See also salowapN.

salowaAnapN c
salowaAnapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

sulowaAnapN c
sulowaAnapN: see salowaI: ― -b2- and see also sulowaAnN, in three places.

sulRaI c
sulRaI, [said to be] like rubRaI, [but it may be sulRFI, as there is no apparent cause for its being imperfectly decl.,] A quality that renders forgetful of the objects of love or affection, or that renders content, or happy, without them. (TA in art. slI.)

saAlK c
saAlK [act. part. n. of 1: as such often signifying] Having his heart free from love, or affection. (Har p. 41.)

musolaApN c
musolaApN [a noun of the class of muboxalapN and majobanapN &c., originally masolawapN]. One says, fiyhi masolaApN Eani Alkurabi [In him is a cause of forgetfulness of, or freedom from, anxieties]: like muEolaApN [in form]. (TA.)

AlmusalRiI c
AlmusalRiI The third [in arriving at the goal] of the ten horses that are started together for a race: so called because he renders his owner content, or happy (yusalRiyhi). (Ham p. 46.)

mutasalRFI c
mutasalRFI [a noun of place from 5]. One says, maAEanohu mutasalRFI [There is not any place in which one may be rendered forgetful, &c., of him, or it; or in which one may be rendered content, or happy, without him, or it]. (TA.)

1 saliyatN c
1. saliyatN, (M, K,) aor.
salaIa
, (K,) inf. n. salFI, said of a ewe, or she-goat, [and of a she-camel,] Her secundine (salaAhaA) became disrupted [in her belly]. (M, K.) ＝ -A2- salaAhaA, inf. n. saloIN; (M;) or slRAhA↓, inf. n. tasoliyapN; (S, K;) He pulled out or off, or removed from its place, her secundine (salaAhaA), namely, a ewe's, or she-goat's, (S, M, K,) or a she-camel's. (So in one of my copies of the S.) And salayotu AlnRaAqapa I drew [forth] the she-camel's secundine (salaAhaA) after the bringing forth without letting it fall (baEoda AlrRaHami or AlrRaHomi). (Lh, M.) ＝ -A3- salayotuhu a dial. var. of salawotuhu, mentioned by Esh-Shereeshee. (TA.) See 1 in art. slw, first sentence.

2 salRaIa
2: see the preceding paragraph.

8 Aisotalato c
8. Aisotalato She (a camel, TA, [or a ewe or goat,]) cast forth her secundine (salaAhaA). (K, TA.) ― -b2- She (a ewe, or goat,) became fat. (K in art. slw, and TA in the present art.) ＝ -A2- Astlt smnFA [i. e. samonFA] She collected smn [or clarified butter]. (TA. [See also 8 in art. slO.])

salFI c
salFI or salFA [thus differently written, the former the more correct, unless the word be derived from AlsRalowapu, as it is said to be in the Ham p. 656, but this is improbable,] The secundine; i. e. the skin, [or membrane,] (M, K,) or thin skin, (S,) in which is the fœtus, or young, [in the womb,] (S, M, Msb, K,) of human beings, and of horses and camels, (M,) or of human beings and of cattle, (K,) or [peculiarly] of cattle, (T, S,) that of human beings being termed maXiymapN: (TA:) it is pulled off from the face of the young camel at the time of the birth, or else it kills it, like as it does when it becomes disrupted in the belly: when it comes forth, the she-camel is safe, and so is the young one; but if it becomes disrupted in the belly, she perishes, and so does the young one: (S:) pl. OasolaMCN. (M, Msb, K.) [Hence,] one says, AinoqaTaEa AlsRalaI fiI AlbaToni (assumed tropical:) [The secundine became disrupted in the belly]; (S, Meyd, K;) i. e. artifice departed [or came to an end]; (S;) a prov. applied in the case of an affair's becoming beyond one's power of accomplishment, and coming to an end; (Meyd;) like the saying, balaga AlsRikRiynu AlEaZoma [The knife reached to the bone]. (S, K.) And huwa Mkilu AlOasolaMCi (assumed tropical:) [He is the eater of secundines]; meaning he is low, base, vile, or sordid. (TA.) And waqaEa Alqawomu fiI salaI jamalK (assumed tropical:) [The people, or party, fell into the like of the secundine of a hecamel]; meaning they fell into a difficult affair or case; (S, K *) or they fell into an unparalleled evil; (Meyd;) for the he-camel has no slI. (S, Meyd.)

saloyaMCu c
saloyaMCu A ewe, or she-goat, (S, K,) and a she-camel, (S,) whose secundine (salaAhaA) has become disrupted [in her belly]. (S, K.) ― -b2- And A ewe, or she-goat, [or she-camel,] whose secundine (salaAhaA) has been pulled out or off, or removed from its place. (TA.)

sulRaI c
sulRaI, [or sulRFI,] mentioned in this art. in the TA: see art. slw.

1 samRahu c
1. samRahu, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
samuma
, inf. n. samRN, (Msb,) He put poison into it; [poisoned it; infected it with poison;] namely, food. (S, Msb, K.) And He gave him to drink poison. (S, K.) And samRatohu AlhaAmRapu The hAmRp [or venomous reptile or the like] smote him with its poison. (M.) ― -b2- [Hence, perhaps, He suggested it, Uilayohi to him: a signification mentioned by Freytag, but without any indication of the authority.] ― -b3- [And, app., It perforated it; transpierced it; or pierced, or passed, through it: for it is said that] masamRN may be an inf. n. of the verb [signifying nafaca], and may also signify a place of nufuwc. (Msb.) ― -b4- And, (K,) aor.
samuma
, (S, TA,) inf. n. samRN, (TA,) (tropical:) He probed it; namely a case, or an affair; and examined, or endeavoured to learn, its depth. (S, K, TA.) ― -b5- Also, inf. n. samRN i. q. XadRahu [He made it firm, fast, or strong; &c.]: (M:) [or this may be a mistranscription for sadRahu; for] you say, samamotu AlqaAruwrapawanaHowahaA, (S, K, *) inf. n. as above, (TA,) meaning sadadotu [i. e. I closed, stopped, or stopped up, the flask, or bottle, and the like]. (S, K. *) ― -b6- Also, (M, K,) aor.
samuma
, inf. n. samRN, (TA,) i. q. OaSolaHahu [He rectified it; or put it into a good, sound, right, or proper, state; &c.]; namely, a thing. (M, K.) And samRa bayona Alqawomi, (S, M,) or samRa bayonahumaA, (K,) aor.
samuma
, [for the verb is trans., AlOamora being understood, or bayona meaning caAta Albayoni,] (M,) inf. n. samRN, (S, M,) i. q. OaSolaHa [He rectified, or reformed, or amended, the circumstances subsisting between the people, or between them two; or he effected a rectification of affairs, or an agreement, a harmony, or a reconciliation, between the people, or between them two]. (S. M, K.) ― -b7- And samRN AlwadaEa He strung the wadaE [or cowries]; which, when strung, are termed sumRapN and sumRN (M.) ― -b8- samRahu, inf. n. samRN, signifies also He appropriated it to a particular, peculiar, or special, object. (M.) You say, samRa AlnRiEomapa He so appropriated the benefit, or bounty. (K.) And samRati AlnRiEomapu The benefit, or bounty, was, or became, particular, peculiar, or special, as to its object: (S, K:) the verb being intrans. as well as trans. (K.) El-'Ajjáj says,
huwa AlRaciI OanoEama nuEomaI EamRato
EalaI AlRaciyna OasolamuwA wasamRato
(S,) or the latter hemistich is
EalaI AlbilaAdi rabRunaA wasamRato
(M,) [He is the Being who has bestowed bounty that has been general and that has been particular upon those who have become Muslims, or upon the countries, namely, our Lord]: he means that it has reached all. (S.) ― -b9- [And i. q. qaSadahu:] you say, samamotu samRaka, i. e. qaSadotu qaSodaka [which means I tended, repaired, betook myself, or directed my course, towards thee; or I have tended, &c.: and also I pursued, or have pursued, thy way, or course, doing like thee]. (S.) ＝ -A2- [sumRa It was smitten by the wind called sumuwm; applied to a plant; and in like manner to a man: see its part. n., masomuwmN. And] sumRa yawomunaA, with damm [to the s], Our day was, or became, attended with the wind called samuwm. (S, K.)

2 tasomiymN c
2. tasomiymN signifies The making loops to the [girth called] waDiyn. (TA.) [You say, smRm AlwaDiyna He made loops to the waDiyn: see the pass. part. n., below. And also He adorned the waDiyn with sumuwm, i. e. strung cowries: see, again, the pass. part. n.]

R. Q. 1 samosama c
R. Q. 1. samosama He (a man) walked, or went along, gently. (IAar, TA.) And He (a fox) ran; [or ran in a certain manner;] inf. n. samosamapN: (TK:) the latter signifies the running, (K,) or a sort of running, (M,) of the fox. (M, K.)

samRN c
samRN Poison, or vemom; (PS, TK;) or deadly poison or venom; (KL;) or the poison, or venom, of the serpent; (MA;) a certain deadly thing, (S, M, Msb, K,) well known; (K;) as also sumRN↓, (S, M, Msb, K,) which is of the dial. of the people of El-'Áliyeh, (Yoo, Msb, TA,) and is said to be the most chaste; (MF, TA;) and simRN↓, (Msb, K,) which is [said to be] of the dial. of Temeem, (Msb,) [but is thought by SM to be vulgar, and] accord. to Yoo, the first is of the dial. of Temeem, (TA,) and this is the most common of the three: (Msb:) pl. simaAmN (S, M, Msb, K) and sumuwmN: (S, Msb, K:) and samosamN↓ signifies the same, in the sing. sense. (ISk, K, TA.) [In some copies of the K, by a mistranscription (waAlsRamRi or waAlsRumRi for wAlsRamRu or waAlsRumRu) samRN or sumRN is made to be syn. with samosamN as signifying “ a fox. ” That the right reading is that which I have followed is shown in the TA by an ex., in which samosam is spoken of as drunk.] ― -b2- [Hence,] samRu AlfaOori Arsenic; [in like manner called by us ratsbane;] syn. AlXRakRu, (K, TA,) i. e. AlrRahaju [which is a modern word for arsenic]. (TA.) [Also applied in the present day to The hyoscyamus muticus of Linn. (Delile's Floræ Aegypt. Illustr., in the Descr. de l'Égypte, no. 242.)] ― -b3- And samRu AlHimaAri The [tree called] difolaI [q. v.]. (K.) ― -b4- And samRu AlsRamaki The tree called maAhiyzahoraho [or maAhiI zahoraho], (K,) which latter appellation is Pers., meaning the same, [i. e. “ fish-poison, ”] (TA,) and also known by the name of AlbuwSiyru: it is beneficial for pains of the joints, and pain of the hip and the back, and the niqoris [i. e. gout, or specially gout in the foot or feet]; but the only part of its tree that is beneficial is its liHaMC [or bark]: (K, TA:) when somewhat thereof, (K, * TA,) kneaded mith leaven, (TA,) is put into a pool of water, it intoxicates the fish thereof, (K, TA,) so that they float upon the surface of the water: (TA:) and its leaves burn in lamps in lieu of wicks, (K, TA,) by reason of their oleaginous property. (TA.) ― -b5- samRu OaboraSa: see saAmRN. ＝ -A2- Also, and sumRN↓, (S, M, Msb, K,) and simRN↓, (Msb, K,) [but the last is thought by SM to be vulgar, in this sense as well as in the first,] A perforation, bore, or hole, (S, M, Msb, K,) of anything; (M;) or such as is narrow; (TA;) for instance, (S, TA,) [the eye] of a needle; (S, Msb, TA;) as in the Kur vii. 38; [see jumRalN;] and the hole of the nose, and of the ear: (TA:) pl. sumuwmN, (M,) or simaAmN, (Msb,) or both. (S, K.) The sumuwm and simaAm of a human being are His mouth and his nostril and his ear, (S,) or his mouth and his nostrils and his ears; (K;) and the sing. is samRN and sumRN↓: (S:) or the sumuwm of a human being, and of a horse or the like, are the clefts (maXaAqR) of the skin thereof. (M.) And the sumuwm of the horse are The thin portions of the hard bone, [extending] from the two sides of the nasal bone to the channels of the tears: sing. samRN: (M:) or, as some say, (M,) the samRaAni, (S, M,) or the samR, (K, [but this seems evidently to be a mistake for the dual,]) means two veins in the nose (Oanof, M, or xayoXuwm, S, K, [which latter often means the same as the former,]) of the horse: (S, M, K:) accord. to Lth, sumuwmN, as pl. of samRN, signifies the channels of the tears of the horse: AO says that in the face of the horse are sumuwm; and the bareness of his sumuwm is approved, and is regarded as indicative of generous breed. (TA.) By the sumuwm of the horse are also meant Any bone [or rather bones] in which is marrow. (TA.) And the sumuwm of a sword are Notches therein, whether new or old. (TA.) ― -b2- OaSaAba samRa HaAjatihi [is app. from samRN as signifying the “ eye ” of a needle, or the like, and] means (assumed tropical:) He hit, or attained, the object of his aim or pursuit: (M, K:) and in like manner, huwa baSiyrN bisamRi HaAjatihi [He is knowing, or skilful, in respect of the object of his aim or pursuit]. (M.) ― -b3- [And hence, perhaps, though another derivation is asserted in what follows,] one says also, maAlahu samRN walaA HamRN gayoruka and walaA HumRN sumRN↓, (S, M,) meaning (assumed tropical:) He has no object in his mind except thee; syn. hamRN: (M:) and in like manner, maAlahu samRN walaA HamRN and walaA sumRN↓ HumRN [alone]: or, accord. to Fr, it means he has not any who hopes for him: this is from [samamotu samRaka and] Hamamotu HamRaka and hamamotu hamRaka meaning qaSadotu qaSodaka; samRN and HamRN being the inf. ns., and sumRN↓ and HumRN the simple substs.; and the meaning is, he has not any who seeks after him; i. e. he has no good in him for which he is to be sought after: (Meyd:) or it means he has neither little nor much. (K and TA in art. Hm.) ― -b4- samRN also signifies The loop (Eurowap) of the [girth called] waDiyn: pl. sumuwmN. (TA. [See musamRamN.]) ― -b5- And Anything like wadaE [or cowries] brought forth from the sea, (S, K, TA,) and strung for ornament. (TA.) And also, (TA,) or sumRN↓ and sumRapN↓, (M,) Strung wadaE [or cowries]: (M, TA:) pl. sumuwmN. (TA.)

sumRN c
sumRN: see the next preceding paragraph, in seven places.

simRN c
simRN: see samRN, in two places.

samRapN c
samRapN The meatus of the vagina of a woman; (As, TA;) as also simaAmN↓, [which is shown to be thus used as a sing., by a citation from a trad., though said to be] from simaAmN as signifying the “ eyes ” (vuqab) of the needle [or of needles]: or the rima of a woman, with the parts that are next to it of the haunch and of the borders of the vulva, i. e. of the labia majora. (TA.) ― -b2- See also simRapN. ＝ -A2- Also AlsRamRapu, (AA, TA,) or samRapu Alqalobi, (TA,) The heart, or cerebrum, of the palm-tree: pl. smm [app. simamN, or sumamN]. (TA.)

sumRapN c
sumRapN: see samRN, last sentence. ＝ -A2- Also A mat, (AHn, M,) or a suforap [q. v.], (K,) or a thing like a wide suforap, (T, TA,) made, (AHn, M,) [i. e.] woven, (T, TA,) of xuwS [or leaves] (AHn, T, M, K) of the gaDaf [a tree resembling a dwarfpalm-tree]: (AHn, M:) it is spread beneath the palm-tree (T, K, TA) when the dates are cut off, (T, TA,) and upon it fall what become scattered (T, K, TA) of the dates: (T, TA:) pl. simaAmN, (AHn, M, TA,) or sumamN, (K,) or, as in the T, sumuwmN. (TA.) ＝ -A3- See also saAmRN, latter part, in two places.

simRapN c
simRapN The Aisot [here app. meaning anus]; as also samRapN↓ [q. v.]. (K.)

samaAmN c
samaAmN A sort of bird, (T, S, M,) less than the species called qaTFA, in make, (T, TA,) like the sumaAnaI [or quail]: (M, TA:) [accord. to explanations of samaAmapN in the MA, mountain-swallows: or, accord. to the same and Meyd, birds like swallows: accord. to Dmr, as stated by Golius, i. q. Tyr AbAbyl: but this is app. said in relation to an assertion of 'Áïsheh, mentioned in art. Abl in the Msb, that the birds termed OabaAbiyl in the Kur cv. 3 were most like to swallows:] the word is a pl., (S,) [or rather a coll. gen. n.,] and the sing. [or n. un.] is with p↓, (S, M,) pl. samaAYimu: (Meyd:) see samaAsimu. ― -b2- And hence, as being likened thereto, A banner, an ensign, or a standard; syn. liwaMCN: (M:) or so samaAmapN↓. (K.) ― -b3- And [hence, also, perhaps, without p, as in a verse cited by IB and in the TA, for the coll. gen. n. may be used as a sing.,] A swift she-camel: (S, IB, TA:) [pl. samaAYimu, mentioned by Freytag, from Reiske, as signifying swift she-camels.] ― -b4- Also, and samosaAmN↓ and sumaAsimN↓ and sumosumaAnN↓ and sumosumaAniIRN↓, applied to anything, [of men and of beasts &c.,] Light, active, or agile, and slender, and swift; (M, K;)
and so samosamapN↓: (M: [thus there written; not samaAmapN nor samosaAmapN, though both of these are app. correct:]) or samosaAmN↓ and sumosumaAniIRN↓, applied to a man, signify light, or active, or agile, and swift, or quick; (S;) and sumosumN↓ so applied, and sumosumapN↓ and samaAmapN↓, applied to a woman, signify light, or active, or agile, and slender: (TA:) or sumosumN↓, applied to a man, signifies [simply] light, or active, or agile. (K.)

simaAmN c
simaAmN a pl. of samRN or sumRN: (S, M, Msb, K:) ― -b2- and also used as a sing.: see samRapN. ― -b3- [In one place, in the CK, erroneously put for samosaAm as syn. with samosam, q. v.]

samuwmN c
samuwmN, of the fem. gender, (S,) A hot wind, (S, M, Msb, K,) or, as some say, a cold wind, (M, [perhaps a mistake occasioned by a misunderstanding of the phrase samuwmN baAridN, expl. below,]) in the night or in the day, (M,) or generally (K) in the day, (Msb, K,) but authorities differ respecting it, as has been shown voce HaruwrN; (Msb;) accord. to AO, it is in the day, and sometimes in the night; and the Haruwr is in the night, and sometimes in the day: (S:) but some say that the former is in the night, and the latter in the day: (Ibn-Es-Seed in the “ Fark, ” TA:) [in the present day it is commonly applied to a violent and intensely-hot wind, generally occurring in the spring or summer, in Egypt and the Egyptian deserts usually proceeding from the south-east or south-south-east, gradually darkening the air to a deep purple hue, whether or not (according to the nature of the tract over which it blows) accompanied by clouds of dust or sand, and at length entirely concealing the sun; but seldom lasting more than about a quarter of an hour or twenty minutes:] the word is used as a subst. [i. e. alone], and also as an epithet [qualifying the subst. riyHN]: (M:) pl. samaAYimN. (S, M, K.) One says also samuwmN baAridN, meaning A samuwm that is constant, continual, permanent, settled, or incessant. (S and L in art. brd.) [See also baAriHN.]

samaAmapN c
samaAmapN: see samaAmN, in three places: ＝ -A2- and see sumosumN. ＝ -A3- Also A certain feather, (daAYirap, M, K, TA,) which is approved (K, TA) by the Arabs, (TA,) in the neck of the horse, (K,) in the middle of the neck of the horse, (M,) or in the side of his neck. (TA.) ＝ -A4- And The XaxoS [or corporeal form or figure, or person,] (M, K,) of a man: (K:) or, as some say, (M, but accord. to the K “ and ”) the aspect; (M, K;) as in the saying, huwa bahiIRu AlsRamaAmapi [He is beautiful, or pleasing, in aspect]. (TA.) ― -b2- And A portion standing up of ruined dwellings. (K.)

samRaAsN c
samRaAsN A seller of simosim [q. v.]; like laORLlN signifying a seller of luWoluW. (IKh, TA.)

samRaAnu c
samRaAnu A certain plant. (K.) ＝ -A2- [See samRaAnN in art. smn.]

simRaAnN c
simRaAnN The decorations, or embellishments, (tazaAwiyq,) of a ceiling: so says IAar; and in like manner, Lh; and he says, I have not heard a sing. of it. (TA.) [See also samRaAnN, in art. smn.]

samosamN c
samosamN: see samRN, first sentence. ＝ -A2- It is also an epithet, of which only the fem., with p, is mentioned: see samaAmN. ― -b2- [Hence,] samosamN and samosaAmN↓, (M,) or AlsRamosamu and AlsRamosaAmu↓, (K, TA,) [the latter erroneously written in the CK AlsRimAm,]) The wolf; (M, K;) because of his lightness, or activity, or agility: (M:) or AlsRamosamu signifies the wolf that is small in the body. (M, K.) ― -b3- And AlsRamosamu The fox; (S, M, K;) as also samosamN [without Al], (M,) and AlsRumaAsimu↓. (K.)

sumosumN c
sumosumN; and its fem., with p: see samaAmN, last sentence, in three places. ＝ -A2- Also, the former, and simosimN↓, or the latter is a mistake, [ascribed in the K to J,] Red ants: n. un. with p: (K:) or sumosumapN (M) and simosimapN (S, M) signify a certain insect, (M,) a red ant; (S, M;) as also samaAmapN↓: (M:) accord. to Lth, an insect of the form of the Aklp [app. a mistranscription for namolap, i. e. ant], of a red colour: Az says, I have seen it in the desert, and it bites, or stings, painfully: (TA:) pl. samaAsimu, (S, TA,) said by Aboo-Kheyreh to be certain things found in El-Basrah, that bite vehemently, having longish heads, and the colours of which incline to redness. (TA.) See samaAsimu below.

simosimN c
simosimN [Sesame; sesamum orientale of Linn.; applied in the present day to the plant and its grain;] a well-known grain; (Msb;) it is called in Pers. kunojudo; (MA, KL;) i. q. julojulaAnN, (M, K,) said by AHn to be abundant in the Saráh (AlsRaraAp), and El-Yemen, and to be white; (M;) [by this is evidently here meant sesame, or the grain thereof, or both; though it also signifies the “ fruit of the coriander; ” for otherwise, the most commonly-known meaning of simosimN would be unmentioned in the M;] the grain of the HalR; [i. e. the grain from which the oil called HalR is expressed;] (S, K; [by the author of the latter of which, this was evidently understood to be different from the julojulaAn, which is mentioned by him after the description of properties here following;]) it is glutinous, corruptive to the stomach and the mouth; but is rendered good by honey; and when it is digested, it fattens; and the washing of the hair with the water in which its leaves have been cooked lengthens and improves it: the wild sort thereof is known by the name of jalobahanok, (K, TA,) thus, with fet-h to the j and b and h, and sukoon to the l and n, [but written in the CK jalobahanako,] a Pers. word, [originally jlobahanoG,] arabicized; (TA;) its action is nearly like that of the xarobaq [or hellebore]; and sometimes from half a drachm to a drachm is administered to him who is affected with palsy, and he is cured thereby, (K, TA,) speedily; (TA;) but a drachm thereof is dangerous, (K, TA,) in a great degree. (TA.) ― -b2- AlsRimosimu AlhinodiIRu: see xirowaEN, in art. xrE. ＝ -A2- Also The serpent: (K, TA:) or a certain creeping thing resembling it. (TA.) ― -b2- See also the next preceding paragraph, where it and its n. un. with p are mentioned.

sumosumaAnN c
sumosumaAnN: see samaAmN.

sumosumaAniIRN c
sumosumaAniIRN: see samaAmN, in two places.

samosaAmN c
samosaAmN: see samaAmN, in two places: ― -b2- and see also samasamN, likewise in two places.

samaAsimu c
samaAsimu A species of bird, (M, K,) resembling the swallow; [but see what follows;] thus expl. by Th, who has not mentioned any sing. thereof; (M;) and Lh adds that its eggs are unattainable: (TA:) so in the prov., kalRafotaniI bayoDa AlsRamaAsimi [Thou hast imposed upon me the task of procuring the eggs of the samaAsim]; (M;) applied in the case of a man's being asked for that which he will not find, and which will not be: (TA:) or AlsRamaAsim is here pl. of Alsmsmp↓ [i. e. AlsRumosumapu or AlsRimosimapu], and means the red ants: thus some relate the prov.: but others say, AlsRamaAYimi↓, pl. of samaAmapN, [n. un. of samaAmN,] which means a species of bird like the swallow, the eggs of which are unattainable. (Meyd. [By Freytag, samaAYimu is erroneously said, as on the authority of Meyd, to be pl. of saAmRapN in this sense.]) In [some of] the copies of the K, AlsRumaAsimu is here erroneously put for AlsRamaAsimu. (TA.)

sumaAsimN c
sumaAsimN: see samaAmN: ― -b2- and see also samosamN.

saAmRN c
saAmRN [act. part. n. of samRa; as such signifying Poisoning, or infecting with poison]. saAmRapN, as an act. part. n. [in the fem. form because applied to things of the fem. gender (such as the Eaqorab &c.), and to such as are denoted by gen. ns., which are used in a pl. sense], (Msb,) Such as is, or are, venomous (S, Msb, K) of animals, (K,) or of creeping things, [and insects,] but of which the venom does not kill; as the scorpion, and the hornet: (Msb:) and such things (Sh, Msb) and the like thereof (Sh) are termed sawaAmRu, (Sh, Msb,) which is the pl. of saAmRapN. (Msb.) ― -b2- [And hence,] saAmRu OaboraSa (S, M, Mgh, K) and saAmRa OaboraSa, as one word, (S and Msb in art. brS, and the latter in the present art. also,) and OaboraSa samRu↓, (K,) A species of the [lizard called] wazag: (M:) or such as are large, of the wazag: (A in art. brS, and Msb:) or [one] of the large [sorts] of the wazag: (S, Mgh, K:) also called AlsRaAmRu: (TA, from a trad.:) [see more in art. brS:] applied to the male and the female: (Zj, Msb:) dual saAmRaA OaboraSa; (TA;) and pl. sawaAmRu OaboraSa. (M, Mgh, TA.) ― -b3- And yawomN saAmRN [as though meaning “ a poisoning day ”] (M, K) and musimRN↓, (IAar, M, K,) the latter rare, (M,) [and anomalous, being from sumRa,] and masomuwmN↓, (S, M, K,) A day attended with the wind called samuwm. (S, M, K.) ＝ -A2- [saAmRapN is also fem. of saAmRN as part. n. of the intrans. verb samRa signifying “ it was, or became, particular,
peculiar, or special. ” And hence,] AlsRaAmRapu signifies also (tropical:) The xaASRap [or distinguished people, or people of distinction; and the particular, peculiar, or special, friends, intimates, familiars, or the like] (S, M, IAth, K, TA) of a man; (IAth, TA;) and AlsumRapu↓, pl. sumamN, signifies the same; (M;) and so AlmasamRapu↓, like as AlmaEamRapu signifies AlEamRapu: (IAar, TA:) or AlsRumRapu↓ signifies the relations, syn. AlqaraAbapu; (K;) or the particular, or choice, relations: (TA:) and Oaholu AlmasamRapi↓ signifies the relations; syn. AlOaqaAribu; (M;) or the xaASRap [expl. above], (El-Umawee, S, K,) and the relations. (K.) One says, kayofa AlsRaAmRapu waAlEaAmRapu (assumed tropical:) [How are the people of distinction, &c., and the common people, or people in general?]. (S.) And Earafahu AlEamRapu waAlsRaAmRapu (tropical:) [The people in general, or the vulgar, and the people of distinction, &c., knew it, or him]. (TA.)

saAmRapN c
saAmRapN [fem. of saAmRN: see the latter in several places]. ＝ -A2- AlsRaAmRapu also signifies Death: (M, K:) but this is extr.: (M, TA:) the word commonly known, (M,) or the correct word in this sense, (TA,) is AlsRaAmu, [belonging to art. swm,] without teshdeed (M, TA) to the m, and without p. (TA.)

OasamRu c
OasamRu A nose narrow (K, TA.) and fat (TA) in the nostrils. (K, TA.)

masamRu c
masamRu A place of perforation, of transpiercing, or of passing through: pl. masaAmRu. (Msb.) [Hence,] masaAmRu Aljasadi (S, K) or Albadani (Msb) The perforations [or pores] of the body (S, Msb, K) through which the sweat and the exhalation of the interior thereof pass forth: (Msb:) AlmasaAmRu [thus] applied to the manaAfic [of the body] is a term of the physicians. (Mgh.)

musimRN c
musimRN: see saAmRN.

misamRN c
misamRN One who eats what he is able to eat. (K.)

AlmasamRapu c
AlmasamRapu and Oaholu AlmasamRapi: see saAmRN.

musamRamN c
musamRamN, applied to a [girth such as is called] waDiyn, Having three sumuwm, i. e. loops (EurFI) [attached to it]. (TA.) And also, thus applied, Adorned with sumuwm, i. e. strung cowries. (TA.)

masomuwmN c
masomuwmN [Poisoned; infected with poison;] having had poison put into it; applied to food. (TA.) And A man having had poison given him to drink. (TA.) ― -b2- Also Smitten by the wind called samuwm; applied to a plant; and in like manner to a man. (TA.) See also saAmRN.

1 samotN c
1. samotN [as an inf. n.] is syn. with qaSodN [in an intrans. sense], (S, * Msb,) and hudFI [in the sense of raXaAdN], and AisotiqaAmapN: (Msb:) or Husonu naHowK: (M, K:) you say, samata, aor.
samuta
, (S, M, K,) and
samita
, (K,) or in this case the former only, (TA,) inf. n. samotN, (M, TA,) He pursued a right course; syn. qaSada: (S, TA:) or (assumed tropical:) he followed a good direction (M, K, * TA *) in the way of religion [&c.]. (TA.) Accord. to Khálid Ibn- Dabbeh, it signifies (assumed tropical:) The following the truth and the right way or direction, and being a good neighbour, and doing little harm. (TA.) [But more commonly, or primarily, it relates to the course that one pursues in journeying.] An Arab of the desert, of [the tribe of] Keys, says,
sawofa tajuwbiyna bigayori naEoti
taEasRufFA Oawo hekacaA biAlsRamoti
i. e. [Thou shalt traverse (addressing a woman), or, more probably, ye shall traverse (addressing camels or other beasts), a land without a description], journeying without any sign of the way and without any track [for guidance], such being the meaning of tEsRfA, or thus, pursuing a right course, AlsRamotu meaning AlqaSodu. (TA.) Accord. to Sh, AlsRamotu signifies The seeking, searching, or inquiring, for, or after, the right way or direction. (TA.) ― -b2- AlsRamotu also signifies qaSdu AlTRariyqi [i. e. samotu AlTRariyqi signifies The road's having a right, or direct, tendency]: (M:) or [samotu AlXRaIoCi] signifies qaSodu AlXRaIoCi [i. e. The thing's having a right, or direct, tendency]. (K.) [This last explanation has been misunderstood by the Turkish translator of the K; who has hence been led to assert that one says, samata AlXRaIoCa as well as samata naHowahu, meaning qaSadahu: it is tasamRatahu that (like samata naHowahu) signifies qaSadahu; not samatahu, for samata is always intrans.] ― -b3- Also The journeying (S, M, K) upon the road (M, K) [guided only] by opinion (S, M, K) and conjecture: (S:) or, as some say, the journeying by conjecture and opinion, not upon a [known] road. (TA.) A poet says,
layosa bihaA riyEN lisamoti AlsRaAmiti↓
[There is not, or was not, in it, a road of any kind (see riyEN) for the journeying by opinion and conjecture of him who so journeys]. (S, TA.) ― -b4- And The pursuing a course, or direction, [of any kind,] and [particularly] (assumed tropical:) in religion and in worldly affairs. (TA.) You say, huwa yasomutu samotahu (assumed tropical:) He pursues his [another's] way, or course, doing as he [the latter] does. (TA.) [samotahu is here an absolute (not an objective) complement of yasomutu; like sayorahu in the phrase huwayasiyru sayorahu. See also samotN below.] ― -b5- Also samata, aor.
samuta
, inf. n. samotN, (assumed tropical:) He (a man) was, or became, grave, staid, steady, sedate, or calm. (Msb.) ― -b6- And samata lahumo, aor.
samita
, (Fr, K,) inf. n. samotN, (Fr, TA,) (assumed tropical:) He prepared, arranged, or disposed, for them, the mode, or manner, of speech, and of judging, or forming an opinion, (Fr, K, TA,) and of work, or action. (Fr, TA.)

2 tasomiytN c
2. tasomiytN The keeping to the samot [i. e. road, &c.]. (K.) It is said in a trad., faQnoTalaqotu laA OadoriI Oayona Oacohabu UilRaA OanRaniI OusamRitu, meaning [And I departed, not knowing whither I should go, but] I kept to the course, or direction, of the road: or as some say, I prayed to God. (TA.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) The mentioning of God, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) or, as in some copies of the S, the mentioning of the name of God, [like tasomiyapN, inf. n. of samRaI,] (TA,) upon, or over, a thing, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) or in any case. (TA.) One says, samRata EalaI AlTRaEaAmi (assumed tropical:) He mentioned the name of God upon, or over, the food. (TK.) ― -b3- And smRt lahu and Ealayohi, inf. n. tasomiytN, (assumed tropical:) He prayed for what was good for him; prayed for a blessing upon him; as also XmRt. (L and TA in art. Xmt, q. v.) In a trad. respecting eating, it is said, samRuwA QllReha wadanRuwA wasamRituwA, meaning (assumed tropical:) [Pronounce ye the name of God, and take what is next you of the food, or make your words to be near together, (see 2 in arts. dnw and smw,) and,] when ye have ended, invoke a blessing upon him at whose abode or table ye have eaten. (TA.) ― -b4- AltRasoniytu also signifies, (M, K,) or tasomiytu AlEaATisi, (S, Msb,) (assumed tropical:) The praying for the sneezer; (M, Msb, K;) saying, hadaAka QllRehu UilaI AlsRamoti [May God guide thee to the right, or good, course]; because the person sneezing is disturbed and disquieted: so says AAF: (M, TA:) or the saying to him, yaroHamuka QllRehu [May God have mercy on thee]: (Th, S, M:) or AltRasomiytu signifies the saying baAraka QllRehu fiyka [May God bless thee]: (ISh, TA:) it is with s and with X: (S, M, Msb:) one says samRatahu, (T, M, Msb,) i. e. samRata AlEaATisa, meaning He prayed for the sneezer, [saying as above,] (A,) and XamRatahu: (T, M, Msb:) Th says that the former is preferred, (S,) or is the original, (Msb,) being from AlsRamotu signifying AlqaSodu, (S, M, Msb,) and AlhudaI, and AlAisotiqaAmapu, (Msb,) and AlmaHajRapu, (S,) or AlTRariyqu; (M;) as though one made a person his object by this prayer; (M;) and that the s is changed [by some] into X: (TA:) but A 'Obeyd says that the pronunciation with X is of higher authority, and more common. (S, Msb.) The Prophet said, When any of you sneezes, let him say, AlHamodu lilRehi [Praise be to God]; and he who prays for him (AlRaciI yuXanRituhu [or yusamRituhu]), yaroHamuka QllRehu; and let him [i. e. the sneezer] say [in reply], yahodiykumu QllRehu wayuSoliHu baAlakumo [May God direct you aright, and render good your state, or condition, or case]. (Har p. 250.)

3 sAmthu c
3. sAmthu, inf. n. musaAmatapN, He, or it, faced, or fronted, or was opposite to or over against, him, or it. (Msb, TA.)

5 tsmRthu c
5. tsmRthu, (As, S, A, TA,) [and] tsmRt lahu, (M,) He directed himself, or his course, or aim, to, or towards, him, or it; syn. qaSadahu, (S, M,) or taEamRadahu, and qaSada naHowahu. (As, A, TA.)

samotN c
samotN inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (M, TA.) ― -b2- Also A road, or way; syn. TariyqN, (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) and maHajRapN, (Th, S,) and naHowN: (A:) [pl. sumuwtN.] One says, Ailozamo hecaA AlsRamota Keep thou to this road, or way. (TA.) ― -b3- And [hence,] (assumed tropical:) The way, or course, that one pursues in his religion and his worldly affairs: (TA:) (assumed tropical:) a way, mode, or manner, of acting or conduct or the like: (S, TA:) (tropical:) the mode, or manner, [of life,] syn. hayoYap, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K, TA,) of good people, (S, A, Mgh, K, TA,) in respect of religion, not in
respect of goodliness of person: (TA:) a metaphorical meaning, from the same word as signifying “ a road, ” or “ way. ” (Mgh.) One says, UinRahu laHasanu AlsRamoti (assumed tropical:) Verily he is good in respect of the way, or course, that he pursues in his religion and his worldly affairs: (TA:) or huwaHasanu AlsRamoti means (assumed tropical:) he is good in his hayoYap [i. e., as here used, mode, or manner, of life]. (Msb.) And maA OaHosana samotahu (tropical:) How good is his way, mode, or manner, of acting or conduct or the like! (S, A, * Mgh, * TA.) ― -b4- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) Gravity, staidness, steadiness, sedateness, or calmness. (Msb.) ― -b5- AlsRamotu also signifies The region, or quarter, to which, or towards which, the course, or aim, is directed. (M.) ― -b6- [And hence, The bearing, or direction, of an object by the compass. And more particularly, The azimuth. ― -b7- And samotu AlrRaOosi The zenith; or vertical point in the heavens. (“ Zenit ” appears to have been, as Golius observes, a mistranscription for “ zemt, ” or “ semt. ”) ― -b8- samotu AlXRamosi The path of the sun; the ecliptic: from samotN signifying “ a road, ” or “ way. ” ― -b9- samotu AlAiEotidaAli The equinoctial colure. And samotu AlAinoqilaAbi The solstitial colure.]

saAmitN c
saAmitN [part. n. of 1]: see an ex. in the latter half of the first paragraph of this art.

musamRitN c
musamRitN (assumed tropical:) Any one praying, or who prays, for what is good, (S and TA in art. Xmt,) liOaHadK [for any one]; (TA in that art.;) as also muXamRitN: (S and TA in that art.:) any one praying, or who prays, for a return to the right, or good, way, and continuance therein. (Msb.)

mutasamRatu AlnRaEoli c
mutasamRatu AlnRaEoli The part of the sandal that is below its muxaSRar [or narrow part, more commonly called its xaSor, extending thence] to its extremity. (K.)

samuja c
samuja, [aor.
samuja
,] inf. n. samaAjapN (S, O, Msb, K) and sumuwjapN; (L, TA;) and samija, [aor.
samaja
,] (Lh, TA, and so in a copy of the A,) inf. n. samaAjapN; (A;) It (a thing, S, O, Msb) was, or became, foul, unseemly, or ugly; (S, A, O, Msb, * K;) or devoid of beauty. (A, L, Msb.)

2 smRjhu c
2. smRjhu, (A, O, L, Msb, K,) inf. n. tasomiyjN, (O, K,) He, or it, rendered it foul, unseemly, or ugly; (O, Msb, * K;) or devoid of beauty. (L, Msb.) One says, maA samRajahu EinodiI UilRaA kacaA [Nothing rendered it foul, unseemly, &c., in my estimation, but such a thing]. (A.)

4 maA Oasomaja fiEolahu c
4. maA Oasomaja fiEolahu [How foul, or unseemly, is his deed!]. (A.)

10 Astsmjhu c
10. Astsmjhu He reckoned it, or esteemed it, foul, unseemly, or ugly; (S, O;) or devoid of beauty. (L.) One says, OanaA Oasotasomiju fiEolaka [I reckon, or esteem, thy deed foul, or unseemly]. (A, TA.)

samojN c
samojN, (S, O, K,) like DaxomN from Daxuma, (S, O,) and samijN↓, (S, A, O, Msb, K,) like xaXinN (S, A, O, Msb) from xaXuna, (S, O,) and samiyjN↓, (S, A, O, K,) like qabiyHN (S, A, O) from qabuHa, (S, O,) Foul, unseemly, or ugly; (S, A, O, Msb, * K;) or devoid of beauty: (A, L, Msb:) pl. simaAjN, (S, O, K,) [of samojN,] like DixaAmN [pl. of DaxomN, or of samiyjN, like qibaAHN pl. of qabiyHN], applied to a number of men, (S, O,) and, so applied, samaAjaI, [of samijN, like HacaAraI pl. of HacirN, or of samiyjN, like qabaAHaI pl. of qabiyHN,] (IF, O, L,) and sumajaMCu, [of samiyjN,] and samijuwna: (L:) samiyjN↓ is of the dial. of Hudheyl; and is said by some to signify possessing no good, or no good things. (L.) One says also samojN lamojN and lamijN samijN↓ and lamiyjN samiyjN↓, using the latter word in each case as an imitative sequent [for the purpose of corroboration]. (AO, S and K in art. lmj, q. v.) ― -b2- samojN applied to milk signifies Greasy, and bad, or foul, in flavour; as also samiyjN↓; (S, O, K;) and so samohajN and samolajN: (S:) or having no flavour; (L;) or so samijN↓: (Msb:) and bad, or foul, in odour. (L.)

samijN c
samijN: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.

samiyjN c
samiyjN: see samojN, in four places.

1 samuHa c
1. samuHa, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
samuHa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. samaAHN and samaAHapN and sumuwHN and sumuwHapN and samoHN and simaAHN, (K,) He was, or became, liberal, bountiful, munificent, or generous; (S, * Msb, * K;) as also AsmH↓: (Msb, K:) but the unaugmented verb commonly known, but faultily omitted in the K, is samaHa, aor.
samaHa
; and this is the only one mentioned by IKtt and IKoot and a number of other authors: samuHa, like karuma, means he became of the people of AlsRamaAHap [i. e. liberality, &c.]: (MF:) [but] samaHa and AsmH↓ both signify as above; he was, or became, liberal, &c.; and he gave from a motive of generosity and liberality: this is the correct explanation of both; though some say that the former only is used in this sense; and the latter, in relation to compliance and submissiveness. (L.) You say, samaHa bihi, (S, A, Msb,) aor.
samaHa
, inf. n. samaAHN and samaAHapN (S, * A, * Msb) and sumuwHN, (Msb,) He was liberal, bountiful, munificent, or generous, with it; (S, A, Msb;) and gave it; and complied therein with that which was desired of him; as also AsmH↓. (Msb.) [And samaHa lahu He was liberal, &c., to him; as also AsmH↓; whence,] God is represented, in a trad., as saying, liEabodiI OasomiHuwA↓ kaUisomaAHihi UilaI EibaAdiI Be ye liberal, &c., to my servant, [meaning Mohammad,] like as he is liberal, &c., to my servants. (L.) And samaHa liI, (S,) or lahu, (A,) He gave (S, A) to me, (S,) or to him: (A:) and bikacaA saAmaHahu↓ he gave him such a thing. (Msb.) And samaHa liI bicelika, and AsmH↓, and sAmH↓, He complied with my desire in that thing. (L: see also a similar phrase below.) ― -b2- samaHato, said of a she-camel, means She became submissive, and went quickly: (L:) and AsmHt↓ said of a beast (daAbRap), it became gentle and submissive after being refractory: (L, K: *) and in like manner AsmH↓; (A;) and smRH↓, inf. n. tasomiyHN; (L;) said of a camel: (A, L:) or tasomiyHN signifies the going an easy pace: (S, L, K:) and the going quickly: (L, K:) or (so in the L, but in the K “ and ”) the act of fleeing. (L, K.) And AsmH↓ It became easy and submissive. (L.) You say, qaruwnatuhu OasomaHato↓, (S, A, K,) and qariynatuhu, as also saAmaHato↓, (L,) His mind became submissive, (S, A, L, K,) licelika AlOamori to that thing. (L.) ― -b3- samaHa, inf. n. samaAHN; (L;) and smRH↓, (Mgh, L,) inf. n. tasomiyHN; (L, K;) and sAmH↓, (Mgh, L,) inf. n. musaAmaHapN; (S, A, L, K;) and AsmH↓, (Mgh,) and tsmRH↓; (L;) also signify He acted in an easy, or a gentle, manner; (S, A, Mgh, L, K;) and he made easy, or facilitated; (L;) fiI OamorK in an affair: (Mgh, L:) and musaAmaHapN↓ signifies the acting in an easy, or a gentle, manner in a contest in thrusting, or piercing, with spears or the like, and smiting with swords, and running. (L.) It is said in a well-known trad., AlsRamaAHu rabaAHN The acting in an easy, or a gentle, manner, in affairs, is a means of gain, or profit, to the performer thereof. (L.) And you say, fiI AlOamori sAmHhu↓ He acted in an easy, or a gentle, manner with him. (TK.) And samaHa lahu and bihi, and AsmH↓, He made [a thing] easy to him. (L.) And AisomaHo yusomaHo laka (Meyd, Mgh, L) and bika, (L,) and yusomaHo laka OasomiHo↓ (Meyd, L) and bika, (L,) a trad., (Mgh, L,) meaning Facilitate thou, and facilitation shall be rendered to thee: (As, Sh, L:) or act thou in an easy, or a gentle, manner, and easy, or gentle, treatment, shall be rendered to thee: (Mgh:) or be thou compliant, and compliance shall be rendered to thee. (Meyd.) And samaHa lahu biHaAjatihi, and AsmH↓, He made easy to him the object of his want. (IAar, L: see also a similar phrase above.) ― -b4- samaAHapN (A, TA) and sumuwHapN, (TA,) [app. inf. ns. of which the verb is samuHa,] in a branch, or rod, signify (tropical:) The being even and smooth, without any knots [or inequality of thickness: see samoHN]. (A, TA.)

2 samRaHa
2: see 1, in two places. ― -b2- tasomiyHu AlrRumoHi means (assumed tropical:) The straightening, or making even, of the spear, (S, K, TA,) so as to render it smooth. (TA. [See 1, last sentence.])

3 saAomaHa
3: see 1, in six places.

4 OasomaHa
4: see 1, in all but four sentences.

5 tasamRaHa
5: see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph: ― -b2- and see also the paragraph here following, in two places.

6 tsAmHwA c
6. tsAmHwA They acted in an easy, or a gentle, manner, one with another. (S, A, K.) ― -b2- [Hence] tasaAmuHN [as a conventional term in lexicology, or in relation to language,] is [A careless, or defective, manner of expression,] when the meaning of a sentence is not known, and, in order to its being understood, requires another word or phrase to be supplied: (KT:) [or the using a careless mode of expression, relying upon the understanding of the reader or hearer; as also tasamRuHN↓: or] a deficiency in what a speaker says, relying upon [the knowledge of] the person addressed. (Marginal note in a copy of the KT, subsigned smE [app. to denote that the authority is Isma'eel Hakkee].) [See also tasaAhulN, which is often used as though it were syn. with tasaAmuHN.] ― -b3- The primary meaning of tasaAmuHN and tasamRuHN↓ is [said to be] The being wide, or ample: whence the phrase fiI AlHaqRi masomaHN [expl. below]. (Msb.)

7 AlsmH c
7. AlsmH [app. syn. with OasomaHa, or perhaps a mistranscription for the latter word]: see AinosajaHa.

samoHN c
samoHN (T, S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and samiHN↓, of which the former is a contraction, (Msb,) [but which is seldom used,] as also samiyHN↓ and [in an intensive sense] misomaHN↓ (T, M, TA) and misomaAHN↓ (T, S, * M, A, * K, * TA) [and samuwHN↓, occurring in the K voce naEuwsN, the last three fem. as well as masc.], Liberal, bountiful, munificent, or generous: (T, S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K, TA:) fem. samoHapN: (T, S, M, A, K:) pl. simaAHN, (Th, T, S, M, A, Msb, K,) applied to women (Th, S, Msb, K) only, (Th, S, K,) or to men and to women, (T, M, TA,) and sumaHaMCu, (T, S, M, A, Msb, K,) applied to a party of people, (S, A,) [i. e.] to men and to women, (T, M, TA,) as though pl. of samiyHN, (S, K,) and masaAmiyHu, (T, S, M, A, K,) applied to men and to women, (T, M, A, *) pl. of misomaAHN, (A,) or as though pl. of misomaAHN. (S, K.) The dim. of samoHN is sumayoHN↓ and sumayRiHN↓; (K;) but the latter is by some disallowed. (TA.) You say also, fulaAnN samoHN lamoHN and lamiyHN samiyHN↓ [app. meaning Such a one is very liberal, &c.; for in each case the latter epithet is probably an imitative sequent, and therefore a corroborative]. (L.) ― -b2- daAbRapN samoHapN [A beast that is submissive, or easy, or gentle: and probably also quick: see 1]. (A, voce jamoHapN, q. v.) ― -b3- [Hence, app.,] samoHapu is the name of A mare of Jaafar the son of Aboo-Tálib. (K. [See also saboHap.]) ― -b4- And OumRu samoHapa The she-goat. (T in art. Am.) ― -b5- And qawosN samoHapN (assumed tropical:) A pliant bow. (K, * TA.) ― -b6- And EuwdN samoHN (tropical:) A branch, or rod, that is even and smooth, (A, * Msb, * TA,) without any knot: (A, K, TA:) or of even growth, so that what is between its two extremities is not more slender than its two extremities or than one of them. (AHn, TA.) One says also saAjapN samoHapN (tropical:) [An oblong squared piece, or a board or tablet, of the wood of the sAj (q. v.), that is even and smooth]. (TA.) ― -b7- And milRapN samoHapN (assumed tropical:) A religion in which is no straitness (K, TA) nor difficulty. (TA.) ― -b8- The saying of 'Omar Ibn-'AbdEl-'Azeez OacRino OacaAnFA samoHFA means (assumed tropical:) [Recite thou a call to prayer] without a prolonging of the voice, and trilling, and without modulation. (Mgh.)

samiHN c
samiHN: see the next preceding paragraph.

simaAHN c
simaAHN Tents (buyuwt) made of skins. (Ibn-ElFaraj, K.)

samuwHN c
samuwHN: see samoHN, first sentence.

samiyHN c
samiyHN: see samoHN, in two places.

sumayoHN c
sumayoHN and sumayRiHN dims of samoHN, q. v. (K.)

OasomaHu c
OasomaHu [More, and most, liberal, bountiful, munificent, or generous]. See an ex. voce laAfiZo.

Ealayoka biAlHaqRi faUinRa fiyhi lamasomaHFA c
Ealayoka biAlHaqRi faUinRa fiyhi lamasomaHFA, (A, Msb, * K, *) Keep thou to the truth, for verily in it is ample scope for avoiding falsity; expl. by matRasaEFA, (A, Msb, K,) and manoduwHapF Eani AlbaATili. (A, Msb.)

misomaHN c
misomaHN: see samoHN, first sentence.

misomAH c
misomAH: see samoHN, first sentence.

samoHajN c
samoHajN, applied to a she-ass and to a mare, (S, O, K,) but not to a male, (AO, S, O,) and sometimes to a she-camel, (TA,) Long in the back; (S, O, K;) as also simoHaAjN↓ (O, K) and samoHuwjN↓: (O:) [see an ex. in a verse cited voce Xagaba:] pl. of the last but one, or of the last, not of the first as it is asserted to be by A'Obeyd and by Kr, samaAHiyju: (TA:) and the first, a mare slender in the body, or lean in the belly, but thick in the part between the shoulder and shoulder-blade, (O, K, TA,) having thick and strong flesh: (TA:) applied only to females. (K.) ― -b2- Also, applied to a bow, Long. (O, K.)

samoHajapN c
samoHajapN Length in anything. (T, O, K.)

simoHaAjN c
simoHaAjN: see samoHajN.

sumoHuwjN c
sumoHuwjN: see samoHajN. ― -b2- Also Tall and hateful or hated; (O, K;) applied in this sense to a man. (O.)

simoHaAqN c
simoHaAqN [The pericranium; i. e.] the thin skin, (T, Mgh, Msb,) or thin integument, (S, Mgh, K,) above the skull: (T, S, Mgh, Msb, K:) and any thin skin resembling that; (Msb;) or [the periosteum of any bone; i. e.] the skin that is between the bone and the flesh, above the bone and beneath the flesh; every bone having what is thus termed: (TA:) [pl. samaAHiyqu. ― -b2- Hence,] one says, EalaI varobi AlXRaApi samaAHiyqu mino XaHomK, (S, K, TA,) i. e. (tropical:) [Upon the fat that covers the stomach and bowels of the sheep or goat is or are] a thin integument [or thin integuments of fat]. (TA.) ― -b3- And samaAHiyqu AlsRamaMCi (tropical:) The [strata or] thin portions of cloud. (S, K, TA.) ― -b4- simoHaAqN also signifies [The cicatrix which is] the mark of circumcision. (TA.) ― -b5- And A wound by which the head is broken (XajRapN [q. v.]) reaching to the thin skin, or integument, thus called. (T, S, Msb, K.)

sukoHuwqN c
sukoHuwqN Tall; applied to a palm-tree; (S, O, K;) as also saHuwqN: (S:) or tall and thin: (Lth, TA:) not known to Az on any other authority than that of Lth. (TA.) [J held the m in each of these words, as he says, to be augmentative; and has therefore mentioned them in art. sHq.]

1 samada c
1. samada, (S, M, &c.,) aor.
samuda
, (M, L,) inf. n. sumuwdN, He (a man, IAar) was, or became, high, or elevated. (IAar, S, M, L, K. [EalACF in the CK is a mistake for EalA.]) ― -b2- He raised his head; (L; [and the same is implied in the S; see saAmidN;]) and so samida: (M, L:) [and] he raised his head in pride. (S, L, K.) And in the former sense it is said of a camel, in his going along. (Bd in liii. 61.) ― -b3- Also He (a man) stood, raising his head, and with his breast erect; like as the stallion [camel] does when excited by lust: (A:) [for] it is said of a stallion [camel] when thus excited. (L.) ― -b4- And hence, (A,) (tropical:) He sang: (M, A, L:) because the singer raises his head and erects his breast: (A:) but Th says that this is rare: (M:) accord. to I'Ab, sumuwdN signifies the act of singing in the dial. of Himyer. (L.) ― -b5- Also, (M, K,) aor. as above, (TA,) and so the inf. n., (S, M,) (assumed tropical:) He diverted himself, sported, or played. (S, M, K, TA. [For lahiIa in the CK, I read lahaA, as in the M, and in MS. copies of the K, and in the TA; and agreeably with the S, in which the inf. n. is expl. as syn. with lahowN.]) ― -b6- He was, or became, negligent, inattentive, inadvertent, inconsiderate, or heedless; and went away from, or relinquished, or left, a thing. (L.) ― -b7- He was, or became, confounded, perplexed, or amazed, and unable to see his right course; or affected with wonder; or cut short, or silent, being confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course; syn. buhita: inf. n. as above: (M:) [or] he stood confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course; syn. qaAma mutaHayRirFA. (K. [After this explanation and lahaA immediately following it, it is said in the K, wAlsRumuwdu yakuwnu HuzonFA wasurwrFA: meaning that it is by reason of grieving, or mourning, as signifying the “ standing confounded ” &c.; and by reason of rejoicing, or being happy, as signifying the “ diverting oneself ” &c. See as an ex. of its usage in a case of grief the verses which I have cited at the close of the first paragraph of art. rd, and which are cited in the present art. in the L and TA.]) ― -b8- Also He kept constantly, or continually, (M, L,) to an affair, (M,) or upon the ground, or in the land. (L.) ― -b9- He strove laboured, or exerted himself, or he wearied himself, in work, (K, TA,) and in journeying. (TA.) And samadati AlUibilu (S, M, K) fiI sayorihaA, (S,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M,) The camels strove, laboured, or exerted themselves, in their journeying: (S, K:) or knew not fatigue, or weariness. (M.) [See also samodN, (which is likewise, perhaps,
an inf. n. of the same verb,) below.] ＝ -A2- samadahu, inf. n. samodN, i. q. qaSadahu [He tended, repaired, betook himself, or directed himself or his course or aim, to, or towards, him, or it; or endeavoured to reach, or attain, or obtain, him, or it; &c.]; like Samadahu. (M.) ＝ -A3- And samada AlOaroDa, inf. n. samodN, He made the land, or ground, plain, or smooth, or soft. (M.)

2 smRdhu c
2. smRdhu, (M, TA,) inf. n. tasomiydN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He diverted him: (M, TA:) [and in like manner, Asmdhu↓; for] one says to a slave-songstress, OasomidiynaA, [in one of my copies of the S, erroneously, AsomudiynaA,] meaning Divert thou us by singing. (S, O, L, TA.) ＝ -A2- smRd AlOaroDa, (M, Msb, K,) inf. n. as above, (S, Msb, K,) He manured the land with samaAd [q. v.]: (S, Msb, K:) he dunged, or manured, the land; syn. zabRalahaA. (M. [So in a copy of the M: in the TA zblhA, without teshdeed; and thus only, I believe, correctly; though it is commonly pronounced with teshdeed in the present day.]) ＝ -A3- smd XaEarahu, (M,) or AlXRaEara, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He removed utterly his hair, or the hair; (M, K, TA;) taking the whole of it [in shaving]: a dial. var. of sbRd. (TA.) tasomiydu AlrRaOosi is The removing utterly the hair of the head [by shaving]: a dial. var. of tasobiyd. (S.) ― -b2- And tasomiydN is also used [alone, the objective complement being app. meant to be understood,] as meaning The leaving off, or neglecting, the anointing of oneself [or of one's hair], and washing: and so tasobiydN. (A 'Obeyd, TA in art. sbd.)

4 Oasomada
4: see 2, first sentence.

9 UisomadRa
9: see Q. Q. 4, in two places.

11 UisomaAodRa
11: see what next follows.

Q. Q. 4 AisomaOadRa c
Q. Q. 4. AisomaOadRa, (S, M, L,) inf. n. AisomiYodaAdN, (S,) He, or it, became swollen: (M, L:) or became much swollen: (AZ, M, L:) or he (a man) became swollen with anger; (S, L;) or so AisomaAdRa↓, inf. n. AismiydaAdN; and AisomadRa↓, inf. n. AisomidaAdN. (K.) One says, AsmOdRt yadahu His arm, or hand, became swollen: and AsmOdRt rijoluhaA Her leg, or foot, became inflated and swollen. (L, TA.) ― -b2- Also, said of anything, It went, or passed, away: or perished; and so AsmdR↓. (L, TA.) And AsmOdR mina AlgaDabi He perished by reason of anger. (L.)

samodN c
samodN Continuing, or unceasing, journeying. (M, L.) [Perhaps an inf. n.: see samadati AlUibilu, and what next precedes it, in the latter part of the first paragraph.] ― -b2- huwa laka samodFA, (K, TA,) or samadFA↓, (M,) [in my copy of the Mgh smdFA, and in the O samdFA,] He, or it, is thine ever, or for ever; syn. saromadFA, (Th, M, Mgh, O, K,) and OabadFA. (Th, M, Mgh.) And laA OafoEalu celika samodFA or samadFA↓, (M,) I will not do that ever. (M, TA.)

samadFA c
samadFA: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

samaAdN c
samaAdN A compost, or manure, consisting of sirojiyn, (S, Mgh, Msb,) or siroqiyn, (K,) [both meaning dung of beasts, such as horses, camels, sheep and goats, wild oxen, and the like,] with ashes, (S, K,) or with earth or dust: (Mgh, Msb:) or a manure consisting of strong earth. (M.)

samiydN c
samiydN i. q. HuwRaAraI (A, K) [app. as meaning White, or whitened, flour: but said in the TK to mean fine bread]: accord. to Kr, i. q. TaEaAmN [app. as meaning wheat]; and said by him to be with the unpointed d: (K:) but more chastely, (K,) and better known, (TA,) with c. (K, TA.) [In the present day, applied to Semoulia; a kind of paste made of very fine wheat-flour, reduced to small grains. See also UisomiydN, below.]

saAmidN c
saAmidN Any [man or animal] raising his head [in pride or otherwise]. (S, M, L.) ― -b2- A man standing: (IAar; and so in a copy of the S:) or standing, raising his head, and with his breast erect; (A, IAth;) as the stallion [camel] does when excited by lust. (A.) ― -b3- [And hence, as is indicated in the A, (see 1,)] (assumed tropical:) A singer; or singing. (M, L; and so in two copies of the S.) And the latter is said to be the meaning of the pl. in the Kur liii. 61. (M, L.) ― -b4- [Hence also,] Behaving proudly. (I 'Ab in explanation of the pl. in the Kur liii. 61; and IAar.) ― -b5- Diverting himself; playing; or sporting. (IAar, S, M; and Bd in liii. 61,) ― -b6- Negligent, inattentive, inadvertent, inconsiderate, or heedless. (Lth, IAar A.) Thus the pl. is said by Lth to mean in the Kur liii. 61. (TA.) ― -b7- Standing in a state of confusion, perplexity, or amazement: (Mgh:) and so the pl. is said to mean in the Kur liii. 61: (TA:) or confounded, perplexed, or amazed, by reason of inordinate exultation. (IAar.) ― -b8- And Silent. (So in a copy of the S.) ― -b9- And Grieving, or mourning, and lowly, humble, or submissive. (So, too, in a copy of the S.) ― -b10- In the saying of Ru-beh, (K,) describing camels, (TA,)
sawaAmidu AllRayoli xifaAfu AlOazowaAdo
the meaning is, Continuing journeying, (K,) or striving, labouring, or exerting themselves, or wearying themselves, [during the night,] having no fodder in their bellies: (L:) F says that J has erred in saying that the meaning is, “ having no fodder in their bellies: ” but this is the explanation of the words xfAf AlAzwAd, as IM and others have expressly stated; and this necessarily indicates that swAmd has the meaning assigned to it in the K; so that no error is attributable to J in this case: or, as some say, xfAf AlAzwAd means not having upon their backs [much] provision for the riders. (TA.) ― -b11- saAmidN as an epithet applied to a waTob [or skin in which milk is put] means (tropical:) Full, [so as to be] standing upright. (A, TA.)

UisomiydN c
UisomiydN What is called in Persian simidN [app. a mistranscription for Xamaco, i. e. white bread]; an arabicized word: [so says ISd; and he adds,] I know not whether it be the same as samiydN expl. by Kr as signifying TaEaAmN, or not. (M.)

misomadN c
misomadN i. q. zabiylN [i. e. A basket of palm-leaves; probably one used for carrying samaAd, or manure]: so says Lh; adding that one should not say misomadapN. (M.)

Q. 4 UisomadarRa
Q. 4: accord. to the M and K, AisomadarRa: and

sumoduwrN c
sumoduwrN and samaAdiyrN: and

musomadirRN c
musomadirRN: see art. sdr.

samayodaEN c
samayodaEN, (S, K, &c.,) of the measure faEayolalN, (Sb, TA,) so accord. to the grammarians, but Aboo-Usámeh Junádeh El-Azdee says that it is of the measure famayoEalN, from sadoEN as syn. with caboHN and basoTN, (Sgh, TA,) pronounced by the vulgar sumayodaE, with damm to the s, (IDrst, TA,) which is a mistake, (Th, IDrst, S, K, &c.,) for there is not in the language of the Arabs a noun of the measure fuEayolalN, (IDrst, TA,) A lord, master, chief, prince, or man of rank or quality; ('Eyn, S, O, K;) to which Et-Teiyánee adds, from As, on the authority of Munteji' Ibn-Nebhán, (TA,) of easy nature or disposition, generous, and very hospitable, or in whose vicinity his companion has power or authority or dignity, not being harmed nor inconvenienced; (S, K, TA;) and thus expl. by AHát also; (TA;) generous; noble, or elevated in rank; liberal, bountiful, or munificent: (O, K:) and also (K) courageous: (Lth, K:) and goodly, and stout, bulky, or corpulent: (AZ, EtTeiyánee:) pl. samaAdiEu. (IJ.) ― -b2- The lion. (Ibn-Ed-Dahhán, T, S, O.) ― -b3- And hence, [accord. to SM, but the reverse I think more probable,] (tropical:) A chief, or person of authority. (TA.) ― -b4- The wolf; (En-Nadr, K;) because of his swiftness. (En-Nadr.) ― -b5- And hence, (TA,) (tropical:) A man active, agile, or prompt, in accomplishing his wants. (K, TA.) ― -b6- And A sword. (K.)

samiycN c
samiycN i. q. samiydN [q. v.]; (K:) [said to be] more chaste than the latter: (K in art. smd:) [but] accord. to Kr, it is with the unpointed d. (M in that art.)

1 samara c
1. samara, (S, M, K,) aor.
samura
, (S, M,) inf. n. samorN and sumuwrN, (M, K,) He held a conversation, or discourse, by night: (S:) or he waked; continued awake; did not sleep: (M, K:) and Asmr↓ may signify the same; or may be of the same class as Oahozala and Oasomana, and thus signify he had, or came to have, a samar [or conversation, or discourse, by night]. (M.) [See also 3.] ― -b2- samarati AlmaAXiyapu, aor.
samura
, inf. n. sumuwrN, (assumed tropical:) The cattle pastured by night without a pastor; or dispersed themselves by night: (M, TA:) [or simply pastured by night; for] one says, UinRa UibilanaA tasomuru, meaning (assumed tropical:) Verily our camels pasture by night: (TA:) and samarati AlUibilu layolatahaA kulRahaA (tropical:) The camels pastured during their night, the whole of it. (A.) And samarati AlmaAXiyapu AlnRabaAta (assumed tropical:) The cattle pastured upon the herbage; (M, K;) aor. as above: (M:) [or pastured upon the herbage by night: like as one says,] samara Alxamora (assumed tropical:) He drank mine, or the mine, (K, TA,) by night: (TA:) and baAtuwA yasomuruwna
Alxamora (tropical:) They passed, or spent, their night drinking wine, or the wine. (A.) ― -b3- See also samiyrN, in three places. ＝ -A2- samura, (S, M, Msb, K,) aor.
samura
; (K;) and samira, (S, K, in a copy of the M samara,) aor.
samara
; inf. n. of each sumorapN; (K;) and AsmArR↓, (S, M, K,) inf. n. AisomiyraArN; (S;) He, or it, was, or became, [tawny, brownish, dusky, or dark in complexion or colour; i. e.,] of the colour termed sumorap [expl. below]. (S, M, Msb, K.) ＝ -A3- smarahu: see 2, first signification. ― -b2- [Hence,] smara Eayonahu i. q. samalahaA, (M, K,) which signifies He put out, or blinded, (faqaOa,) his eye with a heated iron instrument: (S and Msb in art. sml:) or he put out, or blinded, (kaHala,) his eye with a misomaAr [or nail] (Mgh, Msb, TA) of iron (TA) made hot (Mgh, Msb, TA) in fire: (Msb:) or [simply] he put out, or blinded, his eye; syn. faqaOahaA. (K.) ＝ -A4- samara AllRabana: ＝ -A5- and samara somahu: see 2.

2 smRrhu c
2. smRrhu, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. tasomiyrN; (S;) and samarahu↓, (S, M, Mgh, &c.,) aor.
samura
(M, Msb, K) and
samira
, (M, K,) inf. n. samorN; (M, Msb;) or the former has an intensive signification; (Msb;) [He nailed it; i. e.] he made it fast, firm, or strong, (M, Mgh, K,) with a nail [or nails]; (S, * M, * Mgh, Msb, K; *) namely, a door [&c.]. (Mgh, Msb.) [See also sarodN.] ＝ -A2- smRr AllRabana, (M, TA,) inf. n. tasomiyrN; (S;) and samarahu↓, (K, TA,) aor.
samura
; (TA;) He made the milk thin with water; (S;) made it to be what is termed samaAr [q. v.]. (M, K.) ＝ -A3- smRr, inf. n. as above, is also syn. with XamRara (S, M, K) and Oarosala. (M, K.) You say, smRr sahomahu He discharged, or shot, his arrow; (M, TA;) as also samarahu↓: (K, TA:) or the former, he discharged it, or shot it, hastily; (K;) opposed to xaroqala; for one says, samRiro faqado OaxoTabaka AlSRayodu [Discharge, or shoot, thine arrow quickly, for the game has become within thy power], and xaroqilo HatRaI yuxoTibaka [Discharge, or shoot, deliberately, in order that it may become within thy power]. (IAar, TA.) One says also, smRr jaAriyatahu He dismissed his female slave, or let her go free. (S and M, from a trad.) A 'Obeyd says that this is the only instance in which smRr, with s, has been heard [in this sense: but several other instances have been mentioned]. (TA.) You also say, smRr AlUibila He let the camels go, or left them: and he hastened them; syn. kamRaXahaA; as also OasomarahaA↓; originally with X: (TA:) or he sent them, or left them, to pasture by themselves, without a pastor, by night [which is perhaps the more proper meaning (see 1)] or by day; syn. OahomalahaA. (M, TA.) And smRr AlsRafiynapa He sent off, or launched forth, the ship; let it go; or let it take its course. (M, TA.)

3 sAmrhu c
3. sAmrhu, (M,) inf. n. musaAmarapN, (S, A,) He held a conversation, or discourse, with him by night. (S, M.) [See also 1, first sentence.]

4 Oasomara
4: see 1: ― -b2- and samiyrN, in four places: ＝ -A2- and see also 2.

11 AsmArR c
11. AsmArR: see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph.

samarN c
samarN Conversation, or discourse, by night; (S, M, K;) as also musaAmarapN. (S, A. *) It is said in a trad., AlsRamaru baEoda AlEiXaMCi, or, accord. to one relation, AlsRamoru, Conversation or discourse by night is after nightfall. (TA.) And you say, laA OafoEaluhu AlsRamara waAlqamara I will not do it as long as men hold conversation or discourse in a night when the moon shines: (S:) or as long as men hold conversation or discourse by night, and as long as the moon rises: (Lh, M:) or ever. (M.) [See also below. The pl., OasomaArN, is often used as meaning Tales related in the night, for amusement: but this usage is probably post-classical.] ― -b2- (tropical:) Conversation, or discourse, by day. (TA.) ― -b3- A place in which people hold conversation or discourse by night; or in which they make, or remain awake; (M, K;) as also sAmirN↓; (S, * M, K;) which latter is expl. by Lth as signifying a place in which people assemble for conversation or discourse by night. (TA.) ― -b4- A people's assembling and holding conversation or discourse in the dark. (TA.) ― -b5- And hence, (TA,) The dark; or darkness. (As, M, K, TA.) So in the saying Halafa biAlsRamari waAlqamari He swore by the darkness and the moon. (As.) ― -b6- Night: (M, K:) you say, Oatayotuhu samarFA I came to him in the night. (A.) ― -b7- A night in which there is no moon: hence the saying laA OafoEalu celika AlsRamara waAlqamara I will not do that when the moon does not rise nor when it does rise. (Fr.) [See also above.] ― -b8- The shade of the moon. (M, K.) ― -b9- The light of the moon; moonlight; accord. to some, the primary signification; because they used to converse, or discourse, in it. (TA.) ― -b10- The time of daybreak: you say, Turiqa Alqawomu samarFA The people were come to at daybreak. (AHn, M.) ― -b11- See also samiyrN.

samurN c
samurN A certain kind of tree, (M, K,) well known; (K;) i. q.
