TaloHN [the gum-acacia-tree; acacia, or mimosa, gummifera]; (Msb;) or [a species] of the TaloH, (S,) of the kind called EiDaAh, (Mgh, Msb,) having small leaves, short thorns, and a yellow fruit (baramap) which men eat: there is no kind of EDAh better in wood: it is transported to the towns and villages, and houses are covered with it: (M:) its produce is [a pod] termed HubolapN [q. v.]: (TA in art. Hbl:) [the mimosa unguis cati of Forskål (Flora Aegypt. Arab., pp. cxxiii. and 176:)] n. un. samurapN: (M, Mgh, Msb, K:) [in the S, samurN is said to be pl. of samurapN: but it is a coll. gen. n.:] the pl. of samurapN is samuraAtN, and OasomurN, a pl. of pauc., of which the dim. is OusayomirN↓. (S.) It is said in a prov., OaXobaha XarojN XarojFA lawo OanRa OusayomirFA↓ [Sharj would resemble Sharj if a few gum-acacia-trees were found there: Sharj is a certain valley of El-Yemen: for the origin of this prov., see Freytag's Arab. Prov., i. 662]. (S.) yaA OaSoHaAba AlsRamurapi [O people of the gumacacia-tree], in a saying of the Prophet, was addressed to the persons meant in the Kur xlviii. 18. (Mgh.)

sumrapN c
sumrapN [A tawny, or brownish, colour, of various shades, like the various hues of wheat; (see Oasomaru;) duskiness; darkness of complexion or colour;] a certain colour, (S, Msb,) well known, (Msb,) between white and black, (M, K,) in men and in camels and in other things that admit of having it, but in camels the term OudomapN is more common, and accord. to IAar it is in water also; (M;) in men, the same as wuroqapN [in camels]; (IAar, TA;) a colour inclining to a faint blackness; (T, TA;) the colour of what is exposed to the sun, of a person of whom what is concealed by the clothes is white: (IAth:) from samarN signifying the “ shade of the moon. ” (TA.)

AlsRamarapu c
AlsRamarapu: see AlsRaAmirapu.

UibilN samuriyRapN c
UibilN samuriyRapN Camels that eat the tree called samur. (AHn, M, K.)

samaromarapN c
samaromarapN The [demon called] guwl. (Sgh, K.)

samaArN c
samaArN Thin milk: (S:) milk containing much water: (Th, M, K:) or [diluted] milk of which water composes two thirds: n. un. with p, signifying some thereof. (M.) ― -b2- [See also a tropical usage of this word in a prov. cited voce rabaDN.] ＝ -A2- [In the present day it is also applied to A species of rush, growing in the deserts of Lower and Upper Egypt, of which mats are made for covering the floors of rooms; the juncus spinosus of Forskål, (Flora Aegypt. Arab., p. 75,) who writes its Arabic name “ sammar; ” the juncus acutus β of Linn.]

samuwrN c
samuwrN, applied to a she-camel, (K, TA,) Swift: (K:) or generous, excellent, or strong and light, and swift. (TA.)

samiyrN c
samiyrN i. q. musaAmirN↓; (M, A, K;) i. e. A partner in conversation, or discourse, by night. (TA.) You say, OanaA samiyruhu and musaAmiruhu↓ [I am his partner &c.]. (A.) ― -b2- Afterwards used unrestrictedly [as signifying (assumed tropical:) A partner in conversation, or discourse, at any time]. (TA.) ― -b3- [Golius and Freytag add the meaning of A place of nocturnal confabulation; as from the K; a sense in which this word is not there found.] ― -b4- Aibonu samiyrK The night in which is no moon: [contr. of Aibonu vamiyrK:] a poet uses the phrase Qbonu samiyrK maA Oasomara↓, meaning As long as the moonless night allows the holding conversation, or discourse, in it. (M. [See also another explanation of this phrase in what follows.]) ― -b5- samiyrN is also syn. with dahorN [as meaning Unlimited time, or time without end]; (Lh, S, M, K;) as also samarN↓, (Fr, M, K,) whence the saying fulaAnN Einoda fulaAnK AlsRamara Such a one is with, or at the abode of, such a one ever, or always. (M.) Hence, or because people hold conversation, or discourse, in them, (S,) AibonaA samiyrK means The night and the day. (S, M, K.) You say, QbonaA samiyrK laA OafoEaluhu maA samara↓, (S, K,) and laA Mtiyka Alx, (M,) and Qbonu samiyrK maA samara↓, and AlsRamiyru maA samara↓, (M, K,) and QbonaA samiyrK maA Oasomara↓, and Qbonu maA Oasomara↓ samiyrK, (Lh, M, K,) and AlsRamiyru maA Oasomara↓, (K,) i. e. [I will not do it, and I will not come to thee,] ever, (S,) or in all time, (M,) or while night and day alternate. (K.) And laA OafoEaluhu samiyra AllRayaAliI (S, M) [I will not do it] to the end of the nights. (M.) ― -b6- AibonaA jaAlisK wasamiyrK is expl. by AHeyth, in
his handwriting, as meaning Two roads that differ, each from the other. (Az, TA.)

sumayoriyRapN c
sumayoriyRapN A certain kind of ships. (S.) [sumayoriIRN signifies the same, (Golius on the authority of Meyd.,) applied to A single ship of that kind.] ― -b2- IAar mentions the saying, OaEoTayotuhu sumayoriyRapF mino daraAhima kaOanRa AldRuxaAna yaxoruju minohaA, without explaining it: [ISd says,] I think he meant, [I gave him] daraAhim sumor, i. e. dusky dirhems, as though smoke were issuing from them by reason of their duskiness: or dirhems of which the whiteness was fresh. (M.)

samRuwrN c
samRuwrN [The sable; mustela zibellina, or viverra zibellina;] a certain beast, (Mgh, K,) or animal, (Msb,) well known, (Mgh,) found in Russia, beyond the country of the Turks, resembling the ichneumon; in some instances of a glossy black; and in some, of the [reddish] colour termed Xuqorap: (Msb, TA:) costly furred garments are made of its skin: (K, TA:) pl. samaAmiyru. (Msb.) ― -b2- Also A jubRap [or any garment] made with its fur. (TA.)

simRiyrN c
simRiyrN A companion of [or one who habitually indulges in] conversation, or discourse, by night. (M, K.)

saAmirN c
saAmirN A man holding, or who holds, a conversation, or discourse, by night: (S:) pl. sumRaArN (S, M, K) and sumRarN. (TA.) It is also a quasi-pl. n., (M, K,) [as such occurring in a verse cited voce murimRN, in art. rm,] and is syn. [as such] with sumRaArN, signifying persons holding, or who hold, conversation, or discourse, by night: (S, M:) or persons waking, continuing awake, not sleeping; as also saAmirapN↓ [a fem. sing., and therefore applicable as an epithet to a broken pl. and to a quasi-pl. n. and to a coll. gen. n.]: (M, K:) saAmirN is a pl. [or rather quasi-pl. n.] applicable to males and to females: (T, TA:) or it is a sing., and, like other sings., is used as a qualificative of a pl. only when the latter is determinate; as in the phrase tarakotuhumo saAmirFA [I left them holding a conversation & c.]. (Lh, M.) ― -b2- Also A camel pasturing by night. (TA.) ― -b3- See also samarN.

saAmirapN c
saAmirapN: see saAmirN. ＝ -A2- AlsRaAmirapu (M, Msb, K) and AlsRamarapu↓ (TA) [The Samaritans; a people said to be] one of the tribes of the Children of Israel; (M;) or a sect, (Msb,) or people, (K,) of the Jews, differing from them (Msb, K) in most, (Msb,) or in some, (K,) of their institutes: (Msb, K:) Zj says, they remain to this time in Syria, and are known by the appellation of AlsRaAmiriyRuwna↓: (M:) most of them are in the mountain of n-Nábulus: (TA:) saAmiriIRN↓ is the rel. n. of AlsRaAmirapu. (M, Msb, K.)

saAmiriIRN c
saAmiriIRN, and its pl.: see the next preceding paragraph.

Oasomaru c
Oasomaru [Tawny, or brownish; dusky; dark-complexioned or dark-coloured;] of the colour termed sumorapN [q. v.]: (S, M, K, & c.:) fem samoraMCu: (Msb, & c.:) and pl. sumorN. (A.) You say baEiyrN Oasomaru A camel of a white colour inclining to Xuhobap [which is a hue wherein whiteness predominates over blackness]. (M.) And qanaApN samoraMCu [A tawny spearshaft]. (M.) And HinoTapN samoraMCu [Tawny wheat]. (M.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AlsRamoraMCu Wheat: (S, Msb, K:) because of its colour. (Msb.) And AlOasomaraAni Wheat and water: (AO, S, K:) or water and the spear. (S, K.) ― -b3- AlOasomaru, also, signifies Milk: (M:) or milk of the gazelle: (IAar, M, K:) app. because of its colour. (M.) ― -b4- And [for the same reason] AlsRamoraMCu signifies also Coarse flour, or flour of the third quality, full of bran; syn. xuXokaArN. (K.) You say AlsRamoraMCu Bread made of such flour. (L in art. xubozu AlsRamoraMCi.) ― -b5- And The [kind of milking-vessel called] xrj. (Sgh, K.) ― -b6- And EaAmN Oasomaru (assumed tropical:) A year of drought, in which is no rain. (M.)

OusayomirN c
OusayomirN dim. of OasomurN: see samurN, in two places.

misomaArN c
misomaArN A nail; a pin, or peg, of iron; (Mgh;) a certain thing of iron; (S, K) a thing with which one makes fast, firm, or strong: (M, K:) pl. masaAmiyru. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- Also, (K, TA,) or misoamAruUibilK, (A, O,) (tropical:) A good manager of camels; (A, O, K, TA;) a skilful, good pastor thereof. (A.)

masomuwrN c
masomuwrN Nailed; made fast, firm, or strong, with a nail [or nails]. (S, * Mgh.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A man, (TA,) having little flesh, strongly knit in the bones and sinews. (K, TA.) ― -b3- And, with p, (tropical:) A woman, (M,) or girl, or young woman, (A, O, K,) compact, or firm, in body, (M, A, O, K,) not flabby in flesh. (M, O, K.) ＝ -A2- EayoXN masomuwrN (tropical:) A turbid life: (M, O, * K, * TA:) from samaArN applied to milk. (M, TA.)

musaAmirN c
musaAmirN: see samiyrN, in two places.

Q. 1 samorajapN c
Q. 1. samorajapN [inf. n. of samoraja] The collecting of the [tax called] xaraAj: (Ibn-'Abbád, O:) [and the giving, or paying, thereof: for] one says, samorijo lahu, meaning Give thou to him [the tax so called]. (ISh, O, K. [It seems to be intentionally indicated in the O and K, by what immediately precedes the explanation of this phrase, which explanation is OaEoTihi, that AlxaraAja is to be understood after it.])

smrj c
smrj [written without any syll. signs, and therefore probably samorajo,] sing. of samaAriju, (TA,) which signifies Even, or plain, places [or tracts] of land. (T, * Ibn-'Abbád, O, TA. *)

samarRajN c
samarRajN and samarRajapN↓, (S, O, K,) each a Pers. word arabicized, (S, O,) [or rather a compound of the Pers. siho “ three ” and the Arabic marRaho for marRap “ a time, ”] The levying of the [tax called] xaraAj at three several times [or instalments]: (S, O, K:) or the name of the day on which payment of the xaraAj is received; (K;) thus the former word is expl. by ISh; (O;) the day of the collecting of the xrAj; (Ibn-'Abbád, ISd, O, TA;) a day when the foreigners, or Persians, (AlEajam) levy the xrAj at three several times [or instalments]: also mentioned as written with X. (TA.)

samarRajapN c
samarRajapN: see the next preceding parapraph.

samRaAsN c
samRaAsN: see art. sm.

Q. 1 samosara c
Q. 1. samosara, inf. n. samosarapN, He acted as a simosaAr [q. v.]. (K.)

simosAarN c
simosAarN A broker; or one who acts as an intermediary between the seller and the buyer, (Lth, Mgh, K,) for effecting the sale; whom people call dalRaAlN, because he directs the purchaser to the merchandise, and the seller to the price: (TA:) pl. samaAsirapN: (Mgh, K:) a Pers. word, arabicized: (Lth, Mgh:) or one who sells wheat to the people: (M, TA:) or (TA, in the K “ and ”) the possessor of a thing: (K:) or (TA, in the K “ and ”) one who has the care of a thing. (K.) ― -b2- (tropical:) A messenger, or mediator, (safiyrN,) between two lovers or friends. (K.) ― -b3- simosaAru AlOaroDi (tropical:) He who is acquainted with the land, or country; (K;) an acute scrutinizer of its circumstances: (TA:) fem. with p. (K.) ― -b4- huwa Qbonu simosaArihaA [app. means (assumed tropical:) He is the careful and skilful manager of it]. (Fr, TA voce HilsN.)

1 smaTahu c
1. smaTahu, and
samuTa
, and
samiTa
, (S, M, Msb, K,) inf. n. samoTN, (S, M, Msb,) namely, a kid, (S, M, Msb, K,) and a lamb, (M,) He removed its hair, (Msb,) or wool, (K,) or cleansed it of the hair, [or wool,] (S,) by means of hot water; (S, Msb, K;) in order to roast it; (S;) or it is generally done for this purpose: (TA:) or he plucked from it the [hair, or] wool, after putting it into hot water. (A.) ― -b2- [And It scalded it: for] you say, of boiling water, yasomuTu AlXRaIoCa [it scalds the thing]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- samaTahu, (M, K,) inf. n. as above, (M,) also signifies He hung it; suspended it; namely, a thing; (M, K;) as also smRThu↓, inf. n. tasomiyTN: (TA:) or the latter, he hung it, or suspended it, upon, (S, K,) or by means of, (so in some copies of the K and in the TA,) sumuwT, (S, K,) meaning thongs, or straps. (TA.) And AlcRiroEa smRT↓, (M,) inf. n. tasomiyTN, (TA,) He hung the coat of mail upon the hinder part of his horse. (M.)

2 samRaTa
2: see 1, in two places. ― -b2- samRaTotu AlXRaIoCa, inf. n. tasomiytN, also signifies I kept, or clave, to the thing: hence a verse cited voce dariynN. (TA in art. drn.)

5 tsmRT c
5. tsmRT It (a thing, TA) was, or became, hung, or suspended. (K.)

simoTN c
simoTN A thread, or string, having upon it beads
(S, Mgh) or pearls; (Mgh;) otherwise it is called silokN: (S, Mgh:) a string of beads or the like; (M, K;) so called because it is hung, or suspended; (M;) a single string thereof; like yako rasano [in Persian]; a necklace of two strings thereof being called caAtu simoTayoni: (IDrd:) or it signifies, (M,) or signifies also, (K,) a necklace longer than the mixonaqap: (IDrd, M, K:) or [simply] a necklace: (Msb:) pl. sumuwTN: (M, K:) which also signifies the things that are suspended (maEaAliyqu) from necklaces. (TA.) ― -b2- A thong, or strap, that is suspended from the horse's saddle; (S, K;) sing. of sumuwTN. (S.) ― -b3- The redundant part of the turban, which is left hanging down upon the breast and the shoulder-blades: (K:) pl. as above. (TA.) ― -b4- A coat of mail which the horseman hangs upon the hinder part of his horse. (M, K.) ― -b5- (tropical:) A trail, or long and elevated tract, (Habol,) of sand, (K, TA,) regularly disposed, as though it were a necklace. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also sumuTN, in two places.

naEolN sumuTN c
naEolN sumuTN, (M, K,) and samiyTN↓, (S, M, K,) and OasomaATN↓, (M, K,) which last is pl. of samiyTN, (TA,) A sandal, or sole, that is of a single piece [of leather, not of two or more pieces sewed together, one upon another], (TaAqN waAHidN, S, TA,) in which is no patch: (S, M, K:) or the last, (S,) or all, (M,) not having a second piece sewed on to it; (AZ, S, M;) as also simoTN↓. (So in the K, voce farodN.) ― -b2- [vawobN sumuTN (the latter word occurring twice in art. ljf in the TA, and there opposed to mubaTRanN, and said to be masc. and fem.,) i. q.] vawobN simoTN↓ A garment having no lining; [either] a TayolasaAn, or such as is of cotton: (ISh, K:) but one does not say kisaMCN simoTN nor miloHafapN simoTN, because such are not [ever] lined: (ISh:) or [accord. to some] simoTN signifies a garment that is lined below; expl. by saying, Oawi AlsRimoTu mina AlvRiyaAbi maA ZuhRira mino taHotu, (K, TA, [in the CK, and in a MS. copy of the K, for ZuhRira, we find Zahara,]) i. e. juEila lahu ZahorN: (TA:) [but I think that Zahara is undoubtedly the right reading; and that simoTN means any portion that appears of a garment worn beneath a shorter garment:] see sanadN, last sentence. ― -b3- saraAwiylu OasomaATN↓ Trousers, or drawers, not stuffed: (M, K:) i. e., (K,) or, as Th says, (M,) of single cloth, TaAqN waAHidN. (M, K.) ― -b4- naAqapN sumuTN, (Kr, M, K,) and OasomaATN↓, (K,) A she-camel without any brand, or mark made by a hot iron. (Kr, M, K.) ＝ -A2- sumuTN is also a pl. of simaATN [q. v.]. (K.)

simaATN c
simaATN A rank of people: (M, K:) or a side, or lateral part or portion: (Msb:) each of the two sides, or lateral portions, of men, and of palmtrees. (S, Msb.) You say, qaAma bayona AlsRimaATayoni He stood between the two ranks. (TA.) And qaAma Alqawoma Hawolahu simaATayoni The people stood around him in two ranks. (TA.) And humo EalaI simaATK waAHidK They are according to one order. (K.) And maXaI bayona AlsRimaATayoni He walked between the two sides. (S, Msb.) And xucuwA simaATaIi AlTRariIRi Take ye the two sides of the fresh, or moist. (TA.) And AijoEali AlOamora simaATFA waAHidFA Make thou the affair, or case, [uniform, or] one uniform thing. (Fr, TA in art. bOj.) ― -b2- The part of a valley which is between the upper extremity and the lower: (M, K:) pl. sumuTN. (K) ― -b3- simaATu AlTRaEaAmi The thing upon which food is spread: (K:) pronounced by the vulgar sumaAT: [and applied by them to such as is long, prepared for a large company of people:] pl. OasomiTapN [a pl. of pauc.] and simaATaAtN. (TA.)

samiyTN c
samiyTN and masomuwTN↓, applied to a kid, (S, M, Msb, K,) and to a lamb, (M,) Of which the hair, (Msb,) or wool, (K,) has been removed, (Msb, K,) or cleansed of its hair [or wool], (S,) by means of hot water; (S, Msb, K;) in order to its being roasted: (S:) or of which the [hair or] wool has been plucked off from it, after its having been put into hot water: (M:) or the former, plucked of its [hair or] wool, and then roasted with its skin: (Lth:) and a roasted sheep or goat: the former word of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also samiyTN, and its pl. OasomaATN, voce sumuTN; the pl. in three places.

saAmiTN c
saAmiTN Boiling water, that scalds (yasomuTu) a thing. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Hanging a thing by a rope behind him; from AlsRumuwTu [pl. of AlsRimoTu]. (TA.)

masomuwTN c
masomuwTN: see samiyTN.

1 samiEahu c
1. samiEahu, (S, Msb, K, *) aor.
samaEa
, (K,) inf. n. samoEN (S Msb, K) and simoEN, or this latter is a simple subst., (Lh, K,) and samaAEN, (S, K,) or this last [also] is a simple subst., (Msb,) and samaAEapN and samaAEiyapN (K) and masomaEN, (TA,) [He heard it, (namely, a thing, as in the S,) or (tropical:) him;] and tsmRE↓, (Msb, K,) also written and pronounced AisRamRaEa; (K, TA;) and AstmE↓; (Msb;) are syn. with samiEa (Msb,K) as trans. By itself; (Msb;) and AstmE [also] in sys. With samiEa [ as trans. by itself]: (Ham p. 694, where occurs a usage of its act. part. n. showing the verb to be trans. by itself:) or AstmE↓ denotes what is intentional, signifying only he gave ear, hearkened, or listened: but samiEa, [as also tmsmRE↓ and AstsmE↓,] what is unintentional, as well as what is intentional. (Msb.) You say, samiEa AlXRaIoCa [He heard or listened to, the thing] (S.) And AlSRawota tsmRE↓ [He listened to, or heard, the sound]. (TA.) [And samiEotu lahu SawotFA I heard him, or it, utter, or produce, a sound; lit. I heard a sound attributable to him, or it. And samiEahu minohu He heard it form him. And samiEahu Eanohu He heard it as related from him; he heard it on his authority. And samiEahu yaquwlu kacaA He heard him say such a thing.] And samiEa bihi [He heard of it; for samiEa AltRakalRuma bihi, or the like]. (Kur xii. 31 and xxviii. 36 and xxxviii. 6, S, K, TA.) [When trans. by means of li alone, or UilaI, it denotes what is intentional.] You say, samiEotu lahu, (S, Msb, TA,) and Uilayohi, (S, TA,) meaning I gave ear, hearkened, or listened, to him, or it; (S, Msb, * TA;) and lh tsmREt↓ (Msb,) or Alyh, and AisRamRaEotu, (S, TA,) signify the same; (S, Msb, TA;) and so lh AstmEt↓, (S, Msb, K,) and Alyh. (K.) It is said in the Kur [xxxvii. 8], accord. to different readings, laA yasomaEuwna UilaI AlmalaUi AlOaEolaI, and laA yasRamRaEuwna↓, They shall not listen [to the archangels]: (S:) or the former has this signification, they shall not listen to the angels (Bd, Jel) in heaven, (Jel,) or the exalted angels: (Bd:) and ↓the latter, they shall not seek, or endeavour, to listen &c. (Bd.) And in the same [xvii. 50], naHonu OaEolamu bimaA yasotamiEuwna↓ bihi Uico yasotamiEuwna Uilayoka [We are cognizant of that on account of which they hearken when they hearken to thee]; bh meaning bisababihi, (Bd, Jel,) and liOajolihi, (Bd,) alluding to scoffing, or derision. (Bd, Jel.) [For various usages of samoEN and other inf. ns., whether employed as inf. ns. or as simple substs., see those words below.] ― -b2- It also signifies He understood it; (TA;) he understood its meaning; i. e., the meaning of a person's speech. (Msb.) You say, lamo tasomaEo maA qulotu laka Thou didst not understand what I said to thee. (TA.) And such is the most obvious meaning of the verb in the saying, Uino kaAna yasomaEu AlxaTiyba [If he understand the words of the preacher]; for this is the proper meaning in this case: but it may be rendered tropically, (tropical:) if he hear the voice of the preacher. (Msb.) ― -b3- Also He knew it: as in the saying, samiEa QllRehu qawolaka [God knew thy saying]. (Msb.) ― -b4- Also (assumed tropical:) He accepted it; namely, evidence, and praise: or, said of the latter, (assumed tropical:) he recompensed it by acceptance: (Msb:) (tropical:) he paid regard to it, and answered it; namely, prayer: (tropical:) he answered, or assented to, or complied with, it; namely, a person's speech. (TA.) The saying samiEa QllRehu limano Hamidahu means May God accept the praise of him who praiseth Him: or, accord. to IAmb, may God recompense by acceptance the praise of him who praiseth Him: (Msb:) or may God answer the prayer of him who praiseth Him. (TA, as on the authority of IAmb.) ― -b5- Also (assumed tropical:) He obeyed him: as in the saying in the Kur [xxxvi. 24], UinRiI Mmanotu birabRikumo faQsomaEuwni (assumed tropical:) [Verily I believe in your Lord, and do ye obey me]. (TA.) ― -b6- Lth says that the phrase samiEato OucuniI zayodFA yafoEalu kacaA wakacaA means (assumed tropical:) My eye saw Zeyd doing such and such things: but Az says, I know not whence Lth brought this; for it is not of the way of the Arabs to say smEt AcnI as meaning my eye saw: it is in my judgment corrupt language, and I am not sure but that it may have been originated by those addicted to innovations and erroneous opinions. (TA.)

2 tasomiyEN c
2. tasomiyEN [inf. n of smRE, as also tasomiEapN, q. v. infrà, voce sumoEapN,] is syn. with UisomaAEN↓ [The making one to hear]. (K.) You say, smREhu AlSRawota and AsmEhu↓ [He made him to hear the sound]. (S.) And smREhu AlHadiyva (TA) and AsmEhu↓ (S, TA) [He made him to hear the narra-
tive]; both signifying the same. (TA.) [And smRE bihi He made to hear of it, or him.] It is said in a trad., mano samRaEa AlnRaAsa biEamalihi samRaEa QllRehu bihi OasaAmiEa xaloqihi waHaqRarahu waSagRarahu (S, * Mgh, TA) [Whoso maketh men to hear of his deed,] God will make the ears of his creatures to hear of him on the day of resurrection; (TA;) or whoso maketh his deed notorious, that men may see it and hear of it, God will make notorious his hypocrisy, and fill with it the ears of his creatures, and they shall be generally acquainted with it, [and He will render him contemptible, and small in estimation,] so that he will become disgraced; (Mgh;) or the meaning may be, God will manifest to men his internal state, and fill their ears with the evilness of his secret intentions, in requital of his deed: or, as some relate it, [for OasaAmiEa xaloqihi] we should say, saAmiEu xaloqihi, which is an epithet applied to God; so that the meaning is, Go [the Hearer of his creatures] will disgrace him: (TA:) [for] ― -b2- smRE bh, (S, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. tasomiyEN, (S, Mgh, K,) signifies [also] He rendered him, or it, notorious, and infamous: (S, Mgh, K: *) or he spread it abroad, for men to speak of it. (Msb.) ― -b3- Also He raised him from obscurity to fame. (S, K. *) ― -b4- And He made him to hear what was bad, evil, abominable, or foul, and he reviled him: (AZ, T and L in art. nd:) and AsmEhu↓ [also] has the latter of these two significations. (S, K.)

4 AsmEhu c
4. AsmEhu, inf. n. UisomaAEN: see 2, in four places. ― -b2- He told him [a thing]. (Msb) ― -b3- He made him to understand: the verb being used in this sense in the Kur [viii. 23], lawoEalima QllRehu fiyhimo xayorFA laOasomaEahumo [Had God known any good in them, He had made them to understand]. (TA.) ― -b4- OasomaEaka QllRehu May God not make thee to be deaf. (TA.) ― -b5- OasomaEato She sang. (TA.) One says to a female singer, OasomiEiynaA Sing thou to us: thus used in a verse of Tarafeh. (TA.) ― -b6- OasomaEota Thou hast said a saying that ought to be heard and followed. (Har p. 398.) ＝ -A2- AsmE AldRalowa (tropical:) He made, or put, a misomaE [q. v.] to the bucket. (S, K, TA.) And in like manner, AsmE AlzRinobiyla (K) (tropical:) He made, or put, what are termed misomaEaAni to the basket. (TA.) ＝ -A3- OasomiEo bihimo waOaboSiro; and OaboSiro bihi waOasomiEo; see art. bSr.

5 tasamRaEa c
5. tasamRaEa, also written and pronounced AisRamRaEa: see 1, in the former half of the paragraph, in six places.

6 tsAmE bihi AlnRaAsu c
6. tsAmE bihi AlnRaAsu (S, K) The people heard of it, [or him,] one from another: (PS, TK:) [or the people heard one another talk of it, or him:] or it, or he, became notorious among the people. (TA.) ― -b2- tsAmE also signifies He feigned himself hearing. (KL.)

8 UisotamaEa
8: see 1, in the former half of the paragraph, in four places.

10 UisotasomaEa
10: see 1, in the first sentence, in two places.

samoEN c
samoEN inf. n. of samiEa, (S, Msb, K,) like samaAEN↓, (S, K,) [&c.,] or the latter is a simple subst. [used in the abstract sense of the former]. (Msb.) You say, samoEFA waTaAEapF, [for OasomaEu samoEFA waOuTiyEu TaAEapF, an emphatic mode of expression, meaning I hear and I obey, or for samiEotu samoEFA waOaTaEotu TaAEapF, which means the same, but more emphatically; TaAEapF being a quasi-inf. n. for UiTaAEapF;] the verb [of each] being understood: and samoEN waTaAEapN, meaning OamoriI celika [i. e. OamoriI samoEN waTaAEapN My affair is hearing and obeying]. (K.) You say also, [in like manner,] AallRehumRa samoEFA laA balogFA, (K,) and samoEN laA balogN: (TA:) see simoEN. And samoEu OucuniI fulaAnFA yaquwla celika, (K,) [said to be] the only instance of the kind among inf. ns. of trans. verbs except raOoIu EayoniI, (TA in art. rOI,) [in a copy of the M, in art. rOI, written samoEa AcnI and raOoIa EynI,] and AcnI simoEu↓, and AcnI samoEapu↓, and AcnI simoEapu↓ [My ear heard (lit. my ear's hearing) such a one say that]. (K) ― -b2- [As a simple subst., it signifies] The sense of the ear; (K;) [i. e., of hearing;] the faculty in the ear whereby it perceives sounds. (TA.) Thus in the Kur [1. 36], Oawo OaloqaI AlsRamoEu, (TA,) meaning, Or who hearkeneth. (Bd, Jel.) [And hence,] OumRu AlsRamoEi The brain; (Z, O, K;) as also OumRu AlsRamiyEi↓. (O, K.) One says, Darabahu EalaI OumRi AlsRamoEi [He struck him upon the brain]. (TA.) ― -b3- [It is also used for the inf. n. of OasomaEa. Hence] one says, qaAluwA celika samoEa OucuniI, and in like manner, AcnI simoEa↓, and AcnI samaAEa↓, and AcnI samaAEapa↓, i. e. UisomaAEahaA [They said that making my ear to hear]: (K:) and one may say, samoEFA [making to hear]: this latter one says when he does not particularize himself. (Sb, K.) And kalRamahu simoEahumo↓, with kesr, meaning, [He spoke to him making them to hear, or] so that they heard. (TA.) And a poet says,
QllRehi waAlEulamaMCi OanRiI samaAEa↓
OaEuwcu bixayori xaAlika yaAQbona Eamoriw
[Making God and the learned men to hear that I seek protection by the goodness of thy maternal uncle, O son of 'Amr; or OaEuwcu biHaqowi xaAlika, i. e. I have recourse for protection to thy maternal uncle; thus in the TA in art. Hqw;] using the subst. in the place of the inf. n., as though he said UisomaAEFA EanRiI. (TA.) One says also, Oaxacotu celika Eanohu samoEFA, and in like manner, samaAEFA↓, [i. e. I received that from him by being made to hear, which virtually means, by hearsay, or hearing it from him,] making the inf. n. [in each case] to be of a different form from that of the verb to which it belongs [in respect of signification; i. e., using an inf. n. of samiEa for that of OasomaEa]. (K, * TA.) [See also sumoEapN.] ― -b4- It also signifies The ear; (S, * Mgh, Msb, * K;) as also misomaEN↓, (S, Msb, K, TA,) because it is the instrument of hearing, (TA,) and masomaEN↓, [because it is the place thereof,] (Aboo-Jebeleh, TA,) and saAmiEapN↓; (S, K;) or misomaEN↓ signifies the ear-hole; (TA;) and so masomaEN↓, and musotamaEN↓: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and samoEN is also used as a pl., (S, K,) being originally an inf. n.; but sometimes (S) it has for its pl. OasomaAEN (S, Msb, K) and OasomuEN, (Mgh, O, K,) a pl. of pauc., (TA,) [as is also the former,] and OasaAmiEu is a pl. pl., (S, Mgh, O, K,) i. e. pl. of OasomaAEN, (S,) or of OasomuEN: (Mgh, O:) [for an ex. of the pl. pl., see 2:] the pl. of misomaEN↓ is masaAmiEu; (Msb, K;) or this may be an irreg. pl. of samoEN, like as maXaAbihu is of XabahN. (Sgh, TA.) You say, samoEuka UilaIRa i. e. [Incline thine ear to me; or] hear thou from me. (S, K.) And Taraqa AlkalaAmu AlsRamoEu [The speech struck the ear]. (Msb.) samoEN is used as a pl. in the Kur [ii. 6], where it is said, xatama QllRehu EalaI quluwbihimo waEalaI samiEohimo [God hath set a seal upon their hearts and upon their ears]. (S.) One also says, fulaAnN EaZiymu AlmisomaEayoni↓ Such a one is great in the ears. (S.) The phrase huwa bayona samoEi AlOaroDi wabaSarihaA means (assumed tropical:) It is not known whither he has repaired: (AZ, K:) or he is between the ears of the people of the land and their eyes, [so that they neither hear him nor see him,] the prefixed noun Oahol being suppressed: (AO, K, * TA:) or (assumed tropical:) in a void land, wherein is no one; (ISk, K;) i. e., none hears his speech, nor does any see him, except [the wild animals of] the desert land: (K:) or (tropical:) between the length and breadth of the land. (K, TA.) You say also, OaloqaI nafosahu bayona samoEi AlOaroDi wabaSarihaA (assumed tropical:) He exposed himself to perdition, or imperilled himself, and cast himself no one knew where: (IAar, Th:) or (assumed tropical:) he cast himself where no voice of man was heard, nor eye of man seen. (K, * TA.) ― -b5- Also What rests in the ear, of a thing which one hears. (L, K.) ― -b6- See also simoEN, in three places, beside the two places before referred to.

simoEN c
simoEN i. q. samoEN, either as an inf. n. or as a a simple subst. (Lh, K.) You say, AallRehumRa simoEFA laA bilogFA, (S, K,) and laA balogFA samoEFA↓, (K,) and simoEN laA bilogN, and laA balogN samoEN↓, (TA,) a form of prayer, (K,) meaning O God, may it be heard of but not fulfilled: (S, K:) or may it be heard but not come to: or may it be heard but not need to be come to: or it is said by him who hears tidings not pleasing to him: (K:) Ks says that it means I hear of calamities but may they not come to me. (TA.) You say also, simoEu OucuniI fulaAnFA yaquwlu celika: see samoEN. ― -b2- Also i. q. UisomaAEN: so in the phrase qaAluwA celika simoEa OucuniI: (K:) and in the phrase kalRamahu simoEahumo: (TA:) both explained above: see samoEN. ― -b3- Also Mention, fame, report, that is heard; as also samoEN↓, and samaAEN↓: (K:) fame, or good report; (S, Msb, K, TA;) and so samoEN↓ and samaAEN↓. (TA.) You say, cahaba simoEuhu fiI AlnRaAsi His fame, or good report, went among mankind. (S.) And the Arabs say, QllRehi laA wasamoEi↓ [or wasimoEi AllReh,] meaning laA wa cikori QllRehi [No, by the glory of God]. (TA.) ― -b4- [It is also used as an
epithet: thus,] rajulN simoEN means yusamRiEu [A man who makes others to hear of him]: or one says, hecaA QmoruWN cuw simoEK, and cuwsamaAEK↓, [This is a man of fame, or notoriety], (K,) whether good or bad. (Lh, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A certain mongrel beast of prey, (S,) the offspring of the wolf, begotten from the hyena: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) fem. with p: they assert that it does not die a natural death, like the serpent, (K, TA,) but by some accident that befalls it, not knowing diseases and maladies; and that it is unequalled by any other animal in running, (TA,) its running being quicker than [the flight of] the bird; and its leap exceeding thirty cubits, (K, TA,) or twenty. (TA.) It is said in a prov., mina AlsRimoEi AlOazalRi OasomaEu↓ [More quick of hearing than the smE that is lean in the buttocks and thighs; or than the light, or active, smE]: and sometimes they said OasomaEu mino simoEK [more quick of hearing than a smE]. (S.)

samoEapN c
samoEapN A single hearing, or hearkening, or listening. (K.) ― -b2- samoEapu OucuniI fulaAnFA yaquwlu celika: see samoEN. ― -b3- See also sumoEapN. ＝ -A2- OucunN samoEapN: see saAmiEN.

sumoEapN c
sumoEapN is syn. with tasomiyEN, like as suxorapN is with tasoxiyrN. (TA.) You say, faEalahu riYaMCF wasumoEapF He did it [to make men to see it and hear of it, or] in order that men might see it and hear of it. (S.) And maAfaEalahu riYaMCF walaAsumoEapF, and samoEapF↓, and samaEapF↓, He did it not making it notorious so as to make [men] to see and to hear [it]. (K.) And faEalotuhu tasomiEataka↓, and tasomiEapF laka, I did it in order that thou mightest hear it. (AZ, K.) [See also samoEN, where similar phrases are mentioned and explained.] ― -b2- AlsRumoEapu, also, signifies What is heard, of fame, or report, &c.: (Har p. 34:) and [particularly] good report. (Id. p. 196.)

simoEapN c
simoEapN A mode, or manner, of hearing, hearkening, or listening. (K.) You say, samiEotuhu simoEapF HasanapF [I heard it with a good manner of hearing]. (TA.) ― -b2- simoEapu OucuniI fulaAnFA yaquwlu celika: see samoEN.

samaEapN c
samaEapN: see sumoEapN. ＝ -A2- OucunN samaEapN: see saAmiEN.

OucunN samiEapN c
OucunN samiEapN: see saAmiEN.

sumoEunRapN nuZorunRapN c
sumoEunRapN nuZorunRapN, and simoEanRapN niZoranRapN, (S, K,) the former accord. to AZ, the latter accord. to ElAh, (S,) and simoEinRapN niZorinRapN, (K,) or the second and third are without teshdeed, and mentioned by Yaakoob also, (TA in art. nZr, [but this, I think, is a mistake,]) applied to a woman, Who listens, or hearkens, and endeavours to see, and, not seeing nor hearing anything, thinks it, or opines it: (S, * K, * [the latter in art. nZr,] and TA:) and one also applies to her the epithet simoEanapN, meaning who listens, or hearkens, and does so much, or habitually. (K.)

samaEomaEN c
samaEomaEN (of the measure faEaloEalN, S) Small in the head, (S, K,) and in the body; for Aw AllRiHoyapi in the K is a mistranscription for waAljuvRapi: (TA:) cunning, or very cunning: (K, TA:) light of flesh, quick in work, wicked, and clever: (TA:) or [simply] light and quick: and applied as an epithet to a wolf. (K.) ― -b2- Also A woman that grins and frowns in thy face when thou enterest, and wails after thee when thou goest forth. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- And A tall and slender man: (K, TA:) fem. in this sense with p. (TA.) ― -b4- And A wicked, deceitful, or crafty, devil. (TA.)

samaAEK c
samaAEK [an imperative verbal n.] Hear thou: (S, K:) like daraAki and manaAEi, meaning Oadoriko and AimonaEo. (S.)

samaAEN c
samaAEN: see its syn. samoEN; first sentence. ― -b2- Also syn. with UisomaAEN, as in three exs. expl. above; see samoEN, in the middle portion of the paragraph. ― -b3- Also [an inf. n. used in the sense of a pass. part. n., meaning What has been heard, or heard of:] a thing that one has heard of, and that has become current, and talked of. (TA.) [Hence, used in lexicology and grammar as meaning What has been received by hearsay; i. e. what is established by received usage: as in the phrase, maqoSuwrN EalaI AlsRamaAEi restricted to what has been received by hearsay; &c.: and in the phrase XaAcRN fiI AlsRamaAEi deviating from the constant course of speech with respect to what has been receeived by hearsay; &c.; which virtually means deviating from what is established by received usage: “ what has been received by hearsay ” always meaning “ what has been heard, either immediately or mediately, from one or more of the Arabs of the classical times. ”] ― -b4- [Also What is heard, or being heard, of discourse, or narration, and of matters of science. See an ex. voce muricRN, in art. rc.] ― -b5- And [hence,] Singing, or song; and any [musical performance whether vocal or instrumental or both combined, or any other] pleasant sound in which the ears take delight: as in the saying, baAta fiI lahowK wasamaAEK [He passed the night in the enjoyment of diversion and singing, &c.]. (TA.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce muXaArN, in art. Xwr.] ― -b6- See also simoEN, in three places.

samuwEN c
samuwEN: see saAmiEN, in two places.

samiyEN c
samiyEN: see saAmiEN, in six places. ― -b2- It is also syn. with musomiEN [Making to hear; &c.]. (S, K.) Az remarks its being wonderful that persons should explain it as having this meaning in order to avoid the assigning to God the attribute of hearing, since that attribute is assigned to Him in more than one place in the Kur-án, though his hearing is not like the hearing of his creatures: he, however, adds, I do not deny that, in the language of the Arabs, smyE may be syn. with saAmiEN or musomiEN; but it is mostly syn. with saAmiEN, like as EaliymN is with EaAlimN, and qadiyrN with qaAdirN. (TA.) ― -b3- Also [Made to hear; or] told; applied to a man. (Msb.) ― -b4- OumRu AlsRamiyEi: see samoEN. ＝ -A2- AlsRamiyEaAni Two long pieces of wood [fixed] in the yoke with which the bull is yoked for ploughing the land. (Lth, TA.)

samaAEapN c
samaAEapN an inf. n. of samEa. (K.) ― -b2- And i. q. UisomaAEN, whence a phrase expl. above: see samoEN.

samaAEiIRN c
[samaAEiIRN, in lexicology and grammar, applied to a word &c., means Relating, or belonging, to what has been received by hearsay; i. e., to what is established by received usage. See samaAEN.]

sumRaEN c
sumRaEN Light, active, or agile: and applied as an epithet to a guwl. (K.)

samRaAEN c
samRaAEN One who hearkens, or listens, much to what is said, and utters it. (TA.) [Its primary signification is simply One who hears, hearkens, or listens, much, or habitually: and it signifies also quick of hearing.] See also saAmiEN. ― -b2- A spy, who searches for information, and brings it. (TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) Obedient. (TA.)

saAmiEN c
saAmiEN and samiyEN↓ are syn.; [signifying Hearing; and hearkening, or listening;] (Az, S, Msb, K;) like EaAlimN and EaliymN, and qaAdirN and qadiyrN. (Az, TA.) [AlsRamiyEu↓, applied to God, signifies He whose hearing comprehends everything; who hears everything. (TA.) And [hence, also,] ↓this same epithet is applied to The lion that hears the faint sound (K, TA) of man and of the prey (TA) from afar. (K, TA.) You say also, OucunN saAmiEapN, and samiyEapN↓, and samiyEN↓, and samoEapN↓, and samaEapN↓, and samiEapN↓, and samRaAEapN↓, and samuwEN↓: [the first signifying A hearing, or a hearkening or listening, ear: and the last two, and app. all but the first, an ear that hears, or hearkens or listens, much; or that is quick of hearing:] the pl. of ↓the last is sumuEN. (K.)

saAmiEapN c
saAmiEapN fem. of saAmiEN [q. v.]. ― -b2- [It is also used as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant]: see samoEN, in the latter half of the paragraph.

OasomaEu c
OasomaEu [More, and most, quick of hearing]: see simoEN; last sentence.

tasomiEapN c
tasomiEapN [an inf. n. of 2]: see sumoEapN.

masomaEN c
masomaEN A place whence [and where] one hears, or hearkens, or listens. (IDrd, K.) You say, huwa minRiI bimaroOFI wamasomaEK He is where I see him and hear his speech; (IDrd, K;) and in like manner, huwa minRi maroOFI wamasomaEN; (TA;) and maroOFI wamasomaEFA, (M and K in art. rOI, q. v.,) and sometimes they said marFI. (TA.) And fulaAnN fiI manoZarK wamasomaEK Such a one is in a state in which he likes to be looked at and listened to. (T, A, TA, in art. nZr.) ― -b2- See also samoEN, in the latter half of the paragraph, in two places. ― -b3- It is also an inf. n. of samiEa. (TA.)

musomaEN c
musomaEN [pass. part. n. of 4, q. v.]. waQsomaEo gayora musomaEK, in the Kur [iv. 48], means [And hear thou without being made to hear; i. e.] mayest thou not be made to hear: (Ibn-'Arafeh, K:) or mayest thou not hear, (Akh, S, Bd, Jel,) by
reason of deafness, or of death; (Bd;) said by way of imprecation: (Az, Er-Rághib:) or hear thou without being made to hear speech which thou wouldest approve: or not being made to hear what is disliked; accord. to which explanation, it is said hypocritically: or hear thou speech which thou wilt not be made [really] to hear; because thine ear will be averse from it; accord. to which explanation, what follows the verb is an objective complement: or hear thou without having thine invitation assented to: (Bd:) or without having what thou sayest accepted. (Mujáhid, K.)

musomiEN c
musomiEN [act. part. n. of 4, q. v.] ― -b2- [Hence,] musomiEapN A female singer. (S, K.) [See an ex. of the pl. in a verse cited voce XaAribN.] ― -b3- And hence, (TA in art. zmr,) the former is applied to (tropical:) A shackle. (K, and TA in art. zmr.)

misomaEN c
misomaEN An instrument of hearing. (TA.) ― -b2- See samoEN, in the latter half of the paragraph, in four places. ＝ -A2- (assumed tropical:) A loop which is in the middle of the [large bucket called] garob, and into which is put a rope in order that the bucket may be even; (S, K;) so called as being likened to an ear: (ElMufradát, TA:) or the part of the [leathern water-bag called] mazaAdap which is the place of the loop: or what goes beyond, or through, the hole of the loop. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, (K,) or misomaEaAni, (El-Ahmar, TA,) (tropical:) The two pieces of wood that are put into the two loops of the [basket called] zinobiyl when earth is taken forth with it from a well. (El-Ahmar, K, TA.) ― -b3- And the latter, (i. e. the dual,) A pair of socks, or stockings, worn by the sportsman when he is pursuing the gazelles during midday, or during midday in summer when the heat is vehement. (TA.)

musamRaEN c
musamRaEN (tropical:) Shackled: the explanation in the K, shackled and collared, applies to musamRaEN musawojarN together; not to the former of these two words alone. (TA.) [See musomiEN.]

masomuwEaAtN c
masomuwEaAtN [Things heard]. See 4 in art. jwz.

masaAmiEu c
masaAmiEu is pl. of misomaEN (Msb, K) [and of masomaEN]. ― -b2- As a pl. without a sing., it is applied to All the holes of a human being; such as are [the holes of] the eyes, and such as the nostrils, and the anus. (TA.)

musotamaEN c
musotamaEN: see samoEN, in the latter half of the paragraph.

AlsRaAmigaAni c
AlsRaAmigaAni The two sides of the mouth, beneath the two extremities of the mustache, on the right and left; a dial. var. of AlSRaAmigaAni [q. v.]. (IDrd, K.)

1 samaqa c
1. samaqa, (S, O, L, K,) aor.
samuqa
, (O, L,) inf. n. sumuwqN (S, O, L, K) and samoqN, (L,) It was, or became, high, or tall: (S, O, L, K:) or tall in the highest degree: (JK:) said of a plant, or herbage, (JK, L,) of a tree, and [particularly] of a palmtree. (L.) ― -b2- See also sumaAqN.

simiqRN c
simiqRN Tall; applied to a man. (Kr, TA.) [See also saAmiqN.]

sumaAqN c
sumaAqN Pure; sheer; unmixed. (S, O, K.) You say kacibN sumaAqN A sheer, unmixed, lie; (S, O;) and HubRN sumaAqN pure, unmixed, love; meaning such as have overtopped (samaqaA↓) every lie and love. (O.)

samuwqN c
samuwqN: see sumRaAqN.

samiyqN c
samiyqN: see saAmiqN. ＝ -A2- The dual, samiyqaAni, signifies The [yokes or] two pieces of wood that belong to the niyr, surrounding the necks of the two bulls, (S, Z, O, K,) like the neck-ring, (S, O,) the two extremities of each being made to meet together beneath the bull's dewlap, and bound with a cord: (Z, TA:) pl. OasomiqapN. (TA.) ― -b2- And [its pl.,] OasomiqapN, Certain pieces of wood in the utensil upon which bricks, or crude bricks, (labin,) are conveyed. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, L, K.)

sumRaAqN c
sumRaAqN (S, O, K) and samuwqN↓, (O, K,) in the Tekmileh with teshdeed, [i. e. samRuwqN↓,] (TA,) [Sumach; the rhus coriaria of Linn.; or its berry:] a certain fruit, (K,) well known; (S, K;) a certain acid thing, with which one cooks; (O;) the fruit of certain trees of the [high grounds termed] qifaAf and of the mountains, acid, consisting of bunches of small berries, which are cooked; (AHn, TA;) not known to AHn as growing in any part of the land of the Arabs except in Syria; and he says that it is intensely red: in the T, said to be the acid berry called Eaborab: n. un. with p: (TA:) it excites appetence; stops chronic diarrhœa; and the application of water in which it has been steeped, or macerated, as a collyrium, is beneficial for the [disorder termed] sulaAq and for ophthalmia. (K.)

samRuwqN c
samRuwqN: see the next preceding paragraph.

qidorN sumRaAqiyRapN c
qidorN sumRaAqiyRapN: see EaraborabiyRapN, in art Erb

saAmiqN c
saAmiqN and samiyqN↓ High, or tall; applied to a plant, or herbage, and to a tree, and [particularly] to a palm-tree. (L.) [See also simiyqN.]

musomaqirRN c
musomaqirRN: see art. sqr.

1 samaka c
1. samaka, [aor.
samuka
,] inf. n. sumuwkN, It (a thing) rose, or became high or elevated or lofty. (S, K.) ― -b2- And, aor. and inf. n. as above, He ascended. (TA.) One says, Ausomuko fiI AlrRayomi Ascend thou the stairs. (S, TA. [See rayomN.]) ＝ -A2- And samakahu, (S, K,) aor. as above, (TA,) inf. n. samokN, He raised, elevated, upraised, or uplifted, it. (S, K.) So in the phrase, samaka QllRehu AlsRamaMCa [God raised the heaven]. (S.)

samokN c
samokN The roof of a house, or chamber: (S, Mgh, * K: *) or the interior uppermost part [i. e. the ceiling] of a house, or chamber; the exterior uppermost part thereof being called SahowapN: (Ham p. 725:) or [the height] from the top to the bottom of a house or chamber. (K.) [And hence, The canopy of the heaven or sky: or] the measure of the height of the heaven from the earth: or the thickness thereof, upwards. (Bd in lxxix. 28.) And The stature, or height in a standing posture, or anything: (K:) thus expl. by Lth: one says biEiyrN Tawiylu AlsRamoki [A camel tall of stature]. (TA.) [In the present day, it signifies The extent of anything from top to bottom; its height, depth, and thickness: and is vulgarly pronounced sumok.]

samakN c
samakN Fish; syn. HuwtN; (K;) a kind of aquatic creatures: [a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. with p: pl. of the former simaAkN and sumuwkN. (S, TA.) XawaI fiI AlHariyqi samakatahu [He broiled his fish in the fire of a burning house] is a post-classical prov. of the people of Baghdád, relating to the concealing, disguising, or cloaking, of a fault, for the purpose of seizing an opportunity; orginating from the fact that the thief used, when he saw the fire of a burning house in a place, to go thither for the purpose of theft; and if it were in his power, he did what he desired; and if he were lighted on, he said, I came to broil a fish. (Mtr, in Har pp. 481-2.) ― -b2- AlsRamakapu [is a name of (tropical:) The constellation Pisces; also called AlsRamakataAni;] a certain sign of the Zodiac; (K, TA;) thought by ISd to be so called because it is a watery sign; and also called AlHuwtu. (TA.)

simaAkN c
simaAkN A thing with which a thing is raised, elevated, upraised, or uplifted; (K, TA;) whether a wall or a roof: (TA:) pl. sumukN. (K.) ＝ -A2- AlsRimaAkaAni is the name of Two bright stars; AlsRimaAku AlOaEozalu and AlsRimaAku AlrRaAmiHu: (S, O, K:) the former is a star [namely a] in Virgo, called by astrologers AlsRunobulapu [or Spica Virginis]; (Kzw;) and is one of the Mansions of the Moon, (S, O, and Kzw in his descr. of the Mansions of the Moon,) the Fourteenth thereof; (Kzw ibid.;) it is one of the OanowaMC [pl. of nawoCN, q. v.], and rises aurorally in tiXoriynu AlOawRalu [October, O. S.; its auroral rising, in Central Arabia, about the commencement of the era of the Flight, began on the 4th of that month]; it is called AlA Ezl because it has no star [near] before it, like the AEzl that has with him no spear; or, as some say, because, when it rises [aurorally], it is not accompanied by wind nor by cold: (TA:) the latter simaAk, i. e. AlrRaAmiHu, [thus called for a reason expl. in art. rmH, q. v., is the star Arcturus, and] is not of the Mansions of the Moon, (S, O, TA,) and has not any nawoC [here meaning supposed influence in bringing rain &c.]; it is towards the north; the former being towards the south; (TA;) and is also called AlsRimaAku Almirozamu: (AZ, TA in art. rmH:) [it is erroneously said that] the smAkAn are in the sign of Libra: (TA:) and it is said that they are the two kind legs of Leo (rijolaA AlOasadi): (S, O, K: *) [for it appears, as I have before observed, (voce ciraAEN,) that the ancient Arabs, or many of them, extended the figure of Leo (as they did
also that of Scorpio) far beyond the limits which we assign to it: and hence,] AlsmAk AlA Ezl was also called saAqu AlOasadi [the thigh, or the hind shank, of Leo]. (Kzw in his descr. of Virgo.) The rhyming-proser says, UicaA TalaEa AlsRimaAko cahaba AlEikaAko faOaSoliHo finaAko waOajidRa HicaAko faUinRa AlXRitaMCa qado OataAko [When AlsmAk rises aurorally, (i. e. AlsmAk AlA Ezl,) the sultriness has gone, therefore do thou put thy court, or yard, in good condition, and renew thy sandal, for the winter has come to thee: finaAk and HicaAk being contractions of finaMCak and HicaMCak, for the sake of the rhyme]. (O, TA.) The nawoC [here app. meaning the rain consequent upon the auroral setting] of AlsmAk AlAEzl [about the 4th of April, O. S. in Central Arabia] is abundant, but disapproved, because it gives growth to the naXor [q. v.], which diseases the camels that pasture upon it. (Kzw in his descr. of the Mansions of the Moon.) [The epithet simaAkiIRN↓ is applied to the rain above mentioned.] ― -b2- AlsRimaAku also signifies, (K,) or simaAku AltRaroquwapi, (Ibn-'Abbád, O,) The upper part of the chest, next to the collar-bone. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

simaAkiIRN c
simaAkiIRN: see the next preceding paragraph.

sumayokaMCu c
sumayokaMCu i. q. HusaAsN; (S, O, K;) i. e. Certain small fish, which are dried; also called hifRN. (O, TA.)

samRaAkN c
samRaAkN A fishmonger. (MA.)

sanaAmN saAmikN c
sanaAmN saAmikN A high, (S, TA,) or long and high, and plump, (TA,) camel's hump. (S, TA.) ― -b2- Xarafuka taAmikN waUiqobaAluka saAmikN (tropical:) [Thy nobility is lofty, and thy good fortune is high]. (A and Ta in art. tmk.)

AlmusomakaAtu c
AlmusomakaAtu The heavens; (K;) which are seven in number: (TA:) or so AlmasomuwkaAtu↓: (S:) or this is wrong; or it is a dial. var.: (K:) the latter word is used by the vulgar, but is correct. (TA.)

misomaAkN c
misomaAkN A pole of a [tent such as is called] xibaMC, (S, K,) which latter is raised thereby. (S.)

masomuwkN c
masomuwkN Tall; (IDrd, O, K;) applied to a man. (IDrd, O.) ― -b2- And, applied to a horse, [mn AlHaboli in the CK being a mistake for mina Alxayoli,] (tropical:) Firm (Ibn-'Abbád, Z, O, K, TA) in the [ribs called] jawaAniH. (Z, TA.) ― -b3- AlmasomuwkaAtu: see AlmusomakaAtu.

bayotN musotamikN c
bayotN musotamikN and munosamikN↓ A tall house or tent. (TA.)

munosamikN c
munosamikN: see what next precedes.

1 samala Eayonahu c
1. samala Eayonahu, (S, * M, Mgh, * Msb, K,) aor.
samula
, (M, Msb,) inf. n. samolN, (S, M, Msb,) He put out, or blinded, (faqaOa,) his eye (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K, TA) with an iron instrument (S, Msb, TA) made hot; (S, Msb;) or with some other thing; sometimes with a thorn; (TA;) like samarahaA: (M and K in art. smr:) and he pulled it out: (Mgh:) and AstmlhA↓ signifies the same. (Fr, K.) ― -b2- samala AlHawoDa, (S, M, K,) inf. n. as above; (M;) and smRlhu↓, (M, K,) inf. n. tasomiylN; (TA;) He cleansed, or cleared, the watering-trough, or tank, (S, M, K,) from the samalap, (M, K,) [i. e.] from the black mud, or black fetid mud, [that was in it,] and from the mud, or clay. (S.) And samalotu AlbiYora I cleansed, or cleared out, the well. (Msb.) ― -b3- samala bayonahumo, (S, M, Msb, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (S, M,) He effected a rectification of affairs, or an adjustment, or a reconciliation, between them; as also Asml↓: (S, M, K:) or he strove, laboured, or exerted himself, in effecting a rectification between them; and so fiI AlmaEiyXapi [in respect of the means of subsistence]. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- samala, (S, M, K,) aor.
samula
, (M,) inf. n. sumuwlN (S, M, K) and sumuwlapN, [or this is probably the inf. n. of the latter of the next two following syn. verbs,] (K,) It (a garment, or piece of cloth,) was, or became, old, and worn out; as also Asml↓; (S, M, K;) and so samula, like karuma; (K;) and AisomaOalRa↓, inf. n. AisomiYolaAlN. (TA.) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph.

2 smRl AlHawoDa c
2. smRl AlHawoDa: see 1. ＝ -A2- smRl AlHawoDu, (M, K,) inf. n. tasomiylN, (K,) The watering-trough, or tank, yielded but little water. (Lh, M, K.) And in like manner, (K,) smRlt AldRalowu, (M, K,) inf. n. as above, (K,) The bucket yielded, (M,) or produced [from the well], only what is termed AlsRamalap, (K,) i. e., (TA,) little water; (M, TA;) as also samalat↓, (K,) inf. n. samolN; but the former verb is said by Fr to be preferable. (TA.) ＝ -A3- smRl fulaAnFA biAlqawoli He was soft, or tender, or easy and sweet, or elegant, graceful, or ornate, to such a one, (raqRaqa lahu, in the CK rafRaqa lh,) in speech. (K.) ＝ -A4- And accord. to IDrd, tasomiylN signifies A laxness of the cakar on the occasion of jimaAE. (TA.)

4 Oasomala
4: see 1, in two places.

5 tsmRl c
5. tsmRl, (K,) or tsmRl samalFA, (M,) He drank, or took, remains in a vessel, (M, K,) of wine, or beverage, &c. (M.) ― -b2- And tsmRl AlnRabiyca He persevered, or persisted, in the drinking of the [beverage called] nbyc. (Lh, M, K.)

8 Uisotamala
8: see 1, first sentence.

Q. Q. 4 AisomaOalRa c
Q. Q. 4. AisomaOalRa, (S, O, K,) inf. n. AisomiYlaAlN, (S,) He (a man, O) was, or became, slender, lean, or lank, (S, O, K,) in the belly. (S, * O, * K.) ― -b2- Said of the shade, It contracted; or went away; syn. qalaSa, (O,) or AirotafaEa. (TA.) The phrase UicaA QsomaOalRa AltRubRaEu, in a verse which is here cited in the S and O and TA, [and which I have cited in art. tbE,] means [accord. to J,] UicaA rajaEa AlZRilRu UilaI OaSoli AlEuwdi [app. When the shade cast by the leaves of a tree returns to the lower part of the branch; i. e. when the sun becomes high: virtually the same as when the shade contracts]: (S, TA:) or, as some say, by AltRubRaEu is meant [the star, or asterism, called] AldRabaraAn, and the phrase means when AldbrAn rises. (TA. [See art. tbE.]) ― -b3- Said of a person's face, It became altered in consequence of emaciation. (TA.) ― -b4- See also 1, last sentence but one.

samalN c
samalN: see samalapN, in three places. ＝ -A2- Applied to a garment, or piece of cloth, Old, and worn out; (S, M, K;) as also samalapN↓ and samiylN↓ and samuwlN↓ (M, K) and samilN↓ and musomaYilRN↓: (K:) the pl. of samalN is OFsomaAlN: (A'Obeyd, TA:) and one says also vawobN OasomaAlN, (S, M, K,) like rumoHu OaqoSaAdN and buromapN OaEoXaArN. (S.) The phrase samalu qaTiyfapK occurs in a trad. [as meaning An old and worn-out garment of the kind called qTyfp]: and in another trad., OasomaAlu mulRyRatayoni [meaning two old and wornout small garments of the kind called mulaMCap]; mulayRapN being a dim. of mulaMCapN. (TA.) And sawomalN↓ signifies [in like manner] An old and worn-out [garment of the kind called] kisaMC, on the authority of Ez-Zejjájee. (M.) ― -b2- Also, (i. e. samalN,) applied to a ewe, Having ragged wool: ― -b3- and samalo samalo is A cry by which a ewe is called to be milked. (O, TA.)

samilN c
samilN: see the next preceding paragraph.

sumolapN c
sumolapN Tears poured forth (AZ, K) by the eyes affected with pain in consequence of hunger, (AZ,) or on an occasion of vehement hunger, (K,) as though putting out the eye. (AZ, K.) ― -b2- See also the next following paragraph.

samalapN c
samalapN A small quantity of water (S, M, K) remaining in the bottom of a vessel &c.; like vamiylapN: (S:) as also sumolapN↓: (S, M, * K: [app., accord. to the M, the latter is syn. with the former absolutely:]) pl. samalN↓, (S, M, K,) which is used of wine, or beverage, &c., (M,) [or rather this is a coll. gen. n.,] and [the pl. properly so termed is] sumuwlN (As, S) and OasomaAlN [a pl. of pauc.]: (AA, S:) and sumolaAnN↓ [app. pl. of samalN↓, agreeably with analogy,] signifies remains of [the beverage called] nabiyc, (M, K,) and of water also. (TA.) Also A remaining portion of water in a watering-trough, or tank: (M, K:) and, (K,) as some say, (M,) black mud, or black fetid mud, (M, K,) therein: (M:) pl. samalN↓ [or rather this is a coll. gen. n., as observed above,] and simaAlN; (M, K;) and samaAYilu is pl. of the latter of these pls. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also samalN.

sumolaAnN c
sumolaAnN: see the next preceding paragraph.

samuwlN c
samuwlN: see samalN.

samiylN c
samiylN: see samalN.

samRaAlN c
samRaAlN [One who puts out the eyes of others]. A certain tribe were called banuw AlsRamRaAli, (M, K, *) or banuw samRaAlK, (S, TA,) because their founder had put out the eye of a man. (S, M, K.)

saAmilN c
saAmilN One who strives, labours, or exerts himself, (S, M, K,) in, (S,) or for, (M, K,) the right management of affairs for procuring the means of subsistence. (S, M, K.)

sawomalN c
sawomalN: see samalN.

sawomalapN c
sawomalapN A small [cup of the kind called] finojaAnap, (S, M, K, TA,) which latter is a post-classical word, originally filojaAnap: or the swmlp, as some say, is a small fiyaAlajap, an arabicized word from the Pers. PiyaAlaho; which is also called TarojahaArapN; (TA;) and this is the same as the filojaAn. (TA voce TrjhArp.)

musomaYilRN c
musomaYilRN Slender, lean, or lank, in the belly; (M, K;) applied to a man. (TA.) ― -b2- See also samalN. ＝ -A2- Also A certain bird. (K.)

samolaqN c
samolaqN An even plain; (K, TA;) like salaqN; mentioned by J in art. slq; or a desert in which is no herbage: or an even tract of land destitute of herbage: and [the pl.] samaAliqu signifies [deserts such as are termed] SaHaAraI: or, accord. to ElWáhidee, far-extending, long land. (TA.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce Oaroqala: and another voce riyaAgN, in art. ryg.] ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) A woman that bears no offspring: likened to land that does not give growth to anything. (TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) A woman bad in sexual intercourse; as also with p. (TA.) And the latter, (assumed tropical:) A woman that has no UisokataAni [or labia majora of the vulva]: (TA:) [or] a woman having no buttocks. (ISk, TA in art. rqE.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) A clamorous old woman: or, accord. to AA, one of evil disposition. (TA.)

kacibN samalRaqN c
kacibN samalRaqN [like sumaAqN] A sheer, unmixed, lie. (TA.)

1 samina c
1. samina, (S, M, L, Msb, K,) aor.
samana
; (L, Msb, K;) and samuna, aor.
samuna
; (Msb;) inf. n. of the former simanN (S, M, L, K) and samaAnapN, (M, L, K,) or the former is a simple subst. (Msb) [and the latter by rule inf. n. of the latter verb]; He was, or became, fat, or plump; (S, M, L;) or in the condition of having much flesh and fat: (Msb:) and tsmRn↓ has a like meaning [i. e. he was, or became, fattened, rendered plump, or made to have much flesh and fat]. (S, L. *) A poet says,
rakibonaAhaA samaAnatahaA falamRaA
badato minohaA AlsRanaAsinu waAlDRuluwEu
(IAar, M, L,) meaning We rode her during her state of fatness, or plumpness, [but when the edges of her vertebræ, and the ribs, became apparent,...] (M, L.) ― -b2- [Hence,] samina AlburRu, inf. n. simanN, (assumed tropical:) The wheat became full in the grain. (A in art. Sfr.) ＝ -A2- samanahu, (S, M, L, K,) aor.
samuna
, inf. n. samonN, (S, M, L,) He made it, [or prepared it,] namely, food, with samon [q. v. infrà]; (M, L, K;) as also smRnh↓, and Asmnhu↓: (K:) or the first signifies, (S,) or signifies also, and so ↓the second and ↓third, (M, L,) he moistened it, and stirred it about, (S, M, L,) namely, food, (S, L,) or bread, (M, L,) with samon, (S, M, L,) lahumo for them. (S.) ― -b2- Also, and Asmnhu↓, (L,) or samana Alqawoma, (M, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M,) He fed him, or the people, or party, with samon. (M, L, K.) ― -b3- And samanotu lahu I seasoned his bread for him with samon. (L.)

2 smRnhu c
2. smRnhu, (S, M, L, Msb, K,) inf. n. tasomiynN; (K;) He, or it, rendered him fat, or plump; (S, M, L, K; *) or caused him to have much flesh and fat: (Msb:) and Asmnhu↓ signifies the same. (M, L, Msb.) It is said in a prov., samRino kalobaka yaOokuloka [Fatten thy dog, and he will eat thee]. (S, L, Msb. [See Freytag's Arab. Prov., i. 609.]) ― -b2- samRanahumo, (S, M, L,) inf. n. as above, (S, L,) He furnished them with samon for travelling-provision, &c. (S, M, L.) ― -b3- See also 1, in two places. ＝ -A2- tasomiynN also signifies The act of cooling, (S, M, L, K,) in the dial. of Et-Táïf (S, M, L) and ElYemen. (S.) A fish was brought to El-Hajjáj, (S, M, L,) broiled, (L,) and he said to the cook, (S,) or to the man who brought it, (M, L,) samRinohaA, (S, M, L,) meaning Cool it: (S:) the man who brought it knew not what he meant; so 'Ambeseh Ibn-Sa'eed said to him, He says to thee Cool it (M, L) a little. (L.)

4 Asmn c
4. Asmn He (a man, M, L) was fat, or plump, by nature. (M, L, K.) ― -b2- He (a man, S, M, L) possessed a thing that was fat, or plump: (S, M, L, K:) or bought such: (M, L, K:) or gave such (S, M, L, K) to another. (S.) And Asmn Alqawomu The people, or party, became in the state of those whose cattle had become fat, or plump. (M, L, K. *) ― -b3- Also He bought samon. (L.) ― -b4- And AsmnwA They became in the condition of having much samon. (M, L, K.) ＝ -A2- Asmnhu: see 2: ― -b2- and see also 1, in three places.

5 tasamRana
5: see 1. ― -b2- [Hence,] tsmRn also signifies (assumed tropical:) He prided himself in the abundance of his wealth, and collected it but did not expend it: (TA in art. hnO:) or he made a boast of abundance of goodness, or goods, which he did not possess; and laid claim to nobility that was not in him: or collected wealth for the purpose of attaining to the condition of the noble: or loved to indulge himself largely in eatables and drinkables that are the causes of fatness, or plumpness. (L.)

10 Astsmnhu c
10. Astsmnhu He deemed, or reckoned, (S, L, Msb, K,) or he found, (M, L, K,) it, or him, (namely, a thing, M, L, and flesh-meat, L, or a man, K,) to be fat, or plump, (S, M, L, K,) or to have much flesh and fat: (Msb:) or he sought it, or demanded it, fat, or plump. (M, L.) ＝ -A2- And jaAWuwA yasotasominuwna They came seeking, or demanding, that samon [in the CK AlsRamiyn i. e. that which was fat or plump] should be given to them. (S, M, L, K. *)

samonN c
samonN Clarified butter; ghee; i. e. silaMC of fresh butter, (M, L, K,) or of milk; (L;) it is of the cow, and sometimes of the goat: (S, L:) what comes forth, (Mgh,) or is made, (Msb,) [or clarified, by cooking it, or boiling it, sometimes with an admixture of sawiyq (or meal of parched barley or wheat), or dates, or globules of gazelles' dung, (see xulaASapN, and qiXodapN, and qilodapN,)] from the milk of cows, and of goats, (Mgh, Msb,) or sheep: (Msb:) [n. un. with p:] pl. [of mult.] sumonaAnN (S, M, L, Msb, K, in the CK [erroneously] simonaAnN) and sumuwnN and [of pauc.] OasomunN: (M, L, K:) it counteracts all poisons, clears away the filth from foul ulcers, matures all tumours, and removes the [discoloration and spots termed] kalaf and namaX from the face, applied as a liniment. (K.) ― -b2- samonu Alhabiydi [Decocted juice of the colocynth, or of its pulp, or seed]. (TA voce xawolaEN, q. v.)

simanN c
simanN Fatness, or plumpness; contr. of huzaAlN; (M, L;) or the condition of having much flesh and fat. (Msb.) [See 1, first sentence.]

samonapN c
samonapN, (M, L,) or sumonapN↓, with damm, (K,) A certain herb, (M, L, K,) having leaves, and slender twigs, and a white flower: said by AHn to be of the [kind called] janobap, (M, L,) which grows forth binujuwmi AlSRayofi [which may mean either by the influence of the stars of the season called AlSyf, i. e., of its rains, or with the herbs of that season, in either case in spring or summer,] and is evergreen. (M, L, K.)

sumonapN c
sumonapN A medicine for fattening, or rendering plump: (M, L, K:) or a medicine by which women are fattened, or rendered plump. (T, S, L.) ― -b2- See also samonapN.

AlsRumaniyRapu c
AlsRumaniyRapu A certain sect of idolaters, who assert the doctrine of metempsychosis, and deny that knowledge comes from informations; (S, Msb;) a certain people, of the Indians, who hold that the duration of the present world is from eternity, or that it is everlasting, (M, L, K,) and assert the doctrine of metempsychosis: (K:) the word is said to be an irregular rel. n. from suwmanaAt, a town of India. (Msb.)

samiynN c
samiynN Fat, or plump; (S, M, L, K; *) contr. of muhozuwlN; (S, L;) or having much flesh and fat; (Msb;) and saAminN↓ signifies the same: (M, L, K:) fem. with p: (M, L, Msb:) [see saAHRq:] pl. (of the first, and of its fem., Msb) simaAnN, (Sb, M, L, Msb, K,) used instead of sumanaMCu, which they did not say: (Sb, M, L:) accord. to Lh, (M, L,) musominN↓ signifies fat, or plump, by nature; (M, L, K;) applied to a man: and some say AimoraOapN musminapN↓ meaning a woman fat, or plump, syn. samiynapN, (M, L,) or AmrOp musomanapN↓, like mukoramapN [in measure], meaning [a woman rendered fat, or plump,] by nature; (K;) and biAlOadowiyapi musamRanapN↓ [rendered fat, or plump, by medicines]; (M, L, K;) and woe, on the day of resurrection, by reason of languor in the bones, is denounced in a trad. against women who make use of medicine to render themselves thus. (L.) ― -b2- [Hence,] OaroDN samiynapN (assumed tropical:) [Fat land; i. e.] land of good soil, with few stones, strong to foster plants or herbage: (M, L:) or land consisting of soil in which is no stone. (K.) ― -b3- And kalaAmN samiynN (assumed tropical:) Chaste, eloquent, or excellent, language. (L in art. qSd.) ― -b4- See also masomuwnN.

sumaAnaI c
sumaAnaI [accord. to those who make the alif to be a sign of the fem. gender] or sumaAnFI [accord. to those who make that letter to be one of quasicoordination] A certain bird, (S, M, L, Msb, K,)
well known; (Msb;) [the quail; tetrao coturnix: so called in the present day: and also called salowaI:] used as a pl. and as a sing.; (M, L, K;) sometimes as a sing.: (M, L:) [or] the n. un. is sumaAnaApN: (S, M, L, K:) pl. sumaAnayaAtN: (S:) one should not say sumRaAnI, with teshdeed. (S, L.)

samRaAnN c
samRaAnN A seller of samon. (S, M, L.) ＝ -A2- Also Certain dyes [or pigments] with which one decorates, or embellishes. (M, L, K.) [See also simRaAnN, in art. sm.] ＝ -A3- samRaAnu, the name of A certain plant, see in art. sm.

saAminN c
saAminN: see samiynN. ― -b2- Also A possessor of samon: (M, L, K:) like laAbinN and taAmirN as meaning “ a possessor of milk ” and “ of dates. ” (L.)

OasomaAnN c
OasomaAnN Waist-wrappers; syn. OuzurN [pl. of UizaArN]: and old and worn-out garments or pieces of cloth: (L:) or old and worn-out Ouzur. (K.)

musomanN c
musomanN: see its fem., with p, voce samiynN.

musominN c
musominN; and its fem., with p: see samiynN. ― -b2- qawomN musominuwna A people, or party, whose cattle have become fat, or plump. (L.)

TaEaAmN masomanapN lilojisomi c
TaEaAmN masomanapN lilojisomi [Food that is a cause of fattening to the body]. (M, L, K: * in the CK [erroneously] musominapN.) [See also an ex. voce kiZRapN.]

musamRanN c
musamRanN: see its fem., with p, voce samiynN.

masomuwnN c
masomuwnN Food made [or prepared] with samon: (L:) or moistened, and stirred about, therewith: (S:) [and samiynN↓ signifies the same; for] a rájiz says,
laHomu jazuwrK gavRapK samiynapo fabaA karatonaA jafonapN baTiynahN
[And a capacious bowl came to us early in the morning, flesh of a slaughtered camel, lean, prepared with clarified butter]: i. e. fabaAkaratonaA jafonapN baTiynapo, from AlsRamonu, not from AlsRimanu. (S, L.)

samanodalN c
samanodalN [The phenix;] a certain bird that is in India; that enters into the fire without having its plumage burned: (Kr, M, K: * [mentioned in the M as a quadriliteral-radical word; the n being regarded by ISd as augmentative:]) also called sabanodalN, with b [in the place of m]: it is said that when it becomes extremely aged, and is without offspring, it casts itself into burning coals, and returns to its youthful state. (TA.) [See also sanodalN, in art. sdl.]

samahodarN c
samahodarN Fat, as an epithet, (S, K,) applied to a boy, in praise of his fleshiness; (Fr, S;) a boy fat and fleshy. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) The penis, (K,) as likened to a fat, or fat and fleshy, boy. (TA.) ― -b3- Applied to a country, or region, (baladN,) Ample, (S, K,) wide, or far-extending, in its limits: or in which the sight is perplexed by its levelness. (TA.) ― -b4- A land far-extending; that causes one to lose his way in it. (K, TA.)

Q. 1 samohara c
Q. 1. samohara, said of seed-produce, It did not multiply; as though every grain [of the seed] had its [single] head. (T, K.)

Q. 4 AisomaharRa c
Q. 4. AisomaharRa It (a spear, TA) was, or became, hard. (S, K.) ― -b2- It (a thorn) was, or became, dry, or tough, and hard. (S.) ― -b3- It was, or became, strong; (said of a rope; TA;) or pressing, or severe, or difficult; (said of an affair; TA;) or intense; (S, K;) said of darkness: (S, TA:) and, said of darkness, it became disagreeable, and intense. (K.) ― -b4- He (a man) became vehement in fight. (S.) ― -b5- It (a penis) became straight and erect. (K, TA.)

rumoHu samohariIRN c
rumoHu samohariIRN, (S, K,) and qanaApN samohariyRapN, (S,) A hard spear, (S, K,) and a hard spear-shaft: (S:) or so called in relation to a man named samoharN, (S, K,) husband of rudayonapu, (K,) who (as well as his wife, K) used to straighten spears: (S, K:) or in relation to a town or village of Abyssinia, (K,) called samoharN: so says Ez-Zubeyr Ibn-Bekkár, but Sgh distrusts this; and the former opinion is the more common. (TA.) You say also rimaAHN samohariyRapN [Hard spears; &c.]. (S.) ― -b2- wataro samohariIRN A strong bow-string. (TA.) ― -b3- qadRN samohariIRN A straight stature. (TA.)

musomahirRN c
musomahirRN A tough thorn. (TA.) ― -b2- A penis hard and strong; or distended and erect and hard: (L, TA: [but in both, Ewd, as an epithet applied to cakarN, is put by mistake for EardN]:) or the penis [itself]. (K.) ― -b3- Straight. (AZ.)

1 samaA c
1. samaA, (S, M, Msb, K,) first pers. samawotu, like Ealawotu, (S,) aor. yasomuw, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. sumuwRN; (S, M, K;) and samiIa, first pers. samiytu, (Th, S, TA,) like Ealiytu; (S;) He, (a man, Th, S,) or it, (a thing, M,) was, or became, high, lofty, raised, upraised, uplifted, upreared, exalted, or elevated; it rose, or rose high: (S, M, Msb, K:) and tsAmI↓ signifies the same. (MA. [See also 5.]) ― -b2- samaAliIa AlXRaIoCu The thing became raised from afar so that I plainly distinguished it: (K:) or, as in the S, samaA liIa AlXRaxoSu the form, or figure, seen from a distance, rose, or became raised, to me [i. e. to my view] so that I plainly distinguished it. (TA.) ― -b3- samaA AlhilaAlu The moon near the change rose murotafiEFA [app. meaning upreared, not decumbent: see Oadofaqu]. (TA.) ― -b4- [samaA lahu or naHowahu He rose, and betook himself, to, or towards, him, or it. Hence,] maAsamawotu lakumo I will not [or (unless the phrase be an apodosis) I did not] rise and hasten to fight you. (TA.) ― -b5- samaA baSarahu His sight, or eye, rose, or became raised. (S, TA.) [And samaATarofuhu lit. signifies the same; but means (assumed tropical:) His look was lofty; or he was proud: see saAmK, below.] ― -b6- samaA is also said of him who is termed HasiybN and XariyfN [i. e. it signifies He was, or became, noble; or high, or exalted, in rank]. (TA.) ― -b7- samatp himRatuhu UilaI maEaAliI AlOumowri [His ambition soared, or aspired, to high things, or the means of attaining eminence;] he sought glory, or might, and eminence. (Msb, TA.) ― -b8- samaAbiI Xawoqa baEoda Oano kaAna OaqoSara [A yearning, or longing, of the soul arose in me after it had ceased]. (TA.) ― -b9- humo yasomuwna EalaI AlmiAYapi They exceed [or are above] the number of a hundred. (TA.) ― -b10- samawoA, (S, K, TA,) and AstmwA↓, (S,) They went forth to pursue the animals of the chase (S, K, TA) in their deserts: (TA:) [or] one says of the hunter, or sportsman, yasomuw AlwaHoXa, and yasotamiyhaA↓, meaning he sees, or looks to see, (yataEayRanu,) the coming forth of the wild animals, and pursues them. (M. [See also 8 below.]) ― -b11- samaA AlfaHolu, inf. n. samaAwapN, The stallion sprang, or rushed, upon, (S,) or he overbore, (S, * M, K,) his she-camels that had passed seven or eight months since the period of their bringing forth. (S, M, K.) ＝ -A2- samaAbihi: see 4. ＝ -A3- See also 2.

2 smRAhu fulaAnFA c and bifulaAnK
2. smRAhu fulaAnFA bifulaAnK, (S, M, Msb, K,) accord. to Sb originally with b, but Lh says that the former is that which is usual, (M,) [inf. n. tasomiyapN,] and in like manner AsmAhu↓, (S,) i. e. AsmAhu fulaAnFA and bifulaAnK, (M, K,) and accord. to Th, fulaAnFA samaAhu↓ and bifulaAnK, (K, [in the correct copies of which the form of the verb first mentioned is without teshdeed, while in the CK the first and last are both alike with teshdeed, or, as is said in the M, Th has mentioned samawotuhu, but none other has mentioned it,]) He named him, or called him, Such a one; (S, M, Msb, K;) as Zeyd; i. e., he made Zeyd to be his name, his proper name. (Msb.) ― -b2- [One says also, smRI QllReha EalaI XaIoCK, or simply smRI Ealayohi, which is the more common, meaning He pronounced the name of God, saying bisomi QllRehi (In the name of God), upon, or over, a thing; such as food, and an animal about to be slaughtered.] The Prophet said, samRuwA wasamRituwA wadanRuwA, [cited, with some variations, and expl., in arts. dnw and smt,] meaning samRuwA QllReha [Pronounce ye the name of God, &c.]; i. e. whenever ye eat, [before ye begin to do so, accord. to the general custom, or] between two mouthfuls. (M.)

3 sAmAhu c
3. sAmAhu, (S, M, K, TA,) inf. n. musaAmaApN, (TA,) He vied, competed, or contended for superiority, in highness, loftiness, or eminence, or in glory, or excellence, [or in an absolute sense,] with him; syn. EaAlaAhu, (M,) or faAxarahu, and baAraAhu. (K.) It is said in the trad. respecting the lie [against 'Áïsheh], lamo takuni QmoraOapN tusaAmiyhaA gayoru zayonaba, meaning There was not any woman that vied with her in eminence (tufaAxiruhaA and tuEaAliyhaA) except Zeyneb; AlmusaAmaApu meaning AlmuTaAwalapu fiI AlHuiZowapi. (TA.) And one says, fulaAnN laA yusaAmaI waqado EalaA mano saAmaAhu [Such a one will not be vied with in highness, &c.: and he has overcome him who vied with him, &c.]. (S.) And UinRa OamaAmiI maA laA OusaAmiI, said when one fears an affair, or event, before him; on the authority
of IAar; meaning [Verily before me is an affair, or event,] with which I cannot vie. (M.) A poet cited by Th says,
baAta Qbonu OadomaMCa yusaAmiI AlOanodaraA
saAmaI TaEaAma AlHaIRi HatRaI nawRaraA
and he says that saAmaI means AirotafaEa, and SaEida; but [it seems that the verse should be rendered, Ibn-Admà passed the night aspiring to reach the heap of reaped wheat: he aspired to attain the wheat of the tribe until it attained to maturity: for ISd says,] in my opinion he means, as the seed-produce rose by growth, he rose to it, until it attained to maturity, when he reaped it and stole it: and he cites also the saying,
faQrofaEo yadayoka vumRa saAmi AlHanojaraA
[And raise thy hands, then endeavour to reach the windpipe]; explaining saAmi AlHanojara as meaning raise thy hands to his Haloq [or throat, properly, fauces]. (M.)

4 AsmAhu c
4. AsmAhu He raised, upraised, uplifted, upreared, exalted, or elevated, him, or it; as also bihi samaA↓ [lit. he rose, &c., with him, or it]. (M, K.) ― -b2- Oasomayotuhu mino baladK I made him to go up, or away, from a town, or country. (TA.) ― -b3- AsmAnA, (TA,) or AisotamaAnaA↓, (M,) He, or it, incited us to hunt, or chase: so says Th. (M, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also He looked at, or towards, his, or its samaAwap [expl. immediately before the mention of this phrase in the M as meaning the form, or figure, seen from a distance, and the aspect, of anything]. (M, TA.) ＝ -A3- And AsmI He (a man) took the direction of, (S,) or came to, (M,) Es-Semáweh (AlsRamaAwap, S, M) a certain water in the desert (AlbaAdiyap, M) or a place between El-Koofeh and Syria, (K,) a well-known desert. (TA.) ＝ -A4- See also 2.

5 tsmRI c
5. tsmRI [expl. by Golius, first, as meaning Altus fuit, eminuit; like samaA; but for this he names no authority, and I find none for it. ＝ -A2- ] He named himself. (KL.) ― -b2- tsmRI bizayodK He was named Zeyd: (S, * M, * Msb, K: *) tsmRI bikacaA means Such a thing became his name: it is quasi-pass. of samRaAhu and OasomaAhu. (TA.) ― -b3- And tsmRI bibaniI fulaAnK, (M,) or biAlqawomi, (K,) and Uilayohimo, (M, K,) He asserted his relationship to the sons of such a one [by the assumption of a name of relationship to them], or to the people. (M, K.)

6 tasaAomawa
6: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- tasaAmawoA EalaI Alxayoli They mounted upon the horses. (TA.) ― -b3- And tsAmwA They vied, competed, or contended for superiority, [in highness, loftiness, or eminence, or in glory, or excellence, or in an absolute sense, (see 3,)] one with another. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- And tsAmwA signifies also They called one another by their names. (TA.)

8 AstmI c
8. AstmI He (a hunter, or sportsman, [AlSRAEidu in the CK being a mistranscription for AlSRaAYidu,]) attired himself with the socks, or stockings, called misomaAp, (M, K, TA,) to protect himself from the heat of the burning ground, (TA,) for the hunting of gazelles, in the time of heat. (M.) And (M, in the K “ or ”) AstmAhu He asked of him the loan of the socks, or stockings, above named, for that purpose, (M, K, *) i. e. for the hunting of gazelles at midday. (TA.) And AstmI, (M, CK,) or AstmI AlZRibaMCa, (so in some copies of the K and in the TA,) He sought, or pursued, the gazelles in their caves, or hiding-places, (faI giyraAnihaA, M, and so in copies of the K, by the giyraAn being meant the kunus, M,) or in what was not their time, or season, (fiI gayori QnihaA, thus in some copies of the K,) at the auroral rising of Canopus (suhayol [which rose aurorally, in Central Arabia, about the commencement of the era of the Flight, on the 4th of August, O. S.]): (M, K:) so says IAar. (M.) [Freytag says, on the authority of scholia to the Deewán of Jereer, as follows: In the time of the greatest heat, they drive out a wild animal repeatedly from its hiding-place, permitting it to return thither at night, when, thus disturbed, it does not issue from its place; in order that they may be able to strike it.] ― -b2- And He hunted, or chased, wild animals. (M.) ― -b3- See also 1, latter part, in two places. ― -b4- And see 4. ＝ -A2- Aisotamayotuhu also signifies I made him the object of a visit: or I perceived in him good, or goodness, by a right opinion formed from its outward signs. (K.) ― -b2- And AstmAhu He chose it, took it in preference, or selected it. (IAar, L voce AiqotaraHa.) ― -b3- And IAar mentions the saying, Albakorapu mina AlUibili tusotamaI baEoda OarobaEa EaXorapa layolapF OawobaEoda UiHodaI waEiXoriyna, as meaning [The youthful she-camel] is tested for the purpose of discovering whether or not she be pregnant [after fourteen nights or after one and twenty]: but Th disallows this, and says that the word is tusotamonaI, from Almunoyapu, which means “ the period by the end of which one knows whether or not the she-camel is pregnant. ” (M.)

10 AstsmI c
10. AstsmI [or AstsmI fulaAnFA, the word flAnA having app. been inadvertently omitted by a copyist,] He asked, or demanded, his [or such a one's] name. (TA.)

simN c
simN and sumN and samN: see AisomN, in three places, near the beginning of the paragraph; and in four places near the end of the same.

samFA c
samFA: see samaMCN: ＝ -A2- and see also AisomN, near the beginning of the paragraph.

sumFA c
sumFA and simFA: see AisomN, in two places, near the beginning of the paragraph; and in the last sentence but one of the same.

samaMCN c
samaMCN The higher, or upper, or highest, or uppermost, part of anything: [in this sense] masc. (M.) ― -b2- [In its predominant acceptation,] a word of well-known meaning; (K, TA;) i. e. (TA) [The sky, or heaven;] the canopy of the earth: (M, Msb, TA:) in this sense (M, Msb) masc. and fem.; (IAmb, S, M, Msb, K; *) sometimes fem.; (M;) rarely so, and thus as having the next but one of the significations here following: (Fr, Msb:) Az says that it is fem. because it is pl.
