[or coll. gen. n.] of samaMCapN: (TA:) or it is as though it were pl. of samaAwapN↓, [or rather its coll. gen. n.,] like as saHaAbN is of saHaAbapN: (Msb, TA:) Er-Rághib says that the samaMC as opposed to the OaroD is fem., and sometimes masc.; and is used as a sing. and as a pl.; as the latter in the Kur ii. 27 [where it is shown to apply to seven heavens]; and that it is like naxolN and XajarN and other [coll.] gen. ns.: (TA:) in this sense (M) the pl. is OasomiyapN [a pl. of pauc.] (S, M, K) and sumiIRN, (M, K,) the latter [originally sumuwIN] of the measure fuEuwlN, and both [also] pls. of samaMCN in another sense, mentioned in what follows, (TA,) and samaAwaAtN or samewaAtN, (S, M, Msb, K,) and accord. to the K, [in which all of these are mentioned as though pls. of samaMCN in all its senses,] samFA↓, [in the CK sumFA,] but in the M samaMCN [like the sing., as mentioned above], where it is said that it must be a pl. in the Kur ii. 27 for the reason already stated, as though pl. of samaMCapN or samaAwapN; (TA;) and a poet assigns to samaMCN the anomalous pl. samaMCK, by his saying,
samaMCu QloUilehi fawoqa saboEi samaMYiyaA
[The heaven of God, above seven heavens]: (S, M:) the dim. is sumRyRapN↓. (Ham p. 452.) ― -b3- And Any canopy, or covering over-head, of a person. (S, Msb, * TA.) ― -b4- And hence, (S, TA,) The ceiling, or roof, (S, Msb, K, TA,) of a house, or chamber, or tent, (S, K, TA,) and of anything; (K, TA;) in this sense masc.; (Msb, TA;) and samaAwapN↓ also has this meaning. (S.) ― -b5- And The riwaAq, (M, K,) i. e. the XuqRap [or oblong piece of cloth] that is beneath the upper, or uppermost, XuqRapN, (M,) of a bayot [or tent]; (M, K;) in which sense it is fem., and sometimes masc.; (M;) as also samaAwapN↓; (M, K;) [and so, app., simaAyapN↓; for] one says, OaSolaHa simaAyatahu, with kesr, [He repaired his smAyp,] meaning, his samaAwap. (TA.) ― -b6- And The clouds; (Zj, K;) because of their height: (Zj, TA:) or a cloud. (Msb.) ― -b7- And Rain; (S, M, Msb, K;) because it comes forth from the samaMC [i. e. sky or clouds]: (TA:) or a good rain (maTorapN jayRidapN): (K, TA:) or a new rain (maTorapN jadiydapN): (T, TA:) or, as some say, rain that has not fallen upon the earth; so called in consideration of what has been said above [of its meaning the “ clouds ” &c.]: (Er-Rághib, TA:) [but] one says, maA zilonaA naTaOu AlsRamaMCa HatRaI OatayonaAkumo [We ceased not to tread upon the rain until we came to you]: (S, TA:) applied to rain, it is masc., and fem. also because of its connexion with the samaMC that canopies the earth; (M;) or it is fem., as meaning saHaAbapN: (Msb:) the pl. [of mult.] is sumiIRN (S, M, Msb, TA) and [of pauc.] OasomiyapN. (S, TA.) banuw maMCi AlsRamaMCi is an appellation of The Arabs; [signifying the sons of the water of the heaven;] because of their keeping much to the deserts which are the places of the falling of rain [by means of which they subsist]: or by maMC AlsmMC is meant Zemzem, which God made to well forth for the Arabs, who are therefore like the sons thereof. (TA.) ― -b8- [Hence, app., as
being likened to rain by reason of the swiftness of his running,] a certain horse, (M, K,) belonging to Sakhr the brother of El-Khansà, (M,) was named AlsRamaMCu. (M, K.) ― -b9- [Hence, likewise, as being likened to rain, (assumed tropical:) Bounty.] One says, OaSaAbaniI biraXoHapK mino samaAYihi (assumed tropical:) [He gave me a gift from his store of bounty]. (A in art. rXH.) ― -b10- Also (assumed tropical:) Herbage; because produced by the rain, which is thus called. (TA.) ― -b11- And The back of a horse; (S, Msb, K;) because of its height: coupled with [its opposite] OaroDN [q. v.]. (S, TA.) ― -b12- And of a sandal, [in like manner opposed to OaroDN,] The upper part [of the sole, i. e. the upper surface thereof], upon which the foot is placed. (M.) ＝ -A2- See also samaAwapN.

samaAwN c
samaAwN: see samaAwapN.

samiIRN c
samiIRN: see saAmK, in two places. ― -b2- [Also] A competitor, or contender for superiority, in highness, loftiness, or eminence, or in glory, or excel-lence; i. q. musaAmK↓, (S, TA,) and muTaAwilN: (TA:) thus the word, in the accus. case, is said to signify in the Kur xix. 66: (S, TA:) or it there has the meaning here next following. (S, M, TA.) ― -b3- A like, or an equal: (S, M, K TA:) and this meaning the word, in the accus. case, is said by some to have in the Kur xix. 8: or in this instance it has the meaning here following. (M, TA.) ― -b4- A namesake of another. (S, M, K, TA.) ― -b5- The fem. is samiyRapN. (M, TA.)

sumaIRN c
sumaIRN dim. of AisomN, q. v.

sumayRapN c
sumayRapN dim. of samaMCN, q. v.

simawiIRN c
simawiIRN and sumawiIRN: see AisomiIRu.

samaAwapN c
samaAwapN: see samaMCN, in three places. ― -b2- Also The form, or figure, seen from a distance, (S, M, K, TA,) [or] such as is high, or elevated, (TA,) of anything; (S, M, K, TA;) and the aspect thereof: pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] samaMCN↓ and samaAwN↓; the latter mentioned by Ks. (M, TA.) El-'Ajjáj says,
samaMwapu AlhilaAli HatRaI QHoqawoqafaA
[The form, &c., of the moon when near the change, until it became curved]. (S.)

simaAyapN c
simaAyapN: see samaMCN, in the middle of the paragraph.

samaMYiIRN c
samaMYiIRN and samaAwiIRN [Of, or relating to, the sky or heaven; heavenly; celestial;] rel. ns. from samaMCN. (Msb, TA.)

saAmK c
saAmK [High, or lofty; as also samiIRN↓: pl. of the former sawaAmK; applied to women as pl. of saAmiyapN, whence the phrase sawaAmiI AlTRarofi in a verse cited voce buDoEN; and to irrational animals, as in an instance here following]. One says Alquruwmu AlsRawaAmiI The stallions [meaning the stallion-camels high in their heads, or] raising their heads high. (S, TA.) And saAmiyaAtN, [pl. of saAmiyapN,] applied to camels, That raise, or raise high, their eyes and their heads. (Ham p. 791.) And radadotu mino saAmiI Tarofihi [app. an elliptical phrase, naxowatahu (which is expressed in the explanation) or a similar word being understood; i. e. (assumed tropical:) I repelled the pride, or haughtiness, of him who was lofty in look;] meaning I contracted to him [or to the lofty in look] his soul, and annulled his pride, or haughtiness. (S, TA.) And AlOanofi samiIRu↓ [lit. Highnosed] means (assumed tropical:) disdainful, or scornful. (T and K in art. Anf.) ― -b2- [Also act. part. n. of 1 in all its senses. ― -b3- And hence,] sumaApN, (S, M, K,) of which it is the sing., (M,) signifies Hunters (S, M, K) going forth to the chase: (K:) an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates: or, as some say, hunters in the day-time, peculiarly: or hunters wearing the socks, or stockings, called misomaAp. (M.)

AisomN OsAm Osm OsmI Asm sAm sm smA smI wsm Qsm
AisomN, (S, M, Msb, K,) with the conjunctive A, [i. e. written QsomN,] but this is made disjunctive by poetic license [as well as when the word commences a sentence], (S,) usually with kesr [when the | is disjunctive], (Lh, M, TA,) and AusomN, (S, M, K,) of the dial. of Benoo-'Amr-Ibn-Temeem and of Kudá'ah, (M, TA,) mentioned by IAar, (TA,) and simN↓ and sumN↓ (S, M, K) and samN↓, (K,) and sumFA↓ (M, K) and simFA↓ and samFA↓, (K,) [The name of a thing; i. e.] a sign [such as may be uttered or written] conveying knowledge of a thing; syn. EalaAmapN: and a word applied to denote a substance or an accident or attribute, for the purpose of distinction: (M, K:) [or a substantive in the proper sense of this term, i. e. a real substantive; and a substance in a tropical sense of this term, i. e. an ideal substantive:] as expl. by El-Munáwee, in the “ Towkeef, ” the Asm is that which denotes a meaning in itself unconnected with any of the three times [past and present and future]: if denoting what subsists by itself, it is termed Aisomu EayonK; and if denoting what does not subsist by itself, [i. e. an accident or attribute,] whether existent, as AlEilomu [i. e. knowledge], or non-existent, as Aljaholu [i. e. ignorance], it is termed Aisomu maEonFI: (TA:) the pl. is OasomaMCN [a pl. of pauc.] and OasomaAwaAtN, (S, M, K,) the latter said by Lh to be a pl. of AisomN, but it is rather a pl. of OasomaMCN, for otherwise there is no way of accounting for it, (M,) and OasaAmK (S, M, K) and OasaAmiIRu (M, K) are [likewise] pls. of OasomaMCN: (K, * TA:) the word QsomN [i. e. AisomN or AusomN] is derived from samawotu, (S, TA,) or from AlsRumuwRu, (Msb, Er-Rághib, TA,) because the Asm is a means of raising into notice the thing denoted thereby, and making it known: (S, * Er-Rághib, TA:) it is of the measure AifoEN [or AufoEN, accord. to different dialects], the last radical, w, being wanting in it, (S, Msb, TA,) and the hemzeh [or rather |] being prefixed by way of compensation for it, accord to a general rule; (Msb, TA;) for it is originally simowN (S, Msb, Er-Rághib, TA) or sumowN, (S, Msb, TA,) its pl. being OasomaMCN, and its dim. being sumaIRN↓ [originally samayowN]: (S, Msb, Er-Rághib, * TA:) some of the Koofees hold that it is from Alwasomu, meaning AlEalaAmapu, the w, which is the primal radical, being rejected, and the hemzeh [or |] being substituted for it, so that its measure is AiEolN [or AuEolN]; but this is a weak opinion, for, were it so, the dim. would be wasayomN and the pl. would be OawosaAmN. (Msb, TA.) One says, Aisomu hecaA kacaA [The name of this is thus, or such a word]; and if you will you may say, Ausomu hecA kcA; and in like manner, simuhu↓ and sumuhu↓: Lh says that Aisomuhu fulaAnN [His name is Such a one] is the [common] phrase of the Arabs; and he mentions Ausomuhu fulaAnN as heard from [the tribe of] Benoo-'Amr-Ibn-Temeem: and Ks cites, as heard from some of [the tribe of] Benoo-Kudá'ah, the saying,
biQsomi QlRaciI fiI kulRi suwrapK sumuho↓
[In the name of Him whose name is in every chapter of the Kur-án], and simuho↓ as heard from others, not of Kudá'ah. (M.) siro EalaI Qsomi QllRehi is an elliptical phrase [for siro muEotamidFA EalaI cikori Qsomi QllRehi Journey thou relying upon the mention of the name of God]. (IJ, M in art. dl: see daliylN.) ― -b2- [Hence,] QsomN signifies also (assumed tropical:) Fame, renown, report, or reputation, of a person: (TA:) and so sumFA↓, in relation to good, (K, TA,) not to evil; mentioned by Az. (TA.) One says, cahaba Qsomuhu fiI AlnRaAsi, i. e. His fame &c. [went, or spread, among mankind, or the people]. (TA.)

AisomiIRN c
AisomiIRN [Of, or relating to, a name or noun or substantive;] rel. n. from AisomN; as also simawiIRN↓ and sumawiIRN↓. (S, TA.) [Hence, jumolapN QsomiyRapN A nominal proposition or phrase; as distinguished from fiEolyRapN, or verbal.]

AisomiyRapN c
[AisomiyRapN The quality of a name or noun or substantive.]

misomaApN c
misomaApN The socks, or stockings, worn by a hunter, (M, K, TA,) to protect him from the heat of the burning ground. (TA.)

musamRFI c
musamRFI [Named]. ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, huwa mino musamRaI qawomihi and musamRaAtihimo, meaning (assumed tropical:) He is of the best of his people or party. (TA.)

musaAmK c
musaAmK: see samiIRN.

1 sanRahu c
1. sanRahu, (M, L, K,) [aor.
sanuna
,] inf. n. sanRN, (M,) He (a man, M, L) bit him (another man, M, L) with his OasonaAn [or teeth]. (M, L, K: but in the K, with the OasonaAn.) [Hence, app.,] sunRati AlOaroDu The herbage of the land was eaten. (L, K.) ― -b2- And, (M, L, in the K “ or, ”) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M, L,) He broke his (a man's, M, L) OasonaAn [or teeth]. (M, L, K.) ― -b3- sunRati Albadanapu: and sanRahaA QllRehu: see 4. ― -b4- Also, (accord. to the M and L, but accord. to the K “ or, ”) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M, L,) He pierced him, or thrust him, with the sinaAn [or spear-head]. (M, L, K.) And sanRahu biAlrRumoHi He pierced him, or thrust him, with the spear. (L.) ― -b5- And He fixed, or mounted, upon it (i. e. the spear) the sinaAn [or iron head];
(M, L, K;) and OasanRahu↓ he put to it a sinaAn. (L.) ― -b6- Also, (S, M, L, Msb, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M, L, Msb,) He sharpened it, whetted it, or made it sharp-pointed, (S, M, L, Msb, K,) and polished it, (M, L, K,) namely, a thing, (M, L,) or a knife; (S, L, Msb, K;) and so snRnhu↓: (M, L, K:) and sanRa he sharpened, whetted, or made sharp-pointed, a spear-head upon the misanR: (L:) and he rubbed, or grated, a stone upon a stone. (Fr, L.) ― -b7- [Hence,] sanRaniI hecaA AlXRaIoCu (assumed tropical:) This thing [sharpened my appetite;] made me desirous of food. (K.) The Arabs say [also] AlHamoDu tasunRu AlUibila EalaI AlxulRapi (assumed tropical:) The [plants, or trees, called] HmD strengthen the camels [or sharpen their appetites] for the [plants, or trees, called] xlRp, like as the whetstone strengthens [or sharpens] the edge of the knife. (L.) ― -b8- [Hence also,] sanRa OaDoraAsahu, (M, L, K, *) [aor. and] inf. n. as above, (M, L,) He rubbed and cleaned his teeth with the stick used for that purpose; (M, L, K;) as though he polished them. (M, L.) ― -b9- And sanRa AlUibila, (ISk, S, M, L,) or AlmaAla, (K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M, L,) He tended well, (K,) or pastured and tended well, (ISk, S, L,) or pastured, and rendered fat, or plump, (M, L,) the camels, (ISk, S, M, L,) or the cattle; (K;) [so that they became in good condition, free from mange or the like;] as though he polished them. (ISk, S, M, L, K.) ― -b10- And sanRuwA AlmaAla They sent the cattle into the pasturage. (El-Muärrij, S, L, K. *) ― -b11- And sanRa AlUibila, (M, L, K,) [aor. and] inf. n. as above, (M, L,) He drove the camels quickly: (M, L, K:) or, as some say, AlsRanRu signifies AlsRayoru AlXRadiydu [i. e. the making to go vehemently; AlsRayoru being here syn. with AltRasoyiyru]: (M, L:) you say, sananotu AlnRaAqapa I made the she-camel to go (sirotuhaA, S, or sayRarotuhaA, L) vehemently. (S, L.) ― -b12- UKnRamaA UunasRaI liOasunRa, occurring in a trad., meaning I am made to forget only that I may drive men by directing to the right way, and show them what is needful for them to do when forgetfulness occurs to them, may be from sanRa [expl. above as] meaning “ he pastured and tended well ” the camels. (L.) ― -b13- sanRa Ealayohi AlmaMCa, [aor. and inf. n. as above,] He poured forth the water upon him, or it; (M, L, K;) as also AsnRhu↓: (Ham p. 611:) or he discharged the water gently upon him, or it. (M, L.) You say, sananotu AlmaMCa EalaI wajohiI, (S, L,) or EalaI Alwajohi, (Msb,) or sanRa AlmaMCa EalaI wajohihi, (L,) or fiI wajohihi, (Mgh,) aor. as above, (Mgh, L,) and so the inf. n., (L,) I [or he] discharged the water without scattering upon his face: if scattering it in pouring, you say, Xananotu: (S, L:) or I, or he, poured the water gently (Mgh, L, Msb) upon the face, (Msb,) or upon his face. (Mgh, L.) And sanRa AltRuraAba He poured the dust, or earth, gently upon the ground: (S, L:) and he put it gently upon a corpse. (L.) And sanRati AlEayonu AldRamoEa, aor. and inf. n. as above, The eye poured forth tears. (M, L.) And Ausonuno quruwna farasika Make the [issues of] sweat to flow from thy horse by plying him hard, in order that he may become lean, or light of flesh: and sunRa lahu qaronN, and quruwnN, An issue, and issues, of his sweat, was, and were, made to flow. (L.) sanRa Ealayohi AldRiroEa, (S, M, L, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (S, M, L,) He put (lit. poured) upon him the coat of mail. (S, M, L, K.) ― -b14- sanRa AlfaHolu AlnRaAqapa The stallion threw down the she-camel (kabRahaA, in copies of the K [erroneously] rakibahaA,) upon her face. (L, K. * [See also 3.]) ― -b15- sanRa AlTRiyna He plastered pottery with the clay: (M, L:) or he made the clay into pottery. (M, L, K.) ― -b16- sanRahu, (S, L, K,) aor. as above, (S,) and so the inf. n., (S, L,) also signifies He formed it, fashioned it, or shaped it; (S, L, K;) namely, a thing: (K:) and some say, he made it long. (L.) ― -b17- And [from the former of these two meanings, app.,] He instituted, established, or prescribed, it, i. e. a custom, practice, usage, or the like, whether good or bad; set the example of it; originated it as a custom &c. to be followed by others after him. (L.) You say, sananotu lakumo sunRapF faQtRabiEuwhaA [I have instituted &c., for you an institute, a custom, a practice, a usage, or the like, to be followed, therefore follow ye it]. (L.) And sanRa fulaAnN TariyqFA mina Alxayori, aor. and inf. n. as above, Such a one originated [or instituted] an act of goodness, or piety, [or a good, or pious, way of acting,] which his people knew not, and which they afterwards followed, or pursued. (L.) And sanRa QllRehu sunRatahu lilnRaAsi God manifested, or made known, his statutes, or ordinances, and commands and prohibitions, [i. e. his laws,] to men: (M, L:) and sanRa QllRehu sunRapF God manifested, or made known, a right way [of acting &c.]: (L:) [and in like manner one says of any one,] sanRa AlOamora He manifested, or made known, the thing, affair, or case. (K.) ― -b18- And sanRa sunRapF, (M, L,) or TariyqapF, (K,) [aor. and] inf. n. as above, (M, L,) He pursued [a way, course, rule, mode, or manner, of acting or conduct or life or the like]; as also AstnRhA↓; (M, L;) or AstsnRhA↓; (so in the K;) and bihaA AstnR↓: (K in art. syr:) and biTariyqK mina Alxayori AstsnRwA↓ [They followed, or pursued, a good, or pious, way of acting]. (L.) It is said in a trad. respecting the Magians, Oaholi AlkitaAbi sunRuwA bihimo sunRapa↓, i. e. Pursue ye with them the way of the People of the Scripture, or Bible; act with them as ye act with these; granting them security on the condition of receiving [from them] the [tax called] jizoyap. (Mgh, L. *) ＝ -A2- sunRa is also expl. as meaning He, or it, became altered for the worse, or stinking: so in a trad. of Barwaa the daughter of Wáshik, where it is said, kaAna zawojuhaA sunRa fiI biYorK [Her husband had become altered for the worse, or stinking, having died, in a well which he had descended]: from the saying in the Kur mino HamaO masonuwnK: [see masonuwnN:] but some say that he [who used this phrase] meant [to say, or meant thereby,] Oasina, i. e. his head became affected with vertigo by reason of a foul odour that he smelt, and he swooned. (L.)

2 snRnhu c
2. snRnhu: see 1, near the beginning. ― -b2- [Hence,] snRn AlmanoTiqa (assumed tropical:) He made the speech good, or beautiful; (M, L, K;) as though he polished it. (M, L.) ― -b3- And snRn Uilayohi AlrRumoHa, (M, L, K,) inf. n. tasoniynN, (M, L,) He directed, or pointed, the spear towards him, or it. (M, L, K.)

3 sAnR AlnRaAqapa c
3. sAnR AlnRaAqapa, inf. n. musaAnRapN and sinaAnN, (S, M, L, K,) He (the stallion-camel) bit the she-camel with the fore part of the mouth: (L:) or he opposed himself to her, (M, L,) or drove her, (S, L,) or bit her with the fore part of the mouth, and drove her, (K,) to make her lie down, (S, M, L, K,) in order that he might cover her: (S, M, * L, K:) or he covered her without her desiring it, or before she desired it, by force. (IB, L.)

4 AsnR c
4. AsnR, (S, M, L, Msb, K,) inf. n. UisonaAnN, (Mgh, L, Msb,) said of a man, (S, M, L, Msb, K,) and of other than man, (Msb,) i. q. kabira [meaning He became advanced in age, or fullgrown], (S, L, Msb,) or kabirato sinRuhu [which means the same]; (M, L, K;) as also AstsnR↓: (K:) but Az says that AlUisonaAnu in the case of an animal of the ox-kind and of the sheep or goat, is not the same as in that of a man: for in such animals it means [the attaining to the age of] the coming forth of the [permanent] vaniyRap [or central incisor]: (Msb:) or in such animals it means at least [the attaining to the age of] the shedding of the [tooth called] vnyRp [which is generally said to be in the third year]; and at the utmost in such animals, [the attaining to the age of] what is termed AlSRuluwg or AlsRuluwg [which is in the sixth year]; and at the utmost in camels, [the attaining to the age of] what is termed Albuzuwl [which is generally in the ninth year]. (Mgh, L.) [It is also expl. in the K as meaning His tooth grew forth: but the right explanation is one given in the Mgh and L; i. e. his tooth whereby he became masinR grew forth.] lamo yusonano, occurring in a trad. of Ibn-'Omar, as some relate it, is a mistake for lamo yusonino. (Mgh, L.) And Albadanapu sunRati↓, a phrase mentioned by Kt, as meaning The teeth of the bdnp grew forth, is also a mistake [for OasanRat]. (L.) ― -b2- You say also, AsnR sadiysu AlnRaAqapi The [tooth called] sdys of the she-camel grew forth, i. e. in the eighth year. (S, L.) ＝ -A2- Also, said of God, He made a tooth to grow forth. (S, L, K.) QllRehu sanRahaA↓, [referring to the teeth of a badanap,] a phrase mentioned by Kt, is a mistake [for OasanRahaA]. (L.) ― -b2- See also 1, in the former half of the paragraph, in two places.

5 tsnRn bihi c
5. tsnRn bihi [He took him, or it, as an exemplar, example, or object to be imitated]. (K voce qudowapN.) ― -b2- tsnRn fiI Eadowihi He (a man) went at random, heedlessly, or in a headlong manner, in his running; as also AstnR↓. (M, L.) ＝ -A2- See also 5 in art. snh, last signification.

6 tasaAnRati AlfuHuwlu c
6. tasaAnRati AlfuHuwlu i. q. takaAdamat [meaning The stallion-camels bit one another with the fore part of the mouth]. (L, K.)

10 Uisotasonana
10: see 4: ＝ -A2- and see also 1, near the end of the paragraph, in two places. ― -b2- AisotasanRati AlTRariyqu The road was travelled. (K.)

R. Q. 1 sanosanati AlrRiyHu c
R. Q. 1. sanosanati AlrRiyHu The wind blew coldly, or coolly; as also nasonasat: so in the Nawádir. (L.)

sinRN c
sinRN i. q. DirosN [as meaning A tooth; in which sense this latter word is often used; though it is frequently restricted to a molar tooth, or to any of the teeth except the central incisors]: (M, L, K:) [or, accord. to some, a single tooth; i. e. one that is not of the double, or molar, kind; as shown by a description in what follows:] of the fem. gender: (S, M, L, Msb:) pl. OasonaAnN (S, M, L, Msb, K) and OasinRapN and OasunRN, (M, L, K,) the last of these mentioned by Lh, and this and the second anomalous; (M, L;) or the second is allowable as pl. of the first of these pls.; (S;) or it is pl. of the sinaAn of the spear; but may also be pl. of OasonaAnN as pl. of sinRN applied to herbage upon which camels pasture, in an instance to be cited in what follows: (A'Obeyd, T, L:) the vulgar say UisonaAn and OusonaAn, which are wrong: (Msb:) the OasonaAn of a human being consist of four vanaAyaA, and four rabaAEiyaAt, and four OanoyaAb, and four nawaAjic, and sixteen OaDoraAs: or, as some say, four vnAyA, and four rbAEyAt, and four AnyAb, and four nwAjc, and four DawaAHik, and twelve OaroHaMC: (Msb:) or the OasonaAn and OaDoraAs together make up the number of thirty-two; the vnAbA are four, two above and two below [in the middle]; next are the rbAEyAt, which are four, two above and two below; next are the AnyAb, which are four [likewise, two above and two below]; and next are the ADrAs, which are twenty, on each side five above and five below; and of these [last] the four that are next to the AnyAb are the DwAHk; next to each nAb, above and below, is a DaAHik; next to the DwAHk are the TawaAHin, also called the OaroHaMC, which are twelve, on each side [above and below] three; and next to these are the nwAjc, which are the last of the teeth in growth, and the last of the ADrAs, on each side of the mouth one above and one below: (Zj in his “ Khalk el-Insán: ”) the dim. of sinRN is sunayonapN↓, because it is fem. (S.) One says, laA Mtiyka sinRa AlHisoli, (S, M, L,) i. e. I will not come to thee as long as remains the tooth of the young one of the [kind of lizard called] DabR; (M, L;) meaning, ever; (S, M, * L;) because the Hsl never sheds a tooth: (S, L:) or, as Lh relates it, on the authority of ElMufaddal, sinRaIo HisolK; [using the dual form of sinRN;] and [it may be rendered, accord. to the former reading, (assumed tropical:) during the life of the young one of the DRb, for] he says, they assert that the DbR lives three hundred years, and that it is the longest-lived creeping thing upon the earth. (M, L.) A poet (Aboo-Jarwal El-Jushamee, whose name was Hind, L) says, describing camels taken as a bloodwit,
fajaMCato kasinRi AlZRaboIi lamo Oara mivolahaA
bawaMCa qatiylK Oawo Haluwbapa jaAYiEi
[And they came; (assumed tropical:) like the age of the gazelle was the age of every one of them: I have not seen the like of them for an equivalent of a slain person, or a milch camel of one hungry: (I have given a reading of this verse that I have found in the M and TA in art. ZbI, instead of that in the present art. in the S and L, in which snMCa and sanaMCa are put in the place of bawaMCa app. for sinaMCa, an inf. n. of saAnaAhu, and as such here meaning a soothing, or the like:)] he means that they were vunoyaAn, [pl. of vaniIRN], because the vaniIR is one shedding [or that has shed] his vaniyRap, and the gazelle has no vaniyRap [in the upper jaw], so that he is always [one that may be termed] a vaniIR. (S, L.) It is said in a trad., UicaA saAfarotumo fiI AlxiSobi faOaEoTuwA AlrRukuba OasinRatahaA, [expl. as] meaning When ye journey in the land abounding with herbage, enable ye the ridden beasts to take of the pasturage: (S, L:) but Az states that A'Obeyd says, I know not OasinRap except as pl. of the sinaAn of the spear; and if the trad. be [correctly] preserved in memory, it seems to be pl. of OasonaAn; for sinRN [sometimes] signifies the [portion of] herbage upon which camels pasture; and its pl. is OasonaAnN; one says, OasonaAnN mina AlmaroEaI; and the pl. of OasonaAnN is OasinRapN: Aboo-Sa'eed says that this last is pl. of sinaAnN, not of OasonaAnN, and sinaAnN↓ is applied to the [plants, or trees, called] HamoD, as meaning (assumed tropical:) a strengthener [i. e. a sharpener of the appetite] of the camels for the [plants, or trees, called] xulRap: [see a phrase in the earlier part of the first paragraph:] in like manner, also, [he says,] when they light upon what is termed sinRN mina AlmaroEaI [a portion of pasturage], this is termed EalaI AlsRayori sinaAnN↓ [a strengthener, or sharpener, for journeying]: this explanation is approved by Az, and likewise that of A'Obeyd: it is also related, on the authority of Fr, that AlsRinRu signifies the eating vehemently: [a signification mentioned in the K as well as in the L:] and Az says, I have heard more than one of the Arabs say, OaSaAbati AlUibilu Alyawoma sinRFA mina AlmaroEaI [The camels have obtained to-day a good portion of pasturage] when they have eaten well of the best of the pasturage: Z says that OaEoTuwA AlrRukuba OasinRatahaA↓ means (assumed tropical:) Give ye to the ridden beasts what will prevent their being slaughtered; for when their owner pastures them well, they become fat, and goodly in his eye, and therefore he withholds himself, with niggardliness, from slaughtering them, and this [condition of them] is likened to OasinRap [as meaning “ spear-heads ”] pl. of sinaAnN: [see also Oaxacato rimaAHahaA, said of camels, voce rumoHN:] or if the pl. of sinRN be intended by it, the meaning is, enable ye them [i. e. the ridden beasts] to take of the pasturage; and hence the trad., OaEoTuwA AlsRinRa HaZRahaA mina AlsRinRi, i. e. Give ye the possessors of the sinR [meaning tooth] their share of the sinR which is the pasture. (L.) AlsRinRu is also used for cawaAtu AlsRinRi [The possessors of the tooth] as meaning the slave and horses and the like and other animals, [collectively, in like manner as xufRN and HaAfirN are used,] in a trad. of 'Omar. (L.) And it is said in a trad. of Ibn-Dhee-Yezen, laOuwTiYanRa OasonaAna AlEarabi kaEobahu, for cawiI OasonaAni AlEarabi, meaning [I will assuredly make] the great men and the nobles [of the Arabs to tread upon his ankle]. (L.) [But AsnAn in this instance may be pl. of sinRN in the sense here next following; so that cwI AsnAn
may be rendered the advanced in age.]) ― -b2- Hence, (L,) (tropical:) Life; (S, M, L, Msb;) metaphorically used in this sense as indicative of its length and its shortness; (L;) [for the teeth vary with the length of life;] the measure, (K,) or extent, of life; (Msb, K;) [the age attained;] used in relation to human beings and others: (M, L, K:) of the fem. gender in this sense also, (M, L, Msb,) because meaning mudRapN: (Msb:) pl. OasonaAnN, (M, L, K,) only. (M, L.) You say rajulN Hadiyvu AlsRinRi, meaning (assumed tropical:) A young man. (S, Msb, K, all in art. Hdv.) And jaAwazotu OasonaAna Oaholi bayotiI (assumed tropical:) [I have exceeded] the lives of the people of my house. (L.) And SadaqaniI sinRa bakorihi [and sinRu bakorihi, expl. in art. bkr]. (L.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) A like, an equal, or a match, in age, of another; (M, L, K;) like tinRN; (M, L;) as also saniynN↓, (M, L, K,) and siniynN↓, (L,) or sanynapN↓: (M, K:) in this sense also fem.; and [therefore] the dim. is sunayonapN↓; (L;) one says, AiboniI sunayonapu Qbonika [My son is the equal in age of thy son]: (El-Kanánee, L:) and the pl. is OasunRN and OasonaAnN. (L.) ― -b4- Also (assumed tropical:) A tooth of a minojal [or reaping-hook]: (M, L, K: *) pl. OasonaAnN, signifying its OuXur. (L and K in art. AXr.) ― -b5- [And (assumed tropical:) A tooth of a comb.] The Arabs say kaOasonaAni AlmuXoTi meaning (assumed tropical:) [Like the teeth of the comb] in equality, in respect of any state, or condition: but if they mean equality in respect of evil, they say
sawaAsiyapN kaOasonaAni AlHimaAri
[Equals like the teeth of the ass]; swAsyp being an anomalous pl. of sawaMCN. (Har p. 39.) ― -b6- And (assumed tropical:) The nib, i. e. the place of paring, of a writingreed: (S, L, K:) [and each lateral half of that part; for] the writing-reed has a right sinR and a left sinR: (TA in art. Hrf:) [and sinRapN↓ occurs in the K voce jilofapN as meaning the point of a writing-reed.] One says, OaTilo sinRa qalamika wasamRinohaA waHarRifo qiTRataka waOayominohaA [Make long the nib, or pared portion, of thy writing-reed, and make it thick (lit. fat), and make thy mode of cutting the extremity of the nib oblique, and make it to incline towards the right]. (S, L. *) ― -b7- A tooth [or pin] of a key [app. of the kind of wooden lock called DabRap, q. v.]. (MA.) ― -b8- See also sinosinN. ― -b9- Also, (M, K, and A and K in art. fS,) or sinRapN↓, (S, JM,) A clove, (faSRN, S and A as syn. with sinRN in art. fS, and JM in explanation of sinRapN in the present art., or faSRapN, S and L in explanation of sinRapN,) or a HabRap [app. here meaning small distinct portion] of the head [app. here meaning bulb], (M and L and K in explanation of sinRN,) of garlic. (S, M, A, L, K, JM.) ＝ -A2- [Accord. to some,] one says, waqaEa fulaAnN fiI sinRi raOosihi, meaning Such a one fell into [what equalled] the number of his hairs, of good, (M, * L, K, *) and of evil: (L:) or, as some say, into what he willed, or wished, and had authority to decide: (L, K:) but this is a mistranscription: (Meyd:) the correct saying is fiI siIRi raOosihi, (Az, Meyd, L,) and sawaMCi raOosihi, meaning he fell into a state of enjoyment, or welfare; (Meyd;) the former sometimes expl. as meaning, [he lighted upon, or came upon, what equalled] the number of the hairs of his head, of wealth, or good: (A'Obeyd, Meyd:) or what equalled [the hairs of] his head, of abundance of herbage, or of the goods, conveniences, or comforts, of life: (Az, L, and Meyd * on the authority of IAar:) the saying is a prov. (Meyd.) ＝ -A3- AlsRinRu also signifies The wild bull. (L, K.)

sanRapN c
sanRapN, (K,) or sinRapN↓, (so in the L,) A she-bear; syn. dubRapN. (K: in the L dibRap.) And A she-lynx: syn. fahodapN. (L, K.)

sunRapN c
sunRapN A way, course, rule, mode, or manner, of acting or conduct or life or the like; syn. TariyqapN, (Mgh, L, Msb,) as also sananN↓, (S, L,) and siyrapN; (S, M, L, Msb, K;) whence the saying, sunRuwA bihimo sunRapa Oaholi AlkitaAbi, expl. in the first paragraph of this art., last sentence but one, (Mgh,) and the saying of the Hudhalee [Khálid Ibn-Zuheyr] cited in the first paragraph of art. syr; (S;) and this is [said to be] the primary signification; (L;) whether good, or bad; (M, L;) approved or disapproved: (Msb:) or, accord. to Sh, a way [of acting &c.] that has been instituted, or pursued, by former people, and has become one pursued by those after them; and this, he says, is the primary signification: (L:) it signifies also [particularly] a way of acting &c. that is commended, or approved, and right; wherefore one says, fulaAnN mino Oaholi AlsRunRapi [Such a one is of the people of the commended and right way of acting &c.; generally meaning, of those who follow the institutes, or ways, of the Prophet]; and is from sananN↓ signifying “ a way, ” or “ road; ” (T, L;) and is also syn. with sananN: (L:) and [the laws, i. e] the statutes, or ordinances, and commands and prohibitions, of God: (Lh, M, L, K:) [also a practice or saying, or the practices and sayings collectively, of Mohammad, or any other person who is an authority in matters of religion, namely, any prophet, or a Companion of Mohammad, (see Kull p. 203,) as handed down by tradition:] when used unrestrictedly in matters of the law, AlsRunRapu means only what the Prophet [Mohammad] has commanded, and what has been handed down from him by tradition, [or, as in the JM, and what he forbade,] and what he has invited to do, by word or deed, of such things as are not mentioned in the Kur-án; wherefore one says, in speaking of the directions, or evidences, of the law, AlkitaAbu waAlsRunRapu meaning the Kur-án and the Traditions: (L:) [thus used, it may be rendered the institutes of the Prophet; or his rule or usage:] or in the law it signifies the way of acting &c. that is pursued in religion without being made obligatory, or necessary; it is what the Prophet persevered in doing, or observing, with omitting, or neglecting, [it] sometimes; and if the said persevering is in the way of religious service, it constitutes [what are termed] sunanu AlhudaI; if in the way of custom, sunanu AlzRawaAYidi: so that sunRapu AlhudaI [the sunRap of right direction] is that of which the observance is a completion of religion, and it is that to the omission, or neglect, whereof attach blame and misdemeanour; and sunRapu AlzRawaAYidi [the sunRap of supererogatory acts] is that of which the observance is good, but to the omission, or neglect, whereof neither blame nor misdemeanour attaches, such as the ways of the Prophet in his standing and sitting and clothing and eating: (KT:) sunanN is the pl. (Msb.) sunRapu AlOawRaliyna, in the Kur xviii. 53, i. e. sunRatunaA fiI AlOawRaliyna [The way pursued by us in respect of the former, or preceding peoples], means the destruction decreed to befall them; (Jel;) or extirpation; (Bd;) or, as Zj says, their beholding punishment; (OanRahumo EaAyanuwA AlEacaAba; [or, as expl. in the K, muEaAyanapu AlEacaAbi;]) for the believers in a plurality of gods said, [as is related in the Kur viii. 32,] O God, if this be the truth from Thee, then do Thou rain down upon us stones from heaven. (M, L.) ― -b2- Also Nature; natural, or native, disposition, temper, or other quality or property: (M, L, K:) pl. sunanN. (M, L.) ― -b3- And The face; (M, L, K;) because of its polish and smoothness: (M, L:) or the ball of the cheek (HurRu Alwajohi): or the circuit (daAYirap) of the face: or the form: (M, L, K:) or the form of the face: (S:) or the forehead and two sides thereof: (M, L, K:) all from the meaning of polish and smoothness and evenness: (M, L:) or the principal part of the face; the part thereof in which beauty is generally known to lie: (M in art. Am:) or the side of the cheek: pl. sunanN. (L.) You say, rajulN qabiayHu AlsRunRapi A man foul, or ugly, in respect of the form, and of what confronts one, of the face. (L.) And huwa OaXobahu XaIoCK sunRapF waOumRapF He is the most like thing in form, and face, and in stature. (L.) ― -b4- And The black line, or streak, on the back of the ass. (L.) ＝ -A2- Also, (S, K,) or sinRapN↓, (so in the L,) A sort of dates, of ElMedeeneh, (S, L, K,) well known. (L.)

sinRapN c
sinRapN: see sinRN, in the last quarter of the paragraph, in two places. ― -b2- Also i. q. sikRapN, meaning A ploughshare; i. e. the iron thing with which the ground is ploughed up: (AA, IAar, S, L: [see also luWamapN:]) pl. sinanN. (L.) ― -b3- [And] A twoheaded faOosK [i. e. hoe or adz or axe]: (K:) or [its pl.] sinanN signifies [simply] i. q. fuWuwsN [pl. of faOosN]. (L.) ＝ -A2- See also sanRapN: ＝ -A3- and see sunRapN, last sentence.

sananN c
sananN A way, or road: (T, L:) the main and middle part thereof; (A'Obeyd, Mgh, L;) the beaten track, or part along which one travels, thereof; as also sunanN↓: (A'Obeyd, L:) the nahoj [i. e. plain, or open, track] of the road; and so sunanN↓ and sununN↓ (M, L, K) and sinanN↓: (K:) and, all of these, the course, or direction, of the road: (M, L, K:) but ISd says, [in the M,] I know not sinanN↓ on any other authority than that of Lh. (L.) One says, tanaHRa Eano sanani AlTRariyqi (S, L, Msb) and sunanihi↓ and sununihi↓ [Go thou away, or aside, from the main and middle part of the road, or from the beaten track thereof; &c.]:
(S, L:) and Eano sanani Alxayoli (S, Msb) from the way of the horses, (Msb,) or from the course, or direction, thereof. (S.) And taraka fulaAnN laka sanana AlTRariyqi and suanahu↓ (Lh, M, L) and sununahu↓ (L) and sinanahu↓ (Lh, M, L) [respecting which last see what precedes] Such a one left, or has left, to thee the course, or direction, of the road. (Lh, M, L.) And AimoDi EalI sananika and sunanika↓ (L) or sununika↓ (M) Go along on thy course. (M, L.) sananN also signifies A way of acting or the like; syn. TariyqapN; (S, L;) as also sunRapN: (Mgh, L, Msb: see the latter word, in the former half of the paragraph, in two places:) you say, AisotaqaAma fulaAnN EalaI sananK waAHidK [Such a one went on undeviatingly in one way]: (S, L, Msb: *) and [in like manner] jaMCati AlrRiyHu sanaAYina↓ The wind came in one way, (S, K,) in one course, or direction, and one way, (M, L,) not varying: (S, L:) and [similar to the former of these two phrases is the saying] banaI Alqawomu buyuwtahumo EalaI sananK waAHidK i. e. [The people, or party, built their houses, or constructed their tents,] in one mode, or manner. (M, L.) Also The aim, or intention, of a man. (ISh, M, * L.) [Accord. to Fei,] AlsRananu also signifies Alwajohu mina AlOaroDi [by which may be meant The place, or tract, or quarter, of the land, towards which one goes; or it may mean the face, or surface, of the ground]: and so sununN↓ and sunanN↓. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- AlsRananu also signifies AlUibilu tasotanRu fiI EadowihaA [app. meaning The camels that leap, spring, or bound, in their running; (see 8;) or rather AlsRananu mina AlUibili has this meaning, as appears from what here follows]: (K:) or [a horse, or camel,] that perseveres in his running and advancing and retiring: and one says, jaMCa sananN mina Alxayoli, i. e. XawoTN [app. meaning There came a number of horses running a heat; for XwT in this explanation seems, from the phrase to which it relates and from what immediately precedes the mention of that phrase, to be an inf. n. used as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates, and therefore, agreeably with a common rule, applied to a pl. number as well as to a single individual]: (M, L:) and jaMCa mina Alxayolu sananN laA yuradRu wajohuhu [app. meaning, in like manner, There came, of the horses, a number running a heat, the course of which was not to be turned away]; (S, L; not expl. in either;) and so, mina AlUibili [of the camels]. (L.) ― -b2- And Sh explains sananN as applied in a verse of El-Aashà to People, or a party, hastening to fight, or slay. (L.) ＝ -A3- Also, [as a quasi-inf. n.,] The leaping, springing, or bounding, [so I here render AisotinaAn, inf. n. of 8, which see for other, similar, meanings,] of camels and of horses. (L. [It is there mentioned in another place, and in the M, as a subst., meaning a quasi-inf.n., from AisotanRa.])

sunanN c
sunanN: see the next preceding paragraph, in six places. ― -b2- It is also pl. of sunRapN [q. v.]. (Msb, &c.)

sununN c
sununN: see sananN, in five places.

sinanN c
sinanN: see sananN, in three places.

sanaAn c
sanaAn, also pronounced sanRaAn: see sanaA, in art. snw and snI, last sentence.

sinaAnN c
sinaAnN, (K,) or sinaAnu rumoHK, (S, M, Mgh, Msb,) A spear-head; (K;) the iron [head] of a spear: so called because of its polish: (M, L:) pl. OasinRapN. (T, S, Msb, K.) One says, huwa OaTowaEu AlsRinaAni He is one to whom the spear-head is subservient, howsoever he will. (K.) ― -b2- See also an ex. of its pl. voce sinRN, in the middle of the paragraph. ＝ -A2- And sinaAnN is syn. with misanRN, q.v. (S, M, L.) ― -b2- See also sinRN, near the middle of the paragraph, in two places. ＝ -A3- Also Flies; syn. cibRaAnN [pl. of cubaAbN]. (El-Muärrij, L.)

sanuwnN c
sanuwnN A dentifrice; (S, M, L, K;) a medicament with which the teeth are rubbed and cleansed, compounded for the purpose of strengthening and freshening them: (L:) pl. sanuwnaAtN. (K in art. srT [where, in the CK, sufuwfaAtN is erroneously put in its place].) ＝ -A2- See also saniynapN.

sinuwna c
sinuwna and sunuwna pls. of sanapN: see this last in art. snh.

saniynN c
saniynN: see masonuwnN, in two places. ― -b2- Also What flows [upon, or from, the whetstone] on the occasion of sharpening iron [or a knife or the like], and which is always stinking. (Fr, L.) And What falls from a stone when one rubs, or grates, it (Fr, S, L, K) upon another stone. (Fr, L.) ＝ -A2- See also sinRN, in the latter half of the paragraph.

siniynN c
siniynN: see sinRN, in the latter half of the paragraph. ＝ -A2- See also sanapN (of which it is a pl.) in art. snh.

saniynapN c
saniynapN Elevated sands extending lengthwise upon the ground: or sands having the form of HibaAl [pl. of HabolN, q. v.]: and sanuwnN↓ is syn. therewith in the former or latter of these senses: (M, L:) or sanAYinu has the former of these meanings, and saniynapN is its sing. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- Also Wind: (M, L, K:) [or a gentle wind: (Freytag, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees:)] pl. sanaAYinu. (L.) ― -b2- See also the pl., in relation to wind, voce sananN, near the middle of the paragraph. ＝ -A3- See also sinRN, in the latter half of the paragraph.

sunayonapN c
sunayonapN: see sinRN, of which it is the dim., in the former half of the paragraph: ＝ -A2- and again, in the latter half of the same. ＝ -A3- See also sanapN (of which it is an irreg. dim.) in art. snh.

sinosinN c
sinosinN The edge (S, M, L, K) of a vertebra (S, M, L) or of the vertebræ (K) of the back; (S, M, L, K;) as also sinosinapN↓ and sinRN↓: (M, L, K:) pl. sanaAsinu: (S, L:) and the head [of any] of the bones of the breast: and the extremity of the rib in the breast: (K:) or, as some say, sanaAsinu signifies the heads of the extremities of the bones of the breast, which are the soft heads of the bones of the zawor: or the extremities of the ribs in the breast: or, of a horse, the prominent [ribs, or anterior parts of the ribs, called] jawaAniH, resembling the DuluwE, but stopping short of the DuluwE: (M, L:) or the upper part of the hump of a camel: (Ham p. 689:) [or the middle of the lower part of the hump; for,] accord. to Az, laHomu sanaAsini AlbaEiyri signifies the flesh that is between the two sides, or halves, of the hump of the camel; which is the best of the sorts of flesh, and is marbled with fat: (L:) or sanaAsinu signifies bones [in general]; as also XanaAXinu: (IAar, L:) and (S) accord. to Ibn-'Amr [or Aboo-'Amr?] and others, (L,) it signifies the heads of the maHaAlap [app. here meaning vertebræ]; (S, L;) and [it is also said that the sing.] sinosinN signifies the head of the maHaAlap [which signifies a vertebra as well as vertebræ, or is more correctly without p when applied to the latter]. (K.) ＝ -A2- Also Thirst. (K.)

sinosinapN c
sinosinapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

sanosaAnN c
sanosaAnN [app. A blast of smoke]. One says nasonaAsN mino duxaAnK and sanosaAnN, meaning [of] the smoke of fire. (L in the present art. and TA in art. ns.)

riyHN sanosaAnapN c
riyHN sanosaAnapN A cold, or cool, wind; as also nasonaAsapN. (L.)

UasanRu c
UasanRu More [and most] advanced in age: (M, L, K:) a correct Arabic word. (M, L.) You say, hecaA OasanRu mino hecaA This is more advanced in age than this: (M, L, K: *) and Th says, speaking of Moosà Ibn-'Eesà-Leythee, Oadorakotuhu OasanRa Oaholi Albaladi [meaning I lived in his time, he being the most advanced in age of the people of the town, or country]. (M, L.)

musinRN c
musinRN Advanced in age, or full-grown; (L, Msb;) applied to a beast, contr. of fatiIRN: (S and Mgh and Msb in art. ftw:) or, applied to an animal of the ox-kind and to the sheep or goat, [at the least,] in the third year: (L: [see the verb, 4:]) fem. with p: (Msb:) pl. masaAnRN, (L, Msb,) which, applied to camels, is [said to be] syn. with kibaArN [as meaning advanced in age, or full-grown], (K,) contr. of OafotaMCu [pl. of fatiIRN] so applied. (S, L.)

misanRN c
misanRN A whetstone; i. e. a stone, (S, M, L, Msb,) or anything, (K,) with which, (S, K,) or upon which, (M, L, Msb, K,) one sharpens, or whets, or makes sharp-pointed, (S, M, L, Msb, K,) and polishes, (M, L, K,) a knife and the like; (Msb;) and sinaAnN↓ signifies the same. (S, M, L.)

masonuwnN c
masonuwnN [Bitten with the teeth: whence, app., what next follows]. You say OaroDN masonuwnapN and saniynN↓ meaning Land of which the herbage has been eaten. (L, K.) ― -b2- Sharpened, or whetted, or made sharp-pointed, and polished; as also saniynN↓; (M, L, K;) applied to a knife (K) or thing [of any kind]. (M, L.) Made smooth. (S, L.) Formed, fashioned, or shaped. (S, M, L.) Made long. (L.) You say wajohN masonuwnN (assumed tropical:) A face in which is length, without breadth; (maxorwuTN;) smooth and even; or smooth and long; or long, and not high in the ball; or soft, tender, thin, and even; as though the flesh were ground (sunRa
[like as a thing is ground in sharpening and polishing]) from it. (M, L.) And rajulN masonuwnu Alwajohi (assumed tropical:) A man beautiful and smooth in the face: (Lh, M, L, K:) or a man in whose nose and face is length: (S, L, K:) or beautiful and long in the face. (L.) mino HamaO masonuwnK, in the Kur [xv. 26 and 28 and 33], (L,) means (assumed tropical:) [Of black mud] altered [for the worse in odour]; (AA, S, L;) in which sense masonuwn is also applied to water; (AHeyth, L;) [or] stinking: (AA, S, M, L, K:) from sananotu AlHajara EalaI AlHajari “ I rubbed, or grated, the stone upon the stone; ” what flows between them, termed saniyn, being always stinking: (Ksh and Bd in xv. 26: [and the like is said in the L, on the authority of Fr:]) or, accord. to I'Ab, it means moist: accord to AO, poured forth: or, as some say, poured forth in a form, or shape: (L:) or formed, fashioned, or shaped: (Ksh, Bd:) or poured forth in order to its drying [or hardening], and becoming formed, fashioned, or shaped, like as molten, or liquified, substances are poured forth into moulds. (Ksh, * Bd.)

musotanRu AlHaruwri c
musotanRu AlHaruwri is said to mean The place of the running of the saraAb [or mirage, app. in consequence of the hot wind]: or the place of the vehement heat of the hot wind; as though it were running to and fro therein (kaOanRahaA tasotanRu fiyhi EadowFA): or it may mean the place whence issues the [hot] wind: but the first is the explanation given by the preceding authorities. (M, L.) ＝ -A2- AlmusotanRu [an epithet used as meaning] The lion. (K. [Thus applied, act. part. n. of AisotanRa.])

musotasanRu c
musotasanRu and musotasinRu: see what follows.

misanosanN c
misanosanN A travelled road; (T, M, L, and so in the CK; in some copies of the K musotasinRN↓;) as also musotasanRN↓. (K.)

sunobuwqN c
sunobuwqN A small zaworaq [or skiff], (Sgh, K, TA,) made on the coasts of the sea: a word of the dial. of the people of all the coasts of the Sea of El-Yemen: (Sgh, TA:) whether the n be radical requires consideration: Sgh says, in the Tekmileh, that the word is of the measure funoEuwlN, from AlsRaboqu. (TA.)

sunobukN c
sunobukN [mentioned in the S and Msb in art. sbk, and said in the latter to be of the measure funoEulN, The toe of a horse or mule or ass; i. e.] the extremity of the fore part of the solid hoof; (S, Msb;) or the extremity of the solid hoof (Lth, O, K) and its two sides anteriorly: (Lth, O:) pl. sanaAbiku. (S, O, Msb.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) The extremity (T, O, K, TA) of the naEol [or iron shoe at the lower end of the scabbard], (T, TA,) or of the Hiloyap [or gold or silver ornament], (O, K,) of a sword. (T, O, K, TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) The qawonas [or tapering top] of an iron helmet. (O, K,) ― -b4- Of a buroqaE (assumed tropical:) The XibaAm [meaning each, or either, of the two threads, or strings, of the face-veil called brqE, by which the woman draws and binds the two upper corners to the back of her head]: (K, TA: [in the CK, XiyAm is erroneously put for XibaAm:]) the sanaAbik of the brqE are its Xubum. (O.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) A rugged region or tract of the earth or land, in which is little, or no, good: (S, O, Msb, K:) likened to the snbk of the solid hoof. (S, O.) And sanaAbiku AlOaroDi (assumed tropical:) The extremities of the earth or land. (TA.) ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) The first of rain: (O, K:) and, (TA,) as some say, (Msb,) of anything. (Msb, TA.) One says, OaSaAbatonaA sunobukN AlsRamaMCi (assumed tropical:) [The first of the rain fell upon us]. (TA.) And one says also, sunobukN mino kacaA (assumed tropical:) Preceding such a thing. (O, K.) And kaAna celika EalaI sunobukihi (assumed tropical:) That was in the time thereof, (O, K, TA,) and in the first thereof. (TA.) ＝ -A2- It is also said to signify The [tax called] xaraAj: (O:) so says IAar. (TA.) ＝ -A3- And A sort of run. (K.)

Q. 1 sanobala AlzRaroEu c
Q. 1. sanobala AlzRaroEu The seed-produce put forth its sunobul [or ears]; (M, K;) as also Oasobala [q. v.]: the former of the dial. of Temeem, and the latter of that of El-Hijáz. (TA.) ＝ -A2- sanobala vawobahu, (K,) inf. n. sanobalapN, (TA,) He (a man) dragged a shirt of his garment behind him; so says Khálid Ibn-Jembeh: (TA:) or he dragged his garment behind him or before him. (K.)

sunobulN c
sunobulN [Ears of corn: n. un. with p: pl. sanaAbilu and sunobulaAtN, the latter pl. occurring in the Kur xii. 43 and 46: it is said in the M, in art. snbl, that sunobulapN signifies one of the sunobul of zaroE; in the K, in this art., that it signifies one of the sanaAbil of zaroE: see sabalN]. AlsRunobulapu is also the name of A certain sign of the Zodiac [i.e. Virgo]; (K, TA;) the sixth sign; the third of the summer signs: (TA:) [or Spica Virginis;] a certain star in Virgo. (Kzw.) [See, again, sabalN.] ― -b2- Also A certain perfume; (M;) a certain plant of sweet odour, also called sunobulu AlEaSaAfiyri, (K,) and AlrRyoHaAnu AlhinodiIRu; (TA;) [spikenard, called in the present day AlsRunobulu AlhinodiIRu;] the best whereof is the suwriIR, (K,) what is brought from suwr [or suwraI?], a town, or district, of El-'Irák; (TA;) and the weakest is the hinodiIR: it is an aperient; a discutient of flatulences; (K, * TA;) strengthening to the brain and the spleen and the kidneys and the bowels; and diuretic; and has the property of arresting the excessive flow of blood from the womb. (K, TA. [Mentioned also voce sabalN, as called sunobulu AlTRiybi.]) AlsRunobulu AlrRumiIRu [also signifies Spikenard, or perhaps a variety thereof;] i. q. AlnRaAridiynu.(K.)

sanobalapN c
sanobalapN The [kind of trees called] EiDaAh [q. v.]. (Fr, K.) [It is said in the TA that the n in this word is augmentative: but the same is held by some to be the case in other words mentioned in this art.]

qamiySN sunobulaAniIRN c
qamiySN sunobulaAniIRN A shirt ample in length, or reaching to, or towards, the ground: or so called in relation to a town, or district, in the Greek Empire. ('Abd-El-Wahháb El-Ghana wee, K, TA.)

2 snRt Alqidora c
2. snRt Alqidora, inf. n. tasoniytN, He put sanRuwt, (S, K,) meaning kamRuwn [i. e. cumin, or cuminseed], (S,) into the cooking-pot. (S, K.)

3 sAntwA AlOaroDa c
3. sAntwA AlOaroDa They sought after the herbage of the land, doing so diligently, or with labour or perseverance, or time after time. (M, K.)

4 AsntwA c
4. AsntwA They experienced drought, or barrenness: (S, M, A, K:) derived from sanapN; the w being changed into t, [for sanapN is originally sanowapN, or, accord. to one dial. sanohapN,] to distinguish between this verb and OasonaI as signifying “ he remained in a place a year: ” or, as Fr says, they imagined the h [meaning p, in sanapN,] to be a radical letter, finding it to be the third letter, and therefore changed it into t: (S:) accord. to Sb, the t [in Oasonata] is substituted for the I [in OasonaI]; and there is no instance of the like except vinotaAni [in which the t is substituted for the final radical, I], (M in the present art.,) and in words of the measure AifotaEala [as AitRasara for Aiytasara]. (M in art. vnI.)

5 tasanRatahaA c
5. tasanRatahaA [He married her, or took her as his wife, he being an ignoble, or a low-born, but rich, man, and she being a noble, or high-born, but poor, woman; or] he, an ignoble, or a low-born, man, married her, a noble, or high-born woman, because of the paucity of her property and the abundance of his property. (S) And tsnRt kariymapa Mli fulaAnK He married the noble or highborn, woman of the family of such a one in the year of drought, dearth, or scarcity. (TA.)

OaSaAbahumo sanatN c
OaSaAbahumo sanatN, for sanapN, Drought, or barrenness, afflicted them, or befell them. (S, TA.)

rajulN sanitN c
rajulN sanitN, (S, A, * K, *) or rajulN sanitu Alxayori, (M,) A man possessing little, or no, good; possessing few, or no, good things; or poor: (S, M, A, * K: *) pl. sanituwna: (M, K:) it has no broken pl. (M.) And the former, A man afflicted with drought, or barrenness; (TA in art. bqE;) as also musonitN↓: (TA in the present art.:) and rajulN musonitN↓ a man indigent and desolate, possessing nothing: probably from OaroDN musonitapN, or EaAmN musonitN, [both expl. below,] or from OasonatuwA meaning as expl. above. (MF.) ― -b2- And OaroDN sanitapN and musonitapN↓ Land that has not given growth to anything, (AHn, M, K,) in consequence of its not having been rained upon: but if containing any of the dry herbage of the preceding year, it is not termed msntp: it is not thus termed unless having in it nothing. (AHn, M.) [See also saniytN.]

rajulN sanuwtN c
rajulN sanuwtN A man evil in disposition. (M, L.) [See also masonuwtN.]

EaAmN saniytN c
EaAmN saniytN and musonitN↓ A year of drought, or barrenness. (AHn, M, K.) [See also sanitN.]

sanRuwtN c
sanRuwtN, also pronounced sinRawotN, (S, M, K,) the
latter a dial. var. mentioned by Kr, (M,) and sunRuwtN, a form mentioned by IAth and others, but the first is that which is commonly known, and the most chaste; (TA;) a word of which the meaning is differently explained, as follows: (M, TA:) Honey: (S, M, A, K:) i. q. rubRN [i. e. rob, or inspissated juice, &c.]: (M, K:) a species of dates: fresh butter; syn. zubodN: cheese: (K:) i. q. kamRuwnN [i. e. cumin, or cumin-seed]; (Yaakoob, S, M, K;) so in the dial. of El-Yemen: (M:) or a certain plant resembling the kamRuwn: (IAar, M:) i. q. sibitRN [i. e. anethum graveolens, or dill, of the common garden-species; in the CK XibitR]: and i. q. raAziyaAnajN; (M, K;) which last is what is called in the Egyptian dial. XamarN [a name given in Egypt to the anethum graveolens, above mentioned, and to its seed; and also to the anethum fæniculum, or fennel]. (TA.)

musonitN c
musonitN; and its fem., with p: see sanitN, in three places: and see also saniytN.

masonuwtN c
masonuwtN One who associates with another and is angry without cause, (K, TA,) by reason of his evil disposition. (TA.) [See also sanuwtN.]

1 sanaja c
1. sanaja He smeared anything with a colour different from its own colour. (O, K.)

sunujN c
sunujN The EunRaAb [or jujube]. (IAar, K.)

sanojapN c
sanojapN, as also SanojapN, but the former is the more chaste, (T, O, Msb, K,) accord to Fr, (O,) because S and j do not both occur in any [genuine] Arabic word, (Msb,) or the former only is allowable accord. to Fr, (T, Msb,) or, accord. to ISk, (T, O, Msb, and S in art. Snj,) and IKt, (T, Msb,) the latter only is allowable; (T, O, Msb, and S and O in art. Snj;) an arabicized word, (O, Msb, and S and A and K in art. Snj,) from [the Pers.] snk [or sanoGo, as meaning “ a weight ”]; (O;) [or rather from the Pers. sanojaho meaning “ a balance ” and “ a weight; ”] i. q. miyzaAnN [A balance]: (A in art. Snj:) [in the present day, applied to a steel-yard: and also, more commonly, (agreeably with the explanation of SanojapN in the MA,) to a weight of a balance; which last seems to be intended in the S and O and Msb and K &c. by the expressions sanojapu AlmiyzaAni and Sanojatuhu, unless these expressions be instances of what is termed UiDaAfapu AlXRaIoCi UilaI nafosihi (i. e. the prefixing a noun, governing the gen. case, to another noun signifying the same thing), which I think unlikely:] pl. sinajN (A, Msb) and sanajaAtN. (Msb.) One says, AitRazana mnRI biAlsRanojap AlrRaAjiHapi [He received by weight from me with the inclining balance, or with the preponderating weight], and biAlsRinaji AlwaAfiyapi [with the full weights]. (A.) And a rájiz says,
kaOanRahaA sanojapu OalofK raAjiHaho
[As though it, or she, were the weight of a thousand, preponderating]: or, as some relate it, SanojapN. (O.)

sunojapN c
sunojapN i. q. ruqoTapN [i. e. Blackness mixed with speckles of white: or the reverse: or speckles of white, and of black, and of red, and of yellow, in an animal]: (AA, O, K:) pl. sunajN, (O, K, TA, in the CK sunojN,) like HujarN (K, TA, in the CK like HujorN,) as pl. of HujorapN. (TA.)

sinaAjN c
sinaAjN The mark, or effect, of the siraAj [i. e. lamp, or its lighted wick], (A, O, K,) upon the wall. (O, K, TA.) One says, laAbudRa lilsRiraAji mina AlsRinaAji [The lamp, or its lighted wick, cannot but have the mark, or effect, thereof upon the wall]. (A.) ― -b2- Also The siraAj [itself; i. e. a lamp, or its lighted wick]: (ISd, K:) as also saniyjN↓. (K.)

saniyjN c
saniyjN: see what next precedes.

burodN musanRajN c
burodN musanRajN A [garment of the kind called] burod striped. (O, K.) [SM thinks that it may be a mistranscription for musabRajN, meaning “ wide, ” applied to a kisaMC: but this I think improbable.]

sinojaAbN c
sinojaAbN [a Pers. word, arabicized; in the pre sent day applied to The squirrel; and particularly the gray squirrel: and the minever:] a certain animal, of the length of the jerboa, larger than the faOor [or rat], the fur of which is of the utmost softness: furred garments are made with its skin; and the best skins of this animal are the smooth and gray. (Dmr, TA.)

sinojaAbiIRN c
[sinojaAbiIRN Gray; of the colour of the sinojaAb.]

1 sanaHa c
1. sanaHa is syn. with EaraDa [signifying It showed, or presented, its side: and hence, it presented itself; it occurred]. (A, O, L.) One says of a gazelle, (S, K,) or of a bird, (S, * A, Msb,) or some other thing, (IF, S, Msb, as implied by explanations of the part. n. saAniHN,) sanaHa (S, A, Msb, K) liI, (S,) or lahu, (A,) and Ealayohi, (L,) and sanaHahu, (A,) aor.
sanaHa
, (S, L,) inf. n. sunuwHN (S, L, K) and sunoHN and sunuHN; (L;) and sAnH↓, inf. n. sinaAHN; (S, TA;) [It presented to me, or to him, its right side, or its left side, in its passage;] it passed along from the direction of my [or his] left hand to the direction of my [or his] right hand: (S:) or it passed along from the direction of [my or] his right hand (A, L, Msb) to the direction of [my or] his left hand: (L, Msb: *) contr. of baraHa (K. [See saAniHN, below.]) And sanaHa liI fiI AlmanaAmi He presented himself to me in sleep; syn. EaraDa: occurring in a saying of 'Alee, referring to the Prophet. (O.) And sanaHa liI raOoIN (S, A, Msb, K) fiI kacaA, (S, Msb,) aor.
sanaHa
, inf. n. sunuwHN and sunoHN and sunuHN, (K, TA,) the second with damm and sukoon and the third with two dammehs, (TA, [but written in the CK sanoH and sunoH,]) (tropical:) An idea, or an opinion, presented itself, or occurred, syn. EaraDa, (S, A, K,) or appeared, syn. Zahara, (Msb,) to me, (S, A, * Msb, K,) respect ing such a thing. (S, Msb.) sanaHa is also said of poetry, (L, K,) meaning (assumed tropical:) It presented itself, or occurred, syn. EaraDa, to me (liI): (L:) or it became easy; (L, K;) and in this last sense, said of a thing, aor.
sanaHa
, inf. n. sunuwHN (Msb.) And it is related in a trad. of 'Áïsheh, that she said, [referring to the Prophet,] Oakorahu Oano OasonaHahu, mean ing I dislike that I should confront him with my hands [engaged] in prayer; from sanaHa as signify ing EaraDa. (L.) ― -b2- sanaHa bikacaA (assumed tropical:) He mentioned such a thing obliquely, or indirectly, (S, K,) in terms understood by the person addressed but uninteligible to others, (S,) not speaking explicitly. (K.) ― -b3- sanaHa AlxaATiru bihi i. q. jaAda (assumed tropical:) [The mind granted it liberally]. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- sanaHahu He turned him away, or back, (O, K,) EamRaA OaraAda [from that which he desired, or meant], (O,) or Eano raOoyihi [from his opinion]. (K.) ― -b2- And sanaHa bihi and Ealayohi He caused him to fall into straitness, or difficulty; or into sin, or crime; syn. OaHorajahu; (K, TA; in the CK, [erroneously,] Oaxorajahu;) [i. e. OawoqaEahu fiI AlHaraji;] and did evil to him. (K.)

3 saAonaHa
3: see 1, second sentence.

5 tasanRaHa
5: see 10. ＝ -A2- tasanRajo mina AlrRiyHi means AisotacoriminohaA [i. e. Shelter thyself from the wind]: so says Aboo-'Amr Esh-Sheybánee. (O [and so, probably, in correct copies of the K: in my MS. copy of the K, Aisotadori mnhA: in the CK, Aisotadiro mnhA: in the TA, strangely, AstdRar mnhA, and expl. as meaning AuTolubo mnhA AldRarRa: in the TK, Astdbr mnhA, and expl. as meaning wlRhA Zhrk: Freytag, app. having to choose only between the reading in the CK and that in the TK, has followed the latter, without mentioning their disagreement; though, if the meaning were “ turn thy back towards the wind, ” the explanation should be AisotadobirohaA, not AsotadobirominohaA].)

10 AisotasonaHotuhu Eano kacaA c
10. AisotasonaHotuhu Eano kacaA, and tasanRaHotuhu↓, i. q. AisotafoSaHotuhu [meaning I asked him, or desired him, to explain such a thing]: (O, K:) and so AisotanoHasotuhu En kcA, and tanaHRasotuhu. (TA.)

sunoHN c
sunoHN Prosperity, good fortune, good luck, or auspiciousness; blessing, increase, or plenty: syn. yumonN, and barakapN. (O, K.) ― -b2- Also, (K,) or sunuHN↓, with two dammehs, (O,) The middle of a road: (O, K:) like [sujuHN or] sujuHN. (O.) [Both are also inf. ns. of 1, q. v.]

sinoHN c
sinoHN i. q. OaSolN [i. e. Origin, &c.]; like sinoxN [q. v.]. (O, TA.) ― -b2- And i. q. hayoYapN and saHonaMCu [i. e. Form, aspect, appearance, &c.]. (O.)

sunuHN c
sunuHN: see sunoHN.

gaArapN sanoHaMCu c
gaArapN sanoHaMCu [app. as meaning An incursion into the territory of an enemy taking by surprise], accord. to one reading of a trad., is from sanaHa AlrRaOoIu [expl. above]: but the reading commonly known is saHRaMC [q. v.]. (IAth, TA.)

saniyHN c
saniyHN: see saAniHN. ＝ -A2- Also Pearls; or large pearls; syn. durRN: (O, K:) or (K, but accord. to the O, “ also ”) the string upon which they are to be strung, before they are strung thereon: (O, K:) when they have been strung, it is termed EiqodN: (O:) pl. sunuHN. (TA.) ― -b2- And [Ornaments such as are termed] HuliIR. (O, K.)

sinaAHapN c
sinaAHapN i. q. sutorapN [i. e. Anything by which a person or thing is veiled, concealed, hidden, or covered; &c.]. (O.)

sanaHonaHN c
sanaHonaHN A man who sleeps not during night: (K:) or sanaHonaHu AllRayoli a man who is vigilant; who sleeps not; who journeys during the night. (O.)

saAniHN c
saAniHN (S, A, Msb, K, &c.) and saniyHN↓ (S, A, K) both signify the same, (S, A, K,) applied to a gazelle, (S, K, *) or to a bird, (S, A, Msb,) &c., (S, Msb,) Turning its right side towards the spectator; thus expl. by Ru-beh to Yoo, in the presence of AO; i. e. passing from the direction of the left hand of the spectator towards the direction of his right hand: (S:) or coming from the direction of the right side of the spectator (Aboo-'Amr Esh-Sheybánee, IF, A, L, Msb) towards the direction of his left hand; turning towards him its left side, which is that termed AlUinosiIRu: contr. of baAriHN [q. v.]: (Aboo- 'Amr Esh-Sheybánee, L:) the pl. [of the former] is sawaAniHu and saAniHaAtN and [of either] sunuHN: and this last is also employed to signify auspicious and inauspicious gazelles [&c.], accord. to the different opinions of the Arabs. (L.) The Arabs [who apply the epithet in the latter of the two senses first explained] regard the saAniH as a good omen, and the baAriH as an evil omen; (Aboo-'Amr Esh-Sheybánee, S, L;) because one cannot shoot at the latter without turning himself: (S in art. brH:) but some of them hold the reverse of this: (Aboo-'Amr Esh-Sheybánee, L:) the people of Nejd hold the sAnH to be a good omen; but sometimes a Nejdee adopts the [contr.] opinion of the Hijázee. (IB, TA,) It is said in a prov., mano liI biAlsRaAniHi baEoda AlbaAriHi [expl. in art. brH]. (S, K.) ― -b2- [It is said in Har p. 671 that AlsRaAniHu also signifies AlmtTyRr AlmtfARl, as though meaning The person auguring, or who augurs, evil or good, from birds: but I think that the right reading is AlmutaTayRaru bihi waAlmutafaORalu bihi mina AlTRuyuwri, i. e. what is regarded as an evil omen and as a good omen, of birds.]

1 sanixato OasonaAnuhu c
1. sanixato OasonaAnuhu, (JK, A, TA,) [aor.
sanaxa
,] inf. n. sanaxN, (A,) His teeth became eroded at the roots. (JK, A, TA.) ― -b2- And sanixa, said of a man, He had his teeth eroded at the roots. (A, TA.) ― -b3- And said of the mouth, It lost the roots (OasonaAx) of its teeth. (Msb.) ― -b4- Also, (JK,) inf. n. as above, (K,) i. q. tgyRr [meaning (assumed tropical:) It became altered for the worse in odour or otherwise, stinking, rancid, bad, or corrupt]. (JK, K.) It is said [in this sense] of oil, (S, K,) or food, (A, L,) &c., (L,) as a dial. var. of zanixa, (S, K, *) or from sanaxu AlOasonaAni, and therefore tropical; as also tsnRx↓; (A;) its odour became bad. (S, * TA.) And sanixa mina AlTRaEaAmi He ate much food; syn. Oakovara. (L, K.) ＝ -A2- sanaxa, aor.
sanaxa
, inf. n. sunuwxN, (L, K,) He, or it, was, or became, firm, steady, steadfast, stable, fixed, fast, settled, or established; syn. rasaxa. (L, K *) So in the phrase sanaxa fiI AlEilomi, (S, L, Msb,) aor.
sanaxa
, (L,) or
sanuxa
, (Msb,) inf. n. sunuwxN, (S, L, Msb,) [He was, or became, firmly rooted or established, in knowledge, or science;] and this means also he attained to eminence therein. (L.)

2 tasoniyxN c
2. tasoniyxN The seeking, desiring, or demanding, a thing. (K.) You say, sanRaxa minohu AlXRaIoCa He sought, desired, or demanded, from him the thing. (TK.)

5 tasanRaxa
5: see 1.

sinoxN c
sinoxN The OaSol [i. e. origin, source, root, foundation, &c.,] (JK, S, Msb, K) of anything: (JK, Msb, TA:) as also sinoHN: (L:) pl. [of pauc.] OasonaAxN (L, Msb) and [of mult.] sunuwxN. (L.) One says, rajaEa fulaAnN UilaI sinoxi Alkarami [app. meaning Such a one traced back his lineage to an ancestor who was the origin, or source, of generosity or nobility: or such a one returned, or reverted, to the original state, or condition, of generosity: the latter I think the more probable, as it is immediately added], and UilaI sinoxihi Alxabiyvi [which seems to mean, to his bad original state]. (L.) And it is said in a trad., OaSolu AljihaAdi wasinoxuhu AlrRibaATu fiI sabiyli QllRehi i. e. AlmuraAbaTapu Ealayohi [meaning The very essence of fighting against unbelievers, and the first principle thereof, is constancy, or perseverance, or assiduity, in the way, or cause, of God]. (L.) ― -b2- Also The place of growth (manobit) [i. e. the socket] of a tooth: (K:) or the part of a tooth that enters into the flesh [of the gum]; (Zj in his “ Khalk el-Insán; ”) [i. e.] the OasonaAx of the teeth, (S,) or of the central incisors, (Msb,) are the roots thereof (OuSuwluhaA). (S, Msb.) ― -b3- And [The tongue, or tang, of a blade;] the part of a knife, and of a sword, that enters into, or is inserted in, the handle: and the part of an arrow-head that enters into, or is inserted in, the head of the shaft. (L.) ― -b4- And The paroxysm of a fever. (K.) ― -b5- OasonaAxu AlnRujuwmi, accord. to IAar, as is related by Th, means The stars that do not make their [temporary] abode in the Mansions of the Moon, which [latter] are called nujuwmu AlOaxoci: ISd says, I am not sure whether he mean the OuSuwl [a term applied to the seven, or five, planets], or others: some say, [and so IAar is stated in the TA in art. Xyx to have said,] that they are called only OaXoyaAxu AlnRujuwmi [q. v.]. (L, TA. *)

TaEaAmN sanixN c
TaEaAmN sanixN (tropical:) [Food altered for the worse in odour or otherwise, stinking, rancid, bad, or corrupt: see 1]. (A.) ― -b2- And baladN sanixN (assumed tropical:) A town, or country, in which is fever, or much fever. (K.)

sanoxapN c
sanoxapN and sanaAxapN↓ A fetid odour: and the latter, [and app. the former also,] dirt; and remains of matter used for tanning. (K, TA.) One says bayotN lahu sanoxapN (S, TA) and sanaAxapN↓ (TA) or sinaAxapN↓ (so in three copies of the S) [A tent, or house, or chamber, that has a fetid odour; as is indicated in the S and TA]. And Aboo-Kebeer says,
faOatayotu bayotFA gayora bayoti sinaMxapK↓
(so in three copies of the S,) or
fadaxalotu bayotFA gayora bayoti sanaMxapK↓
(so in the TA,) i. e. [And I came to, or and I entered,] a tent, or house, or chamber, not one of tanning-matter nor of clarified butter. (S.)

sunoxataAni c
sunoxataAni The measure of two statures of a man. (K.)

sanaAxapN c
sanaAxapN or sinaAxap: see sanoxapN, in five places.

bayotu fulaAnK bayotu saniyxapK c
bayotu fulaAnK bayotu saniyxapK means [The house of such a one is a house of unstableness; or] is not one of stableness. (JK.)

Oasonaxu c
[Oasonaxu, as stated by Freytag, is expl. by Reiske, in his additions to the Lex. of Golius, as meaning Pulled out from the root (snx): but no authority for this is named by him.]

1 sanad Uilayohi c
1. sanad Uilayohi, (S, M, Msb, K,) aor.
sanuda
, (S, M, Msb,) inf. n. sunuwdN; (S, M, Msb, K;) and sanida, aor.
sanada
; (Msb;) and Astnd↓, [which is the most common,] (S, M, Msb, K,) and tsAnd↓, (S, M, A, K,) and Asnd↓; (M, TA;) signify the same; (S, M, * Msb, K *;) i. e. He (a man, S, Msb, [and in like manner it is said of a thing,]) leaned, rested, or stayed himself, against it, or upon it; syn. AiEotamada; (TK;) [or AEtmd Ealayohi;] namely, a thing, (S, M, Msb,) or a wall, (A, Msb,) &c. (Msb.) ― -b2- sanadafiI Aljabali, (M, K,) aor.
sanuda
, inf. n. sunuwdN, (M,) He ascended the mountain; as also Asnd↓. (M, K.) And [hence,] UilaI fulaAnK Oasonadotu↓ (tropical:) I ascended to such a one. (A.) ― -b3- And sanada fiI Alxamosiyna, (M, and so in some copies of the K,) or liloxamosiyna, (so in other copies of the K,) (tropical:) He approached, or drew near to, [the age of] fifty: (K, TA:) [likewise] from sanada fiI Aljabali. (M, TA. *) ― -b4- sanada canabu AlnRaAqapi, (K,) or Oasonada↓, (so in the O,) The tail of the she-camel tossed about, and lashed her croup, or rump, on the right and left. (O, K.)

2 snRd c
2. snRd, inf. n. tasoniydN, He set up [pieces of] wood [as stays, or props,] against a wall. (KL.
[See the pass. part. n., below. And see also 3 and 4.]) ＝ -A2- Also, inf. n. as above, He (a man) wore, or clad himself with, the kind of burod called sanad. (IAar, K.)

3 saAnadotuhu UilaI AlXRaIoCa c
3. saAnadotuhu UilaI AlXRaIoCa: see 4. [Hence,] suwnida AlmariyDu [The sick man was stayed, or propped up, against a pillow or the like]: and qaAla saAniduwniI [He (the sick man) said, Stay ye me, or prop ye me up]. (A, TA.) And yusaAnidu baEoDuhu baEoDFA [One part of it stays, or supports, and so renders firm or strong, another part]. (Sh, O, K. [See musaAnadapN.]) ― -b2- [And hence,] suwnida xaloquhaA, referring to a she-camel, (assumed tropical:) Her frame, or make, was symmetrical; or conformable in its several parts. (Ham p. 783.) ― -b3- And sAndhu, (S, K,) inf. n. musaAnadapN, (S,) He aided, or assisted, him; namely, another man. (S, K.) ― -b4- And (tropical:) He requited, compensated, or recompensed, him, (A, K, TA,) EalaI AlEamali [for work, or for the work or deed]. (K.)

4 Oasonadotuhu UilaI AlXRaIoCa c
4. Oasonadotuhu UilaI AlXRaIoCa (AZ, S, * M, * Msb, K * TA) I made him, or it, to lean, rest, or stay himself or itself, against, or upon, the thing; (TK;) and Uilayohi saAnadotuhu↓ signifies the same. (AZ, TA.) You say, Asnd Zahorahu UilaI AlHaAYiTi He leaned his back against the wall. (MA.) And Asndhu He stayed, propped, or supported, it; namely, a thing leaning; syn. daEamahu. (TA in art. dEm.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Oasonadotu Uilayohi OamoriI (tropical:) [I rested, or stayed, upon him my affair]. (A.) ― -b3- And Asnd AlHadiyva UilaI qaAYilihi (T, M, * L, Msb,) inf. n. UisonaAdN [q. v. infrà], (S, &c.,) (tropical:) He traced up, or ascribed, or attributed, the tradition to the author thereof, [resting it upon his authority,] (T, S, M, L, Msb, TA,) by mentioning him, (Msb,) or by mentioning, uninterruptedly, in ascending order, the persons by whom it had been transmitted, up to the Prophet; (T, L, KT;) [or by mentioning the person who had related it to him from the Prophet if only one person intervened;] saying, “ Such a one told me, from such a one, ” [and so on, if more than one intervened between him and the Prophet,] “ from the Apostle of God; ” (KT;) [or it may be with an interruption in the mention of the person by whom it had been transmitted: see musonadN, below.] ― -b4- UisonaAdu OamorK UilaI Mxara UiyjaAbFA Oawo salobFA [is a conventional phrase, used in logic, meaning (assumed tropical:) The judging a thing to stand to another thing in the relation of an attribute to its subject, affirmatively or negatively]. (Kull p. 157, in explanation of AlHukomu as a logical term [meaning “ judgment ”].) ― -b5- [UisonaAdN majaAziIRN is another conventional term, used in lexicology and rhetoric, meaning (assumed tropical:) A tropical attribution of an act or a quality or a meaning; as in EiyXapN raADiyapN for maroDiyRapN, and in zabuwnN (q. v.) in one of its senses: see Har p. 432 ― -b6- Ousonida AlfiEolu UilaI zayodK, another conventional phrase, is said of the verb in the phrases qaAma zayodN and Duziba zayodN and zayodN qaAma meaning The verb is made an attributive to Zeyd: and, in an unusual manner, it is said (in the Msb in art. slb) of the verb in the saying salabotu zayodFA vawobahu; so that it means in this instance The verb is made to have Zeyd for its object. And Ousonida Uilayohi faAEilaAni faSaAEidFA is said (in the TA in art. swI) of the verb in the phrase AisotawaI zayodN waEamorNw waxaAlidN fiI hecaA; so that it means Two and more agents are assigned to it.] ― -b7- Asndhu fiI Aljabali He made him to ascend the mountain. (K.) ＝ -A2- Asnd as an intrans. verb: see 1, in four places. ― -b2- You say also, Asnd fiI AlEadowi, (M, L,) inf. n. UisonaAdN (L,) He was vehement in running; he strove, laboured, or exerted himself, therein. (M, L.) ― -b3- And He (a camel) went a pace between that called camiylN and that called hamolajapN. (L.)

6 tasaAonada
6: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- tsAnd Alqawomu means The people went forth, every commander of them with a [separate] corps. (Ham p. 783.) [See also the act. part. n. below.]

8 Uisotanada
8: see 1, first sentence.

sinodN c
sinodN, (S, L,) or AlsRinodu, (M, L, K,) A certain country, (S, L, K,) well known, (K,) said in the “ Marásid ” to be a country between India (Alhinod) and Karmán and Sijistán: (TA:) or a people; (K;) [the people of that country;] a well-known nation; (M, L;) a nation bordering upon India, whose colours incline to yellowness, and who are generally slender: (Mgh:) or one of these meanings is the original of the other: (TA:) sinodiIRN↓ signifies a single person thereof: (S, K:) and sinodN is the pl., (K,) or [rather] is applied to the people collectively; (S;) these two words being like zinojiIRu and zinojN: (TA:) the pl. of sinodN is sunuwdN and OasonaAdN. (M, L.) AlsRinodu is also the name of A great river of Alhinod [or India; i. e. the Indus]: and of a district in El-Andalus: and of a town in Western Africa (Almagorib). (K.)

sanadN c
sanadN The part that faces one, of a mountain, and rises from (Ean) the safoH [i. e. base, or foot]; (S, K;) the acclivity, or rising part, in the face, or front, [or side,] of a mountain or a valley: (T, M, A:) or a rising, or an elevated, portion of ground: (Mgh:) pl. OasonaAdN, (M, A,) [properly a pl. of pauc., but] the only pl. form. (M.) ― -b2- A thing, such as a wall &c., against, or upon, which one leans, rests, or stays himself: (Mgh, Msb:) and misonadN↓ and musonadN↓ [the latter in the TA said to be with fet-h, but this is evidently a mistake, occasioned by a copyist's writing wyftH for wyDmR,] signify [the same,] a thing against, or upon, which one leans, rests, or stays himself; [and the former of these two particularly signifies a cushion, or pillow, and more particularly a large cushion or pillow, against which one leans; as expl. by Golius on the authority of Meyd;] pl. masaAnidu. (L, Msb.) ― -b3- Applied to a man, i. q. muEotamadN [meaning (tropical:) A person upon whom one leans, rests, stays himself, or relies]; (S;) a man's muEotamad [i. e. (tropical:) stay, support, or object of reliance]; (K, TA;) as also musotanadN↓. (TA.) You say sayRidN sanadN (tropical:) [A lord, or chief, upon whom people lean, &c.]. (A, TA.) And huwasanadiI and musotanadiI↓ (tropical:) [He is my stay, support, or object of reliance]. (A.) And HadiyvN qawiIRu AlsRanadi (tropical:) [A tradition valid in respect of the authority upon which it rests, or to which it is traced up or ascribed]. (A, TA. [See also UisonaAdN, below.]) ― -b4- See also musonadN. ＝ -A2- Also A sort of garment of the kind called buruwd, (IAar, K,) of the fabric of ElYemen: (IAar:) pl. OasonaAdN: (K:) or the pl. is like the sing.: (IAar, K:) one says OavowaAbN sanadN [meaning garments of the kind called sanad]: (TA, from a trad.:) Ibn-Buzurj says that AlsRanadu means AlOasonaAdu mina AlvRiyaAbi, i. e. garments of those called buruwd: and he cites, from a poet, the phrase jubRapu OasonaAdK, which, he says, means a red jubbeh of those [made] of what are called buruwd. (TA.) Accord. to Lth, it signifies A sort of clothing, [consisting of] a shirt with a shirt over it: and in like manner, short shirts made of pieces of cloth, one whereof is concealed beneath another: whatever appears (kulRu maA Zahara) thereof is termed simoTN [q. v.]: (O:) [this app. explains the meaning of what here follows:] AlsRanadu is [a term used in the case of] thy wearing a long shirt beneath a shirt shorter than it. (M.)

sinodiIRN c
sinodiIRN: see sinodN [of which it is the n. un.].

sanodaAnN c
sanodaAnN, with fet-h, (Mgh, Msb, K,) or sinodaAnN↓, (thus in a copy of the M, [and thus I have generally found it written, agreeably with the common modern pronunciation,]) The EalaAp, (M,) or zuborap, (Msb,) [both meaning anvil,] of the blacksmith. (Msb, K.)

sinodaAnN c
sinodaAnN Great and strong; applied to a man and to a wolf. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also the next preceding paragraph.

sinodaAnapN c
sinodaAnapN A she-ass [either domestic or wild: probably the latter, because of her strength]. (K.)

sinodiyaAnN c
sinodiyaAnN [The ilex, or evergreen oak; so called in the present day;] a kind of tree. (TA.) [See UisonaAdN.]

sinaAdN c
