sinaAdN applied to a she-camel, (S, M, &c.,) Strong: (K:) or strong in make: (AA, S:) or tall in the hump: (M:) or long in the legs, (A, L,) and elevated [so I render msndp, conjecturally, as though meaning propped up,] in the hump: (L:) or lean, and lank in the belly; (AO, M, L;) but Sh disapproves of this last explanation. (L.)

saniydN c
saniydN: see musonadN.

Oasonadu c
Oasonadu [a comparative and superlative epithet from Oasonada AlHadiyva, q. v., though (like Oasowadu and OaboyaDu when used as epithets of this kind) deviating from a general rule, which requires that such an epithet be formed from an unaugmented triliteralradical verb]. You say Oasonadu liloHadiyvi, meaning OanaSRu lahu, q. v. (TA in art. nS.)

UisonaAdN c
UisonaAdN inf. n. of 4 [q. v.]. (S, &c.) ― -b2- [Used as a simple subst., signifying (tropical:) The ascription of a tradition to an authority in the manner expl. voce Oasonada it has a pl., namely, OasaAniydu; as in the saying,] AlOasaAniydu qawaAYimu AlOaHaAdiyvi (tropical:) [The ascrip-
tions to authorities, whereon they rest, &c., are the foundations of traditions]. (A, TA. [See also sanadN.]) ― -b3- Also used in the sense sf riwaAyapN [q. v., as a simple subst.]: pl. as above. (Har p. 32.) ＝ -A2- Also A certain kind of tree. (M.) [In the TA, it is said that the name commonly known is sinodiyaAn: but I think that this is a mistake: see the latter word.]

masonadN c
masonadN A place in, or upon, which one leans, rests, or stays himself: [and hence applied to a couch, and a throne:] pl. masaAnidu. (KL. [See also musonadN, voce sanadN.])

musonadN c
musonadN [pass. part. n. of 4, Made to lean, rest, &c., against, or upon, a thing: and stayed, propped, or supported; or set up. ― -b2- Hence used in the sense of misonadN, as being a thing set up]: see sanadN. ― -b3- Also (tropical:) A tradition (HadiyvN) traced up, or ascribed, or attributed, to the author thereof, (T, L, K, TA,) [rested on his authority by the mention of him, (see 4,) or] by the mention, uninterruptedly, in ascending order, of the persons by whom it has been transmitted, up to the Prophet; (T, L, KT;) [or by the mention of him who has related it from the Prophet when only one has intervened;] opposed to murosalN and munoqiTiEN; (T, L;) or it may be mnqTE, i. e. interrupted in the mention of the persons by whom it has been transmitted: (KT:) pl. masaAnidu, (K,) agreeably with analogy, (TA,) and masaAniydu, (Esh-Sháfi'ee, K,) which latter has I added to render the sound of the kesreh more full; or, accord. to some, it is a dial. var.; and accord. to some, agreeable with analogy. (TA.) ― -b4- And i. q. daEiIRN [as meaning (assumed tropical:) One who claims as his father a person who is not his father; or an adopted son; or one whose origin, or lineage, or parentage, is suspected]; (S, M, L, K;) as also saniydN↓; (M, L, K; [see an ex. in a verse cited voce OasarRu;]) opposed to kariymN. (L.) ― -b5- Almusonadu, accord. to Sb, signifies (assumed tropical:) The first portion [i. e. the subject] of a proposition; and Almusonadu Uilayohi, (assumed tropical:) the second portion [i. e. the attribute, or predicate,] thereof: (M, L:) of, accord. to Kh, a proposition consists of a sanad↓ and a musonad Uilayoh; and in the phrase Eabodu QllRehi rajulN SaAliHN, [for ex.,] Ebd AllReh is a snd, and rjl SAlH is a msnd Alyh: (O, L:) [but accord. to other authors, and general modern usage, and agreeably with the proper meanings of the terms, Almusonadu (meaning the attributed) signifies the attribute, or predicate; and Almusonadu Uilayohi, (meaning that to which a thing or an accident is attributed) signifies the subject.] ― -b6- Also The Himyeree, or Himyeritic, character of writing; the character of Himyer; (S, M, A, O, K;) differing from the modern Arabic character: (S, O:) they used to write it commonly in the days of their rule; and AHát says that it continued in use among them in El-Yemen in his day [i. e. in the latter half of the second century of the Flight and the former half of the third century]: (M, TA:) Abu-l-'Abbás says, Almusonadu was the language of the sons of Seth; (O, TA;) [i. e. the language written in the character so called;] and the like is said in the “ Sirr es-Siná'ah ” of IJ. (TA.) [See also De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., sec. ed., vol. ii., p. 122 of the Ar. text, and 311 of the transl.] ― -b7- And i. q. AldRahoru [i. e. Time, from the beginning of the world to its end; or time absolutely; or a long time; or a long unlimited time; or time without end; &c.]. (S, M, A, K.) So in the saying, laA OafoEaluhu Mxira Almusonadi [I will not do it to the end of time]. (A, TA.) One says also, laA Mtiyhi yada Almusonadi, meaning [I will not do it, or I will not come to him or it,] ever. (IAar, TA.)

masonadN c
masonadN: see sanadN, second sentence.

musanRadN c
musanRadN [pass. part. n. of 2, q. v.]. In the phrase

xuXubN musanRadapN c
xuXubN musanRadapN, [in the Kur lxiii. 4, meaning Pieces of wood made to lean, or incline, against a wall, (Jel,)] the latter word is with teshdeed because of its relation to many objects (lilokavorapi). (S.) ＝ -A2- musanRadapN also signifies A certain sort of cloths, or garments; and so masonadiyRapN↓. (M, TA.)

masonadiyRapN c
masonadiyRapN: see what next precedes.

musaAnadapN c
musaAnadapN (O, K, and Ham p. 783, in the CK and TK [erroneously] musaAnidapN) (assumed tropical:) A she-camel having the breast and fore part prominent: (As, O, K:) or whereof one part of her frame stays, or supports, (yusaAnidu,) [and so renders firm or strong,] another part: (Sh, O, K:) or having prominent withers: (Ibn-Buzurj, L:) or strong in the back: or whose frame, or make, is symmetrical, or conformable in its several parts: or, as some say, whose frame, or make, is dissimilar, or unconformable, in its several parts; because the hump differs from the other parts; so that it is from the phrase tasaAnada Alqawomu meaning as expl. above [see 6]: (Ham p. 783:) and musaAnadapu AlqaraA (tropical:) a she-camel hard, firmly compacted, in the back. (M, L, TA.)

musotanadN c
musotanadN: see sanadN, in two places.

xarajaA mutasaAnidayoni c
xarajaA mutasaAnidayoni (tropical:) They two went forth aiding, or assisting, each other; (A, * L, TA;) as though each of them leaned, or stayed himself, upon the other, and aided himself by him. (L, TA.) The latter word is used, in this sense, of two men going on a hostile, or hostile and plundering, expedition: and of two wolves attacking a person. (A.) And one says, xarajuwA mutasaAnidiyna, meaning (tropical:) They went forth under sundry, or different, banners, or standards, (S, A, M, L, K, *) every party by itself, (A, L,) the sons of one father under one [separate] banner, (L,) not all under the banner of one commander. (S, L. K.)

Q. 1 sanodarapN c
Q. 1. sanodarapN (M, K) inf. n. of sanodara, which signifies He (a man) went quickly: (TK:) [or was quick or expeditious:] syn. of the former suroEapN: (M, K:) Sgh mentions it in art. sdr, regarding the n as augmentative. (TA.) Hence, accord. to some, the saying of 'Alee,
OanaA AlRaciI samRatoni OumRiI Hayodaraho
kalayovi gaAbaAtK galiyZi AlqaSaraho
Oakiylukumo bAlsRayofi kayola AlsRanodaraho
[I am he whom my mother named Heydereh, like a lion of forests, thick in the neck: I will measure you with the sword with a quick measuring:] meaning, I will slay you quickly, before flight. (TA. [But see what follows.]) ― -b2- A large, or an ample, sort of kayol [or measuring]: (M, K:) so expl. by some in the saying of 'Alee above quoted: or in that saying it is from sanodarapu as the name of a certain woman, who used to sell wheat and give full measure, or of a man who did so. (TA.) [See also sanodarapN as a subst., below.] ― -b3- Also The being bold, or daring: or boldness, or daringness. (TA.) ― -b4- And The being sharp in affairs, and acting with penetrative energy: or sharpness in affairs, and penetrative energy. (TA.)

sanodarN c
sanodarN: see the next paragraph but one.

sinodorN c
sinodorN A man bold, or daring, in his affair, not frightened at anything. (TA.)

sanodarapN c
sanodarapN, [said in the TK to be the inf. n. of Q. 1, q. v.,] (S in art. sdr,) or sanodarN↓, (so in a copy of the M,) or sanodariIRN↓, (IAar, K, TA,) A mikoyaAl [or measure, for measuring corn, &c.], (S, M, K,) well known, (M,) of large size, (S, K,) like the qanoqal and the juraAf: this is said in explanation of the first of these words as used in the saying of 'Alee quoted above: (S, TA:) i. e., the saying has hence been expl. as meaning, I will make a wide and quick slaughter of you: (TA:) or it may be a measure (mkyAl) made of the tree called sanodarapN: (Kt, TA:) [for] ― -b2- it is also the name of A certain tree, (S, M, K,) of which bows and arrows are made. (M, K.)

sanodariIRN c
sanodariIRN A man quick, or expeditious, (K, TA,) in his affairs; who strives, exerts himself, or is diligent, therein. (TA.) ― -b2- And the pl. sanaAdirapN signifies [the contr., or] Persons without occupation; people of sport and idleness; as also sabaAdirapN. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, the sing., Bold, or daring; (O, K, TA;) who makes a boast of more than he possesses. (TA.) ― -b4- The lion; (K;) because of his boldness, or daringness. (TA.) ― -b5- Strong, or vehement; (O, K;) thus applied to anything. (TA.) ― -b6- Tall, or long; (O, K;) thus in the dial. of Hudheyl. (O.) ― -b7- Large in the eyes. (K.) ― -b8- Good: and the contr., i. e. bad. (M, K.) ― -b9- A certain sort of arrows, and of arrow-heads or the like: (M:) or the white of these, (M, K,) i. e. of the latter: (K:) and a spear-head very clear or bright, (K, TA,) and sharp: (TA:) or, applied to an arrow, it means made of the tree called sanodarap: (S * in art. sdr, and M, and TA:) and qawosN sanodariyRapN means a bow made of that tree: (TA:) or a bow having its string braced, and strongly, or skilfully, or well, made. (K, TA.) ― -b10- Also A species of bird. (K.) ― -b11- See also the next preceding paragraph.

sunodusN c
sunodusN Thin, or fine, diybaAj [or silk brocade]: (Th, M, Bd and Jel in xviii. 30, Jel in xliv. 53, Msb, K, TA:) or thin, or fine, Hariyr [q. v.]: (Bd in xliv.:) opposed to UisotaboraqN: (TA:) or i. q.
bizoyawonN [expl. by IB as meaning thin, or fine, dybAj: so in the TA in art. bzn]: (S:) or a kind of bzywn; (Lth, K, TA;) made of [the kind of down called] miroEizRaI: (Lth, TA:) or a kind of buruwd [pl. of burodN, q. v.]: (M, K:) [accord. to Golius, præstans et subtile panni serici genus; as on the authority of Ibn-Maaroof: and Attalicus pannus, aurum argentumve intextum habens; as on the authority of J, who, however, explains it only by the word bizoyawonN: it is mentioned in the S and Msb in art. sds; and in the latter, is said to be of the measure funoEulN; but accord. to the K, the n is a radical letter:] it is [said to be] an arabicized word, without contradiction, (Lth, K,) as well as UisotaboraqN: (Lth:) but both these words occur in the Kur-án, and Esh-Sháfi'ee and others deny that any arabicized word occurs therein: [though they are opposed by Bd (xvii. 37) and others:] some say that they are instances of the agreement of different languages. (MF.)

sunoduwqN c
sunoduwqN a dial. var. of SunoduwqN, q. v.; (Fr, L, K;) like zunoduwqN: (TA:) pl. sanaMdiyqu. (L.)

sanodalN c
sanodalN: see art. sdl.

1 sanira c
1. sanira, aor.
sanara
, (TK,) inf. n. sanarN, (M, K,) He (a man, TK) was, or became, illnatured, or very perverse or cross: (K, TK:) or narrow in disposition. (M.) Hence is derived sinRaworN, in the first of the senses expl. below. (M.) [Or perhaps the reverse may be the case.]

sunaArN c
sunaArN, or sunRaArN: see the last paragraph.

sanawRarN c
sanawRarN A coat made of thongs, (S, M, K,) worn in war, (M,) like a coat of mail: (S, K:) [and] any weapon of iron: (A:) and weapons, or arms, collectively: (M, K:) or, accord. to some, coats of mail: (M:) so As means in explaining AlsRanawRaru as signifying what consists of rings: (TA:) or, as some say, a coat of mail: (Ham p. 352:) or all iron. (AO.)

sinRaworN c
sinRaworN The cat; of the masc. gender; syn. hirRN; (M, A, Msb;) as also sunRaArN↓, (K,) or sunaArN↓: (as in a copy of the M:) fem. with p: (Msb:) pl. sanaAniyru: (S, Msb, K:) but snRwr is rare in the language of the Arabs: hirRN and DayowanN are more common. (IAmb, Msb.) And Aibonu AlsRinRawori The dariS [or daroS, i. e. kitten, or the like]. (T in art. bny.) ― -b2- A lord, master, or chief; (M, K;) in some copies of the K, siyd is erroneously put for sayRid; (TA;) a chief of a tribe: (Sgh:) pl. as above. (Sgh, K.) ― -b3- A vertebra (M, K) of the upper part (TA) of the neck (M, K) of a camel: (M, TA:) pl. as above. (TA.) ― -b4- The root of the tail: (Er-Riyáshee, K:) pl. as above. (K.)

1 sanuTa c
1. sanuTa, aor.
sanuTa
; (M, K;) or saniTa, aor.
sanaTa
, inf. n. sanaTN; (Msb;) or both; (TA;) He was, or became, such as is termed sinaATN [q. v.]. (M, Msb, K.)

sanoTN c
sanoTN [The mimosa Nilotica; also called acacia Nilotica;] a qaraZ, [or this is properly the name of its fruit,] (M, K,) which grows in the SaEiyd [or Upper Egypt], (M,) or [rather] in Egypt; [for it grows in Lower, as well as Upper, Egypt;] (K;) it is the best kind of firewood of the people of that country, who assert that it has most of fire, and least of ashes; so says AHn, on the authority of a person well informed; and he adds that they tan with it [or rather with its pods]: the word is foreign: (M:) and is also written SanoTN: Sgh says that is an arabicized word, from the Indian Hbc. [So in the TA, doubtless a mistranscription. In the CK, AlsRnaTu is erroneously put for AlsRanoTu.]

sinaATN c
sinaATN (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and sunaATN (M, O, L, CK) and sanuwTN↓ (S, M, K) and sanuwTiIRN↓ (S, K) A man (Msb) having no beard: (M, Mgh, Msb:) or having no hair at all upon his face: (M:) or having no hair upon the sides of his face [so I render kawosaj], and no beard at all: (S, K:) or having little hair upon the sides of the face, (Mgh, Msb,) or upon the side of the face, but not reaching to the state of the kawosaj: (IAar, K:) or i. q. kawosajN: (Mgh:) or whose beard is on his chin [only], having nothing on the sides of the face: (As, K:) or this last signification, accord. to As, applies to sanuwTN: (TA:) the pl. (of sanuwTN accord. to some copies of the K and the TA) is sunuTN (IAar, K) and OasonaATN [which is a pl. of pauc.]: (K:) snAT is used as a sing. and pl. epithet: it is used as a pl. by Dhu-r-Rummeh. (IB, TA.)

sanuwTN c
sanuwTN: see the next preceding paragraph. ＝ -A2- Also A well-known medicine. (K.)

sanuwTiIRN c
sanuwTiIRN: see sinaATN.

1 sanafa AlbaEiyra c
1. sanafa AlbaEiyra, aor.
sanifa
and
sanufa
, (S, M, K,) inf. n. sanofN; (M, K;) and Asnqhu↓; (S, * M, K;) or, accord. to As, the latter only; (S;) He bound the sinaAf [q. v.] upon the camel: (S, M, K:) and the latter, he put to him (i. e. the camel), or made for him, a sinaAf; (K, TA;) thus expl. by El-'Ozeyzee. (TA.) [Hence, accord. to some,] one says, in a prov., of a person confounded or perplexed, and unable to see his right course, in his affair, EaIRa biAlUisonaAfi↓, (S, Meyd,) meaning He was confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course, by reason of fright, like him who knows not where to bind the sinaAf: (Z, TA:) it originated from the fact of a man's being thus confounded, or perplexed: (Meyd:) a poet says, (namely, Ibn-Kulthoom, TA,)
UicaA maA EaIRa biAlUisonaAfi qawomN
mina AlOamori AlmuXabRahi Oano yakuwnaA
[as though meaning When a people are unable to find the right way to bind the snAf, in consequence of the affair that is uncertain to be: (thus related by Meyd; but in the TA with HaIRN in the place of qwm, and EalaI in the place of mn:)] Az, however, says that this is not the meaning: that AlAsnAf here signifies the advancing, or preceding; and that the meaning is, are unable to find the right way of advancing, or preceding; (Meyd, TA;) from Oasonafa said of a horse, expl. below. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also the next paragraph.

4 Asnf c
4. Asnf, inf. n. UisonaAfN: see above, in two places. ― -b2- Hence, i. e. from this verb in the sense expl. in the first sentence, (S, TA,) Asnf Oamorahu (tropical:) He performed his affair skilfully, soundly, or thoroughly. (S, M, K, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also He (a horse) preceded the other horses: (S, TA:) and Asnft she (a camel) preceded the other camels (K, TA) in going, or journeying, or pace; (TA;) as also sanafato↓. (K, TA.) [See the verse cited in the preceding paragraph, and the explanation of it by Az.] Said of a camel, it means also He put forward his neck, to go on: (K, TA:) or he advanced, or preceded. (TA.) ― -b2- Said of lightning, It appeared, or was seen, near; and so said of the clouds (AlsRaHaAb). (K.) ― -b3- And Asnft Alr RiyHu The wind blew violently, and raised the dust. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

sanofN c
sanofN: see the next paragraph.

sinofN c
sinofN A leaf; (M, and so in copies of the K, and in the TA;) or leaves: (so in other copies of the K:) pl. sinofN; thus in the copies of the K, [like the sing.,] but this requires consideration; and it seems that it is sunuwfN, a pl. assigned to sinofN in a sense that will be mentioned in what follows: (TA:) [or the pl. is sinafapN, likewise mentioned, as a pl. of sinofN, in what follows, in three places:] also (K) the leaf of the [tree called] marox: (AA, S, O, K:) or the pericarp of the marox: (S, M, O, K:) this, says IB, is the correct meaning, as those acquainted with the mrx affirm; for, as 'Alee Ibn-Hamzeh says, the mrx has not leaves, nor thorns, but consists of slender twigs; it grows in [water-courses such as are termed] XuEab: (TA:) a poet likens thereto the ears of horses: (S:) the pl. is sinafapN: (M:) or the pericarps of any tree having a produce consisting of grains in a long pod, (AHn, O, K,) that become scattered, when they dry, from that pod, the shale thereof remaining; (AHn, O;) one such pod is termed sinofapN↓; (AHn, O, K;) and the pl. [or coll. gen. n.] is sinofN; (K;) and this last has for its pl. sinafapN: (AHn, O, K:) Aboo-Ziyád says that it is like [the pod of] the baAqilRaI [or bean], except that it is wider, and pointed at the extremity; wherefore a poet likens thereto the ear of a horse: (O:) or, accord. to AHn, sinofapN↓ signifies any pericarp, whether oblong or not oblong; and the pl. [or coll. gen. n.] is sinofN; and the pl. of sinofN is sinafapN: (M:) [see also HubolapN:] and the shale of the [bean called]
baAqilRaMC, and of the [species of kidney-bean called] luwbiyaMC, and of the lentil, and the like; (IAar, TA;) or the shale of the first of these three when what was in it has been eaten; (K;) and the pl. is sunuwfN. (IAar, TA.) ― -b2- Also, (K,) or sanofN↓, with fet-h, (IAar, O, L,) A branch, or twig, (EuwdN,) stripped of its leaves. (IAar, O, L, K.) ― -b3- And the former, The [grain called] dawosar [i. e. zuWaAn, q. v.,] which is sometimes in wheat and barley, (O, K,) and which vitiates them, and lowers their prices. (O.) ＝ -A2- Also i. q. SinofN [A sort, or species]. (K.) One says, hecaA TaEaAmN sinofaAni [This is food, or wheat,] of two sorts, good and bad. (AA, O.) ― -b2- And A company of men. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.) One says, jaMCaniI sinofN mina AlnRaAsi A company of men came to me. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O.)

sinofapN c
sinofapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

sunofataAni c
sunofataAni and sanofataAni Two pieces of wood set upright, between which is put the [pulley called] maHaAlap [by means whereof water is drawn.] (K.)

sinaAfN c
sinaAfN The [breast-girth called] labab: (K:) or the appertenance of the camel that is as the labab to the horse or similar beast: (Kh, S:) or a cord which you tie to the taSodiyr [or breast-girth of the camel], then you bring it forward so as to put it behind the callous protuberance upon the breast, [and there, app., make it fast in some manner,] and it keeps the tSdyr in its place: (As, S, O, K:) this is done only when the belly of the camel has become lank, and his tSdyr has [consequently] become unsteady: (S, O, K: *) or a cord that is tied from the hind girth of the camel to his breast-girth and is then tied to his neck, when he has become lank: (M:) pl. [of mult.] sunufN (M, K) and sunofN (K) and [of pauc.] OasonifapN: (TA:) and a leathern strap or thong, or some other thing, that is put behind the [breast-girth called] labab, in order that it may not slip [from its place]. (M.)

sanuwfN c
sanuwfN A horse that shifts the saddle forwards. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.) [See also misonaAfN.]

saniyfN c
saniyfN A cloth that is put, (AA, O, K,) or tied, (M,) upon the shoulders of the camel: pl. sunufN (AA, M, O, K) and sunofN: (K:) the cloths that are similarly placed upon the hinder parts of camels are called OaXilRapN [pl. of XaliylN]. (AA, O.) ― -b2- Also The HaAXiyap [properly meaning selvage, or selvedge,] of a carpet; (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K;) i. e., its xamol [which generally means nap; but this addition I think doubtful]. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.)

musonafapN c
musonafapN A she-camel having the sinaAf [q. v.] tied upon her. (S, TA.) ― -b2- And xayolN musonafaAtN Horses having the [withers, or parts called] manaAsij high, or elevated: denoting a quality approved in them; for it is only in the best, and the generous, thereof: and when they are thus, the saddles recede upon their backs; wherefore the sinaAf is put to them, to keep the saddles in their places. (M.)

musonifapN c
musonifapN A mare, (S, M, K,) and a she-camel, (M,) preceding others in going, or journeying, or pace; (S, M, K;) as also misonaAfN↓: (M:) and masaAniyfN [being pl. of the latter] signifies the same; and is applied to camels: (Th, TA:) or [so in the K, but more properly “ and ”] musonafapN, with fet-h to the n is specially applied to the she-camel, (K, TA,) in the sense first assigned to it above: (TA:) or musonifapN, (K, TA,) with kesr to the n, (TA,) signifies a [youthful she-camel such as is termed] bakorap that has completed the tenth month of her pregnancy, and whose udder has become swollen. (Ibn-'Abbád, K, TA,) ― -b2- Also, (El-'Ozeyzee, O, K,) or musonifN and misonaAfN↓, (AA, M,) applied to a she-camel, Lean, or light of flesh, (AA, El-'Ozeyzee, M, O, K,) or lank in the belly. (AA, M.) ― -b3- And musonifapN signifies also Land affected with drought, barrenness, or dearth: (El-'Ozeyzee, O, K:) or a year of drought, barrenness, or dearth: [thus expl. as a subst., or an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant:] pl. masaAnifu. (AHn, M.)

misonaAfN c
misonaAfN (tropical:) A camel that makes the saddle to shift backwards; (S, M, K, TA;) wherefore a sinaAf is put to him: (S, TA:) and, (K,) or as some say, (S,) that makes it to shift forwards: (S, K, TA:) so says Lth: but ISh disallows his explanation, saying that it means a she-camel that makes the load to shift forwards; and that mijonaOapN [a word which I have not found anywhere except in this instance] signifies the contrary: (TA:) or that makes her fore girth to slip forward; contr. of mudorijN and midoraAjN. (TA in art. drj.) ― -b2- See also musonifapN, in two places.

1 saniqa c
1. saniqa, (S, K,) aor.
sanaqa
, (K,) inf. n. sanaqN, (S,) He (a young camel) suffered indigestion (S, K) mina AllRabani [from the milk]. (K.) One says, of a young camel, Xariba HatRaI saniqa He drank until, or so that, he suffered indigestion. (S.) And one says, of an ass, and of any beast, saniqa, inf. n. as above, meaning, He was affected with what resembled indigestion from eating fresh herbage. (TA.)

4 Asnqhu AlnRaEiymu c
4. Asnqhu AlnRaEiymu i. q. tarRafahu [i. e. Ease and plenty caused him to exult, or to exult greatly, or excessively, and to behave insolently and unthankfully, or ungratefully: or wealth made him to enjoy, or lead, a plentiful, and a pleasant or an easy, and a soft or delicate, life; or a life of ease and plenty]. (O, K.)

saniqN c
saniqN Satiated, or sated, like him who is suffering indigestion: (A'Obeyd, TA:) applied by Lebeed as an epithet to a horse. (TA.)

sunRayoqN c
sunRayoqN A house, or chamber, plastered with gypsum: (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K:) pl. sunRayoqaAtN and sanaAniyqu: (K:) or, accord. to Sh, these are pls. of the word in the sense next following. (TA.) ― -b2- Any [hill of the kind termed] Oakamap: pl. as above: so accord. to Sh: (T, O, TA:) or it is the name of a particular Oakamap, (T, O, K, * TA,) well known; occurring, without Al, in a poem of Imra-el-Keys. (T, O, TA.) ― -b3- And AlsRunRayoqu, A certain white star. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

1 sanima c
1. sanima, (M, Msb, K,) aor.
sanama
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. sanamN; (M, Msb;) so some say; others saying sunima, in the pass. form; and Oasonama↓, as some say; others saying Ousonima↓; (Msb;) He (a camel) was, or became, large in the sanaAm [or hump]. (M, Msb, K.)

2 snRmhu c
2. snRmhu, (M, K,) inf. n. tasoniymN, (K,) It (herbage, or pasture,) made him (a camel) large in the sanaAm [or hump]; as also Asnmhu↓: (M, K:) or both signify it made him fat. (TA.) ― -b2- And He made it gibbous, namely, a grave; i. e. he raised it from the ground like the sanaAm: (Msb:) tasoniym (S, K) of a grave (S) is the contr. of tasoTiyH. (S, K.) He raised it, [app. so as to make it gibbous,] namely a thing. (M.) ― -b3- And He filled it, namely, a vessel, (AZ, M, Msb, K,) and then put upon it what was like a sanaAm of wheat or some other thing, (AZ, Msb,) or so that there was above it what was like the sanaAm. (M.) ― -b4- See also 5. ― -b5- [And see tasoniymN, below.]

4 Oasonama
4: see 1, in two places: ― -b2- and 2, first sentence. ― -b3- Asnm AldRuxaAnu, (S, K,) inf. n. UisonaAmN, (S,) The smoke rose, or rose high. (S, K.) And Asanmt AlnRaAru The fire became large in its flame: (M, K:) or the fire had a high flame. (TA.)

5 tsnRm AlnRaAqapa c
5. tsnRm AlnRaAqapa He mounted, or rode upon, the sanaAm [or hump] of the she-camel. (Har pp. 332, and 390.) ― -b2- He (the stallion) mounted the she-camel; (M, TA;) he leaped the she-camel. (TA.) ― -b3- And tsnRmhu He, or it, mounted, ascended, got, was, or became, upon it, (S, M, Msb, K,) namely, a thing; (M, Msb, K;) as also snRmhu↓, (M, K,) inf. n. tasoniymN. (TA. [Freytag adds Astnmhu in this sense, as on the authority of J, whom I do not find to have mentioned it.]) And He mounted, or ascended, upon it from its side, namely, a wall. (TA.) And He rode upon it, namely, anything, [meaning any animal,] advancing, or retiring. (TA.) ― -b4- Also It became abundant upon him, and spread; said of hoariness; as also taXayRamahu; (IAar, M, TA;) like OawoXama fiyhi. (TA.) ― -b5- And tsnRm AlsRaHaAbu AlOaroDa The clouds rained copiously, or abundantly, upon the land. (TA.) ― -b6- AltRasanRumu also signifies The taking, or seizing, suddenly, unexpectedly, or by surprise. (M, K.)

sanamN c
sanamN [a coll. gen. n.]: see sanamapN [its n. un.].

sanimN c
sanimN A camel having a large sanaAm [or hump]: (Lth, S, M, K:) fem. with p. (Lth, TA.) ― -b2- Also A tall plant, of which the sanamap, (S, K,) i. e. the head, resembling the ear of corn, (S,) or the blossom, (K,) has come forth. (S, K.) [And] sanimapN signifies Any tree (Xajarap) that does not
bear; its extremities having dried up, and become altered. (M. [In the TA, the word in this sense is said to be sanamapN: but the former is app. the right reading.]) ― -b3- Also, (TA,) or sanimN EalaI wajohi AlOaroDi, (S, in which it is only mentioned as said of water,) Water rising, or rising high, and appearing upon the surface of the earth. (TA.)

sanamapN c
sanamapN The blossom (M, K) of a plant; (K;) i. e. (TA) the head thereof, resembling the ear of corn, (S, TA,) [or] it is of the Tariyfap [q. v.], not of the [herbs called] baqol: (M:) and signifies also the extremities [or an extremity] of the SilRiyaAn, which are [or is] shed thereby: (M, TA:) and the head of a tree [or plant] of the kind termed diqR [q. v.], in form like what is upon the head of the reed, or cane, except that it is soft, and the camels eat it in the manner termed xaDomN [inf. n. of xaDama, q. v.]: (TA:) [it is the n. un. of sanamN↓, the latter being a coll. gen. n., as is shown by what follows:] AHn says, some assert that the sanamap is such of the produce of herbs as resembles the produce of the Uicoxir [q. v.] and the like; and such as the produce of the reed, or cane; and that the most excellent of the sanam are the sanam of a herb called the UisonaAmap↓ [n. un. of UisonaAmN]; and the camels eat it in the manner termed xaDomN, because of its softness; or, as in some of the copies [of his work], the camels do not eat it. (M.)

sanaAmN c
sanaAmN of the camel, (S,) of the he-camel and of the she-camel, [The hump; i. e.] the highest part of the back: (M, TA:) [in substance,] it is to the camel like the Oaloyap [here meaning the fat of the tail] to the sheep: (Msb:) pl. OasonimapN (S, M, Msb, K) [and app. OasonaAmN also, as seems to be indicated by an explanation of this latter pl. in what follows]. Hence, in a trad., nisaMCN EalaI ruWuwsihinRa kaOasonimapi Albuxoti [Women upon whose heads are the like of the humps of the Bactrian camels]; meaning such as wind the head-coverings as turbans upon their heads so as to enlarge them [in appearance] thereby. (TA.) [Hence, also, sanaAmu AlnRaAqapi (assumed tropical:) The name of a star in the constellation of Cassiopea: mentioned by Freytag, with a reference to Ideler Untersuch. p. 84.] ― -b2- Also The highest, or highest part, of anything: (TA:) and the best, or choice part, (M, TA,) of anything; (TA;) because the sanaAm is the best, or the choice part, of what is in the camel. (M.) [Hence,] Oasonimapu AlrRimaAli The protuberant, or elevated, parts of the sands; as being likened to the hump of the she-camel: (M, TA:) and Oasonimapu AlrRamoli the backs of the sands, that rise from the main portions thereof. (TA.) And sanaAmu AlOaroDi The baHor [q. v.] (S, TA [in some copies of the S naHor, perhaps correctly najod, i. e. high, or elevated, part]) of the land: (S, TA:) and the middle of the land. (S, K.) And sanaAmu AlnRaEoli The rising part of the middle of the upper side of the sandal, which is in the place of the hollow of the foot. (Har p. 559.) And OasonaAmu naArK The highest parts of a fire: (EM p. 156, and TA:) OasonaAm being pl. of sanaAmN, which signifies the highest part of a thing. (EM ubi suprà.) And sanaAmu Almajodi (assumed tropical:) The highest [of a people] in respect of glory. (TA.)

AlsRunRamu c
AlsRunRamu The ox, or cow; syn. Albaqarapu: (M, K:) or, as some say, the wild baqarap. (TA.)

UisonaAmN c
UisonaAmN The fruit, or produce, of the HaliIR [q. v.]; (M, K, TA; [in the CK, of the HulayRA;]) mentioned by Seer on the authority of Aboo-Málik: (M:) n. un. with p. (K.) And the latter signifies A certain herb: (see sanamapN:) or a species of tree: pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] UisonaAmN. (M.)

tasoniymN c
tasoniymN [originally inf. n. of 2, q. v.,] A certain water in Paradise; so called because running above the elevated chambers (S, K *) and the pavilions: mentioned in the Kur lxxxiii. 27: (S:) or a certain fountain, or source, (EayonN,) in Paradise: so they assert; and this requires its being determinate, imperfectly decl.: or, accord. to Zj, a water coming upon them from above, from the elevated chambers: (M:) or a certain fountain, or source, coming upon them from above. (K [and in like manner Az explains it].)

OaroDN musonimapN c
OaroDN musonimapN A land that gives growth to the UisonaAmap, n. un. of UisonaAmN. (K, TA.)

musanRamN c
musanRamN A camel left unridden [so that he is made to have a large hump]. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- And qaborN musanRamN An elevated [or a gibbous] grave: from AlsRanaAmu. (Mgh.) ― -b3- And majodN musanRamN (assumed tropical:) Great glory. (M, TA.)

1 sanVha
1: see 5, in two places.

3 sAnhhu c
3. sAnhhu, inf. n. musaAnahapN and sinaAhN; and saAnAhu, inf. n. musaAnaApN; (K;) or EaAmalahu musuAnahapF, and musaAnaApF; (Msb;) He made an engagement, or a contract, with him for work or the like, by the year: (K:) and AisotaOojarotuhu musaAnahapF, and musaAnaApF, [I hired him by the year:] (S:) musaAnahapN and musaAnaApN from AlsRanapu are like muEaAwamapN from AlEaAmu, and muXaAharapN from AlXRahoru, and muraAbaEapN from AlrRabiyEu, &c. (TA in art. rbE.) ― -b2- sAnht AlnRaxolapu The palm-tree bore one year and not another; (As, K;) as also EaAwamat. (As, TA.)

4 Oasonaha
4: In this form of the verb, the final radical letter is changed into t, so that they say OasonatuwA, meaning They experienced drought, or barrenness. (TA. [See also art. snt.])

5 tasanRahotu Einodahu c
5. tasanRahotu Einodahu, (S,) and tasanRayotu Endh, (S, Msb,) I remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, with him, or at his abode, a year: (Msb:) both signify the same. (TA.) [See also 5 in art. snw and snI.] ― -b2- tsnRht AlnRaxolapu (assumed tropical:) The palm-tree underwent the lapse of years; (S, Msb;) as also sanihat↓: (S:) and in like manner one says of other things. (Msb.) ― -b3- tsnRh said of food and of beverage, (Fr, S, TA,) (assumed tropical:) It became altered [for the worse]; as also saniha↓, aor.
sanaha
, inf. n. sanahN: (TA:) or it became altered [for the worse] by the lapse of years: (Fr, S, TA:) and AltRasanRuhu in relation to bread and beverage &c. means the becoming mouldy, or musty, or spoiled. (S: and so in some copies of the K and in the TA: in other copies of the K, AlsRanihu, like katif, is put in the place of AltRasanRuhu; and AlmutakarRiju in the place of the explanation AltRakarRuju.) faQnoZuro UilaI TaEaAmika waXaraAbika lamo yatasanRaho, in the Kur [ii. 261], means (assumed tropical:) [But look at thy food and thy beverage,] it has not become altered [for the worse] by the lapse of years: (Fr, S, TA:) Az says that this is the right way of reading, by pronouncing the h in ytsnRh in pausing after it and in continuing without pausing: Ks used to suppress the h in the latter case and to pronounce it in the former: and Aboo-'Amr EshSheybánee says that the original form [of yatasanRa] is yatasanRano; the like change being made in it as is made in taZanRayotu [for taZanRanotu] and in qaSRayatu OaZofaAriI [for qaSRaSotu AZfArI]. (TA. [See also 5 in art. snw and snI, last sentence.])

sanapN c
sanapN a word of which the final radical letter is rejected, (S, Msb,) and of which there are two dial. vars., (Msb,) being, accord. to some, originally sanohapN, (S, Msb,) like jabohapN (S) or sajodapN, (Msb,) and accord to others, sanowpN, (S, * Msb,) like XahowapN, and upon each of these originals are founded modifications of the word, (Msb,) therefore it is mentioned in the K [and S and other lexicons] in the present art. and again in art. snw, (TA,) A year; syn. HawolN; (Msb;) or EaAmN: (M, K:) or, as Suh says, in the R, the sanap is longer than the EaAm; the latter word being applied to the [twelve] Arabian months [collectively], and thus differing from the former word: (TA:) with the Arabs it consists of four seasons, mentioned before [in art. zmn, voce zamanN]: but sometimes it is tropically applied to (tropical:) a single faSol [or quarter]; as in the saying, daAma AlmaTaru AlsRanapa kulRahaA, meaning [The rain continued] during the faSol [or quarter, all of it]: (Msb:) [see more in art. snw and snI:] the dim. is sunayohapu↓ (S, Msb) accord. to those who make the original of sanapN to be sanohapN, (Msb,) and sunayRapN↓ (S, Msb) accord. to those who make the original of sanapN to be sanowapN; (Msb;) and some say sunayonapN, but this is rare: (TA:) the pl. is sanahaAtN (Msb, K) accord. to those who make the original of sanapN to be sanohpN, (Msb,) and sanawaAtN (Msb, K) accord. to those who make the original of sanapN to be sanowapN; (Msb;) and sinuwna also, (S, Msb, K,) like the masc. perfect pl., (Msb,) [agreeably with a rule applying to other cases of this kind,] with kesr, to the s, (S, TA,) and siniyna [in the accus. and gen. cases], (Msb, TA,) so that one says, hecihi sinuwna [These are years], and raOayotu siniyna [I saw years], (TA,) and the n is elided when it is prefixed to another noun, governing the latter in the gen. case, (Msb,) and some say sunuwna, with damm to the s; (S, TA;) and in one dial., the I is retained in all the cases, and the n is made a letter of declinability, with tenween when the word is indeterminate, [so that one says siniynN,] and is not elided when the word is prefixed to another noun, governing the latter in the gen. case, because it is [regarded as] one of the radical
letters of the word; and of this dial. is the saying of the Prophet, AallRehumRa QjoEalohaA Ealayohimo siniynFA kasiniyni yuwsufa [O God, make them to be to them years like the years of Joseph]; (Msb; [but in my copy of the Mgh, I find kasiniI yuwsufa;]) or with respect to siniynN, like miYiynN, with refa [and tenween], there are two opinions; one is, that it is of the measure fiEoliynN, like gisoliynN, with a rejection [of one letter], though this is an anomalous pl., for there sometimes occurs among pls. that which has no parallel, as EidFI, and this is the opinion of Akh; the other is, that it is of the measure faEiylN, changed to fiEiylN because of the kesreh of the second letter; the pl. being in some instances of the measure faEiylN, like kaliybN and EabiydN; but he who holds this opinion makes its final n to be a substitute for w, and that of miAYapN a substitute for I: (S:) you may also suppress the tenween in siniynN; [in which case it seems that one says siniyna in the nom. case (assimilating it to sinuwna) as well as in the accus. and the gen.; like as one does in the instances of buriyn and biriyn, pls. of burapN, accord. to the K, though, as I have shown in art. brw, there is some doubt on this point;] but the suppression of the tenween in siniynN is more rare than its pronunciation: (I' Ak p. 18:) and another pl. is suniIRN, [originally sunuwRN,] of the measure fuEuwlN. (Er-Rághib, TA in art. snw.) The phrase valeva miAYapK siniyna, in the Kur [xviii. 24], is said by Akh to be for valevamiAYapK mina AlsRiniyna [Three hundred of years]: and he says that if the sinuwn be an explicative of the miAYap, it is in the gen. case [to agree with miAYapK]; and if an explicative of the valev, it is in the accus. case [to agree with valeva]. (S. [See also Bd on this phrase; and see De Sacy's Ar. Gr., 2nd ed., i. 423.]) [lisanapK, relating to an animal or a plant or the like, means To the completion of a year: and lisanatihi, to the completion of his, or its, year; i. e. in his, or its, first year.] And one says, laqiytuhu munocu sunayRaAtK↓ [I met him some years ago; three or more, to ten, years ago]: a phrase like laqiytuhu caAta AlEuwayomi. (Az, TA in art. Ewm.) And sunayRapN↓ is a dim. of enhancement, of sanapN: one says sunayRapN HamoraMCu A severe year of drought or barrenness or dearth: (TA:) and AlbiyDi waqaEuwA fiI AlsRunayRaAti↓ [They lapsed into the severe years of scantiness of herbage]: these were years that pressed hard upon the people of ElMedeeneh. (K, TA.) ― -b2- sanapN [alone] also signifies (tropical:) Drought, or barrenness: (Msb, K, TA:) or vehement, or intense, drought: (TA in art. snw:) an instance of a noun used especially in one of its senses, like daAbRapN applied to “ a horse, ” and maAlN applied to “ camels: ” pl., in this, as in the former, sense, sanahaAtN [and sanawaAtN] and sinuwna and siniynN. (TA.) One says of a land (OaroDN), OaSaAbatohaA AlsRanapu (tropical:) Drought, or barrenness, befell it. (Msb.) And in like manner one says of people, OaSaAbatohumu AlsRanahu (tropical:) [Drought, &c., befell them]. (TA.) A seeker of herbage and of a place in which to alight was sent to a tract, and found it dried up by want of rain, and when he returned, being asked respecting it, he said, AlsRanapu, meaning (tropical:) Drought, &c. [has befallen it]. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., AallRehumRa OaEinRiI EalaI muDarabiAlsRanapi, i. e. (tropical:) [O God, aid me against Mudar] by drought &c. (TA.) ＝ -A2- It is also [used as an epithet,] applied to land (OaroDN), as meaning (tropical:) Affected with drought, or barrenness; (As, S, K;) as also sanohaMCu↓ and sanowaMCu. (Msb.) One says likewise, hecihi bilaAdN siniynN (tropical:) These are countries, or tracts, affected with drought &c.: and Et-Tirimmáh says
bimunoxaraqK taHinRu AlrRiyHu fiyhi
Haniyna AlHulobi fiI Albaladi AlsRiniyni
(tropical:) [In a gusty tract, the wind moaning therein like the moaning of the milch ewes or goats (see HaluwbN) in the country affected with drought, or the countries, &c., balad being regarded as a coll. gen. n. and therefore qualified by a pl., like qawomN in the phrase qawomN kaAfiruwna]. (TA.)

sanaho sanaho c
sanaho sanaho, also pronounced with teshdeed to the n: see sanFA, in art. snw and snI, last sentence.

TaEaAmN sanihN c
TaEaAmN sanihN (assumed tropical:) [Food, or wheat,] that has undergone the lapse of years; (AZ, K;) as also sanK. (AZ, TA.) ― -b2- See also mutasanRihN.

naxolapN sanohaMCu c
naxolapN sanohaMCu (assumed tropical:) A palm-tree that bears one year and not another: (S, K:) or a palm-tree affected by a year of drought. (S.) And sanapN sanohaMCu A year in which is no herbage nor rain. (TA.) ― -b2- See also sanapN, last sentence but one.

sunayohapN c
sunayohapN and sunayRapN (dims. of sanapN), and the pl. sunayRaAt: see sanapN, in five places: and see also sunayRapN in art. snw and snI.

mutasanRihN c
mutasanRihN, applied to bread, (S, K,) and so sanihN↓ applied to bread and to beverage &c., (CK, but see 5, third sentence,) (assumed tropical:) Mouldy, or musty, or spoiled. (S, K.)

1 sanaA c
1. sanaA, [aor. yasonuw,] inf. n. sunuwRN and sinaAyapN and sinaAwapN, i. q. saqaI [as meaning He watered, or irrigated, land]. (M.) [Hence,] one says OaroDN masonuwRapN↓ and masoniyRapN↓, (S, M, K,) meaning Watered, or irrigated, land: (M:) the w in masoniyRapN being changed into I, (S, M,) in the opinion of Sb, (M,) like as it is in qinoyapN; (S;) for he knew not sanayotuhaA [as meaning I watered it], holding masoniyRapN to be from [sanaAhaA having for its aor.] yasonuwhaA. (M.) One says [also], sanati AlnRaAqapu, aor. tasonuw, (S, K,) inf. n. [as above, or] sinaAwapN and sinaAyapN, (TA,) The she-camel watered, or irrigated, land. (S, K, TA.) And AlsRaHaAbapu tasonuw AlOaroDa (S, Msb) The cloud waters the land. (Msb.) And sanaAka Algayovu (assumed tropical:) [The rain gave thee water for thy land, or may the rain give thee water], inf. n. snw and snI [app. sunuwRN and suniIRN]. (TA.) And AlsRaHaAbu yasonuw AlmaTara (assumed tropical:) [The clouds send down rain]. (TA.) And sanati AlsRaHaAbapu biAlmaTari (assumed tropical:) [The cloud watered, or irrigated, with rain], aor. tasonuw and tasoniI. (M, TA.) And sanati AlsRamaMCu, aor. tasonuw, inf. n. sunuwRN, (tropical:) The sky rained. (TA.) ― -b2- sanati AldRaAbRapu, aor. tasoniI; (M in art. snI;) or saniyat, (K, * TA,) aor. tasonaI, like taroDaI; (K, TA;) The beast [by which is app. meant, in the M, the horse, for it is there added wagayoruhaA, meaning that the verb is said in like manner of other animals, which is the case, for it is generally said of a camel,] was used for the drawing of water upon it [to irrigate land: see saAniyapN, below]. (M, K.) And sanaA, aor. yasonuw, said of a beast [turning a water-wheel], He turned round about the well. (R, TA.) And Alqawomu yasonuwna liOanofusihimo, (S, K,) inf. n. sinaAyapN, and sometimes sAniyapN, (TA,) The people, or party, draw water for themselves; (S, K; [in some copies of the former of which, UicaA OasoqawoA is erroneously put for UicaA QsotaqawoA, the reading in both of my copies;]) and so AisotanawoOa↓ lAnfshm. (M, * TA.) And sanaA EalaI AlbaEiyri, inf. n. sanaAyapN [app. a mistranscription for sinaAyapN], He drew water upon the camel; which camel is termed saAniyapN. (MA.) And baEiyrN yusonaI Ealayohi A camel upon which water is drawn. (Mgh and Msb in explanation of saAniyapN.) And biYorN yusonaI minohaA [A well from which water is drawn, app. by means of the camel called saAniyap]. (M.) And sanawotu AldRalowa, inf. n. sinaAyapN, I drew the bucket from the well. (TA.) ＝ -A2- sanati AlnRaAru, (M, K,) aor. tasonuw, inf. n. sanaMCN, (M,) The fire became high in its light. (M, K.) And sanaA Albaroqu, (M, K,) aor. yasonuw, inf. n. sanaMCN, (TA,) The lightning shone, shone brightly, or gleamed: (M, K, TA:) [or gleamed upwards, or shot up: for, in the Kur xxiv. 43,] some read, yakaAdu sanaMCu baroqihi yadohabu biQloOaboSaAri, meaning The rising and gleaming upwards of his lightning [nearly taketh away the sight, lit. sights]; others reading sanaA, of which sanaMC is not a dial. var. (M.) And AsnI↓ Albaroqu signifies [in like manner] The lightning shone, or gleamed; or diffused itself, and rose. (M.) And sanaA UilaI maEaAliI AlOumuwri (assumed tropical:) He rose [or aspired] to the means of attaining eminence. (M.) And sanuwa fiI Hasabihi, inf. n. sanaMCN, (assumed tropical:) He became high, or exalted, in his grounds of pretension to respect or honour. (M.) And saniIa, like raDiIa, He (a man, TA) was, or became, high, or exalted, in rank. (K, * TA.) ＝ -A3- See also 2, in two places. ＝ -A4- And see 5.

2 snRAhu c
2. snRAhu, (M, TA,) inf. n. tasoniyapN, (TA,) He ascended, rose, mounted, got, was, or became, upon it, namely, a thing; (M, TA;) as also tsnRAhu↓. (M.) And AlbaEiyru AlnRaAqapa tsnRI↓ The he-camel mounted the she-camel to compress her. (K.) ＝ -A2- And snRAhu, (S, K,) inf. n. as above, (K,) He opened it; (S, K, TA;) namely, a knot, and a lock: (TA:) and made it easy. (S, K, TA. [In the last of these, said to be tropical.]) A poet says,
waOaEolamu EilomFA layosa biAlZRanRi OanRahu
UicaA QllRehu sanRaI Eaqoda XaIoCK tayasRaraA
[And I know with a knowledge that is not mere opinion, that, when God opens, and makes easy, the tying, or knotting, of a thing, it becomes easy]. (S.) And one says, sanRayotu AlXRaIoCa, and AlOamora, (assumed tropical:) I opened the way of doing the thing, and the affair. (TA.) And AlbaAba sanayotu↓, (K,) inf. n. snI [app. sanoIN], (TA,) I opened the door; as also sanawotuhu↓; (K, TA;) the verb in this sense having I and w for its last radical. (TA.) ＝ -A3- See also 5.

3 saAnayotu AlrRajula c
3. saAnayotu AlrRajula, (S, M, * K, *) inf. n. musaAnaApN (TA) [and sinaMCN (see what I have said respecting a verse cited voce sinRN)], (tropical:) I vied with the man in being pleased, well pleased, or content; or I agreed, consented, accorded, or was of one mind or opinion, with him: (S, M, * K: *) and I treated him with gentleness, or blandishment; soothed, or coaxed, him: and behaved well to him in my social intercourse with him: (S, K:) or musaAnaApN signifies the treating one with gentleness, or blandishment, in suing for a thing: (Az, TA:) or the endeavouring to conciliate one. (TA.) ＝ -A2- And sAnAhu, inf. n. musaAnaAopN and sinaMCN, He hired him for [or by] the year; (M, K;) or he made an engagement, or a contract, with him for work or the like, by the year; like saAnahahu: (K in art. snh:) and EaAmalahu musaAnaApF and AisotaOojarahu masaAnaApF signify the same as musaAnahapF [q. v.]. (M, TA.)

4 AsnAhu c
4. AsnAhu He raised, exalted, or elevated, him, or it. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- AsnI AlnRaAra He raised the light of the fire. (M.) ― -b3- AsnI lahu AljaAYizapa He raised [in value], to him, the jAYzp [i. e. gift, or present]. (TA.) And OasonayonaA lahu AljaEaAlapa We made much and high [in amount], to him, the pay. (Har p. 134.) ― -b4- And AsnI jiwaArahu i. q. OaHosanahu [app. meaning He made good his covenant of protection]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- AsnI Albaroqu The lightning sent its light into the house, or tent, or chamber: or fell upon the ground: or flew along in the clouds; (K, TA;) or, sometimes, elsewhere, not in the clouds: but it is only in the night. (TA.) See also another explanation near the end of the first paragraph. ＝ -A3- AsnI Alqawomu, (S, M, K,) inf. n. UisonaMCN, (S) The people, or party, tarried a year (S, K) in a place: (S:) or it signifies OataI Ealayohimu AlEaAmu [the year passed over them; meaning they remained to the end of the year]. (M.) But OasonatuwA signifies They were afflicted with drought, or barrenness: (S, M, * K: [Freytag has erroneously assigned this signification to AisotanawoA:]) the w, (S,) or the I, which is originally w, (M,) being changed into t, (S, M,) to distinguish between this verb and AsnI in the sense expl. above. (S. [See art. snt.])

5 tsnRI c
5. tsnRI: see 2, in two places. ― -b2- Also i. q. rqI rqyp [in the CK raqeI ruqoyapF, and in my MS. copy of the K raqaA ruqoyapF, but correctly raqiIa, meaning He ascended: agreeably with this rendering, the inf. n. is expl. in the TK as meaning ywkskh Jqmq:] said of a man. (K, * TA.) ＝ -A2- Also It opened, or became opened or open: said of a lock [&c.]. (TA.) ― -b2- It was, or became, facilitated, or easy; and ready, or prepared. (Har pp. 159 and 508.) ― -b3- And i. q. tasahRala fiI Oumuwrihi, said of a man, (K,) i. e. He found, or experienced, ease, or facility, in his affairs. (TK.) ＝ -A3- Also i. q. taraDRaI: so in the phrase tsnRI fulaAnFA [He sought to please, content, or satisfy, such a one; or he pleased, contented, or satisfied, such a one, after striving, labouring, or toiling]: (K:) but it is said in the M, [app. a mistake, perhaps for the T, for in the M I do not find it,] that snyt flAnA [by which may be meant either sanayotu↓ or sanRayotu↓] means trDRyth. (TA.) ＝ -A4- tasanRayotu Einodahu I remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, with him, or at his abode, a year; like tasanRahotu Einodahu: (Msb in art. snh:) or it means Oaqamotu Einodahu sunayRaAti↓ [I remained &c., with him, or at his abode, some years; three or more, to ten, years]. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) tsnRI signifies also It became altered [for the worse], (S, K, TA,) accord. to Er-Rághib, so that it lost its freshness, by the lapse of years: (TA: [see also tasanRaha:]) but accord. to AA, it is from the phrase in the Kur [xv. 26 and 28 and 33] mino HamaOK masonuwnK; one of the ns being changed into I; and is similar to taqaDRaI for taqaDRaDa. (S, TA.)

8 AisotanawoA liOanofusihimo c
8. AisotanawoA liOanofusihimo: see 1. ＝ -A2- AstnI AlnRaAra He looked at the light of the fire. (IAar, M.)

sanFA c
sanFA Light: (Msb, MF:) or the light of lightning, (S, M, K,) and of fire: (M:) or the point, or extremity, of the light of lightning: (T, TA:) or light shining or gleaming, or diffusing itself and rising: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or a high light: and applied also to the shining, or gleaming, of weapons: (Ham p. 271:) MF says that the apparent particularization in the K [&c.] seems to have been taken from the verse of the Kur [xxiv. 43], and that the word is correctly a general term, meaning as expl. in the Msb: (TA:) [it is originally sanawN, though mentioned in the K as belonging to art. snI; for] the dual is sanawaAni: As knew not a verb belonging to it. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also [The cassia senna of Linn.; the common senna of medicine; so called in the present day; and also called sanaAmakRap, and sanaA HijaAziIR;] a certain plant, (S, M, Msb, K,) used as a medicine; (S, TA;) and recommended in a trad.; (TA;) an attenuant of the yellow bile and the black bile and the phlegm, (K, TA,) howsoever used; (TA;) [and] used as a collyrium; (M;) AHn describes it as a shrub, or small tree, of the [class called] OagolaAv [pl. of galavN], which is mixed with HinRaMC, and improves and strengthens its colour, and blackens it; and which has a fruit of such kind that, when it dries up, and is put in motion by the wind, it causes to be heard a sound such as is termed zajal [q. v.]: (M in arts. snw and snI, and TA:) its name is as above and sanaMCN↓: (M, K:) and the n. un. is sanaApN and sanaMCapN: (M in arts. snw and snI:) the dual of sanFA is sanayaAni, and some say sanawaAni. (M in art. snI.) [Accord. to a gloss. in a copy of the S, as stated by Golius, the dual sanawaAni is applied to The leaves of cyprus (or HinRaMC) and senna mixed together, with which the hair is dyed black.] In the phrase sanaA Almisoki, in a verse of El-Jaadee, the plant [above mentioned] may be meant, as though it were mixed with musk: or it may be from sanFA signifying “ light; ” because the diffusion of odour is like that of light. (M.) ＝ -A3- sanaA, (JM,) or sanaA sanaA, (TA,) without teshdeed, and also with tesh-deed, to the n, is an Abyssinian expression, meaning Hasuna [q. v.], (JM, TA,) occurring in a trad. of Umm-Khálid; but it is differently related; some saying sanaho sanaho; and some, sanaAn; and pronouncing each with, as well as without, teshdeed: so in the Nh. (TA.)

TaEaAmN sanK c
TaEaAmN sanK [Food, or wheat,] that has undergone the lapse of years; as also sanihN. (AZ, TA in art. snh.)

sanapN c
sanapN, applied to a portion of time, (M,) signifying A year, syn. HawolN, (Mgh,) or EaAmN, (K,) but a distinction is made between EaAmN and sanapN, [as has been stated in art. snh,] (TA,) belongs to arts. snw and snh [in both of which it is mentioned in many of the lexicons: see what has been said respecting it in art. snh in the present work]: (M:) accord. to Suh, in the R, it is from sanaA, aor. yasonuw, said of a beast [turning a water-wheel], meaning “ he turned round about the well; ” so that it signifies a single revolution of the sun; and it is sometimes termed daArN: he says also that it is longer than the EaAm, which is applied to the [twelve] Arabian months [collectively]: but sanapN is also applied to twelve revolutions of the moon: the sanap XamosiyRap [or solar year] is three hundred and sixty-five days and a quarter of a day: and the sanap qamariyRap [or lunar year] is three hundred and fifty-four days and a third of a day: it is also said, on the authority of Er-Rághib, that sanapN is used as denoting a year in which is difficulty, and drought, or barrenness, or dearth; and EaAmN, as denoting that in which is ampleness of the means, or circumstances, of life, and abundance of herbage or the like; and by this is explained the nice point in the words of the Kur [xxix. 13], Oalofa sanapK UilRaA xamosiyna EaAmFA [a thousand years save fifty years]; because the fifty years passed before the mission of the prophet [Noah], before which no harm happened to him from his people; but after his mission, the years were difficult to him. (TA.) [Respecting the dims., (which are sunRyRapN and sunayohapN, the former accord. to those who make the original of sanapN to be sanowapN, and the latter accord. to those who make it to be sanohapN,) and the pls., (which are sanawaAtN and sanahaAtN and sinuwna and sunuwna and siniynN and siniyna, the last whereof is originally siniynN, and suniIRN also,) see sanapN in art. snh ― -b2- Also respecting sanapN used alone as signifying (tropical:) Drought, or barrenness, or vehement or intense drought, see that word in art. snh. ＝ -A2- Also respecting the same word used as an epithet, applied to land (OaroDN), as meaning (tropical:) Affected with drought or barrenness, like sanowaMCu and sanohaMCu, see that same word in art. snh.]

sanapN sanowaMCu c
sanapN sanowaMCu (assumed tropical:) A hard, rigorous, or distressing, year. (M, K.) And OaroDN sanowaMCN (assumed tropical:) A land affected
with drought or barrenness [like OaroDN sanapN]. (TA.) [See also sanohaMCu, in art. snh.]

sanaMCN c
sanaMCN inf. n. of sanat said of fire, (M,) and of sanaA said of lightning, (TA,) and of sanuwa. (M.) ― -b2- [Used as a simple subst.,] High, or exalted, rank or condition. (S, * Msb, K, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also sanFA.

saniIRN c
saniIRN High, or exalted, in rank or condition: (S, M:) as also sanaAyaA↓, applied to a man. (K, * TA.)

sunayRapN c
sunayRapN dim. of sanapN, (S and Msb in art. snh,) accord. to those who make the latter word to be originally sanowapN: (Msb in that art.:) pl. sunayRaAtN. (K and TA in that art., and TA in the present art.) See 5, last sentence but one; and see also sanapN, in art. snh, in four places.

Oaxacahu bisinaAyatihi c
Oaxacahu bisinaAyatihi (S, K) and biSinaAyatihi (S) He took it wholly. (S, K.)

sanaAyaA c
sanaAyaA: see saniIRN.

saAnK c
saAnK Watering: [and drawing water:] applied [as an epithet] to a man and to a camel: pl. sunaApN; which is applied by Lebeed to men [as meaning] drawing water by means of sawaAnK [pl. of saAniyapN, q. v.]. (TA.)

saAniyapN c
saAniyapN [a subst. from saAnK, made so by the affix p,] A she-camel, (S, * M, K,) or a camel, (Mgh, Msb,) a he-camel as well as a she-camel, (TA,) upon which water is drawn (S, * M, Mgh, Msb, K, TA) from a [deep] well (Mgh, Msb) [by a man riding or leading it away from the well, it having the two extremities of a long rope tied to the saddle, and the upper end of the wellrope being tied to the middle of the former rope, as expl. voce vinaAyapN]; i. q. naADiHapN: (S, TA:) [it seems also to signify, sometimes, a camel that carries water for irrigating seed-produce; a meaning likewise assigned to naADiHapN and naADiHN:] and a beast (dAbRp) that turns round about a well [raising water from it by means of the machine called duwlaAb]: (R, TA:) pl. sawaAnK. (S, Mgh, TA.) Hence the prov.,
sayoru AlsRawaAniI safarN laA yanoqaTiEo
[The course of the beasts that draw water in either of the ways described above is a journey that does not end]. (S, Mgh, TA.) ― -b2- Also the garob [or large bucket with which water is drawn] together with its gear, or apparatus. (M, Mgh, K.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) A cloud watering the earth. (Msb.)

OaroDN masonuwRapN c
OaroDN masonuwRapN and masoniyRapN: see 1, second sentence.

musanRaApN c
musanRaApN i. q. EarimN [q. v.]: (S, K:) [or rather] A dam; i. e. a thing constructed [or raised] to keep back the water of a torrent; (Mgh;) a [kind of] wall built in the face of water: (Msb in art. sn:) so called because there are in it sluices, or openings for the water, according to what may be required; from sanRayotu AlXRaIoCa, and AlOamora, expl. above: so in the T: (TA:) pl. musanRayaAtN. (MA.)

masonawiyRapN c
masonawiyRapN, (M, TA,) or biYorN masonawiyRapN, (Az, TA,) A well (Az, M, TA) of which the rope is long, (Az, TA,) from which one draws water only by means of the camel called saAniyap. (Az, M, * TA.)

sahN c
sahN and suhN: see AisotN, in art. sth, in four places.

1 sahobN c
1. sahobN The act of taking. (JK, K.) You say, sahaba AlXRaIoCa, aor.
sahaba
, inf. n. sahobN, He took the thing. (TK.)

2 tasohiybN c
2. tasohiybN The departure of reason, or intellect: its verb [which was probably suhRiba, like Ousohiba, q. v.,] is obsolete. (TA.)

4 Ashb c
4. Ashb He went far, or to a great or an extraordinary length, in a thing; for instance, in journeying; as in a trad., in which it is said of horses, or horsemen, Oasobahato XahorFA They went far for a month; and in eating and drinking; as in another trad.: (TA:) it is from suhobN, signifying “ a plain and far-extending land; ” as though meaning He traversed a plain and far-extending tract of land; like as one says Oasohala and OaHozana. (Har p. 572.) He (a horse) ran with wide steps, and preceded, or outstripped. (S, TA. [See also sahobN, below.]) And [hence,] He was, or became, loquacious, or profuse of speech; (IAar, S, K;) like Ashm; (K * and TA in art. shm;) [and] so Ashb fiI AlmanoTiqi: (JK:) or he doted; or was disordered in his intellect; but when a man makes many mistakes in his speech, you say of him Oafonada: (As, TA:) or he doted much, or often; or was much, or often, disordered in his intellect: (AO, TA:) [and it seems from an explanation of the part. n. musohibN that it probably signifies also he was eloquent, or profuse of correct speech:] or he was very greedy, and (in some copies of the K “ or ”) covetous, so as to refrain from nothing: (K, TA:) and you say also Ashb kalaAmahu He prolonged, or was prolix in, his speech: and fI kalaAmihi UisohaAbN In his speech is prolixity. (A, TA.) Also He (a man) gave much, or largely; and so Asthb↓: (Lth, K:) [or, in this sense,] you say, Ashb fiI AlEaTaMC. (A.) ― -b2- AshbwA They reached sand, in digging [a well], and water came not forth: (S:) or they dug, and came upon sand or a current of air: (K:) or they dug, and came upon a current of air, and the water disappointed them of its coming: (Az, TA:) or they dug without attaining any good: (K:) or Ashb signifies he dug until he reached sand: and, accord. to Th, he dug a well and reached water. (TA.) ― -b3- AshbwA AldRaAbRapa They left the beast alone, or by itself, (K, TA,) to pasture [where it would]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Ashb AlXRaApa waladuhaA Her young one sucked, (K,) or licked, (TA,) the ewe, or she-goat. (K.) ＝ -A3- Ousohiba He (a man, S) lost his reason, (S, K, TA,) as some say, (TA,) from the bite of a serpent, (S, K, TA,) or the sting of a scorpion: (TA:) or his colour became altered in consequence of love or fright or disease: (K:) or, accord. to AHát, Ashb, [so in the TA, in which it seems to be implied that Oasohaba, not Ousohiba, is meant,] inf. n. UisohaAbN, signifies he (a man bitten by a serpent, or stung by a scorpion,) lost his reason and lived. (TA. [See also the part. n., musohabN, below.]) UisohaAbu AllRubRi [in which the former word is probably the inf. n. of Ousohiba, not of Oasohaba,] means The mind's being confounded, or perplexed, by [love of] a woman. (JK.)

8 Uisotahaba
8: see 4, in the middle of the paragraph.

sahobN c
sahobN A desert, or waterless desert; syn. falaApN: (S, K:) pl. suhubN. (TA.) [See also suhobN.] ＝ -A2- A horse wide of step in running, (S, K, TA,) and (TA) vehement therein, (JK, K, * TA,) slow to sweat; (JK, TA;) and musohabN↓ and musohibN↓, (K,) but the latter of these is said to be peculiarly the chaste form in this sense, (TA,) signify the same. (K.) ― -b2- biYorN sahobapN A deep well; (S, A, O, K;) as also biYorN musohabapN↓: (S * O:) or the former, a deep well (JK, TA) from which sand comes forth (JK) or from which wind, or a current of air, comes forth: (TA:) and ↓the latter, a well of which the coarse sand baffles one so that he cannot reach the water [in digging it]; (K;) or a well that people dig until they reach pouring earth, which baffles them by its pouring down, so that they leave it; (Sh, TA;) or a well of which the bottom and the water are not reached; (Ks, TA;) or a well that is dug until one reaches the water upon which is the earth. (Az, TA. [See 4.]) ＝ -A3- A portion of time; as in the saying, maDaI sahobN mina AllRayoli [A portion of the night passed]. (TA.)

suhobN c
suhobN A plain and smooth, or plain and smooth and soft, tract of land: pl. suhuwbN: (K:) or the pl. signifies plain and far-extending tracts of land: (JK, A, TA:) or wide land [or lands (for the sing. is expl. in the TA in one place as signifying a wide land)]: (AA, TA:) or suhuwbu AlfalaApi signifies, (K,) or signifies also, (JK,) tracts, or regions, of the flAp [i. e. desert, or waterless desert,] in which there is no way. (JK, K.) [See an ex. in a verse cited in art. rql, conj. 4: and see also sahobN, above, first sentence.]

musohabN c
musohabN, with fet-h to the h, [contr. to rule, being of the measure mufoEalN in the sense of the measure mufoEilN,] Going far, or to a great or an extraordinary length, in a thing: and prolonging. (TA.) ― -b2- See also sahobN: and its fem., with p, see in two places in the same paragraph. ― -b3- Also Long, or tall: (JK:) applied [in the latter sense] as an epithet to a man: and TawiylN musohabN excessively tall. (A.) ― -b4- Also, and musohibN↓, (K,) both said to have been mentioned by ISk, (TA,) or the former, but not ↓the latter, (AZ, IAar, IKt, Zbd, S, TA,) though the former is extr. [with respect to rule], (S, TA,) Loquacious, or profuse of speech: (AZ, IAar, ISk, IKt, Zbd, S, K, TA:) or, accord. to Aboo-'Alee El-Baghdádee, as is stated by IB, the former signifies profuse and erroneous in speech: and the ↓latter, eloquent, or profuse and correct in speech: and in like manner says El-Aalam, adding that ↓the latter is shown to have this meaning by its being
applied to a horse that is fleet, or swift, and excellent: (TA:) or the former signifies doting; or disordered in his intellect: (As, TA:) or doting much, or often; or much, or often, disordered in his intellect: (AO, TA:) [and similar explanations of it will be found below:] other instances of verbs of the measure OafoEala having mufoEalN as the measure of the part. n. used in the sense of the measure mufoEilN are Oalofaja and OaHoSana and OajoraXati AlUibilu and Oahotara: as used in the first of the senses expl. in this sentence, musohabN is from suhobN signifying “ a wide land: ” or, as some say, it is from OasohabuwA AldRaAbRapa, expl. above; as though the person to whom it is applied were left to speak what he would, or made to have ample scope to say what he would. (TA.) ― -b5- Both musohabN and musohibN↓ signify also Very greedy, and covetous, so as to refrain from nothing. (TA.) ― -b6- And the former, One who has lost his reason; as some say, from the bite of a serpent, or the sting of a scorpion: or one who talks irrationally, or foolishly, or deliriously, in consequence of doting, or disorder of his intellect: or whose colour has become altered in consequence of love or fright or disease. (TA.) And musohabu Aljisomi A man whose body is wasting away in consequence of love: so says Yaakoob: and Lh mentions the phrases AlEaqoli musohibu↓, with kesr, and Aljisomi, and musohim, which is formed by substitution [of m for b], as meaning a man whose reason is departing, and whose body is wasting away, in consequence of love: and accord, to AHát, mshb, [app. musohibN↓, as the context seems to imply,] applied to one bitten by a serpent or stung by a scorpion, signifies who has lost his reason, and lives. (TA.) ― -b7- Also Land farextending, and plain, with depression, consisting of low tracts, the depression whereof is little, extending for the space of a day and a night [of journeying], and thereabout: the buTuwn [or low tracts] of land of which it consists are in [deserts such as are termed] SaHaAraI, and in elevated and plain, or hard and elevated, tracts of ground, and sometimes they flow [with torrents], and sometimes they do not flow, for they comprise parts that are rugged, and parts that are plain, or soft, producing much herbage, and in them are places wherein are trees [or shrubs], and places wherein are none. (L, TA.) ― -b8- Also A place that does not obstruct nor retain water. (TA.)

musohibN c
musohibN: see sahobN, second signification: ― -b2- and see musohabN, in seven places. ― -b3- Also A man who overcomes, or surpasses, and is bountiful, in his gifts. (TA.)

1 sahajati AlrRiyHu c
1. sahajati AlrRiyHu, (S, A, K,) aor.
sahaja
, (JK,) inf. n. sahojN, (TA,) The wind blew violently: (S, A, K, TA: [like sahakat:]) or continually and violently. (TA.) ― -b2- sahajati AlUibilu The camels journeyed, or went, quickly, or hastily. (JK.) ― -b3- sahaja Alqawomu layolatahumo, (S, K,) inf. n. as above, (S,) The people, or party, passed their night journeying (S, K) continually. (TA.) ＝ -A2- sahajati AlrRiyHu AlOaroDa [like saHajat] The wind pared the ground: (S, K:) or pared its surface. (TA.) ― -b2- And sahaja AlTRiyba, (S, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) He bruised, brayed, or pounded, or he pounded small, powdered, or pulverized, the perfume: (S, K:) or sahojN signifies any bruising, braying, or pounding. (TA.)

riyHN sahuwjN c
riyHN sahuwjN and sahowajN (O, K) and sayohajN↓ (S, O, K) and sayohuwjN↓, (S, A, O, K,) in the last two of which the j is asserted by Yaakoob to be a substitute for k, (Az, TA,) and sayohajapN↓, (TA,) A violent wind. (S, A, O, K.) And you say also riyaAHN suhRajN (JK, S, O) and saAhijaAtN (JK) [both pls. of riyHN saAhijapN↓, and signifying, accord. to the context in the JK and O, Violent winds: or, accord. to the context in the S, winds that pare the ground: the sing. like riyHN sahuwkN and saAhikapN &c.].

riyHN saAhijapN c
riyHN saAhijapN; pl. riyaAHN suhRajN and saAhijaAtN: see the next preceding paragraph. ― -b2- gubaArN saAhijN Dust rising high. (JK.)

sayohajN c
sayohajN, and with p: see sahuwjN.

sayohuwjN c
sayohuwjN: see sahuwjN.

OasaAhiyju c
OasaAhiyju [like OasaAhiyku and OasaAhiIRu] Various sorts (JK, O, K) of running, (JK,) or of going, or pace, (O, K,) or, as in one copy of the K, of the going, or pace, of camels. (TA.) ― -b2- And Varieties of false, or vain, things or sayings or deeds. (JK, TA.)

masohajN c
masohajN [like masohakN] A place where the wind passes along [or blows violently]. (AA, S, O, K.) AA cites, as an ex., the saying,
UicaA habaTona musotaHaArF masohajaA
[When they descend into, or enter, a place of confusion, or perplexity, where one is unable to see his right course, a place where the wind blows, or blows violently]. (S, O.)

misohajN c
misohajN One who runs on, in speech, like the wind: (JK:) eloquent; or fluent in speech: (O, K, TA:) applied to an orator; (JK, T, TA;) as also misohakN. (T, TA.) ― -b2- And One who speaks on every true and false subject. (O, K.)

1 sahida c
1. sahida, aor.
sahada
, (S, L, K,) inf. n. suhaAdN (S, * A, * L) and suhodN (A, * L, K *) and sahadN, (S, L,) [all these are mentioned as inf. ns. in the L and TA, and app. in the K, but the first seems to be mentioned in the S as a simple subst.,] He was sleepless: syn. Oariqa; (S, A, * L, K;) he did not sleep (lamo yanamo); contr. of raqada. (L.) [See also suhaAdN below.]

2 shRdhu c
2. shRdhu, (S, A, L, K,) inf. n. tasohiydN; (PS;) and Ashdhu↓; (A, TA;) He, (a man, S, L, K,) and it, (anxiety, or grief, A, L, and pain, L,) rendered him sleepless. (S, A, L, K.) And fulaAnN yasohRadu Such a one is not suffered to sleep. (L.)

4 Oasohada
4: see 2. ＝ -A2- Ashdt biAlwaladi She [a woman] brought forth the child with a single moan, or hard breathing; (IAar, K;) [or with a single impulse;] like zakabato bihi, &c. (IAar, L in art. xfd.)

5 tshRd c
5. tshRd is said by Freytag, as on the authority of the K, in which I do not find it, to signify He was sleepless; like sahida: if used, it more probably signifies he was rendered sleepless; as quasi-pass. of sahRadahu.]

XaIoCN sahodN mahodN c
XaIoCN sahodN mahodN A good, or beautiful, thing: (L, K:) mhd is here an imitative sequent to shd. (L.)

suhodN c
suhodN: see suhaAdN, in two places.

suhudN c
suhudN One who sleeps little; (S, A, L, K;) as also musahRadN↓: (A:) and some say suhadu, like Eumaru; but this is [of a measure used] only in proper names: (Ham p. 39:) and an eye (EayonN) that sleeps little. (L.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (tropical:) Vigilant; cautious; applied to a man; as also musahRadN↓. (A, TA.) ― -b3- And Little sleep. (L.)

sahodapN c
sahodapN (tropical:) Vigilance: so in the saying, huwa cuw sahodap (tropical:) [He is possessed of vigilance] (A, K) fiI Oamorihi [in his affair]. (A.) ― -b2- You say also, maA raOayotu minohu sahodapF, meaning (tropical:) I experienced not, or I have not experienced, from him any mindfulness of what is good, nor any desire for it: (A, TA:) or anything upon which to place reliance, of words or of good actions, (S, L, K,) or of good actions or satisfactory words. (L.)

suhaAdN c
suhaAdN (S, A, L) and suhodN↓ (A, L, K) Sleeplessness. (S, A, L, K. [Both mentioned in the L and TA as inf. ns. of 1.]) One says fiI Eayonihi sahodN↓ and suhaAdN In his eye is sleeplessness. (A.)

sahowadN c
sahowadN, applied to a boy, or young man, Tender, or flourishing, and fresh: (Sh, K:) or tall and strong. (K.)

Oasohadu c
Oasohadu [More, and most, sleepless.] ― -b2- [Hence,] huwa Oasohadu raOoyFA minoka (tropical:) He is more cautious and vigilant in judgment, or opinion, than thou. (A, K, * TA.)

musahRadN c
musahRadN Rendered sleepless. (S, L, K.) ― -b2- See also suhudN, in two places.

1 sahira c
1. sahira, aor.
sahara
, inf. n. saharN, He waked, was sleepless or wakeful, or did not sleep, by night; (S, K;) he abstained from sleep by night; (Lth;) he remained awake all the night or a part thereof: you say sahira AllRayola, or baEoDa AllRayoli, He remained awake during the night, or a part of the night: (Msb:) [he passed the night, or a part of the night, sleepless, or without sleeping:] and sahirotu AlbaAriHapa I remained awake last night. (A.) ― -b2- maAlahu sahira waEahira What aileth him? May he be
sleepless by night, and may he grieve, or mourn, is an imprecation of the Arabs. (AZ, TA in this art. and art. Ebr.) ― -b3- sahira Albaroqu (tropical:) The lightning gleamed, or glistened, during the night. (A.)

3 musaAharapN c
3. musaAharapN signifies The being sleepless, or awake, with another: (KL, and Har p. 329:) [and the vying with another in remaining sleepless or awake:] and [like UisohaArN, but I think this doubtful,] the making [one] sleepless or awake. (KL.) sAhr AlnRujuwma means He passed the night sleepless like as do the stars. (Har ubi suprà.)

4 Ashrhu c
4. Ashrhu He, (S, Msb,) or it, (A,) as anxiety, or trouble of mind, and pain, (TA,) caused him to wake, to be sleepless, or wakeful, or to remain awake. (S, A, Msb, TA.)

saharN c
saharN: see saAhuwrN.

suharapN c
suharapN: see saAhirN.

sahoraAnN c
sahoraAnN: see saAhirN.

suhaArN c
suhaArN A state of waking; sleeplessness, or wakefulness; (K;) i. q. suhaAdN; (T;) as also saAhuwrN↓. (K.)

sahRaArN c
sahRaArN: see saAhirN, in two places.

saAhirN c
saAhirN and sahoraAnN↓ (S, Msb, K) and sahRaArN↓ (K) and suharapN↓, (S, K,) the last of which is an intensive epithet, (S,) [and so is the third, and sometimes the second,] Waking, sitting up, sleepless, wakeful, or not sleeping, by night; (S, K;) [abstaining from sleep by night;] remaining awake all the night or a part thereof: (Msb:) and the last, [and third, and sometimes the second,] wakeful, or waking much, &c. (S.) You say, AlEayoni rajulN sahRaAru↓ A man whom sleep does not overcome. (Lh.) ― -b2- baroqN saAhirN (tropical:) Lightning gleaming, or glistening, during the night. (A.) ― -b3- layolN saAhri (tropical:) A night of waking or sleeplessness or wakefulness: (K:) like as one says layolN naAYimN. (TA.) ― -b4- saAhirapu AlEiroqi (assumed tropical:) A she-camel that yields milk long and abundantly. (TA.) ― -b5- EayonN saAhirapN (tropical:) A running spring or fountain: (K:) a spring or fountain that runs night and day, unremittingly. (A, * TA.) It is said in a trad., xayoru AlmaAli EayonN saAhirapN liEayonK naAYimapK (tropical:) The best of property is a spring of water that runs night and day while its owner is sleeping; (TA;) its owner having his mind unoccupied by it. (A.) ― -b6- OaroDN saAhirapN (tropical:) Land that produces plants quickly: as though it passed the night doing so. (A.) ― -b7- Also saAhirapN [alone], (tropical:) A wide, or an extensive, tract of land, the traverser of which remains awake during the night: (A:) or the earth, or land: (K:) or the surface of the earth: (Fr, Lth, S, K:) because it produces plants or herbage alike by night and day: (Ibn-Es-Seed:) so in the Kur lxxix. 14: (S:) or (TA, but in the K “ and ”) a desert, syn. falaApN, (K,) the traverser of which remains awake during the night: (TA:) or (TA, but in the K “ and ”) an untrodden land: (K:) or (TA) a land which God will create anew on the day of resurrection: (K:) or a land on which none has disobeyed God: (Ibn-Es Seed:) or (TA) Hell: (Katádeh, K:) or (TA) [in the Kur ubi suprà] a certain mountain of Jerusalem: (Wahb Ibn-Munebbih, K:) or (TA) the land of Syria. (Mukátil, K.)

saAhirapN c
saAhirapN fem. of saAhirN [q. v.]. ― -b2- See also saAhuwrN.

saAhiriyRapN c
saAhiriyRapN A certain perfume: [so called] because one is caused to be sleepless in preparing it, and making it good. (Sgh, K.)

saAhuwrN c
saAhuwrN: see sahaArN. ＝ -A2- Also The sheath of the moon, (S, K,) which it enters when it is eclipsed, (TA,) accord. to the assertion of the Arabs; (S, TA;) as also saAhirapN↓. (K.) One says, of the moon, when it is eclipsed, daxala fiI saAhuwrihi It has entered into its sheath. (Kt.) [Or] The shade, or shadow, of the saAhirap, i. e., of the surface of the earth. (S, K.) ― -b2- The moon (K, TA) itself; as also saharN↓; of Syriac origin, accord to IDrd. (TA.) ― -b3- The halo (daArap) of the moon: (K:) a Syriac word. (TA.) ― -b4- And AlsRaAhuwru, The last nine nights of the lunar month: (K:) or so layaAliI AlsRaAhuwri: because the moon is absent in its first part. (ISk.) ― -b5- Also saAhuwrN, The source of a spring of water. (K, * TA.) ― -b6- And Multitude; abundance. (K.)

AlOasoharaAni c
AlOasoharaAni (tropical:) Two ducts (EiroqaAni) in the two nostrils, (S, K, *) in the inside, (TA,) which, when an ass is excited by lust, flow with water, (S, TA,) or with blood: (TA:) so in the verse of Esh-Shemmákh,
tuwaAYilu mino miSakRK OanoSabatohu
HawaAlibu Oasoharayohi biAlcRaniyni
[She seeks to escape from a strong (he-ass) whom the ducts of his two nostrils flowing with mucus have fatigued]: (S:) or the nose and the penis: (Sh, K:) or (TA, but in the K “ and ”) two ducts in the flesh and sinew next the back-bone, through which runs the seminal fluid into the penis: (K:) or (TA) two ducts rising from the two testicles, and meeting together in the interior of the penis, (K,) or of the fayoXalap [or glans of the penis]; which are the ducts of the seminal fluid: (TA:) or the two veins or ducts of the penis which become prominent when it is in a state of erection: (TA:) and two veins or ducts in the eye: (K:) but As disallows Ashryh, and says that the true reading, in the verse of Esh-Shemmákh, is Oasoharatohu, meaning, [that] have not suffered him to sleep. (TA.) [See also HaAlibN.]

1 sahika c
1. sahika, aor.
sahaka
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. sahakN, (Msb,) He (a man, Msb) had a disagreeable smell proceeding from sweat. (Msb, K.) [And app. It (a thing) had a foul smell from fish, and from the rust of iron, &c.: see sahakN below.] ＝ -A2- sahakati AlrRiyHu The wind blew vehemently. (S, O. [And so sahajat.]) ― -b2- And sahakati AldRaAbRapN, (S, O, K,) inf. n. suhuwkN, (O, K,) The beast ran lightly, or with agility: (S, O, K:) or frisked away to the right and left. (O.) ＝ -A3- sahakahu, (S, O, K,) aor.
sahaka
, inf. n. sahokN, (S, O,) i. q. saHaqahu [He bruised, brayed, or pounded, it; &c.]; (K;) a dial. var. of the latter: (S, O:) or it is like the latter, except that sahokN appears to be coarser than saHoqN; for you say of the perfumer, sahaka AlEaTRaAru AlTRiyba EalaI AlSRalaMCapi walamRaA yasoHaqohu [The perfumer bruised, brayed, pounded, or crushed, coarsely, the perfume, upon the stone used for that purpose, and did not as yet powder it, or pulverize it]. (IDrd, O.) ― -b2- And sahakati AlrRiyHu AlOaroDa, (O,) or AltRuraAba Eani AlOaroDi, (K,) or AltrAb Eano wajohi AlOaroDi, (TA,) The wind made the dust to fly [from the ground, or from the surface of the earth]. (O, K, TA.) [And sahajati AlrRiyHu AlOaroDa, q. v., has a similar meaning.]

sahakN c
sahakN (S, O, Msb, K) and sahokapN↓ (Fr, O, K) and suhakapN↓ (O, K) A disagreeable smell which one perceives from a human being when he sweats; (Msb, * K;) and the smell of fish; (S, O, K;) and of the rust of iron; (S, Msb;) or they signify also the rust of iron; (O, K;) and the foulness of the smell of stinking flesh-meat: (K:) and Har uses suhuwkapN↓ in the first of these senses for the purpose of assimilation to suhuwmapN, agreeably with a practice often observed. (Har p. 449.) ― -b2- The first is also inf. n. of sahika [q. v.]. (Msb.)

sahikN c
sahikN Having a disagreeable smell proceeding from sweat. (K.) You say, UinRahu lasahiku AlrRiyHi Verily he is one who has a disagreeable smell, &c. (Moheet, L.) And yadiI mina AlsRamaki wamino SadaOi AlHadiydi sahikapN [My hand is disagreeable in smell from fish and from the rust of iron]; like as you say waDirapN when it is from milk and butter, and gamirapN when it is from flesh-meat. (S.)

sahokapN c
sahokapN and suhakapN: see sahakN.

riyHN sahuwkN c
riyHN sahuwkN and saAhikapN↓ (K) and sayohakN↓ and sayohuwkN↓ (S, K) [like sahuwjN and saAhijapN &c.] A vehement, or violent, wind, (S, K, TA,) paring [the ground]; (TA;) as also masohakapN↓: (O, K:) [pl. of ↓the second sawaAhiku:] El-Kumeyt says,
ramaAdFA OaTaAratohu AlsRawaAhiku rimodidaA
