[Ashes which the violent winds made to fly away reduced to the most minute particles]. (S.) ― -b2- AlsRahuwku The eagle. (K.)

suhuwkapN c
suhuwkapN: see sahakN.

sahRaAkN c
sahRaAkN: see misohakN.

saAhikN c
saAhikN Ophthalmia; syn. ramadN. (K.) So in the phrase, biEayonihi saAhikN [In his eye is ophthalmia]. (TA.) ― -b2- riyHN saAhikapN: see sahuwkN, in two places.

sayohakN c
sayohakN: see sahuwkN.

sayohuwkN c
sayohuwkN: see sahuwkN.

OasaAhiyku c
OasaAhiyku [like OasoAhiyju] Various sorts of running (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K) of beasts; and their frisking away (K, TA) to the right and left. (TA.)

masohakN c
masohakN [like masohajN] A place where the wind passes along [or blows violently]; as also masohakapN↓. (S, K.)

misohakN c
misohakN A horse swift in running; (S;) that
runs much; (K;) that runs like the wind. (TA.) ― -b2- And [like misohajN, q. v.,] Eloquent, or fluent, in speech; running therein like the wind; (O, K;) as also sahRaAkN↓. (Kr, K.)

masohakapN c
masohakapN: see sahuwkN: ― -b2- and see also masohakN.

1 sahula c
1. sahula, said of a place, (S,) or of a thing, and, accord. to IKtt, they said also sahala and sahila, (Msb,) and sahulato, said of land, (OaroDN,) aor.
sahula
, (K,) inf. n. suhuwlapN, (S, Msb, K, KL,) It was, or became, smooth or soft, plain or level, or smooth and soft; (S, Msb, K, KL, TA;) i. e. contr. of Hazuna and Hazunato, (S, * K, * TA,) inf. n. HuzuwnapN. (TA.) ― -b2- And sahula, (MA, Msb, K,) inf. n. suhuwlapN, (MA, KL,) or sahaAlapN, (K,) [but the former is the more common,] It (a thing, Msb) was, or became, easy. (MA, Msb, * K, * KL.) ― -b3- One says kalaAmN fiyhi suhuwlapN (tropical:) [Language, or speech, in which is smoothness, or easiness]. (TA.)

2 sihRlhu c
2. sihRlhu, (Msb, K,) inf. n. tasohiylN, (S, K,) i. q. SayRarahu saholFA [which may mean He rendered it smooth or soft, plain or level, or smooth and soft; namely, a place &c.: or what next follows]. (TA.) ― -b2- He made it easy; he facilitated it; (S, K;) namely, a thing; said of God (Msb) [and of a man]. ― -b3- One says, sahRala sabiyla AlmaMCi [He smoothed, made easy, or prepared, the way, course, passage, or channel, of the water], (S and K in art. AtI,) in order that it might pass forth to a place. (S in that art.) And shRl masiylFA limaMCK [He smoothed, made easy, or prepared, a channel for water]. (M in that art.) ― -b4- And shRl QllRehu Ealayoka AlOamora, and laka, a form of prayer, meaning May God [make easy, or facilitate, to thee the affair; or] take upon Himself, for thee, the burden of the affair; and lighten [it] to thee. (TA.) [And in like manner shRl QllRehu Ealayoka is often said with AlOamora or Oamoraka understood.] ― -b5- [And OahRala bihi wasahRala, or OahRalahu wasahRalahu, inf. ns. taOohiylN and tasohiylN, He said to him OaholFA wasaholFA↓, meaning (as expl. in the Msb in art. Ahl) Oatayota qawomFA OaholFA wamawoDiEFA saholFA, i. e. Thou hast come to a people who are like kinsfolk, and to a place that is smooth, plain, or not rugged: see OahRala and OaholN: and see also Ham p. 184.]

3 sAhlhu c
3. sAhlhu, (MA, K,) inf. n. musaAhalapN, (TA,) He was easy, or facile, with him; (MA, K *) or gentle with him; syn. yaAsarahu: (K:) and tsAhl↓ Ealayohi [has a similar meaning, i. e. he acted, or affected to act, in an easy, or a facile, manner towards him; or gently]. (S and K in art. gmD: see 4 in that art.) [See also the paragraph here following.]

4 AshlwA c
4. AshlwA They descended to the sahol [i. e. smooth or soft, or plain or level, or smooth and soft, tract]: (JK, Msb:) or they betook themselves to the sahol: (S:) or they became in the sahol: (K:) and they alighted and abode in the sahol, after they had been alighting and abiding in the Hazon [i. e. rugged, or rugged and hard, or rugged and high, ground]. (TA.) Hence, in a trad. respecting the throwing of the pebbles [at Minè], yusohilu occurs as meaning He betakes himself to the interior of the valley. (TA.) ― -b2- Also They used smoothness, or easiness, (suhuwlap,) with men: opposed to OaHozanuwA. (TA.) [See also 3.] ＝ -A2- Ashl is also trans., signifying He found [a thing, a place, &c.,] to be smooth or soft, plain or level, or smooth and soft. (Ham p. 675.) ― -b2- Ashl AlTRabiyEapa (S) or AlbaTona, (Msb, K,) said of medicine, (S, Msb, K,) It relaxed, or loosened, the bowels; syn. OalaAna, (K,) or OaTolaqa. (Msb.) And Ousohila AlrRajulu [The man was relaxed in his bowels]: and Ousohila baTonuhu [His bowels were relaxed]. (K.) [Hence the inf. n. UisohaAlN signifies A diarrhœa. And Ashl, likewise said of medicine, signifies also It attenuated a humour of the body.] ― -b3- Ashlt bihi She brought it forth (i. e. her fœtus, or offspring,) prematurely; i. q. OamolaSato bihi [q. v.] &c. (Abu-l-'Abbás [i. e. Th], TA in art. mlS.)

5 tshRl c
5. tshRl [It was, or became, rendered easy, or facilitated;] quasi-pass. of 2: (Msb:) or [like sahula] it was, or became, easy. (KL.) You say, tshRl lahu AlOamoru [The affair was, or became, rendered easy to him]. (Msb in art. AtI.) And tshRlt Tariyqu AlOamori [The way of accomplishing the affair was, or became, rendered easy]. (TA in that art.) ― -b2- And tshRl fiI Oumuwrihi, said of a man, (K in art snI,) He found, or experienced, ease, or facility, in his affairs. (TK in that art.)

6 tasaAhulN c
6. tasaAhulN is syn. with tasaAmuHN. (S, K.) You say tsAhlwA meaning They acted in an easy, or a facile, manner, one with another; (MA, TA in art. ysr;) or gently; syn. tayaAsaruwA. (TA in that art.) ― -b2- See also 3. ― -b3- [In the present day it is used as meaning The being negligent, or careless, fiI OamorK in an affair.] ― -b4- [As a conventional term in lexicology, or in relation to language, it means A careless mode of expression occasioning] a deficiency in the language of a [writer or] speaker without reliance upon the understanding of [the reader or] the person addressed: (KT: [in one of my copies of that work, this explanation is omitted in the text, but written in the margin; and it is there added that it is what commonly obtains:]) or it means [sometimes such a mode of expression] that a phrase is not correct if held to be used according to the proper meaning, but is correct if held to be used according to a tropical meaning: or the mention of the whole when meaning a part. (Marginal notes in the copy of the KT above mentioned.) [See also tasaAmuHN, for which it is often used.]

8 Asthl c
8. Asthl, of the measure AifotaEala from AlsRaholu, occurs in a trad., where it is said, mano kacaba EalaIRa faqadi Qsotahala makaAnahu fiI jahanRama, meaning [He who lies against me] takes for himself easily his place of abode in Hell. (TA.)

10 Astshlhu c
10. Astshlhu He reckoned it sahol, (S, K,) i. e. easy, or facile. (TK.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce Oawo, p. 123.]

saholN c
saholN Smooth or soft, plain or level, or smooth and soft: (Msb:) or anything inclining to smoothness or softness, plainness or levelness, or smoothness and softness; (JK, M, K;) inclining to have little roughness, or ruggedness and hardness; (JK, M, TA;) and sahilN↓ signifies the same. (K.) You say OaroDN saholapN, [meaning the same as saholN used as a subst., expl. in what follows,] (S, Msb,) contr. of HazonapN. (TA.) See also 2, last sentence. ― -b2- Also Easy, or facile; (MA, Mgh, KL;) contr. of SaEobN. (Mgh.) You say rajulN saholu Alxuluqi [A man easy of disposition]: (S, Msb, * TA:) [and] saholu AlmaqaAdapi [easy to be led]. (TA.) And kalaAmN saholu AlmaOoxaci (tropical:) [Language easy in respect of the source of derivation]. (TA.) rajulN saholu Alwajohi, (K, TA,) a phrase mentioned, but not explained, by Lh, (TA,) means A man having little flesh in the face, (K, TA,) in the opinion of ISd: and [it is said that] saholu AlxadRayoni, in a description of the approved characteristics of the Prophet, means having expanded cheeks, not elevated in the balls thereof. (TA.) ＝ -A2- [As a subst.,] A smooth or soft, plain or level, or smooth and soft, tract of land; [generally meaning a soft tract, or a plain;] (IF, S, MA, Mgh, Msb, K, TA;) i. e. contr. of jabalN, (S, Msb,) or of HazonN: (IF, Mgh, Msb, K, TA:) it is one of the nouns that are used as adv. ns. [of place]: (TA:) [for ex. you say, nazaluwA saholFA, (a phrase occurring in the TA,) meaning They alighted and abode in a shl:] pl. suhuwlN (MA, Msb, K) and suhuwlapN [of which latter an ex. occurs in a verse cited voce raOosN.] (MA.) ＝ -A3- Also The crow; i. e. raven, carrion-crow, rook, &c.; syn. guraAbN. (K.)

sahilN c
sahilN: see saholN, first sentence. ― -b2- nahorN sahilN, (S, K,) and OaroDN sahilapN, (K,) [A river, and a land,] having, (S,) or abounding with, (K,) what is termed siholapN [q. v.]. (S, K.)

siholapN c
siholapN Sea-sand: (IAar, TA:) or sand such as is not fine: (S:) or coarse sand, such as is not fine and soft: (IAth, TA:) or a sort of earth like sand, (JK, K,) brought by water: (K:) or sand of a conduit in which water runs: (S in art. rD:) siholapu AlzRujaAji is sea-sand that is made an ingredient in the substance of glass: (Mgh:) Az says that he had not heard the word siholap except on the authority of Lth. (TA.) [And Coarse sand that comes forth from the bladder; (Golius on the authority of Meyd;) what we commonly term gravel.]

suholiIRN c
suholiIRN, with damm, [Of, or relating to, and growing in, and pasturing in, the kind of tract termed sahol;] a rel. n. from saholN, (S, Msb, K,) or from OaroDN saholapN, (Aboo-'Amr Ibn-El-'Alà, TA,) irregularly formed. (S, Msb.) You say nabotN suholiIRN [A plant growing in the sahol]. (The Lexicons passim.) And baEiyrN suhilIRN A camel that pastures in the sahol. (K.)

sahuwlN c
sahuwlN Laxative to the bowels; syn. maXuwRN; (O, K; in the CK [erroneously] muXuwR;) as also musohilN↓; applied to a medicine. (Msb, TA.)

suhayolN c
suhayolN A certain star [well known; namely, Canopus]; (T, S, K;) not seen in Khurásán, but seen in El-'Irák; (T, TA;) as Ibn-Kunáseh says, seen in El-Hijáz and in all the land of the Arabs, but not seen in the land of Armenia; and between the sight thereof by the people of ElHijáz and the sight thereof by the people of El- 'Irák are twenty days: (TA:) it is said that shyl was a tyrannical collector of the tithes on the road to El-Yemen, and God transformed him into a star: (Lth, TA:) [it rose aurorally, in Central Arabia, about the commencement of the ear of the Flight, on the 4th of August, O. S.: the place where it rises, in that latitude, is S. 29 degrees E.; and the place where it sets, in the same latitude, S. 29 degrees W.: (see 10 in art. Hb: and see januwbN:)] at the time of its [auroral] rising, the fruits ripen, and the qayoZ [q. v., here meaning the greatest heat,] ends. (K.) [baAla suhayolN, which is a prov., and the saying of a poet,
baAla suhayolN fiI AlfaDiyxi fafasado
have been expl. in art. bwl.] 'Omar Ibn-'AbdAllah Ibn-Abee-Rabeea says respecting Suheyl Ibn-'Abd-Er-Rahmán Ibn-'Owf, and his taking in marriage Eth-Thureiyà El-'Ableeyeh of the Benoo-Umeiyeh, deeming their coming together to be a strange thing by likening them to the stars named Eth-Thureiyà and Suheyl,
OayRuhaA AlmunokiHu AlvRurayRaA suhayolFA
Eamoraka QllReha kayofa yalotaqiyaAni
hiIa XaAmiyRapN UicaA maA QsotaqalRato
wasuhayolN UicaA QsotaqalRa yamaAniI
[O thou marrier of Eth-Thureiyà to Suheyl, by thine acknowledgment of the everlasting existence of God, (or, as it sometimes means, I ask God to prolong thy life,) tell me, how can they meet together? She is of the northern region when she rises, and Suheyl, when he rises, is of the southern region]. (Har p. 276. [But I have substituted QllReha for AllRehu, and yamaAniI for yamaAnK. See also the notice of the poet above named in the work of Ibn-Khillikán: (I have the express authority of the TA for thus writing this name:) and De Sacy's Anthol. Gramm. Arabe, p. 139.]) [Freytag states that qadamaA suhayolK is the name of Two stars which are behind Canopus; on the authority of Meyd: and also mentions the name of shyl AlXAm, and shyl Alfrd, as given to Certain stars in the constellation Anguis; adding that Canopus is distinguished from shyl AlXAm by the name of shyl Alymn.] The name of OuxotaAsuhayolK [The two sisters of Canopus] is applied to AlXRiEoraI AlEabuwru [or Sirius] and AlXRiEoraI AlgumayoSaMCu [or Procyon], together. (S and K in art. XEr.) [See also HaDaAri and Alwazonu.]

Oakocabu mino suhayolapa c
Oakocabu mino suhayolapa is a prov., (O, K,) said to mean [More lying than] the wind: (O:) or shylp was a certain liar. (K.)

musohalN c
musohalN Relaxed, or loosened, by medicine; applied to the belly: no credit is to be given to people's saying masohuwlN, unless an express authority be found for it. (Msb.)

musohilN c
musohilN: see sahuwlN. [Also an attenuant medicine.]

1 sahamotuhu c
1. sahamotuhu, aor.
sahama
, inf. n. sahomN: see 3. ＝ -A2- sahama, (S, MA, K,) aor.
sahama
; (K;) and sahuma, aor.
sahuma
; inf. n. suhuwmN, (S, MA, K,) of both verbs, (S, TA,) and of the latter suhuwmapN also, agreeably with analogy; (Har p. 449;) He, (a man, TA,) or it, (one's face, S, MA, and Har ubi suprà,) was, or became, altered in colour, (MA,) or he was, or became, lean or lank, in the belly, and altered [in colour]; (S, K, and Har ubi suprà;) [or, accord. to an explanation of suhuwmN in the Ham p. 360, he, or it, was, or became, altered in colour, and emaciated, and dried up;] and suhima, also, aor. yusohamu, inf. n. suhuwmN, has the first of these meanings: (MA:) [see also suhuwmN below:] or suhima signifies he (a man) was, or became, lean, or lank, in the belly: (TA:) or he (a man, S) was, or became, smitten, or affected, by the heat of the [wind called] samuwm, (S, K, [see sahaAmN,]) or by the burning, or vehement heat, of summer. (K, TA.)

2 tasohiymN c
2. tasohiymN The making a garment to be marked with stripes or lines [like sihaAm, i. e. arrows: see the pass. part. n. below]. (KL. [And the same meaning is indicated in the TA.]) Dhu-r-Rummeh says, describing a dwelling, [or rather the traces thereof,]
kaOanRahaA baEoda OaHowalK maDayona lahaA
biAlOaXoyamayoni yamaAnK fiyhi tasohiymu
[As though it were, after years had passed with respect to it, in El-Ashyamán, a garment of El-Yemen in which was a marking with stripes or lines: the epithet yamaAnK being often applied to a garment of this kind, and vawobN being here understood]: (TA:) AlOaXoyamaAni, or, as some call them, AlOaXoOamaAni, are two places, or two mountains, mentioned by Dhu-r-Rummeh in several places in his poetry. (TA in art. Xym.)

3 sAhmhu c
3. sAhmhu, (S, MA, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. musaAhamapN, (Msb,) He shot arrows [sihaAm] with him [in competition]. (MA.) ― -b2- [And hence,] He cast, or drew, lots [or more properly arrows for sortilege, as expl. in the PS,] with him; practised sortilege [or sortilege with arrows] with him; or competed with him in doing so. (S, MA, Mgh, Msb.) You say, saAhamotuhu fasahamotuhu↓; (S;) or saAhamahumo fasahamahumo; (TA;) aor. of the latter verb
sahama
, (S,) and inf. n. sahomN; (TA;) I competed with him in casting, or drawing, lots [or arrows for sortilege] or in practising sortilege [or sortilege with arrows] with him, and overcame him therein; or He did so with them, and overcame them therein. (S, * TA.) Hence, fasaAhama in the Kur xxxvii. 141, (TA,) where [the objective complement] Oahola AlsRafiynapi is understood. (Jel.) ― -b3- [And hence, He shared with him, fiI kacaA in such a thing. See an ex. voce muXidRN, and another voce naAwaba. ― -b4- And app. He contended with him for a thing: see 6.]

4 Ashm bayonahumo c
4. Ashm bayonahumo i. q. OaqoraEa [i. e. He ordered, or commanded, them to cast, or draw, lots, or to practise sortilege, or sortilege with arrows, among themselves, for a thing; or he prepared, or disposed, them for doing so; or he cast, or drew, lots, or practised sortilege, or sortilege with arrows, among them: see OaqoraEa]. (S.) ― -b2- And Oasohamotu lahu I gave him a lot, share, or portion. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- And Oasohama is syn. with Oasohaba, (K, TA,) meaning He was, or became, loquacious, or profuse of speech: its m is said by Yaakoob to be a substitute for b. (TA.) [See also musohamN, below.]

6 tsAhmwA c
6. tsAhmwA: see 8. ― -b2- [Hence, They shared together.] El-Hakam El-Khudree says,
vawobaAhaA fafiI AldRiroEi raAdapN tasaAhama
wafaI AlmiroTi lafRaAwaAni ridofuhumaA Eabolu
i. e. Her two garments shared together; for in the shift was a soft, or tender, body, with a slender waist, and within the waist-wrapper were too thick thighs whereof the part above them, behind, was large. (Ham p. 579.) ― -b3- Also They contended [for a thing], one with another. (JM.)

8 AsthmwA c
8. AsthmwA (S, Msb) and tsAhmwA↓ (S) They cast, or drew, lots, or practised sortilege, [or sortilege with arrows,] one with another; syn. AqtrEwA (S, Msb) and tqArEwA, (S,) both of which signify the same. (S &c. in art. qrE.)

sahomN c
sahomN An arrow; i. e. one of what are called nabol, (Msb, K, TA,) having the iron head [and the feathers] affixed: (TA:) the sahom before it has its feathers and its iron head affixed to it is [generally] called qidoHN: (S and K in art. qdH:) accord. to some it signifies the iron head itself; i. q. naSolN; (Msb;) ISh says that this is its meaning; and he says, if one pick up a nSl, you say “ What is this sahom with thee? ” but if one pick up a qidoH, you do not say thus; and the naSol is the broad and long sahom, and may be nearly of the length of the space between the extremity of the thumb and that of the fore finger when they are stretched out; and the miXoqaS is of half the size of the naSol: (TA:) [but this meaning of sahomN seems to be very rare, and little known:] the pl. [of mult.] is sihaAmN (S, TA) and [of pauc.] OasohumN. (TA.) [Hence,] sahomu AlrRaAmiI (assumed tropical:) [The arrow of the archer], (K,) or [simply] AlsRahomu [the arrow], (Kzw,) a certain constellation, (K, * Kzw,) [namely Sagitta,] one of the northern constellations, composed of five stars, between the bill [meaning the star β] of AldRajaAjapu [which is Cygnus] and AlnRasoru AlTRaAYru [which consists of the stars α and β and γ of Aquila], in the Great Milky Way, having its head towards the east and its notch towards the west; and its length, as it appears to the eye, when it is in the middle of the sky, is about two cubits (naHowu ciraAEayoni: see ciraAEN). (Kzw.) ― -b2- Also The qidoH [or featherless and headless arrow] with which one casts, or draws, lots, (IAth, Mgh, TA,) in the game called Almayosir; (IAth, Mgh, TA;) and the qidoH with which one plays at a game of hazard [of any kind; i. e. an arrow for sortilege, and a
gaming-arrow]; the primary meaning of the word being the missile sahom; (Mgh;) or the primary meaning is the qidoH with which one casts, or draws, lost in the game called Almayosir: (IAth, TA:) pl. sihaAmN (K) [and OasohumN, as above]. See a verse cited voce raqiybN. ― -b3- Then applied to The thing won by him whose arrow is successful [in the game above mentioned]. (IAth, TA.) ― -b4- And then (IAth, TA) applied also to A lot, share, or portion, (S, IAth, Mgh, Msb, K, TA,) whatever it be; (IAth, TA;) as also suhomapN↓: (S, Msb, K:) pl. of the former suhomaAnN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and sihaAmN [both pls. of mult.] and OasohumN [pl. of pauc.] (Mgh, Msb, TA) and [quasi-pl. n.] suhomapN↓, (M, K, TA,) this last like OuxowapN. (TA.) It is said in a trad., kaAna lahu sahomN mina Alganiymapi Xahida Oawo gaAba [There was, or is, for him a share of the spoil whether he were, or be, present or absent]. (TA.) And one says, fulaAnK mino hecaA kacaA suhomapu↓ The share of such a one, of this, is such a thing: and it may be from AlsRihaAmu meaning the arrows (qidaAH) that are shuffled among the persons competing in sortilege, in order that each one may appropriate to himself what comes forth for him as his share. (Ham p. 579.) ― -b5- sahomu AlsRafiynapi [The mast of the ship: so called as being likened to an arrow, because the curved yard of the sail, resembling a bow, is suspended from the top]: (S, and K in art. dql:) [in like manner] called in Pers. tiyri kiXotiI. (PS in that art.) ― -b6- sahomu Albayoti The beam (jaAYiz) of the house or chamber; (S, K;) [similarly] called in Pers. tiyr. (S voce jaAYizN, q. v.) ― -b7- sahomN also signifies The measure of six cubits [as used] in men's sales and purchases in their measurings of land. (K.) ― -b8- And A stone which is placed upon the entrance of a chamber constructed for the purpose of capturing therein the lion, so that, when he enters it, it falls upon the the entrance and closes it. (K, * TA.) [The word in this sense is also mentioned in the K as written with X.]

suhumN c
suhumN, thus, with two dammehs, [The fine filmy substance termed gossamer,] with the article Al, i. q. gazolu Eayoni AlXRamosi [lit. the spun-thread of the rays of the sun]: (IAar, K:) and sahaAmN↓ [signifies the same], with the article Al i. q. muxaATu AlXRayoTaAni [q. v., lit, the snivel of the devil]. (K.) ― -b2- And Overpowering heat. (IAar, K.) ＝ -A2- Also [a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned, signifying] Intelligent, knowing, or skilful or judicious, working men; (K, TA;) and so with X. (TA.)

suhomapN c
suhomapN: see sahomN, in the latter half of the paragraph, in three places. ― -b2- Also Relationship. (S, K.) Whence cuw AlsRuhomapi [A relation]. (S, TA.)

sahaAmN c
sahaAmN The heat of the [wind called] samuwm; (S, K;) and the burning, or vehement, heat of summer; (K;) and the clouds of dust thereof: or a hot wind; and hot winds; used alike as sing. and pl. (TA.) ― -b2- See also suhumN. ― -b3- And see what next follows.

suhaAmN c
suhaAmN (S, K) and sahaAmN↓, (K, and only thus in some copies of the K,) the former mentioned by several authors, (TA,) Leanness, or lankness in the belly, and an altered state (S, K, TA) of the colour, and dryness of the lips. (TA.) ― -b2- And the former, [in some copies of the K the latter, but the former, as is said in the TA, is the right, agreeably with analogy as a word signifying a disease,] A certain disease incident to camels. (El-Umawee, S, K.)

sahuwmN c
sahuwmN, with fet-h [to the s, by Freytag erroneously written sahawomN, in consequence of his having been misled by a double mistranscription immediately preceding in the CK], The flying eagle: (K:) the epithet “ flying ” being here used only as an explicative. (TA.)

suhuwmN c
suhuwmN an inf. n. of 1. (S, &c.) ― -b2- Also A frowning (EubuwsN, K, TA) of the face by reason of anxiety. (TA. [In the CK, AlsRahuwmu and AlEabuwsu are erroneously put for AlsRuhuwmu and AlEubuwsu: in the TA, Alshwm is expressly said to be with damm, in this case, and the meaning is shown by two verses there cited.])

sahRaAmN c
sahRaAmN A maker of arrows. (MA.)

saAhimu Alwajohi c
saAhimu Alwajohi, applied to a man, Altered in face. (TA.) The saying of 'Antarah,
waAlxayolu saAhimapu Alwujuwhi kaOanRamaA
tusoqaI fawaArisuhaA naqiyEa AlHanoZali
is expl. by Th as meaning And the owners of the horses were altered in their complexions in consequence of the state of difficulty wherein they were [as though they, i. e. the riders thereof, were given to drink infusion of colocynth]. (TA.) [But] saAhimu Alwajohi, is applied as an epithet to a horse as meaning Urged, or made, to perform a distressing act of running: and in like manner to a man when he is urged, or made, to perform a distressing part in war, or battle. (TA.) ― -b2- [The fem.] saAhimapN, applied to a she-camel, means Lean, or lank in the belly: (S, K: [see also masohuwmN:]) and [its pl.] sawaAhimu, applied to camels, altered by journeying. (S.)

musohamN c
musohamN A horse half-blooded, got by a stallion of generous race out of a mare not of such race; syn. hajiynN: (K:) to [the rider of] such is given less than the sahom [or share] of the spoil that is given to [the rider of] the horse of generous race. (TA.) [It is applied in this sense to a stallioncamel as well as to a horse.] A poet says,
baniI yavoribiIRK HaSRinuwA OayonuqaAtikumo
waOaforaAsakumo mino Darobi OaHomara musohami
[Sons of Yethribee, keep ye your she-camels and your mares from the being covered by one that is red, (i. e. of goodly appearance, for the red among camels are the most admired by the Arabs, and in like manner the bay among horses,) but half-blooded]: he means, keep ye your women from being taken as wives by such as are not their equals. (TA.) ― -b2- You say also, rajulN musohamu Aljisomi A man whose body is wasting away in consequence of love: (K:) and in like manner, musohamu AlEaqoli [whose reason is departing]: mentioned by Lh: (TA:) and so musohim↓, in both cases: (TA voce musohabN, q. v.:) the m being a substitute for b. (TA in the present art.) ― -b3- And musohamN, (K, TA,) or musohimN↓, (CK,) [both app. correct,] from Oasohama, is like musohabN [q. v.], (K, TA,) or musohibN, (CK,) from Oasohaba, in measure and in meaning; (K, TA;) meaning Loquacious, or profuse in speech: the m, accord. to Yaakoob, being [in this case also] a substitute for b. (TA.)

musohimN c
musohimN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

musahRamN c
musahRamN A [garment of the kind called] burod marked with stripes, or lines, (S, K, TA,) like sihaAm [i. e. arrows]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also the following paragraph.

masohuwmN c
masohuwmN, applied to a man, Lean, or lank in the belly: [see also saAhimN:] or affected with what is termed shAm [app. sahaAm, and meaning the heat of the wind called samuwm]. (TA.) ― -b2- And, applied to a camel, Smitten with the disease termed suhaAm: and so musahRamapN↓ applied to camels. (S, K.)

1 sahaA Eanohu c
1. sahaA Eanohu, (S, Msb,) or fiyhi, (K,) aor. yasohuw, inf. n. sahowN (S, Msb, K) and suhuwRN, (M, K,) He was, or became, unmindful, forgetful, neglectful, or heedless, of it, or inadvertent to it; (S, Msb;) namely, a thing; syn. gafala Eanohu: (S, * Msb:) or he forgot it, or neglected it, (nasiyahu,) and was, or became, unmindful, forgetful, &c., of it, or inadvertent to it, (gafala Eanohu,) his mind adverting to another thing or affair or case; (K, TA;) thus expl. in the M and T; so that AlsRahowu and Algafolapu and AlnRisoyaAnu are made to be one [in signification]; (TA;) but accord. to Esh-Shiháb, AlsRahowu is a slight gafolap [or unmindfulness &c.] of that which is within the scope of the retentive faculty, such as when one's attention is roused by the least rousing thereof; whereas AlnsyAn denotes its passing away from the memory entirely; though all are used in one sense by a careless reliance upon the understanding of the reader or hearer: in the Msb it is said that a distinction is made between AlsRaAhiI and AlnRaAsiI by the latter's being applied to him who, when he is reminded, remembers, and the former's being applied to him who is in the contrary case: accord. to IAth, sahaAfiI AlXRaIoCi means he neglected, or omitted, the thing unknowingly; and sahaA Eanohu, he neglected, or omitted, it knowingly: or, as some say, AlsRahowu is the doing wrong from unmindfulness (Eano gafolap); as when an insane person reviles another, which is pardonable; and as when one drinks wine and then some unpleasing action proceeds from him unintentionally, which is punishable. (TA.) One says, sahaAfiI AlSRalaApi, and EanohaA, i. q. gafala [He was, or became, unmindful in prayer, and of it]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, app., as implying an unexpected event,] Hamalato sahowFA She (a woman, S)
conceived in menstruis. (Az, S, Z, K.) And Hamalato bihi OumRuhu sahowFA His mother conceived him in menstruis. (JK.) ― -b3- AlsRahowu also signifies AlsRukuwnu (JK, S, K) and AllRiynu (JK, S,) [app. as an inf. n., i. e. as meaning The being still, or quiet, and gentle; though it is immediately added in the S that the pl. is sihaMCN; for it seems that an early transcriber of the S has omitted to insert after AllRaynu the words waAlsRaAkinu waAllRayRinu: see sahowN below]. One says, faEalahu sahowFA rahowFA He did it voluntarily, without its being asked, or demanded; (K, TA;) and without constraint: (TA:) or quietly, or calmly, without being hard, or difficult. (TA in art. rhw.) And sahaA Uilayohi He looked at him, or it, with motionless eye. (Msb, TA.) And AlEayonu tasohuw fiyhi The eye expatiates in it; syn. tanobasiTu. (JK.) ＝ -A2- sahaAwapN, as denoting a quality of a camel, The being easy to ride; (K;) an inf. n., of which the verb is sahuwa. (TA.) ＝ -A3- maAlN laA yusohaI walaA yunohaI [Cattle] of which the end is not to be reached. (AA, JK, S, K.) You say, yaraAHu EalaI baniI fulaAnK mina AlmaAli maA laA yusohaIwalaA yunohaI [There returns from the place of pasture in the evening, or afternoon, to the sons of such a one, of cattle,] what is not to be numbered for multitude: (T, TA:) or what is not to be computed, or computed by conjecture. (IAar, TA.) And cahabato tamiymu falaA tusohaI walaA tunohaI, meaning laA tucokaru [i. e. Temeem went away, and will not be remembered, or will not be mentioned]: a saying of El-Ahmar. (TA.)

3 sAhAhu c
3. sAhAhu, inf. n. musaAhaApN, i. q. gaAfalahu [app. meaning He acted with him in the manner of him who is unmindful, forgetful, neglectful, heedless, or inadvertent]. (TA.) [Or] the inf. n. signifies [The acting with moderation with another; or] the abstaining from going to the utmost length in social intercourse: (S, K:) or the being easy, or facile, with another: (A, TA:) or the behaving in a good [or pleasing] manner in social intercourse: (T, TA:) or the comporting oneself with another, or others, (muxaAlaqapN,) in a good manner, in social intercourse. ('Eyn, M, TA.) And one says, huwa yusaAhiI OaSoHaAbahu He comports himself with his companions, or does so with good nature; syn. yuxaAliquhumo. (TA.) And sAhAhu means also He mocked at him, or derided him. (TA.)

4 AshI c
4. AshI He (a man, TA) constructed what is termed a sahowap (K, TA) in a bayot [or chamber &c.]. (TA.)

AlsRuhaA c
AlsRuhaA [often written AlsRuhaI] A certain dim star, (S, K,) in [the asterism called] banaAt naEoX AlkuboraI, (S, [in the K, erroneously, bnAt nEX AlSRugoraI,]) by the middle star of those thus called; (TA;) [i. e.] a small star by that called AlEanaAqu, (which latter is the middle star [ ζ] of the three in the tail of Ursa Major, Kzw,) by looking at which persons try their powers of sight; (Kzw, TA;) mentioned in art. qwd [voce qaAYidN, q. v.]; (K;) [it is the star 80, by ζ;] also called AlsRuhayRaA↓, which is the diminutive. (TA.) It is said in a prov., OuriyhaA AlsRuhaA waturiyniI Alqamara [I show her Es-Suhà and she shows me the moon]. (S, TA. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. vol. i. pp. 527—9.]) And one says, OanRaI yalotaqiI suhayolN waAlsRuhaA How can Suheyl [or Canopus] meet Es-Suhà? for the former is southern and the latter is northern. (Har p. 276.)

sahowN c
sahowN [an inf. n. used as an epithet,] Easy; applied to a man, and to an affair, (K, TA,) and to an object of want: (TA:) and so [the fem.] sahowapN, applied to a mare; and applied to a she-mule as meaning easy in pace, that does not fatigue her rider: the epithet sahowN, however, is not applied to a he-mule: so in the T: (TA:) [but] it is applied to a he-camel, meaning easy to ride: and sahowapN to a she-camel, (K, TA,) meaning gentle, easy to ride: and raAhK saAhK↓, applied to a he-camel, means [likewise] gentle in pace; and so [the pls.] sawaAhK rawaAhK applied to camels: (TA:) [and so sahowaMCu↓ applied to a mare; for] a certain mare was named AlsRahowaMCu because of the gentleness of her pace. (TA.) Also, applied to water, Cool, sweet, or limpid; easy of descent in the throat. (K, * TA.) And qawosN sahowapN A bow that is compliant, (K, TA,) and easy. (TA.) And riyHN sahowN A gentle wind: [or a quiet, gentle wind:] pl. sihaMCN: (TA:) a poet (said to be El-Hárith Ibn- 'Owf, TA) says,
tanaAwaHati AlrRayaAHu lifaqodi EamorKw
wakaAnato qabola maholikihi sihaMCaA
i. e. [The winds blew violently for the loss of 'Amr; but they were before his death] quiet and gentle. (S, TA.) One says also OaroDN sahowapN Soft land, without barrenness. (TA.) ＝ -A2- And AlsRahowu means The moon, in the language of the Nabathæans. (JK.)

sihowN c
sihowN: see sihowaMCN

sahowapN c
sahowapN An instance, or a case, of unmindfulness, forgetfulness, neglectfulness, heedlessness, or inadvertence. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- A rock, or great mass of stone, (K,) in the dial. of Teiyi, who call nothing else by this name: so in the M: or, accord. to the T, in that dial., the rock, or great mass of stone, upon which the waterer [app. of camels] stands: (TA:) or a rock, or great mass of stone, standing up, not having any foundation [app. meaning not partly imbedded] in the ground: and in the dial. of Teiyi, a single stone, great or small. (JK.) ― -b2- A bayot [app. here meaning booth, or the like,] which the Arabs of the desert set up at the water, and by the shade of which they shelter themselves. (TA.) A SufRap [or kind of roofed vestibule, or the like, or a covering for shade and shelter], (K, TA,) between two houses: (TA:) or a thing like the SufRap, which is before, or in the front of, houses: (As, JK, S:) or [in some copies of the K “ and ”] a kind of closet (muixodaE) between two chambers, (K, TA,) in which the waterers of the camels shelter themselves: or, as some say, a small wall which is build between the two [opposite main] walls of the chamber, the roof being placed over the whole; what is in the middle [or main part] of the chamber being [called] a sahowap; [see EarosN;] and what is within it, [app. behind,] a muixodaE: (TA:) or the like of a rafR and TaAq, [app. meaning a kind of arched construction with a flat top which forms a shelf, against a wall; or simply a shelf, or ledge projecting from a wall, (see rafRN and TaAqN,)] in which, or upon which, a thing is placed: (ISd, K:) or a small bayot [or chamber], (S, K,) descending into the earth, having its roof elevated above the ground, (S,) resembling a small xizaAnap [or closet, or storeroom], (S, K,) in which are [deposited] the household-goods, or furniture and utensils; thus as heard by A'Obeyd from more than one of the people of El-Yemen: (S:) or it signifies, (K,) or signifies also, (JK,) four sticks, or pieces of wood, (JK, K,) or three, (K,) which are placed crosswise, one upon another, and upon which is then put anything of the household-goods, or furniture and utensils: (JK, K:) so in the M: (TA:) and (accord. to the T, TA) i. q. kanoduwjN, (K,) which means a small closet or store-room: (TA:) and i. q. rawoXanN and kuwRapN [i. e. a window, or mural aperture]: and a [kind of curtained canopy, or the like, such as is called] Hajalap: and a curtain, or screen, before the court, or yard, of a house, (K, TA,) and sometimes, surrounding the house, like a wall: (TA:) its pl. (in all of these senses, K, TA) is sihaMCN (JK, K, TA) and sahawaAtN. (JK.)

sahowaMCu c
sahowaMCu: see sahowN: ＝ -A2- and see also what here follows.

sihowaMCN c
sihowaMCN, (IAar, JK, S, TA,) like siEowaMCN and tihowaMCN, all with kesr, on the authority of IAar, but in the K sahowaMC↓, (TA,) A [portion, or short portion, such as is termed] saAEap, of the night; (S, K, TA;) and (S, TA) the first part thereof: (JK, S, TA:) or it may be like sahowaAn↓, [which is app. in this case with tenween, and] which seems to mean a period in which people are unmindful of the places, or ways, in which things are, or should be, sought by them; or shwAn may be from saAhiyapN, expl. below: and mina AllRayoli sihowN↓ signifies the same as siEow and saEow [and sihowaMC] and siEowaAC. (Ham p. 708.) One says, laqiytuhu baEoda sihowaMCK mina AllRayoli i. e. [I met him after a portion, or short portion, of the night; or] after the first part of the night had passed. (JK.)

sahowaAn c
sahowaAn: see saAhK: ＝ -A2- and see also sihowaMCN.

AlsRuhayRaA c
AlsRuhayRaA dim. of AlsRuhaA, q. v.

saAhK c
saAhK Unmindful, forgetful, neglectful, heedless, or inadvertent; (JK, S, Msb, K;) as also sahowaAnu↓; (S, K;) whence the prov.,
UinRa AlmuwaSRayona banuw sahowaAno
(S) i. e. Only the unmindful [lit. the sons of the unmindful] are such as require to be enjoined: (S, Meyd:) or, as some say, by bnw shwAn are meant all mankind; because all become unmindful: but the most correct explanation is, that those who are enjoined to do a thing are subject to unmindfulness: it is applied to him who is unmindful of pursuing that which he is commanded to do: and shwAn may be syn. with [the inf. n.] sahowN; or it may be an epithet, syn. with saAhK, and is applied to Adam, because he forgot his cove-
nant, so that bnw shwAn may mean the sons of Adam, and hence, the unmindful. (Meyd. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 3-4.]) ― -b2- See also sahwN.

saAhiyapN c
saAhiyapN A tract of land long and wide, without any covert of trees, or the like, [to obstruct the view, or] to repel the eye. (JK, and Ham p. 708.)

OasohaMCN c
OasohaMCN and OasohaMCapN: see what follows.

OasaAhiIRu c
OasaAhiIRu, (JK, TA,) in the K, erroneously, OasohaMC↓, (TA,) i. q. OalowaAnN [generally signifying Colours; but also meaning sorts, or species; and here used in this latter sense, as is indicated in the TA]: a pl. having no sing.: (K, TA:) so in the M: (TA:) or it signifies, (JK,) or signifies also, (TA,) various sorts (DuruwbN muxotalifpN, JK, TA) of pace of camels; like OasaAhiyju: (TA:) and its sing. is OasohaMCapN↓. (JK.)

sawo c
sawo i. q. sawofa, q. v.

1 saMCa c
1. saMCa, (Lth, M, Msb, K,) aor. yasuwoCu, (Lth, Msb,) inf. n. sawoCN, (Lth, M,) or sawaMCN, like saHaAbN, (K,) [but the former is that which is commonly known,] It (a thing, Lth, M) was, or became, evil, bad, abominable, foul, unseemly, unsightly, or ugly. (Lth, M, Msb, K.) It is used in this sense, (IKt, TA,) or [rather] is like biYosa, (Bd, Jel,) in the Kur [xvii. 34], where it is said, saMCa sabiylFA [Evil, &c., is it as a way of acting]: (IKt, Bd, Jel, TA:) which is like the saying, saMCa hecaA macohabFA [Evil, &c., is this as a way of acting or believing, &c.]: the noun being in the accus. case as a specificative. (IKt, TA.) And so in the saying, saMCa maA faEala fulaAnN SaniyEFA [Evil, &c., as an action, is that which such a one has done]. (TA.) ― -b2- One says also, suWotu bihi ZanRFA, and bihi AlZRanRa OasaOotu↓, [lit. I was evil in opinion respecting him, or it, and I made the opinion respecting him, or it, to be evil, each virtually meaning I held, or formed, an evil opinion respecting him, or it,] the noun being determinate, with the article Al, in the latter case, (ISk, S, Msb, TA,) because it is an objective complement, for the verb is trans., (IB, TA,) and the noun being indeterminate in the former case, (IB, Msb, TA,) because it is in the accus. case as a specificative; (IB, TA;) but some allow it to be indeterminate after OasaOotu↓, which is here the contr. of OaHosanotu. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- It is also trans.: (Lth, TA:) you say, saMCahu, (S, M, K,) aor. yasuwoWuhu, (S,) inf. n. sawoCN (S, M, K) and suwoCN, with damm also, (TA, [and said to be an inf. n. in the Ksh and by Bd in ii. 46, but as it is not mentioned as an inf. n. in the S nor in the M nor in the K, but is expressly said in all these to be a subst., I think that is should be rejected, or regarded as a quasi-inf. n. like kalaAmN and vawaAbN &c.,]) sawaMpN (K) and sawaMCapN (AZ, M, K) and sawaAICiyapN (S, M, K,) of the measure faEaAliyapN, like EalaAniyapN (Kh, S, M,) and sawaAyapN, (S, M, K,) which is a contraction of that next preceding, (Kh, S, M,) and masaMCN (M, K) and masaMCapN, (S, M, K,) originally masowaOapN, (Har p. 81,) and masaAYiyapN, which is originally masaAwiYapN, (Kh, S, M, K,) and masaAyapN, (S, M, K,) which is a contraction of that next preceding, (Kh, S,) and masaAYiyRapN, (M, K,) this last written in the L with two I s, [i. e. masaAyyiapN,] (TA,) [He did evil to him;] he did to him that which he disliked, or hated; (M, K;) he displeased, grieved, or vexed, him; contr. of sarRahu. (S.) One says, suWotu AlrRajula, meaning I displeased, grieved, or vexed, the man by what he saw [or experienced] from me. (S.) And Oaradotu masaMCataka and masaAYiyataka [I desired to displease, grieve, or vex, thee]. (Lth, TA.) And UinRa AllRayola TawiylN walaA yasuWo baAluhu [Verily the night is long, and may the state thereof not displease, grieve, or vex, me]: meaning laA yasuWoniI baAluhu; and expressing a prayer. (Lh, M. [In the TA, in the place of baAluhu is put mA lh; as though meaning maA lahu mina AlHawaAdivi or the like, i. e. its events, or accidents, &c.]) And lahu Einodiy maA saMCahu wanaMCahu [I have, belonging to him, or I owe him, what grieved him, and oppressed him by its weight], and maA yasuwoWuhu wayanuwoWuhu [what does, or will, grieve him, &c.]. (S.) taraka maA yasuwoWuhu wayanuwoWuhu [He left, or has left, what will grieve him, and oppress him by its weight, on the day of judgment, by the responsibility that it has imposed upon him,] is a prov., said of him who has left his property to his heirs. (Meyd, TA.) It is said that El-Mahboobee was possessed of riches; and when death visited him, he desired to make a testament; so it was said to him, “ What wilt thou write? ” and he answered, “ Write ye, 'Such a one,' meaning himself, 'has left what will grieve him, and oppress him by its weight:' ” i. e., property which his heirs will devour, while the burden thereof will remain upon him. (Meyd, TA.) [See also 4.] ― -b2- One says also, suWotu wajoha fulaAnK, aor. OasuwoWuhu, inf. n. masaMCapN and masaAYiyapN, (Lth, TA,) i. q. qabaHotuhu [i. e. I said, May God remove the person (lit. the face) of such a one far from good, or prosperity, &c.]. (TA. [It is said in a copy of the M, that suWotu lahu wajohahu means qabRaHotuhu: but I think that the right explanation is qabaHotuhu, without tesh-deed, meaning I said to him, qabaHa QllRehu wajohaka: see art. qbH.])

2 swRO c
2. swRO [He corrupted, or marred]. You say, sawRi walaA tusawRiYo Rectify thou, and do not corrupt, or mar. (A, TA.) [See also 4.] ― -b2- swRO Ealayohi He said to him OasaOotu [Thou hast done ill]. (M.) You say, sawRaOotu Ealayohi maA SanaEa, (S,) or SaniyEahu, (K,) i. e. fiEolahu, (TA,) inf. n. tasowiYapN and tasowiIoCN, I discommended to him what he had done, or his deed; and said to him OasaOota [Thou hast done ill]. (S, K.) And Uino OasaOotu fasawRiYo EalaIRa [If I do ill, say thou to me, Thou hast done ill]. (S.)

4 OasaMCa c
4. OasaMCa, [inf. n. UisaMCapN,] He did evil, or ill; or acted ill; contr. of OaHosana: (S, M, K:) [and so] AsiMC fiI fiEolihi. (Msb.) You say, AsMC Uilayohi (S, K) and lahu and Ealayhi and bihi (TA) He did evil or ill, or acted ill, to him. (S, K, TA.) ― -b2- [See also OasowaI, in several senses, in art. swy.] ＝ -A2- AsMChu He corrupted it, or marred it; (M, K;) [did it ill;] did it not well; namely, a thing. (M.) It is said in a prov., OasaMCa kaArihN maA Eamila [An unwilling person did ill what he did]; relating to a man who was compelled against his will, by another, to do a thing, and marred it, or did it not well: it is applied to the man who seeks an object of want and does not take pains to accomplish it. (M, Meyd. *) See also 1, in two places, in the former half of the paragraph. [And see 2.]

8 AstMC c
8. AstMC He experienced evil, or that which he disliked or hated, (S, * K, TA,) or displeasure, (TA,) or grief, or anxiety. (M, TA.) AisotaMCa lahaA occurs in a trad. as meaning He (the Prophet) became displeased, or grieved, or anxious, on account of it; i. e., on account of a dream that had been related to him: or, accord. to one relation, the right reading is AisotaMlahaA, meaning “ he sought the interpretation of it, by consideration. ” (TA.)

sawoCN c
sawoCN is an inf. n. of saMCa, (Lth, S, M, K,) intrans., (Lth, M,) and trans.: (S, M, K:) and is also used as an epithet, applied to a man, (M, Msb, and Ham p. 712,) and to an action. (Msb.) You say rajulu sawoCK (S, M, Msb, K) [A man of evil nature or doings; or] a man who does what is evil, displeasing, grievous, or vexatious: (M, TA:) and rajulu AlsRawoCi [the man of evil nature or doings &c.]: (S, K:) and ciYobu AlsRawoCi [the wolf of evil nature &c.], as in a verse cited voce OaHaAla, in art. Hwl: (S:) and Eamalu sawoCK [a deed of evil nature]: (M, Msb:) and Eamalu AlsRawoCi [the deed of evil nature]: (Ham p. 498:) and naEotu sawoCK [an epithet of evil nature]: (O and K in art. sHq:) and saEofu sawoCK a bad commodity: (O and TA in art. sEf:) and if you make the former word determinate [by means of the article Al], you use the latter as an epithet [also], (M, * Msb, and Ham, p. 712, *) and you say AlrRajulu AlsRawoCu [the evil man, or the man who does what is evil &c.]: (Msb, and Ham p. 712:) and AlEamalu AlsRawoCu [the evil deed]: (Msb:) [this last phrase I hold to be correct, regarding AlsRawoCu in this case as originally an inf. n. of the intrans. verb saMCa, and therefore capable of being used as an epithet applied to anything; though] IB says that AlsRawoCu used as an epithet is applied to a man but not to a deed: (TA:) [in what here follows from the S, denying the correctness of another phrase mentioned above on the authority of lexicologists of high repute, there is, in my opinion, an obvious mistranscription, twice occurring, AlsRawoCu for AlsRuwoCu, which I suppose to have passed from an early copy of that work into most other copies thereof, for I find it alike in all to which I have had access:] Akh says, one should not say AlrRajulu AlsRawoCu, though one says AlHaqRu Alyaqiynu as well as HaqRu Alyaqiyni; for AlsRawoCu is not the same as AlrRajulu, but Alyaqiynu is the same as AlHaqRu: he says, also, nor should one say, hecaA rajulu AlsRuwoCi with damm: (S:) [here the expres-
sion “ with damm ” may perhaps be meant to refer to AlswC in all of the three instances above; not in the last only:] IB says, [in remarking on this passage of the S, in which he appears to have read AlsRuwoC, with damm, in all of the three instances,] Akh allows one's saying rajulu AlsRawoCi and rajulu sawoCK, with fet-h to the s in both; but not rajulu AlsRuwoCi, with damm to the s, because AlsRuwoCu is a subst., meaning “ harm, injury, hurt, mischief, or damage, ” and “ evilness of state or condition; ” and rajul is prefixed, as governing a gen. case, only to the inf. n.: and he adds that one says, hecaA AlrRajulu AlsRawoCu, not prefixing [the former noun to the latter, but using the latter as an epithet]. (TA.) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph, in six places.

suwoCN c
suwoCN is the subst. from saMCahu; (S, M, * K;) [so, app., accord. to the generality of the lexicologists;] or inf. n. (Ksh and Bd in ii. 46) of sayRiYN, (Ksh ibid.,) or of saMCa, aor. yasuwoCu, (Bd ibid.,) or of saMCahu [q. v.]; (TA;) signifying Evilness, badness, abominableness, foulness, or unseemliness; [and displeasingness, grievousness, or vexatiousness;] as, for instance, of natural disposition, and of doings: (Ksh ubi suprà:) vitious, immoral, unrighteous, sinful, or wicked, conduct: [hence, ramaAhu bisuwoCK: see art. rmy:] anything disapproved, or disallowed; or regarded as evil, bad, abominable, foul, or unseemly: (S, TA:) [an evil action or event:] evilness of state or condition: harm, injury, hurt, mischief, or damage: (IB, TA:) anything that is mentioned as being sayRiY [i. e. evil, &c.]: (Lth, TA:) any evil, evil affection, cause of mischief or harm or injury, noxious or destructive thing, calamity, disease, or malady: (M, K, TA:) [pl. OasowaMCN, accord. to a general rule.] The saying maA Ounokiruka mino suwoCK means I do not disacknowledge thee in consequence of suwoC [i. e. evilness, &c.,] that I have seen in thee, but only in consequence of my little knowledge of thee. (S.) linaSorifa Eanohu AlsRuwoCa waAlfaHoXaMCa, in the Kur [xii. 24], is said by Zj to mean, [In order that we might turn away from him] unfaithfulness to his master, and adultery. (M, TA.) And suwoCu AlHisaAbi, in the Kur [xiii. 18, i. e. The evilness of the reckoning], is expl. by him as meaning a reckoning in which no good work will be accepted, and no evil work passed over; because infidelity will have made the former to be of no avail: or, as some say, it means a reckoning pursued to the utmost extent, in which no evil work will be passed over. (M, TA.) laA xayora fiI qawoli AlsRuwoCi means There is no good in thy saying suwoC [i. e. a thing that is evil; qwl being here used in its original sense of an inf. n.]: but if you say AlsRawoC↓, [you use qwl in the sense of maquwl, and] the meaning is, in evil speech. (TA as from the K, but not in the CK nor in my MS. copy of the K.) suwoCN accord. to one reading, and sawoCN↓ accord. to another, (K, TA, [but all that is given in this sentence as from the K is so given only on the authority of the TA, not being in the CK nor in my MS. copy of the K]) the latter of which readings is the more common, (TA,) in the phrase daAYirapu AlsRwC, (K, TA,) in the Kur [ix. 99 and xlviii. 6], (TA,) mean Defeat, and evil; (K, TA;) and trial, or affliction, and torment; (TA;) and perdition, and destruction, or corruption: (K, TA:) and in like manner in the saying, OumoTirato maTara AlsRwCi, (K, TA,) in the Kur [xxv. 42]: (TA:) or AlsRuwoC means harm, injury, hurt, mischief, or damage; and evilness of state or condition; [as expl. before;] and AlsRawoC↓, corruption, or destruction, or perdition: (K, * TA:) or AlsRuwoC in the phrase daAYirapu AlsRuwoCi means defeat and evil; and the reading AlsRawoC↓ is from [i. e. syn. with] AlmasaMCap [as inf. n.]. (S. [See also daAYirapN, in art. dwr.]) Accord. to Zj, in the saying in the Kur [xlviii. 6], QlZRaAnRiyna biQllRehi ZanRa QlsRawoCi↓, (TA,) meaning ZanRa AlOamori AlsRawoCi [i. e. Who opine, of God, the opining of the evil thing], (Bd,) it is allowable to read ZanRa AlsRuwoCi; (T, TA;) and thus some read in this instance: (Jel:) but AM says, in the saying in the Kur [xlviii. 12], waZananotumo ZanRa AlsRawoCi↓ [And ye opined the evil opining], it is read only with fet-h, and damm to the s is not allowable in this instance, for there is in it no meaning of trial, or affliction, and torment: (TA:) [for this distinction, however, I see no reason; and it is not correct; for] AlswC is with fet-h and with damm to the s in the three sentences [whereof this last is one] in which it occurs in this chapter. (Jel.) ― -b2- In the Kur vii. 188, it is said to mean (assumed tropical:) Diabolical possession; or insanity, or madness. (M, TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) Leprosy, syn. baraSN, (Lth, S, M, K, TA,) is said to be its meaning in the Kur xx. 23 and xxvii. 12 and xxviii. 32. (S, TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) The fire: so in the Kur xxx. 9, accord. to the reading AlsRuwoCa: (K, TA:) said to mean there Hell: but the reading commonly known is AlsRuwoCaI↓. (TA.) ― -b5- And (assumed tropical:) Weakness in the eye. (K. [Thus, i. e. with damm to the s, in the CK and TK: in the TA said to be bAlftH; but this is evidently a mistake for bAlDmR.])

saIoCN c
saIoCN: see sayRiYN.

sawoCapN c
sawoCapN The Eaworap [or pudendum], (S, Mgh, Msb,) i. e. (Msb) the faroj [which means the same, or the external portion of the organs of generation], (Lth, M, IAth, Msb, K,) of a man, and of a woman: (Lth, Msb, TA:) and the anus: (Az and TA in art. swI:) dual sawoCataAni: and pl. sawoMtN: so called because its becoming exposed to men displease [or shames] the owner thereof; (Msb;) or because of its unseemliness. (Ham p. 510.) In the Kur vii. 19, for sawoMtihimaA, some read sawaAtihimaA; and some, sawRaAtihimaA. (Bd.) ― -b2- In the Kur v. 34, it means The dead body, or corpse; (Bd, Jel;) because it is deemed unseemly to be seen. (Bd.) ― -b3- Accord. to IAth, the former is the primary signification: and hence it is transferred to denote Any saying, or action, of which one is ashamed when it appears: (TA:) any evil, bad, abominable, foul, or unseemly, saying or action; (S, K, TA;) as also sawoMCu↓: (M:) any disgracing action or thing: (Lth, TA:) an evil, abominable, or unseemly, property, quality, custom, or practics; (K, TA;) as also sawoMCu↓, or sawoCaI↓; (accord. to different copies of the K; [the latter perhaps fem. of OasowaOu↓ like the former, of the same class as dafoOaI and danoOaI, or fem. of sawoMnu↓, like EaToXaI fem. of EaToXaAnu;]) or so both of these; (TA;) or so sawoCapN sawoMCu↓: (S:) [or this last means a property, &c., that is very evil &c.] One says, sawoCapF lifulaAnK May a disgracing action or thing befall such a one; [or disgrace, or shame, to such a one;] using the accus. case because it is an expression of reviling and imprecation. (Lth, TA.) [See also sayRiYapN and suwoCaI.] ― -b4- AlsRawoCapu AlsRawoCaI↓ [or AlsRawoCapu AlsRawoMCu↓] also means The contrarious wife or woman. (TA.)

saAyapN c
saAyapN as used in the saying Daraba fulaAnN EalaI fulaAnK saAyapF is held by some to be originally with C, and of the measure faEolapN, from AlsRawoCu; so that the saying means Such a one did to such a one a thing that caused displeasure to him; and did evil to him: others hold that the saying means such a one made a way to do what he desired to such a one; in which case, sAyp is of the measure faEolapN from sawRayotu; originally sawoyapN, which is changed into sayRapN, and then into saAyapN, in like manner as diwRaAnN is changed into diywaAnN. (Aboo-Bekr, TA.) [See the same word in art. swI.]

sawoCaI c
sawoCaI: see sawoCapN, in two places.

suwoCaI c
suwoCaI is [fem. of OasowaOu↓, q. v., as meaning More, and most, evil, bad, abominable, foul, unseemly, unsightly, or ugly: and is also] a subst. signifying an evil, a bad, an abominable, a foul, or an unseemly, action; (Msb, TA;) i. q. faEolapN sayRiYapN [and sayRiYapN alone]: in this sense, [as well as in the former,] (TA,) contr. of HusonaI. (S, M, K, TA.) ― -b2- In the Kur xxx. 9, (S, TA,) accord. to the reading commonly known, (TA,) [as contr. of AlHusonaI,] AlsRuwoCaI means (assumed tropical:) The fire (S, K, TA) of Hell. (TA.) See also suwoCN, last explanation but one.

sawoMCu c
sawoMCu: see OasowaOu (of which it is said by some to be fem.) in two places: ― -b2- and see also sawoCapN, in four places.

xazoyaAnu sawoMnu c
xazoyaAnu sawoMnu is [app. an instance of the alteration of the latter of two epithets to assimilate it to the former, originally xazoyaAnu OasowaOu, meaning Ashamed, or base, or vile, or ignominious, and evil, bad, &c.,] from AlquboHu. (M, TA.) ― -b2- See also sawoCapN.

sayRiYN c
sayRiYN, [originally sayowiYN (as will be shown below, voce sayRiYapN), then sayoyiYN, and then sayRiYN,] applied to a thing [of any kind], (Lth, TA,) Evil, bad, abominable, foul, unseemly, unsightly, or ugly; (Lth, Msb, TA;) contr. of HasanN: (Msb:) sometimes contracted into saIoCN↓, like as hayRinN is contracted in hayonN, and layRnN into layonN; as in the saying of Et-Tuhawee,
walaA yajozuwna mino HasanK misaIoCK
walaA yajozuwna mino gilaZK biliyni
[And they will not requite good with evil, nor will they requite roughness with gentleness]. (S.) You say qawolN sayRiYN [An evil saying; or] a saying that displeases. (M, TA.) And faEolapN sayRiYapN [An evil action or deed]. (TA.) And it is said in the Kur [xxxv. 41], wamakora QlsRayRiYi walaA yaHiyqu Qlomakoru QlsRayRiYN UilRaA biOaholihi [And in the plotting of that which is evil; but the evil plotting shall not beset any save the authors thereof]. (M, TA.) One says also, fulaAnN sayRiYu AlAixotiyaAri [Such a one is evil in respect of choice, or preference]. (S.) [See also the next paragraph.]

sayRiYapN c
sayRiYapN [fem. of sayRiYN, q. v.: and also a subst., being transferred from the category of epithets to that of substs. by the affix p], originally sayowiYapN, (S,) An evil act or action; contr. of HasanapN; (Msb;) a fault, an offence, or an act of disobedience; or such as is intentional; a sin, a crime, or an act of disobedience for which one deserves punishment; syn. xaTiyoYapN: (M, K:) pl. sayRiYaAtN. (TA.) It is said in a trad., AlHasanapu bayona AlsRayRiYatayoni [The good act is between the two evil acts]; meaning that the exceeding of the just bounds is a sayRiYap, and the falling short thereof is a sayRiYap, and the pursuing a middle course between these two is a Hasanap. (TA.) [See also sawoCapN and suwoCaI.] ― -b2- Also; tropically, (tropical:) The recompense of a sayRiYap properly so termed [i. e. as expl. above]. (Msb in art. mkr.) ― -b3- An evil, or evil accident; a calamity; a misfortune; (Ksh in iv. 81;) a trial, or an affliction; opposed to HasanapN; (Ksh and Bd in iv. 80;) scarcity of herbage, or of the goods, conveniences, and comforts, of life; straitness of circumstances; and unsuccessfulness; thus [likewise] opposed to HasanapN in the Kur iv. 80. (Er- Rághib, TA in art. Hsn.)

OasowaOu c
OasowaOu; fem. suwoCaI: see the latter word. One says, huwa OasowaOu Alqawomi He is the most evil, &c., of the people, or party; syn. OaqobaHuhumo: and hiIa AlsRuwoCaI She is the most evil, &c. (Msb.) And the [common] people say OasowaOu AlOaHowaAli, meaning The [worst, or] most scanty, and weakest, of states or conditions. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- [Also,] applied as an epithet to a man, (El-Umawee, M, TA,) Evil, bad, abominable, foul, unseemly, unsightly, or ugly: (ElUmawee, M, K, TA:) fem. sawoMCu↓, (El-Umawee, M, K,) which is thus applied to a woman; (ElUmawee, S, M;) or this is an instance of the measure faEElaMCu having no [masc. of the measure] OafaEalu. (M, TA.) See also sawoCapN, in four places. It is said in a trad. (M, TA) of the Prophet, or of 'Omar, (TA,) waluwdN xayorN mino HasonaMCa EaqiymK sawoMCu↓ [An ugly prolific woman is better than a beautiful barren one]. (M, TA.)

masaMCapN c
masaMCapN an inf. n. of saMCahu: (S, M, K:) and [also a subst. signifying An evil, as being] a cause of grief or vexation; contr. of masarRapN: originally masowaOapN: and therefore the pl. is masaAwK↓, for masaAwiYu; (Msb;) signifying also vices, faults, defects, or imperfections; (S, Msb, K, TA;) and diseases; (S, TA;) and acts of disobedience: (Msb:) so in the saying, badato masaAwiyhi His acts of disobedience, and vices, faults, &c., appeared: (Msb:) and Alxayolu tajoriI EalaI masaAwiyhaA Horses run, notwithstanding their vices, or faults, &c., (S, Meyd, K,) and diseases; (S, Meyd;) for their generousness impels them to do so: (S, Meyd, K: but omitted in the CK:) and in like manner, the ingenuous generous man bears difficulties, and defends, or protects, what he is bound to defend or protect, or to regard as sacred, or inviolable, though he be weak, and practises generosity in all circumstances: (Meyd, TA:) or it is applied in relation to the protection and defence of what should be sacred, or inviolable, or of wives, or women under covert, and the members of one's household, notwithstanding harm, or injury, and fear: or it means that one may seek to defend himself by means of a man though there be in him qualities disapproved: (MF, TA:) but accord. to Lh, AlmasaAwiI has no proper sing., like AlmaHaAsinu: (Meyd, TA: *) accord. to some of the writers on inflection, it is the contr. of AlmaHaAsinu, and an anomalous pl. of AlsRuwoCu, being originally with C. (TA.)

masaAwK c
masaAwK: see the next preceding paragraph.

suwbapN c
suwbapN A long, or far, journey; like suboOapN; (K, TA;) of which it is a dial. var.: a short journey is termed surobapN. (TA.)

suwbiyapN c
suwbiyapN A well-known [beverage of the kind called] nabiyc, prepared from wheat, and much drunk by the people of Egypt, (L, TA,) at their festivals: (TA:) and also prepared from rice: (MF, TA:) [also from the pips of a species of melon, called in Egypt EabodalRaAwiIR; (see art. Ebd; and see also White's “ Abdollatiphi Hist. Aegypti Compendium, ” pp. 52-3; or De Sacy's transl., pp. 34-5;) moistened and pounded, and steeped in water, which is then strained, and sweetened with sugar:] it is mentioned in a trad. and by several writers. (TA.)

1 saAja nasiyjahu biAlmisowajapi c
1. saAja nasiyjahu biAlmisowajapi, said of a weaver, He passed the misowajap, i. e. the sprinkling instrument, to and fro over his web [to dress the warps with the preparation termed sawoj]. (A, TA. *) ― -b2- [Hence, app., unless the reverse be the case, the inf. n.] sawajaAnN signifies The act of going and coming: (AA, O, K, TA:) asserted by some to be sawojaAnN, [and thus it is in the CK,] but this is a mistake. (TA.) You say, saAja, aor. yasuwju, inf. n. sawojN [and sawajaAnN], He, or it, went and came. (TA.) ― -b3- And sAj, (IAar, O, K,) aor. as above, (IAar, O,) inf. n. sawojN and suwaAjN and sawajaAnN, He went along gently, softly, or in a leisurely manner. (IAar, O, K.) IAar cites the following [as an ex. of an epithet hence derived]:
AljilobiHi garRaMCa layosato biAlsRaWuwji↓
[A female fair in face: she is not the ugly old woman that goes along gently, or softly, by reason of decrepitude]. (O.)

2 swRj EalaI Alkaromi c
2. swRj EalaI Alkaromi (A, Msb) wanaHowihi (Msb) He made a siyaAj, i. e. an enclosure (A, Msb) composed of thorns and the like, (Msb,) around the grape-vines (A, Msb) and the like; as also syRj, with I, agreeably with the word syAj [from which it is derived]: (Msb:) and syRj HaAYiTahu, inf. n. tasoyiyjN, he made an enclosure (K and TA in art. syj) of thorns and the like (TA in that art.) around his garden of palm-trees or vines. (K and TA in the same art.)

saAjN c
saAjN [The teak-tree; tectona grandis; to which the name of sAj is applied in Pers.; remarkable for its huge size, and enormous leaves: or the Indian, or Oriental, plane-tree: or the Indian plantain-tree: (see De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., sec. ed., iii. 473:)] a certain species of tree, (S, A, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) of great size, (Msb,) growing to a very great size, (Mgh,) that grows only in India, and is conveyed thence to other countries; (Mgh, Msb;) so they say: (Mgh:) Z says, (Msb,) it is a black, heavy, wood, which is brought from India, (A, Msb,) in pieces made of an oblong form, and squared, (A,) and which the woodfretter can hardly, or not at all, wear, or waste; (A, Msb;) and he says that its pl. is siyjaAnN: (Msb: [but this is said in the A only to be pl. of sAj meaning “ a rounded, wide, TayolasaAn: ”]) some say that it resembles ebony, but is less black: (Msb:) accord to the A, Noah's ark was made of it: but several authors say that it is related in the Book of the Law revealed to Moses that it was made of the Sanawobar [or pine-tree]; and some say that the Snwbr is a species of the sAj: (TA:) AHn describes it, (O, TA,) on the authority of one who had seen it in its places of growth, (O,) as a species of tree that grows to a great size, tall and wide, having leaves like the shields of the Deylem (AldRayolam, q. v.), with one of which leaves a man may cover himself, and it will protect him from the rain, and it has a sweet odour, like the odour of the leaves of the walnut, and is fine and soft, or smooth; (O, TA,) the elephants [he says] are fond of it, and of the leaves of the banana, both of which they eat: it is not of the trees that grow in the land of the Arabs, nor does it grow in any country except those of India and the Zenj; nor does any tree grow so tall, nor any so big: (O:) saAjapN↓ is the n. un.; and its pl. is saAjaAtN: (Msb:) and it signifies a piece of wood of the tree called sAj, made of an oblong form, and squared, as brought from India; (A, * Mgh, TA;) such as is cut and prepared for a foundation and the like: (Mgh:) one says, fiI OasaAsi binaAYihi saAjapN [In the foundation of his building is a piece of wood of the sAj cut in an oblong form, and squared]: (A:) a sAjp from which a door is cloven, or divided off lengthwise, is called saliyjapN: (TA:) and the term saAjapN is also applied to the board, or tablet, [of wood of the sAj,] upon which stand [or rest] the two scales of the balance when one weighs with it. (Ham. p. 818.) ＝ -A2- Also A [garment of the kind
called] TayolasaAn of the colour termed xuDorap [here meaning a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour]: (S, A, O, K:) or a black TylsAn: (IAar, O, K:) or a large, thick, or coarse, TylsAn: (TA:) or a TylsAn made of a round form, (A, TA,) and wide: (A:) or a TylsAn hollowed out in the middle (muqawRarN); so woven: (Az, O, Msb:) this last is said to be meant in a trad. in which it is said that the Prophet used to wear in war such qalaAnis [pl. of qalanosuwapN, q. v.,] as were [made] of siyjaAn: (TA:) siyjaAnN is the pl.: (T, S, A, O, Msb:) the dim. is suwayojN↓. (TA.) It is tropically applied to signify (tropical:) A [garment of the kind called] kisaMC made of a square form, or four-sided; and is described as a sort of miloHafap, woven. (TA.) As meaning a TylsAn, it is said by some, that its A is originally I. (L, TA.) ― -b2- It is also used, by a poet, in the manner of an epithet, as meaning Of the colour termed xuDorap [expl. above]. (TA.)

sawojN c
sawojN A preparation of clay, [app. made into a sort of ooze, and] cooked; with which the weaver does over [i. e. dresses] the warps of the web. (TA. [See 1, first sentence.])

saAjapN c
saAjapN n. un. of saAjN, q. v. (Msb.)

saWuwjN c
saWuwjN [an epithet from saAja in the last of the senses assigned to it above]: see 1, last sentence.

suwayojN c
suwayojN A small TayolasaAn of the kind called saAj, q. v. (TA.)

siyaAjN c
siyaAjN An enclosure (A, Msb) made with thorns and the like (Msb) around grape-vines (A, Msb) and the like: (Msb:) an enclosure made with trees around grape-vines or a garden: (L in art. syj:) an enclosure (O and K in that art.) of any kind (O) around a thing, such as palm-trees and grape-vines: (O, K:) and a wall (O, K) of any kind, whether roofed or not roofed: (O:) pl. [of pauc.] OasowijapN and [of mult.] suwjN; (A, Msb;) the latter originally suwujN, like kutubN pl. of. kitaAbN. (Msb.) Fei makes the medial radical letter to be w, and so do [Z and] AHei and most of the grammarians: Az [and Sgh] and IM hold it to be I. (TA.)

misowajapN c
misowajapN The sprinkling instrument (miraXRap, A) which the weaver passes to and fro over his web [to dress the warps with the preparation termed sawoj]. (A, TA. *)

kisaMCN musawRajN c
kisaMCN musawRajN A [garment of the kind called] ksMC made into a sAj: (A:) or, made round (O, K, TA) and wide, or ample: (TA:) and also applied to signify such as is made square, or four-sided. (TA.)

saAHN c
saAHN [originally sawaHN]: see what follows.

saAHapN c
saAHapN [originally sawaHapN] The court, or open area, of a house; i. e. a spacious vacant part or portion thereof, in which is no building; (Msb voce EaroSapN;) a part of a house in which is no building nor roof: (Har p. 33:) its baAHap: (S:) or its yard; i. e. a spacious place in front of a house: (Msb in the present art.:) or a wide, or spacious, place, among the dwellings of a tribe: and a side, region, quarter, or tract; or a lateral, or an outward or adjacent, part or portion; syn. naAHiyapN: (K:) the pl. is saAHN↓ [or rather this is a coll. gen. n. of which sAHp is the n. un.] and [the pl. is] saAHaAtN (S, Msb, K) and suwHN; (S, K;) the last like budonN pl. of badanapN, and xuXobN pl. of xaXabapN: (S:) the dim. is suwayoHapN↓. (TA.) [See also 7 in art. syH.] One says, Eamara QllRehu saAHataka [May God people thy court, or yard; or make it to be well stocked with people and the like]. (A.) And in a case of drought you say, AiHomarRa QllRuwHu waQgubarRa QlsRuwHu [The air, or atmosphere, has become red, and the courts, or yards, have become very dusty]. (A.) You say also, UinRahu labariIoCu AlsRaAHapi, a phrase like UinRahu labariIoCu AlEacirapi [expl. in art. Ecr]. (TA in art. Ecr.)

suwayoHapN c
suwayoHapN dim. of saAHapN, q. v. (TA.)

1 saAxato qawaAYimuhu c
1. saAxato qawaAYimuhu, (S, Msb, K,) or qawaAYimu AldRaAbRapi, (A,) fiI AlOaroDi, (S, Msb,) or biAlOaroDi, (A,) aor. tasuwxu, (S, A, Msb,) inf. n. sawoxN (L, Msb) and suWuwxN and sawaxaAnN, (L,) His legs, or the legs of the beast, sank into the ground: (Msb, * TA:) or sank, and became concealed, in the ground or earth: (S, Msb, * TA:) and so saAxato, aor. tasiyxu, (S, Msb, TA,) inf. n. sayoxN (Msb) [and sayaxaAnN: see art. syx]: and in like manner one says of the feet: (A, TA:) like vaAxato. (S, K.) ― -b2- And saAxa, (L, K,) aor. yasuwxu, (L,) It (a thing) sank [in water &c.], or subsided; syn. rasaba. (L, K.) ― -b3- And saAxato bihimu AlOaroDu, (A, L, Msb, K,) aor. tasuwxu, (L, Msb,) inf. n. sawoxN (L, Msb, K) and suWuwxN and sawaxaAnN, (L, K,) The ground, or earth, sank with them; or sank with them and swallowed them up or enclosed them; syn. Ainoxasafato, (L, K,) or xasafato: and so saAxato, aor. tasiyxu, inf. n. sayoxN. (Msb.)

4 AsAxhu c
4. AsAxhu He (God) made him, or it, to sink into, or to sink and become concealed in, the ground or earth. (Msb.)

5 tswRx c
5. tswRx He fell into a place rendered very slimy by rain; (L, K;) or into mud rendered very watery by rain; as also tzwRx. (L.)

SaArati AlOaroDu suwaAxFA c
SaArati AlOaroDu suwaAxFA (L, K) and suwRaAxFA↓ (L) and suwRaAxaI↓, (L, K,) or sawaAxaI↓, of the measure faEaAlaI, (S,) said in the K to be a mistake, but the S is not the only lexicon in which it is thus written, (TA,) The earth became very slimy by reason of rain. (S, L, K.)

sawaAxaI c
sawaAxaI: see the next preceding paragraph.

fiyhi sawaAxiyapN c
fiyhi sawaAxiyapN In it is much mud. (K.)

SaArati AlOaroDu suwRaAxFA c
SaArati AlOaroDu suwRaAxFA i. q. suwaAxFA, q. v. (L.)

suwRaAxaI c
suwRaAxaI Mud rendered very watery by rain. (L.) See SaArati AlOaroDu suwaAxFA, above. ― -b2- Also, and masowaxapN↓, Tumid earth that breaks in pieces when trodden upon. (L voce raxRaMCu.) ― -b3- baToHaMCu suwRaAxaI [A wide water-course, or channel of a torrent, containing fine, or minute, or broken, pebbles, &c.,] into which the feet sink, or in which the feet sink and become concealed. (L.)

suwayowixapN c
suwayowixapN dim. of suwRaAxaI. (L, K.)

masowaxapN c
masowaxapN: see suwRaAxaI.

1 saAda c
1. saAda, aor. yasuwdu, inf. n. siyaAdapN (Msb, TA) and suwdN and suwdadN [and its vars. mentioned in the next sentence] and sayoduwdapN, (TA,) or suwdadN is a simple subst. signifying as expl. below, (Msb,) He was, or became, [a sayRid, i. e. chief, lord, master, &c.; or] possessed of glory, honour, dignity, eminence, exalted or elevated state, or nobility. (Msb, TA.) ― -b2- [It is also trans.:] you say, saAda qawomahu, (S, M, * A,) aor. yasuwduhumo, (S, A,) inf. n. siyaAdapN (S, M, K *) and suwdN (M, K *) and suwdadN, (S, M, A, K *) in which last the [final] d is added to render the word quasi-coordinate to words of the measure fuEolalN, as junodabN and buroqaEN, (S,) and suwdudN and suWodadN (M, TA *) and suWodudN, (M, K, *) of the dial. of Teiyi, (M,) and sayoduwdapN, (S, M,) He was, or became, the sayRid [or chief, lord, master, &c.,] of his people; (S;) [he ruled his people, or held dominion over them;] and AisotaAdahumo↓ signifies the same. (M, L.) And saAdahu, inf. n. siyaAdapN and siyaAdN and suwdadN [&c.], He exercised rule, or dominion, over him. (MA.) [See also suwdadN below.] ― -b3- [Hence,] saAdato naAqatiI AlmaTaAyaA (tropical:) My she-camel left behind the [other] camels or beasts. (A, TA.) ― -b4- saAwadaniI fasudotuhu: see 3. ＝ -A2- sawida and saAda as syn. with AisowadRa: see this last, in three places. ＝ -A3- saAdahu as syn. with saAwadahu: see this latter. ＝ -A4- saAda, aor. yasuwdu, also signifies He drank water such as is termed masowadap, which occasions a disease termed suwaAdi. (M, K.) ― -b2- And siyda, (M,) or suYida, like EuniIa, (K,) He was, or became, affected with AlsRuwaAd. (M, K. [In the former, the context indicates that this means here a disease that attacks the liver from eating dates: in the latter, that it here means a disease incident to sheep or goats.])

2 swRdhu qawomuhu c
2. swRdhu qawomuhu, [inf. n. tasowiydN,] His people made him a sayRid [i. e. chief, lord, &c.; generally meaning over them]. (S, M, * A.) It is said in a trad. of 'Omar, tafaqRahuwA qabola Oano tusawRaduwA, (M,) or tasawRaduwA↓ [for tatasawRaduwA], (O,) meaning Learn ye knowledge, or science, before ye be [made] chiefs, looked at; for if ye learn not before that, ye will be ashamed to learn after becoming advanced in age, or attaining to full growth, (baEoda Alkibari,) and so will remain ignorant, taking it [i. e. knowledge] from the younger ones, and that will lower your estima-
tion: (M:) or the meaning is, before ye be married, and become masters of houses, or tents, and be diverted by the marriage-state from [the acquisition of] knowledge, or science. (Sh, O.) [See also 5.] ― -b2- swRd also signifies He slew: (Az, TA:) or [the inf. n.] tasowiydN signifies the slaying of saAdap [i. e. chiefs, lords, &c., pl. of sayRidN]. (K.) ― -b3- [And accord. to the K, tasowiydN is also syn. with juroOapN The being bold, daring, brave, or courageous: but accord. to the O, sawRada signifies xariYa He voided his excrement, or ordure; as though from what next follows: which of these two explanations is right (for it seems improbable that both are right) I find no ex. to indicate.] ＝ -A2- sawRadotuhu, (S, M, * TA,) or swRdth biAlsRawaAdi, inf. n. tasowiydN, (Msb,) I blackened it; made it, or rendered it, Oasowad [i. e. black]; (S, * M, Msb; *) I changed its bayaAD [or whiteness] to sawaAd [or blackness]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, swRd wajohahu lit. He, or it, blackened his face: meaning (assumed tropical:) rendered his face expressive of sorrow, or displeasure; or grieved, or displeased, him: and also, disgraced him: see the contr. bayRaDa: and see also 9. ― -b3- Hence also swRd meaning He wrote anything in a rough manner, as one writes the first draught, or original copy, of a book or the like; contr. of bayRaDa in this sense also: probably post-classical.] ― -b4- And sRwd AlUibila, (S, M, O,) inf. n. tasowiydN, (S, K,) (assumed tropical:) He beat, or pounded, old worn-out hair-cloth, and applied it as a remedy to the galls, or sores, on the backs of the camels. (Fr, A'Obeyd, S, M, O, K. *) ― -b5- And sawRiduwA Dayofakumo (assumed tropical:) Feed ye your guest with something to allay the craving of his stomach before the morning-meal (AlgadaMC). (ElUmawee, TA in art. lhj.)

3 saAowada
3: saAwadaniI fasudotuhu↓ (S, A, K, * &c.) He vied with me, or contended with me for superiority, in the rank, or quality, or qualities, of a sayRid [or chief, lord, &c.], and I overcame, or surpassed, him therein: (S, A, L, K: *) ＝ -A2- and also He vied with me in blackness, and I surpassed him therein. (S, L, K. *) ― -b2- And sAwdhu, inf. n. siwaAdN, He met him in the blackness of the night. (M, L.) ― -b3- And saAwadotuhu, (S, A, O,) inf. n. siwaAdN (S, O, K *) and musaAwadapN, (S,) (tropical:) I spoke secretly with him; (S, A, O, K; *) because you bring near your sawaAd [or person] to his [when you so speak with another]; or [because] originally meaning I brought near my sawaAd, i. e. person, to his: (S:) or sAwdhu, inf. n. siwaAdN, signifies he spoke secretly with him, and so brought near his sawaAd to his [the other's]; as also saAdahu↓, inf. n. sawodN. (M.) It was said to the daughter of El-Khuss, Wherefore didst thou commit fornication? (S, O, L,) or What caused thee to commit fornication? or Wherefore didst thou become pregnant? (M, L,) thou being the mistress of thy people? (S, O, L:) and she answered, qurobu AlwisaAdi waTuwlu AlsRiwaAdi, (S, M, O, L, [in my two copies of the S quroba and Tuwla, as though a verb were understood,]) i. e. [The nearness of the pillow, and the long continuance of] secret speaking with another: (Lh, M, L:) or, as some say, AlswAd here means the enticing to jimaAE: or, as others say, AljamaAE itself [if the question put to her were the last mentioned above]. (M, L.) ― -b4- sAwdhu also signifies (assumed tropical:) He acted deceitfully, or guilefully, with him: (K:) or he endeavoured to turn him [to a thing] by blandishment, or by deceitful arts; or to entice him; as shown above. (TA.) ― -b5- And (assumed tropical:) He drove him away; namely, a lion. (O, K.) ― -b6- And sAwdt AlUibilu AlnRabaAta (assumed tropical:) The camels laboured at the herbage with their lips, and could not master it, because of its shortness (O, K) and its scantiness. (K.)

4 OasaAda c and Oasowada
4. OasaAda Oasowada He begat a boy that was a sayRid [or chief, lord, &c.]: (S, O, K:) or they signify, (O, K,) or signify also, (S,) he begat a black boy: (S, O, K:) or he had a black child born to him: (M:) and Aswdt she brought forth black children. (A.)

5 tswRd c
5. tswRd He became married: (K:) or he became married, and master of a house, or tent. (Sh, O.) See 2, second sentence.

8 Uisotawada
8: see 1. ― -b2- AstAdwA baniI fulaAnK They slew the sayRid [or chief, lord, &c.,] of the sons of such a one: (AZ, S, M, O, K:) or (so in the K, but in the S and O “ and in like manner ”) they took him captive: (S, O, K:) or they asked, or demanded, of him a woman in marriage. (IAar, S, M, O, K.) And AstAd Alqawoma, and fiI Alqawomi, and minohumo, He asked, or demanded, in marriage, a sayRidap [or woman of rank or quality], among the people: (M:) or AstAd fiI baniI fulaAnK, and minohumo, he married one of the chief, or noble, women of the sons of such a one. (IAar, O.) And AstAd He married among saAdap [or chiefs, lords, &c.]. (L.)

9 AswRd c
9. AswRd, (S, M, Msb, K,) inf. n. AisowidaAdN; (S, K;) and AswAdR↓, (S, M, K,) inf. n. AiswiydaAdN; (S, K;) and in poetry it is allowable to say AisowaOadRa↓, to avoid the concurrence of two quiescent letters; imperative [of ↓the second] AisowaAdido, and the last two letters in this may be incorporated together [so that you may say AisowaAdR]; (S;) said of a thing; (S, Msb;) and sawida↓, (S, M, Msb,) said of a man, (S, TA,) and of a thing, (TA,) aor. yasowadu; (Msb;) and saAda↓, (M,) first pers. sudotu, a form used by some; (S;) It, and he, became Oasowad [i. e. black]: (S, M, Msb, K:) and AswAdR↓ it, or he, became intensely so. (TA.) Nuseyb says,
falamo Oamoliko sawaAdiI wataHotahu sawidotu↓
qamiySN mina AlquwhiIRi biyDN banaAYiquho
[I am black, (for Nuseyb was a slave,) and am not master of my person; but beneath it, or within it, is a shirt like the cloth of Koohistán, the gores of which are white: by this qmyS he means his heart; AlqamiySu, or qamiySu Alqalobi, tropically meaning “ the pericardium; ” and, by a synecdoche, “ the heart itself, with its appertenances ”]. (S, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AswdR wajohuhu [lit. His face became black: meaning] (tropical:) his face became expressive of grief, or sorrow, or displeasure, occasioned by fear [&c.]: (Bd in iii. 102:) he became grieved, sorrowful, or displeased; and confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course, by reason of shame, or in consequence of a deed that he had done (Bd in xvi. 60) [&c.: and often meaning he became disgraced]: opposed to AiboyaDRa. (Bd in iii. 102.)

11 UisowaAodRa
11: see 9, in three places.

Q. Q. 4 AisowaOadRa c
Q. Q. 4. AisowaOadRa: see 9, first sentence.

sawodN c
sawodN A safoH (M, K, TA) of a mountain, (M, TA,) [app. meaning, in this case, a low tract at the base, or foot, of a mountain,] forming a narrow strip of ground, (M, TA,) rough and black, (M,) or level, abounding with black stones, (K, TA,) which are rough, and the predominant colour whereof is blackness; seldom found but at a mountain in which is a mine: so says Lth: or a piece of ground in which are black rough stones resembling dry human dung: (TA:) or land, or ground, in which blackness predominates, which is seldom anywhere but at a mountain in which is a mine: (Msb:) pl. OasowaAdN: (M, TA:) and sawodapN↓ signifies a portion thereof; (M, Msb, K, TA;) and the pl. of this is sawodaAtN, and the pl. of sawodaAtN is OasowaAdatN↓, which occurs in a trad. (TA.)

suwdN c
suwdN: see suwdadN.

sayodN c
sayodN a contraction of sayRidN, q. v.

siydN c
siydN: see art. syd

sawodapN c
sawodapN: see sawodN ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) Land in which are palm-trees: opposed to bayoDapN. (TA in art. byD. [See also AlsRawodaMC, voce Oasowadu, near the end.])

suwdadN c
