suwdadN a subst. from saAda, inf. n. siyaAdapN; signifying [The rank, station, or condition, or the quality or qualities, of a sayRid; i. e. chiefdom, lordship, mastery, &c.; or] glory, honour, dignity, (Msb,) or eminence, exalted or elevated state, or nobility: (M, Msb:) or this word, (S, M, K,) and its vars. suwdudN and suWodadN (M, TA) and suWodudN, (M, K,) of the dial. of Teiyi, (M,) and suwidN↓, (M, K,) are syn. with siyaAdapN (S, M, K) and sayoduwdapN as inf. ns. of saAda [q. v.]. (S, M.)

sawodaMCu c
sawodaMCu fem. of Oasowadu [q. v.]. (Msb.)

sawodaAnapN c
sawodaAnapN or suwdaAnapN: see suwdaAniyRapN.

siydaAnapN c
siydaAnapN: see siydN, in art. syd.

suwdaAniyRapN c
suwdaAniyRapN, (M, A, TA,) or sawodaAniyRapN, (Mgh, O,) and sawodaAnapN↓, (M, O,) or suwdaAnapN, with damm, like the first, (TA,) and sawaAdiyRapN↓ (A, K) and Oasowadu↓ (K) all signify the same; (TA;) A certain bird, that eats grapes: or i. q. EuSofuwrN [i. e. the sparrow; or a bird of the passerine kind]: (K:) or a certain small bird, (A, Mgh, O, TA,) having a long tail, (Mgh,) resembling the ESfwr, (TA,) sometimes (Mgh) called also AlEuSofuwru AlOasowadu↓, (Mgh, O,) of such a size that it may be grasped in the hand, that eats grapes (A, Mgh, O, TA) and dates (A, TA) and locusts. (Mgh, O, TA.)

sawaAdN c
sawaAdN Blackness; contr. of bayaADN; (M, Mgh;) a certain colour, (S, Msb,) well known. (Msb.) One says, laqiyahu fiI sawaAdi AllRayoli [He met him in the blackness of night]. (TA.) And AlXRaApu tamoXiI fiI sawaAdK wataOokulu fiI sawaAdK watanoZuru fiI sawaAdK [The sheep, or goat, walks in blackness, and eats in blackness, and looks in blackness]; meaning the blackness of its legs and of its mouth and of what is around its eyes. (Mgh, * Msb.) And UicaA kavura AlbayaADu qalRa AlsRawaAdu [When whiteness becomes much, blackness becomes little]; by whiteness meaning milk; and by blackness, dates. (TA.) ― -b2- Black clothing. (Mgh in art. byD. [See its contr. bayaADN.]) ― -b3- [Hence,] sawaAdu Alqalobi (S, M, A, K) and sawaAdatuhu↓ (M) and Oasowaduhu↓ and sawodaAWuhu↓ (S, M, K) and suwayodaAWuhu↓, (S, M, A, K,) the last a dim., (TA,) The heart's core; the black, or inner, part of the heart: or a black thing in the heart: or the black clot of blood that is within the heart [resembling a piece of liver (Zj in his “ Khalk el-Insán ”)]: or the heart's blood: i. q. HabRatuhu: (S, M, K, TA:) or, as some say, damuhu. (M, TA.) One says, AijoEalohumo fiI sawaAdi qalobika (A, TA) and suwayodaAYihi↓ (A) (tropical:) [Place them in the inmost part of thy heart; i. e. give them the best, or most intimate, place in thy affections]. (A, TA.) ― -b4- sawaAdu AlbaToni signifies The liver. (L, TA.) ― -b5- sawAdN is also syn. with XaxoSN (tropical:) [as meaning A person; and also, in a more general sense, a bodily, or corporeal, form or figure or substance]; (A'Obeyd, S, M, A, Msb, K;) of a man, and of other things; (Msb;) expressly said by A'Obeyd to be of any article of household goods or utensils and furniture and the like, and of other things: (M:) because appearing black when seen from a distance: (TA:) pl. OasowidapN and OasaAwidu, (S, M, A,) the latter a pl. pl. (S, M.) El-Asshà says,
tanaAhayotumu EanRaA waqado kaAna fiykumu
OasaAwidu SaroEaI lamo yuwasRado qatiyluhaA
[Ye refrained from retaliating upon us when there were among you prostrate persons the slain whereof had not been pillowed in graves]: by the AsAwd meaning the XuxuwS of the slain. (S.) And it is said in a trad., UicaA raOaI OaHadukumo sawaAdFA bilayolK falaA yakuno Oajobana AlsRawaAdayoni faUinRahu yaxaAfuka kamaA taxaAfuhu [When any one of you sees a bodily form, or a person, by night, let him not be the more cowardly of the two bodily forms, or persons; for he feareth thee, like as thou fearest him]: swAdA here meaning XaxoSFA. (L.) The saying laA yuzaAyilu sawaAdiI bayaADaka is expl. by As as meaning laA yuzAyilu XaxoSiI XaxoSaka [i. e. My person will not separate itself from thy person]: sawaAdN, with the Arabs, meaning XaxoSN, and in like manner bayaADN. (IAar, L.) [Hence, app.,] qaAla liIa AlXRarRu Oaqimo sawaAdaka [as though lit. signifying Evil said to me, Erect thy person]; meaning (assumed tropical:) be thou patient: a prov. (TA.) ― -b6- As its pl. OasaAwidu means the XuxuwS of the vessels of a house, [accord. to the statement of A'Obeyd cited above,] such as the miToharap and the UijRaAnap and the jafonap, these being called OasaAwidu AldRaAri, it is also used as meaning (assumed tropical:) Household goods or utensils or furniture and the like, absolutely. (Har p. 495.) [And in like manner] the sing. is also used as meaning (assumed tropical:) The travelling-apparatus and baggage and train (vaqal) of a commander: (S:) and (assumed tropical:) the tents and apparatus and beasts and other things, collectively, of an army. (TA.) ― -b7- Also, the sing., (assumed tropical:) Property, or cattle, &c.; syn. maAlN: (Aboo-Málik, TA:) or much thereof; (A'Obeyd, S, K;) as in the saying lifulaAnK sawaAdN [To such a one belongs much property, &c.]. (A'Obeyd, S.) ― -b8- Also (tropical:) A collection, company, or collective body, of men; (M, A, L;) as in the saying kavRarotu sawaAda Alqawomi bisawaAdiI (tropical:) [I increased the number of the collective body of the people, or party, by my person]: (A, TA:) and OFsowadaAtN↓ and OasaAwidu are used in the same sense; (M;) or [rather] as pls. of this meaning: (L, TA:) or all these as meaning (assumed tropical:) sundry, distinct or separate, sorts of men, or people: (M:) [but] sawaAdu Almusolimiyna means (assumed tropical:) the collective body of the Muslims: (Mgh, Msb:) and so AlsRawaAdu AlOaEoZamu, a tropical phrase [in which mina Almusolimiyna is understood]: (A:) or this means (tropical:) the great number of the Muslims agreed in obedience to the Imám. (TA.) (assumed tropical:) The commonalty, or generality, of men of people: (S, K:) (assumed tropical:) the bulk, or main part, of a people: (M, TA:) or (assumed tropical:) the greater number. (Msb.) And (assumed tropical:) A great number (S, Msb, K) of any kind. (S.) ― -b9- (assumed tropical:) A collection of palmtrees and of trees in general; on account of their greenness and blackness, because greenness nearly resembles blackness. (M, L.) ― -b10- And (tropical:) The rural district of any province; i. e. the district around the towns or villages, and the rasaAtiyq [i. e. districts of sown fields with towns or villages], of any province: (M, TA:) or the environs, consisting of towns, or villages, and of cultivated land, (A, TA,) [but more properly applied to the latter than to the former,] of a city, (A,) or of the chief city of a province: (TA:) or the towns, or villages, [but properly with the cultivated lands pertaining to them,] of a province of city: (K:) thus [particularly] of El-Koofeh and El-Basrah: (S, O:) hence, (A,) sawaAdu AlEiraAqi, (A, Mgh, O, Msb,) or [simply] AlsRawaAdu, (K,) the district of towns or villages, and cultivated lands, of El- 'Irák; (O, K; *) or the district between ElBasrah and El-Koofeh, with the towns, or villages, around them; (A;) or extending in length from Hadeethet El-Mowsil to 'Abbádán, and in breadth from El-'Odheyb to Holwán; (Mgh;) so called because of the xuDorap [which means both greenness and a colour approaching to blackness] of its trees and its seed-produce; (Mgh, Msb;) for that which is OaxoDar the Arabs term Oasowad because it appears to be thus at a distance. (Msb.)

suwaAdN c
suwaAdN Secret speech with another; as also siwaAdN: (M, K, TA:) each a subst. from saAwadahu, accord. to A'Obeyd: (M, TA:) but [ISd says,] in my opinion the latter is the inf. n. of saAwada, [and as such it has been mentioned above, (see 3,)] and the former is the simple subst., the two words being like muzaAHN and mizaAHN: (M:) As disallowed the former, but it is authorized by AO and others. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A certain disease incident to sheep or goats. (K.) ― -b2- And A certain disease incident to man; (K;) a pain that attacks the liver, in consequence of eating dates, and that sometimes, or often, kills. (M, TA.) ― -b3- And A yellowness in the complexion, and a greenness (xuDorap [app. here meaning a blackish hue inclining to greenness]) in the nail, (K, TA,) incident to people from [drinking] salt water. (TA.)

sayRidN c
sayRidN, (S, M, K, &c.,) of the measure faEiylN; [originally sawiydN, for a reason to be mentioned below; the kesreh upon the w, being deemed difficult of pronunciation, is suppressed, and the quiescent w and I thus coming thgether, the latter receives the rejected kesreh, and the w is changed into I and incorporated into the augmentative I; as in the case of jayRidN with those who hold it to be originally jawiydN;] or, accord. to the Basrees, it is of the measure fayoEilN; [originally sayowidN;] (S;) and also sayodN↓; (Mz, 40th nwE, section on the class of hayRinN and hayonN;) A chief, lord, or master: (M, L, Mgh, Msb: [accord. to the last of which, this is a secondary signification, as will be seen below:]) a prince, or king: (Fr, L:) one who is set before, or over, others: a master of a household: (L:) a woman's husband: (Fr, M, Msb:) a possessor, an owner, or a proprietor: (L, Msb:) a slave's master, or owner: (Fr, M, Msb:) a superior in rank or station or condition; one possessing pre-eminence or excel-lence; a man of rank or quality; a personage; a man of distinction: (L:) one who surpasses others in intelligence and property, and in repelling injury, and in beneficence, or usefulness, who makes a just use of his property, and aids others by himself: (ISh, L:) one possessed of glory, honour, dignity, eminence, exalted or elevated state, or nobility; (L, Msb; [accord. to the latter of which, this is the primary signification;]) generous, noble, or high-born: (L:) the most generous, noble, or high-born, of a people: (Msb:) a liberal, bountiful, or munificent, person: (Fr, L:) clement; forbearing; one who endures injurious treatment from his people: (L:) devout, abstaining from unlawful things, and clement, or forbearing: (Katádeh, L:) one who is not overcome by his anger: ('Ikrimeh, L:) accord. to As, the Arabs say that it signifies any one who is subdued, or repressed, by his principle of clemency, or forbearance: (L:) and saAYidN↓ signifies the same as sayRidN: or one inferior to a sayRid: (K:) or, accord. to Fr, one says, hecaA sayRidu qawomihi Alyawoma [this is the lord, &c., of his people today]; but if you announce that he will be their syRd after a little while, you say huwa saAYidu qawomihi Eano qaliylK, and sayRidu: (S:) the fem. of sayRidN [and of saAYidN↓] is with p: (M, L, Msb:) pl. of sayRidN, (S, Msb,) or of saAYidN↓, (M, K,) saAdapN (S, M, Msb, K) and sayaAYidu (S, K) and [pl. of saAdapN] saAdaAtN: (Msb:) [J says that] saAdapN is of the measure faEalapN, [orinally sawadapN,] because sayRidN is of the measure faEiylN; [as has been before mentioned;] and it is like saraApN as pl. of sariIRN, the only other instance
of the kind; this being shown to be the case by the fact that sayRidN has also as a pl. sayaAYidu, with C, [and with the w changed into I because it is so changed in the sing.,] like as OafiylN has OafaAYilu, and like as tabiyEN has tabaAYiEu; but the Basrees, who hold sayRidN to be of the measure fayoEilN, say that it becomes of the measure faEalapN in the pl. as though it were saAYidN, like qaAYidN, which has qaAdapN as a pl., and like caAYidN, which has caAdapN as a pl.; and they also say that sayaAYidu, with C, as pl. of sayRidN, is contr. to analogy; for by rule it should be without C. (S.) ― -b2- [In the present day it is also particularly applied to signify, like Xariyf, Any descendant of the Prophet.] ― -b3- One of the poets has used it in relation to the jinn, or genii; saying,
yanodubona sayRidahunRapo
jinRN hababona bilayolK
[Genii that were roused from their sleep by night, summoning, or perhaps bewailing and eulogizing their chief]: Akh says that this is a well-known verse of the poetry of the Arabs: but it is asserted by one, or more, likewise deserving of reliance, that it is of the poetry of El-Weleed [and therefore post-classical]. (M.) ― -b4- And the wild ass is called (assumed tropical:) the sayRid of his female. (TA.) ― -b5- Also, (Ks, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) and siyRadN↓, (K,) the latter on the authority of Aboo-'Alee, (TA,) applied to a he-goat, (assumed tropical:) Advanced in years: (Ks, S, M; Mgh, Msb, K:) or in its third year: (Mgh:) or great, though not advanced in years: (TA:) or it is of general application, for it occurs in a trad. applied to the camel and the ox-kind. (M, TA.) ― -b6- And the former also signifies (assumed tropical:) What is most eminent, exalted, or noble, of any things: and is applied by Zj to the Kur-án, because, he says, it is sayRidu AlkalaAmi (assumed tropical:) [The paragon of speech]. (M.)

siyRadN c
siyRadN: see the last sentence but one above.

suwayodN c
suwayodN the abbreviated dim. of Oasowadu: (S, Mgh, Msb:) see the latter. ― -b2- Also [as a subst., or an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates,] Water; (M, Mgh, L;) as also Oasowadu↓: (M: [but see AlOasowadaAni, voce Oasowadu:]) the former is [said to be] used in this sense in negative phrases only: (M, L:) one says, maAsaqaAhumo mino suwayodK qaTorapF He gave them not to drink a drop of water. (M, Mgh, * L.) ― -b3- OumRu suwayodK means The anus; syn. AlAisotu; (K;) [and] so AlsRuwayodaMCu↓. (M.)

sawaAdapu Alqalobi c
sawaAdapu Alqalobi: see sawaAdN, near the beginning of the paragraph.

suwaAdiIRN c
suwaAdiIRN [or perhaps sawaAdiIRN, i. e. “ belonging to the Sawád of El-'Irák, ”] i. q. sihoriyzN (M) A wellknown sort of dates, (K voce shryz,) found in abundance at El-Basrah. (TA ibid.)

sawaAdiyRapN c
sawaAdiyRapN: see suwdaAniyRapN.

suwayodaMCu c
suwayodaMCu dim. of suwodaMCu, fem. of Oasowadu, q. v.: (Mgh:) ― -b2- see also sawaAdN, in two places: ― -b3- and suwayodN: ― -b4- and Oasowadu, near the end of the paragraph. ― -b5- Also A certain bird. (M.) ― -b6- And Salt tracts (sibaAx) of [plants of the kind called] najiyl: Kr explains it by nibotapN [app. a mistranscription for nabotapN a plant]; without describing it. (M.)

saAYidN c
saAYidN: see sayRidN, in the middle of the paragraph, in three places.

Oasowadu c
Oasowadu Greater, and greatest, in respect of estimation, rank, or dignity; syn. OajalRu: (S, K:) and, as some say, more [and most] liberal or bountiful or munificent: or more [and most] clement or forbearing. (TA.) One says, huwa Oasowadu mino fulaAnK He is greater &c. (OajalRu) than such a one. (S.) And AlOasowadu mina Alqawomi means The greatest &c. (AlOajalRu) of the people, or party. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also Black; i. e. having sawaAd, (M, * Mgh,) which is the contr. of bayaAD: (M, Mgh:) and OasowadiIRN↓ signifies the same as Oasowadu: (Ham p. 379:) [or has an intensive signification, like OaHomarIRN:] the fem. of Oasowadu is sawodaMCu: (Mgh, Msb:) the dim. of Oasowadu is OusayRidu↓, (S, Msb,) and it is allowable to say Ousayowidu↓, [as is shown by an ex. voce OasakRu,] meaning [a little black thing; or blackish, or] approaching to black; (S;) and the abbreviated dim. is suwayodN↓: (S, Mgh, Msb:) the dim. of sawodaMCu is suwayodaMCu↓: (Mgh:) the pl. of Oasowadu (M, Msb) and of sawodaMCu (Msb) is suwdN (M, Msb) and suwdaAnN [which latter is especially applied to human beings]. (M.) AlsRuwdaAnu is said in the R to denote [The negroes;] that particular people, or race, who are the most stinking of mankind in the armpits and sweat, and the more so those who are eunuchs. (TA.) [It (i. e. AlswdAn) is also sometimes used for OaroDu AlsRuwdaAni, or bilaAdu AlsRuwdaAni, (The land, or the country, of the negroes,) or the like: it is thus used in the TA voce samogarapu.] And the epithet Oasowadu is also applied by the Arabs to a thing that is OaxoDar [i. e. green]; because it appears to be thus at a distance. (Msb. [See OaxoDaru: and see HadiyqapN dahomaMCu and mudohaAmRapN, voce Oadohamu.]) ― -b2- [Hence,] Oasowadu Alqalobi and sawodaMWuhu: see sawaAdN. ― -b3- [And AlsRawodaMCu The black bile; one of the four humours of the body; of which the others are the yellow bile (AlSRaforaMCu), the blood (AldRamu), and the phlegm (Albalogamu).] ― -b4- Oasowadu as opposed to OaHomaru [and meaning The Arab race, and also, accord. to some, in this case also, the black]: see OaHomaru, in two places. ― -b5- As applied to a certain bird: see suwdaAniyRapN, in two places. ― -b6- Also, as a subst., (S,) or an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates, (Sh, M,) so that it is used as a subst., (Sh, TA,) but imperfectly decl., (TA,) (tropical:) A great serpent, (S, M, K,) in which is blackness: (S, M:) the worst and greatest and most noxious of serpents, than which there is none more daring, for sometimes it opposes itself to a company of travellers, and follows the voice, and it is that which seeks retaliation, and he who is bitten by it will not escape death: (Sh, TA:) it is pluralized as a subst., (Sh, S, M,) its pl. being OasaAwidu (S, M) and OasaAwiydu and OasowadaAtN↓: (M:) were it an epithet [used as such], its pl. would be suwdN: it is also called Oasowadu saAliHN, because it casts off its slough every year: you do not say Oasowadu saAlixK: (S:) the female is called OasowadapN↓, (S, M,) which is extr.; (M;) and to this the epithet saAlixapN is not applied. (S.) ― -b7- AlOasowadaAni means (assumed tropical:) The serpent and the scorpion; (Sh, Mgh, Msb, K;) which are to be killed during prayer: (Sh, Mgh, Msb:) so called by the attribution of predominance [to the former]. (Sh, TA.) ― -b8- And (tropical:) Dates and water; (El-Ahmar, As, S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) both together being thus called by a term which properly applies to one only, [accord. to some,] for [they say that] AlOasowadu alone signifies dates, not water, and especially, or mostly, the dates of El-Medeeneh; and in like manner, Aboo-Bekr and 'Omar together are called AlEumaraAni; and the sun and the moon together, AlqamaraAni: (TA:) or, as some say, it means water and milk; and is applied by a rájiz to water and the herb called AlfavR, of [the grain of] which bread is made, and is eaten [in time of dearth or drought]. (M, L.) See also suwayodN. ― -b9- Also (assumed tropical:) The HarRap [or tract strewn with black and crumbling stones] and night: (S, M, L:) so called because of their blackness. (M, L.) A party came as guests to Muzebbid El-Medenee, and he said to them, “ There is nothing for you with us but the OasowadaAni: ” and they replied, “ Verily therein is a sufficiency: dates and water: ” but he said, “ I meant not that: I only meant the HarRap and the night. ” (S, M.) And as to the saying of 'Áïsheh, that she was with the Prophet when they had no food, but only the OasowadaAni, which is expl. by the lexicologists as meaning dates and water, [and thus by Mtr in the Mgh, ISd says,] in my opinion she only meant the HarRap and night. (M.) ― -b10- huwa Oasowadu Alkabidi [lit. He is black-livered] means (tropical:) he is an enemy: (A, TA:) and suwdu AlOakobaAdi means (tropical:) enemies. (M, A.) ― -b11- You say also, jaMCa fulaAnN biganamihi suwda AlbuTuwni, and, in like manner, Humora AlkulaI, both meaning (tropical:) Such a one brought his sheep, or goats, in a lean, or an emaciated, state. (As, S, and A in art. Hmr.) ― -b12- And ramaI bisahomihi AlOasowadi (tropical:) He shot with his lucky arrow, (A, K,) that was smeared with blood, (A,) by means of which he looked for good fortune, (K, TA,) because he had shot with it and hit the object shot at, (TA,) or as though it were black (K, TA) with blood, (TA,) or by its having been much handled. (K, TA.) ― -b13- And kalRamotuhu famaA radRa EalaIRa sawodaMCa walaA bayoDaMCa (tropical:) I spoke to him, and he did not return to me a bad word nor a good one: (S, L:) or a single word. (A.) ― -b14- waToOapN sawodaMCu means (assumed tropical:) A footstep, or footprint, that is becoming effaced: a recent one is termed HamoraMCu. (S.) ― -b15- AlsRawodaMCu (assumed tropical:) Cultivated, or planted, land; opposed to AlbayoDaMCu [q. v.]. (TA in art. byD [See also sawodapN.]) ― -b16- [But sanapN sawodaMCu means (assumed tropical:) A very severe year; more severe than such as is termed HamoraMCu; which is more severe than the bayoDMC, and still more so than the XahobaMC: see arts. Xhb and Hmr.] ― -b17- AlHabRapu AlsRawodaMCu, said in a
trad. to be a remedy for every disease except death, (TA,) i. q. AlXRuwniyzu [q. v.], (K,) as also AlsRuwayodaMCu↓, (TA,) [i. e.] this latter signifies HabRapu AlXRuwniyzi, (M,) or properly AlXRiyniyz, for thus the Arabs called it accord. to IAar: or, as some say, i. q. AlHabRapu AlxaDoraMCu [q. v. in art. Hb], because the Arabs [often] call black OaxoDar, and green Oasowad. (TA.) ＝ -A3- It is also used as an epithet denoting excess; but as such is anomalous, being formed from a verb whence the simple epithet is of the measure OafoEalu: so in the saying, Oasowadu mino Halaki AlguraAbi [Blacker than the blackness, or intense blackness, of the crow, or raven: see HalakN]. (I'Ak p. 237. [See also its contr. OaboyaDu, voce bayaADN; and see Har p. 286.])

OasowadapN c
OasowadapN fem. of Oasowadu, q. v., used as a subst. (S, M.)

OasowadaAtN c
OasowadaAtN: see sawodN: ― -b2- and sawaAdN: ― -b3- and Oasowadu.

OasowadiIRN c
OasowadiIRN: see Oasowadu, fourth sentence.

OusayodiIRN c
OusayodiIRN, rel. n. of OusayRidu with the movent I rejected, Of, or relating to, [a blackish colour, or] a colour approaching to black. (S.)

OusayRidu c
OusayRidu and Ousayowidu: see OFsowadu, fourth sentence.

misaAdN c
misaAdN, A skin for clarified butter, or for honey. (TA in this art. [See also art. msd; and see misoOadN, in art sOd.])

masuwdN c
masuwdN One over whom rule, or dominion, is exercised; or of whom another is sayRid [or chief, lord, master, &c.]. (TA.)

musowidN c
musowidN [act. part. n. of Oasowada, q. v.:] with p, i. e. musowidapN, A woman who brings forth black children: the contr. is termed muboyiDapN, (Fr, K in art. byD,) or, more commonly, muwDiHapN. (O and TA in that art.)

maMCN masowadapN c
maMCN masowadapN Water that is a cause of [the disease called] suwaAd (M, K, TA) to such as drink it. (TA.)

ZRlRa wajohuhu musowadRFA c
ZRlRa wajohuhu musowadRFA, in the Kur [xvi. 60 and xliii. 16], means (assumed tropical:) [His face becomes, or continues, or continues all the day,] expressive of sorrow, or displeasure. (Mgh. [See the verb, 9.]) And OayRaAmN musowadRapN means (assumed tropical:) [Days of] evil state or condition, and hardness, or difficulty, of living. (Har p. 304.) ― -b2- [musowadRapN The first draught, or original copy, of a book, or the like: (not called musawRadapN:) opposed to muboyaDRapN, q. v.: probably postclassical.]

musawRadN c
musawRadN Guts (muSoraAn) containing blood drawn by venesection from a she-camel, bound at the head, roasted and eaten. (IAar and K as expl. by MF.)

AlmusawRidapu c
AlmusawRidapu The partisans of the dynasty of the 'Abbásees; [so called because they made their clothes black;] opposed to the mubayRiDap. (S and K in art. byD.)

masoWuwdN c
masoWuwdN part. n. of suYidu. (K. [See 1, last signification.])

1 saAra c
1. saAra, aor. yasuwru, (S, M, K,) inf. suWuwrN, (S,) or saworN, (M,) or both, (K,) or saworapN, (Mgh,) [but this last is an inf. n. of un.,] He leaped or sprang, (S, M, A, Mgh, K,) Uilayohi to, or towards, him, (S, M, K,) and Ealayohi upon him. (A.) ― -b2- He leaped, or sprang, [or committed an assault, upon another,] like as he does who behaves in an annoying manner towards his cup-companion in his intoxication. (TA. [See also 3.]) ― -b3- [Hence,] saAra AlXRaraAbu fiI raOosihi, (S, M, A, K,) inf. n. saworN and suWuwrN (M, K) and suwuwrN, agreeably with the root, (M,) and suwaArN, (TA,) (tropical:) [The wine assaulted, or rushed into, his head]: (A:) [or] the wine circulated in his head, and rose into it: (M, K:) or saAra AlXRaraAbu, inf. n. saworN and saworapN, the wine had an overpowering influence upon the head: (Msb:) and saArato fiyhi HumayRaA AlkaOosi the force or overpowering influence, (saworap,) [or fumes,] of the cup of wine mounted, or rose, to his head, or into his head. (TA in art. HmI.) ― -b4- And sAr, aor. as above, (assumed tropical:) He was angry. (Msb.) ― -b5- sAr, aor. as above, inf. n. saworN, also signifies He (a man) rose, or became elevated. (M.)
surotu Uilayohi fiI OaEaAliI AlsRuwri
means I rose to him [upon the upper, or uppermost, parts of the wall of the city or town &c.]. (TA.) ― -b6- And one says to a man, surosuro [Rise thou, rise thou, to eminence,] in enjoining aspiration to the means of acquiring eminence, or nobility: (IAar, K, * TA:) from surotu AlHaAYiTa, meaning I ascended, or mounted, upon the wall. (TA.) ― -b7- See also 5, in two places. ＝ -A2- suwrabihi: see 2 in art. syr.

2 sawRara
2: [swRr, inf. n. tasowiyrN, He walled a city or town &c. (See 2 in art. xfr.)] ― -b2- See also 5. ＝ -A2- And sawRarotuhu, [inf. n. as above, (see an ex. voce dahoqana,)] I put upon him [or decked him with] the siwaAr [or bracelets; or I decked him with bracelets]. (S.)

3 musaAwarapN c
3. musaAwarapN signifies The leaping, or springing, of two antagonists, each upon the other, or their assaulting, or assailing, each other, in mutual fight. (Har p. 329.) ― -b2- And sAwrhu, (S, M, K,) inf. n. musaAwarapN and siwaArN, (M, K,) He leaped, or sprang, upon him; he assaulted, or assailed, him; syn. waAvabahu. (S, M, K.) You say, AlHayRapu tusaAwiru AlrRaAkiba [The serpent springs upon, or assaults, the rider]. (A.) And it is said in a trad. of 'Omar, fakidotu OusaAwiruhu fiI AlSRalaApi, meaning And I was near to leaping upon him, or assaulting him, and fighting him, during prayer. (TA.) [See also 1.] You say also, saAwaratoniI Alhumuwmu (tropical:) [Anxieties assaulted, or assailed, me]. (A.) ― -b3- Also i. q. Oaxaca biraOosihi [which, as it is mentioned immediately after sawRaArN in the last of the senses assigned to that word below, is app. said of speech, or language, meaning (assumed tropical:) It had an overpowering influence upon his head]. (M, K.)

5 tswRrhu c
5. tswRrhu He ascended, or mounted, upon it; (namely, a wall;) as also saArahu↓, inf. n. saworN: (TA:) he climbed, ascended, or scaled, it, (namely, a wall,) like a thief; (IAar, S, * M, A, * K, * TA;) as also tswRr Ealayohi; (M;) and saArahu↓, inf. n. as above: (K:) and he climbed, or ascended, and took, it; as also tswRr Elyh, and swRrhu↓: (TA: [this last from a trad., in which, however, the verb is, in my opinion, probably mistranscribed:]) he climbed, or ascended, its suwr [or wall]. (Bd in xxxviii. 20.) ＝ -A2- And tswRr He put on himself [or decked himself with] the siwaAr [or bracelet; or he decked himself with bracelets]. (S.)

6 tasAwurN c
6. tasAwurN signifies The leaping, or springing, one with [or upon] another. (KL. [See also 3.]) ― -b2- And tasaAwarotu lahaA means rafaEotu lahaA XaxoSiI [I raised, or elevated, my person to her, or it, or them; or stretched myself up &c.; like taTaAwalotu]. (TA.)

8 AisotaAra c
8. AisotaAra: see AisotaraI in art. srw, from which it is formed by transposition.

suwrN c
suwrN The wall of a city [or town &c.]: (S, M, A, Msb, K:) [properly] masc.; but Ibn-Jurmooz, in a verse, makes it fem., because it is a part of the madiynap: (M:) pl. OasowaArN (S, M, Msb, K) and siyraAnN. (S, K.) ― -b2- And The upper, or uppermost, part of the head; occurring in a trad., as some relate it; or, accord. to others, it is suwrap↓; or XuWuwn, which is said by some of the later authors to be the reading commonly known. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also suwrapN, in three places. ＝ -A3- And see siwaArN. ＝ -A4- Also An entertainment of a guest or guests; (K;) a repast to which people are invited: (Abu-l-'Abbás, TA:) a Pers. word, honoured by the Prophet; (K;) i. e. by his saying to his companions, as is related in a trad., quwmuwA faqado SanaEa jaAbirN suwrFA [Arise ye, for Jábir has made an entertainment, or a repast]. Abu-l-'Abbás, TA.) ＝ -A5- [It is also the name of A species of fig, called by Forskål (Flora Aegypt. Arab., pp. cxxiv. and 180,) ficus sur, (not “ mimosa sur, ” as in Freytag's Lex.,) observed by him at Jubleh, in El-Yemen.]

saworapN c
saworapN A leap, or spring. (TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) The assault of wine upon the head; or its rush into the head: and in like manner, the assault, or rush, of venom, such as that of the scorpion: (S:) or the force, or strength, of wine &c.; (M, K, Msb, and MF voce HadRN;) as also suwaArN↓; (M, K;) and in like manner, of hunger: (Msb:) the overpowering influence of wine upon the head: (Msb:) or suwaArN↓ signifies the creeping of wine in the head: and saworapN is said to signify the assault, or force, or intoxicating operation, or overpowering influence upon the head, (HumayRaA,) produced by the creeping of wine, in, or through, the drinker: and in like manner, faraHK suwaAru↓ means (assumed tropical:) a motion of joy like the creeping of wine in the head. (TA.) ― -b3- [(assumed tropical:) A paroxysm of fever. ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) An ebullition, a fierceness, or an impetuousness, of anger; as when] one says UinRa ligaDabihi lasaworapF (assumed tropical:) [Verily his anger has an ebullition, a fierceness, or an impetuousness]: (S:) [(tropical:) an outburst, or outbreak, of anger: and] (assumed tropical:) anger itself: [or (assumed tropical:) a
fit of anger, or irritation:] pl. saworaAtN. (Msb.) ― -b5- [(assumed tropical:) The flush, or impetuosity, of youth: see HumayRaA.] ― -b6- Impetuousness in war. (A.) [It is said in the TA that fulaAnN cuwsaworapK fiI AlHarobi means cuw naZarK XadiydK, i. e. Such a one has strong inspection in war: but I think that naZarK is here a mistranscription for saTowK, i. e. impetuousness.] ― -b7- Violence, force, or oppression, and tyranny, of a Sultán: (S, K:) and might, or valour, (Msb, TA,) of a Sultán. (TA.) ― -b8- (assumed tropical:) Vehemence, or intenseness, of cold: (K:) or vehement, or intense, cold. (M.) You say, Oaxacatohu AlsRaworapu (assumed tropical:) Intense cold seized him. (TA.) ― -b9- See also suwrapN.

suwrapN c
suwrapN (tropical:) Eminence, or nobility: (S, A, K:) rank or station: (S, M, A, K:) or high, or exalted, rank or station: (Ibn-Es-Seed:) excellence: (A:) pl. suwarN and suwrN↓: [the latter of which is an anomalous pl.; or a coll. gen. n. of which suwrapN is the n. of un., as in another sense mentioned below:] (M:) and suwrapN, (M,) or saworapN↓, (K,) a mark, or sign, of glory, honour, dignity, or nobility; and height thereof. (M, K.) You say, lahu suwrapN fiI Almajodi (tropical:) He has eminence in glory. (A.) And lahu suwrapN Ealayoka (tropical:) He has superiority, and rank or station, over, or above, thee; he is of higher rank or dignity than thou. (A.) And suwaru AlUibili, (M,) [in the A suwarN mina AlUibili,] or suworu↓ AlUibili, (K,) means (assumed tropical:) The excellent ones of camels: (M, K:) sing. suwrapN, which, accord. to some, signifies hardy and strong. (M.) ― -b2- suwrapN also signifies What is goodly and tall, of structures. (M, K.) ― -b3- And The extremity (HadR) of anything. (IAar, TA.) ― -b4- See also suwrN. ― -b5- Also A row of stones or bricks of a wall: (L, K: in the L, EaraqN mino OaEoraAqi AlHaAYiTi: in the K, EaraqN mn Euruwqi AlHAYT, or, as in the CK, EiroqN Alx:) any degree (manozilap) of a structure: (S:) pl. suwrN↓, (S, K,) [or this is a coll. gen. n.,] like as busorN is of busorapN, (S,) and suwarN. (K.) ― -b6- Hence its application in relation to the Kur-án, [to signify A chapter thereof,] because each of what are thus called forms one degree, or step, (S, M, * K,) distinct from another, (S, K,) or [leading] to another: (M:) or from the same word signifying “ eminence: ” (IAar:) or as being likened to the wall of a city: (B:) some pronounce it with hemz; (see art. sOr;) but it is more common without: (TA:) pl. suwarN, (S, Msb,) and suwraAtN and suwaraAtN are also allowable. (S.) ― -b7- A sign, or token. (IAar, M, K.) You say, bayonahumaA suwrapN Between them two is a sign, or token. (IAar, M.)

suwaArN c
suwaArN: see saworapN, in three places: ＝ -A2- and see what here follows.

siwaArN c
siwaArN (S, M, Msb, K) and suwaArN↓ (M, Msb, K) and UisowaArN↓ (S, MF, and others) and OusowaArN↓ (M, K) A woman's bracelet, (S, * M, Msb, * K,) syn. qulobN, (M, K, [in the CK, erroneously, qalob,]) of silver or of gold; (Zj;) [and a man's bracelet also: see 2 and 5, and see also musawRarN:] all arabicized, from the Pers. dstwAr [dasotowaAro or dasotawaAro or dasotuwaAro]: (B, TA:) pl. [of pauc.] of siwaArN, (S, M, Msb,) and of suwaArN, (M,) OasowirapN, (S, M, Msb, K,) and (pl. pl., M) OasaAwiru, (S, M, K,) accord. to Aboo- 'Amr Ibn-El-'Alà pl. of UisowaArN, (S,) and OasaAwirapN, (S, Msb, K,) also pl. of UisowaArN or OusowaArN, (M, TA,) or of OasowarapN, or perhaps of OasaAwiru; (S;) and (pl. of mult., M) suwrN↓, (M, Msb, K,) originally suwurN, like kutubN pl. of kitaAbN, (Msb,) and suWuwrN, (K, [in a copy of the M suwurN,]) said by Sb to be used by poetic license. (M, TA.)

sawRaArN c
sawRaArN is an epithet applied to a dog [as meaning Wont to spring or leap or assault]. (A.) ― -b2- And it signifies The lion; (TS, K;) because of his leaping, or springing; (TA;) as also musaAwirN↓. (TS, TA.) ― -b3- Also One who is wont to leap or spring upon another, or to assault him; (S;) who behaves in an annoying manner towards his cupcompanion in his intoxication; (S, A, Mgh;) who assaults [or insults] his cup-companion when he drinks. (TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) One into whose head wine quickly rises: (M, K:) as though it were he himself that rose. (M.) ― -b5- And (assumed tropical:) Speech, or language, that has an overpowering influence upon the head (AlRaciI yaOoxucu biAlrRaOosi). (M, K.)

suwRaAraI c
suwRaAraI Height: so expl. by Th as used in the saying,
kamaA tuHibRu fraxahaA AlHubaAraI
OuHibRuhu jubRFA lahu suwRaAraI
[I love him with a love that has height (i. e. rising to a high degree), like as the bustard loves her young one]: meaning that the bustard is stupid, and, when she loves her young one, is excessive in stupidity. (M.)

OusowaArN c
OusowaArN: see the next paragraph: ＝ -A2- and see also siwaArN.

UisowaArN c
UisowaArN (S, M, Msb, K) and OusowaArN↓ (S, M, K) The leader of the Persians; (M, A, Msb, K;) like the Oamiyr among the Arabs: (Msb:) or their greatest king: arabicized [from the Pers. suwaAro]: (TA: [but said in the A to be tropical:]) or a horseman of the Persians, (A 'Obeyd, S, TA,) who fights: (A 'Obeyd, TA:) or one who is firm on the back of his horse: (K:) or one who excels in sitting firmly on the back of his horse: (M:) or (so in the M, but in the A and K “ and ”) one who is skilful in shooting arrows: (M, A, K:) pl. OFasaAwirapN (S, M, A, Msb, K) and OasaAwiru; (M, K;) in the former of which the p is to compensate for the I of the original form, which is OasaAwiyru. (S.) ― -b2- See also AlxaDaArimapu. ＝ -A2- And see siwaArN.

misowarN c
misowarN A leathern pillow, upon which one leans, or reclines; as also misowarapN↓: (M, K:) pl. masaAwiru. (TA.)

misowarapN c
misowarapN: see what next precedes.

musawRarN c
musawRarN [Decked with a bracelet or bracelets. And hence,] (tropical:) Made a king [or chief]. (A, TA. [See dahoqana.]) ― -b2- And The place of the bracelet; (M, K;) like as muxadRamN signifies the “ place of the xadamap. ” (M.)

musaAwirN c
musaAwirN: see sawRaArN.

1 saAsa AldRawaAbRa c
1. saAsa AldRawaAbRa, aor. yasuwsu, (A, Mgh,) inf. n. siyaAsapN, (TA,) He managed, or tended, the beasts, (qaAma EalayohaA,) and trained them. (Mgh, TA.) [And saAsa AlmaAla He managed, or tended, the camels or other property. See saAYisN.] ― -b2- Hence, (Mgh,) saAsa AlrRaEiyRapa, aor. and inf. n. as above, (S, A, * Mgh, K, &c.,) (tropical:) He ruled, or governed, the subjects; presided over their affairs as a commander, or governor, or the like; (S, * Mgh;) he commanded and forbade them. (A, K.) And saAsuwhumo, inf. n. sawosN, (tropical:) They were, or became, heads, chiefs, commanders, or the like, over them. (TA.) One says, fulaAnN mujarRabN qadosaAsa wasiysa Ealayohi (S, K) (tropical:) [Such a one is experienced: he has ruled and been ruled: or] he has commanded and been commanded: (S:) or he has taught and been taught; or has disciplined and been disciplined. (K.) ― -b3- saAsa AlOamora, aor. as above, inf. n. siyaAsapN, (tropical:) He managed, conducted, ordered, or regulated, the affair; syn. dbRrhu, (Msb,) and qaAma bihi: (M, Msb, TA:) siyaAsapN signifies the managing a thing (qiyaAmN EalaI XaIoCK) in such a manner as to put it in a right, or proper, state. (TA.) [Used as a simple subst., the inf. n. may be rendered Management, rule, government, or governance.] ＝ -A2- saAsa, (S, M, A, K,) aor. yasaAsu, (S, M, K,) and yasuwsu, (Kr, M,) inf. n. sawasN, (M,) or sawosN; (Ibn- 'Abbád, K;) and sawisa, aor. yasowasu; (K, TA; but the aor. is omitted in the CK;) or saAsa, aor. yasuwsu, inf. n. sawosN and saAsN; and saAsa, aor. yasowasu, inf. n. sawasN; (Msb;) and siysa; (Yoo, K;) and OasaAsa↓; and sawRasa↓; (S, M, A, Msb, K; but the last is omitted in the TA;) and AstAs↓; and tswRs↓; (M, TA;) It (wheat, or other food, [&c.,]) had in it, or became attacked by, [the grub called] suws; [the grub called] suws fell upon it, or into it. (S, M, * A, * Msb, K, * TA.) One says also, saAsati AlXRajarapu, aor. tasaAsu, inf. n. siyaAsN; and AsAst↓; [The tree had in it, or became attacked by, the grub called suws.] (AHn, M, TA. *) And saAsati AlXRaAopu, aor. tasaAsu, (S, M, K,) inf. n. sawosN, (S, K,) or sawasN; (M;) and AsAst↓, (S, M, K,) inf. n. AsaAsapN; (TA;) The sheep, or goat, abounded with qml. (AZ, S, M, K. [In a copy of the S and in one of the K, I find quml: in another of the S and another of the K, and in the CK, and in a copy of the M, qamol: the right reading apears to be qumRal; for this last word is said by some to be syn. with suws.]) You also say, when you are gradually perishing by reason of grief, (UicaA tahaAlakota gamRFA,) EaZomiI wadawRada laHomiI sawRasa↓ (tropical:) [My bone has bred grubs, and so my flesh]. (A.) ― -b2- sawisati AldRaAbRapu, inf. n. sawasN, The beast was attacked by the disease termed sawasN [q. v. infrà]. (TK.)

2 sawRasuwhu c
2. sawRasuwhu (tropical:) They made him, or appointed him, ruler, or governor, over them; (M, * TA;) as also AsAswhu↓. (TA.) ― -b2- suwRisa AlrRajulu Oumuwra AlnRaAsi, (S, K,) or Oamora AlnRaAsi, (as in the TA,) or Oamora qawomihi, (A,)
(tropical:) The man was made ruler of the affairs of the people; (S;) [or of the affairs of his people, accord. as the phrase is given in the A:] or was made king. (K.) Accord. to a relation of a verse of El-Hotei-ah, he uses the expression sawRasota Omora baniyka [as though meaning Thou hast ruled the affairs of thy sons]; but Fr says that sawRasota is a mistake. (S. [Thus I find it in one copy of the S: but in another copy of the S, I find sawRasoti, which is clearly wrong; and in the TA, suwRisota, which Fr can hardly be supposed to have disallowed.]) ― -b3- sawRasa lahu OamorFA (assumed tropical:) He made an affair easy to him; syn. ruwRaDahu and calRalahu. (TA.) You say, sawRasa fulaAnN lahu OamorFA farakibahu (assumed tropical:) [Such a one made an affair easy to him, or, perhaps, commended it to him by making it seem easy, and so he embarked in it, or undertook it]: like as you say, sawRala lahu, and zayRana lahu. (AZ, K. *) ― -b4- swRs AlmaroOapa He slit the vulva of the woman. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 1, in two places.

4 Oasowasa
4: see 2: ＝ -A2- and see 1, in three places.

5 tasawRasa
5: see 1.

8 Uisotawasa
8: see 1.

saAsN c
saAsN: see suwsN. ― -b2- Also A canker, or corrosion, (qaAdiHN,) in a tooth: (AZ, K:) without and without teshdeed. (AZ.) ＝ -A2- And A tooth that has been eaten, or corroded: (L, K, * TA:) originally saAYisN; like haArN and haAYirN. (K.) ― -b2- See also masuwsN, in two places.

suwsN c
suwsN [The grub, or larva of the phalæna tinea and of the curculio; i. e. the moth-worm and the weevil;] the kind of worm that attacks wool (S, A, K) and cloths (TA) and wheat or other food: (S, TA:) and with p, [a n. un.,] i. q. EuvRapN; (Mgh, Msb;) as also saAsN↓; (TA;) i. e., a worm that attacks wool and cloths (Mgh, Msb) and wheat or other food: (Mgh:) and suwsN, the kind of worm (M, Msb) called EuvRN, (M,) that eats grain (M, Msb) and wood: (Msb:) n. un. with p: (M, Msb:) and any eater of a thing is termed suwsuhu, whether worm or other thing. (M.) One says, AlEiyaAlu suwsu AlmaAli (assumed tropical:) [The persons who compose a household are the grubs of property]: i. e., they consume it by little and little like as suws consume grain, which can scarcely be cleared of them when they attack it. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- [The licoriceplant; so called in the present day;] a kind of tree, (AHn, M, K,) or plant, (Mgh,) well known, (Mgh, K,) with which houses are covered above the roofs, (AHn, M, Mgh,) the expressed juice of which is an ingredient in medicine, (AHn, M,) the leaves of which are put into [the beverage called] nabiyc, and make it strong like [the strong drink called] daAciIR, (Mgh,) in the roots of which is sweetness (AHn, M, K) intense in degree, (AHn, M,) and in its branches is bitterness, (AHn, M, K,) and it abounds in the countries of the Arabs: (AHn, M:) or a kind of tree that grows in leaves without twigs: (M:) or a certain herb resembling [the species of trefoil called] qatR. (TA.) [The root is vulgarly called, in the present day, Eiroq suws: and so is a strong infusion prepared from it, which is a very pleasant drink: and its inspissated juice is called rubR AlsRuws.] ＝ -A3- Nature; natural disposition: (S, M, A, K:) and origin. (S, A, K.) One says, AlfaSaAHapu mino suwsihi (S, M) Chasteness of speech, or eloquence, is [a quality] of his nature. (S.) And Alkaramu mino suwsihi (Lh, M, A) Generosity is [a quality] of his nature. (A.) And fulaAnN mino suwsi SidoqK Such a one is of good origin. (S.)

sawasN c
sawasN A certain disease in the rump of a horse or similar beast, (M, K, TA,) between the hip and the thigh, occasioning, as its result, weakness of the kind leg: (TA:) or a disease that attacks the beast in its legs. (M.) [See 1, last sentence.]

sawaAsN c
sawaAsN A certain kind of tree: n. un. with p: (M, K:) AHn says, (M, TA,) on the authority of Aboo-Ziyád, (TA,) it is of the kind called EiDaAh, resembling the marox, having a pericarp like that of the mrx, (M, TA,) without thorns and without leaves, growing high; and persons shade themselves beneath it; one of the Arabs said that it is the same that is called sawaAsK↓ (written with the article AlsRawaAsiI); and AHn says, I asked him respecting it, and he said that this and the marox and the manoH all three resemble one another; (M;) and it is one of the best of materials used for producing fire, (Lth, * M, K, *) not giving a sound without emitting fire, (M,) or because it seldom gives a sound without emitting fire. (Lth, TA.)

suwaAsN c
suwaAsN A certain disease in the necks of horses, rendering them rigid, (ISh, K, TA,) so that they die. (ISh, TA.)

sawaAsK c
sawaAsK (with the article AlsRawaAsiI): see sawaAsN. ＝ -A2- And for the same word, and sawaAsiwapN and sawaAsiyapN: see art. swI.

saAYisN c
saAYisN [A groom, who has the care and management of a horse or horses or the like;] one who manages, or tends, beasts or horses or the like, and trains them: (TA:) pl. saAsapN and suwRaAsN. (A.) And saAYisu maAlK [A manager, or tender, of camels or cattle or other property]. (K in art. AzI, &c.) ― -b2- [And hence,] (tropical:) A manager, a conductor, an orderer, or a regulater, of affairs: pl. as above. (M, TA.)

Oasowasu c
Oasowasu A beast having the disease termed sawasN. (K.) [Freytag, misled by an ambiguity in the K, assigns to it a signification belonging to sawasN.] ＝ -A2- Also, [or OasowasN, unless originally an epithet,] A kind of stone upon which is generated the salt called zahorapu Oasowas: the author of the “ Minháj ” says that this may be caused by the moisture and dew of the sea falling upon it. (TA in art. sys.)

TaEaAmN masuwsN c
TaEaAmN masuwsN and musawRasN↓, (TA,) or musawRisN↓, [which is app. the more correct,] (S,) and saAsN↓, (M,) Wheat, or other food, attacked by [the grub called] suws: (M, TA:) and HinoTapN musawRisapN↓ wheat so attacked. (Mgh.) And OaroDN masuwsapN and saAsapN↓ [Land attacked by such grubs], (M, TA,) in like manner. (TA.) And XajarapN musiysN↓ [or musiysapN A tree containing, or attacked by, such grubs]. (TA.) And XaApN musiysN↓, (M,) or musiysapN, (TA,) A sheep, or goat, abounding with qml [i. e. qumRal: see 1, near the end of the paragraph]. (M, TA.)

musiysN c
musiysN: see masuwsN, in two places.

musawRasN c
musawRasN and musawRisN: see masuwsN, in three places.

sawosanN c
sawosanN, (M, Msb, K,) like jawoharN [in measure], (Msb, K,) by the vulgar pronounced suwsanN, with damm to the first letter, (Msb, [and thus written in one of my copies of the S, in the other of those copies, and app. in most others, omitted,]) a Pers., or foreign, word, (OaEojamiIRN,) current in the language of the Arabs, (M,) [i. e.] an arabicized word, [app. from the Pers. suwsano, in Hebr. שׁוּשַׁן,] (S,) [applied in the present day to The lily: and also the iris: and the pancratium: and app. to other similar flowers:] a certain plant, (M, Msb, K, *) of sweet odour, (K,) resembling what are called rayaAHiyn, with broad leaves, but not having an odour that diffuses itself like the ryAHyn; (Msb;) it is well known, and of many kinds, the sweetest of which is the white: (S: [but only, as mentioned above, in one of my two copies thereof:]) there is a wild kind; and the garden-kind is of two sorts, namely, the MzaAd, which is the white, and the UiyrisaMC, [i. e. the iris, in the CK, erroneously, AaborasA,] which is the MsomaAnojuwniIR, [i. e. azure-coloured, from the Pers. MsomaAno Guwno,] beneficial as a remedy against the dropsy, an attenuant of thick matters; and the MzaAd is of a delicate, or subtile, nature, [so I here render laTiyfN, but it has other meanings,] beneficial as a remedy for cold disorders in the brain, a discutient of the thick kinds of flatus that collect therein; its OaSol [app. here meaning root] is a detergent of the skin, discutient; and its leaves are beneficial as a remedy against the burning of hot water, and against the sting of venomous reptiles or the like, and particularly of the scorpion: the n. un. is with p. (K.)

1 saATahu c
1. saATahu, [aor. yasuwTu,] (M,) inf. n. sawoTN, (S, M, K,) He mixed it, (S, M, K,) one part with another, (S,) and stirred it about, and beat it; (M;) as also swRThu↓, (M, K, *) inf. n. tasowiyTN: (K:) or sawoTN signifies the putting together two things in a vessel, then beating them with the hand until they become mixed: (Jm, K:) or, accord. to some, it relates particularly to a cooking-pot, when its contents are mixed: (M:) you say, saATa qidorahu biAlmisowaTi [he mixed, and stirred about, and beat, the contents of his cooking-pot with the misowaT, q. v.]: (TA:) but you say also, saATa Alhariysapa, and sawRaTahaA↓, he stirred about the [food called] hrysp with a piece of wood, in order that it might become mixed: (TA:) or swRThu↓ signifies he mixed it much. (S.) ― -b2- [Hence,] siyTa HubRuka bidamiI and mino damiI (assumed tropical:) [The love of thee is
mixed with my blood]. (TA.) And huwa yasowTu AlOamora (assumed tropical:) He turns over the affair [in his mind]. (TA.) And fulaAnN yasuwTu AlHaroba and yusawRiTuhaA↓ (assumed tropical:) Such a one superintends, manages, or conducts, in person, the war. (A, TA.) And fulaAnN Oumuwrahu sawRaTa↓, inf. n. as above, (S, TA,) (tropical:) Such a one rendered his affairs confused, or disordered, or perplexed: (TA:) and in like manner, raOoyahu [his opinion]. (M.) And Oamorahu sawRaTa↓ (tropical:) He created confusion, or disorder, in his affair, or case. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- saATahu, (M,) aor. yasuwTu, (S,) inf. n. sawoTN, (M, K,) He whipped him; struck him with a sawoT; (S, M, K;) namely, a beast, and a man. (TA.) ― -b2- saAwaTaniI fasuTotuhu: see 3.

2 sawRaTa
2: see 1, in six places. ＝ -A2- sawRaTa AlkurRaAvu, (M, K,) inf. n. tasowiyTN, (K,) (tropical:) The leeks put forth their siyaAT [or seed-stalks: see sawoTN]. (M, K, TA.)

3 saAowaTa
3: saAwaTaniI fasuTotuhu↓, aor. of the latter OasuwTuhu: thus mentioned by Lh, without any addition: app. meaning He acted roughly with me with his whip, or he contended with me therewith, and I overcame him [with my whip]: a mode of expression which is rare in relation to substances; rather relating to accidents, or attributes. (M.)

8 UisotawaTa
8: 2, which is extr., [for by rule it should be AisotaATa,] It (a thing) was, or became, mixed. (M.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AisotawaTa Ealayohi Oamoruhu (tropical:) His affair, or case, was, or became, confused, or disordered, to him. (M, K, * TA.)

sawoTN c
sawoTN [A whip;] a certain thing, (S, M,) namely, plaited skin, (Bd in lxxxix. 12,) [or a lash,] with which one beats, or strikes, (S, M,) well known; (Msb;) i. q. miqoraEapN: (K:) so called because it mixes the flesh with the blood (IDrd, M, K) when a man or a beast is struck with it; (IDrd, TA;) or because its several component parts are mixed together: (Bd, ubi suprà:) pl. [of pauc.] OasowaATN and [of mult.] siyaATN: (S, M, Msb, K:) the latter originally siwaATN. (TA.) The saying Darabotu zayodFA sawoTFA means Darabotu zayodFA bisawoTK [I struck Zeyd with a whip]: (M, Msb: *) or it is one of those rare instances in which a prefixed n. is suppressed; being originally Darabotuhu Darobapa sawoTK [I struck him a stroke, or lash, of a whip], meaning DarobapF bisawoTK [a stroke, or lash, with a whip]: (M:) or DarobapF waAHidapF bisawoTK [one stroke, or lash, with a whip]. (Mgh.) One says also, Darabahu miAYapa sawoTK [He struck him a hundred strokes, or lashes, of the whip]. (S and K in art. sHl.) ― -b2- In the Kur [lxxxix. 12], where it is said, faSabRa Ealayohimo rabRuka sawoTa EacaAbK, (S, Msb,) it signifies (tropical:) A portion, or share: (S, K:) or (S, Msb, but in the K, “ and ”) (tropical:) vehemence, or severity; (S, Msb, K;) as being likened to the paining of a whip; (Msb;) because punishment is sometimes with the sawoT; (S;) and this word is used by the Arabs to denote every kind of punishment when it is extreme, though there be in it no beating: (Fr:) [therefore,] the above-cited saying in the Kur means, (tropical:) [And thy Lord poured upon them a portion, or a share, or vehemence, or severity, of punishment: or it means,] a mixture; prepared for them, of various punishments: or it is designed to show that what befell them in the present world was, in comparison with what is prepared for them in the final state, like the whip in comparison with the sword: (Bd:) or the meaning is (assumed tropical:) a kind of punishment. (Jel.) [Agreeably with this last explanation, it is said that] the phrase humaA yataEaATayaAni sawoTFA waAHidFA means (tropical:) They two are agreed upon one mode: (A:) or the meaning is (tropical:) [they two enter, or plunge, into; or venture boldly upon, and do;] one thing, or affair; (S, and K; but wanting in one copy of the former; and in the latter, in the place of hmA is put mA;) i. e., one sort [of thing or affair]. (S.) ― -b3- [qiydu sawoTK The measure of a whip, i. e. a whip's length, is an astronomical measure, which seems, from several instances that I have noted, in the work of Kzw &c., to be the same as rumoHN is in modern usage; i. e. four degrees and a half, by rule; but, like the latter, not precise nor uniform in every instance.] ― -b4- [The pl.] siyaATN also signifies (tropical:) The seed-stalks of leeks; (TK;) the stalks, of leeks, upon which are the zamaAliyq thereof: (M, K:) so called as being likened to the syAT with which one strikes. (M.) ― -b5- And sawoTN signifies also (tropical:) A remaining portion (A, K) of water, (A,) or of a pool of water left by a torrent, (K, [in some copies of which Algadiyl is erroneously put for Algadiyr,]) extended like the sawoT [with which one strikes]: (A:) pl. siyaATN. (TA.) ― -b6- And (assumed tropical:) A place where water collects and stagnates: (K:) pl. OasowaATN. (TA.) ― -b7- And (tropical:) A road, or track, of little width, between two elevations: pl. OasoyaATN [or siyaATN?] and OFsowaATN: so in the A: but some say XawoTN, q. v. (TA.) ― -b8- Also (assumed tropical:) A kind of tent, of [goats'] hair. (Ibn-El-Kelbee, TA voce bayotN, q. v.) ― -b9- And sawoTu baATilK (tropical:) Light entering from an aperture in a wall, in sunshine; (K, TA;) also termed xayoTu baATilK: but as some say, with X. (TA: and it is mentioned with X in art. XwT in the S, and again in the K.)

sawiyTN c
sawiyTN; fem. with p: see masuwTN.

sawRaATN c
sawRaATN The XuraTiIR [or officer of the prefect of police] who has with him the sawoT [or whip]. (TA.)

masawTN c
masawTN Mixed. (TA.) So in a trad. of 'Alee with Fátimeh, [in which the former expresses the intimacy of her union with him, as though they two were one person,] masuwTN laHomuhaA bidamiI walaHomiI (assumed tropical:) Her flesh is blended and mixed with my blood and my flesh. (TA.) You say also, OamowaAluhumo bayonahumo sawiyTapN↓ Their possessions are mixed among them; (AZ, S, K;) i. q. musotawTapN↓. (M.)

misowaTN c
misowaTN: see what next follows.

misowaATN c
misowaATN A thing with which one mixes a thing, (S, * M, K,) and stirs it about; (M;) i. e., a stick, or the like, used for that purpose; as also misowaTN↓. (K.) ＝ -A2- A horse that will not put forth his power of running unless by means of the whip; (Ibn-'Abbád and K; and so in a copy of the S, on the authority of AO, but omitted in another copy;) as though (TA) keeping it in store. (S, TA.)

musotawiTN c
musotawiTN; fem. with p: see masuwTN.

1 saAEati AlUibilu c
1. saAEati AlUibilu, aor. tasuwEu, (S, K,) inf. n. sawoEN, (S,) The camels were left to themselves, (S, K,) without a pastor; (K;) as also sAEt with tasiyEu for its aor. and sayoEN for its inf. n. (Sh.)

3 EaAmalahu musaAwaEapF c
3. EaAmalahu musaAwaEapF [He bargained with him for work by, or for, the hour,] is from AlsRaAEapu, like muyaAwamapF from Alyawomu. (S, K. [See also the last sentence of the second paragraph of art. sEI.]) [It is added in the S, that neither of them is used otherwise than thus: but accord. to SM one says also,] sAwEhu, inf. n. siwaAEN, He hired him, or took him as a hireling, for the hour. (TA.)

4 AsAEhu c
4. AsAEhu He left to himself, or itself, left alone, or neglected, and lost, or destroyed, him, or it. (K.) Er-Rághib says, [but why, I do not well see,] that the meaning of neglecting, or the like, is imagined as derived from AlsRaAEapu. (TA.) You say, OasaEotu AlUibila I left the camels to themselves, left them alone, or neglected them. (S.) And rubRa naAqapK tusiyEu waladahaA HatRaI taOokulahu AlsRibaAEu, meaning [Scarce, or many, a she-camel] leaves to itself, or leaves alone, or neglects, her young one [so that the beasts of prey devour it]. (TA.) [See also 4 in art. syE.] ＝ -A2- OasowaEa He (a man, Zj) passed from saAEap to saAEap [i. e. time to time, or hour to hour]; (Zj, K;) as also AsAE, inf. n. UisaAEapN: (Zj, TA:) or he remained behind, or held back, or delayed, for a saAEap [i. e. a time, or an hour]. (Ibn- 'Abbád, K.)

saAEN c
saAEN: see saAEapN, in two places.

sawoEN c
sawoEN and suwaAEN↓ i. q. hdoCN, as used in the phrase, jaMCanaA baEoda sawoEK mina AllRayoli [He came to us after a period, or portion, of the night; or after about a third or fourth part of the night had elapsed, when men were asleep, or at rest, and the night, and the foot of the passenger, were still; or after a third part of the night]: (S, K: *) or this phrase means he come to us after a saAEap [i. e. a short period, or an hour,] of the night. (TA.).

saAEapN c
saAEapN [An hour;] one of the divisions of the night and the day; (Lth, K, TA;) both of which together consist of four and twenty of those divisions; each of them, when they are of equal length, consisting of twelve such divisions; (TA;) [also termed saAEapN falakiyRapN (an astronomical hour; fifteen darajaAt of time; sixty minutes of time;) because sAEp alone is often used in a vague sense, as meaning what is termed saAEapN zamaAniyRapN; i. e.] a time of night or of day: but used absolutely by the Arabs as meaning a time; a while; a space, or period; an indefinite [short] time; and a little while; (Msb;) a [short or] little portion, or division, [or space, or period,] of the night and of the day: (TA:) and AlsRaAEapu signifies the pre-
sent time: (S, K:) pl. saAEaAtN and saAEN↓, (S, Msb, K,) [or the latter is rather a coll. gen. n. of which sAEp is the n. un.,] and siwaAEN. (Msb.) It is used unrestricted in the Kur [vii. 32 and in other places], where it is said, laA yasotaOoxiruwna saAEapF (Msb) They will not remain behind (Bd) for a time, or any while, (Msb,) or the shortest time: or they shall not seek to remain behind, by reason of intense terror. (Bd.) And so in a trad., where it is said, mano raAHa fiI AlsRaAEapi AlOuwlaI Whoso goeth in the first time; not in the first astronomical sAEp, for then it would necessarily mean that he who should come in the latter part thereof would be on a par with the former person, which is not the case. (Msb.) [saAEapF signifies, as shown above, For, or during, an hour: and awhile; for a little while; during a short time; as in the phrase,] jalasotu Einodaka saAEapF I sat with thee, or at thine abode, for a little while, or during a short time. (TA.) [And fiI saAEapK, In a short time: in a moment. And AlsRaAEapa, Now: just now: this moment. And saAEataYicK, Then; at that time: or in that hour.] And muco saAEapNK [A little while ago;] in the first time near to us: (K in art. Anf:) or this signifies AlsRaAEapa [expl. above]. (Zj, T and M in art. Anf.) [And mino saAEatihi At the moment thereof; instantly. Hence, samRa saAEapK An instantaneous poison.] ― -b2- AlsRaAEapu also signifies (tropical:) The resurrection; (S, K, TA;) the raising of mankind for the reckoning; also termed AlsRaAEapu AlkuboraI: (Er-Rághib, B:) or the time thereof: (K:) because of the quickness with which its reckoning will be accomplished: (TA:) or because it will come suddenly upon mankind, in a moment, and all creatures will die at one cry. (Zj, Az, TA.) Hence, in the Kur [liv. 1], Aiqotarabati AlsRaAEapu (tropical:) The resurrection [or the time thereof] hath drawn nigh. (Jel, TA.) And [in vii. 186 and lxxix. 42,] yasoOaluwnaka Eani AlsRaAEapi (tropical:) They ask thee concerning the resurrection [or the time thereof]. (Bd, Jel, TA.) And [in xxxi. last verse and xliii. 85,] Einodahu Eilomu AlsRaAEapi (tropical:) With Him is the knowledge of the resurrection, (TA,) or of the time thereof. (Bd, Jel.) ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) The death of one generation; termed, for distinction, AlsRaAEapu AlwusoTaI: as in the saying of Mohammad, when he saw 'AbdAllah Ibn-Uneys, Uino yaTulo Eumoru hecaA AlgulaAmi lamo yamuto HatRaI taquwma AlsRaAEapu (assumed tropical:) [If the life of this boy last long, he will not die until the death of the generation shall come to pass]: accordingly it is said that he was the last that died of the Companions. (Er-Rághib, B.) ― -b4- Also (assumed tropical:) The death of any man; termed, for distinction, AlsRaAEapu AlSRugoraI: as in the Kur [vi. 31], qado xasira QlRacayna kacRabuwA biliqaMCi QllRehi HatRaI UicaA jaMCatohumu QlsRaAeEapu bagotapF (assumed tropical:) [They have suffered loss who disbelieved in, or denied as false, the meeting with God until, when death came to them suddenly]. (Er-Rághib, B) ― -b5- Also (assumed tropical:) Difficulty, distress, or affliction; and so AlsRaAEu↓. (TA.) ― -b6- And (assumed tropical:) Distance, or remoteness. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also saAYiEN.

saAEapN sawoEaMCu c
saAEapN sawoEaMCu A severe, grievous, or distressing [hour or time]; (S, K;) like the phrase layolapN layolaMCu. (S.)

suwaAEN c
suwaAEN: see sawoEN. ＝ -A2- Also, (S, K, [in the CK erroneously without tenween,]) and sawaAEN, (Kh, K,) A certain idol (S, K) which belonged to the people of Noah, (S,) in whose time it was worshipped; then the deluge buried it, but Iblees exhumed it, and it was worshipped [again]; (K;) so says Lth; (TA;) then it became the property of [the tribe of] Hudheyl, (S, K,) and was at Ruhát, (S,) and pilgrimage was performed to it: (S, K:) or it belonged to [the tribe of] Hemdán: (Bd, TA:) Abu-l-Mundhir says, I have not heard the mention of it in the poems of Hudheyl: but one of the Arabs, in verse, mentions Hudheyl as paying devotion to it: (TA:) it is said that it had the form of a woman: (Har p. 362:) [if so, as a fem. proper name, it would be without tenween: but] it is mentioned in the Kur [lxxi. 22, and is there with tenween]. (TA.) [See also wadRN.]

huwa DaAYiEN saAYiEN c
huwa DaAYiEN saAYiEN He is left to himself, left alone, or neglected. (S, * K, * TA.) saAEapN↓ [is pl. of saAYiEN; and also signifies] In a state of perdition or destruction; perishing; or dying; in a pl. sense; like jaAEapN as signifying jiyaAEN, (K,) and TaAEapN as signifying muTiyEuwna. (TA.)

musiyEN c
musiyEN: see the following paragraph.

misoyaAEN c
misoyaAEN A she-camel that leaves her young one so that the beasts of prey devour it: (Sh, K:) or a she-camel that goes away in the place of pasturing: (S:) belonging to this art. and to art. syE, q. v. (K.) You say also, rajulN miDoyaAEN misoyaAEN lilomaAli [A man who is wont to neglect the camels or the like; or to leave them to themselves, or alone; or to lose them]; and accord. to A'Obeyd, muDiyEN musiyEN↓. (S.)

1 saAga c
1. saAga, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) or sAg fiI AlHaloqi, (JK,) aor. yasuwgu, (S, Msb,) inf. n. sawogN (JK, S, Mgh, Msb, K) and sawaAgN, or suwaAgN, accord. to different copies of the K, (TA,) and sawagaAnN, (CK, [not in my MS. copy of the K nor in the TA,]) and masaAgN, (MA,) It (beverage, or wine, JK, S, K, or food, Mgh, or each of these, TA) [was easy and agreeable to swallow;] was easy of entrance into the fauces; (S, Mgh, Msb, K; *) or passed the fauces easily and agreeably. (Bd in xiv. 20.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce HamiymN.] ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, sugo fiI AlOaroDi maAwajadota masaAgFA↓ (assumed tropical:) Enter thou into the land while thou findest a place of entrance. (TA.) ― -b3- And sAg fiEolu AlXRaIoCi (tropical:) The doing of the thing was allowable; or passed for lawful. (Msb.) And sAg lahu maAfaEala (tropical:) What he did was allowable to him; or passed for lawful to him. (S, K, TA.) ― -b4- And sAg AlnRahaAru (tropical:) The day was, or became, easy. (TA.) ― -b5- sAgt bihi AlOaroDu, (K,) inf. n. sawogN, (TA,) i. q. saAxato (assumed tropical:) [The ground, or earth, sank with him; or sank with him and swallowed him up, or enclosed him]. (AA, K, TA.) ― -b6- And sAgt AlnRaAqapu (assumed tropical:) The she-camel became apart, or alone, syn. XacRato, (K, TA,) or ran, syn. XadRato, (JK, and so in the CK and in my MS. copy of the K,) and went far away. (JK, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 4, in two places.

2 sawRaga
2: [swRghu is app., in its primary sense, syn. with OasaAgahu: and hence what here follows.] ― -b2- You say, swRghu maA OaSaAba, (JK, TA,) inf. n. tasowiygN, (JK,) (assumed tropical:) He made pleasant, or agreeable, to him what he attained: or, as some say, he left clear to him what he had attained. (TA.) ― -b3- And swRghu, (inf. n. as above, K,) (tropical:) He made it allowable, lawful, or free, (S, Msb, K,) lahu to him. (S.) And swRghu maAlFA (tropical:) [He made property allowable, &c., to him]: so in the “ Mufradát. ” (TA.) ― -b4- And swRg lahu kacaA (assumed tropical:) He gave him such a thing. (IDrd, K.) ― -b5- [See also tasowiygaAt, below.]

4 AsAghu c
4. AsAghu, (JK, Msb,) inf. n. UisaAgapN, (JK,) or UisaAgN, (Msb,) said of God, (JK,) or of a man, (Msb,) [He made it easy and agreeable to swallow;] he made it easy of entrance into the fauces; (Msb;) [or made it to pass the fauces easily and agreeably;] namely, beverage [&c.: see 1, first sentence]; (JK;) as also saAgahu↓. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Oasigo liI guSRatiI [Make thou easy to me to swallow the thing that is choking me; or let me swallow it;] meaning (assumed tropical:) grant thou to me some delay, or respite; or act gently, or in a leisurely manner, towards me, or with me; (S, K;) and do not hurry me. (S.) ― -b3- And Oasagotuhu, (S, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. as above, (S, Msb, TA,) I swallowed it: (Msb, and Jel in xiv. 20:) or I received it into my fauces easily (S, Mgh, and Bd in xiv. 20) and agreeably; (Bd ibid.;) namely, beverage, or wine, (S, K,) or food, (Mgh,) or each of these; (TA;) and sugotuhu↓ and sigotuhu, aor. Oasuwguhu and Oasiyguhu, (S, K,) inf. n. sawogN and sayogN, (TA in art. syg,) signify the same. (S, K.) ― -b4- AsAg fulaAnN bifulaAnK means (assumed tropical:) Such a one completed his affair by means of such a one, (Ibn-Buzurj, K, TA, [in the CK, vumRa Amarahu bih is erroneously put for tamRa Oamorahu bihi,]) and accomplished the object of his want by means of him: (Ibn-Buzurj, TA:) the case is that of one's desiring a certain number of men or of pieces of money of which one remains to complete the affair: when he obtains it, one says, AsAg bihi. (Ibn-Buzurj, K.) ＝ -A2- Oasowaga OaxaAhu He (a man, Lh) was born with his brother: (Lh, K:) or he was born [next, or immediately,] after his brother. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) [See what next follows.]

hecaA sawogu hecaA c
hecaA sawogu hecaA and sayoguhu (S, K) and sawogatuhu↓ (K) mean (tropical:) This is he who was born next after this, (S, K, TA,) or, as in the “ Mufradát, ” immediately after this; (TA;) and the like is also said of the female: (K:) one says, hiIa Ouxotuhu sawoguhu and sawogatuhu↓ [She is his sister that was born &c.], (S, TA,) as well as huwa Oaxuwhu sawoguhu and sawogatuhu↓ [He is his brother that was born &c.]: or sawogu AlrRajuli means he who was born after the man, or near after him, though not his brother: and Fr
heard a man of Benoo-Temeem say sawoguhu, and another of the same tribe say sawogatuhu↓, meaning he who followed him: (TA:) [the pl. of sawogN is OasowaAgN; and it is said that] OasowaAgu AlrRajuli means those who were born with the man in one case of childbirth, after him, no other childbirth having occurred between him and them: (TA:) or those born next after him: (JK:) and OaSowaAg is a dial. var. thereof: but IF says that hecaA sawogu hecaA means This is of the cast, mould, form, or fashion, of this; and that the s may be a substitute for S; as though the one were cast, moulded, formed, or fashioned, like the other: (TA:) and [in like manner] one says, hecaA sayogu hecaA this is proportionate to this, or of the proportion of this. (TA in art. syg.)

sawogapN c
sawogapN: see the next preceding paragraph in four places.

siwaAgN c
siwaAgN A thing whereby one makes to enter easily into his fauces [and to pass down his throat] that which is choking him. (S, Msb, K.) One says, AlmaMCu siwaAgu AlguSaSi [Water is that whereby one makes easy of entrance into the fauces and of passage down the throat the things that are choking him]. (S.)

saAYigN c
saAYigN, applied to beverage, or wine, (JK, K, TA,) and food, (TA,) Descending easily [and agreeably] down the throat; (JK, Msb, K, TA, and Bd and Jel in xvi. 68 and Bd in xxxv. 13;) [or easy and agreeable to swallow;] not choking; (Jel in xvi. 68;) and Oasowagu↓ signifies the same; (IDrd, K, TA;) and so sayRigN↓, applied to food [&c.]; (TA;) [and musotasaAgN↓, accord. to Freytag, as from the K, in which I do not find it.]

sayRigN c
sayRigN: see the next preceding paragraph.

Oasowagu c
Oasowagu: see saAYigN. [Freytag assigns to it also another signification, which belongs not to it, but to sawog.]

tasowiygaAtu AlsRalaATiyni c
tasowiygaAtu AlsRalaATiyni is a post-classical term, (O, K,) from sawRagotuhu lahu, inf. n. tasowiygN, meaning “ I made it allowable, lawful, or free, to him: ” (O:) and what is meant by [the sing. of tswygAt i. e.] tasowiygN is The permission [of the Sultán] for the taking of that which is one's right, or due, on a particular account, with facilitation thereof to the taker. (MF.)

masaAgN c
masaAgN [A place of easy entrance or passage for beverage, or food, into the fauces or throat. ― -b2- And hence,] (assumed tropical:) A place of entrance into a land [&c.]; as in a saying cited in the first paragraph of this art., q. v. (TA.) ― -b3- And [hence] one says, hecaA laA Oajidu lahu masaAgFA (tropical:) This, I do not find to it a passage, or an [easy] entrance; or a way, or place, of entrance. (TA.)

musotasaAgN c
musotasaAgN: see saAYigN.

1 saAfa AlXRaIoCa c
1. saAfa AlXRaIoCa, aor. yasuwfu (S, M, Msb) and yasaAfu, (M,) inf. n. sawofN; (S, M, K;) and so sAwfhu↓; (M, TA;) and AstAfhu↓, (M, Msb, K, *) inf. n. AisotiyaAfN; (S;) [and, accord. to Freytag, swRfhu↓; but he has not named his authority; if correct, probably having an intensive signification;] He smelled the thing. (S, M, Msb.) A poet says, (Msb,) namely, Ru-beh, (S, M,)
OaxolaAqa AlTRuruqo UicaA AldRaliylu QsotaAfa↓
[When the guide smells the natures of the roads to know whether he be pursuing the right course or deviating therefrom]. (S, M, Msb.) ― -b2- [And hence, He hunted. (Freytag, from the Deewán el-Hudhaleeyeen.)] ＝ -A2- sawofN is also Syn. with SaborN. (IAar, K.) You say, of a man, sAf Ealayohi, inf. n. sawofN, He endured it with patience. (TK.) ＝ -A3- saAfa, (S, M, O, K,) aor. yasuwfu (S, O, K) and yasaAfu, (O, K,) inf. n. sawofN, (M,) said of a man, (M,) and of cattle, (maAl, M, O, K,) He, or they, perished, or died: (S, M, O, K:) or, said of cattle, they had a murrain occurring among them. (K.) ＝ -A4- [saAfa expl. by Freytag in this art., as though having for its aor. yasuwfu, and meaning He smote a person with a sword, is a mistake, caused by a mistranscription (of sufotuhu for sifotuhu) in art. syf in some copies of the K.]

2 swRfhu c
2. swRfhu, (S, M, K,) or swRf bihi, (Msb,) inf. n. tasowiyfN, (S, M, Msb, K,) He said to him time after time sawofa OafoEalu [I will do such a thing]; (S, Msb, TA;) derived from the particle sawofa: (IJ, M:) and hence, (Msb,) he delayed, or deferred, with him; or put him off with promises; syn. maTalahu; (S, * Msb, K, TA;) saying sawofa OafoEalu; (TA;) or promising to be faithful to his engagement; (Msb;) mostly used in relation to a promise that is not to be fulfilled; as is said by Ibn-Abi1-Hadeed: (MF, TA:) and sAwfhu↓ signifies [the same, as is implied in the M, being syn. with] maATilahu: see an ex. in a verse cited voce sawofa, last sentence. (TA.) AltRasowiyfu is [also expl. as] Syn. with AltRaOoxiyru [app. as meaning the postponing, putting off, delaying, or deferring, anything]. (TA.) [And it is implied in art. EZb of the TA that it is Syn. with AltRamoriynu and AltRaSobiyru: so that you say, swRfhu Ealayohi, meaning He inured, or accustomed, him to it; and made him to endure it with patience: see saAfa Ealayohi, above.] ― -b2- You say also, sawRafotuhu OamoriI, meaning I made him (a man) to have the ordering and deciding of my affair, or case, (S, K,) to do what he would: (S:) and so sawRamotuhu. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 1, first sentence.

3 sAwfhu c
3. sAwfhu: see 1: ＝ -A2- and 2. ＝ -A3- Also i. q. saArRahu [He spoke, or discoursed, secretly to him or with him; or acquainted him with a secret]. (K.) ― -b2- And sAwf AlmaroOapa i. q. DaAjaEahaA [He slept with the woman in, or on, one bed]. (K.)

4 AsAf c
4. AsAf, (S, M, K,) inf. n. UisaAfapN, (TA,) said of a man, (S, M,) His cattle perished, or died: (S, K:) or he had murrain occurring among his cattle: so in a verse of Tufeyl, cited voce AisotaroxaI, in art. rxw. (M.) [Hence,] one says, OasaAfa HtRRI maAyaXotakiI AlsRawaAfa, (AA, S, Meyd, K,) or AlsRuwaAfa, (As, Meyd,) [He had murrain among his cattle until he did not complain of the murrain:] a prov., (Meyd,) applied to him who has become accustomed to casualties; (S, K;) or to him who has become inured to calamities, (A'Obeyd, Meyd, A,) so that he is not impatient of the vicissitudes of fortune. (A'Obeyd, Meyd.) ― -b2- AsAf AlwaAlidaAni The two parents lost their child by his death: in which case, the child is said to be musaAfN↓; and his father, musiyfN↓; and his mother, misoyaAfN↓. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ＝ -A2- AsAfhu QllRehu God destroyed him, or took away his life. (M.) ― -b2- AsAf Alxaroza i. q. xaramahu [i. e. He spoiled the sewing of the skin, or hide; as when one uses a thick instrument for sewing or perforating, and a thin thong; or as when one rends two stitch-holes into one]. (M.) And AsAf AlxaArizu The sewer of a skin, or hide, perforated, or sewed, in such a manner that the two stitch-holes became rent [into one]. (A'Obeyd, K.)

8 Uisotawafa
8: see 1, first and second sentences.

saAfN c
saAfN Any row, or course, (S, M, L, K, TA,) [i. e.] a single row, or course, (Mgh,) of bricks, (S, M, Mgh, L, K, TA,) or (so in the Mgh, but in the TA “ and ”) of clay, (Mgh, TA,) of a wall, (S, Mgh, K, TA,) or in a wall, (TA,) or in a building; (M, L, TA;) as also midomaAkN: (TA:) pl. of pauc. MsufN [formed by transposition, like MdurN pl. of daArN,] (L,) and saAfaAtN: (Mgh:) Lth explains AlsRaAfu as signifying what is between the saAfaAt of the building: its A is originally w. (TA.) [saAfapN mentioned by Freytag as signifying “ a single series of stones in a wall, ” on the authority of the K, I do not find there, nor in any other lexicon.] ＝ -A2- Also A certain bird, that preys. (M.)

sawofa c
sawofa, for which one also says safo, (M, Mughnee, K,) rejecting the medial radical letter, (M, Mughnee,) and sawo, (M, Mughnee, K,) rejecting the final radical, (M, Mughnee,) and saIo, (M, Mughnee, K,) rejecting the final radical and changing the medial into I for the purpose of alleviation [of the utterance], (M, Mughnee,) and accord. to the L saA, (TA,) is a particle, (IJ, M, K,) denoting inception; (K;) or a word denoting tanofiys, (Sb, S, M, K,) i. e. amplification, because it changes the aor. from the strait time, which is the present, to the ample time, which is the future; (Mughnee voce sa [q. v.];) i. e., denoting tnfys with respect to that which has not yet happened; (Sb, S, K;) and postponement; (M;) and is used in terrifying and threatening and promising; (IDrd, K;) or it is a word denoting promising or threatening: (Msb:) it is syn. with sa accord. to some, or has a larger meaning than this latter accord. to others. (Mughnee.) You say, sawofa OafoEalu [I will do such a thing]. (Sb, S.) And one may not introduce a separating word between it and its verb, [except in a case mentioned in what follows,] because it occupies the place of the s in sayafoEalu [&c.]. (Sb, S.) [But] it is distinct from sa by its [sometimes] having l prefixed to it; as in [the phrase in the Kur xciii. 5], walasawofa yuEoTiyka rabRuka fataroDaI [And thy Lord will give thee, and thou wilt be well pleased]: (Mughnee:) in this phrase, [however,] the l is [considered as] pre-
fixed to the verb, not to the particle: (M:) or the phrase is elliptical, for laOanota sawofa yuEoTiyka. (Bd.) And it is distinct from sa in this, that it is sometimes separated [from its verb] by a verb divested of government both as to the letter and the meaning; as in the saying,
wamaA OadoriI wasawofa UixaAlu OadoriI
OaqawomN Mlu HiSonK Oamo nisaMCu
[And I know not, but I shall, I think, know, whether the family of Hisn be a company of men or women]. (Mughnee.) ― -b2- When you desire to make it a subst., [i. e. to use it as a subst.,] you make it to have tenween [when it is indeterminate]. (IDrd, K.) IDrd cites as an ex.,
UinRa sawofFA waUinRa layotFA EanaMCN
[Verily sawofa and verily layota are a weariness]: but one reading is UinRa lawRFA; and another, UinRa layotFA wUinRa lawRFA; and there is no such reading as UinRa sawofFA. (O, TA.) One says also, fulaAnN yaqotaAtu AlsRawofa [lit. Such a one feeds upon the word sawofa]; meaning (tropical:) Such a one lives by means of things hoped for: (S, K, TA:) and in like manner, maA quwtuhu UilRaA AlsRawofu [lit. His food is not anything but, or other than, the word sawofa]. (A, TA.) ― -b3- In the following verse of Ibn-Mukbil, cited by Sb,
bisawofK mino taHiyRatihaA lawo saAwafatonaA↓
sawofa AlEayuwfi laraAHa AlrRakobu qado qaniEaA
[Had she put us off with a sawofa as part of her greeting, with the putting off even of such as is affected with dislike, the riders had gone contented], sawofa is put in the accus. case [for musaAwafapa, i. e.] as an inf. n. with the augmentation [meaning the augmentative letters] rejected. (M.)

siyfapN c
siyfapN: see masaAfapN, in two places.

sawaAfN c
sawaAfN The [cucumber commonly called] qivRaMC [q. v.]: (M, K, TA:) so says AHn, (M, TA,) on the authority of Et-Toosee. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also what next follows.

suwaAfN c
suwaAfN and sawaAfN↓; with damm accord. to As, and so, he says, all the names of diseases, as nuHaAzN and dukaAEN and qulaAbN and xumaAlN [&c.]; accord. to AA, not so, but with fet-h, and in like manner said 'Omárah Ibn-'Akeel; (S;) or none relates it with fet-h except AA, and his relation is nought; (IB;) Disease of cattle, and death thereof: (S:) or each signifies death among mankind and cattle: (M:) or the latter, a mortality, or murrain, among camels; or so the former: or the latter, a mortality among mankind and cattle: (K:) and the former, disease of camels; (AHn, M, K;) and so the latter. (K.) One says, waqaEa fiI AlmaAli sawaAfN [or suwaAfN] Death [or a murrain] happened among the cattle. (S.)

masaAfN c
masaAfN The nose: because one smells (yusaAfu, K, i. e. yuXamRu, TA) with it: (K:) so in the Moheet. (TA.) ― -b2- See also masaAfapN, in two places.

musaAfN c
musaAfN A child taken from his parents by death: see 4. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

musiyfa c
musiyfa A man whose cattle have died. (TA.) ― -b2- And A father having lost his child by death: see 4. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

masaAfapN c
masaAfapN [properly A place of smelling: ― -b2- and hence,] (tropical:) Distance; (S, K, TA;) and masaAfN↓ and siyfapN↓ signify the same in this sense [or in others here following]: (K:) [a space, or tract, or an extent, over which one journeys:] a far-extending tract that one traverses: originally a place of smelling of the guides, in order that they may know whether it be far or near, out of the way or in the right way: (A, TA:) or a [desert, or such as is termed] mafaAzap: (M:) said to be from saAfa AlXRaIoCa meaning “ he smelled the thing; ” for the guide smells the dust of the place wherein he is; and if he smell the odour of urine and dung of camels, he knows that he [or some other] has traversed it; but otherwise, not: (Msb:) or because the guide, when he is in a desert, (S, M, K,) and has lost his way therein, (M,) smells its dust, (S, M, K,) in order that he may know, (S, K,) or and thus knows, (M,) whether he be in the right way, (S, M, K,) or not: (S, K:) then, by reason of frequency of usage of this word [as meaning “ a place of smelling of the guides ”] it became a term for “ distance: ” (S, K:) pl. masaAwifu (A, TA) and masaAfaAtN. (Msb.) One says, kamo masaAfapu hecihi AlOaroDi and masaAfuhaA↓ and siyfatuhaA↓ (tropical:) [How long is the distance, or how much is the extent, of this land?]. (TA.) And bayonahumo masaAfapN baEiydapN (assumed tropical:) [Between them is a far-extending distance or space]. (Msb.) And bayonanaA masaAfapu EiXoriyna yawomFA (tropical:) [Between us is the distance, or space, of twenty days]. (TA.) ― -b3- In the following saying of Dhu-rRummeh, it is doubly tropical:
waOaboEaduhumo masaAfapa gawori EaqolK
UicaA maA AlOamoru cuw AlXRubuhaAti EaAlaA
(tropical:) (tropical:) [And the furthest of them in the extent of the depth of intelligence when the affair, or case, in which are dubiousnesses overcomes and is onerous]. (A, TA.)

musawRifN c
