musawRifN One who does what he will, [as though he said time after time sawofa OafoEalu,] whom no one will make to turn back. (K.) ― -b2- And, with p, A woman who will not comply with the desire of her husband when he calls her to his bed, and strives with him to repel him in respect of that which he desires of her, and says sawofa OafoEalu: such is said, in a trad., to be cursed. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, with p, A well (rakiyRapN) of which one says, Water will be found (sawofa yuwjadu) in it: or of which the water is smelt (yusaAfu), and disliked, and loathed. (Ibn- 'Abbád, Z, K.) ― -b4- And, without p, Very patient or enduring. (TA.)

musotaAfN c
musotaAfN A place of smelling, or that is smelt. (O, K.)

misoyaAfN c
misoyaAfN A mother having lost her child by death: see 4. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

UinRahaA lamusaAwifapN lilsRayori c
UinRahaA lamusaAwifapN lilsRayori [app. referring to a she-camel] Verily she is one that has ability for journeying. (M.)

1 saAqa AlmaAXiyapa c
1. saAqa AlmaAXiyapa, (S, K,) or AlnRaEama, (Mgh,) or AldRaAbRapa, (Msb,) aor. yasuwqu, (S, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. sawoqN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and siyaAqN, (S, [so in both of my copies, but it is said in the JK that this latter is used in relation to death, and such is generally the case,]) or sayaAqN, like saHaAbN, (TA, [but this I have not found elsewhere, and I doubt its correctness,]) and siyaAqapN and masaAqN, (O, K, TA,) He drove the cattle [or the beast]; he urged the cattle [or the beast] to go; (Mgh;) and AstAqhA↓ signifies the same, (S, K,) as also AsAqhA↓, and swRqhA↓; (TA;) or tasowiyqN, the inf. n. [or this last], signifies the driving well: (KL:) [and accord. to Freytag, AstsAq↓, followed by an accus., signifies the same as saAqa as expl. above; but for this he names no authority.] Hence, in the Kur [lxxv. 30], UilaI rabRika yawomaYicK AlmasaAqu (TA) i. e. To thy Lord, and his judgment, on that day, shall be the driving. (Bd, Jel.) And the saying, in a trad., laAtaquwmu AlsRaAEapu HatRaI yaxoruja rajulN mino qaHoTaAna yasuwqu AlnRaAsa biEaSFAhu [properly rendered The resurrection, or the hour thereof, shall not come to pass until a man come forth from the tribe of Kahtán driving the people with his staff], allusive to his having the mastery over them, and their obeying him; the staff being mentioned only to indicate his tyrannical and rough treatment of them. (TA.) [And hence the saying, sAq EalaIRa fulaAnFA (assumed tropical:) He urged such a one to intercede for him with me.] ― -b2- [Hence also,] saAqahu Alqadaru UilaI maA qudRira lahu (assumed tropical:) [Destiny drove him, or impelled him, to that which was destined for him]. (TA.) [And in like manner one says of desire, &c.] ― -b3- And sAq UilaI AlmaroOapi mahorahaA, (K,) or SadaAqahaA, (S, Msb,) inf. n. siyaAqN; (TA;) and AsAqhu↓; (Msb, K;) (tropical:) He sent to the woman her dowry; (K, TA;) or conveyed it, or caused it to be conveyed, to her; (Msb;) though consisting of dirhems or deenárs; because the dowry, with the Arabs, originally consisted of camels, which are driven. (TA.) And hence, maAsuqota UilayohaA, meaning (assumed tropical:) What didst thou give her as her dowry? occurring in a trad.; or, as some related it, maA suqota minohaA, i. e. What didst thou give for her, or in exchange for her? (TA.) And sAq Uilayohi AlXRaIoCa (assumed tropical:) [He made, or caused, the thing to go, pass, or be conveyed or transmitted, to him; he sent to him the thing]. (M and K in art. AtI.) And sAq Uilayohi xayorFA (tropical:) [He caused good, or good fortune, to betide him]. (TA.) And sAq liOaroDihi OatiyRFA (assumed tropical:) [He made a rivulet, or a channel for water, to run to his land], (M in art. AtI.) ― -b4- [Hence likewise,] saAqati AlrRiyHu AlsRaHaAba (tropical:) [The wind drove along the clouds]. (S, * TA.) ― -b5- [And sAq AlHadiyva, inf. n. siyaAqN and sawoqN and masaAqN, (tropical:) He carried on the narrative, or discourse.] You say, fulaAnN yasuwqu AlHadiyva OaHosana siyaAqK (tropical:) [Such a one carries on the narrative, or discourse, in the best manner of doing so]. (Mgh, TA.) And Uilayoka yusaAqu AlHadiyvu (tropical:) [To thee as its object the narrative, or discourse, is carried on]. (TA.) And kalaAmN masaAquhu UilaI kacaA (tropical:) [Speech whereof the
carrying-on is pointed to such a thing]. (TA.) And jiYotuka biAlHadiyvi EalaI sawoqihi (tropical:) [I uttered to thee the narrative, or discourse, after the proper manner of the carrying-on thereof]. (TA.) [In like manner also one says,] sAq AlOumuwra OaHosana masaAqK (assumed tropical:) [He carried on, or prosecuted, affairs, or the affairs, in the best manner of doing so]. (A in art. Hwc.) ― -b6- sawoqu AlmaEoluwmi masaAqa gayorihi [from sAq AlHadiyva expl. above] means (assumed tropical:) The asking respecting that which one knows in the manner of one's asking respecting that which he knows not: a mode of speech implying hyperbole: as when one says, Oawajohuka hecaA Oamo badorN [Is this thy face or a full moon?]. (Kull p. 211.) ― -b7- sAq said of a sick man, (K,) and sAq nafosahu, [app. thus originally,] (Ks, Msb, TA,) and sAq binafosihi, (TA,) aor. yasuwqu, (Ks, S, O, Msb, TA,) inf. n. siyaAqN, (S, O, Msb, K,) originally siwaAqN, (TA,) and sawoqN (O, K) and suWuwqN, (TA,) (tropical:) He cast forth, or vomited, his soul; (Ks, TA;) he gave up his spirit; or was at the point of death, in the agony of death, or at the point of having his soul drawn forth; (S, O, Msb, TA;) or he began to give up his spirit, or to have his soul drawn forth. (K.) You say, raOayotu fulaAnFA yasuwqu (tropical:) I saw such a one giving up his spirit at death. (S, O, TA.) And raOayotu fulaAnFA biAlsRawoqi [or fiI AlsRiyaAqi, as in the Msb,] (tropical:) I saw such a one in the act [or agony] of death; and yusaAqu [having his soul expelled], inf. n. sawoqN: and UinRa nafosahu latusaAqu (tropical:) [Verily his soul is being expelled]. (ISh, TA.) ＝ -A2- saAqahu, (K,) first pers. suqotuhu, (S,) aor. as above, inf. n. sawoqN, (TA,) also signifies He hit, or hurt, his (another man's, S) saAq [or shank]. (S, K.)

2 swRq c
2. swRq, inf. n. tasowiyqN: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- swRq fulaAnFA Oamorahu (assumed tropical:) He made such a one to have the ruling, or ordering, of his affair, or case. (Ibn- 'Abbád, K.) ― -b3- See also 5. ＝ -A2- Said of a plant, (TA,) or of a tree, (K,) more properly of the former, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) It had a saAq [i. e. stem, stock, or trunk]. (K, TA.)

3 sAwqhu c
3. sAwqhu He vied, or competed, with him, in driving: (K: [in the CK, for fI AlsRawoqi, is put fI AlsRuwoqi:]) or he vied, or competed, with him to decide which of them twain was the stronger; from the phrase qaAmati AlHarobu EalaI saAqK. (S.) [Hence,] one says baEiyrN yusaAwiqu AlSRayoda (tropical:) [A camel that vies with the animals of the chase in driving on, or in strength]. (JK, Ibn-'Abbád, O, K, TA.) ― -b2- musaAwaqapN is also syn. with mutaAbaEapN [app. as meaning (assumed tropical:) The making to be consecutive, or successive, for it is added], as though driving on one another, or as though one portion were driving on another. (TA. [See 6, its quasi-pass.].) ― -b3- [Freytag also assigns to sAwq the meaning of He, or it, followed (secutus fuit), as on the authority of the Hamáseh; but without pointing out the page; and it is not in his index of words explained therein.]

4 Oasowaqa
4: see 1, in two places. ― -b2- Oasaqotuhu UibilFA I made him to drive camels: (K:) or I gave to him camels, to drive them: (S, TA:) or (tropical:) I made him to posses camels. (TA.)

5 tswRq Alqawomu c
5. tswRq Alqawomu The people, or party, [trafficked in the suwq, or market; or] sold and bought: (S, TA:) the vulgar say sawRaquwA↓. (TA.)

6 tsAwqt AlUibilu c
6. tsAwqt AlUibilu (tropical:) The camels followed one another; (Az, O, Msb, K, TA;) and in like manner one says taqaAwadat; (O, K, * TA;) as though, by reason of their weakness and leanness, some of them held back from others. (TA.) And tsAwqt Alganamu (tropical:) The sheep, or goats, pressed, one upon another, (K,) or followed one another, (O,) in going along, (O, K,) as though driving on one another. (O.) [See also 7.] ― -b2- The lawyers say, tsAwqt AlxiTobataAni, meaning (tropical:) [The two demandings of a woman in marriage] were simultaneous: but [Fei says] I have not found it in the books of lexicology in this sense. (Msb.)

7 AnsAqt AlmaAXiyapu c
7. AnsAqt AlmaAXiyapu The cattle went, or went along, being driven; [or as though driven; or drove along;] quasi-pass. of saAqahaA. (S, TA.) And AnsAqt AlUibilu [has the like signification: or means] (assumed tropical:) The camels became consecutive. (TA. [See also 6.])

8 Uisotawaqa
8: see 1, first sentence.

10 Uisotasowaqa
10: see 1, first sentence.

saAqN c
saAqN The shank; i. e. the part between the knee and the foot of a human being; (Msb;) or the part between the ankle and the knee (K, TA) of a human being; (TA;) the sAq of the human foot: (S, TA:) and [the part properly corresponding thereto, i. e. the thigh commonly so called, and also the arm, of a beast;] the part above the waZiyf of the horse and mule and ass and camel, and the part above the kuraAE of the ox-kind and sheep or goat and antelope: (TA:) [it is also sometimes applied to the shank commonly so called, of the hind leg, and, less properly, of the fore leg, of a beast: and to the bone of any of the parts above mentioned: and sometimes, by synecdoche, to the hind leg, and, less properly, to the fore leg also, of a beast: it generally corresponds to ciraAEN: of a bird, it is the thigh commonly so called: and sometimes the shank commonly so called: and, by synecdoche, the leg:] it is of the fem. gender: (Msb, TA:) and for this reason, (TA,) the dim. is suwayoqapN↓: (Msb, TA:) the pl. [of mult.] is suwqN (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K) and siyqaAnN and [of pauc.] OasoWuqN, (S, O, K,) the w in this last being with C in order that it may bear the dammeh. (O, K.) A poet says,
lilofataI EaqolN yaEiyXu bihi
Hayovu tahodiI saAqahu qadamuho
meaning The young man has intelligence whereby he lives when his foot directs aright his shank. (IAar, TA.) And one says of a man when difficulty, or calamity, befalls him, kaXafa Eano saAqihi [lit. He uncovered his shank; meaning (assumed tropical:) he prepared himself for difficulty]: so says IAmb: and hence, he says, (TA, [in which a similar explanation is cited from ISd also,]) they mention the sAq when they mean to express the difficulty of a case or an event, and to tell of the terror occasioned thereby. (K, TA.) Thus, the saying yawoma yukoXafu Eano saAqK, (S, K, TA,) in the Kur [lxviii. 42], (S, TA,) [lit. On a day when a shank shall be uncovered,] means (assumed tropical:) on a day when difficulty, or calamity, shall be disclosed. (I'Ab, Mujáhid, S, K, TA.) It is like the saying, qaAmati AlHarobu EalaI saAqK, (S, TA,) which means (assumed tropical:) The war, or battle, became vehement, (Msb in this art. and in art. Hrb,) so that safety from destruction was difficult of attainment: (Id. in art. Hrb:) and kaXafati AlHarobu Eano saAqK, [as also XamRarato Eano saAqihaA,] i. e. (assumed tropical:) The war, or battle, became vehement. (Jel in lxviii. 42.) And in like manner, waQlotafRati QlsRaAqu biAlsRaAqi, (K, TA,) in the Kur [lxxv. 29], (TA,) means (assumed tropical:) And the affliction of the present state of existence shall be combined with that of the final state: (K, TA:) or it means when the [one] leg shall be inwrapped with the other leg by means of the grave-clothes. (TA.) One says also, qaAma Alqawomu EalaI saAqK (assumed tropical:) The people or party, became in a state of toil, and trouble, or distress. (TA.) And qaraEa liloOamori saAqahu, [originating from one's striking the shin of his camel in order to make him lie down to be mounted; lit. He struck his shank for the affair;] meaning (assumed tropical:) he prepared himself for the thing, or affair; syn. taXamRara: (JK:) or he was, or became, light, or active, and he rose, or hastened, to do the thing; or (assumed tropical:) he applied himself vigorously, or diligently, or with energy, to the thing, or affair; i. q. XamRara lahu [q. v.]; (TA;) or tajarRada lahu. (A and TA in art. qrE [q. v.: see also ZunobuwbN, in several places].) [It is also said that] Oawohato bisaAqK means kidotu OafoEalu [i. e. I nearly, or almost, did what I purposed: but this explanation seems to have been derived only from what here, as in the TA, immediately follows]: Kurt says, describing the wolf,
walekinRiI ramayotuka mino baEiydK
falamo OafoEalo waqado Oawohato bisaAqi
[i. e., app., But I shot at thee from afar, and I did not what I purposed, though it (the shot, AlrRamoyapu, I suppose, being meant to be understood,) maimed a shank: which virtually means, though I nearly did what I purposed: the poet, I assume, says Awht bsAq for the sake of the measure and rhyme, for Oawohato saAqFA: see what is said, in the explanations of the preposition bi, respecting the phrase waQmosaHuwA biruWuLsikumo]. (TA.) ― -b2- By a secondary application, saAqN signifies (assumed tropical:) [A greave; i. e.] a thing that is worn on the sAq [or shank] of the leg, made of iron or other material. (Mgh.) ― -b3- Also (tropical:) [The stem, stock, or trunk, i. e.] the part between the OaSol [here meaning root, or foot, (though it is also syn. with sAq in the sense in which the latter is here explained,)] and the place where the branches shoot out; (TA;) or the support; (Msb;) or the jicoE; (S, K;) of a tree, or shrub: (S, Msb, K, TA:) pl. [of mult.] suwqN (Msb, TA) and suwqN and suwuwqN and suWuwqN
and [of pauc.] OasowuqN and OasoWuqN. (TA.) It is related in a trad. of Mo'áwiyeh, that a man said, I applied to him to decide in a litigation with the son of my brother, and began to overcome him therein; whereupon he said, Thou art like as Aboo-Duwád says,
OanRaI OutiyHa lahu HirobaMCu tanoDubapK
laA yurosilu AlsRaAqa UilRaA mumosikFA saAqaA
[Whencesoever, or however, a preparation is made for him, to catch him, he is like a chameleon of a tree of the kind called tanoDub, he will not loose the stem thereof unless grasping a stem]: he meant that no plea of his came to nought but he clung to another; likening him to the chameleon, which places itself facing the sun, and ascends half-way up the tree, or shrub, then climbs to the branches when the sun becomes hot, then climbs to a higher branch, and will not loose the former until it grasps the other. (O, TA. *) ― -b4- [Hence, perhaps, as it seems to be indicated in the O,] one says, waladato fulaAnapu valaAvapa baniyna EalaI saAqK, (K, [in the copies of which, however, I find valaAva put for valaAvapa,]) or EalaI saAqK waAHidK, (S,) or waAHidapK, (O,) i. e. (tropical:) Such a woman brought forth three sons, one after another, without any girl between them: (S, O, K, TA:) so says ISk: and wulida lifulaAnK valaAvapu OawolaAdK saAqFA EalaI saAqK, i. e. (tropical:) Three children were born to such a one, one after another. (TA.) And banaI Alqawomu buyuwtahumo EalaI saAqK waAHidK (assumed tropical:) [The people, or party, built their houses, or constructed their tents, in one row or series]. (TA.) ― -b5- saAqN also signifies (assumed tropical:) The soul, or self; syn. nafosN: hence the saying of 'Alee (in the war of the [schismatics called] XuraAp), laAbudRa liI mino qitaAlihimo walawo talifato saAqiI (assumed tropical:) [There is not for me any way of avoiding combating them, though my soul, or self, should perish by my doing so]. (Abu-l-' Abbás, O, TA.) So too in the saying, qadaHa fiI saAqihi [as though meaning (tropical:) He cankered his very soul]: (IAar, TA in art. qdH:) [or] he deceived him, and did that which was displeasing to him: (L in that art.:) or (tropical:) he impugned his honour, or reputation; from the action of canker-worms (qawaAdiH) cankering the stem, or trunk, of a shrub, or tree. (A in that art.) ＝ -A2- saAqu HurRK [is said to signify] The male of the qamaAriIR [or species of collared turtle-doves of which the female is called qumoriyRapN (see qumoriIRN)]; (S, Msb, K;) i. e. the waraXaAn: (S, Msb:) the former appellation being given to it as imitative of its cry: (As, K:) it has neither fem. nor pl.: (AHát, TA:) or AlsRaAqu is the pigeon; and AlHurRu, its young one: (Sh, K:) the poet Ibn-Harmeh uses the phrase kasaAqi Qboni HurRK. (O, TA.) [See more in art. Hr.]

sawoqN c
sawoqN: see siyaAqN.

suwqN c
suwqN [A market, mart, or fair;] a place in which commerce is carried on; (ISd, Msb, TA;) a place of articles of merchandise: (Mgh, TA:) so called because people drive their commodities thither: (TA:) [in the S unexplained, and in the K only said to be well-known:] of the fem. gender, and masc., (S, Mgh, Msb, K, *) the former in the dial. of the people of El-Hijáz, and the latter in that of Temeem, (S and Msb voce zuqaAqN, q. v.,) the former the more chaste, or the making it masc. is a mistake: (Msb:) pl. OasowaAqN: (TA:) the dim. is suwayoqapN↓ [with p, confirming the opinion of those who hold suwqN to be only fem.]: also signifying merchandise, syn. tijaArapN; as in the phrase, jaACato suwayoqapN [Merchandise came]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] suwqu AlHarobi (tropical:) The thickest, or most vehement part (Hawomap) of the fight; (S, K, TA;) and so AlHarobi suwqapu↓; i. e. the midst thereof. (TA.)

sawaqN c
sawaqN Length of the shanks: (S, K:) or beauty thereof: (K:) or it signifies also beauty of the shank. (S.)

saAqapN c
saAqapN (tropical:) The rear, or hinder part, of an army: (S, Mgh, K, TA:) pl. of saAYiqN↓; being those who drive on the army from behind them, and who guard them: (TA:) or as though pl. of saAYiqN, like as qaAdapN is of qaAYidN. (Mgh.) And hence, saAqapu AlHaAjRi (tropical:) [The rear of the company of pilgrims]. (TA.)

suwqapN c
suwqapN (assumed tropical:) A subject, and the subjects, of a king; (K, TA;) so called because driven by him; (TA;) contr. of malikN; (S, Mgh, Msb;) whether practising traffic or not: (Mgh:) not meaning of the people of the OasowaAq [or markets], as the vulgar think; (Msb;) for such are called suwqiyRuwna, sing. suwqiIRN: (Ham p. 534:) it is used alike as sing. and pl. (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and dual (Mgh, Msb) and masc. and fem.: (S, K:) but sometimes it has suwaqN for its pl. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- suwqapu AlTRurovuwvi [in the CK, erroneously, AltRurovuwvi] The part of the [plant called] Trvwv that is below the nikoEap [or nakaEap or nukaEap, which is the head from the top to the extent of a finger, or the flower at the head thereof]; (O, K;) sweet and pleasant: so says Ibn-' Abbád: (O:) AHn says [of the Trvwv], it is like the penis of the ass, and there is no part of it more pleasant, nor sweeter, than its swqp; which is in some instances long; and in some, short. (TA.) ＝ -A3- See also suwqN, last sentence.

suwqiIRN c
suwqiIRN [Of, or relating to, the suwq, or market]. Its pl., suwqiyRuwna, means The people of the suwq (Ham p. 534.) ― -b2- [Hence,] OadiymN suwqiIRN A skin, or hide, prepared, or dressed; in a good state: or not prepared or dressed: it is ascribed to the vulgar: and there is a difference of opinion respecting it: the second [explanation, or meaning,] is that which is commonly known. (TA.)

sawiyqN c
sawiyqN Meal of parched barley (XaEiyr), or of [the species thereof, or similar grain, called] sulot, likewise parched; and it is also of wheat; but is mostly made of barley (XEyr); (MF, TA;) what is made of wheat or of barley; (Msb, TA;) well known: (S, Msb, K, TA:) [it is generally made into a kind of gruel, or thick ptisan, being moistened with water, or clarified butter, or fat of a sheep's tail, &c.; (see latRa;) and is therefore said (in the Msb in art. Hsw and in the KT voce OakolN, &c.,) to be supped, or sipped, not eaten: but it is likewise thus called when dry; and in this state is taken in the palm of the hand and conveyed to the mouth, or licked up: (see HaAfRq, and qamiHa:) it is also made of other grains beside those mentioned above; and of several mealy fruits; of the fruit of the Theban palm; (see HatiIRN;) and of the carob; (see xarRuwbN;) &c.:] it is also, sometimes, with S: so says IDrd in the Jm: and he adds, I think it to be of the dial. of Benoo-Temeem: it is peculiar to that of Benul-' Ambar: (O, TA:) the n. un. [meaning a portion, or mess, thereof] is with p: (AAF, TA in art. jX:) and the pl. is OasowiqapN. (TA.) ― -b2- And Wine: (AA, K:) also called sawiyqu Alkaromi. (AA, TA.)

siyaAqN c
siyaAqN [an inf. n. of 1 (q. v.) in several senses. ― -b2- As a subst., properly so termed,] (tropical:) A dowry, or nuptial gift; (K, TA;) as also sawoqN↓ [which is likewise originally an inf. n.: see 1]. (TA.) ― -b3- [Also, as a subst. properly so termed, (assumed tropical:) The following part of a discourse &c.; opposed to sibaAqN: you say sibaAqu AlkalaAmi wasiyaAquhu (assumed tropical:) the preceding and following parts of the discourse; the context, before and after: see, again 1. And (assumed tropical:) The drift, thread, tenour, or scope, of a discourse &c.]

suwayoqapN c
suwayoqapN dim. of saAqN, q. v.: (Msb, TA:) ＝ -A2- and of suwqN, also, q. v. (TA.)

sawRaAqN c
sawRaAqN: see saAYiqN. ＝ -A2- Also A seller, and a maker, of sawiyq. (Mgh.)

suwRaAqN c
suwRaAqN Long in the saAq [or shank]. (AA, K. [See also Oasowaqu.]) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) Having a saAq [or stem]; applied to a plant. (Ibn-Abbád, K.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) The TaloE [or spadix] of a palm-tree, when it has come forth, and become a span in length. (K.)

saAYiqN c
saAYiqN [Driving, or a driver;] the agent of the verb in the phrase saAqa AlmaAXiyapa: as also sawRaAqN↓ (S, K) in an intensive sense [as meaning Driving much or vehemently, or a vehement driver]: (S, TA:) pl. of the former saAqapN, q. v. (TA.) maEahaA saAYiqN waXahiydN, in the Kur [l. 20], is said to mean Having with it a driver to the place of congregation [for judgment] and a witness to testify against it of its works: (TA:) i. e. an angel driving it, and another angel testifying of its works: or an angel performing both of these offices: or a writer of evil deeds and a writer of good deeds: or its own person, or its consociate [devil], and its members, or its works. (Bd.)

sayRiqN c
sayRiqN, [originally saywoiqN,] (assumed tropical:) Clouds (saHaAbN, AZ, As, S, K) driven by the wind, (AZ, As, S,) containing no water, (AZ, S, K,) or whether containing water or not. (As.)

sayRiqapN c
sayRiqapN, [a subst. formed from the epithet sayRiqN by the affix p,] originally sayowiqapN, (TA,) Beasts (dawaAbR) driven by the enemy; (S, K;) like wasiyqapN: so in a verse cited voce jabaOa: (S:) or a number of camels, of a tribe, driven away together, or attacked by a troop of horsemen and driven away. (Z, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, AlmaroCu sayRiqapu Alqadari
(assumed tropical:) [Man, or the man, is the impelled of destiny]; i. e. destiny drives him to that which is destined for him, and will not pass him by. (TA.) ― -b3- sayRiqapN signifies also An animal by means of which [in the O bihaA for which fiyhaA is erroneously put in the K,] the sportsman conceals himself, and then shoots, or casts, at the wild animals: (O, K:) like qayRidapN: (A in art. qwd:) said by Th to be a she-camel [used for that purpose]: (TA:) [so called because driven towards the objects of the chase: see dariyoYapN:] pl. sayaAYiqu. (K.) [See also misowaqN.]

Oasowaqu c
Oasowaqu A man (S, * TA) long in the shanks: (S, K: [see also suwRaAqN:]) or thick in the shanks: (IDrd, TA:) or it signifies, (K,) or signifies also, (S,) beautiful in the shank or shanks, (S, K,) applied to a man: and so sawoqaMCu applied to a woman: (S:) Lth explains the latter as meaning a woman having plump shanks, with hair. (TA.)

UisaAqapN c
UisaAqapN (Lth, O, K, in the CK AasaAqp,) The strap of the horse's strirrup. (Lth, O, K.)

baEiyrN misowaqN c
baEiyrN misowaqN, (JK, O, and TA as from the Tekmileh,) or musowiqN, like muHosinN, (K, [but this I think to be a mistake,]) means AlRaciI yusaAwqu AlSRayoda [i. e. (tropical:) A camel that vies with the animals of the chase in driving on, or in strength]; (JK, O, K;) so says Ibn-' Abbád: (O:) accord. to the L, a camel by means of which one conceals himself from the animals of the chase, to circumvent them. (TA. [See also sayRiqapN, last signification.])

misowaqapN c
[misowaqapN A staff, or stick, with which cattle are driven: pl. masaAwiqu: perhaps post-classical.]

munosaAqN c
munosaAqN i. q. taAbiEN [app. as meaning (assumed tropical:) A follower, or servant; as though driven]. (Ibn-' Abbád, O, K.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) A relation; syn. qariybN. (Ibn- ' Abbád, O, K.) ― -b3- And EalamN munosaAqN (assumed tropical:) A mountain extending along the surface of the earth. (Ibn- ' Abbád, O, K *)

1 saAka AlXRaIoCa c
1. saAka AlXRaIoCa, (IDrd, O, Msb, K,) aor. yasuwku, inf. n. suwokN, (IDrd, O, Msb,) He rubbed the thing, or rubbed it well. (IDrd, O, Msb, K.) ― -b2- See also 2. ＝ -A2- And see 6.

2 swRk faAhu c
2. swRk faAhu, (S, O, Msb,) or swRk famahu biAlEuwdi, (K,) inf. n. tasowiykN; (S, O, Msb, K;) and saAkahu↓, (O, K,) aor. and inf. n. as in the first paragraph, (O,) or inf. n. siwaAkN; (Msb; [there said to be an inf. n., as well as a subst. syn. with misowaAkN, but without the mention of its verb;]) and AstAk↓ and tswak↓, these two used without the mention of the mouth (S, O, Msb, K) or the stick; (K;) [He rubbed and cleaned his teeth with the siwaAk, or misowaAk.]

5 tasawRaka
5: see the next preceding paragraph.

6 tasaAwukN c and siwaAkN
6. tasaAwukN siwaAkN [each an inf. n., the verb of the latter, if it have one, being app. saAka↓,] A weak manner of going: or a bad manner of going, resulting from slowness or emaciation: (K, TA:) so says ISk. (TA.) One says, jaMCati AlUibilu tasaAwaku, [for tatasaAwaku,] i. e. The camels came inclining from side to side, in consequence of weakness, in their going along. (S, O.) [Or] tsAwkt AlUibilu means The camels had an agitation of their necks in consequence of leanness. (IF, Msb.) In the M it is said that jaMCat Alganamu maAtasaAwaku means The sheep, or goats, came, not moving their heads, in consequence of weakness. (TA.)

8 Uisotawaka
8: see 2.

siwaAkN c
siwaAkN and misowaAkN↓ signify the same; (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K;) i. e. A tooth-stick; a piece of stick with which the teeth are rubbed [and cleaned, the end being made like a brush by beating or chewing it so as to separate the fibres]; (K, * TA;) [commonly] a piece of stick of the [kind of tree called] OaraAk: (Msb:) accord. to IDrd, derived from sukotu AlXRaIoCa meaning “ I rubbed, or rubbed well, the thing; ” (O, Msb;) accord. to IF, from tsAwkt AlUibilu [expl. above]: (Msb:) accord. to Lth, (T, TA,) siwaAkN is masc. and fem., (IDrd, T, M, O, K,) though it is the more approvable way to make it masc.; (O;) but Az holds this to be a mistake, and the word to be masc. [only]; and Hr says that this assertion of Lth is one of his foul mistakes: (TA:) its pl. is suwukN (S, O, Msb, K) and suwokN (Az, TA) and suWukN, (AHn, TA,) and [of pauc.] OasowikapN; and the pl. of misowaAkN↓ is masaAwiyku. (TA.) In the saying, in a trad., xayoru xilaAli AlSRaAYimi AlsRiwaAku, a prefixed n. is [said to be] suppressed [so that the meaning is The best of the habits, or customs, of the faster is the use of the tooth-stick: but see 2, where siwaAkN is said, on the authority of the Msb, to be also an inf. n.].

misowaAkN c
misowaAkN: see siwaAkN, in two places.

1 saAla c
1. saAla, aor. yasaAlu, (Akh, and S, M, Msb, K, all in art. sOl,) like xaAfa, aor. yaxaAfu, (Msb and K ibid.,) first pers. pret. silotu, [like xifotu,] (Sb, M in the present art., [in the K in this art., erroneously, salotu,]) and aor. OasaAlu, (Sb, M and K in this art.,) imperative salo, (S, Msb, K, TA, all in art. sOl,) dual salaA, and pl. saluwA, these two being irregular, (Msb in that art.,) inf. n. suwaAlN, (M and K in the present art.,) mentioned by Sb and by Th, (M ibid.,) and siwaAlN, (M and K ibid.,) mentioned by Th, (M ibid.,) i. q. saOala [He asked, &c.], (Akh, and S, M, Msb, K, all in art. sOl,) and saOalotu; a dial. var. of the verb with O, (Sb, M and K in the present art.,) the medial radical being originally w, (M and K ibid.,) not a substitute for O, (M ibid.) as is shown by the phrase humaAyatasaAwalaAni, (M and K ibid.,) mentioned by AZ: (M ibid.:) it is of the dial. of Hudheyl. (TA in art. sOl.) [For the pass. (siyla &c.), see saOala.] A certain elegant scholar says,
saAlato hacayolN rasuwla QllRehi faAHiXapF
i. e. [Hudheyl] asked of the Apostle of God as a thing wished for [something beyond measure evil]: it is not from saOala, [i. e. it is originally sawila, not formed from saOala by the substitution of A for O,] as many of the elegant scholars say. (Er-Rághib, TA.) ＝ -A2- sawila, (M, K,) [aor. yasowalu,] inf. n. sawalN, (M,) He, or it, was, or became, lax, flaccid, or uncompact; or it hung down loosely; was, or became, pendent, or pendulous: (M, K:) [or, said of a man, he was, or became, flaccid, or pendulous, in the belly, or in the part of the belly below the navel; as appears from an explanation of Oasowalu and from what here follows:] sawalN, (S, TA,) in the K, erroneously, sawolap↓, (TA,) signifies flaccidity, or uncompactness, or pendulousness, (S, K, TA,) of the belly, (K,) and so tasawRulN↓ and tasawRunN, (TA,) or of the part of the belly below the navel; (S, TA;) and of other things, (K, TA,) as, for instance, (TA,) of a cloud also. (S, TA.)

2 sawRalato lahu nafosuhu OamorFA c
2. sawRalato lahu nafosuhu OamorFA, (S,) or kacaA, (M, K,) or AlXRaIoCa, (Msb,) inf. n. tasowiylN, (TA,) His soul embellished [or commended] to him (S, M, Msb, * K) a thing, or an affair, (S,) or such a thing, (M, K,) or the thing: (Msb:) or made it [to appear] easy to him, and a light matter in his eyes; from sawalN signifying “ laxness ” or the like: (Bd in xii. 18:) the inf. n. signifies the embellishing, a thing, and making it to be loved or approved, in order that one may do it or say it: (TA:) or the soul's embellishing a thing that is eagerly desired, and picturing what is foul thereof as goodly: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and it is said to be from suwlN signifying “ an object of a man's desire, which embellishes to the seeker thereof that which is false, or vain, and other things of the deceptions of the present world. ” (TA.) ― -b2- You say also, yusawRalu UilaIRa kacaA Such a thing is imaged in the mind to me; is an object of fancy to me; or seems to me. (L in art. hd.) ― -b3- And swRl lahu said of the Devil, He led him into error; or made him to err: (M, K:) or facilitated to him the commission of great sins; from sawalN meaning as expl. above in this paragraph: or incited him to indulgence in appetences, or lusts; from AlsRuwlu meaning [by implication] AltRamanRiI: (Bd in xlvii. 27:) or [as though meaning] let down his rope [to him to aid in the accomplishment of his desire]. (Ham p. 748.)

5 tasawRala
5: see 5 in art. sOl: ＝ -A2- and 1, last sentence, in the present art.

6 humaAyatasaAwalaAni c
6. humaAyatasaAwalaAni [They two ask, or beg, each other; i. q. yatasaMCalaAni, q. v.]: (M, K:) a phrase mentioned by AZ. (M.)

suwlN c
suwlN i. q. masoOalapN [as signifying A petition; or a request; meaning a thing that is, or has been, asked, or begged; see suWolN]; (TA;) as also suwlapN↓; (K, TA;) each, (TA,) a dial. var. of the word with C: (K, TA: [but it is also said in the latter that suWolN is the original of suwlN because the readers of the Kur-án read the word with C in chap. xx. verse 36:]) or an object of desire or wish (OumoniyRapN), which one asks; (TA:) or an object
of want, which the soul eagerly desires: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or an object of a man's desire (OumoniyRapN), which embellishes to the seeker thereof that which is false, or vain, and other things of the deceptions of the present world: but there is a difference between suwlN and suwlapN↓ on the one hand and OumoniyRapN on the other hand, in that the former relate to what is sought, or demanded, and AmnyRp relates to what is meditated (qudRira); (TA;) [for] this last primarily signifies “ a thing that a man meditates (yuqadRiruhu) in his mind, ” from manaI signifying qadRara; (Bd in ii. 73;) so that the suwlap↓ seems to be after the OumoniyRap: (TA:) suwlN may be from sawRalato lahu nafosuhu kacaA in the first of the senses assigned to it above, and [from] sawRala said of the Devil in the last of the senses assigned to it above. (Ham p. 748.) [See also suwaAlN, below.]

sawolapN c
sawolapN: see 1, last sentence.

suwlapN c
suwlapN: see suwlN, in three places.

suwalapN c
suwalapN, (M, K,) applied to a man, (M,) One who asks, or begs, much; (K;) i. q. [suWalapN and] saWuwlN. (M.)

suwaAlN c
suwaAlN an inf. n. of saAla as syn. with saOala: (Sb, Th, M, K:) [and used as a simple subst., like suwlN and suwlapN, for] IJ mentions OasowilapN as its pl. (M, TA.)

sawiylN c
sawiylN An equal. (M, K.) So in the saying, OanaA sawiyluka fiI hecaA AlOamori [I am thy equal in this affair]. (M.)

Oasowalu c
Oasowalu Lax, flaccid, or uncompact; or hanging down loosely; or pendent, or pendulous; in the lower part: (M, K:) or a man flaccid, or pendulous, in the part of the belly below the navel: fem. sawolaMCu: and pl. suwlN. (S.) And saHaAbN Oasowalu Clouds that are uncompact, (S, TA,) their skirts, or fringes, hanging down; and in like manner, saHaAYibu suwlN; sing. saHaAbapN sawlaMCu. (TA.) And dalowN sawolaMCu A large bucket. (M, K. *)

1 sawomN c
1. sawomN, inf. n. of saAma, primarily signifies The going, or going away, engaged, or occupied, in seeking, or in seeking for or after, or in seeking to find and take or to get, a thing: and sometimes it is used as meaning the going, or going away; as when it is said of camels [or the like]: and sometimes, as meaning the seeking, or seeking for or after, or seeking to find and take or to get; as when it relates to selling or buying. (Er-Rághib, TA.) ― -b2- You say, saAmati AlmaAXiyapu (S, Mgh, Msb, TA) or AlnRaEamu (M) or AlmaAlu, (K,) aor. tasuwmu, (S, M, Msb,) inf. n. sawomN, (S, M, Mgh, Msb,) The cattle pastured (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K, TA) by themselves (Msb) where they pleased; and in like manner, Alganamu [the sheep or goats]: or went away at random, or roved, pasturing where they pleased. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence, sAm, inf n as above, He did as he pleased.] You say, xalRayotuhu wasawomahu I left him to do as he pleased. (S, M, K * [In the CK, xalRAhu wasawRamahu limaAyuriyduhu is put for xalRaAhu wasawomahu limaA yuriyduhu; and the like is done in one of my copies of the S. See also 2.]) ― -b4- And saAma, (S,) or saAmati AlUibilu, and AlrRiyHu, (M, K,) or AlrRiyaAHu, (S,) inf. n. as above, (S, M,) He, or it, (S,) or the camels, and the wind, (M, K,) or the winds, (S,) passed, went, or went on or along: (S, M, K:) or sawomN signifies the passing, &c., quickly; one says of a she camel, saAmat, aor. and inf. n. as above, she passed, &c., quickly; (As, TA;) and hence the saying of Dhu-l-Bijádeyn cited in art. ErD, voce taEarRaDa: or the passing, &c., quickly, with the desire of making a sound in going along. (TA.) ― -b5- And saAmati AlTRayoru EalaI AlXRaIoCi, (M, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M,) The birds went, [or hovered,] or circled, round about the thing: (M, K:) or, as some say, sawomN signifies any going, [or hovering,] or circling, round about. (M.) ＝ -A2- [As mentioned in the first sentence of this art.,] sawomN is also in selling and buying. (S.) You say, sAm AlsRiloEapa, (Mgh, Msb,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Msb,) He (the seller) offered the commodity, or article of merchandise, (Mgh, Msb:) and it is also said of the purchaser, like AisotaAmahaA↓, (Mgh, Msb,) meaning he sought to obtain the sale of the commodity, or article of merchandise: and one says also of the seller, and of the purchaser, sAm biAlsRiloEapi, meaning he mentioned the price of the commodity [in offering it for sale, and in offering to purchase it]: (Msb:) and in like manner, sumotu fulaAnFA siloEatiI, inf. n. as above, I said to such a one, “ Wilt thou take [or purchase] my commodity for such a price? ” (TA:) and saAmaniI bisiloEatihi he (the seller, Msb) mentioned to me the price of his commodity [in offering it for sale]: (Msb, TA:) [and, agreeably with these explanations,] Kr says that AlsRawomu signifies AlEaroDu [i. e. the act of offering, &c.]: (M, TA:) or sumotu biAlsRiloEapi, inf. n. sawomN (M, K) and suwaAmN, with damm; (K, TK; [in the former only said to be syn. with sawomN in selling and buying;]) and saAwamotu↓, (M, K,) inf. n. siwaAmN; (TA;) and bihaA Aisotamotu↓ and EalayohaA; signify gaAlayotu [which means I offered the commodity for sale, mentioning its price, and was exorbitant in my demand: and also I purchased the commodity for a dear, or an excessive, price: and both these meanings are app. here intended]: (M, K, TA:) and in like manner, AlsRiloEapa Aisotamotuhu↓ [I offered to him the commodity for sale, &c.: and I purchased of him the commodity, &c.]: (TA:) or, as some say, (so in the TA, but in the M and K “ and, ”) this last, as also EalaI AlsRiloEapi, Aisotamotuhu↓, means saOalotuhu sawomahaA↓ [i. e. I asked him the price at which the commodity was to be sold]: (M, K, TA:) and saAmaniyhaA, (M,) or saAwamaniyhaA↓, (TA, [but the former is app. the right,]) means cakara liI sawomahaA↓ [i. e. he mentioned to me the price at which it was to be sold]: (M, TA:) you say also, Ealayohi Aisotamotu↓ bisiloEatiI when you mention the price of the commodity [i. e. it means I mentioned to him the price at which I would sell my commodity]: and you say, minRiI siloEatiI AisotaAma↓ when he is the person who offers to thee the price [i. e. it means he offered to me a price for my commodity; or he sought to obtain from me the sale of my commodity by offering a price for it]: (TA:) and EalaIRa AisotaAma↓ he contended [by bidding] against me in a sale: (S, * PS:) or EalaIRa AlsRiloEapa AisotaAma↓, which means AstAm EalaI sawomiI [i. e. he sought to obtain the sale of the commodity in opposition to me, or to my seeking it]. (Msb. [See also 3.]) Hence, [Mo- hammad is related to have said,] laA yasuwmu AlrRajulu EalaI sawomi Oaxiyhi, (Mgh,) or lAyswm OaHadukumo ElI swm Axyh, (Msb,) i. e. [The man, or any one of you,] shall not purchase [in opposition to his brother]: (Mgh, Msb:) and it may mean shall not sell; the case being that of a man's offering to the purchaser his commodity for a certain price, and another's then saying, “ I have the like thereof for less than this price: ” so that the prohibition relates in common to the seller and the buyer: (M:) and the saying is also related otherwise, i. e. laAyasotaAmu↓, meaning shall not purchase. (Mgh.) And it is said in a trad., nahaI Eani AlsRawomi qabola TuluwEi AlXRamosi, meaning, accord. to Aboo-Is-hák, Oano bisiloEatihi yusaAwima↓ [i. e. He (Mohammad) forbade the offering a commodity for sale before the rising of the sun]; because that is a time in which God is to be praised, and one should not be diverted by other occupation: or, he says, it may mean the pasturing of camels; because, before sunrise, when the pasturage is moist with dew, it occasions a fatal disease. (TA.) You say also, sumotuka HasanapF baEiyraka siymapF↓ [I have mentioned to thee a good price for thy camel]. (S.) And fiyhi AisotaAma↓ gaAliyapF siymapF↓ [He demanded for it a dear price]. (TA in art. Hvr.) And saAmahu biEamalK [He made to him an offer of working, mentioning the rate of payment; or bargained, or contracted, with him for work]. (K in art. Eml. [See also 3.]) ― -b2- The Arabs also say, EaraDa EalaIRa sawoma EaAlRapK [He offered to me in the manner of offering water to camels taking a second draught]; meaning like the saying of the vulgar, EaroDa saAbiriIRK: (Ks, TA: [see art. sbr:]) a prov. applied to him who offers to thee that of which thou hast no need. (Sh, TA. [See also art. El; and see Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 84.]) ― -b3- And you say, saAmahu AlOmora, (M, K,) aor. as above, (TA,) inf. n. sawomN, (M, TA,) He imposed upon him, or made him to undertake, the affair, as a task, or in spite of difficulty or trouble or inconvenience; or he ordered, required, or constrained, him to do the thing, it being difficult or troublesome or inconvenient: (M, K, TA:) or he brought upon him the affair, or event; (Zj, M, K, TA;) as also sawRamahu↓, (K,) inf. n. tasowiymN: (TA:) or he endeavoured to induce him, or incited him, or made him, to do, or to incur, the affair, or event: (Sh, TA:) it is mostly used in relation to punishment, and evil, (Zj, M, K, TA,) and wrong-doing: and hence the saying in the Kur [ii. 46 and vii. 137 and xiv. 6], yasuwmuwnakumo suwoCa QloEacaAbi They bringing upon you evil punish-
ment or torment: (Zj, M, TA:) or seeking, or desiring, for you evil punishment: (Ksh and Bd in ii. 46:) or endeavouring to induce you to incur it: (Ksh ibid.:) from saAmahu xasofFA [expl. by what here follows]. (Ksh and Bd ibid.) You say, sumotuhu xasofFA I brought upon him xasof [i. e. wrong, or wrong treatment, as expl. in the Ksh and by Bd ubi suprà]: or I endeavoured to induce him to incur it (Oaradotuhu Ealayohi): (S:) [see also xasofN: and sumotuhu xuTRapa xasofK; expl. in art. xT:] and siyma Alxasofa He was constrained to incur, or to do, what is termed Alxasof [meaning abasement or ignominy, or that which was difficult]: (TA:) and sumotuhu culRFA I abased him. (Msb.) ＝ -A3- saAmahu, aor. as above, also signifies He kept, or clave, to it, not quitting it. (M, * TA.) ＝ -A4- See also 4.

2 swRm Alxayola c
2. swRm Alxayola, (S, K,) or AlUibila, (M,) [inf n. tasowiymN,] He sent forth (S, M, K) the horses, (S, K,) or the camels, (M,) [sometimes meaning] to the pasturage, to pasture where they would. (TA. [See also 4.]) ― -b2- [Hence,] swRmhu means xalRaAhu wasawomahu, (AZ, S, M, K,) i. e. [He left him] to do as he pleased; namely, a man. (AZ, S, K. [In the CK is a mistranscription in this place, before mentioned: see 1, fourth sentence.]) Whence the prov., EabodN wasuwRima A slave, and he has been left to do as he pleases. (TA.) ― -b3- And sawRamotu fulaAnFA fiI maAliI I gave such a one authority to judge, give judgment, pass sentence, or decide judicially, respecting my property. (AO, S: and in like manner sawRmhu fiI maAlihi is expl. in the M and K.) And sawRamotuhu OamoriI I made him to have the ordering and deciding of my affair, or case, to do what he would; like sawRafotuhu OamoriI. (TA in art. swf.) ― -b4- And swRm EalaI Alqawomi He urged his horses [xayolahu being understood] against the people, or party, and made havoc among them. (S, K.) ― -b5- And tasowiymN signifies also The making a horse to sweat well. (KL.) ― -b6- See also 1, in the last quarter of the paragraph. ＝ -A2- And swRm Alfarasa, (M, K,) inf. n. tasowiymN, (K,) He put a mark upon the horse: (M, K:) he marked the horse with a piece of silk (bHryrp [perhaps a mistranscription for biHadiydapK i. e. with an iron such as is used for branding]), or with something whereby he should be known. (Lth, TA.) See also 5. [And see 4.]

3 saAwamotuhu c
3. saAwamotuhu (S, Msb) biAlsRiloEapi (MA) [and fiI AlsRiloEapi agreeably with what here follows and with an ex. in art. bkr], inf. n. siwaAmN (S, Msb) and musaAwamapN, (TA,) [I bargained, or chaffered, with him, or] I contended with him in bargaining, or chaffering, for the commodity, or article of merchandise, (MA, Msb, * TA,) and in deciding the price: (TA:) and tasaAwamonaA↓ (S, Msb, TA *) fiI AlsRiloEapi (TA) [and biAlsRilaEapi agreeably with what here precedes] We bargained, or chaffered, for the commodity, or article of merchandise, [or contended in doing so,] one offering it for a certain price, and another demanding it for a lower price. (Msb.) See also 1, in three places.

4 AsAm AlmaAXiyapa c
4. AsAm AlmaAXiyapa, (S, Mgh, Msb,) or AlUibila, (M, K,) inf. n. UisaAmapN, (Mgh,) He pastured the cattle, or the camels: (M, Mgh, K, TA:) or he sent forth, or took forth, the cattle, or the camels, to pasture: (S, TA:) or he made the cattle [or the camels] to pasture by themselves [where they pleased (see 1)]: (Msb:) and [in like manner] AlUibila sumotu↓ I left the camels to pasture [by themselves where they pleased]. (Th, TA. [See also 2.]) Hence, in the Kur [xvi. 10], fiyhi tusiymuwna (S) Upon which ye pasture your beasts. (Jel.) ― -b2- [And accord. to Freytag, AsAm occurs in the Deewán of Jereer as meaning He urged a horse to run: or, as some say, he marked a horse with some sign. See also 2.] ― -b3- AsAm Uilayohi bibaSarihi He cast his eye, or eyes, at him, or it. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also saAmapN.

5 tswRm c
5. tswRm He set a mark, token, or badge, upon himself, whereby he might be known [in war &c.]. (S.) In a trad. (S, TA) respecting [the battle of] Bedr, (TA,) occur the words, tasawRamuwA faUinRa AlmalaAYikapa qadE tasawRamato, (S, TA,) or fAnR AlmlAYkp qd sawRimuwA↓ sawRamato, accord. to different relations; i. e. Make ye a mark, token, or badge, for yourselves, whereby ye may know one another [in the fight, for the angels that are assisting you have done so]. (TA.)

6 tasaAowama
6: see 3.

8 tusotaAmu c
8. tusotaAmu musotaAmapN↓, (M,) or OaroDN tusotaAmu fiyhaA AlUibilu, (TA,) means A land in which the camels pasture by themselves where they please (tasuwmu fiyhaA): (M:) or a land into which they go away [to pasture]. (TA.) [See also masaAmN.] ＝ -A2- AstAm AlsRloEapa: &c.: see 1, in ten places.

saAmN c
saAmN Death: (IAar, S, M, Mgh:) and saAmapN [as its n. un.] a death: (IAar, TA:) but the former [signifies the same in Pers., and] is said to be not Arabic. (TA.) It is related in a trad., respecting the salutation of the Jews, that they used to say, AlsRaAmu Ealayokumo [Death come upon you, instead of AlsRalaAmu Ealayokumo]; and that he [i. e. Mo- hammad] used to reply, Ealayokumo; accord. to the generality of the relaters, waEalayokumo, but correctly without the w, because the w implies participation: and it is related of 'Áïsheh that she used to say to them, Ealayokumu AlsRaOomu waAlcRaOomu waAllRaEonapu, as mentioned in art. sOm: (TA:) the Jews are also related to have said [to the Muslims], Ealayokumu AlsRaAmu AldRaAmu meaning Almawotu AldRaAYimu. (TA in art. dwm: see daAYimN in that art.) ＝ -A2- Also A kind of tree, of which are made the masts (OadoqaAl [pl. of daqalN]) of ships: (Kr, M, TA:) accord. to Sh, (TA,) the [tree called] xayozuraAn. (K, TA. [And accord. to some copies of the K, saAmapN also has this signification, and the signification expl. in the sentence here next following: but accord. to the text of the K as given in the TA, waAlsRaAmapu has been erroneously substistituted in the copies above referred to for waAlsRaAqapu, which, by reason of what precedes it, means that saAmapN also signifies the same as saAqapN; and if the former reading were right, the context in the K would imply that AlsAmp is also the name of a son of Noah, which is incorrect; the name of that son being only saAmN.]) ＝ -A3- Also A [hollow, or cavity, in the ground, such as is called] nuqorap, in which water remains, or stagnates, and collects. (K. [For the verb in this explanation, which is written yunoqaEu in the CK and in my MS. copy of the K, I read yanoqaEu.]) ＝ -A4- Also a pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] of which the sing. [or n. un.] is saAmapN: (M, K:) the former signifies Veins of gold: and the latter, a single vein thereof: (S:) or the latter, a vein in a mountain, differing from its [general] nature; (M, K;) if running from east to west, not failing of its promise to yield silver: (M:) or the former, (M,) or latter, (K, TA,) gold, and silver; (M, K, TA;) accord. to As and IAar: (M, TA:) or, as some say, an ingot of gold, and of silver: (TA:) or veins of gold, and of silver, in the stone [or rock]: (M, K:) En-Nábighah El-Jaadee, (M,) or Edh-Dhubyánee, (TA,) uses AlsAm as meaning silver; for he likens thereto a woman's front teeth in respect of their whiteness: (M, TA:) and Aboo-Sa'eed says that silver is called in Pers. siymo, and in Ar. saAmN: (TA:) but the meaning most commonly known is gold. (M, TA.) A poet says, (M,) namely, Keys Ibn-El-Khateem, (S,)
lawa QnRaka tuloqiI HanoZalFA fawoqa bayoDinaA
tadaHoraja Eano ciI saAmihi AlmutaqaAribi
(S, M,) [i. e. If thou threwest colocynths upon our helmets, they would roll along from what is gilded thereof, they being near together: lawa QnRaka is for lawo OanRaka: and] the h in saAmihi relates to the byD [which are described as] gilded therewith: (S:) the poet is describing the party as being close together in fight, so that colocynths, notwithstanding their smoothness and the evenness of their parts, if they fell upon their heads, would not reach the ground. (Th, S, * M.)

sawomN c
sawomN [is originally an inf. n.: see 1, passim: ＝ -A2- and is also used as a subst. signifying The price of any commodity, or article of merchandise; like siymapN↓ and suwmapN↓]. You say, saOalotuhu sawomahaA, and cakara liI sawomahaA, referring to a siloEap [or commodity]: see 1, in the former half of the paragraph. And HasanapF sumotuka baEiyraka siymapF↓, and AisotaAma gaAliyapF fiyhi siymapF↓: see again 1, in the latter half of the paragraph. And UinRahu lagaAliI AlsRiymapi↓ (S, M, K) and AlsRuwmapi↓, meaning AlsRawomi [i. e. Verily it is dear in price]. (M, K.) siymapN↓ and suwmapN↓ are both substs. from saAma as used in the phrase saAmaniI AlrRajulu bisiloEatihi [and the like]; (TA;) syn. with qiymapN. (Har p. 435 in explanation of the former.)

saAmapN c
saAmapN [as n. un. of saAmN: see the latter, first sentence, and last but one. ＝ -A2- Also] A Hafor, (M, and so in copies of the K,) or Huforap, (K accord. to the TA,) [i. e. hollow dug in the ground, app. to be filled with water for cattle,] by a well (EalaI rakiyRapK): its pl. is siyamN [originally siwamN]: and you say, OasaAmahaA↓, (M, K, TA,) inf. n. UisaAmapN, meaning He dug it [i. e. the sAmp]. (TA.) ＝ -A3- Also i. q. saAqapN [q. v.], (K, accord. to the TA, [as mentioned above, see saAmN,]) on the authority of IAar. (TA.)

suwmapN c
suwmapN; see sawomN, in three places. ＝ -A2- Also, (S,
M, K,) and siymapN↓ (M, K) and siymaI↓, also written siymaA, (S, M, K, TA, but omitted in some copies of the K,) and siymaMCu↓ and siymiyaMCu↓, (S, M, K,) the last mentioned by As, (TA,) [and it occurs with tenween by poetic license, being properly like kiboriyaMCu, a rare form, q. v.,] A mark, sign, token, or badge, by which a thing is known, (S, * M, K,) or by which the good is known from the bad: (TA:) accord. to J, (TA,) the suwmap is a mark, &c., that is put upon a sheep or goat, and such as is used in war or battle; (S, TA;) whence the verb tasawRama [q. v.]: (S:) and accord. to IAar the siymap↓ is a mark upon the wool of sheep; and its pl. is siyamN: [see also simapN, in art. wsm:] accord. to IDrd, one says, Ealayohi siymaI↓ HasanapF, meaning Upon him, or it, is a good mark &c.; and it is from wasamotu, aor. Oasimu; being originally wisomaI; the w being transposed, and changed into I because of the kesreh before it: (TA:) this form occurs in the Kur [xlviii. 29], where it is said, siymaA humo fiI wujuwhihimo [Their mark is upon their faces; and in several other places thereof]. (S.)

siymapN c
siymapN: see sawomN, in five places: ＝ -A2- and see also suwmapN, in two places. [For the meanings “ pactus ” and “ pastum missus, ” assigned to it by Golius, as from the S, and copied by Freytag, I find no foundation.]

siymaI c
siymaI, also written siymaA: see suwmapN, in two places.

siymaMCu c
siymaMCu: see suwmapN.

siymiyaMCu c
siymiyaMCu: see suwmapN. ― -b2- [In the present day it is applied to Natural magic: from the Pers. siymoyaA.]

sawaAmN c
sawaAmN: see saAYimN. ＝ -A2- Also Two small hollows (nuqorataAni) beneath the eye of the horse. (K.) ＝ -A3- [And accord. to Freytag, it occurs in the Deewán el-Hudhaleeyeen in a sense which he explains by “ Malum ” (an evil, &c.).]

suwaAmN c
suwaAmN [The offering a commodity for sale, &c.: see 1. ＝ -A2- Also] A certain bird. (K.)

laAsiyRamaA c
laAsiyRamaA: see art. swI.

saAYimN c
saAYimN [Going, or going away, engaged, or occupied, in seeking, or in seeking for or after, or in seeking to find and take or to get, a thing: (see 1, first sentence:)] going away at random, or roving, wherever he will. (TA.) And [particularly], (S,) as also sawaAmN↓ (As, S, M, K) and saAYimapN, (As, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) Cattle, (maAlN, S, TA, or maAXiyapN, Mgh, Msb,) or camels, (As, M, K, TA,) and sheep or goats, (TA,) pasturing (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K, TA) by themselves (Msb) where they please; (TA;) or sent forth to pasture, and not fed with fodder among the family [to whom they belong]; (As, Mgh, TA;) or pasturing in the deserts, left to go and pasture where they will: (TA:) the pl. of saAYimN and of saAYimapN is sawaAYimu: (S:) the pass. part. n. musaAmN is not used. (Msb.) It is said in a trad., fiI saAYimapi Alganami zakaApN [In the case of pasturing sheep or goats, there is a poor-rate]. (TA.) And in another trad., AlsRaAYimapu jubaArN, i. e. The beast (daAbRap) that is sent away into its place of pasture, if it hurt a human being, the injury committed by it is a thing for which no mulct is exacted. (TA.) And it is related in a trad. respecting the emigration to Abyssinia, that the Nejáshee said to those who had emigrated to his country, AumokuvuwA faOanotumo suyuwmN biOaraDiI, i. e. [Tarry ye, and ye will be] secure [in my land]: IAth says that thus it is explained: and sywm is [said to be] an Abyssinian word: it is related also with fet-h to the s: and some say that suyuwmN is pl. of saAYimN [like as XuhuwdN is said to be of XaAhidN]; i. e., ye shall rove (tasuwmuwna) in my country like the sheep, or goats, pasturing where they please (kaAlganami AlsRaAYimapi), no one opposing you: (TA:) or, as some relate the trad., it is XuyuwmN. (TA in art. Xym.)

masaAmN c
[masaAmN A place where cattle pasture by themselves where they please; a place where they rove about, pasturing: like OaroDN musotaAmapN. ― -b2- Freytag explains it as meaning A place of passage: ― -b3- and A quick passage: from the Deewán el-Hudhaleeyeen.]

masaAmapN c
masaAmapN A wide and thick piece of wood at the bottom of the qaAEidataAni [or two side-posts] of the door. (K.) ― -b2- And A staff in the fore part of the [women's camel-vehicle called] hawodaj. (K.)

Alxayolu AlmusawRamapu c
Alxayolu AlmusawRamapu means The pastured horses: (S, Msb, TA:) or the horses sent forth with their riders upon them: (AZ, Az, Msb, TA:) or it means, (TA,) or means also, (S, Msb,) the marked horses; (S, Msb, TA;) marked by a colour differing from the rest of the colour; or by branding: (TA:) or the horses of goodly make. (Ham p. 62, and TA. [See the Kur iii. 12.]) ― -b2- musawRamiyna, in the Kur [iii. 121], may mean, accord. to Akh, either Marked [by the colours, or the like, of their horses, so as to be distinguished from others], or sent forth; and is thus with y and n [because applied to rational beings, namely, angels, and] because the horses were marked, or sent forth, and upon them were their riders. (S.) ― -b3- And HijaArapF mino TiynK musawRamapF Einoda rabRika, (S, * M, K, *) in the Kur [li. 33 and 34], (S, M,) means [Stones of baked clay] having upon them the semblance of seals [impressed in the presence of thy Lord], (S, K, Er-Rághib,) in order that they may be known to be from God: (Er-Rághib:) or marked (Zj, M, Bd, K, Jel) with whiteness and redness, (Zj, M, K,) as is related on the authority of El-Hasan, (Zj, M,) or with a mark whereby it shall be known that they are not of the stones of this world (M, K) but of the things wherewith God inflicts punishment, (M,) or [each] with the name of him upon whom it is to be cast: (Jel:) or sent forth: (Bd, TA:) but Er-Rághib says that the first is the proper way of explaining it. (TA.)

musotaAmapN c
musotaAmapN, applied to a land (OaroDN): see 8.

5 tasawRuwnN c
5. tasawRuwnN: see 1 in art. swl, last sentence.

1 sawiIa c
1. sawiIa, aor. yasowaI: see 3, in two places. ＝ -A2- [Accord. to Golius, sawaI, inf. n. siwFI, signifies He intended, or proposed to himself: this he says as on the authority of the KL, in which only the inf. n. is mentioned with the explanation qSd wMhnG krdn: and to this, Freytag adds the authority of Meyd; and also that the verb governs the thing which is its objective complement in the accus. case. In the S and other lexicons of good repute, I find the meaning of qaSada assigned to AisotawaI followed by UilaI; but in none to sawaI.]

2 swRAhu c
2. swRAhu, (S, M, &c.,) inf. n. tasowiyapN, (K,) He made it equal, equable, uniform, even, level, flat, plane or plain; (S, * M, MA, Msb, K;) or equal in respect of elevation or of depression; (Er-Rághib, TA;) [and straight, right, direct, or rightly directed; (see its quasi-pass. 8;)] and AswAhu↓ signifies the same; (M, K;) namely, a place, (Msb, K,) or a thing, (S, M, Er-Rághib, TA,) or an uneven, or a crooked, thing. (Mgh.) It is said in a trad., faOamara biAlxirabi fasuwRiyato [And he gave orders respecting the ruins, and they were levelled]. (TA in art. xrb.) And in another trad., sawRayonaA EalaI ruqayRapa, meaning We buried Ru- keiyeh, and made the earth of the grave even, or level, over her. (Mgh.) [Hence also,] suwRiyto Ealayohi AlOaroDu: see 8. And hence the saying in the Kur [iv. 45], luwo tusawRaI bihimu QloOaroDu, (TA,) i. e. That they were buried, and that the ground were made level over them; (S, * Bd;) bi being here syn. with EalaI: (TA in art. b:) or the meaning is, that they became like the dust of the earth; (M, Jel;) thus expl. by Th; (M;) or that they had not been created, and that they and the earth were alike. (Bd.) [Hence also,] balaI qaAdiriyna EalaI Oano nusawRiIa banaAnahu, in the same [lxxv. 4], is said to mean [Yea: we are able] to make his hand like the foot of the camel, without fingers: or to make his fingers uniform, of one measure or size: (TA:) or the meaning is, we are able to put together the bones of his fingers [consistently] as they were. (Bd, Jel.) And bayona HatRaI UicaA saAwaI↓ QlSRadafayoni, in the Kur [xviii. 95], means sawRaI bayonahumaA [i. e. Until, when he had made the space between the two sides of the mountains even, or level, by filling it up]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Also He made it uniform, equal, or consimilar, with another thing.] One says, sawRayotuhu bihi, (M, K,) inf. n. as above; (K;) and bh saAwayotuhu↓, (M, * TA, TK,) and bh Oasowayotuhu↓; I made it uniform, or equal, with it; or like it: (M, K, TA:) and saAwayotu↓ hecaA bicaAka I raised this so as to make it equal in measure, or quantity, or amount, with that. (TA.) And sawRayotu bayonahumaA, and saAwayotu↓, (S, M, K,) I made them uniform, or equal, each with the other; or like each other. (M, K, TA.) ― -b3- [And He made it symmetrical or symmetrically, by, or with, a just adaptation of its component parts; made it congruous or consistent in its several parts, or with congruity or consistency in its several parts: he made it, formed it, or fashioned
it, in a suitable manner: he made it to be adapted, or so as to be adapted, to the exigencies, or requirements, of its case, or of wisdom: he made it complete, or in a complete manner; completed it, or completed its make: he made it right or good, or in a right or good manner; rectified it; adjusted it; or put it into a right, or good, state.] In the Kur xxxii. 8, it means He made him symmetrical [or symmetrically], by the fit, or suitable, formation of his members. (Bd,) And sawRayotuhu in the same, xv. 29 and xxxviii. 72, I made his creation symmetrical: (Bd:) or I completed him, or made him complete. (Jel.) And sawRaI in the same, lxxxvii. 2, He made what He created congruous or consistent in the several parts. (Jel.) And QlRaciI xalaqaka fasawRaAka, in the same [lxxxii. 7], means [Who created thee,] and made thy creation to be adapted to the exigencies, or requirements, of wisdom. (TA.) wanafosK wamaA sawRaAhaA, in the same, [xci. 7, means By a soul and what made it to be adapted to its exigencies, i. e., to the performance of its functions, for it] is indicative of the faculties of the soul: this explanation is more proper than that which makes mA to mean [Him who, i. e.] God. (TA.) And rafaEa samokahaA fasawRaAhaA, in the same, lxxix. 28, means He hath raised high [its canopy, or] the measure of its elevation from the earth, or its thickness upwards, and made it symmetrical, or even, (Bd,) or completed it by adorning it with the stars, (Bd, TA, *) agreeably with what is said in the Kur xxxvii. 6, (TA,) and by means of the revolvings [thereof], &c.: from the saying next following. (Bd.) swRI fulaAnN Oamorahu Such a one rectified, or adjusted, his affair; or put it into a right, or good, state. (Bd in lxxix. 28.) [Hence,] one says, sawRi walaA tusawRiYo Rectify thou, and do not corrupt, or mar. (A and TA in art. swO.) [One says also, swRI AlTRaEaAma He cooked the food thoroughly: see 8 as its quasi-pass.] And swRI fulaAnN manoSuwbapF [Such a one framed a stratagem, or plot]. (TA in art. nSb.) ＝ -A2- sawRaI [as an intrans. verb, if not a mistranscription for suwRiIa], inf. n. as above: see 8. ＝ -A3- And suwRiIa, [app. for suwRiYa,] inf. n. as above, signifies It was, or became, altered [for the worse]; syn. guyRira. (TA.)

3 sAwAhu c
3. sAwAhu, (S, * M, * Msb,) inf. n. musaAwaApN (M, Er-Rághib, Msb, TA) and siwMCN, (M,) It was, or became, equal to it, (S, Er-Rághib, Msb, TA,) and like it, in measure, extent, size, bulk, quantity, or amount, and in value, (Msb, TA,) or in linear measure, and in weight, and in the measure of capacity, [as well as in value:] one says hecaA licelika AlvRawobi AlvRawobu musaAwK↓ [This garment, or piece of cloth, is equal in length and breadth to that garment, or piece of cloth]; and hecaA AlvRawobu licelika AldRirohami musaAwK↓ [This garment, or piece of cloth, is equivalent to that dirhem]: and sometimes it means in mode, or manner of being: one says, licelika AlsRawaAdi hecaA AlsRawaAdu↓ [This blackness is equal in quality to this blackness]. Er-Rághib, TA.) It is said in a trad., saAwaI AlZRilRu AltRilaAla The shade, or shadow, was like, in its extent, to the mounds, in their height. (TA.) [And sAwI AlXRaIoCu raOosahu means The thing equalled in height his head: see an ex. of the verb tropically used in this sense voce siIRN.] One says also, hecaA yusaAwiI dirohamFA This is worth, or equal in its value to, a dirhem: and in a rare dial., one says, dirohamFA sawiIa↓, aor. yasowaAhu; (Msb, TA;) which AZ disallows, saying, one says sAwAh, but not yasowaAhu. (Msb.) And hecaA AlXRaIoCu laA yusaAwiI kacaA This thing is not equivalent to [or is not worth] such a thing: (Fr, S:) or laAyusaAwiI XayoYFA [It (a garment, or some other thing, M) is not worth anything]: (M, K:) lA yasowaI↓ is of a rare dial., (K,) unknown to Fr, (S,) disallowed by A'Obeyd, but mentioned by others: (M:) Az says that it is not of the language of the Arabs [of pure speech], (Msb, TA,) but is post-classical; and in like manner lA yusowiI↓ is not correct Arabic: this last is with damm to the [first] I: MF says that the generality of authorities disallow it, and the Fs expressly disallows it, but the expositors thereof say that it is correct and chaste, of the dial. of the people of El-Hijáz, though an instance of a verb of which the aor. only is used. (TA.) One says likewise, sAwI AlrRajulu qironahu The man equalled his opponent, or competitor, in knowledge, or in courage. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 6. ＝ -A2- And see 2, in four places, in the former half of the paragraph.

4 AswI c
4. AswI as a trans. verb: see 2, in two places, in the former half of the paragraph. ― -b2- laAyusowiI in the sense of laAyusaAwiI is not correct Arabic: see 3, in the latter part of the paragraph. ＝ -A2- As an intrans. verb: see 8. ― -b2- Also He was like his son, or offspring, [in some copies of the K his father, which, as is said in the TA, is a mistake,] in make, (M, K,) or in symmetry, or justness of proportion; (Fr, TA;) or simply he was like his son, or offspring. (M.) [In this instance, and in all the senses here following that are mentioned in the K, the verb is erroneously written in the CK AstwI.] ― -b3- AswI fiI AlmaroOapi i. q. OawoEaba, (M, K, TA,) i. e. He inserted the whole of his cakar into the faroj [of the woman]. (TA.) ＝ -A3- Also, [as though originally OasowaOa,] He was, or became, base, abased, object, vile, despicable, or ignominious; syn. xaziIa; (M, K;) from AlsRawoOapu. (TA.) ― -b2- And He voided his ordure; syn. OaHodava; (Az, M, K;) [likewise] from AlsRawoOapu, as meaning “ the anus. ” (Az, TA.) ― -b3- And hence, in the opinion of Az, and thought by J to be originally OasowaOa [as he says in the S], (TA,) [though trans.,] He dropped, left out, omitted, or neglected, (S, M, K,) and did so through inadvertence, (S, K,) a thing, (S,) or a letter, or word, of the Kur-án, (M, K,) or a verse thereof: (M:) mentioned by A'Obeyd: (S:) and in like manner, accord. to IAth, in reckoning, and in shooting, or casting: and Hr says that OaXowaI, with X, is allowable, as meaning OasoqaTa. (TA.) ― -b4- Also He was, or became, affected with baraS [or leprosy, which is sometimes termed AlsRuwoCu; so that the verb in this sense also seems to be originally OasowaOa]. (TA.) ― -b5- And He was, or became, restored to health, [or free from suwoCN as meaning an evil affection, (as though the verb were in this sense likewise originally OasowaOa, the incipient O being privative, as it is in many other instances, like the Greek privative α,)] after a disease, or malady. (TA.) ＝ -A4- Oasowayotuhu bihi: see Q. Q. 1 in art. Asw.

5 tasawRaIa
5: see 8.

6 tasaAwayaA c
6. tasaAwayaA They two were, or became, equal, like each other, or alike; as also AisotawayaA↓. (M, K.) AstwI↓ has two and more agents assigned to it: one says, AstwI zayodN wuEamoruw waxaAlidN fiI hecaA [Zeyd and 'Amr and Khálid were equal, or alike, in this]; i. e. tasaAwawoA: whence the saying in the Kur [ix. 19], Einoda QllRehi laA yasotawuwna↓ [They will not be equal, or alike, in the sight of God]. (TA.) And one says, tasaAwawoA fiI AlmaAli They were, or became, equal in respect of the property, none of them exceeding another; as also fiyhi AisotawawoA↓. (Msb.) It is said in a trad., as some relate it, mano saAwaI↓ yawomaAhu fahuwa magobuwnN, in which the meaning is said to be tasaAwaI [i. e. He whose two days are alike, neither being distinguished above the other by any good done by him, is weak-minded]. (TA.) And in another it is said, laA yazaAlu AlnRaAsu bixayorK maA tafaADaluwA faUicaA tasaAwawoA halakuwA, (S, * TA,) i. e. [Men will not cease to be in a good state while they vie in excellence,] but when they cease from vying in excellent qualities and are content with defect [and thus become alike, they perish]: or when they become equal in ignorance: or when they form themselves into parties and divisions, and every one is alone in his opinion, and they do not agree to acknowledge one exemplar or chief or leader [so that they are all alike]: or, accord. to Az, when they are alike in evil, there being none among them possessed of good. (TA.)

8 AstwI c
8. AstwI [seems, accord. to Bd, to signify primarily He sought, or desired, what was equal, equable, uniform, even, or the like: for he says (in ii. 27) that the primary meaning of AlAisotiwaMCu is Tlabu AlsRawaMCi; app. indicating the sense in which AlswMC is here used by what follows. ― -b2- And hence, accord. to him, but I would rather say primarily, as being quasi-pass. of sawRaAhu,] It was, or became, equal, equable, uniform, even, level, flat, plane or plain, [or equal in respect of elevation or of depression, (see 2, first sentence,)] straight, right, direct, or rightly directed; syn. AiEotadala (S, M, Msb, K, TA, and Ksh and Bd in ii. 27) fiI caAtihi, (TA,) said of a place, (Msb,) and AisotaqaAma, said of a stick, or piece of wood, &c. (Ksh ubi suprà.) And sawRaI↓, [if not a mistranscription for suwRiIa,] inf. n. tasowiyapN, signifies the same as AstwI [app. meaning as above], accord. to IAar; and so does OasowaI↓, as also OawosaI, formed from it by transposition. (TA.) One says, Aisotawato bihi AlOaroDu [lit. The earth, or ground, became equable, uniform, even, &c., with him, he having been buried in it], meaning he perished in the earth; as also tasawRato↓, and Ealayohi suwRiyato↓. (M, K.) And Astwt OaroDuhumo Their land became [even in its surface, being] affected with drought, or barrenness. (M, *
TA.) And AstwI AlmaMCu waAlxaXabapa, meaning maEa AlxaXabapi [i. e. The water became even, or level, with the piece of wood]. (TA.) See also 6, in four places. One says also, AstwI AlmuEawRaju [or AlmuEowjRu (as in the MA) i. e. The crooked, or uneven, became straight, or even]: (Mgh:) and AstwI mini QEuwijaAjK [It became even from a state of unevenness]. (S.) faQsotawaI EalaI suwqihi, in the Kur xlviii. last verse, means And has stood straight, or erect, (Bd,) or become strong, and stood straight, or erect, (Jel,) upon its stems. (Bd, Jel. [Golius erroneously assigns a similar meaning to AstswI, a verb which I do not anywhere find.]) And faQsotawaI in the same, liii. 6, And he stood straight, or erect, in his proper form in which God created him: or was endowed by his strength with power over the affair appointed to him: (Bd:) or became firm, or steady. (Jel.) AstwI said of a stick &c. means It stood up or erect: and was, or became, even, or straight: hence one says, AstwI Uilayohi kaAlsRahomi Almurosali He, or it, went towards him, or it, with an undeviating, a direct, or a straight, course, like the arrow hot forth: and hence, vumRa QsotawaI UilaI AlsRamaMCi is metaphorically said of God, in the Kur ii. 27 [and xli. 10]; (Ksh;) meaning (tropical:) Then He directed himself by his will to the [heaven, or] elevated regions, (Ksh, Bd,) or upwards, (Ksh,) or to the heavenly bodies; (Bd;) syn. Eamada, (Zj, M, K,) and qaSada (Zj, S, M, K, and Ksh and Bd) biUiraAdatipi; (Ksh, Bd;) for when AlAisotiwaMCu is trans. by means of UilaI it imports the meaning of the directing of oneself, or, as in this case, of one's design: (TA;) you say of any one who has finished a work and has directed himself to another, qadi QsotawaI lahu and Uilayohi: (Har p. 631:) or the meaning here is SaEida, (Zj, M, K,) or SaEida Oamoruhu [i. e. his command ascended]; (M;) and this is what is intended here by SaEida: (TA:) or Oaqobala EalayohaA [i. e. He advanced to it, namely, the heaven]; (Fr, Th, M, K;) like as one says, kaAna fulaAnN muqobilFA EalaI fulaAnK vumRa QsotawaI EalaIRa yuXaAtimuniI and UilaIRD also, meaning Oaqobala [i. e. Such a one was advancing against such a one, then he advanced against me, and to me, reviling me, or contending with me in reviling]: (TA:) or it means AisotawolaI, (M, K,) as some say: (M:) J says, [in the S,] but not explaining thereby the verse above cited, that it signifies also AisotawolaI and Zahara [as meaning He had, or gained, the mastery, or victory]: and hence the saying of El-Akhtal, cited by him [in the S,]
qadi QsotawaI biXorN EalaI AlEiraAqi
mino gayori sayofK wadamK muhoraAqi
[Bishr has gained the mastery over El-'Irák without sword and without shed blood]: Er-Rághib says that when this verb is trans. by means of EalaI, it imports the meaning of AlAisotiylaMC; as in the saying in the Kur [xx. 4], AalrRaHomenu EalaI QloEaroXi QsotawaI [which may be rendered, The Compassionate hath ascendancy over the empyrean so as to have everything in the universe equally within his grasp; agreeably with what here follows]: he then adds, it is said to mean that everything is alike in relation to Him in such manner that no one thing is nearer to Him than another thing, since He is not like the bodies that abide in one place exclusively of another place. (TA.) The saying lamRaA Qsotawato bihi raAHilatuhu EalaI AlbayodaMCi means [When his riding-camel] ascended with him upon the desert: or stood up with him straight upon its legs. (Mgh.) And one says, AstwI EalaI Zahori daAbRatihi, (S, TA,) or EalaI Alfarasi, (Msb,) He was, or became, firm, or steady, [or he settled himself, or became firmly seated, or sat firmly,] upon the back of his beast, or upon the horse: (S, Msb, TA:) and AstwI jaAlisFA [He became firm, or steady, sitting; or he settled himself in his sitting place; or sat firmly]. (Msb.) [AstwI as quasi-pass. of sawRaAhu also signifies It was made, or became, symmetrical; congruous, or consistent in its several parts: was made, formed, or fashioned, in a suitable manner: was made, or became, adapted to the exigencies, or requirements, of its case, or of wisdom: was made, or became, complete: was made, or became, right, or good; became rectified, adjusted, or put into a right or good state. And hence,] AstwI AlrRajulu i. q. balaga OaXudRahu [q. v.]; (M, K;) [generally meaning] The man [became full-grown, of full vigour, or mature, in body, or in body and intellect; i. e.] attained the utmost limit of [the period termed] his XabaAb; (S;) or attained the utmost limit of his XabaAb, and the completion of his make and of his intellect, by the completion of from twenty-eight to thirty [years]: (T, TA:) or attained to forty (T, M, K) years. (K.) And AstwI AlTRaEaAmu The food became thoroughly cooked. (Msb.) [xaTRu AlAisotiwaMCi means The equinoctial line.]

saIRN c
saIRN, [app. a dial. var. of siIRN]: see laA siyRamaA, in the next paragraph.

siIRN c
siIRN, originally siwoIN; and its dual: see sawaMCN, in ten places, all except one in the latter half of the paragraph. ― -b2- [Hence,] of him who is, or has become, in a state of wealth, or welfare, [or rather, of abundant wealth or welfare,] one says, huwa fiI siIRi raOosihi and raOosihi sawaMCi↓, (Fr, S,) or waqaEa fiI siIRi raOosihi [in the CK (erroneously) saIRi] and rOsh sawaMCi↓ (M, K) and rOsh siwaMCi↓, (K,) or waqaEa rOsh mina AlnRiEomapi fiI siwaMCi↓, (Ks, M,) i. e. (assumed tropical:) [He is in, or has lighted upon, or come upon,] what is in the predicament of his head (Hukomi raOosihi) [in point of eminence, of wealth, or welfare]: or what covers his head [thereof]: (M, K:) or what equals his head [in eminence] (yusaAwiI raOosahu), of wealth, or welfare: (T, TA:) or what has equalled his head [in eminence], of wealth, or welfare; i. e. what has accumulated upon him, and filled [or satisfied] him: (M:) or [what equals] the number of the hairs of his head, of wealth, or good; (A'Obeyd, S, K;) as some explain it. (A'Obeyd, S.) See also sinRN, last sentence but one. ― -b3- [Hence likewise,] laA siyRamaA, (S, M, Msb, K,) also pronounced lA siyamaA, without teshdeed, (Msb, Mughnee, K,) and lA sayRamaA↓ is a dial. var. thereof, (Msb,) a compound of siIR and maA, denoting exception: (S:) one says, laA siyRamaA zayodK, i. e. laA mivola zayodK [lit. There is not the like of Zeyd; virtually, and generally, meaning above all Zeyd, or especially Zeyd]; maA being redundant: and lA syRmA zayodN also; like as one says, daEo maA zayodN: (M, K:) [J says,] with respect to the case of the noun following mA, there are two ways: you may make maA to be in the place of AlRaciI, and mean that an inchoative is to be understood, [namely, hw or the like,] and put the noun that you mention in the nom. case as the enunciative; thus you may say, jaMCaniI Alqawomu laA siyRamaA Oaxuwka, meaning laA siIRa AlRaciI huwa Oaxuwka [i. e. The people, or party, came to me, and there was not the like of him who is thy brother; or above all, or especially, he who is thy brother]: (S, TA: [thus in a copy of the S: in other copies of the same, and in the TA, for siIRa, siyRamaA:]) but this rendering is invalidated in such a phrase as walaA siyRamaA zayodN by the supression of the correlative of the noun in the nom. case where there is no lengthiness, and by the applying mA to denote a rational being: (Mughnee:) or you may put the noun after it in the gen. case, making mA redundant, and making siIR to govern the noun in that case because the meaning of siIR is mivol: [and this is the preferable way:] (Mughnee:) in both of these ways is recited the saying of Imra-el-Keys,
OalaA rubRa yuwomK laka minohunRa SaAliHK
walaA siyRamaA yawomNK bidaArapi julojuli
[Verily many a good day was there to thee by reason of them; but there was not the like of a day, or above all a day, or especially a day, at Dárat Juljul, a certain pool, where Imra-el-Keys surprised his beloved, 'Oneyzeh, with others, her companions, bathing: see EM pp. 9 and 10]: you say also, OaDoribu Alqawoma walaA siyRamaA Oaxiyka, meaning walaA mivola Darobi Oaxiyka [i. e. I will beat the people, or party, but there shall not be the like of the beating of thy brother]: and if you say, walaA siyRamaA Oaxuwka, the meaning is, walaA mivola AlRaciI huwa Oaxuwka [and there shall not be the like of him who is thy brother]: in the saying UinRa fulaAnFA kariymN walaA siyRamaA Uino Oatayotahu qaAEidFA, accord. to Akh, mA is a substitute for the affixed pronoun hu, which is suppressed; the meaning being, walaA mivolahu Uino Oatayotahu qaAEidFA [i. e. Verily such a one is generous, and there is not the like of him if thou come to him sitting]: (S, TA:) it is said in the Msb, [after explaining that mA in syRmA may be redundant, and the noun after it governed in the gen. case as the complement of a prefixed noun; and that mA may be used in the sense of AlRcI, and the noun following put in the nom. case as the enunciative of the inchoative hw which is suppressed;] that, accord. to some, the noun following may be in the accus. case, as being preceded by an exceptive; [or, as a specificative; (Mughnee;) in which case we must regard mA as a substitute for the affixed pronoun hu;]
but that this is not a good way; [and in this case, accord. to the generality of the authorities, it must be an indeterminate noun, not, like zayodN, determinate: (Mughnee:)] also that syRmA should not be used without lA preceding it: and that it denotes the predominance of what follows it over what precedes it: but it is added that lA is sometimes suppressed [as is said in the Mughnee] because known to be meant, though this is rare. (TA.) One says also, laAsiIRa limaA fulaAnN (Lh, M, K) i. e. There is not the like of such a one: (TA:) and laA siyRaka maA fulaAnN (Lh, M, K) i. e. Such a one is not the like of thee. (TA.) [In both of these instances, mA is obviously redundant. Other (similar) usages of siIR are mentioned voce sawaMCN, to which reference has been made above.] ― -b4- siIRN also signifies A [desert such as is termed] mufaAzap; (S, M, K) because of the evenness of its routes, and its uniformity. (TA.) [Hence AlsRiIRu is the name of a particular tract, said in the M to be a certain smooth place in the baAdiyap.] ― -b5- See also art. syw.

siyRap c
siyRap: see sawaMC, near the end of the paragraph.

suwFI c
suwFI: see sawaMCN, in seven places: ― -b2- and see also siwFI, in two places.

siwFI c
siwFI: see sawaACN, in seven places. ― -b2- Also, and likewise suwFI↓, (Akh, S, Msb, Mughnee, K,) and sawaMCN↓, (Akh, S, M, Mughnee, K,) and siwaMCN↓, (Mughnee,) i. q. makaAnN, (Mughnee,) or gayorN, (Akh, S, M, Msb, Mughnee, K,) accord. to different authorities: each used as an epithet, and as denoting exception, like gayor; accord. to Ez-Zejjájee and Ibn-Málik, used in the same sense and manner as gayor: but accord. to Sb and the generality of authorities, an adv. n. of place, always in the accus. case, except in instances of necessity: (Mughnee:) one says, EinodiI rajulN siwaI zayodK, meaning badala zayodK and makaAna zayodK [i. e. I have with me a man instead of Zeyd and in the place of Zeyd]: (Ham p. 570, and TA: *) [but] one says [also] mararotu birajulK siwaAka and suwaAka↓ and sawaAYika↓, meaning gayorika [i. e. I passed by a man other than thee]: (S:) and jaMCaniI sawaAWuka↓ [and siwaAk &c. Other than thou came to me], using it as an agent; and raOayotu sawaMCaka↓ [and siwaAka &c.
