I saw other than thee], using it as an objective complement: and maA jaMCaniI OaHadN sawaMCaka↓ [and siwaAka &c. None except thou came to me]: and maA jaMCaniI OaHadN sawaAWuka↓ [and siwaAka &c. None other than thou came to me]: (Mughnee:) and qaSadotu Alqawoma siwaI zayodK, meaning gayora zayodK [i. e. I betook myself to, or towards, the people, or party, others than Zeyd, which is virtually the same as except Zeyd]: (Msb:) and laYino faEalota caAka waOanaA siwaAka layaOotiyanRaka minRiI maA takorahu, meaning [If thou do that] when I am in a land other than thy land, [what thou dislikest, or hatest, shall assuredly come to thee from me.] (Ibn-Buzurj, TA.) ― -b3- The Arabs also said, Eaqoluka siwaAka, meaning Thine intellect has departed from thee. (IAar, M.) ＝ -A2- The strangest of the meanings of siwaI, in this sense with the short alif and with kesr, is qaSodN. (Mughnee.) siwaI AlXRaIoCi means qaSoduhu [i. e. The tendency, or direction, of the thing]. (M.) And one says, qaSadotu siwaI fulaAnK, meaning qaSadotu qaSodahu [i. e. I tended, or betook myself, in the direction of, or towards, such a one]. (S, K. * [In the CK, and in my MS. copy of the K, sawaAhu is erroneously put for siwaAhu.]) And hence, (Mughnee,) a poet says, (namely, Keys Ibn-El-Khateem, TA,)
walaOaSorifanRa siwaI Hucayofapa midoHatiI
[And I will surely turn towards Hodheyfeh my eulogy]. (S, Mughnee.)

sawaMCN c
sawaMCN [in some copies of the K erroneously written without C] in its primary acceptation is an inf. n., [but without a proper verb, used as a simple subst.,] meaning Equality, equability, uniformity, or evenness; syn. AisotiwaMCN; (Mughnee;) as also sawiyRapN↓: (M, K:) or [rather] it is a subst., (S, and Ksh and Bd in ii. 5,) meaning AisotiwaMCN, (Ksh and Bd ibid.,) from AisotawaI in the sense of AiEotadala; (S;) and signifies [as above: and] equity, justice, or rectitude; syn. EadolN; (S, M, K;) as also sawiyRapF↓; (M;) and siwFI↓ and suwFI↓, as well as sawaMCN, accord. to Fr, are syn. with naSafN; and accord. to him, (TA,) and to Akh, (S, TA,) syn. with EadolN; (S, K, TA;) [but app., only syn. with EadolN and naSafN not as a subst. but as an epithet, like wasaTN thus used, as will be shown by what follows, although] each said by Er-Rághib to be originally an inf. n. (TA.) One says, humaA mino hecaA AlOamori EalaI sawiyRapF↓, meaning sawaMCK [i. e. They two are on an equality, or on a par, in respect of this affair, or case]: (S, TA:) and humo EalaI sawiyRapK↓, meaning [likewise] AisotiwaMCN [i. e. They are on an equality, or on a par], (M, K,) fiI hecaA AlOamori [in this affair, or case]. (M.) And qasamotu AlXRaIoCa bayonahumaA biAlsRawiyRapi↓, (S,) meaning biAlEadoli [i. e. I divided the thing between them two with equity, justice, or rectitude]. (TA.) And it is said in the Kur [viii. 60], faQnobico Uilayohimo EalaI sawaMCK, meaning EadolK [as expl. in art. nbc, q. v.]. (S, * TA.) [Hence,] layolapu AlsRawaMCi The night of the thirteenth [of the lunar month; the first being that on which the new moon is first seen]; (As, S, K, TA;) in which the moon becomes equable or uniform (yasotawiI) [in illumination]: (TA:) or the night of the fourteenth. (M, K.) ― -b2- And i. q. wasaTN [as meaning The middle, or midst, of a thing]; (S, M, Mughnee, K;) as also suwFI↓ and siwFI↓. (Lh, M, K.) Hence, sawaMCu AlXRaIoCi The middle, or midst, of the thing; (S, M;) as also suwaAhu↓ and siwaAhu↓. (Lh, M.) It is said in the Kur [xxxvii. 53,] faraMhu fiI sawaMCi QlojaHiymi [And he shall see him] in the middle or midst [of the fire of Hell]. (S, * Mughnee, TA.) In like manner also one says sawaMCu AlsRabiyli [The middle of the road]: or, accord. to Fr, it means the right direction of the road or way. (TA.) And one says, AinoqaTaEa sawaAYiI, meaning My waist [broke], or my middle. (TA.) And sawaMCu AlnRahaAri means The middle of the day. (M, K. [In some copies of the K, mutRasaEuhu is erroneously put for munotaSafuhu.]) ― -b3- [Hence, perhaps, as being generally the middle or nearly so,] The summit of a mountain. (M, K.) And An [eminence, or a hill, or the like, such as is termed] Oakamap: or a [stony tract such as is termed] HarRap: or the head of a HarRap. (M.) ＝ -A2- It is also used as an epithet; (Mughnee;) and signifies Equal, equable, uniform, or even; syn. musotawK↓; (M, Mughnee, K;) applied in this sense to a place; (Mughnee;) as also, thus applied, sawiIRN↓, and siIRN↓; (M, K;) or these two signify, thus applied, [like sawaMCN as expl. hereafter,] equidistant in respect of its two extremities. (TA.) And as syn. with musotawK↓, it is applied [to a fem. noun as well as to a sing., and] to one and more than one, because it is originally an inf. n.; whence the phrase layosuwA sawaMCF [They are not equal; in the Kur iii. 109]. (Mughnee.) Using it in this sense, one says OaroDN sawaMCN [An even land]: and daArN sawaMCN A house uniform (musotawiyapN↓) in respect of the [appertenances termed] maraAfiq: and vawobN sawaMCN A garment, or piece of cloth, equal, or uniform, (musotawK↓,) in its breadth and its length and its two lateral edges: but one does not say jamalN sawaMCN, nor HamaArN sawaMCN, nor rajulN sawaMCN: (M, TA:) though one says rajulN sawaMCu AlbaToni A man whose belly is even with the breast: and sawaMCu Alqadami having no hollow to the sole of his foot. (TA.) One says also Alxaloqi rajulN sawiIRN↓, (S, M,) meaning musotawK↓ [i. e. A man uniform in make, or symmetrical; or full-grown, of full vigour, or mature in body, or in body and intellect: see 8]: (S:) and rajulN sawiIRN↓ A man equally free from excess and deficiency in his dispositions and his make: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or sound in limbs: (TA voce mirRapN, q. v.:) and gulaAmN sawiIRN↓ A boy, or young man, uniform in make, or symmetrical, (Alxaloqi musotawiI↓,) without disease, and without fault, or defect: (Mgh:) and the fem. is sawiyRapN. (M.) Accord. to Er-Rághib, AlsRawiIRu↓ signifies That which is preserved from excess and deficiency: and hence AlSRiraATi AlsRawiIRi↓ [in Kur xx. last verse, as though meaning The road, or way that neither exceeds, nor falls short of, that which is right]; (Er-Rághib, TA;) the right, or direct, road: (Bd, Jel:) and some read AlsRawaMCi, meaning the middle, good, road: and AlsRawoCi (Ksh, Bd) i. e. the evil, or bad, road: (Bd:) and AlsRuwoCaI [i. e. most evil, or worst; fem. of OasowaOu; for AlSRiraATu is fem. as well as masc.]: (Ksh, Bd:) [and] AlsRuwaIa↓, of the measure fuEolaI from AlsRawaMCu, [with which it is syn.,] or originally AlsRuwoCaI [mentioned above]: (K:) and AlsRuwaIRi↓, (Ksh, Bd,) which is dim. of AlsRawaMC, (Lth, TA,) [or] as dim. of AlsRawoC [in which case it is for AlsRuwaIoCi]. (Ksh, Bd.) ― -b2- [Hence,] it signifies also Complete: (Mughnee:) you say, hecaA
dirohamN sawaMCN (M, Mughnee) This is a complete dirhem; (Mughnee;) using the last word as an epithet: and sawaMCF also, using it as an inf. n., as though you said AisotiwaMCF: and in like manner in the Kur xli. 9, some road sawaMCF; and others, sawaMCK. (M.) ― -b3- And Equitable, just, or right; syn. EadolN: used in this sense in the saying in the Kur [iii. 57], taEaAlawoA UilaI kalimapK sawaMCK bayonanaA wabayonakumo [Come ye to an equitable, or a just, or right, sentence, or proposition, between us and you]. (Az, TA.) ― -b4- And Equidistant, or midway, (EadolN, and wasaTN, S, or naSafN, Mughnee,) between two parties, (S,) or between two places; (Mughnee;) applied as an epithet to a place; as also siwFI↓ and suwFI↓; (S, Mughnee;) of which three words the second (siwFI) is the most chaste; (Mughnee;) or the last two signify equal (musotawK) in respect of its two extremities; and are used as epithets and as adv. ns.; originally, inf. ns. (Er-Rághib, TA.) makaAnFA siwFI↓ and suwFI↓, (M, K,) in the Kur xx. 60, accord. to different readings, means A place equidistant, or midway, (Ksh, Bd, Jel,) between us and thee, (Ksh, Bd,) or to the comer from each of the two extremities: (Jel:) or makaAnN siwFI and suwFI means muEolamN [i. e. a place marked], (so in a copy of the M and in one of the K,) or maEolamN, (so in other copies of the K and in the TA,) which is for cuw maEolamK, meaning having a mark, or sign, by which one is guided, or directed, thereto. (MF, TA.) ― -b5- [Also Equal, or alike, in any respect.] One says, mararotu birajulK sawaMCK waAlEadamu, (M, Mughnee, K,) and waAlEadamu siwaMCK↓, (K,) and waAlEadamu siwFI↓, and waAlEadamu suwFI↓, (M, K,) meaning wujuwduhu waEadamuhu sawaMCN [i. e. I passed by a man whose existence and whose non-existence are equal, or alike, to me, or in my opinion]: (M, K: *) and Sb mentions the phrase, sawaMCN huwa waAlEadamu [as meaning His existence and his nonexistence are equal, or alike, to me]. (M.) And sawaMCN EalaIRa qumota Oawo qaEadota [It is equal, or alike, to me, that thou stand or that thou sit, or whether thou stand or sit; or that thou stand or that thou sit is equal, or alike, to me: see Kur ii. 5, and the expositions thereof]. (S.) [And siwFI↓ is used as an adv. n., or as an inf. n. adverbially, meaning Alike: see an ex. in a verse cited voce sabotN.] ― -b6- Also A like; a similar person or thing; (S, M, K;) and so siIRN↓: [each used as masc. and fem.; and the former as sing. and dual and pl., though having proper dual and pl. forms:] the pl. of the former is OasowaMCN, (S, M, K,) and also, (S, * K,) but anomalous, (S,) or [rather] quasi-pl. ns., all anomalous, (M,) sawaAsiyapN↓ (S, M, K) and sawaAsK↓ and sawaAsiwapN↓: (M, K:) and OasowaMCN is also pl. of siIRN↓: (TA:) as to sawaAsiyapN↓, Akh says, sawaMCN is of the measure faEaAlN, and siyapN may be of the measure fiEapN or filapN, the former of which is the more agreeable with analogy, the w being changed into I in siyapN because of the kesreh before it, for it is originally siwoyapN; and it is from Oasowayotu AlXRaIoCa meaning “ I neglected the thing: ” [see 4:] (S:) accord. to Aboo-'Alee, the I in sawaAsiyapN is changed from the w in sawaAsiwapN, in which latter some preserve it to show that it is the final radical: (M:) accord. to Fr, sawaAsiyapN has no sing., and relates only to equality in evil: (T, TA:) so in the saying,
sawaAsiyapN kaOasonaAni AlHimaAri
[Equals like the teeth of the ass]. (TA.) It requires two [or more nouns for its subjects]: you say, sawaMCN zayodN waEamorNw, meaning cawaA sawaMCK [i. e., lit., Two possessors of equality, or likeness, are Zeyd and 'Amr], (M, K,) because it is [originally] an inf. n.: (M:) and humaA fiI hecaA AlOamori sawaMCN [They two are in this affair, or case, likes]: (S:) and humaA sawaAMni (S, M, K) and siyRaAni↓ i. e. They two are likes: (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K:) and humo sawaMCN and OasowaMCN and sawaAsiyapN↓ i. e. They are likes; (S; [the first and last of these three are mentioned in the Mgh as identical in meaning;]) or, accord. to Fr, the last means they are equals in evil, not in good: (T, TA:) and maAhuwa laka bisiIRK↓ He is not a person like to thee: and maAhumo laka biOasowaMCK [They are not persons like to thee]: (Lh, M:) and maAhiIa laka bisiIRK↓ (Lh, M, K *) i. e. She is not a person like to thee: (TA:) and maAhunRa laka biOasowaMCK [They (females) are not persons like to thee]: and limano faEala caAka laA siIRa↓ [There is not a like to him who did that]: and UicaA faEalota caAka laA siyRaka↓ [There is not the like of thee when thou doest that]: (Lh, M, K:) and fulaAnK laA siyRapa↓ (K) [There is not the like of such a one: in the CK, fulaAnN: perhaps the right reading is fulaAnN laA siyRaka↓ Such a one is not the like of thee]. sawaMCN and siyRaAni↓ should not be used with Oawo in the place of wa except by poetic license: one of the exceptions to this rule is the saying of Aboo-Dhu-eyb,
wakaAna siyRaAni OalRaA yasoraHuwA naEamFA
Oawo yasoraHuwhu bihaA waQgobarRati AlsRuwHu
[And they were two like cases that they should not send forth cattle to pasture or send him forth with them when the tracts were very dusty by reason of drought]. (M.) For two other exs. of sawaMC, [as well as of its syn. siIR, and for laA siyRamaA also,] see siIRN. ― -b7- See also siwFI in six places.

siwaMCN c
siwaMCN: see siIRN, second sentence, in two places: and sawaMCN also, in the latter half of the paragraph: ― -b2- and see siwFI. ― -b3- baEavuwA biAlsRiwaMCi waAllRiwaMCi means (assumed tropical:) They sent seeking, or demanding, aid, or succour. (K in art. lwI. [The proper signification of AlsRiwaMC in this instance I do not find explained.])

sawiIRN c
sawiIRN: see sawaMCN, in the former half of the paragraph, in six places.

suwaIRN c
suwaIRN: see sawaMCN, in the middle of the paragraph.

sawiyRapN c
sawiyRapN: see sawaMCN, in five places. ― -b2- [Also fem. of sawiIRN. ― -b3- And hence, as a subst.,] A kind of vehicle of female slaves and of necessitous persons: (K:) or a [garment of the kind called] kisaMC, stuffed with panic grass (vumaAm), (S, M, K, and L in art. krb,) or palm-fibres (liyf), (M,) or the like, (S, M, and L ubi suprà,) resembling the barocaEap [q. v.], (S, and L ubi suprà,) which is put on the back of the camel, (M,) or on the back of the ass &c., (L ubi suprà,) and which is one of the vehicles of female slaves and of necessitous persons: (M:) and likewise such as is put upon the back of the camel, but in the form of a ring because of the hump, and [also] called HawiyRapN [q. v.]: pl. sawaAyaA. (S.)

sawaAsK c
sawaAsK and sawaAsiwapN and sawaAsiyapN: see sawaMCN, in the latter half of the paragraph; the last of them in three places.

sawRaMCN lawRaMCN c
sawRaMCN lawRaMCN, each of the measure faERaAlN, irregularly derived from AisotawaI and AilotawaI; a prov., applied to women, meaning Straight and bending, and collecting together and separating; not remaining in one state, or condition. (Meyd.) ― -b2- And OaroDN sawRaMCN Land of which the earth, or dust, is like sand. (IAth, TA.)

saAyapN c
saAyapN is [held by some to be] of the measure faEolapu from AltRasowiyapu [inf. n. of swRI]; (K;) mentioned by Az on the authority of Fr; but in copies of the T, faEolapN from AlsRawiyRapu. (TA.) One says, Daraba liI saAyapF, meaning He prepared for me a speech: (K:) or an evil speech, which he framed (sawRaAhaA) against me to deceive me: mentioned by Az on the authority of Fr. (TA.) [See the same word in art. swO.]

OasowaI c
OasowaI [More, and most, equal, equable, uniform, or even: and more, or most, equitable, &c.]. One says, hecaA AlmakaAnu OasowaI hecihi AlOamokinapi i. e. [This place is] the most even [of these places]. (M.)

tasowaMCN c
tasowaMCN An even place; occurring in a trad.: the t is augmentative. (TA.)

musowK c
musowK [act. part. n. of 4]. One says in answer to him who asks, “ How have ye entered upon the morning? ” (S,) or “ How have ye entered upon the evening? ” (M, TA,) musowuwna SaAliHuwna [as enunciatives of naHonu understood], (S, M,) or SaAliHiyna musotawiyna↓ [as enunciatives of OaSobaHonaA or OamosayonaA understood, but I think that musotawiyna is a mistranscription for musowiyna], meaning In a good, right, state, with respect to our children and our cattle. (S, M, TA.)

musaAwK c
musaAwK: see 3, in three places.

musotawK c
musotawK: see sawaMCN, in the former half of the paragraph, in six places: and see also musowK. [hilaAlN musotawK: see Oadofaqu.]

saIo c
saIo i. q. sawofa, q. v.

saIRN c
saIRN and siIRN: see art, swI; and see the latter in art. syw.

2 syRO AlnRaAqapa c
2. syRO AlnRaAqapa, (K,) or tsyROhaA↓, (M,) or both,
(TA,) He drew forth the she-camel's saIoC, or milk that descended before the full flow: (M, K:) from El-Hejeree. (M.)

5 tasayRaAa
5: see above. ＝ -A2- tsyROt, (S, M, and so in copies of the K,) or AisRayRaOato, [a variation of the former,] (TA, as from the K,) She (a camel) emitted her milk, (Fr, S, K,) i. e., what is termed saIoC, (M,) without its being drawn forth. (Fr, S, K.) ― -b2- Hence, UinRa fulaAnFA layatasayRaOu liI biXaIoCK qaliylK (assumed tropical:) [Verily such a one yields me, or gives me, little]. (TA.) ― -b3- tsyRO biHaqRIi (assumed tropical:) He acknowledged my right, or due, after he had denied it. (K.) ― -b4- tasayRaOto EalaIRa AlOumuwru (assumed tropical:) The affairs have become discordant, or diverse, to me, (K, * TA,) so that I know not which of them to pursue; (TA;) as also tasaOosaOato. (TA in art. sO.)

7 AnsyO AllRabanu c
7. AnsyO AllRabanu The milk, such as is termed saIoC, issued without being drawn forth. (Fr, S.)

saIoCN c
saIoCN (Fr, S, M, K) and siIoCN↓ (M, K) The milk that issues without being drawn forth; (Fr, S;) the milk (S, M, K,) that is in the extremities of the camel's teats, (S, K,) or in the fore part of the udder, (IAth, TA,) descending (K) before, (qabola, so in copies of the S and M and K,) or at the first of, (qubula, so in the TA as from the K,) the full flow. (S, M, K.) ＝ -A2- See also the former word in art. swO.

siIoCN c
siIoCN: see the next preceding paragraph.

sayRiYN c
sayRiYN: and sayRiYapN: see art. swO.

sayRaMCN c
sayRaMCN, occurring in a trad., is expl. as meaning One who sells grave-clothes, and [therefore] wishes for people's death: it may be from AlsRawoCu and AlmasaMCapu: or from AlsRaIoCu meaning “ the milk that is in the fore part of the udder: ” or it may be from sayRaOotuhaA meaning “ I milked her. ” (IAth, TA.)

1 saAba c
1. saAba, (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor. yasiybu, (S, A,) inf. n. sayobN, (S, M, A, K,) It ran; (S, M, A, * Mgh, Msb, K;) said of water: (S, M, A, Msb:) and AnsAb↓, likewise said of water, it ran of itself. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] sAbt AlHayRapu, (M,) aor. as above; (M, A;) and AnsAbt↓; (S, M, A, Msb;) (tropical:) The serpent ran: (S, A, * Msb:) or went along (M, TA) in a uniform, or continuous, course, (M,) or quickly. (TA.) sAb and AnsAb↓ both signify (assumed tropical:) He, or it, walked, or went along, quickly: (K, TA:) [or] so the former verb. (M.) It is said in a trad., respecting a man who drank from the mouth of a skin, fiI baTonihi HayRapN AinosaAbato↓ (tropical:) A serpent entered and ran into his belly with the running of the water: wherefore it was forbidden to drink from the mouth of a skin. (TA.) El-Hareeree, in [his first Makámeh, entitled] the San'áneeyeh, [p. 20,] uses the phrase, fiyhaA EalaI garaArapK AnsAb↓, meaning He entered into it as the serpent enters into its lurking place. (TA.) And you say of a viper, sAb and AnsAb↓, meaning (tropical:) It came forth from its lurkingplace. (TA.) And naHowakumo AnsAb↓ (assumed tropical:) He returned towards you. (S.) ― -b3- sAb, (Mgh, Msb,) aor. as above, inf. n. sayabaAnN, said of a horse and the like, (assumed tropical:) He went away at random: (Msb:) or (assumed tropical:) he [app. a horse or the like] went any, or every, way: (Mgh:) or sAbt AldRaAbRapu (tropical:) The beast was left alone, or by itself, to pasture, without a pastor. (S, * A, TA.) ― -b4- And sAb fiI manoTiqihi (tropical:) He took every way [or roved at large] in his speech: (TA:) or he dilated, or was profuse, without consideration, in his speech. (A, TA.) And sAb fiI AlkalaAmi (tropical:) He entered into talk, or discourse, with loquacity, or irrationality. (TA.) It is said in a trad., UinRa AlHiylapa biAlmanoTiqi Oabolagu mina AlsRuyuwbi fiI Alkalimi, meaning (tropical:) [Verily art, or skill, in speech is more eloquent, or effective,] than what is loose, or unrestrained, [or rambling,] in words; i. e. elegance of speech, with paucity, [is more eloquent, or effective,] than profusion. (L, TA. [AlsRuyuwb is here an inf. n.])

2 syRb c
2. syRb (assumed tropical:) He left, left alone, or neglected, a thing. (M.) ― -b2- (tropical:) He left a beast, (S, A,) or a she-camel, (Mgh,) alone, or by itself, to pasture where it would, without a pastor. (S, A, Mgh.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) He emancipated a slave so that he (the emancipator) had no claim to inherit from him, and no control over his property; he made him to be such as is termed saAYibap. (Msb.) ― -b4- See also what next follows.

4 AsAb c
4. AsAb, said of a horse, [and jurodaAnahu syRb↓ has the same or a similar meaning,] i. q. rafRaDa, q. v. (TA in art. rfD.)

7 Uinosayaba
7: see 1, in seven places.

sayobN c
sayobN [is an inf. n. of 1, used in the sense of saAYibN (q. v.), as will be shown in what follows in this paragraph. ― -b2- And hence,] (tropical:) A gift: (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K:) and a voluntary gift, by way of alms, or as a good work: (TA:) and a benefaction, an act of beneficence or kindness, a favour, or a benefit: (M, K:) pl. suyuwbN. (L, TA.) It is said in a trad. respecting a prayer for rain, waQjoEalohu sayobFA naAfiEFA (tropical:) And make Thou it to be a beneficial gift: or the meaning in this instance may be, a flowing rain. (TA.) And one says, faADa sayobuhu EalaI AlnRaAsi (tropical:) His gifts flowed abundantly upon the people. (A, TA.) [See also an ex. in a verse cited voce jubRaON.] ― -b3- Also i. q. rikaAzN (tropical:) [i. e. Metal, or mineral; or pieces of gold or silver, that are extracted from the earth; or any metals or other minerals; or buried treasure of the people of the Time of Ignorance]: (A, Msb:) or so suyuwbN; (A 'Obeyd, S, M, Mgh, K;) which is the pl.: (A, Msb:) the latter signifies, accord. to Th, metals, or minerals: (M, TA:) accord. to Aboo-Sa'eed, veins of gold and of silver, that come into existence, and appear, in the mines: so called because of their running (liQnosiyaAbihaA) in the earth: accord to Z, treasure buried in the Time of Ignorance: or metal, or mineral: (TA:) because of the gift of God, (M, Z, Mgh, TA,) to him who finds it. (Z, TA.) The Prophet said, (Mgh, TA,) fiI AlsRuyuwbi Alxumosu, i. e. In the case of rikaAz, the fifth part [is for the government-treasury]. (A, Mgh, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also The hair of the tail of a horse. (M, K.) ＝ -A3- And A pole with which a ship or boat is propelled. (M, K.)

siybN c
siybN A place, or channel, in which water runs: (S, M, K:) or so siybu maMCK: (A:) pl. suyuwbN. (M.) ＝ -A2- And The apple: in this sense a Pers. word [arabicized]: and hence the name of [the celebrated grammarian] siybawayohi; as though meaning “ the scent of apples; ” (M, K, * TA;) accord. to Abu-l-'Alà, (M, TA,) and Seer: (TA:) by some, [app. such as mispronounce it,] this name is said to be from the Pers. siIo signifying “ thirty ” and buwyaho signifying “ odour; ” as though meaning “ thirty odours: ” (MF, TA:) and some say that wayohi is an ejaculation; and that the relaters of traditions dislike pronouncing this name therewith, as also other similar names, and therefore say siybuwyaho, changing the h into p, but pausing upon it [so as to pronounce it h]. (TA.)

sayaAbN c
sayaAbN and suyRaAbN↓ (S, M, K) and sayRaAbN↓ (K) [Unripe dates in the state in which they are called] balaH: (S, M, K:) or [in the state in which they are called] busor: (K:) or green busor: (AHn, M:) As says that the flowers of the palm-tree when they have become balaH are termed sayaAbN, without teshdeed: (TA:) [but see busorN:] the n. un. is sayaAbapN (S, M) and suyRaAbapN (S) [and sayRaAbapN]: Sh says that they are called sadaMC in the dial. of ElMedeeneh, and one is called syAbp in the dial. of Wádi-l-Kurà: and he adds, I have heard the Bahránees say suyRaAb↓ and suyRaAbap. (TA.)

sayaAbapN c
sayaAbapN n. un. of sayaAbN; (S, M;) like as suyRaAbapN is of suyRaAbN. (S.) ― -b2- Also Wine. (K.)

suyRaAbN c
suyRaAbN and sayRaAbN: see sayaAbN, in three places.

saAYibN c
saAYibN Running water. (Msb.) [See also sayobN, first sentence.]

saAYibapN c
saAYibapN (tropical:) Any beast that is left to pasture where it will, without a pastor: (M, A, K: *) pl. sawaAYibu and suyRabN. (A.) (assumed tropical:) A camel that has lived until his offspring have had offspring, and is therefore set at liberty, and not ridden, (M, K,) nor laden with a burden. (M.) In the Kur v. 102, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) A she-camel that was set at liberty to pasture where it would, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) in the Time of Ignorance, (S, K,) on account of a vow (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and the like: (S, K:) or the mother of a baHiyrap; (S, Mgh; [in the Msb, said to be a baHiyrap (itself); and in one place in the TA said to be a she-camel of which the dam is a baHiyrp; but both of these explanations require consideration, as will be seen from what follows;]) or (K) a she-camel which, having brought forth females at ten successive births, was set at liberty to pasture where she would, (S, K,) and not ridden, nor was here milk drunk except by her young one or a guest, until she died, when the men and the women ate her together; and the ear of her last female young one was slit, and she was [therefore] called baHiyrap, and was a saAYibap like her mother: (S:) or a she-camel of which a man, (M, IAth, K,) in the Time of Ignorance, (M,) when he came from a far journey, (M. IAth, K,) or re-
covered from a disease, (IAth, TA,) or had been saved by his beast from difficulty or trouble, (M, IAth,) or when his beast had been saved therefrom, (K,) or from war, said, hiIa saAYibapN; (M, IAth, K;) i. e. she was left to pasture where she would, without a pastor, and no use was made of her back, nor was she debarred from water, nor from herbage, nor ridden: (IAth, TA:) thus it signifies in the Kur: (M:) or a she-camel from whose back a vertebra or [some other] bone was taken forth, (M, K,) so that she became known thereby, (M,) and which was not debarred from water nor from herbage, nor ridden, (M, K,) nor milked: (TA:) the pl. is suyRabN, like nuwRaHN pl. of naAYiHapN, and nuwRamN pl. of naAYimapN; (S;) and sawaAYibu. (TA.) It is said in a trad., “ I saw 'Amr Ibn-Loheí dragging his intestines in the fire [of Hell]: ” and he was the first who set at liberty sawaAYib: the doing of which is forbidden in the Kur v. 102. (TA.) And it is related that a hostile attack was made upon a certain man of the Arabs, and he found not any [other] beast to ride, so he rode a saAYibap: whereupon it was said to him, “ Dost thou ride what is forbidden? ” and he replied, yarokabu AlHaraAma mano laA HalaAla lahu [He rides what is forbidden who has not what is allowed]: and this saying became a proverb. (M.) AlsRaAYibataAni means The badanataAni [i. e. two camels, or cows or bulls, for sacrifice,] which the Prophet brought as offerings to the House [of God at Mekkeh], and which one of the believers in a plurality of gods took away: they are thus called because he gave them up (sayRabahumaA) to God. (TA.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) A slave emancipated so that the emancipator has no claim to inherit from him, (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) except, accord. to EshSháfi'ee, in the case of the slave's dying without appointing any heir, in which case his inheritance belongs to his emancipator, (TA,) [for] such an emancipated slave may bestow his property where [or on whom] he pleases, (S, Mgh, Msb, TA,) agreeably with a trad.: (Mgh, TA:) [in the S, and in the Msb as on the authority of IF, it is added, that “ this is what is related to have been forbidden: ” but from what has been stated above, this appears to be a mistake; and I think that these words have been misplaced in the S and Msb, and that they relate only to the she-camel termed saAYibap:] a slave is thus emancipated by his owner's saying to him, Oanota saAYibapN. (S.) 'Omar said, AlsRaAYibapu waAlSRadaqapu liyawomihimaA [The sáïbeh and alms are for their day]: i. e., for the day of resurrection; so that one may not return to the deriving of any advantage from them in the present world. (AO, Mgh, TA.)

2 syRj c
2. syRj: see art. swj.

siyaAjN c
siyaAjN: see art. swj.

1 saAHa c
1. saAHa, (S, Mgh, K,) or saAHa EalaI wajohi AlOaroDi, (A,) aor. yasiyHu, (S, K,) inf. n. sayoHN (S, A, Mgh, K) and sayaHaAnN, (K,) It (water) ran upon the surface of the earth. (S, A, Mgh, K.) ― -b2- And hence, (TA,) saAHa fiI AlOaroDi, (S, A, Msb,) aor. as above, (S, Msb,) inf. n. siyaAHapN, (A,) or sayoHN, (Msb,) or both, and suyuwHN and sayaHaAnN, (S, K,) said of a man, (A,) (tropical:) He went, or journeyed, through the land, or earth, (S, L, K, &c.,) for the purpose of devoting himself to religious services or exercises: (L, K:) or in this restricted sense, which MF asserts to be unmentioned in most of the older books, and thinks to be conventional, the verb has only the first of the inf. ns. above, and in the absolute sense it has the second and third and fourth. (TA.) It is said in a trad., laA siyaAHapa fiI AlUisolaAmi (S, A, TA) i. e. (tropical:) [There shall be no going about through the land, or earth, in the way of devotees, in ElIslám: or] no quitting of the cities, or towns, and going, or journeying, through the land, or earth: (TA:) or no quitting of the cities, or towns, and dwelling in the deserts, and forsaking the being present at the congregational prayers and at assemblies: or no going about through the land, or earth, doing evil, or mischief, and calumniating and corrupting. (IAth, TA.) The siyaAHap of the Muslims [in a religious sense, and such as is approvable,] is (assumed tropical:) Fasting. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] saAHa AlZRilRu The shade changed, or turned, or moved, from side to side, or from place to place. (S, K.)

2 sayRaHa
2: [syRH is said by Golius, as on the authority of the K, to signify He made water to flow: and this is probably its primary and proper signification, whence other meanings, which are tropical: but it is not in the K.] ― -b2- See 4. ― -b3- syRH fulaAnN, [app. for syRH kalaAmahu,] inf. n. tasoyiyHN, (tropical:) Such a one talked much. (A, TA.) ― -b4- And suyRiHa, inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) It (a garment, or piece of cloth,) had in it [or was diversified with] various stripes. (L.) [And in like manner it is said of other things: see its part. n., musayRaHN.]

4 AsAH nahorFA c
4. AsAH nahorFA He made a river, or rivulet, to flow, or run. (A, K.) [See also 2.] ― -b2- AsAH Alfarasu jurodaAnahu (A) or cakarahu (L) (tropical:) The horse put forth his veretrum from its prepuce; (L;) and syRH↓ signifies the same: (A, L:) or both of these verbs, said of a horse, are syn. with rafRaDa [q. v.]. (TA in art. rfD.) ― -b3- And AsAH bicanabihi, said of a horse, (assumed tropical:) He let his tail hang down loosely: (K:) accord. to the K, J is in error in writing this verb AXAH; and Az says that AsAH is right, and that AXAH is a mistranscription: the like is also said in the TS: but AXAH is asserted by more than one to be the right word. (TA.)

7 AnsAH baTonuhu c
7. AnsAH baTonuhu (assumed tropical:) His belly became large (K, TA) and wide, (TA,) and approached [the ground] by reason of fatness. (K, TA.) One says of a she-ass, AnsAH baTonuhaA, meaning (assumed tropical:) Her belly became big, and approached the ground. (IAar, T.) ― -b2- AnsAH baAluhu (tropical:) [His, or its, state, or condition,] became free from straitness, or unstraitened. (S, O, K.) A poet says, (S,) namely, Dhu-r-Rummeh, (O,)
OumanRiI Damiyra AlnRafosi UiyRaAki baEodamaA
yuraAjiEuniI bavRiI fayanosaAHu baAluhaA
(tropical:) [I make the secret thoughts of the soul to wish for thee after my grief, or sorrow, returns to me; and then the state, or condition, thereof, becomes free from straitness]. (S, O.) ― -b3- AnsAH said of a garment, or piece of cloth, (K, TA,) &c., (TA,) (assumed tropical:) It became much rent, or rent in several places. (K, TA.) In like manner it is said of the dawn [as meaning (assumed tropical:) It broke]. (TA.) And it is said in the trad. relating to the cave (AlgaAr [mentioned in the Kur ix. 40]) faQnosaAHati AlSRaxorapu, meaning (assumed tropical:) [And the mass of rock] became impelled and riven: and hence, [accord. to some,] the saAHap↓ of a house [expl. in art. swH]: but as some relate it, the verb in this instance is [AnSAxt,] with S and x. (TA.)

sayoHN c
sayoHN Running water; (S, Msb;) an inf. n. used as a subst.: (Msb:) or running external water: (K:) or external water running upon the surface of the earth: (T, TA:) the water of rivers and valleys: (Mgh:) pl. suyuwHN. (T, TA.) [And it is used as an epithet:] you say also (TA) maMCN sayoHN (A, TA) and saAYiHN↓ (A) Water running upon the surface of the earth: (A, TA:) pl. of the former OasoyaAHN. (TA.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) A striped [garment of the kind called] kisaMC, (K, TA,) with which one covers himself, and which one spreads: (TA:) or a striped [garment such as is called] EabaMCap: and a sort of [the garments called] buruwd: (S:) pl. suyuwHN. (TA.) See also musayRaHN.

saAHapN c
saAHapN: see 7; and see also art. swH.

sayRaAHN c
sayRaAHN (tropical:) An itinerant, a roamer, or frequent traveller: (A, * MA:) from saAHa fiI AlOaroDi. (A.)

saAYiHN c
saAYiHN: see sayoHN. ― -b2- [Hence,] (tropical:) A man going, or journeying, [as a devotee, or otherwise,] through the land or earth. (A.) ― -b3- And, as being likened thereto, (tropical:) Fasting, or a faster: (A:) or a faster who keeps to the mosques: (K:) the faster is said to be thus called because he who journeys as a devotee does so without having any provision with him, and eats only when he finds provision: therefore the faster is likened to him. (TA.) AlsRaAYiHuwna in the Kur ix. 113 means (tropical:) The fasters: (Bd, Jel, TA:) so say Zj and I'Ab and Ibn-Mes'ood: (TA:) or those who observe the obligatory fasts: or those who fast constantly: (TA:) or those who journey to war against unbelievers, or to seek knowledge. (Bd.) And saAYiHaAt in the Kur lxvi. 5 means (assumed tropical:) Women who fast: or who forsake their country or homes [for the sake of God]. (Bd, Jel.) ― -b4- This last (sAYHAt [if not a mistranscription for saAbiHaAt]) also means (assumed tropical:) Swift horses: ― -b5- and (assumed tropical:) The planets. (KL.)

masaAHN c
masaAHN or masaAHapN, the latter of the measure mafoEalapN, from AlsRiyaAHapu, [each app. meaning (assumed tropical:) A place of siyaAHap, or journeying,] is sing. of masaAyiHu, in which the I is like that in maEaAyiXu, as in other similar words of which the medial radical is an
infirm letter, except maSaAYibu, by rule maSaAwibu. (Har p. 15.) ― -b2- [The pl. masaAyiHu is also expl. by Freytag as applied in the Deewán of Jereer to (assumed tropical:) The part of the head between the temples as far as the forehead (where the hairs are).]

musayRaHN c
musayRaHN (assumed tropical:) Striped; applied in this sense to a [garment of the kind called] burod; (S, K;) and also, with p, to a [garment such as is called] EabaMCap: (S:) or applied to [the garments called] EabaMC as meaning having alternate stripes of white and black, the latter not intensely black: every EbACp also is termed sayoHN↓ and musayRaHapN: but that which has not stripes is a kisaMC, not an EbACp. (ISh, TA.) So too applied to locusts (jaraAd); (K;) and with p applied to a single locust [i. e. jaraAdap]: (TA:) or, applied to locusts, it means marked with black and yellow and white stripes or streaks. (As, TA.) It is also applied as an epithet to the [bird called] HayoquTaAn. (S.) ― -b2- (tropical:) The wild ass: so called because of his streak that makes a division between the belly and the side. (K, TA.) musayRaHu AlEajiyzapi (tropical:) [He that has the rump streaked] is an epithet applied to the [wild] ass because of the whiteness on his rump. (A, TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) A road of which the tracks (Xarak or Xuruk in different copies of the K) are rendered apparent: (K, TA:) likened to the EabaMC thus termed. (TA.)

misoyaAHN c
misoyaAHN (tropical:) One who goes about calumniating, and making mischief, in the land: (S, A, K:) pl. masaAyiyHu: so in the trad., layosuwA biAlmasaAyiyHi walaA biAlmacaAyiyEi Albucuri (tropical:) [They are not of those who go about calumniating, &c., nor of the babblers who cannot keep secrets.] (S, TA.) Sh derives it, not from AlsRiyaAHapu, but, from tasoyiyHu AlvRawobi. (L, TA.)

1 saAxa c
1. saAxa, aor. yasiyxu, inf. n. sayoxN and sayaxaAnN, i. q. rasaxa and vaAxa [both app. as signifying It sank into the ground: or by the former may here be meant it was, or became, firm, steady, steadfast, stable, fixed, fast, settled, or established]. (K.) See also 1 in art. swx, in two places.

siyaAxN c
siyaAxN A building of clay, (JK, TK,) of any kind: (JK:) pl. suyuwxN. (JK, TK.) In the copies of the K, bunaApu AlTRiyni is erroneously put for binaMCu AlTRiyni. (TK.)

sayodN c
sayodN a contraction of sayRidN, q. v. in art. swd.

siydN c
siydN A wolf: (S, M, A, K: mentioned in the K in art. swd; and in the S, at the close of that art.:) accord. to Sb, its medial radical letter is I; its dim. being suyayodN↓: not like riyHN [of which the dim. is ruwayoHapN], nor like diymapN: (M:) and siydaAnapN↓ signifies the same: (K:) or so siydaAnN↓; (M;) which is the pl. (S, M, A) also: (M:) and siydaAnapN↓ signifies a she-wolf; (M, A, and Ham p. 274;) [and] so siydapN↓; (Ks, S;) or this is not allowable. (Ham ubi suprà.) One says siydu ramolK [A wolf of sands; i. e., that frequents the sands; meaning a savage wolf]. (S.) Hence, AimoraOapN siydaAnapN↓ (tropical:) A bold woman, (M, A,) like the she-wolf. (A.) ― -b2- And A lion (S, M, K) is sometimes thus called, (S,) in the dial. of Hudheyl. (M.) The former is the primary signification accord. to J and others; though the contr. seems to be indicated in the K. (TA.)

siydapN c
siydapN fem. of siydN, q. v., accord. to Ks: (S:) but said to be not allowable. (Ham p. 274.)

siydaAnN c
siydaAnN: see siydN.

siydaAnapN c
siydaAnapN: see siydN, in three places.

suyayodN c
suyayodN dim. of siydN, q. v. (Sb, M.)

sayRidN c
sayRidN: and siyRadN: see art. swd.

masoyidN c
masoyidN mentioned by Ez-Zarkeshee as a dial. var. of masojidN [q. v.]: though by MF to be postclassical: and in the [classical] language of the Arabs i. q. makotabN [A place where the art of writing is taught]. (TA.)

1 saAra c
1. saAra, aor. yasiyru, inf. n. sayorN and masiyrN, (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) which latter is extr., for by rule it should be of the measure mafoEalN, with fet-h [to the E], (S,) and masiyrapN (M, K) and sayoruwrapN (M, Mgh, K) like qayoluwlapN, but [Mtr says] we have not heard it, (Mgh,) and tasoyaArN, (S, M, K,) which last denotes repetition or frequency of the action, (M,) He, or it, went [in any manner, or any pace]; went, or passed, along; marched, journeyed, or proceeded; went away, passed away, or departed; (M, * K, * TA;) by night and by day. (Msb, TA.) You say, saArati AldRaAbRapu [The beast went, went along, &c.]. (S.) [And sAr sayorFA XadiydFA He (a camel or other beast, and a man,) went a vehement pace, or vehemently. And sAr AlEanaqa He (a camel, or a horse,) went the pace, or in the manner, termed AlEanaq: and the like.] And saAruwA mino baladK libaladK [They went, or journeyed, from town to town, or from country to country]: (A:) or sAr mino baladK UilaI baladK [he went, &c.]. (Mgh.) And baAraka QllRehu fiI masiyrika i. e. sayorika [May God bless thy journeying]. (S.) And siro Eanoka Go thou from thy place; pass thou from it: (L in art. nfc:) or (assumed tropical:) feign thou heedlessness, and bear, or endure, or be forbearing; an elliptical phrase; as though it were originally siro wadaEo Eanoka AlmiraMCa waAlXRakRa [go thou, and leave wrangling and doubt]. (S.) ― -b2- [Hence, sArt AlsRafiynapu (tropical:) The ship went, or sailed: for] sayoru AlsRafiynapi is a tropical phrase. (Mgh.) ― -b3- And sAr siyrapF HasanapF (tropical:) [He pursued a good way, course, mode, or manner, of acting, or conduct, or the like], (S, A, Msb,) and siyrapF qabiyHapF [a bad way, &c.]. (Msb.) ― -b4- And sAr fiI AlnRaAsi (assumed tropical:) It became current, or commonly known, among the people; [as also tasayRara↓, alone; (see Har p. 318;)] i. e. a proverb, and a saying. (M.) ― -b5- And sArt sunRapN (assumed tropical:) [A way, course, mode, or manner, of acting, or conduct, or the like, obtained, or was usual, among people]. (M.) ＝ -A2- sAr is also trans., syn. with sayRara. (S, M, Msb, K.) See the latter, in five places. ― -b2- [Hence,] sAr sunRapF (assumed tropical:) He made, or caused, a way, course, mode, or manner, of acting, or conduct, or the like, to obtain, or became usual, among people. (S, M, * TA.) The Hudhalee (Khálid Ibn-Zuheyr, M) says,
falaA tajozaEano mino sunRapK Oanota sirotahaA
faOawRalu raADK sunRapF mano yasiyruhaA
[Then by no means be thou impatient of a way of acting which thou hast made usual; for the first who should be content with a way of acting is he who makes it usual]. (S, M, L, TA: but in the M and TA, in the place of tjzEn, we find tagoDabano.)

2 syRrhu c
2. syRrhu, (M, A, Msb, K,) inf. n. tasoyiyrN; (TA;) and AsArhu↓; (M, A, K;) and sArhu↓, (K,) inf. n. sayorN and siyrapN and masaArN and masiyrapN [or masiyrN, as below]; (TA;) and bihi sAr↓; (IJ, M, K;) He made him (a man, A, Msb) to go [in any manner, or any pace]; to go, or pass, along; to march, journey, or proceed; to go away, pass away, or depart: (M, A, Msb, K, TA:) and bihi suwra↓ [for siyra bihi, the reg. pass. form of saAra bihi,] is mentioned; like huwba and kuwla. (M.) And syRr AldRaAbRapa; (M, A, Msb;) and AsArhA↓; (M;) and sArhA↓, (S, M, Msb,) inf. n. sayorN and siyrapN and masaArN and masiyrN [or masiyrapN, as above]; (M;) He made the beast to go &c.: (S, M, A, Msb:) or sirotu↓ AldRaAbRapa signifies I rode the beast [and thus made it to go &c.]: (Ibn-Buzurj, TA:) but when you ride it to pasture, you say, OasarotuhaA↓, (Msb,) or AsrthA UilaI AlkalaOi (Ibn-Buzurj, TA) or AlI AlmaroEaI. (A.) And syRrhu mino baladihi He made him to go, or depart, from his town, or country; expelled, or banished, him from it. (S, A.) ― -b2- [Hence] syRr (tropical:) He removed, or put off, or took off, the horsecloth, or covering, (S, A, K,) from the horse, (K,) or beast, (A,) or from the back of the beast. (S.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) He made a proverb, (K,) and a saying, (TA,) to become current; (K;) he published it among the people. (TA,) ― -b4- And syRr siyrapN (assumed tropical:) He related stories of the ancients. (M, K.) ＝ -A2- syRrhu [from sayorN meaning “ a thong ”] He made stripes upon it; namely, a garment, or piece of cloth, and an arrow. (M.) And sayRarato xiDaAbahaA She (a woman) made her dye to have the form of stripes, like thongs. (K, * A, * TA.)

3 sAyrhu c
3. sAyrhu, (S, M, A,) inf. n. musaAyarapN, (A,) He went, went along, &c., (saAra,) with him: (M:) he went at an equal rate, or kept pace, with him: (PS:) he ran with him; syn. jaAraAhu. (S, A.) ― -b2- [And He vied, contended, or competed, with him in going, or in running: and hence, (assumed tropical:) in any affair; like jaAraAhu,] See also 6.

4 Oasoyara
4: see 2, in three places.

5 tasayRara
5: see 8: ― -b2- and see also 1, in the latter half of the paragraph. ＝ -A2- tsyRr [from sayorN meaning “ a thong ”] said of a man's skin, It peeled off, (A, K, TA,) and became like thongs. (TA.)

6 tsAyrA c
6. tsAyrA They two [went, or went along, (see 3,) or] went at an equal rate, or kept pace, each with the other: (PS:) or ran, each with the other. (S, A.) ― -b2- One says of a great, or frequent, liar, laA tasaAyarahu xayolaAhu [lit. His two troops of horses will not run together, each troop with the other: meaning (assumed tropical:) his assertions will not be found to agree together]: (so in a copy of the M:) or laA tusaAyaru↓ xayolaAhu. (So in the K and TA voce xayolN, q. v.; and so in the TA in the present art. [See also 6 in art. slm.]) ― -b3- [And They two vied, contended, or competed, each with the other, in going, or in running: and hence, (assumed tropical:) in any affair.] ― -b4- One says also, tasaAyara Eano wajohihi AlgaDabu (tropical:) Anger went [or disappeared by degrees] from his face. (TA, from a trad.)

8 AstAr bisiratihi c
8. AstAr bisiratihi, (O, K, TA,) or bsyrth tsyRr↓, (as in the CK,) (assumed tropical:) He pursued his way, course, mode, or manner, of acting, or conduct, or the like. (O, K, * TA.) ＝ -A2- And AstAr [from siyrapN in the last of the senses assigned to this word below] He procured for himself wheat, or other provision, from a place, to be laid up in store. (S, O, K.)

saArN c
saArN: see saAYirN.

sayorN c
sayorN an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (S, M, A, &c.) [Used as a simple subst., A going, in any manner, or any pace; passage, march, journey, progress, or course: a pace: pace as meaning degree of celerity, or rate of going: departure: see also siyrapN.] ＝ -A2- Also A thong, or strap, or strip of skin or leather; (S, Msb, K;) i. q. XiraAkN: (M:) pl. [of mult.] suyuwrN (S, M, A, Msb) and suyuwrapN and [pl. of pauc.] OasoyaArN. (M.) It is said in a prov., qudRato suyuwruhu mino Oadiymika [His thongs have been cut from thy hide]: applied to two things exactly resembling each other. (AHeyth, Meyd.) And layosa fiI AlEaSaA sayorN is a post-classical prov., (Meyd,) meaning There is not in the staff, or stick, a thong: the syr in this case being the thong that is inserted into the perforation of the head of the staff, or stick, and whereof a ring is tied, into which the hand is put: the prov. is applied to him who is unable to perform that which he desires to do. (Har p. 232.)

sayorapN c
sayorapN: see the next paragraph, in two places.

siyrapN c
siyrapN [i. q. sayorN as meaning A going, in any manner, or any pace; &c.: see above:] a subst. from 1 in the first of the senses assigned to it above. (M, K.) Lh mentions the saying, UinRahu laHasanu AlsRiyrapi [Verily he is good in going, &c.]. (M: in the TA, AlsRayorapi↓, as having the meaning here next following.) ― -b2- Also, (M,) or sayorapN↓, (K,) [but the former seems to be the right, being agreeable with analogy, whereas the latter is anomalous,] A mode, or manner, of going, &c. (M, K.) ― -b3- And the former, (tropical:) A way, course, rule, mode, or manner, of acting or conduct or life or the like; syn. TariyqapN (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and sunRapN (M, K) and macohabN: (Mgh:) pl. siyarN. (Mgh, Msb.) You say, saAra bihimo siyrapF HasanapF (tropical:) [He pursued with them a good way of acting]. (S.) And saAra AlwaAliI fiI AlrRaEiyRahi siyrapF HasanapF (tropical:) [The prefect, or governor, pursued among the subjects a good way of acting]; (A, Msb; *) and in like manner, siyrapF qabiyHapF [a bad way of acting]. (Msb.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) The record of a man's actions and pious works; the prefixed noun SaHiyfap being understood. (Mgh.) ― -b5- (tropical:) Stories of the ancients: (M, K:) [or so siyrapu OawRaliyna:] you say, hecaA fiI siyrapi AlOawRaliyna (tropical:) [This is in the stories of the ancients]. (A.) ― -b6- [Hence it is used in the present day as meaning (assumed tropical:) The mention of a person or thing: and (assumed tropical:) a matter, or subject, of discourse.] ― -b7- Also, as a law term, (Mgh,) or so [the pl.] siyarN, (Mgh, Msb,) (assumed tropical:) Military expeditions; or the memorable actions thereof; (Msb;) or the affairs thereof. (Mgh.) And they say AlsRiyaru Alkabiyru [meaning (assumed tropical:) The great book of military expeditions; for kitaAbN AlsRiyaru Alkabiyru]; using a masc. epithet in lieu of the [suppressed] prefixed noun kitaAb. (Mgh.) ― -b8- Also, the sing., (assumed tropical:) Mode, or manner, of being; state, or condition; syn. hayoYapN, (M, O, Msb, K,) and HaAlapN. (O, Msb.) So in the Kur xx. 22. (M, O, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also Wheat, or other provision, that is brought from a place to be laid up in store. (S, O, K.)

suyarapN c
suyarapN That goes, or journeys, much: or a great goer: (IJ, M, K:) and sayuwrN↓ is applied as an epithet [in the same sense] to a hackney, and to an ass. (Az, TA in art. frh.)

siyaraMCu c
siyaraMCu (S, M, K, &c.) and siyoraMC (TA) [which latter, according to analogy, should be with tenween, but perhaps it is without tenween as being a contraction of the former,] A sort of garment, or cloth, of the kind called buruwd, (Fr, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) having yellow stripes; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) or mixed with silk; (K;) or mixed with [the silk termed] qazR: (AZ, A'Obeyd, Mgh:) or a sort of buruwd of silk: (A:) or a sort of garment, or cloth, having stripes, made of of qazR: or certain garments, or cloths, of El-Yemen; (M;) which are now commonly known by the name of maDof: (TA:) or a sort of buruwd mixed with silk like thongs; and hence its appellation, from sayorN, “ a thong: ” it is asserted by certain of the later writers that it is a subst., not an epithet; and he who says so cites Sb as asserting that a word of the measure fiEalaMCu is not an epithet, but is a subst.: hence, he says, it is used with a prefixed noun, as in the ex. HulRapu siyaraMCa; and is expl. as signifying clear silk. (IAth, TA.) ― -b2- Also (tropical:) The diaphragm, or midriff: (M, K: *) metaphorically used in this sense by a poet. (M.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) The peel [or pellicle] adhering to the stone of a date. (M, K.) ― -b4- And A palm branch stripped of its leaves. (M, K.) ― -b5- And Gold: (M:) or clear, pure, gold. (K, * TA.) ― -b6- And A certain plant, (M, K, TA,) not described by Ed-Deenawaree [i.e. AHn]; as some say, (TA,) resembling the xulRap [q. v.]: (K, TA:) so in the Tekmileh. (TA.)

sayuwrN c
sayuwrN: see suyarapN.

sayRaArN c
sayRaArN A journeyer, or traveller: (A:) and sayRaArapN, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) for jamaAEapN sayRaArapN, (Mgh,) or qawomN sayRaArapN, (A,) a company of persons journeying: (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K:) [accord. to ISd,] sayRaArapN is made fem. because meaning rufoqapN, or jamaAEapN. (M.) ― -b2- AlsRayaArapu [and AlsRayRaAraAtu] (assumed tropical:) The five planets; Mercury, Venus, Mars, Jupiter, and Saturn. (TA in art. kns.)

saAYirN c
saAYirN [part. n. of 1, Going, &c. ― -b2- Hence,] (assumed tropical:) A proverb [and a saying] current, or commonly known. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, and saArN↓, (S, M, K,) both are syn., (K,) signifying The rest, or remainder, of a thing: (M:) [and accord. to some,] the whole, or all, of a thing or of people. (S, TA.) [See the former word in art. sOr.]

masuwrN c
masuwrN: see the next paragraph.

masiyrN c
masiyrN an inf. n. of saAra. (S, M, A, &c.) ― -b2- [Also A place, and a time, of going, or journeying.] ― -b3- And pass. part. n. of saAra; (Msb, MF;) [and so masuwrN↓, for] you say TariyqN masuwrN, (K,) or TariyqN masuwrN fiyhi, (IJ, M,) [A travelled road,] and rajulN masuwrN bihi [A man made to go, or journey, &c.]: (IJ, M, K:) accord. to Kh, in this case, and in others like it, the I is changed into w [so that masoyuwrN, the original form of masiyrN and of masuwrN, becomes masowuwrN, and is then contracted into masuwrN]: (M:) or, accord. to Kh, the I is rejected: but accord. to Akh, it is the w that is rejected [so that masoyuwrN becomes masoyurN; and then, masuyorN; and then masuwrN]. (TA.)

masiyrapN c
masiyrapN A space which one traverses in journeying; a journey as measured by the time that it occupies; as in the phrase, masiyrapu XahorK a month's journey; (TA;) and bayonahumaA masiyrapu yawomK [Between them two is the space of a day's journey]. (S, TA.) masiyrapu yawomK [A day's journey] is twenty-four miles. (MF in art. qrTX.)

masayRarN c
masayRarN A garment, or piece of cloth, figured with stripes (S, M, A, K) like thongs, (S, M, A,) made of silk: or a burod mixed with silk. (TA.) [See also siyaraMCu.] ― -b2- And EuqaAbN musayRarapN A striped eagle. (M.) ― -b3- And AlmusayRarN, (K,) or musayRaru AlqrEi, (TA, [but the orthography of the latter word I think doubtful,]) A certain sweetmeat, (K, TA,) wellknown. (TA.)

musotaArN c
musotaArN [A place whence one procures wheat, or other provision, for subsistence, to be laid up in store: from AisotaAra in the latter of the senses assigned to it above, agreeably with analogy, and as is indicated in the S]. A rájiz says, [namely, Aboo-Wejzeh, as in a copy of the S,]
OXokuw UilaI QllRehi AlEaziyzi AlgafRaAro
vumRa Uilayoka Alyawoma buEoda AlmusotaAru
[I complain unto God, the Mighty, the Very Forgiving, then unto thee, this day, the remoteness of the place whence I have to procure provision for subsistence]: or, accord. to some, AlmusotaAr, in this verse, is of the measure mufotaEalN from AlsRayoru [and, like it, meaning the journey]. (S.)

1 saAEa c
1. saAEa, aor. yasiyEu, inf. n. sayoEN and suyuwEN, It (water, and the saraAb [or mirage],) ran, and was in a state of commotion, upon the surface of the ground; (S, O, K;) as also AnsAE↓: (S:) or the latter, said of water, it ran upon the surface of the ground; as also tsyRE↓: and AnsAE↓, said of a thing in a congealed or solid state, signifies also it melted; became fluid, or liquid. (TA.) ― -b2- saAEati AlUibilu, (Sh, K,) aor. as above, inf. n. sayoEN, (Sh,) The camels were left to themselves, without a pastor; (Sh, K;) as also sAEt having tasuwEu for its aor. and sawoEN for its inf. n. (Sh, S * and K * in art. swE.) ― -b3- And saAEa AlXRaIoCa, aor. as above, The thing became left, or neglected, or lost; or it perished. (TA.)

2 tasoyiyEN c
2. tasoyiyEN The act of plastering with mud [or with sayaAE]. (K.) You say, sayRaEotu AlHaAYiTa I plastered the wall with mud and chopped straw. (S.) ― -b2- And The act of anointing with fat and the like. (K.) You say, sayRaEati AlmaroOapu mazaAdatahaA The woman anointed [with fat, or the like, her leathern water-bag]. (TA.)

4 AsAEhu c
4. AsAEhu He left it, neglected it, lost it, or destroyed it. (TA.) [See also art. swE.]

5 tasayRaEa
5: see 1. ＝ -A2- tsyRE Albaqolu The herbs, or leguminous plants, dried up; or became yellow. (TA.)

7 UinosayaEa
7: see 1, in two places.

sayoEN c
sayoEN Water running upon the surface of the ground. (Lth, K.)

sayaAEN c
sayaAEN, (K,) or siyaAEN, (S,) or both, (MF, TA,) Mud: (TA:) or mud [mixed] with chopped straw, with which one plasters. (Kr, S, K.) The saying of the poet, (S, K,) namely El-Kutámee, (K,) describing his she-camel, (TA,)
falamRaA Oano jaraI simanN EalayohaA
kamaA TayRanota biAlfadani AlsRayaAEaA
presents an inversion, the meaning being kmA TyRnt biAlsiyRaAEi Alfadani [i. e. And when fatness extended upon her, as when thou plasterest with mud and chopped straw the pavilion]; Alfadan signifying AlqaSor. (S, K: [but in the former, only the latter hemistich is cited; and in some copies of the former, and in the O, we find baTRanota in the place of TayRanota.]) ― -b2- Also Fat with which a mazaAdap [or leathern water-bag] is anointed. (K.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) Pitch, or tar; syn. zifotN; as being likened to mud, because of its blackness. (TA.)

DaAYiEN saAYiEN c
DaAYiEN saAYiEN, mentioned in this art. in the TA: see art. swE.

saraAbN OasoyaEu c
saraAbN OasoyaEu A mirage [running upon the surface of the ground, (see 1,) and] in a state of commotion: (S, * TA:) or, as some say, [in a state of exceeding commotion; for] the form of the epithet in this case denotes mufaADalap. (TA.)

misoyaEapN c
misoyaEapN A plasterer's trowel; syn. maAlajapN: (S:) a piece of wood made smooth, used by skilful plasterers with mud. (Lth, K.)

misoyaAEN c
misoyaAEN A she-camel that goes away in the place of pasturing: (K:) mentioned by J in art. swE, q. v.: (TA:) or that bears, or suffers, neglect, or being left alone, (AalRatiI taHomilu AlDRayoEapa, [for the last of which words we find in some copies of the K AlDRayoEapa, but it is said in the TA that the former is the right reading, as is shown by its being added,]) and bad superintendence or management; (K, TA;) thus expl. by As: (TA:) or upon which one journeys and returns; (K;) thus expl. by Sgh, but this is the explanation of mirobaAEN, with which it is coupled. (TA.)

1 sigotuhu c
1. sigotuhu, aor. Oasiyguhu, inf. n. sayogN: see 4, in art. swg.

hecaA sayogu hecaA c
hecaA sayogu hecaA: see hcA sawogu hcA, in art. swg, in two places.

sayRigN c
sayRigN: see saAYigN, in art. swg.

1 saAfahu c
1. saAfahu, (S, M, O, K,) first pers. sifotuhu, (S, O, Msb, K, [in the CK, erroneously, sufotuhu,]) aor. yasiyfu, (S, O, Msb, K,) inf. n. sayofN, (M,) He struck him, or smote him, with the sayof [or sword]; (S, M, O, Msb, K;) as also tsyRfhu↓. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 3. ＝ -A2- sayifa, inf. n. sayafN; and AnsAf↓; [app., as seems to be indicated by the context, said of palm-trees (naxolN) or of palmbranches (saEafN), as meaning They had upon them what is termed siyf, q. v.:] (M, TA: *) and sayifat and AnsAft↓ are said of a palm-tree (naxolapN) [app. as meaning it had siyf upon it]. (TA.)

3 musaAyafapN c
3. musaAyafapN signifies The contending with another in fight, or in smiting, with the sword. (S, Mgh.) saAyafaniI fasifotuhu↓, a phrase mentioned, without his adding anything thereto, by Lh, app. means [He contended with me in smiting with the sword, and] I was more skilled in the use of the sword (kunotu Oasoyafa) than he. (M.) ― -b2- See also 6.

4 AsAf Alqawomu c
4. AsAf Alqawomu The people, or party, came to the siyf [or sea-shore]. (AAF, M.) ＝ -A2- AsAf Alxaroza (S, K) i. q. xaramahu (S, TA) [expl. in art. swf] is said to belong to the present art., in which it is mentioned by IF as well as J. (TA.)

5 tasayRafa
5: see 1. ＝ -A2- [Accord. to Freytag, tasayRafa signifies He was slain with the sword: but he mentions no authority for this. Perhaps the pass. form of this verb may have this meaning.]

6 tsAyfwA c
6. tsAyfwA They contended, one with another, in smiting with swords; (S, M, K;) as also sAyfwA↓; (K;) and so AstAfwA↓, (M, K,) as expl. by the lexicologists; but this last properly signifies they took, or took hold of, the swords. (IJ, M.)

7 Uinosayafa
7: see 1, in two places.

8 AisotiyAafN c
8. AisotiyAafN signifies The act of [putting to the sword,] destroying, or killing. (KL.) One says, Ausotiyfa Alqawomu [app. meaning The people, or party, were put to the sword]: (K:) a phrase mentioned by Lth. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 6.

sayofN c
sayofN A sword; (MA, PS, &c.;) a certain thing with which one smites; (M;) well known: its names exceed a thousand: (K: in which it is added that its author has mentioned these names in [his book entitled] AlrRawoDu Almasoluwfu:) [for the names of particular parts thereof, see cubaAbN:] pl. [of pauc.] OasoyaAfN (S, M, O, Msb, K) and OasoyufN (Lh, M, O, K) and [of mult.] suyuwfN (S, M, O, Msb, K) and [quasi-pl. n.] masoyafapN↓, like maXoyaxapN, (O, K, TA,) or masiyfapN, like maXiyxapN. (CK.) [Hence,] sayofu AljabRaAri (assumed tropical:) [The sword of Orion;] the three stars [ η, θ, κ, beneath the girdle] of AljbRAr, in a sloping direction, near together, disposed in a row. (Kzw.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A certain fish, (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K,) resembling a sayof [or sword]; (Ibn-'Abbád, O;) as also siyfN↓. (K.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) The sabiyb, (M,) [i. e.] the hair of the tail, (K,) of a horse. (M, K.) ― -b4- sayofu AlguraAbi (assumed tropical:) i. q. AldRalabuwvu; (K) A certain plant, the stem (OaSol) and leaves of which are exactly like those of the saffron, and the bulb of which is enclosed in a covering of [fibres of the kind called] liyf; (AHn;) so called because its leaves are slender at the extremity like the sayof [or sword]. (AHn, K.) ― -b5- humo OasoyaAfN [lit. They are swords] means OaHozaAbN [i. e. (assumed tropical:) they are bodies, or parties, of men prepared, or ready, for fighting, &c.]. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.) ― -b6- And one says, bayona fakRayohi sayofN SaArimN (tropical:) [Between his two jaws is a sharp tongue; lit., a cleaving sword]. (TA.)

siyfN c
siyfN The shore (saAHil) of the sea or of a great river: (S, M, O, Mgh, Msb, K:) and the side (saAHil) of a valley: or [the margin of the shore of a sea or of a great river; for it is added,] every saAHil has a siyf: or AlsRiyfu is applied only to the siyf [or sea-shore, or seaboard,] of 'Omán: (K:) [if otherwise applied,] its pl. is OasoyaAfN. (S, M.) One says, humo Oaholu OasoyaAf K waOaroyaAfK [They are people of the shores of the sea or of a great river, and of the tracts of towns, or villages, and cultivated lands]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A thing that adheres to the lower parts, or roots, of palm-branches, like [the fibres called] liyf, but not the same as liyf: (S: in which is added, “ this I have taken from a book, without having heard it: ”) or the [fibrous substance called] liyf, (K,) or the thick, or coarse, liyf, (M,) adhering to the lower parts, or roots, of palm-branches, which is the worst sort thereof, [i. e. of lyf,] (M, K,) and the harshest, and coarsest. (M.) [See XiyfN.] ＝ -A3- See also sayofN.

siyfapN c
siyfapN: see art. swf.

sayofaAnN c
sayofaAnN, applied to a man, Tall and slender, (Ks, S, M, O, K,) like the sayof [or sword], (M,) lank in the belly: (Ks, S, O:) and with p applied to a woman, (Ks, S, M, O, K,) meaning tall; resembling a sword-blade: (O:) or it is peculiar
to women; (K;) [i. e.] accord. to Kh, one does not apply to a man the epithet sayofaAnN. (O.)

sayRaAfN c
sayRaAfN An owner, or a possessor, of a sayof [or sword]; (S, M, O, K;) as also musiyfN↓: (M:) pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] of the former sayRaAfapN: (S, M, O, K:) or this last signifies a people, or party, whose HuSuwn [or fortresses] are their suyuwf [or sword; i. e. whose only means of defence are their swords]. (Lth, O, K. *) ― -b2- Also (tropical:) A man who is a frequent shedder of blood; or who sheds much blood. (TA.) [An executioner who slays with the sword.] ― -b3- And A maker of suyuwf [or swords]. (TA.) [And A seller of swords.]

saAYifN c
saAYifN Striking, or smiting, with the sayof [or sword]. (S.) ― -b2- And A man having a sayof [or sword]: (S, O, K:) or having with him a sayof. (Msb.)

Oasoyafu c
Oasoyafu [More, and most, skilled in the use of the sword]: see 3.

musiyfN c
musiyfN One having upon him a sayof [or sword]; (S, O, K;) having hung upon himself a sayof: (Ks:) and (K) accord. to Ibn-'Abbád, a courageous man having with him a sayof. (O, K.) ― -b2- See also sayRaAfN. ＝ -A2- And see art. swf.

masoyafapN c
masoyafapN, or masiyfapN: see sayofN.

musayRafN c
musayRafN, applied to a [garment of the kind called] burod, Having upon it what resemble the forms of suyuwf [or swords]: (M, TA:) and, so applied, having broad stripes, like the sayof [or sword]. (TA.) ― -b2- And applied to a dirhem, of which the sides are plain, or clear of any impress or the like. (IAar, O, K.)

misoyaAfN c
misoyaAfN A wind (riyHN) that cuts like the sayof [or sword]. (M.) ＝ -A2- See also art. swf.

1 saAla c
1. saAla, (S, M, Msb, K,) said of water, (S, Msb, TA,) or of a thing, (M,) aor. yasiylu, (Msb, K,) inf. n. sayolN and sayalaAnN (S, M, Msb, K, TA) and masiylN and masaAlN, (TA,) It flowed, or ran: (M, K, TA:) or, said of water, it rose so as to become excessively copious, and flowed, or ran: and sAl said of thing, it was, or became, fluid, or liquid; contr. of jamada. (Msb.) ― -b2- The Arabs say, saAla bihimu AlsRayolu wajaAXa binaA AlbaHoru [The torrent flowed with them, and the sea estuated with us so as to be unnavigable;] meaning, (assumed tropical:) they fell into a hard case, and we fell into one that was harder than it: (M, Meyd:) a proverb. (Meyd.) ― -b3- And saAlato Ealayohi Alxayolu (tropical:) [The horsemen poured upon him]. (TA. [See also 6.]) ― -b4- And sAlt AlgurRapu (assumed tropical:) [The blaze upon the face of a horse] extended, or spread, long and wide: (S:) [or, simply, extended down the face; as appears from an explanation of the word XimoraAxN in the S and K &c.: see also saAYilapN, below. And in like manner sAl is often said of flowing, or defluent, hair.] ＝ -A2- siyla &c. for suYila, pass, of saOala: see this last word, in art. sOl.

2 sayRala
2: see 4.

3 saAyalotu c
3. saAyalotu: see 3 in art. sOl.

4 AsAlhu c
4. AsAlhu, (S, M, Msb, K,) inf. n. UisaAlapN, (Msb,) He made it to flow, or run; (S, * M, Msb, K;) as also syRlhu↓, (S, TA,) inf. n. tasoyiylN. (TA.) It is said in the Kur [xxxiv. 11], waOasalonaA lahu Hiyna AlqiTori (M, TA) i. e. And we made [the source of copper, or of brass,] to flow, or run, for him. (TA.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) He made it long, (M, K,) and complete; (M;) namely, the point of the iron head or blade an arrow or of a spear &c. (M, K.)

6 tsAylt AlkataAYibu c
6. tsAylt AlkataAYibu (tropical:) [The troops of horse] poured [together] from every quarter. (S, TA. [See also 1.]) ＝ -A2- hmaA yatasaAyalaAni: see 6 in art. sOl.

sayolN c
sayolN A torrent, or flow of water; (MA;) [i. e.] much water, (M, K,) or a collection of rainwater, (Msb,) flowing, or running, (M, Msb, K,) in a valley, or water-course, or torrent-bed: (Msb:) or water that comes to one [from rain, in any case, or] from rain that has not fallen upon one: (TA:) originally an inf. n.: (Msb, TA:) pl. suyuwlN: (S, M, Msb, K:) saAYilapN↓, also, signifies the same as sayolN; and its pl. is sawaAYilu [expl. in the M as meaning flowing, or running, waters]. (TA.) ― -b2- And they said also, maMCN sayolN, meaning saAYilN↓ [i. e. Flowing, or running, water]; (M, K;) putting the inf. n. in the place of the epithet. (M.) wajadotu baqolFA wabuqayolFA wamaMCF EalalFA sayolFA, meaning I found herbs full-grown and large and tall, and herbs not full-grown and therefore small, [and water among trees, flowing, or running,] is a saying of one sent to seek for herbage and water; mentioned by Th. (M.)

siylapN c
siylapN A mode, or manner, of flowing or running of water. (K.)

siylaAnN c
siylaAnN The sinox [or tongue] of [meaning that enters into] the hilt, or handle, of a sword (M, K) and of a knife (M) and the like; (M, K;) the part, (S, TA,) in the A the tail, (TA,) that enters into the hilt, or handle, of a sword and of a knife: heard by A'Obeyd, though not from a learned man: (S, TA:) but AA cites the following ex. from Ez-Zibrikán Ibn-Bedr:
walano OuSaAliHakumo maA daAmo liI farasN
waQXotadRa qaboDFA EalaI AlsRiylaAni UibohaAmiI
[And I will not make peace with you while I have a horse and my thumb grasps firmly upon the tongue of the sword]. (El-Jawáleekee, IB, TA.) (assumed tropical:) sayaAlN pl. of sayaAlapN, (K,) [or rather the former is a coll. gen. n. of which the latter is the n. un., applied in the present day to A species of mimosa, or acacia, mentioned by Forskal in his Flora Aegypt. Arab., pp. lvi. and cxxiv., and by Delile in his Floræ Aegypt. Illustr. (in the Descr. de l'Égypte), no. 965: and to a species of thistle; carduus lacteus; or wild artichoke:] a species of trees having thorns, of the kind called EiDaAh: (S:) certain trees having white thorns: (M:) or the [thorny plant called] Xabah: (AA, M:) a certain plant; (K;) said to have white thorns, from which, when these are plucked, there issues what resembles milk: (AA, M, K: *) certain trees having lank branches and white thorns of which the bases resemble the middle pairs of the teeth of virgins: (TA:) or, (K,) accord. to Aboo-Ziyád, (AHn, M,) tall samur [or gum-acacia-trees]: (AHn, M, K:) accord. to the A, the trees called xilaAf [now applied to the salix Aegyptia of Linn.] in the dial. of El-Yemen. (TA.)

sayRAlN c
sayRAlN [Flowing, or running, much]. One says, nazalonaA biwaAd K nabotuhu mayRaAlN wamaAWuhu sayRaAlN [We alighted in a valley the herbage whereof was inclining much, by reason of its luxuriant growth, and the water whereof was flowing, or running, much, by reason of its copiousness]. (TA.) ― -b2- [And Distilling much: see ranodN.] ＝ -A2- Also A certain mode of calculation. (O, K, TA. [In the CK, AlHiytaAno is erroneously put for AlHisaAbi.])

sayRaAlapN c
sayRaAlapN: see saAYilapN. ― -b2- Also A bending in a sea or great river. (TA.)

saAYilN c
saAYilN: see sayolN. ― -b2- Also Fluid, or liquid. (Msb.) ― -b3- saAYilu AlOaToraAfi, in a description of the Prophet, means (assumed tropical:) Extended in the fingers: or, as some relate it, saAYin, with n, which has the same meaning. (O.) And gurRapN saAYilapN means (assumed tropical:) [A blaze upon the face of a horse] extending, or spreading, long and wide: (S:) or [extending so as to be] equable, or uniform, upon the bone of the nose: or that has extended upon the extremity of the nose so as to make it white: (M, K:) or that has spread widely upon the forehead and the bone of the nose: (TA:) if narrow, it is termed XimoraAxN. (S, TA.)

saAYilapN c
saAYilapN [as a subst. formed from the epithet saAYilN by the affix p]; pl. sawaAYilu: see sayolN. ― -b2- [Hence the saying,] raOayotu saAYilapF mina AlnRaAsi (assumed tropical:) I saw a company of men that had poured from some quarter; and so sayRaAlapF↓. (TA.) ― -b3- The pl. sawaAYilu also signifies Valleys [app. flowing with water, or because they flow with water]. (T in art. cnb.)

masalN c
masalN: see masiylN.

musaAlN AlxadRayoni c
musaAlN AlxadRayoni [app. meaning (tropical:) Having expanded cheeks, not elevated in the balls thereof, like saholu AlxadRayoni,] is a tropical phrase. (TA.) ― -b2- musaAlaA AlrRajuli (assumed tropical:) The two sides of the beard of the man: (O, and so in one of my copies of the S:) or, of his jaws: (so in the TA and in my other copy of the S; i. e. laHoyayohi instead of liHoyatihi:) sing. musaAlN: and pl. musaAlaAtN. (S, O.) And also (assumed tropical:) The two sides of the man [himself]; syn. EiTofaAhu. (S, O.)

masiylN c
masiylN A place [or channel] in which a torrent flows: (Msb:) or masiylu maMCK and maMCK masalu↓, (S, K,) the latter anomalous, so much so that a parallel to it is scarcely, or in no wise, known, (MF,) a water-course; i. e. a place [or channel] in which water flows, or runs: pl. [of pauc., of the former,] OamosilapN, (S, K,) and [of mult.] masaAyilu and musulN; and musolaAnN; (S, Msb, K, TA;) the second
pl. regular, without C, (TA, [though written in the CK with C,]) and the rest irregular, (S, * TA,) the sing. being likened to rigiyfN, (S, Msb, TA,) which has for its pl. OarogifapN and rugufN (S, TA) and rugofaAnN. (S, Msb, TA.) ― -b2- It is also an inf. n. (TA. [See 1, first sentence.]) ― -b3- Also Rain causing much flowing; opposed to mazoragN [q. v.]. (Ham p. 632.) [See also what follows.]

musiylN c
musiylN Rain that causes the valleys and water-courses (tilaAE) to flow; opposed to murozigN [q. v.]. (S in art. rzg, and Ham p. 632.) [See also what next precedes.]

siymapN c
siymapN and siymaI and siymaMCu and siymiyaMCu: see art. swm.

suyuwmN c
suyuwmN: see saAYimN [of which it is said to be pl.], in art. swm.

lasiyRamaA c
lasiyRamaA and lA siyamaA and lA sayRamaA: see art. swI.

siynN c
siynN One of the letters of the alphabet: (S, M, L, K:) [i. e., the name of that letter: (see art. s:)] of the masc. gender as being supposed to be a Harof [or letter], and fem. as being supposed to be a kalimap [or word]. (L.) The saying fulaAnN laA yaHosinu sinahu means Such a one will not form well one of the three XuEab [i. e. teeth, or cusps,] of his s. (S, L.)

siynaMCu c
siynaMCu Certain stones, (M, L, K,) so says Zj, (M, L,) well-known: (K:) whence the name of a certain mountain in Syria. (M, L.)

siyniyRapN c
siyniyRapN A certain tree; (M, L, K;) mentioned by AHn on the authority of Akh: (M, L:) pl. siyniynN. (M, L, K.)

siyapN c
siyapN The curved part of each of the two extremities of a bow: pl. siyaAtN: (S, K:) the p in the sing. is a substitute for w: AO says that Ru-beh used to pronounce it [siYapN,] with C; and the rest of the Arabs, [siyapN,] without C. (S, TA.) [See also art. sOw.]

saIRN c
saIRN: see art. swI.

siIRN c
siIRN, with the compound siyRamaA: see art. swI. ― -b2- [Hence, perhaps, because of its uniformity, and, if so, belonging to art. swI,] kalaON siIRN Much, or abundant, herbage: mentioned by Sgh. (TA.)

siyRapN c
siyRapN: see art. swI.

siyawiIRN c
siyawiIRN Of, or relating to, the siyap of a bow. (S.)
